title: Does This Make Sense, Warren?
description: Warren Buffett, in his annual report out today, has his usual dose of scorn for corporate executives  this year focusing on those who made stupid mortgage loans and on those who inflate reported profits by making optimistic assumptions about how well their pension investments will do.

title: A Cousin Speaks About Jewell Ward
description: Sherry Brooks, cousin of Jewell Ward, speaks about the tragic murder of her cousin.

title: Why Downloads Won't Kill the DVD
description: David Pogue offers six reasons why Internet downloads will not replace the DVD anytime soon.

title: The Night of My Nights, No Longer
description: Right here, at the top of the page, I apologize for bringing up a subject about which you have probably heard and read quite enough, thank you very much.

title: Dept. of Beauty: Head Trip
description: Although bunssleek or softhave been prevalent on the runways, several designers and hair stylists had other ideas. At Junya Watanabe, models were like blacked-out Carmen Mirandas, their heads piled with randomly shaped objects and covered. Jun Takahashi used latex cone heads to suggest the mutation in his Under Cover collection. At Saint Laurent, Stefano Pilati put his models in identical bowl-cut wigsin contrast to the versatility of the clothes.

title: Bloggingheads: Democrats as Wimps
description:
Jacob Heilbrunn of the National Interest, left, and Eli Lake of the New York Sun debate whether Democratic and Republican foreign policies are really so different.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Clinton Talks About Stepping Up Effort in Afghanistan
description: WACO, Tex.  Heres something that got lost today in all the coverage of Senator Hillary Clintons rally here, where she further questioned Senator Barack Obamas readiness to serve as commander in chief: She also suggested she wanted to step up action in Afghanistan.

title: Regular-Season Champs in Czechia, Slovakia and Switzerland
description: The regular season is ending in Europe at the appropriate time nature dictates for the end of hockey seasons, late February and early March. The Czech, Slovak and Swiss leagues ended a few days ago, with the rest of the Top 7 coming up this weekend and next. Here are the champions and top scorers so far, with their runners-up for perspective:

title: Silver Defends Appointment of a Law Firm Colleague to a Judicial Panel
description: ALBANY  Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the State Assembly, on Friday defended his decision to appoint a senior partner in the law firm where he works part time to a state committee that recommends judicial nominees to the governor.

title: Prices for Most MetroCards Are Going Up This Weekend
description: It will cost more for most people to ride the subways and buses in New York City beginning Sunday morning.

title: The Ins and Outs of Impotence Drugs
description: Dr. Laurence A. Levine is a professor of urology at Rush University Medical Center in Chicago. He is president of the Sexual Medicine Society of North America and the author of numerous research studies on erectile dysfunction.

title: Its a Science Fair, Not the Nobel Prize
description: I DONT remember a whole lot from my elementary-school days, but I do recall my science fair project  putting one plant in the sun, one in the shade, watering a third and denying a fourth any hydration.

title: Livery Driver Arrested in Baby Case
description: A Queens livery driver who had become something of a hero after he took to a firehouse a baby that he said had been abandoned in his cab was arrested on Saturday after his story unraveled, the police said.

title: Owner Says Clemenss Contract Not at Issue
description: One day after the Houston Astros owner, Drayton McLane, expressed uneasiness about Roger Clemenss presence at the teams spring-training facility, Clemens flew home to Houston. McLane, however, emphasized Friday that he was not trying to terminate a 10-year personal services contract that Clemens signed with the club.

title: Ever Loyal, Yao Risks His Career
description: Yao Ming never wanted to be trapped between the Rockets and a hard place, Western capitalists and his country. He chose to honor both, and the bargain that was struck when the Chinese ceded contractual rights, if not year-round control, of their most valuable sports export.

title: Investor to Spend Up to $1 Billion to Acquire Stake in Bond Insurer
description: Wilbur L. Ross, the billionaire investor, said Friday that he would acquire a stake of up to $1 billion in Assured Guaranty, choosing to invest in a smaller but more stable bond insurance company over its larger but weakened rivals.

title: Knicks Stumble Late, and Hawks Run Past
description: ATLANTA  Joe Johnson, Atlantas All-Star forward, was finally confronted by a defender he could not take inside or shoot over, and the Hawks offense just stopped in the fourth quarter Friday night. The Knicks Jared Jeffries, who is 6-foot-11, made the 6-foot-7 Johnson disappear.

title: Producer May Leave Early Show
description: Shelley Ross, the executive producer of CBSs morning news program, The Early Show, has so alienated staff members on and off camera that she may be ousted from her position within the next few weeks, executives with knowledge of the situation said on Friday.

title: Selected Studies: Erection Problems
description: Government agencies, universities, doctors and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Clinton Questions Role of Obama in a Crisis
description: WACO, Tex.  With four days to go before voters in Texas and Ohio could determine the fate of her presidential bid, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday all but declared Senator Barack Obama unprepared to serve as commander in chief.

title: Marrying on a Leap Day: That Special Touch
description: As is sorely known, many marriages  at least two out of five  end in divorce.

title: A Card-Carrying Civil Libertarian
description: Washington

title: Police Scandal Grows to Include Possible Misuse of Money
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.  A police lieutenant in charge of the SWAT team here who has been at the center of a widening scandal has been accused of improprieties in connection with his involvement with several Hooters waitresses, his lawyer said on Friday.

title: Eni of Italy in Oil Deal in Venezuela
description: Venezuela and the Italian oil company Eni have agreed to spend $10 billion to develop a large oil field in the prolific Orinoco Belt, site of Venezuelas heavy oil deposits.

title: Jets Trade Vilma to Saints and Add Jenkins
description: The Jets were among the most active N.F.L. teams during the first day of free agency Friday. The flurry of movement included two trades: the acquisition of defensive tackle Kris Jenkins from the Panthers and the trade of linebacker Jonathan Vilma to the Saints. The Jets also made progress toward signing Steelers guard Alan Faneca.

title: On the Press Bus, Some Questions Over Favoritism
description: On the bus ferrying a group of reporters to an appearance by Senator Barack Obama at Ohio State University on Wednesday, Lee Cowan, the NBC reporter assigned to the campaign, was asked the media question of the week: Had journalists like himself been going easier on Mr. Obama than his opponent for the Democratic nomination, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton?

title: Commander Testifies He Felt Under Fire Outside Nightclub
description: The commanding officer of the detectives charged in the fatal shooting of Sean Bell testified on Friday that believing he was under fire, he drew his gun and pointed it toward the passenger windows of his car that night. He was ready not only for ambush, he said, but ready to add to the fusillade of 50 shots that claimed Mr. Bells life.

title: And Obamas Quick Response
description: This is a television advertisement for Senator Barack Obama in response to the one released on Friday by the Clinton campaign. It will begin running in Texas on Saturday.

title: Hezbollah Scolds U.S. for Sending Ships Toward Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  As American warships moved toward Lebanon on Friday, Hezbollah accused the United States of threatening regional stability, and the countrys pro-Western prime minister took pains to distance himself from the decision.

title: U.S.-Europe Team Beats Out Boeing on Big Contract
description: WASHINGTON  The Air Force, in a stunning upset against the Boeing Company, awarded a $40 billion contract for aerial refueling tankers on Friday to a partnership between Northrop Grumman and the European parent of Airbus, putting a critical military contract partly into the hands of a foreign company.

title: Canada Again Transfers Afghan Prisoners
description: OTTAWA  The Canadian military has resumed handing over prisoners captured in Afghanistan to the Afghan government, a practice it quietly suspended late last year over concerns about torture, the military said Friday.

title: As Kenya Bleeds, Tourism Also Suffers in Land of Safaris
description: KEEKOROK, Kenya  Nancy Holan just had the safari of her life. She and a friend flew to Kenya from Detroit and as they cruised the wide open plains, they had the lions, zebras and elephants all to themselves.

title: Inquiry Into Bank Practices
description: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York is investigating whether credit card marketers have offered payments or other incentives to colleges in exchange for exclusive access to the institutions students. The general counsel at Dartmouth College, Robert B. Donin, confirmed through a spokesman that the institution had received a subpoena from Mr. Cuomos office asking questions about the credit card arrangement Dartmouth has with Bank of America including marketing practices. It is not clear how many other institutions may have received subpoenas.

title: Footnotes
description: Thomas Quasthoff, the bass-baritone who was scheduled to perform as soloist with the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Monday has canceled because of a severe cold. The orchestra will perform Brahmss Serenade No. 2 instead of the previously announced Schubert songs. ... The Grammy and Emmy Award-winning rapper Eminem, below, is at work on a new book, The Way I Am, described as an intimate look inside his life, The Associated Press reported. His publisher, Dutton Books, a Penguin Group imprint, said the book was expected to reach stores in the fall. ...  Gina Gershon and Mary McCormack have landed two of the three flight attendants roles in Boeing-Boeing, the 1960s Marc Camoletti farce scheduled to open at the Longacre Theater on May 4. Ms. Gershon, whose credits include the television series Ugly Betty and Curb Your Enthusiasm, will play Gabriella, the Italian attendant. Ms. McCormack, who played Howard Sterns wife in the film Private Parts, will play Gretchen, the German flight attendant. The role of the third attendant remains to be filled. ... Adam Pascal and Anthony Rapp will reprise their original Broadway (and film) roles in Rent in a 2009 national tour of that Pulitzer Prize- and Tony Award-winning musical, which will begin in January, Playbill reported. The Broadway production ends its 11-year run on June 1 at the Nederlander Theater. ... Rod Stewart will start an 18-city North American tour in Paso Robles, Calif., on July 30 and end it in Tampa, Fla., on Aug. 28, Reuters reported. ... The Grammy winner Herbie Hancock is among the headliners scheduled for the Playboy Jazz Festival, June 14 and 15 at the Hollywood Bowl. The lineup for that 30th-annual event also includes Al Jarreau, Tower of Power, Keb Mo, the James Moody Quartet and the Roy Hargrove Big Band.

title: Concerns About the Climate That Go Beyond Snow
description: MENTION global warming and there is a good chance the conversation will turn to the future of ski resorts. But Rob Katz, chief executive of Vail Resorts, is not worried. Vail had more snow in a recent 30-day period than it has had in the last 10 years. And should snowfall decrease significantly in the future, Mr. Katz said, there will be greater concerns than how much snow there is.

title: New Lines 40 Years of Reaching Brows High and Low
description: Four years ago, on the night before the Academy Awards, I found myself at the Beverly Hills home of Bob Shaye, the founder and co-chairman of New Line Cinema.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The headline on a report in the Sports Briefing column last Saturday about the golfer Nick Prices strong second-round performance at the Mayakoba Golf Classic in Mexico misstated his standing at that point in the event. As the report noted, he was tied for eighth place  not the leader. (He finished tied for 42nd place.)

title: Super-Short Sitcoms, No TV Needed
description: Brevity may be the soul of wit, but that doesnt mean that a 5-minute online sitcom is any funnier than the standard 22-minute network version. On the other hand, the 5-minute kind does take only 5 minutes to watch  including commercials. Disney, which owns ABC, is getting into the short-form business with the introduction this week of Squeegees, a series that is being shown on ABC.com and YouTube.

title: Woman, 84, Dies After Hit-and-Run
description: An 84-year-old woman was killed by a hit-and-run driver on Friday evening while crossing Union Turnpike in the Glen Oaks section of Queens, according to the police.

title: Bush Aide Lends Support to Corzines Plan for Tolls
description: TRENTON  He may have won zero legislative support for a proposal that would raise fees on toll roads 800 percent by 2022 to support a multibillion-dollar transportation bond issue, a plan he admits needs rethinking.

title: Samuel Leaves Patriots for a 6-Year Deal With the Eagles
description: Cornerback Asante Samuel, a two-time Pro Bowl selection who won two championship rings in New England but who was beaten by David Tyree for a touchdown and dropped what might have been a game-saving interception in the Super Bowl last month, signed a six-year contract with the Philadelphia Eagles on Friday.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Films Superheroes Face Threat of Strike
description: LOS ANGELES  Do five or so of the greatest superheroes in the universe have the power to make a movie these days? Warner Brothers is struggling to find out.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an obituary on Wednesday about Dan Shomron, the Israeli military officer who led the raid to free hijacked hostages at Entebbe airport in 1976, misstated his rank at the time the picture was taken, in 1987. He was a major general, not a brigadier general. (He became a lieutenant general later in 1987.)

title: After 8 Days, Turkey Pulls Its Troops Out of Iraq
description: Turkeys military announced Friday that it had withdrawn all of its combat troops from northern Iraq, bringing an eight-day ground offensive against Kurdish guerrillas to an abrupt close, a day after the American secretary of defense warned Turkey to pull out.

title: No Charges for Winehouse
description: The British police are no longer investigating Amy Winehouse, the singer, on suspicion of trying to interfere with a court case involving her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, who was charged with attacking a pub owner and then conspiring in an attempt to bribe the owner to withdraw as a trial witness, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Winehouse, 24, had been arrested in December, then released on bail. Mr. Fielder-Civil appeared in a London court on Friday, where he pleaded not guilty to the charges against him. His next court hearing is scheduled for April.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article in Business Day last Saturday about health care costs for college students misspelled the surname of the founder of the Highland Campus Health Group, which collects third-party insurance for college health centers. He is Andrew Menter, not Mentor.

title: Gun Crazy
description: The Valentines Day massacre at Northern Illinois University, like the killings at places such as Columbine High School and Virginia Tech, has evoked expressions of horror and sympathy and familiar questions about the killers motives and mental health. Atrocities like these make Americans feel angry and perhaps helpless.

title: Mayor Vetoes Bill Protecting Section 8 Tenants From Landlord Bias
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg vetoed a bill on Friday that would prohibit landlords from discriminating against prospective tenants who use rent subsidies, setting the stage for an expected override by the City Council.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Feb. 14 about Steve Gerber, the creator of the comic-book character Howard the Duck, misspelled the surname of a survivor. The survivor, Mr. Gerbers sister, is Lisa Bedell, not Bidell.

title: NASA Announces Shuttle Mission
description: NASA managers cleared the shuttle Endeavour for liftoff on March 11 to begin a 16-day mission to the International Space Station. The mission, which involves bringing part of a new Japanese science module to the station and five space walks, will be launched at 2:28 a.m. The teams are ready to go launch, said William Gerstenmaier, the agencys manager of space operations, at a press conference at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Mr. Gerstenmaier said that analysis of the debris from a disabled satellite that the Navy destroyed last week created a trivial rise in risk.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Saturday about the outlook for the Moynihan Station project, a $14 billion proposal to rebuild Pennsylvania Station, construct skyscrapers and relocate Madison Square Garden, misstated the age of the Garden. It is 40 years old, not 30. (Go to Article)

title: Bushs Czar to Rebuild Gulf Coast Is Resigning
description: WASHINGTON The White House said Friday that the administrations Gulf Coast reconstruction czar, Donald E. Powell, was resigning to return to his family in Texas.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on page 48 of Play magazine this weekend about the turnaround of the Boston Celtics misstates the number of times forward Kevin Garnett has been an all star. It is 11, not eight. The article also refers incorrectly to Brian Scalabrine, who plays forward and center. He is one of two white players on the team, not the only one. (Scot Pollard is also white.)

title: So Theres This Orangutan, a Little Shy but Nice
description: On Sunday evening the Farrelly brothers, Peter and Bobby, will arrive on network television, as executive producers of Unhitched, a new Fox show that feels less like a comedy than an exercise in lawyerly manipulation. A look at the lives of four newly single friends in Boston, Unhitched is practically a game, an experiment in just how big a mud bath a few feral minds can make dating seem before inviting parental disinheritance or future fines from the Federal Communications Commission.

title: A Streetcart Named Healthy
description: Health experts have taken to calling low-income neighborhoods food deserts, and it is easy to see why. Supermarkets are usually in short supply and specialty produce and health-food stores are even rarer. Residents are often forced to do their food shopping in small grocery stores that carry few fresh fruits and vegetables.

title: Driver Says Man Couldnt Care for Baby Girl
description: A man who abandoned a baby girl in the back of a livery cab in Queens on Thursday confided to the driver just beforehand that the babys mother had left four days earlier and that he was incapable of caring for the child, the driver said on Friday.

title: Shanghai Cancels Art Exhibition
description: An exhibition of works by the artist Zhang Huan, right, was canceled by Shanghais local government just before it was to open this week at the Shanghai Art Museum. The Shanghai Cultural Bureau, which oversees the museum, declined to comment on Friday, as did museum officials and Mr. Zhang. But people in Shanghai closely involved with the exhibition said government officials seemed to be troubled by some of his installation works, including two sculptures, Giant 1 and Giant 2, 16-foot-tall deformed creatures with human faces and body parts made from cowhide. The same people said that museum officials were still negotiating with the government and that they hoped that it would allow the show to open within a month. China regularly censors or closes art shows, particularly if they depict work that is overtly political or has sexual or violent themes. But in recent years the government has allowed many formerly banned artists to exhibit. Mr. Zhang was once known as a performance artist, whose provocative shows caused him to be blacklisted in China.

title: The Mighty Political Legacy of William F. Buckley Jr.
description: Christopher Buckley never fully recovered from his fathers mayoral campaign in 1965.

title: Judge Reverses His Order Disabling Web Site
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A federal judge on Friday withdrew his earlier order disabling a Web site that allows the anonymous posting of documents to discourage unethical behavior in governments and corporations.

title: Pitches and Spirits Are Up in Santanas Debut
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  At Tradition Field on Friday, people in Mets caps draped themselves over a railing like bunting to get a better look at pitcher Johan Santana. And that was just in the home dugout.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Saturday about the outlook for the Moynihan Station project, a $14 billion proposal to rebuild Pennsylvania Station, construct skyscrapers and relocate Madison Square Garden, misstated the age of the Garden. It is 40 years old, not 30.

title: At Least 45 Killed in Israeli Strikes in Gaza
description: GAZA CITY  Israeli aircraft and troops attacked Palestinian positions in northern Gaza on Saturday, killing at least 45 Palestinians, 19 of them civilians, and wounding more than 100 in the deadliest day of fighting in more than a year.

title: Late Works, From Composers 34 to 89
description: In its three Examining Late Style programs at Weill Recital Hall, the Brentano String Quartet is playing music that composers wrote late in their careers. As unifying concepts go, this has a guarantee of quality built in: few composers were considered to be at their best in their early years, and late works almost always have a patina of experience and depth.

title: A Nominee? Or a Debacle?
description: When does a dandy fight become an ugly brawl?

title: Politics and Gun Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Prince Harry and the Secret Kept by Fleet Street
description: Every morning for 10 weeks, Bob Satchwell typed the words Prince Harry and Afghanistan into Google, and every morning, the top result was the same: Prince Harry Is Forbidden To Fight Alongside Soldiers In Afghanistan.

title: A C.E.O. Sells the Store
description: Womens suits. Mickey Drexler has womens suits on the brain.

title: White House E-Mail Gone Missing
description: Historians eager to search through the daily minutiae of the Bush administration can expect scandalously little help from the White Houses shoddy and suspiciously gap-ridden e-mail archives. Estimates of the number of missing e-mail messages range into the millions.

title: Vials of Ricin Are Found in Las Vegas Hotel; Man Is Hospitalized
description: LAS VEGAS  A man who stayed in a Las Vegas hotel room where ricin was found on Thursday has been hospitalized in critical condition since Feb. 14 with symptoms consistent with exposure to the deadly poison, the police said Friday.

title: Saint Laurent Finally Regains Its Swagger
description: Paris

title: Vulgarity Becomes Perfectly Wholesome
description: LAS VEGAS, March 1  Just what this city desperately needed: a bracing injection of vulgarity!

title: Education Cuts in California
description: To the Editor:

title: McCain Was Born in the Panama Canal Zone. So?
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqi Leaders Say the Way Is Clear for the Execution of Chemical Ali
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi leaders say they have found a way to execute Ali Hassan al-Majid, known as Chemical Ali and one of Saddam Husseins most notorious henchmen.

title: In Tennessee, 2 Endangered Groups Meet by Chance
description: BELLS BEND, Tenn.  Two unexpected guests showed up over the winter at George Wests farm here, rare whooping cranes that landed in Mr. Wests rich, boggy turnip field five miles from Nashville and were spotted by local birders during the annual Audubon count.

title: Colombian Forces Kill Rebel Leader
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Colombias defense ministry announced Saturday that security forces had killed a senior commander of the countrys largest guerrilla group in combat along the southern border with Ecuador.

title: FEMA Seeks Alternative to Trailers
description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency plans to start trying out new kinds of manufactured housing for disaster victims later this year, in the hopes of finding an acceptable alternative to its much maligned travel trailers, agency officials said. FEMA has stopped using the tinny white trailers, in part because they have been found to contain high levels of formaldehyde. There are still more than 36,000 occupied trailers along the Gulf Coast, but the agency is trying to move people out of them by June 1. In addition to ensuring safe air quality for disaster victims, the agency is hoping to find something roomier than trailers, which are not designed for long-term use, said David Garratt, deputy assistant administrator of the disaster assistance directorate.

title: Cuba Signs Two Treaties on Rights
description: HAVANA  Just days after Ral Castro took office as president of Cuba, its Communist government signed two important international human rights treaties that Fidel Castro had long opposed, another sign the new administration may be willing to set a new course.

title: A Semifinal in Taiwan, and a Gem of Defense
description: The best finish by an American team in the Yeh Bros Cup, played in Taiwan two weeks ago, was by U.S.A. I, JoAnna and Lew Stansby of Castro Valley, Calif.; George Jacobs and Ralph Katz of Hinsdale, Ill.; and Howard Weinstein of Sarasota, Fla.

title: Evidence of Positive Drug Tests for Bonds
description: Grand jury testimony given by Barry Bonds nearly five years ago was unsealed Friday and it revealed that prosecutors have evidence that Bonds had elevated levels of testosterone on two private tests.

title: Paper Is Penalized for Labor Violations
description: LOS ANGELES  One of the areas largest Chinese-language newspapers was ordered by a federal judge here Friday to pay millions of dollars to 200 employees who were denied years of overtime pay and subjected to other labor law violations.

title: A Town and a Baptist Pastor Vie Over Eternity
description: CATHEDRAL CITY, Calif.  Upon reflection, Jim Nimmons could think of no particular event that led him to crawl atop the roof of the First Southern Baptist Church with a can of red paint and splash the world eternity across its shingles.

title: Free Lunch Isnt Cool, So Some Students Go Hungry
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Although Francisco Velazquez, a 14-year-old freshman with spiky hair and sunglasses, qualifies for a free lunch at Balboa High School here, he was not eating.

title: Obama Walks a Difficult Path as He Courts Jewish Voters
description: As he battles for the Democratic nomination, Senator Barack Obama is trying to strengthen his support among Jewish voters and in doing so, is navigating one of the more treacherous paths of Democratic politics.

title: Un-Naming Rights
description: IF the University of Wisconsin business school ever writes a case study about itself, the lesson may be that some things are more valuable unsold.

title: What to Ask About Erection Problems
description: Talking to your doctor about erectile function shouldnt be embarrassing, but it still is for some men. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: Petraeus to Seek to Limit Pause in Pullout to 6 Weeks
description: WASHINGTON  The top American military commander in Iraq will recommend that President Bush order a brief pause in troop reductions from Iraq this summer, but the White House expects that the withdrawals will resume before Mr. Bush leaves office, a senior administration official said Friday.

title: After All That, Theyre Still Standing
description: To the Editor:

title: A Poet Laureate for Minnesota
description: Robert Bly, who lives in Minneapolis, has been named Minnesotas first poet laureate by Gov. Tim Pawlenty, The Minneapolis Star-Tribunes Web site reported. In accepting the honorary post, the 81-year-old Mr. Bly  who has written more than 30 books of poetry but is probably best known for Iron John: A Book About Men, a 1990 prose exploration of mythology  said: I dont know of any official duties. I may do an anthology of Minnesota poets, but I wont be writing any state poems. Ill give it a year or two and then turn it over to one of the younger poets.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Monday about the trainer Nick Zitos success with horses running at Gulfstream Park in Florida in two events, the Fountain of Youth Stakes and an allowance race, misstated the timing of the races. They were on Sunday, not last Saturday.

title: Separating Gender and Political Identity in Clinton Story
description: Move beyond the tactical skirmishes in this campaign, and one of the most intriguing issues remains the influence of gender on Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons candidacy.

title: Giants Lose Three Players in Free Agency
description: The Super Bowl champion Giants proved popular on the first day of free agency Friday. They lost the starting linebacker Kawika Mitchell to the Buffalo Bills, safety Gibril Wilson to the Oakland Raiders and the backup linebacker Reggie Torbor to the Miami Dolphins.

title: In Kenya, U.S. Added Action to Talk of Democracy
description: WASHINGTON  Within hours of Thursdays power-sharing deal between Kenyas rival leaders, the State Department issued a rare statement from Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, praising the pact and citing the United States for providing intensive support to bring it about.

title: Violence Dips, but Israel and Hamas Sharpen Words
description: JERUSALEM  It was a day of threats and protest on Friday in Israels conflict with Hamas, with considerably less violence and death than over the previous two days, when more than 30 Palestinians died, five of them children, and one Israeli died in the border town of Sderot.

title: Amputee Wrestler Loses, but Wins a Following
description: The high school wrestling career of Dustin Carter ended Friday in defeat but with an ovation from the crowd at the Schottenstein Center in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Japanese Drop Rape Charges Against Marine
description: TOKYO  An American marine accused of raping a 14-year-old girl on Okinawa was released by the Japanese police on Friday after the girl dropped her accusation, the police said.

title: Directors Brief Stay at Dia Is Over
description: Only nine months after taking over, Jeffrey Weiss has resigned as director of the Dia Art Foundation, saying he had realized he was not cut out for the job.

title: U.S. Seeks Sanctions Against Lender
description: Countrywide Home Loans, the troubled mortgage lender that has agreed to be sold to Bank of America, engaged in questionable conduct in a bankruptcy case involving two borrowers in Atlanta, the United States Trustee contended in a lawsuit filed late Thursday.

title: Corzine Defies a History of Failed Buyout Packages
description: A year ago, the Corzine administration expressed reservations about using early retirement incentives to reduce state spending. With good reason: New Jersey had tried it at least five times, and it worked so poorly each time, actually costing the state money, that a special commission advised against ever doing it again.

title: Head of Financial Products Unit Stepping Down at A.I.G.
description: American International Group, the insurance company, said Friday that the head of its financial products unit, Joseph Cassano, was stepping down after the insurer reported $11.1 billion in losses on contracts sold to fixed-income investors.

title: Barbara Seaman, 72, Dies; Cited Risks of the Pill
description: Barbara Seaman, a writer and patients rights advocate who was one of the first people to bring the issue of womens reproductive health to wide public attention, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 72.

title: Bloomberg Steps In to Help G.O.P. in Albany Fight
description: While declaring his commitment to nonpartisanship, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is quietly injecting himself  and his money  into one of the most explosive partisan battles in decades in New York.

title: Rhythm in Abundance, With a Spirit of Adventure
description: Anyone who has suffered an extended bout of heart arrhythmia will tell you that it can be a profoundly discomfiting experience, accompanied by lightheadedness, shortness of breath and fatigue, and utterly devoid of aesthetic fascination or gratification. So it is just as well that the contemporary-music ensemble Alarm Will Sound only meagerly evoked the real thing in its program A/rhythmia on Thursday night at Zankel Hall.

title: A Bride, a Groom and Bellinis Bel Canto Hurdles
description: During the triumphant premiere of Bellinis Sonnambula in 1831, both singers and audience members wept in the second act, the Russian composer Glinka reported. There were no meltdowns during the Opera Orchestra of New Yorks concert performance on Wednesday, but plenty of emotion onstage and off accompanied some fine singing.

title: My Forbidden Fruits (and Vegetables)
description: Rushford, Minn.

title: In 08 Politics, Rhode Island Defies Its Size
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  For the first time anyone can remember, this small state is relishing its role in the presidential primary cycle.

title: Rhetoric: High; Anxiety: Low
description: WASHINGTON  The warnings from President Bush and his senior aides have grown more urgent over the last few weeks, now that Congress has let a temporary wiretapping law expire. But there is little sign of anxiety among many intelligence and phone industry officials.

title: Long Slump May Mean Drug Stocks Are Bargains
description: SHARES of drug makers are usually in demand when the economic outlook is cloudy and investors are avoiding risk. The companies stable earnings may be less appealing this time because the sector faces some new risks.

title: Arctic Monkeys Rule British Music Awards
description: The Arctic Monkeys, above, were nominated for seven awards and won three at the annual NME Awards in London, including best band, best video (Teddy Picker) and best track (Fluorescent Adolescent,), the BBC reported. The awards, named for the music magazine NME (for New Musical Express), are determined by readers, who voted Pete Doherty of Babyshambles Hero of the Year, and President Bush Villain of the Year. Winners of the other major awards included the Killers (best international band); the Enemy (best new band); Muse (best live band); Kate Nash (best solo artist). Myths of the Near Future, by the Klaxons, was voted the best album.

title: Buffetts State of the World: Theres Folly in Wonderland
description: The billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett disclosed Friday that he had earned profits for shareholders of Berkshire Hathaway by speculating in the Brazilian currency, the real, and by buying a large stake in a French pharmaceutical company, Sanofi-Aventis.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A Spare Times listing in Weekend on Friday about daily walking tours that focus on Park Slope and Prospect Park in Brooklyn misstated part of the name of the group that runs them. It is A Tour Grows in Brooklyn, not A Tree Grows in Brooklyn.

title: Protest Calls for Resignation of Filipino President
description: MANILA  In one of the largest demonstrations against President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo since she took office in 2001, thousands of Filipinos took to the streets on Friday, demanding her resignation over a corruption scandal.

title: Bankruptcy Court Asked to Sanction Countrywide
description: In a move that escalates the legal trouble faced by the mortgage lender, the Countrywide Financial Corporation, federal regulators have asked the courts to sanction the company for abusing the bankruptcy system.

title: On a Golf Course, Seeking Out the Water Hazards
description: BOYNTON BEACH, Fla.  As with any piece of water that you fish a lot, I have become intimately acquainted with the golf course water hazards of Hunters Run, my parents condo community: the patches of lily pads, the small stands of reeds, the palm trees imported at great expense, the fairways and greens in a state of never-ending manicure. Lifes landmarks abound here for me as much as they do on my favorite trout pool in the Catskills or bonefish flat in the Keys.

title: Wanted by F.B.I., but Walking Out of a Yemen Hearing
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Jaber Elbaneh has been one of the F.B.I.s most wanted terrorism suspects ever since he escaped from a high-security prison two years ago in Sana, the capital of Yemen.

title: Frugality Can Be Acquired, but It Cant Be Bought
description: Consumers, long held up as the saviors of the American economy as it rose, are taking some of the blame for its fall. Consumers, their critics now say, were too eager to buy big, expensive houses and to fill them with the latest electronic gadgets. Consumers used their houses as piggy banks, these critics go on, to pay for their profligate ways. The question is, How do consumers learn how to deal with their finances? How do they learn how to save, invest and manage their money?

title: Markets Fall on Drumbeat of Grim Reports
description: An outpouring of negative economic and financial reports soured the mood on Wall Street Friday as banks and other lenders further tightened credit in their struggle to contain damage from losses on mortgages, business loans and related debt.

title: The Outsider in Their Midst: Brittens Tale of the Haunted Misfit
description: The Metropolitan Operas landmark 1967 production of Brittens Peter Grimes, directed by Tyrone Guthrie and mounted for the colossal tenor Jon Vickers, was bound to be a tough act to follow. But the time had come for a new roster of artists to take a fresh look at this work, among the true operatic masterpieces of the 20th century. So there were high expectations on Thursday night when the Met presented a new staging by the noted director John Doyle, in his company debut.

title: Musical Diplomacy
description: To the Editor:

title: New Role for Oprah: Playing Fairy Godmother on Reality TV
description: Good, new-fashioned American know-how is the ability to blend contradictory impulses, from all-you-can-eat diet plans to altruism that pays. And nobody is better at that kind of alchemy than Oprah Winfrey. Her companys first network reality show, Oprahs Big Give, which makes its debut on ABC this Sunday, is ingenious: a fierce, cutthroat competition between people who are dedicated to doing good.

title: A Cable Drama Gets a Makeover Ripped From the Tabloid Headlines
description: LOS ANGELES  In a world where a former Mouseketeer is involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward, where celebutantes flash their private parts to photographers, and actors seemingly have bail bondsmen on speed dial, it might seem easy to make a fictional television show about a tabloid devoted to outrageous celebrity behavior.

title: Bush Aide Resigns After Admitting Plagiarism
description: WASHINGTON  A longtime aide to President Bush who wrote occasional guest columns for his hometown newspaper resigned on Friday evening after admitting that he had repeatedly plagiarized from other writers.

title: Clinton on Experience ...
description: This is a television advertisement for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton that began running on Friday in Texas:

title: A Lawmaker Whose Nation Dislikes Her Friends
description: Caracas, Venezuela

title: As a City Was Remade, a Teachers Dedication Never Faltered
description: NEWARK  There was no trace of thunder in his voice or malice in his rebukes, but somehow Caesar Casale led a school here for decades, transforming it into something like a family.

title: The Art of the Save, for Goalie and Investor
description: When it comes to choosing what to do, sometimes the best thing is nothing.

title: Inspired by Her Idol, Vonn Has Raced to the Top
description: Lindsey Vonn remembers when she was 9 years old and first met Picabo Street, who had emerged as a skiing star in the Olympics and on the World Cup circuit. Street was signing autographs at a ski shop in Minneapolis.

title: Small and Quirky Davidson Faces Uphill Fight
description: DAVIDSON, N.C.  Among the unusual facets of Davidson College, besides a basketball team with the nations longest winning streak, is a low-slung building amid the stately ones made of red bricks and white columns.

title: Woman Fatally Stabbed at East Village Store
description: A worker at a grocery store in the East Village who colleagues said was despondent over a breakup with his girlfriend, a cashier there, fatally stabbed her at the store on Friday afternoon and also slashed another employee, the police said.

title: Boyd Coddington, 63, King of Hot Rods, Dies
description: Boyd Coddington, one of the first, and perhaps the best known, of the Southern California hot-rod builders, who turned a backyard hobby of tattooed guys in T-shirts into a boutique industry of high-end car customizers, died Feb. 27 in Whittier, Calif. He was 63 and lived in La Habra Heights, Calif.

title: Of Ohio, Texas and Onion Dip
description: CINCINNATI

title: Shuttle Cleared for Scheduled Liftoff
description: NASA managers cleared the shuttle Endeavour for liftoff on March 11 to begin a 16-day mission to the International Space Station. The mission, which involves taking part of a Japanese science module to the station and conducting five spacewalks, will be launched at 2:28 a.m. William Gerstenmaier, the agencys manager of space operations, also said that analysis of the debris from a disabled satellite that the Navy destroyed last week created a trivial rise in risk.

title: 'Lyrics' Outdraws 'Lost'
description: Dont Forget the Lyrics, on Fox, drew its highest ratings ever on Thursday, delivering 14.6 million viewers and beating ABCs Lost (12.8 million) at 9 p.m. But among adults 18 to 49, Lost held a slight lead. Lyrics, a singing game show, benefited from following Foxs American Idol, which led the night with 25.9 million viewers at 8, Nielsen estimated. ABC ranked third for the night, trailing Fox and CBS, which ranked second, thanks to Survivor: Micronesia at 8 (12.5 million), followed by reruns of CSI (11.6 million) and Without a Trace (10.4 million). ABC ran close behind CBS in the 18-to-49 set. NBC was a distant fourth over all, drawing its highest ratings at 9 with The Celebrity Apprentice (7.6 million) but struggling at 10 with Lipstick Jungle (5.7 million).

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Page 32 of The Times Magazine this weekend about Edward Limonov, a Russian novelist and political dissident, misspells the name of a city he spent time in during the early 60s. It is Kharkiv, not Kharkov.

title: Opening Night of a Portfolio of Premieres and Old Favorites
description: Only four choreographers alive today have each created a number of works that stand as classics. It is remarkable that all four  Merce Cunningham, Paul Taylor, Twyla Tharp and Mark Morris  are American. Though all have had important contact with ballet during their careers, its also remarkable that they first made their mark in modern dance, and only Ms. Tharp has become so much a crossover artist that she can no longer be counted as primarily a modern-dance choreographer.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Page 40 of Play magazine this weekend about the shift in control of the Yankees from George Steinbrenner to his sons misstates the number of years Mr. Steinbrenner has owned the team. It is 35, not 30.

title: F.D.A. Approves Wyeth Antidepressant
description: Faced with the looming loss of patent protection for its top-selling drug, the antidepressant Effexor XR, Wyeth received federal approval on Friday for a successor drug, Pristiq, which the company hopes will also become a blockbuster.

title: At Lent, a Most Powerful Rendering of the 14 Stations
description: The Stations of the Cross are many things, as visitors to an exhibit at Manhattans historic Trinity Church, at the intersection of Broadway and Wall Street, are reminded.

title: Suspects Charged in Bhuttos Killing
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistani police formally accused the militant leader Baitullah Mehsud on Saturday of planning the assassination of the former prime minister and opposition leader Benazir Bhutto.

title: Outlining an Operation That Preyed on Builders
description: Escorted by detectives, Anthony Lewis clanked into a Manhattan courtroom this week to make his public debut as a shakedown artist of dazzling originality, a charge he denied by calling not guilty without rising an inch from his chair.

title: Dangerous Neighborhood
description: Turkeys anger at cross-border attacks by Kurdish rebels is understandable. But its decision to send what the Turkish news media said were thousands of troops into Northern Iraq last week was risky, verging on foolhardy. The last thing Iraq, Turkey or the United States need is more chaos in the region.

title: Entering and Exiting Myths at Her Own Quiet Pace
description: The three pieces in Dagmar Spains Beside Me, presented on Thursday night at Danspace Project at St. Marks Church, use the same simple set. Two free-standing white panels, side by side, with utilitarian doors cut into them, sometimes serve as video screens. The dancers come in and out of the doors, unassumingly and at perfectly timed moments, to enter and leave the worlds of the dances.

title: Reconstructing Bach
description: Experts have digitally rebuilt the face of Johann Sebastian Bach, Reuters reported. Using his bones and computer modeling, they have come up with an image of a thick-set man with closely cropped white hair. The new Bach face, the creation of a Scottish forensic anthropologist, Caroline Wilkinson, is to go on display at the Bachhaus museum in Eisenach, Germany, his birthplace, next month. For most people Bach is an old man in a wig, it is a stylized image, we have no realistic portrait of him, Joerg Hansen, the managing director of the museum, said. Bachs bones were excavated in 1894 and first used to help create a bust in 1908. But it was mainly based on a portrait of him, and critics at the time said it was so inaccurate that it might as well have been Handel.

title: Preserving a Forest and a Philosophy
description: MONTEVERDE, Costa Rica  A group of pioneers in the green business were getting back to their roots with a two-day hike through a pristine rain forest in Costa Rica when they hit Fer-de-lance Hill.

title: Aloof From Recession
description: IN a scene from the fourth season of the HBO mob saga The Sopranos, the crime boss Tony Soprano gathers his crew chiefs together for a dressing-down. The 2002 recession is in full swing, but that is no excuse, he tells them. They are not earning enough for the family. He asks his consigliere, Silvio Dante, to name the two industries that are known to be recession-proof. Certain aspects of the entertainment business, Mr. Dante says. And our thing.

title: Yankees Put Their New Look on Display
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Change is everywhere in George Steinbrenners Yankees empire. There is a new stadium rising in the Bronx, a new manager in the dugout, new pitchers on the mound, new leadership in the front office.

title: First Come Erectile Ills, Then Heart Troubles
description: As if a blow to ones masculinity werent bad enough. Researchers now say that for men over 40, having trouble getting or maintaining an erection is often a sign of something more worrying: cardiovascular disease. Indeed, theres growing consensus that erection problems are a risk factor for heart disease, right up there with smoking and high blood pressure.

title: In Parts of U.S., Foreclosures Top Sales
description: Mortgage foreclosure notices are going out so fast that in some states the number of new foreclosure proceedings each month is greater than the number of homes sold that month.

title: Age-Specific Advice for Erection Problems
description: Dr. Harry Fisch is director of the Male Reproductive Center at Columbia University Medical Center of New York-Presbyterian Hospital and the author of The Male Biological Clock (Free Press, 2004). He has written widely on erectile dysfunction and treated thousands of men with the problem. He offers these five important things to know if youre having erection problems.

title: Paul Hamm, After Hiatus, Works for Chance to Defend Title
description: Paul Hamm could be angry, or at least upset.

title: One Work in Progress, One Tug of War
description: Attending any kind of contemporary performance requires a leap of faith. Its not a small one, either, as most of what is being made at any given moment is safe, predictable and wholly without reason for being. In the leap lies the excitement, of course, but it dies fast if the artist hasnt taken a few leaps of his or her own.

title: Eclectic Mix to Testify at Hollywood Detectives Trial
description: LOS ANGELES  A hedge fund manager, the billionaire founder of a buyout firm and the former wives of a television actor and a major real estate developer will be crucial witnesses at the racketeering trial of Anthony Pellicano, the Hollywood private eye, beginning next week.

title: Vladimir Putin and Russias Battle With the N.H.L.
description: If you happened upon the home page of the Russian Hockey Federations Web site on Leap Day, youd have come across this article, with its photograph of outgoing President Vladimir Putin at his desk and the headline Putin Signs Federal Law on Introduction of Changes to Russian Federation Labor Code.'

title: Respond to Todays Column: Of Ohio, Texas and Onion Dip
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Saturday, Mar. 1 column.

title: Paris: Rocks Off
description: Around midnight, Mr. Alloux left me on the corner of Rue St. Honore and I went into the Castiglione for a nightcap. Augustin, one of the barmen, was starting to close up and he tipped over the change coaster, signaling the drink was on the house. I had just come from listening to Amy Winehouse sing at the Fendi party, a collision of names, I admit, that is strange but no stranger than a lot of the stuff you hear or see in the course of the day here.

title: Day 1: Hallo Salzburg
description: SALZBURG, Austria  This is not exactly the end of the earth, but traveling here from Newark made for a long, long day that melted into a long, long night.

title: Paris Fashion Week | Alexander McQueen
description: The Fashion Telex: In which the editors of T: The New York Times Style Magazine file almost-real-time dispatches from the show of the moment. This week, the Telex comes from Paris womens fashion week.

title: All roads in Rome lead to Contemporary Art
description: All roads its said lead to Rome. Including, this weekend,  The Road to Contemporary Art, the quirky name given to a weekend-long cutting-edge cultural smorgasbord concocted by Roberto Casiraghi, who helped put Turin on the contemporary art map.

title: Live From Colette | Eve
description: This week, as The Moment blogs from the Colette boutique in Paris, were stalking the fashion faithful as they pass through the chic boutique.

title: The Early Word: Little Rhody in a Big Way
description: The smallest state is a big deal politically these days, as the candidates campaign in Rhode Island in advance of its primary on Tuesday. The Timess Abby Goodnough finds that while the state is heavy with Mrs. Clintons base voters, young voters (who tend to support Mr. Obama) made up a disproportionate share of new registrants. The Washington Post also looks at the campaign in the state, including the Obama camps efforts to lower Clinton morale by opening an office in what should be her stronghold.

title: Video: There Will Be Blood
description: Video

title: Day 2: Salzburg Storm Warning
description: SALZBURG, Austria  An intermittent alpine gale, which included high winds, rain, thunder and lightning, on Saturday caused officials to postpone the scheduled scrimmage between the Red Bulls and the reserve team of their Salzburg sister club. In addition, Austrian league officials postponed the days slate of games in the T-Mobile Bundesliga. Both matches are now expected to be played on Monday.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Saturday, Mar. 1:

title: Its a Good Day to Be Shelley Duncan
description: The Yankees plan to use Jason Giambi at first base every other day, Manager Joe Girardi said, and today is Shelley Duncans turn. An inning into their game in Clearwater against the Phillies, it has been Duncans kind of day.

title: Ive Fallen and I Cant Get Up
description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

description: The Sudanese Government has responded to my Thursday column as follows:

title: Torre Is in Demand, at Mets Camp
description: A Dodger coming off knee surgery found himself the main target of autograph-seeking Mets fans Saturday at Tradition Field.

title: Send in the Celebrities
description: In case the Democratic voters of Texas, Ohio, Vermont and Rhode Island are still having trouble making up their minds after nearly two weeks of uninterrupted campaigning in those states, the celebrities are here to help.

title: Separating Gender and Political Identity in Clinton Story
description: In her Web column today, Robin Toner writes that some of the enduring questions about Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons candidacy are fundamental and  even with modern polling technology  almost impossible to answer. For example: How much of Senator Clintons political vulnerability is linked to being a woman, and how much to her own, very specific political identity and past? Why do so many Democratic men and women, at this particular moment, see the race so differently? Go to column

title: Shelley Ross May Leave Early Show
description: Shelley Ross moved to The Early Show on CBS last September. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

title: Sundays Breakfast Menu, March 2
description: On the last Sunday before the March 4 primaries, the candidates surrogates are putting in their time on the talk circuit, but also shifting the conversation gradually back to the legislative business of Washington.

title: Cold Weather in a Warming Climate
description: [UPDATE, 3/5  Related followup post is here.][UPDATE 3/9: Some readers have urged me to close the comment string. I think that may be sensible at this point. Please email me at dotearth@nytimes.com if you strongly object.]I have a story this weekend exploring the recent global cold snap and the first big conclave of scientists and citizens who reject  for personal or professional reasons  the dominant scientific view that humans are poised to dangerously heat the planet.

title: Obamas Rhode Island Jaunt
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  Senator Barack Obama arrived about an hour late at Rhode Island College in Providence, first addressing an overflow crowd of several thousand who had waited for hours in the cold rain and mud but were turned away from the packed college gymnasium. He then spoke for nearly an hour to about 5,000 more people in the gym as he tried to woo a state where the Clinton campaign has been counting on a victory.

title: Idiomatic Depression
description: From The Onion:

title: A Beached Whale Was Spotted Driving a Camaro
description: Aired Friday night on NBC: Political experts are saying that to offset his weaknesses, Barack Obama should choose a running mate who is older, a veteran and from a different part of the country. So today, Obama chose John McCain.

description: (Jessica Antola)

title: For the Moment | Emmanuel Perrotin Samples Gelitin
description: As a special treat for readers of The Moment, the power gallerist Emmanuel Perrotin writes about new exhibitions in Paris.

title: Letters: Readers Speak
description: Re What That McCain Article Didnt Say (Feb. 24): The beauty of the Feb. 21 front-page article about Senator John McCain is that it was constructed in such a way that The New York Times could go either way with it, depending on how the public responded.If the public bought in, the paper could leverage the impact with expanded editorial and Op-Ed coverage. If the public thought it was a lot of hooey, which they did, they could go to Plan B and send the public editor into the fray to apologize for any misunderstanding and point out that the story did not actually say what it was intended to suggest.Either way, The Times would keep alive a story that the public correctly recognized as insubstantial.Margaret McGirrGreenwich, Conn., Feb. 25, 2008

title: The Contours of the Race in Ohio
description: In Ohio, the potentially decisive battle between Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton is being waged with money and organization.

title: So What Is This Voting Anyway?
description: Among the legions turning out for the first time? Take this faux 1950s civics lesson featuring Ed Helms of The Daily Show:

description: There will be more soon on our pro football page, but the news is this: A day after beefing up their defensive line with the All-Pro Kris Jenkins, the Jets have signed the All-Pro guard Alan Faneca for the offensive side. Greg Bishop reports:

title: Changing Times at Harvard?
description: Harvards freshman basketball class for next season is expected to be among the 25 best in the country. However, as Pete Thamel reports, the influx of recruiting talent has some wondering if Harvard has lowered its academic standards in the hopes of being more successful on the court.

title: Spiritual Comfort
description: A stretch of White Plains Road in the north Bronx is home to many houses of worship.

title: Clintons Surprise SNL Appearance
description: When the Clinton campaign plane took off from Texas this afternoon, one person was missing: Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Meet the Ambulance Halfway
description: Aired Friday night on NBC: Happy Leap Year! This is February 29th. How about that? In fact, when President Bush heard that, he said, Remember, turn your clocks ahead one year, everybody.

title: Your Comments on my Sunday Sudan Column
description: My Sunday column is from Abyei, on the oil-rich divide between north and south Sudan. Id welcome your comments.

title: Overheard During Free Agency
description: We feel this is a significant day in Buffalo Bills history.  Russ Brandon, the Bills chief operating officer.

title: Crowning Achievements for Two Brother-Architects
description: GEORGE AND EDWARD BLUM are known for their sinuous, carefully crafted Art Nouveau apartment houses built around 1910. After that, their designs verged on the conventional, but in 1929 and 1930, near the end of their practice, they did two striking Art Deco buildings, one at 210 East 68th Street and the other at 235 East 22nd Street.

title: Get Me Rewrite!
description: To the Editor:

title: Why We Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: Religion Is Less a Birthright Than a Good Fit
description: I WAS raised a Protestant in a Rockwellian New Hampshire village that was the proud home to stout, wood-frame churches and Saturday night ham-and-bean suppers.

title: Dark Art
description: When Stephen King accepted the National Book Foundation Medal for Distinguished Contribution to American Letters in 2003, he drew attention to the cultural divide between the so-called popular fiction and the so-called literary fiction. The award of the medal to a guy like me inspired the hope that in the future things dont have to be the way theyve always been. Bridges can be built.

title: In Acapulco, a Return to Glamour
description: IT was a balmy evening in Acapulco, and up and down the towns main drag, the college party crowd was again on its nightly pub crawl, belting out one too many Jimmy Buffett tunes and guzzling a few too many Coronas. Nearby, the famous La Quebrada cliff divers had finished the evenings last show, sending moms and dads to Planet Hollywood to keep their antsy kids distracted, as two hulking cruise ships sat towering on the waterfront.

title: A Carload at a Time
description: AS he stepped into the small storefront on Norfolk Street, Stephen Kushner, a hairdresser from Long Island, was transported to a youth spent steaming up car windows with his steady at drive-in theaters.

title: Abbas Puts Talks With Israel on Hold Amid Violence
description: ASHKELON, Israel  Israeli-Palestinian violence spilled over from Gaza to the West Bank on Sunday, and a spokesman for the Western-backed Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, said contacts with Israel had been temporarily suspended in light of the Israeli aggression.

title: Letter: Going for the Cold
description: To the Editor: In the article "Cold Water Cruises" (Feb. 17) on cruises to colder climes (Antarctica, Greenland, Canada), it seems you focused on only traditional cruise lines. For those truly interested in a cold-destination adventure, there are much more intrepid ships available.

title: Fitting In, Japanese Style
description: I WAS born in New Jersey. In high school I was a floater at Bloomingdales in Short Hills, N.J., on the weekends, which means I worked wherever they needed me.

title: High Crimes
description: MOUNT EVEREST, NEPAL  MAY 18, 2004

title: Pakistani Police Accuse Militant in Bhutto Death
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani police formally accused the militant leader Baitullah Mehsud on Saturday of planning the assassination of the former prime minister and opposition leader Benazir Bhutto.

title: Afghanistan. Pakistan. Forgotten.
description: THE next president will have to rally America and the world to fight them over there unless we want to fight them over here. The over there is not, as President Bush has claimed, Iraq, but rather the border of Afghanistan and Pakistan.

title: Oedipus Bronx
description: Hank Steinbrenner was driving like he owned the place. This things got no pickup, he said, gunning my midsize Hyundai down Steinbrenner Drive in Tampa, Fla. We had just finished lunch on a January afternoon at a Steinbrenner family favorite, an Italian restaurant called Iavarones, and were on our way back to his new office at Legends Field in my rental car, which Hank had insisted on driving. As we approached the ballpark, he steered the car up onto the curb, drove it on the main walkway, between the Yankees merchandise store and a small memorial park devoted to Yankee immortals, and came to a stop just a few feet from the tinted-glass door marked Executive Offices. This is where I usually park, Hank said, stepping out of the Hyundai and tossing me the keys.

title: Julianne Forrest, Michael Wainstein
description: Julianne Himiko Forrest, the daughter of Kazue Forrest and Gene Forrest of Delray Beach, Fla., was married on Thursday at the New York City Municipal Building to Michael Wainstein, a son of Fanny Wainstein and Dr. Sasha Wainstein of Hewlett Bay Park, N.Y. Blanca Martinez, a staff member of the City Clerks Office, officiated.

title: Big-time Losers
description: Behold the spectacle of the Bad Owner. He says he wants to win  really, he does!  but he never seems to have a clue as to how to go about it. (James Dolan of your New York Knicks, ladies and gentlemen?) Sometimes he spends his money so freely he appears to have forgotten the business acumen that made him rich in the first place. (How about the Texas Rangers owner, Tom Hicks, the original over-payer of Alex Rodriguez?) In other cases, he cant bring himself to bid for free agents and keeps his payroll so low that players flee the franchise as soon as they can. He chews through coaches  or keeps them too long. He surrounds himself with mediocre executives. Even though he gets top draft picks almost every year (and, in the National Football League, an easier schedule) to compensate for all the losing, his fortunes never seem to change. (Bill Bidwill and the Arizona Cardinals, anyone?)

title: I Need a Virtual Break. No, Really.
description: I TOOK a real day off this weekend: computers shut down, cellphone left in my work bag, land-line ringer off. I was fully disconnected for 24 hours.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 1, 2008

title: Its No Time to Cut Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Colombian Forces Kill Senior Guerrilla Commander, Official Says
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Colombias Defense Ministry announced Saturday that security forces had killed a senior commander of the countrys largest guerrilla group in combat along the southern border with Ecuador.

title: Preserving the Best of the Old
description: AN exceptional brownstone presides over a block just off Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem. While most of the houses on the street have things to recommend them, this particular house  designed by Cleverdon & Putzel  has the most panache and much of its original detail.

title: Still Looking for a Job? Its Time to Refocus
description: Q. You have been out of work and looking for a job for several months and feel discouraged. How can you re-energize yourself and your search?

title: Newest High Rollers Playground Gets Set to Open Its Doors
description: High rollers, get ready. Connecticuts newest resort casino, set to open this May, will be taking reservations starting tomorrow. The MGM Grand at Foxwoods, located in Mashantucket, will feature 825 guest rooms and suites, a 4,000-seat MGM Grand Theater, a casino, a nightclub, 115,000 square feet of meeting space, a 5,500-square-foot outdoor swimming pool and a 21,000-square-foot spa with 12 treatment rooms. There will also be a retail concourse on the property and several celebrity-chef restaurants, like Michael Schlows Alta Strada and Tom Colicchios Craftsteak. Guests will have access to the Lake of Isles golf courses. Nightly rates start at $295. To make reservations, call (866) 646-0050 or visit www.mgmatfoxwoods.com.

title: A Doctors Notes
description: I am an internist. A life-insurance company rejected a patient of mine when it saw on his medical records, read with his consent, that he has used drugs recreationally. He angrily told me he didnt know this would be in his records (although he saw me taking notes during his visits). Should I include such things in patients records and emphasize that Im doing so, even if it leads my patients to withhold important information?  MICHAEL WOHLFEILER, M.D., MIAMI BEACH

title: Chalkboard Special: Soup
description: Rustic charm is to be expected at the Fairmount Country Store in Chatham. But this 40-seat luncheonette, on a bend in the road, also yields some surprises.

title: From Grandmother to Grandson
description: SAM HERZLINGER, 27, is one of those struggling artists who manage to live in New York against all odds. His guardian angel is his beloved grandmother Molly (ne Manya) Cohen, who bought a brand-new apartment in Astoria, Queens, 58 years ago. She died in 2000, and he moved in during the summer of 2003.

title: Putins Pariah
description: It began inauspiciously. On a frozen afternoon in late November, as Moscow was draped with blocklong plastic billboards, banners and flags, each proclaiming a variation on a single theme  POBEDA PUTINA  POBEDA ROSSII! (A Victory for Putin Is a Victory for Russia)  a few thousand Russians converged on the city center for a rare act of political theater. It seemed, at first, like a tableau from the last days of the U.S.S.R., those heady months when glasnost swelled the streets with protesters. A handful of dissidents stood on a flatbed truck; a jumble of loudspeakers were stacked below; the crew of foreign reporters vastly outnumbered the local press; and across the way, the secret policemen with their unseen amplifiers were drowning the protest in canned laughter and Soviet waltzes.

title: What a Difference a Freakishly Long, Ungodly Talented, Defensive Wizard of a Man Makes
description: There are many things that N.B.A. players excel at doing. Running, Jumping, Selling shoes. At these specific skill sets, N.B.A. players rank among the worlds elite. But there are other things that N.B.A. players consistently struggle with, and talking about their feelings is one of them. This should not be surprising: there is not a lot of motivation for professional basketball players to explain the texture of their existence. Self-actualization does not help you get an offensive rebound. In fact, its possible that pondering the nature of ones life might be detrimental to success in the N.B.A.; happiness (or the lack thereof) is just one more thing that can shut you down.

title: Castaway or Swept Away?
description: Toward the end of Shipwrecked! An Entertainment at Long Wharf Theaters Stage II, a six-year-old movie came to mind. I was momentarily transported back to A Beautiful Mind, and what a clever decision it had been to show the interactions of the mathematician-hero John Nash (Russell Crowe) with a government agent (Ed Harris) and his enlistment in a top-secret project. So later, when someone has the nerve to suggest to Nash that these events were just one big schizophrenic delusion, we the audience are as disbelieving as he is.

title: Bring It Back to the Home
description: THE mortgage crisis has paralyzed the nations economy and threatens to force millions of Americans from homes they can no longer afford.

title: A Big Rig to Call Home, With Style
description: THE truck driver has long had the image of the heroic loner, an image reinforced in country music and in films like They Drive by Night in 1940 with George Raft and Humphrey Bogart and Convoy in 1978 with Kris Kristofferson.

title: The Hatters
description: MY grandmother Thalia Callinicos, an immigrant from the Greek island of Ithaca, told me that to the islands mostly poor villagers, to wear a hat meant that you had arrived. Men returning from their travels to the United States, where they had gone to seek their fortunes, returned sporting brand-new hats, tilted at a fashionable angle. To woo a bride, a hat was indispensable.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Page 40 of Play magazine this weekend about the shift in control of the Yankees from George Steinbrenner to his sons misstates the number of years Mr. Steinbrenner has owned the team. It is 35, not 30. (Go to Article)

title: Itll Be the Law Soon: Dont Fertilize Too Early
description: THIS will be the last spring in Suffolk County to dump fertilizers on lawns without checking the calendar first.

title: Can a Real Estate Broker Serve as a Co-op Director?
description: Q A residential broker who is very active representing sellers and buyers in our co-op is running for a position on the board of directors. Some shareholders consider this inappropriate and a potential conflict of interest. Is there any regulation that governs this situation?

title: Back in Portland, the Latest Outsider Has a Skateboard
description: CRIME AND PUNISHMENT on skateboards  that was one of the early tag lines floating around the production of Paranoid Park, the new film by Gus Van Sant. Based on a novel by Blake Nelson, the story follows a teenage skateboarder in Portland, Ore., who accidentally kills a security guard and is then left to ponder his guilt in a void of suburban amorality.

title: Livery Driver Who Took Baby to Firehouse Is Charged
description: The livery cab driver had become something of a hero on Thursday after turning in a baby girl he said had been abandoned in his cab by a man he had picked up on a street in Queens.

title: A Family Crisis
description: THIS was the central idea I tried to bring to the presidential race: we need to rebuild the family and renew the culture in America.

title: Horrifying and Unnecessary
description: In the next few days President Bush is expected to again claim the right to order mistreatment of prisoners that any civilized person would regard as torture.

title: A Polish Prince Seizes the Stage
description: SOME of the qualities the Polish baritone Mariusz Kwiecien brings to his work are typical products of raw talent, good training and hard work. His voice, for one: burnished and rich, with robust carrying power and a ringing high A many a tenor would covet. His good looks, trim physique and agility are also givens, though at 35 he stays fit through routine exercise. Even his hobby  nature photography in mountainous regions like Peru  keeps him pretty limber.

title: Latest Sport at Some Schools Is Pay-Your-Way Football
description: GRANBY

title: Hey, Swinger
description: The dust jacket of Mitchell Spearmans book, AIM of Golf: Visual-Imagery Lessons to Improve Every Aspect of Your Game, boasts that he is the worlds most expensive golf instructor. That kind of claim is tough to verify. Who knows how much Butch Harmon used to pocket as private tutor to His Royal Majesty King Hassan II? But Spearman gets $600 an hour, and a lesson typically lasts three hours and seldom less than two  time, he says, for the golfer to learn something, falter a bit and then reboot himself. Spearman, who used to be a David Leadbetter protg in Florida and began teaching in the New York City area in 1999, originally gave group lessons, three pupils at a time for $500 apiece. Then a golfer booked three hours and said he would pay for the two other guys not to show up. That was the beginning of the three-hour, $1,500 golf lesson, Spearman recalled recently. And Ive been busier than I could ever have imagined. I had a client once who was a lawyer, and he said, Your rate is even higher than mine!

title: Forsaking Foreclosures
description: WE need a plan that is big enough, bold enough and fair enough to deal with the nations foreclosure crisis.

title: American Hybrid
description: When the Portuguese conquered parts of the western coast of India in the 16th century, Jesuits leading gangs of African slaves captured the local Hindus and rubbed their mouths with raw pork, instantly transforming them into untouchables. The Roman Catholic Church then embraced these outcasts via mass baptisms, creating a large population of converts. This, Tony DSouza shows us in his second novel, The Konkans, was just one of the methods used by the 252-year Goa Inquisition, and partly explains the continuing existence of a significant Catholic, pork-eating minority in and around Goa. These are the Konkans.

title: The Softer Side of Wrestlings Showman Extraordinaire
description: STAMFORD

title: Letters: Taking Play Seriously
description: Robin Marantz Henig (Feb. 17) begins and ends her article with the psychiatrist Stuart Browns focus on the meaning and joy of play, but she devotes the body of the article to looking for the reasons for play in recent interspecies studies. I half expected some researcher had claimed to have found a play gene. It is not enough to look at comparative brain studies. The interest generated by Browns lecture at the New York Public Library calls for the addition of a more reflective approach from the social sciences and philosophy. Plato observed that play was a given quality of animal nature. In The Laws, he wrote that all young animals leap and bound, they dance and frolic, as it were with glee.

title: Another Swastika Is Found on a Building in Brooklyn
description: A swastika was found on Saturday spray-painted on a building on the same block in Brooklyn Heights that was home to a man who confessed to an anti-Semitic vandalism spree in the neighborhood last fall.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: COMEDY

title: A Major Event in a Strangely Minor Key
description: OF the many mental images that linger from 48 hours in Pyongyang, this one came hours before the New York Philharmonic ended its most unusual tour last week.

title: Local Hero? Not the Doctor Next Door
description: EVER since Mike and Delfina Franco moved into their prim white brick house in Pelham Gardens in the northeast Bronx 15 years ago, they had enjoyed the expanse of lush shrubbery and evergreens in the backyard of a neighboring property. For Mr. Franco, the pastoral scene on Astor Avenue offered an unexpected hint of country living in an otherwise densely developed borough.

title: Popping Another Question: Invite Children?
description: ITS a question almost every bride thinks about. Does she want children  at her wedding?

title: At the Plaza, Restoring Life Lived Luxuriously
description: Lets say somebody has bought a famous but slightly dilapidated property and spent a lot of time and money fixing it.

title: Grande Dame
description: As one of the best-known liberal journalists in the country, you presumably intended some sort of political message with your new book, Two Weeks of Life, a moving account of your husbands death from kidney cancer at age 64? If there is a message here, I guess its that its time to take death out of the closet and talk about it and recognize the steps you need to take should some medical calamity befall you.

title: Letters
description: Zeroing In

title: Now Comes the Tough Part in Russia
description: DMITRI A. MEDVEDEV will be anointed president of Russia today thanks to the political handiwork of Vladimir V. Putin. But maybe the real winner is economic globalization.

title: Questions to Ask Before Taking a Reverse Mortgage
description: Reverse mortgages are complex loans typically available only to homeowners older than 61. They permit owners to borrow against their houses, but they do not require loan repayment until the borrower moves out of the home or dies. Then the loan is repaid from the proceeds of selling the house.

title: To Accompany Asparagus
description: Few wines match asparagus. Kim Crawford, a New Zealander, has solved the problem.

title: The End of Jihad
description: When the United States invaded Iraq and overthrew Saddam Hussein in 2003 it destabilized the whole Middle East. The American military had taken over the one Arab state with plenty of oil and a large population. Washington threatened to overthrow the governments of Iran and Syria. The first Shiite government to hold power in the Arab world in 800 years was soon installed in Baghdad. The entire region was engulfed by a tidal wave of anti-Americanism.

title: Skeptics on Human Climate Impact Seize on Cold Spell
