description: The world has seen some extraordinary winter conditions in both hemispheres over the past year: snow in Johannesburg last June and in Baghdad in January, Arctic sea ice returning with a vengeance after a record retreat last summer, paralyzing blizzards in China, and a sharp drop in the globes average temperature.

title: Teaching Boys and Girls Separately
description: On an unseasonably cold day last November in Foley, Ala., Colby Royster and Michael Peterson, two students in William Benders fourth-grade public-school class, informed me that the class corn snake could eat a rat faster than the class boa constrictor. Bender teaches 26 fourth graders, all boys. Down the hall and around the corner, Michelle Gay teaches 26 fourth-grade girls. The boys like being on their own, they say, because girls dont appreciate their jokes and think boys are too messy, and are also scared of snakes. The walls of the boys classroom are painted blue, the light bulbs emit a cool white light and the thermostat is set to 69 degrees. In the girls room, by contrast, the walls are yellow, the light bulbs emit a warm yellow light and the temperature is kept six degrees warmer, as per the instructions of Leonard Sax, a family physician turned author and advocate who this May will quit his medical practice to devote himself full time to promoting single-sex public education.

title: Up Front
description: What does a critic look for when reviewing a biography? According to David Michaelis, the author of Shulz and Peanuts: A Biography, he first checks to see whether the writer has done his or her homework. I always read the sourcing at the back of the book first, Michaelis said in an e-mail conversation. Good biographers spend years amassing a mountain of material only to spend still more years compressing that information into a smart, readable narrative.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Nothing to Fear

title: Correction: Breaking the Mold of the Musical
description: An article and a picture caption last Sunday about the prevalence of plays set in high school misstated the decade in which Cry-Baby, a theatrical adaptation of the John Waters film, is set. It is the 1950s, not the 60s.

title: Now Her Brothers Dreams for an Art School Are Hers, Too
description: Oyster Bay

title: Letter: Taos Recommendations
description: I liked the article "Taking the Bite Out of a New Mexico Winter" by Henry Shukman (Feb. 10), about food and lodging in Taos, N.M. I am the 68-year old Catholic Archbishop of Santa Fe and I can still ski and appreciate good food and wine. Just days before the article, I had been on the slopes skiing with several of my priests, and we agree with Mr. Shukmans assessment of Josephs Table and Lamberts.

title: Gods Row
description: AS noon approached on a recent Sunday, the mostly Jamaican congregation of New Life Tabernacle gathered in its small storefront on White Plains Road in the Wakefield section of the north Bronx. Women in elaborate, wide-brimmed hats and men in dark suits filled six rows of pews and two dozen wooden chairs. The pastors wife, Paulette Randall, wearing a violet dress and holding a microphone, stood before the congregation.

title: Obama Backers Urge Clinton to Exit if She Loses
description: WASHINGTON  Top supporters of Senator Barack Obama, joined by at least one prominent Democrat yet to endorse a candidate, put pressure on Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Sunday to bow out of the presidential race unless she scores clear victories in the crucial big-state primary contests on Tuesday.

title: Still Soldiering On
description: Senator Hillary Clinton was having a bad night. She had just started her speech at an outdoor rally in San Antonios HemisFair Park on Friday when the power failed. The lights went out. The sound system blew out, too.

title: Be Nimble, Be Quick . . .
description: It is something that I have slowly had to come to terms with: I am no longer, by almost any athletic definition, a young man. Its a reality that becomes more apparent with each year after 30 (Im now 34) and was never clearer than when I decided to take up soccer again after more than a decade away from the pitch. My decline was immediately obvious. I had lost ball skills and instincts, was noticeably slow to react and always felt a step or three  or five  behind where I wanted to be. I tried to tell myself that I was just rusty. Then I played against a team of twentysomethings, and it felt as if I were dribbling in moon boots.

title: Sabina Yusupova and Semeon Korsunsky
description: SABINA YUSUPOVA was a wide-eyed 19-year-old when she came to New York four years ago from Tashkent, Uzbekistan. She had long dreamed of visiting the city and found just the entree she sought in a course of study at the ASA Institute of Business and Computer Technology in Manhattan.

title: Speak, Tootsie
description: Tootsie came out in 1982, when most Americans assumed that if you didnt catch a movie while it was playing in theaters, you might never see it. Moviegoers were largely ignoring the climactic developments in home-entertainment technology  including the so-called format war between Betamax and VHS  that would, in the coming decades, transform not just movie watching but also home design and romantic relationships. The best format for audiovisual data storage was still considered to be the human memory.

title: With Jon Bon Jovi
description: Jon Bon Jovi and his band typically play to larger audiences than those found at Arena Football League games, but he would not mind if that changed. Bon Jovi is a co-owner of the Arena Football Leagues Philadelphia Soul, and anything but silent. The Soul opened its fifth season Saturday night.

title: Santa Monica, Calif.: The Huntley Santa Monica Beach
description: THE BASICS

title: Ill Have a Big Mac, Serenity on the Side
description: HACIENDA HEIGHTS, Calif.  On a busy commercial strip in this Los Angeles-area community is a quiet place where the walls are dabbed with red, the booths form a semicircle  perfect for a palaver with a paramour  and two waterfalls flow silently.

title: Nickelodeon to Open Theme Park in Mall
description: Looking for a pop culture-inspired adrenaline rush? Then head to Bloomington, Minn., where the entertainment company Nickelodeon is opening its first theme park in the 4.2 million-square-foot Mall of America on March 15. The seven-acre theme park, called Nickelodeon Universe, will feature several rides inspired by hit television shows, including the SpongeBob SquarePants Rock Bottom Plunge, above, a roller coaster that features vertical lifts, spirals and 90-degree turns. Another roller coaster, the Avatar Airbender, reaches a height of 70 feet and takes riders through the curl of a wave, while the Splat-O-Sphere takes riders almost 60 feet high before bringing them back downwards again and stopping just short of ... well, splatting. The cost of an unlimited-ride wristband is $29.95 (www.mallofamerica.com).

title: Game of Chicken in the Andes
description: After much haggling, the House and the Senate have extended preferential trade benefits to Colombia, Peru, Ecuador and Bolivia, a crucial part of the United States strategy to fight the illegal drug trade at its source in the Andes. Unfortunately, that extension is only for 10 months, which means more haggling  and more economic uncertainty in a region that produced virtually all of the cocaine brought into this country last year.

title: United Technologies Makes Bid for Diebold
description: The United Technologies Corporation made public on Sunday an unsolicited $3-billion bid for Diebold, one of the largest makers of automated teller machines and voting machines.

title: The Color of Rebellion, Once Upon a Time
description: PARENTS bristling over their teenagers orange Mohawks might direct their anger at two women in Long Island City, Queens, if only the women werent so sweet and earnest about peddling rainbow-colored hair dye.

title: Now Batting, the Best Deal the Yankees Never Made
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Yankees hitters are so accomplished that there is little room for wonder. Some are chasing hallowed career numbers, others are fading with age. Few conjure awe about feats unseen, potential still untapped. It is the nature of a veteran lineup.

title: Delgados Woes Show How Fragile Mets Are
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets dual worries, age and injury, were joined at Carlos Delgados hip Saturday. While his teammates set out to win their first game of spring training, Delgado, the Mets 35-year-old first baseman, traveled to New York to have a magnetic resonance imaging test on his right hip, which came back negative.

title: Please Call Earth. We Still Havent Found You.
description: NEARLY half a century ago, Frank Drake, a young radio astronomer with extraterrestrials on his mind, stepped up to a blackboard in Green Bank, W.Va., and scribbled a string of symbols intended to bring some clarity to the question of just how alone humanity is in the cosmos.

title: Keeping Lean in Camp, Brewers Hope to Pile On Wins
description: This is how far the Milwaukee Brewers have come along the road to contention. The Washington Nationals have 72 players in camp, looking for 25 who will make them respectable. The Brewers were in that position not long ago, failing to win 70 games in four successive seasons (2001-4) and failing to have a winning season for 14 seasons in a row.

title: The Office as Architectural Touchstone
description: IT will be either one of the most challenging fixer-uppers in the history of modern architecture or one of the most significant tear-downs.

title: Jets Give Faneca a Record Deal
description: The Jets and the seven-time Pro Bowl guard Alan Faneca agreed to the richest free-agent contract in team history Saturday, according to Fanecas agent, Rick Smith.

title: Such Madness
description: Its that time of year again, when CBS holds you prisoner and you start seeing the Cheerios form brackets in your cereal bowl. (Wait, didnt they just spell out Kansas?) Unfortunately, last years tournaments provided little in the way of madness  just massacres, as Florida ran away with a second straight championship, and Tennessee, led by Candace Parker, rolled to its seventh womens title.

title: Will the Heist Work? Will the Movie?
description: IF you go to the movies at all regularly, chances are good that by the time the end credits have rolled on your earthly existence, youll have spent a couple hundred hours or so sitting in the dark watching small groups of very intense people stealing stuff from banks, art museums, racetracks, casinos, high-end jewelers, armored cars and railroad trains.

title: Photographers, on the Other Side of the Lens
description: MY passion has never been for photography itself, Henri Cartier-Bresson says in the documentary Henri Cartier-Bresson: The Impassioned Eye, by Heinz Butler. The passion he describes instead is for the possibility of forgetting yourself while taking pictures, and of capturing in the fraction of a second the emotion of a subject and the beauty of form.

title: Clack-Clang-Z-z-z-i-i-i-p: Music From a Maestro
description: Maybe you noticed the typewriter in the photo of the writer W. C. Heinz that accompanied his obituary in The New York Times on Thursday. He was holding the typewriter lovingly, with the keyboard facing out, as if he were presenting a trophy or displaying a cake before it was cut.

title: In a Small Town Council, a Clash of Partisan Titans
description: South Plainfield

title: The Many Loves of Nicolas Sarkozy
description: To the Editor:

title: Sweet, Tricky, Sticky (and Not From Vermont)
description: IN the world of maple syrup, Connecticut is small but mighty. It ranks last among the 10 maple syrup-producing states, with a meager 1 percent of the national product, but it still has some 300 producers, who sell every golden, and expensive, drop they make.

title: The Soul Thief
description: He was insufferable, one of those boy geniuses, all nerve and brain.

title: A Frigidaire in the Court of King Arthur
description: DETRACTORS fault Mark Morris for his cheerful ego, his sometimes dogged obeisance to music and his annoying failure (in their eyes) to make better use of ballet vocabulary. But whatever you think about him, the one thing he is incontestably about is joy. His dances and his increasingly frequent opera stagings glow with a giddy humor and a humanistic warmth that can be profoundly captivating  at least to his many devotees.

title: Second Life
description: Most young architects  particularly those in big cities  can only dream about working in a building of their own. And making that dream come true often involves finding a building no one else seems to want, in a less-than-desirable neighborhood. Which is exactly what happened to David Yocum and his partner, Brian Bell. Their firm, bldgs, is housed in a former automobile electrical-parts business in a transitional part of Atlanta. From the outside, it looks ghostly and boarded up, but open the door and you are in an expansive, open courtyard, lined on three sides with rusting walls. At the far end, a wall of full-height glass doors forms the front of the firms spare, sunny office.

title: Pataki Spent PAC Money After Opting Not to Run
description: After ending his exploration of a presidential bid early last year and all but disappearing from politics, former Gov. George E. Pataki spent more than $1 million from his political action committees for Broadway theater tickets, gatherings at the Yale Club and payments to political loyalists and advisers.

title: Exxon Mobil Needs a Hug
description: AS I was sitting at my majestic TV in a majestic suite at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Miami a couple of weeks ago, going over notes for a speech the next morning and waiting for Crockett and Tubbs to speed by, chasing drug kingpins in their Miami Vice motorboat, I watched Barack Obama speak in Madison, Wis.

title: Africas Next Slaughter
description: ABYEI, Sudan

title: Correction: Letter
description: A letter on Feb. 10 about a linguistic parallel for the term extraordinary rendition misspelled a French word for surrender. It is reddition, not rendition.

title: Does the Eye of the Artist Ever Wink?
description: WE like to think that between the outside and inside worlds, there is a simple, impartial one-way window called the eye.

title: Novice Finds Learning Curve Sobering, and Compromise an Art
description: LaGrangeville

title: The Emerging Minority
description: Barack Obama, who does not have too many problems nowadays, does have a Hispanic problem. In Nevada, the first state with a large Latino population to hold a primary, Hillary Rodham Clinton won 64 percent of the Hispanic vote and Obama only 26 percent. By the time of the Super Tuesday primaries on Feb. 5, Obama had apparently picked up many of John Edwardss Hispanic votes, but Clinton still held her own, 63 percent to Obamas 35 percent. With her back now against the wall, Clinton is counting on Hispanics to carry her to victory in Texas this Tuesday and thus preserve her electoral viability.

title: For Singh and a Family, an Eagle to Remember
description: The last time he was hospitalized, Tyler Whaley was asked by an aide at St. Jude Childrens Research Hospital whether he felt up to a visit from a big-time pro golfer who had inquired about seeing him, a fellow by the name of Vijay Singh.

title: Coming Soon: Health Care Debate, Part 2
description: THE skirmishing between the Democratic presidential candidates over the mechanics of universal health coverage will soon give way to a quite different general-election debate  about whether universal coverage should even be a national priority.

title: Giddyap
description: The first and most intimate affiliations we have are the genetic ties we share with our family and the language we speak. In the first case, the links are pretty straightforward. Without exception, everyone is created by two parents, who each had two parents, who themselves had two parents, and on and on, so that behind every reader of this review, thousands of mothers and fathers fan out and multiply in a completely predictable way.

title: How a Bubble Stayed Under the Radar
description: ONE great puzzle about the recent housing bubble is why even most experts didnt recognize the bubble as it was forming.

title: War and Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: The Border and the Ballot Box
description: ON June 7 of last year, a bill to overhaul the nations immigration system  a bill supported by President Bush and the Democratic leaders of Congress  died in the Senate. It died mostly because of grass-roots opposition, and its downfall appeared to serve as an announcement of the issues new political potency. For much of 2007, immigration seemed certain to play a dominant role in the 2008 presidential campaign.

title: Murder in a Small Town
description: In the prologue to Mary Swans first novel, a boy escapes a beating from his violent father by climbing a tree, where he carves his name and vows that hell grow up into a very different sort of man, that he would find the life he was meant to have, somewhere far from this terrible place, where all would be well and people would know his name. That name haunts The Boys in the Trees. William Heath keeps dreaming big; as a husband and father, he gets a version of the life he wants, then becomes famous for destroying it in an afternoon.

title: In Student Hands, Films That Take Serious Aim
description: MICHELLE OUTHOUSE, 17, has never had a friend or family member stricken with AIDS. But she has cared deeply about fighting the disease ever since a speaker on the subject came to her school when she was a sophomore. So she made a movie about it.

title: Israel Takes Gaza Fight to Next Level in a Day of Strikes
description: GAZA  Israeli aircraft and troops attacked Palestinian positions in northern Gaza on Saturday, killing at least 54 people and wounding more than 100 in the deadliest day of fighting in more than a year. Two Israeli soldiers were killed and seven wounded, the military said.

title: On Local Radio, an Accent on Spanglish
description: RONKONKOMA

title: The Free Agent Adjusts His Truss
description: Grandpa I asked the wrinkled, 85-year-old athlete sitting before me, will you tell me about the time you collapsed between third base and home plate?

title: Unsettling, in a Funny Sort of Way
description: Los Angeles

title: Tattoo You
description: To the Editor:

title: Aggressive Play and Fewer Draws in Mexico
description: Exciting, fighting chess is alive and well among the games elite.

title: What Jesus Really Did
description: Garry Wills is not only one of the countrys most distinguished intellectuals, but also one of its most provocative, bringing his learning to bear on great questions of history and contemporary politics, often at the same time. Add to this his regular disquisitions on the church (he is Roman Catholic) and you have a combustible mix that can delight, infuriate or illuminate, usually all three. The irony of Willss latest work, What the Gospels Meant, is that it lacks polemics yet is full of observations sure to rile fearful souls who view ambiguity as the enemy of faith.

title: A Rerun, Maybe, but of What Show?
description: IS it 1989 all over again? Or 2001? Or, for those old enough to remember, a replay of 1973-74?

title: Clinton Makes Appearance on Saturday Night Live
description: LANCASTER, Ohio Hillary Rodham Clinton dropped off the campaign trail Saturday to make a guest appearance on Saturday Night Live, reveling in a skit that lampooned the news media as biased toward Barack Obama and poking a little fun her 11 straight losses to Mr. Obama.

title: It Arrived in an Awfully Big Kit
description: Hastings-on-Hudson

title: GiGi Gordon, Archibald Foster III
description: GiGi Marie Gordon and Archibald McGhee Foster III were married on Saturday at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Christiane M. Lang, an associate pastor at the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Jessica Clement, Jordan Greenbaum
description: Dr. Jessica Mary Clement, a daughter of Barbara A. Praiano of Haverhill, Mass., and David A. Clement of Southern Pines, N.C., was married on Saturday evening in Montego Bay, Jamaica, to Dr. Jordan Neels Greenbaum, the son of Beth L. Greenbaum and Nathan J. Greenbaum of Potomac, Md. Stephen Henriques, a marriage officer for Jamaica and acting leader of the United Congregation of Israelites there, led a Jewish ceremony at the Rose Hall Resort & Country Club.

title: Events in Westchester
description: Comedy

title: The Lease Is Up, but He Stays Put
description: HAROLD GREGORY, 52, was sitting at a desk in his peeling, leaky three-bedroom apartment, in a squat city-owned building on a dreary block of Morrisania in the Bronx. This building sometimes lacks heat and hot water, he said, but its better than dealing with a personal landlord.

title: Ahmadinejad Heads to Iraq as Chairman of U.S. Joint Chiefs Visits
description: BAGHDAD  Army and police checkpoints dotted the Iraqi capital on Saturday in preparation for a visit by President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, which will coincide with a visit by the chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: Russias Bad Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: Master Builders of Ballets Future
description: An article on Feb. 17 about the ways in which choreographers have shaped the New York City Ballet misstated the post that George Balanchine held while at the company. He was ballet master  not ballet master in chief, a title created after his tenure.

title: The Object of His Rejection
description: TIM, I have to say I dont see any difference between rejecting and denouncing.

title: Events on Long Island
description: FILM

title: Duma Key
description: My Other Life

title: Looking Into the World of Genomes and Seeing an Unreliable Future
description: Given the increasing role of genetic technology in the world, its not surprising that artists have begun to pay attention to its potential impact on medicine, the body and all organic matter.

title: Corzine Leans Closer and Gets an Earful
description: TRENTON

title: In a Legal Tug of War, Its Bird vs. Crab Egg
description: THE fate of the red knot, a shorebird that alights along the Delaware Bay to feed on horseshoe crab eggs during its annual migration, may rest in the hands of the state Legislature.

title: The Higher They Climb
description: In 2003, on the 50th anniversary of the first ascent of Mount Everest, Sir Edmund Hillary, who died in January, returned to the mountain. He looked around at base camps satellite dishes, electric generators and free-flowing booze, and despaired. Just sitting around in a big base camp, knocking back cans of beer, I dont particularly regard as mountaineering, he said.

title: Happenstance Can Help
description: MICHAEL HELLER CHU knew just where he wanted to live: Withers Place, a two-year-old condominium building in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: Public Broadcasting: What PBS Really Offers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Buck Has Stopped
description: BEN S. BERNANKE, the Federal Reserve chairman, told Congress last week that fighting off a possible recession in the United States was Job 1 for his crew. But a consumer-led recession has already begun, according to a new index that reflects how much money Americans can actually spend right now.

title: At the Site of Disaster, Dust and Dismay
description: RETURNING in the evening to his loft on Murray Street in Lower Manhattan, Dr. Nathaniel Hupert, inspecting the paws of his Australian shepherd, often finds them coated in black dirt and dust.

title: A Long Wharf-Quinnipiac Partnership
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Seismic Shifts
description: Alan Drews first novel opens with a loss. When 9-year-old Ismail lets go of his fathers hand as they board an Istanbul ferry, they are suddenly whirled apart in the mass of passengers. But this is a city where a fathers panic wont go unnoticed, even in a surging crowd: within minutes, the word is out and Ismails father, Sinan, sees the boy floating back to him, lofted from one man to the next like a king raised high above the people.

title: Bradley Says He Is Who He Is, So Just Get Over It
description: SURPRISE, Ariz.  Milton Bradley has his plan. The crowd is screaming for repentance, for heartfelt regret over his final and spectacularly memorable act on a baseball field last year  arguing with an umpire so maniacally that he tore a knee ligament and cost himself the rest of the season and quite possibly his San Diego Padres a playoff spot. His answer to it all will come as he strides to the plate for his first at-bat of 2008, blaring out of the stadium loudspeakers.

title: Rutgers Gets Past Syracuse Before Showdown With UConn
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Rutgers did what it had to do. Playing before a capacity crowd of 8,079 on Saturday, the Scarlet Knights had no problem with Syracuse, winning, 64-49, in a game that was decided well before the final buzzer. Now, things figure to get interesting.

title: The Cat Drinks Absinthe
description: THE evening had just started, but the Whitest Kids U Know were already sleepy. While they dined on hamburgers the five-man comedy troupe was waiting for the hallucinogenic effects of their absinthe drinks to kick in. Van Gogh cut his ear off when he was high on it, Zach Cregger said of the emerald-green cocktail that went back on sale in the United States last year for the first time since 1912.

title: Sophie Hayward and Timothy Hanrahan
description: Sophie Vall Hayward, the daughter of Mary H. Hayward of St. Louis and John H. Hayward Jr. of Wilton, Conn., was married on Saturday evening to Timothy James Hanrahan, a son of Deborah B. Hanrahan and John D. Hanrahan of Washington. The Rev. Randolph L. C. Weber, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Colony Club in New York.

title: Deluxe Future for Sag Harbor Site?
description: IN the small former whaling village of Sag Harbor, on the South Fork, officials who are faced with what they acknowledge as the areas acute need for affordably priced housing instead seem on the verge of accepting a developers plan to build multimillion-dollar luxury condominiums.

title: Mining the Gender Gap for Answers
description: Move beyond the tactical skirmishes in this campaign, and one of the most intriguing issues remains the influence of gender on Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons candidacy.

title: Whiners Go Home
description: On Saturday, the United States gymnastics team takes the first step in its journey to the Beijing Olympics when some of its top performers compete in the Tyson American Cup at Madison Square Garden. Martha Karolyi, the U.S. women's coach, sat down with PLAY Magazine earlier this year and talked about her coaching style and the issues facing the sport.

title: Big Fruit
description: When the Banana Company arrives in Macondo, the jungle town in Gabriel Garca Mrquezs One Hundred Years of Solitude, it brings with it first modernity and then doom. Endowed with means that had been reserved for Divine Providence in former times, Garca Mrquez writes, the company changed the pattern of the rains, accelerated the cycle of harvests and moved the river from where it had always been. It imported dictatorial foreigners and hired assassins with machetes to run the town; it unleashed a wave of bullets on striking workers in the plaza. When the Banana Company leaves, Macondo is in ruins.

title: Now, Right Side of the Tracks
description: FOR years, the district of Marunouchi, next to the Tokyo Station, was on the wrong side of the tracks. Unlike its super-upscale neighbor, Ginza, on the other side of Tokyo Station, Marunouchi was known as a boring and characterless neighborhood of office towers.

title: Letters: Miracle Workers?
description: Im grateful to David Rieff (Feb. 17) for his discussion of the complex relations we may have with our physicians, especially when facing death. However, his treatment of medical resources and of doctors time as being infinitely elastic was frustrating. His mother wanted a bone-marrow transplant. But to what extent is it the physicians responsibility to recognize a limited resource and refuse to mask a patients rejection of death with costly, painful and, in all probability futile, treatment?

title: As the Nation Crumbles
description: THE most pressing problems can sometimes be the dullest  until they force their way into our attention in an instant.

title: Scaring Up Demand
description: Organic pet food

title: Eun Choi and Justin Paul
description: Eun Kyung Choi and Justin Christopher Paul were married on Friday evening at the Mount Vernon Hotel Museum in New York. The Rev. Jeff White, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Islanders Lose, and Lose Ground in Standings
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Philadelphia defenseman Lasse Kukkonen shoveled the puck out of the Flyers zone with so much force that it sailed over the glass and dropped into the stands. A fan had a souvenir. The Islanders had so much more.

title: From Kindergarten Cutup to Big-Screen Actor at 9
description: NEW BRUNSWICK

title: Off The Dribble
description: A Spark for the 76ers

title: To Sip and Nibble
description: Wine bars, like these in or near Hells Kitchen, are becoming increasingly popular. The establishments cuisines may vary, but all offer interesting selections of small plates or tapas and an array of wines by the glass.

title: If Its Not the Barking, Its the Parking
description: MONTCLAIR

title: Sap Happy
description: The maple syrup you poured on your waffles this morning probably came from Quebec, where more than 75 percent of the worlds supply is produced. And its at least one year old. Maple trees cant be tricked into thinking its harvest time, and in Canada the sap doesnt start running until early March, when the nights are still freezing but the days are bright.

title: Kristan Murray and Christopher Sands
description: Kristan Murray, a daughter of Carol and Dennis Murray of Clifton, N.J., was married on Friday to Christopher Sands, a son of Barbara and Craig P. Sands of Cranford, N.J. The Rev. Victor J. Mazza, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Paul Church in Clifton.

title: A Web Site Tries to Redefine Value
description: YOU thought you got a good deal when you booked that $200 flight from New York to Fort Lauderdale after scouring various Web sites to find the lowest fare. But after suffering through a long delay, a cramped flight on an old plane and the airlines losing your bags, that flight may not have felt like a bargain after all.

title: Whats a Historic House You Cant Enter in Style?
description: RYE

title: Thinking Russian, but at American Speed
description: THE Classic Stage Companys production of The Seagull, currently in previews with a March 13 opening, was in rehearsal a few weeks ago at a studio on West 28th Street in Manhattan. During a break the plays director, Viacheslav Dolgachev, the artistic director of the Moscow New Drama Theater and a former director at the Moscow Art Theater, and Dianne Wiest, the two-time Oscar-winning actress, who will play Arkadina, paused to answer questions from Rosemarie Tichler. Mr. Dolgachev spoke through an interpreter. Here are excerpts:

title: Carlyn Worstell, Michael Maksymuk
description: Carlyn Marie Worstell, the daughter of Linda and Carl Worstell of Sandy, Utah, was married on Saturday evening to Michael Roger Maksymuk, a son of Siglinde and Peter Maksymuk of Manhattan. Richard Binder, a nondenominational marriage officiant, led the ceremony at the Stotesbury Mansion, a historic town house, in Philadelphia.

title: Winning That One in a Million
description: MOST New Yorkers would greet the prospect of a $51,000 two-bedroom co-op in Chelsea with slack-jawed wonder, since the average price for an apartment in the city now exceeds $1.4 million.

title: Toppling Stereotypes, Past and Present
description: ANNE FITZSIMMONS and Darrin Odome would not ordinarily train together at a session on improving job performance. Ms. Fitzsimmons is an assistant police chief in White Plains, and Mr. Odome is a school safety agent in New York City.

title: Blood on the Tracks
description: MIKE DEE, a 33-year-old bicycle messenger with waist-length dreadlocks and a chipped front tooth from a bike injury, has been zipping around Manhattan on two wheels for more than a decade, picking up and delivering packages, currently for Checker Courier.

title: A Verdict for Workers, for a Change
description: The Supreme Court ruled last week that a group of employees suing for age discrimination should get their day in court even though they filed their complaint on the wrong form. The decision is noteworthy because it suggests that this court could be pulling back from what has often seemed like a knee-jerk inclination to rule for corporations over workers and consumers.

title: Emily Steinhagen, Allen Golbig
description: Emily Steinhagen, the daughter of Gail Rothenberg Steinhagen and Dr. Randolph Steinhagen of Tenafly, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Allen M. Golbig, a son of Myra Golbig and Norbert Golbig of Merrick, N.Y. Rabbi Matthew A. Reimer officiated at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios, a film production complex in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: Prophetic Dreams
description: Song Yet Sung is the second novel by James McBride, best known until now for The Color of Water, his memoir of growing up as the black son of a white mother. Defining the son of a white mother as 100 percent black is a special device of American racism that has defied logic for more than 200 years. His unusual position may well give McBride an advantage in writing this antebellum story of fugitive slaves. Anyone handling such material runs the risk of reprising Uncle Toms Cabin, which, however effective it was as propaganda, has no real claim to the truth of art. McBrides portrayal of the situation is more lucid, better controlled and in the end much more convincing.

title: What Would Reagan Do?
description: When George W. Bush became president, he set out to honor Ronald Reagans approach to foreign and domestic policy. He succeeded. The more Bush flounders, the better Reagan looks by comparison. The result has been a fresh wave of Reagan nostalgia.

title: Tapping Into Homes Can Be Pitfall for the Elderly
description: Erika Baker was 67 years old, divorced and worried about her job when a saleswoman showed up at her door in late 2006.

title: Auteur Writes Herself Another Chance
description: BEFORE she had time to savor losing everything, Amy Sherman-Palladino was offered a chance to get it all back, and more.

title: Howard Dominates as Magic Rout the Knicks
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  If the N.B.A. is evolving, or devolving, or in any way diminishing the impact of tall, muscular centers, it was hard to see it here Saturday night. Dwight Howard, it seems clear, has not been phased out of anyones game.

title: In Search of Bush
description: With almost a year still to go in George W. Bushs presidency, he has already become the subject of an astonishing amount of literature  on the war in Iraq, on his controversial economic and social policies, on his two contested presidential elections and on the man himself. So Jacob Weisberg, the editor of Slate, treads some familiar ground in his effort to understand the origins of Bushs much explored psyche. His analysis is not as original or startling as he sometimes claims; his explanations of Bushs behavior are often highly speculative; and he relies too much on such overworked clichs as the parallels between the president and Shakespeares Henry V. But The Bush Tragedy is, nevertheless, an intelligent and illuminating book. It takes much of what we already know and uses it to create a mostly persuasive account of the character and behavior of a man whom many observers have already called the most disastrous president in our history.

title: Editors Choice
description: DANGEROUS LAUGHTER: Thirteen Stories, by Steven Millhauser. (Knopf, $24.) In his latest collection, Millhauser advances his chosen themes  the slippery self, the power of hysterical young people  with even more confidence and power than before.

title: Letters: The Ethicist
description: The Ethicists (Feb. 17) recommendation regarding the restriction of online recordings of medical lectures was generous at best. If the practice of withholding these study aids is indeed at each professors discretion, there is not even a moral issue present. I sympathize with the students early-morning plight; the professor, however, holds no obligation to students other than to present his talks at the scheduled hour. It should be up to students to make the most of the tutelage they seek.

title: All You Need Is the Dream
description: AFFORDABLE co-ops and condominiums are hard to come by in New York City, but there are a few things that can be done to ease the search.

title: A Wild 21st-Century Take on a Rabbis Mystical Tale
description: Meet Elliot Green  a nebbishy neurotic in permanent denial.

title: The Jump-Start That Hasnt Started
description: WHATEVER became of the much-ballyhooed Fed rally?

title: A Real Estate Sequel
description: A report in the Big Deal column last Sunday about real estate purchases by the actor Daniel Radcliffe misspelled the surname of the architect who designed 40 Mercer Street, where Mr. Radcliffe bought an apartment. He is Jean Nouvel, not Nouvelle.

title: Correction: The Pyrotechnic Imagination
description: An article on Feb. 17, about Cai Guo-Qiang, a Chinese artist, misstated the location of an auction house where a set of his works was sold. It was Christies in Hong Kong, not London.

title: Amazing Grace: The Art and Ordeal of the Kimono
description: IT was one of those sweet female rituals that felt timeless and universal and that made me feel like a cross between Scarlett OHara and a submissive in an S & M frolic: In a centuries-old wooden town house in Kyoto where two Japanese matrons were teaching me how to wear a kimono, Id been wrapped in gossamer layer after layer, and my captors were getting down to business with the waist-cinching.

title: Torre, Facing His Former Team, Is Comfortable With New One
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  A Dodger coming off knee surgery found himself the main target of autograph-seeking Mets fans Saturday at Tradition Field.

title: Universities Make Plans to Expand
description: The In the Region article in Long Island copies last Sunday about expansion plans by colleges in the area misstated the enrollment of Farmingdale State College. It is 6,447, not 1,150.

title: Preeti Kundra and Vinay Deshmukh
description: Preeti Kundra and Dr. Vinay Deshmukh were married Saturday evening at the Andrew Mellon Auditorium in Washington. Suresh Chander, a Hindu priest, officiated.

title: Correction: Dont Let the Green Grass Fool You
description: An article on Feb. 10, about concern over the fact that suburban communities use more energy and emit more carbon dioxide than cities do, misstated the energy resource purchased in an emissions-control effort by Northbrook, Ill., a Chicago suburb. It buys credits for 4,500 megawatt-hours of electricity a year from wind farms, not 4,500 megawatts.

title: Transformative
description: But is it transformational?

title: Heres His Story: People Still Read
description: Leonard S. Riggio, the founder and chairman of Barnes & Noble, thinks that Steven P. Jobs is wrong, at least when it comes to the reading habits of Americans.

title: Left Coast Ideas, Floating East
description: BERKELEY, Calif.

title: Danish Guest Asks Bush to Back Climate Treaty
description: CRAWFORD, Tex.  With less than a year to go in office, President Bush has begun offering valedictory courtesies to favored foreign leaders, including a much coveted ranch visit this weekend to the Danish prime minister, Anders Fogh Rasmussen.

title: Kosovo Declares Independence: Two Views
description: To the Editor:

title: Thinking One Step Ahead of a Downturn
description: SAY the economy has fallen into recession, as so many people on and off Wall Street think. Is it time to bail out of stocks?

title: Starving Themselves, Cocktail in Hand
description: MANOREXIA. Orthorexia. Diabulimia. Binge Eating Disorder.

title: A Bold New Place as Strong as Its Name
description: WHEN Nicole Puzio and Edward Radich were casting about for a name for their new restaurant in downtown Jersey City, one of them, in a loopy moment, came up with Babe the Blue Ox. They kicked that around a bit and discarded everything but the last word.

title: McCain Channels His Inner Hillary
description: BEFORE they were sidetracked into a new war against The New York Times, the Rush Limbaugh posse had it right about John McCain. He is a double agent. Some Democrats do admire and like him. So does Jon Stewart, and so do many liberal editorial boards and card-carrying hacks in the mainstream American press. So, in fact, do many at The Times, including myself. As long as I dont look too hard at the fine print.

title: Thirsting for Energy in Indias Boomtowns and Beyond
description: GURGAON, India  It is Friday night in the mecca of new Indian ambition.

title: In a New Era at Harvard, New Questions of Standards
description: BOSTON  Harvard has never won an Ivy League title in mens basketball and has not reached the N.C.A.A. tournament since 1946. This season, the team won only 8 of its first 28 games. Like all the universities in the Ivy League, Harvard does not award athletic scholarships.

title: 72 McGovern Team Rallies for One of Its Own: Clinton
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Frank Herrera, a prominent lawyer in Texas, was sitting at home two Saturdays ago when he received a telephone call.

title: For Last-Minute Deals on Hotels, Join the Club
description: LastMinuteTravel.com, a Web site that lists late-breaking travel deals, has introduced a new club that gives its members exclusive access to discount rates on almost 13,000 hotels in 255 cities worldwide, including Miami, New York and Paris. Members pay an annual fee of $49.99 to join the Last Minute Travel Club, which will in turn list hotel rates with booking discounts ranging from 23 to 66 percent. Recently featured properties include Hotel Edison in New York and Hotel Sax in Chicago.

title: Correction: Trying to Put New Zip Into Moores Law
description: The Prototype column last Sunday, about technology to improve the performance of semiconductors, described the tiny transistors in a high-end chip incorrectly. They are no wider than the nucleus of a small cell, not of a bacterium. (Bacteria do not have nuclei.)

title: The Confession
description: In Lebanon, there is passion and there is blood. Elias Khourys new novel, Yalo, heavy with both, is a dizzying journey into the extremes of human experience  into intense sensuality and stomach-turning violence. The title character is a child of war, growing up on the back streets of Beirut during the conflict that ripped the country apart from the mid-1970s to the early 1990s. In such dark times, societys norms evaporate like the morning mist. Yet for some, like Yalo, the chaos also presents opportunities. A talented woodworker and calligrapher, he puts down his pen and his tools and joins one of the militias, where he learns how to kill.

title: Reducing the Tax Bite on Apartment Sales
description: MOST co-op and condominium owners know they get income-tax deductions for the mortgage interest and property taxes they pay on their apartments.

title: A Taste of Colombia Rolls Through New Yorks Streets
description: The party was off to a raucous start. A chorus of whoops and yelps from the crowd followed a loud Buenas noches! from the M.C. A band played traditional Colombian music. Liberal pourings of rum and Cokes helped lubricate the festivities.

title: The Good Rat
description: United States District Court Eastern District of New York U.S. Courthouse Brooklyn, New York March 14, 2006 10:00 A.M.

title: SoHo Meets HoJo in Atlantic City
description: IF all goes well, after Memorial Day you may not be considered good enough to be welcome at a former fleabag hotel in Atlantic City.

title: Aging Parent, Compulsive Clutter
description: IT is the heart of winter. I left the New York cold behind me, the one that whips off Long Island Sound and stings my face the moment I step outside my door. Two hours flying time away, I found a kinder version of the season. From my suburban home in Westchester County, minutes north of New York City, Ive come to see my mom in Atlanta, where she was born, and where I believe she intends to die.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: Delectable Indian, With Dietary Guidance
description: OVER the past 33 years Simpson Kalathara, chef and owner of Bengal Tiger, has never left delicious well-enough alone. He is and always has been exploring new combinations from the myriad flavors provided by Indias rich culinary tradition.

title: We Can Make It
description: DURING this campaign season, one issue has often been left out of the national discussion: the deterioration of our industrial base. More than three million manufacturing jobs have been lost over the last eight years alone and, for the first time since 1950, fewer than 14 million Americans are employed by domestic manufacturers.

title: Sheringham Retiring
description: Teddy Sheringham, the former English national team striker who was pivotal in Manchester Uniteds injury-time victory over Bayern Munich in the 1999 Champions League final, said he would retire at the end of the season, concluding a playing career that began 24 years ago. Sheringham, 41, is currently with Colchester United of the second-tier Championship. He has played with eight other clubs and made 51 appearances for England.Sheringham helped Manchester United win three titles in 1999. He has 361 goals in his career, including 11 for England.The peak of Sheringhams career occurred in the 1999 Champions League final match in Barcelona, Spain. Manchester United had trailed Bayern Munich, 1-0, since the fifth minute of the game. Sheringham tied the score in the first minute of injury time and set up Ole Gunnar Solskjaers winning goal two minutes later. Sheringham started his career at Millwall in 1984.

title: Hellenic Offerings, Beyond Feta and Ouzo
description: A Greek weekend in New York means dividing your time between the citys two Hellenic factions.

title: When Houses Arrived in 30,000 Pieces
description: Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Crash and Burnout
description: To understand the toll that overtraining can take on an athletes life, consider the competitive arc of Whitney Myers, a fifth-year senior and a world-class swimmer at the University of Arizona. In 2006, Myers won the womens N.C.A.A. title in the 200- and 400-yard individual medleys and, to the surprise of almost everyone, won gold in the 200-meter individual medley at the Pan Pacific Championships. The accolades kept coming: Myers was named an all-American in several events and an N.C.A.A. Breakout Performer of the Year and swam for the United States national team. But barely a year later, she floundered badly at the 2007 long-course championships, making the finals in only one event. For weeks before that, her performance in practices had been miserable: slow times, inert form. I remember standing behind the starting blocks at the pool and thinking, I dont want to be here,  she says. I felt terrible, mentally and physically. While trying to build on her breakthrough season, she had pushed too hard. She had overtrained. She was, for a while at least, finished as a swimmer.

title: Sleepy-Eyed Writer, Wandering Byzantium
description: YOU might not know it to look at him, but the novelist Richard Price has over the years picked up what one of his characters might call some cheddar. He has a house in Gramercy Park and a summer place out on the Island; his work has earned him an Edgar award for television writing, an Academy Award nomination and an award in literature from the American Academy of Arts and Letters. But Mr. Price, who grew up in the Parkside Projects, has shed neither his Bronx accent nor any of his street-smarts.

title: Liukin Makes Statement for a Spot on the Olympic Team
description: Nastia Liukin has the breeding. Her father and coach, Valeri, won four medals in gymnastics in the 1988 Olympics for the Soviet Union. Her mother was a world champion in rhythmic gymnastics in 1987, when she was known as Anna Kotchneva.

title: Inside the List
description: THE LITTLE GEEKETTE: When one of his books received a negative review, Kingsley Amis liked to say, he let it ruin his breakfast but never his lunch. These days, thanks to the magic of blogging, its possible to watch a novelist respond to his or her reviews in something like real time. Take Lauren Groff, the author of the winsomely dark first novel The Monsters of Templeton, which enters the fiction list this week at No. 14. On her blog (www.laurengroff.com), Groff cheerfully noted the A grade she received from Entertainment Weekly, her pretty glowing review in The Christian Science Monitor and a review in The San Francisco Chronicle that actually made me cry, in a good way. ... I even agree with her critiques! Groff was not as pleased with her review in the daily New York Times. But she was philosophical about it. Even a tepid review by The Times is like the little geekette in glasses getting wedgied by the big, handsome quarterback, she wrote. At least he knows Im alive. Sigh.

title: Low-Salt Pigeons
description: Low-Salt Pigeons

title: As Developer Heads to Trial, Questions Linger Over a Deal With Obama
description: Tony Rezko was obviously in trouble. He was a defendant in at least a dozen lawsuits, federal investigators in Chicago were poking around, and his name was in newspaper articles about corruption and fraud.

title: Protesters and Police Clash as Armenia Unrest Grows
description: YEREVAN, Armenia  The largest crowds this tiny, mountainous country has seen in years have clogged central streets here for 11 days, as Armenians of all ages have protested the results of a presidential election they say was stolen.

title: Overnight With Frank Lloyd Wright
description: THE Duncan House in Acme, Pa., crowns a gentle rise off a secluded country road. Long and low, it shouts out its horizontality with stripes of red-painted wood against soft yellow siding. A wide stone chimney signals the fireplace that Frank Lloyd Wright considered the proper center of any family home.

title: Cleaner Water With a Wand (No Magic Required)
description: TRAVELERS who dont trust the water from a mountain stream or a hotel-room faucet have often used chemicals or filters to purify it. Now they have a high-tech option as well: swirl the water with a portable, lightweight wand that beams rays of ultraviolet light.

title: Heavy Winter Snow Means More Spring Skiing
description: April showers, May powders. Thanks to its deepest snowfall in 30-plus years, Heavenly Mountain Resort (www.skiheavenly.com), along the California/Nevada border in South Lake Tahoe, has extended its season to Sunday, May 4. The resort had its snowiest January on record (more than 13 feet in 31 days), and when officials learned that the mountains snow pack was 23 percent higher than average, they decided to extend the season for two extra weeks. Meanwhile, Vail, Colo., has set a new record for snowfall  with 16 feet in both December and January. Elsewhere in Colorado, Beaver Creek (www.beavercreek.snow.com) has amassed about 24 feet of snow so far this winter, while Breckenridge (www.breckenridge.snow.com) and Keystone Resorts (www.keystone.snow.com) have had snowfall up to 33 percent above average. So far, however, Heavenly is the only resort to have extended its season into May.

title: Communities Roar Over Track Expansion Plan
description: NEW HYDE PARK

title: Letter: Photo Plaudit
description: To the Editor: Kudos to the photo editor of the "Why We Travel" feature of the Travel section. The photos are consistently wonderful.

title: Iranian Leader, Visiting Iraq, Assails Bush
description: BAGHDAD  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, arriving Sunday in Baghdad to begin what he declared a new chapter in relations between his country and Iraq, warned President Bush that Americas problems in the Middle East would worsen as long as he continued to accuse Iran of interfering in Iraq.

title: Memory on Molokai
description: For more than 100 years, until 1969, people who contracted leprosy in the Hawaiian Islands were forcibly removed to the Kalaupapa peninsula, on Molokai, to live out their days in exile. They were lost to their families, and after they died, most were lost to history as well.

title: Paperback Row
description: CHRISTINE FALLS, by Benjamin Black. (Picador, $14.) In a fog-draped 1950s Dublin, a pathologist named Quirke is conducting an autopsy on the corpse of a young woman (well named, as he says) called Christine Falls. When the body disappears and it develops that Quirkes adoptive brother, also a doctor, has tampered with the death certificate, Quirke is forced to become a detective; many of the other characters are also keeping secrets. Writing in The Times, Janet Maslin praised the cool precision and contemplative allure of Blacks debut  not surprising, since Black is the Irish author John Banville. This is crossover fiction of a very high order, Maslin said.

title: Datebook
description: BRUSSELS

title: Farm-to-Table Feasting
description: The organizers of Hudson Valley Restaurant Week, begun in the fall of 2006, have moved this years feasting to late winter, a traditionally quiet time for restaurants. From March 9 through March 21, excluding March 15, chefs from some 80 restaurants in Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Dutchess, Orange, Ulster and Columbia counties hope to coax diners out of hibernation with prix fixe menus at gentle prices (three-course lunches for $16.09; three-course dinners $26.09).

title: Rell Wants State Land to Be Billboard Free
description: HARTFORD

title: E-ZPass Was Just the Beginning
description: CALIFORNIA, Pennsylvania, Texas and Virginia may be all over the map when it comes to the presidential primaries, but they do have one thing in common: all are grappling with how to collect tolls from the drivers who use their highways.

title: Me and My Shadow
description: Whats the difference between a novel, a novella and a collection of stories? Is it a simple matter of pages, or do questions of mood, intent, resonance and reach complicate the distinction? Heart of Darkness, The Time Machine and Death in Venice are all novellas, but they feel larger, while collections of connected stories, like John Updikes Too Far to Go or James Joyces Dubliners, can match or exceed the impact of a traditional novel. Linked narratives, as Michael Chabon once put it, can be like a series of snapshots taken over time in which the interest lies in what has happened in the interstices.

title: How Do You Prove Youre a Jew?
description: One day last fall, a young Israeli woman named Sharon went with her fianc to the Tel Aviv Rabbinate to register to marry. They are not religious, but there is no civil marriage in Israel. The rabbinate, a government bureaucracy, has a monopoly on tying the knot between Jews. The last thing Sharon expected to be told that morning was that she would have to prove  before a rabbinic court, no less  that she was Jewish. It made as much sense as someone doubting she was Sharon, telling her that the name written in her blue government-issue ID card was irrelevant, asking her to prove that she was she.

title: John Lewis Dies at 64; Lawyer Fought for Poor
description: John D. B. Lewis, the son of a Wall Street titan who became a lawyer to fight for the rights of the poor and powerless, and in December persuaded Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York to pardon a paroled convict, died on Feb. 22 at home in Manhattan. He was 64.

title: In Tuscany, the Revealing of a Forbidden Love
description: PRATOS all-time favorite scandal  the love affair of the local Renaissance painter Fra Filippo Lippi, who also happened to be a monk, and his model, a beautiful nun  has for centuries overshadowed the spectacular work that was born of their romance. But no longer. Against Pratos Tuscan backdrop of Romanesque and Gothic churches adorned with local albarese stone and rich green marble, Lippis magnificent frescoes in the Cattedrale di Santo Stefano are newly restored after seven years under scaffolding.

title: The Plot Against Britain
description: Henry James wrote that the novelists task, in an imperfect and disappointing world, is to create the record, in default of any better enjoyment of it; to imagine, in a word, the honorable, the producible case. Perhaps the most overt way of creating the record in fiction is to rewrite history entirely, to place credible characters in a hypothetical world. What if the South had won the Civil War? What if India and Pakistan had remained one country after 1949? What if Muslims had conquered Europe during the Crusades? These are enticing conceits, on the surface, but rarely successful in practice. Perhaps the most notable recent example is Philip Roths 2004 novel The Plot Against America, which imagines an anti-Semitic regime taking power in the United States during World War II. In an essay that appeared in the Book Review when Plot was published, Roth admitted he had no literary models for reimagining the historical past.

title: No. 15 Connecticut Denies West Virginia a Signature Win
description: HARTFORD  West Virginia has had little trouble defeating the teams it ought to defeat. But at tournament time, that is not always enough.

title: What Id Be Talking About if I Were Still Running
description: Last spring, as the presidential campaign began, there were 10 Republican candidates on the debate stage and eight Democratic ones, each explaining in some detail what he or she would do for America if elected.

title: Other Voices: More About That McCain Article
description: Re What That McCain Article Didnt Say (Feb. 24):

title: Yuckster Fricassee
description: For two decades, Dan Patrick and Rick Reilly were two of the most successful wiseacres in sports. Reilly, the writer, sent up flares from his back-page column in Sports Illustrated. Patrick, the TV anchor, helped make ESPNs SportsCenter into an institution so cheerfully subversive that it took 10 years and the combined efforts of dozens of anchors, producers and executives to remove its fangs. It was quite an occasion last October, then, when Patrick and Reilly announced they were swapping logos. Patrick left ESPN, his home of 18 years, and become a contributor to Sports Illustrated; Reilly, a 22-year vet of S.I., transferred to ESPN. It wasnt a trade! Reilly clarified recently. Me for him as a broadcaster is like bringing a giant truck of Velveeta to a French chef.

title: Mother and Child
description: To the Editor:

title: Jamie Vichinsky, Seth Braunstein
description: Jamie D. Vichinsky, a daughter of Renee Aizenszpis Vichinsky and Howard Vichinsky of Ulster Park, N.Y., is to be married Sunday afternoon to Rabbi Seth Robert Braunstein, a son of Beth Anshen Braunstein and David Braunstein of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Avi Weiss is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Keter Torah in Teaneck, N.J.

title: Yalo
description: Yalo did not understand what was happening.

title: A Catch That Caught Reggie Jacksons Eye
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  The eighth inning ended Saturday with a low line drive to center field by the Philadelphia Phillies Michael Cervenak. The Yankee wearing No. 95 raced in and speared the ball, just above his shoe tops. The Yankee wearing No. 44 bounded from the dugout and into the clubhouse, raving about what he had seen.

title: Jennifer Corbet, Matthew Ciesla
description: Jennifer Anne Corbet and Matthew Thomas Ciesla are to be married on Sunday at the Hotel Jerome in Aspen, Colo. Judge Beverly Reid OConnell of State Superior Court in Los Angeles is to officiate.

title: The Primary Season Is Embracing Sports Images
description: Obama plays it safe for a field goal. Clinton needs to hit a grand slam. McCain is preparing for a marathon. Candidates cannot afford any blunders, like Billy Conn trying to knock out Joe Louis in 1941.

title: Carey Likes Clinton, Too, but Backs Obama
description: Hugh L. Carey, the former two-term governor of New York who was instrumental in rescuing the city and state from insolvency in the 1970s, has endorsed Senator Barack Obama for the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: Correction: Bites: Weinere
description: The Bites column on Feb. 10 about three wine bars in Berlin, where customers leave whatever amount of money they think is fair for sampling a selection of wines, misspelled the surname of an artist who was tending bar at Fra-rosa. She is Paula Bogati, not Bigoti.

title: Armchair Traveler
A Wake-Up Call for Hillary
description: SAN ANTONIO

title: Nicole Kantor, Cole Rubin
description: Nicole Saba Kantor, a daughter of Leslie W. Kantor and David Kantor of Boca Raton, Fla., was married on Saturday evening to Cole Schwaber Rubin, the son of Deborah Schwaber and Jeffrey Rubin, both of Baltimore. Rabbi Robert A. Silvers officiated at the Four Seasons Resort in Palm Beach, Fla., with Rabbi Richard Agler participating.

title: Heath Kern, Joseph Gibson
description: Heath Thayer Kern and Joseph Henry Gibson were married Saturday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. Fred R. Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: A Dismal Friday Erases the Gains
description: After a sparkling start to the week, stocks plummeted on Friday, pulling the market down for the week and for the fourth consecutive month.

title: Letters: Fun for Wonks
description: To the Editor: Regarding "The Love Boat for Policy Wonks" (Feb. 17), by Henry Alford: This Travel piece is the best Ive ever read!

title: Quick in His Seat
description: Tony Stewart doesnt look like your idea of an elite athlete, unless youre thinking of a professional bowler. Doughy and unimposing, Stewart, 36, is nevertheless one of the finest racers of his generation. A two-time Nascar series champ, Stewart is the only driver to have won titles in stock cars and Indy cars, as well as midget, sprint and Silver Crown cars, and he is now routinely placed alongside his hero, A. J. Foyt, racings most protean driver. Stewarts former crew chief Scott Diehl says, I believe Tony Stewart could make a bicycle fast. What is it, then, that makes a good driver great?

title: New Jersey Begins Tighter Phone Rules for Drivers
description: RIDGEFIELD, N.J.  The signs along the New Jersey Turnpike read, Cellphone enforcement starts today. They were there to remind drivers about a law that took effect on Saturday and allows police officers to cite motorists solely for talking on hand-held cellphones or sending text messages, even if their driving is otherwise legal.

title: Tales From the Firing Line
description: WILLIAM F. BUCKLEY Jr. famously claimed that he could  and did  write a column in 20 minutes. I saw him do it once. It was after one of his Firing Line debates, which were usually broadcast live in front of an audience at some university. For many years, I played the moderator so that Bill could lead one side.

title: The Death of a Bookshop
description: To the Editor:

title: Can a Co-op Board Waive the Flip Tax?
description: Q Is it permissible for a co-op board to waive an existing flip tax for a sitting board member who sells his apartment? Would doing so be a breach of the boards fiduciary responsibility to the co-op, and can any action be taken?

title: Traveling on Dual Passports
description: AT its headquarters in Detroit, Saturns process of Germanification is nearly complete.

title: The Boardwalk and the Bling
description: IT was just after 6 on a recent Tuesday evening, but Coney Island was so dark it could have been midnight. The Nathans sign was on, but the service windows facing the sidewalk were closed. A single car sped down Surf Avenue, honking at anyone who stepped off the curb. The Parachute Jump, a ride that hasnt had a rider in decades, looked dark from the subway station a few blocks away, except for a single blinking light at its tip.

title: On the Auction Block, Ill-Gotten Loot
description: UNIONDALE

title: A Mature Ski Town Gets a Face-Lift
description: ON a chilly evening in late December, hundreds of revelers gathered in the newly remade center of Lionshead, a village in Vail, Colo., for hot cocoa, ice skating and fireworks. The festivities were for the opening of the Arrabelle at Vail Square, a luxury resort featuring a 36-room hotel, 66 condominiums and, soon to be completed, a spa and conference center.

title: Is a Lean Economy Turning Mean?
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  NICOLE FLENNAUGH has a college degree, office experience and the modest expectation that, somewhere in this city on the eastern lip of San Francisco Bay, someone will want to hire her.

title: Infusion of Old Blood Revitalizes Ducks
description: When the Detroit Red Wings and the Ottawa Senators galloped ahead of the field early in the season, the Anaheim Ducks were still finding their legs. Now, with less than a quarter of the regular season remaining, the Stanley Cup champion Ducks have the smoothest stride in the N.H.L.

title: Bedeviled by the Sugar Sickness
description: SEVENTY-FOURTH STREET, the main drag in the South Asian section of Jackson Heights, Queens, is something of a sucrose alley. There are New Aladdin Sweets, Al-Naimat Sweets and Restaurant, and Delhi Palace Sweets, whose fogged-up window is stacked high with steaming trays of desserts.

title: And the Doula Makes Four
description: LIKE any other conscientious, organic-fruit-buying expectant mother, Pamela Myers knew what she wanted from her childbirth experience. And, as is the case with growing numbers of women, that meant hiring a doula  the word means servant in Greek  to help during labor.

title: German Cousins Seeking Citizenship
description: WHEN General Motors founded Saturn in 1985, the new division was presented as a different kind of car company.

title: New Pickups Are Packing
description: WHILE builders of big trucks focus on making drivers comfortable, builders of pickups focus on fitting more stuff into their trucks.

title: In Racetrack Roulette, an Owner Spins the Wheel
description: When the Concord, N.C., City Council found out that the owner of Lowes Motor Speedway, O. Bruton Smith, was beginning work on a drag strip last fall, it acted quickly. Council members voted unanimously to change the zoning, halting construction, and demanded assurances that area homeowners would be protected from the ear-splitting noise the drag strip would create.

title: Election in Russia Confirms Putins Chosen Successor
description: MOSCOW  His election choreographed by the Kremlin, Dmitri A. Medvedev secured a predictably commanding victory on Sunday to become Russias next president.

title: Letters: Under Things
description: I dearly love The New York Times Magazine, and most issues are chock-full of thought-provoking and even inspiring articles and features. But, whats with the Feb. 17 Style feature? Does anyone really enjoy looking at emaciated and pouty women in their underthings?

title: He Drew Great Mud
description: Until surprisingly late in World War II, Army cartooning consisted of gags about mean old drill sergeants and raw recruits on K.P. duty. Then came Bill Mauldin, an impish rifleman from the 180th Infantry Regiment, who volunteered as a cartoonist for The 45th Division News. On July 10, 1943, he stumbled ashore, pistol drawn, in the Allied invasion of Sicily and went on to fight in the Italian campaign while turning the raw material of the front into captioned panel cartoons, often at the expense of superiors in the rear. Mauldin listened to his fellow dogfaces in their foxholes and sketched quickly, sometimes rendering finished work on the back of whatever scrap he could find in the rubble.

title: Scorched-Earth Strategy Returns to Darfur
description: SULEIA, Sudan  The janjaweed are back.

title: A Tough Guy Has a Weak Spot
description: THE rough, tough 2008 Hummer H3 wasnt as mighty as its less macho competitors in the frontal crash test results released Tuesday by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. The H3 was the only model of nine midsize S.U.V.s and crossover vehicles not to receive the top rating.

title: Can Executives Learn to Ignore the Script?
description: MANAGERS striving to foster creativity often use the time-worn phrase thinking outside the box to encourage workers to come up with something nobody else in the room is thinking. But the improvisational actress Patricia Ryan Madson has a better idea: Look inside the box and take a fresh look at whats already there.

title: Cries of Anguish Fill Church as 3 Slain Children Are Mourned Together
description: At a packed Baptist church on Long Island, three children lay in a single coffin of white, themselves dressed in white. The oldest child, age 6, had her arms wrapped around the two younger ones, and with them in the small gold-trimmed coffin, just above their heads, were two ceramic angel figurines.

title: Seedlings? For Sissies. Bring On Instant Forests!
description: GARDENERS guilt overtook me last spring as I stumbled over the dusty shop lights on our attic floor; in years past, they would be beaming faux sunlight over flats of seedlings by mid-March. But with time and patience in short supply the last two growing seasons, I waved a gossamer white row cover in surrender and skulked off for some nursery seedlings.

title: Devie Deland, J.W. Perry
description: Janet Devor Deland, the daughter of Jane and Rawle Deland of New Canaan, Conn., was married on Saturday evening to John Whitney Perry, a son of Kathy and Justin Perry of Columbia, Mo. The Rev. Richard C. Devor, a United Methodist minister and a great-uncle of the bride, officiated at the Knickerbocker Club in New York.

title: One Wall Down, Thousands to Paint
description: SPRAY cans clink in Alis bag as he walks down a cobblestone street in Berlins post-hip neighborhood of Prenzlauer Berg. He stops in front of a grocery truck parked near a childrens playground and pulls out a can. With a fluid motion, he strokes his name in bubbly, bright red letters, before leaving his mark on a telephone booth, a dozen doors and a concrete wall next to the train tracks.

title: Lament for a Limping Pony
description: ON a recent Monday evening, Mariano La Manno, a good-natured man of 56, sat at a table in the back garden of his Italian restaurant in Brooklyn, Acqua Santa, and traced the long history of the cars in his life.

title: Getting the Whole Picture, in and Out of Class
description: RESPONDING to the film classes and clubs proliferating in high schools around the county, the Westchester International Film Festival has added a Future Filmmakers Division this year. The student submissions in grades 9 through 12 will be screened at the City Center 15: Cinema de Lux in White Plains on March 9 and, through the support of the Matthew S. Hisiger Film Foundation, the student capturing first prize will win $1,000 and the students school will receive a professional high-definition camera package valued at $5,000.

title: Accusations, Depositions: Just More Fodder for Art
description: FROM a distance the artwork seems to be some kind of Minimalist drawing, mostly horizontal lines and words on white paper, like Carl Andre typewriter poems or a text piece by Lawrence Weiner. But up close it looks pretty much like what it is: dozens of simply framed copies of budget spreadsheets, partially redacted e-mail messages and letters, and transcripts of legal depositions.

title: Bomb Kills 42 at Gathering in Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A powerful bomb exploded at a tribal gathering in the frontier town of Darra Adamkhel on Sunday, as tribal elders were discussing ways to eliminate militants from the area, killing 42 people and wounding 58, hospital officials said.

title: Patriots, Green Carts and a Soup Kitchen in Greenpoint
description: To the Editor:

title: The Lemur
description: Chapter 8: The Sheepfold

title: Disintegration of a Mothers Life Was Long Hidden in Plain Sight
description: This article was reported by Richard G. Jones, Corey Kilgannon and Paul Vitello and written by Mr. Vitello.

title: Correction: Minority Rules
description: An article on Feb. 17 about multiculturalism in Turkey referred imprecisely to a European delegation that visited the country to monitor the trial of a Turkish mayor who spoke Kurdish in public, and misstated the number of its visits. It represented the Council of Europe Congress, not the European Union, and it made a single visit to Turkey, not frequent visits.

title: Hustler
description: John Rechy might be called the first bard of West Hollywood. Now nearly 74, he became famous (or infamous) thanks to three books  City of Night, Numbers and The Sexual Outlaw  that portrayed the gay subculture of urban Los Angeles in the 1960s and 70s. Read today, across a divide of 30 years defined by the AIDS crisis, these books can seem dated, even quaint. Others of Rechys books  especially Marilyns Daughter, which theorizes that Marilyn Monroe had a child by Robert F. Kennedy  revel in their own schlock value. So does the Web site over which he now presides: it features beefcake photos of the author in younger days, the sort of photos one would more usually encounter on, well, different kinds of Web sites. Even the biography page of the site includes a line drawing based on a portrait of Rechy in a tight white T-shirt, leaning in classic muscle-queen posture against an invisible wall. Its the very opposite of a typical author photo. Indeed, based on this image one might easily confuse Rechy with Johnny Rio, the ex-hustler hero of Numbers whose name hints at the history that the books elide.

title: 36 Hours in Taipei, Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, the vibrant capital of Taiwan, distills the best of what Asian cities have to offer  great street food, crackling night life, arguably the worlds best collection of Chinese art, and hot springs and hiking trails reachable by public transport. With interest in mainland China surging, Taipei  one of the most underrated tourist destinations in Asia  offers a look at a different side of China, one that escaped the deprivations of early Communist rule and the Cultural Revolution. Here is a Chinese culture (some contend that it is uniquely Taiwanese) that practices bare-knuckled democracy and has preserved traditions thousands of years old in a way that was impossible to do on the mainland.

title: In Curbing Walking Sprees, a Mall Sets Off Protests
description: Yorktown Heights

title: Online Scrabble Craze Leaves Game Sellers at Loss for Words
description: NEW DELHI  The latest bane of office productivity is Scrabulous, a virtual knockoff of the Scrabble board game, with over 700,000 players a day and nearly three million registered users.

title: Clinton and Obama Intensify Attacks
description: DALLAS  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton escalated her attack on Senator Barack Obamas qualifications to be president on Saturday, arguing that both she and the presumptive Republican nominee, Senator John McCain, could offer voters a lifetime of experience while Mr. Obama could only hold out his 2002 speech opposing the Iraq war.

title: Savage Detectives
description: When Jimmy Breslin resigned from newspaper writing in 2004 after roughly a half-century and countless thousands of column inches, it was ostensibly to devote more time to books. But there might have been another reason. Like a novelist, a great reporter needs his cast of characters  especially, for Breslin, the mobbed-up ones. The Good Rat, a book that combines personal anecdotes about the Mafia with the story of two really dirty Brooklyn cops, reminds us that by the time he quit, Breslin had lost his gangsters.

title: Watching the Past Come Crashing Down
description: A FEW weeks ago, while attempting to enjoy a steak dinner at the ridiculous hour of 5 p.m. because who can get a last-minute reservation at Peter Luger at a civilized hour, I overheard a New York couple lamenting to a couple from Texas that the city was just not what it used to be.

title: A Place to Feel Homey While Staying Hip
description: GASLIGHTS line the streets of South Orange, casting an old-fashioned gauzy glow. But this township of about 16,000 residents is stirring from its slumber as a cozy bedroom suburb and becoming more hip.

title: Risks and Rewards of a High-Priced Ace
description: There was perhaps only one thing General Manager Omar Minaya could do to make Mets fans forget the teams collapse last September: acquire the games best pitcher, Johan Santana. Although Minaya had a far weaker farm system than his rivals for Santana, the Minnesota Twins accepted four middling Mets prospects.

title: Its Pan-Asian Dominance in East-West Cuisine
description: THE West East Bistro in Hicksville might more aptly be called East West, given its cuisine. Yes, there are a few Western entrees like rack of lamb with honey-mint sauce, grilled asparagus and roasted rosemary red potatoes, and familiar desserts like cheesecake and chocolate cake. Still, the vast majority of dishes are Eastern.

title: Inventory
description: 2 pairs desert camo boots sleeping bag assault pack: NODs, ammo, night-vision goggles wind-stopper gloves

title: How Far Afield Are Job Seekers Willing to Go?
description: When assessing the health of the economy, economists normally look at such markers as spending, growth and unemployment. They might also want to look at what could be called the career complacency index.

title: Correction: A Kingdom in the Mountains Shares Its Secrets
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about a Honolulu Academy of Arts exhibition on religion and ritual in Bhutan misidentified the nationality of Dr. Reda Sobky, an expert on Buddhist iconography who advised the shows curators. He was born in Egypt and lives in the United States; he is not Bhutanese.

title: In Second Stint, Hockey Color Analyst Finds a Comfort Zone
description: NEWARK

title: Melissa Mandelker, Jay Weinberger
description: Melissa Beth Mandelker, a daughter of Cheryl and Michael Mandelker of Manhasset, N.Y., was married on Saturday evening to Jay Steven Weinberger, a son of Sue and Donald Weinberger of Fairfield, N.J. Rabbi Irwin A. Zeplowitz officiated at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Lake Success, N.Y.

title: Correction: The Road to Vegas: $55 and 70 Years
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption with the Suits column last Sunday, showing executives celebrating a companys 60th anniversary in 1998, misspelled the companys name. It is Carlson, not Carlton.

title: Cure More, Spend Less
description: THE presidential candidates are not focusing enough on how government can be administered more efficiently and successfully, especially in the health care arena. The Republicans held four debates before even one question was asked about health care. Our party has definite positions on this issue, but it would seem that the news media have assumed Republicans are not focused on it.
