Nor is anyone asking how the Republicans would make Medicare and Medicaid more efficient.

title: In Alabama, a Fight to Regain Voting Rights Some Felons Never Lost
description: DOTHAN, Ala.  The Rev. Kenneth Glasgow, onetime criminal and founder of a ministry called The Ordinary People Society, spent years helping people with criminal records regain the right to vote in Alabama, where an estimated 250,000 people are prohibited from voting because of past criminal activity.

title: Yes, the Market Has Its Bright Spots
description: EAGER brokers may seize on any positive development as a harbinger of improvement. But market analysts continue to advise caution, pointing out that the supply-and-demand cycles for both the rental and sales markets ordinarily take years to play out.

title: After Brawl Is Posted on the Web, a Teenager Reels From the Fallout
description: Ossining, N.Y.

title: I, Guppy
description: To the outside observer, my Miracle Swimming class doesnt look all that miraculous. One student floats facedown like a Mafia victim. Another grips the poolside ladder. Im floating like a channel buoy, bobbing up and then back under the surface. The miracle is that were all in nine feet of water, a place none of us would have gone two classes ago.

title: Allison Card, Andrew Massad
description: Allison Marie Card and Andrew Carter Massad were married on Friday evening at Banchet Flowers, a florist in New York. Carissa Templeton, a Rose Ministries pastor, officiated.

title: Kathleen DeLaney and Courtney Thomas
description: Kathleen DeLaney, a daughter of Mary F. DeLaney and William F. DeLaney of Annandale, Va., was married on Monday to Courtney Brooke Thomas, the son of Clarice Thomas-Womble of East Orange, N.J., and the late Charles M. Thomas. Blanca Martinez, a staff member in the office of the City Clerk, officiated at the New York City Municipal Building.

title: When DNA and Insurance Collide
description: To the Editor:

title: After Week of Unrest, Cameroon Appears Calmer
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  Calm appeared to be returning to Cameroon after rare violent demonstrations inspired, in part, by frustrations over the presidents recent announcement that he wanted to amend the Constitution to allow him to run for another term.

title: Finishing Tarrytown Hall, in Nick of Time
description: TARRYTOWN

title: Feeling Up, Feeling Young, Feeling Good
description: THE British singer Alison Goldfrapp supplies the ethereal voice of the electropop duo that carries her last name. She also plays synthesizer and writes and produces music with the groups other member, Will Gregory. The result is typically a confection of equal parts driving club beats, computerized blips and lush, dreamy escapes. Goldfrapps fourth studio album, Seventh Tree (Mute), released last week, delivers much of the same, with songs about lost or unrequited love and missed opportunities.

title: A Fine Cup From Which to Sip
description: MY family of origin dined on plates made of a dubious substance called Melmac (a trade name for Melamine resin). The plastic duly recorded every cut of the steak knife and soon scarred, looking even more hideous than when it was created. Those Melmac dishes bore pathetic designs  a faded rosebud, a sheaf of wheat  intended to recall fine porcelain. Even today, on Web sites selling vintage products, where other domestic goods of the 1950s and 1960s have become hot commodities, Melmac still sells for a relative pittance.

title: A Sports Mecca (Pardon the Expression)
description: Never mind that they were in the middle of a desert. The grains of sand all around them, microscopically speaking, were too round. Perfect sand traps require angular sand (so that golf balls dont stick in trap walls but roll to the bottom); angular sand was located and ordered from Saudi Arabia, next door. Trucks were loaded, but they were turned back at the border. For reasons unclear, Saudi Arabia wanted to hold on to that sand. So the builders of the Els Club golf course at Dubai Sports City, a vast sports complex now rising in the round-sand desert, had to settle for their second-choice sand  also from Saudi Arabia, but of a type the Saudis were willing to export.

title: More Families Are Shunning Inoculations
description: AS states move to require more vaccines for school-age children, an increasing number of parents are saying no to some of the inoculations. They are seeking exemptions from the state in growing numbers, citing religious reasons or saying that they believe the vaccines will do more harm than good.

title: Bordering on Disaster
description: THE near universal acknowledgment in 2008 that we need border security is an important achievement, but campaign rhetoric is not enough to secure the border. We need a plan.

title: Daddys Little Phenoms
description: Robert Howard is a doting father, a cheerleader kind of dad. He records for posterity his two daughters every achievement, every nuance of their lives, as he has done since they were 3 and 4, on film, on paper, on his computer. He punctuates each achievement, no matter how mundane, with exhortations: Congratulations, Howard sisters! Excellent work, girls! Great job, girls! Robert is proud of his daughters, but one overwhelming worry shadows his pride: he is waiting anxiously for them to grow. Robert is 6-foot-4. His wife, Gianna, however, is 5-foot-5. His daughters, Ginger, 13, and Robbi, 12, are not much over 5 feet. An average height for girls their age, but the Howard sisters are not average girls.

title: Rock n Droll
description: The music industrys decline has been swift, merciless and bloody; perhaps its best to broach such a dire story by laughing. A memoir of Dan Kennedys 18-month stint in the music business, Rock On is a succession of gently mordant vignettes, with hilariously spot-on asides about media image-making, music-biz hierarchies and sensitive singer-songwriters. Its also a coming-of-age story.

title: The Academy Awards: Give the Public a Say
description: To the Editor:

title: They Cannot be Serious!
description: Dont tell tennis fans that the March 10 NetJets Showdown between Roger Federer and Pete Sampras is just a friendly exhibition. Nineteen thousand tickets have been sold. The excitement stems from the belief that Sampras may really make it a match. Retired five years, he is a still-robust 36, roughly the same age Andre Agassi was when he pushed Federer to four sets in a U.S. Open final. And then theres that serve. As Federer, 26, has said of Sampras: You can wake him up at 2 in the morning and hell hit a monster serve. Rare, if not unprecedented, is the opportunity to watch champions from different eras  perhaps the two greatest of all time  take a whack at each other. A few thoughts on Samprass attempt at the nearly impossible.

title: Susan Clark, James David Jr.
description: Susan Jennifer Clark and James Leroy David Jr. were married on Saturday at the North Shore Community Church in Oyster Bay, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. John Yenchko, a Presbyterian minister and the churchs senior pastor, performed the ceremony. The Rev. Eraclio Conde Morales, another Presbyterian minister, took part.

title: Me, My Daughter and Them
description: MY newest guy, vintage four weeks, was spending his first overnight at our Upper West Side apartment en famille and didnt know the drill.

title: The Mind of a One-Woman Multitude
description: THE day after she finished her new album at Electric Lady Studios, the West Village recording shrine that Jimi Hendrix built, the multiplatinum R&B singer Erykah Badu was back in her surprisingly modest apartment in Brooklyn, puttering. In the tiny kitchen she poured organic pomegranate juice into a jelly jar, then stretched out on a mattress on the floor as New AmErykah, Part One (4th World War), just released by Universal Motown, played on her laptop. After weeks in the studio, she was so happy to be home that she refused to leave, rescheduling appointments and interviews around her domestic whim and one really, really good bath. (More on that later.)

title: Minority Report
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Plan Widens Role in Training Pakistani Forces in Qaeda Battle
description: WASHINGTON  The United States military is developing a plan to send about 100 American trainers to work with a Pakistani paramilitary force that is the vanguard in the fight against Al Qaeda and other extremist groups in Pakistans restive tribal areas, American military officials said.

title: Correction:  I Have Just the Client for You
description: An article last Sunday about Marilyn Heston, an owner of a public relations company who tries to persuade celebrities to wear her clients clothing and jewelry at awards shows, misspelled the given name of an actress who performed a nominated song at the Oscars ceremony that evening. She is Kristin Chenoweth, not Kristen. The error also appeared the same day in The Times Magazine in an article about Anita Renfroe, a comedian who performs on the Christian womens circuit.

title: Declaring Something a Lot Like Dependence
description: IN the Balkans, many things did not change when Kosovo declared independence from Serbia on Feb. 17. It remains a small, poor, landlocked territory of two million people, riven by ethnic hatreds and memories of atrocities. And independence, despite its heroic ring, is an exaggeration. Kosovo still depends, for its very existence, on the presence of 16,000 NATO troops, both to keep order and to discourage any thoughts of reprisal by the kind of Serbian nationalists who rioted in Belgrade to protest the secession. In the background, meanwhile, there stands a resentful Russia, Serbias ally, whose presumptive new president, Dmitry A. Medvedev, declared to the world that Serbia and Kosovo are still a single state.

title: I Write in Brooklyn. Get Over It.
description: I live in Brooklyn. I moved here 14 years ago for the cheap rent. It was a little embarrassing because I was raised in Manhattan, and so I was a bit of a snob about the other boroughs. At the time there was a big buzz about the Black Renaissance of Fort Greene. It was one big house party thrown by Spike Lee and Branford Marsalis, Rosie Perez swinging from the chandelier. I wanted to be part of the vibrant cultural scene. Who doesnt want to be part of a vibrant cultural scene? That didnt happen, but it was cheap, and I grew to love it and its my home.

title: Zesty Vegetarian
description: Before Lisa Cucinello opened the Tiger Lily Cafe with her mother, Jo Anne, in 1998, she was frustrated at the blandness of most prepared vegetarian food she had tried. I wanted people to know that there were alternatives to meat that actually tasted good, she recalled.

title: No Exit
description: Yesterday morning, on my way to see the Paris agricultural fair, I stopped by my favorite public pool for a swim, but it was not opened yet. Mr. Alloux proposed the Josephine Baker pool, which is on a barge in the Seine, and off we went. But as we approached the barge, there was no sign of activity, no cars or people.

title: Anand Holds Lead at Morelia-Linares
description: Viswanathan Anand of India, the world champion, held a slim lead at the Morelia-Linares tournament after 10 rounds. Magnus Carlsen of Norway, the 17-year-old prodigy, was only a half point back after he beat Alexei Shirov of Spain in Round 9 and drew with Anand in Round 10. Levon Aronian of Armenia was another half point behind Carlsen. A crosstable and games from the event, as well as information about the players and a list of the previous winners, is on the tournaments Web site.

description: So its the last day of the Paris collections: no more clean clothes, no more Advil.

description: Much has been made of record-breaking turnout for early voting in Texas, and if one county is any indication, Ohioans are similarly excited about the primary election.

title: Rangers Newcomers Debut at Home; Jagr Goes Mysterious
description: The Rangers two trading deadline acquisitions play at Madison Square Garden Sunday afternoon for the first time, with defenseman Christian Backman and forward Fredrik Sjostrom both in the lineup against the Flyers.

title: The Guy Whose Wife Forced Him To Go on a Cruise
description: Aired Friday night on CBS: I think the world of John McCain. He looks like the kind of guy who still talks real loud on a long-distance phone call. McCain looks like the guy you are waiting for to stop gabbing with the teller, you know. McCain looks like a guy who sits at his dinner tray and watches The Beltway Boys. McCain looks like the guy whose wife forced him to go on a cruise. McCain looks like the guy you have to nudge when his name is called. McCain looks like a freelance crosswalk guard.

title: Frank Williams enthusiasm for F1
description: On Friday at the Royal Automobile Club in London a few of the top people from the Williams team  including the drivers  got together with a few members of the media to talk about the coming season. I will be drawing on that in my coverage in the days to come as I prepare to head off to the first race.

title: The Critic as Advocate
description: I was really interested in Franks question about why August has connected with a large and diverse audience in a way that other equally well-reviewed plays have not. This question opens the floodgates to a huge issue, which is the relationship between critics and the audience. What responsibility, if any, do critics have to theatergoers? What is the purpose of criticism now? Is it anything more than what youd find in TV Guide  whos in the thing and whats it about? Or is it sevice journalism  is this piece of entertainment worth 47 bucks of your hard earned cash? (Thats the median price paid for a Broadway ticket, by the way.) What kinds of experience should be required before a person becomes a critic? Should they be held responsible to anybody or anything, or can they just write with a free hand, and be loose cannons for life, some of them?

title: Auto Ego: 1967 Ford Mustang
description: For Mariano La Manno, the cars he has owned are biographical bullet points of his desires, goals and sacrifices.

title: Russia Votes for a New President
description: With nearly all ballots counted, Dmitri A. Medvedev, the chosen successor to President Vladimir V. Putin, won with some 70 percent of the vote.

title: Op-Classic, 1994: William F. Buckley Loses Faith
description: Every week, the Opinion section presents an essay from The Timess archive by a columnist or contributor that we hope sheds light on current news or provides a window on the past.

title: Opels From Another Era
description: Cars sold as Saturns in the United States are largely designed by Opel, making them truly a different kind of car.

title: The economy never really got its groove back
description: Mark Zandi of economy.com, quoted in this NYT piece on the weak job market, has a nice turn of phrase for what Ive been trying to say on a number of occasions: even during the best years of the Bush boom, the job market never got remotely as good as it was in the late 1990s. The official unemployment rate has been a deceptive indicator; the employment-population ratio has been a much better guide to how the economy feels.

title: Still Yogi After All These Years
description: A few of us were standing in the clubhouse today, talking about how productive Jorge Posada still is as a catcher at age 36. We wondered how old Yogi Berra was when he switched to the outfield, and as if on cue, Yogi shuffled on by.

title: Rangers, Flyers, Guaranteed Point
description: Lets see, the seventh-place Rangers meet the eighth-place Flyers. Theyre 3 and 2 points ahead of the ninth-place Sabres, respectively. Will the game go to overtime?  Why, yes, it will  and both the Rangers and Flyers get a guaranteed point for that! What an unexpected outcome! How surprising that the first 60 minutes of their game should end in a deadlock! Unless Ive missed my guess, that result benefits both teams. What good fortune for the Rangers and Flyers that the game should turn out that way!

title: The Faces of War in Sudan
description: Towns have been burned to the ground by government forces and allied militias in a return to the tactics that terrorized Darfur in the early stages of the conflict.

title: And the Commercial Oscars Go To
description: The Academy Awards on ABC on Feb. 24 may have drawn a record low audience, but many of the people who stayed in front of the set did watch the commercials.

title: Day 3: Americans in Munich
description: MUNICH  It was an oh-so-quiet day Sunday in Salzburg, Austria, where the visiting Red Bulls had the day off. So it was off to Germany, taking an often-harrowing drive on the Autobahn 90 minutes north to Munich to see the Bundesliga.2 match between TSV 1860 Munich and TSV Alemannia Aachen at the striking, futuristic-looking Allianz Arena.

title: Mixed Reviews for Oprah the Merciful
description: Oprahs Big Give, which will debut Sunday night on ABC, represents Oprah Winfreys first foray into prime time network television. Ms. Winfrey, who is widely known for her philanthropic endeavors, lends her name to the series but leaves the hosting duties to Nate Berkus, the interior designer who regularly hosts makeover sessions for The Oprah Winfrey Show. She makes Oprah ex machina appearances on the show, Alessandra Stanley notes in todays New York Times.

title: United Technologies Makes Bid for Diebold
description: The United Technologies Corporation made public on Sunday an unsolicited $3 billion bid for Diebold, one of the largest makers of automated teller machines and voting machines.

title: Simmons Endorses Obama
description: Russell Simmons has just announced his endorsement of Senator Barack Obama, but the hip-hop mogul did not always have kind words for the candidate.

title: Still Soldiering On
description: In her column today, Katharine Q. Seelye writes about one of Hillary Rodham Clintons most salient characteristics: soldiering on.

description: AKRON, Ohio  All weekend here in Ohio  especially in Columbus  weve been feeling very uh, unfit and lets say muscle-less . what with the bodybuilders convention (and, indeed California Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger) here and the states high school wrestling championships.

title: Signs of the Struggling Economy
description: AKRON, Ohio  If you drive through the slushy streets around here in the Firestone Park neighborhood near Garfield High School, political signs for Summit County candidates peek out from snowbank remnants left over from last weeks storm.

description: JJ Hat Center has been open since 1911, and is one of the few remaining hat stores in New York City. Photos and text by Alexia Webster.

title: Why McCain Would Vote For Obama
description: If it is McCain vs. Obama in the general election, look for something to happen that was unthinkable only a short time ago. The Iraq War will become a Republican plus.

description: This week, more than any other of the 2008 Democratic campaign, has acquired an air of decisiveness.

title: Digital Age Is Right Up His Tin Pan Alley
description: Irving Fields is 92. Yes, you read that right. Hes a pianist and lounge performer, whose album Bagels and Bongos, a Jewish-tinged Latin jazz record, became a huge hit after its release in 1959. He doesnt seem to have eased up much over the years. He recently wrote a theme song for YouTube (no word on that fan in the background):

title: India, Old and New
description: A beacon of India's red-hot economy, the new suburb of Gurgaon on the edge of the capital, New Delhi, is also a symbol of India's fast-growing hunger for energy.

title: Is global real estate on the rebound? Probably not.
description: At first glance, good news is tough to find in Ernst & Youngs annual report on the state of the global real estate market. The situation isnt likely to ease in 2008, writes Dale Anne Reiss, global real estate director for the consulting firm.

title: My Technology Training Program
description: Two of my goals for the new year are to continue working with my personal trainer and to continue my technology training program. Both rely on the same philosophy. Since I learn best from listening to an instructor, I am finding ways to get some private coaching until Im ready to go it alone. Teach a gal to fish, as they say.

title: As Economy Lags in U.S., Oil Nations Rethink Cuts
description: With high oil prices weighing on a struggling economy, the OPEC oil cartel is reconsidering its plans to cut production, a move that could push prices above their current record levels. Instead, OPEC is likely to keep output unchanged when its members meet Wednesday.

title: Trials of the Saints
description: LAST month, while Americans celebrated the feast days of two secular saints, George Washington and Abraham Lincoln, the Vatican issued a surprising new directive calling for greater rigor in its own saint-making process. Published by the Vaticans Congregation for the Causes of Saints, the 45-page document called for strict adherence to existing rules, in response to some concerns that the canonization procedures had been watered down over the last two decades.

title: Worlds Outfoxed by a Wily Inner Child
description: In the catalog of the terrific exhibition From The New Yorker to Shrek: The Art of William Steig, at the Jewish Museum, the artists daughter, Maggie Steig, recalls a game her father used to play with her: What would you rather be?

description: MOSCOW  Gazprom, the worlds largest natural gas company, cut about a quarter of the gas supply to Ukraines domestic market on Monday to force the country to settle a debt.

title: Robert Skolrood Is Dead at 79; Argued Religion Cases
description: Robert K. Skolrood, a lawyer who battled for fundamentalist Christians on issues that included nativity displays and gay rights and who often examined the intricacies of the United States Constitution, died on Feb. 20 in Venice, Fla. He was 79.

title: Ahmadinejad, in Iraq, Chides Bush on Iran Criticism
description: BAGHDAD  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, arriving in Baghdad to open what he declared a new chapter in relations between Iraq and Iran, warned President Bush on Sunday that Americas problems in the Middle East would worsen as long as he continued to accuse Iran of interfering in Iraq.

title: Mets May Keep Delgado Out Several Days
description: The recovering Carlos Delgado was not in the lineup as the Mets edged the Los Angeles Dodgers, 6-5, in an exhibition game in Vero Beach, Fla., on Sunday. The Mets spoke optimistically about Delgados hip injury being minor, but it was another concern for a team that already seems fragile.

title: Diebold Receives a Takeover Offer
description: The United Technologies Corporation made public on Sunday an unsolicited $3 billion bid for Diebold, one of the largest makers of automated teller machines and voting machines.

title: Utah Home Is Searched in Ricin Case
description: LAS VEGAS  F.B.I. agents on Sunday searched a home and storage space in Utah for evidence that might explain why a man believed to have been exposed to ricin had the deadly substance and what he intended to do with it.

title: McCain Steps Into Debate Over Cause of Autism
description: Its indisputable that autism is on the rise among children, Senator John McCain said while campaigning recently in Texas. The question is whats causing it. And we go back and forth and theres strong evidence that indicates that its got to do with a preservative in vaccines.

title: With Software and an iBand, Theres No Need for Roadies
description: Many people who own the Apple iPhone speak with a sort of evangelical fervor about the product and the things it can do. E-mail! Music! Internet! Phone calls! It takes pictures!

description: DEAR DIARY:

title: In Ohio, Tense Race Hinges on Grass-Roots Organizers
description: CLEVELAND  The callers, volunteers at a Clinton campaign field office here, had some exciting news last week for the randomly dialed Democrats on the other end of the line. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York was appearing at a high school in Toledo the next day, and there was still plenty of room for cheering spectators.

title: A Speck of Sunlight Is a Towns Yearly Alarm Clock
description: LONGYEARBYEN, Norway  This week, this remote Arctic settlement  which bills itself as the northernmost town in the world  is buzzing with excitement and expectation. It is not because a polar bear was spotted in the adjacent valley last week. (It was deemed well fed, and officials decided to let it lumber on toward the coast instead of shooting it as a matter of public safety.)

title: 7,600 Miles From UConn, Thabeet Is Big Man Off Campus
description: STORRS, Conn.  An airplane landed in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, in May 2007 with a man of immense stature aboard.

title: Trials Spotlight Finds a Shadowy Place
description: Exhibit No. 2A, a simple floor plan of a night club, was placed into evidence by the prosecution in State Supreme Court in Queens last week. It is a crime scene investigators pen-and-ruler rendering of Club Kalua, and while it had the clubs dimensions down to the inch, the number of stools at the bar and the size of the stages, it managed to tell nothing about the place.

title: Putting Innovation in the Hands of a Crowd
description: IF executives are going to rely on the wisdom of the masses for business help, its probably time the masses get a little compensation for it.

title: Executives Must Answer for Steroids
description: Whenever journalists write about baseballs steroids era, they invariably write that baseball knew about the scourge and turned a blind eye.

title: All Rise! Hail the Would-Be Rock Star
description: A few years ago James Blunt was what Sara Bareilles is today: an emerging singer and songwriter with a big hit and a growing fan base. His major-label debut album, Back to Bedlam, became one of this decades most popular. Hers, Little Voice, is just getting started; it was released in July and finally climbed into the Top 10 last week.

title: Black and White and Graphic All Over: A 1930s Tale of Race, Passing and Pain
description: Zane Pinchback, a reporter for The New Holland Herald of New York, is a black man who can pass for white. Zane uses this ability to go undercover to investigate lynchings in the 1930s South. Identity is open-ended, he proclaims. Why have just one? That belief is a theme that comes up in unexpected ways in this engrossing graphic novel, with its smart dialogue and sharp images.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Empire Zone column in some editions last Monday about Lloyd Constantine, an aide to Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York who is backing Barack Obama in the Democratic presidential contest instead of the governors choice, Hillary Rodham Clinton, misspelled the surname of a former business associate of Mr. Constantines who he said convinced him that Mr. Obama was the candidate to back. He is Bob Rivkin, not Rifkin.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Thursday about the expanded Brooklyn Childrens Museum, which is to open in May, referred incorrectly to its possible certification as a green childrens museum by the Green Building Councils Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design program. Other childrens museums have received such certification; the Brooklyn museum would not be the first in the nation.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article in Business Day last Monday about an e-mail newsletter on business journalists from Gorkana, a British public relations firm, omitted the credit. The photograph, of Rob Ingram, director of Gorkana in Manhattan, was taken by Annie Tritt for The New York Times.

title: Trial of 2 Shiite Ex-Officials Tests Iraqs Judicial System
description: BAGHDAD  The highest-ranking Iraqi official to be charged with sectarian crimes stood before a court on Sunday, accused of murder, kidnapping and corruption in the most high-profile judicial effort to come to terms with the factional violence that has cut to the heart of the governments credibility.

title: Obesity Researcher Quits Over New York Menu Fight
description: A food fight within the Obesity Society has led to the resignation of its incoming president.

title: Trial to Offer Look at World of Information Trading
description: WASHINGTON  From its headquarters near the Capitol, the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, or Aipac, has for decades played an important though informal role in the formation of the United States governments Middle East policy.

title: New CDs
description: STEPHEN MALKMUS & THE JICKS Real Emotional Trash (Matador)

title: New Affiliation for TriBeCa Institute
description: The Tribeca Film Institute, the nonprofit organization affiliated with the Tribeca Film Festival, and Renew Media, founded by the Rockefeller Foundation as National Video Resources, are joining forces under the name Tribeca Film Institute to support film, media arts and artists. In an announcement scheduled for Monday, the groups say the primary objective of the combined organization is innovation in film and media, the enrichment of audiences and the promotion of education, understanding and creativity through the media arts. The institute will seek a permanent home in Lower Manhattan that will have exhibition space, screening rooms and work space. Jane Rosenthal and Robert De Niro, two of the founders of the Tribeca Film Festival, will lead a combined board in a merger expected to be approved next month.

title: Semi-Pro Cashes In
description: Semi-Pro, the raunchy basketball comedy starring Will Ferrell, took over first place in the weekend movie box office standings in its debut. The New Line release grossed an estimated $15.2 million, pushing last weeks leader, the thriller Vantage Point (Columbia Pictures), into the No. 2 spot with $13 million, according to the box office tracking company Media by Numbers. Also down one notch was The Spiderwick Chronicles (Paramount and Nickelodeon), which took in $8.8 million. Fourth place and $8.3 million in its debut went to The Other Boleyn Girl (Columbia Pictures and Focus Features), a tale of sisterly rivalry starring Natalie Portman as Anne Boleyn, Scarlett Johansson as Mary Boleyn and Eric Bana as the lustful Henry VIII. Rounding out the Top 5 was last weeks third-place finisher, Jumper (Fox), with $7.6 million.

title: Sears Joins With Hearst for a Multimedia Blitz
description: TWO decades ago, shoppers were told theres more for your life at Sears. An ambitious campaign that begins this week  the result of an unusual retailer-media partnership between Sears and Hearst  may help determine whether there is more life for Sears.

title: With Partners, ESPN Is Expanding in Filmmaking
description: LOS ANGELES  ESPN dominates sports on television. Now, the cable heavyweight is making a run at the big screen.

title: On Signature Issues, McCain Has Shown Some Inconsistencies in the Senate
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain likes to present himself as the candidate of the Straight Talk Express who does not pander to voters or change his positions with the political breeze. But the fine print of his record in the Senate indicates that he has been a lot less consistent on some of his signature issues than he has presented himself to be so far in his presidential campaign.

title: Slipping Away
description: For the first time, an Israeli leader and a Palestinian leader seem genuinely committed to peace. They set a deadline for a deal by years end. Yet the likelihood of achieving the two-state solution they have embraced diminishes with every rocket lobbed into Israel from Hamas-controlled Gaza and with every Israeli military strike or squeeze on civilian life in Gaza.

title: Yale and the Machu Picchu Artifacts
description: To the Editor:

title: Pettitte Shakes Off the Rust and Gets Back to Business for the Yankees
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Yankees broadcasters interviewed Manager Joe Girardi during Sundays game, which was playing on the television in the middle of the clubhouse. Girardi spoke of how well Andy Pettitte was dealing with the potential distraction of Roger Clemenss legal drama. Pettitte lowered the volume, and then changed the channel to a horse race.

title: Knicks See a Seasons Failures in a Week
description: Isiah Thomas gave his players the day off Sunday  their third break in seven days. It was, perhaps, the only way to avoid more self-inflicted damage, on or off the court. The past week was truly bewildering and disastrous, even by Knicks standards.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Thursday with an article about a meeting between President Bush and Prime Minister Mirek Topolanek of the Czech Republic misidentified the photographer in some editions. The picture of the two leaders in the Oval Office was taken by Larry Downing of Reuters, not by Stephen Crowley of The New York Times. (Go to Article)

title: Engineer Faces Perjury Charge After Fatal Bronx Fire in 06
description: The Bronx district attorneys office has decided to pursue criminal charges against an engineer whose failure to fully inspect a Bronx construction job was cited in a Fire Department report on the deaths of two firefighters, according to a person who has been briefed on the investigation.

title: Emotions Drove Pair in Abandonment
description: Echoes of their own lives led the aunt of the baby girl who was dropped off at a firehouse in Queens last week and the livery cab driver who initially claimed that a stranger abandoned the baby in his car to want the child to have a better life.

title: In Texas, Clintons Veterans Test Obamas Rookies
description: TEXARKANA, Tex.  Just 32 miles from a place called Hope, this small working-class city at the Texas and Arkansas border is Clinton country, as people here frequently and firmly remind you.

title: Sales Decline at Big Three Automakers
description: DETROIT  Honda was the only large automaker whose sales increased in February, a month when oil prices rose above $100 a barrel and concerns about a recession rattled consumer confidence, according to figures released on Monday.

title: City on the Gulf: Koolhaas Lays Out a Grand Urban Experiment in Dubai
description: It has been 12 years since the Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas unleashed his concept of the generic city, a sprawling metropolis of repetitive buildings centered on an airport and inhabited by a tribe of global nomads with few local loyalties. His argument was that in its profound sameness, the generic city was a more accurate reflection of contemporary urban reality than nostalgic visions of New York or Paris.

title: Stocks Flat as Oil Hits Record
description: Stocks meandered their way to a flat close on Wall Street on Monday, with investors rushing into the traditional havens of gold, Treasury bonds and commodities as they faced a new round of reports showing weakness in the economy.

title: Reforming Medicare
description: To the Editor:

title: Troops Mass at Colombian Borders
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Venezuela and Ecuador mobilized troops to their borders with Colombia on Sunday, intensifying a diplomatic crisis after Colombian forces killed a senior guerrilla leader at a jungle camp in Ecuador.

title: Tuesday Is the End, or the Beginning
description: This week, more than any other of the 2008 Democratic campaign, has acquired an air of decisiveness.

title: Intel Announces New Chip for Small Computers
description: In an industry where smaller is better, Intel announced on Sunday a new brand of processors intended to power what it hopes will foster the development of a new category of compact, low-cost wireless Internet computers known as netbooks.

title: Britain Makes Eurovision Pick
description: First Ireland picked a big-beaked glove puppet, Dustin the Turkey, to represent it in the Eurovision Song Contest in May. Now Britain has chosen its champion: a former garbage collector. Carrying the nations hopes to Belgrade, Serbia, will be Andy Abraham, 43, who came to attention in 2005 by reaching the final of the British talent show X Factor, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Abraham earned a ticket to Belgrade when he beat five other finalists with his song Even If in a contest broadcast Saturday on the BBC. Last years British hope, Scooch, finished 22nd among 24 competitors.

title: Home Appraisal Standards Stiffened
description: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the home mortgage giants, said Monday that they would stop buying loans from lenders that do not use independent home appraisers, as part of an agreement with the attorney general of New York.

title: Electing a Woman to the White House: Whos on Deck?
description: If not Hillary, who?

title: Bill Would Set Foreclosure Moratorium
description: The Bush administration recently announced a plan to delay foreclosures for some troubled homeowners for 30 days. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination, has called for a 90-day moratorium on foreclosures.

title: Peter B. Neubauer, 94, Noted Child Psychiatrist, Is Dead
description: Dr. Peter B. Neubauer, a child psychiatrist and researcher who raised public alarms early on about the possible effects of television violence on the emotional development of children, died on Feb. 15 in Manhattan. He was 94.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Friday about the N.F.L.s modest free-agent market this off-season misstated the timing of an increase of more than $30 million in the leagues salary cap. It was put in place in 2005, not this year.

title: SNL Writer Narrows the Gap Between Politics and Farce
description: Like many of his fellow Americans, James Downey was a bit surprised to see Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Saturday Night Live over the weekend, satirically protesting the treatment she has received from the news media.

title: A Big Noise Blows in, and Swing Is Swung
description: A shortcut to describing the show business chemistry of Christine Ebersole and Billy Stritch might be to call them, with reservations, the next generations Bette Midler and Mel Torm, two singers you would never think of mentioning in the same breath. This odd couple, who performed together on Friday evening at the Allen Room as part of Lincoln Centers American Songbook, are a longstanding team who have recorded two albums, the second to be released in May.

title: An Irish Salute at the Oscars Pains Some Ears
description: For some Irish people who watched the Oscars last week, pride was tinged with shame when their countryman won the Academy Award for best song  and promptly botched an attempt to say thank you in his nations native tongue.

title: Executive Wants to Sue for Libel, but Only if He Can Do It Secretly
description: People who file libel lawsuits against journalists want their day in court. But one plaintiff wants that day to be very quiet.

title: Joseph Juran, 103, Pioneer in Quality Control, Dies
description: Joseph M. Juran, who helped establish the field of quality management and wrote the Quality Control Handbook, which taught manufacturers worldwide how to be more efficient and productive, died Thursday in Rye, N.Y., where he lived with his wife of 81 years, Sadie. He was 103.

title: Unseen Film Roils Egyptian Festival
description: An Egyptian festival on Sunday reversed a ban on a Dutch childrens film, saying it had received an apology from the Dutch government for another, unreleased short film made by a far-right member of the Dutch Parliament that is expected to attack Islam and antagonize many Muslims, Agence France-Presse reported. Naem al-Baz of the Cairo International Film Festival for Children said it took only a minute after the Dutch apology was received for the festivals committee to agree to reinstate Where Is Winkys Horse?, which was banned on Thursday. Had the ban stood, Agence France-Presse reported, it would have been the first punitive action in a Muslim country in response to the film by Geert Wilders, , a member of the Dutch Parliament. On Thursday Prime Minister Jan Peter Balkenende of the Netherlands called on Mr. Wilders to rethink the short film, Fitna, which Mr. Wilders planned to show on the Internet this month, because of a possible violent Muslim reaction.

title: Spitzers Fiscal Certainty Is Met With Skepticism
description: ALBANY  From New Jersey to California, many states are contemplating a raft of painful budget cuts as they wrestle with evaporating tax revenue and ballooning deficits.

title: Building Walls Isnt the Only Way to Prevent Floods
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Town Called Bill, a Boomlet of Sorts
description: BILL, Wyo.

title: Combining Grocery Shopping With Doctors Appointments
description: LONDON  Some Britons can add a visit to the doctor to their shopping lists. On Monday, J Sainsbury, one of Britains largest supermarket chains, is to become the first in the country to offer a visit to a family doctor in one of its stores.

title: Expansionist in the Realm of the Guitar
description: Celebrations of composers birthdays are easily done: if youve played their music, youve paid tribute to them in the best possible way. Celebrating a performer is harder. The things that make a performer special  a particular approach to sound, an identifiable way of turning a phrase or a special measure of eloquence in a certain repertory  are by definition nontransferable. And performances based on another performers style are never very satisfying.

title: Deliverance or Diversion?
description: After their victory in the 2006 Congressional elections, it seemed a given that Democrats would try to make this years presidential campaign another referendum on Republican policies. After all, the public appears fed up not just with President Bush, but with his party. For example, a recent poll by the Pew Research Center shows Democrats are preferred on every issue except terrorism. They even have a 10-point advantage on morality.

title: Priced Out of the Market
description: The worlds food situation is bleak, and shortsighted policies in the United States and other wealthy countries  which are diverting crops to environmentally dubious biofuels  bear much of the blame.

title: Review of Book on Murdoch Is Killed
description: When Rupert Murdoch took control in December of Dow Jones, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, he also collected a small Hong Kong monthly, The Far Eastern Economic Review.

title: Democrats in Intense Battle Before Big Vote
description: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama battled over national security and trade in a frantic burst of last-minute campaigning on Monday as Mrs. Clinton accused Mr. Obama of deception as new evidence of discord surfaced within her own camp.

title: For Sabathia, Big Plans and Yet an Uncertain Future
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla.  Johan Santana and C. C. Sabathia are left-handed pitching stars who recently won American League Cy Young awards in midmarket cities in Midwestern states. But they are different in one major detail.

title: Hollywood, Silicon Valley and AT&T? Its a Deal
description: Hollywood and Silicon Valley have something of a Mars/Venus problem: the two sides are talking but they dont speak each others language. A new venture involving a phone company may just add Pluto into the mix.

title: Patti Smith in the Parlor, Still Raw and Rock n Roll
description: For some musicians the ordinary rules just dont apply. I would call the intangible quality that makes ignoring them possible purity of soul. More than artistic integrity, it has a mystical component and requires the listener to make a leap of faith.

title: After Suicide, Blog Insults Are Debated
description: Advertising blogs churn out some of the Webs more scathing, and personal, vitriol. Last week, the bloggers absorbed some body blows of their own.

title: Youre Welcome to See Her Live, Not to Ask About Her Life
description: Mary-Louise Parker tried to get out of this interview. She said so halfway through. Not in a confrontational way, just matter-of-factly, as if she were saying she hadnt ordered those fries but had started to eat them anyway.

title: After Ribbing Clinton, Fawning Over Obama
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton is a fashion victim, but Barack Obama? Oh, hes a good dancer, a cool dad, a regular guy who likes ice cream and chili, and who happens to be a pal of Bono and George Clooney even though he isnt impressed by celebrity.

title: Strong Words in Ohio as Obama and Clinton Press On
description: WESTERVILLE, Ohio  Like rival warships pulling into the same small harbor, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton held rallies hours apart and exchanged oratorical barrages here Sunday.

title: Oil Prices Pass Record Set in 80s, but Then Recede
description: Capping a relentless rise in recent years, oil prices rose to an all-time record during the day on Monday, then pulled back to close below the record.

title: These Ads Send a Message  by Mail, Of Course
description: HBO is joining forces for the first time with the Postal Service, for a multimillion-dollar, multimedia campaign that is all about the write stuff.

title: Meeting on Arms Data Reignites Iran Debate
description: Last Monday, the chief United Nations nuclear inspector gathered ambassadors and experts from dozens of nations in a boardroom high above the Danube in Vienna and laid out a trove of evidence that he said raised new questions about whether Iran had tried to design an atom bomb.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Thursday with an article about a meeting between President Bush and Prime Minister Mirek Topolanek of the Czech Republic misidentified the photographer in some editions. The picture of the two leaders in the Oval Office was taken by Larry Downing of Reuters, not by Stephen Crowley of The New York Times.

title: Harris Scores 21 Points, but Nets Needed More
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Devin Harris delivered again, in his second game in a Nets uniform. Harris, the point guard brought over from Dallas in the Jason Kidd trade, scored 21 points Sunday night, but the Nets needed something more.

title: A Furor After Brunos Role Is Revealed
description: ALBANY  The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, concedes in an interview in the current issue of New York magazine that he was paid by a Connecticut investment firm to encourage trustees of union pension funds in New York to do business with the company.

title: Iraq Needs Strides in Economy and Governance to Cut Attacks, a Top General Says
description: FORT HOOD, Tex.  The former No. 2 American commander in Iraq says that, without economic and political progress, it will not be possible to reduce substantially the current level of violence there.

title: Deal Close on Wiretap Law, a Top Democrat Tells CNN
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the House Intelligence Committee hinted Sunday that a battle over an expired eavesdropping law might be moving toward a conclusion that gave phone companies the retroactive legal protections long sought by President Bush.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Friday with an article about the troubles of Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick of Detroit carried an erroneous credit. As an another caption with the article noted, Rebecca Cook, who took the photograph of the mayors residence, works for Reuters  not for The Associated Press.

title: Two Single Women, Stylishly Shallow, in Pursuit of a Killer
description: Ever since the 1970s, when Son of Sam made headlines and the slasher film was born, the serial killer on the rampage has been one of the publics favorite story lines.

title: The Senate Shills for Big Oil
description: One of the major shortcomings in last years admirable energy bill was its failure to extend vital tax credits to producers of wind, solar and other renewable fuels. This was entirely the doing of the Senate, which caved in to the oil companies and their White House friends.

title: A Bishop Unveiled Gods Secrets While Keeping His Own
description: As is customary during Lent, the sermon at St. John the Divine Cathedral on Sunday touched on the themes of seen and unseen truths, knowing and not knowing what is before ones very eyes.

title: To Recruit Caseworkers, a Dose of Reality
description: Wanted: men and women willing to walk into strange buildings in dangerous neighborhoods, be screamed at by unhinged individuals  perhaps in a language you do not understand  and, on occasion, forcibly remove a child from the custody of a parent because the alternative could have tragic consequences.

title: HBO Puts Episodes of a Series Online at No Charge
description: HBO executives knew the risks they were taking when they scheduled the new series In Treatment to run five nights a week for nine consecutive weeks.

title: A Clash Between Popular Culture and Orthodox Piety
description: For thousands of Orthodox Jews, the Big Event  a concert featuring the popular Hasidic entertainer Lipa Schmeltzer  was supposed to happen next Sunday at the WaMu Theater at Madison Square Garden. But fans and organizers were shocked to learn late last month that a group of rabbis had issued an edict against the show, effectively canceling it.

title: Publishers Phase Out Piracy Protection on Audio Books
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Some of the largest book publishers in the world are stripping away the anticopying software on digital downloads of audio books.

title: The Very Model of a Modern Media Mogul
description: LOS ANGELES  When Michael D. Eisner left the Walt Disney Company in 2005 and set about remaking himself in new media, investing in a video-sharing Web site and starting a digital studio, some people in Hollywood snickered. Here we go, the whispers went, another fading star who doesnt know when to leave the stage.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The Ad Club of Boston inducted three executives into the New England Advertising Hall of Fame. They are: Jack Connors, founding partner and chairman emeritus at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies; Ed Eskandarian, chairman and chief executive at Arnold Worldwide Partners, a division of Havas; and Paul LaCamera, general manager at the WBUR Group, which includes a Boston radio station that belongs to National Public Radio.

title: Bossa Novas Jubilee
description: Brazil celebrated the 50th anniversary of bossa nova on Saturday, when Rio de Janeiro organized a free concert on the beach at Ipanema starring pioneers of the style, mixing samba and jazz, that originated in 1958 and spread worldwide in 1963 with the release of The Girl From Ipanema, Agence France-Presse reported. The song was written by Antonio Carlos Jobim and Vinicius De Moraes and performed by Joo and Astrud Gilberto, with saxophone accompaniment by Stan Getz. Saturdays lineup included veterans like Roberto Menescal, Carlos Lyra and Oscar Castro-Neves as well as contemporary artists like Bossacucanova, a group that mixes bossa nova with electronica. Solange Kafuri, an organizer of the show, said, Bossa nova has its eternal audience, and there is also a new one. ... The sounds of Brazil will be saluted at Birdland in New York from April 15 through 19 at the BossaBrasil Festival, featuring the Grammy Award-winning pianist and composer Cesar Camargo Mariano; the vocalist, guitarist and composer Joo Bosco; and the saxophonist Harry Allen.

title: About Those Health Care Plans by the Democrats ...
description: WASHINGTON  While Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama fight over who has the better health plan for the uninsured, they say little about a more immediate challenge that will confront the next administration, whether Democratic or Republican: how to tame the soaring costs of Medicare and Medicaid.

title: Woman Killed as Man Rams Crowd
description: A man rammed a borrowed Cadillac into a crowd of people outside a Newark club early Saturday, the police said, killing a woman and pushing up the citys homicide count to four so far this year.

title: New Life for Old Church
description: The Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, above, in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, has been a lot of things in its history: a shelter for runaway slaves; a forum for speakers like Frederick Douglass, Charles Dickens and P. T. Barnum; and now, or at least soon, an Off Broadway theater. The 25-year-old Irondale Ensemble Project, a theater and education group, is renovating the churchs former Sunday school, a 5,400-square-foot space, and making it into a 168-seat theater to be called the Irondale Center. (The space was to be the site of the Twyla Tharp Dance Studio, but that fell through.) Construction on the $2.5 million project began on Wednesday; a grand opening is expected for the fall.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions last Monday about an Oscar party in West Orange, N.J., to celebrate Freeheld, a film that chronicled the struggle of a lesbian Ocean County prosecutors investigator to win benefits for her partner, misspelled, in some copies, the surname of a partygoer who said she felt a rush of joy when Freeheld won the Oscar for best documentary short subject. She is Joan Hervey, not Harvey.

title: A Naughty-but-Nice Miss M Sets Up Shop in Sin City
description: LAS VEGAS  Just what this city desperately needed: a bracing injection of vulgarity.

title: Asian Stocks and Dollar Fall Sharply
description: TOKYO  Asian stocks fell sharply and the U.S. dollar fell to levels not seen for three years against the Japanese yen on Monday, on speculation the Federal Reserve board may lower rates further to soften a possible recession. At the start of trading in Europe, most stocks were showing moderate losses.

title: Major Economic Reports Scheduled for the Week
description: SIGNALS ON THE ECONOMY Economic news will dominate the week, punctuated by the unemployment report for February (Friday).

title: In Las Vegas, Its All About the Odds
description: Casino owners and bridge experts benefit from small advantages. The diagramed deal was played Friday during a knockout team event at the Las Vegas Regional. Kent Mignocchi of New York found a line that gave him an additional chance to make his contract, which was missed at the other table.

title: Putin Protg Secures Election Victory
description: MOSCOW  His election choreographed by the Kremlin, Dmitri A. Medvedev secured a predictably commanding victory on Sunday to become Russias next president.

title: Trade Case Takes Aim at China on Financial Data
description: WASHINGTON  In a new escalation of trade disputes with China, the Bush administration joined with the European Union on Monday in filing suit with the World Trade Organization to protest Chinas requirement that foreign financial news services operate through a government-designated distributor.

title: Santanas Changeup: Hitters Never See It Coming
description: Johan Santana carried a baseball with him every day, for hours at a time, trying to become more comfortable with the feel of his fingers against the seams. He would scoop up a ball as a minor leaguer with the Minnesota Twins and immediately move his fingers across the four seams, the same way he held his fastball and his evolving changeup.

title: Gaza Pitfalls in Every Path
description: WASHINGTON  Ever since the militant Islamist organization Hamas took over Gaza eight months ago, President Bushs peace plan for the Middle East has been to prop up the more moderate Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, in the hopes that Palestinians would rally behind him as man who could bring them statehood and make Hamas irrelevant.

title: Emergency Order Empties Armenian Capitals Streets
description: YEREVAN, Armenia  Tanks blocked central streets in the capital of this tiny mountain country on Sunday, a day after Armenian authorities clashed with demonstrators in a violent confrontation that left at least eight people dead and more than 130 wounded.

title: For a Third Consecutive Day, All Quiet on the Moss Free-Agent Front
description: It has become the guessing game of N.F.L. free agency: wheres Randy?

title: Detective Charged With Sex Abuse
description: A veteran Newark police detective was charged with sexually abusing a teenage girl from West Orange repeatedly during a span of four years, according to the Essex County prosecutors office.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 2, 2008

title: Twangy Tones and Vibes in a Fistful of Nostalgia
description: John Zorn is capable of a coarse and brazenly puckered timbre on alto saxophone, and he long ago mastered its use as a sort of serrated blade in musical form. On Friday night at St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn, the first of two weekend performances there, he practiced this skill for a total of two minutes, maybe three, and the concision was wickedly effective. For the rest of the show, Mr. Zorn sat onstage in a folding chair and conducted his band with basic but emphatic hand gestures. The saxophone sat on the floor beside him, a tantalizing threat.

title: European Firm Says U.S. Jet Deal Means Jobs for Both Countries
description: PARIS  The European company that won a part of a major American military contract for air tankers emphasized over the weekend that it would assemble those planes in the United States, along with other big jets for commercial sale.

title: Holocaust Memoir Turns Out to Be Fiction
description: A best-selling Holocaust memoir has been revealed to be a fake. The author was never trapped in the Warsaw ghetto. Neither was she adopted by wolves who protected her from the Nazis, nor did she trek 1,900 miles across Europe in search of her deported parents or kill a German soldier in self-defense. She wasnt even Jewish, The Associated Press reported. Misha Defonseca, 71, right, a Belgian writer living in Dudley, Mass., about 60 miles southwest of Boston, admitted through her lawyers last week that her book, Misha: A Mmoire of the Holocaust Years, translated into 18 language and adapted for the French feature film Surviving With Wolves, was a fantasy. In a statement to The Associated Press, Ms. Defonseca said: The story is mine. It is not actually reality, but my reality, my way of surviving. I ask forgiveness to all who felt betrayed. I beg you to put yourself in my place, of a 4-year-old girl who was very lost. Ms. Defonseca, who gave her real name as Monique De Wael, said her parents were arrested and killed by Nazis for Belgian resistance activities when she was 4; she was cared for by her grandfather and uncle. She came under pressure to defend her book after Sharon Sergeant, a genealogical researcher in Waltham, Mass., said she had found clues in the unpublished United States version of the book.

title: Bomb Kills 42 as Pakistani Tribal Leaders Discuss Forming Force Against Militants
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A powerful bomb killed 42 people and wounded 58 at a tribal gathering in the frontier town of Darra Adam Khel on Sunday, hospital officials said, as tribal elders were discussing forming a force to eliminate militants from the area.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Consumer Watchdogs
description: Last fall, when children lost consciousness after eating toy beads, parents could not quickly find information about others who had endured the same harrowing ordeal. One reason is that there was and is no official government site that includes real-time reports of injuries or problems with products like toys with lead paint or deadly cribs or hazardous paint sprays.

title: When Is a Cigar Not a Cigar? When It Tries to Kill Castro
description: Now that Fidel Castro has resigned as president of Cuba, it seems likely that illness and age will finally be allowed to accomplish what two generations of Cuban exiles have been unable to, despite obsessive zeal and the help of the American government. For a quick and entertaining roundup of their attempts, Sundance Channel is offering the well-timed American television premiere of 638 Ways to Kill Castro, a 2006 British documentary being shown Monday night.

title: More Clues to a Russian Choreographers Style
description: Last month Alexei Ratmansky, the departing artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet, seemed on the verge of becoming resident choreographer of the New York City Ballet. Very few people in New York, however, had then seen more than three or four of his works.

title: Abbas Puts Peace Talks on Hold as Israel Continues Military Offensive in Gaza
description: ASHKELON, Israel  Israeli-Palestinian violence spilled over from Gaza to the West Bank on Sunday, and a spokesman for the Western-backed Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, said contacts with Israel had been temporarily suspended in light of the Israeli aggression.

title: In Oscars, No Country for Hit Films
description: At the Governors Ball, the gilded post-Oscar fete, many of the evenings winners swanned about with statues in one hand and glasses of Champagne in the other, while the losers washed down what was left of the evening with stronger spirits.

title: A Tough Sell: Movies on Small Screens
description: Apple TV, Vudu, Movielink, Unbox: the Internet is littered with ventures that offer the ability to download movies legally online. Few have had the predicted success. A new report by the Diffusion Group, a research firm, says that less than 10 percent of adults with broadband connections have ever used such services, and only about 1 percent use them frequently. TDG surveyed 1,975 broadband users.

title: Wal-Mart Tastemakers Write Unfiltered Blog
description: Microsoft is one of Wal-Marts biggest suppliers. But that did not stop the Wal-Mart employee in charge of buying computers from panning Microsofts newest operating system, Vista.

title: After Wild First Period, Rangers Outlast Flyers
description: Steve Valiquette told himself this was just like practice. He skated to the Rangers crease to start the second period Sunday against the Philadelphia Flyers, after being handed the unenviable job of stopping the chaos of a wild first period.

title: Big Question: Did Officers Identify Themselves?
description: Police!

title: The Indispensable Man
description: In my high school yearbook (Collegiate School, class of 1970), theres a photo of me wearing a political button. (Everyone did in those days. I wasnt that much dorkier than everyone else.) The button said, Dont let THEM immanentize the Eschaton.

title: Crossing Borders, Crossing Time
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Jewish Refugees in New York | The Story of Mark and Rachel Kanal
description: Mark and Rachel Kanal describe their journey to the United States and the challenges they faced as Jewish immigrants in early 1950s New York City.

title: 'Lush Life'
description: Prologue

title: That Word Is Centerfold
description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below)

title: Taking Back a Qaeda Stronghold
description: ARAB JABOUR, Iraq  A former stronghold of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, this rural and overwhelmingly Sunni area south of Baghdad on the west bank of the Tigris was once a country getaway for Saddam Husseins cronies. His sons Uday and Qusay had a weekend house here.

title: Peloton Blames Credit Squeeze for Liquidation
description: Peloton Partners, the hedge fund manager that is liquidating a $1.8 billion asset-backed fund, says that it is a victim of Wall Streets reduced lending.

title: Icahn Boosts Federal-Mogul Stake to 75%
description: A partnership led by the billionaire investor Carl Icahn exercised an option to buy 50.1 million shares of Federal-Mogul, the auto supplier, raising his ownership to 75 percent, according to a federal filing this week.

title: Hollywood, Silicon Valley and AT&T? Its a Deal
description: Hollywood and Silicon Valley have something of a Mars/Venus problem: the two sides are talking but they dont speak each others language. A new venture involving a phone company may just add Pluto into the mix.

title: Australias Oxiana to Buy Rival Zinc Miner for $5.6 Billion
description: An Australian miner, Oxiana, bid 6 billion Australian dollars ($5.6 billion) for Zinifex on Monday to expand its zinc output and diversify into other metals.

title: No I.P.O. Soon for Yelp, Chief Says
description: Yelp, whose Web site lets users review restaurants and other local services, isnt likely to hold an initial public offering anytime soon, its chief executive, Jeremy Stoppelman, told The Deals VC Ratings blog.

title: G.M. Becomes Delphis Lender of Last Resort
description: Almost a decade after spinning off the auto parts maker Delphi and more than two years after Delphi filed for bankruptcy, General Motors still finds itself shelling out cash to its former subsidiary.

title: KKR Private Equity Discloses Write-Downs
description: KKR Private Equity Investors, the publicly traded buyout fund of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, wrote down stakes in seven investments as a slowing economy hurt earnings and declining bond prices eroded the value of holdings.

title: Seven Bank Shares Jump 24% in Debut
description: Seven Bank, a Japanese bank that provides A.T.M. services, rose 24 percent on its market listing on Friday in the biggest initial public offering in Japan since October.

title: Traders Lawyer Criticizes Socit Gnrale Inquiry
description: A lawyer for Jrme Kerviel, the former trader who Socit Gnrale says cost it 4.9 billion euros in losses, on Friday accused the bank of not looking deeply enough at dozens of people in its management hierarchy during a recent internal investigation into the trading scandal.

title: Restoration Rebuffs Sears for Private Equity Bid
description: Restoration Hardware, a retailer of home furnishings and gifts, accepted a buyout bid from Catterton Partners, a private equity firm, after deciding a competing bid from Sears Holdings was inferior.

title: HSBC in Talks to Sell French Unit for $3.2 Billion
description: HSBC Holdings, Europes largest bank, said Friday it had received an offer of about $3.2 billion in cash for its French regional banking subsidiaries from Frances Banque Federale des Banques Populaires.

title: Buffetts State of the World: Theres Folly in Wonderland
description: The billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett disclosed Friday that he had earned profits for shareholders of Berkshire Hathaway by speculating in the Brazilian currency, the real, and by buying a large stake in a French pharmaceutical company, Sanofi-Aventis.

title: A Different Kind of Incubator
description: Y Combinator has seeded about 80 start-ups since 2005 through a series of remarkably small investments  just barely enough to cover living expenses for three months, the San Jose Mercury News writes.

title: Xstrata Says Vale Talks Continue
description: Xstrata said on Monday it was still in deal talks with Companhia Vale do Rio Doce of Brazil after reporting that its profit more than tripled for the year, helped by the $18 billion acquisition of Falconbridge and by ravenous emerging-markets demand for metals.

title: HSBC Profits Rise 10%
description: Profit at HSBC, the European bank, rose 10 percent last year, just below analysts forecasts, as strong gains in Asia helped it absorb a $17.2 billion hit for bad debts related largely to housing problems in the United States.

title: Barclays Buys Russias Expobank
description: Barclays , the British bank, acquired a Russian lender, Expobank for $745 million in its first overseas acquisition since losing the bidding contest for ABN Amro Holding.

title: Candover Said to Offer $2.6 Billion for Expro
description: Candover, the private equity firm, has made an approach to acquire Expro International, an oilfield services company, in a deal that could value Expro at 1.3 billion pounds ($2.6 billion), The Financial Times reported.

title: Hedge Fund Nominates Slate for New York Times Board
description: A shareholder group pressing for change at The New York Times officially proposed its own set of directors for four vacant seats on Friday.

title: Volkswagen to Raise Stake in Scania
description: The German carmaker Volkswagen said on Monday it would raise its stake in a Swedish truck maker, Scania, to 68.6 percent, a move that may lead to a merger of Scania and the German truck maker MAN.

title: Circuit City Investor Launches Proxy Battle
description: A shareholder group has proposed the ouster of the entire corporate board at Circuit City Stores, the electronics retailer.

title: I.P.O. Cancellations Hit $21.4 Billion
description: Companies have shelved initial public offerings totaling $21.4 billion so far this year, almost double the value of new equity issuance, Thomson Financial data showed.

title: Eisner: A New-Wave Media Mogul
description: When Michael D. Eisner left the Walt Disney Company in 2005 and set about remaking himself in new media, investing in a video-sharing Web site and starting a digital studio, some people in Hollywood snickered. Here we go, the whispers went, another fading star who doesnt know when to leave the stage.

title: Dechert Law Firm to Lay Off 13 Associates
description: As investment banks cope with the growing economic slowdown, so too are big law firms. According to the Legal Intelligencer, the latest to pare down its associates roster is Dechert.

title: Hedge Fund Activist to Sue S.E.C. Over Marketing Rules
description: Phillip Goldstein, who two years ago successfully sued the Securities and Exchange Commission to overturn a rule requiring hedge fund managers to register as investment advisers, is planning to sue the regulator to lift its ban on hedge fund marketing and advertising.

title: U.S. Seeks Sanctions Against Countrywide
description: Countrywide Home Loans, the troubled mortgage lender that has agreed to be sold to the Bank of America, engaged in questionable conduct in a bankruptcy case involving two borrowers in Atlanta, the United States Trustee contended in a lawsuit filed late Thursday.

title: States and Cities Start Rebelling on Bond Ratings
description: Does Wall Street underrate Main Street?

title: Global-Warming Skeptics Convene in N.Y.
description: Hundreds of skeptics in the global-warming debate are convening in New York today and tomorrow. The meeting, sponsored by the Heartland Institute, is an assortment of climate scientists, economists and free-market think-tankers  some who have impressive credentials, some of whom are listed in the conference program simply as Scientist or Meteorologist. Sorting out the wheat from the chaff will not be easy, but heres one way to start: Check out this report being presented at the conference today.

title: China Merchants Shows Interest in Visa I.P.O.
description: China Merchants Bank is interested in buying into a planned initial public offering of shares by Visa, the credit card network, but any deal would first need Chinese regulatory approvals, its president Ma Weihua said on Monday.

title: Clinton Shakes the Pre-Dawn Hands
description: Updated | 10 a.m.  TOLEDO, Ohio  Hillary Clinton isnt wasting any time sleeping.

title: E*Trade Said to Choose Next Chief
description: E*Trade Financial, the online bank and broker, plans to give Donald Layton, currently its chairman, the additional role of chief executive, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: They Do Windows (Badly)
description: When Michael D. Eisner is behind an Internet hit (Prom Queen), you know the Web isnt in Kansas anymore. His old employer is not to be outdone either. Here are a couple of episodes from the ABC.com online series Squeegees, about slacker window-washers:

title: Carlyle Hires UBSs Sarkozy for Financial Deals
description: The Carlyle Group, the private equity firm, said Monday that it had hired Oliver Sarkozy, one of UBSs top investment bankers for financial services deals, to work as co-head of a similar practice.

title: SNL Writer Narrows the Gap Between Politics and Farce
description: In an SNL career that has spanned 27 seasons over 32 years, James Downey has written much of the shows most enduring political comedy, anticipating the sentiment of the moment as often as responding to it, Dave Itzkoff reports in Mondays New York Times.

title: HBOs Strategy: Sample In Treatment Online, Then Watch It On TV
description: HBO executives knew the risks they were taking when they scheduled the new series In Treatment to run five nights a week for nine consecutive weeks.

title: Greasy Kid Stuff
description: Tell us whats going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned photos were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: Hair of the dog
description: One argument Ive been hearing a lot lately runs as follows: Low interest rates got us into this mess, so its crazy to think that low interest rates are the solution.

title: The Early Word: Ohio, Texas Delegate Grab
description: Its the last day of campaigning for the presidential candidates in Ohio and Texas (and Rhode Island and Vermont), and the Democratic race is tight in both states.

title: Congress Gets Ready to Tackle the Budget
description: Congress is set to get serious about the federal budget this week as both the Senate and House begin writing spending plans in separate committee sessions.

title: Engineer Faces Perjury Charge After Fatal Bronx Fire
description: The Bronx district attorneys office has decided to pursue criminal perjury charges against an engineer whose failure to fully inspect a Bronx construction job was cited in a Fire Department report on the deaths of two firefighters, John Sullivan reports. Firefighter Michael C. Reilly and his boss, Lt. Howard J. Carpluk Jr., were fighting a fire in a Walton Avenue discount store in August 2006 when rotting support columns gave way, the floor collapsed and they were trapped, the report concluded.

title: Prisoner of the Gender War
description: The event took place on Saturday, but given the subject  belittling of John McCains wartime experience  and the speaker  Gloria Steinem  its still the talk of the blogosphere Monday morning.

title: Diebolds Fuzzy Numbers
description: As one of the largest makers of voting machines and A.T.M.s in the United States, Diebold is presumably good with figures. But when it comes to the firms own accounts, it has hit more than a few glitches.

description: Stephen Heine, a member of The Caucus's virtual round table of voters, talks about the Ohio primary.

description: The weekends results in racing and more

title: Farewell to Freedom for a While
description: Freedom has disappeared from ground zero.

description: NAIROBI, Kenya

title: Giambi on Johan, Pedro and Coney
description: When I interviewed Jason Giambi for an article about Johan Santanas changeup, the Yankees slugger segued into a discussion of Pedro Martinez and David Cone. Believe it or not, Giambi said that he loved facing Martinez and Cone because of their creativity. Giambi loves the challenge of guessing along with pitchers.

title: Father of Elizabeth Edwards Is Dead at 87
description: Elizabeth Edwards and her family are in mourning today after the death of her father, a war veteran and, by her description, a man of many friends and many talents.

title: Morgan Stanleys Hostile Tendencies
description: In journalism, three examples usually makes a trend. By that rule, Morgan Stanley has hopped onto the hostile bid bandwagon.

title: Clinton Vows to Press On to Pa. and Beyond
description: TOLEDO, Ohio  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said she would make no predictions about Tuesdays primaries in Texas and Ohio or comment on what the results might mean for her campaign.

title: Video: Open Caucus in Ohio
description: In Cambridge, Ohio, we sat down with one of our voters in the Open Caucus roundtable to talk about Tuesdays primary and the issues on the minds of Ohioans. Stephen Heine, 62, a moderate Republican, has decided to support Senator John McCain, although he said he had favored former Senator Fred Thompson before he dropped out of the race.

title: ESPNs Next Expansion: Filmmaking
description: ESPN, which dominates sports on television, is collaborating with Creative Artists Agency and Walt Disney Studios to produce and distribute theatrical films, Brooks Barnes reports in Mondays New York Times. The network is also hiring 30 filmmakers to produce one-hour mini-movies to appear on the channel starting in September 2009.

description: With President Vladimir V. Putins endorsement assuring more than enough votes for Dmitri A. Medvedev, the result of Russias election was hardly in doubt. But there was room for debate on a finer point: would the protg exceed his patron?

title: Meet Me in Ohio
description: Politicians and foreign manufacturers arent the only ones besieging Ohio these days. On Sunday, Connecticuts United Technologies sent a bear hug letter to Ohio-based Diebold Industries. The letter proposed an acquisition of Diebold at a price of $40 a share and described a failed two-year courtship between the two companies.

title: A Sweeping New Lineup at TNT
description: TNT wants to be known for more than Law & Order repeats.

Bruno, Unplugged, on Bruno
description: The issue of New York magazine published today contains a lengthy profile of Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, by Geoffrey Gray. The article has caused a furor in Albany, with Mr. Brunos staff members asserting that the reporter violated the terms of the interview. The magazine says that it fully stands behind its story and that Mr. Bruno understood he was speaking on the record.

title: Day 4: Battle of the Bulls
description: SALZBURG, Austria  So much for corporate harmony.

title: Tonight: Hillary Chats With Jon Stewart
description: Monday night, hours before voting begins in the Ohio and Texas primaries, Hillary Rodham Clinton will appear on Comedy Centrals The Daily Show with Jon Stewart.

title: Strawberry Back in a Mets Uniform
description: In the Red Cross ward otherwise known as the Mets clubhouse, infielder Ruben Gotay hobbled in Monday on crutches, with his right ankle heavily bandaged. It was a cloudy day but outfielder Ryan Church walked in wearing sunglasses, his eyes still sensitive to light two days after he sustained a Grade 2 concussion.
