title: Two Hot Dogs, a Drink, and a Nod to Obama
description: Since 1973, the griddled frankfurters at Grays Papaya, home of the $3.50 Recession Special (two franks and a 14-ounce drink), have been served with fresh fruit juices, tangy sauerkraut and a side of politics.Nicholas A. B. Gray, the chains founder and resident pundit, has offered endorsements of candidates seeking the presidential nomination from Jimmy Carter in 1976 to Bill Bradley in 1999 to, most recently, the noncandidate Michael R. Bloomberg.Last August, Mr. Gray, 71, began displaying signs at two of his three stores encouraging the candidacy of the mayor with the slogan Run Mike, Run! He told The Times in October that he was hoping for a Bloomberg run for the White House because hes cool under pressure and he believed that the mayors personal wealth made him less corruptible.

title: Clintons 11th-Hour Ads
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton is pulling out all the stops today, the last day of campaigning before the must-win Ohio and Texas primaries. Shes got a brand-new, state-specific ad airing in each of those delegate-rich states.

description: As Olivier Sarkozy prepares to move to the Carlyle Group from UBS, the Swiss bank is wasting little time in shifting personnel inside its financial institutions group to fill that gap.

title: Crime and Punishment, +1
description: Chelsea won handily at West Ham this weekend, 4-0, but the Blues lost the midfield engine Frank Lampard when he was shown a straight red card for reportedly shoving Luis Boa Morte. He was slapped with a three-match ban and, tempting fate, Chelsea has decided to appeal.

title: Just Friends?
description: Well, the Obama campaign may not have lost much sleep over Hillary Clintons Its 3 a.m. ads, but this from ABC News could inject a little fear into the race: Sen. Barack Obama could be called as a witness for his longtime friend and accused Illinois fixer Tony Rezko, according to Chicago lawyers following the case.

description: Elliot G. Sander, executive director and chief executive officer of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, used what officials called the first State of the M.T.A. address this morning to outline an ambitious plan for growth in subway, rail and bus service by the year 2050.

title: Does Vista SP1 Break Times Reader?
description: Short Answer: No.

title: Ohio Does Not (Heart) Arbs
description: Earlier on Monday, we discussed in detail the Ohio aspects of United Technologiess bid for Diebold. As we noted, before United Technologies can acquire Diebold in an unsolicited offer, it must gain pre-approval of a Diebolds shareholders under Ohios antitakeover control share acquisition statute.

title: Diebold Rejects Bid as Opportunistic
description: Much as DealBook expected, Diebold is pointing to its bookkeeping problems as a reason shareholders should give the cold shoulder to United Technologies.

title: Genescos Costly Potential Settlement
description: Genesco and Finish Line appear to have reached an armistice in their battle over a failed $1.5 billion deal. But the news propelled Genescos stock down drastically, while it lifted Finish Lines by just as much.

title: House Fires With a Message in the Northwest
description: For people who are anti-sprawl activists  or have baser motives  a new-built house sitting empty in a previously rural area evidently makes a ripe target for an attack by fire.

title: Detective Describes Scene at Club Before Sean Bell Shooting
description: Updated, 5:45 p.m. | The first undercover detective to enter an exotic dancing club in Queens hours before Sean Bells shooting had misgivings from the start, telling his lieutenant he was uncomfortable with the size and rowdiness of the crowd at Club Kalua, the detective testified on Monday.Theres more guys, its a lot rowdier, the detective, Hispolito Sanchez, 36, said he told Lt. Gary Napoli that night, Nov. 24, 2006. His fellow detective, Gescard F. Isnora, sat beside him, but Detective Sanchez was concerned about a man giving him hard looks from across the room. I didnt feel comfortable, he testified.

title: A Dysfunctional Credit Market
description: The Bank for International Settlements  the central banks central bank, as it is known  is out today with its quarterly review. For a normally reserved institution, it is blunt is discussing what is wrong with the credit market. Heres an excerpt, with italics added by me for emphasis:

description: Before dawn every Sunday morning, at the foot of the Santa Monica Pier, volunteers set up crosses in memory of American service members killed in Iraq.

title: The Menaker Group
description: Daniel Menakers online book show, Titlepage, makes its debut today. Menaker, a former fiction editor at The New Yorker and the former executive editor in chief of the Random House Publishing Group, is the host and editorial producer of this round-table program. According to Motoko Rich in The Times, Titlepage will be one part Charlie Rose, one part Dinner for Five and one part Apostrophes, the French literary show.

title: Saturday in the Bronx
description: In the last couple months, the notable food folks John Mariani and Arthur Schwartz have lavished praise on Trattoria Zero Otto Nove, a new Italian restaurant on Arthur Avenue in the Bronx. Mr. Schwartz wrote that it serves the best Neapolitan pizza in New York City on his site foodmaven.com; the restaurant is the best pizzeria to open in the U.S. in years, according to Mr. Mariani over at Bloomberg.com. Theres even a thread on the place over at chowhound.com titled Is Trattoria Zero Otto Nove the best pizza in NY?

description: On Monday, Porsche gained approval from its supervisory board to raise its stake in Volkswagen from 31 percent to more than 50 percent.

description: The CW has announced early renewals for six series, including its most popular show, Americas Next Top Model, and its most promising new drama, Gossip Girl.

description: The Opinionator missed this little nugget from over the weekend, but as Matt Yglesias at the Atlantic points out, ABC Newss Jake Tapper reported that John McCain seems to have taken on the scientific consensus on autism and vaccinations.

description: The former press baron Conrad Black surrendered at a Florida prison on Monday to begin serving his 6-and-1/2 year sentence for fraud and obstructing justice.

title: A New Role for Defense Contractors?: Counting Votes
description: There has long been good reason to worry about Diebold voting machines. Many are black box electronic machines that do not produce paper records, so voters have to accept the results they report on faith.

title: Video Captures Plane Near-Crash in Hamburg
description: The above footage is unlikely to make it into any commercials for Lufthansa, yet it depicts one of the companys pilots in a manner deemed heroic in news reports and many more comments on the Web.

description: Barack Obama, flush with all that campaign cash, has bought two minutes of airtime during all of the Texas and Ohio network newscasts tonight.

description: One baseball team is selling a special, very expensive ticket starting Monday, reports CNBC's Darren Rovell.

title: Tanker Contract Opposed by McCain Resurfaces
description: WACO, Tex.  When Senator John McCain talks on the campaign trail about cutting wasteful spending, one example he points to with pride is his investigation of a corrupt contract that the Air Force wanted to give Boeing for aerial refueling tankers.

title: Official State Author and Poet Are Named
description: Mary Gordon was named the New York State author, and Jean Valentine was named the state poet today, Gov. Eliot Spitzers office announced. The honorary two-year designations, which each carry an honorarium of $10,000, are made by the New York State Writers Institute. The two writers will promote fiction and poetry across the state through a series of public readings and talks.

title: A (Former) Critic Responds
description: Marsha Norman raises more questions about critics than I could possibly answer, but I do want to play devils advocate on a few points, speaking from my experience as a past Times drama critic. I realize that some of these arguments will never end: the Shuberts first barred a Times critic (Alexander Woollcott) from their productions in the years after World War I because he had too much power, liked too few shows, etc., etc., and this back in the day when The Times was still a much smaller enterprise and there were many more papers competing with it. The plus a change.

title: Jarndyce v. Jarndyce, Takeover Division
description: Theres been a resolution, sort of, to the Genesco-UBS-Finish Line imbroglio that I wrote about in December.

title: Not A Matter of If But When

title: On the Ground: The View From Texas and Ohio
description: The Timess Randy Kennedy and Andrew Jacobs have been embedded in Texas and Ohio over the past weeks, writing about the tight primary races in those states. We invited them to compare notes.

description: Just three games on the docket tonight, but all three are beauties.

John McWhorter (l) of the Manhattan Institute and Megan McArdle of The Atlantic discuss how Barack Obama's rhetoric is suited to the modern moment.

description: Rangers forward Sean Avery broke his three-week media silence on Monday and announced he had cut off negotiating a new contract until the end of the season.

description: Alex Ovechkin needed another goal to hit 50. How about a hat trick?

title: A Little Wrinkle
description: Minutes after my optimistic blog post on Friday, when I thought we really could make an April completion date, the phone rang. It was Peggy Edwards, the lighting consultant from LyteWorks in Bradenton.

title: Comedy Stop: What Would Alex Keaton Do?
description: Its been almost 20 years since Family Ties went off the air. And Alex P. Keatons political idols, Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan, have each gone off to their deserved places in history. Yet I still get asked a lot  O.K. maybe not a lot but more than twice  whether Alex Keaton would be a Republican today. And, if so, who would be his candidate in the 2008 presidential election.

title: False Resume Gets Chef Cut From Food Network
description: After rising to culinary stardom preparing impossible meals on his Food Network series, Robert Irvine has met an obstacle his kitchen prowess couldnt overcome  an embellished resume, the Associated Press reports.

title: Answers About Baghdads Red Zone
description: The following is the first set of answers from reporters and staff members in the Baghdad Bureau, which is taking questions from readers through March 7 on life in the Iraqi capital outside the protection of the Green Zone. Readers can submit additional questions using the comment box below.

title: Demonstrations in Armenia
description: After 10 days of peaceful protests in Yerevan, the capital of Armenia, supporters of Levon Ter-Petrossian, who failed to capture the presidency on Feb. 19, faced off with the police.

title: Blame in Canada
description: OTTAWA  Its not at all unusual for Stephen Harper, the prime minister of Canada, and the members of his cabinet to grilled by the opposition parties in Parliament. It isnt common, however for the partisan bickering here to be focused on the Democratic primary in the United States.

title: The Social Life of Hyenas
description: Spotted hyenas live in a complex, hierarchical, female-dominated society.

title: Supporters Flood Texas and Ohio
description: Staff and volunteers for the Clinton and Obama campaigns were doing whatever they could to get voters to the polls.

title: The Day Before Texas and Ohio
description: The presidential candidates hit the trail in a burst of last-minute campaigning.

title: Does TV Belong in a Childs Bedroom?
description: Many parents think about how much TV their kids watch, and they worry about the content of television programs. But research shows parents also should consider the location of the set itself. My Well column in Tuesdays Science Times takes a look at the effect that a television in the bedroom has on a child. Studies show bedroom television is associated with poor schoolwork, sleep problems, obesity and even higher smoking risk.

title: Many Eyes on Rezko Trial
description: The gallery was packed with news reporters Monday as the criminal trial of businessman Antoin Rezko opened in federal district court in Chicago. Potential jurors filed into the courtroom throughout the day, as lawyers began trying to select a panel to hear the case of the fast-food chain owner and real estate developer.

title: When Music Takes Flight, Over and Over Again
description: EVER since I was a kid, I wanted to be a traveling musician. I can be in Washington, D.C., one week and Istanbul the next. But unlike many frequent fliers, I love traveling.

title: Mayors Donation Angers Albany Democrats
description: ALBANY News that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg quietly provided $500,000 to state Republicans to help them retain control of the Senate triggered anger among Democrats in the Capitol on Monday, with some predicting that the mayor had badly damaged his legislative agenda.

title: Hazards: Sleeping Through Noise, but Still Feeling Its Effects
description: Noise while you are sleeping can significantly raise your blood pressure, even when it does not wake you up, a new study suggests.

title: Texas: Settlement Ends Suit Against Sheriff
description: Closing a case that forced the resignation of the Harris County district attorney, county commissioners approved a $1.7 million payment to two brothers who said they were falsely arrested and abused for videotaping a drug raid by sheriffs deputies on a neighbors home in 2002. The lawsuit against Sheriff Tommy Thomas and deputies that was filed by the brothers, Erik and Sean Ibarra, led to the disclosure of sexually explicit and other embarrassing e-mail messages by District Attorney Charles A. Rosenthal Jr., who recently quit and still faces contempt charges for erasing messages against court orders. The settlement also provided $1.3 million to the Ibarras lawyer, Lloyd E. Kelley.

title: Violence Leaves Young Iraqis Doubting Clerics
description: BAGHDAD  After almost five years of war, many young people in Iraq, exhausted by constant firsthand exposure to the violence of religious extremism, say they have grown disillusioned with religious leaders and skeptical of the faith that they preach.

title: In Alaska, Ex-Governors Aide to Plead Guilty
description: The chief of staff under former Gov. Frank H. Murkowski of Alaska agreed Monday to plead guilty to concealing donations made to Mr. Murkowskis 2006 re-election campaign by an influential private contractor at the center of a wide-ranging federal investigation into Alaska politics and government.

title: Sounds of St. Petersburg in a Diverse Patchwork
description: Typically, the Vienna Philharmonics programs for its annual weekend in Carnegie Hall bring little mystery. They tend to center on the orchestras Germanic heritage: Haydn, Mozart, Beethoven; Schubert, Brahms, Bruckner; Schoenberg, Berg, Webern; Richard Strauss, Johann Strauss, whatever Strauss. The orchestra seems to be saying: This is our music. We play it better than anyone else on earth. And as often as not, they do.

title: Eradicate Malaria? Doubters Fuel Debate
description: Last year, challenging global health orthodoxy, Bill and Melinda Gates called for the eradication of malaria.

title: Fed Chief Urges Breaks for Some Home Borrowers
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke, urged mortgage lenders and investors on Tuesday to reduce the principal on loans for many people whose homes are no longer worth as much as the amount they still have to repay.

title: Ex-Presidents Words Cast Shadow Over Contests
description: It was a declaration that quickly became etched in the granite of conventional wisdom.

title: An Advocate for Stretching (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Afghanistan: Taliban Destroy Cell Towers
description: The Taliban knocked out two cellphone towers near the city of Kandahar over the weekend, carrying out a threat they made last week against all four cellphone companies in Afghanistan. The Taliban demanded that the companies stop operating at night because, they said, American and NATO forces were using phone signals to track Taliban movements.

title: Drug Pitchmen: Actor, Doctor or Pfizers Option
description: Years ago, a large poster featuring an appealingly sweaty and smiling young man climbing a mountain appeared in my subway station, directly across from my usual waiting spot. Purportedly he had been invigorated by one of the first AIDS drugs marketed directly to the public. He looked magnificent on top of his mountain, a lot better than my AIDS patients  a lot better than me.

title: Memo Gives Canadas Account of Obama Campaigns Meeting on Nafta
description: The denials were sweeping when Senator Barack Obamas campaign mobilized last week to refute a report that a senior official had given back-channel reassurances to Canada soft-pedaling Mr. Obamas tough talk on Nafta.

title: A One-Eyed Invader in the Bedroom
description: Heres one simple way to keep your children healthy: Ban the bedroom TV.

title: Stocks Flat as Oil Hits Record
description: Stocks meandered to a flat close Monday, as investors sought shelter in the traditional havens of gold, silver and commodities as they faced new reports showing weakness in the economy.

title: Flapping Past Gravitys Pull, Bat Has a Vortex at Its Wings
description: The power to fly is so handy that it has arisen multiple times during the evolution of life, but it does not come cheap. Pterodactyls, birds and bats had to cede two of their four legs to wingdom, while we humans have sacrificed many a Swiss Army knife, manicure kit, oversized bottle of shampoo and the occasional pair of novelty fuzzy handcuffs, all for the privilege of flipping through SkyMall magazine.

title: The Last Word, Loud and Clear
description: Paris

title: Baroque Fidgets Sublimated Into Joyous, Flowing Swirls
description: Life-changing dance experiences are a fine thing. But there is something to be said for pleasant evenings spent in the company of good dancers and a choreographer who understands them. On Saturday night Jessica Lang gave the dancers of the Richmond Ballet a chance to shine at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College.

title: Mourning Resonates From Staten Island to Sri Lanka
description: It sounds like a throwback to another century: A healthy, middle-class woman sickens late in her pregnancy, gives birth and dies two and a half weeks later, leaving her young husband to care for their newborn son alone.

title: France: Court Tells Web Site to Stop Grading Teachers
description: A court ordered that a Web site can no longer allow the practice of letting students anonymously rate teachers by name. The court sided with teachers unions that argued that the comments represented a breach of privacy and an incitement to public disorder. The Web site, which opened in January, is modeled after similar sites in the United States, Britain and Germany.

title: A Donor Match Over Small Talk and Coffee
description: TACOMA, Wash.  Annamarie Ausnes is known for holding up the line at her favorite Starbucks here, carefully counting out her coins to pay for her short drip, double-cupped daily jolt. Over the years, Sandie Andersen, a friendly barista behind the counter, might have rolled her eyes once or twice but she has also taken these morning moments to make conversation, to make friends.

title: Fresh Start as Yanks for Former Astros
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  The entrance to Osceola County Stadium still proclaims the Houston Astros the 2005 National League Champions, a crown they clinched when a fly ball settled into Jason Lanes glove in right field in St. Louis that October. Lane asked a club official to hold the ball while he celebrated, but he never got it back. The Astros said it belonged to the team, not the player.

title: Prevalence of Bacteria in Making Snowflakes Is Seen as Widespread
description: Raindrops and snowflakes dont just form by accident. They usually grow on tiny ice crystals, and unless it is supercold, the crystals have to grow on even tinier particles called ice nucleators.

title: Health Care and Albany
description: To the Editor:

title: Want to Trade? An Obama Will Cost You
description: While Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton duke it out in Texas and Ohio on Tuesday, Mr. Obama has trounced his Democratic rival in another arena: trading cards.

title: North Korea Says War Games Could Set Back Nuclear Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said Monday that annual American-South Korean military exercises that began over the weekend could further delay progress on ending the Norths nuclear weapons programs.

title: A Kaleidoscopic Perspective on a Murder, and Dreams Lost and Found
description: No one writes better dialogue than Richard Price  not Elmore Leonard, not David Mamet, not even David Chase. Not only does Mr. Price have perfect pitch for the lingo, the rhythms and the inflections of how people talk, but he also knows how to use a line or two or even a single phrase to conjure a characters history and emotional vibe. Hes as adept as Tom Wolfe at using his journalistic eye for social detail  for how people juggle work and love and money, and navigate the confounding maze of class and social status in big cities today  but he does so without turning his characters, as Mr. Wolfe so often does, into caricatures or cartoons.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Feb. 15 about Frank Piasecki, a pioneer in helicopter design, misstated the significance of the helicopter license he was issued by the federal government on Oct. 20, 1943, when he arrived in Washington to demonstrate his first helicopter. It was the first helicopter license issued to someone who did not already have a license to fly a fixed-wing aircraft; it was not the first government-issued helicopter license. (C. L. Morris, the chief test pilot for Igor Sikorsky, another helicopter pioneer, had received the first helicopter license, in March 1942.)

title: Want to Save a Coral Reef? Bring Along Your Crochet Hook
description: The exotically shaped creatures that began to sprout silently all over the cozy lecture hall were soon spilling onto empty chairs and into womens laps and shopping bags. When fully grown, these curiously animate forms will find a home as part of a mammoth version of the Great Barrier Reef. But at the moment they were emerging at a remarkable pace from the rapidly flicking crochet hooks wielded by members of the audience.

title: Regrets? Yankees May Have One
description: The Yankees have made two major decisions since the end of last season that they could come to regret this season. Last October there was Joe Torre; more recently there was Johan Santana.

title: Honor and the Prince
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about preparations in Baghdad for a visit by President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran described Irans ethnic makeup incorrectly. Slightly more than half of the countrys population is Persian; Iran is not overwhelmingly Persian. (It is overwhelmingly Shiite Muslim.)

title: Another Twist in Red Bulls Feud With the Fire
description: It has often been said that Major League Soccer is a collection of 14 teams with few authentic rivalries.

title: Falcons Used Formula for Glider Thermals Before Human Pilots
description: Paragliders, hang gliders and other practitioners of the art of soaring go through a lot of ups and downs in their travels. They will climb by circling within a thermal, a column of rising warm air, and then advance while descending until they hit the next thermal, when they repeat the process.

title: Bundled Mortgages and Dubious Fees Complicate Foreclosure Cases
description: When Ohioans head to the polls Tuesday to vote in one of the nations most scrutinized presidential primaries, Mark and Gina Wellman of Circleville, Ohio, will be watching another vote  what buyers are bidding for the house they built themselves when it goes on the sheriffs auction block.

title: Crisis at Colombia Border Spills Into Diplomatic Realm
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The three-way crisis in the Andes escalated Monday as Ecuador broke off diplomatic relations with Colombia, and Venezuela expelled Colombias ambassador and other diplomats.

title: NATO Could Block Macedonia Over Name
description: ATHENS  NATOs secretary general said Monday that Macedonias effort to become a member could be blocked if it failed to resolve a longstanding dispute over its name with Greece, a longtime NATO member.

title: The Refrain That Follows Bronfman
description: For a brief, shining moment, Edgar Bronfman Jr. had redeemed himself.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: New Yorkers Sure Love to Spend. Who Knew?
description: Were in the wrong business. All of us.

title: O Rose, Thou Art Energetic! New Look for a Fokine Classic
description: Dominic Walsh and his Houston ballet ensemble had several fine dancers and luxe production values going for them on Saturday night at the Joyce SoHo. But Mr. Walsh, a former principal dancer in the Houston Ballet, has the same problem as most other companies these days: disappointing choreography.

title: U.S. Told to Reconsider Cuts to Housing Aid
description: A federal court in Sacramento ruled Monday that the Bush administration must reassess its plan to eliminate a down payment assistance program used by more than 100,000 low- and middle-income home buyers.

title: A Wave of the Watch List, and Speech Disappears
description: Steve Marshall is an English travel agent. He lives in Spain, and he sells trips to Europeans who want to go to sunny places, including Cuba. In October, about 80 of his Web sites stopped working, thanks to the United States government.

title: From a Master Craftsman, Recurring Themes of Divinity, Death and Desire
description: Lifes a curse, loves a blight, Gods a blaggard, cherry blossom is quite nice. With these words a character in Tom Stoppards play The Invention of Love sums up A. E. Housmans book of verse A Shropshire Lad. A latter-day cynic could apply them to the dance works of Paul Taylor.

title: A Defining Moment
description: The Democratic presidential primary campaign began around Christmas 2006, and it may end Tuesday night. But of all the days between then and now, the most important was Nov. 10, 2007.

title: Men and Prostate Tests (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Relief for Homeowners Is Given to a Relative Few
description: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration, releasing new data on Monday, said that mortgage companies were showing more willingness to relax the loan terms for subprime borrowers who are in danger of losing their houses.

title: When People Drink Themselves Silly, and Why
description: The urge to binge mindlessly, though it can strike at any time, seems to stir in the collective unconscious during the last weeks of winter. Maybe its the television images from places like Fort Lauderdale and Cabo San Lucas, of communications majors face planting outside bars or on beaches.

title: After 5 Years, City Council Holds First Hearing on Mayors Control of Public Schools
description: Since taking control of New York Citys 1,400 public schools, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has steadfastly maintained that centralized, mayoral oversight is critical to turning around the vast system. But that view came under sharp attack on Monday as the City Council held the first public hearing on the state law authorizing mayoral control.

title: Perceptions: Watch Your Weight, Sure, but Dont Worry About It
description: Worrying about weighing too much may be bad for you, no matter how much you actually weigh.

title: Spitzer Helps Donors Skirt $10,000 Limit He Set
description: ALBANY  On Dec. 3, Richard P. Richman, a real estate developer from Connecticut, wrote a check to Gov. Eliot Spitzers campaign account.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about preparations in Baghdad for a visit by President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran described Irans ethnic makeup incorrectly. Slightly more than half of the countrys population is Persian; Iran is not overwhelmingly Persian. (It is overwhelmingly Shiite Muslim.) (Go to Article)

title: Weeks Notables
description: PLAYER In Spain, Sergio Aguero, Atletico Madrids 20-year-old Argentine striker, scored two goals Saturday in a 4-2 victory against Barcelona. The defeat ended Barcelonas eight-game unbeaten streak in La Liga and left it 5 points behind league-leading Real Madrid. Aguero, who is nicknamed Kun, after a Japanese comic book character, has 11 goals this season.

title: Klimt Frieze in Liverpool
description: Gustav Klimts monumental installation, The Beethoven Frieze, measuring more than 100 feet in length and celebrating the unification of all the arts, will be reconstructed at the Tate Liverpool museum in what is billed as Britains first comprehensive exhibition dedicated to the artist, Reuters reported. The show, scheduled for May 30 to Aug. 31 as part of Liverpools designation as a European Capital of Culture for 2008, will examine the role of Klimt (1862-1918) in the Secession movement, which inspired artists, architects, fashion designers and furniture makers. Klimt created The Beethoven Frieze, detail above, for the Secessions 14th exhibition, in 1902. Though it was to be destroyed after the show, a patron of the movement ordered it removed and stored, and the Austrian state eventually acquired and restored it for exhibition in the Secession building in Vienna.

title: Giuseppe di Stefano, a Tenor Whose Career Flamed Out Too Early, Is Dead at 86
description: Giuseppe di Stefano, a flamboyant, sometimes erratic opera star who in his prime after World War II was lauded as the most thrilling Italian tenor in a generation, died on Monday at his home in Santa Maria Hoe, north of Milan. He was 86.

title: Dinosaur Graveyard as Tourist Draw
description: LAKE BARREALES, Argentina  As Jorge Calvo strode along the dusty banks of this Patagonian lake, he scanned the reddish dirt, pointing to the remains of a dinosaur in the desert sun.

title: Van Gundys Inner Comedian
description: Jeff Van Gundys mirthless intensity as coach of the Knicks and the Houston Rockets did little to prepare viewers for Van Gundy the funny, sharp and relaxed TV analyst.

title: New Jersey Senate Votes for Leave to Care for Kin
description: TRENTON  After an unusually emotional debate bursting with political indignation and personal anguish, the State Senate narrowly approved legislation Monday that would make New Jersey the third state in the nation to give employees the right to take paid leave to care for a newborn or a sick relative.

title: Into the Fray Over the Cause of Autism
description: Its indisputable that autism is on the rise among children, Senator John McCain said while campaigning recently in Texas. The question is, Whats causing it? And we go back and forth, and theres strong evidence that indicates that its got to do with a preservative in vaccines.

title: Rice Urges More Mideast Talks, but Wont Mention a Cease-Fire
description: BRUSSELS  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice on Monday called for Israeli and Palestinian negotiators to return to peace talks and said that the longer negotiations were suspended, the more it is a victory for those who dont want to see a two-state solution.

title: Jeff Healey, Guitarist and Singer, Dies at 41
description: Jeff Healey, a Canadian guitarist, singer and songwriter whose band sold millions of blues-rock records and who also pursued a passion for old-time jazz, playing the trumpet and clarinet, died on Sunday in Toronto. He was 41.

title: BBC Set to Open Its New Arab World TV Channel
description: LONDON  A new Arabic-language television news channel from the British Broadcasting Corporation will cover events in the Arab world without fear or favor, as it seeks to set itself apart from other government-financed broadcasters in the region, Nigel Chapman, director of the BBC World Service, said Monday.

title: Vehicle Sales Fell by 10% Last Month
description: DETROIT  Sales of cars and trucks in the United States fell 10 percent in February as oil prices climbed past $100 a barrel and worries about a recession rattled consumer confidence.

title: Breathing Room
description: Q. Has the oxygen content of Earths atmosphere varied?

title: Before Firefighters, Engineer Pleads Not Guilty to Perjury
description: As two dozen firefighters in dress uniforms looked on, a structural engineer was charged on Monday with lying to city investigators looking into the circumstances of a building collapse that killed two of their colleagues in 2006.

title: Primary Season at the Modern
description: In the film Pleasantville (1998) the staid world of a black-and-white 1950s town is upended by the introduction of color. Something similar is happening at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Confessions on Climate
description: The Bush administration has now provided the rationale for its lamentable decision to deny California permission to develop its own stricter rules to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from vehicles. The explanation was full of holes, but it was not a total setback for those who want urgent action on global warming.

title: Nostrums: To Prevent Pain in Infants, How About Sugar Water?
description: Infants have to get shots, and they hurt. But a new study finds that there is an anesthetic that is not only effective but also easy to administer and safe: sugar water.

title: Antibiotics Questioned in Care at Lifes End
description: A yearlong study is raising questions about the widespread use of antibiotics in nursing homes to treat infections in patients with terminal dementia  a treatment that the authors suggest is of dubious value to the patients and may be dangerous in the long run.

title: To Be Eternally Young, Single and in Manhattan
description: Being John Amsterdams girlfriend would probably feel like a trying business, partly because he is a New York homicide detective, but mostly because he has lived for 366 years, accomplishing enough to acquire a not entirely unwarranted sense of arrogance. To make matters even more troublesome, John has spent all of his exceedingly long life in New York, where, ever since the first days of the pelt trade, presumably, the dating scene has been at once so vigorous and disappointing that he has gone out with more than 600 women, never finding the one.

title: When Bad Women Stalk Good Ratings
description: The slogan for the WE network is We Have More Fun, but it might as well read We Have More Deviance. On Tuesday the channel will begin showing a prurient true-crime series, Women Behind Bars, that is the most recent manifestation of the obsession womens television has with female aberrance: incessant portrayals of fat brides, crazy brides, hoarders, obsessive-compulsives, cheaters, gold diggers and black widows.

title: Security Council Adds Sanctions Against Iran
description: UNITED NATIONS  The Security Council on Monday adopted its third resolution imposing sanctions on Iran for its refusal to cease enriching uranium, an activity that the West suspects Iran may be using to create fuel for a nuclear weapon.

title: Ecoterrorism Suspected in House Fires in Seattle Suburb
description: MALTBY, Wash.  Five luxury homes in a subdivision marketed as built green near here were destroyed or severely damaged by fire early Monday, and evidence at the scene suggested the fires might have been started by radical environmentalists who viewed the homes as violating rather than complementing the wooded wetlands in which they were built.

title: A Blueprint to Improve Front Offices in the N.B.A.
description: It should surprise no one familiar with the professional basketball career of Charles Linwood Williams, more commonly known as Buck, that he is the vice president of a construction and building supplies company in the Washington area.

title: U.S. Forces Fire Missiles Into Somalia at a Kenyan
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  American naval forces fired missiles into southern Somalia on Monday, aiming at what the Defense Department called terrorist targets.

title: New DVDs: German Expressionism
description: GERMAN EXPRESSIONISM

title: U.S. and Europe Protest a Chinese News Regulation
description: WASHINGTON  In a new escalation of trade disputes with China, the Bush administration joined with the European Union on Monday in filing a suit at the World Trade Organization to protest Chinas requirement that foreign financial news services operate through a government-designated distributor.

title: Its All About Salary (Well, Not Always)
description: Putting a price tag on a staff job can be a lot harder than pricing your companys products and services, Joanna L. Krotz writes in Microsofts Small Business Center.

title: Museum to Show Stolen Munch Art
description: Stolen and damaged in an armed daylight robbery in 2004, the restored Edward Munch masterworks The Scream, above left, and Madonna, above right, will be returned to public view at the Munch Museum in Oslo in May, Agence France-Presse reported. A statement from the museum said that repairs were coming to an end and that the paintings would be featured in an exhibition from May 23 to Sept. 26. The museum was reluctant to discuss the damage, but Ingebjoerg Ydstie, a curator, said a humidity stain remained in a corner of The Scream. Munch painted several versions of the two paintings, but the ones in the Munch Museum are considered among the most complete. At the time of the robbery their worth was estimated as high as $100 million. Security at the museum has been tightened since the crime. Three men were convicted, but Bjoern Hoen, regarded as the mastermind, is to be retried.

title: Charges Are Dropped Against 2 Shiite Ex-Officials Accused in Sectarian Killings
description: BAGHDAD  A three-judge panel dropped charges on Monday against two former high-ranking Shiite government officials accused of using the Health Ministry to run death squads and enrich themselves.

title: The Claim: Caffeine Causes Dehydration
description: THE FACTS

title: Hall Will Give to Museum
description: The National Track and Field Hall of Fame has agreed to provide memorabilia to the Sports Museum of America. The museum is scheduled to open in May at 26 Broadway in Lower Manhattan, next to the Charging Bull bronze sculpture and near the Statue of Liberty ferry.The track hall of fame is in the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan. It will send the museum such archival material as a medal won by Jim Thorpe, a discus Al Oerter used in one of his four Olympic victories, Carl Lewiss running shoes, Rafer Johnsons Olympic uniform, and a cap worn by Archie Hahn during the 1906 Olympics.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about bluegrass and other acoustical music in New York referred incorrectly to a song performed by Levon Helm at a recent musical gathering at his home studio in Woodstock, N.Y. The song, Long Black Veil, is not on Mr. Helms new album, Dirt Farmer. (Mr. Helm is scheduled to play at the Beacon Theater this weekend.)

title: As Israelis Pull Out of Gaza, Hamas Celebrates Its Rocketry
description: GAZA  As Israel withdrew its forces from the northern Gaza Strip on Monday after a two-day assault on Hamas militants, and as Palestinians emerged from their houses to inspect the damage, Hamas leaders seemed to be following the playbook of their Lebanese ally, Hezbollah, in its 2006 war with Israel.

title: Court Allows Suit Against Drug Maker
description: WASHINGTON  A 4-to-4 vote on Monday left the Supreme Court unable to decide a pharmaceutical pre-emption case that was argued a week ago.

title: Rolen Enjoying New Address: With Toronto, and Far From La Russa
description: DUNEDIN, Fla.  Scott Rolen answered a simple question with a question on a sleepy Monday morning. When Rolen, the Toronto Blue Jays new third baseman, was asked if he would agree to an interview, he turned from infielder to interrogator. Rolen wanted to know what kind of questions he would have to field.

title: Iran President, in Baghdad, Calls for U.S. to Leave
description: BAGHDAD  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, on the second day of his visit here, called on Monday for the withdrawal of American troops from Iraqi soil, saying their presence was the root of Iraqs instability and violence.

title: Detective Tells of Tense Hours on Night of Sean Bell Shooting
description: The first undercover detective to enter an exotic dancing club in Queens hours before the fatal shooting of Sean Bell had misgivings from the start, telling his lieutenant he was uncomfortable with the size and rowdiness of the crowd at Club Kalua, the detective testified on Monday.

title: Seeking a Spot, a Mets Pitcher Has to Be Creative
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Pitcher Nelson Figueroa Jr. likes to go headhunting. It is one of his favorite ways to unwind when he is not trying to nail down a roster spot with the Mets.

title: Fighting Tuberculosis
description: To the Editor:

title: Border Insecurity
description: From San Diego on the Pacific to Brownsville on the Rio Grande, a steel curtain is descending across the continent. Behind it lies a nation so confused and conflicted by its immigration problems that it has decided to wall itself off and wait for things to fix themselves. This country once was a confident global magnet for an invigorating flow of immigrant workers and citizens-to-be. Now it is just hunkering.

title: In Deal With Cuomo, Mortgage Giants Accept Appraisal Standards
description: Responding to criticism that home appraisers had inflated prices in recent years, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac said Monday that they would buy mortgages only from lenders that use independent appraisers.

title: Marbury Is Absent, but the Knicks Account for Another Defeat
description: The Knicks clinched their seventh consecutive losing season and fell to a season-low 24 games under .500 Monday night amid another chapter of Will He or Wont He Show Up?

title: Arizona Senator Sweeps 4 Primaries
description: Senator John McCain, a one-time party rebel whose campaign appeared doomed only seven months ago, became the Republican nominee for president on Tuesday night as he won sweeping victories in Ohio, Texas, Vermont and Rhode Island and as his dogged but lagging competitor, former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas, dropped out of the race.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Advertising column in Business Day last Tuesday, about commercials that ran during the Academy Awards show, misidentified the writer of Killing the Blues, a song featured in a commercial for J. C. Penney. And a correction in this space on Thursday cited another incorrect writer for the song. Killing the Blues was written by Rowland Salley. It is not by Alison Krauss and Robert Plant, whose version of the song on their new album was heard in the ad. And it is not by John Prine, who recorded it, as did many other arists.

title: Kenyan Opposition Leader Says Foreign Pressure Must Continue
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Raila Odinga is a happy man.

title: For Democrats, a Pivotal Night, but in Which Direction?
description: When 22 states selected Democratic delegates on a single day last month, the sheer scale made election night returns difficult to follow.

title: Avery and Rangers Will Resume Contract Talks After Season
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Although his play has improved drastically, Rangers forward Sean Avery has hit a roadblock in his quest to sign a contract extension. Avery said Monday that he and the team have cut off negotiations for the rest of the season because we are extremely far apart in each others view of what Im worth as a player.

title: Democratic Rivals Clash Before Pivotal Primaries
description: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama battled over national security and trade in a frantic burst of last-minute campaigning on Monday as Mrs. Clinton accused Mr. Obama of deception and new evidence of discord surfaced within her own camp.

title: Iran May Block Internet on Election Day
description: TEHRAN  Irans government might block private access to the Internet on its election day, March 14, two Iranian news outlets reported Monday.

title: Lone Star Liberals Are Back
description: Houston

title: Unlike Consumers, Companies Are Piling Up Cash
description: At least someone knows how to fill a piggy bank.

title: Spree Continues for Jets With 2 More Free Agents
description: The Jets, the Patriots heated  and hated  rival, are apparently desperate to catch their nemesis and avoid another losing season. They continued their head-spinning free-agency spree Monday by signing linebacker/defensive end Calvin Pace and offensive lineman Damien Woody.

title: Gene Map Becomes a Luxury Item
description: On a cold day in January, Dan Stoicescu, a millionaire living in Switzerland, became the second person in the world to buy the full sequence of his own genetic code.

title: A Debunker on the Road to World War II
description: SOUTH BERWICK, Me.  Nicholson Baker no longer collects old newspapers. For the last decade or so he has lived in an old farmhouse in this little southern Maine town, and he now accepts that Maine winters and the quirks of his local news agent do not make him a person ideally situated to assemble a complete archive of The New York Times.

title: Strawberry, in New Role, Is Back With the Mets
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets newest hire looked fit enough to take batting practice Monday. In a clubhouse that has taken on the look of a triage center, Darryl Strawberry appeared like a hallucination, looking so resplendent in his Mets jersey that it was like 1986 again.

title: Larry Norman, Singer of Christian Rock Music, Dies at 60
description: Larry Norman, a singer and songwriter considered by many to be the father of Christian rock despite years of being shunned by more traditional Christians, died on Feb. 24 at his home in Salem, Ore. He was 60.

title: Shooting at South Florida Restaurant Kills 2
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  A gunman dressed in a coat and tie walked into a Wendys fast food restaurant here at lunchtime on Monday and opened fire, killing one customer and wounding four others before killing himself, the police said.

title: Announcing an Ending to What Never Began
description: Im using this column to announce that I will not attempt an independent race for the presidency.

title: Chef Cooks Up Hoax
description: The celebrity chef, author and aspiring St. Petersburg, Fla., restaurateur Robert Irvine will be replaced by the Food Network as host of Dinner Impossible after admitting to inaccuracies in a rsum that included a British knighthood, ownership of a castle in Scotland, friendship with Prince Charles and cooking for four United States presidents, the BBC reported. The British-born Mr. Irvine, 42, who also said he had helped to make the wedding cake for Prince Charles and Lady Diana, told The St. Petersburg Times that he had fabricated parts of his history because he felt pressure to keep up with the Joneses and that he was truly sorry. Mr. Irvine, the author of an autobiography, Mission: Cook!, and the owner of a company that sells his own brand cookware, did work at the White House, but in the Navy Mess, not as a personal chef to a president. A spokesman for the Food Network said, We appreciate Roberts remorse about his actions, but added that for now we will be looking for a replacement host.

title: Le Carre's Return
description: John le Carr, the British writer of literary spy thrillers, has returned to a previous publisher for his forthcoming novel, A Most Wanted Man. Mr. le Carr has signed a one-book deal with Scribner, a unit of Simon & Schuster, for the United States rights to the novel, which will be simultaneously published in Britain (by Hodder & Stoughton) in October. Mr. le Carr, above, is leaving Little, Brown & Co., the publisher of his last two books, The Mission Song and Absolute Friends, and returning to Scribner, which published Single & Single and The Constant Gardener. The new novel is set in Germany and takes place in one day. It chronicles the fate of a Muslim man who moves to Hamburg to enroll in medical school but because of his murky background ends up being followed by both local and other Western intelligence agencies. Its John le Carr, so of course you dont know who to trust, Susan Moldow, publisher of Scribner, said. You dont know whos telling the truth. Its wonderful mind games and also very reflective of how intelligence communities operate. Michael Rudell, the lawyer who negotiated the Scribner deal for Mr. le Carr, declined to comment on the size of the advance but said it was a very significant deal.

title: A Package That Lights Up the Shelf
description: ABOUT a year ago, when Jamie Leventhal was trying to convince big chain stores to stock his new line of shaving gels for young men, a buyer for Target asked a crucial question: How much would he spend on advertising?

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Friday about the return of Alexei Yashin and other National Hockey League players to Russia to join a resurgent professional league misstated the nature of Yashins relationship with the model Carol Alt. She is his longtime companion, not his wife.

title: Joint Chiefs Chairman Asks Pakistanis What They Need
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. Mike Mullen, arrived here on Monday to emphasize Americas eagerness to help Pakistan in its fight against foreign terrorists and homegrown militants operating in the countrys northwestern tribal areas.

title: Compositions to Do Battle With War and Injustice
description: Artists have long created art as a means of political protest with works like Picassos Guernica, now a tribute to victims of war. Composers have a less direct means of rebellion than the more literal expression of painters, photographers and playwrights. But even if there had not been descriptions in the program, the new music performed at the Great Hall at Cooper Union on Saturday evening during a concert commemorating the fifth anniversary of the war in Iraq clearly evoked conflict and anguish.

title: Jagger Death Plot
description: A plot by the Hells Angels, above with Mick Jagger at Altamont, Calif., in 1969, to kill Mr. Jagger nearly 40 years ago failed when the would-be assassins, traveling by boat, encountered a storm and were thrown overboard, according to a new BBC radio series. In one episode of the series, The F.B.I. at 100, a former F.B.I. agent, Mark Young, said that Angels became enraged in the aftermath of the Rolling Stones free concert at Altamont. During the concert a fan was stabbed and killed by the Angels, who had been providing security for the Stones. The Stones then distanced themselves from the Angels, which made the Angels angry with Mr. Jagger, the program said. They were going to kill him in retribution for his firing their security forces, Mr. Young said in the program, the BBC reported on its Web site. Their plan involved making entry into his Long Island property, going by boat. As they gathered the weaponry and their forces to go out on Long Island Sound, a storm rolled up, which nearly sunk the watercraft they were in, and they escaped with their own lives. Mr. Young told the program that the botched plot came to life much later, in the course of a wider investigation into the Angels activities. The episode is to be broadcast next week. A spokesman for Mr. Jagger said he would have no comment.

title: Health and the Jazz World
description: To the Editor:

title: In an Answerless Canadian Inquiry, 3 Bodyless Feet
description: GABRIOLA ISLAND, British Columbia  Should a fourth human foot float ashore here in the evergreen Gulf Islands off the west coast of Canada, the person who finds it would no doubt want to know the answers to three questions.

title: Menu Fight Over Calories Leads Doctor to Reject Post
description: A dispute over food industry influence has resulted in the resignation of the incoming president of the Obesity Society.

title: Gang Memoir, Turning Page, Is Pure Fiction
description: In Love and Consequences, a critically acclaimed memoir published last week, Margaret B. Jones wrote about her life as a half-white, half-Native American girl growing up in South-Central Los Angeles as a foster child among gang-bangers, running drugs for the Bloods.

title: Facebook Hires Google Executive as No. 2
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook is not stepping aside for a chief executive as Larry Page and Sergey Brin did at Google or as Jerry Yang and David Filo did at Yahoo. He is following the Bill Gates model and holding the top post as he hires a Google executive, Sheryl Sandberg, as chief operating officer.

title: Venezuelan Pleads Guilty in Cash Delivery
description: A Venezuelan businessman has pleaded guilty to taking part in a conspiracy to cover up Venezuelas role in delivering $800,000 to the campaign of Argentinas president, American prosecutors said Monday.

title: Nine Shot in a Memphis Home, and Six Are Dead
description: MEMPHIS  Six people were found dead Monday, and three more were critically injured in Memphis in what news reports said was the worst mass killing there in at least 15 years.

title: Footnotes
description: Miley Cyrus, better known as Hannah Montana, has joined the lineup of entertainers at Nickelodeons 2008 Kids Choice Awards, to be broadcast from the Pauley Pavilion at University of California, Los Angeles, on March 29. Other participants in the show include Nickelodeons Naked Brothers Band, Steve Carell, Cameron Diaz, America Ferrara, Harrison Ford, Jennifer Love Hewitt, Heidi Klum, Shia LaBeouf, Hayden Panettiere and Ryan Seacrest. ... Kid Rock has pleaded not guilty to a misdemeanor charge of battery arising from a fight in October at a Waffle House after a performance in Atlanta, The Associated Press reported. The musician, whose real name is Robert James Ritchie, was not present in DeKalb County State Court for the plea.

title: Teaching Kids About H.I.V. (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the resignation of Tim Goeglein, a White House aide who admitted repeatedly plagiarizing other writers for his guest columns in The News-Sentinel of Fort Wayne, Ind., misidentified the hometown of Nancy Nall, the blogger who first discovered the plagiarism. She lives in Grosse Pointe Woods, Mich.  not in Fort Wayne, where she was once a columnist for the same newspaper.

title: A Quarter of Gas Cut to Ukraine by Gazprom
description: MOSCOW  Gazprom, the Russian natural gas company and the worlds largest, cut about a quarter of the gas supply to Ukraine on Monday to force the country to settle a debt.

title: Germany: Samsung to Expand in Office Products
description: Samsung, the worlds largest electronics maker, said it was starting a major push into the personal computer and office equipment markets, leveraging its position as the leading maker of computer monitors. Jong Woo Park, the president for Samsungs digital media business, announced the sales offensive in Hanover, Germany, as he introduced an expanded line of laptop computers and laser printers for business customers at Cebit, the largest European technology convention. The new line of laptops is geared toward business users, with models beginning at about $1,215.

title: Clinton Defeats Obama in Ohio Primary; McCain Clinches Race as Foe Concedes
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton captured the Ohio Democratic primary on Tuesday, snapping Barack Obamas streak of 12 victories and giving her the chance to extend her campaign beyond the days races and possibly to the Pennsylvania contest next month.

title: The Air Shuttles to Boston and Washington Endure Industrys Changes
description: The Delta and US Airways shuttles from New York to Boston and Washington are the archetypal power flights, relied upon by politicians, Wall Street executives and other business travelers for their hourly service and privileged ambience.

title: Nine Inch Nails Fashions Innovative Web Pricing Plan
description: LOS ANGELES  Since being released from its major-label recording contract last year, Nine Inch Nails has joined the growing ranks of prominent artists who are navigating the digital wilderness on their own. Like another independent-minded act, Radiohead, Nine Inch Nails has responded to the wash of free music on the Internet, but with its own tactic: the band has uploaded tracks from its new album directly to an unauthorized file-sharing network even as it offered more elaborate versions for up to $300.

title: One-Ounce Mississippian of 55.8 Million Years Ago
description: It is hard to picture a wee monkeylike adult creature weighing no more than an ounce. But fossils of the 55.8 million-year-old animal, the earliest known primate to inhabit North America, have emerged from coastal sediments in Mississippi.

title: Oil Tops Inflation-Adjusted Record Set in 1980
description: Capping a relentless rise in recent years, oil prices hit a record high during the day on Monday, then pulled back to close below the record.

title: City Rejects Sale of Building Seen as Hip-Hops Birthplace
description: The Bronx apartment building recognized as a birthplace of hip-hop may be saved from gentrification, for the time being.

title: Major Carriers Raise Fares
description: ANOTHER FARE INCREASE Major airlines raised fares again over the weekend by $10 round trip on most routes. The latest round of increases, the sixth this year, was started on Thursday by Delta Air Lines, said Rick Seaney, the chief executive of FareCompare.com. Mr. Seaney said that jet fuel prices were nearing $3 a gallon last week, compared with $1.85 a gallon a year ago. Soaring fuel costs will force carriers to continue to raise airline ticket prices or dramatically cut back capacity, he said.

title: Cool View of Science at Meeting on Warming
description: Several hundred people sat in a fifth-floor ballroom at the Marriott Marquis Hotel in Times Square on Monday eating pasta and trying hard to prove that they had unraveled the established science showing that humans are warming the world in potentially disruptive ways.

title: A Bug Rises, and With It a Company
description: Patients might not particularly like the new admission procedure at a growing number of hospitals: having what looks like an elongated Q-Tip stuck up their noses. But it smells great to Cepheid.

title: Polluted Worms Help Starlings Song, but Not Mating Fitness
description: To the long list of the unintended effects of environmental contaminants, add one  eating polluted worms affects the songs of male starlings.

title: Europes Journey to the Center of the Space Station
description: Europe is set to significantly increase its involvement with the International Space Station with the launching of a large new spacecraft that is to regularly supply the outpost with fuel, oxygen and other cargo.

title: Hot Demand for Political Gear in a Hot Race
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Senator Barack Obama was an hour and a half late to a rally last week at Ohio State University, and the crowd was becoming bored. Suddenly, squeals and cheers erupted from a corner of the arena, and all 8,000 heads turned to catch a glimpse of the candidate.

title: Affair Is Cited at Fraud Trial of Ex-Mayor of Newark
description: NEWARK  There was still the familiar gap-toothed grin, the same garrulous demeanor. But once the door closed to Courtroom 4B at the Martin Luther King Jr. Federal Courthouse here on Monday, it was a decidedly different Sharpe James who took center stage from the one who ruled this city as mayor for two decades. Mr. James did not say a word.

title: Former Player Helps Purdue Return to Prominence
description: In 2004, Matt Painter completed a 25-win season with Southern Illinois and then signed on as the head-coach-in-waiting at his alma mater, Purdue, as Gene Keady took one last victory lap before retirement.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about a Colombian announcement that security forces had killed a senior commander of the countrys largest guerrilla group in combat misspelled the province where the fighting took place. It is Putumayo, not Putamayo.

title: The Bolshoi Ballet Appoints a New Artistic Director
description: MOSCOW  Yuri Burlaka, a choreographer known for reconstructing classic ballets, has been appointed as the successor to Alexei Ratmansky as the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet.

title: After the Sunshine, the Gathering Storm
description: Before the Escher String Quartets concert on Sunday afternoon at the New School, part of the Schneider Concerts series, a gentleman in the audience remarked to his companion that there was once a civilized time when string quartets sat down to play. While not quite a trend, standing up to perform has become more common recently, with prominent ensembles like the Emerson, Brodsky and Skampa string quartets playing chairless (except for the cellist).

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 3, 2008

title: Putins Mini-Me (or Not?)
description: And so it came to pass as Vladimir Putin decreed: Dmitri Medvedev will be Russias next president. There were no surprises in Sundays balloting. After eight years as Russias head of state, Mr. Putin ruthlessly and efficiently engineered the selection  none dare call it an election in any credible democratic sense  of his successor, who won slightly more than 70 percent of the vote.

title: Sociable, and Smart
description: For the past two decades, Kay E. Holekamp has been chronicling the lives of spotted hyenas on the savannas of southern Kenya. She has watched cubs emerge from their dens and take their place in the hyena hierarchy; she has seen alliances form and collapse. She has observed clan wars, in which dozens of hyenas have joined together to defend their hunting grounds against invaders.

title: For Devils, Any Loss Is Costly in Standings
description: The Devils ended practice Monday by stretching at center ice. Brent Sutter, their first-year coach, made a slow circle, tapping every player with his stick and whispering words of encouragement. They will need all the nudging they can get.

title: Moss Stays Put After Flirtation in Free Agency
description: The mystery of Randy Moss ended Monday right where it started, with Moss a member of the New England Patriots.

title: Zinc and Lead Mining Company Acquires a Rival
description: Zinifex, an Australian mining company that specializes in zinc and lead, agreed to be acquired by Oxiana, one of the largest mining companies in Australia, for 6 billion Australian dollars ($5.6 billion). The deal, which requires shareholder approval, comes after a year of discussions, the companies said. Oxiana agreed to pay 3.1931 of its shares for each share of Zinifex. Both companies are based in Melbourne.

title: The $2 Trillion Nightmare
description: Weve been hearing a lot about Saturday Night Live and the fun it has been having with the presidential race. But hardly a whisper has been heard about a Congressional hearing in Washington last week on a topic that could have been drawn, in all its tragic monstrosity, from the theater of the absurd.

title: Porsche Closer to a Takeover of Volkswagen
description: FRANKFURT  Porsche and Volkswagen demonstrated on Monday that empire building is alive and well in the European auto industry, as the sports car maker crept closer to taking over Volkswagen, even as VW bought control of a rival truck manufacturer.

title: Two Officers Who Abandoned Teenager Face Indictments
description: Two police officers who were accused of leaving a teenager in an isolated Staten Island marsh on Halloween have been indicted on 33 counts, some of them felonies, law enforcement officials said.

title: A Virtual Travel Agent With All the Answers
description: I HATE being addressed by machines. We have a microwave that says, Enjoy your meal! when the bell goes off, even if you have only warmed up a cup of coffee. I tell the microwave to shut up, though not exactly in those words.

title: Having a Baby: Blood Pressure Troubles Linked to a Virus Infection
description: Pre-eclampsia, the high blood pressure in pregnancy that can endanger both mother and baby, may be associated with a virus infection of the fetus, an Australian study has found.

title: UConn Rules the Big East, as Usual
description: HARTFORD  It sounded like nothing more than the joyous and incoherent screaming of 15,779 fans Monday night, but the message was clear: Connecticut, the top womens basketball team in the country, will once again enter the postseason as the favorite to win the national championship.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an art review in Weekend on Friday about Gustave Courbet, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, misidentified the region of France where Courbets birthplace, Ornans, is located. It is in eastern France, not the southwest.

title: Limiting Young Pitchers Puzzles Mussina
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  In his first full professional season, 1991, Mike Mussina threw 210 innings. The next season, he threw 241 and made the All-Star team for the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Candidates Responding Almost as Fast as They Can Attack
description: WASHINGTON  This may be the year politics finally moves at the speed of the Internet.

title: What Sudan Needs Now
description: To the Editor:

title: From Multiple Sclerosis, a Multiplicity of Challenges
description: When it comes to understanding, preventing and treating chronic diseases, multiple sclerosis ranks among the most challenging. The word multiple is apt in more ways than one.

title: Spitzer to Present a Plan to Reduce Foreclosures
description: The Spitzer administration plans to propose a legislative package on Tuesday intended to help stem the rising tide of home foreclosures by requiring lenders to try to work out repayments with borrowers before suing them.

title: Rem Koolhaas Does Dubai
description: Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas has developed a typically audacious and provocative design plan for the proposed 1.5-billion-square-foot Waterfront City in Dubai. The plans calls for Manhattan-like square blocks of high density towers, offset by bold architectural statements.

title: A Record-Setting Career
description: For 18 years, Brett Favre set the bar for grittiness among N.F.L. quarterbacks.

title: Early Americas
description: Images from two exhibitions in Chicago and Washington.

title: $8 Million Homes
description: Properties on the market in Montana, Florida and Arizona.

title: Three Stars for Amador
description: The three stars of the famous Michelin guide set my stomach rumbling. For the first time, I was going to dine in a restaurant that had wrangled the tip-top award from a most prestigious critic.

title: Drink In That Knowledge
description: Its Joe Science goes to a kegger. In a science article today on binge drinking, some of the research raises questions about whose brain cells are being depleted:

title: Indiana Jones and the Gold Watch
description: More of your late night humor (send via the comment link below):

title: Back on the Drugs
description: Aired Monday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Rush Limbaugh is urging Republicans to vote for Hillary Clinton in the Texas primary tomorrow. Political experts say it could only mean that Rush is back on the drugs.

title: Full Development Slates For TBS, TruTV
description: TV Decoder highlighted TNTs strategy of original shows on Monday, but TNT isnt the only Turner network pitching a new programming plan. The Associated Press reports:

title: Minivan Hillary Fans
description: As The Jeannie Tate Show goes to a Hillary Clinton rally for a school civics project, the mother-daughter issue dominates the agenda:

title: The First Circumcision
description: 15,000 years ago

title: Follow the Bouncing College Teams
description: Another weekend of college hockey is over and three of the six Division I conferences are heading to the playoffs. Michigan won the CCHA regular season title, Clarkson and Army won the ECAC and Atlantic Hockey crowns, respectively. But even with some resolution in the standings, the NCAA Tournament picture remains cloudy. For an explanation of the tournament selection process, read this.

title: Japans Takefuji Faces $290 Million Loss on Investment
description: The Japanese consumer lender Takefuji said it might lose as much as 30 billion yen ($290 million) on a structured finance deal arranged by Merrill Lynch, making it the first money lender in the country to be hit by the global credit crisis.

title: Former Adelphia Executives Lose Final Appeal
description: Adelphia Communications  founder John Rigas and his son Timothy lost their final appeal Monday of their convictions for fraud that led to the collapse of the nations fifth-largest cable television company.

title: Security Capital Hires Rothschild to Explore Options
description: Security Capital Assurance, a bond insurer, lost more than half its market value on Monday after it said it had hired Rothschild as an adviser to consider strategic options and warned of a big loss.

title: Porsche Closer to a Takeover of Volkswagen
description: Porsche and Volkswagen demonstrated on Monday that empire building is alive and well in the European auto industry, as Porsche crept closer to taking over Volkswagen, even as VW bought control of a rival truck manufacturer.

title: Acer Dials Up $290 Million Deal for Taiwans E-Ten
description: Continuing its spending spree, Acer announced Monday it plans to acquire E-Ten for $290 million.

title: Nikes Umbro Deal Crosses the Finish Line
description: Nike said Monday it had completed its acquisition of Umbro, a British soccer equipment company, and Umbros chief executive officer has decided to leave the company.

title: SocGen Offers Buyouts to Rosbank Shareholders
description: Frances Socit Gnrale, which holds a controlling stake in the Russian bank Rosbank, has offered to buy the stakes of minority shareholders for 194.09 rubles per share, Rosbank said on Tuesday.

title: BHP Billiton in Talks for Record $55 Billion Loan
description: The mining giant BHP Billiton has approached sub-underwriting banks in an effort to secure a record $55 billion loan to back its hostile bid for its rival Rio Tinto, according to Reuters.

title: The Playoffs Before the Playoffs
description: Dave Caldwell takes a look at how the Devils are coping with the giant knot that is the Eastern Conference playoff race.

title: Continental Is Uniteds Number One Pick, Union Official Says
description: Continental Airlines is without question United Airlines first choice as a merger partner, but any deal is in limbo until it becomes clear whether Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines will combine, a top United union official and board member told The Houston Chronicle.

title: StatoilHydro to Pay $1.8 Billion for Anadarko Assets
description: StatoilHydro on Tuesday said its paying at least $1.8 billion to Anadarko Petroleum for stakes in heavy-oil and deep-water projects in Brazil and the Gulf of Mexico, part of a strategy at the Norwegian firm to compensate for difficulties from gas pipelines closer to home.

title: Hedge Fund Sues Citigroup and Wachovia
description: Citigroup and Wachovia are facing separate lawsuits filed in a federal court in New York by a $58-million-asset hedge fund, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: Citigroup May Need More Capital, Dubai Fund Chief Says
description: Dubai International Capital said on Tuesday it would take a lot more money to rescue Citigroup, even after investments from rival sovereign wealth funds in Abu Dhabi and Kuwait.

title: Sears May Still Have Restoration in Its Sights
description: Sears Holdings is apparently not giving up on Restoration Hardware, even though the home furnishings retailer rejected a revised offer from Sears on the last day of Restorations go-shop period.

title: Specialty Funds Continue To Tap Big Money
description: Leveraged buyout activity may be down, but that hasnt dampened limited partner appetite for private equity funds  especially targeted ones.

title: Handango Palms $9.5 Million From V.C.s
description: Handango, a seller of software and games for mobile devices, said Monday it picked up $9.5 million in a third round of funding from investors interested in its smart phone content distribution.

title: Turn Reels In $15 Million in New Round
description: An online ad network, Turn, has raised a $15 million second round funding, Paid Content reported.

title: Whitman Takes on Ackman Over Bond Insurers
description: A respected value investor, Martin Whitman, is going toe-to-toe with another well known value investor, the hedge fund manager William Ackman, over the future of the bond insurance industry.

title: Companies Are Piling Up Cash
description: At least someone knows how to fill a piggy bank.

title: The Refrain That Follows Bronfman
description: Just two years ago, Edgar Bronfman Jr. seemed to have found redemption after nearly losing his familys fortune, reinventing himself as a music mogul and helping to lead a remarkable overhaul at the Warner Music Group.

title: Ambac Said to Abandon Plan to Split Itself
description: In an apparent reversal, the Ambac Financial Group, the second-largest bond insurer in the world, has decided not to split itself into two as part of a $2 billion to $3 billion recapitalization, The Financial Times reported on Tuesday.

title: Whos Next for the Deal Dead Pool, Part Deux
description: In light of the looming termination of the Genesco/Finish Line tie-up, a new nominee for the deal dead pool is needed. Previous honored candidates have included Reddy Ice and PHH Corporation.

title: The Never-Ending Story
description: Last night I would have loved nothing more than to play a bedtime song for my 9-year-old son, Jack, and then relax with my wife, a hard-working middle-school science teacher.

title: What Price Scrabulous?
description: The fight over the future of Scrabulous, the latest bane of office productivity, may come down to a question of how many zeroes all the sides can score.

title: Market Street SPAC Files for $350 Million I.P.O.
description: Another blank-check company is coming down the pike with an initial public offering.

title: Predictions From a Top Bankruptcy Lawyer
description: As companies begin to pile up bankruptcy protection  Sharper Image, Lillian Vernon and Plastech, just to name a few recent filings  Investment Dealers Digest went to Harvey Miller of Weil Gotshal & Manges, one of the nations most prominent bankruptcy lawyers, to get his take on whats in store.

title: McCain Previews Broad General Campaign
description: SAN ANTONIO, Texas  Looking ahead a little to what a general election campaign might look like, Senator John McCain, who hopes to wrap up the Republican nomination as early as Tuesday night, said that he would like to compete in California, which has voted reliably for Democrats in recent presidential elections.

title: Returning to Basra
description: BASRA, Iraq  In early February, the week before a journalist and his interpreter were kidnapped from a downtown hotel, I traveled into this city for a couple of furtive glances. It was the first time I had been there since 2005, when I stayed at that very same hotel.

title: The Cover Boy (And His Accordion)
description: Picking cover art for a novel is never an easy job.

title: Spitzer Helps Donors Skirt $10,000 Limit He Set
description: Despite his high-profile pledge not to accept donations greater than $10,000  less than one-fifth the $55,900 allowed under state law  Gov. Eliot Spitzers political organization has raised more than $1 million above the cap he imposed on himself, by directing his donors to the Democratic state party account, which he controls, Danny Hakim reports. The strategy has helped bring the governor and his party within one seat of gaining control of the Senate. But it has raised questions about whether Mr. Spitzer is living up to the high ethical expectations he set, especially among those who looked to him to change the way business is done in Albany.

title: The Early Word: Off to the Polls
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  With a flood watch in effect in southern Ohio and an icy mix predicted for northern parts of the state, like the heavily populated Cleveland area, the storm system that is sweeping eastward and northward (think Vermont) has stirred serious worries about what had been anticipated as a high turnout at the polls in four primary states today.

title: Sovereign Funds Make Case on Hill
description: CNBC interviews Luis Gutierrez, Democratic  congressman from Illinios, about hearings in the House Financial Services Committee on the role of sovereign wealth funds in the U.S.

title: Tough Questions, Hard Numbers
description: So, with Super Tuesday already taken, what do we call today? Elimination Tuesday? Resurrection Tuesday? Oh-no-get-ready-for-three-more-months-of-primaries Tuesday?
