title: Lessons From the Genesco Fight
description: The troubled merger of Genesco/Finish Line has come to an ignominious end. Finish Line, a footwear chain, announced early Tuesday that the parties had agreed to settle all litigation among them relating to their proposed merger and UBSs financing of the deal. As part of the settlement, the merger has been dropped. Genesco will get $175 million  $136 million of it from UBS, the rest from Finish Line  as well as 6.5 million shares of Finish Line stock.

title: France Faces Off With Germany Over Car Emissions Criteria
description: French carmakers manufacture cheaper and lighter vehicles than their German counterparts. As a result, under proposed European Union legislation, French automakers wont have to cut their vehicles emissions as much as the Germans.

title: A Last Glimpse of the 9/11 Stairway, Before It Moves
description: Something astonishing is now visible on Vesey Street: the Vesey Street staircase.

title: Picking a Tour Group to Hike Perus Inca Trail
description: I am traveling to Peru on March 9th. I am looking into doing a rigorous hike to Machu Picchu via the Inca Trail. I have researched many tour groups and their availability and narrowed my choices to Andean Treks, Enigma, Andean Life, Trek Peru and United Mice. I was wondering if you had any advice or recommendations about which tour group I should go with.

title: Makers of Airborne Settle False-Ad Suit With Refunds
description: The following news may not astonish many of you, but feel free to quietly claim your cut: The makers of Airborne, a line of popular herbal supplements that was marketed as a miracle cold buster, have decided to settle the false-advertising complaints in a class-action lawsuit for $23.3 million, according to one of the plaintiffs in the suit.

title: Recipe of the Day: Vanilla Pudding
description: You might find it easy to believe that egg-thickened custards are vastly superior to puddings made with corn starch. But while they are generally richer and  if made well  considerably more delicate, there are few desserts more enjoyable than a good panna cotta or chocolate pudding, neither of which contains eggs.

description: The CW has become the first network to dramatically alter its executive structure in the wake of the writers strike, Variety reports.

title: Attack of the Lizard People
description: My apologies, folks: when I posted here two weeks ago about the television series V and its literary sequel V: The Second Generation, I shouldnt have been so flippant about the dangers posed to our planet by a race of lizard-like aliens who are able to disguise themselves as humans.

title: Wearing the Meat Necklace
description: Hows that succession plan working out at Texas Tech? Well, the early line isnt so good, especially with the Red Raiders stumbling through the worst loss in the history of the Big 12 conference on Monday night. (Yes, that includes Baylor results.) In the aftermath of the 58-point drubbing, Pat Knight tells the Associated Press: I feel like someone put a meat necklace around my neck and threw me into a lions den.

title: Its Not Enough For Fox Business To Succeed; CNBC Must Fail!
description: In every skirmish, certain individuals become symbols of a much larger fight. In the competition between CNBC and the upstart Fox Business Network, Eric Bolling was that symbol.

title: A Postcard From the Big Bend
description: ALPINE, Tex.  Brewster County embraced change today, first of the climactic sort.

title: Those Inexplicable Traffic Jams
description: Whats worse than getting stuck in a traffic jam? Not having anything to blame  no sign of road work, police activity, a jackknifed tractor trailer, a bottleneck merge or any other tangible cause. Just brake lights, and then a sudden burst of speed at the far end, with the pack of ambling cars fading in the rearview mirror.

title: For the Moment | Resort Wear In March
description: (Jessica Antola)

title: Och-Ziff Fund Bounces Back (But Not Its Stock)
description: Choppy markets, plus some other problems, are wreaking havoc with hedge funds  and denting their reputations as the heavyweights of high finance. Banks have reportedly seized the assets of Peloton Partners, a London-based firm whose bets on mortgage-backed securities went bad. Sailfish Capital Partners, also stung by the credit markets, decided last month to shut down. Accounting problems recently forced D.B. Zwirn to close two of its largest funds.

title: Falling Object Creates Real Drama on Broadway
description: Last night while walking into the St. James Theater to see the new production of Gypsy starring Patti LuPone, my friend noted that there might be glitches, since the show is still in previews. Sometimes technical things happen, like stuff falls out of the ceiling, she told me.

title: A Swiss Space
description: A look at a chalet in Villars sur Ollon, Switzerland.

description: SALZBURG, Austria  Dane Richards sat alone in the second row of the stands at Wals-Siezenheim Stadium on Tuesday as his New York Red Bull teammates went through a late-afternoon training session, first in the rain, then in the snow.

title: Bloomberg Orders More Budget Cuts
description: Updated, 6:30 p.m. |In another sign of the troubling economy, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg today will ask all city agencies to find ways to trim 3 percent more from their budgets for fiscal year 2009, which begins on July 1. The step comes on top of 2.5 percent cuts they were asked to make in the last half of this fiscal year and a 5 percent cut next year. Those cuts ended up being about 2.7 percent in the 2008 fiscal year and 4.4 percent for the 2009 fiscal year.Mark Page, the citys chief budget officer, blamed the need for the additional reductions on Gov. Eliot Spitzer, whose executive budget, Mr. Page said, contains $747 million less in financing to the city than was anticipated when budget projections were made in January.

title: Goose Gossage Says Thanks
description: In our continuing quest to share humorous anecdotes from Yankee Hall of Famers, heres a scene from this morning in Joe Girardis office. We were wrapping up our interview session when Goose Gossage poked his head in the door.

title: Off to the Polls
description: Voters went to the polls in Texas, Ohio, Rhode Island and Vermont in primaries that could be decisive in the Democratic race.

title: Q and A: Scott Fratangelo
description: In early 2005 Scott Fratangelo opened what quickly turned into many diners favorite small restaurant on the Upper East Side: Spigolo, which serves Italian dishes in a tight space with big windows.

title: Lawmakers Put Focus on Sovereign Funds
description: Capitol Hill is stepping up its scrutiny of sovereign wealth funds. These funds, run by foreign governments, have been investing billions of dollars in well-known American companies such as Citigroup and Merrill Lynch in recent months. Are there ulterior, political motives? Thats what some in Washington are wondering.

title: A Perfect Lunch in Liguria
description: Kelly and I met Mario and Antonio at the off-ramp for Albenga, which might be thought of as the Castroville of Italy  Castroville being the self-proclaimed artichoke capital of California. It was gray and cool, perfect artichoke-growing weather, and the broad area past the tolls was crowded with parked cars  turned out this was a popular meeting place. We proceeded to drive in a convoy of three, up into the hills, to Onzo, about 15 miles inland. This is the part of Liguria west of Genoa, the less popular, less glamorous, slightly wilder (and also somewhat more commercially agricultural) region.

title: Now Screening | The Adidas Story
description: What do Jesse Owens, Mark Gonzales, Ilie Nastase, and Oasiss Liam and Noel Gallagher have in common? Each is a part of Adidass all-star heritage. Its not often that one can sit through an overview of a multi-billion dollar companys history without slitting ones wrists, but thanks to a series of short films, Adidas has managed to make the process surprisingly enjoyable. Click here to view the first installment of the story of Adi Dassler (Adidass founder), narrated by the German actor Jrgen Prochnow, scored by the Prague Symphony orchestra and rendered in what appears to be Claymation 2.0.

title: McCain Has a New Answer on Autism
description: Campaigning last week in Texas, Senator John McCain weighed in on one of the most politicized scientific issues in a generation, raising the notion that the epidemic in autism is related to the preservative in vaccines.

title: Why Is the 1998 Ford F-150 No. 1 on Mexicos Most Wanted List?
description: On Monday, Mexico initiated a strict limitation on used cars entering the country. Only cars and trucks built for the 1998 model year are now allowed to be imported into Mexico.

title: Study Sees Shift in Press Coverage
description: If Senator Hillary Clinton wins today in Ohio and Texas, will analysts look back and point to the Feb. 23 edition of Saturday Night Live as a crucial turning point in her campaign?

title: McCain Wouldnt Answer That Phone Call Dig
description: HOUSTON  When Senator John McCains campaign stopped here Tuesday afternoon to conduct a town-hall-style meeting at a western-themed saloon, there was a new twist on Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons famous 3 a.m. phone call commercial  the one about who is best prepared to field emergency calls at the White House.

title: The Boys in the Boys Room
description: O.K., heres an obvious chuckle, brought to us by The Los Angeles Timess Andrew Malcolm:

title: Lessons from the Skeptics Conference
description: Yesterday I asked you to analyze a report presented at the Heartland Institutes conference of global-warming skeptics. A lot of readers had the same reaction I did after I read the report and attended the conference yesterday: There are some interesting points here, but who knows? The skeptics point to some genuine discrepancies between the climate models and whats actually happened; theyre probably right in criticizing the United Nations I.P.C.C. for not paying enough attention to the impact of solar variations on the Earths climate. But climate is so complicated, and cuts across so many scientific disciplines, that its impossible to know which discrepancies or which variables are really important.

title: Ohio Flooding Thwarts Some Voting
description: COLUMBUS  Several counties in southeastern Ohio have reported flooding from the winter storm that began last night, forcing elections officials to seek court approval to move polling locations and in some cases, to allow voters to cast ballots at the county boards of elections rather than individual precinct sites.

title: Pequot to Separate Its V.C. and Hedge Fund Units
description: Pequot Capital Management, the giant hedge fund run by Arthur Samberg, said Tuesday that it would spin off its venture capital arm into a separate company.

title: Royals Make ABC Flush
description: Long live the interest in the royal family. A two-hour documentary about the British monarchy attracted 14.1 million viewers to ABC on Monday, making the network number one for the night despite a poor performance for October Road at 10 p.m.

title: Facebook Finds a No. 2 Unlike Its No. 1
description: Sheryl Sandberg may well be a perfect hire to be the No. 2 executive at Facebook. Shes very smart, well liked, seasoned, and comes with that Google aura.

title: Just Browsing
description: Just Browsing sews together the latest fashion news from our global sources of mags, trades, blogs and tipsters.

title: Now Screening |  Pharrell Williams for Louis Vuitton
Detective Describes Shouts Before Sean Bell Shooting
description: A detective who was around the corner from other officers moments before the shooting of Sean Bell testified on Tuesday that he heard shouts, but did not hear any of the words shouted and could not say whether anyone identified themselves as police officers.

title: Obama: Press Bought Into Clinton Line on Bias
description: On the campaign plane from Dallas to San Antonio, Senator Barack Obama chided the reporters on board the plane today, saying they were influenced by the Clinton campaigns flood of complaints about media bias over the last week.

title: Austin Votes  and Even the Dogs Are Welcome
description: AUSTIN  At the Ann Richards School for Young Women Leaders, a middle school for girls here, turnout was brisk in the morning, but election workers said the lines were slightly smaller than usual, probably because of the amount of early voting in the area.

title: Brett Favre Retires (Will He Change His Mind?)
description: Brett Favre listed stress as the reason for his retirement today, and he said the more the Packers won, the more stress he felt.

title: Eckstein Knows How to Make a Reporter Feel Old
description: It happened so fast that I wanted to ignore it, but I couldnt. When I approached the Blue Jays shortstop David Eckstein on Monday to interview him about Scott Rolen, his teammate, Eckstein called me, Mr. Curry. Again.

title: Despite the Democratic Showdown, Business as Usual on Broadcast
description: NBC News calls Tuesdays primaries Judgment Day. ABC News says Hillary Clinton needs to win today to keep her candidacy. But the broadcast networks are opting not to present any special political programming for what some analysts have called Super Tuesday II.

title: Citi Touches 52-Week Low as Bad News Continues
description: How low can Citigroup go?

title: F.C.C. Asks TV Station to Explain Blackout in Alabama
description: Updated, 4:50 p.m. Chairman Martin has decided to ask the Alabama station to provide an explanation for the blackout, according to The A.P. He also cautioned against jumping to conclusions about what might or might not have occurred. About 20 complaints were filed, he estimated.

title: Metro-North Service Restored After Building Collapse
description: Updated, 5:48 p.m. | Service on all three main lines of the Metro-North Railroad  the Hudson, Harlem and New Haven lines  was suspended at 3:15 p.m. after a vacant five-story building collapsed at 124th Street and Park Avenue, one block from the 125th Street station in Harlem, where all three lines stop on their way to and from Grand Central Terminal.

title: Short Day for Hughes, Satisfying Day for the Kei-Man
description: The Yankees brought a lineup packed with stars to Dunedin Tuesday  Damon, Jeter, Abreu, A-Rod, Giambi and Posada all made the short trip from Tampa. Unfortunately for the fans here, including Spike Lee, all those players were gone by the time play resumed after a second-inning rain delay.

title: Stranger Than Truthiness
description: The fake memoir wave continues. In Tuesdays Times, Motoko Rich reports that contrary to the premise of her new memoir, Love and Consequences, Margaret B. Jones is not half-white, half-native American and was not raised as a foster child by a black family in South-Central L.A. Her real names Margaret Seltzer and shes from Sherman Oaks. (Click here for Richs Wednesday follow-up, and here for todays story on how Seltzer apparently fabricated a charitable foundation.)

title: Paris Fashion Week | Miu Miu
description: (Pierre Verdy/AFP/Getty)

title: Soft Serve | Five-Star Hospitals, Johansson for Sale, Happy Rims
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: A New Womens Team Names Its First Coach
description: The ink is barely dry on his contract as the first coach of the New Jersey/New York Sky Blues of the new womens soccer league and Ian Sawyers is already traveling to scout players  at the Algarve Cup in Portugal.

title: City Sees Decrease in Homeless Population
description: The number of people living on the streets has dropped by 12 percent since last year, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said this morning at a City Hall news conference, citing his administrations annual Homeless Outreach Population Estimate, which was conducted on Jan. 28.The mayor and administration officials said the decline in the so-called street homeless population, which includes those living on the subways, is because of a number of approaches, like more aggressive clearing of encampments and offering housing options with fewer restrictions.

title: Is Anybody Laughing?
description: Help yourself to Vanity Fairs self-generated controversy over whether women are very funny or not. In the January issue, Christopher Hitchens said no, they arent

title: Columbia Maps the African-American Past
description: Columbia University is unveiling a new Web site  MAAP, for Mapping the African American Past  that will use video, audio and historic maps and images to showcase 52 historic sites and people in the city, ranging from the familiar (the African Burial Ground) to the rarely acknowledged.

title: The Boys Stood Watching It
description: Im working on a caption for the latest orphan video to appear and disappear from YouTube, delivering, while it stood, a sharp, cruel blow to the stomach. Its the one from yesterday, with the uniformed men and the hurled dog.

title: The Puppy Screen Cleaner
After Tuesday: Another Debate?
description: From The Hollywood Reporter (via Reuters):

title: Firebrand Burns Out
description: Update: Thursday, 2:20 p.m.: A spokesman for Ion Television said on Thursday that the last Firebrand TV show will be broadcast on Friday night.

title: Paris Fashion Week | Louis Vuitton
description: (Pierre Verdy/AFP/Getty)

title: Competitors Crack the Egg Integrity Code
description: The reigning champion of the Cooper Union annual egg drop competition was, as he put it, feeling cautiously optimistic about a repeat performance today.

title: In the Thick of Things
description: Ive never bought a stock that subsequently took off. Ive never won an Oscar pool. Im bad at predicting who will end up in the Super Bowl (the Giants?), and Im worse at guessing whether a pregnant friend is going to have a boy or girl.

title: Blogtalk: Tales from the Precincts
description: All those stereotypes about Midwesterners being hardy and hard-working must be true. Despite wild storms, roving polling places and new voting systems, voter turnout has been high, state officials say, and problems have been minimal.

title: Wines Off the Beaten Trail
description: I gave a presentation last weekend at the New York Times Travel Show, a big exhibition at the Javits Center. Its a big extravaganza that gathers travel industry types from many countries and gives them booths to promote tourism in their lands. They extol the gorgeous contours of their countries, the exquisite cuisine, the warmth and generosity of their people, the beauty and creativity of their culture, etc. There was music, dancing, cooking demonstrations, and then there was me, all the way in a back corner of the Javits Center, leading a wine tasting over the beat of an African drumming demonstration going on next door.

title: Vintage Alka-Seltzer Ad
description: Vintage ad features the pixie Speedy Alka-Seltzer, who is returning in a new promotional campaign.

title: Speedy Alka-Seltzer
description: Vintage ad features the pixie Speedy Alka-Seltzer, who is  returning in a new promotional campaign.

title: Slight Cancer Risk Remains After Hormone Therapy Stops
description: Among the many unanswered questions about hormones prescribed for menopause is whether a womans health risks change after she stops taking the pills. A new study shows that virtually all the benefits disappear but that a slightly higher risk for breast and other cancers persists for at least three years after stopping the drugs.

title: Talk to the Newsroom: A Political Q & A
description: In an article today, John Harwood wrote that the primaries in Texas, Ohio, Rhode Island and Vermont could be decisive for the Democratic race. Few could argue that a sweep of the four states by Barack Obama would extinguish the hopes of Hillary Clinton. But what about a split decision?What if Mrs. Clinton loses Texas but wins Ohio? What if she splits the primary and caucus vote in the Lone Star State?

title: Caution: G.O.P. Crossing
description: Well, this seems as good a place as any to begin the night: Gallup Poll Daily tracking finds Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama tied once again, with 45% of Democratic voters nationwide preferring each as the partys 2008 presidential nominee.

title: Obama: Clinton Attacks Wont Change His Campaign
description: Senator Barack Obama cast a disbelieving look at reporters on his campaign plane and suggested that his opponent, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, had spun their little tribe like so many tops.

title: Paradise for Dinosaur Aficionados
description: A fossil trove in Argentina draws scientists and tourists.

title: At Tenement Museum, a Fight Over Unionization
description: The Lower East Side Tenement Museum, which explores the stories of downtrodden immigrants exploited by employers and landlords, is now the subject of a unionization drive by nearly 30 part-time tour guides who say the organization has been blocking their efforts to organize for higher wages, better benefits and more regular work schedules.

title: Forgotten Chapter of Jewish History
description: Upon arriving in the United States, Jewish refugees faced new struggles and discrimination.

title: Council Members Urge Congestion Pricing Changes
description: The road to enact Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs plan to charge drivers an $8 fee to bring their cars into Manhattan below 60th Street just got a little more twisted.A group of 20 City Council members sent a letter to Mr. Bloomberg urging changes so that New Jersey commuters pay a partial fee or so that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey use a portion of tolls it collects from Manhattan-bound drivers to pay for New York City mass transit, almost half the body which must, along with the State Legislature, approve the plan for it to qualify for federal financing.

title: Crisis Over Colombia Raid in Ecuador
description: Times correspondent Simon Romero analyzes the repercussions of  Colombia's incursion into Ecuador to raid a FARC camp.

title: Curtain Call
description: Please give a round of applause to Eliza, Marsha and Frank for digging into August so deeply over the last couple weeks, and to all of the commentors who joined us  plenty of evidence to me that the theater still has a serious, engaged audience (and that printed plays still have readers!).

title: The Chronic Crisis in Gaza
description: Israel may consider launching a broader ground invasion of the Gaza Strip if rocket attacks continue.

title: Crisis Over Colombia Raid in Ecuador
description: Times correspondent Simon Romero analyzes the repercussions of Colombia's incursion into Ecuador to raid a FARC camp.

title: One Down
description: Tonights amuse-bouche, Vermont, has been swallowed up in the expected fashion, but even as the polls close in Ohio the drama is escalating.

title: The Chronic Crisis in Gaza
description: Israel may consider launching a broader ground invasion of the Gaza strip if the rocket attacks continue.

title: Election Day in Key States
description: Voters are getting their say in Texas, Ohio, Rhode Island and Vermont.

title: Change Trumps Experience . . . For the Moment
description: What voters want, at least today: The theme of change continues to resonate in Ohio and Texas, but not by as wide a margin as in most previous primaries, reports ABC News.

title: Bones Are Not the Only Fossils
description: I put my foot beside the footprint. Whatever made it had feet the same size as mine. Almost exactly. I stepped to the next print. But it had longer legs; or, at least, it took longer strides than I usually do. I knelt down to take a photograph. Three toes. Like the foot of a wading bird. But big.

title: Anand Has Slim Lead Over Carlsen at Morelia-Linares
description: Viswanathan Anand of India, the world champion, leads after 12 rounds of the Morelia-Linares super tournament going into the last rest day. Magnus Carlsen of Norway continued his up-and-down (mostly up) play by beating Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria to close within a half point of Anand. A crosstable and games from the event, as well as information about the players and a list of the previous winners, is on the tournaments Web site.

title: Down Goes Huckabee
description: Well, Clinton and Obama will battle well into the night, if not into the summer, but it seems official for John McCain: Sen. John McCain of Arizona rolled up victories Tuesday in primaries in Ohio, Texas, Rhode Island and Vermont, capturing enough delegates to secure the GOP nomination, according to projections by NBC News and the Associated Press.

title: Rove Rules In Foxs Strategy Room
description: Fox News Channel introduced its newest strategic weapon on Tuesday: a studio labeled the Strategy Room.

title: Mike Huckabees Next Stage: Television?
description: How does The Mike Huckabee Show sound?

title: Mike Huckabees Next Stage: Television?
description: How does The Mike Huckabee Show sound?

title: Crash the Party Line
description: Tonights biggest news on the Democratic side may have less to do with votes than with lawyers, which cant excite anybody except, maybe, lawyers. Barack Obamas top lawyer, Bob Bauer, made an unexpected appearance on the Clinton campaigns conference call this evening, calling in on a line intended for reporters to challenge Clinton aides claims of irregularities in several Texas precincts, reports the Politicos Ben Smith.

title: On the Dot: More Population and Climate Questions
description: Here are a couple of updates on human activities down on our blue marble  seen here in an image just released by NASA but taken last October by a camera aboard a satellite orbiting Mars (hat tip to Michael Schlesinger at UIUC).Population: In Beijing, state-controlled media denied reports last week that China was planning to relax its longstanding one child policy, saying reporters had misquoted a vice minister of the National Population and Family Planning Commission. But the new comments, from Wu Jianmin, a spokesman for the advisory body to the Chinese parliament, seemed to reaffirm that a shift was in the works. More here from The Los Angeles Times. In a comment to my initial post on the news, Max Zhang, a young Chinese student studying in Pennsylvania, provided a look at life as a single child in a single-child culture. Are there others out there who grew up in China from the 1970s on who can share experiences here, good or bad?

title: Guilty Pleasures in Hong Kong: Feeding Your Inner Taai Taai
description: For nearly four years, Ive juggled a life between tiny apartments in New York and Hong Kong on a freelance writers income. The double happiness of living in two fabulous cities far outweighs the stressed out nights worrying over logistics and budgeting. But sometimes, a girl really needs to let go of those shoestrings and stop pinching those pennies. I adore snacking in a cha chaan teng and dining in steamy noodle houses (More about those cheap and tasty mihn ga in a forthcoming post.)

title: To Be Continued
description: The networks are calling Ohio over, and Hillary Clinton will apparently live to fight another day (although her delegate advantage in the Buckeye State may not reflect the degree of her victory). Jonathan Chait at The New Republic doesnt find the win is much to brag about:

title: McCain Clinches G.O.P. Race
description: Former Gov. Mike Huckabee conceded; Senator John McCain and his supporters celebrated.

title: Paul and Kucinich Hold Seats
description: Updated Representative Ron Paul has won his first Republican primary of the 2008 season, The Associated Press projects. Though his Internet groundswell did not translate into a nomination for the presidency, he easily held back a challenger for his Congressional seat in Texass 14th Congressional District. With 56 percent of precincts reporting so far, Mr. Paul has 69.4 percent of the vote, while Chris Peden has 30.6 percent.

title: Live Blogging the March 4 Results
description: 1:38 p.m. | Wrapup:  Well, Caucus readers, all the networks and The Times have called Texas for Mrs. Clinton. But results from the Texas caucuses (the second part of that Texas two-step) are still a little fuzzy. Only about 13 percent of those results are in, and Mr. Obama is ahead 54 percent to 46 percent. As predicted earlier, Mrs. Clinton could win the popular vote while Mr. Obama wins more delegates. (Stay tuned to the nytimes.com throughout the wee hours for the latest results.)

title: Battles continue over Trump projects in New York and Scotland
description: Gosh, it seems like ages since we posted anything on Donald Trump. So lets update a couple of controversies involving projects trumpeted by His Donaldness.

title: John McCain in Dallas
description: John McCain comments on the results from the March 4 primaries. (NBC Video)

title: TV Networks Resort to the Crawl Instead of Real News Coverage
description: Its official: the networks no longer cover news, they slap it onto the bottom edge of their regular programming like Post-it notes.

title: Ban on Using Nationality to Exclude Jurors Is Upheld
description: A federal judge has affirmed that allowing American-born blacks on a Bronx jury but systematically excluding West Indians is discriminatory.

title: Harvard and Ivy League Will Review Recruiting
description: BOSTON  Harvard and the Ivy League have said they will review the possibility that the Crimson mens basketball program committed recruiting violations.

title: Woman Arrested in Threat to Brother of Slain Dentist
description: The older sister of a Queens doctor who is facing charges in the killing of her estranged husband, a dentist who was fatally shot at a playground in October, was charged on Tuesday with threatening the victims brother, officials said.

title: Corrections
description: Editors' Note

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about Barack Obamas efforts to court Jewish voters misstated the year he was sworn in as a United States senator and the dates relationship to a trip he took to Israel. Mr. Obama took office in January 2005, not 2006; he traveled to Israel in January 2006, not weeks after he was sworn in.

title: More Expensive Placebos Bring More Relief
description: In marketing as in medicine, perception can be everything. A higher price can create the impression of higher value, just as a placebo pill can reduce pain.

title: One Pot
description: SUVIR SARAN has a palate that seems to be made of asbestos. A few years ago, while visiting friends in Old Goa, India, he ate a fiery shrimp curry with a pinkish-red sauce flavored and inflamed with curry leaves, black pepper, dried chilies, cayenne and tomatoes, and then soothed with coconut milk.

title: Being a Housewife Where Neither House Nor Husband Is Needed
description: Not one is a traditional housewife; one is not a wife at all. But, hey, they are all rich enough and thin enough. And so Bravo expanded its Real Housewives franchise with the premiere on Tuesday night of The Real Housewives of New York City, seven episodes of glitter and soap opera. In an international city of more than eight million souls, the series documents the lives of five white socialites who juggle Hamptons estates and charity balls.

title: Suicide Bombings Kill 4 in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Two suicide bombers attacked a naval war college in the eastern city of Lahore on Tuesday, killing at least four people, including three in the Pakistani Navy, naval officials said.

title: A Talented Public Servant
description: To the Editor:

title: Next Question: Can Students Be Paid to Excel?
description: The fourth graders squirmed in their seats, waiting for their prizes. In a few minutes, they would learn how much money they had earned for their scores on recent reading and math exams. Some would receive nearly $50 for acing the standardized tests, a small fortune for many at this school, P.S. 188 on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

title: Presidential Primaries Lift CNN
description: The morning after the Democratic primary debate on Feb. 21, while both sides argued over who had come out ahead, there was one clear winner: CNN. The debate, broadcast by CNN and Univision, the Spanish-language network, drew 7.6 million viewers, one of the biggest audiences ever for a primary debate on a cable network.

title: Assurances From Citigroup, but Skepticism on Wall Street
description: Sanford I. Weill built Citigroup into one of the worlds largest banking companies. Now, Vikram S. Pandit is watching Mr. Weills creation wither in the stock market.

title: Germanys Hesitance Slows Technology Cooperation With France
description: HANOVER, Germany  At the opening this week of Cebit, the European technology fair, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France surprised his hosts by suggesting that France and Germany work together to develop a supercomputer.

title: Yahoo Looks at New Way to Survive
description: As it scrambles to avoid defeat in its battle with Microsoft, Yahoo may try to put a little more time on the clock.

title: McCain Wins Bush Endorsement
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain of Arizona was greeted here Wednesday as the new standard bearer of a Republican Party he has sometimes battled, winning the endorsement of a president he has feuded with in the past and the embrace  and financial help  of the Republican National Committee.

title: No Marbury? No Comment From Thomas
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Isiah Thomas spent another day dodging questions about Stephon Marbury on Tuesday. More precisely, he spent about 129 seconds dodging the questions before cutting off the interview.

title: Packed Powder as a Corporate Amenity
description: OGDEN, Utah  Michael Dowse was talking on the telephone one day in January and watching the snow build up outside the windows of his newly rehabbed office in a 1915 factory complex in this historic railroad town, where his company, Amer Sports Winter and Outdoor Americas, has made its headquarters since last summer.

title: 7. Coi
description: 373 Broadway, San Francisco; (415) 393-9000, coirestaurant.com.

title: Court Hears Detectives Call to 911 After Shooting at Club
description: A Queens courtroom listened with rapt attention on Tuesday as a seemingly confused undercover detective shouted, There were shots fired! to a 911 operator in the frantic seconds after Sean Bell was shot outside a Jamaica strip club.

title: To Cook an Octopus: Forget the Cork, Add Science
description: I FIRST tasted octopus at its meaty yet tender best years ago in Athens, and have made sporadic efforts to replicate that experience ever since.

title: Memphis Police Ask for Help in Solving Slayings of 6
description: MEMPHIS  Police officials asked the community for help on Tuesday in solving the murders of six people, including two children, and the wounding of three children. The attacks occurred sometime between Saturday evening and Monday evening.

title: China Plans Steep Increase in Military Spending
description: BEIJING  China announced a further sharp increase in military spending on Tuesday, a day after the United States renewed its warning that a lack of openness surrounding the rapid buildup of Chinas armed forces posed a threat to stability in Asia.

title: Parents in Crisis Have Many Options for Giving Babies Haven, Officials Say
description: Daniella, the 6-month-old, pink-clad baby abandoned by her parents and dropped off at a firehouse in Queens last week, took a circuitous and unusual route to safety with the help of her fathers sisters companion, a livery cab driver.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Feb. 23 about the Accenture Match Play Championship misspelled the surname of the Australian golfer who lost in the events title match in 2007. He is Geoff Ogilvy, not Ogilvie.

title: Unemployed, and Skewing the Picture
description: (UPDATED March 7, 9:55 a.m.) This month's jobs report is a great example of how misleading the unemployment rate can be. In February, the economy shed 63,000 jobs, which is a strong indication a recession may be at hand. But the unemployment rate actually fell, to 4.8 percent from 4.9 percent.

title: Ambac Plan Disappoints Investors
description: The Ambac Financial Group, the troubled bond insurer, announced plans on Wednesday to sell $1.5 billion of common stock and equity units to shore up its capital base and retain the triple-A rating for its insurance unit.

title: Area Womens Pro Team Names Its Coach
description: The ink is barely dry on his contract as the first coach of the New Jersey/New York team in a new womens soccer league, and Ian Sawyers is already traveling to scout players  at the Algarve Cup in Portugal.

title: In East Harlem, Sharing Ways to Eat Better
description: Last year, as part of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs environmental initiatives, Scott M. Stringer, the borough president of Manhattan, began a project called Go Green East Harlem. Among the accomplishments is the new Go Green East Harlem Cookbook, edited by Mr. Stringer (Jones Books, $17.95). Half the book is in English, half in Spanish, with each half giving the same 68 recipes, contributed by restaurants, food shops and local organizations. A neighborhood map is included.

title: In 2 Battlegrounds, Voters Say, Not Yet
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons victories in Ohio and Texas on Tuesday night not only shook off the vapors of impending defeat, but also showed that  in spite of his delegate lead  Senator Barack Obama was still losing to her in the big states.

title: Bush Urges Action on Corn Price Rises Fueled by Ethanol
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush said Wednesday that the national drive toward ethanol production was also driving up the cost of corn and other foods, a problem he said needed to be addressed.

title: Once Polluted, Now Profitable for New Jersey Builders
description: With the number of potential building sites in New Jersey declining, developers seem to be taking a second look at brownfields, which are heavily polluted sites ranging from derelict factories to municipal dumps.

title: From the North of Italy, a Haunting Smoky Taste
description: Most pancetta is not smoked. The meat, a relatively lean Italian pork belly, is cured with salt and spices, especially black pepper. It is often sold rolled and gives a meaty base to sauces, pasta dishes and stews.

title: Easily Overlooked Lesions Tied to Colon Cancer
description: An easily overlooked type of abnormality in the colon is the most likely type to turn cancerous, and is more common in this country than previously thought, researchers are reporting.

title: Blakes Text Writ Large and Loud by Bolcom
description: William Bolcoms Eighth Symphony writes out the poetry of William Blake in capital letters. Its four movements, as played by the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening, think big in every way.

title: Sweet and Sour, From the Bees
description: Honey Ridge Farms Balsamic Honey Vinegar is a very nice addition to the pantry, though it certainly was not made according to the centuries-old Italian method, and thus is not a true balsamic. It bears a resemblance, however, to common balsamics on the market because caramel is one of the ingredients. Despite its name, it is an honest product; even the caramel is made with honey. It is mellow enough to use for salads and to add a splash of acidity when deglazing a pan.

title: Morgan Stanley Retreating From Railyards Development
description: Morgan Stanley, the anchor tenant for one of the four developers vying to buy the development rights for the West Side railyards, is backing away from a deal to build its headquarters on the site.

title: Clinton Says Her Campaign Has Turned a Corner
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton defeated Senator Barack Obama in the Ohio and Texas primaries on Tuesday, ending a string of defeats and allowing her to soldier on in a Democratic presidential nomination race that now seems unlikely to end any time soon.

title: Facebook Hires a Google Executive as No. 2
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook is not stepping aside for a chief executive as Larry Page and Sergey Brin did at Google or as Jerry Yang and David Filo did at Yahoo. He is following the Bill Gates model and holding the top post as he hires a Google executive, Sheryl Sandberg, as chief operating officer.

title: Abbas Rebuffs Call by Rice to Return to Talks
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, refused Tuesday to publicly commit to restarting suspended talks with Israel, frustrating Bush administration officials who contended that he was giving Hamas, the militant Islamist organization, a tactical victory by allowing it to hijack Arab-Israeli peace negotiations.

title: Obama Moves to Sharpen His Critique of Clinton
description: Seeking to rebound from defeats Tuesday night in Texas, Ohio and Rhode Island, Senator Barack Obamas campaign signaled on Wednesday that it was preparing to sharpen its critique of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, challenging her contention that she has been more thoroughly scrutinized than her opponent.

title: Era Ends in N. Ireland as Paisley Says Hell Retire
description: LONDON  Ian Paisley, the 81-year-old Protestant evangelist who spent decades in implacable opposition to a compromise settlement of Northern Irelands sectarian violence before agreeing last year to join Irish nationalists in a power-sharing government, announced Tuesday that he will resign in May as the provinces first minister and as the leader of the Democratic Unionist party he founded.

title: In Switzerland, an Alpine Chalet
description: Villars sur Ollon, Switzerland

title: Editors Note
description: The Books of The Times review in The Arts on Feb. 26 and an article in House & Home on Thursday described the experiences of Margaret B. Jones, who said that she had been a foster child and gang member in South Central Los Angeles and survived to write a book about that life. Margaret B. Jones turned out to be a pseudonym, and her story a complete fabrication, as The Times reported on Tuesday. An article about how her publisher, and the newspaper, failed to discover the truth earlier appears today in The Arts.

title: Detroit City Council Delays Vote on Resolution Urging the Mayor to Step Down
description: DETROIT  Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick at least temporarily avoided what had appeared to be a certain vote of no confidence from the City Council on Tuesday, but became the focus of new accusations that his office was behind arm-twisting and threats to some Council members who want him to resign.

title: A 1950s Brand Mascot Fights 21st-Century Indigestion
description: A MAJOR marketer is plop-plopping a vintage brand character back into ads, hoping to generate some fizz-fizz among a new generation of consumers.

title: Filings for Bankruptcy Up 18% in February
description: Americans filed for bankruptcy in growing numbers in February, buckling under the combined weight of rising energy prices, a weakening housing market and sky-high personal debts.

title: Credit Rating Cut for Sallie Mae
description: The SLM Corporation, the educational lender known as Sallie Mae, had its long-term credit ratings cut by Moodys Investors Service to two levels above junk Tuesday on concern that a change in the companys strategy will erode profitability.

title: Skateboarders Find Bones and a Skull in Queens
description: Bones and a skull that may be human remains were found by teenagers playing in a Queens park late Tuesday afternoon, the police said.

title: Yankees Say They Have Time to Wait for Igawa to Catch Up
description: DUNEDIN, Fla.  No, Yogi Berra said, he was not tempted to jump into the pitchers arms after the final out on Tuesday. It is true that the Yankees pitched a perfect game, but this was not Don Larsen in the 1956 World Series.

title: Pink Slips at CW
description: CW, the fifth-place broadcast television network, handed pink slips to more than 25 staffers on Monday. The network eliminated its comedy department and merged two other programming units to create a single office for scripted shows. It also cut some marketing jobs from its cable channel operation. The moves were described by network officials as a restructuring of some programming and marketing functions as part of an effort to streamline both areas. The two-year-old network, which has lost 20 percent of its audience this season, currently schedules only one night of comedies, relying more heavily on unscripted fare like Americas Next Top Model and dramas like Gossip Girl. Also on Monday, the network announced the early renewals of six series for next fall, including the sitcom Everybody Hates Chris and the drama Smallville. Among the shows that are new this year, only Gossip Girl was picked up.

title: Seeking Florida Redfish, Catching Only Glimpses
description: The redfish of southwest Floridas lower Caloosahatchee River estuary, which includes Pine Island Sound, Matlacha Pass and San Carlos Bay, have a well-deserved reputation as some of the spookiest in the United States. Locals refer to them as Pine Island Sound bonefish. Despite, or perhaps because of, its challenges, it is a fishery that draws thousands of anglers  especially fly fishers  from around the world each year.

title: A Game Where Resources Dwindle and Partners Shift
description: In the 21st century the empires strike back. The United States, the European Union and China dare not call themselves imperial powers, Parag Khanna argues in The Second World, his sweeping, often audacious survey of contemporary geopolitics, but they are busy reshaping the globe to suit their interests. The game is afoot, with the natural resources and potential wealth of countries like Ukraine, Turkey and Brazil as the prize.

title: Gary Gygax, Game Pioneer, Dies at 69
description: Gary Gygax, a pioneer of the imagination who transported a fantasy realm of wizards, goblins and elves onto millions of kitchen tables around the world through the game he helped create, Dungeons & Dragons, died Tuesday at his home in Lake Geneva, Wis. He was 69.

title: Colombia Is Flashpoint in Chvezs Feud With U.S.
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  In the four days since Colombian forces crossed into Ecuador and killed a guerrilla leader taking refuge there, tensions between Colombia  Washingtons top regional ally  and its leftist neighbors have erupted, highlighting the fact that Colombia and its policies are increasingly viewed here as American proxies.

title: Definition of Marriage Is at Heart of California Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For almost four hours on Tuesday, the California Supreme Court heard arguments in the most important same-sex marriage case since Massachusettss highest court allowed gay and lesbian couples to marry there more than four years ago.

title: Arizona Weighs Bill to Allow Guns on Campuses
description: PHOENIX  Horrified by recent campus shootings, a state lawmaker here has come up with a proposal in keeping with the Taurus .22-caliber pistol tucked in her purse: Get more guns on campus.

title: Beef Giant Buys Assets in the U.S. and Australia
description: JBS S.A., the worlds biggest beef producer, agreed on Tuesday to pay $1.27 billion in cash and stock for assets in the United States and Australia, including the beef unit of the pork producer Smithfield Foods.

title: Pete Doherty Plots a Stage Musical
description: Pete Doherty and Carl Barat, a former band mate from the Libertines,  are writing a musical for the Donmar Warehouse in London, the BBC reported. The show is said to be about the struggles of an up-and-coming rock n roll band. A spokeswoman for the Donmar Warehouse said its associate director, the actor Douglas Hodge, had been working with Mr. Doherty and Mr. Barat but added that the project was very much in the early stages of development, with no deadlines attached. Mr. Barat told The Sunday Mirror: The theater wants lots of new songs. Well probably have to write about 20. Since the Libertines broke up, Mr. Doherty, who has been in court frequently on drug-related charges, has recorded two albums with Babyshambles, and Mr. Barat has fronted the band Dirty Pretty Things. The Donmar Warehouse has sent Frost/Nixon, Cabaret, The Blue Room and other shows to Broadway.

title: Delay, Turmoil and High Costs Plague Meadowlands Projects
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It was supposed to transform an expanse of toxic landfills into a slice of Boca Raton without the beach, a country club community with luxury homes, hotels and two golf courses on gently rolling hills in the shadow of Manhattan.

title: Ray Kane, Master of Slack-Key Guitar, Dies at 82
description: Ray Kane, an internationally known master of the Hawaiian slack-key guitar, died last Wednesday in Honolulu. He was 82 and lived in Nanakuli, on the island of Oahu.

title: The Fans on Favre
description: Comments from the Fifth Down blog on the announcement by Packers quarterback Brett Favre that he was retiring. To participate in the discussion, go to fifthdown.blogs.nytimes.com. Some comments have been condensed.

title: Jazz at Lincoln Center Unveils New Season
description: Jazz at Lincoln Center has announced its 2008-9 program, with what it calls its biggest season ever: more than 3,000 events.

title: Yahoo Seeks Way to Block Microsoft
description: As it scrambles to avoid defeat in its battle with Microsoft, Yahoo is trying to put a little more time on the clock.

title: Mexico: Backyard Body Count at 14
description: The federal attorney generals office said agents had uncovered 14 bodies buried in the backyard of a house in Ciudad Jurez, a city that has gained infamy for its gangland slayings and the unsolved murders of hundreds of women. The agents began digging at the house in the neighborhood of La Cuesta, across the border from El Paso, last month, after a drug raid. They first found the dismembered bodies of nine victims, some of whom died more than five years ago. Five more bodies were unearthed in the last week. Prosecutors have yet to determine why the victims were killed, but they noted that agents found 3,700 pounds of marijuana in the initial raid.

title: News Coverage Changes, and So Does Tone of the Campaign
description: Over the last few days, the tone of the Democratic contest seems to have shifted, with Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign more buoyant and Senator Barack Obamas more defensive.

title: The City Withdraws Its Proposal for a $375 Million Jail in the South Bronx
description: The Bloomberg administration said on Tuesday that it had withdrawn its plan to build a 2,040-bed jail in the South Bronx, a proposal opposed by community groups and elected officials. At the same time, city officials said that the decision would not affect their plan to reopen and expand the Brooklyn House of Detention.

title: Fed Report Notes Slowing Growth
description: The Federal Reserve on Wednesday presented a snapshot of an economy that is gradually slowing, weighed down by creeping inflation pressures and a more hesitant consumer.

title: Guides Say Museum Is Blocking Union Drive
description: The Lower East Side Tenement Museum, which features stories of downtrodden immigrants exploited by employers and landlords, is now the subject of a unionization drive by nearly 30 part-time tour guides who say the organization has been blocking their efforts to organize for higher wages, better benefits and more regular work schedules.

title: Huckabee Cites Personal Victories in Conceding the Race to McCain
description: DALLAS  Mike Huckabee, the bass-playing Baptist preacher and former governor of Arkansas, dropped out of the race for the Republican presidential nomination on Tuesday night and endorsed Senator John McCain as the partys candidate in November.

title: A Nagging Call to Tidy Up an Unfinished Life
description: That commonplace gadget you are advised to turn off when the lights in the theater go down, or when the plane takes off, becomes a mysteriously powerful totem of transformation in Dead Mans Cell Phone, the beguiling new comedy by Sarah Ruhl that opened on Tuesday night at Playwrights Horizons.

title: Ever Upward, No Matter What
description: Featuring exceptional people doing extraordinary things, Blindsight is one of those documentaries with the power to make you re-examine your entire life  or at least get off the couch.

title: Butch Cassidy Supplies the Wine
description: They may be the perfect wines to go with chips and Newmans Own salsa or with pasta and Newmans Own sauce. Paul Newmans company, which has donated all profits for educational and charitable purposes through the Newmans Own Foundation for the past 25 years, has added wines to its line of products.

title: Rushing Spring With a Dash of the Tropics
description: USE your eyes, use your nose, use your hands; thats how you find the sweetest one. So commanded Germaine, my childhood baby sitter. We were standing in front of the pineapples at the supermarket, and it was my responsibility, at age 10, to choose the ripest.

title: Brooklyn Jury Acquits Man of Trying to Murder Officers
description: In 2006, Damion Henry was the first person charged under a new law that increased prison sentences for the attempted murder of a police officer.

title: Rangers Rally, but Fall Short in Shootout
description: Say this about Wade Dubielewicz, the Islanders backup goalie: the underdog tag fits him well.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Tuesday about the Bolshoi Ballets appointment of a new artistic director, Yuri Burlaka, misstated the length of a predecessors service. The predecessor, Yuri Grigorovich, who has been named a staff ballet master, was artistic director from 1964 to 1995  not to 1985.

title: A Trump Plan to Offer $300 Meals at Jones Beach Draws Fire
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y.  Donald Trumps plan to build a catering hall at Jones Beach suffered a setback on Tuesday at the end of a prolonged hearing into the technical barriers in building a basement on the edge of the Atlantic Ocean. But technical issues were not what drew most of the 200 people who attended, or what kept many of them waiting five hours for a chance to speak.

title: Marist Getting Used to the Spotlight
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y.  The Marist College womens basketball players Meg Dahlman and Courtney Kolesar were eating dinner at an Applebees early last season when they realized their transformation from student-athletes to celebrities had begun.

title: A Skyline That Sways in the Breeze
description: Larry Borger, tree man, bent a poplar branch into view. Its buds were well-spaced, meaning that the tree has been growing vigorously. With just a glance, he had started to break its secret codes.

title: China to Focus on Reducing Inflation, Prime Minister Says
description: BEIJING  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao said Wednesday that curbing fast-rising inflation and preventing economic overheating were Chinas top fiscal priorities for 2008.

title: Van Halen Tour Is Interrupted
description: Because the rock guitarist Eddie Van Halen, below, is undergoing tests for an unspecified medical problem, his band, Van Halen, has rescheduled four concerts. The March 3 Dallas show was rescheduled for April 24, the March 5 Cincinnati show for April 22, the March 7 Raleigh, N.C., show for April 13, and the March 9 Baltimore show for April 15, Billboard reported. Mr. Van Halen, 53, has dealt with cancer and alcohol in the past, but according to a statement released by the tour promoter, Live Nation, his physician said Mr. Van Halen was undergoing a battery of comprehensive medical tests to determine a defined diagnosis and recommended medical procedures. The band returned to touring last fall with its original lead singer, David Lee Roth, for the first time in more than 20 years. The tour has routinely sold out arenas in North America.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Tuesday about the Italian tenor Giuseppe di Stefano omitted the names of two survivors and referred incorrectly to his daughter Luisa in some editions. Luisa, who died in 1975, was not his only daughter. A second daughter, Floria, and a son, Giuseppe, both from his second marriage, also survive him.

title: More Than Just Background
description: Sundays and Mondays for the last 18 years at Le Madeleine, the Manhattan bistro on 43rd Street near Ninth Avenue, Gene Bertoncini has sat by the window and played his nylon-string guitar at a volume that does not cast a shadow over the skate wings and lamb-shank pasta.

title: 8. Restaurant Guy Savoy
description: Caesars Palace, 3570 Las Vegas Boulevard South, Las Vegas; (877) 346-4642, caesarspalace.com.

title: A College President Whose Credentials Stress Taking Care of Business
description: LANCASTER, Pa.  John Frys path to the presidency of Franklin & Marshall College fits none of the conventions of academic life. He did not earn a doctorate, did not teach or publish research and was never a department chairman or dean or provost.

title: Spanish Premier and Challenger Trade Barbs in Angry Debate
description: MADRID  Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero, the Socialist prime minister, prevailed over his conservative rival, Mariano Rajoy, in a televised debate on Monday night, according to polls taken immediately afterward. However, Spaniards hoping for a glimpse of the candidates plans for the country would have been disappointed, analysts said Tuesday.

title: Royal Welcome for Documentary
description: Long live the interest in the royal family. A two-hour documentary about the British monarchy attracted 14.1 million viewers to ABC on Monday, making the network No. 1 for the night despite a poor performance for October Road at 10 p.m. The game show Deal or No Deal, in a new time slot at 9 p.m., averaged 10.8 million viewers, enough to earn NBC a second-place finish. CBS placed third, as strong showings by Two and a Half Men (9.9 million at 9) and CSI: Miami (9.2 million at 10) offset lower-rated sitcoms like the new series Welcome to the Captain (5.6 million at 8:30). In the 18- to 49-year-old demographic, ABC and Fox were tied for first place. Almost eight million viewers watched the conclusion of Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles on Fox.

title: Lottery Numbers
16-Year Sentence in Honor Killing
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli court sentenced a man to 16 years in prison on Tuesday for aiding in the so-called honor killing of his sister. The case was unusual in that the women of the family broke their code of silence and testified against the man.

title: A Treat Whose Time May Be Here
description: EVERY few years, I get the feeling that octopus has become mainstream enough to write about. But not long after each of these instances, I have realized that my instinct was premature. Well see about this one.

title: Injuries Give Pagn Chance to Make the Mets
description: JUPITER, Fla.  Not to get all metaphysical, but there must be a reason, ngel Pagn said, he is here. There must be a reason the Mets, after more or less giving him away to the Chicago Cubs two years ago, reacquired him in January.

title: McNamees Lawyers Seek Ouster of Hardin
description: Lawyers for Roger Clemenss former personal trainer Brian McNamee filed a motion Tuesday to disqualify Clemenss lead lawyer from representing him in a defamation lawsuit. The motion was filed along with a second motion, which asked that a lawsuit brought by Clemens against McNamee be thrown out.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening this Week

title: Big Wins for Clinton in Texas and Ohio; McCain Clinches Race as Foe Concedes
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton defeated Senator Barack Obama in Ohio and Texas on Tuesday, ending a string of defeats and allowing her to soldier on in a Democratic presidential nomination race that now seems unlikely to end any time soon.

title: Correction: A Rule Just Waiting to Be Broken
description: The Pour column last Wednesday, about unusual wine pairings, misspelled the surname of the maker of a Chinon red. She is Olga Raffault, not Riffault.

title: Tracking the Fallout of (Another) Literary Fraud
description: One day after the author of Love and Consequences confessed that she had made up the memoir about her supposed life as a foster child in gang-infested South-Central Los Angeles, the focus turned to her publisher and the news organizations that helped publicize what appeared to be a searing autobiography.

title: A.M.D. Cuts Time Needed to Shift Production Method
description: Advanced Micro Devices said Tuesday that it was closing a technology gap with its rival Intel, cutting about in half the time required to move to a new manufacturing process.

title: Bjork Voices Politics in Shanghai
description: The Icelandic singer Bjork, above, stirred controversy in China when she finished her concert and a performance of her song Declare Independence at the Shanghai International Gymnastics Center on Sunday by shouting, Tibet! Tibet!, the BBC reported. China has ruled Tibet since 1951, and talk of independence is taboo. Some members of the audience were clearly uneasy and left hurriedly; others appeared not to have heard Bjork. Afterward, Chinese Web sites carried some negative reactions. I like Bjork, said one. Its O.K. for her to have a different point of view, but for her to do this is disrespectful to fans here  very selfish of her. The state-controlled Chinese news media did not report on Bjorks behavior.

title: 8 Die in Iraqi Copter Crash, One From U.S.
description: BAGHDAD  An Iraqi Army helicopter crash in northern Iraq on Monday killed all eight people on board, including one American serviceman, Iraqi military officials said Tuesday.

title: Last Pass by Favre: A Special Gift
description: Brett Favre threw more passes than anyone in N.F.L. history. The last ball he threw  No. 9,479  was intercepted by Giants cornerback Corey Webster on Jan. 20. It now belongs to Greg Gadson, a United States Army lieutenant colonel who lost his legs in May while serving in Iraq and who became an inspirational leader for the Super Bowl champion Giants.

title: 6. Frache
description: 9411 Culver Boulevard, Culver City, Calif.; (310) 839-6800, fraicherestaurantla.com.

title: Study Says Gifts of Stock Precede Sharp Price Dips
description: Top corporate executives often make large gifts of their companys stock to their family foundations shortly before the stock price drops sharply, according to a new study by a New York University professor. As a result, the executives are able to claim the maximum possible tax deduction and escape capital gains taxes.

title: For Fans of Trader Vics, an Adventure in Tikiland
description: RICHMOND, Calif.  Some might call it a pupu platter of pop Polynesiana  the place to find thatched fish traps, carved tiki poles and vintage ceramic parrots that perch on the rims of cocktail glasses.

title: Kosovo Builds Economy From the Ground Up
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo  Bekim Kuqi has braved civil war, exile, bombs falling on his factories and the detonation of a car filled with explosives in one of his stores. So he says he is prepared for the daunting challenge of doing business in the newly independent Kosovo.

title: Winning the Battle, Losing the War
description: Fort Leavenworth, Kan.

title: 213 Deer Are Killed in Hunt at Park
description: After five weeks of controlled hunting, the first deer cull in a park in Essex County, N.J., has killed 213 white-tailed deer at the 2,047-acre South Mountain Reservation, the county said on Tuesday.

title: Experiment in Queens Speeds Firefighters, and Draws Criticism
description: For the dispatcher, it is a short conversation, often with a person in distress.

title: Police Gun Is Jarring Evidence at Detectives Trial
description: Sean Bells mother, Valerie Bell, spent her 52nd birthday in the third row of a chilly courtroom in Queens on Wednesday and watched in silence as a police sergeant held aloft the gun that is believed to have killed her son.

title: Interest Rates in Australia Are Raised to a 12-Year High
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Australias central bank raised interest rates to a 12-year high Tuesday in another attempt to contain inflationary pressures in an economy fueled by Chinas hunger for resources.

title: Hope When?
description: A report issued Monday by Hope Now, the White House-backed mortgage industry group formed to help hard-pressed homeowners, makes one thing clear: homeowners arent getting the help they need.

title: The Shape of Eggs Benedict to Come
description: WYLIE DUFRESNE loves eggs. He particularly loves eggs Benedict and wanted to put the dish on the dinner menu at WD-50, but of course it had to be a different kind of eggs Benedict, a Wylie Dufresne kind of eggs Benedict: novel in look, concentrated in taste.

title: Assembly Plan Would Add to Taxes of More Affluent
description: ALBANY  With the economy weakening and tax collections slowing, members of the State Assembly are discussing a plan that would raise income taxes on the wealthiest 3 to 4 percent of New Yorkers.

title: Goan-Style Shrimp Curry
description: Adapted from Suvir Saran and Hemant Mathur, Devi

title: Yes, MSG, the Secret Behind the Savor
description: IN 1968 a Chinese-American physician wrote a rather lighthearted letter to The New England Journal of Medicine. He had experienced numbness, palpitations and weakness after eating in Chinese restaurants in the United States, and wondered whether the monosodium glutamate used by cooks here (and then rarely used by cooks in China) might be to blame.

title: Central Park Race Adds Another Top Name
description: Shalane Flanagan, who holds the American womens records for 5,000 meters outdoors and 3,000 indoors, has agreed to run in Central Park for the first time as a professional. The New York Road Runners announced that Flanagan would run March 15 in a womens 8-kilometer (4.97-mile) invitational race. The field will include Katie McGregor, Jen Rhines, Carrie Tollefson, Amy Rudolph, Erin Donohue and Lisa Galaviz, all potential American Olympians, and Carmen Douma-Hussar of Canada and Liliya Shobukhova of Russia.The race is part of the Central Park Challenge, which will be highlighted by the national 8-kilometer championship for men. That race has attracted Alan Webb, Dathan Ritzenhein and Jorge Torres. Abdi Abdirahman, a two-time American Olympian, has withdrawn, saying he was not ready.

title: Bid to Jump Off 86th Floor Was Illegal, Court Rules
description: New Yorkers may not jump off the Empire State Building, even with a parachute, after all, an appellate court in Manhattan ruled on Tuesday.

title: Did Bill Clintons Call-to-Arms Rally Supporters?
description: It was a declaration that quickly became etched in the granite of conventional wisdom.

title: Getting Teenagers Home Safely
description: There are few things more anxiety-inducing for parents than watching their children learn to drive  and for good reason. Even the most mature teenager can take ill-advised risks, and inexperience behind the wheel can be deadly. Automobile accidents are the leading cause of death for 15- to 19-year-olds.

title: Hollywood on Edge of Its Seats as Wiretapping Trial Is Set to Start
description: LOS ANGELES  More than five years have gone by since a Hollywood reporter who had been menacingly warned off of a story learned that her phones had also been tapped. On Wednesday, Anthony Pellicano, the onetime sleuth-to-the-stars accused of that eavesdropping, will go on trial here on racketeering charges in a case that has alternately seized the entertainment industrys attention and left it wondering what all the fuss was about.

title: Duel of Historical Guilts
description: SAN ANTONIO

title: Two New Shows Cast Light and Darkness on Early Cultures in the Americas
description: As you reach the close of the ambitious exhibition The Ancient Americas at the Field Museum in Chicago, after viewing remarkable pottery displays and large-scale evocations of the great empires of the Incas, Maya and Aztecs, you reach a darkened gallery with a display case labeled When Worlds Collided. At its base is a single object: a tilted, disembodied head of an Aztec stone statue.

title: Family Leave Legislation
description: To the Editor:

title: Pinched by Gas Prices? There Is Another Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Airline Fires Chief Pilot After Runway Stunt
description: HONG KONG  Poor judgment as a flier, maybe. Poor judgment of the mood of his bosses, definitely.

title: Out of Prison, and Facing Job Discrimination
description: To the Editor:

title: Tony Silver, 72, Documentary Director, Dies
description: Tony Silver, an award-winning independent filmmaker whose 1983 documentary, Style Wars, was one of the earliest accounts of hip-hop culture, died on Feb. 1 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 72.

title: Musharraf Is Still Focus in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The parties that won Pakistans elections say they will select a prime minister any day now, but that is not expected to calm the countrys turbulent politics, as the next government refocuses opposition to President Pervez Musharraf.

title: Ex-Mayor of Atlanta Enrolled in Prison Drug Program After Denial of a Problem
description: ATLANTA  The federal Bureau of Prisons allowed Bill Campbell, the former mayor of Atlanta now serving time for tax evasion, to shorten his sentence by enrolling in a drug treatment program just a few months after he told a federal judge that he had no substance abuse problems.

title: Advisers for Clinton Plan the Endgame
description: Advisers to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton today began plotting a ground game, advertising budgets and a confidence-brimming outreach strategy in hopes of both scoring a big victory in Aprils Pennsylvania primary and accumulating enough superdelegates over time to even the nomination fight against Senator Barack Obama.

title: Affordable Broadband
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Hits $104 as OPEC Rebuffs Bush
description: Oil prices reached a record close, surging above $104 after OPEC decided Wednesday to keep its production unchanged. The cartel ignored calls from President Bush to pump more oil into an ailing economy.

title: Octopus, Galician Style
description: Time: about 2 hours

title: Ballot Shortages Plague Ohio Election Amid Unusually Heavy Primary Turnout
description: A federal judge in Ohio granted a request late Tuesday from Senator Barack Obamas campaign to extend the voting hours in 21 precincts in Cleveland by an extra 90 minutes because of a lack of paper ballots.

title: For Israel and Gaza, a Perilous Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Double Bubble Trouble
description: Hong Kong

title: Packers Quarterback Favre to Retire From N.F.L.
description: The boyish enthusiasm that drove him to a Super Bowl championship and three N.F.L. Most Valuable Player awards gave way to weariness. And so Monday night, Brett Favre, the beloved quarterback of the Green Bay Packers and one of the most iconic, crowd-pleasing players in football history, told the Packers he was retiring.

title: Mass Transit Needs Congestion Pricing
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority says it will need $29.5 billion over the next five years for system improvements, including buying new subway cars, upgrading signals and expanding. Anyone who rides New Yorks subways, buses and commuter rails would have to concede that the system badly needs the help. The question is how to find all that cash without sticking up riders again. A big part of the answer should be congestion pricing.

title: Cellos Add Wordless but Lyrical Voices
description: Sequitur usually performs in the expanding and contracting configuration that has become the standard for new-music ensembles. But on Monday evening it turned over the stage of Merkin Concert Hall to its cellist, Greg Hesselink, for an unusual program of works for cello and voice.

title: Blaming the State, Mayor Orders Cuts in City Budget
description: The simmering tensions between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. Eliot Spitzer spilled over into the city budget on Tuesday as the mayor ordered new spending reductions to account for diminished state aid in the next fiscal year, and state officials called the mayors numbers inaccurate and highly misleading.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Flavors of the World

title: Canada Bestows Film Honors
description: Away From Her was the big winner when the Genie Awards, Canadas equivalent of the Oscars, were handed out Monday night in Toronto, Reuters reported. The film, about the impact of Alzheimers disease on a married couple, won seven awards, including best picture, best actor (Gordon Pinsent as the husband), best actress (Julie Christie as the wife), best director (Sarah Polley), best adapted screenplay (Ms. Polley), best supporting actress (Kristen Thomson) and the Claude Jutra Award for outstanding achievement by a first-time feature film director (Ms. Polley). Eastern Promises, the David Cronenberg film about the Russian mob in London, also won seven awards, including for best supporting actor (Armin Mueller-Stahl) and best original screenplay (Steve Knight).

title: When Knicks Look at Future, the Future May Look Away
description: There were boos Monday night at Madison Square Garden, though not for the usual reasons. The Knicks were losing, of course, but the jeers were stoked by a more subtle act: the removal of Nate Robinson from the game in the final minutes.

title: Movement Complemented by Immobility and Silence
description: A reasonable amount of fanfare usually greets the arrival in New York of a piece by Ohad Naharin, the artistic director of the Batsheva Dance Company of Israel and one of the most fascinating dancemakers on the planet. But Kamuyot, which he choreographed in 2003 for the Batsheva Ensemble, the companys junior troupe, slipped quietly into the city over the weekend as part of the Israel Non-Stop Arts Festival at the Jewish Community Center in Manhattan.

title: Experimenting in Bed When Not After Vampires
description: Buffy Summers, the vampire slayer of film, television and comic books, is all confidence in fighting the forces of darkness. But shes often shakier in her intimate relationships.

title: The Met Plans a Gala to Celebrate Its 125-Year History
description: After relentless efforts to modernize, the Metropolitan Opera will pause a moment, look back and celebrate its 125th anniversary in the 2008-9 season with a gala performance, the house said Tuesday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Sunday about Milton Bradley, a talented outfielder now with the Texas Rangers who has a reputation for losing his temper, misstated the position played by Michael Young, a teammate who praised Bradleys effort and baseball instincts. It is shortstop  not second base, which he played earlier in his career.

title: A Building Collapses in Harlem, Stalling Train Service
description: Train service to and from Grand Central Terminal was suspended for about 90 minutes on Tuesday after a vacant five-story building in Harlem collapsed and officials worried that trains rumbling by would endanger a larger building next door.

title: Twins Take a Balanced Approach to Liriano
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Francisco Liriano of the Minnesota Twins will never have the type of classic motion that would be depicted in a pitchers handbook. He is a large left-hander with an aggressive, even violent motion, which is part of his DNA. The Twins realize this and do not want to make a significant change in his delivery.

title: Shakespeare for 4-Year-Olds
description: The Royal Shakespeare Company, starting a new initiative to improve the teaching of Shakespeare, is recommending that children be taught his works beginning at 4, The Guardian of London reported. Theres been a lot of success with 4-year-olds, said Jaqui OHanlon, director of education at the company, referring to previous experience with teaching the young. With primary school kids, there isnt a fear factor, because theyve never heard of him. Michael Boyd, artistic director of the company, said: Really, the right time to learn Shakespeare is when children are fearless, when they are used to trying out new language. This is very young childrens daily existence; new words arent a problem. You need to get them before they lose the habit of singing songs and have had the fairy dust shaken out of them.

title: Chinas Role in Sudan
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain: BP Adds to Claims Fund
description: BP, the oil company, increased the amount of money it has set aside to settle claims from the deadly 2005 Texas City, Tex., refinery explosion by almost a third, to $2.1 billion. BP said in December that it had depleted its claims reserve of $1.6 billion. The company used the initial money to settle more than 2,000 cases, a spokeswoman, Wendy Silcock, said. In December, BP said it still had about 1,250 claims, none involving death, after it had spent the $1.6 billion. The company, based in London, raised the set-aside by $500 million. The explosion, on March 23, 2005, killed 15 workers

title: Charitable Hikers Erode Mountain and Towns Patience
description: WASDALE HEAD, England  When Richard Palmer surveys a vista that some have deemed the loveliest in the land, he discerns, as well, a conflict he believes to be insoluble.

title: Kenny Chesney Leads Country Nominations
description: Kenny Chesney was showedwith 11 nominations when the contenders for the Academy of Country Music Awards were announced on Tuesday, Reuters reported. Rodney Atkins was second with six nominations, followed by Brad Paisley with four as an individual and Big & Rich and Sugarland with four each as duos. Along with the nominations, announced in Nashville, came word that for the first time fans will choose the winner of the entertainer of the year prize. Voting will begin May 5; the awards will be presented on May 18 in a program to be telecast on CBS from Las Vegas.

title: With McCain Atop Ticket, Talk Shifts to Spot No. 2
description: DALLAS  Now that Senator John McCain is headed to the nomination, he can begin thinking seriously about perhaps the most important decision he will have to make as the Republican presidential nominee: the selection of a running mate.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Monday about consumer safety misidentified the group surveying the governments delays informing the public of product hazards. Public Citizen, not Citizens Union, wrote the report.

title: Grandmas Chicken, Shaken and Stirred
description: A GOOD fried chicken is hard to find. Especially in New York City.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, the Media Equation column in Business Day on Monday, about the shrinking television audience for the Academy Awards show, misstated the number of Oscars won this year by No Country for Old Men. The film won four Oscars, including best picture  not three. (Its writers-directors, Joel and Ethan Coen, shared the Oscars for best achievement in direction and best adapted screenplay, and Javier Bardem was named best supporting actor.)

title: Ex-Chief at Bellevue Hospital Is Accused of Taking Bribes
