description: The former executive director of Bellevue Hospital Center, the nations oldest public hospital, was charged on Tuesday with taking $27,500 in bribes from a private vendor.

title: Obama Seeks to Rally Backers After Clinton Victories
description: SAN ANTONIO  Senator Barack Obamas winning streak snapped Tuesday evening, and he braced his supporters to settle in for a longer fight for the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: Bush and Fed Step Toward a Mortgage Rescue
description: WASHINGTON  However much they might oppose it on ideological grounds, the Bush administration and the Federal Reserve are inching closer toward a government rescue of distressed homeowners and mortgage lenders.

title: Emerging, in Spain, to Warm Applause
description: THE shelves are filled with anonymous white wines.

title: Storing Information for Profit
description: BPO Management Services of Anaheim, Calif., wants small to midsize companies to hand over their confidential files and corporate documents. So does Cloudworks, of Thousand Oaks, Calif. Docstoc.com of Beverly Hills, Calif., is seeking to make all business and legal documents available online to small companies and counsel them on their use.

title: A Clean, Fair Fight
description: If recent history is any guide, this falls presidential election will be marred by vote suppression and cynical dirty tricks. Congress still has time to stop some of the worst offenses. The Senate is considering two bills, one to outlaw so-called vote caging and another to rein in duplicitous robo-calls. Congress should pass both bills well before Election Day.

title: Canadas Central Bank Cuts Overnight Rate a Half-Point
description: OTTAWA  The Bank of Canada said on Tuesday that it had reduced its benchmark lending rate by half a percentage point, to 3.5 percent, despite the continued robustness of Canadas energy and mining industries.

title: Switzerland: Adeccos Profit Falls
description: Adecco, a temporary-employment company, said fourth-quarter profit fell 29 percent as hiring slowed in the United States. Net income fell to 150 million euros ($228 million) from 212 million euros a year earlier, when earnings were increased by a tax benefit, Adecco said. Fourth-quarter sales gained 2 percent, to 5.38 billion euros. Revenue from the United States and Canada fell 15 percent, to 752 million euros, in the fourth quarter.

title: Gazprom Feud With Ukraine Heats Up
description: MOSCOW  For the second time this week, the Russian natural gas giant Gazprom reduced the flow of gas to neighboring Ukraine on Tuesday as negotiations unraveled over the price and terms of transit for the gas.

title: European Commission Moves to Broaden the Attack on Tax Havens
description: BRUSSELS  Jolted by a tax dispute with Liechtenstein, European countries took steps Tuesday toward clamping down on tax havens.

title: What You Get for ...$8 Million
description: Miami Beach

title: Study Details Womens Risks After Stopping Hormones
description: Among the many unanswered questions about hormones prescribed for menopause is whether a womans health risks change after she stops taking the pills. A new study shows that virtually all the benefits disappear but that a slightly higher risk for breast and other cancers persists for at least three years after stopping the drugs.

title: Surrounded by Movement, Mirrors and Sounds
description: Yanira Castro likes to inhabit evocative spaces, like the Old American Can Factory complex in Brooklyn, and the Brooklyn Lyceum. Gaining access to these buildings is a treat, just as it was a lark for the audience on Friday to explore the stage of Dance Theater Workshop, which Yanira Castro & Company repurposed for Center of Sleep.

title: Conseco, Again
description: Its been almost five years since Conseco emerged from bankruptcy, having been run into the ground by Steve Hilbert, its founder, who became the big man of Indianapolis while being paid hundreds of millions of dollars  and running up huge debts for the company. The local symphony hall was named for him, and the basketball arena bore the Conseco name. After Mr. Hilbert was ousted, the company turned to Gary Wendt, formerly of General Electric, and destroyed his reputation too.

title: Clinton Gains Momentum
description: A crucial victory in Ohio provided a boost for the campaign of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Hillary Clinton in Columbus, Ohio
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton comments on the results from the March 4  primaries. (NBC Video)

title: Dim Sum Fit for an Ambassador
description: China House, the Chinese restaurant of Bangkoks Oriental Hotel, is a handsome building near the hotel entrance. The interior is stunning: Modeled in black-lacquer, Shanghai chic, its hard to imagine that the building once served as the Moroccan Embassy. Its also an ideal place for weekend dim sum. Theres privacy here in the nooks and crannies of the duplex interior. And its relatively quiet, making conversation easy.

title: Thinking Like a (Red) Fox
description: Ohio State Coach Jim Foster has faced the Marist womens basketball team twice, in the opening round of last years N.C.A.A. tournament (a game won by the Red Foxes, 67-63) and in a non-league contest Nov. 11 that was won by the Buckeyes, 63-57.

title: Murcers Brain Biopsy Shows Scar Tissue
description: A biopsy of Bobby Murcer's brain found scar tissue, not a recurrence of cancer, and the former Yankee left the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston on Wednesday.

title: CNNs Advantage in Espaol
description: In Texas, Hispanic voters may be the deciding factor in the contest between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama. In its coverage of the voting patterns, CNN had a distinct advantage: a Spanish-language network named CNN en Espaol.

title: In Coverage, No Competitive Edge
description: Tuesdays proclamation of Senator John McCain as the presumptive Republican nominee was, as Brit Hume put it on Fox News Channel, something to talk about when we dont know whats happening on the other side.

title: Health Food in Moscow: Honey
description: After a month and a half of battling a cold/flu that keeps coming back this winter, I decided it was high time to give folk remedies a try. Loads of garlic did the trick when I suffered a similar bout several years ago, but I kept putting that cure off this time and finally went for something, well, less smelly.

title: Dim Sum, Medvedeviate or Mini-Pootey
description: More of your late night humor (send via the comment link below):

title: Barack Obama in San Antonio
description: Barack Obama comments on the results from the March 4 primaries. (NBC Video)

title: Moving to Baghdad
description: Balen Y. Younis is an Iraqi employee of The New York Times.

title: Everybody Else Headed for Tyra Town
description: Aired Tuesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Senators Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama had primaries in Ohio, Texas, Rhode Island, and Vermont tonight. Many people waited until the very last minute to decide who theyre going to support. According to the exit polls, 53 percent of the voters still hadnt made up their mind, even after they voted.

title: HSBCs Deal for Korea Exchange Bank Is Approved
description: HSBC Holdings, The European bank, won antitrust approval in Seoul for its $6.45 billion takeover bid for the Korea Exchange Bank.

title: Bank of Montreals Earnings Drop
description: Bank of Montreals first-quarter profit fell 27 percent, hurt by write-downs related to the capital markets and higher provisions for bad loans.

title: Morgan Stanley Retreats From Railyards Development
description: Morgan Stanley, the anchor tenant for one of the four developers vying to buy the development rights for the West Side railyards, is backing away from a deal to build its headquarters on the site.

title: Arthrocares Review Announcement Leaves Some Puzzled
description: The Embattled surgical device maker Arthrocare said Tuesday that it is seeking an end-run around its battle with short-sellers and has hired a major investment bank to explore strategic alternatives, including a possible sale of the company.

title: Spielberg Gets Spooky With Social Networking Site, Report Says
description: Steven Spielberg is preparing to introduce a new social network for people interested in sharing paranormal and extraterrestrial experiences, TechCrunch reported.

title: Credit Agricole Posts Worst-Than-Expected 4Q Loss
description: Credit Agricole, Frances biggest retail bank, posted a fourth-quarter loss on Wednesday after large write-downs related to the global credit crunch and said it was not planning any major acquisitions.

title: Ex-Broadcom Executive Settles in Stock Option Case
description: A former executive at Broadcom will pay $1.4 million to settle claims she participated in a scheme to backdate stock options at the chip maker, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Tuesday.

title: Fremonts Future Threatened by Default Notice
description: Fremont General, a financial services concern that regulators forced out of the subprime mortgage business last year, said Tuesday that two purchasers of its loans had declared it to be in default, raising the possibility that they could put it out of business.

title: Facebook Hires a Google Executive as No. 2
description: Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook is not stepping aside for a chief executive as Larry Page and Sergey Brin did at Google or as Jerry Yang and David Filo did at Yahoo. He is following the Bill Gates model and holding the top post as he hires a Google executive, Sheryl Sandberg, as chief operating officer.

title: Credit Rating Cut for Sallie Mae
description: The SLM Corporation, the educational lender known as Sallie Mae, had its long-term credit ratings cut by Moodys Investors Service to two levels above junk Tuesday on concern that a change in the companys strategy will erode profitability.

title: MySpace Co-Founder Buys Revver
description: Brad Greenspan, co-founder of MySpace.com and founder of LiveUniverse, an online entertainment network, announced that his company had acquired an ailing video-sharing site Revver.

title: Beef Giant Buys Assets in the U.S. and Australia
description: JBS, the worlds biggest beef producer, agreed on Tuesday to pay $1.27 billion in cash and stock for assets in the United States and Australia, including the beef unit of the pork producer Smithfield Foods.

title: Europe Moves to Broaden the Attack on Tax Havens
description: Jolted by a tax dispute with Liechtenstein, European countries took steps Tuesday toward clamping down on tax havens.

title: Khosla Invests in Pax Streamline
description: Khosla Ventures, a venture capital firm controlled by Vinod Khosla, a co-founder of Sun Microsystems, has invested in Pax Streamline, maker of turbines, heating and air-conditioning systems, and aerospace technologies.

title: Goldman Said to Be Joining New Futures Exchange
description: The move to craft a new futures exchange gained ground Tuesday as reports emerged that Goldman Sachs may join 12 other banks in creating an alternative to the market-leading Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: Countrywide Is Sued Again by U.S. Overseer
description: The United States Trustee has filed a second lawsuit against the mortgage lender Countrywide Financial, accusing the company of abusing the bankruptcy process.

title: Cowen Names New Chief Executive
description: The Cowen Group said Tuesday that Kim Fennebresque would retire as the investment banks chief executive effective immediately, to be succeeded by David Malcolm, who had been an executive vice chairman at the firm.

title: Liverpool Soccer Club Owners Reject Dubai Bid, Report Says
description: The owners of Liverpool, Tom Hicks and George Gillett Jr., have rejected a bid from Dubai International Capital for the Premier League club, according to The Associated Press.

title: Ad Start-Up Firebrand Shutters
description: It turns out people really dont want to watch ads.

title: Spains Colonial Said to Agree to Takeover
description: The Investment Corporation of Dubai has agreed with leading shareholders of a Spanish property firm, Colonial, on the broad terms of a 3 billion euro ($4.56 billion) takeover, Dow Jones reported.

title: Yahoo Looks at New Way to Survive
description: As it scrambles to avoid defeat in its battle with Microsoft, Yahoo may try to put a little more time on the clock.

title: K-Sea GP Files for $100 Million I.P.O.
description: K-Sea GP Holdings, a holding company affiliated with K-Sea Transportation Partners, filed on Wednesday to raise up to $100 million in an initial public offering.

title: 2 Hedge Funds Target Dillards
description: After starting a campaign to press for changes at the department store chain Dillards last month, the Barington Capital Group has taken its insurgency up a notch.

title: Citic Confirms Talks With Bear Stearns for Bigger Stake
description: Citic Securities, The Chinese broker, is in talks to get a bigger stake in Bear Stearns to reflect a drop in the share price of the Wall Street bank since the two firms agreed to swap stakes last October, a Citic executive said on Wednesday.

title: Tata Scours the Globe for Jaguar Deal Financing
description: Indias Tata Motors plans to borrow $3 billion from nine banks to finance its purchase of Ford Motors Jaguar and Land Rover luxury-car brands, Bloomberg News reported citing unnamed sources.

title: Hedge Fund Said to Seek $500 Million British Listing
description: After failing to charm investors the first time around, Brevan Howard Asset Management, a hedge fund group, is making another run at the public markets.

title: British Investor Melrose Raises Offer for Wire-Rope Maker FKI
description: Melrose, a British investment company, increased its planned bid for FKI of Britain, a maker of wire rope, by 17 percent, to 482 million pounds ($953 million).

title: Upek Pulls the Plug on I.P.O.
description: Upek, which makes fingerprint security products for notebook computers, has canceled its proposed initial public offering because of difficult market conditions, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing Tuesday.

title: Lax to the Max
description: From David Bourgeois and Tim Saccardo of the humor site 236.com:

title: Ford Plans to Hang on to Volvo
description: Ford Motor told analysts Tuesday it would operate its Volvo luxury line on a more stand-alone basis but doesnt plan to sell it.

title: Ranking the Biggest Hedge-Fund Firms
description: JPMorgan Chase retained its position as the largest hedge fund manager in the United States as total assets of the biggest hedge fund firms topped $1.6 trillion as of Jan. 1.

title: Study Says Gifts of Stock Precede Sharp Price Dips
description: Top corporate executives often make large gifts of their companys stock to their family foundations shortly before the stock price drops sharply, according to a new study by a New York University professor. As a result, the executives are able to claim the maximum possible tax deduction and escape capital gains taxes.

title: A Board of Advisers  for Your Life
ABC Learning to Sell Stake in U.S. Unit to Morgan Stanley
description: ABC Learning Centers, the largest child-care center operator in Australia, said Wednesday that it would sell 60 percent of its operations in the United States to Morgan Stanleys private equity unit, raising 750 million Australian dollars ($695 million).

title: Bank Group Said to Work on Pay Guidelines
description: As critics increase their attacks on bankers paychecks  seen as excessive in light of todays market turmoil  several financial firms are planning new guidelines on pay and bonuses, The Financial Times reported.

title: Three Fine Meals, and Halfway There
For Mint.com, More Money in the Bank
description: Mint.com, an online personal-finance organizer, was expected Wednesday to announce a $12 million round of venture funding led by Benchmark Capital. The infusion follows last years $4.7 million Series A round, led by Shasta Ventures.

title: Do Financial Incentives Work for Students?
description: New York City, which has the largest public school system in the country, is in the forefront of a movement to pay for performance, even at the student level, Jennifer Medina writes. More than 200 city schools are experimenting with incentives, and at more than a dozen schools, students, teachers and principals are all eligible for extra money, based on students performance on standardized tests.

title: Banking Analysts Reach For the Eraser
description: Analysts are constantly churning out buy, sell and hold ratings. But at two well-known Wall Street firms this week, oops seemed to be the operative word.

title: The Early Word: Math vs. Momentum?
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton, looking chipper after just a few hours of sleep, made the celebratory rounds on the breakfast news shows this morning.

title: Networks Resort To The Crawl
description: Alessandra Stanleys review of Tuesdays coverage:

title: Doing the Math
description: So, Hillary Clinton has the momentum, but does she have the numbers that count? Not according Bill Burton, an Obama spokesman, who told The Timess Patrick Healy: This was her last, best chance to significantly close the gap in pledged delegates  They have failed.

title: U.N. Drug Panel Faults Celebrity Treatment
description: In its annual report today, the International Narcotics Control Board took on a new issue (a painkiller shortage for worlds poor), reinvigorated an old one (Afghanistans opium crop), and covered many more in dutiful fashion.

title: With Deadline Eased, Yahoo Gives an Update
description: Jerry Yang, the chief executive of Yahoo, reached out to the rank and file Wednesday to explain Yahoos decision to postpone a deadline tied to its annual shareholder meeting  a move that gives it more time to maneuver ahead of a potential proxy fight with Microsoft, whose takeover bid Yahoo rejected last month.

title: Clinton Hints at Shared Ticket
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said Wednesday her close race with Barack Obama might result in a shared ticket. Speaking on CBSs Early Show, she said, Well, that may be where this is headed, but of course we have to decide who is on the top of the ticket. She said her victory in Ohio indicated that the choice should be her.

title: A Trio of Jeers for Magazines
description: Last week, Senator Charles Schumer may have hurt feelings in the magazine industry by suggesting that the kids arent reading Time or Newsweek.

title: Having Your Own Color Man Helps
description: SALZBURG, Austria  I cant watch football sitting down, Red Bulls Coach Juan Carlos Osorio said as he took his place on a perch way in the back of Murphys Law Irish pub, a grotto-like establishment carved into the side of a mountain in Salzburgs Old Town. Sit down? No thanks.

title: Just How Fast Is Kevin Slowey?
description: The Twins will start the right-hander Kevin Slowey against the Yankees Wednesday, and he seems to be a pretty good prospect. But I think theres just something funny about a pitcher named Slowey.

description: More on the history of unemployment -- and unemployment statistics -- can be found in John Garraty's 1978 book, "Unemployment in History." Mr. Garraty, a longtime professor of history at Columbia, died in December, and his Times obituary is available here.

title: Recipe of the Day: Greek-Style Green Beans
description: This is a phenomenally simple and classic preparation of cooked green beans, tossed at the last moment with olive oil and lemon. If you can find flat (Romano) beans, so much the better.

title: A Ferrys Berth, and Rebirth, on Governors Island
description: Finished With Engine, reads the white dial of the brass engine telegraph in the wheelhouse of the double-ended M/V Islander ferry.

title: A Ferrys Rebirth on Governors Island
description: The Islander at its Governors Island berth. (Photos by David W. Dunlap/The New York Times) Slide Show: A Tour of the IslanderFinished With Engine, reads the white dial of the brass engine telegraph in the wheelhouse of the double-ended M/V Islander ferry.   Finished, indeed.   After 57 years of service on the seven-mile route between Woods Hole, Mass., and Vineyard Haven on Marthas Vineyard, the Islander is now berthed at Governors Island, where it is to begin a second life in 2009, serving the four-tenths-of-a-mile route between the island and the Battery Maritime Building in Manhattan.   But though its long days under the ensign of the Woods Hole, Marthas Vineyard and Nantucket Steamship Authority ended exactly one year ago, on March 5, 2007, the Islander looks in many respects as if the crew had just stepped off a few minutes ago.   Navigational charts showing approaches to Woods Hole and Vineyard Haven are still affixed firmly in the boat's wheelhouse. A box of triangular pencils (they cant roll away in a rolling sea) lies open. A roster showing crew changes hangs from a clipboard. So does this stern notice from the port captain:   It is the responsibility of Steamship Authority employees to make certain that passengers and visitors on the Islander during its final trips do not remove any items from the vessel as "souvenirs." Deck watch crew are to be especially aware of possible theft, and are to report any items noted as missing to the captain. Personnel on the freight decks should be aware of items "liberated" from the vessel being placed in vehicles.  The policy did and didnt work. Ghost outlines of plaques in the cafe attest to some successful liberation. But much remains, ranging from the beautiful (the engine telegraph manufactured by Chas. J. Henschel & Company Inc., Amesbury, Mass.) to the mundane (stacks of timetables, piles of Marthas Vineyard Best Read Guide and more orange life jackets than can be counted).   A copy of Yachting magazine  appropriately enough  can be seen discarded near a crew members bunk. A drawer in the pursers office yields the lost-and-found log, a potentially rich lode of sociological information. (Lots of cellphones go missing at sea, it seems.) The last recorded object left behind on the Islander was a pair of wired frame reading glasses, found at 1630 hours, Feb. 27, 2007, on the Woods Hole-to-Vineyard Haven leg.   Leslie Koch, the president of the Governors Island Preservation and Education Corporation, which paid $500,000 for the Islander, sees it as the latest milestone in a long maritime tradition stretching back to Henry Hudsons 1609 voyage and Robert Fultons steamboat nearly two centuries later. From the Half Moon to the Clermont to the Islander, she said.   The reason we acquired the boat was for redundancy and also to increase capacity, Ms. Koch said.  There is no charge for the hourly ferry service to the island, which the public may visit during summer months. (It reopens May 31.) The south end is being prepared for redevelopment and parkland.    The ship formerly served on the seven-mile route between Woods Hole, Mass., and Vineyard Haven on Marthas Vineyard.  Slide Show: A Tour of the Islander The corporation controls all but the 22-acre historical north end of the island, which is administered by the National Park Service, and currently operates the 53-year-old Lt. Samuel S. Coursen ferry. It has a capacity of 493 passengers and 30 vehicles in four lanes on an open-ended deck. The Islander, designed by Eads Johnson of New York and christened in 1950, currently has a capacity of 770 passengers and 47 vehicles in six lanes on a closed deck. The two outside vehicle lanes may be converted to passenger use.   Rehabilitation will almost certainly include removal of the enormous double doors at either end of the Islanders car deck, which helped seal the vessel for what could be very rough weather. This is basically an oceangoing ship, said Jon Meyers, director of real estate. We much prefer the open visual access of the Coursen. It takes as long to open the doors as it does to run our ferry route.   Two years ago, as Massachusetts prepared to say farewell to the Islander, the chief engineer, Steve Broderick, said: This thing is a fighter. Its got tenacity, but nobody in their right mind runs a 56-year-old boat.   The Islanders architect, Mr. Johnson, might have disagreed. Age means little where intelligent maintenance prevails, he said in 1947, when 71 ferryboats served New York Harbor, one of which had passed the half-century mark.   No matter what changes may be made to the hull and its fittings, Ms. Koch promised that the Islander would stay the Islander.   We are keeping the name," she said. And we promise a free ride to everyone from Marthas Vineyard.

title: Not Employed, or Unemployed
description: My colleague David Leonhardt has an excellent column today on why the unemployment rate is low by historical standards, but the proportion of people without jobs is not low.

title: El Duque: Please Cross Your Fingers
description: That phrase, an early favorite for quote of the spring, came from Orlando Hernandezs mouth after he finished up a fairly intriguing bullpen session. After pitching the same way his entire life (42 years?)  high leg kick, chin dropped down   El Duque has changed his windup as a concession to the problems plaguing his right foot. He now keeps his back foot flat on the rubber, which reduces the stress placed on his toes, and pitches with a much lower leg kick.

title: Octopus You Can Make at Home
description: Octopus is tough. Or is it? Check out todays Minimalist column and the accompanying video for a dish thats easy to make and just as good as what youd find at a restaurant.

title:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by David Hajdu
description: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for Living With Music, a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

description: After the high-pitched news releases and the posturing are over, the fate of Microsofts bid for Yahoo may come down to what the majority of Yahoos shareholders want.

description: John Harwood, of The Times and CNBC, analyzes the results of Tuesday's primaries and looks ahead to what's next.

description: In todays New York Times, Tim Arango writes about CNNs profits:

title: Do the Media Fail to Give Climate its Due?
description: Joe Romm, a climate blogger and Clinton-era acting assistant secretary of energy for efficiency and renewable energy, has posted a fresh complaint about the inadequate coverage of global warming in the mainstream media and particularly The New York Times.

title: Ray Davies, Rock Poet?
description: Can rock lyrics (or pop music lyrics like those of Cole Porter and Lorenz Hart) be considered poetry? I was reminded of this late-night, dorm-room, bull-session question by a recent Talk of the Town item in The New Yorker in which the writer Nick Paumgarten followed Ray Davies around the Upper West Side while he reminisced about his years in New York.

title: What Wed Like to Hear
description: Like so many of the other supposedly decisive moments in this campaign  the New Hampshire primary and Super Tuesday spring to mind  Tuesday night's showdown in Texas and Ohio once again failed to resolve the Democratic presidential nominating contest. That does not trouble us. It means, at least, that the absurd frontloading of the primary season did not do what we feared: deprive the majority of Democratic voters of the chance to be heard.

title: Angry Journalist, Happy Journalist
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Should Pharmacists Give Flu Shots?
description: Citing an increase in flu cases in New York City, the citys Department of Health and Mental Hygiene today called on Albany to pass a bill allowing pharmacists to give flu and pneumonia shots. The bill, similar to legislation already adopted in 47 states, could increase the number of older New York City residents who get the shots by at least 50,000, officials said.

title: Obama Pledges to Sharpen Clinton Critique
description: SAN ANTONIO  Senator Barack Obama said today that he would raise the level of scrutiny and sharpen the distinctions with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton as the Democratic presidential nominating fight enters its third full month with no end in sight.

title: No More Bedbugs, but What About the Dog Hair?
description: I confess to being one of those travelers who checks for bedbugs whenever I stay in a hotel. So I was interested to read that some businesses are using dogs specially trained to sniff out bedbug infestations.

title: Clintons Mission Not-Impossible
description: A friend of mine observed this morning that this campaign has gone through several four-month phases. On the GOP side, there was the McCain-will-win-the-nomination phase, followed by the McCain-is-doomed phase followed by the Mac-is-back phase. On the Democratic side, the Hillary-is-invincible phase was followed by the Obama-is-magical phase.

title: Lens: 'King Arthur'
description: A backstage look at New York City Opera's production of "King Arthur."

title: Garrison Keillor Leaves Home for Greener Prairies
description: For those in the market for a place to live in St. Paul, Minn., Garrison Keillor of public radios Prairie Home Companion has just put his seven-bedroom Georgian, built in 1914 on a historic plot of ground, on the market for $1.65 million. The House & Home section of The New York Times profiled the place in 2006, from its 13-foot ceilings to the curving flight of steps that is quite suitable for hauling Scarlett up the stairs.

title: Pondering Microsofts Options
description: Yahoos announcement Wednesday that it would delay its nominations deadline poses an interesting question for Microsoft. Does Microsoft wait until the announcement of the meeting date and the nominations deadline to start a proxy contest or does it attempt to nudge Yahoo by nominating directors beforehand (i.e., now)?

title: Details of Woodens Fall Emerge
description: Bill Dwyre of the Los Angeles Times has some details on John Woodens recent fall, including the fact that the 97-year-old Wooden, the legendary U.C.L.A. coach who still lives on his own, may have spent as many as seven hours on the floor before anyone found him.

title: Great News From Bobby Murcer
description: Heartwarming news today from Bobby Murcer, the former Yankee and current YES broadcaster. Heres a statement from Murcer, just released by the Yankees:

title: Brett Favre Retires
description: It's the end of an era as Packers QB Brett Favre retires, reports CNBC's Darren Rovell.

title: Bush Energy Secretary on Record Oil
description: CNBC interviews Energy Secretary Samuel Bodman on OPEC's plan to keep oil production targets steady.

title: Mets Injury Update
description: Before we give you todays lineups from sunny Port St. Lucie, there is actually one bit of good injury-related news, and it involves Jose Valentin. He said that his knee (ACL) has held up well in workouts so far and that he wants to run the bases Saturday. If all goes well, he hopes to play Sunday against the Astros. Come to think of it, Carlos Delgado didnt sound that discouraged about his hip, either. He took ground balls, hit some soft-toss. Thats my word of the day  progression, he said.

title: Jackson Calls for Changes to Visa I.P.O.
description: At more than $17 billion, Visas initial public offering is expected to be the largest ever in the United States. Along with that comes a wealth of fees for the banks underwriting the credit-card giants offering  and a prominent voice is calling for a change in how those fees are doled out.

title: Kitty Likes Cake
description: From Rathergood.com (Your One-Stop Shop for Good and Evil Kittens). The site features animated animals and songs from Joel Veitch, an animator, commercials director and singer-songwriter:

title: McCain Receives Bush Endorsement
description: A triumphant Senator John McCain went to the White House on Wednesday to receive the political blessing of a man with whom he once feuded bitterly, President Bush.

title: Markowitz Gets to Fork in the Road, and Will Take It
description: Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, insists that for the first time he is totally unclear which direction to take in his career. Facing a term limit, Mr. Markowitz is slowly approaching the end of his tenure in Borough Hall. And more than a few friends and supporters, he said, are urging him to run for mayor. Others tell him he would make a great public advocate, the No. 2 position under the mayor. I have never been indecisive in my life, Mr. Markowitz said in an interview on Wednesday. For the first time in my adult life, I feel like Im at a fork in the road and have no idea which way to go. Do I want to continue a career in elective office? Or do I want to open a new chapter in my life that doesnt include public office. Its difficult.

title: At Citi, Pandit Offers a Pep Talk
description: Its fair to say that Citigroup has had a rough day  and week, and month and year for that matter. The financial giant has been battered by a panoply of concerns, from fears that it may need to seek more capital to worries that it will take a hit from credit cards and home equity loans.

title:
Egg for Breakfast, Too,
Of Course
description: While writing todays $25 & Under about Egg  a mighty fine place for a Southern dinner  I neglected to mention that the restaurant has been a breakfast institution for the past few years. Dinners a new thing for Egg, so I was focusing on that, but I dont want to totally ignore breakfast.

title: So Did Her Husband
description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

title: How About a Three-Way Merger for Yahoo?
description: As Yahoo flails around for an anything-but-Microsoft plan, here is a crazy, but maybe not too crazy, idea: Merge AOL, Myspace and Yahoo. That would leave an independent, publicly traded Yahoo with both the News Corporation and Time Warner as major holders.

title: Ambac Seeks $1.5 Billion in Capital-Raising Move
description: The troubled bond insurer Ambac Financial Group said Wednesday that it will offer $1.5 billion in common stock and equity units to increase its reserves in an effort to maintain its triple-A credit rating.

title: Primaries, Schmimaries, Americans Watched Idol
description: Television viewers preferred unscripted fare on Tuesday, as an hour of American Idol on Fox dominated the nights ratings and two hours of The Biggest Loser on NBC gained audience every half-hour from 8 to 10 p.m.

title: Summer on NBC: Olympics, Gladiators, Singers and a Circus
description: NBC has announced its All-American Summer, a May-to-August programming schedule, featuring a horror series and a circus competition. (Oh, and the Summer Olympics, too.)

title: An Odd Meal in Liguria
description: At my urging, Mario took us and his wonderful family to La Vecchia, in Bastia  just north of Albenga. I had heard that it was dirt cheap, family-style food, with a super limited menu that changed daily, and run by an old lady  thats what La Vecchia means, after all.

title: Soft Serve | Herms Sports Car, Microsoft Soda, Shaving-Cream Modernism
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: Drunken sailor watch
description: John McCain likes to say that the government has been spending like a drunken sailor. As Ive tried to point out, what has actually happened under Bush is a surge in military spending, an increase in Medicare costs, and not much else. The good folks at CBPP have a new, helpful analysis that makes the point in more detail. Heres the rate of increase under Bush of real per capita spending in four categories: Defense/security, SocialSecurityMedicareandMedicaid (I wish theyd broken that up), other mandatory, and domestic discretionary:

title: Should Sovereign Funds Be Taxed?

title: Paris Fashion Week Catch-Up | Suzy Menkes
description: If last weeks Paris fashion shows blew by you faster than you could say Balenciaga, The Moment feels your pain. Here we present a handy digest of the exhaustive fashion criticism produced by Suzy Menkes of the International Herald Tribune. Be it for dinner-party purposes or for basic fashion literacy, feel free to print out this blog post. We wont tell. (Read digests of Suzys reviews from the New York shows here and here.)

title: Rio C.E.O. Says China Stake Purchase Shows Companys Value
description: Chinalcos recent purchase of a stake in Rio Tinto, the worlds second-largest mining company, reinforces Rios rejection of BHP Billitons hostile takeover bid on the grounds that the bid undervalues the firm, Rio Tintos chief executive said on Wednesday according to Reuters.

title: Torre and Francona: More Friends Than Foes
description: Get your cameras ready if you are in Fort Myers, Fla. on Thursday. Terry Francona, the Red Sox manager, will finally meet and speak with Joe Torre, the manager of the Dodgers, on the field before a game. That is something the two managers never did while Torre managed the Yankees.

title: Murtha Blasts McCain Over Tanker Contract
description: WASHINGTON  Representative John P. Murtha of Pennsylvania, one of the most powerful House Democrats on military affairs, accused Senator John McCain, the Republican presidential candidate, of slowing down the efforts by the Air Force to replace its aging fleet of refueling tankers.

title: McCains First Stop: An Embrace from Mr. 32%
description: John McCains first stop after clinching the Republican nomination in last nights primaries was the White House, for lunch and an endorsement from President Bush. Mr. Bushs embrace is one Mr. McCain should be wary of.

title: A $299 Sony Blu-ray Player, but No Cheap Chinese Models
description: Stan Glasgow, the president of Sony Electronics, held his semi-annual update today in New York, and there were a few new tidbits.

title: Zimbabwe Dollar Slides to New Low
description: If the constant flow of depressing news about the U.S. dollars decline breeds yearning for the boom times of yore, look no further.

title: Hillary Clinton on 'Morning Joe'
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton appears on the 'Morning Joe' show on March 5.  (NBC Video)

title: Fla. and Mich. Governors: Give Us Our Delegates
description: Floridas Republican governor and Michigans Democratic governor have one major gripe in common: the national parties have punished both of their states by limiting delegates to the national conventions. They released a joint statement today asking for their delegates to be seated.

title: A darker shade of beige
description: The Federal Reserve knows something about official economic statistics  that theyre not always a good guide to whats really happening. (I like to describe economic data as a peculiarly boring form of science fiction.) So the Fed also relies on an informal survey of economic conditions, the Beige Book. And the latest Beige Book does suggest a slowing economy, possibly even a recession.

title: A Pool in Progress
description: One of the many things weve learned about building a house is that everything takes longer than we think it will (or should). So, when it came to picking out the decorative tile border that will be visible just above and below the waterline in our pool, we figured it would eat up another hunk of time we didnt have.

title: Barack Obama on 'Today'
description: Barack Obama appears on the 'Today' show on March 5.  (NBC Video)

title: A Call 311 Campaign to Help the Homeless
description: A 311 call reporting a homeless person will now result in the citys Department of Homeless Services calling back on the same day with an update about what happened as a result of the phone call.

title: Shaking It Off
description: Jeff Tweedy is primarily known as the lyricist, lead singer and guitarist of Wilco, one of Americas most popular and critically successful rock bands. He is also a lifelong migraine sufferer whose headaches were for decades compounded by bouts of depression and panic disorder.

title: New Patentable Idea: A Way to Invalidate Vague Patents
description: Theres not much love in legal circles for the so-called business method patent, an exclusive intellectual property right over a novel way of doing business. Critics of such patents  think Amazon One Click or Pricelines name your own price patents  argue that they clog up the United States Patent and Trademark Office, lead to excessive litigation and have little connection to real, physical invention.

title: To Dream the Possible Dream Ticket
description: Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton hinted at the possibility of a Democratic dream ticket with Sen. Barack Obama, CBS News informs us.

title: Stiffer Penalties for Elevator Violations
description: In its latest crackdown on bad landlords, the citys Department of Buildings announced a push to sharply increase fines for chronic elevator violations and to shame the worst offenders into bringing their elevators into compliance.Beginning today, the agency will post the addresses and owners of the 10 buildings with the worst elevator violations on its Web site. (As for just how the list is expected to shame building owners is questionable, because while the Department of Buildings Web site lists the address of the offending buildings and will list the owner of record, the owner is often a faceless limited liability corporation or partnership.)

title: Wanted: A More Digital Congress
description: When it comes to taking advantage of all the Internet has to offer, some media gurus say Congress is a little behind the curve.

title: An Activist Fund Managers Unusual New Project
description: Philip Falcone is no stranger to taking on big tasks. He is a senior managing director of Harbinger Capital Partners, one of the hedge funds attempting to shake up The New York Times Company, an endeavor in which a Morgan Stanley fund manager failed last year. (Harbinger, who with Firebrand Partners owns more than 19 percent of the newspaper company, is seeking to install four directors on its board.)

title: Gambling the Franchise
description: Before 2000, if you talked about having the franchise somewhere in America, it generally meant that you had secured the right to open a Subway sandwich shop or a Ben & Jerrys. But then came the nightmare in Florida, and ever since then, voters everywhere  and especially those in the Democratic Party  have talked about being disenfranchised, in the political sense, as easily as they talk about being polled or being undecided. In my book, The Argument, I described a 2004 party in which Lynda Resnick, an agribusiness billionaire who is active in Democratic politics, stood on the spiral staircase of her Sunset Boulevard mansion and exclaimed: Were so tired of being disenfranchised! More recently, the former vice presidential candidate Geraldine Ferraro argued in a Times Op-Ed  that the Democratic voters of Florida and Michigan, whose primaries were disqualified by the national party, surely dont deserve to be disenfranchised. A few Floridians have employed the same word in their comments here.

title: Questions on Grand Canyon Blow Out
description: An effort to restore the Grand Canyon after years of erosion began today as two pipes in the Glen Canyon Dam were opened wide, the beginning of a 60-hour flood. Authorities are hoping that sediment stuck at the bottom of the Colorado River spreads to depleted sandbars, which are used by endangered species and campers alike.

title: Exxon Chief Discusses Oil Prices
description: CNBC interviews Rex Tillerson, ExxonMobil's chief executive, about meeting the world's growing demand for energy.

title: Cafeteria Workers Protest on Wall Street
description: Hundreds of cafeteria and other food-service workers rallied in Lower Manhattan on Wednesday afternoon for higher wages and improved benefits as part of an ongoing battle between the Aramark Corporation and the union Unite Here, which represents about 20,000 Aramark employees, including about 4,000 in the New York region.

title: I Thought Every Day Was Womens Day at Bike Week
description: Motorcycle news and blog items were reading around the Web

title: French Artist to Internet: Its All Other Peoples Memories
description: The crowd at Beet.TV, a Medium favorite, scored an online-video interview with Claude Lelouch, the French auteur. (There, finally, the word fits!)

title: The Cost of a Slice
description: Pizza prices may be going up, but the New Yorkers we spoke to still enjoy their slices.

title: The View From Abroad
description: Its not just Americans who are following the presidential nomination process  people all over the world have a stake in which candidates will get the nod and who will win come November. Below are links to foreign television broadcasts to show what people in other countries are hearing about yesterdays primaries.

title: Sell More NAND, Watch Margins Drop
description: Paul Otellini, Intels chief executive, tried to reassure financial analysts Wednesday that he would move quickly to address the problem the company was seeing in its NAND memory chips business.

title: Electability, again
description: Rasmussen has started running a tracking poll on head-to-heads against McCain, with numbers running back about a month; I havent seen people mentioning it. All the usual caveats, blah blah.

title: The Fourth Quarter
description: The Obama camp wanted the race to be over on Tuesday night; the Clinton camp wanted it to continue. With Senator Clintons wins in Ohio, Texas and Rhode Island, continue it will. But lets look beyond how the continuation of the race advantages one candidate over the other, and instead look at broader questions: Is the prolonged race a good thing or a bad thing for the Democrats? Was  as some have suggested  the only real winner on Tuesday night John McCain?

title: Whitney Biennial 2008
description: A preview of the Whitney Biennial show and interviews with the curators.

title: Summer at CBS: Cops and Swingers
description: Flashpoint, the Canadian cop drama picked up by CBS during the writers strike in January, will debut in July, the network announced today.

title: The Very First TED 2008 Video
description: I didnt attend the TED conference this year, much to my deep regret. I stayed home to attend my parenting duties.

title: Day 6: Red Bull Salzburg Wins, Trapattoni Speaks
description: SALZBURG, Austria  At a spry 68 years old, with sparkling eyes, Giovanni Trapattoni said he is ready for a new challenge  taking the national team of Ireland to a place it has not been since 2002, the World Cup.

title: Profile in Style: Jean Touitou
description: APC designer Jean Touitou.

title: No Pity Party for HD-DVD Suckers
description: From this weeks mailbag:

title: Bank Moves to Withdraw Its Suit Against Wikileaks Site
description: A Swiss bank on Wednesday moved to withdraw a lawsuit that it had filed against a Web site that it asserted had displayed stolen documents revealing confidential information about the accounts of the banks clients.

title: Celebrating a Cadillac Milestone
description: A hundred years ago today, three Model K Cadillacs made a historic journey. The cars were first driven 25 miles from London to the Brooklands racetrack, where each one was taken apart inside a brick shed. Three piles of parts  some 720 parts per car  were jumbled together. Then they were reassembled from the resulting shuffle and driven another 500 miles.

title: An Actors Diagnosis May Bring Attention to a Neglected Cancer
description: Actor Patrick Swayze, 55, star of the 1987 hit movie Dirty Dancing, has been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer, according to a statement issued on Wednesday by his publicist. Although tabloid reports claimed Mr. Swayze has terminal cancer, the statement said those reports were not correct.

title: Bloggingheads: The 'Iraq Recession'
description:
Robert Wright of Bloggingheads.tv, left, and Mickey Kaus of Kausfiles debate whether Democrats can link the war's financial toll to the economic downturn.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Retro Television Goes Nouveau
description: What is TV Land? Many viewers would say its the cable channel for The Brady Bunch, Bonanza and Leave It To Beaver. And that would be partially true. But the channel, which is owned by Viacom, wants to be known for original programming.

title: Oils End
description: From the steps of the Supreme Court to the White House press room, from global trading exchanges to the snowy reaches of Alaska  over the last week, you could hear the creak of history as it began to pivot in a half-dozen locales.

title: Kosovo's Economic Uncertainty
description: Superficial signs of economic success mask the harsh uncertainties of a newborn nation, whose very existence is not recognized by Serbia, Russia or some European countries.

title: How Should We Moderate Comments?
description: As you know, all comments on this blog are moderated, and Id love to get feedback about what we should allow and what we should delete. In general, I tend to let most things sail through, although I delete comments in all caps, or those in which people try to include a long text of a high school term paper. I also delete obscenities or gratuitous insults against other posters (although I tend to leave insults directed at me, figuring that I skewer people periodically in my column and so should be able to receive what I dish out).

title: Your Comments on my Aid Column
description: Tonights column is my last from South Sudan, and its really as much about us as about them. I argue that the American presidential election may well affect poor countries like Sudan as much as America  after all, well all survive a dreadful president, but in Africa the American president can make a difference of life or death.

title: Brit singer Craig David among buyers of hip Miami project
description: The marketers for Mondrian South Beach claim the recent sale of a tower suite in the high-rise set a new price record for West Ave, the fast-growing area on Biscayne Bay, south of Miami. The 4,000-square-foot suite with 2,000-square-feet of terrace sold for $5 million (3.3 million) to an undisclosed U.K. buyer, according to a company spokeswoman.

title: Respond to Todays Column: Hillarys Edge
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Mar. 6 column.

title: Credit and Mortgage Woes Sink Stocks
description: Renewed anxiety about the availability of bank loans  and fears that the Federal Reserve may be unable to curb the credit slump  sent stock markets down sharply on Wall Street on Thursday.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Designs in Swirl and Flourish

title: Jurors Are Selected in Trial of Hollywood Detective
description: LOS ANGELES  A jury was quickly empaneled on Wednesday in the Anthony Pellicano wiretapping and racketeering case, paving the way for opening arguments Thursday in what is expected to be an 8- to 10-week trial of Mr. Pellicano and four co-defendants.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the impending trial of two former senior analysts for the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, or Aipac, on charges that they violated the Espionage Act, referred incorrectly to Aipacs work. The organization, a pro-Israel lobby, works in the United States to advance Israels interests. It does not work directly for the state of Israel or its government.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A headline on Wednesday with the continuation of a front-page article about results from four presidential primaries on Tuesday misidentified, in some editions, one of the states that voted. It was Ohio, not Iowa.

title: Mortgage Defaults Reach a New High
description: WASHINGTON  Defaults on home mortgages touched another all-time high at the end of the last year as foreclosures surged on adjustable-rate mortgages, an industry group reported on Thursday.

title: F.B.I. Says Records Demands Are Curbed
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Bureau of Investigation improperly obtained personal information on Americans in numerous terrorism investigations in 2006, but internal practices put in place since then appear to have helped curtail the problems, Bush administration officials said Wednesday.

title: Benefits of the Andean Trade Preferences
description: To the Editor:

title: What Wed Like to Hear
description: Like so many of the other supposedly decisive moments in this campaign  the New Hampshire primary and Super Tuesday spring to mind  Tuesday nights showdown in Texas and Ohio once again failed to resolve the Democratic presidential nominating contest. That does not trouble us. It means, at least, that the absurd front-loading of the primary season did not do what we feared: deprive the majority of Democratic voters of the chance to be heard.

title: U.S. Universities Join Saudis in Partnerships
description: Three prominent American universities  the University of Texas at Austin, the University of California, Berkeley, and Stanford University  are starting five-year partnerships, worth $25 million or more, with King Abdullah University of Science and Technology, a graduate-level research university being built in Saudi Arabia.

title: Tip of the Week: Viewing Images in 3-D
description: PicLens makes viewing photos on your computer screen a 3-D experience. You can do a Google search for a particular image, and a wall of images floats across your screen. You pull the stream of photos across the screen as if you were Tom Cruise in Minority Report. PicLens, a Web browser add-on, displays photos from Flickr, Facebook, MySpace and Yahoo Images, too. Best of all, PicLens is free at www.cooliris.com and works on PCs and Macs with Internet Explorer, Firefox or Safari browsers. And it takes less than a minute to download and install.

title: Two Tests Added to Recommended List to Prevent or Detect Colorectal Cancer
description: The American Cancer Society and other health groups are recommending two tests they had not previously endorsed to prevent or detect colorectal cancer, the groups said Wednesday.

title: Campaign Sends Its Youngest Clinton to Pennsylvania to Open the Next Round
description: PHILADELPHIA  Fresh off three important victories on Tuesday, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton wasted no time planting her flag in the next big battleground state, sending her daughter, Chelsea, here Wednesday to speak to students.

title: Close Race to Replace Ex-Speaker in House
description: ELGIN, Ill.  When Representative J. Dennis Hastert, the long-serving former House speaker, announced his retirement last year, both parties saw an opportunity to make a statement from his district here.

title: Alou Out 4 to 6 Weeks, Making Mets' Injury Report  Complete
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The injury report that Manager Willie Randolph peruses every day details the progress his players are making from strained hip flexors, ankle sprains, bruised sternums, sore feet, concussions, tight hamstrings, knee operations, shoulder rehabilitations and elbow problems. An altogether new ailment  groin discomfort  appeared Wednesday, and this latest batch of bad news will cost the Mets their starting left fielder for at least the next four to six weeks.

title: California: Bank Seeks to Drop Web Lawsuit
description: A Swiss bank moved to withdraw a lawsuit it brought against a Web site that it claimed had displayed stolen documents revealing confidential information about its clients. Lawyers in the case said the move by Bank Julius Baer & Company probably ends its battle against Wikileaks, a site that allows people to post documents anonymously to be of assistance to people of all regions who wish to reveal unethical behavior in their governments and corporations. Although the bank obtained an order last month from Judge Jeffrey S. White of Federal District Court in San Francisco that obstructed, but did not absolutely prevent, access to material on Wikileaks, the judge on Friday withdrew that order.

title: Turnout, Technology and Nature Marred Balloting in Ohio
description: For election officials everywhere, Tuesdays votes in Ohio and Texas were contentious and drawn-out reminders to expect the unexpected in a year of enormous enthusiasm.

title: Lawmaker Calls His Bill on Earnings a Sure Loser
description: ALBANY  Many of the bills introduced here each year have little hope of becoming law. But one that is pre-emptively dubbed the Snowballs Chance in Hell Bill  by the legislator who introduced it  is perhaps worth a second look.

title: Gay Marriage Gains Notice in State Court
description: On the way home from work in Rochester, Patricia Martinez stopped at a liquor store and bought a small bottle of Champagne to celebrate her marriage to another woman. The wedding took place in Canada nearly four years ago, but it wasnt until Feb. 1 that a New York appellate court declared it valid in the state.

title: Britain: Builders Profit Rises Sharply
description: Balfour Beatty, Britains biggest builder, said full-year profit surged 66 percent as an acquisition in the United States increased military housing orders and as construction demand rose in Britain and Europe. Net income rose to 151 million ($300 million) from 91 million a year earlier. Revenue climbed 44 percent to 6.47 billion ($12.7 billion). Balfour said it had won contracts from the United States military and hotel industry valued at more than $1.2 billion.

title: Good News: Karlo Will Live
description: NUBA MOUNTAINS, Sudan

title: That Was the Wind That Toppled the Tree That Flattened 2 Cars
description: Marina Farez, 37, was speechless in both English and Spanish.

title: A Night of Warpaint, a New Set of Crowes
description: Chris Robinson, the lead singer of the Black Crowes, let a few songs rattle by before he said a word to the capacity crowd at the Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza on Tuesday night. Then he played hard to get, knavishly sidestepping the microphone. When he shimmied back and spoke, he still seemed evasive. Since we made our last record in 1978, its been a long ... he waited a beat, flashing a toothy grin. A very long time.

title: An Old Friend of Ancient Wood
description: WANDER into the penthouse lounge of the new Huntley Hotel in Santa Monica, or the Tides Hotel in South Beach designed by Kelly Wearstler, or Philippe Starcks recently opened Hotel Fasano in Rio de Janeiro, and you cant help but notice the cocktail tables and other furniture made of chunks of rustic wood. Such eco-chic pieces seem to have edged out Buddhas, communal tables and taxidermy as the latest symbol of cool in boutique hotels, restaurants and luxury condos.

title: Sometimes Politics Can Be Top-Heavy
description: CROMWELL, Conn.

title: Where Waterfalls Freeze, Theres a Path to the Top
description: JUNE LAKE, Calif.  Pinned 100 feet up a frozen wall by the picks I have hammered into the ice and the toothy bite of the crampons strapped to my boots, I pause to rest. Water trickles under the clear sections of ice in front of my chest. It is as if the ice is weeping from the abuse.

title: Cops Seeking a Clue, Digital Effects Aside
description: Embedded in the plodding forensics vrit series Crime 360 is subliminal confirmation of a growing societal fear that our reliance on technology is making us dumber.

title: Lords Spurn Springer Lawsuit
description: The House of Lords in Britain has rejected an appeal by an evangelical lobbying organization seeking to prosecute the BBC for blasphemy for broadcasting the satirical musical Jerry Springer: The Opera, the BBC reported. Upholding a High Court decision and spurning the petition by the evangelical organization, Christian Voice, the House of Lords said it did not raise an arguable point of law of general importance. Christian Voice called the Lords decision an ignoble move, and Stephen Green, its national director, said: It brings down the judgment of God on us all. I love my neighbor, and I do not want that to happen. Mr. Green had argued that the musical included images that vilify God and the Bible.

title: Marbury Is Seen at Garden, but Its Not a Welcome Sight
description: Didnt anybody want to talk about LeBron James? That was Isiah Thomass plaintive question to reporters who kept badgering him about Stephon Marbury, an apparition much like Sasquatch or the Loch Ness Monster.

title: Regional Bloc Criticizes Colombia Raid in Ecuador
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The Organization of American States approved a resolution on Wednesday declaring the Colombian military raid into Ecuador a violation of sovereignty, in a move aimed at easing a diplomatic crisis in the Andes involving Colombia, Ecuador and Venezuela.

title: A Password for Every Router
description: Q. Everyone always says to change the password on your home wireless router from the default one. Why is this, and how do I change my password when the router is already up and running?

title: Downloading: That Other Way to Get a Video Game
description: HARDLY a day passes when someone doesnt breathlessly tell us that downloading movies will be the next big thing.

title: Hillarys Edge
description: AUSTIN, Tex.

title: Iraq in Talks With American and European Companies to Develop 5 New Oil Fields
description: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi government is negotiating with American and European oil companies to manage the development of five new fields in northern and southern Iraq, an Oil Ministry official said Wednesday.

title: The Goat Pasture?
description: Sam Zell, the new owner of the Chicago Cubs and Wrigley Field, said last week that he might sell the naming rights to the historic ballpark. What do you think would be the best possible name?

title: New Printer, Old Software
description: Q. I got a free Hewlett-Packard printer/scanner/copier when I bought a laptop, but I didnt hook it up for months. I finally got around to setting it up, and even though it prints basic documents, every time I try to scan, the software crashes. What can I do?

title: A Camera That Frees Your Face
description: Just by looking at it, youd never guess that Sonys new Alpha A300 digital camera represents a huge technical breakthrough. To discover what it is, you need a tour of its innards. Keep hands and feet inside the tram at all times.

title: American Axle and UAW to Hold Strike Negotiation
description: DETROIT  Negotiators from the United Automobile Workers union and American Axle & Manufacturing plan to meet for the first time since Feb. 25 in the hopes of ending a strike that has caused more than 16,000 workers at General Motors and its suppliers to be temporarily laid off.

title: Clemency Urged for Czech Art Hackers
description: Academics at Charles University in Prague have initiated a petition urging the Czech president, Vaclav Klaus, to pardon the Ztohoven collective of young artists who superimposed an image of a nuclear explosion and mushroom cloud, above, over an image of the Krkonose Mountains, by hacking into a Czech Television CT2 weather broadcast in June, Agence France-Presse reported. Seven members of the group, which achieved international renown and won a national art prize for its images, are to appear in court on March 25, when they face sentences of as much as three years for scaremongering. The academics petition argues that the case is ridiculous and a waste of money. The image introduced onto the broadcast was so absurd that it is impossible to regard it as scaremongering, they said in a statement. Denisa Kera, a teacher and organizer of the protest, said the petition had gathered 3,500 signatures in its first three days.

title: Irans Religious Conservatives Are Expected to Solidify Power at Polls
description: TEHRAN  With eight days before Irans parliamentary elections, there is little doubt that religious conservatives will tighten their grip on power, pushing aside some of the veteran politicians who helped found the Islamic Republic 29 years ago.

title: Food-Service Workers Rally to Press Demands With Operator of Cafeterias
description: Hundreds of cafeteria and other food-service workers rallied in Lower Manhattan on Wednesday afternoon for higher wages and improved benefits as part of a continuing battle between the Aramark Corporation and Unite Here, a union that represents about 20,000 Aramark employees, including about 4,000 in the New York region.

title: Corruption Allegations Batter South Koreas New President
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A corruption scandal at Samsung engulfed the government of the new South Korean president on Wednesday as his intelligence chief and top anticorruption aide faced accusations of receiving bribes from the company.

title: Night of the Living Room Dead
description: Now this is adult entertainment. By that I dont mean that Parlour Song, the smart and rueful new play by the British dramatist Jez Butterworth that opened Wednesday night in a world premiere from the Atlantic Theater Company, is filled with steamy encounters unfit for the eyes of children.

title: Lawmakers Threaten to Kill Tanker Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Lawmakers on the House Appropriations Committee warned Wednesday that they would kill a multibillion-dollar contract to replace the fleet of Air Force fueling tankers if the Pentagon did not adequately explain why it gave the deal to a partnership between Northrop Grumman and the European parent of Airbus, instead of to Boeing.

title: With Marbury Watching, James Scores 50 Points at Garden
description: LeBron James passed through the Knicks twisted corner of the universe Wednesday night and, despite his celestial talents, was nearly overshadowed by a spectator in a salmon-and-beige houndstooth coat.

title: Ambac Disappoints Market With a Plan to Raise Cash
description: A bid to bolster the Ambac Financial Group, the troubled bond insurance company, fell flat on Wednesday, sending the companys stock tumbling 20 percent and disrupting the broader stock market.

title: Take a Deep Breath
description: South America has had more than its share of border conflicts. Still, it is hard to believe that in the 21st century the democratically elected governments of Colombia, Ecuador and Venezuela would be talking about war.

title: Buckley Memorial to Be Held April 4
description: A memorial service for the writer and editor William F. Buckley Jr. will be held on April 4 at 10 a.m. at St. Patricks Cathedral in Manhattan, his family said. The service will be open to the public. Mr. Buckleys son, the writer Christopher Buckley, and Henry A. Kissinger, the former secretary of state, will speak.

title: New Zealands Interest Rate Is Unchanged
description: New Zealands central bank left the benchmark interest rate at 8.25 percent, saying slowing growth will not relieve pressure on inflation until next year. We expect that the official cash rate will need to remain at current levels for a significant time, the Reserve Bank governor, Alan Bollard, said. Inflation is being fanned by a record low jobless rate, rising commodity prices and the promise of income tax cuts.

title: Suggested Read: The Favre DNA
description: Of Brett Favre's many amazing performances, perhaps none was greater or more memorable than the one that took place the night after his father died in 2003, when in front of a "Monday Night Football" audience he passed for 399 yards and four touchdowns. As Joe Drape reported for The Times shortly after Irvin Favre died, "Big Irv" possessed the same toughness as his son, and was known in his hometown of Kiln, Miss., where he had coached high school football, as "more than the daddy of Green Bay quarterback Brett Favre."

title: Senate Backs Overhaul of Product Safety Laws
description: WASHINGTON  Responding to a wave of defective toys and other goods, the Senate approved a measure on Thursday that would overhaul the nations consumer product laws and strengthen the safety agency that oversees the marketplace.

title: Ramn Barqun, Cuban Colonel, Dies at 93
description: Ramn M. Barqun, a respected Cuban Army officer whose struggles to restore the rule of law in Cuba clashed with both the dictator Fulgencio Batista and later the revolutionary government of Fidel Castro, died on Monday at his home in exile in Guaynabo, Puerto Rico. He was 93.

title: E.C.B. and Britain Hold Rates Steady
description: The European Central Bank and the Bank of England left their interest rates unchanged on Thursday, highlighting their differences with the Federal Reserve in the United States.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Wednesday with a front-page article about cash incentives for students, teachers and principals in New York City public schools misidentified the position held by Dalia Johnson at Public School 188 in Manhattan. She is director of the middle school, not the schools overall director.

title: Court Questions Planned Oil Project in Canada
description: OTTAWA  The Federal Court of Canada has ordered a environmental review panel to take a second look at the greenhouse gas implications of oil sands project in Alberta proposed by Imperial Oil, an oil producer based in Calgary, Canada.

title: A New Job Track for Single Mothers in Wyoming
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo.  The lunch table was full of people in the same boat: Single mothers who are trainees in the hydraulics and pipe-fitting trades, thrown together and traveling to a place none of them could quite imagine.

title: Hollywood Report Card
description: The average price of movie tickets jumped 5 percent last year to $6.88; the number of tickets sold in the United States and Canada edged up three-tenths of one percent to 1.4 billion, and domestic box-office revenue rose 5.4 percent to a record $9.6 billion, according to an annual survey of the theatrical movie market released on Wednesday by the Motion Picture Association of America. During a conference call with reporters, Dan Glickman, the associations chief executive, said the number of films taking in more than $100 million at the box office expanded sharply. When people liked us, they really loved us, Mr. Glickman said. According to the figures, compiled in partnership with Nielsen EDI, the international box office expanded about 4.9 percent to $26.7 billion. That figure was given a boost by the weakness of the dollar against some foreign currencies, including the euro. One of the more startling year-to-year changes was a sharp rise in spending by the studios specialty divisions, which make and distribute some films intended for the annual awards races and others aimed at getting fans of horror and other genres. According to the report such divisions investment in production rose 6 percent to an average $42.9 million per movie, while marketing costs jumped 44 percent to $25.7 million.

title: Deadline Nears for Weather Channel Bids
description: A half-dozen media companies have signaled that they plan to bid for the Weather Channel, which is up for auction, people involved in the talks said Wednesday.

title: Picking Up Pieces, Gazans Debate Israel Incursion
description: JABALIYA, Gaza  In a small shop by their rocketed, bullet-pocked apartment building, the Abed Rabo family argued raucously about the impact of the 48-hour Israeli military incursion, which killed nearly 100 Palestinians, including some neighbors.

title: Social Networking Moves to the Cellphone
description: PARIS  Social networks may be nothing new to habitus of the Internet. Several years of competition among Facebook, MySpace and Friendster have generated tens of millions of members.

title: Mexico: U.S. Frees Drug Lord
description: Francisco Rafael Arellano Flix, the eldest of five brothers who control the drug cartel in Tijuana, is back in Mexico after being freed from a United States prison this week, Mexican authorities said. He was released at a border crossing in El Paso and walked to Mexican soil, where family members met him, ushered him into a sedan and drove off. The authorities say there are no outstanding charges against him in Mexico. For years, Mr. Arellano Flix, 58, ran the powerful Tijuana cartel, known for ruthless killings and the smuggling of tons of cocaine. Mexican authorities arrested him in 1993 and sentenced him to 11 years in prison, and he stayed in prison two more years while he fought extradition to the United States. He was finally transferred to the United States in 2006 and convicted of selling cocaine to an undercover agent in 1980. He served a year and five months in an American prison. Two of his brothers are currently in prison, one died in a shootout in 2002 and one is at large.

title: Clinton Success Alters Delegate Races Dynamic
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons victories in the primaries on Tuesday barely dented Senator Barack Obamas lead in delegates, but they seemed to slow the Democratic Party establishments move in his direction while giving her campaign time to try to turn the race in her favor.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,967 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Wednesday:

title: Part Hip-Hop, Part Haughty, All Decadent
description: THE brand is strong, the numbers are great ... yet Gucci seems to be going through a minor midlife crisis. A fling, maybe. Nothing serious.

title: Southwest Air Faces Big Fine on Plane Inspections
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Aviation Administration proposed a record penalty of $10.2 million against Southwest Airlines on Thursday, saying the carrier had continued to fly 46 Boeing 737s that it said it had grounded because they had not been properly inspected for fuselage cracks.

title: Hollywood Hopes to Laugh to the Bank
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywoods big studios have found their cure for the surfeit of dour movies last fall and winter: a spring-summer comedy glut.

title: Ethereal Harmonies That Transcend Loss and Grief
description: Among Requiem settings that have become staples of the nonliturgical repertory, Gabriel Faurs is the most paradoxical. Faur, who claimed to have written the piece for fun, avoided the blood-and-fire histrionics that make the splashiest moments in the Requiems of Mozart and Verdi, two more settings that often turn up in the concert hall. Instead, he favored ethereal sounds and a conciliatory tone. His was a Requiem of acceptance rather than terror and sorrow.

title: Turning Glare Into Watts
description: BOULDER CITY, Nev.  At first, as he adjusted pumps and checked temperatures, Aaron Boucher looked like any technician in the control room of an electrical plant. Then he rushed to the window and scanned the sky, to check his fuel supply.

title: Student Arrested for Bomb Materials
description: A freshman at the University of California Davis has been arrested after the campus police found what they said were explosive materials in his dorm room, university officials said Thursday morning.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Wednesday about Brett Favres final N.F.L. pass misstated the military title of Greg Gadson, who now has the ball from that play. He is an Army lieutenant colonel, not a lieutenant.

title: Volvo Chief Sees a Plus in Shrinking Done by Ford
description: GENEVA  For Volvo, the Swedish maker of safe, sturdy cars, life is getting lonely. Its aristocratic English cousins in the Ford Motor Company family, Jaguar and Land Rover, are in the final stages of being sold to Tata Motors of India, leaving Volvo as Fords only European luxury brand.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Headlines in some editions on Wednesday about testimony in the trial of three New York City police detectives charged in the shooting death of Sean Bell outside a Queens nightclub in 2006 referred incorrectly to the case. It is being heard by a judge only; there is no jury.

title: Where Theres Racket, a Headset Walkie-Talkie Keeps the Conversation Going
description: Is that a walkie-talkie hanging off your ear? It might just be Callpods new Dragon Bluetooth headset, which packs a lot of functions into a small package.

title: Gazprom Settles With Ukraine, for Now
description: MOSCOW  Gazprom, the worlds largest natural gas producer, and Ukraine resolved their latest dispute over natural gas pricing on Wednesday before it could disrupt supplies to Western Europe.

title: Video-Sampling Syria: Global Politics From a Grounds-Eye View
description: LOS ANGELES  Julia Meltzer and David Thorne decamped for Damascus in March 2005 with a vague notion of assessing the toll exacted on ordinary Syrians by the Bush administrations treatment of their country as an axis of evil understudy.

title: Whats in a Chair?
description: ANN LOFTIN could write a textbook on the nuances of modern psychotherapeutic methods  and the personality types of their practitioners  based on the home office dcor of the therapists who have treated her. There was the strict Freudian whose couch was covered in plastic and who barely spoke, though every once in a while a phrase like mothers milk might have slipped out. Anothers office featured phallic African statuary and pictures of a young wife, who was herself always audible somewhere in the background. A licensed clinical social worker had lots of comfy, overstuffed furniture and encouraged patients to sit anywhere (sessions ended in long hugs that suggested much countertransference). Her last analyst, with whom she spent a fruitful decade, did not see patients in his home, but in an office building, and his room there held nothing more than two nondescript leather chairs, a bookcase lined with medical texts and a table holding a box of tissues.

title: Choir Director Quits
description: Craig Jessop, music director of the Mormon Tabernacle Choir, resigned unexpectedly on Tuesday night. The decision by Mr. Jessop, who became the choirs associate director in 1995 and director and conductor in 1999, stunned some members of the acclaimed ensemble when it was announced after a regular rehearsal, The Deseret Morning News of Salt Lake City reported. Mack Wilberg, the associate music director, will serve as interim director of the choir, which reached No. 1 on the Billboard Classical Music chart with several albums during Mr. Jessops tenure. He said he intended to remain active in music, including teaching, and hoped to spend more time with his family.

title: Francona Has Soft Spot for Yanks: Their Rivalry With Red Sox
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.  Terry Francona was acting like a passionate baseball fan, not the manager of the abysmal Philadelphia Phillies, when he bought tickets to see the Yankees and the Atlanta Braves in Game 4 of the 1999 World Series.

title: Fed Says Real Estate and Retailing Are Soft
description: The Federal Reserve on Wednesday presented a snapshot of an economy that is gradually slowing, weighed down by creeping inflation pressures and a more hesitant consumer.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about Indias energy consumption misstated the number of people in the country who rely on animal waste and firewood as fuel for cooking. It is about 700 million, not 700,000. (Go to Article)

title: The Lords of Dumbo Make Room for the Arts, at Least for the Moment
description: George Dombek pays rent on his 1,400-square-foot, light-filled studio at 20 Jay Street with his paintings, which lately focus on water towers and upside-down tin pails on posts.

title: Cathay Pacifics Profit Rose 72% Last Year
