description: HONG KONG  Cathay Pacific, the international air carrier based here, said Wednesday that its profit rose 71.8 percent in 2007 on booming growth in Asia, despite historically high oil prices.

title: Great Set of Wheels for Olympic Hopeful
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  From his lonely practice lane, a catwalk over a local gym and gymnastics facility, Dallas Robinson chases his dream of being an Olympic sprinter.

title: Australias Trade Deficit Approaches Record
description: Australia posted its second-largest trade deficit on record in January as imports rose and floods disrupted exports of coal. The shortfall widened to 2.72 billion Australian dollars ($2.5 billion) from a revised 1.94 billion in December, the Bureau of Statistics said.

title: As Shadows Approach, Its Time to Grow Up
description: Beware the Moores of England, Jim Glass writes in his notebook, bored stiff while listening to his history teacher describe the English landscape and weather. At the start of The Blue Star Jim is a 17-year-old high school senior. He has things other than schoolwork on his mind. He sits in class transfixed by the long hair of Chrissie Steppe as that hair cascades onto his history textbook. In the beguilingly crisp and unfettered language of Tony Earley, that hair conjures thoughts of a small, glossy animal curled and napping in the sun.

title: Police Guns Make Jarring Evidence at Detectives Trial
description: Sean Bells mother, Valerie Bell, spent her 52nd birthday in the third row of a chilly courtroom in Queens on Wednesday and watched in silence as a police sergeant held aloft the gun that is believed to have killed her son.

title: Our All-Knowing, Inner-Vibe, N.C.A.A. Tourney Expert Speaks Out
description: March is here, and madness will soon be upon us. PLAY caught up with Rob Weintraub, who previewed the N.C.A.A. tournament in "Main Event" for the March issue of PLAY, and got his thoughts on some of the story lines. Rob's passion is beyond question: Even if he didn't have a brand-new daughter, he would still be up at 2 a.m. watching the Big Sky tournament.

title: Boldface in Cyberspace: Its a Womans Domain
description: IT was another season of fashion runway shows and a group of friends, chatting about the revival of Halston, were reminiscing about their personal encounters with the designer. Candice Bergen shared how he had lent her a white mink bunny mask and strapless gown for Truman Capotes 1966 Black and White Ball. Liz Smith spoke of how cocaine had destroyed the man during the disco era. Joni Evans admitted to attending a party and gushing to Calvin Klein about how she adored his designs, only to realize that she was gushing to Halston.

title: The Mets From A to Z: One Fans Perspective
description: Matthew Silverman has been in mourning since Oct. 1, the day he observed two passings.

title: F.B.I. Investigates Missing G.O.P. Money
description: WASHINGTON  Hundreds of thousands of dollars are missing and presumed stolen from the chief fund-raising arm of House Republicans, according to party officials who described the findings of emergency internal audits.

title: Canada Seeks Clemency From Saudis
description: OTTAWA  The government will ask Saudi Arabia for clemency in the case of a 23-year-old Canadian who was convicted of murder and sentenced to death by beheading.

title: In the Bronx, Former Halls of Justice Will Soon Fill With Pupils
description: A 93-year-old South Bronx courthouse that has been designated a landmark but has been boarded up for years will become a charter school in the fall, officials said last week.

title: In Europe, Central Banking Is Different
description: FRANKFURT  On Jan. 21, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, abruptly canceled plans to travel to New York so he could stay in Washington to engineer the largest one-day reduction of interest rates in recent times.

title: Lesson of Defeat: Obama Comes Out Punching
description: CHICAGO  Senator Barack Obama woke up on Wednesday talking of his delegate lead and of taking the fight to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. But after defeats in two of the most populous states, he also sounded like a chastened candidate in search of his lost moment.

title: A Lily to Look Up To
description: Q. My clump of Cardiocrinum giganteum had flowers each of the last two summers in my northwest Connecticut garden. When is the best time to lift the bulbs and divide them?

title: Necklace Ascending a Staircase
description: THIS month, Justin Giunta plans to introduce two collections under his jewelry label, Subversive.

title: Judge Lectures Countrywide but Decides Not to Punish It in Texas Mortgage Case
description: HOUSTON (Bloomberg News)  The Countrywide Financial Corporation, the largest American mortgage lender, did not show bad faith in the handling of a Texas homeowners mortgage and will not be sanctioned merely for unprofessional and unethical conduct, a federal judge ruled on Wednesday.

title: Canadian Leader on Obama Leak
description: OTTAWA  Prime Minister Stephen Harper said on Wednesday that the leak of a Canadian diplomatic memorandum about Senator Barack Obamas position on Nafta was unfair to his campaign for the Democratic nomination and possibly illegal.

title: Trump Entertainment Loss Grows
description: Trump Entertainment Resorts, the casino company founded by Donald J. Trump, posted on Wednesday its biggest loss since emerging from bankruptcy in 2005.

title: Straying From Tradition, With a Touch of Individuality
description: There was an almost generic quality to the dancing presented by Flamenco Vivo Carlota Santana on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. Estilos Flamencos, one of two pieces in the program, could serve as a textbook for new students and relatively new audiences. (For the record, the Joyce audience responded with convincing excitement.) The suite of traditional dances, well staged by Zenn Ramos, suggested a crisp, friendly company style and occasional glints of individuality of a sort not often seen in the form.

title: Gunman Kills 8 in Attack on School in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM  A gunman entered a famous Jewish seminary in the heart of Jerusalem Thursday night, killing at least eight students and wounding at least nine others, three of them seriously, Israeli police said.

title: Earn $1 Million a Year? Assembly Democrats Will Seek a Tax Rise Just for You
description: ALBANY  If you earn a million dollars in New York this year, beware. Albany has its eyes on your money.

title: A Flawed Response in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Its Official: Party and President Back McCain
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain of Arizona was greeted here Wednesday as the new standard-bearer of a Republican Party he has sometimes battled, winning the endorsement of a president he has feuded with in the past and the embrace  and financial help  of the Republican National Committee.

title: New Device for Germophobes Runs Into Old Law
description: With so many people worried about getting sick  whether from the common cold and flu or exotic new strains of antibiotic-resistant bacteria  Paul and Jeffrey Metzger had every reason to hope that the germ-fighting key fob they invented would be a runaway hit.

title: National Gallery to Get a Wing in Maryland
description: The Baltimore County Council voted on Monday to permit the Baltimore philanthropist Robert E. Meyerhoff, a major collector of post-World War II art, to turn his home and galleries into a public museum and study center under the supervision of the National Gallery of Art. In 1986 Mr. Meyerhoff and his wife, Jane, now deceased, began donating and lending works from their collection to the gallery. The collection includes paintings by Willem de Kooning, Jackson Pollock, Richard Serra, Jasper Johns, Robert Rauschenberg,  Ellsworth Kelly and Roy Lichtenstein, among others. The museum, on a 250-acre farm, is to open after the death of Mr. Meyerhoff, who is 84, The Baltimore Sun reported.

title: St. Anthony Closes in on Title
description: Mike Rosario scored 19 points as St. Anthony of Jersey City, the No. 1-ranked boys basketball team in the country, beat No. 9 St. Patrick of Elizabeth, 64-52, for the North Non-Public B championship in Piscataway, N.J. If St. Anthony (29-0) defeats Trenton Catholic on Saturday in the Non-Public B final in Toms River, it will set a national record with its 25th state title. The Friars are tied with Central High School of Cheyenne, Wyo., with 24.

title: A Cheaper Test for That Sore Knee
description: A study released Wednesday suggests that you may not need a magnetic resonance image (M.R.I.) to tell you what's wrong with your creaky knees. Many physicians automatically order the expensive test for all patients with knee pain. But in the study, reported at the annual conference of the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons in San Francisco, researchers at the University of Illinois at Chicago found that a simple X-ray uncovered arthritis more reliably and at a fraction of the cost of an M.R.I.

title: District to Settle Bible Suit
description: A West Texas school district has agreed to change the curriculum for a high school course on the Bible to settle a lawsuit that said it amounted to religious indoctrination.

title: Online Pitches Made Just for You
description: ITS an offer you cant resist: fly to Honolulu for $200 round trip.

title: Carlyle Fund Misses Margin Calls
description: LONDON  A fund linked to the private equity firm Carlyle Group became the latest investment firm to run into trouble amid deteriorating credit markets when it said on Thursday that it failed to meet some margin calls and had received a notice of default.

title: At Hearings Tied to Killing of Dentist, Angry Stares
description: Stony glares and bitter words between two families again filled the halls of the Queens County Courthouse on Wednesday, as another member of a family was arraigned in a tangled murder case that has plunged an immigrant community in Rego Park into crisis.

title: Text Messaging Again? No, This Time Theyre Studying for a Vocabulary Exam
description: Those seeking further evidence of the relentless pace of electronic miniaturization should note the introduction of Franklins Speaking Spelling Bee, a cellphone-size multimedia game. If your eyes start to strain as you as thumb-out words like sovereign or erroneous on the two-inch screen, a video-out port lets you plug it into your TV.

title: In Trial, Alaska Says Lilly Concealed Risks of a Schizophrenia Drug
description: ANCHORAGE  Eli Lilly, the drug maker, systematically hid the risks and side effects of Zyprexa, its best-selling schizophrenia medicine, a lawyer for the State of Alaska said Wednesday in opening arguments in a lawsuit that contends the drug caused many schizophrenic patients to develop diabetes.

title: Fidelity to Pay U.S. to End Case Over Gifts
description: Days at Wimbledon. Nights at U2 concerts. Flights aboard the Concorde.

title: New Forum to Try to Improve Catholic-Muslim Ties
description: ROME  The Vatican on Wednesday announced a new Catholic-Muslim Forum to try to improve relations between the religions. The announcement came after a delegation of Muslim scholars met with members of the Pontifical Council for Interreligious Dialogue on Tuesday.

title: Pilot Fired Over a Low-Flying Salute
description: HONG KONG  A Cathay Pacific pilot has been dismissed for making a low-level airfield fly-by in January that the airline says was unauthorized.

title: The Obamas of the World
description: NYANGOMA-KOGELO, Kenya

title: Torrent in Colorado River Is Unleashed to Aid Fish
description: A torrent of water was released into the Colorado River from the Glen Canyon Dam in Arizona on Tuesday, in a disputed effort to improve the environment for fish in the Grand Canyon.

title: Idol Lends Life to Dead Detective
description: Television audiences preferred unscripted fare on Tuesday, as an hour of American Idol on Fox dominated the nights ratings and two hours of The Biggest Loser on NBC gained viewers every half-hour from 8 to 10 p.m. Fox hoped that the 28.2 million viewers of Idol would stay tuned for the premiere of New Amsterdam, and almost half did. The drama about an immortal New York homicide detective averaged 13.7 million viewers. On NBC, The Biggest Loser drew 7.2 million viewers in its first hour and 10.2 million viewers in its second. A repeat of Law & Order: Special Victims Unit delivered 9.4 million viewers, easily doubling the time periods average from last week, when the Internet series Quarterlife made an attempt at television. CBS started the night strong with 10.5 million viewers for a repeat of NCIS but lost traction at 9 with Big Brother (7 million). At 10, Jericho delivered 5.9 million viewers, a million fewer than the previous week. Sitcoms did not draw many viewers to ABC, ranking it fourth for the night, although a Primetime hidden-camera newsmagazine averaged 7.6 million viewers, making it the most popular program at 10 p.m.

title: To Feed the Birds, First Feed the Bugs
description: OXFORD, Pa.

title: Woman Due to Testify in 2 Cases Dies in Fall From Harlem Building
description: The police were investigating the death of a woman who was scheduled to testify in two Manhattan criminal cases but died in a plunge from a Harlem apartment building on Wednesday, the authorities said.

title: Leonard Rosenman, Composer for Films, Dies at 83
description: Leonard Rosenman, an Oscar-winning film composer who helped introduce avant-garde music to Hollywood movie scores, died on Tuesday in the Woodland Hills section of Los Angeles. He was 83 and a former Hollywood resident.

title: Esquire Publishes a Diary That Isnt
description: After Heath Ledger was found dead in his SoHo apartment on Jan. 22, David Granger, the editor in chief of Esquire magazine, dispatched a writer named Lisa Taddeo to report on the actors final days.

title: President Fails to Budge OPEC on Production
description: OPEC on Wednesday rebuffed calls from President Bush to increase oil output, instead citing mismanagement of the American economy as a major factor driving prices up.

title: For One Party, the Race Is Still On
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking Control of His Future
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Ian Kennedy was not the kind of kid who taped a strike zone to the side of a wall and threw at it all day long. He did not pester friends or family to catch him in the backyard. Kennedy loved to pitch, but there was no need to practice. He simply threw hard, and the ball went where he wanted it to go.

title: Cars Failed Inspection Costs Edwards Points
description: The stock car driver Carl Edwards, who punctuates each victory by doing a back flip off his car, was docked 100 points by Nascar on Wednesday because his winning Ford failed an inspection last Sunday. The penalty dropped him out of first place, to seventh, in the standings.

title: Oceans Unfruitful Stretches Multiplying
description: Relatively barren stretches of the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans around the tropics have expanded about 15 percent since 1998, according to a new satellite study. The studys authors said that the change could be temporary given the short period of observations but that it matches a slight but steady warming trend in the affected ocean regions and matches a pattern scientists have predicted would occur under global warming. The studys authors, from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the University of Hawaii, said warm surface waters tended to block upwellings of deeper, nutrient-filled water necessary to support plankton and other marine life. The Indian Ocean has seen similar changes but with a less measurable trend, they said.

title: Trump Vows Fight After Board Rejects Expansion of Jones Beach Plan
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y.  Donald Trump said on Wednesday that he would go to court for the right to expand a planned catering hall at Jones Beach to include a 26,000-square-foot basement to accommodate its kitchens, a proposal that was rejected the night before by a state code enforcement review board.

title: Under Pressure, Abbas Says Hell Talk Peace, but Actual Dialogue May Be Remote
description: JERUSALEM  After coming under heavy pressure from the United States, Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, said Wednesday that he intended to resume negotiations with Israel on a peace plan.

title: Remarks That Led to Hand-Wringing in Clinton Camp May Have Paid Off
description: It was a declaration that quickly became etched in the granite of conventional wisdom.

title: A Monstrous PC Gaming Rig Comes With a Nonthreatening Price Tag
description: Gaming PCs have long had hefty specs and even heftier price tags. But gaming beasts like the Dell XPS 630 are paving the way for new machines with impressive performance and impressively low prices.

title: Cyber-Rebels in Cuba Defy States Limits
description: HAVANA  A growing underground network of young people armed with computer memory sticks, digital cameras and clandestine Internet hookups has been mounting some challenges to the Cuban government in recent months, spreading news that the official state media try to suppress.

title: Drug Tied to China Had Contaminant, F.D.A. Says
description: WASHINGTON  Federal drug regulators said Wednesday that a critical blood thinner that had been linked to at least 19 deaths and whose raw components were produced in China contained a possibly counterfeit ingredient that mimicked the real drug.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article in some editions on Sunday about the American Cup gymnastics event at Madison Square Garden described incorrectly a vault performed by Shawn Johnson, the world all-around champion, who finished second in the womens competition. She completed a somersault and two and a half twists, not two and a half somersaults.

title: Gift to Teach Business to Third-World Women
description: Goldman Sachs & Company will donate $100 million to give at least 10,000 women a business education and, more broadly, to develop and enhance business education programs at universities in Africa, the Middle East and other developing regions, the firm announced Wednesday.

title: Yahoo Extends Nomination Time
description: Yahoo has amended its bylaws to give shareholders who want to nominate directors more time to do so, as it tries to buy time to explore alternatives to an unsolicited buyout offer from Microsoft.

title: Study Says Grand Canyon Older Than Thought
description: Coming upon the Grand Canyon long ago, an old prospector is supposed to have said in amazement, Something awful happened here.

title: Time Is Short for Japan to Name a Central Banker
description: TOKYO  At a time when global financial turmoil would seem to require a firm hand at the economic tiller, Japan is facing the uncomfortable prospect of having no leader at its central bank.

title: More Than One Revival in a Manhattan Ruin
description: IF the Manhattan apartment of Cynthia and Dan Lufkin, with its vaulted ceiling, arched windows and touches of gold leaf, is reminiscent of a church, that is because it was one  the chapel of the New York Cancer Hospital, built in the 1880s. The living room, which looks out on Central Park West between 105th and 106th Streets, has a 38-foot ceiling. The stenciling of the plaster walls was inspired by an English abbey.

title: Record Three Weeks Worth of Promises, for Playback After November
description: Its an election year, so miniature voice recorders are everywhere. While many of them can hold a few hours of political hot air, the Sony ICD-UX80 can hold more than three weeks worth.

title: Fashion Sees Its Shadow
description: Paris

title: Health Technology
description: To the Editor:

title: Floridas Theory of ...
description: Has Florida come to its senses over the teaching of evolution? Sound science appears to be winning the latest round, but the struggle isnt over.

title: No Parking Spot? Here Are About 142,000 Reasons
description: Why is it so hard to find a parking place in New York City?

title: Republican Quits Senate Race in New Jersey
description: TRENTON  Ever since Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, who is 84, made it clear that he intended to seek re-election in November, the conventional wisdom had been that health would be a factor in the race.

title: My Root Canal? Its a Blur
description: A MAN in a mask is wielding a drill that is so loud it makes you feel as if a bulldozer is plowing through your head.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about the religious disillusionment among young people in Iraq carried an incomplete list of reporting credits. In addition to three Iraqi reporters who contributed from Baghdad, where the article was written, Iraqi employees of The Times interviewed residents in Basra, Falluja, Baquba and Mosul.

title: On the Other End of the Line, Discipline
description: CLOSE your eyes, breathe deeply, and imagine yourself at your most well. What does it look like?

title: Education Sources on the Web
description: Several organizations and agencies that specialize in substance abuse and aging have recently added educational material on their Web sites regarding addiction among older adults. These include pamphlets, data and fact sheets, geared to the public, as well as technical assistance, new research and power-point presentations designed for professionals.

title: Janet Jackson Is No. 1
description: The new math of the music industry: Sell fewer albums but reach higher on the Billboard chart. Janet Jacksons new record, Discipline (Island Def Jam), sold 181,000 copies last week to reach No. 1, Nielsen SoundScan reported. Her last two opened at No. 2 but sold better; Damita Jo, released four years ago, had more than twice as many opening-week sales as Discipline. This weeks No. 2 album, Erykah Badus New AmErykah, Part One (4th World War) (Universal Motown), is also new. Ms. Badus first full album in eight years, it sold 124,000 copies. Jack Johnsons Sleep Through the Static (Brushfire/Universal), the top seller for the last three weeks, dropped to third place with 92,000. Savage Life 2 (Asylum) by the Louisiana rapper Webbie opened at No. 4 with 72,000, and Alicia Keyss As I Am (J) fell three spots to No. 5 with 57,000 sales.

title: Grand Old Protectionists
description: Washington

title: Those Lipitor Ads: Dr. Jarvik Makes His Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Special Report: Big Papi Infiltrates SportsCenter
description: When Hank Steinbrenner disparaged the notion of Red Sox Nation and told PLAY Magazine "this is a Yankee country" ("Oedipus Bronx," March 2), he sent another tremor along the New York-Boston fault line, with Red Sox owner John Henry playfully offering Steinbrenner a membership in Red Sox Nation and Steinbrenner declining. Virtually overlooked was his contention that the idea was promulgated by ESPN, which Steinbrenner said was "filled with Red Sox fans."

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 5, 2008

title: Talking Points
description: If you do seek out a wellness coach, keep in mind:

title: Footnote
description: Jazz at Lincoln Center announced on Wednesday the 2008 inductees into the Nesuhi Ertegun Jazz Hall of Fame in Frederick P. Rose Hall on Broadway at 60th Street. They are Ornette Coleman, Gil Evans, Bessie Smith and Mary Lou Williams.

title: In Balanced Movements, Clean, Spare Choreography
description: Studio spaces have their limitations, but one of the best things about Pam Tanowitzs Dream Sequence (No Secrets), shown at City Center Studio 5 on Tuesday night, was the way she and her production designer, Philip Trevio, made the space feel as if it was the only possible setting for the work.

title: Young Spinner of Silken Tones
description: Many current stars of the classical music world were chosen for Young Concert Artists Awards very early in their careers. Judging by her recital at Zankel Hall on Monday, the 21-year-old Japanese violinist Mayuko Kamio is standing on the gilded threshold.

title: Putting Some Fun Back Into 9 to 5
description: WORK, in its most traditional sense, is the antithesis of fun. As my grandmother used to say, when I complained about a boss or a deadline, Theres a reason they call it work.

title: Honoring Karen Carpenter With a Dollop of Boy George
description: Who would imagine that the steady, mildly wistful voice of Karen Carpenter would be anybodys muse, much less a primary inspiration for a supple Scottish tenor with Broadway credentials? But at Tuesdays opening-night performance of his three-week engagement at the Oak Room in the Algonquin Hotel, Euan Morton went out of his way to pay tribute to his idol, who died 25 years ago last month.

title: New Medium, Old Stories: A High-Tech Look at the Citys Black History
description: The teeming restaurant was called Downings Oyster House, and its 19th-century patrons were bankers, politicians and lawyers. But even as the swells did their deals upstairs, the proprietor, Thomas Downing, a free black man, presided over a far different scene in his basement, a hiding place for escaping slaves.

title: Russia: Opposition Figure Detained
description: A Russian opposition leader has gone on a hunger strike in St. Petersburg after being arrested before a march on Monday to protest the presidential election. Maxim Reznik, leader of the citys branch of Yabloko, a liberal opposition party, was detained on charges of insulting and fighting with police officers. The party called the charges ridiculous. A judge has ordered Mr. Reznik held for two months, an unusually harsh ruling. The election on Sunday was won by Dmitri A. Medvedev, a close aide to President Vladimir V. Putin.

title: Auxiliary Police See Parking Permit Cut as an Insult
description: One strategy the city has settled on to bring down the number of free parking permits is to take them away from auxiliary police officers. And that has drawn howls of protest from those unpaid and unarmed officers, who saw the placards as a rare perk in an often thankless  and always voluntary  job.

title: When Death (That Bowler-Hatted Gent) Comes Calling in Dreams
description: Back in 1992 I wrote in The New Yorker that it seemed the modern-dance master choreographer Paul Taylor had created his latest and probably worst work, Oz, in a deep sleep. Mr. Taylor wrote me a letter saying Not bad. B+ and signed it Paul zzz Taylor.

title: Border Counties Shortchanged in Immigrant Costs, Study Says
description: LOS ANGELES  Counties along the Mexican border from California to Texas are shortchanged millions of dollars a year in costs related to prosecuting and jailing illegal immigrants, according to a study released Wednesday.

title: Good News for Murcer
description: A biopsy of the former Yankees center fielder Bobby Murcer found scar tissue, not a recurrence of brain cancer, and he left the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston on Wednesday.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. How do I update my kitchen without spending the money to gut and remodel it?

title: Foundation Is Questioned After Memoir Is Exposed
description: The author who confessed this week to making up her memoir, Love and Consequences, about growing up as a foster child in gang-ridden South-Central Los Angeles, appears also to have made up a foundation that she claimed was helping to reduce gang violence and mentor urban teens.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about a decision to pursue perjury charges against a New York City engineer in connection with the deaths of two firefighters in the Bronx in 2006 misstated the number of inspectors hired by the Buildings Department in the past six years. It is 149, not more than 500. (The higher figure represents the total increase in staff over that time.)

title: Big Moynihan Station Plan Is Sputtering
description: In 1999, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan unveiled plans to transform the classical elements and monumental scale of the James A. Farley Post Office on Eighth Avenue into a gleaming new train station. It would be, he pledged, a return to an era of great public works.

title: House Approves Bill on Mental Health Parity
description: WASHINGTON  After more than a decade of struggle, the House on Wednesday passed a bill requiring most group health plans to provide more generous coverage for treatment of mental illnesses, comparable to what they provide for physical illnesses.

title: New Generation Gap as Older Addicts Seek Help
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  All is peaceful and orderly on the older adult unit at Hanley Center, where substance abusers over the age of 55 are spared the noisy swagger of addicts half their age across the campus.

title: As Players Gather in Detroit, a Look Back
description: The Spring North American Championships begin today in Detroit. The premier event is the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams. Last year in St. Louis the winners were Christal Henner-Welland, Bjorn Fallenius and Roy Welland of New York, Antonio Sementa from Italy and Cezary Balicki and Adam Zmudzinski from Poland. In the 64-board final they defeated Lou Ann ORourke of Scottsdale, Ariz.; Eric Greco of Philadelphia; Geoff Hampson and Marc Jacobus of Las Vegas; and Norberto Bocchi and Giorgio Duboin from Italy by 118 international match points to 103.

title: State Department Gives India a Deadline for a Nuclear Pact
description: NEW DELHI  A senior State Department official on Wednesday gave India a three-month deadline to complete negotiations on a landmark nuclear energy deal so that Congress could vote on the issue before its summer recess.

title: Blasts Kill at Least 54 in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  Two bombings killed at least 54 people and wounded 123 more in a bustling shopping district in the heart of Baghdad on Thursday evening, Iraqi authorities said.

title: Fine Dining Takes Small but Stellar Strides in Germany
description: LANGEN, Germany  A traditional ham-and-egg sandwich called a strammer Max costs about $6 or $7 at a local greasy spoon here. But at Juan Amadors restaurant the sandwich  along with a tube to sip a few drops of pork fat and smoked oil, followed by a quails egg swaddled in paper-thin dough  is part of a multicourse meal that runs about $240.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The TV Watch column, in some editions on Wednesday, about coverage of the presidential primaries on Tuesday night, misstated the year the war in Iraq started, a night on which MSNBC drew its highest rating until its broadcast of the Democratic debate last week. It was March 19, 2003  not 2002.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about Indias energy consumption misstated the number of people in the country who rely on animal waste and firewood as fuel for cooking. It is about 700 million, not 700,000.

title: Looking at the Math and the Map, and Hoping the Tide Can Turn
description: Now that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has shown that persistence pays off, with her comeback victories in the Ohio and Texas primaries on Tuesday, a new question immediately confronts her and her campaign: Can she persevere to ultimately win the nomination?

title: Frederick Seitz, Physicist Who Led Skeptics of Global Warming, Dies at 96
description: Frederick Seitz, a renowned physicist who led both the National Academy of Sciences and Rockefeller University and became a prominent skeptic on the issue of global warming, died Sunday in Manhattan. He was 96 and lived in Key West, Fla.

title: Smart Eating at Work  Part 1
description: In my last Shifting Careers column, I wrote about In Good Company Workplaces, an all-female, shared office space in Manhattan. When the founders gave me a tour of the space, they were especially proud of the spotless and well-organized kitchen where members can keep their food. The office offers free tea and coffee, and I noticed they also stocked Agave nectar, my sweetener of choice. I had another bout of workplace envy. It is relatively easy to eat good foods when you can control the choices, but how many times are we working somewhere and not in control of what we can eat?

title: A Superdelegates Dilemma
description: Tuesday was supposed to deliver clarity to the Democratic nomination battle. Instead, Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons victories in Ohio, Texas and Rhode Island  and the slowing of Senator Barack Obamas momentum  left the political waters as murky as ever. And some of the undecided superdelegates are as flummoxed as ever.

title: The June Benchmark
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has often responded to criticisms about the prolonged Democratic battle with a nod back to another Clinton campaign.

title: Look Out, Dennis Maruk
description: The Capitals Alex Ovechkin scored two more goals Wednesday night, bringing his season total to a league-leading 54, and nearing the lofty 60-goal plateau. With 14 games left in the regular season, Ovechkin is on pace for 65, which would surpass Washingtons single-season record of 60 held by the compact Dennis Maruk.

title: The Cathay Hotel: Penangs Magnificent Pile
description: There was no question: I couldnt leave Penang, Malaysia without spending at least one night at the Cathay Hotel. But it was completely booked. I begged, shamelessly. I showed up twice a day to chat up one or another of the elderly Chinese men who manned the marvelous, Art Deco front desk with its vintage square 1950s clock above. I even pulled out my secret weapon: I chatted them all up in Cantonese.

title: Blast Damages Times Square Recruiting Station
description: Latest Update, 10 p.m. | The police said the explosive device involved in the Times Square blast this morning was roughly similar to the devices used in two earlier bombings at foreign consulates in Manhattan, in 2005 and 2007, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said at an afternoon news conference . The device had been placed in an ammunition box like the kind that can be bought at a military supply store. Officials said that in todays attack, a man bundled in a gray hooded jacket or sweatshirt and wearing a backpack was seen riding a bicycle around the recruiting station and acting suspiciously moments before the explosion. Video footage from a surveillance camera showed a bicyclist dismounting, approaching the recruitment center, then returning to the bike and riding away before the explosion occurs. (See a related slide show and the latest from Fridays print edition.)

title: The real Mexican meal in Paris
description: France maybe be able to boast 300 kinds of cheeses and some 28 three star restaurants, but for a native Californian like me, the nation has long been a bone-dry desert for authentic Mexican food.

title: Would You Believe  3 Get Smart Trailers?
description: Todays Arts section reports Hollywoods big studios have found their cure for the surfeit of dour movies last fall and winter: a spring-summer comedy glut, including an adaptation of the 1960s TV cold-war spy comedy Get Smart. Since at least one Laugh Lines editor thinks Get Smart represents the best work Mel Brooks has ever done, please indulge us. There are at least three different trailers out illustrating how the film pays homage to trademark gags of the series. (Spoiler alert: You never know  These could be the best bits of the film.) Heres one trailer

title: Visions of Heaven Under the Big Top
description: As the Charles Mee season at the Signature Theater Company winds down, Paradise Park, the last, weightiest and darkest of the seriess three works, finally offers a glimpse into why the company thought his plays were worth staging, and why his resistance to any cogent structure remains so frustrating. The setting is an amusement park that is home to most of the characters, like a young man in a mouse costume and tourists who have never left, including an unhappy married couple and their teenage daughter. These people have found a refuge from the present in an anachronistic place of bumper cars, photo booths and dance halls.

title: Ziff Davis Media Seeks Bankruptcy
description: Ziff Davis Media, publisher of technology and video game magazines, filed for bankruptcy protection on Wednesday, citing a decrease in revenue from print advertising and subscriptions as contributing to its decline.

title: Trump Entertainment Loss Grows
description: Trump Entertainment Resorts, the casino company founded by Donald J. Trump, posted on Wednesday its biggest loss since emerging from bankruptcy in 2005.

title: Merrill Shuts Unit Making Home Loans
description: Merrill Lynch said on Wednesday that it would stop making subprime mortgages through its First Franklin Financial unit and would eliminate 650 jobs.

title: McGuireWoods to Merge With Helms Mullis
description: McGuireWoods, a Virgina-based law firm with 750 lawyers, has joined forces with North Carolinas Helms Mullis Wicker to form a 900-lawyer, 17-city firm.

title: Carrefour Rises on Stake Sale Chatter
description: Carrefour, the French retailer, posted a slight increase in 2007 profit and forecast faster growth in 2008 on Thursday while speculation that a major shareholder may increase its stake lifted its shares.

title: New Plankton-Seeding Venture Reaps $3.5 Million
description: Venture capitalists, it seems, havent entirely given up on trying to turn a profit by fertilizing the ocean with iron dust, despite the recent failure of such a start-up to stay afloat.

title: RingCentral Dials Up $12 Million
description: RingCentral, a start-up that allows small businesses to unify and manage their phone, mobile, fax and e-mail communications, said it had raised $12 million more in a second round of financing.

title: Where Men Are Stranded
description: Beau Willimons Lower Ninth, about three men on a roof above the floodwaters of Hurricane Katrina, has the intensity and the rickety structure of something thrown together in the passion of a moment. But the national outrage about Katrina is more than two years old, so immediacy cant stand as an excuse for the undigested themes or slapdash structure of this disappointing play at the Flea Theater.

title: Googles DoubleClick Deal Said to Receive E.U. Approval
description: European regulators plan to approve Googles proposed $3.1 billion takeover of DoubleClick without conditions, rejecting complaints by Microsoft that the deal would hurt competition, according to Bloomberg News.

title: Ladenburg Thalmann Buys Punk Ziegel
description: Ladenburg Thalmann Financial Services reached a deal to buy Punk, Ziegel & Company for an undisclosed amount, the investment bank said Wednesday.

title: Fidelity to Cough Up $8 Million to End Case Over Gifts
description: Days at Wimbledon. Nights at U2 concerts. Flights aboard the Concorde. And a dwarf to toss.

title: Goldman To Give $100 Million to Teach Women in Third World
description: In its biggest charitable act to date, Goldman Sachs, the worlds largest investment bank, presented a plan Wednesday to spend $100 million to teach business and management skills to 10,000 women across the globe.

title: Hedge Fund Vet Duff Hangs His Own Shingle
description: Phil Duff, co-founder of FrontPoint Partners and a former executive at Morgan Stanley and Tiger Management, opened his own hedge-fund firm Wednesday, using a $500 million investment from a private-equity firm.

title: Delta and Northwest Pilots Unions Said to Meet
description: Pilot union leaders at Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines met Wednesday in Washington, a hopeful sign that formal negotiations over integrating seniority lists to facilitate a combination of the two carriers could soon resume, according to The Associated Press.

title: Lehman Chief Rakes in $22.1 Million in 2007
description: Richard S. Fuld, Lehman Brothers chairman and chief executive, received compensation valued at $22.1 million in 2007, a year in which the company weathered the subprime mortgage collapse better than its rivals.

title: Buffett Beats Gates to Become Worlds Richest Person
description: Warren E. Buffett has beat his longtime bridge buddy Bill Gates to take the title as the richest person in the world with $62 billion to his name, according to Forbes annual ranking of the worlds wealthiest people.

title: Appaloosa Agrees to Extend Deadline on Delphi Deal
description: Delphi, the auto partsk maker, said on Wednesday that a hedge fund, Appaloosa Management, had extended a deadline on a planned equity infusion of $2.55 billion to give it more time to finance its exit from bankruptcy.

title: Is Al Gores I.P.O. a Bit Too Convenient?
description: Al Gores plan to hold a $100 million initial public offering for his cable company Current Media is generating some heat in BusinessWeek.

title: Hedge Funds Lock the Gates
description: With more hedge fun portfolios falling victim to the credit crunch, managers by the dozen are freezing investor redemptions, preventing a mad rush to the exits that would force funds to sell beaten-down assets to raise cash.

title: Expanding Deserts, by Land and Sea
description: Scientists have long projected that areas north and south of the tropics will grow drier in a warming world - from the Middle East through the European Riviera to the American Southwest, from sub-Saharan Africa to parts of Australia.

title: Microsoft Said to Hire Bear C.E.O. as Adviser in Yahoo Pursuit
description: Microsoft has brought in some muscle to help it clinch a deal for Yahoo The software maker has enlisted Bear Stearnss chief, Alan D. Schwartz, to advise it on the $42 billion deal, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: Ambacs Plan Disappoints Market
description: A bid to bolster the Ambac Financial Group, the troubled bond insurance company, fell flat on Wednesday, sending the companys stock tumbling 20 percent and disrupting the broader stock market.

title: Buyout Shops Said to Consider Trying Cavalli on for Size
description: Roberto Cavalli an Italian fashion group, is ready to sell a stake to a private equity fund in a move to finance its development.

title: Xstrata Tightens Grip on Resource Pacific
description: The Swiss mining company Xstrata increased its stake in Resource Pacific Holdings of Australia to 94 percent and has begun the acquisition process, as is compulsory under Australian law.

title: UBS Shares Fall Amid Fire-Sale Fears
description: Shares in UBS, the Swiss bank, fell on Thursday on speculation that it had sold a huge portfolio of risky mortgages at a deep discount and planned to announce another massive writedown in the first quarter.

title: Small Explosion in Times Square
description: Traffic was diverted for about two hours after what police described as an improvised explosive device damaged the armed forces recruiting station.

title: Margin Menace: Carlyle Fund Comes Up Short
description: A Dutch-listed affiliate of the Carlyle Group has not been able to meet some margin calls and has received a notice of default, it said on Thursday.

title: Big Names Line Up for Weather Channel
description: A half-dozen media companies have signaled that they plan to bid for the Weather Channel, which is up for auction, according to The New York Times.

title: A CSX Defenders Railroad Ties
description: When it comes to the rail system, it seems to be politics as usual.

title: Cafeteria Workers Take Protest to Wall Street
description: From our colleagues at City Room:

title: Swiss Bank Moves to Drop Suit Against Wikileaks Site
description: From our colleagues at Bits:

title: City Parking Placards Are Under Scrutiny
description: The top news in the city this morning is the small blast that damaged the army recruiting station in Times Square around 4 a.m. No one was injured, and subways and traffic are now running. City Room has all the details here and will continue with updates through the day.

title: Weather Channel Bids Due Friday
description: Andrew Ross Sorkin reports:

title: The Early Word: Delegates and Do-Overs
description: Those delegate calculators have been buzzing and buzzing since Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons wins on Tuesday rocked the landscape of the primary map going forward.

title: Denver Officials Ignore Marijuana Votes
description: Remember when Denvers voters decided back in November to make pot the citys lowest law-enforcement priority? The ballot measure joined another, passed in 2005, saying that residents had the right to carry less than an ounce of marijuana, leading to hopes that marijuana arrests were about to become a thing of the past in the Mile High City.

title: Penn Doesnt Feel the Love
description: Team Hillary was vindicated on Tuesday night, but according to The Washington Post, the campaign didnt exactly break out the cake and champagne yesterday (although the knives were a different story):

title: Sony's Digital S.L.R. Revolution
description: David Pogue takes Sony's Alpha A300 and A350 digital S.L.R.'s for a test drive.

title: Will Europe Let Google Out of the Penalty Box?
description: Googles year in the penalty box may be over.

title: Nascar Penalizes Driver for Cheating
description: Carl Edwards, winner of Sundays Sprint Cup race in Las Vegas, was docked 100 points on Wednesday because his car had failed a post-race inspection. He will also lose 10 bonus points should he make it into the Chase for the Cup, Nascars version of the playoffs. His crew chief was fined $100,000 and suspended for six races.

title: Private Equity to the Rescue?
description: As an affiliate of the Carlyle Group struggled Thursday with missed margin calls, DealBook presents this nomination for the quote of the day: Private equity is going to have a role to play in the recapitalization and restructuring of this industry.

title: Tech Support Gets a Reprieve While Users Take a Hit
description: On my blog recently (nytimes.com/pogue), I've been making fun of bad tech-support reps. Actually, not just recentlythey've been one of my favorite topics for years.

title: If Food Be the Music: Frache
description: As I dined cross-country for my ongoing series on great new restaurants, I was struck anew by how surprising the music in many restaurants is, or how closely it seems to reflect the very particular tastes of the chef or restaurateur whos running the show.

title: Another Russian Bomber Intercepted
description: For the second time in a month, American fighter jets scrambled to intercept a Russian bomber that flew close to a contingent of United States Navy ships at sea, including the aircraft carrier U.S.S. Nimitz. The fighters flew alongside the bomber until it was out of the area.

title: Can Karlo Be Saved?
description: Nicholas D. Kristof travels to the Nuba Mountains in Sudan, where a family struggles to save their infant boy.

title: Easter Time in Italy: Good Idea?
description: I hope to take a trip to Italy the weekend of Easter, specifically Venice, but I am concerned that many things will be closed and that getting around will be difficult. Do you have any advice ?

title: Global-Warming Payola?
description: All right, lets talk about the money.

title: The Housing Market: How Low Will It Go?
description: It could be a long way down to the bottom of the housing market.

title: Tech Support Gets a Reprieve While Users Take a Hit
description: On my blog recently (nytimes.com/pogue), Ive been making fun of bad tech-support reps. Actually, not just recentlytheyve been one of my favorite topics for years.

title: Recipe of the Day: Seared Steak
description: When I was growing up, my mother had a rotisserie, a kind of stovetop broiler (which, in theory, could also be used for spit-roasting, though it never did that very well). It broiled steaks perfectly. My broiler  and many others  isnt as effective. Thus for many of us, this is the best indoor method for searing a steak, and it works for pretty much any size.

title: Some Dreams Are Made of Smuggling
description: At the heart of Debra Ehrhardts one-woman show Jamaica, Farewell is a loopy, increasingly funny story about how she achieved her lifelong dream of coming to America by smuggling a million dollars in cash from Kingston, Jamaica, to Miami in exchange for a businessmans help in getting a visa.

title: Bears M&A Chief to Join Hedge Fund
description: Another highly placed Wall Street banker is jumping to a new job.

title: Obama Aide: Neither Candidate Ready for 3 a.m. Call
description: Updated As Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton prepares for an afternoon news conference here in Washington, where she is to be surrounded by military officers, her campaign has put up a YouTube moment that you can bet will be replayed over and over.

title: Did the Clinton Campaign Darken Obamas Complexion?
description: Obama fans are protesting a Clinton attack ad that seems to darken Obamas complexion, inviting calls of racism. Hes substantially blacker in the attack ad than he is in real life or in other videos. Factcheck.org, an indispensable site, investigated and concluded that the ad did indeed seem to be unusually dark. But it found that everything in the ad was dark, including Hillary. Apparently, its standard to run attack ads in dark hues, so Factcheck says that this was evidence more of negativism than of racism. Incidentally, I recommend signing up for Factchecks email notifications.

title: Growing Up With Miami on Her Mind
description: Like a washed-out photograph from a forgotten era Liberty City, a brisk coming-of-age story set in urban Miami of the 1970s, evokes a time and a place without the illumination of vivid details.

title: Love and Glare
description: (Rus)h features some of the slickest and most pointless high-tech work in New York theater today. Its a big shiny so-what of a show that with its multitude of swirling projections and video images, appears to have borrowed the aesthetic of CNNs Situation Room.

title: Now Screening | Exclusive Whitney Biennial Preview
description: In the latest offering from T: Online, we bring you exclusive access to the show everybody is talking about this morning  this years Whitney Biennial. We sat down with curators Henriette Huldisch and Shamim M. Momin to get their distilled view of the contemporary art of the past two years. The results of their pledge to look a little bit harder, and harness the organic and spontaneous art that often becomes institutionalized in typical museum settings, will be on view March 6 to March 23 at the Park Avenue Armory. Click here (or the video player below) for a preview of the plaster-coated sculpture of river debris by Charles Long, an installation entitled Divine Violence by Daniel Joseph Martinez and cast bronze body masks by Sherrie Levine.

title: Bucknells 40-Foot Prayer
description: We have an early front-runner for most unbelievable moment from the conference tournaments. Bucknell not only overcame a 17-point deficit in the second half and withstood three overtimes to beat Navy in the Patriot League tournament. The Bison won because John Griffin made a half-court shot at the buzzer to give them an 87-86 victory.

title: Coming F1 attractions at the IHT
description: I just wanted to check in to mention a few things to watch out for over the next week, as were so close to the beginning of the new season and it might be a time when readers wonder what will be happening in Formula One coverage at the IHT.

title: Are You Being Served?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Who Is Worth $1.15 Million a Month?
description: Its a good living if you can cut it.

title: Mmm  Pizza! (A Slice, but at What Price?)
description: Video

title: Dubai International Says It Takes Back Citi Comments
description: How does one say never mind in Arabic?

title: As Went Love Connection, So Goes Lingo.
description: Annul: a five-letter word for canceled.

title: Clinton Raises Millions Following Tuesdays Wins
description: It pays to win, evidently.

title: The Goat Pasture?
description: Sam Zell, the new owner of the Chicago Cubs and Wrigley Field, said last week that he might sell the naming rights to the historic ballpark. What do you think would be the best possible name?

title: Our All-Knowing, Inner-Vibe, N.C.A.A. Tourney Expert Speaks Out
description: Rob Weintraub has his opinions about the upcoming NCAA tournaments. Tell us yours.

title: A Year of Cashing Out
description: Dont despair, Bill Gates: You may have lost your position atop Forbess annual billionaires list, but you are No. 1 on another ranking this week: Vanity Fairs Windfall Report, a rundown of the 50 biggest American paydays of 2007 and the people who got them. The focus of the article is transactions  public offerings, mergers or even inheritances  that yielded cold, hard cash.

title: Some Old Favorites, and Stories, in Genoa
description: Genoa doesnt have the, ahem, difficult reputation Naples does, but if anything it has fewer American visitors. In the case of both cities, this is near-tragic; in the case of Genoa its unbelievable. Both are central cities of former kingdoms, and in both the evidence is plain to see. But in Genoa  reminiscent of the Barcelona of twenty years ago  much of the core of the ancient city remains intact, pleasant to visit and relatively ungentrified (thats changing of course).

title: Not Afraid to Knit in Public
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Cancer Funding: Does It Add Up?
description: Should cancer spending be focused on the most common cancers? Or the most deadly cancers?

title: For the Moment | Muchkins and Fashion Meltdowns
description: (Jessica Antola)

title: Mexico's $60 Billion Man
description: CNBC looks at Carlos Slim, the billionaire Mexican investor, who was just named the world's second richest human by Forbes.

title: Working Out at Harvard
description: How accommodating: Six times a week, Harvard kicks all the guys out of the Quadrangle Recreational Athletic Center at the request of the Harvard Islamic Society, reports The Boston Heralds Michael Graham.

title: The World's Richest Human
description: CNBC looks at Warren Buffett, the chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, who is the world's wealthiest human being, according to Forbes.

title: Now Showing | Jim Hodges
description: (Jim Hodges/CRG Gallery)

title: Lowe's Tries to Jump-Start Spring
description: Amid a sluggish economy, Lowe's is trying to stimulate sales by reminding consumers that Spring is just around the corner.

title: Tuesday Nights Victors: Clinton And CNN
description: CNN easily defeated the other cable news networks in ratings for primary election coverage on Tuesday night, particularly in the advertiser- friendly 25- to 54-year-old demographic.

title: Lowe's Aims to Jump Start Spring
description: Amid a sluggish economy, Lowe's is trying to stimulate sales by reminding consumers that Spring is just around the corner.

title: State Assemblyman Is Charged With Drunken Driving
description: Updated, 1:40 p.m. | Assemblyman Adam Clayton Powell IV, a Democrat who represents parts of Harlem and East Harlem and is a scion of one of New Yorks most prominent political families, was arrested early this morning in Manhattan on charges of driving while intoxicated, according to his lawyer and law enforcement officials.

title: CNN Also Claims a Tuesday Night Victory
description: CNN easily defeated the other cable news networks in ratings for primary election coverage on Tuesday night, particularly in the advertiser- friendly 25- to 54-year-old demographic.

title: All Was Going Just Perfectly, Until
description: Aired Wednesday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: I want to say congratulations to Senator John McCain of Arizona, who last night captured the Republican nomination for president. It was a great night for McCain. In fact, all was going just perfectly  until today, when President Bush endorsed him.

title: Mike Huckabees Long Goodbye
description: Jon Stewart on the aftermath of Super Tuesday II:

title: A Hunting Trip With Dick Cheney
description: Aired Wednesday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: John McCain, of course, won the Republican nomination. As a reward, he got a visit to the White House. Mike Huckabee finished second. His reward is a hunting trip with Dick Cheney. Goodbye, Mike.

title: Bugatti Supercar Now More Ridiculous
description: On Tuesday, Bugatti unveiled a limited-edition version of its Veyron supercar at the Geneva auto show. Could it be faster? Does it handle better? Is it even more streamlined to exceed the originals stated top speed of 253 miles an hour?

title: The Florida-Michigan Morass
description: Updated What to do about those Florida and Michigan outliers whose votes in January dont count because their states defied the national Democratic party and held early primaries? Those fat slates of discounted delegates  210 pledged delegates and 28 superdelegates in Florida and 156 pledged delegates and 25 superdelegates in Michigan  have become more and more valuable as the two Democratic candidates march neck-and-neck through this incredible, cliffhanging, elongated primary season.

title: Federal Charges in Online Prostitution Ring
description: Federal authorities have announced the arrests of four people accused of running an online prostitution ring that had clients in major cities from New York to Paris and took in more than $1 million in profits over four years. The ring was known as the Emperors Club VIP and had 50 prostitutes available for appointments in New York, Paris, Washington, Miami and London, according to a federal complaint issued in United States District Court in Manhattan.

title: Al Gores Big Investment
description: His bid for the presidency didnt pan out, but financially speaking, the past eight years or so have apparently been good ones for Al Gore.

title: Get Well Wishes For Bobby Murcer
description: Bobby Cox and Bobby Murcer were teammates on the 1969 Yankees, which was Coxs last of two years as a major leaguer. Since Murcer recently underwent a biopsy to determine if he had a recurrence of brain cancer, Cox, the manager of the Atlanta Braves, sent his friend an interesting get-well gift: an autographed picture from Tiger Woods.

title: New Yorkers See a Threat in Global Warming
description: A large majority of people in New York believe that global warming is happening because of human activities, and more than two-thirds think that parts of the city will even have to be abandoned over the next 50 years because of rising sea levels, according to survey results released this morning by Columbia and Yale Universities, which called the research the first comprehensive study of opinions from residents of the five boroughs about global warming.

title: Nevada Health Threat: A Clinics Re-used Needles
description: Ricin, that exotic poison beloved by authors of whodunits, grabbed all the attention when several vials of it were found in an extended-stay hotel in Las Vegas last week. Indeed, a man lies unconscious in a hospital there, presumably as a result of exposure to ricin.

title: Lehman Suspends Two Equity Traders in London
description: Lehman Brothers suspended two London-based equity traders after some of their trades were picked up by the banks internal control system, a spokeswoman said.

title: Syms and the Future of Sarbanes-Oxley
description: The Sarbanes-Oxley Act has many detractors. They claim that the Act is an over-burdensome piece of regulation, one that has imposed costly and unneeded obligations on issuers. It has driven U.S. companies to exit the public markets and go private, and it has deterred non-U.S. companies from raising capital and listing in the United States.

title: Immigration Agency Learns From 07 Raid
description: What a difference a year makes  or does it?

title: Obamas Money (Not to Be Outdone)
description: CHICAGO  With Hillary Rodham Clinton reporting her impressive fund-raising after Tuesdays primary, Senator Barack Obama chose to report today that he raised $55 million during the month of February, breaking the previous one-month fund-raising record of $44 million that was set in March 2004 by Senator John Kerry. The number essentially confirms earlier reports about his impressive fund-raising for the month.

title: Vice Presidential Tea Leaves and a Dig at Obama
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  After Senator John McCain campaigned here Thursday morning with Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida  one of his many oft-mentioned possible running mates  Mr. McCain pointed out to reporters that the governor had committed to serve the State of Florida when he ran to be governor of the State of Florida.

title: Developer Wants U.N. for His Proposed Tower
description: The United Nations, which has long sought to renovate the Secretariat building on First Avenue and build a new office building, is considering a move to a proposed tower at a development site along the East River that is wending its way toward final approval by the city.The project is owned by the developer Sheldon H. Solow, who hopes to persuade the City Council to grant his $4 billion project final approval next week. The project, which includes seven glass towers along First Avenue, between 35th and 41st Streets, has come under criticism from community groups and Councilman Daniel R. Garodnick who contend that the buildings are too big and have urged the developer to eliminate the sole office tower from what they say is a residential neighborhood. The six other buildings are apartment houses.

title: Alaia: Form and Filigree
description: Before the Paris collections ended, I stopped by Azzedine Alaias place to see what he was preparing for fall. I found him upstairs in the studio, which consists of many racks of samples and dress patterns, stacks of shoe boxes, ironing boards and, at the far end, near a huge mirror, his ample work table. Alaia offered me a chair next to the table. A number of writers had trooped by over the weekend and we probably all had the same thought: Gee, what a fantastic way to look at clothes.

title: Alaia: Form and Filigree
description: (Photo: One of several styles in printed calf skin that Azzedine Alaia designed for fall. (Photo: Jean-Luce Hur for The New York Times) )   Before the Paris collections ended, I stopped by Azzedine Alaias place to see what he was preparing for fall. I found him upstairs in the studio, which consists of many racks of samples and dress patterns, stacks of shoe boxes, ironing boards and, at the far end, near a huge mirror, his ample work table. Alaia offered me a chair next to the table. A number of writers had trooped by over the weekend and we probably all had the same thought: Gee, what a fantastic way to look at clothes.   Alaia had made a runway out of a path between some dress racks. The first thing he showed me was a violet-gray wool coat that was snug through the waist and then opened to a skirt of tubular-like pleats. Each pleat was formed by an arch of stitches at the top. Its intriguing that a number of designers have shown rounded shapesAlexander McQueen, Marc Jacobs (the ribbing and necklines at Vuitton), the fellows at 6267, with their fluted leather collars. Alaias coat suggested to me Moorish architecture. A knit jacket in pinkish beige wool had a high rolled collar and dolman sleeves; the flaring skirt was ribbed and ruched in places. The outfit was all a knit, as were sleeveless tops and matching skirts that combined sheerness and curly bands of wool.   What Alaia is able to do with knitting is remarkable. He produces ruffles and poodle curls that look like lace. The skirt of one outfit, in a boiled black knit, consisted of vertical rows of overlapping circles, like sugar cookies arranged on a buffet tray. And all of these effects are a technical extension of recent work, like the pleated caterpillar dresses worn at last years Costume Institute party by Stephanie Seymour and Naomi Campbell, and the new crinkled cotton shirt dresses for spring that use embroidery anglaise.   Slide Show: Azzedine Alaia

title: Londons Watching
description: LONDON  If the United States is mesmerized, and excited, by the primary races, so is England.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Thursday, Mar. 6:

title: Clinton and Obama on Radio in Wyoming
description: When Republicans in Wyoming moved their caucuses to Jan. 5, the states Democrats held back. And now, even though their contest is much later in the game, on Saturday, Democrats are getting perhaps more attention than the Republican contest did.

title: Tracking Cellphone Driving Laws
description: New Jersey recently strengthened a law banning cellphone use while driving, and police there reportedly are already handing out tickets. I drive a lot in New Jersey and wasnt aware of the law change until a friend pointed it out to me.

title: Shelley Ross Departs CBS; Rick Kaplan to Oversee Early Show
description: Shelley Ross, the hard-charging morning television producer who joined The Early Show on CBS just last September, is leaving the network.

title: Scent Notes | Aqva Pour Homme Marine by Bulgari
description: Bulgaris new masculine, Aqva Pour Homme Marine, which has been on the market for a few weeks, carries two fingerprints. The first is of its creator, Jacques Cavallier, a prolific perfumer so successful these days that he often seems to generate a quarter of each years worldwide fragrance product. The second is the unmistakable scent of a molecule, methylbenzodioxepinone, also known to the trade as Calone. Cavallier, plucked it from the crowd and cast it in starring roles in several of the biggest commercial successes the perfume industry has ever seen. It virtually defined perfume style in the 1990s. Whether Bulgari is making a wise choice in launching an updated 90s scent in 2008 is another question.

title: Guns n Pampers
description: Actually, this isnt too far from reality: a parody ad for a collection of kids songs interpreted by famous bands and singers:

title: Wolfson: Obama a Starr
description: The fight is over Hillary Clintons refusal to release her tax returns, and I dont think anybody whos been following the Democratic campaign closely could fail to guess the author of this quote (courtesy of the Politico):

title: The Name of the Game Is Domain
description: The Caucus blog reports the presidential election has triggered an avalanche of cybersquatter activity, featuring Republicans and others puckishly snapping up domain names:

title: Is There a Killer Stove in Your Kitchen?
description: For about a year now, consumer groups have been waging a war against killer stoves.

title: A Satirical Video One Shining Moment Shy
description: The whole point of a headline on the Web is to earn a click, but this one did much more: One Shining Moment for Republicans.

title: R.N.C. Snaps Up Domain Names
description: Cannotrustclinton.com? clintonisbad.com? At least 25 domain names related to Hillary Rodham Clinton have links to the Republican National Committee: the names were either registered by the R.N.C. last year or showed up on servers the committee uses. Half a dozen seemed to guess at Mrs. Clintons eventual running mate, like clintonomalley.com, referring to Gov. Martin OMalley of Maryland.

title: The In Box That Wants You in a Box
description: Whoever posted this guesses the book in question is Killing Yourself to Live by Chuck Klosterman.

title: New Yorkers and Climate Change
description: City Room has an interesting post up on some fresh polling examining New Yorkers concerns on climate and energy.

title: Podcast: Oh, Brotherhood, Its Complicated
description: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

title: You Could Hear the Enamel Cracking
description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

title: 'J'Entends Plus la Guitare'
description: A. O. Scott reviews "J'Entends Plus la Guitare," a remake about a tumultuous love affair.

title: Soft Serve | Fashion Granola, Secret Tunnels, Cell Phone Condoms
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: Javits Directors Dismayed Over Shelved Expansion
description: Even directors of the Jacob K. Javits Development Corporation are unhappy about the states recently revamped plans for the convention center. A number of directors forcefully expressed their unhappiness Wednesday morning  at the corporations first board meeting since April 18, 2007  with how tens of millions of dollars had been spent and how the state arrived at its decision to scuttle a long-awaited expansion plan.

title: Runway Finale Breaks Ratings Record for Bravo
description: Thursdays season finale of Project Runway on Bravo drew an average of 3.75 million viewers in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic, topping two of the three broadcast networks (ABC and CBS) at 10 p.m.

title: Pretty in Pink with Pudracar
description: As a traveler, you know the anxiety of arrival. New in town, and shining like a euro penny to anyone ready to take advantage, you plan to catch a cab, but worry that the meter might be broken, or that the driver will take the long way around, by a matter of, oh, several miles.

title: Wednesday Nights Truth: More Viewers, Fewer Confessions
description: When a wife admits on television that she cheated on her husband, as a contestant did on Foxs The Moment of Truth last week, its bound to attract some attention. It is perhaps unsurprising, then, that the lie detector show  without the tense confessions this time  delivered 15 million viewers on Wednesday night, its best performance in a month.

title: Podcast: Election Veto Exposes a Shiite Rift
description: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

title: Rococo: The Continuing Curve
description: Images from the show at the Cooper Hewitt, National Design Museum.

title: Paris Memories | Friends of The Moment
description: Last week The Moment invaded Colette, Pariss chic fashion/gadgets/books/beauty boutique, and along the way we met some fabulous nobodies and A-list friends  Kanye West, Anna Wintour, to name drop a few. As a final au revoir to our Paris pals, we present a slide show of memories.

title: Jack Ruby Comment Stirs Up Bell Case
description: A man standing outside the courtroom where three detectives are on trial in the shooting of Sean Bell made a reference to the murder of Lee Harvey Oswald when the detectives passed by today, a court officer said.The man was heard saying, Jack Ruby will be back. Bang, bang, bang, according to Dennis W. Quirk, president of the New York State Court Officers Association.

title: Fla. Senator to D.N.C.: Pay for a New Primary
description: Updated Senator Bill Nelson, Democrat of Florida and supporter of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, today called for the national Democratic party to either seat the delegates from the January contest or pay for another primary to be held in the Sunshine State.

title: Trade Talks
description: Ross Perot must have been proud. As Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton campaigned across Ohio last week, staking their candidacies on which of them is more strongly opposed to opening trade markets between the United States and the rest of the world, Mr. Perot might as well have been playing ventriloquist.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Snow Angels'
description: A. O. Scott reviews "Snow Angels," directed by David Gordon Green.

title: The Chainsaw and the Butterfly
description: The Transvolcanic Mountains of central Mexico contain about 60 square miles of forests of oyamel fir and pine which for thousands of years, biologists believe, have provided a winter haven for monarch butterflies that migrate there from eastern North America.

title: Bill Clinton Heads to Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA  One of the first skirmishes of Pennsylvanias presidential primary is set to take place here Friday, when the campaigns of Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama vie for the endorsement of this citys ward leaders.

title: Color as Field: American Painting
description: Images from the show at the Smithsonian American Art Museum.

title: One Month to Go to the Playoffs
description: April 6 is the last day of the 2007-8 regular season. The playoffs begin April 9. Heres something to ponder:

title: Under Apples Watchful Eye, Games and Business Applications
description: Think of Apple as the Singapore of the technology world. It is impeccably clean, very functional, supportive of capitalism  and ruthless with miscreants.

title: 'Last Acts'
description: An excerpt from "Last Acts" by Jake Heggie at the Houston Grand Opera.

title: The Switch
description: Agnes Boulard, known as Mademoiselle Agnes on a popular French television series about fashion, did not get home until 7 oclock on Sunday morning. She had been out dancing. By the time of the Lanvin show, she was remarkably changedas Anna Wintour. Lots of people in the moments before the show assumed that Mlle Agnes was Madame Wintour. She had on a fur coat and dark glasses and looked ready for the models to get moving. The give-away was that the figure in the front row did not have a posse of Vogue editors around her. Its hard being Anna, Boulard said, lowering her shades. (I just didnt believe it was her.) She and her Canal+ collaborator Loic Prigent, who made that great documentary about Marc Jacobs, do an irreverent segment called Signe Anna, or signed Anna, for their show.

title: More electability
description: And now Survey USA, which has covered itself with glory this primary season  often at odds with everyone else, and right each time. Their national matchups now show Obama gettiing 280 electoral votes, Clinton getting 276; a slight edge for Clinton in popular vote.

title: Backgrounder: Zimbabwe's Election
description: A look at the leading candidates in Zimbabwe's Presidential election, including Robert M. Mugabe, ruler of Zimbabwe since its inception, and Morgan Tsvangirai, the opposition leader.

title: Meanwhile, on a happier note
description: Soothing news of market panic (well, I find it more soothing than politics, anyway):

title: Leadership Change in Zimbabwe?
description: Robert M. Mugabe, ruler of Zimbabwe since its inception, might finally be about to lose his grip on power.

title: Cyprus one of few bright spots cited in annual Europe study
description: Hows this for a grabber: 2007 will probably go down in history as the year that the great European house price boom ended.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Knights in Shining T-Shirts
description: Remember the days, before the coming of titling systems, when opera buffs felt free to ignore all the convoluted plots and librettos and just bask in the music? Mark Morriss unabashedly fanciful production of Purcells King Arthur, which opened the spring season at the New York City Opera on Wednesday night, offers audiences a throwback to those times.

title: Employment Falls for Second Month
description: WASHINGTON  The worst fears of consumers, investors and Washington officials were confirmed on Friday, as deepening paralysis on Wall Street collided with stark new evidence of falling employment and a likely recession.

title: Gunshots Underneath a Gray Sky
description: The first half of David Gordon Greens Snow Angels unfolds in the looming shadow of an awful tragedy. The audience knows something bad is coming because of the gunshots at the end of the opening scene, after which we are pulled back to a series of events beginning weeks earlier. But even without this framing device, it would be hard to mistake the mood of dread, defeat and lurking violence.

title: Rock n Roll Camp
description: Young women find expression for more than their music in Girls Rock!, a jubilant documentary about a place where power chords and empowerment go hand in hand.

title: Mathematics Explains Mysterious Midge Behavior
description: Heres a place thats unlikely ever to be a vacation spot for Yankee pitcher Joba Chamberlain: Lake Myvatn, in Iceland.

title: Free Parking
description: For decades, parking passes have been distributed too freely to New York City workers, many of whom abused the privilege to leave their cars, penalty-free, almost anywhere. Mayor Michael Bloomberg is right to vow to take the passes away from city workers who view what should be a rare perk as an entitlement.

title: Weightless Color, Floating Free
description: WASHINGTON  Starting in the late 1950s the great American art critic Clement Greenberg only had eyes for Color Field painting. This was the lighter-than-air abstract style, with its emphasis on stain painting and visual gorgeousness introduced by Helen Frankenthaler followed by Morris Louis, Kenneth Noland and Jules Olitski.

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about reaction among Gaza residents to a weekend military incursion by Israel misstated the death toll in some editions. The number of Palestinians killed in the weekend operation was nearly 100  not 126, which is the number of Palestinians killed in Gaza by Israeli military operations since an increase in the conflict began on Feb. 27. (A front-page Inside summary repeated the incorrect number.) Because of an editing error, the article also misstated a slogan painted on an Internet cafe. It was Word Without Borders, not World Without Borders.

title: Tunneling Thieves Strike a Lode of Loot (and Valuable Smut)
description: The workmanlike title The Bank Job is a nice fit for this wham-bam caper flick. Efficiently directed by Roger Donaldson from a busy script by Dick Clement and Ian La Frenais, it fancifully revisits the mysterious whos and speculative hows of a 1971 London vault cleanout on Baker Street labeled the walkie-talkie robbery. (The thieves squawked on the airwaves like crows.) It was headline news and, then, with a wave of the official wand, it was hush-hush. Thats one story, anyway.

title: Mexicos Congress Passes Overhaul of Justice Laws
description: MEXICO CITY  Mexicos Senate gave final approval on Thursday to a historic overhaul of this countrys often-foggy criminal justice system, introducing oral trials in which lawyers will argue cases before judges and the public can see the evidence.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 23 about molecules used to make perfumes misstated the length of patents in the United States. It is 20 years, not 17. The article also misidentified the makers of two perfumes and misspelled the name of one of the perfumes. Polo Blue from Ralph Lauren is made by International Flavors and Fragrances, and Acqua di Gio (not Aqua di Gio) from Armani is made by Firmenich. Neither are made by Givaudan. The article also misstated the proprietary status of Amber Ketal, a scent used in both perfumes. It was no longer under patent when it was used in those two fragrances. (Go to Article)

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: A Parallel Path Connects Murcer With New Friends
description: When Bobby Murcers brain biopsy found no recurrence of cancer on Tuesday, Jay Larkin told me, Thank God, thank God, thank God. There was great caring and relief in his voice for a man he has never met. But he feels their lives are intertwined.

title: Spare Times
