description: AROUND TOWN

title: Democratic Fund-Raisers Trial Starts in Illinois
description: CHICAGO  A prosecutor on Thursday described Antoin Rezko, a businessman and political fund-raiser, as the man behind the curtain, pulling the strings in an influence-peddling scheme to extort millions of dollars from companies that wanted to do business with the State of Illinois.

title: In Times Square Blast, Echoes of Earlier Bombings
description: The British Consulate in 2005. The Mexican Consulate last year. And on Thursday, the Times Square military recruiting station.

title: Killington Resort
description: Updated: December 2008

title: As the Snows Melt, Lowes Encourages Spring Thinking
description: ANOTHER major advertiser is placing a big bet on its ability to cajole wary consumers into behaving as if gasoline prices were not climbing, housing values were not falling and the stock market was not gyrating.

title: Congress Questions Executives on Pay
description: WASHINGTON  Three prominent financial executives faced questioning from a House committee on Friday about the huge paydays that they earned from the subprime mortgage boom, even as their companies have lost billions of dollars and thousands of borrowers have lost their homes.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about a study that concluded that counties along the Mexican border are being shortchanged in costs related to prosecuting and jailing illegal immigrants gave an incorrect address for the Web site that posted the report. It is bordercounties.org.

title: Shattered Glass and Rattled Nerves Outside the Blast Site
description: The attack took just a few minutes. Times Square was aglow in the morning darkness but nearly deserted as a shadowy figure on a bicycle pedaled in and planted a small bomb that shattered the glass facade of the military recruiting station on Broadway just north of 43rd Street.

title: The Dakota Mountain Lodge and Luma
description: The Dakota Mountain Lodge

title: Roddick and Connors Part Ways
description: Andy Roddick split with his coach, Jimmy Connors, ending a 19-month relationship. Roddick, the worlds sixth-ranked player, whose 24 singles titles include the 2003 United States Open, announced after defeating Rafael Nadal in the quarterfinals of the Dubai Open on Thursday that he and Connors had severed ties. Roddick said Connors resigned. Roddick, 25, said the timing and logistics of his schedule made it difficult to work with Connors on a part-time basis.Roddick was ranked 10th in the world when he began working with Connors in July 2006. He rose as high as third in the world rankings under Connors.

title: Hoping to Earn a Diploma
description: SALLIE MAE is flunking on Wall Street.

title: An Ansel Adams Trove Is Scheduled for Auction
description: An Ansel Adams Trove

title: On Election Eve, Hazy Prospects for Malaysia Premier
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Public protests are frowned on by Malaysias mildly authoritarian government and often broken up by the riot police. So when a group of opposition party members and activists wanted to send a message to Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi earlier this year they chose a softer and safer alternative  delivering a pillow to his office.

title: Heard the One About the Farmers Ethanol?
description: After motherhood and apple pie, energy independence probably qualifies as the most popular political slogan in the land. It is, as they say, a no-brainer. Robert Bryce agrees: You have to have no brain to think it is possible or even desirable.

title: Nobel Winner Retracts Research Paper
description: A team of scientists including Linda B. Buck, who shared the 2004 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, has retracted a scientific paper after the scientists could not reproduce their original findings.

title: Barbara Cook, Scampering and Swinging on the Edge of Jazz
description: Unless you are under a doctors orders not to get too excited, who would disagree with the chipper title of Barbara Cooks lighthearted new Caf Carlyle show, Love Is Good for Anything That Ails You? The title, taken from the mid-30s swing tune by Cliff Friend and Matt Malneck that was sung by Bernadette Peters in the movie Pennies From Heaven, defines the tone of a program in which the balance between far-sighted introspection and good-time gal tilts toward the rollicking side. Less than one-third of the material in the show is held over from her recent Avery Fisher Hall concerts.

title: On Floridas Gulf Coast, the South Is Still the South
description: AS you glide through the waters of Wakulla Springs State Park in Florida on a small sightseeing boat, the vibe is pure country. The spring air is a perfect 65 degrees, and the only creatures sunning themselves waterside are turtles, jet-black anhinga birds and a series of listless alligators. Everything about this tucked-away treasure of a nature preserve  home to a 125-foot-deep spring basin ringed with bald cypress trees that drip with boas of Spanish moss  feels more like the Louisiana bayou than a corner of the Sunshine State.

title: Japans Bank Keeps Rate Unchanged
description: TOKYO (Bloomberg News)  The Bank of Japan kept interest rates steady Friday at the final board meeting of the governor, Toshihiko Fukui, on concern that economic growth was slowing.

title: New Museum in Madrid
description: A new museum of contemporary art, the CaixaForum, has opened in Madrid near the Prado, the Reina Sofa and the Thyssen-Bornemisza museums, The Art Newspaper reported. Financed by the Caixa Foundation, the philanthropic arm of the Spanish bank Caixa dEstalvis, the $94 million museum, above, was designed by the Swiss architects Herzog & de Meuron. A wall of the square in front of the building has an 80-foot vertical garden designed by the botanist Patrick Blanc that features 15,000 plants of 250 species. Artists represented in its opening show, running through April 6, include Cindy Sherman, Anselm Kiefer and Georg Baselitz.

title: Tradition or Fluff? A Dog Show Wrestles With Its Image
description: BIRMINGHAM, England  Perhaps you believe that a legitimate dog-show competition should not include an event in which a middle-aged lady sashays moodily alongside her dog to the Irene Cara anthem What a Feeling while wearing a John McEnroe-style headband and pink leg warmers.

title: Maryland Coach Returns With 2 New Fans
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  Coach Brenda Frese stepped ever so slowly around the Greensboro Coliseum basketball court Wednesday night as Maryland prepared for the Atlantic Coast Conference womens tournament. Two and a half weeks after giving birth to twins and still recovering, Frese is nevertheless back in time to lead the Terrapins into a postseason filled with hope and expectations.

title: Playing by Clinton Rules
description: Barack Obama had a theory. It was that the voters are tired of the partisan paralysis of the past 20 years. The theory was that if Obama could inspire a grass-roots movement with a new kind of leadership, he could ride it to the White House and end gridlock in Washington.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about news media coverage of the presidential campaign paraphrased incorrectly from a letter that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton sent to MSNBC after it suspended one of its correspondents, David Shuster, for making an off-color remark about Chelsea Clinton. Mrs. Clinton said in the letter that no temporary suspension or half-hearted apology is sufficient. She did not specifically call for the network to fire Mr. Shuster.

title: A Year Later, a Deadly Fire Is Recalled
description: The big red brick house on Woodycrest Avenue is empty now. Neighborhood cats have taken to sunning themselves on the porch, but the children who played outside in their bare feet in past winters have all gone.

title: For Fox, Cheating Pays
description: When a wife admits to cheating on her husband, as a contestant on an episode of the Fox series Moment of Truth did last week, its bound to attract some attention. It is perhaps unsurprising, then, that the lie-detector show  without the tense confessions this time  delivered 15 million viewers on Wednesday night, its best performance in a month. Combined with 28 million viewers for American Idol, Fox easily placed first for the night. NBC finished in second with 9 million viewers for Deal or No Deal and 9.6 million for Law & Order. CBS ranked third, with a lukewarm 5.7 million for Big Brother but a stronger 9.2 million for Criminal Minds and 8.6 million for CSI: NY. ABC finished fourth. At 10 p.m. the season finale of Project Runway on Bravo averaged 3.7 million viewers in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, topping ABC and CBS in that group for the hour.

title: Gusher of Lies
description: The Persistent Delusion

title: New at Lincoln Center
description: Lincoln Center Theater has officially announced a new program dedicated to producing the work of emerging playwrights, directors and designers. The program, called LCT3, will begin this fall with two productions at the Duke Theater on 42nd Street. Plans are in the works to build a 99-seat theater in or near Lincoln Center, which would be a permanent home for LCT3; until then the series will be presented each year at an off-site theater. The first production will be Clay, a one-man hip-hop musical written and performed by Matt Sax and directed by Eric Rosen. Clay will begin a five-week engagement in October. The Roundabout Theater Company began a similar program last year with the Roundabout Underground series in its new 65-seat space below the Laura Pels Theater.

title: For the Record
description: A letter online on Feb. 24 stated that a two-year study by If Americans Knew  from Sept. 29, 2000, to Sept. 28, 2001, and in 2004  of The New York Timess coverage of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict discovered that the newspaper had covered Israeli childrens deaths at a rate seven times greater than it reported on Palestinian childrens deaths. This study examined headlines or first paragraphs of news articles.

title: Grand Canyon Still Grand but Older
description: Coming upon the Grand Canyon long ago, an old prospector is supposed to have said in amazement, Something awful happened here.

title: Apple to Encourage iPhone Programmers
description: CUPERTINO, Calif.  Steven P. Jobs, Apples chief executive, is hoping to expand the iPhones appeal by luring software developers to create programs for it.

title: Effort to Overturn Emissions Decision
description: Two Democrats introduced a bill that would overturn the Environmental Protection Agencys decision to block California from issuing its own standard for automotive carbon emissions. Representatives Peter Welch of Vermont and Brad Sherman of California introduced the measure, which would grant California its waiver and also allow 12 other states to put those standards in place. Similar legislation has been introduced in the House. The E.P.A. ruled Dec. 19 that states are barred from regulating carbon emissions because a bill signed by President Bush seeks cuts in heat-trapping gases through mileage standards.

title: A Mans 6-Pack Can Serve as His Castle
description: HOUSTON  From his front porch, John Milkovisch was able to see the beer truck heading for the local grocery, spurring him into action. Hed run over there and clean them out, recalled his son Ronald. He never had less than 8 to 10 cases stacked up in the garage.

title: Loggers Invaded Butterfly Haven, Photos Show
description: Illegal loggers have chopped their way deep into unique forest reserves in a mountain range in central Mexico where millions of monarch butterflies from eastern North America roost for the winter, according to researchers who posted satellite photographs of the area on a NASA Web site Wednesday evening.

title: Gunman in Jerusalem Attack Identified
description: JERUSALEM  The families of the eight students who were killed by a gunman at a prominent Jewish seminary in Jerusalem on Thursday night buried their dead on Friday as the Israeli authorities tightened security around the city.

title: In the Berkshires, Turning Back the Clock
description: DURING a broadcast of A Prairie Home Companion from Tanglewood last summer, Garrison Keillor called the Berkshires a beautiful place  New England towns where people come to enjoy a way of life thats practically vanished.

title: Rapper Moving From Known to Notorious
description: Biggie lives. After an international search, Fox Searchlight Pictures announced that Jamal Woolard, a Brooklyn rapper, will play the Brooklyn-born hip-hop star Christopher Wallace, better known as Biggie Smalls and the Notorious B.I.G., in its forthcoming film Notorious. In October the studio held an open casting call in New York, auditioning more than 100 men to find the right personality to play the 6-foot-3, 300-pound Smalls, who was killed in a drive-by shooting in Los Angeles in 1997. Though he wasnt part of that open call, Mr. Woolard, who performs as Gravy, had the right combination of looks and swagger. It was Jamals charming personality, warm spirit, wonderful sense of humor and beautiful smile that won my heart, Voletta Wallace, Smallss mother and a producer of the film, said in a statement. Angela Bassett will play Ms. Wallace. The film is scheduled for release in January. Anthony Mackie will play Tupac Shakur, the Notorious B.I.G. rival also killed in a drive-by shooting, in 1996. Mr. Woolard is known for getting shot in the buttocks outside the hip-hop radio station WQHT-FM, known as Hot 97, before an interview there in 2006. He still made it to the interview.

title: German Authorities Report Problems With Blood Thinner
description: WASHINGTON  Concerns about the safety of the blood thinner heparin spread to Germany on Thursday after drug authorities there received reports of patients being sickened after taking the drug.

title: Dark Days in Armenia
description: The democracy that Armenians dreamed of during their long decades under Moscows yoke is slipping away. After opponents challenged last months flawed presidential election, the government imposed a brutal state of emergency. At least eight people are now dead, independent news outlets throttled and all protests silenced. President Bush and other Western leaders need to make clear to Armenias government that such behavior is unacceptable and will jeopardize future relations. Compared to post-Soviet tyrannies like Belarus or Uzbekistan, Armenia may not look so bad. That is why it is so important to halt this slide into authoritarianism before it is too late.

title: France: Sarkozys Ex-Wife to Remarry
description: Ccilia Ciganer-Albniz, as she is known since divorcing President Nicolas Sarkozy in October, and Richard Attias, left, an event planner, will marry in New York this month. The news came from Versace, which will dress the wedding party. Ms. Ciganer-Albniz, 50, had a public affair with Mr. Attias, 48, in 2005 but returned to be with Mr. Sarkozy during his campaign for president last May. Mr. Sarkozy, 53, married Carla Bruni, 40, a model and singer, last month.

title: Back to When Indies Were Cut-Rate and Gritty
description: The worm turns and squirms in Frownland, an aptly named film made on the cheap in and around New York. An up-close, painfully intimate portrait of a hapless, manipulative schlub, a Loser with a capital L, the film offers for our horror and our empathy a creature whose very existence is a rebuke to the stultifying uniformity (the niceness, the neatness) of what now often passes for American independent cinema. Written and directed by Ronald Bronstein, making his feature-film debut, this is personal cinema at its most uncompromising and fierce.

title: A Filmmaker Triumphant, a Film About Triumph
description: CYNTHIA WADE toted her hefty Oscar  it weighs eight and a half pounds, reminiscent of a healthy newborn, which is perhaps why her husband calls it their third child  home to Brooklyn on a red-eye flight. She had the option of leaving the statuette behind to be properly labeled and engraved, gratis, with her name and Freeheld, the title of the wrenching 38-minute film that won for best documentary short subject. But she chose not to part with it.

title: Footnote
description: Baby Mama, written and directed by Michael McCullers, a former Saturday Night Live writer, will open the Tribeca Film Festival on April 23. Starring Amy Poehler and Tiny Fey, the film was described in an announcement as a comedy about a 37-year-old career woman, her apartment and the woman she chooses to carry her child. The festival will run through May 4.

title: Kenyan Parliament Opens on Theme of Unity as Rivals Sit Apart
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The Kenyan Parliament met Thursday for the first time since a power-sharing deal was struck to end a political crisis that had plunged the country into chaos.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Can a Screwball Fable Have an Eye for Detail and a Heart for Fun? Discuss
description: Acting, of course, has something do with it. But the charm that emanates from Amy Adams like a perfume in Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day is also a natural gift.

title: The Rangers Bounce Back, to the Isles Dismay
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  In the final minute of a hard-fought victory Thursday, Rangers forward Sean Avery charged toward the Islanders empty net with defenseman Aaron Johnson hanging on and finally wrestling him to the ice.

title: Party Donations Show G.O.P. Edge
description: WASHINGTON  For all the success that Democratic presidential candidates have had in raising money  taking in a combined total of over $500 million in the current race  the Republicans are beating them in one crucial area of fund-raising: the money being raised by the parties themselves.

title: Where Greek Ideals Meet New England Charm
description: A GROUP of first-time visitors to the Providence Athenaeum climbed the steep stones steps to the imposing front door. One pried open the door tentatively, peered inside and exclaimed, Oh, this is what a library is supposed to look like!

title: Favre, Laid-Back and Tearful, Says Goodbye on His Own Terms
description: With tears streaking down his face and a catch in his voice, Brett Favre bade an emotional  at times painful  farewell to football Thursday at a news conference in Green Bay, acknowledging that he knows he can still play, but he does not think he wants to.

title: Correction:  Off the Set, Into the Desert
description: The Away column on Feb. 15 about the Southern California retreat of Tracy Tynan and Jim McBride, misstated the birthplace of Rocio Romero, an architect whose designs inspired the couples own designer. She was born in California, not Chile.

title: Aversion to Risk Deepens Credit Woes
description: The credit markets came under renewed stress Thursday as investors sought absolute safety and even moved away from debt issued by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-sponsored mortgage lending enterprises.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: With Race Unfinished, Attention Turns to Wyoming
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo.  Being a Democrat in this state means that ones status in political life is rarely in question and rarely that good. Republicans have a more than two-to-one edge in voter registration  or even 10 to 1 in some counties  and the Democrats, who are gearing up for their presidential caucuses on Saturday, usually get the leftovers.

title: Two Top Jobs Open, One Filled
description: Jean-Marie Guhenno, the under secretary general for peacekeeping, and Louise Arbour, the Geneva-based high commissioner for human rights, have told their staffs that they will be leaving their posts in July. Ms. Arbour, a former Canadian Supreme Court justice and United Nations war crimes prosecutor, said she would not run for a second four-year term, and Mr. Guhenno, a French career diplomat who has been peacekeeping chief for eight years during which the number of soldiers abroad rose to a record 100,000, said he would depart after his contract expired at the end of June. In another move, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon told the Security Council that he was naming Kai Eide, a former Norwegian ambassador to NATO, as his new envoy for Afghanistan. He replaces Tom Koenigs of Germany and became a candidate after Hamid Karzai, the Afghan president, rejected Mr. Bans reported first choice, Paddy Ashdown of Britain.

title: Searching for Optimism but Finding Government
description: March, in case you missed this factoid, has been designated Optimism Month by whatever force it is that decrees such things. Why we are supposed to be optimistic isnt clear. The Ides of March alone offer no reason for cheer, especially if your name is Julius or Caesar.

title: Belleayre Mountain
description: Updated: January 2009

title: Carlyle Capitals Lenders Liquidating Securities
description: LONDON  Carlyle Capital, the investment fund linked to the private equity firm Carlyle Group, said Friday that it was considering all available options after it received further margin calls, prompting some analysts to warn that more funds could struggle to meet increasingly tighter margin requirements.

title: The Netherlands: TV Shuns Anti-Islam Film
description: No Dutch television broadcaster is willing to show a short film critical of Islam and the Koran by the right-wing politician Geert Wilders, Radio Netherlands said on its Web site, citing a report in the newspaper De Volkskrant. Mr. Wilderss demand that the film be shown unedited and in its entirety is the biggest obstacle to its broadcast, the paper said, adding, It now appears that the whole film, which lasts about 15 minutes, will not be seen on Dutch television. Mr. Wilders has said that he would also show the film on the Internet.

title: Plastic Surgeon Sued by Dozens Surrenders His Medical License
description: A Manhattan plastic surgeon whose practice has been the subject of dozens of lawsuits, including a pending malpractice suit on behalf of a woman who died in 2005 after a face-lift, has surrendered his medical license and can no longer practice medicine, his lawyer said on Thursday.

title: Taking the Symphony Out for a Test Drive
description: Alan Gilbert has conducted two dozen New York Philharmonic concerts since he made his debut with the orchestra in 2001, but his appearance on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall was his first since he became its music director-designate last year. If the performance was inevitably an opportunity to listen for clues about the Philharmonics immediate future, it turned out that Mr. Gilbert got an earful as well.

title: Stocks Slide on Renewed Fears of Recession
description: Stocks slid on Wall Street on Friday as investors digested a discouraging employment report that revived fears the nation may already be in a recession.

title: Shares Tumble as Credit Worries Worsen
description: Stocks slid on Wall Street on Friday as investors digested a discouraging employment report that revived fears the nation may already be in a recession.

title: Girardi Says Wang Has Work to Do
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  Mike Mussina, Ian Kennedy and Joba Chamberlain have not been sharp for the Yankees this week, but for sheer shock value, Chien-Ming Wangs line Thursday stands out the most.

title: Assemblyman Faces a Charge of Drunken Driving
description: The car was moving erratically, weaving in and out of lanes on the West Side Highway in the early hours of Thursday, the police said, in a scene that soon seemed to belong in a cynical Hollywood movie about the rise and fall of a political dynasty.

title: Giving an Unpredictable Force His Due
description: The past of jazz ought to be revisited and understood, just as it ought to be betrayed. But contemporary musicians and old music are often parallel lines. Jazz repertory concerts are often benign contrivances, history lessons or concept shows.

title: New Englands Snow Becomes Too Much for Roofs
description: LACONIA, N.H.  It has been a great winter for skiers in central and northern New England, but the heavy snowfall has become a nightmare for municipal budgets and the owners of dozens of buildings whose roofs have collapsed.

title: Senate Votes to Strengthen Product Safety Laws
description: WASHINGTON  Responding to a wave of defective toys and other goods, the Senate approved a measure on Thursday to overhaul the countrys consumer product laws and strengthen the beleaguered safety agency that oversees the marketplace.

title: Disney to Offer Some Vintage TV Series on Its Web Site
description: The Walt Disney Company will begin showing its classic television shows on the Internet, its chief executive, Robert A. Iger, told shareholders on Thursday.

title: A Dockside Retreat
description: WHO Allan Price, 66, an executive with a financial company, from Atlanta. WHAT 3-bedroom condominium WHERE Destin, Fla.

title: Time Out of Mind
description: Berlin

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Investigation Into Death of Owner of L.I. Estate
description: Homicide detectives are investigating the death of the owner of a fabled Gatsby-era estate on Long Islands Gold Coast that has been the center of a decades-long family feud, the Nassau County police said on Thursday.

title: Paul Raymond, Britains Erotic Entertainment Magnate, Dies at 82
description: LONDON  Paul Raymond, who began his entrepreneurial life selling black-market nylons and fuel coupons from a market stall during World War II and then went on to become one of Britains richest men, overseeing an empire of Soho striptease clubs, salacious magazines and real estate holdings, died on Monday in London. He was 82.

title: Senate Democrats Hope for a Majority Not Seen in 30 Years: 60 Seats
description: WASHINGTON  When Mark Begich, the popular 45-year-old mayor of Anchorage, came to town for a meeting of mayors in January, he was beckoned to the Capitol by the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada. There was one agenda item: ousting Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, the senior Republican in Congress.

title: More Than Ever, Yanks Will Look to Farnsworth
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  Kyle Farnsworth is a nine-year veteran, 6 feet 4 inches tall, with a massive upper body and telephone poles for legs. He is a workout fanatic and a highly paid setup man, yet he has been handled with extreme caution as a Yankee.

title: Alabama County Facing Deadline on Sewer Debt
description: Jefferson County, Ala., is among the latest to become caught in troubles related to the faltering credit market.

title: Artist as Therapist Burrows Into the Psyche of New York
description: All day on Wednesday, men and women wandered hesitantly around a large white minimalist box on display at the Park Avenue Armory. They usually stopped for a moment on the far side of the box, which had a door. They tried to peer inside. They put their ears to the wall. Sometimes they knocked, loudly.

title: Confiscated Old Master Is Back on the Market
Harry and Pat and Kay and Richard in 1949
description: Married Life, a period comedy of manners merged with a suspenseful psychological thriller, aspires to be a hybrid of the sort that Alfred Hitchcock polished to perfection in the age of sexual subtext and subterfuge.

title: Post-It Notes in Books?
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Pact Controversy in Democratic Race Reaches Into Canadian Parliament
description: OTTAWA  Canada is in a tizzy.

title: NPR Chief, in Office Since 2006, Will Depart
description: The board of National Public Radio announced Thursday that the chief executive, Ken Stern, 44, was leaving after less than 18 months in the job. The board said the departure was by mutual agreement.

title: F.A.A. Fines Southwest Air in Inspections
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Aviation Administration proposed a record penalty, $10.2 million, against Southwest Airlines on Thursday because, it said, the carrier had misled officials about whether it kept flying older Boeing 737 planes for several days last year after failing to inspect them for cracks in the fuselage.

title: Yet Another Life for Maggie the Cat
description: Those eternal adversaries, irresistible force and immovable object, clash with gusto in the first act of the otherwise flabby revival of Tennessee Williamss Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, which opened Thursday night at the Broadhurst Theater.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article on Feb. 27 about the coming retirement of Jeff Orleans, the longtime executive director of the Ivy League, described incorrectly the extent of womens sports in the league in 1981, three years before Orleans was hired to run the conference. Women were competing for league championships in 10 sports by the early 1980s, and opportunities were on the rise. Womens sports were not virtually nonexistent.

title: Panel to Review Payouts Given by Troubled Firms
description: Chief executives of three financial companies who received outsize pay packages even as their shareholders lost billions in the spreading credit crisis are scheduled to testify before Congress on Friday, and if a memorandum released ahead of the hearing is any guide, they can expect quite a grilling.

title: Moms Leave the Sidelines to Mix Souls and Goals
description: The opening scene of Secrets of a Soccer Mom may have the clich-averse ready to head for the exits of the Snapple Theater Center. Ah, the daydreaming laundry-folding mom dancing to power pop; if this image hasnt actually been used in a thousand detergent commercials, it feels as if it has.

title: Prosecutor Says Detective Bragged of Wiretapping
description: LOS ANGELES  Anthony Pellicano masterminded a lucrative criminal enterprise aimed at discrediting and destroying the enemies of his Hollywood clients, a federal prosecutor charged Thursday in opening arguments in a long-awaited wiretapping trial.

title: Research Is Retracted
description: A team of scientists, including Linda B. Buck, who shared the 2004 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, has retracted a scientific paper that described neural pathways in the sense of smell, after the scientists were unable to reproduce the results. The Harvard Medical School, where Dr. Buck and her colleagues worked when the findings were published in the journal Nature in 2001, has begun a review of the research to determine whether there is evidence of misconduct. In the retraction, the scientists said they had found inconsistencies between the original data and what was published. Dr. Buck is now at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle. The papers first author, Zhihua Zou, who provided the data for the paper, is now at the University of Texas medical branch in Galveston. The university said Dr. Zou was cooperating with the review and remained confident of the papers conclusion.

title: Norman Smith, Engineer for the Beatles, Dies at 85
description: Norman Smith, who was the lead recording engineer for every Beatles song through 1965 and who as a producer helped usher in an era of psychedelic rock when he discovered the band Pink Floyd, died early Tuesday in East Sussex, England. He was 85.

title: European Bank Leaves Rate at 4%
description: FRANKFURT  Moments after Jean-Claude Trichet explained on Thursday that fears about inflation had prompted the European Central Bank to leave interest rates unchanged, the euro touched a new high against the dollar, rising to $1.537.

title: The Anxiety Election
description: Democrats won the 2006 election largely thanks to public disgust with the Iraq war. But polls  and Hillary Clintons big victory in Ohio  suggest that if the Democrats want to win this year, they have to focus on economic anxiety.

title: Left-Field Question Has the Mets Looking for an Answer
description: VIERA, Fla.  Omar Minaya is, by nature, an optimist, so he fully expects to see Moises Alou back to his dangerous old self with the Mets sometime in the middle of April. He looks at Alous injury, a hernia that was surgically repaired Thursday, as an isolated occurrence, something that should not have the lingering effect of the quadriceps strain that sidelined him for two and a half months last season.

title: Gusher of Lies
description: The Persistent Delusion

title: Mexicos New Frontier
description: THE 8,000 acres of the Loreto Bay Resort on Baja California snuggle on flat, hard desert between the charismatically craggy Giganta range and the spookily glassy Sea of Cortez. The most basic elements of nature  sun and water, rock and sand, the vertical and the horizontal  collide with that particular grace that only nature can produce.

title: Two Lawsuits Are Filed in Americas Cup Dispute
description: A contentious Americas Cup scene became more litigious Thursday when Emirates Team New Zealand filed two lawsuits in New York against Alinghi, the Swiss-based syndicate that successfully defended the Cup against Team New Zealand last July.

title: A (Green) Place for Dance and Performance to Bloom
description: Until John Jasperse laughs  the sound is a bit like a high-pitched machine gun, but friendly  it can be hard to know what hes thinking. Tall, pale and serious, he stood in the middle of the Center for Performance Research in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, last month, scrutinizing a fresh coat of paint as if he were a scientist peering into a microscope. Its good, he finally said, punctuating his approval with a contagious peal of laughter. Its turning into what we imagined it would be.

title: City Schools Fail to Comply With State Rule on Arts Classes
description: Only 4 percent of the citys elementary schools meet the states requirement for arts education, according to the results of a city survey Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced on Thursday.

title: Muscular Dystrophy
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Believe Recovered Bike Was Bombers
description: In a new development on Friday morning, investigators say they strongly believe that a bicycle recovered on Thursday morning was the one ridden by the person who bombed the Times Square military recruitment station earlier that morning.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about federal approval for Pristiq, a new antidepressant drug made by Wyeth, misstated the process by which the medication interacts with a patients liver. The drug avoids a major metabolic pathway in the liver that is often used by other drugs, but it does not completely avoid being metabolized by the liver.

title: Protecting All Waters
description: Half of the waters in the United States are at risk of pollution or destructive development because of a wrongheaded Supreme Court decision in 2006. The decision narrowed the scope of the Clean Water Act, weakened the laws safeguards and thoroughly confused the federal agencies responsible for enforcing it.

title: The Feminist Factor, With or Without Shoulder Pads
description: To the Editor:

title: Latinos Seek Citizenship in Time for Voting
description: A lawsuit filed Thursday in a federal court in New York by Latino immigrants seeks to force immigration authorities to complete hundreds of thousands of stalled naturalization petitions in time for the new citizens to vote in November.

title: Pushing and Pulling, Together and Apart
description: Netta Yerushalmy grew up in Israel. Lee Sher and Saar Harari were born there. All three create small, charged spaces on the stage of the Ailey Citigroup Theater in Out of Israel, part of the 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Festival, first performed there on Thursday night. But they are very different worlds.

title: Pianistic Tales, Fanciful and Eccentric
description: Emanuel Axs piano recital at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night asked in part how composers begin their composing lives. Both Schumanns Papillons and the second of Beethovens 32 piano sonatas bear the parenthetical subtitle (Op. 2). Schumann was emerging from his teens. Beethoven was 25, and this was his latest try at fame and fortune.

title: Glavine Says Devastation Isnt the Word
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  Tom Glavine could not sleep. He moped around the house and was a cranky father and husband. One game, the last game he pitched for the Mets, kept replaying in his head. The questions about that bloody Sunday smothered him.

title: In California, a Generational Tale of Real Estate Boom and Bankruptcy
description: YUBA CITY, Calif.  When George P. Dunmore started his business in Sacramento in the early 1950s, World War II was over and the building boom was on. Over the next several decades his company, Dunmore Construction, along with other respected builders, took the tabula rasa that was Californias Central Valley and etched it with entire neighborhoods filled with well-built ranch houses on trim lawns.

title: As Foreclosures Rise, Investors Pull Back
description: WASHINGTON  Defaults on home mortgages touched another historic high late last year as foreclosures on adjustable-rate mortgages surged, an industry group reported on Thursday.

title: Arts Economic Indicator
description: Advertisements for the 2008 Whitney Biennial promise a show that will tell us where American art stands today, although we basically already know. A lot of new art stands in the booths of international art fairs, where styles change fast, and one high-polish item instantly replaces another. The turnover is great for business, but it has made time-lag surveys like the biennial irrelevant as news.

title: Oscar Peterson Proposal in Montreal Causes Flap
description: A grass-roots movement to rename a busy Montreal subway station in honor of the jazz pianist Oscar Peterson, below, has run into a snag, The Globe and Mail of Toronto reported. The station, around the corner from where Peterson was born and reared, already memorializes Lionel-Adolphe Groulx (1878-1967), a Canadian priest, historian and powerful influence on the Quebec nationalist movement who was also known for anti-Semitism. Oscar Peterson is important as a symbol of success over adversity, said Michael Citrome, a Montreal graduate student in law whose campaign on Facebook on behalf of Peterson, who died in December, has attracted 5,000 members. Lionel Groulx has a message that immediately divided Quebeckers. Hes the symbol of an era that we need to put behind us. Mr. Citromes supporters point out that renaming the station would honor Peterson and give overdue recognition to Montreals black community. None of the citys 68 Mtro stations is named for a member of a minority. City Hall says a committee will study the matter. Jarrett Rudy, director of the Quebec Studies Program at McGill University, proposed a compromise: calling the subway stop Station Oscar Peterson-Lionel Groulx.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Monday about an uproar among Orthodox Jews over the cancellation of a New York concert that was to feature a popular Hasidic entertainer misidentified the newspaper that published comments on the dispute from Shmuel Kamenetzky, one of 33 rabbis who signed a decree against the show. The newspaper was The Jewish Star, not Hamodia.

title: Some See Prosecution Tactic in 50-Shot Case: Just the Facts
description: After eight days of testimony in the Sean Bell trial, some onlookers have asked a variation on the old saw about friends and enemies: With prosecution witnesses like these, who needs a defense?

title: Pataki Has Surgery for Stomach Ailment
description: Former Gov. George E. Pataki underwent surgery on Thursday to relieve an intestinal blockage after experiencing severe abdominal pain, his spokesman said. Mr. Pataki, 62, is now in private law practice and is a consultant on environmental issues. He had been scheduled to speak at a conference on renewable energy in Washington when he went to a hospital there on Wednesday, complaining of pain.

title: 13-Year-Old Blazes a Lane in Swimmings Olympic Pool
description: Back and forth the swimmers went, one lap in the 25-yard course turning into four, four laps becoming 400 by the end of the two-and-a-half-hour practice. In one lane, the chain of bodies skimming the surface had a strong link in the middle, the swimmer two behind the leader commanding the eye with her long, fluid strokes.

title: In Crisis, Zimbabwe Asks: Could Mugabe Lose?
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe  Robert G. Mugabe has run this country for so long that his presence is like some common particulate in the air, taken in with every breath. Gladys Sithole can barely recall a Zimbabwe without him, this inescapable old man, as she calls him, with godlike powers and all-too-human failings.

title: Trustees of Polytechnic University in Brooklyn Approve Merger With N.Y.U.
description: The trustees of Polytechnic University in Brooklyn approved a merger with New York University on Thursday, even though a state senators investigation into possible improprieties involving the merger was not complete and the attorney generals office began making inquiries about the merger on Wednesday.

title: CBS Dismisses 'Early Show' Producer
description: In a move expected for at least a week, CBS News on Thursday fired Shelley Ross, executive producer of its morning news program, The Early Show. But the network is not naming a full-time replacement yet. Instead it announced that Rick Kaplan, executive producer of the CBS Evening News With Katie Couric, would take on the added responsibility of overseeing the morning program on an interim basis. Mr. Kaplan will turn over some day-to-day duties on the evening news program to senior staff members, led by Chris Dinan, a senior broadcast producer. Mr. Dinan was in charge of the newscast for a month this year while Mr. Kaplan recuperated from a broken hip. Ms. Ross joined The Early Show only in September, but her management style stirred some harsh reaction from its staff. CBS had removed two executive producers, Michael Bass and Steve Friedman, to make room for Ms. Ross. She had led ABCs Good Morning America, which was a competitive second to the morning program leader, NBCs Today.

title: Loophole Lets Bank Rewrite the Calendar
description: It is not often that a major international bank admits it is violating well-established accounting rules, but that is what Socit Gnrale has done in accounting for the fraud that caused the bank to lose 6.4 billion euros  now worth about $9.7 billion  in January.

title: Art in Review
description: A NEW HIGH

title: Relative Says Slain Girl Feared Stepfather
description: Throughout the trial for the murder of 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown, her stepfathers lawyers have said that the girls mother, reeling from postpartum depression and mental illness, fatally struck her child.

title: Love May Not Be All You Need After All
description: JEntends Plus la Guitare, a film by Philippe Garrel, is a fugue composed in a key of philosophical melancholy. Though its subject is love, the movie is less a romance or the story of a breakup than a series of meditations on, and analytical explorations of, need, truth and the passage of time. The dialogue is abstract and cerebral as only French discussions of lamour can be, but Mr. Garrels hovering, undulating camera movements impart a dimension of sensuality to the endless, sometimes inscrutable talk.

title: The Year It Snowed in Vermont, and Snowed, and ....
description: IT was outside the general store in the sleepy central Vermont town of Rochester that the grizzled man in a worn hat and coat approached my car. He passed a pile of snow that rose 10 feet above the street. Behind him, on the village green, an ornate gazebo was nearly buried in drifting snow.

title: Rabbi Is Found Dead in River, Inside His Car
description: JERSEY CITY  After Rabbi Zev Segal, 91, finished an appearance on his sons radio program here on Wednesday, he headed to Livingston, N.J., on an errand.

title: Buy the Best Tanker
description: The Air Forces selection of a European supplier over Boeing for its next generation of tanker aircraft has sparked a frenzy of predictable bipartisan complaints: How could the military outsource these patriotic jobs?

title: More Money Is Pouring In for Clinton and Obama
description: The Democratic candidates for president continued to post formidable fund-raising numbers, with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton using her victories in Tuesdays primaries to raise $4 million through noon on Thursday.

title: Rice Presses NATO Allies to Expand Afghan Force
description: BRUSSELS  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, tiptoeing through a minefield of European squabbling, on Thursday urged NATO allies to step up troop contributions and other efforts to help defeat the Taliban in Afghanistan.

title: Pizza at $3 a Slice?
description: Sharp increases in the price of commodities worldwide, particularly record wheat futures and soaring flour costs, are being felt in a staple of the New York diet: pizza.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 23 about molecules used to make perfumes misstated the length of patents in the United States. It is 20 years, not 17. The article also misidentified the makers of two perfumes and misspelled the name of one of the perfumes. Polo Blue from Ralph Lauren is made by International Flavors and Fragrances, and Acqua di Gio (not Aqua di Gio) from Armani is made by Firmenich. Neither are made by Givaudan. The article also misstated the proprietary status of Amber Ketal, a scent used in both perfumes. It was no longer under patent when it was used in those two fragrances.

title: New Jersey Towns Fear Cuts Will Change Their Way of Life
description: HELMETTA, N.J.  Beginning little more than a century ago, local historians say, this tiny town was home to one of the worlds largest snuff mills.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about a vote by the New Jersey Senate to give employees the right to take paid leave to care for a newborn or a sick relative misstated the number of state senators. There are 40  not 80, the number of members in the Assembly. (The article correctly noted the vote. It was 22 to 16, with one senator abstaining and one absent.)

title: Foggy Window to November in Race to Replace Ex-Speaker
description: Special House elections are not especially popular with Congressional political operatives.

title: On Ramps and Off, Free-Falling Through Time
description: Paranoid Park is a swooping skateboarding free zone where young men learn to fly. Its also the title of Gus Van Sants most recent film, a haunting, voluptuously beautiful portrait of a teenage boy who, after being suddenly caught in midflight, falls to earth. Like most of Mr. Van Sants films Paranoid Park is about bodies at rest and in motion, and about longing, beauty, youth and death, and as such as much about the artist as his subject. It is a modestly scaled triumph without a false or wasted moment.

title: Nicaragua Breaks Ties With Bogot Over Crisis
description: MEXICO CITY  Nicaragua broke off diplomatic relations with Colombia on Thursday, entering the fray on the side of Ecuador and Venezuela in a tense standoff over Colombias decision last week to raid a rebel camp on Ecuadorean soil.

title: Democrats Try to End Impasse Over Delegates
description: WASHINGTON  With the two Democratic presidential candidates in near-deadlock and battling for every delegate, party leaders and the rival campaigns started searching in earnest on Thursday for a way to seat barred delegations from Florida and Michigan. But they remained deeply divided over how to do so.

title: Adventures of a Boy, His Dad and His Alien
description: A devilishly entertaining curveball thrown at unsuspecting family audiences, CJ7 is E.T. as reimagined by the premier clown of Chinese cinema, Stephen Chow. Whether American viewers will respond with the enthusiasm of their Chinese counterparts remains to be seen. What is clear, however, is that Mr. Chows notion of family is decidedly more Addams than Brady.

title: Human Civilization: The Prequel
description: Only time can teach us what is truth and what is legend. This bit of fake-folk wisdom commences the voice-over narration of 10,000 BC, and the more you think about it, the more preposterous it seems. If anything, time confuses the issue. But its best not to think too hard about anything in this sublimely dunderheaded excursion into human prehistory, directed by Roland Emmerich from a script he wrote with Harald Kloser, who also helped compose, using his better ear, the musical score.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 6, 2008

title: Recreation Fees Rising in Wake of Fires Costs
description: HAMILTON, Mont.  Reeling from the high cost of fighting wildfires, federal land agencies have been imposing new fees and increasing existing ones at recreation sites across the West in an effort to raise tens of millions of dollars.

title: National Book Critics Circle Awards
description: The National Book Critics Circle Awards were announced, and Junot Daz won the award for fiction for his debut novel, The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao (Riverhead Books). Edwidge Danticat, the author of Brother, Im Dying, (Alfred A. Knopf) won for autobiography. Stanley: The Impossible Life of Africas Greatest Explorer (Yale University Press) by Tim Jeal was honored for biography. Mary Jo Bang took the poetry prize for Elegy (Graywolf Press). Harriet Washington won the nonfiction prize for Medical Apartheid: The Dark History of Medical Experimentation on Black Americans from Colonial Times to the Present (Doubleday), and Alex Ross won for criticism with The Rest is Noise: Listening to the Twentieth Century (Farrar, Straus and Giroux).

title: He Took On Kings and Now Wants to Be the Mayor
description: Kevin Johnson spent 12 seasons in the N.B.A. as one of the best point guards of his era. Before this week, Johnson, like most players who have played for a championship, thought that the ultimate high was reaching the N.B.A. finals.

title: Credit and Mortgage Woes Sink Stocks
description: Renewed anxiety about the availability of bank loans  and fears that the Federal Reserve may be unable to curb the credit slump  sent shares down sharply on Thursday.

title: Clemens Investigators Look at Houston Clinic
description: This article was reported by Katie Thomas, Michael S. Schmidt, Thayer Evans and Duff Wilson and was written by Ms. Thomas.

title: 'Pal Joey' to Return
description: Its been knocking around for more than a decade, but the revival of Rodgers and Hart classic Pal Joey, with a book adapted by Richard Greenberg from John OHaras original, appears set for a Broadway stage; it even has an opening date and a theater. The Roundabout Theater Company will produce Pal Joey in association with Marc Platt, the last commercial producer to have his hands on it, at Studio 54. Previews are to begin on Nov. 21 with an official opening scheduled for Dec. 11. Choreography will be by Graciela Daniele and musical direction by Paul Gemignani; Joe Mantello will direct. The cast has not been announced.

title: George Fredrickson, 73, Historian, Dies
description: George M. Fredrickson, a historian who cast new light on the study of race and who helped define the field of comparative history with a penetrating examination of racial relations in the United States and South Africa, died on Feb. 25 at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 73.

title: 4 Executives Are Charged Over Tainted Toothpaste
description: Criminal charges were filed on Thursday against four executives at two American companies who imported toothpaste from China that contained a poison used in some antifreeze, the city attorney in Los Angeles said in a statement.

title: No Need to Take Discs Along
description: JUST because you have two homes doesnt mean you need to have two of everything else: cable or satellite TV subscriptions, DVRs, telephone systems, music libraries, Internet packages. Thanks to a little thing called technology, you can set up those services in your primary home and then access them while on vacation.

title: Simpsons Trial Is Pushed Back 6 Months
description: LAS VEGAS  O.J. Simpson will not be tried on armed robbery and kidnapping charges until at least September, six months after his trial had been scheduled to start in April.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Four Charged With Running Online Prostitution Ring
description: Federal authorities arrested four people Thursday on charges of running an online prostitution ring that serviced clients in New York, Paris and other cities and took in more than $1 million in profits over four years.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in the Circuits pages of Business Day on Thursday about downloading video games referred incorrectly to the availability of hard drives on game consoles. Only the PlayStation 3 from Sony has a built-in hard drive. The Microsoft Xbox 360 has three models that come with detachable hard drives. The Wii from Nintendo does not have a built-in hard drive or the option of adding an external hard drive.

title: Gilded Curls Just Want to Have Fun
description: A great soup tureen welcomes visitors to Rococo: The Continuing Curve, 1730-2008, a dazzling exhibition at the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum. Made entirely of silver, it takes the form of a giant clamshell on whose fluted lid are piled the ingredients for a rich stew. Cast from real objects, they include a pheasant, a crayfish, beets and mushrooms. The bowl rests on a bed of greens, and the whole is displayed on a platter whose curled edges are suggestive of cabbage leaves.

title: California Plan Focuses on Battling Wildfires
description: SAN DIEGO  As officials here wrestle with how to improve regional firefighting, a state senator is sponsoring a package of bills intended to address Californias most pressing firefighting and wildfire-protection needs.

title: Russian Charged With Trying to Sell Arms
description: WASHINGTON  A Russian businessman regarded by the United States as one of the worlds most notorious arms dealers was arrested in Thailand on Thursday as part of an American-led sting operation. He was promptly charged in the United States with conspiracy for trying to smuggle missiles and rocket launchers to rebels in Colombia.

title: We Cant Afford to Ignore the Iraq War
description: To the Editor:

title: Bombs Kill 54 and Wound 123 in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  Two bombs struck a bustling shopping district in the heart of Baghdad on Thursday evening, turning display windows and cabinets and glass shelves into deadly shrapnel, and killing 54 people and wounding 123, the Iraqi authorities said.

title: At Charter School, Higher Teacher Pay
description: Would six-figure salaries attract better teachers?

title: Her So-Called Life (Fact-Checking Required)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tragedy of Gun Deaths
description: To the Editor:

title: Paul Admits Conventional Defeat
description: In a message posted on YouTube on Thursday, Representative Ron Paul acknowledged that he would not be able to win the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Art on the Strip
description: Images from the public art proposal in Las Vegas.

title: McCain Asked About 2004 Conversation With Kerry
description: The following is the exchange between Senator John McCain and The Times's Elisabeth Bumiller as transcribed by The New York Times.

title: T Magazine | The Boys Are Back In Town
The Will-Rogers Candidate?
description: Clockwise from top left: Wayne, Will, McCain, Wayne

title: Enterprise Search Deals: More to Come?
description: Microsofts recent acquisition of FAST Search & Transfer is one of the latest and largest deals in the enterprise search space.

title: Sallie Mae: Hoping to Earn a Diploma
description: Sallie Mae is flunking on Wall Street.

title: Aversion to Risk Deepens Credit Woes
description: The credit markets came under renewed stress Thursday as investors sought absolute safety and even moved away from debt issued by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-sponsored mortgage lending enterprises.

title: In Time Warner Fight, Icahn Says He Laughed Last
description: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn may have lost his bid to break up Time Warner, but that apparently didnt stop him from lining his pockets.

title: Motorola and Icahn Gird for Second Round
description: Motorola is preparing for a second showdown with the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, who has increased his stake in the company ahead of a May battle over board seats.

title: Bill Clintons Boots on the Ground in Wyoming
description: LARAMIE, Wyo.  Pausing before he launched into an hourlong speech, Bill Clinton stood in front of hundreds of college students Thursday night and proudly showed off his cowboy boots.

title: Britains Lyceum Positions Itself for Law Firm Buyouts
description: Lyceum Capital has become one of the first private equity houses to train its sights on law firms ahead of sweeping deregulation in Britain, hiring three industry figures to advise it on potential buyouts in the sector, Legal Week reported.

title: Visa I.P.O. Could Be Boon for Lawyers, Too
description: Visa has two big challenges ahead. The first is its plan for what is expected to be an $18 billion initial public offering, which would be the biggest ever in the United States.

title: Endo Shoots Down D.E. Shaw Proposals
description: Endo Pharmaceuticals is apparently none too keen on any of the suggestions tabled by its largest shareholder, the hedge fund D.E. Shaw.

title: Sprint Nextel Becomes Grist for the Rumor Mill
description: Sprint Nextel, whose shareholders are still stinging from a $29.7 billion fourth-quarter write-down related to its 2005 purchase of Nextel, is generating plenty of speculation about the companys fate.

title: Kleiner Perkins to Aid iPhone Developers
description: Steven P. Jobs, Apples chief executive, is hoping to expand the iPhones appeal by luring software developers to create programs for it.

title: Breaking the Rules and Admitting It
description: It is not often that a major international bank admits it is violating well-established accounting rules, but that is what Socit Gnrale has done in accounting for the fraud that caused the bank to lose 6.4 billion euros  now worth about $9.7 billion  in January.

title: China Railway Said to Raise $2.35 Billion in Hong Kong I.P.O.
description: China Railway Construction, builder of more than half the nations rail links since 1949, raised the maximum 18.3 billion Hong Kong dollars ($2.35 billion) sought in a Hong Kong initial stock sale, Bloomberg News reported.

title: More Margin-Call Woes at Carlyle Capital
description: Carlyle Capital, the investment fund affiliated with the private equity firm the Carlyle Group, said on Friday that it was exploring all its options after receiving another wave of margin calls from lenders.

title: Ambac Raises $1.5 Billion
description: The Ambac Financial Group, the bond insurer, said on Friday it had sold $1.5 billion of shares and convertibles, protecting the company from ratings cuts but not satisfying some analysts who had wanted the company to raise more.

title: I.B.M. Says It Wont Do a Yahoo
description: International Business Machiness chief executive, Sam Palmisano, said on Thursday the company is on track to meet its 2010 earnings target, and he ruled out mega-mergers on the scale of Microsofts $40 billion-plus bid for Yahoo.

title: Justice Department May Have Beef With JBS Deals
description: A pair of deals by a Brazilian meat company, JBS, to acquire beef production assets in the United States is likely to direct political heat toward the Justice Department, according to The Deal.com.

title: History Lessons, With Song and Dance
description: Before the start of Year One of the Empire, the cast assembles onstage and sings The Star-Spangled Banner. At the end of the anthem you half expect an umpire to shout, Play ball! What follows, however, is an enlightening, entertaining and at times engrossing dramatized survey of Americas coming of imperialistic age at the turn of the 20th century.

title: Infogrames Wants to Take Atari Private
description: Atari said on Thursday that its majority shareholder Infogrames Entertainment has said it wants to buy the rest of the company for for $1.68 per share.

title: Kirtland Sells Essex Crane to Hyde Park
description: Kirtland Capital Partners agreed to sell Essex Crane Rental, one of the countrys largest construction crane suppliers, for $210 million to a publicly traded blank-check company, Hyde Park Acquisition.

title: A Mans 6-Pack Can Serve as His Castle
description: From Fridays Times, a weekend project you might not want to take on (except for the drinking part):

title: Sinopec Inks $599 Million Deal for AED Assets
description: China Petrochemical, known as the Sinopec Group, agreed to buy 60 percent of AED Oils Puffin and Talbot oil ventures in the Timor Sea for 600 million Australian dollars ($559 million), gaining production in Australia.

title: F.T.C. Approves NYSE Deal for Amex
description: The Federal Trade Commission has given NYSE Euronext the go-ahead to acquire the American Stock Exchange, the companies said Thursday.

title: Macquarie Unit Buys Stake in a U.S. Fixed-Income Adviser
description: Macquarie Banks funds management group has agreed to purchase a majority stake in Allegiance Investment Management, a fixed-income adviser, as Macquarie expands its presence in the United States.

title: Lehman Snags Robeco Unit
description: Robeco Investment Management, an asset management company, has agreed to sell its municipal fixed-income business in the United States to Lehman Brothers as it nears the completion of its plans to exit the fixed income market in the United States.

title: High-Paid Chiefs on the Hot Seat
description: The chief of Countrywide Financial and the former chiefs of Citigroup and Merrill Lynch were set to testify before Congress on Friday about the abundant pay packages they got even as their shareholders lost billions  and if a memorandum released ahead of the hearing is any guide, they can expect quite a grilling.

title: Storytelling With Two Conditions
description: Edward Einhorn sets himself an impossible task with the two short plays he has written and is offering under the banner Brains and Puppets at Walkerspace. He wants not just to tell stories about Aspergers syndrome and synesthesia, but also to let the audience see the world as people with those unusual conditions see it.

title: Disney to Offer Some Vintage Shows Online
description: Bloomberg reports:

title: UrbanEye: King Arthur
description: A new performance of Purcell's "King Arthur," directed and choreographed by Mark Morris, opens at Lincoln Center.  Melena Ryzik reports.

title: Citi Said to Consider Changes at U.S. Consumer Unit
description: In his pep-talk to his troops earlier this week, Vikram S. Pandit mentioned strong points in Citigroups performance. But perhaps most noticeable was what he didnt mention: the United States operations of the beleaguered financial giant.

title: Creation Under the Clouds
description: It sounds like the kind of gathering you wouldnt want to miss. The guests on the Ohio Theater stage include Mr. Survival of the Fittest himself, Charles Darwin, and his wife, Emma; the author Mary Shelley and her son, the Creature, from her novel Frankenstein; Alfred Russel Wallace, the neglected other father of evolutionary theory, and his Moluccan Islands assistant, Thursday (Friday is nowhere in sight); and a latecomer who arrives in a cape and a hurry, Eugenie Doe, the title character and the first biogenetically engineered human.

title: Second-Round Bids for G.M. Building Said to Top $3 Billion
description: Harry Macklowe is making progress in selling the crown jewel of his New York real estate empire, having received several bids in the second round of bidding for the General Motors Building that top $3 billion, The New York Post reported Friday, citing a source it did not identify.

title: Life Isnt Always a Box of Chocolates
description: The worst confections ever:

title: The Early Word: Headed Toward a Second Vote?
description: Delegates, superdelegates, hypotheticals, addition, subtraction, X factors  we havent seen this many equations since high school algebra. (Which we do not miss, by the way.)

title: An Incentive for Men Avoiding Chores
description: A statistic mentioned this week in The New York Times  that men who have dropped out of the labor force actually do less housework on average than working women  got the attention of Josh Patashnik of The New Republic: This reminds me that I need to clean my bathroom.

title: It has begun
description: OK: payrolls down 22,000 in January, 63,000 in February. Hard to see things improving any time soon, thanks to dramatically worsening conditions in the credit markets.

title: Trying to Make Sense of the Times Square Blast
description: The bombing of the armed forces recruiting station in Times Square early Thursday morning  which had striking similarities to two earlier, unsolved bombings in 2005 and 2007  is the focus of New York City coverage this morning.

title: Family Ties
description: So the Democratic campaign may come down to Pennsylvania (emphasis on may there, as weve heard this sort of thing before) and weve been told often that Hillary Clinton may (ditto) be in the catbird seat thanks the support of Gov. Ed Rendell and his formidable political machine.

title: A Scream
description: Eyes popping and mouths agape, Martin Lawrence and Raven-Symon mug their way through College Road Trip as if it were a silent movie  which, come to think of it, would have been a lot less irritating.

title: War Wounds
description: Shot in battlefield hospitals in Iraq and rehab centers in the United States, Fighting for Life takes an unflinching look at the physical sacrifices of soldiers and marines, and the fortitude of the doctors and nurses who treat them.

title: After Monster Remark, Aide to Obama Resigns
description: Updated | 11:45 a.m.: CHICAGO  A senior foreign policy adviser and close friend of Senator Barack Obama said today that she was resigning from the campaign, after she apologized for referring to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton as a monster.

title: Q&A: Answers About Baghdads Red Zone
description: The following is the second set of answers from reporters and staff members in the Baghdad Bureau. The first part of the Q&A was published on March 3.

title: A Rejected Sweetener for ONeals Exit Package
description: In Washington on Friday, a House committee is taking a close and, in many cases, skeptical look at the departing paycheck and other perks bestowed on E. Stanley ONeal. The former Merrill Lynch chairman and chief executive took home $161.5 million in cash, stock and stock options as he was forced out of the ailing financial securities firm.

title: Goldmans Golden Five: What They Earned
description: Heres a number to ponder: $322 million.

title: Stray Questions for: Lucinda Rosenfeld
description: Lucinda Rosenfeld is the author of the novels What She Saw . . . and Why She Went Home.

title: Love the Series? You May Hate the Game
description: Dexter, the popular Showtime television series about a serial killer, will be adapted as a video game. Showtime Networks and Marc Ecko Entertainment say they are in talks with developers to design the game.

title: Ergo Proxy: The Official Language of the Internet
description: Two-thirds of Internet users dont know English, according to this fascinating book. And yet English is the dominant language online, with Chinese coming in second.

title: The KGB Bars Former Lawyer for the Damned
description: If there is any doubt that Denis Woychuk, the owner of the KGB Bar in the East Village and the writer of a new rock musical about a lawyer representing the criminally insane, knows what he is writing about, consider the grisly case of Daniel Rakowitz, the last person he represented in his 10 years working for mentally ill defendants. Mr. Rakowitz, also of the East Village, was charged in 1989 with killing his girlfriend and dismembering her. Accounts of what happened have varied over the years as Mr. Rakowitzs story has changed, but one account, which he has denied, had him boiling the victims body into soup that he served to the homeless.

title: Fridays Links: Business Cards for Slash-Filled Lives
description: In the category of wish Id written that, The Wall Street Journal ran an article yesterday on the surge in business card offerings. The article included a reference to the growing need for multiple  business cards for slasher types like the accountant/artist referred to by a vice president at Staples.

title: Funerals in Jerusalem
description: The families of the eight students who were killed by a gunman at a prominent Jewish seminary in Jerusalem on Thursday night buried their dead on Friday.

title: Ask About the Car of the Future
description: On March 17, the Monday before the New York auto show opens, The Times will sponsor a  panel discussion on designing the car of tomorrow with Edward T. Welburn Jr., vice president for global design at General Motors; Joel Piaskowski, chief designer of Hyundai North America; and Franz von Holzhausen, design director of Mazda North America.

title: Recipe of the Day: Olive Oil Cookies
description: Olive oil remains unusual in sweet baked goods, but the flavor of extra virgin olive oil is a powerful and welcome addition to sweet and savory cookies, the type that are best nibbled with a glass of sweet wine. Olive oil is not butter, of course, and you will never get that incomparably tender crumb when using it in cookie dough. But olive oil does produce cookies with a caky interior and nicely crisped surface.

title: For the Moment | The Starbucks At Fashions Epicenter
description: (Jessica Antola)

title: Like a Bomb Going Off
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Google Street View on Army Bases? Better Not.
description: Youve seen this feature they added to Google Maps last spring called Street View, right? Click on certain streets and highways highlighted in blue on the map, and you get a panoramic street-level view of the place, including anyone who happened to be there when the Google camera van drove by to capture the images.

title: Responding to a Less Heated Market
description: Sellers are working harder to attract buyers, and buyers are taking their time to make decisions. Both sides seem willing to negotiate.

title: Another Eccentric Innovation From France
description: GENEVA  In the world of micro automakers, the French touch has a weird, innovative side. There is Guy Ngre, whose company MDI in the south of France has developed a car that runs on compressed air; the idea has been licensed to Tata in India. And there is Venturi, which actually has its headquarters in Monaco, whose solar-powered Eclectic, due in early 2009, will travel seven kilometers a day powered by the sun alone.

title: Whistling Out West
description: U.C.L.A. clinched the outright Pac-10 title Thursday night, no small feat in whats strongly considered the toughest league in the country this season. But they may have gotten a little help from the zebras. Tim Kawakami of the San Jose Mercury News spells it out pretty clearly here: That foul call on a clean Lawrence Hill block of Darren Collisons lay-up attempt with 2.5 left at Pauley Pavilion was awful.

title: Spotted At Work | Pierre Hardy for Gap
description: Finally the shoe collection that Pierre Hardy designed for Gap has become available. There are only three styles online at this point (and more in some stores), but they are very cute. Here at the T Magazine office, several stylish staffers have placed their orders (me included). The consensus seems to be in favor of the sandal flats ($78), above, and the three-strap sandals ($98)  their wooden heels are amazing and a lot like the Chlo sandals that a lot of the girls already have (me included). If you havent bought a pair yet, hurry up. It looks like the sizes are already selling out. Just dont wear them the same day as me.

title: Paris Fashion Week Catch-Up | Cathy Horyn
description: Before the jet lag wears off, wed like to remember the Paris fashion shows of last week. Who better to provide an overview than The Timess fashion critic, Cathy Horyn, who flew thousands of miles and endured countless ear-splitting remixes so you didnt have to? The Moment presents a digest of Cathys criticism from the Paris shows.

title: Blame the Celebrities, Part II
description: First, a United Nations watchdog blamed celebrities for their endorsement of drug-related lifestyles. Now, Tim Martin, the chairman of one of Britains most popular pub chains, JD Wetherspoon, is piling on when it comes to binge drinking.

title: Play Looks at Being Black With a Badge
description: Can a black police officer be racist against black people? And how does that play out in the moments before a gun confrontation with another black man? Those questions were explored in a one-act play, In That Moment, and the subsequent panel discussion at John Jay College of Criminal Justice on Thursday night.How race plays out in policing (both for the officers and the public) is a theme in the play, but has so far been a subtler issue in the trial before a judge of the three detectives charged in the shooting of Sean Bell, a black man who was killed in the early morning of his wedding day in November 2006.

title: Chapel Hill Mourns Student Everyone Knew
description: Another college is tested by senseless death. Another heartbreakingly sweet portrait emerges. All-important questions rise from the mourning: Who did it and why?

title: Reader Ideas on Fish Recipes
description: There is no easy answer on sustainable fish recipes.

title: Show and Tell
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Movie Magic, or Real Product?
description: From todays mailbag:

title: Executive Pay on the Hill: The C.E.O.s Respond
description: The reality is that I received no severance package.

title: The Week in Comments: Imagine That!
description: Monday, March 3

title: A Silence at the Clinton Library
description: Well, this might make people forget the whole tax-return thing  Federal archivists at the Clinton Presidential Library are blocking the release of hundreds of pages of White House papers on pardons that the former president approved, including clemency for fugitive commodities trader Marc Rich, reports USA Today.

title: Foggy Window to November in Race to Replace Ex-Speaker
description: In his Web column today, Carl Hulse looks at the race to replace J. Dennis Hastert, the former House Speaker, in Illinois, and finds that while many see Saturdays special election as a test case for the general election, there are a few variables that might mean the results are not fully applicable elsewhere. Go to column

title: Can Soccer Replace War in Chechnya?
description: Soccer is that rare activity that can transcend politics, when it isnt being used as a manipulative political tool. It did so, to some extent, in Iraq, when the national team won the Asian Cup last year. Also in Ivory Coast, where the Elephants 2006 World Cup performance rallied a nation of fans still weary from the brutality of ethnic and civil war touched off when a 2002 failed coup split the West African country.

title: For Orbitz Shareholders, a Truly Bad Trip
description: Orbitz Worldwides initial public offering last summer got savage reviews from many business writers, bloggers and other industry experts. The GigaOm blog nominated it for the worst I.P.O. of the year. Others suggested that Blackstone Group, which had bought Orbitzs parent company, Travelport, less than a year before the offering, was just trying to executive the kind of quick flip that has given private equity firms a bad rap.

title: Maternal Instinct Is Wired Into the Brain
description: A mothers impulse to love and protect her child appears to be hard-wired into her brain, a new imaging study shows.

title: F1 Season Preview
description: The IHT F1 season preview is now up on the site, as is the first installment of the IHT Global Sports Forum  F1 edition! Bookmark the special F1 page where the preview is located, as that will be the location of my stories in the coming F1 Special Reports throughout the season, and it has a link to this blog.

title: Bids on G.M. Building May Top $3 Billion
description: Four bidders turned in their second-round offers on Thursday for the General Motors Building, the white marble real estate trophy on Fifth Avenue, according to an executive involved in the sale. But mystery surrounds the sale of the 50-story tower by its financially troubled owner, Harry B. Macklowe.There are reports that the bids topped $3 billion, but it was unclear exactly who made what would be a record-setting price for an office building. Joseph Cayre and S L Green did not submit new offers with the others, unwilling to go over the $3 billion threshold. And there is conflicting information whether another first-round bidder, the developer Larry A. Silverstein, made a second offer.

title: Just Browsing
description: Just Browsing sews together the latest fashion news from our global sources of mags, trades, blogs and tipsters.

title: Goldman Names Head of Americas M&A
description: As Goldman Sachs continues to make changes to its top ranks, the investment bank has promoted Tim Ingrassia to head its mergers and acquisitions practice in the Americas, according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook.

title: Puerto Rico Plans Switch From Caucus to Primary
description: Puerto Rico is moving to hold a presidential primary instead of a caucus on June 1, the Associated Press reports.

title: Ratings: How Many New Ways Can We Say It? Just Sing, Dammit. Sing!
description: Like a knife-wielding psycho that cant be stopped, American Idol destroyed Thursdays ratings for the third and final time this week, boosting the young Fox drama New Amsterdam and giving Fox an easy win for the evening.

title: NBC Still Looking for an Open Receiver for Friday Night Lights
description: NBC says a deal has not been reached yet. And DirecTV has no comment. But fans of Friday Night Lights are hopeful that the rumors of a third season deal for the football drama are true.

title: Thornburg Mortgage Says Survival in Doubt
description: Thornburg Mortgage, the second-largest independent mortgage lender in the United States, said Friday that its survival was at stake because it was unable to meet $610 million of margin calls.

title: Sculpture Park Takes Shape at the Holland Tunnel
description: The words sculpture park bring the rolling expanses of Orange County to mind (Storm King Art Center) or, at least, the rivers edge in Queens (Socrates Sculpture Park). They do not instantly conjure the traffic-jammed corner of Varick and Canal Streets.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Friday, Mar. 7:

title: In Connecticut: Slamming the College Door on an Unfortunate Few
description: Connecticuts Republican governor, M. Jodi Rell, vetoed a bill last year  and opposes a similar bill this year  that would have allowed residents who are illegal immigrants to pay in-state tuition at state colleges.
