title: I Spy a Problem
description: So Commissioner Roger Goodell has asked for new powers to keep N.F.L. teams from spying on each other. (Never mind the fact that he has previously argued that he has put an end to the practice.) From John Branch and Greg Bishop:

title: Memories of the Jura
description: One of the great joys of the wine beat is discovering new and unfamiliar flavors. Even better than simply finding them is becoming obsessed with them. Not that Im the obsessive type. Maybe entranced is a better word.

title: Scenes From High School Confidential
description: WE's documentary series tracks 12 girls through pregnancy, depression, eperiments with sex, drugs and alcohol, and, finally, one brain tumor.

title: Weekend Explorer
description: Behind the curtains, our love affair with the photo booth, first unveiled in Times Square in 1926, goes on.

title: Quenching Your Thirst in Vietnam
description: Join Neil Katz as he explores the different beverages of Vietnam.

title: Spitzer Makes Plans to Save Moynihan Station
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzers rescue plan for the Moynihan Station project may involve having the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey take control of plans from another agency, build a new Pennsylvania Station and transform the surrounding neighborhood with a half-dozen skyscrapers. The project, which calls for relocating Madison Square Garden a block away and constructing a grand new train station in Manhattan at 33rd Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, has neared collapse because of shortfalls in government financing, logistical problems and political inertia.

title: 2709_a1_wg_vietnam1_nk.mov
description: Join Neil Katz as he explores the different beverages of Vietnam.

title: Turn Their Smoke Detectors Forward
description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

title: Some Ding Wild
description: An escalating parking lot dispute that many of us can imagine (although it does seem more of a guy thing):

title: Giants and Coughlin Sign a Four-Year Deal
description: The negotiations are complete, and the Giants and Coach Tom Coughlin have agreed on a four-year contract that will pay the Super Bowl-winning coach roughly $21 million.

title: My Clever Idea for Financing Furniture
description: Normal people, when they move into a new house, take most of their old possessions with them  beds, kitchen table and the like  and buy a couple of new pieces to spruce things up.

title: Calling Commander McCain
description: Please keep running those 3:00 A.M. ads about who you want to answer the phone, because we like those. That, according to Foreign Policys Mike Boyer, is what McCain adviser Randy Scheunemann asked of Clinton staffer Mara Rudman at a Council on Foreign Relations event today. Boyer continues:

title: R.N.C. Embraces McCain Candidacy
description: Work on the general election at the Democratic National Committee may be stalled as the party sorts out its delegate mess, but the Republican National Committee is pressing forward.

title: Huge Executive Pay Amid Meltdown
description: CNBC covers a House hearing on executive pay at Merrill Lynch, Countrywide and Citigroup following the firms' billion-dollar losses.

title: Viva Biba
description: From left, Kate Moss and Barbara Hulanicki; Ronnie Wood; Lady Laura Wollesley (Photos: Toby Summerskill).

title: Puzzling Case of the Ex-Missing Ex-Model
description: Waris Dirie is the kind of woman they use the word striking about, with her slender 5 foot 9 frame and the face and poise of the supermodel-actress she once was. The native Somalian would be hard to overlook on a Northern European street even if she werent familiar from the James Bond thriller she appeared in, or the fashion, fragrance and cosmetics ads she has done.

title: McCain Asked About Kerrys V.P. Offer
description: NEW ORLEANS  Senator John McCain got a question at a town hall meeting this morning in Atlanta that he never has addressed publicly before: Since Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, had approached Mr. McCain about being his running mate for the White House in 2004, would Mr. McCain now return the favor?

title: College Hockey: The Battle of I-25
description: Three conferences get their playoffs under way this weekend, but lets take a moment to appreciate one last regular season matchup while theres still time.

title: The Back Story | Sweetbreads
description: (Tony Cenicola/The New York Times)

title: A Good Fed Move
description: Notes on wild markets, and worried economists:

title: Fun With Mirrors and Dust  a Climate Fix?
description: The trajectories for emissions of carbon dioxide as the worlds industrial and industrializing countries boost coal burning are clearly going to be tough to turn around, whether through caps on emissions or efforts to improve non-polluting energy technologies. And big hurdles remain before there will be any large-scale capturing of carbon dioxide to pump it underground or elsewhere for safekeeping.

title: Things Vital to the Honor of Human Life
description: Samuel Johnson once cautioned against the practice of recommending Shakespeare through the greatest-hits approach of quoting selected passages. Remarkable as the chosen passages might be, Johnson warned, the critic who relied simply on quotation was like the man who, when he offered his house to sale, carried a brick in his pocket as a specimen.

title: In This Weeks Magazine: The Rerun of the Repressed
description: UPDATE: The subtitled BeTipul is, as far as I can tell, unavailable in the United States. Efforts are being made to find a link  or a source  for interested fans. Watch this space. And eBay.

title: Letter Writer Becomes Odd Footnote to Times Square Bombing
description: When David A. Karnes, a California lawyer, sent letters late last month to members of Congress with a picture taken of a man standing in front of the Times Square recruiting station, he could not have imagined that days later, F.B.I. agents would swarm his Los Angeles home and interrogate him. The authorities have ruled out a connection between the bombing of the recruiting station on early Thursday morning and Mr. Karnes, who has become an odd footnote to a story that has perplexed investigators.

title: Dent and Torrez Reunited
description: I had dinner Thursday in Tampa with Michael Kay, the play-by-play announcer for the YES Network who has been a friend of mine for over 20 years. We ended up at a restaurant where Bucky Dent and Mike Torrez, two players who are forever linked in baseball history, were sitting at the same table.

title: SAC Sells Part of Its Stake in Alliance Data
description: As Alliance Data Systems deal with the Blackstone Group remains in limbo, it appears a notable investor is bailing out.

title: MAAC the Knife
description: ALBANY  Greetings, college basketball junkies. Im in New Yorks capital city, about to head over to the Times Union Center (formerly Pepsi Arena, and before that Knickerbocker Arena) for the first round of the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conferences mens tournament tonight.

title: Is Arrested Assemblymans Electability Tainted?
description: Among many politicians in Harlem and beyond, it has been a period of reflections and day-after quarterbacking on the prospects of Assemblyman Adam Clayton Powell IV. Mr. Powell, the son of a Harlem political icon, was charged on Thursday with drunken driving and pleaded not guilty in a Manhattan Criminal Court.

title: The is Have It: The BBCs iPlayer on the iPhone
description: I keep harping on the potential of video on the iPhone, because it is such an attractive video playback device and because this market will show how much Apple will allow other companies with different business models to compete with its own iTunes store.

title: Friday Dump: Pairs of Links on a Variety of Topics
description: Good things come in pairs, from Ring Dings to the following links that we found in our Web travels this week.

title: Donald Trump Goes to the Beach
description: Donald Trump  who likes getting his way, and his name on things  could be handed a setback on both scores. He hasnt been getting anywhere in his plan to build an enormous catering hall bearing the Trump brand at Jones Beach State Park.

title: The Week in Pictures for March 7
description: Here is a slide show of photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a windy storm in Corona, Queens, preparations for spring in Bryant Park and Colombian party buses.

title: Frugal Cancun
description: The Frugal Traveler explores the playas and parties of Cancun for pocos pesos.

title: Soft Serve | Tom Ford for Costco, Amazons Wine Shop, Pillow Talk
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: Pelosi Asks Campaigns to Simmer Down
description: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi asked the campaigns of Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama to stop their bickering, The San Francisco Chronicle reports.

title: The Frugal Traveler:
description: The Frugal Traveler explores the playas and parties of Cancn for pocos pesos.

title: Spectrum Auction: The Battle for Minot Nears an End
description: Imagine that a $20 billion bank merger is about to be consummated, but the parties pause to spend weeks bickering about the fate of the branch in Minot, N.D.

title: What is to be done?
description: Ive been reading Tim Geithners talk on the financial situation, via Mark Thoma. Lay readers may not know this, but Geithner, as the president of the New York Fed, is at the center of the hurricane: when markets go blooey, its generally the New York Fed  which is where the markets are  rather than officials in DC thats trying to manage the chaos.

title: Bloggingheads: Do the Media Matter?
description:
David Corn of Mother Jones, left, debates Rachel Sklar of Huffington Post about whether "the media" remain influential enough to bias the presidential campaign.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: A Most Uncommon Man
description: It was my freshman year at Yale. I was fresher than most  and from Nebraska  so just about everything I saw, heard and did that year astonished me.

title: The Florida-Michigan Futures
description: O.K., people, we knew this debate wouldnt end in a debate or in a week.

title: Vows: Chloe and Patrick
description: A bike ride through Argentina's wine country brought Chloe O'Connor and Patrick O'Brien together.

title: Paris: Back to Black
description: During the Paris shows I kept noting the number of variations on the chic black dress. It wasnt hard. There were those three killer examples from Balenciaga, the ribbon dresses at Lanvin, and a softly draped number from Louis Vuitton with black embroidery around the neckline that suggested (to me) barbed wire. I think Junya Watanabes jersey dresses count, too.

title: The New York Times Close Up
description: In his weekly program on NY1, Sam Roberts's guests include the columnist Bob Herbert.

title: The New York Times Close Up
description: In his weekly program on NY1, Sam Roberts guests include William Kristol, A.O. Scott and Nathaniel Rich.

title: Hair Razing Season
description: ALBANY  Were going to take a guess that Manhattans Barry Rohrssen is probably the only basketball coach in the country with a quote in his media guide bio from David Dinkins, the former New York City mayor.

title: From Girlish Squeals to Murky Depths
description: The jazz singer Diane Schuur has a stage personality that brings to mind the kind of garrulous partygoer whose slightly hysterical laughter can be heard pealing above the din. She is a blowzy next-door neighbor in frayed housedress gulping coffee while dispensing back-fence gossip with a cheery gusto. When she gets excited during a song, she flutters her hands and snaps her fingers. On Thursday evening at the Blue Note, where she began a four-night engagement, she referred to people in the audience as dear and sweetheart.

title: Colleges Reduce Out-of-State Tuition to Lure Students
description: HAYWARD, Calif.  California State University, East Bay, has never had the cachet of nearby Berkeley. But it has a great location overlooking the San Francisco Bay and aspires to raise its profile and grow.

title: China Hurt by Bjork
description: China will tighten its restrictions on foreign performers following an appearance last Sunday in Shanghai by the Icelandic singer Bjork, who shouted Tibet, Tibet after performing her song Declare Independence. Chinas Ministry of Culture responded to Bjorks action on Friday by posting a statement on its Web site, saying that she broke Chinese law and hurt Chinese peoples feelings, The Associated Press reported. Bjork has sung the song before in support of independence movements; performing in Japan in February, she dedicated it to Kosovo.

title: Rolling and Unraveling Through Thick and Thin and Smoking the Result
description: I CROUCHED over a wooden bench inside the rolling room in El Credito Cigars factory in the Little Havana neighborhood of Miami, peering at a light brown tobacco leaf. It was half past 9 on a Monday morning, and I had just gulped down two paper thimbles of Cuban coffee. My head was buzzing with caffeine and ambient cigar smoke. My mentor, Leo Peraza, a 67-year-old Cuban-born master cigar roller in a blue apron, leaned over my shoulder.

title: A Family Tree of Literary Fakers
description: When the news emerged this week that Margaret Seltzer had fabricated her gang memoir, Love and Consequences, under the pseudonym Margaret B. Jones, many in the publishing industry and beyond thought: Here we go again.

title: How Art Is Framed: Exhibition Floor Plans as a Conceptual Medium
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  The California artist Michael Asher may never have a museum retrospective. He deserves one, being among the patron saints of the Conceptual Art phylum known as institutional critique, an often esoteric dissection of the assumptions that govern how we perceive art. The sticking point is that his 40-year career hasnt produced much that could add up to a survey.

title: Obama Camp Sees Fine Line in Hitting Back
description: CASPER, Wyo.  Since opening his presidential bid 14 months ago, Senator Barack Obama of Illinois has answered many questions about his candidacy.

title: Deal in an Autism Case Fuels Debate on Vaccine
description: WASHINGTON  Study after study has failed to show any link between vaccines and autism, but many parents of autistic children remain unconvinced. For the skeptics, the case of 9-year-old Hannah Poling shows that they have been right along.

title: 3 Admit Guilt in $8 Million Theft From an Armored Car Company in Ohio
description: AKRON, Ohio  A young man and his girlfriend pleaded guilty Friday to stealing $8.4 million in November from an armored car company where he worked.

title: Goodell Proposes New Rules to Keep Teams From Spying
description: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell wants to strengthen the leagues oversight on rules and strengthen his powers to penalize violators.

title: Market Storm Clouds Show No Sign of Lifting
description: This weeks tape told a painful tale.

title: Woman With a Mission: Keeping Tabs on Sex Offenders
description: STONY BROOK, N.Y.  After a quick aerial survey of Long Island and the sites where its 1,200 registered sex offenders reside, Laura Ahearn used her computers mouse to swoop down on the Nassau County village of Hempstead, dotted with 50 icons resembling pushpins: green for Level 2 offenders, blue for Level 3. She headed east over Brentwood in Suffolk County, home to about 60 offenders, and zeroed in on the thickest cluster: the Gordon Heights section of Coram, with 69 pushpins, more than a dozen crowded onto a single block.

title: Of Cannon Fire and Daylight Saving Time
description: Benjamin Franklin was wrong. Or maybe not. The sage of Philadelphia conceived of a system similar to daylight saving time in 1784 while serving as Americas first ambassador to France. In a letter to the editor of the Paris Journal, he estimated that the simple act of awakening at sunrise and retiring at sunset in the months between spring and fall would result in an annual saving of a little more than 64 million pounds in candle wax for Pariss residents.

title: A Broadway Mother of Many Identities
description: As Mother in the critically acclaimed Passing Strange, Eisa Davis is the quietest character in a loquacious, exuberant and really loud Broadway musical about the search for authenticity and meaning by her son, a restless character named Youth.

title: Arab Leaders, Angry at Syrian President, Threaten Boycott of Summit Meeting
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Several Arab leaders say they may boycott the annual Arab summit meeting scheduled for this month in Damascus, the Syrian capital, because of anger at Syria over its role in Lebanon and its continuing links to Iran.

title: A Pilgrimage Tale (Not Chaucers) Amuses and Inspires
description: DSSELDORF, Germany

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Sunday about Barack Obamas effort to land a knockout blow to the campaign of Hillary Rodham Clinton with large advertising expenditures referred incorrectly to the indie-rock band Arcade Fire, which performed a concert for Mr. Obama in Ohio. Some members are from Canada and some from Texas; they did not all grow up in Texas.

title: Gains for Opposition in Malaysia Elections
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Malaysias ruling coalition, which has governed this multiracial country without any major challenges for the past four decades, suffered a string of election defeats in key constituencies on Saturday, including the relatively prosperous industrial state of Penang.

title: Bush Vetoes Bill That Would Limit Interrogations
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush on Saturday further cemented his legacy of fighting for strong executive powers, using his veto to shut down a congressional effort to limit the Central Intelligence Agencys latitude to subject terrorism suspects to harsh interrogation techniques that are prohibited by the military and law enforcement agencies.

title: Belarus: U.S. Ambassador Told to Leave
description: Belarus said it was withdrawing its ambassador from Washington, complaining about sanctions imposed by the United States over its crackdown on the political opposition and the press. Belarus also demanded that Washington withdraw its ambassador from Minsk, but the Bush administration gave no indication that it would do so. An administration spokesman instead criticized the Belarus government for its repressive actions.

title: McCain Grows Testy on Question About 04 and Kerry Partnership
description: NEW ORLEANS  Senator John McCain fielded a question at a public forum on Friday morning in Atlanta that he said he had never been asked before. Because Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, had approached him about being his running mate for the White House in 2004, would Mr. McCain now return the favor?

title: Border Agents Murder Trial Ends
description: TUCSON  The case of a Border Patrol agent who faced charges of second-degree murder and other crimes in the shooting death of a Mexican immigrant last year resulted in a mistrial on Friday when a jury could not reach a verdict.

title: A Cross-Country Trip Could End in Pinstripes
description: TAMPA, Fla.  It is quite a trip from Los Angeles to Port St. Lucie, Fla., but Billy Traber was happy to drive it in the spring of 2001. After a summer in which a magnetic resonance imaging exam had cost him $1.3 million, Traber eagerly hopped in his 1992 Ford Ranger and took on a challenge to start his career.

title: To Revive Hunting, States Turn to the Classroom
description: MORGANTOWN, W.Va.  When David Helms was in seventh grade, he would take his .22-caliber rifle to school, put a box of ammunition in his locker and, like virtually all the other boys, lean his rifle against a wall in the principals office so he could start hunting squirrels and groundhogs as soon as classes let out.

title: Armenia: Vote Observers More Critical
description: An election observation team from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe issued a second report on the presidential election that handed an overwhelming victory to the prime minister, delivering a more negative assessment of the Feb. 19 vote and its recount than it initially gave. The report documented numerous cases of violence, including a case in which a domestic observer lost consciousness, and implausibly high voter turnout at a number of polling stations. It assessed the vote count at 17 percent of the stations as bad or very bad and reported significant procedural errors, including placing ballots on the wrong candidates pile.

title: After Penalty, Owner Comes to Defense of Edwards
description: HAMPTON, Ga.  Jack Roush was scheduled to address the news media late Friday afternoon regarding the penalties Nascar levied against his driver Carl Edwards and the Office Depot team after last Sundays Sprint Cup race in Las Vegas.

title: A Longer Prison Term for a Former Mayor
description: ATLANTA  The Federal Bureau of Prisons has extended the prison term of former Mayor Bill Campbell of Atlanta, a spokeswoman confirmed Friday, a week after news reports questioned his participation in an early release drug treatment program.

title: On a Minimal Set, Maximizing Puccini
description: Gerard Mortier, the director of the Paris National Opera, has said he will focus on contemporary works when he becomes general manager and artistic director of the New York City Opera next year. Though Puccini will presumably not remain in the spotlight on Mr. Mortiers watch, there may still be room for Mark Lamoss strikingly elegant, spare production of Madama Butterfly, which returned to the New York State Theater on Thursday.

title: Indie Company Cuts Staff
description: LOS ANGELES  Sidney Kimmel Entertainment, the producer of an eclectic string of upscale movies including Lars and the Real Girl and The Kite Runner but not a single commercial hit, said on Friday that it was scaling back its ambitions.

title: MBIA, the Bond Insurer, Asks Fitch to Quit Rating Some Units
description: The bond insurer MBIA Inc., which is facing a downgrade, asked Fitch Ratings on Friday to stop issuing credit ratings on its insurance units.

title: Robert Kraichnan, Physicist Who Studied Turbulence, Is Dead at 80
description: Robert H. Kraichnan, an innovative physicist who shed light on the dynamics of turbulence in ocean waters and winds in the upper atmosphere, died on Feb. 26 in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 80.

title: What to Do About Electronic Waste?
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Names in Retail Fashion Are Trading Teams
description: Its free-agency season in American fashion.

title: Sharp Drop in Jobs Adds to Grim Economic Picture
description: WASHINGTON  The worst fears of consumers, investors and Washington officials were confirmed on Friday, as deepening paralysis on Wall Street collided with stark new evidence of falling employment and a likely recession.

title: NBC May Be Considering Kathie Lee Gifford for Today
description: Kathie Lee Gifford would return to morning television as a host of the fourth hour of NBCs Today program under an arrangement that her representatives have been discussing with the network, a person with direct knowledge of the conversations said on Friday.

title: Crisis Over Colombian Raid Ends in Handshakes
description: The leaders of four Latin American nations embroiled in a diplomatic crisis over a Colombian military raid in Ecuador ended the dispute on Friday with handshakes and warm embraces at a summit meeting that had earlier been marked by insults and accusations of treachery.

title: Dispute Is Threatening to Tear Apart Cycling
description: The eight-day Paris-to-Nice race unofficially marks the start of the professional cycling season. When this years event begins Sunday, however, it may also spark a collapse of the troubled sports organizational structure or the expulsion of its most important event, the Tour de France, from the race calendar.

title: Stuck in Traffic? A Sculpture Park May Ease the Pain
description: The words sculpture park bring the rolling expanses of Orange County to mind (Storm King Art Center) or, at least, the rivers edge in Queens (Socrates Sculpture Park). They do not instantly conjure up the traffic-jammed corner of Varick and Canal Streets.

title: American Axle Strike Idles More G.M. Plants
description: General Motors will idle production at nine more plants next week because of a strike at a parts supplier, American Axle and Manufacturing Holdings, bringing the number of shutdowns to 29.

title: A Construction Sector, Once Robust, Now Falters
description: IT has been the worst of times for the residential construction industry in America  and among the best of times for construction companies that build other kinds of buildings, ranging from hotels to office buildings and stores.

title: Letter Leads F.B.I. on False Trail to California After Bombing
description: When David A. Karnes, a California lawyer, sent letters last week to members of Congress with a picture of himself standing in front of the Times Square recruiting station, he could not have imagined that days later, F.B.I. agents would swarm around his house in Los Angeles and interrogate him. But that is what happened after Mr. Karness letters were briefly  and erroneously  linked to the bombing of the recruiting station on Thursday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Tuesday about the innovative release of new music by the band Nine Inch Nails in various formats, including digital downloads, referred incorrectly to BitTorrent. It is an online protocol that can be used in the distribution of files, like the bands new recordings. It is not a distinct file-sharing network. Because of an editing error, the article misstated the Web address of the company that oversees the protocol. It is bittorrent.com.

title: Men, Women and the Knots That Bind
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  After Liam Steel presented Sinner, a work he created with Rob Tannion for their company Stan Wont Dance at Performance Space 122 in 2006, it seemed that half of New York was enraptured with the production. Others, including me, were less delighted with that formulaic dance-theater work, based on the story of David Copeland, who in 1999 became known as the London nail bomber.

title: Flood Insurance Program
description: To the Editor:

title: Last Things Cant Wait Till Last
description: SOLELY from a financial perspective, death is a tedious topic. It is fraught with paperwork, bureaucracy and legal jargon like revocable living trust.

title: Covering a Notorious Crime in Spanish: Fascination, and a Different Angle
description: As the crowd shuffles out of the Brooklyn courtroom where Cesar Rodriguez is being tried in the killing of his stepdaughter, a small group of reporters gathers around his lawyers.

title: Herald of a Global Imagination Revolution
description: Deep in the woods, a lonely boy with thick glasses grew up without siblings, without television and without the Internet. But he had books, and in the tomes of a new sort of game called Dungeons & Dragons he discovered a fantastic world of sorcerers, maidens and trolls. He discovered loyalty and betrayal, cowardice and courage. In those books he realized that his mind had the power to transport him beyond barriers of class and religion, race and income. In those books, he realized he could be anyone.

title: ETA Is Blamed for a Killing in Spain That Curtails Election Campaigning
description: MADRID  Spains two main political parties abruptly curtailed campaigning for Sundays general election after a gunman suspected of belonging to the Basque militant group ETA killed a former city councilman in northern Spain on Friday.

title: Chiefs Pay Under Fire at Capitol
description: WASHINGTON  In pointed exchanges with Congressional lawmakers Friday, three prominent financial executives defended the multimillion-dollar pay packages they received even as their companies were brought to their knees by the spreading credit crisis.

title: Thailand Plans Inquiry on Arms Suspect as U.S. Seeks Custody
description: BANGKOK  The Thai police said Friday that a Russian businessman regarded as one of the worlds most notorious arms dealers would be held here for investigation even as the United States sought his extradition.

title: Local Farmers
description: To the Editor:

title: Banks Springing Up to Serve the Underserved
description: AT first glance Raleigh, N.C., may not seem like a logical place to open a Latino-oriented bank. After all, Raleigh is not a city like Los Angeles, for instance, where more than 47 percent of the population is Hispanic.

title: A Blood Drug From China
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqi Leader Tries to Mend Relationship With Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  The president of Iraq, Jalal Talabani, visited Turkey on Friday as part of a joint effort to mend relations strained by a Turkish ground offensive against Kurdish militants in northern Iraq.

title: Massachusetts: House Approved Near Hopper Site
description: A regional land use commission has approved the construction of a home in Truro that some say will alter the landscape Edward Hopper saw from the cottage where he painted and lived. The Cape Cod Commission voted 11 to 1 to allow Donald and Andrea Kline to build a planned 6,500-square-foot home on the 9.3-acre property. The commission put restrictions on the parcel, including that the home be no more than 14 feet high, no additional structures can be built and an existing home on the land be preserved. Foes of the development are calling for an additional review of the plans, which still must be approved by the Town of Truro. Hopper spent summers in Truro from 1930 until his death in 1967.

title: Lawyers Rally Against Musharraf Government
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan  Beside racks of hanging meat and barrows of oranges in the alleys of the old town here, Aitzaz Ahsan, the leader of the lawyers movement in Pakistan, was back on the campaign trail Saturday, calling for the release of the nations detained judiciary leaders.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Tuesday about the guitarist, singer and songwriter Jeff Healey misspelled the given name of his wife, who survives him. She is Cristie Healey, not Christie.

title: Mother Told of Helping to Kill Girl, Inmate Testifies
description: For weeks, defense lawyers for the stepfather of Nixzmary Brown, a 7-year-old girl who was beaten to death in Brooklyn, have been promising that jurors would hear bombshell testimony that Nixzmarys mother had admitted killing her.

title: Traffic Plan Needs Votes on Council, Survey Finds
description: Its the signature policy item of his second term, but Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs congestion pricing plan may be in serious trouble, not only in Albany but in the New York City Council, which after two years of bowing to much of the mayors agenda seems suddenly emboldened to resist him.

title: Steppenwolf Announces 2008-9 Season
description: The Steppenwolf Theater Company of Chicago, now on Broadway with its production of August: Osage County, said its 2008-9 season would open with a stage adaptation of Haruki Murakamis novel Kafka on the Shore by a Steppenwolf member, Frank Galati, who will also direct. Kafka is to be followed with a new production of Conor McPhersons Seafarer featuring John Mahoney. The season also includes a production of Yasmina Rezas Art; Shakespeares Tempest, directed by Tina Landau; and Bridget Carpenters Up, which will be directed by Anna D. Shapiro.

title: Clinton Works Wyoming to End Caucus Streak
description: Correction Appended

title: Dance in Review
description: LIMERENCE

title: Hefty Raises at Goldman Sachs
description: Goldman Sachs, the investment bank, awarded $67.5 million each to its co-presidents, Gary D. Cohn and Jon Winkelried, increasing their pay 27 percent as the company evaded the mortgage losses spreading through the economy.

title: Police Arrest Seven as Members of Heroin Ring
description: A heroin mill operated out of an apartment building opposite a middle school on the Upper East Side was broken up on Friday, and seven people involved in buying and selling the drugs, one of them a court officer, were arrested, the police said.

title: Sold on a Sense of Family at Rutgers
description: On the October morning Chelsey Lee awoke with her decision made, her destination clear, she summoned Shirlene Horne into her room and said, Mommy, Im going to commit.

title: Some Criticism of Procedure After Train Cars Disconnect
description: TRENTON  Cars on a New Jersey Transit train on its way to New York during the evening rush two weeks ago uncoupled as the train was leaving the North Elizabeth station, stunning riders and drawing criticism from the conductors union.

title: Man Ray Show in Paris
description: Spanning seven decades and including many objects seldom seen in public, an exhibition devoted to Man Ray (1890-1976), the American-born artist who was a father of Dada and Surrealism, opened at the Pinacothque de Paris museum, The Associated Press reported. The Workshop of Man Ray, running through June 1, includes portraits of Picasso and Ernest Hemingway as well as oddities like a life-size pair of golden lips and a blue baguette that adorns the cover of a book of lithographs.

title: Paul Raymond, 82, Dies; Built an Erotic Empire
description: LONDON  Paul Raymond, who began his entrepreneurial life selling black-market nylons and fuel coupons from a market stall during World War II and went on to become one of Britains richest men, overseeing an empire of Soho striptease clubs, salacious magazines and real estate holdings, died on Monday in London. He was 82.

title: Fort Drum Prints Photos After Arrests for D.W.I.
description: WATERTOWN, N.Y.  The Fort Drum Blizzard, the weekly newspaper for the Armys 10th Mountain Division, is the place soldiers usually turn for stories about new wartime missions, community events and classified ads.

title: Returning Improv to Its Classical Roots
description: Composers like Bach, Mozart, Beethoven, Chopin and Liszt were not just great performers but renowned improvisers. In earlier eras improvisation was no stunt, though it involved an undeniable element of showing off. Improvisation was a serious component of a public musicians craft.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 25 about Britney Spearss finances in the wake of her public breakdown misstated the support she has given to her family, including her father, Jamie, since she first became a pop star in 1999. Although she has helped her father financially during that time, she has not been the primary breadwinner for Mr. Spears, who works as a caterer in Los Angeles.

title: TVs Newest Daredevils Saw Away in the Woods
description: Reality television producers scouting around for something new might be wise to consider cooking up a series called Whos Got It Worse Off? The drivers on Ice Road Truckers could go up against the fishermen on Deadliest Catch, and now the loggers of Ax Men, in a contest to determine who endures the coldest, dampest weather, the worst on-the-job lunch, the ugliest outerwear, the most danger and the most unrelenting misery.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Sunday about John D. B. Lewis, a lawyer who fought for the rights of the poor, misspelled one of his middle names. He was John David Bonnor Lewis, not Bonner. The obituary also included erroneous information from his wife about a surviving brother, Salim B. Lewis. He lives in Essex, N.Y.; his whereabouts are not unknown.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Wednesday with coverage of Green Bay quarterback Brett Favres retirement described incorrectly, in some editions, the context for his wave to fans while walking off the field. It was after the Packers defeated the Seattle Seahawks in the playoffs in January, not after they lost to the Giants in the National Football Conference championship game. The caption also misstated the timing of the title game in some editions. It, too, was in January  not last month.

title: Visitors Retrace Paths of Faith at Billy Graham Library
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  With silver hair and vivid memories, the faithful are coming to the Billy Graham Library to relive the glory.

title: 142,000 Free Parking Permits? Fuhgeddaboutit!
description: To the Editor:

title: The Camera Doesnt Lie, but It Can Get Confused
description: The first camera in the room grabbed my face, put it on a screen and then began a computer analysis. It correctly identified me as male. Then the camera focused and followed my eyes, with a little box appearing around each one on the screen.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article last Saturday about a decision by the Air Force to award a contract for aerial refueling tankers to a partnership between Northrop Grumman and the European parent of Airbus referred imprecisely to the site of the plant where final assembly of the planes will take place. It is in Mobile, Ala., not near it.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 7, 2008

title: Text: Bush on Veto of Intelligence Bill
description: Following is the text of President Bushs radio address to the nation for Saturday, as released by the White House.

title: 2 Markets, of Varying Security, Highlight Challenge for U.S. Troops in Iraq
description: HAWIJA, Iraq  As Adm. Mike Mullen, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, sits down over the coming days to prepare his formal recommendation to President Bush on future troop levels in Iraq, he will reflect on his visits to two markets.

title: Text: Bushs Message to the House of Representatives
description: Following is the text of President Bushs message to the House of Representatives about his veto of the Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008.

title: Talk, but No Peace
description: There are a few certainties when it comes to the Middle East. One is that Hamas militants will do anything to sabotage Israeli-Palestinian peace efforts. Another is that Israel will retaliate against serious assaults on its people. And a third is that without measurable improvements in the lives of both Israelis and Palestinians, a few spectacular acts of terrorism can derail even the best-intentioned peace talks.

title: Donald Lopez, 84, World War II Pilot and Smithsonian Official, Dies
description: Donald S. Lopez, who became a World War II ace flying fighter planes in China and later helped develop the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum, died Monday in Durham, N.C. Mr. Lopez, the museums deputy director, was 84.

title: Fisk University Keeps Its O'Keeffes
description: A Tennessee judge has ruled that while Fisk University in Nashville violated the terms under which Georgia OKeeffe donated art to the institution, it should not lose the works to a New Mexico museum, The Associated Press reported. Ellen Hobbs Lyle, a Davidson County Chancery Court judge, permanently banned the sale of the 101-piece OKeeffe collection, but also ruled that Fisk must take the artworks out of storage and display them by October. Chancellor Lyle had vetoed previous efforts by the financially ailing university to raise money by selling the art, including OKeeffes 1927 oil painting Radiator Building  Night, New York, above. The Georgia OKeeffe Museum in New Mexico, representing her estate, had sued to get the collection, citing Fisks bids to sell the paintings and their removal from display as violations of the terms of the 1949 donation. Last month the judge rejected Fisks proposed $30 million sale of a half-interest in the artworks to the Crystal Bridges Museum in Bentonville, Ark., founded by the Wal-Mart heiress Alice Walton.

title: The Contaminated Blood Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Germans Seek China Tie to Blood Thinner Heparin
description: FRANKFURT  The German authorities said Friday that they had asked all German producers of the blood thinner heparin to check whether their ingredients came from China, after allergic reactions to the drug there were linked to two Chinese suppliers.

title: Manage Money Like a Star
description: MAINSTREET.COMS slogan is where life and money intersect. Judging by its content, the site equates life with celebrity gossip.

title: Tight Credit, Tough Times for Buyout Lords
description: Just over a year ago, William E. Conway Jr., a founding partner of the Carlyle Group, celebrated the riches that easy credit were bringing to the kings of Wall Street.

title: Coughlin Signs Deal to Coach for 4 Years
description: Tom Coughlin signed a four-year contract worth roughly $21 million to coach the Giants through 2011, completing a comeback on Friday just as surprising as the teams recent championship run.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article last Saturday about a decision by the Air Force to award a contract for aerial refueling tankers to a partnership between Northrop Grumman and the European parent of Airbus referred imprecisely to the site of the plant where final assembly of the planes will take place. It is in Mobile, Ala., not near it. (Go to Article)

title: A Third Night for 'Idol'
description: American Idol dominated ratings for a third and final time this week on Thursday, lifting the Fox drama New Amsterdam and giving the network an easy win for the evening, Nielsen estimated. About 26.2 million viewers watched the field of Idol finalists narrow to 12, and almost 10.6 million viewers stayed to watch the second episode of New Amsterdam at 9 p.m., a drop of three million from the viewership of its premiere on Tuesday. ABC won the 9 oclock hour when 12.8 million viewers tuned in for Lost; CBS placed third with 9.8 million viewers for CSI. At 10 p.m., Without a Trace averaged 9.4 million viewers for CBS, beating the 6.8 million for Eli Stone on ABC and the 5.8 million for Lipstick Jungle on NBC.

title: An Intellectual Rocker Steeped in Tradition
description: Greco-Roman mythology, misgivings about the Catholic Church and thoughts of Atlantis wouldnt seem to be the makings of a No. 1 album. Yet they were just that in Italy, where Carmen Consolis 2006 album Eva Contro Eva (Eve Against Eve) topped the charts. (It has been released here by Universal Music Latino.)

title: Clashing Over Church Ritual and Flag Protocol at the Naval Academy Chapel
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md.  On Sundays at the Naval Academy Chapel, at a few minutes past 11 a.m., the choir stops singing and a color guard carrying the academy flag and the American flag strides up the aisle.

title: Confronting the Kitchen Sink
description: The high anxiety in the Obama circles has thrown the campaign off its game.

title: Injuries Limit Rodriguez and Posada
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Alex Rodriguez was already in the on-deck circle when a Houston Astros hitter grounded out to end the top of the second inning. When he stepped into the batters box, Rodriguez lashed the first pitch he saw down the left-field line for a double.

title: Ethnic Divide Worsens as Sri Lanka Conflict Escalates
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  There are no eyes on this war. A truce between the Sri Lankan government and the separatist Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam is over, and gone are the Nordic monitors who kept watch over it.

title: A One-Party New York State
description: Democrats in New York are only one Senate election away from full control of state government. This could be a chance for one party finally to break the gridlock and start getting things done. In Albany, however, the idea of one party in total control, even a party with many promising goals, should stir great public concern.

title: Safety for Consumers
description: When millions of Elmos and Barbies and Thomas the Tank Engines were recalled last year, Americans got a warning about the cost of cheap imported goods and the weakness of this countrys regulatory system. Now, Congress and the Bush administration are finally trying to make sure these toys and millions of other imported products are safe for consumers of all ages.

title: Lord Francis Pym, Ex-Foreign Secretary of Britain, Dies at 86
description: LONDON  Francis Pym, Britains foreign secretary under Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher during the 1982 Falklands War only to be fired a year later, died on Friday after a long illness. He was 86.

title: Avoiding a Problem C.E.O.
description: Observers are often amazed when executives with impressive track records are mysteriously transformed into corrupt and tyrannical monsters once they become C.E.O.s, Terry Leap, a management professor at Clemson University, writes in Sloan Management Review.

title: And the Good News Is ...
description: We live in a great country. Despite all our problems, this is still a nation where parents believe that if their child works hard and plays by the rules, some day he or she may grow up to be a superdelegate.

title: Thinking of Championships and a Marathon Final Round
description: The Spring North American Championships of the American Contract Bridge League are under way in Detroit.

title: Armed Guard and No Door, but Recruiters Carry On
description: The scene of the crime on Friday morning had no yellow crime scene tape blocking off the sidewalk, and no locks on the door. The door had been so badly shattered that it had to be removed.

title: Got a Mint, Comrade? Chinese Ban Liquid Lunch
description: XINYANG, China  Li Bin, a barrel-chested retiree on special assignment for this citys Communist Party boss, strode down an empty hallway of the Xinyang Middle Court in search of bureaucrats. He rattled locked doorknobs and barged into offices without knocking. A court officer retreated in red-faced terror.

title: 8 Burials for Jerusalem Seminarys Dead
description: KFAR ETZION, West Bank  They carried the body of Avraham David Moses, 16 years old, on a stretcher down the slope of the vibrant green cemetery here, shaded by tall pines, overlooking a valley, in utter silence.

title: In the Land of Glitter and Gambling, Plans for an Oasis of Art
description: LAS VEGAS  In a boisterous town legendary for shining the spotlight on Elvis, Sinatra and Celine, its a safe bet that few could have envisioned these names as Strip attractions:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture in some editions on Wednesday of Hillary Rodham Clinton with supporters in Ohio carried an erroneous credit. It was by Todd Heisler of The New York Times, not by David Ahntholz. Another photograph on Wednesday, of a polling place in Cleveland, omitted a credit for Mr. Ahntholz.

title: Richard J. Durrell, First Publisher of People Magazine, Dies at 82
description: Richard J. Durrell, the founding publisher of People magazine, died on Friday at his home in Fairfield, Conn. He was 82.

title: A Conviction Might Limit, but Not End, a Political Career, Observers Say
description: A charge of drunken driving is the kind of news development that can hurt a politicians ambitions for higher office. But in the case of Assemblyman Adam Clayton Powell IV, it is far from a political kiss of death, many politicians in Harlem and around the city said on Friday.

title: Buckley and the Ideologues
description: To the Editor:

title: Pistons Take Revenge Against Young Knicks
description: Not that the Knicks needed bad luck  they have fallen on their faces just fine on their own throughout the season  but the Detroit Pistons had something to prove Friday night.

title: Songs of Love, Peace and Land Mines
description: Juanes, the Colombian rocker and global megastar, was the picture of smoldering intent at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night. Singing with equal conviction about love and violence, he offered no spectacle greater than his own charisma. His fallback stance was heroic  feet planted wide, chin pointed out, arms outstretched or cradling a guitar  but his gaze proposed a covenant of intimacy, at least to anyone watching one of the three large video screens above the stage.

title: Martnezs Changeup: Less Talk, More Action
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Shortly after 10 a.m. Friday, Pedro Martnez prepared to throw his first pitch of the day. He looked in to see Damion Easley, his teammate, wearing a windbreaker and limbering up in a batting cage. Behind Martnez was a screen that protected observers like Manager Willie Randolph and the pitching coach Rick Peterson. A crowd of teammates, officials and assorted guests stood a few feet foul of the first-base line.

title: Ex-Labor Leader, Guilty of Racketeering, Recites a 45-Minute Catalog of Crimes
description: The former head of the nations biggest municipal labor council painstakingly detailed years of thievery from his own union and the state on Friday as he pleaded guilty to racketeering charges in federal court in Manhattan.

title: Seeing an End to the Good Times (Such as They Were)
description: If history is a reliable guide, the recession of 2008 is now unavoidable.

title: Concern in Europe on Cellphone Ads for Children
description: PARIS  The MO1 beginner mobile phone is not as cuddly as a teddy bear, but manufacturers of the curvy crimson-and-blue handset for 6-year-olds promise a similarly warm and fuzzy relationship. They boast about socialization, emotional health and the comforts of peace of mind.

title: Footnotes
description: A San Francisco Opera performance of Puccinis Rondine, starring Angela Gheorghiu, will be presented on screen at the Ziegfeld Theater in Manhattan on Saturday and Sunday at 2 p.m. and on Monday and Tuesday at 7 p.m. (The same production is to open at the Metropolitan Opera in December.) ... Lou Pearlman, the music mogul behind the Backstreet Boys and N Sync, pleaded guilty Thursday to federal charges of conspiracy, making false statements during bankruptcy proceedings and money laundering, The Associated Press reported. He is scheduled to be sentenced on May 21 and faces $1 million in fines and up to 25 years in prison. ... Mario Lopez, once known as A. C. Slater in Saved by the Bell and more recently a second-place finisher in Dancing With the Stars, will be stepping into the role of Zach in A Chorus Line on Broadway from April 15 to Sept. 7.

title: Chinese Rights Activist Reported Missing
description: BEIJING  A Chinese lawyer who has urged the Communist Party to improve its human rights record in advance of the Summer Olympics has disappeared, according to his wife, who said Friday that she was worried that the authorities might have detained him because of his political advocacy.

title: For a Conductors Milestone Performance, Opera in Concert and as a Celebration
description: Eve Quelers 100th performance at Carnegie Hall with the Opera Orchestra of New York, on Thursday night, was an accurate encapsulation of the previous 99. Ms. Quelers long-running opera-in-concert series has had a winning way of making novelty and discovery compensate for uneven quality.

title: F.B.I. Opens Criminal Inquiry Into Countrywide
description: WASHINGTON  Federal agencies have opened a criminal inquiry into Countrywide Financial for suspected securities fraud as part of the continuing fallout over the mortgage crisis, government officials with knowledge of the case said on Saturday.

title: China Defends Sudan Policy and Criticizes Olympics Tie-In
description: BEIJING  China has expressed grave concerns to the Sudanese government about the recent violence in western Darfur and is actively working to resolve delays in establishing an international peacekeeping force, Chinas special envoy to Darfur said Friday.

description: We are playing Russian roulette with the American food supply, thundered Wayne Pacelle.

title: Retooling for a Changing Telecom Landscape
description: LONDON  Competition is fierce in the European telecommunications industry, where companies are vying for customers by undercutting each other on prices for services like broadband while trying to keep up with new technologies.

title: Mixed Economic Picture in Next Big State to Vote
description: PHILADELPHIA  A dismal jobs report on Friday thrust the nations ailing economy to the forefront of the presidential campaign. But as the candidates shift their attention to Pennsylvania, which votes April 22, they are likely to find a more positive economic landscape than they might have expected from a Rust Belt state once heavily dependent on steel, coal and manufacturing jobs.

title: Court Extends Role of Spears's Father
description: In the latest development in Britney Spearss continuing family drama, a Los Angeles Superior Court commissioner ordered the troubled singers estate to pay her father, James Spears, $2,500 in weekly compensation, and extended his authority over his daughters affairs at least until July 31, The Associated Press reported. The commissioner, Reva Goetz, also ordered the estate to make a $58,800 payment to the court-appointed lawyer, Samuel D. Ingham III, who represents Ms. Spears in the conservatorship case, and authorized Ms. Spearss psychiatrist to hire two other doctors and pay them retainers totaling $9,000 from her estate. Following Ms. Spearss hospitalization in January, Mr. Spears was named her conservator and co-conservator of her estate.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with the continuation of a front-page article on Friday about an attack by a gunman at a Jewish seminary in Jerusalem referred incorrectly to comments by the police about the ages of the victims. Although the police said that many of the dead were thought to be in their 20s, they did not say conclusively at the time that they were. (On Friday morning the police released the names and ages of the dead, showing that they ranged in age from 15 to 26 and that most of them were teenagers.)

title: Lilly Waited Too Long to Warn About Schizophrenia Drug, Doctor Testifies

title: Flowers and Blini: Moscow Traditions this Weekend
description: Russia has geared up fore a double-hitter holiday weekend that will offer an entertaining mix of Soviet and pre-revolutionary pagan traditions: Saturday, March 8 is Womens Day, an official Soviet-era holiday that has carried over to capitalist Russia. Sunday, March 9, is the culmination of Maslenitsa, a pagan celebration of spring that became the Russian version of Carnaval, which is being celebrated with new fervor as Russians re-embrace old traditions.

title: Whats Ben doing? (Very wonkish)
description: The financial crisis seems to have entered its third wave. Panic in August, then partial recovery thanks to lots of money thrown at the system by the Fed. title: The Early Word: Wyoming? Why Not?
description: Updated For the time being, it doesnt matter whether the Clinton campaigns contention that caucuses are undemocratic is accurate  they count. And Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton appears determined to break her all-but-Nevada (and New Mexico!) losing streak in them. Over the past several days, she and her family have been stumping around Wyoming, which is holding Democratic caucuses throughout the morning and early afternoon today. The intensity of her late efforts there appear to be helping her catch up to Senator Barack Obama, according to state party officials, even though he was more organized there, meaning weve got a real race today in Vice President Dick Cheneys home state.

title: Kathie Lee For Fourth Hour Of Today?
description: Jacques Steinberg reports: Kathie Lee Gifford would return to morning television as a host of the fourth hour of NBCs Today program under an arrangement that her representatives have been discussing with the network, a person with direct knowledge of the conversations said on Friday.

description: CHEYENNE, Wyo.  At times its lonely being a Democrat in Wyoming, John Millin, the chairman of the Wyoming Democratic Party, said this morning.

title: Can Thou Play, Romeo?
description: Heres a novel way to get a college scholarship: be the rapper son of a hip-hop mogul, the star of a kids television show and a good friend of a highly touted prospect. The Wall Street Journals Jon Weinbach reports on how this combination of factors seems to have helped Romeo Miller, better known as Lil Romeo, get a scholarship to play at Southern California.

title: If You Dont Like Your Grade, Fire the Teacher
description: MBIA, the bond insurance company, has asked Fitch Ratings to stop rating it. It seems that Fitch, unlike Moodys and Standard & Poors, has not yet bought into the idea that MBIA deserves a AAA rating despite the structured finance debacle. (Investors dont buy it either, judging by the yields they demand on insured bonds.)

title: Anand Wins Morelia-Linares
description: Viswanathan Anand of India, the world champion, has won the Morelia-Linares super tournament. It is the third time that Anand has won this prestigious tournament and the second time in a row. Magnus Carlsen of Norway was second, a half point behind, followed by Levon Aronian of Armenia and Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria, who were another half point back. A crosstable and games from the event, as well as information about the players and a list of the previous winners, is on the tournaments Web site. Interviews with some of the players, including Anand, are on the Europe-Echecs Web site.

title: Gone to Deletopedia
description: Does Nicholson Baker throw anything away? He has written articles in defense of old card catalogs, chided microfilm-happy librarians  for sending books to warehouses (and landfills), and founded the American Newspaper Repository, a home for abandoned historical newspapers. According to a profile in this weeks Times, even the prospect of returning the library books he used to research his new book Human Smoke makes him sigh wistfully. (Is this because he doesnt trust librarians to safeguard them, or other people to actually read them?)

Elsewhere, supporters of Senator Barack Obama were writing and calling other forums, including The Caucus, asking about the effect of Mr. Limbaughs decree to listeners on the results in Texas and Ohio.

title: The Bus, the Snow and the Doctor in Distress
description: LAST winter, right after my back injury, my physical therapist encouraged me to think of the human body like a sweater. If you pull a thread in one place, she said, you never know what damage youll do somewhere else. This advice was given in an effort to explain why a muscle in my shoulder had reached down like a vine, wrapped around one of my lower vertebrae and tugged it significantly to the left.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Play magazine last Sunday about the turnaround of the Boston Celtics gave an outdated name for the teams home arena in two references. It is TD Banknorth Garden, not the Fleet Center. The article also misidentified the game in which Brian Scalabrine, now a forward and center for the Celtics, made four three-pointers near the end. It was the 2004 Eastern Conference semifinals, not the 2005 Eastern Conference finals. And the article referred incorrectly to the parquet floor used for Celtics games at TD Banknorth Garden. The team moved the floor to the Fleet Center from the Boston Garden, the teams former arena, in 1995. That floor was replaced after a game on Dec. 22, 1999, so the team no longer plays on the parquet floor originally used in the Boston Garden. (Go to Article)

title: Double Dutch
description: The story of how Gert Jonkers and Jop van Bennekom, two Dutchmen from the Bible Belt of the Netherlands, came to found a magazine for gays called Butt, followed by a style magazine for anyone called Fantastic Man, is a story of dreams, dreams being really the start of identity. If it werent for the fact that Jonkerss father was a Protestant minister who made his six children read on Sundays  reading was the only activity allowed except church services  would Jonkers have found a way through the boringness of his youth to make a magazine that was essentially about reading? It is an interesting question. And van Bennekom, whose father owned a garage in the same region and whose aunts, uncles and grandparents were all farmers: would van Bennekom, without such humbleness, have quite so clearly identified that the central experience missing in magazines in the early part of the 21st century was a feeling for simplicity and directness?

title: A Fitting Farewell to a Literate and Offbeat Character
description: There was the lingering smell of incense. The long white ecclesiastical candles were lit. The windows were stained glass. Into the echoing Chapel of St. James, inside the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in Morningside Heights, they came to pay their respects on Saturday afternoon.

title: This Ho Chi Minh Trail Ends at the 18th Hole
description: IT felt a little odd, even a touch irreverent, swinging a Callaway driver in the land of Apocalypse Now, Khe Sahn and Ho Chi Minh. And yet there I stood on a carpet of manicured grass outside Hanoi, looking toward a small flag in the distance.

title: A Girl Lost in a Chasm of Race
description: Even in todays America, where a black man stands at the portal to the presidency, the cultural power we accord blond hair and blue eyes is astonishing. So who can fail to be moved by little Pecola Breedlove, a black child in 1940s Lorain, Ohio, who fervently believes that her loveless existence will be transformed if only  and only if  she can acquire a pair of blue, blue eyes?

title: Erica Jensen, Kirk McGee

description: TRENTON  Gov. Jon S. Corzines austere budget proposal calls for cutting 3,000 jobs from the state payroll, but it is a payroll that has 1,879 fewer full-time employees than when he took office two years ago.

title: Good Instincts
description: Charity, do-gooding, philanthropy its all just selfishness masquerading as virtue. So says the cynic. In modern times, the theory that each of us, despite occasional appearances of self-sacrificial nobility, is ultimately and invariably looking out for No. 1 got a big boost from Darwins theory of evolution. By the logic of natural selection, any tendency to act selflessly ought to be snuffed out in the struggle to survive and propagate. So if someone seems to be behaving as an altruist  say, by giving away a fortune to relieve the sufferings of others  that person is really following the selfish dictates of his own genes. The evolutionary psychologist Randolph Nesse confessed that he slept badly for many nights after absorbing this supposed discovery, which he called one of the most disturbing in the history of science.

title: Leading Men
description: Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana are cracking wise. The pair are holding court during Milan Fashion Week and appear surprisingly relaxed, given that the last few days have been one long Dolceandgabbanarama, including a V.I.P. dinner to celebrate a calendar featuring their new underwear model, David Gandy. Did you see Silvio Berlusconi at the dinner? asks Dolce, referring to the former Italian prime minister, who at one point during the night was cornered by a fashion-world gender illusionist whos had more work done than Zsa Zsa. Says Gabbana, I think Berlusconi thought it was Liza Minnelli. Since Dolce and Gabbana are inexorably linked to a pantheon of cinema and sporting gods, they can afford to joke about the important business of dressing one of Italys reigning heartthrobs: Riccardo Scamarcio, the 28-year-old star of My Brother Is an Only Child, coming out this month. Riccardo who? Gabbana asks. Seriously, he is becoming like Brad Pitt in Italy. The clothes that the designers have chosen may require that Scamarcio do some advanced role playing. Which is perfectly O.K. with him.

At left is the original hardcover design; at center is the 1981 mass market paperback cover, tied to the film version starring Brooke Shields; and at right is the Ecco edition currently available in bookstores. title: The Celebrity Solution
description: In 2004, Natalie Portman, then a 22-year-old fresh from college, went to Capitol Hill to talk to Congress on behalf of the Foundation for International Community Assistance, or Finca, a microfinance organization for which she served as ambassador. She found herself wondering what she was doing there, but her colleagues assured her: We got the meetings because of you. For lawmakers, Natalie Portman was not simply a young woman  she was the beautiful Padm from Star Wars. And I was like, That seems totally nuts to me,  Portman told me recently. Its the way it works, I guess. Im not particularly proud that in our country I can get a meeting with a representative more easily than the head of a nonprofit can.

title: The Rerun of the Repressed
description: Watching the Israeli TV show BeTipul, on which HBO based its captivating new melodrama In Treatment, is like subjecting the American program to psychotherapy. You get to witness the formative inner workings of a mysterious and seductive patient. You gaze directly into its unconscious, from which all its weird habits and preoccupations and virtues and torments presumably arise. BeTipul makes clear that In Treatment is American only on the surface. Its psyche is entirely Israeli.

title: A Global Need for Grain That Farms Cant Fill
description: LAWTON, N.D.  Whatever Dennis Miller decides to plant this year on his 2,760-acre farm, the world needs. Wheat prices have doubled in the last six months. Corn is on a tear. Barley, sunflower seeds, canola and soybeans are all up sharply.

title: Math Suggests College Frenzy Will Soon Ease
description: High school seniors nationwide are anxiously awaiting the verdicts from the colleges of their choice later this month. But though it may not be of much solace to them, in just a few years the admissions frenzy is likely to ease. Its simply a matter of demographics.

title: Food, Glorious Food
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding the Unexpected Beneath the Gaudy
description: ONE Friday evening last December, in a typically modern Cancn condo complex, a party was under way. A motley crew of revelers  well-tanned men with curly gray hair, 20-something tourists, women with children and grandchildren on their hips  crowded around four long folding tables sagging with food, and the turquoise-trimmed white walls reverberated with the sounds of familiar songs sung in unison.

title: Middle-Aged and Out of Work? Lets Have Breakfast and Talk
description: West Hempstead

title: Editors Choice
description: DREAMS AND SHADOWS: The Future of the Middle East, by Robin Wright. (Penguin Press, $26.95.) This fluent and intelligent book describes the struggles of people from Morocco to Iran to reform or replace long-entrenched national regimes.

title: Amy Fleischer, James Bryce
description: Amy Jennifer Fleischer and James Thomas Bryce were married on Saturday in the chapel of the Presbyterian Church in Morristown, N.J. The Rev. David G. Carpenter performed the ceremony.

title: Gauging Age of Universe Becomes More Precise
description: The universe is 13.73 billion years old, give or take 120 million years, astronomers said last week.

title: YouTube Posting Leads to Arrests in an Assault
description: THE Ossining police relied on a vital piece of evidence in their decision late last month to charge four high school students with first-degree gang assault: video images of the crime that were posted on YouTube by one of the teenagers after he used the camera on his cellphone to record the attack, the police said.

title: UConn as Favorite Is Business as Usual
description: HARTFORD  The road to Tampa and the Final Four begins this weekend for the Connecticut womens basketball team. According to the major polls, No. 1 UConn is the team to beat. But roadblocks await, starting with the Big East tournament at the XL Center.

title: What Did You Earn in School Today?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jack The Dripper
description: The police report filed after Jackson Pollocks death in 1956 states that when the artists

title: They Criticized Vista. And They Should Know.
description: ONE year after the birth of Windows Vista, why do so many Windows XP users still decline to upgrade?

title: Killer Whale in a Desert: Dubai Plans Theme Parks
description: Shamu is heading to Dubai. Last month, the Busch Entertainment Corporation and property developer Nakheel announced plans to build SeaWorld, Aquatica, Busch Gardens and Discovery Cove theme parks on Palm Jebel Ali, one of Nakheels (www.nakheel.com) three man-made islands in Dubai.

title: The Candela Cachet
description: WILL the cool winds of recession settle over the luxury Manhattan market, as some market analysts are expecting? So far, the available evidence does not support that hypothesis.

title: Red, White and Greenbacks
description: WERE giving away some cash! yelled the young man wearing the ruffled boa made of mock hundred-dollar bills. Just for wearing a green sticker, he added, his voice echoing amid the archways of the entrance to the Shops at Atlas Park, an outdoor mall in Glendale, Queens.

title: Tried And True
description: Formulaic scents for men are, like death and taxes, inevitable. Sometimes, given their smell, youd take death. But every so often a perfume house has a masculine fragrance that is actually good. Even great. It can happen three ways.

title: Deborah Kogan, Jeffrey Eilender
description: Deborah Jill Kogan and Jeffrey Morton Eilender were married Saturday evening in the Palm House at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Rabbi Janet Roberts officiated.

title: What Makes People Give?
description: Not long after the 2004 presidential election, John List and Dean Karlan formed an unusual partnership, with the idea of teaching a little-known liberal group how to raise more money. Karlan, an economics professor at Yale who spent much of his time studying global poverty, was himself a liberal and disheartened by President Bushs re-election. He had given money to this particular group in the past.

title: Waterboarding
description: Some locutions begin as bland bureaucratic euphemisms to conceal great crimes. As their meanings become clear, these collocations gain an aura of horror. In the past century, final solution and ethnic cleansing were phrases that sent a chill through our lexicon. In this young century, the word in the news  though not yet in most dictionaries  that causes much wincing during debate is the verbal noun waterboarding.

title: Scenes From Newarks City Hall, Replayed in Federal Court
description: NEWARK

title: Miami Vice
description: Many are the sparkly charms of the opera. The live camels, the castrati. The preoccupation with the worlds oldest profession. The implication that narrative gathers its force from the combined efforts of caterwauling and wig tape. The plots that are not unleavened by coincidence and melodrama. The assertion that overweight people, when dying, brim over with song.

title: When Location Is the Enemy
description: BLACK ROCK

title: Serbia, Split on Kosovo, May Have Early Elections
description: PRAGUE  Serbias president, Boris Tadic, said Saturday that he would call early elections after the prime minister announced that he planned to dissolve his governing coalition, which would have effectively toppled the government. The elections could help determine whether Serbia embraces the West or returns to virulent nationalism.

title: Fighting on a Battlefield the Size of a Milk Label
description: IT may be the last stand of Posilac.

title: 1-2-3, Jump!
description: Elvis Presley, with his assortment of bedazzled jumpsuits, may be the king of one-piece dressing, but thankfully he wasnt the inspiration for this seasons styles. Designers like Miuccia Prada and Alexander McQueen were more interested in the functional garments first worn by workers and pilots; Dsquared went for pit stop mechanics; and Calvin Kleins futuristic versions brought to mind 2001: A Space Odyssey. Levi Strauss introduced denim Koveralls for children in 1912; Lee followed the next year with its Union-All suit, intended for farmers and factory workers. World War I pilots wore flight suits based on Lees adaptable model, and avant-garde artists zipped up after the war: the Constructivist artist Alexander Rodchenko had a two-piece productivist outfit designed to look like a jumpsuit. In the 1940s, cartoonists added fantasy to the onesie, outfitting the Flash and Green Lantern. But it took man walking on the moon to usher in the golden age of the jumpsuit  the 1970s. Soon, entertainers kicked it up a notch: David Bowie as Ziggy Stardust wore outrageous versions; Evel Knievel was sometimes carried into the emergency room in a star-studded red, white and blue leather number. Devo performed in yellow jumpsuits. And in the early 1980s, retro-futurist designers like Thierry Mugler introduced styles with padded shoulders. Oddly, it was President Bush who refocused the publics attention on the flight suit when he modeled one in front of the infamous Mission Accomplished banner in 2003. And lets not forget shackled terrorists and their orange prison suits. The latter can be had for $13.95 at nationaltextile.us. Surplus flight suits on eBay are $30, and a repro of Elviss Sunburst suit is $3,300 at b-k-enterprises.com. Zip carefully, my man. [?][?][?]ROBERT E. BRYAN

title: Saintly Streets Tell a Citys Long Tale
description: LOS ANGELES  Saint may not be the first word that springs to mind when contemplating the inhabitants of Los Angeles. J. Michael Walker, a local artist, had not given the beatific much thought, either  until the day seven years ago, pre-MapQuest and global positioning systems, that he opened up his spiral-bound Thomas Guide to the citys streets searching for an avenue that began with an s.

title: Far Beyond That Old Song and Dance
description: A MISERABLY married bookkeeper, fired from his job after 25 years of dutiful service, promptly offs the boss. A manic-depressive embarks on a long pharmacological odyssey to cure her mental illness. An environmental activist takes up the cause of laborers on a remote island.

title: Social Justice and the Well-Dressed Head
description: To the Editor:

title: I, Narcissus
description: From time to time, residents of England produce advancements in that nations major art forms: narcissism, glibness and camp. Steven Patrick Morrissey corrupted an entire generation in the 80s with his important work regarding self-involvement and the treatment of pain with sarcasm. A decade later, Jarvis Cocker quite successfully mixed that self-indulgence with class rage and the love of a good chemical.

title: Countrywide Said to Be Subject of Federal Criminal Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  The federal authorities have opened a criminal inquiry into Countrywide Financial for suspected securities fraud as part of the continuing fallout over the mortgage crisis, government officials with knowledge of the case said on Saturday.

title: Just a Little Business Trip to a War Zone
description: SKIMMING those periodic State Department travel-warning lists is enough to make you want to book a trip to Las Vegas instead of some far-flung foreign spot where kidnappings, insurrections, epidemics, machete attacks, robberies, militia shoot-outs, terrorist bombings and bus hijackings seem part of the routine. Yet sometimes, for one reason or another, people just have to go to one of those places.

title: Finishes Dont Measure Up at World Championships
description: VALENCIA, Spain  The second day and night of the world indoor track and field championships were more about what did not happen than what did.

title: Taking the Two-Family Path
description: AS natives of Seattle, where they paid $1,100 for a one-bedroom rental in a downtown neighborhood called Belltown, Brandon and Jette Starniri faced culture shock when they moved to New York three years ago and settled into a Brooklyn Heights walk-up.

title: Boy Toys
description: Projection Boom

title: Best Quarterbacks a Juicy, but Fruitless, Topic
description: In all the adulation accompanying Brett Favres retirement, anybody the least bit familiar with N.F.L. history was quick to bronze him on the ladder of the best quarterbacks ever, anywhere from the top rung to the top 10. But that wont happen here. Theres no ladder here, just a top shelf where more than a dozen quarterbacks from Sammy Baugh to Tom Brady deserve to be.

title: Slum Visits: Tourism or Voyeurism?
description: MICHAEL CRONINs job as a college admissions officer took him to India two or three times a year, so he had already seen the usual sites  temples, monuments, markets  when one day he happened across a flier advertising slum tours.

title: Southern Reds in a Bold Mix
description: Faugres, a small, hilly Languedoc region, produces rustic reds that belong with grilled meats and hearty stews.

title: Water Leaks at Law Library Prompt Lawsuit
description: HARTFORD

title: Michelle Lieberman and Daniel Lubetzky
description: Dr. Michelle Lynn Lieberman, a daughter of Joanne Lieberman and Michael Lieberman of Silver Spring, Md., was married on Monday to Daniel Lubetzky, a son of Sonia Lubetzky of San Antonio, Tex., and the late Roman Lubetzky. Rabbi Aryeh Scheinberg officiated at a civil service in his study at Congregation Rodfei Sholom in San Antonio. On Saturday evening, Rabbi David Rosen performed a religious ceremony on Maroma Beach in Mexico.

title: Buffalo Area Wonders: Could It Lose the Bills?
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y.  Buffalo has absorbed its share of civic body blows over the years, from the shuttering of steel plants to the exodus from its neighborhoods. So last month, when the hometown Bills confirmed plans to play eight games in Toronto over the next five football seasons, fans like Paul Isaac naturally feared it was a prelude to the teams eventual departure for Canada.

title: An Early Easter Brings April Deals
description: PLANNING a spring-break vacation? Brace yourself for huge crowds and high prices.

title: Alternative Dealers Selling Alternative Power
description: Portland, Ore.

title: Face to Face
description: 1. JeanRichard 2. Rolex 3. Cartier 4. Vacheron Constantin 5. IW 6. Audemars Piguet

title: Excitement in a Bottle
description: Channing Daughters aptly names one of its white blends Envelope. The Bridgehampton winerys Web site explains, We will continue to push the envelope of what is possible in our vineyards, our cellar and our region.

title: The Monster Mash
description: WASHINGTON

title: Jitters for First-Time Homebuyers
description: An article on Feb. 17 about difficulties that some first-time buyers have experienced in getting mortgages misstated the range of the credit scores that are used in part to determine mortgage rates. They range from 300 to 850, not from 500 to 850.

title: Girardi Says Collision at Plate Is Uncalled For
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Spring training games are usually leisurely affairs, but Francisco Cervelli, a Yankees reserve catcher, will probably take issue with that characterization after the teams 4-1 loss Saturday to the Tampa Bay Rays.

title: Hormones, Genes and the Corner Office
description: Why do girls on average lead boys for all their years in the classroom, only to fall behind in the workplace? Do girls grow up and lose their edge, while boys mature and gain theirs?
