title: Guards, and Their Paychecks, Are Finally Standing Out
description: Derrick Dockery learned the value of offensive tackles early. He was one in high school, earning the prestige afforded to the very large bodyguards for the most important player of all, the quarterback. Every kid wanted to play one of the hot offensive positions, Dockery said  quarterback, wide receiver, left tackle.

title: Caught Out
description: Sunny Fernando, a Sri Lankan expatriate, lives a minor life amid major events. His mother killed herself when he was 8, and he has spent most of the ensuing years in exile. As an adult, he devotes himself to routines in which nothing had weight, nothing mattered but the chores, the schedules, the trappings of the moment.

title: The Crying Game
description: Fad-prone Japan has yet another obsession: public displays of emotion. Groups of pent-up salarymen are swapping karaoke for tear therapy  the chance to rent a room and watch cinematic weepies like Love Story. So powerful is this mawkish urge that entrepreneurs have even started crying clubs, where otherwise stoic guys can bond over shame-free sobbing jags for about 1,000 yen ($9.40). The rock musician Tadayuki Inui organizes Minnade Nako Kai in Kyoto; the film buff and restaurateur Kosuke Kimura in Sendai owns Ruisen Kai (the Lachrymal Gland Club in English). Englands stiff upper lip is also quivering. The artist Viktor Wynd holds teary events called Loss: An Evening of Exquisite Misery (below), inspired by Gnter Grasss sad nightclub, the Onion Cellar, in The Tin Drum. Gloomy guests swoon around in vintage clothes, listen to fado music and carry peacock feathers, half-dead flowers salvaged from cemeteries or freshly signed divorce papers. Come midnight, attendees are handed knives and onions to chop to the sound of the Mozart Requiem. Overly chirpy attendees are fined one pound per smile and two pounds per laugh. Melancholia is not such a bad thing, says Wynd, who is hoping to bring his mournful bashes to New York soon. I dont know why people think theyre supposed to be happy all the time.[?][?][?] MARK ELLWOOD

title: What to Catch on Canadas West Coast
description: TOP reader suggestions on Vancouver, compiled from user comments on the Travel sections Web site. You can read more comments, as well as add your own, at nytimes.com/travel. If you want your own comment to be considered for future publication in the paper, please include your full name.

title: Spanish Voters Go to Polls in Fierce Rematch
description: MADRID  They are two angry political warriors bearing grudges from the past, convinced the other is a liar and an incompetent destined to destroy the country.

title: Easy Come, Easy Go for Idealistic Heirs
description: ANNE GLICKMAN, 34, inherited several million dollars in stock on her 18th birthday. She preferred not to think or talk about the money into her 20s because, she said, as a political activist, her wealth was a bit inconvenient.

title: Book Lovers Ask, Whats Seattles Secret?
description: Seattle

title: Students Imagine Little Rock, on Film
description: SCARSDALE

title: Prewar Apartments, Rising Just Down the Street
description: PREWAR used to refer to sturdily built apartment houses with high ceilings, walls so thick you couldnt hear your neighbors and perhaps black and white tiled floors in the bathroom.

title: Lawyers Demand Release of Judges in Pakistan
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan  Beside racks of hanging meat and barrows of oranges in the alleys of the old town here, Aitzaz Ahsan, leader of the lawyers movement in Pakistan, was back on the campaign trail on Saturday, calling for the release of top justices from house arrest.

title: A Marrakesh Getaway With a Story to Tell
description: Visitors to Marrakesh who want to stay in the lively, bustling Medina district without sacrificing a posh, tranquil lodging experience might want to consider the AnaYela Riad (www.anayela.com). Upon arrival, guests are given traditional Moroccan slippers and are encouraged to pad around the hotels interior courtyard, above, or relax on its terrace, which has views of the city and the Atlas Mountains. The 300-year-old palace, recently renovated by the German entrepreneur Bernd Kolb, also offers a lounge, an open-air restaurant, a pool, meeting spaces and Wi-Fi access.

title: A Builder of Broadways World, From Chicago to Spamalot
description: YONKERS

title: Barbaros Trainer in Position for Return to Derby
description: Barbaros trainer may be on his way back to the Kentucky Derby.

title: Betony Vernon | Mistress
description: The multitalented Betony Vernon may be (ahem!) an educator, designer and author, but first and foremost she wants to teach the world some sexual common sense. People are not natural born lovers, she says. We learn skills over time, like a painter. Vernon, who designs a line of titillating jewel tools (read: sex accessories) sold at boutiques like Kiki de Montparnasse and Coco de Mer, recently opened a store-cum-boudoir in a historic 17th-century building in Paris and is at work on a book detailing the possibilities of pleasure and erotic ceremonies. Just dont mistake her for a sex-shop habitu. My work is a response to all things plastic, black, evil and cheap that dont give people the chance to explore the power of the body. Michel Foucault would be proud. [?][?][?]ALEX HAWGOOD

title: Paperback Row
description: THEN WE CAME TO THE END, by Joshua Ferris. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $13.99.) This first novel  one of the Book Reviews 10 best books of 2007  is set in a Chicago advertising agency as the dot-com boom implodes. The firms anxious, gossipy employees, who have no idea who will be the next to go, are the collective narrator; Ferris writes mostly in the first-person plural. Then We Came to the End is acidly funny, but it isnt only satire; it also conveys the purpose and meaning to be found in work. A lighter take on office life is BECAUSE SHE CAN, by Bridie Clark (Grand Central, $14.99). This is chick lit of the assistant subgenre; in this case the boss from hell, Vivian Grant, is a vulgar but brilliantly successful publisher modeled on Judith Regan. The narrator of this charming little caper, as Alexandra Jacobs called it in the Book Review, is a Coleridge-loving young editor.

title: Back to Broadway
description: EVERY time she goes to work, Anika Noni Rose gets told shes a terrible wife. It can make her loopy.

title: As School Mourns Its Own, Virtues Come to Light
description: Farmington

title: Boy Meets Squirrel
description: The hero of Lydia Millets latest novel is a real estate developer. Not a green developer, not a developer of affordable housing, just a regular, in-it-for-cash purveyor of tacky housing complexes and upscale resorts for well-to-do retirees and adventurous tourists. This is unexpected; Millets fiction is heavy with ecofriendly themes. But the developer at the center of How the Dead Dream undergoes a conversion. He doesnt so much renounce his vocation as gradually lose interest in it, becoming instead fixated upon animals in danger of extinction.

title: The C.I.A. on Interrogation
description: To the Editor:

title: Snappy, Witty and Steamy (Till the Energy Runs Out)
description: For snappy, witty dialogue and a melodramatic confrontation with life-shattering implications, the start of Act II of The Scene, Theresa Rebecks hip comedy at George Street Playhouse, cannot be beat. It also includes one of the steamiest, most explicit sexual romps currently to be seen on local stages.

title: A Bouquet and a Space Heater
description: TRYING to analyze the seasonal trends in weddings is a little like trying to gauge how rapidly the polar ice caps are melting. But as temperatures rise, wedding vendors and couples are beginning to look toward that once-frosty patch between November and March with all the optimism once saved for spring.

title: Take Off Your Coat And Stay Awhile
description: Mens stores are going for a luxurious residential feeling, hoping their clients will never want to leave. Tom Ford started the trend with his New York flagship, which has a Claude Lalanne desk, plush sofas and butler service; his Milan outpost, opening this summer, will have an equally homey quality. Meanwhile, Ermenegildo Zegnas new 9,200-square-foot Manhattan pied--terre (left) features architectural details designed to reference Zegnas custom fabrics, artwork by Frank Thiel and a fireplace.

title: Downturn Tests the Feds Ability to Avert a Crisis
description: In the last seven months, policy makers have cut interest rates, injected money into the banking system and approved a fiscal stimulus package in an effort to keep the economy from slipping into a recession. Often, the moves seemed to work at first, only to be overtaken by more bad news.

title: Out of the Boardroom for a Bollywood Turn
description: The British entrepreneur Richard Branson  known for his hot-air ballooning and powerboating  has added a new feat to his list of attention-getting accomplishments: he is now a Bollywood movie star.

title: Revealing a Magical Life With Light
description: ALYSON DENNY would be the first to admit that the vista from her living-room windows is not exactly picturesque. Whats the view? she said. A bunch of other ugly apartments.

title: Public Broadcasting: A Stations Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Day Trippers
description: Turn off your laptop, grab a Lanvin windbreaker and take a hike. Everybody, it seems, is celebrating the great outdoors. While bands like Midlake and the Guillemots are writing songs about seabirds

title: Besieged
description: Beaufort Castle, built by crusaders on a mountaintop in what is now southern Lebanon, passed through many hands before being captured from the P.L.O. by invading Israeli troops in 1982. In this gritty first novel, the young Israeli journalist Ron Leshem imagines the tedium and terror of a small group of soldiers inside the fortress walls in the months leading up to the Israeli Armys withdrawal in 2000.

title: Helping Families Help Their Bored Teenagers
description: Traveling with bored and adventure-starved teenagers can be daunting. Loews Hotels (www.loewshotels.com) is offering some assistance and maybe even a little inspiration with its new Edu-cations packages. These consist of a one- or two-night stay and action-filled activities appropriate to the hotels location.

title: Rift Over AIDS Treatment Lingers in South Africa
description: KWANGWANASE, South Africa  Colin Pfaff, a slight doctor imbued with Christian zeal, had reached a moral crossroads.

title: Letters: Battle Company Is Out There
description: Elizabeth Rubins article (Feb. 24) is the best combat reporting to come out of a bewildering war since Marguerite Higgins, Homer Bigart and David Halberstam sent their dispatches from Vietnam. Her report, focused on soldiers rather than on strategy, produced an image of Afghanistan that shows its ridges and slopes are the front lines of the war on terror. Capt. Dan Kearney and his men  along with the men and women in the sky above them  are fighting a war that is about blood, death and uncertainty, not a war about freedom and political abstraction.

title: Oceans at Risk
description: There is no shortage of scientific studies documenting the degradation of the worlds oceans, the decline of marine ecosystems and the collapse of important fish species. Several have appeared in the last month. What is in short supply is a sustained effort by world governments and other institutions to do something about it.

title: Tips for Surviving a Power Failure
description: LATE last month, nearly three million Floridians were without electricity after a cascade of power failures, caused by equipment problems, swept across the state.

title: Off to London, but Not Packing Their Best
description: ON Wednesday New York City Ballet will open a season in London, its first there in more than 24 years and its first ever at the London Coliseum (a good theater for ballet: its dance history, which includes recent seasons by the Kirov and the Bolshoi, goes back to Diaghilev). The opening piece will be George Balanchines Serenade (1934).

title: Wok On
description: Chinese restaurants are more American than apple pie, says Jennifer 8. Lee in The Fortune Cookie Chronicles: Adventures in the World of Chinese Food. There are twice as many of these restaurants as there are McDonalds franchises, and the food they serve is every bit as predictable. What Chinese restaurant menu doesnt offer beef with broccoli, sesame chicken, roast pork lo mein, fried wontons, egg rolls and egg drop soup? asks the author, an American-born Chinese who cheerfully admits to an obsession with Chinese restaurants.

title: Rabbi Zev Segal, Orthodox Leader Who Took Interfaith Approach to Social Issues, Dies at 91
description: Rabbi Zev Segal, who as president of one of the most influential Orthodox Jewish organizations in the country in the 1960s clashed with leaders of what he called more liberal Jewish alternatives, but who also worked with Conservative and Reform Jews on social issues, died Wednesday in Jersey City, N.J. He was 91 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Ego Check
description: I wonder what Matt Lauer would make of Cleaver. He might want to take a look at it, one morning during makeup, perhaps, because like Harold Cleaver  the bulbous protagonist of Tim Parkss excellent new novel  Lauer has tangled on camera with an American president. He has felt, against painted cheeks, the heat of power perturbed. Readers may remember Lauers televised set-to with George W. Bush in 2006, on the carpets of the Oval Office: the two men were standing, and Bush  quizzed with unexpected robustness about torture, secret sites and the rest  began squaring up to his interlocutor, poking and patting him, inching into head-butt range. Lauer, eyes dilated, respectfully but doggedly pursued his questions. Future generations will barely believe it.

title: Text Generation Gap: U R 2 Old (JK)
description: AS president of the Walt Disney Companys childrens book and magazine publishing unit, Russell Hampton knows a thing or two about teenagers. Or he thought as much until he was driving his 14-year-old daughter, Katie, and two friends to a play last year in Los Angeles.

title: Kips Bay Goes White-Brick
description: YOU can dress it up in beaver rugs and silk taffeta, crown moldings and chandeliers, but can you sell it?

title: Seven Apartment Houses in a Piazza-Like Setting
description: IN the development of upper Park Avenue, the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola looms large. Originally named the Church of St. Lawrence OToole, it began building on its blockfront between 83rd and 84th Streets in the 1880s, and its massive Baroque-style main sanctuary was dedicated in 1898.

title: In the Kitchen for a Party and a Chefs Lessons
description: Rowayton

title: Self-Made Philanthropists
description: One day in the fall of 2006, Paul Steiger got a call from Herb and Marion Sandler. It came completely out of the blue. At the time, Steiger was the managing editor of The Wall Street Journal, the papers top editorial position, a job hed held for 15 years. Hed had his share of great moments, including 16 Pulitzer Prizes, and his share of miserable ones, including the murder of Daniel Pearl and the steady drip, drip, drip of cutbacks and layoffs. A year away from The Journals mandatory retirement age of 65, Steiger was just beginning to think about what he might do next.

title: The Bounce Is Returning to Westhoffs Steps
description: Mike Westhoff had endured eight operations over the years to repair his left leg, but the ninth, performed in mid-February, was the most difficult.

title: PJ Max
description: I started wearing pajamas during the day shortly after I founded Playboy in 1953. It made sense because the first few issues were put together in my apartment, where I would often work straight through the night. In the early 60s, when I moved into the Playboy Mansion in Chicago, I stopped going to the office altogether; by the 80s, I had begun using pajamas in a more social way. When I had friends over for a buffet and a movie on Friday nights, I didnt bother to put on a shirt or a suit, and people started to be disappointed if I didnt wear PJs. I think I have about 100 different pairs in silk custom-made for me by a tailor named Mr. Brown. During the day I wear black; for weekends I prefer purple; and on holidays and special occasions, red. My bedsheets are black satin, and my girlfriends like to wear pink pajamas. Holly stays with me overnight, and my other two girlfriends, Kendra and Bridget, have their own bedrooms. It would be crazy if we all tried to sleep together, because Holly has four dogs that stay in our bed, Bridget has a dog and a cat, and Kendra has two dogs. But we like to throw pajama parties to give our guests the opportunity to dress the way I do. Its very comfortable, and if you can pull it off, theres definitely a certain style to it.

title: Are You Ready for Some Rugby?
description: IT has been weeks since the New York Giants miraculous run to a Super Bowl championship concluded, but fans in the metropolitan area have still been turning up in bars to watch their favorite players tackle, pass and kick.

title: Robinson Gets 45, but Knicks Fall Short
description: Nate Robinson would have passed more, but he was perhaps his own best option Saturday night. Jamal Crawford and Stephon Marbury were on the bench, in designer suits. Eddy Curry was in the locker room, an ice bag on his knee. Zach Randolph was in Indiana.

title: The Lemur
description: Chapter 9: Odalisque

title: Imperfect Heroes
description: Becoming a doctor, I hoped, would bring me back into the real world, Sandeep Jauhar writes in Intern, his fine memoir of his training in a New York City hospital. It would make me into a man. The story he tells here is antiheroic, full of uncertainty, doubt and frank disgust, aimed at both himself and, sometimes, his patients. Intern succeeds as an unusually transparent portrait of an imperfect human being trying to do his best at a tough job.

title: The Wife of a Coach Is Seen and Heard
description: ALBANY  On its N.C.A.A. tournament rsum, Siena has a victory against Stanford, which was ranked No. 20 at the time, a victory at Boise State and a regular-season conference title.

title: All Hail Brooklyn: Alt-Rock Thrives in Alt-Borough
description: SHOUTS of Brooklyn! cut through the applause at the Music Hall of Williamsburg on Valentines Day for the sold-out homecoming show of Yeasayer and MGMT, two of the boroughs reigning new buzz bands. And as Yeasayer rang out the last chords of 2080, an echoey, disorienting song about environmental apocalypse, its singer, Chris Keating, made an announcement.

title: Vinho Culture
description: The Samurai Sipper, an older sister, mourns the bygone era of sibling rivalry, when she routinely crushed her younger brothers infuriating smirks in a salvo of right hooks so thunderous he called for his mommy. Ah, the glory days. The Samurai Sibling was just a big sissy pants till puberty, when he grew stronger and hairier and finally landed a monster uppercut on my jaw. We called it even. But Sippers superiority continues unchallenged in nonpugilistic matters, and if the Sib mutters age before beauty within earshot, I go below the belt and over his head with two words: Viagra and Rogaine.

title: A Cure for the College-Bound Blues
description: BY the time she graduated from high school, Sabrina Skau needed a break. She was 18. She was exhausted.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Feb. 24 in T: Womens Fashion magazine, about the Osmothque, a scent museum in Paris, misspelled part of the name of a cosmetics company. It is Helena Rubinstein, not Rubenstein.

title: Democrat Wins Seat Once Held by G.O.P. Speaker
description: CHICAGO  Stunning many who considered the district west of Chicago reliably Republican territory, Bill Foster, a physicist and Democrat, won a special election on Saturday to fill the Congressional seat that J. Dennis Hastert, the former speaker of the House, held for two decades.

title: Magic Man
description: For a boxer who routinely conjures magic in the ring, it is fitting that Wladimir Klitschko is fascinated with sleight of hand. Its a great passion of mine, says the 31-year-old Klitschko, a two-time world heavyweight champion. I know quite a few tricks, but lets just say I dont have a Ph.D. in it. Klitschko originally wanted to be an ear-nose-and-throat specialist; instead, he settled for a Ph.D. in sports science and philosophy. (His dissertation was on the pedagogic control over young athletes, ages 14 to 19, in the old Soviet system.) Known as Dr. Steelhammer for his formidable power, he is also a polyglot: he speaks four languages and is more likely to chew your ear off figuratively than literally. Klitschko once had his own clothing line and is sponsored by Hugo Boss. I am really amazed by the power of fashion to transcend the ugly reality of the world, he says. And my brother met his wife at a fashion show, so maybe there is hope for me, too.[?][?][?]HORACIO SILVA

title: In the Land of Black Coats
description: TAKE the D train to 55th Street in central Brooklyn, and you feel as if you have set foot in a different world.

title: The Taste of Nothing, the Smell of Mars
description: PARIS

title: Maria Durans Endless Wait
description: THE night last May when the soldiers came to her butter yellow house in Corona, Queens, with their solemn faces and formal dress, Maria del Rosario Duran was waiting for them.

title: Pushing for the Last Word to Be Against Censorship
description: Mineola

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Praise for Harvards Amaker

title: Responding to a Less Heated Market
description: NEW YORK CITY real estate has become a shadow of its frenzied former self in recent months, as buyers and sellers take a more deliberate approach to reaching deals.

title: How Much Information Must a Board Provide?
description: Q I recently asked my co-op board for a copy of the agreement between the building and its managing agent, but the board declined to provide it, stating that shareholders are not authorized to inspect business documents. Is that an accurate statement of the law?

title: Bothered and Bewildered
description: To the Editor:

title: Horse Therapy for the Troubled
description: NEW EGYPT

title: Peter Grimes: Britten as an Outsider
description: To the Editor:

title: Letter: Quirky Lodgings
description: To the Editor: Regarding your Check In/Check Out column, on the "Danhostel Copenhagen City" on Feb. 3: No more Danhostel! It was also written about a year or so ago, and because my husband thinks anything in The Times is gospel, we stayed there in June of 2007. The rooms at Danhostel are like prison cells designed by the warden. Our room was on the third floor in the back, but the traffic noise was so unbearable I purchased silicone earplugs from a Mata store. The elevator key card reader had episodes of dementia. The seating for computer use should have come with a chiropractor coupon.

title: Washington Doesnt Sleep Here
description: WASHINGTON

title: Friendly Chatter in the Kitchen
description: WESTFIELD

title: Geek Love
description: San Francisco

title: Drawings Set Apart in a World of Lines
description: Is it possible to make a drawing without using a pen, pencil or paper? Why not  these days artists make art from anything at all, then call it what they like. Two who are experimenting with the formal properties of drawing are Serena Bocchino and Gelah Penn, the artists in The Notion of Line, a show at the Alpan Gallery in Huntington.

title: Profile in Style JEAN TOUITOU
description: His worldview

title: As Good as Cash, Until Its Not
description: INVESTORS across the nation are finding themselves in Wall Streets version of the Hotel California: they have checked into an investment they can never leave.

title: Grand Slam
description: When Ren Lacoste, one of Frances most tenacious tennis champions, stepped onto the courts of Roland Garros and Wimbledon in the 1920s, the concept of athletic clothing was nonexistent. The female champion Suzanne Lenglen was playing in long outfits by Chanel and Patou; it wasnt uncommon for her male counterparts to duke it out in belted slacks, dress shirts and leather lace-ups. On occasion, espadrilles (a sartorial leftover from the Basque game of pelota) would lend a welcome  if sometimes ankle-wrenching  sense of ease to the proceedings.

title: 36 Hours in Puebla, Mexico
description: PUEBLA may be home to classic Mexican dishes like mole poblano, but theres more to do in this wealthy city than just eat. A two-hour drive from Mexico City past snow-capped peaks and volcanoes, Puebla, a city of some 1.3 million people, is chock full of colonial treasures, cafe-lined squares and a vibrant arts-and-crafts culture. The large historic center has been designated as a World Heritage Site by Unesco, new hotels are springing up, and airlines now offer easy access from the United States. But if your main obsession is food, Puebla wont disappoint. This crayon-colored city is still considered by many to be the gastronomic capital of Mexico.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: FILM

title: Homey New Uses for Old Utilities
description: AS long as lights go on when switches are flipped, and water runs when faucets are turned, most people dont think much about where these essentials come from. But what if you lived, shopped or sipped drinks inside a former power or water plant?

title: Batmans Burden: A Director Confronts Darkness and Death
description: CHICAGO

title: The Lost City
description: Caballo Muerto

title: New and Varied
description: These bright places in the West 80s, which all have opened since last spring, are welcome additions to this largely residential neighborhood.

title: Flood-Damaged Landmark Home Awaits Repair
description: RIVER EDGE

title: SoCal Color
description: For much of the 20th century, Los Angeles was perceived as a kind of paradise. And for the first 60 or 70 years of the century, the perception was deserved. Perfumed with the scent of orange blossom, it was a place of wide-open spaces and untamed canyons, its rhythm set by the ocean, pulsing like a heartbeat to the west. We all know what happens to paradises, of course  they get lost  and the golden age of Los Angeles receded many years ago. Its just another world city now: crowded, polluted and in a hurry.

title: Correction: A Place to Park That Million-Dollar RV
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Comings & Goings column on Feb. 24 about a chain of luxury communities for RVs misstated the number of American households that own an RV. It is about 8.3 million, not 8.3.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: The Faculty Is Remote, but Not Detached
description: BECAUSE of the Internet, distance learning in higher education has come a long way since correspondence courses were sent through the mail. And technology like Web streaming has made online learning more like a real classroom experience.

title: Mag Hags
description: If you fancy telling the story of style, one of the easiest ways to do it would be to chart the changing design of magazines. Not all of them, of course, just the ones that set the agenda for their particular era.

title: Letter: Useless Miles?
description: To the Editor: Your Practical Traveler column "Curves in the Road to Redeeming Miles" (Feb. 10) was spot on  finding an award ticket or being able to use miles even for an upgrade on a paid ticket is like looking for a needle in a haystack. The problem has become such a headache that last year I converted all my credit cards from ones that gave you miles to ones that give you a percentage rebate at the end of the year. At least I can calculate the return and know when to expect it to be useful.

title: Hoboken Comes to Union City
description: UNION CITY

title: Faces From a Neighborhood on the Brink
description: WHEREVER the baggage of a life in the theater takes her, the actress April Yvette Thompson carries with her a little shrine, a small altar woven through with the Afro-Latino Santeria traditions that are part of her backgrounds very many strands. Back home in her apartment in Harlem, she has assembled a more permanent one, studded with mementos: her first baby picture, family portraits, childhood jewelry and adolescent keepsakes intended to celebrate the preciousness of her past. Her Vassar diploma doesnt fit, and she keeps it on her desk.

title: The No. 1 Detective Agency
description: Like any good private-eye yarn, Pinkertons Secret begins with a dame walking into a gumshoes office. The gumshoe is Allan Pinkerton, real-life founder of the Pinkerton National Detective Agency, and the dame is Kate Warne, soon to become the nations first female detective  and Pinkertons mistress. Eric Lerners novel, styled as Pinkertons confessional memoir, documents his lamplight clutches with Mrs. Warne as well as other, less private, accomplishments.

title: Roush Team Rolls On as Osborne Looks On
description: HAMPTON, Ga.  The background noise suggested Bob Osborne was not going to hole up in his home in Harrisburg, N.C., and fill himself with despair over his six-race suspension and the $100,000 fine levied against him by Nascar, the sanctioning body of the Sprint Cup Series.

title: The Chilean Job
description: On Saint Anthonys Day, the 13th of June, the president declared an amnesty for certain common criminals. So begins the Chilean writer Antonio Skrmetas fanciful new novel The Dancer and the Thief, translated by Katherine Silver. Among those unexpectedly liberated are ngel Santiago, a petty thief, and Nico Vergara Gray, a celebrated criminal mastermind  this storys odd couple of leading men.

title: A Glossy Rehab for Tattered Careers
description: LINDSAY LOHAN wants you to know that shes all right. Reminiscing about the series of scandals that have sullied her name and nearly deep-sixed her career, she is all contrition. When I look back on this last year, its like what was I thinking? she confided in the March issue of Harpers Bazaar. Ive learned so much, though, like learning to live my life a different way.

title: Sexual Healing
description: Scott Spencer has, through his career, established an instantly recognizable voice: blunt, earthy and intellectual, if not always wise. When employed well, this voice has great appeal. In orbit around the novels themselves are a few reliable moons. Spencers central characters are typically misruled by obsession  with women, usually younger; with their parents, often still living; and with money, rarely their own. It is not a Scott Spencer novel if the main character does not, at some point, fear for his sanity.

title: Chinese Lawyer Says He Was Detained and Warned on Activism
description: BEIJING  Beijing public security agents released a Chinese human rights lawyer on Saturday after detaining him two days earlier without notice and forcing him to endure intensive questioning at an unknown location, the lawyer said.

title: For Hoyas and Ewings, Another One for Books
description: WASHINGTON  Georgetown forward Patrick Ewing Jr. was recently surprised to hear that the Hoyas had never won consecutive Big East Conference regular-season titles. Ewing said he thought he was well versed in Georgetown history because his father, Patrick Ewing Sr., had crafted so much of it.

title: Powerhouses to the People
description: AS long as lights go on when switches are flipped, most people dont think much about where power comes from. But what if you lived, shopped, or sipped drinks inside a former power plant?

title: Correction: Evening Hours
description: The Evening Hours column on Feb. 24 misspelled the given name of the daughter-in-law of Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman, who celebrated their birthdays with a dinner on Feb. 16. She is Laurie Benenson, not Lori.

title: For 2 Black Detectives, the Beat Is Recruiting
description: Jersey City

title: It Had the Setting; Now It Has the Housing
description: Like a caterpillar undergoing a metamorphosis, the down-and-out industrial waterfront of Yonkers is shedding its old skin.

title: High-Scoring Frenchmen Are Flying
description: At the end of November, the streaking Ottawa Senators were falling back to earth, but the Montreal Canadiens could not catch up. Now, with a month left in the regular season, the Canadiens have shot past Ottawa and are competing with Pittsburgh and the Devils for first place in the Eastern Conference.

title: Vaccines Protect More Than Your Own Child
description: To the Editor:

title: Los Angeles: Intelligentsia
description: Theres something about Los Angeles that has kept the latest wave of fine specialty coffee at bay. So the August opening of Intelligentsia Coffee in Silver Lake, complete with some imported Pacific Northwest baristas, was a quantum leap.

title: The Talk
description: SoCal / (so\& kal) / adj. / a syllabic abbreviation for Southern California, e.g., The exhibition was a lo-cal SoCal cultural smoothie; this season, fashion shorthand for youthful nonchalance as designers go west for inspiration, as in, BosWash is so last season  blind Freddie can see its an artsy SoCal moment, or Im all for laid-back SoCal surf wear, but I draw the line at an embroidered rash guard.

title: Tuition Break
description: I began saving for my two sons college education 18 years ago through U.G.M.A. accounts, whose funds revert to the beneficiary at 21. My older son attends a state school and could have $100,000 remaining when he graduates. My younger son will likely go to a private school and perhaps grad school and could deplete his account. May I ask my older son to share his remaining money with his brother?  NAME WITHHELD, SEATTLE

title: Curry Sidelined With Swelling in His Right Knee
description: Eddy Curry sat out Saturday nights loss to Portland, and he may be out longer because of a right knee injury that will require further tests.

title: This Year, Even Bay Hill May Not Stop Woods
description: As any casual golf fan knows, Tiger Woodss game travels well. He has won in the East, the Far East, the Middle East, the West, the Midwest and the Far West. He has won in the Northeast, the Northwest, the Southeast and the Southwest.

title: Trumpets vs. Crumpets in a Robot Duel
description: Tokyo

title: The Dark Side of the Law, on Wings of Song
description: DENIS WOYCHUKS office, in a creaky attic of a room upstairs from the KGB Bar on East Fourth Street, is packed to the gills with books, odd miscellanea like a pair of boxing gloves and two giant metal Soviet-made film projectors, and, in the middle of the floor, on a worn Oriental rug, an array of electric guitars, cables and amps.

title: Recycling Made Beautiful
description: The use of glass beads for decoration and ceremony in Ghana probably dates to the 16th century, when Europeans took them to West Africa in ships to trade for gold and, later, slaves. These imports encouraged a new creative industry, at first using the foreign beads, and later with local versions made from recycled glass ground into a fine powder, mixed with dyes, and refired in clay molds.

title: After a Fight to Survive, One to Succeed
description: They came to New York as displaced persons in the early 1950s, Jewish refugees who had survived the Holocaust. Today, in film and story, such survivors are treated with a kind of awe, and their arrival in America is considered a happy ending. But a very different picture, with an oddly contemporary twist, emerges from the yellowing pages of social service records now being rescued from oblivion at the Center for Jewish History in Manhattan.

title: A Breed of 4-by-4 Hatched on the Fly
description: THE Flight of the Phoenix movies  both the 1965 original and the tepid 2004 remake  chronicled a group of quirky characters who, after crash-landing a plane in a desert, built another plane out of the undamaged bits and flew to safety. Such an industrious approach was not unlike the business model of the American Motors Corporation in the 1970s and 80s.

title: Obama Wins Wyoming Caucuses
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo.  Senator Barack Obama chalked up a victory in another caucus state on Saturday, beating Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in Wyoming by a wide margin.

title: Coming Soon: Nothing Between You and Your Machine
description: Menlo Park, Calif.

title: Dirty Work
description: Denise Minas bold, brave crime novels make up for all the indignities women suffer in genre fiction  especially the notion that a female protagonist is better off being likable than being real. Mina smashed that false article of faith with her dead-grim Garnethill trilogy, featuring a hard-bitten heroine who fights the social conditions that lead to the abuse of women, children and the elderly in a Glasgow slum. Field of Blood began a second series, not nearly as gritty but just as truthful, about Patricia Meehan, known as Paddy, a Glasgow newspaper copyboy (so inconsequential she could have hanged herself at her desk without exciting comment) who develops into a first-rate crime reporter by investigating a series of child murders in her working-class neighborhood.

title: The Marriage Closet
description: To the Editor:

title: Income and Happiness: An Imperfect Link
description: DOES money buy happiness? This week, Senator Byron Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, will join a long line of people who have taken serious stabs at trying to answer that thorny question. He will hold a hearing exploring whether traditional economic measures like per-capita income accurately capture peoples sense of well-being.

title: Can You Beat the Market? Its a $100 Billion Question
description: INVESTORS collectively spend around $100 billion a year trying to beat the stock market. Thats the finding of a rigorous effort to measure the total costs of Americans efforts to surpass the returns they would have received by simply holding a stock index fund. The huge price tag helps explain why beating a buy-and-hold strategy is so difficult.

title: Corporate Giver
description: As the head of Googles philanthropy division, you oversee a budget of about $1 billion to be spent on socially constructive causes, like developing plug-in cars or tracking bird flu along the Mekong River. Is that enough money to make a difference? I think that we have a generous allotment of resources  money and people and the talent of engineers to get started. I can do an awful lot more than I could before I got here.

title: The Italian Job
description: ADRIANO GIANNINI

title: The Loneliness of MySpace
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bush Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Design to Set Thoughts Aloft
description: HUNTINGTON

title: Richard Price: Drugs? No Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Maintenance Fees: Up, Up, Up
description: An article on Feb. 24 about steep increases in monthly fees in co-ops and condominiums misidentifed a building where a $13 million co-op has a maintenance charge of $13,000 a month. It is 50 Gramercy Park North. (There is no 15 Gramercy Park North.)

title: A Confection of Life, Death and Laughter
description: Thirtysomething went off the air in 1991. Timothy Busfield, who played the imperfect adman Elliot Weston in the series, is 17 years older now. His face is fuller. But his gift for projecting a certain kind of selfish vulnerability is unchanged.

title: Letters: Questions for Gov. Rick Perry
description: Gov. Rick Perry was right to champion the mission of the Boy Scouts (Deborah Solomon, Feb. 24). Its not about sex. Its about helping young men become productive, contributing citizens. And perhaps having some fun on the way. The scouts require merit badges in citizenship in the world, citizenship in the nation and citizenship in the community to achieve the rank of Eagle Scout. And a significant community-service project.

title: Amis and Islam
description: Im a passionate multiracialist and a very poor multiculturalist, Martin Amis said a few weeks ago. He was on the phone from London, praising his hometowns ethnic variety  Its exhilarating and moving to live in a city with so many races and so many colors  and denouncing its fissures, particularly over radical Islam. I dont think that we can accommodate cultures and ideologies that make life very difficult for half the human race: women. Amis was explaining his stance in a gloves-off row thats been raging in the British press since last fall, when the literary theorist Terry Eagleton likened some of Amiss statements on Muslims to the ramblings of a British National Party thug.

title: Michelle Davidowitz and Jed Schwartz
description: Michelle Davidowitz, the daughter of Ronni G. Davidowitz and Louis Davidowitz of Great Neck, N.Y., was married on Saturday evening to Jed M. Schwartz, a son of Cheryl Schwartz and Bart M. Schwartz of South Salem, N.Y. Rabbi Erica Rachel Gerson officiated at the Rainbow Room in Manhattan.

title: Brain Enhancement Is Wrong, Right?
description: SO far no one is demanding that asterisks be attached to Nobels, Pulitzers or Lasker awards. Government agents have not been raiding anthropology departments, riffling book bags, testing professors urine. And if there are illicit trainers on campuses, shady tutors with wraparound sunglasses and ties to basement labs in Italy, no one has exposed them.

title: Poisoned
description: The Web site of Khaufpur, India, makes much of the citys scenery and sparkling lakes, even its quaint institutions. One such, the Lazies Club, is dedicated to the art of inertia: seated members take precedence over those standing, who are obliged to pay for the drinks. Aside from a brief reference to an unspecified past calamity, theres no hint that life in Khaufpur is anything less than blissful. Or that Khaufpur does not, in fact, exist.

title: A Scorecard on Conventional Wisdom
description: Washington

title: Out of the Raspberry Patch
description: WHEN I was very young, my grandmother had a house in New Hampshire, and my sister and I used to pick raspberries. We put up a sign saying pick your own raspberries. I was 4 and my sister was 6.

title: A Hitting Expert Extends His Reach
description: Lou Piniella rejects the suggestion that he is the godfather of Japanese hitters in the major leagues. No, it just happens Ive been on teams where a young man like Ichiro chose to come to Seattle and now Fukudome has come to Chicago, he said.

title: Bottom-Line Philanthropy
description: The Soccer Boy Effect

title: Brother of Victim Is Charged in Deadly Memphis Shootings
description: MEMPHIS  The brother of a man who was killed in a mass murder here last week that left six people dead has been charged in the crime, the police said on Saturday.

title: Job Losses Add to Another Rough Week
description: It was another difficult week for the stock market, and it worsened on Friday morning, after the Labor Department reported that the economy had lost 63,000 jobs in February.

title: North Carolina Pulls Away From Duke
description: DURHAM, N.C.  Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski and his North Carolina counterpart, Roy Williams, managed to add even more fuel to one of the most intense rivalries in college sports with a public dispute last month over the disclosure of injuries, of all things.

title: Watching the Rich Give
description: For 23 years, Paul Schervish, a sociologist and former Jesuit priest, has asked wealthy people what motivates them to give away money. He has interviewed more than 250 affluent Americans and has attended exclusive gatherings where the well-off discussed their feelings about money and giving. For a scholar whose views were shaped by the study of Marx, as well as Weber, Durkheim and Veblen, he takes an unusually charitable attitude toward the upper crust. He doesnt look at the wealth boom of recent decades and bemoan the excesses. Instead, he foresees more wealthy people finding purpose and happiness through a philanthropic vocation.

title: In a Makeover Contest, Shelter Hopes for Space
description: IN the cattery at the Voorhees Animal Orphanage about 75 cats live in steel cages, packed into a small room.

title: Following the Rum Into the Wild
description: THINK Africa. Now think cocktails. Now admit you just pulled a muscle. Its kind of a clean map, said Marcus Samuelsson, the chef best known for his work at Aquavit in New York. Mr. Samuelssons latest venture is Merkato 55, a pan-African restaurant and lounge that opened this month on Gansevoort Street in the meatpacking district of Manhattan.

title: As Crime Visits Mosques, the Imams Grow Anxious
description: IN the predawn darkness, Mohamed Azeem Khan unlocked the front doors of the mosque in Jamaica, Queens, to prepare for the morning prayer. For Mr. Khan, the imam of Masjid Omar Ben Abdel-Aziz for 18 years, opening the mosque every morning has become as routine as the rising sun.

title: For Good, Measure
description: Philanthropys largest problem these days probably isnt a lack of big gifts. Over the past few years, new records have been set in the number of individual donations of $100 million or more, and talking with those in the philanthropic community who advise potential donors reveals a sense of widespread anticipation that many billions of dollars, earned during the recent boom in the hedge-fund and private-equity markets, will soon pour into the social sector. At a moment of widespread economic distress, philanthropy is a growth industry, its golden age, at least in terms of dollars spent, almost certainly yet to come. Last year, Americas top giver, according to The Chronicle of Philanthropys rankings, was William Barron Hilton of the Hilton hotel chain, who pledged $1.2 billion. The financier George Soros was No. 4 ($475 million), Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York was No. 7 ($205 million) and Pierre Omidyar, the founder of eBay, and his wife, Pam, finished at No. 21 ($98 million).

title: Up Front
description: Scott Turow, the author of Presumed Innocent and many other books, has received plenty of admiring reviews over the course of his 30-year career. But its the negative ones, he told us recently by e-mail, that stick with you.

title: Prelates and Rappers Strike a Pose
description: IN nearly four decades of collaboration Alexander Melamid and Vitaly Komar were known for conceptual art projects that both celebrated and skewered mass culture. In the early 1970s in Moscow they created paintings that purported to examine Socialist Realism, but the works irony was so obvious that they were branded as political dissidents. By the late 1990s they were training their satirical sights on elephants and the art world, teaching the beasts to paint and establishing an international market for their work.

title: Real Men Eat Meat
description: Millennia ago, long before the birth of calculus or the dawn of the subjunctive, our grunting ancestors roamed

title: Bands Of Insiders
description: Designers searching for indie cred need look no further than a Pitchfork review. Here, a few rising alt-rockers whose style is as distinctive as their sound.

title: Add Alleycat Races to List of Bike Messengers Risks
description: Bike messengers believe that their profession is one of the most grueling and perilous that any person can pursue  especially in Manhattan.

title: Mets Are Happy to See Some Familiar Faces
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets lineup for their game Saturday against the Florida Marlins had an unfamiliar feel. Only one player did not have his last name on the back of his jersey, a telltale sign of a minor leaguer. And ngel Pagn, who had started 8 of 9 games, was given the day off because Manager Willie Randolph did not need him.

title: Cooking Classes Cater to All Tastes
description: GARDEN CITY

title: G.M.s Tiny Gift to Toyota et al.
description: WHAT WAS IT? The 1976-87 Chevrolet Chevette.

title: Mortgages and the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawsuit Takes Aim at Colleges Billing Practices for Study Abroad
description: NORTON, Mass.  A month after graduating from Wheaton College, Jennifer Bombasaro-Brady was back on campus urging the student government to ask the state attorney general to investigate the colleges billing practices for students studying abroad.

title: Whole Lot of Shakin Going On
description: PITTSBURG, N.H.

title: Events on Long Island
description: COMEDY

title: An Exhibition to Make You Smile
description: Brightly colored papier-mch figures of tango dancers, snake charmers, football stars and bodybuilders dont usually find their way into museums, or at least not museums that present themselves as beacons of good taste. But in the renovated art galleries at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, right now you will find all of these things and more as part of an entertaining show devoted to Red Grooms, the eccentric sculptor and illustrator known for his love of folk art and kitsch.

title: No. 813 Is Eighty-Sixed
description: NO. 813 has been an unlucky address on Park Avenue for almost a quarter of a century. Tucked away between East 73rd and East 74th Streets, amid some of the grandest apartments ever built in New York City, the 25-foot-wide limestone building has undergone wave after wave of renovations. Since the early 1980s, it has been under construction, in foreclosure or on the market more often than not.

title: When the Big O First Played the Garden: 56 in 58
description: At halftime of the University of Cincinnatis Big East Conference tournament first-round game on Wednesday, the Bearcats and Madison Square Garden will commemorate the 50th anniversary of my first game at the old Garden at Eighth Avenue and 50th Street.

title: Off The Dribble
description: Andersen Inks Up

title: Claudine DeMatos, Raphael De Niro
description: Claudine Dominique DeMatos, a daughter of Joo DeMatos of New York and the late Margarett Ann Dufanal, who lived in Port Washington, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Raphael Eugene De Niro, the son of the actors Robert De Niro and Diahnne Abbott-Copeland, both of New York. The Rev. Dianne Coverley, a nondenominational minister and marriage officer in the Bahamas, officiated there at a private estate in Nassau.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Play magazine last Sunday about the turnaround of the Boston Celtics gave an outdated name for the teams home arena in two references. It is TD Banknorth Garden, not the Fleet Center. The article also misidentified the game in which Brian Scalabrine, now a forward and center for the Celtics, made four three-pointers near the end. It was the 2004 Eastern Conference semifinals, not the 2005 Eastern Conference finals. And the article referred incorrectly to the parquet floor used for Celtics games at TD Banknorth Garden. The team moved the floor to the Fleet Center from the Boston Garden, the teams former arena, in 1995. That floor was replaced after a game on Dec. 22, 1999, so the team no longer plays on the parquet floor originally used in the Boston Garden.

title: A Virtual Gathering of the Adventurous
description: If trekking through Laos, hiking the Inca Trail, or cycling through the Dolomites is your idea of a vacation well spent, then visit AdventureUs.com. This new Web site is yet another free social-networking service for travelers, but one that focuses more on the sporty, risk-taking set. Couch potatoes need not apply.

title: Veto of Bill on C.I.A. Tactics Affirms Bushs Legacy
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush on Saturday further cemented his legacy of fighting for strong executive powers, using his veto to shut down a Congressional effort to limit the Central Intelligence Agencys latitude to subject terrorism suspects to harsh interrogation techniques.

title: Datebook
New Home for Arts Refugees
description: THE borough of Hackney, in Londons dingy northeast fringes, feels like a discount bazaar for immigrants. There are African wig shops next to Turkish kebab stands next to hole-in-the-wall stores that sell hijabs and handbags. There is even a Caribbean bookstore, Centerprise, that also sells Jamaican patties, and a Little Saigon area with pho noodle shops and nail salons.

title: Heat Some Tea. Look at the Ceiling. Now, Thats Acting.
description: COMEDY is hard, and quitting cigarettes makes it harder. Hamish Linklater, who plays Julia Louis-Dreyfuss brother, Matthew, on the CBS show The New Adventures of Old Christine, learned this last year.

title: A Prescription for Flu Shots
description: It is accepted sound public health policy to inoculate as many people as possible every year against influenza before they can become infected. That is why 47 states allow not just doctors and nurse practitioners but also pharmacists to administer vaccines. New York is one of the three states (Maine and West Virginia are the others) clinging to a wrongheaded policy that endangers everyone, especially the elderly and the very young.

title: Vanilla Nice | A Softer Shade Of Male
description: MELLOW YELLOW

title: Senate Committee Seeks Audit of Iraq Oil Money
description: Two senior members of the Senate Armed Services Committee have requested a full accounting of how Iraq is spending its soaring oil revenue, amid starkly conflicting estimates of how much the country has invested in rebuilding its broken infrastructure and providing basic services to its citizens.

title: Cars Bumper to Bumper, and Consternation, Too
description: MANDINGO TSHAKA, a self-described community agitator, bluntly states his feelings about the car dealerships that line a stretch of Northern Boulevard in Bayside, Queens: Id love to see them shut down.

title: Adrienne Accardi, Noah Saad
description: Adrienne Marie Accardi, the daughter of Susan M. Accardi of Huntley, Ill., was married yesterday to Noah H. Saad, a son of Dale J. Saad and Dr. Saad A. Saad of Long Branch, N.J. The Rev. Godfrey E. Meghoo, a United Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Grand Cayman Marriott Beach Resort in the Cayman Islands. In August 2007, the couple received a ceremonial Islamic blessing in Amman, Jordan, at the home of Mohamad al-Saad, an uncle of the bridegroom.

title: Look Out Below. The Arms Race in Space May Be On.
description: WASHINGTON

title: The Broke Benefactor
description: Our little family was struggling. My husband and I were both freelancing but not making enough. We were two months behind on our rent, and almost everything was going to our high-priced health insurance and the occasional lead-laced Dora toy for our daughter. Instead of planning our second child, we were packing our stuff to move in with my parents for the summer, subletting our home to help get us out of the hole. We werent where we were supposed to be in life, and with lots of self-pity, I wondered if we ever would be. One thing I wasnt thinking about was philanthropy, unless it was a fund-raiser for me.

title: In Praise of Early Adapters
description: IF you were to say that Oliver Sacks, the neurologist who has made as much sense of the human mind as any writer has, has a passion for objects and subjects whose appeal is less than obvious, it would not really be an understatement.

title: A Night Spent Picking Through Someone Elses Trash
description: Montclair

title: The Fatalist
description: There are few sadder or more frantic pieces of literary exegesis than the surviving draft of a letter written by Michel Epstein to the German ambassador in occupied France on July 27, 1942  two weeks after the arrest of Epsteins 39-year-old wife, the novelist Irne Nmirovsky. Desperate for her return, Epstein points out to the ambassador that the Russian-born Nmirovsky had lived in France for 20 years and that while her grandparents may have been Jewish, she herself is a Roman Catholic. Epstein does not mention that he and Nmirovsky had converted to Catholicism only three years earlier, hoping to gain some security against the threat posed by Hitler.

title: Now Feeling | Lovaboys
description: Old-fashioned seems an odd way to describe the three hip-looking best friends behind Lova, a new mens-wear label out of Los Angeles. While they definitely have the looks to make the fashion scene out there, Giuseppe Valentini, Nikolas Apostolopoulos and Daniel Murphy (above) have little interest in hanging out with Lindsay or Paris. In fact, they are as inclined to trawl the farmers markets as the bars, so they can serve up elaborate Greek dinners and anecdotes about their grandmothers in the three-bedroom duplex they share. The trios quaint sensibilities translate into pinstriped blazers, short-sleeved cashmere cardigans and narrow-collared shirts with buttons made of corozo nut. Rather than staging a runway show to showcase their line, the guys made a short film, which has the look of a Super 8 home movie taken at a sunny backyard barbecue  albeit one where all the guests are impeccably dressed bright young things. Rather than just show the clothes, we wanted to evoke an emotion, Murphy says. That emotion is suffused with hazy nostalgia, much like the collections creators. [?][?][?]JEN WANG

title: When He Was 17
description: Sincerity is in. Never mind the skewering irony of the Facebook generation, or the postmodernism that led boomer intellectuals to see the fractures in every value system. Since 9/11, American readers have shown an appetite for simple tales told with becoming directness. While that approach may never characterize our most self-important fiction, it has been reflected in a number of artful works of popular literature in the last few years. I am thinking of Khaled Hosseinis tale of Afghanistan, The Kite Runner, and Alice Sebolds Lovely Bones, about a murdered little girl in heaven who still longs for life. Less venerated by critics, but very much on point, are Mitch Alboms wildly popular short novels  The Five People You Meet in Heaven and For One More Day  which, at a minimum, deserve the respect due any works that so resonantly reflect the tenor of their times. In the wake of 9/11, Americans seem to crave the reassurance of straightforward tales about good people trying to live good lives, who believe in love and friendship, work and honor and charity, the prosaic but immense forces that dignify most of our lives.

title: The Week Ahead: March 9  March 15
description: Theater

title: Throwaway Lines
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Barbers Chair, and Feeling His Pain
description: LONG BEACH, N.Y.

title: Pakistan Rivals Join to Fight Musharraf
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The leaders of the two major political parties, in an unexpectedly strong show of unity against President Pervez Musharraf, agreed Sunday that they would reinstate judges fired by the president and would seek to strip him of crucial powers.

title: This Is Your Teenager on Camera
description: EVEN in this age of voyeuristic television, in which story lines can be manipulated and an unguarded moment can haunt someone for decades, there are still plenty of parents who allow their high school children to be followed by cameras for months, even years.

title: Playing Favorites? Dont Be So Sure.
description: IN the 10 days leading up to Hillary Clintons victories last week in Ohio and Texas, the news media came under withering attack for being, in the words of a Saturday Night Live skit, totally in the tank for Barack Obama. After Clinton won, Obama said the news media caved under pressure from her campaign and suggested that her record has not been as thoroughly examined as she claims.

title: What McCain Could Do About Taxes
description: DEAR John McCain:

title: Malaysias Governing Coalition Suffers a Setback
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Malaysias governing coalition, which has run this multiracial country without any major challenges for the past four decades, suffered a string of election defeats on Saturday, losing control of three major states and all but surrendering urban areas to the opposition.

title: The Office Phone Call Was Music to the Ears
description: YOU hardly ever hear the phone ring any more, the publicity director at my publishing company said last summer. I walk down the hall now, and its just so quiet.

title: Pickup Pix
description: 1. Y-3 JACKET, $419. GO TO Y-3.COM. CHEAP MONDAY T-SHIRT, $20. GO TO URBANOUTFITTERS.COM. HOWE SHORTS, $110. GO TO HAUSEOFHOWE.COM. CESARE PACIOTTI SNEAKERS. GILES & BROTHER BRACELET. 2. GAP SHIRT. HUGO BOSS SKIRT. J. CREW SCARF WORN AS HEADBAND. 3. GAP SHIRT, $40. GO TO GAP.COM. SHIPLEY + HALMOS T-SHIRT, $53.

title: Regina Hosler, William Lamb
description: Regina Anne Hosler and William Turner Lamb were married on Saturday evening in Jersey City. The Rev. Peter R. Carey, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Liberty House Restaurant in Liberty State Park.

title: Friends With Benefits
description: Chefs are vocationally predisposed to generosity. They feed themselves by feeding others. And because their product, their stock in trade, is universally enjoyed and they themselves have become personalities, they are an easy mark for groups trying to raise money for a cause. Not many charities are going to hit up a building-supply-company C.E.O. to donate Sheetrock and hand out drill bits at a benefit. Ah, but the promise of a bowl of fresh fettuccine with shaved white truffle served by Mario himself, well now, that will sell tickets.

title: Be Mine, Mine, Mine
description: Every Feb. 14 since 1986, Ted Kooser  former poet laureate and self-described harmless geezer  has attached a Valentines Day poem to a postcard and sent it off to a mailing list of favored ladies. The recipients were mostly his friends wives (his own didnt mind, he says), but over the years the list expanded to some 2,500 women. To this critic, it all sounded more than a little problematic: theres a fine line, in poetry as in life, between harmless geezer and multitasking player. Besides, who wants a valentine stained with 2,500 thumbprints?

title: So a Senior Citizen Walks Into a Bar ...
description: THESE are trying times for late-night television comics, who this year have been handed a tricky proposition: how to make fun of the two presidential candidates who happen to be an African-American and a woman?

title: Gains Cited in Hunt for Liberia Ex-Warlords Fortune
description: THE HAGUE  For two years, Charles Taylor, the West African warlord and former president of Liberia, has been locked in a Dutch high-security jail, leaving the compound only in an armored car that speeds across The Hague as it delivers him to his war crimes trial.

title: The Fortune Cookie Chronicles
description: American-Born Chinese

title: Witness to the Poor, and a Grand Ship Undone
description: EVERY generation needs to rediscover Jacob Riis for itself. Born with a preachers passion, building on decades of prodigious research by scholars and fellow reformers and empowered by the emerging potency of photography, Riis transformed himself from a penniless Danish immigrant into the conscience of New York and a confidant of Theodore Roosevelts.

title: Face Oddity
description: LOVING THE ALIEN

title: When Ben Bernanke Speaks ...
description: In a speech on Tuesday, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben Bernanke, observed that the upsurge in mortgage delinquencies is closely linked to falling prices, which have left many borrowers owing more on their houses than they are worth. With little or no home equity, he noted, borrowers cannot refinance, which means higher payments for those who have adjustable-rate mortgages. The result, all too often, is foreclosure  especially given the added strain of todays higher prices for food and gasoline and a contracting job market.

title: The State of Iraq: An Update
description: IRAQS security turnaround has continued through the winter. The question for 2008 is whether Iraqi security forces can preserve and build on this improvement as they increasingly bear more of the responsibility as the number of American troops declines (and as refugees and internally displaced Iraqis try to return to their homes).

title: The New Collectibles
description: CITY SLICKER

title: Centenarian Directors Very Long View
description: WHEN referring to the Portuguese director Manoel de Oliveira, it is now  and has been for some time  customary to affix the phrase worlds oldest active filmmaker. The operative word is active. Mr. Oliveira, who turns 100 in December, has made at least one movie a year since 1990 (when he was 82). His late-career surge, a gratifyingly long goodbye, defies preconceptions of what an artists twilight period should be. Mr. Oliveiras undaunted productivity is remarkable, as is the undimmed creative vigor of his films.

title: Events in Westchester
description: Comedy

title: In Pursuit of Justice  and the Hot Dogs
description: ONE weekday afternoon last August, a stout 44-year-old Bangladeshi hot-dog vendor named Mohammed Liaket Ali left his apartment on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, and 30 minutes later arrived at a gray warehouse in TriBeCa, where he pays $400 a month to park his silvery cart. After loading the cart with hot dogs, pretzels, soft drinks and condiments, he wheeled it downtown with the intermittent help of a finicky, battery-operated motor.

title: In the Bronx, Mourning the Loss of a School
description: Diana Santana was making her usual morning rounds at St. Pius V School in the Bronx on Wednesday when the principal, Violeta G. Domingo, pulled her aside to tell her something. As she spoke, Ms. Domingo stumbled over her words, and her voice cracked. Ms. Santana, who has two children at the school, sensed something was wrong.

title: Fight Fiercely, Harvard
description: As a Harvard graduate approaching my 50th reunion, I have never paid much attention to the schools basketball team, and with good reason. Harvard has never won an Ivy League basketball championship, and it has been more than six decades since it made it into the mega-tournament run by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Settling of Crisis Makes Winners of Andes Nations, While Rebels Lose Ground
description: After leaders in the Andes tiptoed from the edge of war to bear hugs and oaths of brotherhood, Latin America was trying to sort out the winners and losers in the regions worst diplomatic dispute in years.

title: Riveras a Closer With an Open Heart
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The dollars were staggering, the richest deal for a closer, the reward for a decade of sterling service and the lightning still left in his right arm.

title: On The Q.t.: Mc Hammer
description: Stanley Kirk Burrell, also known as MC Hammer, has had his fair share of lives. He started out as a batboy, became a rap superstar, was born again as a preacher and is now a Web entrepreneur promoting his site, DanceJam.com. Needless to say, that doesnt include his sideline as a fashion icon. Did you know that Hammer pants are back? Labels like Dior (left) and Burberry have been doing really baggy trousers. Yes. To have invented the Hammer pants and have them re-emerge with a twist is an honor. When and how did you start wearing them? In the late 70s, during the disco era, when we were going out to the clubs. The looser the pants, the more accentuated your dancing becomes. Initially I would buy triple-pleated zoot-suit trousers from the 40s; when I became MC Hammer, I started having my own versions made. Did you wear Hammer pants later on, when you were a pastor officiating at the weddings of people like Corey Feldman and Mtley Cres Vince Neil? I use Hammer pants to perform. For day-to-day life, I have 30 suits that I rotate. Ive always been a high-fashion dresser and love the bespoke style. Once, I bought 80 suits from Versace in all the colors of the rainbow  as bright as canary yellow. To accessorize I had special-edition Versace watches and Rolexes customized with rubies and baguettes. And then came the earrings. Have you ever considered fashion design? Part of my vision is to have a clothing line with a great strategic partner. Not just upper-end, but scaled back to a great pair of Hammer-style jeans  baggy, but not the baggy kind that kids are wearing falling off the butt. I mean baggy Hammer in the crotch area  big difference. Maybe you should call some of the designers that are doing Hammer pants now and ask to be in their ad campaigns. I think you should suggest it, and Id certainly be interested. [?][?][?]ARMAND LIMNANDE

title: Car Crash Stops Subway Service
description: A car crashed through a chain-link fence, plunged roughly 30 feet onto subway tracks and burst into flames in Brooklyn early Saturday, disrupting service on the N line for several hours, authorities said.

title: Stolen Suffering
description: ON a March day four years ago, a very old lady, striking, snowy-haired, unsmiling, was looking at me with disgust. A Polish Jew who had survived the Holocaust, shed been telling me how she and her young son had managed to keep a step ahead of the people who were hunting them down, and at the end of this stupefying tale of survival Id looked up at her and said, What an amazing story! It was at that point that she flapped her spotted hand at me in disdain. Amazing story, she mimicked me, tartly. She fetched a heavy sigh. If you didnt have an amazing story, you didnt survive.

title: Vietnam Culture by the Glass
description: Many people go to Vietnam for the food, for the beaches, for the history. My wife and I went there to drink.

title: Cold War, Hot Pianist. Now Add 50 Years.
description: FORT WORTH, Tex.

title: Masked Marauders
description: Masked Marauders

title: Reinventing the Wheels
description: The sculptor Josh Hadars hybrid-powered hot rods and superstreamlined

title: The Medium and the Message
description: Ah, those great enemies, Word and Image! Their battle rages on in a thousand editorial offices, through the pages of newspapers and glossy magazines. The partisans of Word denigrate their adversaries as dumbers-down, seeking to replace depth and nuance with cartoons and dingbats, encroaching ever farther on their precious line counts and column-inch real estate. The champions of Image cast their rivals as condescending literalists, unwilling to recognize that there are things their precious verbiage is inadequate to express. Occasionally some do-gooder will point out that the two work best together, but page space and attention is limited, and the temptation to battle over the word-to-picture exchange rate  pegged long ago by literary bankers at a thousand to one  is too great.

title: Enter the Boosters, Bearing Theaters
description: IT isnt every day that a busy portion of Philadelphias longest thoroughfare gets shut down, at least not on purpose. But one scorching morning in October, the block of Broad Street from Pine to Lombard, part of a stretch somewhat grandly called the Avenue of the Arts, was taped off, tented, festooned with mums and Mummers. While hundreds of guests sat wilting before the dais, awaiting words from Mayor John F. Street, Gov. Edward G. Rendell and Senator Arlen Specter, a clown on stilts entertained. It was all so quaint and civic, youd have thought President Taft was coming to town.

title: In Queens, No Breach of an Ecuadorean-Colombian Border
description: The Colombian military raid in Ecuador that sparked a South American crisis between Colombia, Ecuador and Venezuela played out on an international stage last week. But another world away, in the Roosevelt Shopping Center in Jackson Heights, Queens, the crisis reverberated on a smaller scale, at Orlando Travel and the House of Cards.

title: A Science Prodigy in an Unlikely Place
description: BAYONNE, N.J.

title: Obama in Senate: Star Power, Minor Role
description: Senator Barack Obama stood before Washingtons elite at the spring dinner of the storied Gridiron Club. In self-parody, he ticked off his accomplishments, little more than a year after arriving in town.

title: Man, Godard and Nature (and Bardot, Too)
description: JEAN-LUC GODARDS radiant, ambiguous, serenely perverse Contempt, 45 this year, is being revived again, in startling color and elegant, ribbony CinemaScope, for the second time in just over a decade, and its beginning to look like one of those movies we cant do without for very long: a classic. Film Forum, which in 1997 gave New Yorkers their first opportunity in many years to see the film on the large screen it practically requires, starts another run (two weeks, minimum) on Friday. That 1997 revival opened a lot of eyes  of older filmgoers whod been baffled by Contempt on its initial release, and of younger ones who knew it only by its reputation as Mr. Godards failed attempt at big-budget commercial moviemaking, or who had perhaps endured a college film society screening of a choppy, faded print. Its time to open our eyes to its troubling beauty again.

title: Chloe OConnor, Patrick OBrien
description: Chloe Kai Salamon-OConnor and Patrick John OBrien were married on Friday evening at the Church of St. Francis Xavier in New York. The Rev. Peter Fink, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Tristan Star to Miss Monday Performance
description: Because of illness, the tenor Ben Heppner will be unable to sing the role of Tristan in the revival of Wagners Tristan und Isolde at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday evening. He will be replaced by John Mac Master, and Deborah Voigt will sing Isolde.

title: Letters
description: Who Profits Most From Oil Profits?

title: Harnessing the Wild Sax, Calming the Mad Metal
description: Matana Roberts

title: Gangsta Wrap
description: JUNIOR MAFIA

title: Formalities
description: Back in the 20th century, when such things seemed to matter, poets argued about the virtue of meter and rhyme. Occasionally the debate produced insights of lasting consequence, like Robert Frosts snarky metaphor for free verse (playing tennis with the net down) and Charles Wrights brilliant response: the high wire act without the net. But the debate was perpetuated more often by tribal loyalties than by artistic necessity. An argument that forecloses possibilities for art  that says X is good because Y is bad  can rarely be trusted.

title: Hardcover Advice
Specter Raises New Questions on Spying
description: Senator Arlen Specter said Saturday that he doubted the N.F.L. would ever talk to Matt Walsh, the former New England video assistant who may have information about the Patriots spying tactics.

title: Travel Warning
description: This hauntingly uneasy novel starts as it means to go on. A 21-year-old Englishman, having pitched his lonely tent in an Andean wasteland, wakes in the morning to find himself drugged, almost penniless, robbed of his passport and saddled with the company of a young Peruvian orphan and a cat.

title: Giving Wheelchairs Access
description: Q Is there a law in New York City that says whenever you change a door in your home, it has to be large enough to accommodate a wheelchair?

title: Bathing Beauty
description: In the past few years ceviche  that humble South American dish of marinated raw fish  has suddenly become cool, table-hopping from one starred restaurant to another. But despite our newfound obsession, most home cooks defer to the professionals and only eat it when going out  or, even worse, they give in to skittish fears and first poach or roast the fish.

title: Glamour and Cars? Its Still the Swiss
description: GENEVA

title: Socialists Win Spanish Election, Retaining Power
description: MADRID  Spains ruling Socialists triumphed in a national election on Sunday, giving Prime Minister Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero a fresh mandate to pursue his agenda of sweeping social and political liberalization.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 17 about the state of public broadcasting misstated the Nielsen rating for the wrestling show Friday Night Smackdown, whose viewership was compared with that of the average PBS prime-time show during the 2006-7 season. The wrestling shows average rating for all households over the first four weeks of February is 2.7  not 1.4, the average for PBS.

title: Letters: Iran Dialogue
description: To the Editor: Your story "The Other Iran" (Feb. 10) prompted several letters reporting that Iranians evidence no anti-American sentiment but object only to our president. Fair enough. But apparently all of the writers were unaware of Irans brutal repression of individual liberties, suppression of women, support for terrorism and calls for the destruction of Israel. Otherwise they might have replied, Were not really sold on your president either and a real dialogue might have begun.

title: A Welcoming Place to Build Wealth
description: GENSPRING FAMILY OFFICES, a financial company that specializes in managing family wealth, rechristened itself last fall after doing business as Asset Management Advisors for 18 years. With a new name came a fresh new logo and sleek corporate identity. When it opened a new New York office on Oct. 1, the company wanted to make sure that its look and feel communicated the message behind the brand: welcoming, family-oriented and focused on building wealth.

title: Long-Awaited Plan in Armonk Nears Approval
description: Its definitely been a long time in coming, and were just about there, North Castles supervisor, Reese Berman, said last week, relieved that a proposal for a 51,000-square-foot residential, retail and commercial complex in the upscale hamlet of Armonk is close to approval.

title: Birder of Paradise
description: As goes bird-watching, one of Americas fastest growing forms of outdoor recreation, so go the bird-watching books. Once, Roger Tory Petersons Field Guide to the Birds and a pair of binoculars were all you needed. Then came The Sibley Guide to Birds, with drawings that made things a little easier for the not-so-eagle-eyed. Now, Jonathan Rosen has written the birding book for the birder who ponders philosophy and theology while quietly sitting by a pond at dusk. If Peterson and Sibley provided checklists  birding as scratching off answers on multiple-choice tests  then The Life of the Skies is the essay question, the question being: Does bird-watching offer a bird-watcher an avenue toward greater meaning, like prayer or yoga? For his part, Rosen, a novelist and the author of The Talmud and the Internet, has a lot of faith in it as a meditative act. I cant think of any activity that more fully captures what it means to be human in the modern world than watching birds,he writes.

title: Take Aid From China and Take a Pass on Human Rights
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka

title: Letters: Did You Hear the One About the Christian Comedian?
description: I had not even finished Mimi Swartzs article (Feb. 24) and had to write. I was coming off one of my worst, most challenging weeks as a newly single mother and found a few minutes of peace, during which I decided to read my beloved New York Times Magazine. How wonderful it was to see the article on Anita Renfroe. I received her video of the Total Momsense monologue a while ago, shared it with a few mom-friends of mine and actually said to my best friend: Watch. This woman will be on all the morning talk shows and in The Times. Lo and behold!

title: A Bugs Life. Really.
description: IN a scandal thats sending shock waves through both the publishing industry and academia, the author Franz Kafka has been revealed to be a fraud.

title: How Many Billionaires Does It Take to Fix a School System?
