description: For as long as wealthy Americans have given their money away, education has been a leading recipient of their largess. Andrew Carnegie, Henry Ford, John D. Rockefeller: the biggest philanthropists of the 20th century all gave significant portions of their fortunes to schools, teachers and libraries. Today, according to the Foundation Center, about a quarter of all foundation giving goes to education; overall, only religious organizations receive more charitable donations.

title: Obama and the Bigots
description: The ugliest prejudices in this campaign season are not directly about race. Barack Obamas skin color may cost him some working-class white voters, but its also winning some votes among blacks and among whites eager to signal their open-mindedness.

title: Marissa Scalia and Philippe Sucosky
description: Marissa Rose Scalia, the daughter of Lynn Conley of Lakewood, N.J., and Joseph Scalia of Farmingville, N.Y., was married on Saturday to Philippe Sucosky, the son of Marie-Thrse and Claude Sucosky of Nice, France. Rabbi Ronald D. Gerson officiated with Msgr. Henry C. Gracz, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Trolley Barn, a historic site in Atlanta now used as an event space.

title: The Muckraker
description: Your new film, Leatherheads, which you directed and star in, is about the early days of professional football. What attracted you to this project?

title: Scrutiny for Puerto Rico Over Animal Treatment
description: BARCELONETA, P.R.  This much seems certain about the events of last October at three housing projects in this town near Puerto Ricos northern coast: Men working for the municipality entered the projects, rounded up dozens of dogs and cats that they said violated the housing authoritys no-pets policy and took them away.

title: Deflated Hope for Nitrogen
description: EARL STEWART spends about $50,000 a month honoring his lifetime tire-replacement guarantee for many of the cars he sells at his Toyota dealership in Lake Park, Fla. He hoped that using nitrogen to fill those tires would save him money by getting the tires to last longer. It didnt.

title: Making Up for Lost Timeless Matchups
description: One of my editors thinks I am a rube, a mark, living proof that a sucker is born every minute. She thinks Mondays Roger Federer-Pete Sampras match is, at best, showbiz.

title: Will They Survive?
description: ALBANY  The old Jim Valvano clich about surviving and advancing is overused this time of year.

title: Wales Tops Ireland to Win Six Nations Tournament
description: Wales won one trophy and stayed on course for something even more significant by slogging its way to a 16-12 victory Saturday over Ireland in Dublin in the Six Nations tournament.

title: So This Geezer Walks Into a Bar
description: The Week in Review explores why codger jokes are huge in a campaign hypersensitive about race and gender. As readers of the late-night TV jokes posted here know, comics have gone to town on Senator John McCain:

title: A Quiet Pain
description: A mother in Queens quietly awaits news of her soldier son, who is missing in Iraq.

title: Taking the Two-Family Path
description: A lovely house in Clinton Hill house charmed a pair of Seattle natives into becoming landlords.

title: Correction: Is PBS Still Necessary?
description: An article on Feb. 17 about the state of public broadcasting misstated the Nielsen rating for the wrestling show Friday Night Smackdown, whose viewership was compared with that of the average PBS prime-time show during the 2006-7 season. The wrestling shows average rating for all households over the first four weeks of February is 2.7  not 1.4, the average for PBS.

title: Correction: Theater Listings
description: This article has been revised to reflect the following correction:

title: Correction: Photographers, on the Other Side of the Lens
description: An article last Sunday about a Sundance Channel series of documentaries on photographers included an outdated title supplied by a publicist for Laura Michalchyshyn, who helped select the documentaries that would be broadcast. She is executive vice president for programming and creative affairs  not executive vice president for programming and marketing.

title: Op-Classic, 2000: John McCain Bows Out
description: Every week, the Opinion section presents an essay from The Timess archive by a columnist or contributor that we hope sheds light on current news or provides a window on the past.

title: A Tour of Terminal 5
description: A sneak preview of JetBlue Airways' sleek new 26-gate, $750 million terminal at John F. Kennedy International Airport.

title: His Supporter Is Devastated
description: Aired Friday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: Last night, Congressman Ron Paul of Texas said hes winding down his presidential campaign. His supporter is devastated.

title: Castle fixer-uppers; Brits in Florida; Golf in India; and more
description: Headlines from the world of real estate:

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Sunday, March 9:

title: A Space for Life in Closeup
description: In the Upper East Side apartment she shares with her husband, Alyson Denny's eye is always on the details.

title: Following Nolan
description: A look at the films of Christopher Nolan.

title: Whale Wars Intensify  Stink Bombs, a Bullet?
description: [UPDATE 12/14/08: A lot of people have found this post after watching, or searching for, the Whale Wars show on Sea Shepherds hunt for Japanese commercial whale hunters. Im going to try to watch an episode and catch up!.] Both sides in the war over whaling intensified tactics and public-relations efforts over the last few days. Japans subsidized whaling fleet and the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society traded video and photo releases showing salvos of flash grenades and liquid stink bombs tossed ship to ship near Antarctica  as well as charges over whether a bullet struck the leader of the anti-whaling campaign.

title: Florida and Michigan Dominate the Sunday Chatter
description: Theres still no resolution to the question of what to do with the results from Florida and Michigan, but a few of the principals involved seem to be leaning toward some type of do-over.

title: Living in the Yonkers Waterfront District
description: After decades of neglect, the industrial waterfront of Yonkers is being reclaimed for residential use.
From the Borowitz Report:

title: Why sterilization matters
description: Brad DeLong, commenting on my last post, misses the point, I think:

title: Every Billion Counts
Competing Prescriptions
description: Jacob S. Hacker is a professor of political science at Yale (full biography).

title: Nourishing Academic Stars
description: A growing number of schools in the New York region are finding ways to nourish talented students.

title: The Global Wheat Trade
description: Wheat prices are rising, increasing the price of bread around the world.

title: A Shared Moment of Silence
description: Something unexpected happened Saturday night when I was out in New York watching the North Carolina-Duke game. It was also something remarkable.

title: Democrats Down the Ticket Worry About an Impasse
description: Suddenly the Democratic presidential race is teetering on the edge  not just between Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton, but between boost or burden for the partys hopes in the fall.

title: Why I Write These Columns
description: Every once in a while I feel that it might be helpful to readers if I explained what it is I am trying to do in these columns. It is easier to state the negative: For the most part, it is not my purpose in this space to urge positions, or come down on one side or the other of a controversial question. Of course, I do those things occasionally and sometimes inadvertently, but more often than not I am analyzing arguments rather than making them; or, to be more precise, I am making arguments about arguments, especially ones I find incoherent or insufficiently examined.

title: AOL Brings Out the Penguins to Explain Ad Targeting
description: In a few weeks, AOL plans to introduce an ad campaign featuring a penguin to educate its users on ad targeting. (Yes, a penguin.) AOL says its hard to communicate all the ins and outs of targeting because theyre technical.

title: Lets Make a Deal, Starring Matt Walsh
description: In statements released to the news media Sunday night, the N.F.L. and the lawyer representing the former Patriots video assistant Matt Walsh revealed that the sides were nearing a deal that would finally allow Walsh to reveal what he knows about spying in the N.F.L.

title: Trading Vows in Montana, No Couple Required
description: KALISPELL, Mont.

title: Toddler Returns to Iraq After Life-Saving Surgery
description: HADITHA, Iraq  She is an amazingly lucky girl in a country where bad luck is everywhere. But 2-year-old Amenah al-Bayati is not aware of her good fortune.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Dec. 25, 2007, about Queen Elizabeths use of YouTube to broadcast her Christmas address misidentified the speech in which she used the phrase annus horribilis to describe a troubled period for the royal family. It was a speech at the Guildhall in November 1992, not her Christmas message that year. This correction was delayed because several e-mail messages from a reader went astray at The Times.

title: Lottery Numbers
McCains Daunting Task
description: Buried inside Sundays papers was a noteworthy election result. In a special election to replace former Speaker Dennis Hastert, an Illinois Republican, first-time Democratic candidate Bill Foster emerged victorious. George Bush easily carried the district in 2004, as has every recent G.O.P. presidential candidate.

title: Time Change Boggles Cable
description: For more than a million Time Warner Cable customers in New York, it was as if daylight saving time never happened.

title: Prison Nation
description: After three decades of explosive growth, the nations prison population has reached some grim milestones: More than 1 in 100 American adults are behind bars. One in nine black men, ages 20 to 34, are serving time, as are 1 in 36 adult Hispanic men.

title: Carlyle Fund Seeks Halt to Liquidation
description: LONDON  The Carlyle Groups troubled mortgage-debt investment fund, Carlyle Capital, said on Monday that it had asked lenders to halt further liquidation of collateral worth as much as $16 billion while the two sides discuss ways to repay debt.

title: For Those Who Fled, a Retort to Cuba
description: Carmen Pelez is a liberal with a deep laugh and a great sense of the absurd. All of those qualities are tested when she encounters fellow New Yorkers who still admire Fidel Castro.

title: India Nurtures Business of Surrogate Motherhood
description: MUMBAI  Yonatan Gher and his partner, who are Israeli, plan eventually to tell their child about being made in India, in the womb of a stranger, with the egg of a Mumbai housewife they picked from an Internet lineup.

title: An American Dance Form Fluent in Many Languages
description: Tap in America carries lots of baggage  historical, racial, sexual  and all these issues understandably affect its aesthetics. One tediously tenacious example is the authenticity debate, which has far too many tap dancers maneuvering to prove proper lineage; surely Jimmy Slyde, one of the few remaining 20th-century giants, couldnt have mentored as many youngsters as claim him in their bios.

title: U.N.C. Claims Another Victory Over Duke
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  The second confrontation between Duke and North Carolina basketball teams in 24 hours came Sunday in the Atlantic Coast Conference womens tournament final at Greensboro Coliseum.

title: Pakistan Rivals Join to Fight Musharraf
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The leaders of the two major political parties here, in an unexpectedly strong show of unity against President Pervez Musharraf, agreed Sunday that they would reinstate the judges fired by the president and would seek to strip him of crucial powers.

title: No Game About Nazis for Nintendo
description: The Nintendo DS video game console has made itself indispensable to the playground set by serving up a steady menu of Super Mario games, plus the occasional SpongeBob SquarePants or Hannah Montana title.

title: Journalism in the Hands of the Neighborhood
description: PHILADELPHIA  We are uncomfortable with the term citizen journalism, said Todd Wolfson, 35, a doctoral candidate at the University of Pennsylvania and one of the organizers of the Media Mobilizing Project in Philadelphia. We prefer the term community journalism.

title: Five American Soldiers Killed in Baghdad
description: Five American soldiers on foot patrol in an upscale shopping district in central Baghdad were killed Monday when a man walked up to them and exploded the explosive-laden vest he was wearing, according to American military officials.

title: MSNBC Cancels Tucker Carlson Show
description: MSNBC said this afternoon that it was canceling Tucker, the low-rated, early evening program led by Tucker Carlson, and replacing it with a new, politically oriented program featuring David Gregory, chief White House correspondent of NBC News.

title: TV Puts an Odd Lens on Politics
description: Last Tuesday, millions of viewers were riveted by the wrestling match in Ohio and gunfight in Texas between Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama, not to mention by the unlikely coronation of the conservative bugbear John McCain as the Republican nominee.

title: Cable Firms Join Forces to Attract Focused Ads
description: In an effort to slow Googles siphoning of advertising dollars away from television, the nations six largest cable companies are making plans for a jointly owned company that would allow national advertisers to buy customized ads and interactive ads across the companies systems.

title: Comedy With Many Faces (When Ones a Crowd)
description: Tovah Feldshuh brings to cabaret the same relentless drive that propels her recurring character, Danielle Melnick, on Law & Order. Win or lose, Danielle, a defense lawyer usually on the wrong side of a case, fights with such belligerent gusto that the mention of her name provokes a shudder by the prosecution.

title: China Says Plane and Olympic Plots Halted
description: BEIJING  A Chinese passenger jet that departed Friday morning from the heavily Muslim region of Xinjiang was forced to make an emergency landing after crew members apprehended at least two passengers who the authorities said intended to sabotage the airplane, the state news media reported Sunday.

title: Pennsylvania Ties Could Help Clinton
description: SCRANTON, Pa.  She is about 3 1/2 years old, a prim little blonde in a light dress, road-testing her white anklets and Mary Janes. Her mother, slim and stylish in a 1940s fitted suit, hat and strapped white heels, clutches her hand and guides her down some outdoor steps.

title: Educators or Kingmakers?
description: IF the Democratic race is settled at the partys convention this summer  not unlikely, given Hillary Clintons victories over Barack Obama in Ohio and Texas  certain delegate constituencies are going to be the object of much affection from the candidates. Most prominent among these is the delegate and superdelegate bloc affiliated with the National Education Association and the American Federation of Teachers, the nations two largest teachers unions. In 2004, more than 400 regular delegates to the convention were members of the two unions, making up a group bigger than every state delegation except Californias.

title: New Challenge to Times Board: Dissidents With Large Stake
description: Last year, The New York Times Company fended off a major investor who complained of poor decision-making and was bent on shaking up the company. This year, management is facing another challenge from dissident investors with similar criticisms.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Monday about reactions by parishioners at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine to a New Yorker essay by Honor Moore revealing that her father, Paul Moore Jr., the late Episcopal bishop of New York, had a hidden homosexual life referred imprecisely to the timing of her realization that he had had gay relationships. According to the essay, she found out nearly two decades after the early 1970s, not after his death in 2003.

title: The View From Uptown: American Dreaming to a Latin Beat
description: It has been lamented in certain circles that they dont make Broadway musical stars the way they used to. Well not see the likes of Ethel Merman again. Or Mary Martin or John Raitt. Or, for that matter, Patti LuPone or Mandy Patinkin.

title: Plan to Let U.S. Troops Bring Families to Korea
description: WASHINGTON  The commander of American forces in South Korea is urging the Pentagon to adopt a major change in deployment policies that for the first time would allow thousands of troops stationed there to bring spouses and children to live with them during tours of duty.

title: The High Cost of a Cancer Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administrations recent approval of Avastin, a hugely expensive drug, to treat advanced breast cancer has raised perplexing issues for women, their doctors and the entire health care system.

title: Disinvited to a Screening, a Critic Ends Up in a Faith-Based Crossfire
description: Shortly before he was to attend a screening in January of the documentary Expelled: No Intelligence Allowed, which is about alternatives to the theory of evolution, Roger Moore, a film critic for The Orlando Sentinel, learned that his invitation had been revoked by the films marketers.

title: Dancers in the Crowd Bring Back Thriller
description: FROM their seats on the rumbling London Underground, a group of stony-faced passengers rose at random and burst into the jerky slide kick of a zombie dance before melting away without a word.

title: Poet Honors Centenarian
description: Andrew Motion, the British poet laureate, is visiting the past again. Fresh from his memoir In the Blood (David R. Godine), he has written a poem for Harry Patch, at 109 the oldest surviving veteran to fight as a Tommy in the trenches of World War I. Composed under a commission from the BBC program Inside Out West, the five-section work explores different stages of Mr. Patchs life, the BBC reported. Prince Charles  described Mr. Patch as epitomizing the courage, long-sufferingness and tenacity of his generation. The poem moves from its subjects childhood home to the battlefields of the Western Front, where he was wounded and, in its final act, to a nursing home in Wells, England, where he lives. Mr. Motion said of the poem, It is by some distance the most interesting of these sorts of commissions that Ive done. Last month Mr. Patch attended a special event to hear the poem recited for the first time. He told Mr. Motion: Its a great honor to have a poem written for me by you. Thats all I can say.

title: At 18, Adu Will Shoulder an Olympic Quest
description: BRADENTON, Fla.  Only 18, Freddy Adu seems too young to experience moments of nostalgia. Yet as he motioned around the soccer fields at the IMG Academies on Friday, Adu fondly soaked in the memories of the place where he became a prodigy.

title: Giving the Outsiders a Say on Movies
description: Film enthusiasts vote at the box office on which movies succeed or fail. The idea behind a new Web site, Massify.com, is to give them a vote on which films are made in the first place, along with some say in the script and the casting.

title: China Bans Actress
description: The Chinese actress Tang Wei, right,  has been blacklisted in China because of her role in Ang Lees erotic Lust, Caution, a drama that unfolds during Japans occupation of Shanghai in the 1940s, Agence France-Presse reported, citing The United Evening News of Taiwan. The newspaper said Chinese print and electronic news media were told on Friday to immediately remove any works and commercials featuring Ms. Tang, but it was not clear how long the ban would continue. The newspaper report, citing unnamed sources, said Lust, Caution was regarded as beautifying those who collaborated with Japan. In the film, Ms. Tang portrays a member of the Chinese resistance who is assigned to assassinate a collaborator, but she changes her mind at the last minute. In December, her performance won her honors as best new performer in Taiwans Golden Horse Awards, considered the Chinese-language Oscars. The report said that Mr. Lee, born in Taiwan and the winner of an Academy Award for his direction of Brokeback Mountain (2005), was not blacklisted; he is an artistic adviser to the summer Olympics this year in Beijing.

title: China Reports Suspected Terrorist Activity
description: BEIJING  A Chinese passenger jet that departed Friday morning from the heavily Muslim region of Xinjiang was forced to make an emergency landing after the flight crew apprehended at least two passengers who authorities say intended to sabotage the airplane, state media reported Sunday.

title: Ultimate Fighting, Toned Down, Seeks Legalization
description: ALBANY  The Ultimate Fighting Championship is ready for a rematch with New York State.

title: In Detroit, Pinpoint Bidding on the Way to a Pairs Title
description: At the American Contract Bridge Leagues Spring North American Championships in Detroit, the winners of the Baldwin Flight A North American Pairs, which ended on Thursday, were Xiaodong Shi of Des Plaines, Ill., and David Yang of Chicago. They finished nearly two boards ahead of Chuck Said of Nashville and David Siebert of Little Rock, Ark. Third were Erez Hendelman and Melih Ozdil of New York.

title: Engineering a Tough Switch: Getting New Yorkers to Recycle Electronics
description: They are often wedged in closets, collecting dust. Some inevitably end up between banana peels and apple cores in a landfill. In New York City, finding an appropriate final resting place for aging computers, boom boxes and televisions can be an arduous task.

title: Bledsoe Is Out of Football and in Business for Himself
description: BEND, Ore.  On the first day of the first football season after his retirement, Drew Bledsoe actually missed two-a-days. In the morning, he climbed into his boat and floated on Whitefish Lake in Montana and allowed for 30 minutes of reflection.

title: Sniping by Aides Hurt Clintons Image as Manager
description: This article is by Adam Nagourney, Patrick Healy and Kate Zernike.

title: Canadian Town Seeks Star Trek Premiere
description: Vulcan, a small Canadian prairie town, is bidding to be the host of the world premiere of the next Star Trek movie, Agence France-Presse reported. Situated among the oil wells, wheat fields and cow pastures of Alberta, the community is already home to a three-day annual Star Trek convention. Dayna Dickens, a spokeswoman for Vulcan, said: Because the films story line is based on a young Mr. Spock and a young Captain Kirk in their early days at Starfleet and because we think of Mr. Spock as our native son, it would be a neat tie-in to bring Spock home for the movie launch. I mean, Vulcan is his birthplace. Actually, a surveyor named the railroad stop in 1910 for Vulcan, the Roman god of fire. Ms. Dickens said the town had sent a proposal in September to the executive producers of the film, tentatively titled Star Trek Zero, and was told last month they were considering it, she said. Ms. Dickens noted that Vulcan has logistical issues, including no movie theater. But she said, noting that movies are regularly screened in the school gymnasium, we can work around them.

title: Scholarly Feminist Brought to Light
description: Curators at Britains National Portrait Gallery, researching an exhibition that is to open on Thursday, rediscovered a painting of an 18th-century female scholar who was a member of the Bluestocking group of intellectuals who promoted the advancement of women, the BBC reported. The oil portrait, above, regarded as a major work, was created between 1735 and 1741 by John Fayram and depicts Elizabeth Carter as Minerva, goddess of wisdom and warfare. Carter was known for her translation of the Stoic philosopher Epictetus, but her friend Samuel Johnson said that besides her talent for translation, she could also make a pudding, work a handkerchief and compose a poem. The curators knew of the existence of the painting from a poem published in 1741 and a photograph sent to the gallery in the 1940s and found it in a private collection. Never previously on public display, it will be seen in Brilliant Women: 18th-Century Bluestockings, running until June 15.

title: Serving Up Television Without the TV Set
description: The stupid computer is a repeated target of the dimwitted office manager Michael Scott on The Office. But the show itself may be motivating viewers to put down their remote controls and pick up their laptops.

title: Facebook Is Extending Its Network to Blood Donations
description: Facebook, the vast and expanding social networking Web site, is about to confront users with a serious new question: Whats your blood type?

title: N.A.I.A. Reports Aid Differently
description: The National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics also provided scholarship data to The New York Times. The athletes received an average of $6,784 in 19 sports during the 2003-4 academic year.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Dec. 25, 2007, about Queen Elizabeths use of YouTube to broadcast her Christmas address misidentified the speech in which she used the phrase annus horribilis to describe a troubled period for the royal family. It was a speech at the Guildhall in November 1992, not her Christmas message that year. This correction was delayed because several e-mail messages from a reader went astray at The Times. (Go to Article)

title: A Fading Sound Spreads Echo Far From Indonesia
description: BOGOR, Indonesia  Every day, a dozen grizzled men  shirtless, shoeless and with clove cigarettes dangling from their lips  hover over a pit of fire here in a tin-roofed shack, taking turns pounding glowing metal into the shape of a gong with the crudest of hammers.

title: Siena Advances to Final, Aided by Unlikely Hero
description: ALBANY  The basketball heroes this time of year can come in all shapes and sizes. They can emerge because of epic games or transcendent moments, and can define careers, ignite towns and compensate for otherwise miserable afternoons.

title: U.S. Shows Depth Amid Top Performances
description: VALENCIA, Spain  Tariku Bekele of Ethiopia looked delighted as he kept the mens 3,000-meter title in the family Sunday, the last day of the world indoor track and field championships.

title: Addenda: Accounts, People, Miscellany
description: Accounts

title: After a Glitch, on the Road to California
description: In an era dependent on technology, classical music has largely been spared the unpredictability of equipment malfunction. But the techies had to stage an emergency operation on Saturday night when the amplifier used in John Adamss Dharma at Big Sur (basically a concerto for electric violin and orchestra) broke down right before the performance at the Howard Gilman Opera House of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Lundqvist and Rangers Finally Gain on Bruins
description: The Rangers and the Boston Bruins went into Sundays game chasing one of the last playoff spots in the Eastern Conference, level on points and locked in a battle for sixth place. With the postseason a month away, style means less than results.

title: Malcolm McKenna, 77, Fossil Seeker, Dies
description: Malcolm C. McKenna, a paleontologist who hunted fossils from the Rockies to the Gobi Desert, from Patagonia to the Canadian Arctic, and who published an authoritative classification of mammals, died last Monday in Boulder, Colo. He was 77.

title: Their So-Called Lives: Documenting High School Years
description: At the turn of the last century, G. Stanley Hall, a pioneer in adolescent psychology, introduced a term  storm and stress  to describe the human experience between the ages of about 12 and 19. Hall was a serious, stern-looking man; yet he still understood just how soul-searing it can be when the Noxzema fails and the only boy to ask you to homecoming looks like a young Mussolini.

title: Shuttle Appears Ready for Launch Early Tuesday
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  Neither technical nor weather issues appear to be blocking the launch of the Space Shuttle Endeavour and its crew of seven astronauts early Tuesday morning on a 16-day mission to the International Space Station.

title: A D.I.Y. Approach to Making a Web Commercial
description: THE masses have flooded the Web with schlocky home movies. Big companies have added streams of more polished videos. But millions of businesses have sat out the revolution because they would rather not make fools of themselves trying to make their own commercials.

title: Tribalism Here, and There
description: NAIROBI, Kenya

title: So Many Characters, Yet So Little Resolution
description: After all these years, all those dead bodies and so many criminal contortions of the law, the wiretap in The Wire didnt bring the bad guys to justice.

title: At Art Fair, the A-List Includes Rembrandt
description: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands  Collectors, curators, museum directors and auction house experts have flocked here in record numbers in recent days to browse through Rembrandts, Warhols, opulent French furniture and rare antiquities at the European Fine Art Fair. Yet so far sales have been mixed, many dealers said.

title: This Weeks Scheduled Economic Reports
description: ECONOMIC INDICATORS Another reading on inflation will come on Friday with the Consumer Price Index for February.

title: The Face-Slap Theory
description: Fridays employment report  which was so weak that it had many economists declaring that were already in a recession  was bad news. But it was actually less disturbing than whats going on in the financial markets.

title: Going to the Company Elders for Help
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  On a recent Saturday afternoon, John Toppel, a retired Hewlett-Packard sales manager, did not spend his leisure time golfing or mowing the lawn. He spent it at a local electronics store extolling the virtues of H.P. laptop computers to customers.

title: For Church, Concussion Reveals Baseballs Hazards
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The morning after playing for the first time in a week, Ryan Church entered the clubhouse Sunday to find Marlon Anderson waiting for him.

title: Boeing to Appeal Air Force Tanker Contract
description: WASHINGTON  The Boeing Company said Monday that it would seek to overturn the award to rival manufacturers of a multibillion-dollar contract to build aerial refueling aircraft.

title: Sri Lankas Wild East Plans First Vote in Over 10 Years
description: VAVUNATHIVU, Sri Lanka  Lawless, contested, notorious for a string of abductions and unsolved killings, this region has long been known as the Wild East of Sri Lanka.

title: Patricia N. Nanon, 84, Modern-Dance Patron, Is Dead
description: Patricia N. Nanon, who supported the creation of modern-dance works as the founder and director of the Yard, a summer dance colony on Marthas Vineyard, died on Feb. 29 at her home in Manhattan. She was 84 and also lived in Chilmark, Mass., where she established the Yard in 1973.

title: Aversion to Death Penalty, but No Lack of Cases
description: They are an ignominious bunch: two Bronx heroin dealers who murdered an informant, a father and son who killed three people in a drug deal, a Brooklyn gangster hired in the killing of a husband for the victims wife.

title: Footnote
description: Because of illness, the tenor Ben Heppner will be unable to sing the lead role in Wagners Tristan und Isolde at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday evening. He will be replaced by John Mac Master. Isolde will be Deborah Voigt.

title: Revered Relic of World Trade Center Is Moved
description: The steel cables tensed, like a sprinters muscles at the start of a race. Then, the cranes engine roared as the operator pulled a lever, moving the staircase off the ground and 180 degrees from south to north.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Feb. 13 about the development of property owned by Cooper Union misstated the name of a Toronto architecture firm that is designing a tower at 51 Astor Place, Manhattan. It is Adamson Associates Architects, not Adams & Associates.

title: Teaching Change
description: WHEN teachers at two Denver public schools demanded more control over their work days, they ran into opposition from a seemingly odd place: their union. The teachers wanted to be able to make decisions about how time was used, hiring and even pay. But this ran afoul of the teachers contract. After a fight, last month the union backed down  but not before the episode put a spotlight on the biggest challenge and opportunity facing teachers unions today.

title: Showcasing New Ballets and Female Choreographers in Boston
description: BOSTON  Boston Ballet has a repertory that judiciously ranges from 19th-century ballet classics by way of George Balanchine, Frederick Ashton and Antony Tudor to recent works by living choreographers. In its artistic director, Mikko Nissinen, it has a figure remembered as a star dancer for 10 years at the San Francisco Ballet. It also has in Jorma Elo, a resident choreographer in demand elsewhere: he has made dances for American Ballet Theater and New York City Ballet and has a premiere at San Francisco Ballet next month.

title: In Tanker Bid, It Was Boeing vs. Bold Ideas
description: WASHINGTON  Just hours before the Air Force announced the winner of a $35 billion contract to build aerial refueling aircraft on Feb. 29, an Airbus plane lumbered off the runway in Getafe, Spain, and climbed to 27,000 feet to rendezvous with a Portuguese F-16 fighter.

title: French Socialists Appear to Make Gains in Local Elections
description: PARIS  In a blow to Nicolas Sarkozys 10-month presidency, Frances opposition Socialist Party appeared to be winning control of several city governments from his center-right camp after the first round of local elections on Sunday.

title: Louisville Women Oust Rutgers, but UConn Keeps Rolling Along
description: HARTFORD  A funny thing happened Sunday en route to another Big East womens final between Connecticut and Rutgers.

title: Democrats Down the Ticket Worry About an Impasse
description: Suddenly the Democratic presidential race is teetering on the edge  not just between Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton, but between boost or burden for the partys hopes in the fall.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Another DVD Format, but This One Says Its Cheaper
description: No sooner has the battle for the next-generation high definition DVD format ended, with Blu-ray triumphing over HD DVD, than a new contender has emerged.

title: Democrats Confident After Taking Hasterts Seat
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional Democrats on Sunday were celebrating an election victory that they said increased their confidence of holding the House in November and affirmed that party positions on the Iraq war and health care were resonating with voters.

title: Bloomberg Seeks New Outlet After Radio Show Shake-Up
description: There was the joke about shooting the police commissioner.

title: Music Ripe to Remix
description: NINE INCH NAILS

title: Southern Baptists Back a Shift on Climate Change
description: Signaling a significant departure from the Southern Baptist Conventions official stance on global warming, 44 Southern Baptist leaders have decided to back a declaration calling for more action on climate change, saying its previous position on the issue was too timid.

title: On Campus, a Video Reminder of Apartheids Pain
description: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa  The homemade video  a crude protest against the racial integration of student housing here at the University of the Free State  moves in for a close-up behind a white student as he appears to urinate into a container of stew.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about the Metropolitan Operas 2008-9 season misstated the date of the first event, a free performance of Verdis Requiem in memory of Luciano Pavarotti. It is Sept. 18, not Sept. 19.

title: To Aim Ads, Web Is Keeping Closer Eye on You
description: A famous New Yorker cartoon from 1993 showed two dogs at a computer, with one saying to the other, On the Internet, nobody knows youre a dog.

title: Socialists Re-elected in Spain, After a Bitter Campaign
description: MADRID  Spains governing Socialists triumphed in elections on Sunday, giving Prime Minister Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero a fresh mandate to pursue his agenda of sweeping social, cultural and political liberalization.

title: A Book of Big Names in Economics, and Only One Makes It to the Cover
description: The best-selling author Michael Lewis has surveyed the culture of Wall Street in Liars Poker and studied salaries and statistics of Major League Baseball in Moneyball. Whats next  a 1,472-page economics text?

title: New Jerseys Republican Problem
description: Once upon a time New Jerseys Republicans fielded moderate candidates for high office and won. A notable example was Clifford Case, who served four terms in the United States Senate but was beaten by a conservative challenger in the 1978 Republican primary.

title: Despite Risks, Clinton Resorts to Attacking Obama
description: WASHINGTON  For much of the year, Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign has struggled to find a way to attack Senator Barack Obama.

title: The Complications of More Leisure Time
description: For this weeks Shifting Careers column, I spoke with Linda Nazareth, an economist in Toronto for Business News Network, Canadas national cable station for business news. She is the author of a new book, The Leisure Economy. Below are excerpts from our conversation:

title: The (High) Road to the White House
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Patriots Employee and N.F.L. Close to Deal
description: Lawyers for the N.F.L. and Matt Walsh, a former Patriots video assistant, released separate statements Sunday indicating progress in their negotiations.

title: Prehistoric Adventure Strikes Gold
description: A movie with a big-number title, 10,000 BC, brought in a big-number weekend gross  $35.7 million  according to figures compiled by the tracking company Media by Numbers. The estimated North American gross for the film (from Warner Brothers), about early tribesmen on a rescue mission, earned it a No. 1 ranking in its debut weekend and far outstripped the $14 million earned by another new film, College Road Trip, a Disney comedy starring Martin Lawrence and Raven-Symon as a domineering police chief and his teenage daughter on a journey to her interview at Georgetown University. Third place went to the thriller Vantage Point (Columbia Pictures) with $7.5 million in its third week. The No. 4 ranking and $5.75 million went to another holdover, the raunchy basketball comedy Semi-Pro (New Line), the previous weekends No. 1 film. Just behind, with $5.71 million in its debut, was The Bank Job (Lionsgate), a caper movie starring Jason Statham.

title: McCain Uses Breathing Room to Focus on Coffers
description: Sewing up the Republican presidential nomination while the Democratic candidates continue to battle each other has given Senator John McCain a valuable commodity: time he can use to unite a fractured Republican Party, ramp up his lackluster fund-raising and transform his shoestring primary operation into a general election machine.

title: The Amazing Adventures of the Midcentury Comic Book Trade
description: The Ten-Cent Plague is the third book by David Hajdu to take a subject suitable for fans hagiography and turn it into something of much wider interest. After his oddball, revelatory forays into the worlds of jazz (Lush Life) and folk music (Positively 4th Street), Mr. Hajdu has delved into the lurid, untethered world of early comic books. A representative story cited here is The Wild Spree of the Laughing Sadist, from the mockingly titled magazine Crime Does Not Pay. It depicts a boy so murderous that his victims included the family goldfish and parakeet.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture with a report in the Observatory column in Science Times on Tuesday about birds using thermal columns of rising air like paragliders to gain altitude was published in error. It showed a skydiving canopy, not a paraglider.

title: George B. Litchford Sr., 89, Aviation Inventor, Is Dead
description: George B. Litchford Sr., a prolific aviation inventor who had a vital role in the development of the collision warning system now used on every airliner in the United States, died on Feb. 28 in Albany. He was 89 and had lived most of his life in Northport, N.Y.

title: From Public and Blogosphere, Shock
description: It may be days before the full political toll of the news that Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York was a client of a prostitution ring becomes apparent. But the reaction from the public, online and in the blogosphere, was loud and immediate, with many expressing shock and disappointment and others calling for his head.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the National Briefing column on March 1 about the next launching of the space shuttle misidentified the branch of service that recently destroyed a disabled satellite. It was the Navy, not the Air Force.

title: The Best Kind of Traffic for Web Sites
description: If you sell things on the Internet, should you tinker with your Web site so that it ranks high in search results? Or would you be wiser to spend money on the paid listings that appear beside those results?

title: Pop All Over
description: Janet Jackson, whose new album, Discipline (Island Def Jam), below left, was No. 1 on the Billboard chart last week, isnt resting on that laurel. She is planning a world tour, beginning in the United States in mid-September, Billboard.com reported. Were talking about America first, but I think were going all over, she said. I think Im going to go back to Australia, back to Africa, obviously go to Asia, go to Europe for sure. Seven years after her last tour, she said, she is looking forward to being onstage. I love being able to see the sea of faces, to have that connection, to feel that love, she said. ... Paula Abdul is at work on her first new album since Head Over Heels in 1995, Billboard.com also reported. Still untitled, it will include remixes of her best-known hits, as well as new songs. ... The Police will hold an open-air concert on June 2o at Stormont, the Parliament building in Belfast, Northern Ireland, the BBC reported. The performance is being billed as their last performance in Ireland. First Minister Ian Paisley called the concert a fantastic coup for Northern Ireland. Others who have performed at Stormont, where Deputy First Minister Martin McGuinness said he hoped 35,000 fans could be accommodated, are Luciano Pavarotti, Elton John, Rod Stewart and the Eagles.

title: Supercharged Solo Followed by a Cosmic Energy Riot
description: That the Montreal Symphony Orchestra sounded so terrific at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night should reassure longtime admirers of this top-tier ensemble. The orchestra has had a rough few years.

title: Curry Has Tear in Knee; Will Try to Play
description: Eddy Curry will try to play again this season, despite a cartilage tear in his right knee that will probably require surgery at some point.

title: House Panel Sues to Force 2 Bush Aides to Testify
description: The House Judiciary Committee filed a lawsuit on Monday seeking to force the White House chief of staff and the former White House counsel to cooperate with the committees investigation into the firing of a group of federal prosecutors.

title: Kyle Busch Sticks to Reputation and Tames Tough Conditions
description: HAMPTON, Ga.  It was a 500-mile race on asphalt, but it might as well have been on dirt, or perhaps on the slick grass apron at Atlanta Motor Speedway, because cars were sliding all around the 1.5-mile track Sunday. The knuckles on drivers hands were probably white as they gripped the steering wheels tightly to try to control their cars in the Kobalt Tools 500.

title: The Night They Drove Old Man Trouble Down
description: Routes from the Appalachians, the bayou, Texas, Chicago, Memphis, New York and New Orleans converge at a geographically unlikely but historically proven nexus: Woodstock, N.Y., where Levon Helm has a home studio in a barn. Mr. Helm, 67, played drums and sang in the Band, which recorded The Basement Tapes with Bob Dylan and made its indelible debut album in neighboring West Saugerties, N.Y. He has been putting on monthly concerts in Woodstock called Midnight Rambles since 2005. At those shows, Mr. Helm leads a core band while friends drop in, and lately he has taken the idea on the road.

title: 2 Clinton Backers Offer a Way to Stage New Primaries
description: Two of Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons biggest supporters, who are also two of the Democratic Partys most successful fund-raisers, have offered to help raise millions of dollars to stage new primaries in Florida and Michigan.

title: Whats on TV Tonight? Humiliation to the Point of Suicide
description: In November 2006, a camera crew from Dateline NBC and a police SWAT team descended on the Texas home of Louis William Conradt Jr., a 56-year-old assistant district attorney. The series To Catch a Predator team had allegedly caught Mr. Conradt making online advances to a decoy who pretended to be a 13-year-old boy. When the police and TV crew stormed Mr. Conradts home, he took out a handgun and shot himself to death.

title: Big Visions for Building Dont Include People Inside
description: If New York were a building, it might be found on the corner of Tiffany Street and Lafayette Avenue in the Bronx.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Samuel J. Hamrick, Who Wrote as W. T. Tyler, Dies at 78
description: Samuel J. Hamrick, a former officer in the Foreign Service who, under the pseudonym W. T. Tyler, wrote spy novels about the adventures of burnt-out cases, died on Feb. 29 at his home in Boston, Va. He was 78.

title: The Crew of STS-123
description: The seven men who make up the crew of the shuttle Endeavours mission to the International Space Station have formed a tight team that will take on a busy 16 days of spacewalks and robotics work. They will attach the first part of a large Japanese science laboratory to the station, assemble a two-armed robotic helper that will do some of the outdoor maintenance aboard the station, and test a method for repairing the shuttles delicate heat shield on orbit. Four of them are making their first trip to orbit.

title: Expectations Lose to Reality of Sports Scholarships
description: At youth sporting events, the sidelines have become the ritual community meeting place, where families sit in rows of folding chairs aligned like church pews. These congregations are diverse in spirit but unified by one gospel: heaven is your child receiving a college athletic scholarship.

title: Zapatero: Spains Bold Liberal
description: MADRID  He was the accidental prime minister, an unproven Socialist contender swept into power by a surge of public rage about the way Spains conservative government handled the terrorist bombings of March 11, 2004.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: AbelsonTaylor, Chicago, hired two employees and promoted two others. Stacy Auer joins as an account supervisor; she had been an account supervisor at Draft FCB, Chicago, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Donald Hanson joins as a senior account executive, managing an account for the treatment of gastroesophageal reflux disease, or GERD. The two employees being promoted are Kaelin Dezelan, to senior account supervisor from account supervisor, and Tommy Schenck, to account supervisor from senior account executive.

title: Husbands Gift to Widow: A List of Secrets and Lies
description: If youre not going to tart up a classic, then the acting has to be superb. Thats hardly the case in the Pearl Theater Companys faithful, earnest production of Ibsens still dynamic Ghosts. The clich about Ibsen is that his plays, so shocking in the 19th century, easily lose their impact now. (So Nora walks out the door in A Dolls House; what dissatisfied wife wouldnt?) In reality, with that layer of social outrage gone, Ibsens deeper issues come closer to the surface.

title: Spitzer Is Linked to Prostitution Ring
description: ALBANY - Gov. Eliot Spitzer, who gained national prominence relentlessly pursuing Wall Street wrongdoing, has been caught on a federal wiretap arranging to meet with a high-priced prostitute at a Washington hotel last month, according to a law enforcement official and a person briefed on the investigation.

title: Classroom Extends to Court
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md.  Two 15-year-old tennis players are blasting forehands at each other on a crisp and clear weekday morning, when most other 15-year-olds are in high school classrooms.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about a penalty proposed by the Federal Aviation Administration against Southwest Airlines for safety related violations misidentified the state represented by the chairman of the House Transportation Committee, Representative James L. Oberstar, who has asked the Transportation Departments inspector general to investigate. He is a Democrat from Minnesota, not Michigan. The article also misspelled the surname of a spokeswoman for the F.A.A.. She is Diane Spitaliere, not Spitalieri.

title: In Detectives Trial, Judges Stone Face Gives Little Away
description: There have been times in the Sean Bell trial when lawyers, out of sheer habit, have asked a witness to please tell the jury this or that, but the seats in the jury box sit empty. Missing are those 12 precious yet unscientific instruments that display the impact of any particular moment of testimony: the faces of the jurors.

title: Israel Approves Home Building in West Bank
description: JERUSALEM  The government of Israel said Sunday that it had approved the construction of hundreds of homes in a West Bank settlement north of Jerusalem, a move that could further complicate a peace effort already hobbled by violence.

title: Daffy Songs of Fish Feet and Tumors
description: Later, when Tim Minchin is burning in eternal hellfire, he may regret a particular bit in his self-titled one-man show at New World Stages. It begins with a monologue about the first primordial fish to evolve feet, and it ends with a song of sorts in which Mr. Minchin skewers a few things he has little use for, one of which is religion.

title: Start-Up Airlines Campaign Takes Cheeky Approach
description: Not so long ago, airline advertising was, well, high-flying, using majestic or serene themes like The wings of man, for Eastern Air Lines; Something special in the air, for American Airlines; and Pan Am makes the going great, for Pan American World Airways.

title: Spitzer Linked to Prostitution Ring
description: New York governor Elliot Spitzer apologizes to his family and the public following his implication in a prostitution ring.

title: How Do They Track You? Let Us Count the Ways
description: In my article in Mondays Times, To Aim Ads, Web Is Keeping Closer Eye on What You Click, I worked with comScore to develop a new measure for Web companies: how much data they can collect from users.

title: Has Push Come to Shove?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Bledsoe's Life After Football
description: On a recent two-day tour of his new life, Drew Bledsoe conducted a business meeting over wine, coached third graders in basketball and closed a business deal on the ski slopes.

title: Downgraded to a Naughty-Naughty
description: Fresh late night comedy from readers (use the comment link below):

title: Red Phone Kid Backs Obama
description: From our sister newspaper The Boston Globe:

title: Time Change Boggles Cable
description: For more than a million Time Warner Cable customers in New York, it was as if daylight saving time never happened, Mondays New York Times reports.

title: Your Questions for Iraqis
description: What would you like to know about Iraqis thoughts on the war, the United States and life in Iraq today? Well take a video camera and a translator out on the streets of Baghdad to ask people your questions. This isnt an opinion poll  the answer you get may only reflect one persons views. Still, that may offer a little insight into how the Iraqi people see things. Submit your questions this week using the comment box below or suggest a topic for future Q&As. The first set of responses will appear on Monday, March 17.

title: If Youre in the Mood for Ad Humor, Say, Yes, Siam
description: Type in funny Thai ads on YouTube and get stuff like this (apparently for a dance competition)

title: Mussolini Hosts Carlo Levi: Art at Villa Torlonia
description: There is something uniquely satisfying about seeing the marvelous paintings of Carlo Levi  Jewish, anti-fascist, painter and author  displayed at Villa Torlonia, a sumptuous villa that served as the personal residence of Italian fascist dictator Benito Mussolini for nearly 20 years. In his life, Levi spent decades fighting the rise of Mussolini, imprisoned as a founder of the anti-fascist Justice and Liberty movement.

title: Who Advised a Young Rivera? Probably Not Who Youd Think
description: While reporting Sundays articleabout Mariano Rivera and his willingness to mentor his teammates, I asked him if anyone had helped him out when he was a young Yankee. Rivera surprised me with the first name he mentioned: Steve Howe.

title: Death and More Death. Why?
description: BAGHDAD  Karada is a bustling mosaic where people from different ethnicities and sects and places in Baghdad come to shop. Security here started to improve over the past few months, and people started to breathe again. Shop owners, after a long time of sitting jobless, are trying to do the same job they were doing before in 2003.

title: No Pop for China Construction in Shanghai Debut
description: Shares of the contractor China Railway Construction rose by a smaller-than-expected 28 percent early Monday after an initial public offering that raised $5.4 billion  the biggest public offering so far this year.

title: Shenzen Plans Start-Up Stock Exchange
description: Shenzhen is ready to start a Nasdaq-style second exchange for start-up shares as soon as the Chinese government gives it the go-ahead, the mayor of the southern Chinese city said Sunday.

title: After Tata Deal, What Next for Ford?
description: As Ford Motor closes in on a deal to sell its Jaguar and Land Rover brands, the company could be nearing the end of the road on asset sales that have been cushioning its turnaround.

title: Taiwan Mulls Sovereign Wealth Fund
description: In the run up to Taiwans presidential election, the Central Bank of China, the islands central bank, says it is contemplating setting up a sovereign wealth fund. The fund could initially be financed using part of the central banks $277 billion in foreign exchange reserves and could be modelled after Singapores Temasek.

title: Bondholder Lawsuit Against BCE Is Dismissed
description: BCE, seeking approval for a 52 billion Canadian dollar ($52.4 billion) buyout, scored a victory after a Canadian judge dismissed a lawsuit by a group of bondholders opposed to the deal.

title: Warburg to Let MBIA Executives Buy Stock at Lower Price
description: Warburg Pincus has agreed to lower the purchase price for some shares certain MBIA executives have agreed to buy and to extend the deadline for the purchases. The move lowers the investment that MBIA will receive.

title: HSBC Said to Have Applied to Raise Stake in Chinese Lender
description: HSBC Holdings, the European bank, has applied for regulatory approval in China to raise its stake in the Bank of Communications to 40 percent, the Chinese bank said.

title: Banker Returns to Helm of Debt-Laden Telecom Italia
description: Nearly 10 years after he left, Franco Bernab again faces the task of running Telecom Italia as chief executive, and he will probably need all the skills he honed at the investment bank Rothschild to reduce debt.

title: Countrywide Said to Draw Criminal Inquiry
description: Federal authorities have opened a criminal inquiry into Countrywide Financial for suspected securities fraud as part of the continuing fallout over the mortgage crisis, according to The New York Times.

title: Financial Firms Take $215 Billion Hit on Subprime Losses, Japan Says
description: Subprime-related losses at global financial institutions have so far totaled as much as $215 billion, with about 55 percent of that coming from the United States, the head of Japans financial regulator said on Monday.

title: Legg Mason Secures Financing to Prop Up Money Funds
description: Legg Mason, the asset management company, threw its short-term money funds a new lifeline on Friday by securing a $150 million letter of credit to prop up portfolios exposed to troubled structured investment vehicles.

title: Will Bidders Dance to Chrysalis Tune?
description: Despite the $4.9 billion buyout of the EMI Group and the February 28 sale of Univision Communicationss music division, theres no siren song beckoning buyers to the record business these days.

title: Knight Vinke Renews Attack on HSBC Strategy
description: A rebel investor, Knight Vinke Asset Management, renewed its attack on HSBCs management over the weekend, criticizing its treatment of shareholders as truly irresponsible, according to The Telegraph.

title: Gigya Raises $9.5 Million
description: Gigya, a company that allows widget makers to track how advertising performs on their Web applications, has raised $9.5 million in a second round of funding from Mayfield Fund and two existing investors, Benchmark Capital and First Round Capital.

title: EADS Targets U.S. Acquisitions
description: EADS, currently battling opposition in Congress to a United States Air Force deal, wants to identify up to two acquisitions in the United States this year, according to Reuters, which cited an internal memo.

title: M&A in Ethnic Food Industry Heats Up
description: Acquisition activity in the so-called ethnic foods market has been cooking, as the Hispanic and Asian populations continue to increase in the United States and mainstream America gets a bigger appetite for an ever-widening range of cuisines, The Deal.com reports.

title: As Good as Cash, Until Its Not
description: Investors across the nation are finding themselves in Wall Streets version of the Hotel California, The New York Timess Gretchen Morgenson writes in her Sunday column: they have checked into an investment they can never leave.

title: New Challenge to Times Board: Dissidents With Large Stake
description: Last year, The New York Times Company fended off a major investor who complained of poor decision-making and was bent on shaking up the company. This year, management is facing another challenge from dissident investors with similar criticisms.

title: Blackstone Said to Mull Rival Bid for Britains FKI
description: The Blackstone Group, the private equity company, has hired bankers to examine making a bid for the engineering group FKI, according to The Telegraph.

title: Congress Budget Battles
description: Who says budgets dont matter? Both parties in Congress intend to use budget debates this week in the House and Senate to score political points and totry to embarrass the other side and the various presidential contenders.

title: Buyout Firms Said to Eye $6 Billion Bid for Virgin Media
description: A consortium of private equity firms, including the  Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, are considering a takeover bid for Richard Bransons Virgin Media, according to The Observer.

title: Chiefs Pay Under Fire at Capitol
description: In pointed exchanges with Congressional lawmakers Friday, three prominent financial executives defended the multimillion-dollar pay packages they received even as their companies were brought to their knees by the spreading credit crisis.

title: Giant Realm Reels In $3.5 Million
description: Giant Realm has raised $3.5 million to expand its entertainment Web site for young male adults.

title: Are C.D.O.s Really Dead?
description: On Wall Street, nothing ever really seems to die. At least, not forever. So, will collateralized debt obligations, like leveraged buyouts and junk bonds before them, make a comeback at some point?

title: Tight Credit, Tough Times for Buyout Lords
description: Just over a year ago, William E. Conway Jr., a founding partner of the Carlyle Group, celebrated the riches that easy credit were bringing to the kings of Wall Street.

title: Meet the Bloggers (the 700 Level)
description: Its an Eagle-themed week at the Fifth Down. One stat to start the show: The Eagles were a plus-36 in net points in 2007 and the Giants were a plus-22. It says here that the Eagles werent as far off the pace as people think  and that the very last thing the franchise should do is trade Donovan McNabb.

title: Autogrill Does Duty-Free Deals for $1.5 Billion
description: Autogrill, the manager of airport restaurants, agreed to buy a BAA unit and the shares it doesnt own in Aldeasa for $1.5 billion, becoming the worlds largest owner of duty-free stores.

title: Hillary Clinton's Pennsylvania Roots
description: While the future Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton grew up in Illinois, her family ties are in many ways stronger in Scranton, Pa.

title: Carlyle Capital Requests Standstill From Lenders
description: Carlyle Capital, an affiliate of the private equity firm the Carlyle Group, said on Monday it had asked lenders for a standstill agreement as it faces more than $400 million in margin calls.

title: Healing Amenah
description: Two-year-old Amenah al-Bayati returns to Haditha after life-saving surgery.

title: Jivox Raises $2.7 Million Seed Round
description: Jivox, which provides an online video advertising platform for businesses, said it raised a $2.7 million seed round from a group led by a venture firm, Opus Capital.

title: Microsoft Would Not Rush to Merge Yahoo Technology
description: Microsoft would not rush to merge its technology platform with Yahoos after a takeover of the Internet company, even if meant delaying some of the potential benefits to shareholders from any deal, Microsofts chief software architect told The Financial Times.

title: Uncomfortable Feelings: On Watching the Giants Win the Super Bowl
description: Our guest contributors of the week are Enrico Campitelli Jr. and Matt Pesotskiof the 700 level, the brotherly Philadelphia sports blog.

title: BC Partners Plans New York Expansion
description: BC Partners, a British private equity firm, said Monday that James Rubin and Daniel Selmonosky, both previously of One Equity Partners, would join the firm as senior partners as part of an expansion of its New York office.

title: Jana Meets With CNet and No Love Is Lost, Report Says
description: A meeting between CNet Networks board of directors and Jana Partners, the hedge fund seeking to replace a majority of the troubled companys directors, apparently did not go so well.

title: Porsche Denies Seeking 75% Stake in Volkswagen
description: The German sports car maker Porsche denied on Monday it is seeking to increase its stake in Volkswagen to 75 percent, noting talk of such a move overlooks the realities in VWs shareholder structure.

title: Why New York Juries Eschew the Death Penalty
description: In the 20 years since the federal death penalty statute was revived, no federal juries have been more reluctant to sentence federal defendants to death than those in New York, writes Alan Feuer. According to records compiled by the Federal Death Penalty Resource Counsel Project, which coordinates the defense of capital punishment cases, federal prosecutors in New York State have asked juries to impose death sentences 19 times since 1988. In only one case did a jury rule for execution.

title: The Early Word: Delegate Uncertainty
description: The still-unresolved issue of whether to seat the Florida and Michigan delegates at the Democratic nominating convention takes another turn today. Rev. Al Sharpton has threatened to sue the Democratic National Committee if, in fact, it does allow the delegates from Florida to count, reports The New York Sun.

title: Healing Amenah
description: Two-year-old Amenah al-Bayati returns to Haditha after life-saving surgery.

title: Margin Calls Pummel Hedge Funds
description: If you have leverage, youre stuffed.

title: Nationwide Financial Receives Buyout Offer From Parent
description: Nationwide Financial said Monday that its parent company, Nationwide Mutual, had offered to buy shares in the subsidiary that it does not already own for $2.2 billion in cash.

title: Regular-Season Champs in Finland, Sweden and Germany
description: The last regular seasons in Europe ended over the weekend. Heres a look at the table-toppers and runners-up in Finland, Sweden and Germany.

title: Blackstones 4th-Quarter Earnings Fall Steeply
description: The Blackstone Group reported on Monday $128 million in net income excluding expenses tied to its initial public offering, an 86 percent decline from a year ago as the private equity firm grapples with a choppier credit market.

title: Endangered Pork
description: Could Congressional Democrats be more anti-pork (the legislative kind) than Congressional Republicans? Robert Novak, criticizing the Republican establishment for its charade of pretending to crack down on budget earmarks while in fact preserving its addiction to pork, is worried that the answer is yes.

title: A Sneak Peek at JetBlues Saarinen Project
description: A brand-new 26-gate, $750 million terminal  designed from the ground up to serve a post-9/11 world and 44,000 JetBlue Airways passengers daily by years end  would be a high-profile project anywhere else. But at the corner of Kennedy International Airport where Eero Saarinens Trans World Airlines Flight Center has captured the imagination of generations of travelers, JetBlues enormous new terminal has a remarkably low profile, by necessity and design.As a result, travelers long accustomed to JetBlues makeshift accommodations at Kennedy may not be aware that all that construction behind the gull-winged T.W.A. terminal is supposed to yield an actual, usable Terminal 5 in six months.

title: The High Low | J.Crew Necklace, $98
description: You dont need a degree from Central St. Martins to know that good style mixes high-ticket items with brilliant affordable gets. In this column, Ts fashion team roll up their Balenciaga sleeves to rummage for the cheap and the chic.

title: Blackstones 4th-Quarter Earnings Fall Steeply
description: The Blackstone Group reported on Monday a net loss of $170 million for its fourth quarter, a sharp reversal from the same time in 2006 amid expenses tied to the private equity firm's initial public offering and a choppier credit market that has hurt its businesses.

title: The Skim
description: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

title: The Ongoing Democratic Primary
description: John Harwood, of The Times and CNBC, analyzes the results of the weekend's primaries and looks ahead to what's next.

title: Gunston Checks In
description: Dont look now, but George Mason is one victory away from securing an automatic berth to the N.C.A.A. tournament. And we all know what can happen once the Patriots get into the field of 65. While youre passing the time until Monday nights Colonial Athletic Association title game, here are some deep thoughts to ponder from the teams mascot Gunston.

title: The Purpose of Project Canoe
description: Tim Arango reports:

title: Latest news from Michael Jacksons Neverland
description: For sale: Santa Barbara ranch. 2,800 acres. Merry-go-round. Choo-choo train. Llamas not included.

title: Red Sox Nation Invades Port St. Lucie
description: The Mets are expecting a record crowd for Monday afternoons game against the World Series Champions. All the seats are taken and all the tables by the Island Girl Tiki Bar have been sold. No room on the grass berm, either, and Id venture to say that Mets fans are going to be grossly outnumbered. The only space might be for wheelchairs, I was told, so good luck with that.

title:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Real Estate Editor Bill Goss
description: Bill Goss, real estate editor for The Times, answered reader questions March 10-14, 2008.

title: There Are Drugs in Drinking Water. Now What?
description: There are traces of sedatives in New York Citys water. Ibuprofen and naproxen in Washington, D.C. Anti-epileptic and anti-anxiety drugs in southern California.

title: M.T.A. Announces Grace Period for Old MetroCards
description: Unlimited-ride MetroCards that were bought before fares increased on March 2 will be honored until June, but the expiration date will vary according to the type of card, New York City Transit announced today. The decision was made after a careful examination of the number of unlimited ride cards purchased prior to March 2 in circulation, the agency, part of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said in a statement.

title: Magazine Regrets Printing Prince Harrys Whereabouts
description: New Idea, the Australian magazine that planted the seed that would help undo Prince Harrys military tour of Afghanistan, is sorry:

title: Amy Winehouse Camp Hits Back at U.N.
description: When a United Nations panel released a report criticizing celebrity endorsement of drug-related lifestyles, they seemed to be talking about Amy Winehouse, a singer in the British tabloids more for her partying than for her songs, although one of them was a screed against rehab.

title: Hedge Funds Under Fire
description: Hedge funds are reeling from collateral calls, reports CNBC's David Faber

title: Blackstone Walks Wall St. Through Its Pain
description: This downturn is different.

title: Warner Brothers Revives The WB
description: The Internet is about to breathe new life into a dead television network.

title: Making Sense of Other Peoples Memories
description: What do we get out of looking at anonymous snapshots? Snapshots  small prints with basic compositions, smiling faces and commonplace subject matter  have not traditionally interested professional photographers and art historians. But in recent years scholars have started taking photographs much more seriously, not only as revealing artifacts of American society but also as works of art in themselves.

title: In praise of expected inflation
description: There has been a lot of hand-wringing over the fact that interest rates on some TIPS  Treasury Inflation Protected Securities, which are indexed to consumer prices  have gone negative. Its said to be a sign that inflation expectations are getting out of control. And its true that the implied 5-year rate of inflation has risen a fraction of a percentage point over the past few months.

title: Monday Morning Motorsports: Another Toyota First in Nascar
description: The weekends results in racing and more

title: The Answer Man: On Tourists and Tipping
description: A reader wrote me with the following story: My boyfriend and I were dining at Bombay Masala near Times Square when the British trio next to us got up to leave. The waiter looked at their check and told them they had left $60 on a $59 check, and that $1 was not an acceptable tip.

title: Recipe of the Day: Chicken Thighs Stuffed With Chard
description: Almost any stuffing you like will work here, and because chicken thighs are relatively fatty, the stuffing can be quite lean. I use a light, leafy green, along with pine nuts and raisins. The result is nicely browned meat and a lean stuffing with acidity, crunch and sweetness.

title: CBS Radio Plays Tortoise to AOL Musics Hare
description: CORRECTION AT END

title: The Big MAC
description: We are now a good nine months into the market turmoil that began early last summer. The crisis has left a host of dead deals and tarnished companies in its wake  not to mention scores of scarred merger arbitrageurs who were repeatedly blindsided by cratered transactions.

title: Help Desk | Attractive People
description: (Romano Cagnoni/Getty)

title: A New Function for the Farmers Market
description: Ed Scheider forwarded me a piece from the L.A. Times written by my friend Russ Parsons. It left both Ed and me open-mouthed, though after about a minutes thought it made perfect sense. Read about the evolution of the Santa Monica Farmers Market, and how it has become a clearinghouse for boutique vegetables.

title: Line Dancing
description: (Matthew Sandager)

title: Bloomberg Moves to a New Channel in NYC
description: Bloomberg TV is moving to a new and more desirable channel position in the nations financial capital, where it will be closer to its two chief rivals.

title: In-Flight Safety Video
description: Virgin America's in-flight safety video.

title: Stolen Art
description: Images from the shows in Stockholm and Vienna.

title: A Good Google Idea
description: After all of this time, Id think that it would be hard to think of a simple way to make Googles search function better. But this reader has come up with one:

title: Soft Serve | Bespoke Ferraris, Floating Beds, Boar Hunting
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: Sometimes, Life Is More Difficult Than Just Soccer
description: The 16-year-old Santino Quaranta was a supremely confident, physically gifted striker when he was drafted straight out of high school by D.C. United in 2001.

title: A Change at Chloe
description: Chloe has just announced that Paulo Melim Andersson has stepped down as creative director after less than 18 months with the Paris house. Hannah MacGibbon will take over. A graduate of Central Saint Martins, MacGibbon worked with Phoebe Philo from 2001 to 2006. Ralph Toledano, the chief executive of Chloe, declined to comment on Anderssons departure. A former assistant at Marni, Andersson had a difficult time capturing the spirit and energy that Philo brought to Chloe, or providing a new direction.

title: Sean Avery, King of the Trash-Talkers
description: The rise of trash-talking in todays NHL is the subject of an intriguing story in Saturdays Calgary Herald, and it should come as no surprise that the article identifies the Rangers Sean Avery as the biggest mouth in the league. Anaheim fighter George Parros and Calgary center Mark Smith had this to say to The Heralds Scott Cruickshank about Averys antics:

title: Checking Up on Your Spring Break Reveler
description: Now you can get a glimpse of what really happens on spring break.

title: The Animated Life: Postcards From Warren
description: Jeff Scher's posthumous portrait of a friend and mentor using an assemblage of images he carefully selected.

title: Ask About the Rights of Students and Parents
description: Andrew Tirrell, a lawyer with the nonprofit organization Advocates for Children of New York, is taking questions from readers through March 14 on the rights of parents and students in New York City schools.

title: Farewell Time Crunch, Hello Leisure
description: When Linda Nazareth, a Canadian economist, emailed me to tell me about her new book, The Leisure Economy, the title immediately grabbed me. If there is one thing missing in my life at the moment, it is leisure. So I was eager to find out where this leisure-filled economy existed and how I could get some of it for myself. The only problem was that given the state of my calendar, it took me about four months to get to The Leisure Economy and another few weeks to find the time to interview her.

title: The Wire: The End
description: The last chapter of The Wire did not cut to black like another infamous HBO serial. Instead, its light faded along the creases of the Baltimore skyline, ending five seasons of David Simons Greek tragedy.

title: Rome, Part One: Dinner at Andreas
description: We arrived in Rome after a serious schlep from Onzo, and almost immediately headed over to Andrea and Bruna's house for dinner. Andrea, as I've mentioned before, has been my main guru on things Italian for nearly 25 years, and his cooking is as consistent as that of the best simple Italian restaurant you know. He grew up in Rome, but works mainly in Naples (where, last year, he took me to the amazing La Tavernetta) and his cooking reflects that.   This dinner focused on pasta with seafood, in a red sauce. (The fish was from the nearby supermarket, which I've visited and he now claims sells better -- and more expensive -- fish than that of the local fishmonger. All I know what that it tasted good.) Artichokes, which we'd come to expect daily on this trip. Good local bread and incredible local gelato.   But the winner, ironically, was a dish that I thought I knew how to make: escarole with garlic, pine nuts (Andrea calls them pine seeds, and you may know them as pignolis), capers and raisins. And I do, I guess, but just not as well as he does. When I asked him what was going on, he said it was "actually a re-elaboration of two classical Neapolitan recipes: Scarola all'aglio, and Scarola with Passi -- raisins -- and Pignoli."   Check it out:      Print  Andrea

title: Rome, Part One: Dinner at Andreas
description: We arrived in Rome after a serious schlep from Onzo, and almost immediately headed over to Andrea and Brunas house for dinner. Andrea, as Ive mentioned before, has been my main guru on things Italian for nearly 25 years, and his cooking is as consistent as that of the best simple Italian restaurant you know. He grew up in Rome, but works mainly in Naples (where, last year, he took me to the amazing La Tavernetta) and his cooking reflects that.

title: Bear Denies Rumors of Liquidity Squeeze
description: As rumors about a liquidity crunch sent Bear Stearnss shares sharply lower, Alan Ace Greenberg, the chairman of the companys executive committee, appeared on CNBC Monday morning calling such speculation totally ridiculous.

title: Obamas Learning Curve
description: On a conference call with reporters Monday, where Clinton supporters from the military discussed her ability to be commander in chief, Clinton spokesman Howard Wolfson was asked why the Clinton camp was talking up Mr. Obama as a possible running mate since it was also arguing that he was not qualified to be commander in chief  a standard that most presidents want their vice presidents to meet.

title: Obama Hits Back on V.P. Chatter
description: COLUMBUS, Miss.
