Senator Barack Obama implored voters here today to discount the political chatter about him joining the Democratic presidential ticket with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, declaring: I dont know how somebody whos in second place can offer the vice presidency to someone whos in first place.

title: Fake Buyout Executive Is Given a Fine, not Execution
description: The penalty for impersonating a private equity maven may be high. But it apparently isnt death by firing squad.

title: What Is the Fallout for Spitzer?
description: Updated, 3:20 p.m. | Citing a Spitzer administration official, The Times reported on Monday afternoon that Gov. Eliot Spitzer had informed his most senior administration officials that he had been involved in a prostitution ring. Shortly after 3 p.m., the governor issued a brief statement to the news media and took no questions.

title: Wooing the Hispanic Vote
description: Hispanic voters are used to being wooed rather unevenly by presidential candidates, most of whom have shown few signs that they get them.

title: Updates: One-Child Rule; Yellowstone Rabbits; Whose Bullet?
description: Some updates related to recent posts:China Leaves No DoubtChina has ended any doubt about whether it was ending its one-child policy. The state-controlled China Daily quoted government family planning officials saying that the one-child rule will persist for at least another decade.Rabbits Not Redux (They Never Left)In support of the time-tested idea that the important thing about science is the trajectory of understanding, not any single study, a Montana wildlife biologist says he erred in concluding in a recent paper that jackrabbits, once abundant around Yellowstone National Park, were now entirely gone from the regional ecosystem there.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Monday, Mar. 10:

title: The Risk of Attacking Your Opponent
description: In his column today, Adam Nagourney writes that for the Clinton campaign, attacks on Barack Obama that once seemed off-limits suddenly were pushed to the front of the stage. As much as anything, the Clinton campaign was concerned about launching an attack that could provide ammunition to Republicans should Mr. Obama become the partys nominee. Bad enough that Mrs. Clinton should fail in her bid to become the second Clinton and first woman to be president. Worse if she should end up being blamed for the failure of Mr. Obamas attempt to become the first African-American president. What changed? Go to Column

title: Q&A: Breaking the Hedge-Fund Silence
description: Last week, Phillip Goldstein, the hedge fund manager, announced a not-so-modest proposal: He told The Financial Times that he plans to sue the Securities and Exchange Commission over a rule about hedge-fund advertising that is often blamed for muzzling hedge fund executives.

title: Isaac Bruce to Wear Jerry Rices No. 80?
description: Our guest contributors of the week are Enrico Campitelli Jr. and Matt Pesotskiof the 700 level, the brotherly Philadelphia sports blog.

title: Seven More Sins, Thanks to Vatican
description: Lust, gluttony, greed and the rest of the seven deadly sins gathered in the 6th century will have to get used to a modern companion. A Vatican official has articulated seven new categories of sin due to the phenomenon of globalization.

title: I Apologize to the Public
description: Updated, 8:35 p.m. | Following is a transcript of Gov. Eliot Spitzers brief statement to the public, delivered at his Midtown Manhattan office on Monday afternoon:

title: Plaster Saints?
description: My friend Deanna and I were driving back from Asbury Park after seeing the New York Dolls at the Stone Pony  shes a young rock n roll photographer and was working that night; I, somewhat older, was having an acid flashback to 1973  and we started coming up with nominations for the most overrated band. She chose the Ramones, and I went with the Doors (certainly not the Dolls). The conversation turned to the most overrated book, and after first saying, Everything I read in high school, she settled, decisively, on The Catcher in the Rye. I wavered between Women in Love (unevenly written, philosophically confused) and the Bible (unevenly written, philosophically confused).

title: No Joy Over Spitzers Troubles
description: The world of opinion hasnt quite processed the news that Gov. Eliot Spitzer has been caught on a federal wiretap arranging to meet with a high-priced prostitute at a Washington hotel last month, according to a person briefed on the federal investigation, as Danny Hakim and William K. Rashbaum report in The Times.

title: Wall Street on Spitzer: There Is a God
description: As news that New York Gov. Eliot Spitzer has been linked to a prostitution ring swept Wall Street Monday afternoon, the reaction can be described in one word: schadenfreude.

title: Magneto trouble
description: One of my favorite Keynes quotes comes from Essays in Persuasion, in which he tried to explain the nature of the Great Depression, which was still in its early stages, and declared that we have magneto [alternator] trouble. The economic engine was as powerful as ever  but one crucial part was malfunctioning, and needed to be fixed.

title: Television Without the TV Set
description: The stupid computer is a repeated target of the dimwitted office manager Michael Scott on The Office. But the show itself may be motivating viewers to put down their remote controls and pick up their laptops.

title: Decorating the Family Room
description: Ive spent a lot of my spare time over the past several weeks trying to decide on furniture for the family room. My research has included:

title: McCain on His Health: Everythings Fine
description: Updated ST. LOUIS  Senator John McCain of Arizona spoke Monday about the melanoma he had nearly eight years ago, saying that he should have sought medical help sooner. He then urged people to get checked regularly by dermatologists.

title: 24/7 Cable Eye Turns to New York
description: Updated, 4:26 p.m. | A breathless, sputtering shock set the tone on the cable news networks in the immediate aftermath of the revelation by The Times of Gov. Eliot Spitzers involvement as a client in a high-priced prostitution ring.Moments after the first early report was posted on line at NYTimes.com, the three major cable news networks shifted to wall-to-wall coverage  lacking in specifics but already questioning how he could survive a possible scandal of the magnitude suggested by the first report.

title: Make Me Over (Or Just My House)
description: Home renovations and life transformations were the favorite fare of viewers on Sunday night, as a combination of Extreme Makeover: Home Edition and Oprahs Big Give vaulted ABC to first place during prime time.

description: Eliot Spitzer, governor of New York, apologized to his family and the public following reports that he had been linked to a prostitution ring.

description: Student exam answers found here (cant be verified but theyre funny):

title: MSNBC Cancels Tucker Carlson Show
description: MSNBC said this afternoon that it was canceling Tucker, the low-rated, early evening program led by Tucker Carlson, and replacing it with a new, politically oriented program featuring David Gregory, chief White House correspondent of NBC News, Jacques Steinberg reports.

title: Let Dan Abrams Be the Judge of That
description: Dan Abrams, who went from being a host to a general manager at MSNBC and then back again, is re-inventing himself again, this time as a self-styled television judge.

title: Thing and a Prayer
description: Tell us whats going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned photos were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: Obama Aides Tout His Credentials to Be Commander in Chief
description: Bandied back and forth during this campaign, but at a particularly high pitch recently from the 3 a.m. advertisement on, is the question of who has the best characteristics to be the nations commander in chief.

title: In Spitzers Corner
description: More instant reactions to the news that Eliot Spitzer has been caught on a federal wiretap arranging to meet with a high-priced prostitute at a Washington hotel last month are starting to trickle in.

title: A cartoon model of the crisis (more serious wonkery)
description: The other day I realized how much the Feds attempts to resolve the financial mess resemble sterilized foreign exchange intervention. That set me thinking about other parallels  and I realized how much the stories now being told about systemic margin calls and all that resemble the stories we all tried to tell about the Asian financial crisis of 1997-98. Leverage, balance sheet effects, self-reinforcing financial collapse  the details are different, but there are some clear common themes.

title: Guns
Prostitution and the Law
description: The big news here in New York is Governor Spitzer being linked to a prostitution ring. That raised my eyebrows, because a few months ago the governor encouraged me to write about his anti-trafficking work in New York (which was indeed impressive). All this raises obvious questions: Should prostitution indeed be illegal? Is it worse to be caught paying for sex than simply having an affair?

title: Client9.com Is Quickly Snapped Up
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Critics Win Again
description: Score another one for the right to badmouth bad food.

title: Succession in the State Constitution
description: Joseph N. Mondello, the chairman of the New York State Republican Committee, and James N. Tedisco, the leader of the Republican minority in the State Assembly, have called for Gov. Eliot Spitzer to resign, following reports that the governor was caught on a wiretap arranging to meet with a prostitute at a Washington hotel last month. Several readers have also wondered what would happen if the governor were to leave office. So far the governor has not indicated his political intentions.

title: Kefi News!
description: Kefis new location is a secret no more: the restaurant will move from its current location on West 79th Street between Broadway and Amsterdam to 505 Columbus Ave., near West 84th Street. Thats where a restaurant called Loft was.

title: Beyond Kittens, Beyond Angels
description: It was a typical entry in Kerrie Smyres blog, thedailyheadache.com, not one she would probably consider extraordinary among the dozens of other entries she has made there since 2005. But it stuck with me when I read it, as an example of the revolutionary phenomenon of online openness and sharing about chronic pain.

title: Jay Brown Keeps Fighting
description: Jay Brown, the chief executive of MBIA, is determined to persuade us that his decision to cut off Fitch was a reasonable one. As Felix Salmon commented on his Portfolio.com blog, The overall impression one gets from Brown is that hes fighting hard, but fighting fairly, on behalf of his company.

title: Rangers Avery Apologizes, but Not for Being Hated
description: After a penalty that angered him in Sundays game at Madison Square Garden against the Bruins, Rangers forward Sean Avery threw a water bottle against the back of the penalty box. But he threw it a little too aggressively and it flew into the stands, splashing some fans.

title: Games in Odd Places
description: The Rangers made one unusual game site official on Monday, with general manager Glen Sather in Prague, Czech Republic, to announce two games there against the Tampa Bay Lightning at the start of next season.

title: Drop and Give Me Twenty!
description: The humble push-up has long been a symbol of strength and vitality.

title: The Spitzer Matter: The Candidates React
description: SCRANTON, Pa.  Will Gov. Eliot Spitzers situation have any effect on Senator Hillary Clintons presidential campaign?

title: The Gap Widens
description: In the Eastern Conference standings today, youll find eight teams in close formation, with the Flyers in the eighth spot. Four points separate them from ninth-place Buffalo.

title: Bloggingheads: Is McCain Cheney?
description:
Matthew Yglesias, left, of The Atlantic and Jonathan Chait of The New Republic discuss where John McCain's views on foreign policy actually lie.
