title: Postcards from Warren
description: The postcards in this film were all sent to me by my friend and filmmaking mentor, Warren Sonbert, who died of AIDS in 1995. Warren was a great traveler and postcards were his preferred method of communication.

title: Eliot Spitzer's Apology
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York apologized to his family and the public after being linked to a prostitution ring.  Nicholas Confessore reports.

title: Where Every Ad Knows Your Name
description: Just how personal can advertising from the Web giants get? Thats a question you may be wondering after reading my article in Mondays Times and the related blog post. With big Internet companies, which already have a lot of data about users, moving into the ad network business, is every ad you see on the Internet going to reflect what you have been doing and reading about lately.

title: Defending SocGen
description: My Friday column criticized the French bank Socit Gnrale for its decision to report its 2008 losses from fraudulent trading in the 2007 year, and quoted one former and one current member of the International Accounting Standards Board as saying the rules were not written to allow such things.

title: Eliot Spitzer's Apology
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York apologized to his family and the public after being linked to a prostitution ring. Nicholas Confessore reports.

title: Presidential Candidates React to Spitzer News
description: The Caucus covered reactions from the three candidates for president about the prostitution scandal involving Gov. Eliot Spitzer, Democrat of New York, who is a superdelegate committed to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. Following are highlights.Hillary Rodham Clinton: Lets wait and see what comes out over the next days. But right now I dont have any comment and I think its appropriate just to wish his family well and well wait and see how things develop.

title: Yanks Sign 59-Year-Old Comedian
description: When Joe Torre appeared on the Late Show with David Letterman last October, after his messy breakup with the Yankees, he asked the real question on the minds of Americans: Who gets custody of Billy Crystal?

title: The Web 2.0 Rsum
description: A while ago, I blogged about spiffing up your rsum. Now I am starting to think the paper rsum may soon go the way of the eight-track tape, Betamax and the manual typewriter (visual aids included for those of you who have never seen any of these things).

title: The Stranger
description: A supermodel, Mariacarla Boscono, and a supermusician, Sean Lennon, create a portrait of three intertwined lives.

title: Happy Bid Day, um, Birthday
description: ALBANY  Siena clinched its first N.C.A.A. tournament birth since 2002 on Monday night, and the Saints march back was more of a cakewalk. Siena torched an undermanned and overmatched Rider team, 74-53, to win the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament.

title: Clinton at Home in Scranton
description: SCRANTON, Pa.  Theres nothing like a hometown crowd.

title: II: The Best Weird-Name Story Contest
description: [Update: The contest is over and a winner has been announced.]

title: I: The Worst Bad Name Contest
description: [Update, April 7: The contest is over and a winner has been announced.]Before I get to the prizes and rules for the Labs two Bad Name contests, I must make a quick apology to my fellow Marions. I meant no disrespect in my Findings column about the psychology of undesirable names. Although I complained about the travails of growing up with Marion as a middle name, I am no longer a self-hating Marion. In fact, Ive just come across a factoid that should be new cause for Marion Pride, which Ill discuss at the end of this post.

title: Joba Meets His Idols  and Learns His Teammates Sinker
description: Joba Chamberlain used 14 of his 49 pitches on Monday against Cincinnatis Edwin Encarnacion in the second inning, striking him out on a curveball. But the at-bat Chamberlain may remember the longest came in the first inning, when he induced a pop out from Ken Griffey Jr. He was drafted when I was 2 years old, Chamberlain said.

title: Former Yahoo! chief turns his attention to Mexico development
description: Freed from the grind of corporate life, former Yahoo! C.E.O. Tim Koogle is focusing his energy and a few of his millions on a luxury development in Mexico.

title: Top U.S. Commander in Mideast to Retire Early
description: WASHINGTON  Adm. William J. Fallon, the top American commander in the Middle East whose views on Iran and other issues have seemed to put him at odds with the Bush administration, is retiring early, the Pentagon said Tuesday afternoon.

title: When Bringing Back the Mangoes, Ants Specialize for the Job
description: To have a good football team, youve got to match the players to the positions. Your linemen must be big and beefy, your receivers lean and lithe. Anything less optimal and youre headed for disaster.

title: Hostility Has Its Rewards
description: MENLO PARK, Calif.  Its crazy to say you will only grow through innovation, Larry Ellison, the hard-charging chief executive of Oracle, was telling me last week. Its bizarre that theres a stigma to buying something rather than building it yourself.

title: Soprano Returns, Bellini and Komitas in Tow
description: Isabel Bayrakdarians latest major appearance in New York was to have been singing Susanna in the Metropolitan Operas production of Le Nozze di Figaro in October. But Ms. Bayrakdarian, very pregnant at the time, bowed out. On Saturday evening, five months later and one child lighter, this Armenian-Canadian soprano, supported by her husband and pianist, Serouj Kradjian, was in fighting trim, or at least fine voice, in a recital at Zankel Hall.

title: Long a Public Scold, Now Facing Life as a Punch Line
description: He didnt say much, not publicly anyway. But Gov. Eliot Spitzer said just enough on Monday to make shiningly clear that he doesnt get it and perhaps never will.

title: A Space Robot With Arms to Make R2D2 Jealous
description: The International Space Station is finally getting its robot.

title: Affidavit: Client 9 and Room 871
description: It was after 9 p.m. the night before Valentines Day when she arrived, a young brunette named Kristen. She was 5-foot-5, 105 pounds. Pretty and petite.

title: In a Pianists Expanding Repertory, Currents of Energy, Humor and Drama
description: The Peoples Symphony Concerts offer performances by top-drawer musicians at bargain prices, but the trade-off is sometimes an audience on the restive side. When Garrick Ohlsson played in this series at Town Hall on Sunday afternoon, he made a point of demanding quiet. Mostly that meant sitting still at the keyboard and glancing at the audience when coughing, program rustling or chatting led him to reconsider beginning. Before one work, he asked, Is everybody ready?

title: Officials Process News of Scandal and Ponder Future
description: In corner alcoves and cafeteria lines, through whispered phone calls and frantically typed e-mail messages, a single urgent question hung in the air in Albany on Monday: Who would be governor on Tuesday?

title: For the Record
description: The Media Equation column in Business Day on Monday, about the major networks decreasing coverage of presidential campaigns, misstated the academic position of C. Robert Zelnick, who commented on the trend. Mr. Zelnick, a veteran of ABC News, is a professor of journalism at Boston University, but is no longer chairman of the department. (That position is held by Lou Ureneck, a former deputy managing editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer.)

title: Obama Rejects Idea of Back Seat on Ticket
description: COLUMBUS, Miss.  At first, the suggestion was a quiet one, raised by their supporters. Soon, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and her husband, former President Bill Clinton, lent credence to the idea, telling voters in Mississippi and beyond that Senator Barack Obama would make a fine partner  most likely as No. 2  on the Democratic ticket.

title: Companies Hold Down Increases in Inventories
description: WASHINGTON (Bloomberg News)  Inventories at wholesalers rose less than a third as much as sales, reflecting efforts by companies to keep stockpiles lean amid concerns about an economic slowdown.

title: Bomber Kills 5 U.S. Soldiers in Iraqs Capital
description: BAGHDAD  A man walked up to a group of American soldiers on foot patrol in an upscale shopping district in central Baghdad on Monday and detonated the explosives-filled vest he was wearing, killing five soldiers and wounding three others and an Iraqi interpreter who accompanied them.

title: Japan: Heparin Recalled as Precaution
description: Three Japanese companies have recalled heparin products made with raw materials from China that were processed by Scientific Protein Laboratories, according to a statement by the Wisconsin-based lab. The three Japanese companies made clear that the recall was simply a precaution, as there has not been a pattern of adverse reactions to the blood thinner, the statement said. Heparin processed by S.P.L. has been linked to 19 deaths in the United States and was found to contain an unidentified contaminant.

title: Western Authors Celebrate a Master
description: POINT REYES STATION, Calif.  Mostly, they called him Wally. The use of Wallace Stegners nickname was in keeping with the familiar, almost familial tone of last weekends gathering of writers  mostly Western writers  seeking new relevance in the work of this protean author some 15 years after his death and a month after what would have been his 99th birthday.

title: Why Knowledge and Logic Are Political Dirty Words
description: There are few subjects more timely than the one tackled by Susan Jacoby in her new book, The Age of American Unreason, in which she asserts that America is now ill with a powerful mutant strain of intertwined ignorance, anti-rationalism and anti-intellectualism.

title: The Best Seat in the Plane
description: Remember when first-class seats meant the best on the plane? Thats not always the case anymore.

title: Imelda Marcos Acquitted, Again
description: MANILA  A Manila court acquitted Imelda Marcos, the former first lady, of 32 counts of illegal money transfers, in one of a series of corruption trials she has faced over roughly two decades.

title: Flexing Those Mind and Body Muscles
description: It is the strange fate of radicals to end up in museums. On Saturday, as part of the sprawling survey WACK! Art and the Feminist Revolution, P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Queens honored a choreographic firebrand, Yvonne Rainer.

title: George Mason Earns N.C.A.A. Bid
description: RICHMOND, Va.  The most tenuous moments of George Masons shocking 2006 Final Four run came several days before it played an N.C.A.A tournament game.

title: Curry Sits Out Again as Knicks Lose by 29
description: DALLAS  Eddy Curry might postpone knee surgery to play the rest of the Knicks season. The sanity of that decision could be questioned on many levels.

title: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Monday about the unrealistic expectations of families in the pursuit of college athletic scholarships omitted a reporting credit. Griffin Palmer analyzed college and high school statistics for the article.

title: A TV in the Kids Room (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Revelations Began in Routine Tax Inquiry
description: The rendezvous that established Gov. Eliot Spitzers involvement with high-priced prostitutes occurred last month in one of Washingtons grandest hotels, but the criminal investigation that discovered the tryst began last year in a nondescript office building opposite a Dunkin Donuts on Long Island, according to law enforcement officials.

title: A Fall From White Knight to Client 9
description: He stands close to ruins precipice, this tireless crusader and once-charmed politician reduced to a notation on a federal affidavit: Client 9.

title: Columbia University to Offer Financial Aid to More Students
description: Columbia University will join a number of other selective universities in significantly expanding the financial aid it offers to lower- and middle-income students, university officials announced.

title: Some With MS Put Their Hopes in a Diet
description: What you are about to read is not an endorsement of any particular diet as a therapy for multiple sclerosis. Nor is it a suggestion to forgo established medical treatments.

title: Highly Recruited Center No Longer Set to Attend Harvard
description: The centerpiece of Harvards highly regarded recruiting class, Frank Ben-Eze, no longer plans to attend the university.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 10, 2008

title: A Profitable 18 Hours Thats All Business
description: WHAT a time for airlines. Delays and cancellations. Oil more than $100 a barrel. Customers are furious and flight crews bedraggled. And thats before the economic slowdown in the United States brings its own miseries.

title: A $100 Million Donation to the N.Y. Public Library
description: The New York Public Librarys venerable lion-guarded building on Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street is to be renamed for the Wall Street financier Stephen A. Schwarzman, who has agreed to jump-start a $1 billion expansion of the library system with a guaranteed $100 million of his own.

title: From Sea Cucumbers, an Idea for a Material That Can Soften Up
description: In experimental treatments for Parkinsons disease and other neurological disorders, researchers have implanted electrodes in the brain in an effort to restore functions.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Saturday about the Opera Orchestra of New York, at Carnegie Hall, misidentified the singer who performed a duet with Aprile Millo. The singer was Stephen Gaertner, not Dolora Zajick. The review also misidentified the work they performed. It was Mira, di acerbe lagrime from Verdis Trovatore, not a duet from Bellinis Norma. (The errors resulted from the reviewers confusion over his notes.) (Go to Article)

title: Something to Lose in a Just-for-Fun Match
description: There was a point in the second-set tie breaker when Pete Sampras timed Roger Federers first serve and clocked a forehand down the line. A step inside the baseline, Federer could only watch the ball land, a clean winner, and turn away in dismay.

title: A World of Data to Help Your Plans to Go Skiing
description: ALTA, Utah  After a weekend of unusually wet snow, Jim Steenburgh stood atop Altas Sugarloaf Pass, surveying the mostly blue sky. Clouds were forming to the south, moving in over Sundance. But no, Dr. Steenburgh predicted, the weather would not come this way.

title: Formula for Idol: Popular Yet Predictable
description: LOS ANGELES  American Idol is down to 12 finalists, and among them are all the archetypes of seasons past. There is the perky blond cowgirl, her hair now straightened and her outfits looking to be straight from the mall; the soulful crooner who channels Luther Vandross supremely; the rocker gal who has to fight against lapsing into a Janis Joplin imitation; and the budding teenybopper now stylized to attract an older audience.

title: A Patchwork Land Confronts a Lie of Whole Cloth
description: SAMSUN, Turkey  When the word spread that they were coming, they were suspected of being missionaries. Then fugitives. But when the small band of Turkish intellectuals finally arrived at this Black Sea city in February, people seemed to understand that they really wanted only to tell stories.

title: Many Doctors, Many Tests, No Rhyme or Reason
description: I recently took care of a 50-year-old man who had been admitted to the hospital short of breath. During his monthlong stay he was seen by a hematologist, an endocrinologist, a kidney specialist, a podiatrist, two cardiologists, a cardiac electrophysiologist, an infectious-diseases specialist, a pulmonologist, an ear-nose-throat specialist, a urologist, a gastroenterologist, a neurologist, a nutritionist, a general surgeon, a thoracic surgeon and a pain specialist.

title: The Red Phone in Black and White
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: A Seasons Worth of Splashes From Paul Taylors Rich Reservoir
description: The Paul Taylor Dance Companys three-week season at City Center ends on Sunday. Anyone can afford to find (as I do) several of the 19 individual works flawed or negligible, because there remain the central classics of the repertory, from Aureole (1962) to Promethean Fire (2002). Its agreeably tantalizing, too, to realize how many major Taylor works are absent from any one season. (Just to list The Rite of Spring, Mercuric Tidings and Sunset, none shown here this year, is a reminder of his diversity.)

title: Sea Levels Are Falling Over the Long Term Because of Lower Basins
description: Mention the idea of sea level changes in this era of environmental concern and all the discussion will be about the effect of melting glaciers and shrinking ice caps over the coming decades or centuries.

title: Reminder to Smokers: Your Lungs Are Aging
description: A simple discussion of lung capacity appears to double the rate patients follow a doctors advice to quit smoking.

title: From Start, Rodriguez Worked to Be the Best
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Bobby Meacham was a shortstop who had been a first-round draft choice, so he kept an eye out for players of the same pedigree. One such player crossed his path in Zebulon, N.C., in 1994.

title: Britain: Restaurant Libel Quashed
description: An appeals court in Northern Ireland overturned an award of about $50,000 to the owner of a popular restaurant who had sued a Belfast newspaper for libel over a critical review. In a 2000 review of Goodfellas restaurant, a critic for The Irish News described the staff as unhelpful, the cola as flat and the chicken masala as so sweet as to be inedible. The provinces chief justice, Sir Brian Kerr, in ordering a new trial, said a properly directed jury would have found sufficient factual basis for the criticism.

title: Pollution Is Called a Byproduct of a Clean Fuel
description: MOUNDVILLE, Ala.  After residents of the Riverbend Farms subdivision noticed that an oily, fetid substance had begun fouling the Black Warrior River, which runs through their backyards, Mark Storey, a retired petroleum plant worker, hopped into his boat to follow it upstream to its source.

title: Buyout Industry Staggers Under Weight of Debt
description: With their big paydays and bigger egos, private equity moguls came to symbolize an era of hyper-wealth on Wall Street.

title: Bribery Trial of Legislator Starts in Brooklyn
description: Jury selection began Monday in the trial of State Assemblywoman Diane M. Gordon of Brooklyn, who is charged with arranging to receive a bribe from a developer.

title: Lazard Chiefs Pay
description: Lazard Ltd. said on Monday that its chairman and chief executive, Bruce Wasserstein, received a salary of $4.8 million in 2007.

title: Panel Asks Judge to Rule in Contempt Case
description: WASHINGTON  The confrontation between the White House and Congressional Democrats escalated on Monday as the House Judiciary Committee asked a federal judge to force Harriet E. Miers, former White House counsel, and Joshua B. Bolten, White House chief of staff, to provide information about the dismissals of federal prosecutors in 2007.

title: Rangers Have Sabres Number This Season
description: BUFFALO Rangers center Scott Gomez said he had no idea what he was going to do when he skated in for a crucial shootout attempt in Monday nights game against the Buffalo Sabres. Neither did goalie Ryan Miller.

title: G.M. Wont Intervene in Strike at American Axle
description: DETROIT  A top executive at General Motors said Monday that the automaker is concerned by a two-week-long strike at a parts supplier that has slowed or stopped production at 29 G.M. plants, but he indicated that the automaker did not plan to intervene in the dispute.

title: Gloria Shayne Baker, Composer and Lyricist, Dies at 84
description: Gloria Shayne Baker, who composed the hit Christmas song Do You Hear What I Hear?, died on Thursday at her home in Stamford, Conn. She was 84.

title: Proposal Would Let U.S. Troops in South Korea Have Families With Them
description: WASHINGTON  The commander of American forces in South Korea is urging the Pentagon to allow thousands of troops stationed there to have spouses and children live with them during tours of duty.

title: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about strategies at Volvo misstated part of the name of its division of Ford Motor Company. It is the Premier Automotive Group, not the Premium Automotive Group.

title: Citigroup Acts to Bolster Hedge Funds
description: Citigroup, the banking giant, moved Monday to shore up six of its hedge funds pressured by a tightening in the municipal bond market, the newest problem to entangle the struggling company.

title: Politics, and Scandal, as Usual
description: It keeps happening. Recklessly, shamelessly, cavalierly  as if this time theyre the ones who will somehow manage to get away with it all.

title: Radio Fear America
description: Mayor Fiorello LaGuardia read the funnies over the radio to cheer up New Yorkers during a newspaper strike. President Franklin Roosevelt gave fireside chats to bolster Americans during the depression. President Bush used his radio address on Saturday to try to scare Americans into believing they have to sacrifice their rights and their values to combat terrorism.

title: Italy: Airport Restaurant Operator Makes Deals
description: Autogrill, the manager of airport restaurants, agreed to buy a BAA unit and the shares it does not own in Aldeasa, the Spanish-based airport retailer, for $1.5 billion, becoming the worlds largest owner of duty-free stores. Autogrill, based in Rozzano, Italy, will pay 546.6 million ($1.1 billion) to purchase World Duty Free Europe from BAA, which is part of Ferrovial of Spain. Autogrill will also acquire the Imperial Tobacco Groups 49.95 percent stake in Aldeasa for 275 million euros ($423 million). The takeovers will increase Autogrills annual revenue by about 1 billion euros, to 6 billion euros. BAA, under fire from airlines and travelers for worsening delays at Londons Heathrow, will use the sale proceeds to reduce 4.1 billion of debt.

title: A Puzzling Autism Case
description: The federal governments concession that vaccines may have triggered brain deterioration with symptoms like autism in a young girl is sure to exacerbate concerns among parents worried about immunizations. It is imperative that the court for vaccine compensation unseal documents involved in this unusual case so that experts, families and their doctors can better understand exactly how Hannah Poling, now 9 years old, came to be harmed after receiving a battery of shots when she was a toddler.

title: S.I. Grand Jury to Examine Marshal Death
description: A Staten Island grand jury will begin hearing testimony on Tuesday in the death of a New York City fire marshal found shot in his bed on Dec. 2, according to people involved in the case.

title: Morgan Stanley Chief Grappling With New Risk
description: John J. Mack stood before his board and shareholders at Morgan Stanleys 2007 annual meeting and struck an aggressive tone. Coming off a year of record profits fueled by using the firms capital to take some highly lucrative risks  particularly by diving deeply into subprime mortgages, leveraged loans and complex derivatives  Mr. Mack had much to celebrate.

title: Ashcroft Defends Receipt of No-Bid Contract
description: WASHINGTON  Former Attorney General John Ashcroft responded angrily on Tuesday to Congressional Democrats who suggested that a no-bid private contract awarded to him by the Justice Department last year amounted to a backroom, sweetheart deal that would earn his consulting firm tens of millions of dollars.

title: Around the U.S., High Courts Follow Californias Lead
description: The California Supreme Court is the most influential state court in the nation.

title: Havens for Tax Evasion
description: To the Editor:

title: Foes of Indian Point Begin Legal Battle
description: WHITE PLAINS  Opponents of the Indian Point nuclear power plants, including New York State, got their day in court on Monday  sort of  to explain why they thought the two reactors should not be allowed to operate 20 more years. It signified the first time that a state had stepped forward to flatly oppose license renewals.

title: The Method of Payment May Decide Any Charges
description: After decades as a prosecutor, Gov. Eliot Spitzer on Monday found himself involved in a criminal investigation from a different perspective.

title: Stupidity in High Places (Like 30,000 Feet)
description: IM a problem solver and have spent most of my career helping companies unravel everything from complex financial issues to complicated regulatory matters.

title: Wigs, Wit and Eyelashes of Theaters Great Ladies
description: So many divas: 32 in Alan Palmers one-man show. Thats about 2.7 minutes per diva.

title: Mr. Spitzers Private Matter
description: New York Gov. Eliot Spitzer could not have been more wrong in his brief public appearance after the world learned that he was suspected of patronizing a prostitution ring. He did not just betray his family in a private matter. He betrayed the public, and it is hard to see how he will recover from this mess and go on to lead the reformist agenda on which he was elected to office.

title: Affidavit: Client 9 and Room 871
description: It was after 9 on the night before Valentines Day when she finally arrived, a young brunette named Kristen. She was 5-foot-5, 105 pounds. Pretty and petite.

title: Heath Ledger's Will
description: Heath Ledgers will left nothing to his former girlfriend and their 2-year-old daughter because it was filed in Australia in 2003 and never updated after they became part of his life, The Associated Press reported. A copy of the will, filed in Manhattan Surrogates Court, shows that Mr. Ledger, a native of Australia, left everything to his parents and three sisters. The will offers no hint at the size of the estate, but papers filed with it value the actors New York City assets at $145,000, including $100,000 in miscellaneous bank accounts. Mr. Ledgers father has said the family would provide for the actors former girlfriend, the actress Michelle Williams, and their daughter, Matilda Rose.

title: The Torture Veto and Americas Image
description: To the Editor:

title: Siena Makes News by Capturing MAAC Title
description: ALBANY  After two languid performances in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament, Siena used the title game as a celebration and a coronation.

title: From Prison to Zenith of Politics in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Asif Ali Zardari, the widower of the slain opposition leader Benazir Bhutto, now sits at the pinnacle of Pakistani politics. It is a startling comeback for a man who, though never convicted here, spent 11 years in jail here on corruption and murder charges as one of Pakistans most ostracized figures.

title: More Wheelchair Accessibility
description: In a settlement that ends a civil lawsuit in federal court, the University of Michigan has agreed to nearly quadruple the number of seats accessible to persons with wheelchairs in its football stadium. There were 88 such seats in Michigan Stadium last season; by 2010, the number will increase to 329 in the main seating bowl along with an equal number of companion seats for fans accompanying disabled persons.

title: Top Athletes in Absentia at World Indoor Meet
description: VALENCIA, Spain  Wedged between an outdoor world championship and a particularly high-profile Olympics in Beijing, the indoor meet that ended here Sunday was for connoisseurs only.

title: Europe Approves Googles Merger With DoubleClick
description: BRUSSELS  European regulators on Tuesday approved Googles $3.1 billion takeover of the online advertising company DoubleClick, the final hurdle to a deal that would strengthen Googles already powerful position on the Web.

title: Summerstage Concerts
description: Crosby, Stills & Nash; Mavis Staples, above; the experimental Brooklyn rockers Battles and Black Dice; DanceBrazil; and the Mexican pop singer Julieta Venegas will be among the performers at Central Park SummerStage this year, the City Parks Foundation has announced. Crosby, Stills & Nash will play on July 29 in one of the six paid benefit concerts during this 23rd SummerStage season. The other performances, along with the Afro-funk scion Seun Kuti and the vintage-soul revivalists Sharon Jones and the Dap-Kings, are free, beginning with Ms. Stapless concert on June 13. The complete lineup will be announced in April.

title: Malvin Wald, Creator of Naked City, Dies at 90
description: Malvin Wald, who conceived and was a co-writer of the gritty 1948 crime film The Naked City, a prototype for modern police dramas, including the popular television show of the same name, died on Thursday in Sherman Oaks, Calif. He was 90 and lived in Sherman Oaks.

title: Corrections
description: The Books of The Times review in Weekend on Friday, about Gusher of Lies: The Dangerous Delusions of Energy Independence, misstated the authors surname at several points, and a description of an online excerpt from the book misstated his surname as well. As the review noted elsewhere, he is Robert Bryce, not Bruce or Boyce. The bibliographical capsule with the review misidentified the publisher. It is PublicAffairs, not Basic Books.

title: Medvedev. Mehd-V(y)EHD-yehf. Whatever.
description: Paris

title: New Guidelines Ahead of Ashcroft Testimony
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department announced guidelines Monday to prevent the sort of conflict-of-interest accusations that followed its decision to steer a private contract worth tens of millions of dollars to former Attorney General John Ashcroft to monitor a large out-of-court settlement.

title: China Sticking With One-Child Policy
description: BEIJING  Chinas top population official said the countrys one-child-per-couple family planning policy would not change for at least another decade. The announcement refutes speculation that officials were contemplating adjustments to compensate for mounting demographic pressures.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Saturday about the Opera Orchestra of New York, at Carnegie Hall, misidentified the singer who performed a duet with Aprile Millo. The singer was Stephen Gaertner, not Dolora Zajick. The review also misidentified the work they performed. It was Mira, di acerbe lagrime from Verdis Trovatore, not a duet from Bellinis Norma. (The errors resulted from the reviewers confusion over his notes.)

title: Advice for the Candidates: What You Could Say
description: To the Editor:

title: Uganda: Vaccine Program Vanquishes a Dangerous Type of Childhood Meningitis
description: A dangerous type of childhood meningitis has been virtually eliminated in Uganda in just five years after a vaccine was introduced, according to a study released this week.

title: The Spoils of War in Peaceable Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM  Its hard to find anyplace in Europe today, even here in peaceable Sweden, where people arent squabbling over cultural property and the spoils of war. For some time, it turns out, a handful of nationalist Danes have been loudly barking about booty that the Swedes nabbed 350 years ago in a war with Denmark. The cache includes an ornate canopy from Kronborg Castle, of Hamlet lore, and recently people in Skane, a region in the south of Sweden that was ceded by Denmark in 1658 after losing the war, said they wanted the canopy handed over.

title: Genomes on the Market (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Talks, but No Truce, Accompany Lull in Gaza Violence
description: JERUSALEM  A senior Israeli official and leaders of militant groups in Gaza have held talks with Egyptian officials in recent days, but Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel denied on Monday that Israel was engaged in talks to broker a truce, despite several days of relative quiet near the Gaza border.

title: Alice in Charge
description: Urban Stages 259 West 30th Street, Manhattan (212) 868-4444, urbanstages.org Through April 6

title: Kissing the Earth Goodbye in About 7.59 Billion Years
description: In the end, there wont even be fragments.

title: Mysterious Creatures in a Laid-Back World of Dance
description: There are dances that seem to open a door and welcome you into another world. Laura Pawels pieces beckon from rocking chairs on a front porch, where old friends are engaged in murmured, antic conversation. Ms. Pawels company, which performed on Saturday night at the Dance Forum studio, includes members who have performed together since the 1960s, when they were familiar faces in New Yorks downtown dance scene. Others are newer, with interesting day jobs. One is an operating room nurse, another a lamp maker. Two wear eyeglasses as they move.

title: Woman Replaces Colleague for South Koreas First Space Mission
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea announced Monday that a woman who is a bioengineering student would become its first astronaut. She is scheduled to blast off on board a Russian Soyuz rocket on April 8 on a trip to the International Space Station that will be watched on television by millions of South Koreans.

title: Michigan Stadium Will Expand Seating for Disabled Fans
description: In a settlement that ended a civil lawsuit in federal court, the University of Michigan agreed to nearly quadruple the number of seats accessible to persons with wheelchairs in its football stadium in Ann Arbor.

title: Chinas Rate of Inflation Is Highest in 11 Years
description: HONG KONG  Consumer prices in China surged to a 8.7 percent annual rate in February from a 7.1 percent rate in January, the fastest pace of increase in more than 11 years, Chinas National Bureau of Statistics announced on Tuesday morning.

title: Oliviers Go for Big Hair
description: Londons Olivier Awards proved a triumph for the West End production of the musical Hairspray, which won best new musical as well as the awards for best actor in a musical for Michael Ball, above right; best actress, Leanne Jones, above left; and best supporting actress, Tracie Bennett. Kristin Scott Thomas won best actress in a play for her role in The Seagull, and Chiwetel Ejiofor was named best actor for the title role in Othello. The latest production of George Bernard Shaws Saint Joan won for best revival, and Rory Kinnear was best supporting actor in a play for his performance in The Man of Mode. The Magic Flute was named best musical revival, and Simon McBurneys production of A Disappearing Number was named best new play. Rupert Goold won the best director award for his production of Macbeth, which is now at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Andrew Lloyd Webber was honored for lifetime achievement.

title: For the Record
description: A listing of credits and theater information on Monday with a review of In the Heights, at the Richard Rodgers Theater, misstated the telephone number to call for tickets. It is 212-307-4100.

title: Hazards: Rise in Car Fatality Rates Seen at Age 12
description: Children in their early teens are more likely to be killed in a car accident than younger children are, a new study finds.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column in Science Times last Tuesday, about the challenges of treating multiple sclerosis, misstated the number of immune-modulating drugs approved by the Food and Drug Administration for treatment of the disease. It is six, not five; the drug omitted was Tysabri. The column also misstated the year Tysabri was withdrawn from the market after reports of complications in three patients. It was 2005, not 2004. (The drug has since been returned to the market.) And the column misspelled the name of another drug for multiple sclerosis. It is Copaxone, not Copaxane.

title: Workers Sue Gulf Coast Company That Imported Them
description: NEW ORLEANS  A group of 500 foreign welders and pipefitters brought in to work at Gulf Coast oil rig yards after Hurricane Katrina said Monday that they had sued their employer, claiming they were lured with false promises of permanent-resident status, forced to live in inhumane conditions and then threatened when they protested.

title: A Painful Commemoration in Vienna
description: An exhibition at the Vienna State Opera house that opened on Monday details how its Jewish employees were purged under Nazi rule, Reuters reported. Few of the 92 who lost their jobs and survived the war were reinstated. The exhibition is part of a national commemoration of Austrias willing acceptance of annexation by Hitlers Germany, whose forces took control on March 12, 1938. The Opera is one of the institutions ready to face up to its past even if it was painful at times, the Austrian chancellor, Alfred Gusenbauer, said in opening the exhibition. Such institutions in Austria in 2008 are sadly still the exception. The anniversary has prompted a wave of reflection, with special television programs and an appeal by the Roman Catholic Church to learn the lessons of the past. A candlelight vigil will take place on Wednesday, the anniversary, at the citys Heldenplatz (Heroes Square), where jubilant Austrians gathered to greet Hitler days after the annexation, and both houses of Parliament will hold a special joint session on Wednesday morning to mark the anniversary.

title: Finding a Disorders Cause (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Perspectives on Nature, After a Storm
description: Nature demanded its due on Sunday afternoon, as clocks pushed forward for daylight saving time provided an extra hour of sunlight to observe debris strewn by the ferocious windstorm on Saturday night. The New Amsterdam Singers seemed to have planned in advance with As Nature Wakes, an enjoyable mix of American and Czech works featuring nature as subject or metaphor, presented that afternoon at the Church of the Holy Trinity.

title: Switzerland: Nestl Plans Chocolate Research Center
description: Nestl, the food company, will open a Swiss research center that will develop new chocolate products to meet anticipated growth in demand for luxury and premium confections. The center will employ 30 chocolatiers and will open in the first half of next year at the candy makers factory in the Swiss town of Broc, Roland Decorvet, head of Nestl Switzerland, said at a news conference. Nestl will invest 20 million Swiss francs ($19.6 million) in the project.

title: A Weaker Dollar?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paying at the Pump, in a Big Way
description: CLEVELAND  Ricardo Caraballo was having a familiar American experience at the filling station the other day, groaning as the pump clicked up, up, up. By the time he finished it read $505, and his tank was only half full.

title: House Steers Its Own Path on Wiretaps
description: WASHINGTON  In continued defiance of the White House, House Democratic leaders are readying a proposal that would reject giving legal protection to the phone companies that helped in the National Security Agencys program of wiretapping without warrants after the Sept. 11 attacks, Congressional officials said Monday.

title: Fed Plans to Lend $200 Billion to Banks
description: Scrambling to ease the strain on the credit market, the Federal Reserve announced a $200 billion program on Tuesday that would allow financial institutions, including the nations major investment banks, to borrow ultra-safe Treasury money by using some of their riskiest investments as collateral. Wall Street responded with a rally, with the Dow Jones industrials surging more than 400 points.

title: Business Travel Miscellany
description: KEEP TRAVELING, WORK HARDER A new survey for American Express shows that most midsize companies hope to hold travel spending at current levels this year. But many plan on spending more for on-the-road productivity tools like laptops and mobile phones and other wireless devices. Two-thirds of the companies said they expected to be in a better position on negotiating prices with suppliers, and more than half said they needed to put more effort into monitoring employee compliance to expense policies, American Express said. CFO Research Services conducted the survey in November by interviewing more than 400 senior finance executives at midsize companies.

title: Dallas Is Slow to Adjust to Kidd in Fast-Paced West
description: DALLAS  To play with Jason Kidd is to know that a triple-double is always possible, that a victory is more than likely and that the ball might be an inch from your nose if you look away at the wrong moment.

title: An Airline Terminal for a Security-Wary Era
description: From the moment that passengers first arrive at JetBlue Airways $750 million terminal at Kennedy International Airport in September, they will face an unmistakably post-9/11 world.

title: UConn Gets Rolling and Pitt Cant Keep Up
description: HARTFORD  This is how Monday nights semifinal between Connecticut and Pittsburgh in the Big East Conference womens tournament began:

title: WellPoint Cuts Its Outlook, Sending Shivers Through Shares of Health Insurers
description: Shares of WellPoint, one of the nations largest health insurers, plummeted more than 16 percent in after-hours trading Monday after the company lowered its profit forecast, citing higher medical costs and lower-than-expected insurance enrollments.

title: Keeping Iraq in the Dark
description: LACK of electricity is still a big problem in Iraq, and theres lots of blame to go around. Much of it goes to the usual suspects: too many insurgent attacks, too few experienced engineers and technicians. But theres another factor, big and getting bigger, which you probably havent read about. Its one that Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki and his bureaucrats could solve quickly, if they wanted to: Iraqs Ministries of Oil and Electricity are at loggerheads.

title: Managing a Chronic Illness (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: At MSNBC, Tucker Is Out, and David Gregory Is In
description: Tucker, the struggling early-evening talk show led by the often bow-tied Tucker Carlson, was canceled on Monday by MSNBC and replaced by a new politically oriented program featuring David Gregory, chief White House correspondent of NBC News.

title: For Reyna, New Ally and New Role
description: The 2007 M.L.S. season was supposed to be a glorious homecoming for Claudio Reyna.

title: Recruits Clamor for More From Coaches With Less
description: The countrys celebrity college football and basketball coaches lead nationally ranked teams on television, controlling a bevy of full scholarships and a sophisticated marketing machine that swathes college athletics with an air of affluence. They are far from typical.

title: Nostrums: Aromatherapy Rarely Stands Up to Testing
description: There is little that aromatherapy has not been claimed to help with at one time or another. It is said to reduce pain and anxiety, bring both energy and relaxation and even make the immune system stronger.

title: U.S. Will Aid Polish Military
description: President Bush pledged to help modernize Polands military as part of the administrations plans to base missile interceptors in the country. His press secretary, Dana M. Perino, said the pledge was not a quid pro quo, but Prime Minister Donald Tusk, who faces a public skeptical of having American missiles based in Poland, directly linked the issues after meeting with Mr. Bush at the White House. Our joint intention is to cooperate in all aspects of global security, American security and Polish security, he said. And an element of the security is the missile defense system.

title: Fix It Up, Give It Away
description: Extreme Makeover: Home Edition and Oprahs Big Give vaulted ABC to first place for Sunday night, according to Nielsen. Extreme Makeover was the most-watched program with 12.4 million viewers, and the second week of Oprahs Big Give averaged 11.8 million, down 3.7 million from the week before, Nielsen estimates. Helped by an audience of 11.6 million for 60 Minutes, CBS finished second for the night in total viewers but finished in fourth place in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic. A two-hour 100 Most Outrageous Moments of All Time on NBC added viewers every half-hour, peaking with 10.6 million viewers at 8:30. But a Law & Order repeat at 9 garnered just under seven million viewers for the hour. Law & Order: Special Victims Unit delivered 8.5 million at 10. On Fox, the animated comedies The Simpsons and Family Guy averaged more than seven million viewers. Fox was fourth overall but second among the 18- to 49-year-old set.

title: New DVDs: Forbidden Hollywood
description: FORBIDDEN HOLLYWOOD COLLECTION, VOLUME 2

title: Els Withdraws
description: Ernie Els surprised the tournament host Arnold Palmer by withdrawing from the 30th annual Arnold Palmer Invitational at Bay Hill Club and Lodge in Orlando, Fla. The tournament  which features the return to play of the top two golfers in the world, Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson  had received an e-mail message over the weekend from Elss management group that Els, ranked No. 3, might withdraw.

title: As Mallets Fly, Bells Ring, Woodblocks Knock, Drums Beat
description: The stage of Weill Recital Hall became a crowded playpen of percussion instruments for Martin Grubingers evening of new and recent music on Friday. Had the stage been a little bigger, there would have been more of them. Mr. Grubinger, a young Austrian, had to change his program for an unanticipated lack of space.

title: A Boy Named Sue, and a Theory of Names
description: During his 1969 concert at San Quentin prison, Johnny Cash proposed a paradigm shift in the field of developmental psychology. He used A Boy Named Sue to present two hypotheses:

title: Shuttle Launches on 16-Day Mission
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  The shuttle Endeavour blazed a roaring trail into orbit as a spectacular night launch kicked off a 16-day mission to the International Space Station.

title: For Mets, Tradition Field Looks Like Red Sox Nation
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Johan Santana received a pleasant round of applause when he was introduced as the Mets starting pitcher before Mondays game. The fans, though, were just warming up their vocal cords. They were really waiting for the next player to be announced: Leading off the game for the Boston Red Sox, the center fielder, No. 46, Jacoby Ellsbury.

title: G.E. Chairman Rejects Talk of NBC Sale
description: Now hear this: NBC Universal is not for sale. No how, no way.

title: Pace of Change Too Slow to Keep Entrepreneurs in France
description: LONDON  Four years ago, Caroline Sivilia, a Parisian who worked for the ad agency Publicis Groupe, left France to start a magazine for French people living in London.

title: Using a Founding Father to Promote the Art of Letter-Writing
description: HBO and the Postal Service are joining forces for the first time to co-sponsor a multimillion-dollar multimedia campaign that is intended to evoke the pleasures of sitting right down and writing yourself  or anyone  a letter.

title: For Britain, Fewer Troops in Iraq, but Costs Continue to Rise for the Taxpayers
description: LONDON  A parliamentary committee warned Monday that Britains military operations in Afghanistan and Iraq were likely to cost almost twice as much for the past 12 months as they did in the previous financial year, despite a drop in British troop numbers in Iraq.

title: Britain Seeks to Silence a Former Secret Agent
description: The British government is trying to prevent a former MI5 member from publishing a book on the inner workings of the secret service, The Daily Telegraph in London reported. The 300-page manuscript is said to reveal some successes, failures and recruiting techniques of the covert organization. The author reportedly penetrated the Irish Republican Army and organized gangs and recruited agents to infiltrate jihadist groups plotting terror attacks in Britain. Legal proceedings, to be held in secret, are expected to begin at the High Court in London this week before a senior judge, who will rule on whether publication would breach national security. The controversy is reminiscent of the Spycatcher scandal of 1987, when the government unsuccessfully tried to prevent Peter Wright, another former MI5 officer, from publishing details of his work to uncover a traitor within the security service. Attempts to ban Spycatcher failed, and the book went on to sell more than two million copies.

title: State in Limbo as Questions Swirl About Spitzers Future
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer remained in office Tuesday evening, offering no public statements on whether he would resign following allegations that he was linked to a high-priced prostitution ring.

title: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Saturday about the playwright and actress Eisa Davis, who is appearing in the Broadway musical Passing Strange, misstated the given name of her mother, who is represented by a character in Ms. Daviss latest play, Angelas Mixtape. She is Fania Davis, not Sania.

title: Psychotherapy for All: An Experiment
description: SIOLIM, India  At the faded one-story medical clinic in this fishing and farming village, people with depression and anxiety typically got little or no attention. Busy doctors and nurses focused on physical ailments  children with diarrhea, laborers with injuries, old people with heart trouble. Patients, fearful of the stigma connected to mental illness, were reluctant to bring up emotional problems.

title: Safety: A Health Benefit to Playing by the Rules
description: When you put high school students in motion on a field or court with a ball, sooner or later someone is going to get hurt. But a new study suggests that many fewer injuries would occur if the rules of the games were better followed.

title: EADS Posts Big Annual Loss
description: PARIS  EADS, the parent of Airbus, posted a big loss for 2007 on Tuesday but insisted that it has put the worst behind it.

title: Dow Climbs 416.66 for Its Biggest Gain in Over 5 Years
description: Wall Street enjoyed its best trading day in more than five years on Tuesday  complete with a 400-point gain in the Dow Jones industrial average  after the Federal Reserve injected a burst of financial adrenaline into the ailing banking system.

title: Boeing Says It Will Protest Tanker Deal
description: CHICAGO  Boeing said Monday that it would protest the Air Forces award of a $35 billion contract to build aerial refueling planes to a group that includes its European rival Airbus.

title: Carlyle Fund Seeks Halt to Liquidation
description: LONDON  The Carlyle Groups troubled mortgage-debt investment fund, Carlyle Capital, said Monday that it had asked lenders to halt further liquidation of collateral worth as much as $16 billion while the two sides discuss ways to repay the debt.

title: Weeks Notables
description: TEAM In Argentina, Arsenal played the final 45 minutes with only nine men, but managed to snatch a 3-3 tie with last-place Gimnasia when goalkeeper Mario Cuenca scored on a penalty kick in the final minute. Arsenals Daro Espnola and Anbal Matelln had been ejected in the first half.

title: 8 U.S. Soldiers Killed in 2 Iraq Attacks
description: BAGHDAD  A man walked up to a group of American soldiers on foot patrol in an upscale shopping district in central Baghdad on Monday and detonated the explosives-filled vest he was wearing, killing five soldiers and wounding three others and an Iraqi interpreter who accompanied them.

title: Patersons Reflections on Projecting Strength, Despite the Obstacles
description: Most New Yorkers know little about Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson, who would ascend to the governors chair if Eliot Spitzer were to resign.

title: The Power of Drug Ads (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: In Developers Trial, E-Mail Note Cites an Obama Role
description: CHICAGO  An e-mail message made public on Monday in the fraud trial of Antoin Rezko, a businessman and political contributor, brought attention to Senator Barack Obamas role in discussions involving a state health planning board that Mr. Rezko is accused of improperly influencing.

title: Pearl Cornioley, Resistance Fighter Who Opposed the Nazis, Is Dead at 93
description: Pearl Cornioley, who parachuted into Nazi-occupied France to work as a courier between the British and the French resistance and rose to command 3,000 underground fighters, died on Feb. 24 in the Loire Valley of France. She was 93.

title: Obama Wins Mississippi Primary
description: Senator Barack Obama beat Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Tuesday in Mississippis Democratic primary, the final contest before what promises to be a crucial showdown in Pennsylvania in six weeks.

title: Footnotes
description: Daniel Walker Howe, a professor emeritus at University of California, Los Angeles, has won the third annual New-York Historical Society American History Book Prize for What Hath God Wrought: The Transformation of America, 1815-1848 (Oxford University). The award, which carries a $50,000 prize, will be presented on April 4, when Mr. Howe will also be named American historian laureate.... Francine Prose, having finished her one-year term, has re-upped for another as president of the American center of PEN, the international writers organization, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Prose runs unopposed in a vote to be held this week.

title: Top European Banker Finesses the Euro
description: FRANKFURT  The president of the European Central Bank on Monday criticized the increasing volatility of the currency markets, which have repeatedly sent the dollar to record lows against the euro.

title: Long Ocean Voyage Set for Vessel That Runs on Wave Power
description: On Sunday, a boat will sail from Honolulu on a planned voyage of 3,780 nautical miles, powered just by the wave action of the sea.

title: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Inducts Madonna
description: Leave it to Madonna to make the right gesture. For her induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, she didnt worry about whether her career as a pop hitmaker, image maker, sex symbol and provocateuse qualified her as a important figure in any narrowly defined genre of rock n roll. She just brought on an unquestioned rocker  Iggy Pop, the blunt, anarchic and durable songwriter and performer whos a fellow Michigan-born musician  to sing punk-chorded versions of her hits Burnin Up and Ray of Light. He was shirtless, hyperactive and backed by the Stooges, who along with him have been nominated but snubbed by the Hall of Fame.

title: Malone Speaks of Diller as Court Battle Starts
description: WILMINGTON, Del.  The cable media mogul John C. Malone told a judge on Monday that he held no ill will toward his longtime business partner, Barry Diller, who controls IAC/InterActiveCorp, even though the two are now battling over who controls what at IAC.

title: The Planet Club
description: Q. I am perplexed by the sentence chosen by National Geographic to help remember eight planets and three dwarf planets: My Very Exciting Magic Carpet Just Sailed Under Nine Palace Elephants, for Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Ceres, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune, Pluto and Eris. Who decided on this list? What happened to Xena, about which I used to hear a lot?

title: Arms Ruling Overturned by Dutch
description: PARIS  A Dutch appeals court on Monday overturned the conviction of a lumber trader who had been found guilty of breaking a United Nations embargo and smuggling weapons for Charles Taylor, the former president of Liberia, during that countrys civil war.

title: No. 1 Detective Agency Goes From Book to TV
description: HBO, the Weinstein Company and the BBC have announced a partnership to create a television series from Alexander McCall Smiths The No. 1 Ladies Detective Agency books. A two-hour pilot was filmed on location in Botswana, directed by Anthony Minghella, and 13 one-hour episodes will begin filming this summer. Jill Scott plays Precious Ramotswe, the proprietor of the only female-owned detective agency in Botswana; Anika Noni Rose plays her secretary, Grace Makutsi; and Lucian Msamati is Ramotswes devoted suitor, J. L. B. Matekoni.

title: Marijuana Is Defense Point in Queens Trial
description: Lawyers for three detectives on trial in Queens in the killing of Sean Bell in 2006 will try to link small bags of marijuana found near the shooting site to one of Mr. Bells friends who was wounded and who fled a short distance, perhaps tossing the drugs as he ran.

title: The Claim: Identical Twins Have Identical DNA
description: THE FACTS

title: Citing Pollution, Gebrselassie Opts Out of Olympic Marathon
description: Pollution in Beijing will deprive the Summer Olympics of an international star in one of the Games marquee events.

title: State Says Deaf Student May Take Service Dog to School
description: More than a year after the East Meadow School District in Nassau County barred a deaf high school student from taking his service dog to school, a state official ruled on Monday that the district had violated the states Human Rights Law.

title: Spitzer Allegations Send Wave of Shock
description: The idea that Gov. Eliot Spitzer  the square-jawed crusader who promised to bring ethics to Albany, the former prosecutor who chased corruption on Wall Street so ferociously that people nicknamed him Eliot Ness  was somehow involved in a prostitution scandal was too much. New Yorkers who thought they had heard everything were, for a change, dumbfounded.

title: An Enduring Measure of Fitness: The Simple Push-Up
description: As a symbol of health and wellness, nothing surpasses the simple push-up.

title: Sharing the Pain
description: Now that the economic crunch is reaching those near the top of the pyramid, there is finally a sense that the U.S. is facing a real crisis.

title: Testing Over, Hulu.com to Open Its TV and Film Offerings This Week
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Hulu.com, the long-gestating Internet joint venture between NBC Universal and Fox, emerges from limited testing on Wednesday to make its catalog of TV shows and video clips available to anyone on the Web.

title: New Rules Threaten Sports Tryout Process
description: Perhaps no college sport has better exemplified the undefined nature of athletic scholarship distribution than baseball, where some players traditionally received as little as $400 a year while stars were awarded full scholarships.

title: Discovery Challenges Finding of a Separate Human Species
description: More bones of unusually small-bodied people who lived long ago have been found on another Pacific island, and some scientists say this calls into question claims that the first such specimens, from Indonesia, represent a separate human species.

title: The Dispute in the Andes
description: To the Editor:

title: Spitzer Said to Be Weighing Resignation
description: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer continued to weigh whether to resign early Tuesday, a day after law enforcement officials said he was a client of a high-end prostitution ring broken up last week by federal authorities.

title: Should Spitzer Resign
description: On the streets of New York, people weigh in on Eliot Spitzer's political future in the wake of a scandal.

title: Do Do That Hulu That You Do So Well
description: A roster of blue-chip advertisers is joining two media giants to do the Hulu.

title: College Hockey: Curiouser and Curiouser
description: Its officially playoff time in college hockey and 12 of the 59 Division I teams are already out of the NCAA Tournament picture after losing their first-round series over the weekend. Up for grabs for the remaining 47 teams are six conference auto bids and 10 at-large spots in the tourney. For a look at the conference playoff brackets go here.

title: The Late-Night Comics Take on Spitzer
description: These days, a political scandal does not seem real until the late-night TV comics start cracking jokes about it. The first round in the Eliot Spitzer joke-fest was Monday night.

title: Instamatic Karma
description: May Pangs new book, Instamatic Karma, is a 140-page collection of casual photos that Ms. Pang took during her time with John Lennon.

title: Here Today, Gone 7.59 Billion Years From Now?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Rock's Newest Hall-of-Famers
description: Madonna and John Mellencamp entered the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in its 23rd annual induction ceremony.

title: Chatman Quietly Added to Jets Backfield Does This Mean No McFadden?
description: Our guest contributors of the week are Enrico Campitelli Jr. and Matt Pesotskiof the 700 level, the brotherly Philadelphia sports blog.

title: Minnesota: Al Franken Rival Steps Aside
description: MIDWEST

title: Stage Frights
description: The title of this shrewdly produced series of nine spooky short plays raises a question: Who is the scariest of The Scariest?

title: Plays by Numbers
description: When you take a guest to the theater, its nice if she says, as youre walking out, That was very entertaining. But sometimes what you really want her to say is, Im embarrassed by how amused I was by that.

title: In Kurdistan, Brisk Business in Blast Walls
description: GOPALA, Iraq  Just northeast of Kirkuk is a factory doing some of the best business in Iraq, but whose workers would be content to see it close down.

title: Nothing but the Hits
description: Unintentional and gallows humor at the Rock Hall of Fame induction ceremony Monday night:

title: Lazard Unveils Wassersteins Pay
description: Lazard said on Monday that its chairman and chief executive, Bruce Wasserstein, received a salary of $4.8 million in 2007.

title: Iomega Rejects EMC Offer
description: The computer storage provider Iomega said Monday it had received an unsolicited acquisition offer from a rival, EMC for $178.1 million but said the offer was not superior to a share purchase deal.

title: Citi to Inject $1 Billion Into Hedge Funds
description: Citigroup, the banking giant, moved Monday to shore up six of its hedge funds pressured by a tightening in the municipal bond market, the newest problem to entangle the struggling company.

title: Dow Jones Snaps Up Dutch News Service
description: Dow Jones & Company, a unit of global media conglomerate News Corporation, said Monday it acquired Betten Financial News, a Dutch-language news service covering the corporate sector in the Netherlands.

title: Murdoch Says He Wont Go Up Against Microsoft for Yahoo
description: One of Yahoos long-shot white knights in its struggle to avoid being taken over by Microsoft closed the chances down entirely.

title: Buffett Swaps White Mountain Stake for Cash and Other Units
description: Warren Buffetts Berkshire Hathaway has agreed to trade its 16.3 percent stake in the White Mountains Insurance Group for two subsidiaries and $751 million.

title: Bank of America Plans to Move Ahead With Countrywide Deal
description: Bank of America plans to press ahead with its $4 billion takeover of Countrywide Financial, the mortgage lender under F.B.I. investigation for possible securities fraud.

title: Air France Board Green-Lights Alitalia Bid
description: The Air France-KLM Group won approval Monday from its board to make a binding bid for the Italian state-controlled carrier Alitalia.

title: Malone Speaks of Diller as Court Battle Starts
description: The cable media mogul John C. Malone told a judge on Monday that he held no ill will toward his longtime business partner, Barry Diller, who controls IAC/InterActiveCorp, even though the two are now battling over who controls what at IAC.

title: G.E. Chairman Rejects Talk of NBC Sale
description: Now hear this: NBC Universal is not for sale. No how, no way.

title: Lehman Said to Hand Out More Than 1,400 Pink Slips
description: Lehman Brothers, the Wall Street investment bank, is laying off 5 percent of its work force, or about 1,430 people, because of difficult market conditions, according to Reuters.

title: Rendell on an Obama-Clinton Ticket
description: SCRANTON, Pa.  Gov. Edward G. Rendell of Pennsylvania, a big backer of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, told reporters tonight that he would be happy with the so-called Dream Ticket of Mrs. Clinton and Senator Barack Obama  even if it meant that Mrs. Clinton was No. 2.

title: iPhone Entrepreneurs Line Up for Funding
description: It was only last week that Appleannounced that Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, run by venture capitalist John Doerr, would pony up $100 million to invest in start-ups seeking to create applications for iPhone, but already hopeful entrepreneurs are knocking on Kleiners door.

title: Kyte Soars With New Funding
description: Less than three months after announcing its initial funding, a mobile social networking start-up Kyte said Monday it had raised $21.1 million in a second investment round led by Steamboat Ventures, which is affiliated with the Walt Disney Company, and Intellect Capital Ventures.

title: Fluid Snags $3.2 Million from V.C.s
description: Fluid Entertainment, a kid-oriented online video game company, is near a test run of its massively multiplayer online game.

title: Diamonds in a Rough Trade
description: Over at Slate, women blog about the Spitzer-hooker scandal (turns out its pretty much all about Hillary). But one has been thinking about rating systems for women ever since she read an ad in an in-flight magazine:

title: Eyeblaster Launches I.P.O. Campaign
description: Eyeblaster, a global provider of online campaign management solutions and services, said on Monday it is planning an initial public offering of as much as $115 million in common stock.

title: Bostwick Laboratories Eyes $100 Million I.P.O.
description: Bostwick Laboratories, which focuses on cancer diagnostics, plans an initial public offering of common stock, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing Friday.

title: Charming Shoppes Sues 2 Activist Funds
description: The owner of womens plus-size apparel retailer Lane Bryant is suing a pair of activist hedge funds, accusing them of misleading the chains investors as they mount a proxy campaign to shake up the companys board.

title: Morgans Mack Under Pressure Over Risk
description: John J. Mack stood before his board and shareholders at Morgan Stanleys 2007 annual meeting and struck an aggressive tone. Coming off a year of record profits fueled by using the firms capital to take some highly lucrative risks  particularly by diving deeply into subprime mortgages, leveraged loans and complex derivatives  Mr. Mack had much to celebrate.

title: Spitzers Woes Cast Shadow on Troubled Bond Insurers
description: Wall Street may have cheered when news hit that New York Gov. Eliot Spitzer, once dubbed the Sheriff of Wall Street for his crusade against their transgressions, was considering resignation after being linked to a prostitution ring.

title: When John McCain Was a Boy
description: Fresh late night reader comedy (use the comment link below):

title: Societe Generale Raises $8.5 Billion in Offering
description: Societe Generale, seeking to restore its status as a top-tier bank after a massive trading scandal, said Tuesday it had raised 5.5 billion euros ($8.44 billion) in new capital through a share offering.

title: Take-Two Hit by Shareholder Suit
description: A Securities and Exchange Commission filing, a shareholder lawsuit and a dollop of verbal jousting kept things percolating Monday in Electronic Arts pursuit of Take-Two Interactive Software.

title: The Debt Burden Squeezing Buyout Firms
description: With their big paydays and bigger egos, private equity moguls came to symbolize an era of hyper-wealth on Wall Street. Now their fortunes are plummeting.

title: From Buyouts to Books: Schwarzmans Big Donation
description: The New York Public Librarys venerable lion-guarded building on Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street is to be renamed for the Wall Street financier Stephen A. Schwarzman, who has agreed to jump-start a $1 billion expansion of the library system with a guaranteed $100 million of his own.

title: Hostility Has Its Rewards
description: They are copying us, Oracles Larry Ellison says of Microsoft and Electronic Arts. Others would be foolish not to try.

title: The Early Word: Mississippi, Youre Up
description: Updated Its primary day in Mississippi  and none of the candidates are spending the day there.

title: Things That Look Like a Duck
description: There are things that look like a duck and a Web site for things that look like a duck:

title: The Overnight Shift on Fifth Avenue
description: Updated, 10:13 a.m. | The Spitzer watch lasted all night.

title: Craziness
description: One measure of how crazy people on at least one side of the Democratic nomination struggle have become: Ive gotten a number of complaints that the end of my last  entirely non-political  column, hope is not a plan, was a swipe at Obama.

title: Notes on the Spitzer Scandal
description: The revelation that Gov. Eliot Spitzer was a client of a high-end prostitution ring broken up last week by federal authorities has attracted international attention, threatening to end his career and throwing the political world of New York State into chaos. The New York Times, which broke the story on its Web site on Monday afternoon, has three front-page articles explaining the situation.In a main overview, Danny Hakim and William K. Rashbaum review the details of the federal investigation, Mr. Spitzers terse apology and the shock in Albany. In addition, Mr. Rashbaum explains that the federal inquiry into the prostitution ring began with a routine tax investigation after Mr. Spitzers bank noticed a series of unusual transactions. Michael Powell and Mike McIntire explore the dizzying rise and fall of Mr. Spitzers career, an arc that includes a sterling educational pedigree and eight years as a crusading state attorney general.

title: Sandras Sources | Karla Fuentes
description: T Magazines Senior Editor Sandra Ballentine opens up her little black book of tips on where to go, what to buy and whom to know.

title: Sterilized intervention, big time
description: The Fed is making its sterilized intervention  monetary policy on the asset side of its balance sheet  even bigger. Now theres the Term Securities Lending Facility  would that be pronounced tiss-lif?  which, according to the Fed,

title: Geneva Auto Show: 5 Cars That Matter
description: After a so-so Detroit show, I was glad to be surrounded by excitement and fun ideas, Bill Diem, a Wheels contributor, wrote in an e-mail at the end of press days for the Geneva auto show, which continues through the 16th.

title: Never Mind the Governor, Can We Deal With It?
description: Could Spitzer survive? National Reviews Byron York spins a scenario for how Eliot Spitzer could remain governor of New York. He writes:

title:
If Food Be the Music:
Central Michel Richard
description: Brian Zipin, the general manager and sommelier at the glossy brasserie Central Michel Richard in Washington, D.C., said that he has created different play lists for different days, different times of the night, different moods.

title: The Art of the Push-Up
description: Fitness guru Jack LaLanne knows push-ups. During his 30-plus years on television, he regularly demonstrated the proper push-up technique and wowed us with feats of strength like finger-tip push-ups and one-armed push-ups.

title: Now Screening | Mariacarla Boscono in The Stranger
description: Today, T Online reveals an another intriguing fashion collaboration  the pairing of a supermodel, Mariacarla Boscono, and a supermusician, Sean Lennon. In The Stranger, a Sean Lennon and The Pyramids score provides the backdrop for the Italian catwalkers acting foray  a delicate portrait of three lives, intertwined in identity and intimacy. The director, Michele Civetta is no stranger to beautiful faces and tunes. The beau of Asia Argento, Civetta co-wrote (with Lennon) Friendly Fire, a 52-minute surreal fantasy piece set to Lennons album of the same name. The film featured Argento, Devon Aoki and Bijou Phillips. Now, dim the lights and click the player below.

title: Bell Testimony on Bullet That Hit AirTrain Platform
description: A Port Authority police officer testified in the trial of three detectives charged in the killing of Sean Bell on Tuesday morning, recalling the errant round that struck the AirTrain platform near 94th Avenue on Nov. 25, 2006, as officers opened fire with 50 shots at Mr. Bells car on the street below in Queens. The damage to the AirTrain station was recorded on video and played on news stations repeatedly after the shooting, and that particular bullet became emblematic of the perception that the shooting was wild and chaotic.John Cea, the police officer, was standing patrol with a partner on the platform when the calm of the early morning was shattered shortly after 4 a.m., he testified.

title: No. 1 Detective Agency Goes From Book to TV
description: HBO, the Weinstein Company and the BBC have announced a partnership to create a television series from Alexander McCall Smiths The No. 1 Ladies Detective Agency books, The New York Times reports.

title: Obama Campaign Criticizes Ferraro Comments
description: Updated | 8:10 p.m. Reached at her home Tuesday evening, Ms. Ferraro said that in her original remarks, she was asked why there was so much excitement about Mr. Obamas candidacy. And I said, I think part of it is because hes black, she said. People are excited about this historic candidacy. I am too.

title: G.E. Chairman Rejects Talk of NBC Sale
description: Bill Carter reports:

title: Air Force Plane Mistakenly Drops Device in Britain
description: A United States Air Force jet plane has mistakenly dropped an anti-missile device over the British countryside, setting off a hunt for a device that could be dangerous to civilians who may stumble across it.

title: We Are What We Drink Is What We Are
description: That headline isnt a typo.

title: Bailing Out at Take-Two
description: As Take-Two Interactive does battle with an unwanted bidder, two of its biggest shareholders have slashed their stakes. So the question on the Street is this: Does that make a higher offer from Electronic Arts less likely?

title: Recipe of the Day: Spaghetti With Fried Eggs
description: There are pasta dishes of the desperate cook, the one who has been too busy to shop or too busy to think, or who must put dinner on the table in 20 minutes. I love those kinds of recipes. This is one of them, taught to me a decade ago or so by Arthur Schwartz, who knows as much about Italian food as any native New Yorker has a right to.

title: To the Tune of Love Potion No. 9
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: David A. Paterson, Next in Line
description: Updated, 2:11 p.m. | Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson, 53, who is in line to succeed to the governors office if Gov. Eliot Spitzer were to resign, would be the first African-American governor of New York State and the fourth black governor in the nations history.

title: For the Moment | Bing Bangs Anna Sheffield
description: Liz O. Baylen

title: Just Browsing
description: Just Browsing sews together the latest fashion news from our global sources of mags, trades, blogs and tipsters. Kicked to the Curb with a High Wooden WedgeNews broke yesterday afternoon that Chlo had ousted designer Paulo Melim Andersson, formerly of Marni, after a mere three seasons. Seems the market couldnt bear another pricey line of interesting, clown-colored sack dresses, when Vera Wang had already gotten prime position on Marnis asymmetrical coattails. So Chlo hired successful previous designer Phoebe Philos lieutenant, Hannah MacGibbon. WWD reports today that she had been offered the job before, but refused and stuck around as a consultant. Expect the brand to return to its Marcia Brady-style roots by next season.

title: Trials of a Political Wife
description: Did Silda Wall Spitzer really need to be on stage with her husband yesterday as he explained (or didnt explain) his conduct?

title: Just Get a Receptionist
description: Aired Monday night on NBC: Past couple of days  youve all heard about this  Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama and John McCain have all claimed that they are the person who should answer the phone at the White House if it rings at 3 a.m., but most Americans think the White House should just get a receptionist.

title: A Guy Who Is Dating Your Mom
description: Aired Monday night on CBS: The big news scandal here in New York City just breaking a couple of hours ago is that New York Gov. Eliot Spitzer was caught in one of those sting deals. They caught Spitzer with a wire, recording him soliciting a prostitute. And Im thinking holy cow! We cant get bin Laden but by God, we got Spitzer. We got Spitzer!

title: Grease
description: From New York-based Improv Everywhere, which sprecializes in creating scenes in public before the unsuspecting. Here the troupe stages a musical number in a Los Angeles shopping mall food court:

description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: Now, the Games Can Begin
description: As Eater.com and others reported yesterday, the soccer tacos scene at the Red Hook Ball fields will be back this summer, and for at least five summers after that, thanks to a six-year permit the Parks Department awarded to the Food Vendors Committee of Red Hook Park, which represents the vendors.

title: George Fox, Spitzer Supporter and Alias, Responds
description: George Fox, a longtime friend and supporter of Gov. Eliot Spitzer, has issued a statement on the news that the governor was caught on a federal wiretap as a client of a high-priced prostitution ring broken up last week by the authorities. Mr. Foxs name was used to book Room 871 at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington, where Mr. Spitzer is said to have met with a prostitute. Mr. Fox issued the following statement through the public-relations firm Burson-Marsteller:

title: Yes, if Theres a God in Heaven
description: Aired Monday night on NBC: Hey, did you all remember daylight saving time? Spring forward, fall back? Kind of like Hillary in the primaries. You know, they said on the news today neither Barack nor Hillary can win the nomination outright, because theyre so close. So, Hillary is kind of caught between Barack and a hard place.

title: Wall Street Names, in Limestone and Lights
description: With his $100 million pledge to the New York Public Library, Stephen A. Schwarzman of Blackstone Group is set to become the latest Wall Street heavyweight to put his name on a high-profile building.

title: The Great Grippe Mystery
description: Its flu season.

title: A Scandal Tailor-Made for Late Night
description: The saying the jokes write themselves certainly applies to Mondays revelations about New York Governor Eliot Spitzers links to a prostitution ring.

title: The Toreros Enjoy the Madness
description: San Diego was overmatched and overtaxed against Gonzaga in the West Coast Conference tournament final, writes Tim Sullivan of the San Diego Union-Tribune, but that didnt stop the Toreros from clinching a berth in the N.C.A.A. tournament.
