title: Spitzer Critic Speaks Out
description: CNBC interviews Ken Langone, a former director of the New York Stock Exchange and Spitzer critic, on news that the governor has been linked to a prostition ring.

title: Pouring Sordid Stories Into the Minds of Children
description: In his new book The Ten-Cent Plague: The Great Comic-Book Scare and How It Changed America, David Hajdu spends a fair amount of time parsing the career of Fredric Wertham, a particularly wild-eyed, energetic anti-comics zealot.

title: A Big Mac of a Different Sort
description: You say, MacIntyre. I say, McIntyre.

title: Reform Group Urges Spitzer to Resign
description: Citizens Union, an influential reform organization that was founded in 1897 to advocate for transparency and openness in government, has called for Gov. Eliot Spitzer to resign. The decision by the organization, which endorsed Mr. Spitzer in his race for governor in 2006, signals that even close allies are abandoning the governor, amid the disclosures that Mr. Spitzer was a client of a high-priced prostitution ring broken up last week by federal authorities. The statement follows:

title: $40,000 for Man Tasered on YouTube
description: About two months went by after Jared Massey was tasered by a highway cop in Utah before he turned to YouTube. The video, footage filmed from within the police car, was an instant hit, rocketing up the charts and making him the latest internet celebrity. Its been played more than 1.7 million times.

title: Meet the Work Bully
description: The playground bully has grown up and gotten a job.

title: Google Gets Its DoubleClick
description: Google said it completed its $3.1 billion takeover of DoubleClick, a merger that rivals such as Microsoft and Yahoo had fiercely opposed. It took Google nearly a year to close the hotly debated deal: The final obstacle fell away Tuesday when European regulators approved the transaction.

title: EADS Responds to Boeing
description: In a CNBC interview, Louis Gallois, chief executive of EADS, defends a $35 billion tanker contract with the United States Air Force.

title: Outside, Waiting for the Governor
description: By 1 p.m., there was still no sign of Gov. Eliot Spitzer outside his Manhattan apartment building, at 985 Fifth Avenue on the Upper East Side. Still, about 75 reporters, camera operators and photographers were gathered outside the yellow brick high-rise, clustered in the biting cold at the edges of the semicircular driveway. Tourists atop passing double-decker buses elbowed one another and snapped pictures of the media throng, while three helicopters whirred overhead.

title: The Best Night Life for a Layover in South Beach
description: My friend and I are traveling to the Bahamas for a week long getaway this month. We are flying through Miami and will spend Friday night in South Beach. Were both 20-somethings and would like to have fun on our long layover. Where should two girls go for a fun time?

title: Enter Skeptics, Stage Left
description: Most say that Eliot Spitzer has nobody but himself to blame for his troubles. Some on the left, however, disagree  where theres scandal, apparently, there is always the vast right-wing conspiracy:

title: Cost of Red Bulls Training Trip Adds Up
description: Remember that rough-and-tumble scrimmage in Austria between the New York Red Bulls and the Red Bull Salzburg reserve team that Jack Bell wrote about? You know, the friendly practice game between two sister teams that was marred by chippy fouls and ill-tempered play. It was the game that saw second-year midfielder Dane Richards helped off the field wearing a knee brace after a hard tackle and left to sit alone in the stands for the rest of his teams Austrian training trip.

title: Fitzgerald Would Rather Be in Arizona
description: Our guest contributors of the week are Enrico Campitelli Jr. and Matt Pesotskiof the 700 level, the brotherly Philadelphia sports blog.

title: Non-standard Ben
description: Ive mentioned this before, but anyone trying to understand what the Feds up to should look at the 2004 paper Ben Bernanke co-authored on Monetary Policy Alternatives at the Zero Bound. One alternative was quantitative easing  basically forcing extra reserves on banks, whether they want them or not, which is what the Fed did in the first wave of panic. Another is changing the composition of the central banks balance sheet, that is, buying assets other than the usual T-bills.

title: CNBC Video: Langone Lashes Out at Spitzer
description: Few have bayed for Eliot L. Spitzers blood more loudly than Kenneth Langone. The former New York Stock Exchange director, who battled the former New York attorney general over Richard Grassos pay, gloated over Mr. Spitzers fall to CNBC Monday night.

title: Economics: the final frontier
description: Thirty years ago I was an oppressed assistant professor, caught up in the academic rat race. To cheer myself up I wrote  well, see for yourself. Joshua Gans of the University of Melbourne scanned a copy of the thing I wrote  back then academics did their work with typewriters, abacuses, and stone axes  and was good enough to send me a copy. Ladies and gentlemen, I give you The Theory of Interstellar Trade.

title: Nice Work If You Can Get It: John Ashcrofts Big Payday
description: John Ashcroft, the former Attorney General, insisted today that there was nothing wrong with a former employee giving him a no-bid monitoring contract that could be worth as much as $52 million.

title: The Spitzer Hit List
description: To say that Wall Street cheered reports linking Eliot L. Spitzer to a high-priced prostitution ring would be an understatement.

title: Legalize It?
description: Is the illegality of prostitution silly, as Andrew Sullivan wrote yesterday? In the wake of the scandal surrounding Gov. Eliot Spitzer, Lisa Schiffren, a former speechwriter for Vice President Dan Quayle, feels the need to rise in defense of the legal prohibition.

title: Spitzer Hires Former Firm as Legal Counsel
description: In hiring a legal defense team, Eliot L. Spitzer is turning to a name hes familiar with: Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison.

title: One Mans Feeling: The Mango Salsa Is Spicy
description: In the early 1980s, Paul Newman and A. E. Hotchner started selling bottled salad dressing, which has since expanded to a whole line of Newmans Own food products, including popcorn, pasta sauces, lemonades and salsa. The creations have generated about $200 million in donations to charities. But perhaps they should have considered going into pharmaceuticals with a more high-margin approach?On Monday night at City Center, at a tribute to the Hole in the Wall Gang camps, summer respites for children with cancer and other life-threatening illnesses, Nathan Lane read some letters from customers of Newmans Own, including the following:

title: U.S. Begins Beijing March in Earnest
description: The United States mens Olympic soccer team, led by the veteran teen-age phenom Freddy Adu, will try tonight to erase the embarrassment of 2004 when the Americans failed to qualify for the summer games in Athens.

title: Adapting to Earth After 120 Days in Space
description: Daniel M. Tani recently got back home from a business trip that would daunt the most seasoned road warrior: he spent 120 days aboard the International Space Station.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Tuesday, Mar. 11:

title: The Keystone Battleground
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.  In the bitter duel between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama over who has the national security credentials to be commander-in-chief, the Obama campaign unleashed one of its most powerful voices today.

title: Good Airport Advice Not to Follow
description: I was flipping through the March issue of Wired magazine, and ran across an article called, How To Fly Through Airport Security.

title: The Whores of Woody
description: Does life imitate Woody Allen? The Emperors Club at the center of the Spitzer prostitute scandal set its fees according to the individual education, sophistication and and ambiance created by each of our models. So say screen grabs of its Web site on thesmokinggun.com (italics added). Also: Beauty: elegance, erudition and educational standing/accomplishments are preliminary decisive factors in hiring. Sort of reminds you of Allens parody detective story The Whore of Mensa, doesnt it?

title: On the Web, Calls for Medvedev to Root Out Corruption
description: Dmitri A. Medvedev, the president-elect of Russia, needs to focus in the early part of his tenure on rooting out corruption and establishing an independent judiciary that is free of political influence, according to Russian bloggers who were asked to give their vision for the initial priorities of the Medvedev administration.

title: Rome, Part Two: True Roman Food
description: Ill get to the point here in a minute, but indulge me while I reminisce.

title: Rome, Part Two: True Roman Food
description: (Photo: Pizza from a bakery in Campo di Fiori.) I'll get to the point here in a minute, but indulge me while I reminisce.   I was first in Rome in 1976. Due to luck or arrogance, I wound up staying with a couple of kind Romans who took good care of my wife and me. I do believe I had not yet eaten spaghetti a la carbonara (I do believe I had not yet heard of Marcella), but my better-traveled American friends insisted I order it immediately.   That I did not do. We went out to a little trattoria the first night, ordered something we were comfortable with, then spied a gent eating a huge bowl of mussels. We tried to change our order, but our confusion with the phrasebook led us to order mosquitoes, which they didn't have.   The next night we went to another place and ordered spaghetti carbonara and something unmemorable and got yelled at for ordering two primi and no secondo -- in those days they did that. But in those days we couldn't afford six dollars a person; we tried to stick to three. (If I remember correctly our daily budget for this trip, food-wise, was 15 dollars, for both of us. And we pretty much stuck to it.)   The carbonara was a mindblower. I grew up in New York, a mile from Little Italy. We ate lasagna, spaghetti with meatballs, clams or mussels with tomato sauce, veal "parmigiano" with tomato sauce and so on. I am not sure I ever had an Italian dish whose roots were not in Naples or at least the South. It was my first inkling that Italian food was more complicated than what we saw in Manhattan and Brooklyn.   (Photo: Pizza with potatoes) But when we got back to where we were staying, Gigi -- the male half of the couple hosting us -- told me I'd made a mistake, that the true Roman dish was pasta all' amatriciana, essentially carbonara with tomato sauce replacing the eggs. Twenty years later, I came to understand the relationship between the two, and their progenitor, pasta alla Gricia (read it here). The next night Gigi took us out for amatriciana, and the mind boggled again.   At breakfast, he arrived with two white bags. In the first was pizza bianca. Can you imagine? White pizza, no cheese, a little oil and salt and rosemary? As an indication of how things have changed, I think it would now take someone bringing me a dish made with tempeh that I liked as much as a good grilled steak to come near the shock and joy I felt at seeing and tasting that pizza bianca.  And the other bag: pizza with potatoes, immediately and still my favorite all-carb dish. Had some just the other day, at the incomparable bakery in Campo de' Fiori, along with a couple of other beauties, pictured here. Whenever I become disenchanted with Rome -- whenever I see American-style pizza there -- I head to this place, as early in the morning as I can get there. It restores the faith. It practically makes me young.

title: Neckties of the Fallen Pols
description: Is there a fashion of contrition? Don Deibart thinks just maybe .

title: Woody and Elliot
description: How much does the Eliot Spitzer scandal remind you of Woody Allens short story The Whore of Mensa?

title: A Light Bulb Went Off: Print the Lights
description: Print publications are migrating to the Internet, but it seems lighting is migrating to the printing press.

title: Britney Spears Will Guest Star on CBS Mother
description: The Associated Press reports:

title: Morgan Stanley Trading Executive Has Left, Reports Say
description: Neal Shear, who formerly ran Morgan Stanleys sales and trading business before being demoted last November, has left the securities firm, according to The Wall Street Journal and Bloomberg News.

title: Fox Goes Kind of Cable-y
description: Monday nights premiere episode of Canterburys Law, a new legal drama on Fox, felt dark, mature and realistic  fare found more often on cable than broadcast. But viewers in the choice demographic seemed to show little interest in it, and the program finished in fourth place among 18- to 49-year-olds.

title: The Elite Rental Where the Spitzers Live (Pets Allowed)
description: While Gov. Eliot Spitzer may live in a rental building owned by his father, he is not roughing it in Manhattans second-tier rental world. The 25-story Fifth Avenue apartment tower where he is now encamped  with a scrum of press outside  is by the account of Manhattan real estate brokers one the citys most elite rental buildings.

title: Keeping Art Safe From Earthquakes
description: To protect art from earthquakes, the Getty Museum conducts a test using a base isolator, a specially designed mount that protects the pieces from the shaking of an earthquake.

title: Women and Pontiacs
description: What is it these days with women and Pontiacs? Theres the film Bonneville, named for the big ol 1966 Pontiac Bonneville convertible that takes Kathy Bates, Joan Allen and Jessica Lange on a Thelma and Louise-style road trip (Thelma and Louise drove a 1966 Thunderbird). And then there is Vera Wangs ad for her Simply Vera line for Kohls  young women riding through the desert in a similar 1960s Pontiac convertible, with Americas Horse of No Name as soundtrack. Was it inspired by the film? And where does Lyle Lovetts Pontiac song figure in all this?

title: Sir Alex of Aberdeen
description: There is oil in the North Sea off the northeast coast of Scotland and the city of Aberdeen has often been called the Oil Capital of Europe. And while one day the oil may run out, the city and its soccer fans will always have the stunning success of the 1980s to forever remember.

title: New Batch of Political Videos Hit Web
description: The president  dancing? Little kids wearing pantsuits? We cant resist.

title: Logging On and Tuning In at 40,000 Feet
description: The Webs last unconquered frontier  the airplane  is about to be invaded yet again.

title: Gore Raises $5 Billion for Investment Fund
description: The sustainable investment firm run by Al Gore is about to be closed to new investors, having raised close to its $5 billion target.

title: $1 Million Homes
description: Properties on the market in Colorado, California and North Carolina.

title: Gov. Spitzer: New Yorkers React
description: Local opinion on Gov. Spitzer's fate.

title: Bullish on America
description: Merrill Lynch: Recession to Be Worst Since 1970s.

title: Measuring the Size of Your Digital Shadow
description: The digital universe  the pile of digital information that includes everything from e-mail to YouTube videos  is growing faster than previously thought, according to a new study from the research firm IDC.

title: Americas Election HQ Replaces Big Story on Fox News
description: Fox News Channel is replacing its 5 p.m. news broadcast The Big Story with an election-themed program for the foreseeable future, marking the first time in eight years that the cable news channel has tinkered with its popular early evening line-up.

title: Six Civil Servants Will Be Honored
description: Municipal workers dont always get much credit. But the Sloan Public Service Awards, an annual program managed by the Fund for the City of New York and financed by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, believes that they should. It aims to honor city employees whose daily commitment to excellence is exceptional and whose accomplishments are remarkable. The six winners this year were selected by a panel led by Caroline B. Kennedy, the daughter of President John F. Kennedy, and Joseph M. Sullivan, a retired auxiliary bishop for the Diocese of Brooklyn.

title: Lazard Hires Executive for Corporate Finance Advisory Group
description: Lazard said Tuesday that it has hired Brendan Dyson as a managing director in its corporate finance advisory group, based in San Francisco. Mr. Dyson was previously a managing director at Piper Jaffray and led that firms convertible securities group.

title: Hannah Montana vs. the Ticket Bots
description: Updated, 11 a.m. Wednesday | In the end, it wasnt the hard-to-get World Series, Super Bowl or Bruce Springsteen tickets that unleashed government wrath against ticket brokers (read scalpers?), but rather those for an imaginary Disney Channel persona.Parental outrage nationwide at how concert tickets for Hannah Montana, a popular Disney character played by Miley Cyrus, sold out near instantly late last year has spawned government investigations, legal action and proposed legislation.The attorneys general in Missouri, Arkansas and Pennsylvania have all taken steps against ticket resellers, with Missouri formally suing three of them. Now a Queens City Councilman has proposed legislation [pdf] to combat ticket scalping (and yes, its actually nicknamed the Hannah Montana Bill).

title: Slipping Free
description: ABC News has done some digging into a question that has puzzled the Opinionators since the Spitzer scandal broke: How could the governor have managed a clandestine rendezvous without his security detail being privy?

title: Storm of Blog Criticism Follows Fallon Resignation
description: The retirement of Adm. William J. Fallon, the top American commander in the Middle East, shocked some of the blogosphere away from its fixation on the sex scandal involving Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York. As The New York Times story says, Adm. Fallons views on Iran and other issues have seemed to put him at odds with the Bush administration, a point that turned out to be a third rail out in the blogosphere.

title: Gov. Spitzer: New Yorkers React
description: Local opinion on Gov. Spitzer's fate.

title: Will It Work This Time?
description: The stock market leaped today as the Fed moved again to ease the credit crunch.

title: Trenton Outfield Will Be Worth Watching
description: The Yankees sent five players to their minor league camp on Tuesday, including three outfielders who made a strong impression while they were here: Colin Curtis, Austin Jackson and Jose Tabata.

title: Views of a Scandal on an Inconclusive Day
description: Video

title: Romney Would Be Honored to be V.P.
description: Mitt Romney has emerged from hibernation to do his first televised interview since he suspended his presidential campaign last month, saying he would be honored to serve as Senator John McCains vice-presidential nominee.

title: Albany in Limbo
description: New York State politicians expect Gov. Eliot Spitzer to resign.  But no one has made any moves yet.

title: A Night at the Museum
description: What's it like to spend a night at the real Museum of Natural History? A group of kids found out.

title: Even Outside of Silicon Valley, Venture Capital Is Growing
description: Venture capital is on the move  to New Mexico, Pittsburgh and points beyond.

title: Meet Me at the Irish Forum?
description: In a statement released today, Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign announced that yes, she would be attending the Irish American Presidential Forum this year.

title: Olympic Qualifying
description: Terrific.

title: Bloggingheads: Inside Spitzer's Mind
description: Christopher Hayes of The Nation, left, and Reihan Salam of the blog The American Scene ponder why Eliot Spitzer would commit the transgression he allegedly committed.

title: Still Counting in Texas
description: That second step of the Texas two-step? Its lasting almost as long as a season of Dancing With the Stars.

title: Yahoo May Join Google-Led Social Networking Alliance
description: Yahoo intends to join OpenSocial, a Google-led alliance that is developing a common set of standards so developers can create programs that run on many social networks and other Web sites, according to a person with direct knowledge of Yahoos plans.

title: New York, a Hockey Town At Last?
description: Remember when the Rangers played the Sabres in the playoffs last spring and, even though the New York TV market is about a dozen times larger, more people watched the series in Buffalo? (Look in the second item of the column I just linked to.) Its amazing but true: in every game of that series, roughly 50 percent more people watched the NBC, MSG and Versus telecasts in Buffalo than in New York.

title: Stop the Mutants!
description: This week, Im going to do an impossible experiment.

title: Handicapping the Big East Tournament
description: With the Big East tournament tipping off at noon on Wednesday at Madison Square Garden, here is a look at the 12 participants and odds for each team winning the championship.

title: Cracks appear in luxury markets
description: Over and over for the last six months developers and property agents have repeated the same refrain: The luxury market is not affected. Buyers of multi-million-dollar properties arent bothered by the credit crunch; they dont need credit. They see deals, not troubled markets. The rich are only getting richer.

title: Re-Enter the Gilded Age
description: THE rich are different from the rest of us, and just how different is on display at museums that house the treasures of avid millionaire collectors like Henry Clay Frick, the Wallaces, the Huntingtons and the Wrights-mans.

title: When a Corporate Donation Raises Protests
description: WHEN the Columbus Childrens Hospital agreed to name a new lobby after two retail chains to thank their corporate parent for a $5 million donation, everyone was all smiles. The same was true when the Ohio hospital renamed itself Nationwide Childrens Hospital, to acknowledge a $50 million gift from Nationwide insurance, a large local company.

title: Vick Case Exposes Rift Among Animal-Rights Advocates
description: The lingering image of Michael Vicks dogfighting case last summer was the daily courthouse appearance by members of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals.

title: Clinton and Obama Split Over Florida and Michigan
description: WASHINGTON  After a week of shadow-boxing, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama issued their clearest statements yet on how they would prefer to resolve the impasse over the disputed Florida and Michigan primaries.

title: The Myth of the Victimless Crime
description: WHAT do we know about the woman Gov. Eliot Spitzer allegedly hired as a prostitute? She was the one person he ignored in his apology. What is she going through now? Is she in danger from organized crime because of what she knows? Is anyone offering her legal counsel or alternatives to prostitution?

title: Rocket Endangers Palestinian-Israeli Respite
description: JERUSALEM  Gazan militants fired a rocket at the Israeli coastal city of Ashkelon on Tuesday, fracturing a tenuous lull in fighting between Israelis and Palestinians, which escalated sharply in late February and early this month.

title: Stand by Yourself
description: MY heart aches for Silda Wall Spitzer. Not only do she and her children have to weather the storm brought on by her misguided husband, she also has to endure the judgments of the commentariat, many of whom have asked, with some frequency, why on earth she would stand by her man during his public  and anemic  mea culpa.

title: Kennedy Center Plans Season
description: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington announced on Tuesday the 2008-9 season of theater, dance, music, and childrens productions. The season will include Arabesque: Arts of the Arab World, a three-week festival that will bring Arab art and culture to Washington with dance, theater and music presentations from 22 Arab nations. It will run from Feb. 25 through March 15, 2009. We really focused a lot on bringing unknown international art to Washington, Michael M. Kaiser, president of the center, said of the show, which has taken years to plan. We thought it was about time we looked at Arab cultures, he added. The centers newly renovated Eisenhower Theater will reopen in October with Broadway: Three Generations, followed in November by Frost/Nixon, with Stacey Keach playing Richard M. Nixon; in April a new production of Ragtime starts. The contemporary-dance series will include performances from the Martha Graham, Merce Cunningham, Jos Limon, Mark Morris, Alvin Ailey, Paul Taylor and Shen Wei companies. The ballet season will begin in October with performances by the Suzanne Farrell Ballet and include the American Ballet Theater, the Bolshoi Ballet, the Joffrey Ballet, the San Francisco Ballet and the Kirov Ballet.

title: Why Do the Wives Stand There, Next to Their Men?
description: Perhaps as vivid as the lurid details of what the authorities have called Gov. Eliot Spitzers involvement in a high-end prostitution ring was the lingering image of the woman who was most personally affected by the revelation.

title: Your Favorite Museum, Coming Soon to a Theater Near You
description: CASTING Ben Stiller and Robin Williams with Attila the Hun and a feisty Tyrannosaurus rex made box-office magic in Night at the Museum, one of the top-grossing films of 2006. The movies location, the American Museum of Natural History in New York, earned a box-office bump as well.

title: Europe Backs Google Bid to Acquire DoubleClick
description: BRUSSELS  European regulators on Tuesday approved Googles acquisition of DoubleClick, a significant player in the $37 billion online advertising business, brushing aside complaints that the combination would allow Google to extend its Internet dominance.

title: Aetna to Offer an Online Service That Helps Patients Link Records and Research
description: In step toward personalized online medical information, Aetna plans to announce Wednesday a new service that draws upon a patients own medical history to help answer questions about symptoms and treatments.

title: Taiwans Independence Movement Likely to Wane
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  No matter who wins Taiwans fiercely contested presidential election on March 22, the fervent independence movement that has so agitated relations with mainland China in recent years seems destined to suffer a significant setback.

title: Rival Unions Battle in Ohio Over Workers at Hospitals
description: The Service Employees International Union was brimming with confidence about unionizing 8,300 workers at nine Ohio hospitals through elections that were scheduled for this Wednesday and Friday. But then organizers from a rival union, the California Nurses Association, swept into town, buttonholing workers and maneuvering their way into hospital wards, to press the workers to vote not to join the S.E.I.U.

title: Killer Statue  Psyched About the Site!
description: THE Indianapolis Museum of Art has its own video channel on YouTube. The Oakland Museum of California reaches out to online tastemakers to help push events. The Brooklyn Museum of Art has built its own application on the social networking site Facebook, allowing people to share images of museum artwork.

title: Arkansas Woman, Left in Cell, Goes 4 Days With No Food or Water
description: A woman was locked for four days in a tiny holding cell in a northern Arkansas courthouse, forgotten by the authorities and left without food or water, the local Sheriffs Department said Tuesday.

title: Boot Camp for Curators Who Want the Top Job
description: ELIZABETH W. EASTON was asked at a Guggenheim Museum symposium in 2005 why there were so few ways for curators to advance. Specifically, why werent more curators becoming directors?

title: Opponents of Earmarks Gain Ground in Congress
description: WASHINGTON  A proposal to ban spending earmarked for home-state projects for one year gained momentum in Congress on Tuesday as Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama joined Senator John McCain and other fiscal conservatives in support of the idea.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Thursday about plans by Hollywoods big studios to release several comedies in the coming months referred imprecisely to the role of Shawn Levy in the production of one, What Happens in Vegas, coming out in May from 20th Century Fox. He is a producer, not the executive producer. (The executive producers are Arnon Milchan, Joe Caracciolo Jr. and Dean Georgaris.)

title: Broker Held in French Trading Case
description: PARIS  The French authorities have arrested a broker at Socit Gnrale in connection with the trading scandal that the French lender says cost it more than $7 billion, the French prosecutors office said Wednesday.

title: Britain: Manchester Police Chief Found Dead
description: The top official of one of Britains largest police forces was found dead in the North Wales countryside a day after he left for a walk in the mountains, the authorities said. The official, Michael Todd, the chief constable of the Greater Manchester Police, was found by rescuers on the side of Bwlch Glas, a section of Mount Snowdon. The BBC reported that hikers in the area had called the emergency services after finding items belonging to Chief Constable Todd and that notes addressed to his loved ones were found near his body.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The State of the Art column in Business Day on Thursday, about the Sony A300 digital camera, attributed an erroneous distinction to one of its features. The cameras ability to display an uninterrupted preview of an image on the back-panel screen because of a second image sensor is a refined version of a system that appeared in the Olympus E-330 in 2006; it is not a technical breakthrough.

title: Corrections
description: Editors' Note

title: Obama Wins in Mississippi
description: Senator Barack Obama won Mississippis Democratic presidential primary on Tuesday, building his delegate lead over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the final contest before the nominating fight heads to Pennsylvania for a six-week showdown.

title: Your Waiter Tonight... Will Be the Chef
description: AT what point in the chef-diner relationship is it O.K. to offer a backrub?

title: At Bar Boulud, the Message Is in the Terrine
description: MUCH of what you need to know about the direction of fine dining these days is distilled in Bar Boulud, where one of the most accomplished French traditionalists on this side of the Atlantic stages a production whose weakest facet is the conventional three-course dinner.

title: Stocks Close Lower After Gains Overseas
description: Stock markets closed lower on Wall Street on Wednesday after overnight gains in Asia and Europe, a day after the Federal Reserve led global central banks in flooding the financial system with liquidity.

title: A Louisville Guard Hopes Home Can Help
description: The living room of his familys apartment in the Bronx has a parquet floor and two corners crammed with about 75 basketball trophies, some taller than Edgar Sosa himself. A computer sits in another corner. The screen saver is a photograph of Sosa playing basketball for Louisville last season as a freshman.

title: Ashcroft Defends Contract That U.S. Steered to Him
description: WASHINGTON  Former Attorney General John Ashcroft responded angrily Tuesday to Congressional Democrats who suggested that a no-bid private contract directed to him by the Justice Department last year amounted to a back-room sweetheart deal worth tens of millions of dollars to his consulting firm.

title: At Least 24 Killed as Two Bombs Strike Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Two powerful explosions in suicide attacks minutes apart rocked the eastern city of Lahore on Tuesday, killing 24 people, the Interior Ministry said.

title: Foes of Sex Trade Are Stung by the Fall of an Ally
description: As New Yorks attorney general, Eliot Spitzer had broken up prostitution rings before, but this 2004 case took on a special urgency for him. Prosecuting an international sex tourism business based in Queens, he listened to the entreaties of womens advocates long frustrated by state laws that fell short of dealing with a sex trade expanding rapidly across borders.

title: Paterson to Ascend to Power in Midst of Storm
description: With the resignation of Gov. Eliot Spitzer, David A. Paterson, the calm and affable legislative leader turned lieutenant governor, is set to ascend New Yorks highest office in the midst of a political storm.

title: Correction
description: A photograph with the Wines of The Times column last Wednesday, about the white wines of Rueda, Spain, was published in error. It showed the monastery of Rueda, which is in Zaragoza in the Aragon region of Spain. (Rueda is in the Castile region.)

title: Hes Hauling in the Visitors by Livening Up the Events
description: HE doesnt wear Gucci loafers. He doesnt smoke cigars. His last name is neither Bialystock nor Bloom. Yet when titles were being assigned at the newly established Rubin Museum of Art three and a half years ago, Tim McHenry was designated producer. An anomaly in the museum world, the title suits Mr. McHenry, who is in charge of public programming at the museum.

title: Mideast Commander Retires After Irking Bosses
description: WASHINGTON  Adm. William J. Fallon, the commander of American forces in the Middle East whose outspoken public statements on Iran and other issues had seemed to put him at odds with the Bush administration, is retiring early, the Pentagon announced Tuesday.

title: Parent of Airbus Posts First Annual Loss in 5 Years
description: PARIS  The European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, the parent of the plane maker Airbus, posted its first annual loss in five years on Tuesday, but said its prospects had improved after the Air Force awarded it and an American partner a $35 billion contract to build a fleet of refueling planes.

title: J. Crews Profit Tops Expectations
description: The J. Crew Group, the clothing retailer, posted adjusted earnings on Tuesday that beat Wall Street estimates, even while quarterly net profit fell because of a tax benefit a year ago.

title: Ruth Might Have Built It, but Many Have Used It
description: It is incongruous and maybe historically impertinent that the final event at Yankee Stadium may be a National Hockey League game. Shouldnt its 85-year run end with the bang of a game-winning home run or the whimper of a ninth-inning flyout?

title: Liberty, Equality, Free Admission: The French Take a Cue From the British
description: PARIS

title: Divvying Scholarship Dollars Can Divide a Team
description: An athletes worth to a college is often negotiated behind the closed door of a coachs office with the scholarship amount kept a guarded secret, like a salary in a workplace. But the figures have a way of eventually getting out, as they do in any office.

title: 3. Cochon
description: 930 Tchoupitoulas Street, New Orleans, (504) 588-2123; www.cochonrestaurant.com

title: To Keep or to Donate: Foundations Wrestle With the Question
description: ELI BROADS announcement that he is leaving his vast collection of contemporary art in one of his foundations rather than donating it to a museum has left the museum world virtually speechless.

title: Young Conductor Leads Russian Orchestra
description: Alondra de la Parra, above, a 27-year-old Mexican student at the Manhattan School of Music, has cut short her spring break to head for Florida. Shes not going to seek a suntan but to step in to conduct the Russian National Orchestra in concerts this week that feature the flutist James Galway on Wednesday, and the violinist Joshua Bell on Friday. Ms. de la Parra, a candidate for a master of music degree in May from the Manhattan School of Music, was studying conducting in Salzburg, Austria, during the break when a call came inviting her to step in for an ailing Teodor Currentzis, the director of the Novosibirsk Opera and Ballet Theater, who was to lead the Russian National Orchestra in the performances as part of the Festival of the Arts Boca in Boca Raton, Fla. Ms. de la Parra, the founder and music director of the Philharmonic Orchestra of the Americas, which is based in New York, will lead works by Mozart, David Overton and Schubert on Wednesday and by Tchaikovsky and Debussy on Friday.

title: Getty Museum Buys a Seldom-Exhibited Gauguin
description: LOS ANGELES  The J. Paul Getty Museum announced Tuesday that it had acquired Arii Matamoe, an 1892 painting by Paul Gauguin that has been in a private collection in Switzerland for decades and has been exhibited publicly only once since 1946.

title: Waiting for Mr. Spitzer
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer has now twice violated his obligations to the people of New York. He violated their trust when, according to law enforcement officials, he patronized a prostitution ring. He compounded that violation Tuesday by hiding in his Fifth Avenue apartment and refusing to explain his actions or his future plans.

title: Editors Note
description: An article on Tuesday reported the reactions of political figures in Albany to the news that Gov. Eliot Spitzer had been a client of a prostitution ring. The last two paragraphs referred to remarks that Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson made at a breakfast meeting in October where he discussed his post, and it quoted him as saying he had been initially reluctant to attend a conference of lieutenant governors. The Times reporter and his editors were not clearly told by a contributing reporter that the quotation and the context had come from an article on the Web site of City Hall, one of the publications that organized the breakfast. The context should have been paraphrased and the information attributed to the site.

title: Most Stunning View in Town Is the One at the Pump
description: GORDA, Calif.  James Willman seems to be a nice enough guy: polite, good-humored and hard-working, pumping gas seven days a week at the Amerigo Gas Station. But at least once a day, Mr. Willman says, someone pulls in and starts cursing him.

title: Democrats in a Fight to Define Winner
description: With the fight for the Democratic presidential nomination likely to go on for weeks or months, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton are battling to define what it means to be winning  and, in some instances, they are overstating their own advantage and understating the gains of the other.

title: Serbias Choice
description: Kosovo made a historic choice for independence last month. Serbia will soon have a chance to make its own historic choice  either for a better future as part of the European Union or for isolation, stagnation and decline.

title: Indiana: Grandson Wins House Seat
description: Andre Carson, a Democrat, won a special election to fill the House seat formerly held by his grandmother Julia Carson, a Democrat who died of lung cancer last year. Mr. Carson took 53 percent of the vote, defeating Jon Elrod, a Republican, who had 44 percent, and Sean Shepherd, a Libertarian, who had 3 percent in the district, which includes most of Indianapolis.

title: Luring Sports Fans of All Seasons to Lower Manhattan
description: FROM a second-floor arched window at 26 Broadway, near the start of the Canyon of Heroes ticker-tape parade route in Lower Manhattan, Philip Schwalb can see beyond the Battery to the Statue of Liberty. He watches tourists heading to Liberty and Ellis Islands and thinks about those who will honor the fallen of 9/11 at the World Trade Center Memorial when it is done.

title: Chambers Is Called a Heroin Addict
description: Robert E. Chambers Jr., who strangled Jennifer Levin, 18, during what he called rough sex 22 years ago, was addicted to heroin when he was arrested in October on drug charges, his lawyer said on Tuesday.

title: Drug Defendant Attacks Prosecutor in Court
description: Facing a mandatory life sentence, a man convicted in a drug case attacked a prosecutor in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on Tuesday with a razor he sneaked into the courtroom, the authorities said.

title: Risks of Anemia Drugs for Patients With Cancer to Get More Scrutiny
description: With federal drug regulators planning another meeting on Thursday to weigh the safety of widely used anemia drugs, Dr. Athanasius Anagnostou resists any urge to say I told you so.

title: Capturing the Essence of Mr. Lincoln With Theatrics
description: EQUAL parts Vegas glitz and geeky gadgets have turned the Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum into one of the most visited tourist attractions in the Midwest. Drawing on theatrical lighting, digital video production and computing technology, the museum uses showmanship and tricks to bring the scholarship of Lincolns life and the Civil War era into context.

title: Imprisonment and Forced Servitude in Rural China
description: Every so often in his slow-to-boil, hard-to-shake drama Blind Mountain, the Chinese director Li Yang slips in a moment of beauty  a blooming valley wreathed in mist, a shepherd tending his flock  of the sort you find in glossy travel magazines. These pastoral visions initially feel like a reprieve, a respite from the storys increasing heaviness, but theres something about these bucolic images that begins to gnaw at you too. This native, touristic fantasy about the unspoiled China, you realize, comes with a brutal price tag.

title: Now a Different, but No Less Dogged, Governor
description: On Day 442, everything changes. Again.

title: Museums Refine the Art of Listening
description: IF it seems someone   is watching every time you go to a museum, youre not far off.

title: McCain Misfires at Grizzlies
description: Senator John McCain loves to present himself as a fighter against waste and pork-barrel spending. His fusillades against the bridge to nowhere in Alaska and other such projects were well justified. But his jabs at a study of grizzly bears in Montana are way off the mark.

title: Say What? It Wasnt a Just War After All?
description: In 1939 the editor of a Zionist newspaper in New York sent a letter to Mahatma Gandhi pointing out that in Nazi Germany a Jewish Gandhi would last about five minutes before he was executed. Gandhi stuck fast to his nonviolent principles. I can conceive the necessity of the immolation of hundreds, if not thousands, to appease the hunger of dictators, he replied.

title: Latin Food Vendors to Stay at Brooklyn Soccer Field
description: The crisis of Red Hook Park is, for the most part, over.

title: Creative Visions, but for Many Millions Less
description: Chicago

title: Techs Late Adopters Prefer the Tried and True
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Every time he fired up his Netscape Web browser since mid-February, John Uribe was greeted with a message urging him to switch to one of Netscapes two successors, Firefox or Flock.

title: Its Fair to Scrutinize a Candidates Religious Beliefs
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain: Pledging Allegiance to Her Majesty
description: A government-appointed panel recommended that students pledge allegiance to the queen and take part in citizenship ceremonies similar to those held for immigrants. The measures would help young people feel part of a greater Britain and increase pride in the nation, the panel said in a report. The report was commissioned as part of Prime Minister Gordon Browns effort to encourage a sense of national unity to counter disaffection from groups, like Muslims and Scottish people, who say they feel alienated from Britain.

title: Upton Sinclair, Now Playing on YouTube
description: AN undercover vegan wired with a camera no bigger than a sugar cube spent six weeks last fall working at a Southern California slaughterhouse. To fit in, he brought sandwiches made with soy riblets and ate them in a dusty parking lot with the other workers.

title: Spitzer Resigns, Citing Personal Failings
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer, whose rise to political power as a fierce enforcer of ethics in public life was undone by revelations of his own involvement with prostitutes, resigned on Wednesday, becoming the first New York governor to leave office amid scandal in nearly a century.

title: Looking Back on a Political Career: The Good, the Bad and the Contradictory
description: After more than 36 hours with no audible breaths, Eliot Spitzer emerged from his political coma just before noon on Wednesday to utter his final words, wife and criminal defense lawyer at his side.

title: That Dashboard Light Now Casts Its Glow on Nostalgia
description: The subtitle In Search of Paradise, for a documentary about Meat Loafs 2007 tour, refers to that rockers classic single, the hormone-saturated high school epic Paradise by the Dashboard Light. But it doubles as an artistic credo. The films director, Bruce David Klein, portrays his subject  who was 59 during shooting  as an obsessive, self-punishing performer, striving in vain to put on a live show that matches the visions in his head.

title: Citing Faith, Bush Defends War Actions
description: NASHVILLE  President Bush delivered a rousing defense of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan on Tuesday, mixing faith and foreign policy as he told a group of Christian broadcasters that his policies in the region were predicated on the beliefs that freedom was a God-given right and every human being bears the image of our maker.

title: Trial on Control of IAC Focuses on a Deals Intent
description: WILMINGTON, Del.  The testimony on the second day of a trial to settle a dispute over the control of IAC/InterActiveCorp reduced a clash of billionaire titans to a debate about detail.

title: Lieutenant Governor Has a History of Defying the Publics Expectations
description: On Tuesday, Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson waited. Around noon, he was driven from his home outside Albany to the Capitol, raising expectations that Gov. Eliot Spitzer would soon resign and that Mr. Paterson was about to become the states 55th governor  and the first African-American to hold the post.

title: Leonard Cohen Hits the Road
description: One day after his induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, the Canadian singer and songwriter Leonard Cohen, 73, below, announced plans on Tuesday for his first tour in 15 years, Reuters reported. The tour, beginning in Toronto on June 6, will include an appearance at the Glastonbury Festival in Britain on June 29. The final announced date is Aug. 29 in Vienna, but organizers said more performances were expected. ... The rock band Van Halen has postponed all shows through April 19 while the guitarist Eddie Van Halen, 53, undergoes tests for an unspecified medical condition, Reuters reported. The announcement came a week after the band postponed four concerts for the same reason. Fans were asked to keep their tickets, which will be honored at makeup dates. ... The rapper the Game, whose real name is Jayceon Taylor, has been released from a Los Angeles jail after serving 8 days of a 60-day sentence for possession of a firearm in a school zone, The Associated Press reported.

title: A Lunch That Provides Its Own Box
description: IVE never set foot in a tin mine and I dont often take my lunch out of the house, but that hasnt affected my recent obsession for pasties, the portable meat and vegetable pies historically carried by Cornish miners.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the effect of proposed budget cuts in New Jersey on the states smallest towns misstated, in some editions, the percentage by which state aid would drop in Helmetta, a working-class borough of 2,023 people. Aid will drop by about 55 percent, not by about 40 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary headline on Feb. 15 about Arthur D. Lewis, a transportation executive who was involved in the formation of Conrail, misstated his age. As the first paragraph of the obituary noted, he was 89, not 88.

title: Flying Avatars Admire the Artwork
description: AT the Art Positions fair in Miami in December, the Chinese experimental artist Cao Fei sold a work to a private collector for $100,000.

title: Its Not an Adventure, Its a Job
description: A few months into her first year at Villanova, Stephanie Campbell was despondent.

title: Brooding and Brute Force Are Here to Share the Stage
description: Theres nothing like an industry showcase for fostering strange musical bedfellows. Under normal circumstances, you probably wouldnt expect to see a Norwegian jazz-metal band on the same bill as a Brooklyn indie-pop outfit, a Baltimore art-rock duo and a calmly introspective singer-songwriter, also Norwegian. But that was the lineup at the Knitting Factory on Monday night, for a show presented by Oh My Rockness, the indie-rock listings Web site (ohmyrockness.com), and Oya, a summer festival in Oslo.

title: Contractor at Airports Settles Suit in Bias Case
description: DALLAS  Allied Aviation Services, which fuels planes at airports nationwide, agreed on Tuesday to pay $1.9 million to settle a discrimination lawsuit begun by 15 black and Hispanic employees at its Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport facility who said they had been forced to endure racial slurs and other harassment.

title: Louisville Puts Up Fight, but UConn Takes Title
description: HARTFORD  The Connecticut womens basketball team has the ability to play brilliantly for some stretches and disjointed for others. The Huskies, ranked No. 1 in the nation, showed both faces Tuesday night in the Big East tournament final. Fortunately for them, their superior talent prevailed and they finished off unheralded Louisville, 65-59.

title: Air Fares to Japan Are Investigated
description: European Union antitrust officials raided the offices of several international airlines as part of an investigation into suspected price fixing on scheduled flights between the Europe and Japan. Spokeswomen for Lufthansa of Germany and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, a unit of Air France-KLM, confirmed that their offices in Frankfurt and Amsterdam had been raided and said they were cooperating with the investigation. The European Commission, the European Unions executive arm, said it and national competition regulators had carried out unannounced inspections at the premises of a number of international airlines. It did not identify the carriers. The commission believes that the companies may have violated its rules on restrictive business practices, officials said, without elaborating.

title: Spitzer to Resign Soon; Paterson Set as Successor
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer, reeling from revelations that he had been a client of a prostitution ring, announced his resignation today, becoming the first governor of New York to be forced from office in nearly a century.

title: House Creates a Panel to Watch Over Lawmakers Behavior
description: WASHINGTON  In the wake of a string of Congressional misconduct and corruption cases, the House on Tuesday created an independent panel to investigate suspected wrongdoing by lawmakers, despite deep reservations from rank-and-file lawmakers from both parties.

title: Tentative Lovers, Embracing Darkness
description: Among major companies, the Metropolitan Opera has been particularly responsible about ensuring that worthy backup singers are on hand should a scheduled cast member have to withdraw. But when the role in need of rescuing is Wagners Tristan, a companys back is against the wall. There are, realistically, no more than a handful of tenors in the world who can sing this long and daunting part.

title: $250 Million Settlement Over Asbestos Is Announced
description: WASHINGTON  W. R. Grace & Company, a worldwide chemical company driven into bankruptcy by hundreds of millions of dollars in asbestos poisoning claims, has agreed to pay the federal government $250 million for environmental cleanup around its mining operations in Libby, Mont.

title: Who Will Stop a Tyrant if His Enemies Just Sit and Sulk?
description: These guys look awful: haggard, unsmiling, glassy-eyed. As convincingly embodied by an illustrious crew that includes Brian Dennehy, Aidan Quinn and David Strathairn, the noble Romans of Richard Nelsons Conversations in Tusculum, which opened Tuesday night at the Public Theater, have a ragged aspect that insomniacs will recognize immediately. It comes from sleeping too little and thinking too much.

title: High Finance Backfires on Alabama County
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  In 2002, a banker named Charles E. LeCroy arrived here with a novel pitch to ease taxpayers burden. Some Wall Street wizardry, he said, could lighten their load.

title: Fudge, Humbug and ONeill
description: In Ah, Wilderness! (1932) Eugene ONeill, a playwright more accustomed to looking back in anger, put a nostalgic spin on the world he grew up in. He called it a comedy of recollection and later said its quality depended on an exact evocation of the mood of the dead past.

title: South Africa: Party Leader Asks Court to Dismiss Evidence
description: Jacob G. Zuma, who heads the countrys governing party, the African National Congress, is seeking to convince the Constitutional Court that reams of evidence should be excluded from his trial in August on corruption charges connected with an arms deal. Mr. Zuma, who denies the charges, says the search warrants were vague, overly broad and did not protect his communications with his lawyer. If convicted, Mr. Zuma would be barred from serving as president of South Africa. In court papers, the state says the evidence establishes that Mr. Zuma, above, took hundreds of payments from his financial adviser, Schabir Shaik, and Mr. Shaiks companies. The state says Mr. Zuma did not pay income taxes on much of that money.

title: Dow Climbs 416.66 for Its Biggest Gain in Over 5 Years
description: Stocks had their biggest one-day gain in five years Tuesday after the Federal Reserve announced that it would step up its lending to ease strain on the dysfunctional money market.

title: China Retools Its Government in Efficiency Push
description: BEIJING  China announced Tuesday that it would reorganize the central government by creating five so-called superministries, including one responsible for improving environmental protection. But the plan stopped short of creating a single agency to oversee the contentious issue of energy policy.

title: Take-Two Vows to Beat Expectations and a Bidder
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Facing a takeover bid from rival Electronic Arts, Take-Two Interactive sought to assure Wall Street investors on Tuesday that it is capable of growing on its own.

title: A Director With an Eye for the Fresh and the Local
description: BONNIE CLEARWATER recognized Miamis potential to become an important arts center as far back as 1990, on a visit from Los Angeles. At the time, South Beach was a somewhat desolate spot on the cusp of revitalization, and a local collector and developer enticed Ms. Clearwater to work her magic discovering new talent in Miami as she had done on the West Coast.

title: Classes for Young Hunters?
description: To the Editor:

title: Younger Viewers Spurn New Legal Drama
description: Canterburys Law, the new Fox legal drama, felt dark, mature and realistic  fare found more often on cable than on broadcast television. Julianna Margulies, the shows star, said the network wanted to bring a little FX to Fox. But young viewers showed little interest in Canterburys Law, as the shows premiere finished in fourth place in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic at 8 p.m. on Monday, Nielsen reported. Fox suggested that the transition to daylight saving time might have had some impact on the ratings. Canterburys Law averaged 7.6 million viewers, enough to place second in total viewers behind ABCs Bachelor, but delivered a disappointing 1.7 rating in the 18-to-49 demographic favored by advertisers. At 9 p.m. New Amsterdam picked up some viewers for Fox, averaging 8.8 million viewers and a 2.5 rating in that demographic. The 11.7 million viewers for Two and a Half Men and the 10.1 million viewers for CSI: Miami put CBS into first place for the night. NBC was a close second, as ho-hum viewership for My Dad Is Better Than Your Dad (6.9 million) was offset by high ratings for Deal or No Deal (11.6 million) and Medium (9.2 million). ABC placed fourth for the night with two episodes of the low-rated October Road (4.6 million at 9, and 4.8 million at 10).

title: In Santa Fe, on the Trail of New Deal Artists
description: SANTA FE, N.M.

title: Belgium: $170 Million in Holocaust Compensation
description: The government and banks agreed to pay $170 million to compensate Jews whose property was looted by the Nazi occupying forces during World War II. Under the arrangement, $54 million will be paid to Holocaust survivors while the rest will go to a foundation to help needy families of victims and toward efforts to assure that the Holocaust is remembered. Belgium collaborated with Nazi Germany, and victims relatives said the state should look more closely at its role.

title: After Fine, Southwest Suspends 3 and Hires Specialist
description: Southwest Airlines, initially combative in the face of a $10.2 million fine from the Federal Aviation Administration for inspection lapses, took a more conciliatory tone on Tuesday. The company said that it had suspended three employees, hired an outside maintenance expert and was fully engaged with F.A.A. officials auditing the carrier.

title: Really Dangerous Liaisons
description: AS a former sex worker, Im puzzled by what is reported to be Gov. Eliot Spitzers preference for the riskiest form of indoor prostitution I have ever experienced. Escort agencies are constantly being investigated, infiltrated and spied on.

title: Knicks and Heat in a Battle to Rebuild
description: MIAMI  There was a time not long ago when the mere convergence of Knicks and Heat jerseys inspired instant malice on the court. Glares were a given, fisticuffs a strong probability. When the two old rivals meet Wednesday night, they may just convene the game with incense and a group hug.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Feb. 14 about a bombing that killed Imad Mugniyah, a Hezbollah commander blamed by the United States and Israel for numerous terrorist attacks, referred incompletely to accusations against him. While some American officials said he had not been involved in new attacks for more than a decade, reports in the Israeli press in July 2006 said he had been in charge of Hezbollah military operations in southern Lebanon since the mid-1990s and was believed responsible for the capture of two Israeli soldiers on July 12, 2006, an event that led to the Israel-Hezbollah war that summer.

title: Pickles, Deconstructed and Frozen
description: Texas, the land of oddities like mesquite jelly, also has a passion for pickle juice. You can even buy snow cones drizzled with the briny liquid (theyre refreshing).

title: Dennis Irwin, 56, Bassist Popular in New York Jazz, Is Dead
description: Dennis Irwin, who for more than 30 years was a much-in-demand New York jazz bassist and whose recent illness became a rallying point for jazz musicians without medical insurance, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 56.

title: Oldfangled Interaction Gains Steam
description: AS museums add online exhibitions and try to envelop visitors in virtual worlds, some are also taking steps to reinvent themselves as communities  places where people engage with one another, not just with computers.

title: A More Efficient Way to the Thinnest Slivers, With Hand Protection
description: Perfectly even rounds of potato for pommes Anna, beautiful cucumber scales to decorate poached salmon and parchment-thin slices of white mushroom caps for a salad are best cut on a mandoline instead of by hand or in a food processor. The new Microplane Adjustable Slicer does the job efficiently, and with a few pluses, like a comfortable handle and nonskid feet so it can be held in place on a cutting board.

title: Newark Chief Is Suspended in Police Personnel Dispute
description: NEWARK  Exposing a deepening rift in this citys Police Department, Chief Anthony Campos was suspended for five days on Monday by the departments police director, Garry F. McCarthy, after the two disagreed over personnel matters, according to law enforcement and union officials.

title: Standoff in Japan Over Central Bank Nominee
description: TOKYO  A political showdown is blocking Japan from selecting the next leader of its central bank, increasing the chances that the post could sit vacant at a time of growing financial turmoil.

title: McCain Advisers Lobbied for Europeans to Win Air Force Tanker Deal
description: WASHINGTON  A co-chairman of Senator John McCains presidential campaign and other top campaign advisers and supporters were lobbyists for the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, part of a group that beat out Boeing for a $35 billion contract to build aerial refueling tankers for the Air Force.

title: A Heart Device Is Found Vulnerable to Hacker Attacks
description: To the long list of objects vulnerable to attack by computer hackers, add the human heart.

title: Frustrated Defense Rests Case in Beating Death of 7-Year-Old
description: Lawyers for Cesar Rodriguez, accused of murdering his 7-year-old stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown, abruptly rested their case on Tuesday after the judge rejected their attempts to undo the damage caused last week by one of their own witnesses.

title: Bush Defends Wars, Citing Freedom
description: NASHVILLE  President Bush delivered a rousing defense of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan on Tuesday, mixing faith and foreign policy as he told a group of Christian broadcasters that his policies in the region were predicated on the beliefs that freedom was a God-given right and every human being bears the image of our maker.

title: Behind the Green Glass, Vintage Aromas to Sip and Savor
description: The green glass bottle from Jameson panders to St. Patricks Day, but the deep amber Irish whiskey inside is far better than green beer  and many whiskeys.

title: Medicare to Keep Paying for Heart Scans
description: Medicare said Wednesday that it would continue to cover the use of an increasingly popular scanning procedure used to detect heart disease, despite the agencys earlier misgivings over whether there was sufficient evidence to justify paying for the tests.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 11, 2008

title: What You Get for...$1 Million
description: Apex, N.C.

title: 5. Fearings
description: Ritz-Carlton hotel, 2121 McKinney Avenue, Dallas; (214) 922-4848, fearingsrestaurant.com

title: Iraq Attacks Lower, but Steady, New Figures Show
description: BAGHDAD  Newly declassified statistics on the frequency of insurgent attacks in Iraq suggest that after major security gains last fall in the wake of an American troop increase, the conflict has drifted into a stalemate, with levels of violence remaining stubbornly constant from November 2007 through early 2008.

title: A Homecoming for a Former Times Square Fixture
description: The address, One Times Square, may not be instantly recognizable, but the building certainly is. Bedecked with enormous digital billboards, a huge television screen and a zipper of electronic headlines, it is the worlds most familiar New Years Eve backdrop. The ball descends along its flagpole.

title: Silda Wall Spitzer: Public Ordeal of Private Person
description: Silda Wall Spitzer gave up a high-powered career as a corporate lawyer to raise three daughters and support her husband as he sought elective office, yet has always had deep reservations about his political career. Time and again, she has found herself in the particular bind of encouraging him during critical junctures in his public life while still holding on to some regret that he had chosen to put himself  and their family  there in the first place.

title: The Natural World, Up Close and Personal
description: San Francisco

title: Jets Sign Running Back
description: Running back Jesse Chatman became the fifth unrestricted free agent to sign with the Jets in the past two weeks. Chatman, 28, who will join Thomas Jones in the Jets backfield, had career highs of 515 yards rushing and 276 receiving yards for the Miami Dolphins last season, his fifth in the N.F.L.

title: Trying to Add a Pulse to a World of Machines
description: Mountain View, Calif.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about an offer by two supporters of Hillary Rodham Clinton to pay for restaging the Florida and Michigan primaries misstated the current standing of the Democratic presidential race. Senator Barack Obama has more delegates and has received more popular votes than Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. They are not in a virtual tie.

title: Protecting Treasures on a Shaky Planet
description: Los Angeles

title: Music in Review
description: STEPHEN HOUGH

title: In Israel, a Tailored Home
description: ZICHRON YAACOV, Israel

title: 4. Michaels Genuine Food & Drink
description: 130 NE 40th Street, Miami; (305) 573-5550. www.michaelsgenuine.com

title: A Tropical Hotel Weekend Just Outside Chicago
description: GURNEE, Ill.  With the snows of winter lingering, the opening of a $137 million indoor water resort with a 414-room hotel came at an opportune time in this fast-growing suburb 40 miles north of Chicago.

title: The Choice Shows All Around the Country
description: Theres nothing like an art exhibition to draw the fervid. Here is a summary of the latest:

title: Letters
description: MSG and Migraines

title: Inquiry Into Doctor May Link Players to Drugs
description: Prosecutors at the United States attorneys office for the Northern District of California are investigating a California doctor to determine whether he illegally wrote prescriptions for patients, including major league baseball players, according to three lawyers who have been briefed on the investigation.

title: Overseas Skepticism Meets Fed Move
description: PARIS  Stocks surged Wednesday in Asia and Europe, a day after the Federal Reserve had led global central banks in flooding the financial system with liquidity, but investors remained skeptical about the impact of the Feds move.

title: A Great Teacher: And Watch the Students Soar
description: To the Editor:

title: Fox Votes Out the Big Story
description: Fox News Channel, tinkering for the first time in eight years with its popular early evening lineup, is replacing its 5 p.m. news broadcast, The Big Story, with an election-theme program for the foreseeable future. The network confirmed this week that Americas Election HQ, a program that displaced The Big Story temporarily last month, would continue indefinitely. The programs hosts, Bill Hemmer and Megyn Kelly, also anchor the networks mid-morning newscast and are seen as rising stars on the channel. The change was first reported by the blog TVNewser.com. John Gibson, the longtime host of The Big Story, will continue to have a role on television, the network said, although it appears that his future for now lies mostly on radio. For two years Mr. Gibson, a conservative commentator, has been the host of a three-hour program for Fox News Radio immediately following his television show. Fox News Channel, the top-rated cable news network, has benefited in recent years from a stable programming schedule, while CNN and MSNBC have made multiple on-camera changes. The programming shift underscores the emphasis placed on election-year programming by the cable news networks.

title: Single-Artist Spaces Have Their Issues, Too
description: SOON after Jenny Dixon became the director of the Isamu Noguchi Foundation and Garden Museum, she realized that we were really a very different animal to most museums, she said.

title: At Gettysburg, Farther From the Battle but Closer to History
description: THE old visitor center and museum at the Gettysburg National Military Park was cramped, obsolete and a little too close to history. The brick building, built in the 1920s as a private home, was part of a complex that sat where Union lines had stood for the last two days of the most famous battle in the Civil War.

title: Revisiting Fiamma
description: Fiamma

title: Mars and Venus Dissect the Spitzer Scandal on the TV Talk Shows
description: Many a man stared at Gov. Eliot Spitzers news conference on Monday and thought, There but for the grace of God go I. So did a lot of women, only they were looking at the stricken face of his wife, Silda Wall Spitzer.

title: Looking Back at World War II From 3,000 Feet
description: Farmingdale, N.Y.

title: Despite Security, Politicians Still Find Trouble
description: ALBANY  Secret trysts are complicated under any circumstances, but the logistical challenges are steeper for elected officials who live surrounded by armed security officers whose mandate is to remain close enough to step in front of a bullet.

title: A Slumber Party Where the Wild Things Are
description: WHAT happens in a museum at night, after all the people go home and the lights dim? These days, thousands of children in bunny slippers and flannel pajamas are finding out.

title: Principal Sees Injustice, and Picks a Fight With It
description: PHOENIX  One morning last August, Yvonne Watterson, the principal of GateWay Early College High School here, sat in her office, grimly scrolling through the database of its 240 students.

title: Mark Morris and Purcell in King Arthurs Court
description: At a performance by the Paul Taylor Dance Company at City Center last weekend, the man in front of me told me how he loved Mark Morriss production of King Arthur at New York City Opera. Hed seen it in Berkeley, Calif., and he hoped soon to have seen it seven times.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph with the Wines of The Times column last Wednesday, about the white wines of Rueda, Spain, was published in error. It showed the monastery of Rueda, which is in Zaragoza in the Aragon region of Spain. (Rueda is in the Castile region.)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the widespread use of monosodium glutamate by cooks around the world misstated the role of excitotoxins, which may include MSG. They can raise levels of glutamate, which can overstimulate neurons, not neurotransmitters. (Glutamate is itself a neurotransmitter.)

title: Xavier Follows Its Basketball Heart
description: CINCINNATI  Even with a foot of fresh snow and blinding conditions here Saturday, Cintas Center was full for the mens basketball game between Xavier and the University of Richmond.

title: Focus on a Bump That Preceded 50 Shots
description: Prosecutors displayed photographs on Tuesday of an injury sustained by one of the three detectives on trial in the killing of Sean Bell. The injury occurred when Mr. Bells car struck him before officers began a 50-shot barrage, the police said.

title: A Curator Who Even Considers the Office Chair
description: ART museums that pride themselves on being encyclopedic have a new historical period to cover: the 20th century.

title: Mark Your Art Calendars for These 3 Exhibitions
description: A critic for The New York Times looks at three coming exhibitions that have special appeal.

title: Three Youths in Montclair Are Charged in Sex Attack
description: Three students from Montclair High School were charged on Tuesday with sexually assaulting a 16-year-old special education student at one of their homes last week, prosecutors and the police in the suburban New Jersey community said.

title: Mollycoddling Lamb for Tender Eating
description: The lambs at the Elysian Fields Farm in Waynesburg, Pa., near Pittsburgh, are pampered. They are fed only grain and hay, they drink only water that has been tested for purity, the skin beneath their wool is inspected regularly and all their comings and goings are duly recorded.

title: Profit at Dicks Sporting Goods Surpasses Forecasts
description: Dicks Sporting Goods posted fourth-quarter results on Tuesday that topped market estimates, helped by sales at its new stores, but the retailer forecast lackluster results in the first quarter and 2008.

title: Democrats in Florida Are Near Plan for New Vote
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  Democratic Party officials here are close to completing a draft plan for a new mail-in primary that would take place by early June, a proposal that seeks to give Florida delegates a role in the partys presidential contest, several people involved in the discussions said Tuesday.

title: On the Comic Docket, Probing the Question Which Is More Evil?
description: Ever since he surfaced on The Daily Show a decade ago as a commentator whose volcanic detonations only enhanced his charm, Lewis Black has struggled to find a television showcase he could call his own.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on the Box Seats page in sports on Sunday by Oscar Robertson, a basketball Hall of Fame member, about his first game at the old Madison Square Garden in 1958, misstated the location of the Garden at the time. It was at Eighth Avenue and 50th Street, not 48th.

title: European Spacecraft Problems Fixed
description: The propulsion problem with the European Jules Verne cargo spacecraft has been corrected, and the robot ship began maneuvers to take it to the International Space Station, the European Space Agency said. A problem developed in one of the spacecrafts four propulsion units shortly after launching on Saturday, and the unit shut down. Flight control officials in Toulouse, France, sent new computer instructions to the ship, then shut down and restarted the propulsion system, space agency officials said. The Jules Verne is to dock with the station on April 3 to deliver food, water, equipment and fuel.

title: Boeing, in Contract Protest, Cites Changes to Air Tanker
description: CHICAGO  Boeing filed a formal protest on Tuesday seeking to overturn the Air Forces award of a $35 billion contract to build aerial-refueling planes to a team that includes its European rival, Airbus. It said that the military had changed specifications to accommodate the bigger Airbus plane.

title: Rising From Obscurity, Asian Art Reflects New York Success
description: STANDING before a graduate art history class at New York University one February morning, Melissa Chiu recounted how little more than a decade ago as a doctoral student in Australia, a professor raised questions about her choice of specialty: Chinese contemporary art.

title: Type in Native American and Search (Someday) 13 Million Photos
description: THE Smithsonian Institution has a photography collection of more than 13 million images. The sheer size is difficult to grasp, but even more brain-numbing is the institutions balkanized method of organization: the photographs are spread across its 19 museums in 700 archives and special collections.

title: Henrietta Bell Wells, a Pioneering Debater, Dies at 96
description: Henrietta Bell Wells, the only woman, the only freshman and the last surviving member of the 1930 Wiley College debate team that participated in the first interracial collegiate debate in the United States, died on Feb. 27 in Baytown, Tex. She was 96.

title: Dreadlocks Make the Maiden
description: Even in timeless fairy tales characterizations and morals can creak like a rusty door hinge. Kneehigh Theater, a British troupe from Cornwall that often reworks fantastical stories, manages to winnow the worthy from the hoary with its buoyant, revisionist Rapunzel, at the New Victory Theater and intended for audiences 7 and older.

title: TiVo and YouTube to Deliver Web Video to TV
description: Pick up the remote, turn on the television  and watch YouTube.

title: Otto Schnellbacher, Two-Sport Star at Kansas, Dies at 84
description: Otto Schnellbacher, a football and basketball star at the University of Kansas who became an all-pro defensive back for the N.F.L. Giants and also played pro basketball, died Monday at his home in Topeka, Kan. He was 84.

title: A Slavery Museum Negotiates the Treacherous Route to Funding
description: RICHMOND, Va.

title: A Stand Against Wal-Mart and, for Now, a Victory
description: MONSEY, N.Y.  It was Friday afternoon when the developer who had been intent on building a 215,000-square-foot Wal-Mart in this hamlet sent word to the town offices in Ramapo. The fax was terse, but its message clear: We will not continue to proceed with the development.

title: Government Reports Warn Planners on Sea-Rise Threat to U.S. Coasts
description: A rise in sea levels and other changes fueled by global warming threaten roads, rail lines, ports, airports and other important infrastructure, and policy makers and planners should be acting now to avoid or mitigate their effects, according to new government reports.

title: Studios Announce a Deal to Help Cinemas Go 3-D
description: LAS VEGAS  Eager to get American cinema complexes ready for a surge in 3-D movies next year, four major Hollywood studios announced on Tuesday a deal to subsidize the conversion of 10,000 theaters to digital projection systems.

title: Psst! Follow Me and Ill Show You the Exhibition
description: NOT far from I-95 in Maryland, halfway between Washington and Baltimore, lives an old, one-story motel that is home to the National Cryptologic Museum, an institution devoted to two contradictory human impulses: keeping secrets and telling stories.

title: Spitzer Wrestles Over Response, Paralyzing Albany
description: State government remained paralyzed on Tuesday as Gov. Eliot Spitzer, reeling from revelations that he had been a client of a prostitution ring, was engaged in an intense legal and family debate about whether to resign or, as aides said his wife was urging, to stay on.

title: Saut and Sauce, Green and Greener
description: THERE are so many things I like about this Mexican-style preparation that Im not sure where to start.

title: Southwest Grounds 38 Boeing 737s for Review
description: Southwest Airlines said Wednesday that it had grounded 38 of its Boeing 737s after a review of maintenance records Tuesday night led it to question whether required testing had been done. The airline said the groundings forced it to cancel 4 percent of its flights on Wednesday.

title: North Carolina Student Wins $100,000 Intel Science Award
description: When Shivani Sud was 6, a relative developed a brain tumor. The cancer turned out to be benign, but the experience piqued the girls interest in cancer research. And on Tuesday night, Shivani, now 17, a high school senior in Durham, N.C., took home top honors and a $100,000 scholarship in the Intel Science Talent Search for her project on colon cancer.

title: In a Changing Neighborhood, the Gospel Falls on Achy Ears
description: WASHINGTON  Street preachers have worked the corner of H and Eighth in Northeast Washington for decades, calling to the hungry, the addicted and the homeless over a chorus of sirens and bus noise.

title: Correction: For the Record
