description: An article in the special Museums section today about a 1975 video by two San Francisco art collectives that recreates the Kennedy assassination misidentifies, in some copies, the make of limousine used in the video. It was a Lincoln Continental, the same make President Kennedy rode in  not a Cadillac.

title: U.S. Drops China From List of Top 10 Violators of Rights
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department no longer considers China one of the worlds worst human rights violators, according to its annual human rights report released Tuesday, a decision that immediately earned the ire of human rights groups.

title: A Moment in History, Recaptured for a Second Time
description: Los Angeles

title: Controversial Canal Tests South Koreas New Leader
description: MUNGYONG, South Korea  Like the weed-infested, rusting railroad tracks that run through here, this once prosperous mining town was left behind in South Koreas economic growth  until President Lee Myung-bak began pitching the countrys most ambitious, and controversial, construction project.

title: Ferraros Obama Remarks Become Talk of Campaign
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Democratic presidential contest was jolted Tuesday by accusations surrounding race and sex, set off by remarks from Geraldine A. Ferraro that Senator Barack Obama had received preferential treatment because he is a black man.

title: Turkey Set to Invest in Better Relations With Kurds
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Turkeys government is planning a broad series of investments worth as much as $12 billion in the countrys largely Kurdish southeast, in a new economic effort intended to create jobs and draw young men away from militancy, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said.

title: Sex Infections Found in Quarter of Teenage Girls
description: The first national study of four common sexually transmitted diseases among girls and young women has found that one in four are infected with at least one of the diseases, federal health officials reported Tuesday.

title: A Fond Look at Lennons Lost Weekend
description: If theres one thing that May Pang has been fighting for the last 28 years, its the idea that John Lennon was depressed, isolated and out of control during the 18 months she lived with him, from the summer of 1973 to early 1975, when he reconciled with his second wife, Yoko Ono.

title: Martnez Faces the Toughest Outs Available at the Mets Camp
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Pedro Martnez has faced Derek Jeter more than any other hitter. Next is Bernie Williams. Making his way up that list is Vctor Mndez, who has batted against Martnez nine times in the past five days.

title: Irate Prince Scraps Art Loan
description: Irked by a tax dispute with Germany, Crown Prince Alois of Liechtenstein has canceled a planned loan of family-owned art to the Neue Pinakothek museum in Munich, Bloomberg News reported. Last month Prince Alois, right, called the methods employed by Germany to obtain information on tax evaders an attack on Liechtenstein, which punishes infringements on its banking secrecy. And a written statement from the princes office said, All other approved loans for exhibitions in Germany will also be retracted. The Neue Pinakothek exhibition Viennese Biedermeier Painting From the Collection of the Prince of Liechtenstein was to have run from May 21 to Sept. 21. Its a shame, said Herbert Rott, the curator responsible for the show. We hope we can reschedule it for a later date.

title: Young Yankees Pitcher Has Love for Ranching
description: TAMPA, Fla.  There are 52 players in the Yankees camp, winnowed from 69 at the start of spring training. By the end of the month, more than half of those remaining will be farmed out to the minors. At any time, the team could bring in better players through a trade.

title: 13 Charged in Plan to Stage Fender Benders for Profit
description: They staged fender benders all over the city, then treated the victims for fake cases of whiplash and back pain, the authorities said, performing unnecessary medical tests, then handing out remedies like egg-crate mattresses, bed boards, cervical collars and heating pads as if they were candy.

title: Fed Hopes to Ease Strain on Economic Activity
description: WASHINGTON  Impelled to take extraordinary measures for the second time in less than a week, the Federal Reserve moved on Tuesday to subdue the deepening crisis in credit markets by stepping up as lender of last resort.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: For American Indians, a Chance to Tell Their Own Story
description: IT isnt often that curators will bless a museum exhibition before it opens.

title: Ways of the Wayward
description: FAIRLESS HILLS, Pa.

title: Eliot Spitzers Dizzying Descent
description: To the Editor:

title: When the Final Touch Is the Exit Door
description: WHEN the Milwaukee Art Museum completed its expansion in 2001, there was great acclaim. The soaring new pavilion by Santiago Calatrava was named design of the year by Time magazine, and it quickly became a reference point for visitors to the city.

title: Need to Know
description: When companies are sued for selling unsafe consumer products or creating environmental hazards, the cases too often end with court orders that keep vital health and safety dangers secret. This practice works out well for the wrongdoers, but it is bad for ordinary Americans, who need to know about these threats.

title: War Crimes Trial Begins for Croatian General Who Worked With Americans
description: PARIS  A popular Croatian general who led a brutal operation that drove the Serbs out of western Croatia near the end of the Balkans war went on trial in The Hague on Tuesday for war crimes and crimes against humanity.

title: Whose Table Is It, Anyway?
description: IT is hard to imagine Joseph Bastianich, who owns a dozen restaurants with Mario Batali and controls some of the most coveted tables in the country, being flustered by a reservation for two at Babbo for 6:15 on a Friday night.

title: The Reports That Drew Federal Eyes to Spitzer
description: WASHINGTON  Last summer, employees at a large New York bank detected something suspicious: Gov. Eliot Spitzer was moving around thousands of dollars in what they thought was an effort to conceal the fact that the money was his own, federal officials said on Tuesday.

title: Shuttle Is Carrying Laboratory and Robot to Space Station
description: HOUSTON  The space shuttle Endeavour made its way toward the International Space Station on Tuesday after brightening the early morning skies in a launching from Cape Canaveral, Fla.

title: Chief of AOLs Parent Is Open to Deal
description: AOL, the company that introduced millions of people to the Internet, has tried to reinvent itself many times. The latest effort, like those before it, does not seem to be going well.

title: U.S. Squanders Chances Against Cuba
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The United Statess margin for error shrank considerably Tuesday night in a 1-1 tie with Cuba. Sloppy mistakes replaced stylish play. Tight defense and crisp passes gave way to incongruity.

title: Tibetan Protest Marchers Vow to Reach Homeland
description: NEW DELHI  About a hundred Tibetan exiles on a six-month protest march to their homeland defied the Indian governments orders to halt Tuesday, and could be headed for a conflict with the local police.

title: Throwing a Bash? Surround It With Culture
description: ONE of the more curious chapters in the history of museums is the evolution of the Temple of Dendur, built in Nubia in 15 B.C. and installed at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1978, into one of Manhattans premier party spaces.

title: Public Affairs
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Tea and Treasure in Taipeis National Palace Museum
description: After two trance-like hours floating through Taipeis National Palace Museum, Anh-thu and I were deep in Aesthetic Overload..and wed only just gotten through the porcelains. The National Palace Museum, reopened in 2006 after a big 4-year renovation, is Taiwans version of the Met, the Uffizi and the Louvre. The museum boasts more than 650,000 precious artifacts from more than 5,000 years of Chinese history. Its probably the best collection of Chinese art anywhere.

title: The House as a Palette
description: The concrete block walls are painted orange, pink, blue and purple, the ceilings are yellow and the metal stairs are maroon.

title: Paddock talk begins in Melbourne
description: Team meetings have begun in Melbourne, and they are not only all about the gathering together of the drivers and the media and fans to discuss the new season. They are also occasionally about the gathering together of old friends and F1 participants as well.

title: Three More Standout Meals
description: Frank Bruni dined at 15 significant restaurants that opened in 2006 or 2007, and ranked his top 10. This is the third in a series of four articles that list his favorites in reverse order.

title: Sinbad vs. Hillary
description: The comedian Sinbad, a Barack Obama supporter, is ridiculing Senator Hillary Clintons claim in Iowa that she was sent on a dangerous foreign policy trip to Bosnia in 1996, replete with the threat of sniper fire. Sinbad was on the same trip (Sheryl Crow too), and according to the Washington Post blog The Sleuth:

title: Clients 1 Through 8 Were Charlie Sheen
description: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Yesterday The New York Times reported that New York Governor Eliot Spitzer was a customer of high-end prostitution ring and that the prostitutes knew him as Client 9. Not surprisingly, Clients 1 through 8 were Charlie Sheen.

title: BNP May Set Terms of SocGen Bid in May, Report Says
description: BNP Paribas could set out terms for any offer for embattled rival Socit Gnrale in May, La Tribune newspaper reported on Wednesday without saying where it got the information.

title: European I.P.O.s Fall to Record Lows
description: As firms continue to to pull the plug on initial public offerings in the United States, their European counterparts dont seem to be any more active.

title: Mindray to Buy Datascope Unit
description: A Chinese medical device maker, Mindray Medical, said Tuesday it planned to buy Datascopes patient monitoring business for $202 million.

title: Final Bidders Emerge for Indonesian Bank, Report Says
description: HSBC, the European bank, the Bank of China and Malayan Banking Bhd of Malaysia, have emerged as the final bidders for a stake in Bank Internasional Indonesia that is currently held by a Singapore state investor, Temasek, and is valued at more than $800 million, Reuters reported.

title: Valero to Sell Refineries
description: The refining company Valero Energy of Texas said on Tuesday it is considering selling nearly a third of its North American refineries amid an economic slowdown in the United States that is crimping fuel demand.

title: Citadel Makes Macro Hire
description: The Citadel Investment Group, the Chicago-based hedge fund and financial services group founded by Kenneth Griffin, has hired a portfolio manager from Moore Capital Management to manage global macro strategies, marking the firms first move into the industrys best performing investment strategy this year.

title: Sovereign Wealth Funds May Surpass Global Foreign Reserves
description: Sovereign wealth fund assets may soon surpass total official foreign reserves held by central banks and become the main vehicle for capital investment, a Morgan Stanley economist said on Tuesday.

title: Milberg Weiss Tops Class-Action Ranking
description: The law firm Milberg Weiss, set to go on trial later this year on charges of paying illegal kickbacks to clients, was the top-ranked class-action firm in the United States last year with $3.8 billion in settlement winnings for plaintiffs, according to a new report.

title: BlackRock Plans a Listed Fund of Hedge Funds
description: BlackRock, the money manager, said on Tuesday it is planning a London-listed closed-end fund of hedge funds that will offer exposure to its $11 billion (5.5 billion pound) Appreciation Strategy.

title: Time Warners Chief Seems To Favor Cable Spin Off
description: The chief executive of Time Warner, Jeffrey Bewkes, signaled Tuesday that he was leaning toward a spin off of Time Warner Cable, saying that the cable business might perform better for shareholders if it were not locked to the rest of the businesses, which includes AOL along with extensive properties in the film and online and print publishing industries.

title: Bear Shares Recover After S.E.C. Remarks
description: Shares in Bear Stearns pared losses late Tuesday after securities regulators said they were comfortable with capital levels at the nations largest investment banks, including Bear. Analysts, however, continued to cut their targets for Bear.

title: Kirkland & Ellis Partner to Join Claims Agent
description: Michael Frishberg, a former partner in Kirkland & Elliss restructuring department, has joined Kurtzman Carson Consultants, a claims agent for companies undergoing restructuring. Mr. Frishberg will work as a senior managing consultant, Kurtzman Carson said in a statement Tuesday.

title: London Fund Faces Charges in Switzerland
description: Laxey Partners, the activist British hedge fund, is facing possible criminal prosecution in Switzerland after the countrys banking regulator said it had breached disclosure laws while building a 23 percent stake in a local construction company.

title: Approval of DoubleClick Deal May Help Microsoft
description: A decision Tuesday by regulators in Europe to approve Googles acquisition of DoubleClick could strengthen Microsofts argument that it should be allowed to buy Yahoo, were it to succeed in its battle with that company, analysts said.

title: Take-Two Vows to Beat Expectations and a Bidder
description: Facing a takeover bid from a rival, Electronic Arts, Take-Two Interactive sought to assure Wall Street investors on Tuesday that it is capable of growing on its own.

title: Gabelli to Host Meeting Betwen Media General and Harbinger
description: Media General, a family-owned newspaper publisher and television station operator, will meet with a hedge fund trying to nominate directors to its board to improve profits.

title: Should Microsoft Be Selling, Not Buying?
description: As Microsoft looks to buy Yahoo to shore up its search business, a recent column in The New York Times suggested that Microsoft might consider acquiring SAP instead  a move that would bolster its business-software unit, which sells under the brand Microsoft Dynamics.

title: Chief of AOLs Parent Is Open to a Deal
description: AOL, the company that introduced millions of people to the Internet, has tried to reinvent itself many times. The latest effort, like those before it, does not seem to be going well.

title: Jets Fans: America Hates Your QBs
description: Our guest contributors of the week are Enrico Campitelli Jr. and Matt Pesotskiof the 700 level, the brotherly Philadelphia sports blog.

description: Just like one of his NPR stories only its video and takes less time:

description: So much for the battle of the billionaires.

title: Fed Hopes to Ease Strain on Economic Activity
description: Impelled to take extraordinary measures for the second time in less than a week, the Federal Reserve moved on Tuesday to subdue the deepening crisis in credit markets by stepping up as lender of last resort.

title: Pixim Raises Additional $5.1 Million
description: Pixim, the start-up founded in 1999 to create chips that delivered better processing power for visual imagery, has raised $5.1 million, extending a $15 million round raised in 2007 from its current investors, Mayfield Fund  and Tallwood Venture Capital, VentureBeat reported.

title: V.C.s Throw $55 Million into Highwinds
description: The Highwinds Network Group said on Tuesday it had closed a $55 million round of venture financing led by General Catalyst Partners and Alta Communications.

title: What Happened at Carlyle Capital?
description: What was the Carlyle Group thinking?

title: Can Formula One Really Make Motor Sports Green?
description: Once airlines and carmakers started rebranding as green businesses, it was only a matter of time before Formula One motor racing  the sport that is perhaps the most emblematic of our fossil-fuel-powered world  took a similar path.

title: Lampooning Gunmen, Carefully
description: Anyone who believes that the pen is mightier than the sword doesn't live in Iraq.

title: High Finance Backfires on Alabama County
description: In 2002, a JPMorgan Chase banker named Charles E. LeCroy arrived in Birmingham, Alabama with a novel pitch to ease taxpayers burden. Some Wall Street wizardry, he said, could lighten their load.

title: The Early Word: Six Weeks of Waiting
description: Is it Groundhog Day again? Now that we have the Mississippi primary results, six weeks of campaigning will go on before the next round on April 22 in Pennsylvania.

title: Teams With a Ticket
description: Here is a list of the teams that have secured an automatic bid in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Check back throughout the week as the number of teams increases.

title: When Is It Time to Panic?
description: It was no doubt frustrating for U.S. soccer fans Tuesday night, whether they were among the handful of lonely souls at Raymond James stadium or watching at home on Fox Soccer Channel or, like me, sitting on the couch with a lap top tuned to ESPN360.com.

title: iPod Scare Leads to Inquiry in Japan
description: Its 3 a.m. and your children are safe and asleep  but theres an iPod in the house, and its recharging

title: Spitzer to Resign Today, Aides Say
description: Aides to Gov. Eliot Spitzer, the Democratic governor of New York, are saying this morning that he is likely to resign today in the face of the widening scandal over his role as a client of a high-end prostitution ring. As of Tuesday night, Mr. Spitzer had continued to be sealed up in his Fifth Avenue home with his family and top aides, debating whether to resign or  as some aides say his wife was advocating  to try to stay in office and fight on, as Danny Hakim and Ian Urbina reported. Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson would be sworn in as New Yorks governor in Albany on Monday, when the resignation takes effect, an aide to the governor said.

title: Performances to Remember
description: The Big East tournament gets underway Wednesday, which got us thinking about some of the great individual performances in major conference tournaments.

title: Bears Chairman Buys $26 Million Condo
description: Bear Stearnss stock may be hitting new 52-week lows, but the firms chairman just put the finishing touches on a high-flying real-estate deal.

title: Another Societe Generale Trader Is Held
description: The French bank Socit Gnrale said Wednesday that another trader has been taken into custody for questioning in connection with a multibillion dollar trading scandal.

title: Ferraro Speaking Freely
description: Is Barack Obama leading the Democratic race for the presidential nomination because, as Geraldine Ferraro suggested, he is black? (If Obama was a white man, he would not be in this position, Ferraro told the Daily Breeze, a California newspaper.)

title: Lampooning Gunmen, Carefully
description: BAGHDAD  Anyone who believes that the pen is mightier than the sword doesnt live in Iraq.

title: How KKR Could Pull the I.P.O. Plug
description: Call a search party: KKRs initial public offering is missing in action. KKR  the proposed name for the publicly traded affiliate of Henry Kraviss private equity firm, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts  first filed its documents to go public with the Securities and Exchange Commission way back on July 3, 2007. Since that time, it has amended its registration statement twice, the last time on Nov. 13.

title: Questions for Earth Scientists From the Academy
description: Humans seem to crave lists. You can see it any time a speaker says, Okay, here are my three take-home points. Everyone kind of perks up. When the Science Times section had its 25th anniversary in 2003, we devoted a special section to 25 enduring science questions. The ones I explored were: How Much Nature is Enough? and When Will the Next Ice Age Begin?

title: Premiering Tonight: The Root of All Evil
description: Lewis Black, the comedian for whom the word acerbic could have been coined, is finally becoming the host of his own show. Lewis Backs Root of All Evil premieres Wednesday at 10:30 on Comedy Central.

title: After the Diet: Counseling Helps Keep Pounds Off
description: Dieters are more likely to lose weight and keep it off if they have contact with a weight-loss counselor, a new study shows.

title: The Battle of New Orleans Goes On
description: Over on his GQ blog, Alan Richman gently vivisects Les Halles, the bistro with a longstanding but by now highly notional claim to Anthony Bourdains chefly oversight.

title: Subways Show a Softer Side
description: We could say that advertising in the subway has hit bottom, but that would be playing right into Kimberly-Clarks hands.

title: Local, Seasonal, Wishful
description: The restaurant Michaels Genuine Food & Drink, which ranks Number 4 in my countdown of favorite new restaurants around the country, rightly presents itself as a champion of local and seasonal ingredients, and it gets mentioned by people writing or talking about the whole farm-to-table movement.

title: Blogs, Good for Vocabulary and Relationships?
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Not Quite Irish, But Its Green
description: Over the years, Ive been asked at least 25 times to come up with recipes that jive with Thanksgiving. Never before, however, have I done the St. Patricks Day thing.

title: Bruno: A Crisis Unlike Any Other Ever Faced
description: Updated, 12:07 p.m. | ALBANY  It must have been tempting. But Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader in the State Senate and Gov. Eliot Spitzers nemesis for the last year, refused to gloat. Repeatedly, he was asked whether he wrung any satisfaction out of the governors downfall.

title: For the Moment | Kid in a Candy Store
description: Liz O. Baylen

title: There but for a Declined Master Card Go I
description: Aired Tuesday night on CBS: You folks are in a great mood, and I know why: because its a beautiful day in New York City. Isnt it lovely outside? Beautiful blue skies, sunny, very, very sunny - its so sunny and bright outside that earlier today, Eliot Spitzer came out of a brothel squinting.

title: Some Sort of Consolation Prize
description: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: You know what the highest paid government position in the country is? Working under New York Governor Spitzer. It pays like $5,000 an hour.

title: Spitzers Trek Through Midtown
description: Updated, 12:27 p.m. | Eliot Spitzer left his Manhattan apartment building at 11:12 a.m. this morning for one of the last times as governor of the State of New York. He was scheduled to make a statement at 11:30 a.m. at the governors Midtown office, at 633 Third Avenue, where he arrived at 11:38 a.m. In a brief statement, he announced his resignation as New Yorks 54th governor, effective Monday, turning over the reins of power to Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson.

title: The Double Life of Veronique
description: Veronique Branquinho (Mark Segal)

title: Aches and Pains Fell Two Yankees
description: As far as we can tell, Billy Crystal, that rookie sensation wearing No. 60, is healthy. Some more important Yankee players are a little banged up today.

title: Tony Blairs Part-Time Job: Middle East Peace
description: When Tony Blair was named by the United States, the European Union, Russia, and the United Nations  the Middle East Quartet  to help Palestinians prepare for statehood, we were encouraged that the appointment of Britains former prime minister was a sign of serious purpose on all sides.

title: J. Crews Stylish Run on the Big Board
description: Last week, DealBook highlighted Orbitzs slumping stock as the kind of thing that gives ammunition to critics of buyout-backed initial public offerings.

title: McCain Campaign Responds to Tanker Deal
description: Updated | 2:30 p.m. Ever since the Air Force decided to award a huge contract to build aerial refueling tankers to the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company and Northrop Grumman, Democrats have sought to highlight that fact that it was Senator John McCain who helped scuttle an earlier, corrupt deal that would have awarded the business to an American company, Boeing.

title: Recipe of the Day: Churros
description: In the world of fresh pastry, few things are quicker than churros, those cruller-like strips of crisp fried dough that are street-corner snacks in Spain, Mexico and some New York City subway stations.

title: The Forgotten Story of How the Cougar Ace Was Saved
description: Remember the Cougar Ace? It was the cargo ship carrying 4,703 new Mazdas from Japan to North America. It nearly capsized off the coast of Alaska in 2006.

title: Welcome to New York
description: Its always a bit surreal seeing scalpers hawking tickets at 10 a.m. The Syracuse band is pouring out of the Hotel Pennsylvania in the morning sunshine on 6th Ave. and Villanova cheerleaders are toting lattes on their way to Madison Square Garden.

title: Living With Music: A Playlist by Marisa Silver
description: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for Living With Music, a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

title: Epic Frescoes
description: Images from the new book about the cycle of frescoes by Giovanni Battista Zelotti.

title: Try the Shapes Experiment
description: Heres your chance to play a game and participate in an experiment. It takes just two minutes and is a simple series of exercises: you repeatedly choose between two shapes and get more points by choosing the larger one. Click here to play the game. Youll get your score after you play.

title: U.S. Attorney Says There Is No Deal With Spitzer
description: The United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, Michael J. Garcia, whose office last week announced four arrests of officials in a prostitution ring of which Gov. Eliot Spitzer was a client, just issued a statement in response to press speculation. Mr. Garcias one-line statement said, There is no agreement between this office and Gov. Eliot Spitzer, relating to his resignation or any other matter. The statement is unusual, because federal prosecutors rarely comment on pending investigations.

title: No New Fall Shows on ABC?
description: ABC may not introduce any new shows this fall, a consequence of the writers strike and the fact that the network has several strong series entering their sophomore years.

title: Emmy Awards: Same Statues, New Venue
description: The Emmy Awards, the most prestigious award in television entertainment, will be handed out at a new location this fall: the Nokia Theatre in Los Angeles.

title: Responses Pour In to Spitzers Resignation
description: Updated, 9 p.m. | Elected officials, other government leaders, and other prominent New Yorkers have begun issuing a flood of statements in response to Gov. Eliot Spitzers announcement that he will resign from office effective Monday and be succeeded by Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson. (See the separate blog posts on Mr. Patersons statement and reactions from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and former Gov. George E. Pataki.) Texts of the statements follow.

title: Chicago's Creative Visions
description: Two recent Chicago museum projects have earned praise for realizing their clients' big dreams on small construction budgets.

title: Consumer Reports Top 10
description: I meant to post this last week. But with the New York auto show opening next week, the notice got lost in my e-mail inbox, which has been rapidly filling up with invites to press events all over town, including a green fashion show, a green art opening and even a green drive in a green car.

title: 2 Men Charged in Killing of U.N.C. Student President
description: Updated, 5:27 p.m. Authorities announced today that two suspects faced first-degree murder charges in the case of Eve Carson, the slain student body president at University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. One remained at large this afternoon, with police asking for help while warning that he was considered armed and dangerous.

title: New Deal Artists in Santa Fe
description: Northern New Mexico was a hub of New Deal artistic activity during the Great Depression.

title: Mad at Your Parents? Motherhood May Be Rocky
description: Women who have unresolved conflict with their own parents are more likely to struggle with the transition to motherhood, a new study shows.

title: The Ohio Ad Wars
description: As the Democratic primary race moves to Pennsylvania, an analysis of the television ad spending in neighboring Ohio may offer a few lessons along the way. About $8 million was spent in the Buckeye State on television ads overall on the Democratic side, and 15 percent of that came from outside groups like labor unions and new 527 organizations.

title: Soft Serve | Vuitton Roses, Cond Nasts Ferrari Magazine, Abercrombie to the Rescue
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: Luis Castillo Still M.I.A.
description: Luis Castillo remains the lone position player who has yet to play in a game. It wont be today. Wont be tomorrow, either. He said hes shooting for Saturday, which would give him a little more than two weeks of at-bats before the season begins March 31.

title: A Great Vintage Raises All Vineyards
description: That enormous, gaping void you see in the Dining Out section today? Well, maybe it only looks that way to me. But when I dont have a column in the newspaper I like to think that somethings missing.

title: Clinton Presses for Florida, Michigan Voters
description: As Hillary Rodham Clinton woos superdelegates by trying to make the case that she is winning the big Democratic-leaning states, she and her campaign are doing all they can to secure those discounted votes in Florida and Michigan.

title: Spitzer Resigns
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer, with his wife by his side, announced his resignation at his Manhattan office.

title: You Know Whats Stupid? Everything I Dont Understand

title: Mission not accomplished  not yet, anyway
description: Is it fair to judge the Feds plan yet? No, not in either direction. The big stock rally yesterday reflected investors belief that it might work  or maybe investors belief that other investors would believe that it would work  rather than an actual demonstration of effectiveness.

title: Bear Stearns' C.E.O. on the Markets
description: Bear Stearns chief executive Alan Schwartz talks with CNBC's David Faber about his firm's troubles in the mortgage market and its stagnant stock.

title: Villanova Comfortably on the Bubble
description: Though Tuesdays game between Syracuse and Villanova was being dubbed the Battle for the Bid, the realistic question looming now that Villanova won 82-63 is if the Wildcats are actually assured a spot in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Rome, Part Three: A Great European Market
description: RadicchioCampo de' Fiori was not the first great European market I visited. (That would be London's sorely missed Covent Garden -- the real Covent Garden, not the touristy shopping mall that took its place -- that I stumbled upon during a snowy -- yes! -- morning in 1968).    But it was among my favorites, and remains so. What I saw last week, mostly local:  Early tomatoes    Gorgeous greens (look at that radicchio!)   Some rather excellent early tomatoes (a little more on these tomorrow)   Cavolo nero (which I've written about here)    The gentleman with the peeler.Puntarelle, the best spring salad green there is (especially dressed with anchovy vinaigrette, as it is throughout Italy). A screen-like gizmo is used for separating the edible from inedible portion of the thick stems.    A few decent looking artichokes    And an old guy with a fancy peeling device, which he so loved he couldnt be bothered to talk to customers.

title: Rome, Part Three: A Great European Market
description: Campo de Fiori was not the first great European market I visited. (That would be Londons sorely missed Covent Garden  the real Covent Garden, not the touristy shopping mall that took its place  that I stumbled upon during a snowy  yes!  morning in 1968).

The Art of Listening

description: More than 31 million people watched the top 12 finalists perform on American Idol Tuesday night, down slightly from the same episode in previous seasons but still enough to bring Fox more viewers than all the other broadcast networks combined.

description: Just how the Feds latest move should help to bail out Thornburg Mortgage is not clear to me. But a lot of money is being bet that it will.

title: Goodman, Ex-Senator, Is Hospitalized After Choking
description: Roy M. Goodman, a former state senator and candidate for mayor, was hospitalized on Tuesday night and is expected to return home later this week after a choking incident at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria hotel, Leslie Goodman, his daughter, said today.

title: Kind of Illegal
description: Eliot Spitzer was right to resign, but prosecutors were also wrong to target him. Thats Michael Barones take on New Yorks fallen governor at his U.S News blog. He held an office in which he was responsible for enforcing the laws and violated prostitution laws (though theyre generally not enforced) and, perhaps, laws on currency transaction reports. As a former federal prosecutor he can hardly claim ignorance of the law, Barone writes. But Im still troubled by aspects of the case. The law says prostitution is illegal. But it is an openly practiced business. Somethings wrong here. He also writes:

title: The Insider | Ed Droste
description: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here Ed Droste, lead singer of the band Grizzly Bear, shares with The Moment a few of his stylish essentials. You can catch Grizzly Bear over at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Howard Gilman Opera House in April, when the band performs alongside Paul Simon  for a tribute concert.

title: Nothing Is Free
description: Construction is coming along nicely  we will give you a detailed update soon  and despite the fact that Johnny just had surgery (hes fine; everything went well), he is back on the job pushing to get everything done by the end of the month.

Readers are invited to submit additional questions using the comment form below.

title: Are Women Too Sexy for I.T.?
description: Viviane Reding, the European Unions telecommunications commissioner, has thousands upon thousands of jobs to fill in the next few years and a huge chunk of the population completely uninterested in applying. Her solution? Open a campaign to prove that the information technology industry isnt just for geeky, unsociable people.

title: If Not Nos. 1 through 5, Greene Will Return to Syracuse

description: Villanova defeated Syracuse, 82-63, in the first round of the Big East tournament. After the game, Wildcats Coach Jay Wright, Orange Coach Jim Boeheim and some of their players talked to the media at a postgame news conference. Listen below to what they had to say.

Paterson for his intelligence and integrity and said that the new governor deserves the support of New Yorkers and has tremendous potential to lead this state.

description: A John McCain presidency would take away workers rights and reduce their standard of living, alleges the AFL-CIO in its new online e-journal, McCain Revealed: The Briefing Book.

description: South by Southwest starts today in Austin. Now in its third decade, SXSW is the annual rite of spring for the music business: more than a thousand bands playing day and night in Austins clubs, convention center, parks, barbecue joints, parking lots and backyards, surrounded by potential fans and backers.

title: Q&A on the Spitzer Scandal
description: Through Friday, Sam Roberts, the urban affairs correspondent, is fielding selected readers' questions on City Room for a panel of New York Times reporters and editors who worked on the coverage of Eliot Spitzer's resignation amid a prostitution scandal.   Read the answers here.  Thanks to all the readers who participated. Questions are no longer being accepted, but we are still preparing answers that address the topics raised most often in the more than 400 comments below. If you are looking for a place to comment about the scandal and its fallout, we are still accepting comments on other posts about the investigation and resignation.

title: Big States, Big Deal
Pride in Harlem at Patersons Elevation
description: Among people in central Harlem, where Barack Obama posters seem to be taped to nearly every storefront window and where many people say they feel disconnected from political power, there is a palpable mixture of pride and fascination that one of their own is to become governor of the state of New York.For a number of afternoon shoppers, as well as people escorting children from school and commuters, the No. 1 topic on Wednesday was the unexpected ascension of David A. Paterson, who represented the neighborhood in the State Senate for two decades before becoming lieutenant governor little more than a year ago. (He was born in Brooklyn in 1954.)

title: McCain Returns to New Hampshire
description: EXETER, N.H.Senator John McCain returned on Wednesday to the state that launched his 2000 and 2008 presidential campaigns, but the nostalgic quasi-homecoming was mixed with the political reality that New Hampshire will be a hard fight for him in November.

Mr. Trabocchi took charge of Fiammas kitchen in the late summer.

title: Resignation Will Take Effect at Noon Monday
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzers resignation will take effect at noon on Monday. In a resignation letter [pdf] just released by his office, dated today, Mr. Spitzer informed the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, I am writing to advise you that I am resigning my position as Governor of the State of New York effective at 12:00 noon on Monday, March 17, 2008.

title: Practice Makes Perfect
description: Before the presidential campaigns were shoved to the back burner by developments in New York, the staffs of both Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama were in the news  and not in a good way. Recent reports have painted a picture of a Clinton campaign wracked with strife and internal discord, suggesting a dysfunctional operation. And one of Senator Obamas top foreign policy advisers had to step down from the campaign because she called Senator Clinton a monster in an off the record aside not long after another adviser to Senator Obama got tripped up for statements he made about the candidates position on NAFTA.

title: An Antidote to Spitzers Style
description: I was all set to write about Penelope Trunks new company, BrazenCareerist.com, but Eliot Spitzers fall from arrogance got me distracted. Then I realized that Ms. Trunks style of career management might just offer a timely antidote to the current unraveling of Mr. Spitzers career.

title: Friar Cooked?
description: The Providence administration will likely decide in the next few days if it will keep Coach Tim Welsh for another season. Its a tricky case, as Welsh has been solid but not spectacular in his 10 seasons at Providence. The Friars finished their season with a 15-16 record, the second time in three years that they wont be in any kind of postseason.

title: SXSW: Business Hell and Information Heaven
description: It takes a little while to acclimate to South by Southwest, which may be why the convention uses Wednesday to ease in. Major panels dont start until tomorrow, and a few clubs havent joined the six-bands-a-night showcase schedule.

description: O.K., stipulating that Jerry Reese has earned enough credibility to make 10 David Carr signings

title: New Yankee Stadium Rising in The Bronx
description: As I was driving along the Major Deegan on Wednesday, a highway I frequent often during the baseball season and hardly at all during the offseason, it was cool to see these words above Yankee Stadium: 19 Days Until Opening Day.

title: Nothing Comes Between Cal, Washington  Not Even Oregon
description: Cal and Washington seem unwilling to let anything come between them. Cal, the ninth seed, and Washington, the eighth seed, split their regular-season games, each winning on the others court. Now they are playing on a neutral court - Staples Center, which is beige (Get it? Neutral?)  and headed to halftime separated by only 2 points, with Washington leading.

title: SXSW Video: Kindred Spirits
description: Pretty easy to tell whos in Austin for SXSW, even at the airport. We were skinny-jean- and Converse-spotting the whole ride down.

title: Home Cooking
description: Before every road game, the Pittsburgh Panthers have a tradition of taking a halfcourt shot at the end of practice before the game. But the Panthers play so often at Madison Square Garden and have had so much success here over the years that Coach Jamie Dixon treats Garden game like home games. That means no halfcourt shot.

title: A look at the bold, beautiful and wild in Dubai building design
description: Dubai is an architects dream. Its a country with plenty of money, available land and a mandate to create edifices that impress and overwhelm.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Shaker Design

title: Parents Charged in Death of Queens Infant
description: A Queens couple faced criminal charges on Wednesday in connection with the death of their infant daughter in October, the authorities said.

title: In Knockouts in Detroit, 4 Top Teams Take a Fall
description: The Vanderbilt Knockout Teams is the weeklong premier event at the American Contract Bridge Leagues Spring North American Championships in Detroit. Four top-rated teams lost in the Round of 32 on Tuesday. The No. 2 seeds, captained by Nick Nickell, the most successful team over the last 15 years, lost to the No. 31 seeds, Judith Bianco, Winthrop Allegaert, Kevin Bathurst, Lapt Chan, Justin Lall and Jaggy Shivdasani of New York. The No. 8 seeds, led by Steve Garner and including the defending champions, Christal Henner-Welland and Roy Welland of New York and Antonio Sementa from Italy, lost to the No. 40 seeds, Connie Goldberg of Merion Station, Pa.; Wafik Abdou of Bakersfield, Calif.; Henry Bethe of Ithaca, N.Y.; Billy Eisenberg of Perris, Calif.; Nader Hanna from Canada; and Allen Tan from the Philippines. The No. 9 and No. 11 seeds were also ousted.

title: Smithsonian Officer Plans to Leave
description: Ned Rifkin, the under secretary for art at the Smithsonian Institution, will resign on April 11, the Smithsonian announced on Wednesday. Mr. Rifkin said he was stepping down in anticipation of the appointment of a new secretary sometime this month. The previous secretary, Lawrence M. Small, resigned last March after investigations into his personal spending. I think its time to think about other things, Mr. Rifkin said in an interview. An institution with new leadership deserves to have the opportunity to restructure. As the under secretary since 2004, Mr. Rifkin has overseen the Smithsonians art museums and organizations: the National Portrait Gallery; Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum; Freer Gallery of Art and Arthur M. Sackler Gallery; Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden; National Museum of African Art; the Smithsonian American Art Museum and Renwick Gallery; Archives of American Art; and Smithsonian Photography Initiative.

title: Gus Giordano, 84, Innovator of Modern Jazz Dance, Is Dead
description: Gus Giordano, an early and tireless popularizer of American jazz dance who organized the first Jazz Dance World Congress, died on March 9 in Chicago. He was 84.

title: Welshs Hold on Toughest Job in Big East in Jeopardy
description: Its hard to cast a larger shadow on the sideline than the West Virginia Coach Bob Huggins, who made his Big East tournament coaching debut on Wednesday afternoon.

title: 4 Arrests, Then 6 Days to a Resignation
description: The beginning of the end came on Monday morning, as Eliot Spitzer rode south through Manhattan in his black S.U.V. with his wife, Silda, still not sure if he would resign as governor of New York.

title: Shares Recover From Early Tumble
description: Stock markets closed higher Thursday afternoon, recovering from an early sell-off as investors grappled with a precipitous decline in the dollar, poor retail sales, and an uneasy milestone: gold at $1,000 an ounce.

title: Moving Past Foot Woes, Clearing Path to Games
description: Shalane Flanagan ran the 5,000 meters in the 2004 Olympics in Athens and the 2005 world championships in Helsinki. But her left foot hurt so badly in 2005 she could hardly train, and after Helsinki she decided not to run again until she found what was wrong. She went from doctor to doctor, looking for an answer.

title: Priest-Cosmologist Wins $1.6 Million Templeton Prize
description: The $1.6 million Templeton Prize, the richest award made to an individual by a philanthropic organization, was given Wednesday to Michael Heller, 72, a Roman Catholic priest, cosmologist and philosopher who has spent his life asking, and perhaps more impressively answering, questions like Does the universe need to have a cause?

title: What Price an Authentic Louis Kahn House?
description: If you were clever enough to snap up a house by Louis Kahn, one of the most revered architects of the 20th century, in the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia in 1981, as Robert Gallagher, a dentist, and his wife, Lynn, did, it was $152,500. It had just one bedroom, but its lineage was awfully smart: it had been built between 1959 and 1961 for Margaret Esherick, a relative of the sculptor Wharton Esherick, who gave the home its name, Esherick House. By 2004 the assessed value of the home, according to 2006 county tax rolls, was $303,000. But what do bureaucrats know of beauty? On May 18, the Wright auction house in Chicago, which specializes in 20th-century art and design, will be offering Esherick House in its Important Design sale. Richard Wright, the firms president, estimates that it will bring $2 million to $3 million. Louis Kahn only did three major architectural homes in his career, Mr. Wright said. Joe Rosa, the curator of the architectural department at the Art Institute of Chicago, who wrote a book on Louis Kahn, feels that it is his best residential structure. He articulates his mature style in the monumentality of the facade, in the treatment of the windows, and then the warm and human quality in the interior.

title: For an Aspiring Singer, a Harsher Spotlight
description: She left a broken home on the Jersey Shore at 17 and came to New York City to work the nightclubs as a rhythm and blues singer. Now, at 22, she is the unwitting, and as yet unseen, star of the seamy drama that is the downfall of Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York.

title: Billionaire Rivals Spoke Often of Deals, Trial Is Told
description: WILMINGTON, Del.  The first hint of drama in the dispute between John C. Malones Liberty Media and Barry Dillers IAC/InterActiveCorp came on Wednesday, the third day of a trial that turns on whether Mr. Dillers plan to split IAC into five companies can survive a challenge by Mr. Malone.

title: Senators Join Citizens in Attacking Corzines Budget Plan
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  It was supposed to be the first chance for legislators to conduct a listening tour focusing on Gov. Jon S. Corzines belt-tightening $33 billion budget. But instead, it was the legislators who ended up making the most noise.

title: Rice Trip to Skip Argentina in Sign of a Growing Rift
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice is scheduled to touch down in Brazil on Thursday for a two-day visit to South America, less than two weeks after Colombias assassination of a top rebel leader enraged Ecuadors president and drew threats of military action by Venezuelas president, Hugo Chvez.

title: Jury Is About to Decide Fate of Dead Girls Stepfather
description: The photo hung above Cesar Rodriguezs head.

title: Heart Scans Still Covered by Medicare
description: Reversing a proposed decision issued in December, the federal government said Wednesday it would continue to cover the use of an increasingly popular procedure to detect heart disease.

title: Zimbabwe: Mugabe Woos Votes With Raises and Tractors
description: President Robert G. Mugabe, campaigning to be re-elected for another five-year term on March 29, has suddenly found enough cash in his destitute nations treasury to raise the pay of all civil servants, the state-controlled newspaper The Herald reported. Just yesterday, I was signing a new salary schedule for teachers and civil servants, The Herald quoted the president as saying. Without specifying the amount of the raises, he added, I hope they will be happy. Over the past week, he also gave away hundreds of tractors and other machinery and tools to farmers.

title: French Police Questioning Bank Worker
description: PARIS  Authorities took a second employee at the French bank Socit Gnrale into custody on Wednesday in connection with a trading scandal that the bank said had cost it nearly 5 billion euros (more than $7 billion).

title: Colombia: Russia Moves to Extradite Israeli Mercenary
description: Russia moved to extradite Yair G. Klein, a former Israeli Army officer, to Colombia, where he is wanted in connection to the training of paramilitary death squads. He was sentenced in 2001 to 10 years in prison in Colombia for advising on the formation of the private armies in the 1980s that became enmeshed in the countrys cocaine trade. Mr. Klein, arrested in Moscow last year, has 10 days to appeal the decision by the Moscow City Court.

title: Pro-Clinton? SNL Says Youre Joking
description: Lorne Michaels has an answer to the political columns, cartoons and comments that have accused his show, Saturday Night Live, of favoring Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton during her primary showdown with Senator Barack Obama: Nope.

title: Plan for Ambitious East Side Project Clears Big Hurdle
description: More than seven years after he signed a contract to buy the last large undeveloped site on the East Side, the developer Sheldon H. Solow gained an important approval from a City Council committee on Wednesday for his $4 billion plan to build seven towers on nine acres along First Avenue.

title: Iraqi Troops May Move to Reclaim Basras Port
description: BASRA, Iraq  Several senior Iraqi officials said on Wednesday that the government might soon deploy Iraqi Army troops to seize control of this citys decrepit but vital port from politically connected militias known more for corruption and inciting terrorism than for their skill in moving freight.

title: The Red Phone Ad: A Rorschach Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Teenage Driving Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: New Inspections Ground 38 Southwest Jets
description: Southwest Airlines, combing through its maintenance files after being fined $10.2 million last week for an inspection lapse uncovered in 2007, said it found another problem and grounded 38 planes Wednesday, canceling about 125 flights.

title: Spitzer Fall Began With Bank Reports
description: Last July, the North Fork Bank raised a red flag about suspicious financial transactions involving Gov. Eliot Spitzer. But for several months, the electronic report languished unnoticed in a vast Treasury Department database in Detroit.

title: Hope for Harmony in a Shaken Albany
description: On Day 442, everything changes. Again.

title: Better, Faster, More Colorful Printers, for (Even) Less Money
description: The eternal promise of gadgetland  that devices will keep getting cheaper and better  continues to play out among low-end printers.

title: Pentagon Cites Tapes Showing Interrogations
description: WASHINGTON  The Defense Department is conducting an extensive review of the videotaping of interrogations at military facilities from Iraq to Guantnamo Bay, and so far it has identified nearly 50 tapes, including one that showed what a military spokesman described as the forcible gagging of a terrorism suspect.

title: Skimp on the Champagne? Not This Cancer Patient
description: The premise of Terminal City  a cancer patient is hounded by the producers of a reality TV show  sounds as though it were something out of bad experimental theater. Right away you suspect an agenda. An award-winning Canadian mini-series being shown Thursdays on the Sundance Channel, Terminal City leads you to wonder if it might be trying to right the wrongs of so many years of Survivor and its culturally malignant offspring. I feared the worst: something that sought to tell us just how misplaced our priorities are.

title: Crystal Puts Bat on Ball and Tongue in Cheek
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Say this about Billy Crystal, a 5-foot-5 infield prospect who bats right-handed, throws right-handed and left everything on practice field No. 2 at Legends Field during a workout Wednesday: He has a strike zone the size of a fire ant. And he can pull the ball.

title: At Trial of Newarks Former Mayor, Feelings of Loyalty, and of Being Let Down
description: NEWARK  Sharpe James could not help himself.

title: Like a Negotiator, a Camera Finds Middle Ground Between a Point-and-Shoot and an S.L.R.
description: Carrying a digital single-lens reflex camera has long required a certain amount of dedication. These cameras have long been heavier and bulkier and required more accessories  flashes, bags, fishing-style vests  than standard point-and-shoot models.

title: Attention Deficits That May Linger Well Past Childhood
description: A recent groundbreaking brain-imaging study found that children with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder experience a development delay with a distinct biological basis. Investigators at the National Institute of Mental Health discovered that areas of the brains cortex undergo a thinning maturation process about three years later in children with A.D.H.D. than in those without the condition. Areas that integrate sensory information with executive functions like focused attention, remembering things from moment to moment and controlling movement  functions that are often compromised in people with A.D.H.D.  showed the longest lag time.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with a theater review of 27 Rue de Fleurus at Urban Stages, using information provided by a publicist, misidentified the actress shown on the left. She is Susan Haefner  not Sarah Chalfy, another cast member.

title: In Homes Across the Region, Parents Struggle to Find Words for What Spitzer Did
description: Over their dinner table in Maplewood, N.J., Joy and Jeff Yagid tried to answer delicately when their daughter, Bella, 6, asked why her father had remarked that Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York was having a bad day on Monday.

title: Nature, Nurture and Attention Deficit
description: Susan Smalley, Ph.D., is a professor in the department of psychiatry and biobehavioral sciences at the University of California, Los Angeles, Semel Institute for Neuroscience and Human Behavior and director of its Mindful Awareness Research Center. Dr. Smalleys work has a dual focus: the genetics of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder and the use of techniques of mindfulness in promoting well-being.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A report in the Observatory column in Science Times on Tuesday about a study of sea level changes over the last 80 million years misidentified the journal in which the findings appeared. It was Science, not Nature.

title: New Delivery for Hernndez Gives Him a Leg to Stand On
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  There was no formal goodbye. No wake, no memorial service, no chance to pay final respects. For a man of his nobility, it hardly seemed fair. One spring morning, Orlando Hernndez began his windup, raised his left knee to waist level and threw the ball. Then he did it again.

title: Footnotes
description: The prolific playwright Horton Foote turns 92 on Friday. In Chicago, where the Goodman Theater is running a Horton Foote Festival of plays, films and discussions through April 6, he is to appear on Monday night in connection with a screening of his films at the theater. ... The Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College, State University of New York, in Purchase, N.Y., plans to open a satellite museum opposite the New York Public Library in early 2009. Under an agreement with the SUNY College of Optometry, the museum will occupy 3,500 to 5,000 square feet of exhibition space on the ground floor of the colleges building at 33 West 42nd Street . ... Dawn Wells, above, who played the wholesome Mary Ann on Gilligans Island, is serving six months of unsupervised probation after a sheriffs deputy in Idaho arrested her as she was driving home from a surprise birthday party in October, The Associated Press reported. The arresting officer, who described her driving as erratic, said he found half-smoked marijuana joints and two small cases for holding marijuana in the car. Ms. Wells, 69, said she had just given a ride to three hitchhikers and dropped them off when they began smoking. On Feb. 29 she was sentenced to five days in jail, fined $410.50 and placed on probation after pleading guilty to one count of reckless driving. Three misdemeanor counts, including possession of a controlled substance, were dropped.

title: Almost a Dozen Youths Said to Be at House Where Police Say Rape Occurred
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  The three-bedroom house on Hartley Street here was filled with young people  but no adults  on the day that the authorities said three teenage boys raped a 16-year-old girl with a broomstick, a relative of one of the suspects said on Wednesday.

title: Bush Signals Intent to Force Vote in Congress This Year on Colombian Trade Deal
description: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration signaled Wednesday that it would defy the wishes of Congressional Democrats and force a vote this year on a free trade agreement with Colombia, hinting that it would try to gain support for the pact by stoking fears of anti-American sentiment in the region.

title: Warm Welcome for Winner of Iditarod
description: NOME, Alaska  The dogs did not want to stop.

title: Daly Misses a Tee Time and Is Disqualified
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The ever-shifting fortunes of golfs most unconventional player took another nosedive Wednesday when John Daly missed his pro-am tee time and was kicked out of the Arnold Palmer Invitational at Bay Hill.

title: Marquette Again Has Seton Halls Number
description: Barring what would be an unexpected bid from a postseason tournament, Seton Halls season sputtered to an end Wednesday night. The Pirates inability to beat Marquette caught up with them again as they lost for the third time in three games this season against the Golden Eagles.

title: Fruit Trees Suited for Every Yard
description: FRUIT can be grown almost anywhere, but that said, fruit is picky. Particular varieties prefer particular regions.

title: Putting a Hard Number on Retirement
description: ING, the large Dutch financial services company known for its quirky orange logos and latte-dispensing banking cafes, has your number.

title: Felled by Scandal, Spitzer Says Focus Is on His Family
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer, whose rise to political power as a fierce enforcer of ethics in public life was undone by revelations of his own involvement with prostitutes, resigned on Wednesday, becoming the first New York governor to leave office amid scandal in nearly a century.

title: Unwelcome Surprises
description: Confession: I thought electing Eliot Spitzer governor of New York was a really good idea. Now its clear to me why some people refuse to register to vote. You never know.

title: Shuttle Docks at Station
description: The shuttle Endeavour docked with the International Space Station as part of a 16-day mission to bring new components to the oribiting outpost. Meanwhile, experts on the ground have been examining three incidents during the ascent on Tuesday in which bits of debris were seen falling near the shuttle. It is not clear whether any of the debris  detected at less than one second into launching, at nine seconds and at 83 seconds  struck the shuttle. There is speculation that the second object might have been a bird. Teams on the ground will examine images taken with the shuttles robot arm and during a backflip maneuver as the shuttle approached the station, but LeRoy Cain, the head of the mission management team, added, Theres nothing out there that stands out or that were concerned about in any way.

title: 2 Weeks Off for Almost Everyone at Chrysler
description: DETROIT  Chrysler said Thursday that it planned to halt virtually all of its operations for two weeks in July as part of its effort to cut costs and return to profitability.

title: Unions Unveil McCain Attack
description: Even before he officially becomes the Republican nominee, Senator John McCain is facing a general election assault from organized labor.

title: Ferraro Is Unapologetic for Remarks and Ends Her Role in Clinton Campaign
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro resigned Wednesday from Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign finance committee but remained unapologetic for citing Senator Barack Obamas race as the decisive factor in his success.

title: Release Schedule for Movies in 3-D
description: Movies in 3-D scheduled for release, with the studio for each, as compiled by the Rentrak Corporation.

title: To Avert Veto, Council Alters New Electronics Recycling Bill
description: Facing a veto threat from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the City Council on Wednesday called back a bill it passed last month that would have established one of the toughest electronics recycling programs in the country.

title: My Invitation Isnt in the Mail
description: GIORGIO ARMANI does not want me at his fashion shows.

title: U.S. Troops Kill Iraqi Girl; 3 Soldiers Die in Attack
description: BAGHDAD  American soldiers accidentally shot and killed a young Iraqi girl in Diyala Province on Wednesday, and three soldiers were killed in a rocket attack in the southeast, as a wave of deadly violence continued.

title: Meat Packer Admits Slaughter of Sick Cows
description: WASHINGTON  The president of a slaughterhouse at the heart of the largest meat recall denied under oath on Wednesday, but then grudgingly admitted, that his company had apparently introduced sick cows into the hamburger supply.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial on Friday about city workers parking passes misstated the number of metered parking spots in New York. The city government says there are 75,900 metered spots, not 18,500.

title: HUD Secretary Draws Strong Criticism at Hearing
description: WASHINGTON  Several Democratic senators sharply criticized the secretary of housing and urban development on Wednesday, warning that accusations of wrongdoing threatened to undermine his leadership.

title: Tip of the Week: Renaming Digital Photos
description: To rename a bunch of digital photos all at once on a Windows PC, hold down the Control key and click on each file to select them all, then right-click on the first one.

title: Bambi vs. Godzilla 2008
description: On Monday night, I found myself unexpectedly holding the hottest sports ticket in town, watching Pete Sampras play Roger Federer at Madison Square Garden. This was an improvement over every other professional sporting event at the Garden this year; at least these guys were in shape.

title: Syracuse Is Sent Home After Rout by Villanova
description: In the quiet of the Syracuse locker room Wednesday, whispers about the future filled the room. Most years at the Big East Conference tournament, those conversations revolve around seeds, regions and potential opponents in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: New Dinnerware From Daniel Levy
description: Yum, Daniel Levys new dinnerware, is a departure for Mr. Levy, who is known for designing formal porcelain patterns that are popular with brides. With its indigo-blue rim, above, it looks like everyday china, but its casual appearance belies the labor-intensive way it is made. All pieces are finished by hand in Mr. Levys Chelsea studio.

title: Armory Will Again Be Host to Music
description: Clandestinely  or as clandestinely as you can with Mahlers huge Symphony No. 2  an orchestra gathered inside the Park Avenue Armory one day in December for an unusual sound check.

title: Panel Proposes Streamlining Math
description: American students math achievement is at a mediocre level compared with that of their peers worldwide, according to a new report by a federal panel. The panel said that math curriculums from preschool to eighth grade should be streamlined to focus on key skills  the handling of whole numbers and fractions, and certain aspects of geometry and measurement  to prepare students to learn algebra.

title: Mountain Topography as Abstract Art
description: Famous Canadian Mountains, a line of 10 canvas rugs based on topography, was recently introduced by Patricia Baun, a Vancouver designer who owns a company called Maude Dcor. Ms. Baun hand-paints each rug, covers it with sealant and then cuts it to match the footprint of a particular mountain. Topography offered variations in proportion, design and shape that were highly irregular without being contrived, she explained. Although when most people think of painting mountains, they think of something more pictorial, she said, her rugs are abstract, like the 6-by-9-foot Three Sisters ($2,984), right. Sizes range from 4 1/4 by 7 feet (Mt. Tremblant, $1,761) to 8 by 8 feet (Mt. Temple, $3,536). Information: (604) 879-7775 or maudedecor.com.

title: Lessons From the Fall of Spitzer
description: To the Editor:

title: Councilman Accused of Rape Is Said to Be Close to Plea Deal
description: A New York City councilman accused of rape is close to a deal with prosecutors to avoid jail in return for his resigning from office, seeking alcohol abuse treatment and apologizing to the victim, according to two people familiar with the negotiations.

title: Democrats Are at Odds Over Plans for 2 States
description: WASHINGTON  After a week of shadowboxing, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama on Wednesday issued their clearest statements yet on the impasse over the disputed Florida and Michigan primaries.

title: After Eliot Spitzer
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer did exactly the right thing on Wednesday, announcing his resignation after 14 months in office. His departure spares New Yorkers more of this sordid spectacle. And it means that Lt. Gov. David Paterson can now prepare to take over and begin addressing the states many urgent problems.

title: Media Players, Untethered
description: Yeah, yeah, O.K., so the glaciers are melting, polar bears are becoming extinct and oceanfront property will soon open up in Philadelphia. But c'mon, people, try to look at the bright side.

title: Rating Municipal Bonds
description: To the Editor:

title: Garden Q&A
description: Q. Ive read about something called the strawberry tree. Does it grow edible fruit? Will it thrive in Manhattan or southern Connecticut?

title: Cassini Gets a Cool Shower From an Ice-Spewing Moon
description: No other 310-mile-wide ice ball in the solar system is attracting quite the attention as Enceladus, a moon of Saturn.

title: A Slide Leads to a Cut and a Festering Wound
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Two of his players and two of his coaches were ejected Wednesday, but Yankees Manager Joe Girardi insisted his team had not been looking for a fight. In the visiting dugout after Round 2 of a bruising bout with the Tampa Bay Rays, Girardi calmly explained that only one thing upset him.

title: When Imitations Unflattering
description: IN the fashion industrys ongoing debate about knockoffs, two factions  high-end designers and mainstream clothing manufacturers  agree that truly original ideas should be protected. They just cant decide what that means.

title: Video Road Hogs Stir Fear of Internet Traffic Jam
description: Caution: Heavy Internet traffic ahead. Delays possible.

title: Childrens Games and Shows by Subscription, From PBS
description: Next week, preschoolers can watch Curious George and Mister Rogers Neighborhood on their computer screens as part of PBS Kids Play (www.pbskidsplay.org), a subscription-based service that mixes 14 games with clips from these and other shows. After you download the necessary software (a three-megabyte file) for Windows computers, you get free access for 15 days, but then must pay $10 a month or $79 a year.

title: No Charges Against Police in Fatal Shooting of Officer
description: WHITE PLAINS  A grand jury here voted not to indict four Westchester County police officers who were involved in the fatal shooting of an off-duty police officer from nearby Mount Vernon in January, the authorities said on Wednesday.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 12, 2008

title: In Chicago, Tinted Green
description: CHICAGO

title: Sex Diseases in Many Gay Men Go Unfound, Experts Say
description: Many cases of sexually transmitted diseases are escaping detection because gay men are not being tested each year as advised, federal health officials said Wednesday. And if the men do show up, the officials added, many doctors and clinics are not following screening recommendations.

title: Can a Toyota Man Fix Chrysler?
description: DETROIT  Of the big American car companies, Chrysler has a well-earned reputation for extravagant marketing stunts.

title: Choice of Central Banker Is Snarled in Japans Politics
description: TOKYO  A political showdown is blocking Japan from selecting the next leader of its central bank, increasing the chances that the post could remain vacant at a time of widespread financial turmoil.

title: Richard Burke, Founder of Trek Bicycle Company, Is Dead at 73
description: Correction Appended

title: Kicking and Screaming Toward Reform
description: After months of anxiety and arm-twisting, the House has taken the boldest step yet toward ethics reform, creating an independent ethics office. The panel of six nonpartisan outsiders is empowered to field allegations against representatives, refer serious charges for investigation by the House ethics committee, and tell the public what is frivolous and what is not.

title: Solid-State Drives, the Costly Innards of Slim Laptops
description: When Apple unveiled the MacBook Air, much of the fanfare focused on its sleek design. But one of the most interesting things about it was hidden inside: a solid-state drive, the next generation of computer storage.

title: Corrections
description: An article and headline on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Feb. 20 about the development of movie theaters with restaurants and other upscale features misstated the 2007 statistics for admissions to movie theaters in the United States and Canada and referred incorrectly to the status of the industry. Total admissions were 1.4 billion, not 1.39 billion, according to the National Association of Theater Owners. This figure was up 0.36 percent from 2006, not down 4 percent. Consequently attendance was not at a 10-year low, and cinemas are not using these new features to stem attendance losses. (Go to Article)

title: Ogres, Dragons, Medusa and More, All in an Epic on a 4-Inch Screen
description: The hand-held Sony PlayStationPortable game console can barely contain the action-adventure game God of War: Chains of Olympus. With its ogres and dragons, stone temples and massive ancient machinery, the game feels as though at any moment it will burst through the four-inch screen and bring hellfire and destruction to your sofa.

title: The Threat of a Free Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Episcopal Church Votes to Oust Bishop Who Seceded
description: The Episcopal Church moved to remove the bishop of the San Joaquin Diocese in California on Wednesday, in reaction to the dioceses unprecedented decision late last year to secede from the church over theological issues.

title: F.D.A. Panel Votes to Continue Use of Anemia Drugs
For an Operatic Life, Check Out the Composers
description: HOUSTON  Lethal injection. Suicide. Heartbreak. Obsession. And Jake Heggie is only now getting around to his own story.

title: Leaving Vista for Windows XP
description: Q. I recently bought a small laptop for travel but it only came with Windows Vista, which I find troublesome. I love the laptop for its size and would like to keep it, but can I remove Vista and install Windows XP instead?

title: An Anniversary, but Thomas Isnt Celebrating
description: MIAMI  One year ago Wednesday, the Knicks future looked so bright to James L. Dolan that he hastily signed Coach Isiah Thomas to a contract extension and declared, I believe we have clearly seen significant and evident progress.

title: On the Assembly Line, Learning How Things Are Made
description: There have been better titles than Who Knew? With Marshall Brain. It doesnt tell you much beyond the fact that theres someone out there named Marshall Brain. Who knew?

title: Corrections
description: An editorial on Friday about city workers parking passes misstated the number of metered parking spots in New York. The city government says there are 75,900 metered spots, not 18,500.

title: Hirschfelds Art to Guide Students
description: A program exploring the arts through the lines and shapes of the artist Al Hirschfeld, above, was announced on Tuesday by the Al Hirschfeld Foundation and the New York City Department of Education. Called the Al Hirschfeld Project  after the artist most famous for his theatrical caricatures in The New York Times  the program will help public school arts teachers (grades K-12) educate students about the performing arts over the last century. The Hirschfeld curriculum was developed to complement the Department of Educations Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts, a set of standards outlining what students should know and be able to achieve in dance, music, theater and visual arts through high school.

title: To Stretch or Not to Stretch? The Answer Is Elastic
description: NEWS about stretching seems to come in waves. Stretch as part of your warm-up. No, stretch after your workout. No, dont even bother stretching. Or the doozy: Even if you think you like it, its been oversold as a way to prevent injury or improve performance.

title: U.S. Image Abroad Hard to Fix, Longtime Ally Says
description: PARIS  Bernard Kouchner, the foreign minister of France and a longtime humanitarian, diplomatic and political activist, said this week that whoever succeeds President Bush might restore something of the United States battered image and standing overseas but that the magic is over.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about the victory by Bill Foster in a special election in Illinois for a seat in the House of Representatives misstated Mr. Fosters business involvement with a theater lighting company. He co-founded the company with his brother Fred; he was not the sole founder. (The error first appeared last Thursday in an article previewing the election.)

title: French Trader Released After Questioning
description: PARIS  An employee of the banking giant Socit Gnrale has been released after French authorities questioned him in connection with a trading scandal that cost the bank nearly 5 billion euros or $7.2 billion, a spokeswoman for the Paris prosecutor said Thursday.

title: Idol Hands Rivals a Tuneful Defeat
description: More than 31 million viewers watched the top 12 finalists perform on American Idol Tuesday night, down slightly from previous seasons, but still attracting more viewers to Fox than all the other broadcast networks combined, according to Nielsen. New viewers tuned in every half-hour of the performances, from 25.6 million at 8 to 31.6 million at 9:30 p.m. The two-hour broadcast averaged 29.3 million viewers and a 10.8 rating in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. Behind Idol, NBCs programs fared best. The Biggest Loser averaged 7.7 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., and a repeat of Law & Order: Special Victims Unit was the second most popular show of the night, averaging 9.4 million viewers at 10 p.m. for NBC. On CBS, a repeat of NCIS attracted 8.6 million viewers, but many tuned out Big Brother at 9 and Jericho at 10 (5.9 million each). ABCs sitcoms drew fewer than 5 million viewers, but the network showed life at 10 p.m. when a new installment of the What Would You Do? hidden-camera investigation show averaged 7.5 million viewers.

title: With Wires Out of Sight, the Bunny Slippers Under the Bed Will Be Visible
description: The area on and around many modern bedside tables has become a rats nest of charger wires for phones and other gadgets. The Idapt intends to change that with a unique triple charger that just might also complement the duvet cover.

title: Out of the Shadows, a Camelot of Italian Knights and Daring Deeds
description: BATTAGLIA TERME, Italy  In his heyday the 16th-century painter Giovanni Battista Zelotti was so well regarded that he was handpicked by Titian to work in the Ducal Palace in Venice alongside Paolo Veronese.

title: A Real and Treatable Disorder: A.D.H.D.
description: Dr. Joseph Biederman is a professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School and the director of a program on attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. A staunch advocate for the early diagnosis and treatment of A.D.H.D., Dr. Biederman identifies five things all adults and children with the disorder should know.

title: Collapse of Salmon Stocks Endangers Pacific Fishery
description: Federal officials have indicated that they are likely to close the Pacific salmon fishery from northern Oregon to the Mexican border because of the collapse of crucial stocks in Californias major watershed.

title: Some Advice From the Sidelines
description: IF the expense of a remodeling coach is out of the question, experts say there are still ways for homeowners to avoid the worst nightmares of renovation, and save aggravation, time and money.

title: After Winning the Format War, Blu-rays Future Looks Bright
description: I GOT the lecture as a 10-year-old, from the father of one of my friends. This is the future, he said, waving his arms enthusiastically toward the squat box resting on a shelf in his living room. He had never before spoken to me with such fervor about anything, even his children. Mark my words, kid, he grinned. This was the best $1,000 I ever spent.

title: Ski, Bike, Boat, Run
description: Here's how to burn off some of that spring-fever energy (or stave off some meltdown melancholy): In mountain towns, offbeat multi-sport races have become an increasingly popular way to celebrate the changing seasons. Typically, these events combine the best of both winter and summer sports, with the conditions often sloppy, sunny and soggy.

title: Backyards, Beware: An Orchard Wants Your Spot
