description: GERRY GRUNSFELD, a genial 32-year-old lawyer who grew up in England and now lives in a narrow two-story house in Midwood, Brooklyn, has the kind of backyard youre not sure whether to envy or pity.

title: If Youre Young and Not Fainthearted
description: MONSTROUS cinema villains are not, as a rule, inspired dressers. They usually go for some moldering garment that suggests they shopped in a victims dirty laundry pile rather than the racks of Jeffrey New York.

title: Subdued in Color, Mysterious in Mood
description: BEING an undercover Critical Shopper calls for some stealth. You must pretend you have six credit cards and wear a confident expression while you stare at lovely, out-of-your-league items. Then, when no one is looking, you surreptitiously scribble your impecunious thoughts in a little notebook.

title: Corrections
description: An article and headline on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Feb. 20 about the development of movie theaters with restaurants and other upscale features misstated the 2007 statistics for admissions to movie theaters in the United States and Canada and referred incorrectly to the status of the industry. Total admissions were 1.4 billion, not 1.39 billion, according to the National Association of Theater Owners. This figure was up 0.36 percent from 2006, not down 4 percent. Consequently attendance was not at a 10-year low, and cinemas are not using these new features to stem attendance losses.

title: What a Stars Orbiting Disk Is Made Of
description: The winking star has sand in its eye.

title: Lazare Ponticelli, Frances Last Veteran of World War I, Is Dead at 110
description: Lazare Ponticelli, who outlived more than 8.4 million other soldiers who fought under the French flag in World War I to become Frances last living veteran of the war intended to end all wars, died Wednesday at his home in Kremlin-Bictre, a Paris suburb. He was 110.

title: Paterson Faces Early Test With State Budget
description: ALBANY  Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson said Thursday afternoon that meeting the looming state budget deadline is the most pressing task he will face upon assuming office as governor on Monday and that he plans to work through the weekend to get up to speed on budget negotiations.

title: Construction Worker Killed as Wall Collapses in Brooklyn
description: A construction worker digging a foundation in Brooklyn was killed on Wednesday when part of a wall from the building next door collapsed on him.

title: Telling His Own Tale of Passions and Piety
description: Anne Rice silenced doubting Thomases when she wrote Christ the Lord: Out of Egypt, a novel narrated by Jesus of Nazareth. Whatever that book was, it wasnt another semi-pornographic vampire story. It was a genuinely stirring display of piety, rich with the fruits of Ms. Rices copious research into the Gospels. If her 7-year-old narrator sounded oddly preoccupied with matters of dcor and ritual, that 2005 novel was still stirringly sincere.

title: Drawing Lots for Health Care
description: BEND, Ore.  Last month, right after he had the heart attack and then the heart surgery and then started receiving the medical bills that so far have topped $200,000, Melvin Tsosies joined the 91,000 other residents of Oregon who had signed up for a lottery that provides health insurance to people who lack it.

title: Suggested Read: Racing Against Death
description: Lance Mackey crossed the finish line first in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race yesterday, the second year in a row that he's won the race. It's kind of a family tradition -- both his brother and his father have won the race through Alaska, which this year awarded the winner $69,000 and a new truck.

title: Gazprom and Ukraine Detail Gas Settlement
description: MOSCOW  Gazprom, the worlds largest producer of natural gas, and Ukraine have ironed out details of a settlement announced last week that narrowly averted a shutoff of some Russian natural gas supplies to European consumers, Gazprom said Thursday in a statement.

title: For an Aspiring Singer, a Harsher Spotlight
description: She left a broken home on the Jersey Shore at 17 and came to New York City to work the nightclubs as a rhythm and blues singer. Now, at 22, she is the unwitting, and as yet unseen, star of the seamy drama that is the downfall of Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York.

title: Greece Hit by Labor Strikes
description: ATHENS  Professional workers and members of Greeces largest trade union staged a three-hour work stoppage Wednesday, joining striking electrical workers and garbage collectors in their protest of legislation to overhaul the countrys pension system.

title: Correction: My Root Canal? Its a Blur
description: An article last Thursday about new sedation techniques used by dentists misspelled the brand name of a sleeping pill. It is Halcion, not Halcyon.

title: A Sand Dollar Riddle
description: What did the baby sand dollar say to itself when it smelled a fish that would like to eat it?

title: Bush Warns House on Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON  With the House moving toward a vote on electronic surveillance legislation that the White House has said falls far short of its requirements, President Bush warned legislators strongly Thursday morning against passing what he called a partisan bill that will undermine American security.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about the politics of a meat recall, misidentified the location of the Westland/Hallmark Meat Company, where an animal rights organization filmed cows being abused. It is in Chino in Southern California, between Los Angeles and San Bernardino; it is not in Chico, in the northern Sacramento Valley.)

title: Selected Studies: A.D.H.D.
description: Government agencies, universities, doctors and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Old Dog, New Trick: Acupuncture
description: WHEN my dog Otto was a puppy he behaved like an idiot, even for a Labrador retriever.

title: What to Ask About A.D.H.D.
description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening  and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: Alan Jackson in First Place
description: A new album from the country star Alan Jackson toppled Janet Jackson from the top spot on the Billboard chart. Mr. Jacksons Good Time (Arista Nashville), sold 119,000 copies, Nielsen SoundScan estimated, dropping Ms. Jacksons Discipline (Island Def Jam) into third place on sales of 57,000 albums. Climbing one notch from last week, Jack Johnsons Sleep Through the Static captured second place with sales of 65,000 copies. The rock band Flogging Molly and its new album, Float (SideOneDummy), took fourth place with sales of 48,000 and the Black Cowes Warpaint (Silver Arrow), selling 46,000 copies in its debut, was No. 5.

title: Amid Heavy Subjects, Subtle Challenges
description: On Tuesday night at the Highline Ballroom you could almost get inside Jos Gonzlezs guitar, and it was loud in there. For a musician whose appeal seems to be an even, responsible, enlightened serenity  dont-wake-the-baby music  he was nice and forceful, just alone with his instrument, his voice dry and his guitar laden with echo. Nylon-string guitars often produce a rounded sound, but with his economical, decisive, percussive strikes he made a sound like an ax splitting a log.

title: Israeli Raid in West Bank Imperils Talk of Truce
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli undercover troops killed four Palestinian militants in the West Bank city of Bethlehem on Wednesday, shattering a five-day lull in violence and threatening Egyptian efforts to mediate a cease-fire.

title: Bridging Eras: What Palmer Did, Woods Is Doing
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  To arrive at golfs present requires a stroll through its past, a walk to remember just how closely linked the games eras and stars are.

title: Calling in the House Therapist
description: KRISTIN LUND and her husband, Peter Coccoluto, did not have the nerve to stand up to their architect.

title: Do as He Said
description: The last time I saw Eliot Spitzer, he encouraged me to write about his work involving prostitution. So here goes.

title: New Hope for the Rich
description: Americans are getting poorer. In 2007, home equity fell below 50 percent for the first time on record since 1945. Total equity also fell for three straight quarters through last December. Adjusted for inflation, the annual income of the typical working household is still below its peak before the last recession, in 2001. That means the Bush-era expansion is on track to be the first since the government began keeping records in the 1960s in which household income fails to hit a new high.

title: Report on F.B.I. Use of Personal Data
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Bureau of Investigation has made significant progress in how it handles the personal information of Americans as it pursues terrorists, but the agency has a way to go to stamp out all procedural abuses, a Justice Department report said on Thursday.

title: Environmental Agency Tightens Smog Standards
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency announced a modest tightening of the smog standard on Wednesday evening, overruling the unanimous advice of its scientific advisory council for a more protective standard.

title: Everything (Even Ballet) Is Up to Date in Kansas City
description: The audience looked like a Whos Who of noted choreographers, dancers and company directors when the Kansas City Ballet opened on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. This was not surprising. The company has a glittering lineage at odds with New Yorkers notion that little of value in the arts goes on west of the Hudson River. That heritage could be felt in the three ballets at the Joyce, all created for the troupes 50th anniversary, this season.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. What should I do with the tiny foyer in my studio apartment?

title: Another Speeding Wreck
description: The governor was a young man in a hurry, a rocket of energy, chutzpah and ambition who surprised almost no one by going so far so fast. A lot of people thought he had the potential to go further still.

title: Democrats Face Racial Issue Again
description: After the Democratic primary in South Carolina turned racially divisive in January, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama essentially declared a truce and put a stop to fighting between their camps. But this week, race has once again begun casting a pall over the battle between the two.

title: Ex-Military in Tow, Democrats Make Case
description: CHICAGO  As the Democratic presidential race enters a prolonged period of intensity, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and her advisers have argued that Senator Barack Obama has not crossed the threshold to serve as commander in chief.

title: Carlyle Fund Expects Assets Will Be Seized
description: LONDON  Shares of Carlyle Capital plunged on Thursday, losing most of their value, after the company said it expected its lenders to promptly take over all its assets after discussions with banks to refinance the fund failed.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the rising price of diesel misstated the amount of diesel and gasoline used by Americans in 2007. They used about 3.395 billion barrels of gasoline, not 3.395 billion gallons, and about 1.55 billion barrels of diesel and heating oil, not 1.55 billion gallons. (At 42 gallons to the barrel, the correct figures in gallons are 143 billion gallons of gasoline and 65 billion gallons of diesel and heating oil.) The article also misquoted Jim Frieze, equipment director for O & S Trucking of Springfield, Mo., who commented on the driving practices of some truckers. He said that gearshifts that take the engine over 1,800 r.p.m.  not 8,000 r.p.m.  waste fuel.

title: Pettitte Insists Elbow Soreness Is No Reason for Concern
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Andy Pettitte knows the difference between serious and minor elbow trouble. His issue Wednesday, he insisted, was nothing to be worried about.

title: Joseph Weizenbaum, Famed Programmer, Is Dead at 85
description: Joseph Weizenbaum, whose famed conversational computer program, Eliza, foreshadowed the potential of artificial intelligence, but who grew skeptical about the potential for technology to improve the human condition, died on March 5 in Grben, Germany. He was 85.

title: F.B.I. Made Blanket Demands for Phone Records
description: WASHINGTON  Senior officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation repeatedly approved the use of blanket records demands to justify the improper collection of thousands of phone records, according to officials briefed on the practice.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Langen Journal article last Thursday, about a three-star restaurant in Langen, Germany, that reflects a surprising increase in the countrys haute cuisine misidentified an eating-induced malady attributed partly to the worsening nutritional habits of low-income Germans. It is Type 2 diabetes  not juvenile diabetes, also known as Type 1 diabetes, which is believed caused by an immune system disorder.

title: Astro Boy Goes Digital
description: Papyless, an online book store in Japan, announced plans to sell digital versions of the work of Osamu Tezuka, known as the father of manga, Agence France-Presse reported. The works include Astro Boy, the atomic-powered robot, created in 1951 for the pages of a comic book, and Black Jack, the adventures of a doctor that drew on the medical training of Mr. Tezuka, who died in 1989. Astro Boy was developed into a cartoon, which was imported to the United States in 1963, and a CGI version is scheduled to hit the big screen in 2009. The online stories, at papy.co.jp/, will be available beginning on Tuesday and will cost about $1 to read a volume over two days.

title: Pearls That Start, and End, With Grit
description: DONT pearls deserve something better? Despite numerous attempts over the years to disentangle them from their good-girl image, they have resisted. Even Audrey Hepburn, recklessly tossing about that magnificent rope of pearls in Breakfast at Tiffanys, could not dislodge them from the altar of good taste.

title: Stretching for Answers
description: Most athletes remain convinced that stretching helps, Gina Kolota writes in The Times today, and the popularity of yoga has created some social pressure to show flexibility. But the truth, Kolata writes, "is that after dozens of studies and years of debate, no one really knows whether stretching helps, harms, or does anything in particular for performance or injury rates."

title: Nets Overcome James to Halt a Six-Game Skid
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Richard Jefferson tailed LeBron James all game, often poking his forearm into Jamess back and wrapping his arms around James when the referees were not looking. James scored 42 points anyway.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the special Museums section on Wednesday about museum directors who leave after the completion of expansion projects described the status of two directors incorrectly. Marc Wilson, director of the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, Mo., and Graham Beal, director of the Detroit Institute of Arts, have not left their positions.

title: Christensen Novel Wins Prize
description: The Great Man, a novel written by Kate Christensen and published by Doubleday, won the 2008 Pen/ Faulkner Award for Fiction. Described as the largest peer-juried prize for fiction in the United States, the award brings its winner $15,000. Ms. Christensen, whose book about a painter and the women in his life was chosen from nearly 350 novels and short-story collections written by Americans and published in the United States in 2007, will receive her prize at the 28th annual Pen/ Faulkner Award ceremony on May 10 at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington. Prizes of $5,000 each will go to four finalists: Annie Dillard for The Maytrees (HarperCollins); David Leavitt for The Indian Clerk (Bloomsbury USA); T. M. McNally for The Gateway: Stories (Southern Methodist University Press) and Ron Rash for Chemistry and Other Stories (Picador USA). ... The Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award goes this year to Sonya Hartnett, an Australian who has written nearly 20 novels for children, young people and adults, Agence France-Presse reported. The prize, including $822,000, was established by the Swedish government and named for the creator of Pippi Longstocking. It will be presented by Crown Princess Victoria of Sweden in Stockholm on May 28.

title: This Defense Wont Rest
description: Chatham, N.J.

title: Infidelity and Other Lyric Amusements
description: In art, as in life, immorality and lust were on display on Tuesday night, at Weill Recital Hall. But there was plenty of humor and little of the tragedy of real-life marital indiscretions during the premieres of two short comic operas presented by the New York Festival of Song.

title: Its Easy, and Expensive, to Forget About Old Equipment
description: DOES the Panasonic phone that is gathering dust in your basement still work? Where did you store the Dell monitor your brother gave you after he acquired a wide-screen Samsung? Whatever happened to your original computer  the one you used to write the first draft of the Great American Novel?

title: In Harlem, Delight Over a Favorite Sons Rise to Governor
description: Among people in central Harlem, where Barack Obama posters seem to be taped to nearly every store window and where many residents say they feel disconnected from political power, there is a palpable mixture of pride and fascination that one of their own is to become governor of New York.

title: Be a Fashion Insider or Just Look Like One
description: THREE tidbits of recent fashion news that may have escaped your attention:

title: For a Speech Like No Other, a News Media Extravaganza
description: The white door in the corner opened and, for the second time in three days, Gov. Eliot Spitzer poked through and took a couple of long, jerky steps toward the lectern.

title: Now Rated R (for Resale)
description: IN Tom Judsons house in upstate New York there is just one piece of memorabilia that would, to a casual observer, give any indication that he has had a career in entertainment.

title: Race and Revenge in Lives of Father and Injured Son
description: Poor Boys Game is a movie built around a boxing match, but its most powerful scenes involve no jabs or hooks. They are the quiet, almost wordless moments between Danny Glover, playing a dockworker named George, and K. C. Collins, playing his brain-damaged son, Charlie.

title: Lasik Surgery: When the Fine Print Applies to You
description: I WAS vain.

title: Mayor Offers Permit Parking to Help Traffic Pricing Plan
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Wednesday proposed a system of parking permits that would reserve on-street spots for residents of some neighborhoods.

title: British Budget Raises Taxes and Borrowing
description: LONDON  The British chancellor of the exchequer, Alistair Darling, cut his economic growth forecast for this year in a budget speech Wednesday that was nonetheless criticized by the opposition Conservatives and some economists as too optimistic.

title: World Cup Title in Reach for Lindsey Vonn
description: BORMIO, Italy  Lindsey Vonn was handed a marking pen by an official, who pointed toward a poster commemorating these World Cup Grand Finals. Vonn signed her name along with Follow Your Dreams.

title: Japan: Consumer Confidence Falls
description: In February, Japans consumer confidence dropped to its lowest level in five years as rising oil prices and weak wages sapped households spending power. The sentiment index fell to 36.1 last month from 37.5 in January, the Cabinet Office said. It was the lowest level since March 2003, when the unemployment rate was close to a postwar high. The governor of the Bank of Japan, Toshihiko Fukui, above, and his board agreed last month that stagnant wages and deteriorating consumer sentiment might adversely affect the nations cycle of growth, according to meeting minutes published Wednesday.

title: Stronger Rules for Mortgages Are Proposed
description: WASHINGTON  The nations top economic policymakers, hoping to prevent a repeat of the excesses that led to the mortgage bubble and bust, on Thursday proposed a broad series of reforms aimed at tightening oversight of financial institutions.

title: A Simple Fix for Abraded Keys
description: Q. Is there any remedy for worn-off keyboard letters? Ive had this keyboard for less than a year, and already Ive eroded several letters.

title: YouTube Coming to TV, With TiVo the Gateway
description: Pick up the remote, turn on the television and watch YouTube.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The TV Watch column on Wednesday, about coverage of the Eliot Spitzer scandal, referred incompletely to the departure of Mike Barnicle from The Boston Globe in 1998. In addition to having been accused of plagiarism, he was also suspected of having fabricated material in a column for The Globe. (Mr. Barnicle was cited in the column with other cable television commentators who have weathered their own scandals.)

title: Argentina Agrees to Guarantee Natural Gas Supply to Chile
description: Chiles National Energy Commission said Argentina had an agreement to provide Chile with sufficient natural gas so its supply for commercial and residential use would be uninterrupted, particularly during the winter months. Last winter, Argentina, facing an energy crisis, cut its gas supply to Chile, straining the two countries relations.

title: Liechtenstein Issues Warrant for Tax Informant
description: FRANKFURT  Liechtenstein has issued an international arrest warrant for a man suspected of selling stolen banking data to German authorities that formed the basis of a vast tax evasion scandal.

title: Bill to Propose Expanded U.S. Backing of Home Loans
description: An influential congressman is expected to offer a plan on Thursday that would provide federal backing to hundreds of thousands of home loans.

title: New Hampshire Voters Cling to a Legacy
description: The New England town meeting may seem like an anachronism, but it has not lost its appeal in New Hampshire.

title: Cyclists Trial May Foreshadow Perjury Case Against Bonds
description: The first trial in connection with the five-and-a-half-year investigation of the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative appears to be one and a half weeks away.

title: Health Report Raises Dispute Over Great Lakes Pollution
description: WASHINGTON  Top federal health officials said Wednesday that they had asked the Institute of Medicine, the governments premier medical adviser, to referee a dispute over a report suggesting that pollution in the Great Lakes region may have serious health consequences for people who live there, including infant mortality and breast cancer.

title: Warehouse Sale at Duane
description: Duane, a TriBeCa institution known for its for midcentury modern furniture, will hold a warehouse sale beginning next Wednesday. Merchandise includes vintage tables, chairs and lamps, at discounts of up to 70 percent off retail prices. A white Murano glass table lamp from the 1970s is marked down to $850 from $1,500 (above), and a 1960s Saarinen coffee table from Knoll with a round white marble top is reduced to $1,800 from $3,800. Other pieces include 1950s Drexel side tables with leather tops ($2,000 for a pair) and 1960s metal side chairs, painted gold ($4,000 for the pair). Through March 30 (except for Sunday, March 23) at 184 Duane Street (Hudson Street), (212) 625-8066.

title: The Road to Dystopia
description: The search for a silver bullet to slay illegal immigration continues. Hard-liners are turning the country upside down looking for it.

title: Million-Dollar Prize Given to Cosmologist Priest
description: The $1.6 million 2008 Templeton Prize, the richest award made to an individual by a philanthropic organization, was given Wednesday to Michael Heller, 72, a Polish Roman Catholic priest, cosmologist, and philosopher who has spent his life asking, and perhaps more impressively, answering, questions like Does the universe need to have a cause?

title: Court Reduces Jury Award to Woman Hit by Subway Train
description: A woman who was hit by a subway train while stooping to pick up her Bible from a Manhattan station platform is entitled to damages, but less than half of what a jury had awarded her, an appellate court ruled on Tuesday.

title: A Slim, Handy Console Table
description: Pivot, a console table with a slight profile, has a flexible fanlike structure that allows its drawers to open simultaneously. Each drawer is slightly taller in back, so it catches on the piece above, holding it in place; the back of the table attaches to a screw drilled into the wall. Shay Alkalay, the product designer who created the table with Yael Mer, his partner at Raw-Edges Design Studio in London, said he envisions it in an entrance hall. You put in your eyeglasses and your mobile phone and your keys, he said, and in the morning, when youre really rushed, you can save time by opening both drawers at once. Pivot is 40 inches high and 31 inches wide, and comes in various shades of lacquered oak ($2,200) and in natural walnut ($2,350), at M2L, 215 East 58th Street, (212) 832-8222.

title: Mental Health Parity
description: To the Editor:

title: Scouting the Bigger East Conference
description: This is how much the Big East Conference has grown: Back in the old days, there was a dismal little game between the eighth and ninth teams, the two bottom teams, on a lost and lonely Wednesday night, just for the right to carry on.

title: Lamenting a Lost Trust, and Lost Opportunities
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzers candidacy attracted professionals and students, union leaders and retirees, progressives and conservatives. People switched careers for him, crossed party lines for him and gave him something far more simple yet just as precious: their votes. They thought of Mr. Spitzer as almost a crusader, someone whose zeal to clean up Albany was more than just hype.

title: With Theaters Barely Digital, Studios Push 3-D
description: LAS VEGAS  Coming soon, and coming straight at you: houseflies in astronaut suits, Brendan Fraser boldly exploring the earths core and an animated, nearly 50-foot-tall she-monster with Reese Witherspoons voice.

title: Giants Sign Carr to Back Up Manning
description: In a move that could have signaled a quarterback controversy a year ago, the Giants signed David Carr, a former No. 1 overall draft choice, to play behind Eli Manning, another former No. 1 pick.

title: Islands Treasure, the Dollar, Lures Venezuelans
description: WILLEMSTAD, Curaao  Stroll down Columbusstraat. Enter the smoke-filled lobby of the San Marco Hotel and Casino. Proceed up a flight of stairs to the front desk. Dial Room 106. Bring a credit card issued in Venezuela.

title: Dean Potter, BASE-Jumper
description: A 2008 profile of extreme athlete and technical climber Dean Potter shows his determination to perfect baselining.

title: Your Comments on my Spitzer Column
description: My Thursday column is about Eliot Spitzer and, more broadly, how we should approach prostitution. I argue that the evidence suggests that legalization has not worked well, and that the Swedish model of going after johns may be the best bet. Id welcome your comments. And any Swedes or Dutch out there? What do you find?

title: California Dreaming
description: After Cal struggled to shake away from Washington, the Bears quickly turned their attention to U.C.L.A. With only 17 hours until their next game, the they had little choice.

title: Respond to Todays Column: Unwelcome Surprises
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Mar. 13 column.

title: Going Gonzo?
description: Its been a pretty sleepy day here at Madison Square Garden, all things considered.

title: An Unknown Future, and a Quiet Exit
description: Bubble teams add the intrigue to conference tournaments. Bubble coaches add the behind-the-scenes discomfort. The tournaments often just delay an inevitable firing, or muddle the possibilities of a coaching change.

title: Hello BlackBerry, Meet the iPhone
description: Before you start reading this, a word of warning: this column is about the iPhone. If youre one of those people who are sick and tired of hearing about the iPhone, then scroll on while you still can.

title: A World of Art
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Italy's Contemporary Art Scene
description: A look at what's happening in cities across Italy.

title: Boring press conference, telling moment
description: A large percentage of the media walked out of the very well attended official FIA press conference at Melbourne today with the same word on their lips: Boring.

title: Bill Clinton Has Gained a Super Wing Man
description: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: New Yorks Governor Eliot Spitzer resigned today and to make things official, Governor Spitzer had to write a letter of resignation to New Yorks Secretary of State. Out of habit, Spitzer addressed the letter, Dear Penthouse.

title: Like Dinner With the Spitzers
description: Aired Wednesday night on CBS: Last night - what a horrible audience. And I really dont like talking about people when theyre gone, but, oh, I mean, its not so much that they were horrible, they were just quiet. I mean, my God, it was like dinner at the Spitzers.

title: No Bias! Funny!
description: Is Saturday Night Live pro-Hillary? In todays Times, Lorne Michaels says you must be joking  most of the staff is pro-Obama. Still, the debate skit that presented Mrs. Clinton (Amy Poehler) as victim of biased media pulled one of its punches:

title: A Dyspeptic Coyote in Charge of Bunny Feeding
description: Fresh late night reader comedy (use the comment link below):

title: Dude, Catch Me  Im Falling!
Shareholder Activists Take to the Web
description: Activist investors are stepping up their use of the Web to push for change at companies, Compliance Week wrote in a recent article.

title: Electronic Arts Starts Tender Offer for Take-Two
description: Electronic Arts, the video game maker, began a $2 billion tender offer for shares in Take-Two Interactive on Thursday, officially marking its hostile effort to acquire Take-Two, the maker of the blockbuster Grand Theft Auto franchise.

title: Azure and Bridgescale Buy Internet Provider
description: Azure Capital Partners and Bridgescale Partners, two West Coast venture capital firms, said they had acquired NeoNova Network Services, an Internet service provider in rural areas.

title: A Shift for a Possible Buffett Successor
description: There is a job change coming for an executive whom investors say could become the next Warren E. Buffett.

title: GO Capital Halts Fund Redemptions
description: GO Capital Asset Management temporarily halted redemptions from its Global Opportunities Fund, in what Bloomberg News said was at least the seventh hedge fund in the past month forced to take steps to protect itself from market fluctuations.

title: Love for Deals Bound Diller and Malone, Court Is Told
description: The first hint of drama in the dispute between John C. Malones Liberty Media and Barry Dillers IAC/InterActiveCorp came on Wednesday, the third day of a trial that turns on whether Mr. Dillers plan to split IAC into five companies can survive a challenge by Mr. Malone.

title: Liechtenstein Issues Warrant for Tax Informant
description: Liechtenstein has issued an international arrest warrant for a man suspected of selling stolen banking data to German authorities that formed the basis of a vast tax evasion scandal.

title: JPMorgans Dimon Says Recession May Be Upon U.S.
description: Jumping into the are-we-arent-we-in-a-recession debate, JPMorgan Chases chief executive, James Dimon, told a group of economists in Washington on Wednesday that the United States is likely in recession already and the housing market is expected to deteriorate further.

title: What If Yahoos Earnings Disappoint?
description: While some Yahoo investors might be waiting for a richer bid from Microsoft, some industry observers have been speculating that the software giant might be waiting for its opportunity to table a lower bid.

title: House Bill Could Cast a Cloud Over Visa I.P.O.
description: As Visa prepares its $19 billion initial public offering for next week, Washington is mulling a move that could put a significant dent in the rosy outlook of the offering, The New York Post reported.

title: Deal Gossip on Jossip
description: Jossip Initiative, the company that owns the mediacentric Web site jossip.com and other ventures, is on the block and Conde Nast may be a potential buyer, The New York Post reported.

title: Blackstones Golden One: Schwarzman Is Paid $350 Million
description: Heres another number to ponder: $350 million

title: Blue River to Liquidate Hedge Fund
description: Blue River Asset Managements main municipal-bond hedge fund, which reportedly previously held more than $1 billion in assets, is liquidating after a harsh sell-off in the bond market, Reuters said.

title: CRH Cements Deal for Pavestone
description: CRH, a maker and distributor of building materials, agreed to buy the Pavestone Group for $540 million to expand in concrete landscaping products.

title: WeGame Lands $3 Million from V.C.s, Report Says
description: San Francisco based WeGame, described as a YouTube for gamers seems to be off to a solid start since opening last month.

title: Microsoft Buys Virtualization Start-Up
description: The latest in a spate of deals for virtualization start-ups is Microsofts acquisition of Kidaro, an Israeli developer of desktop virtualization software for enterprises.

title: Drake May Liquidate Its Hedge Funds
description: Drake Management, a New York based-firm started by former BlackRock money managers, told investors on Wednesday it is considering liquidating all three of its hedge funds, including its largest, the $3 billion Global Opportunities fund.

title: Blackstone Said to Jump on Titagarh Wagons Ahead of I.P.O.
description: The Blackstone Group has picked up a minority stake in Titagarh Wagons, an India-based railway freight wagon manufacturer, for 672 rupees per share in a pre-I.P.O. placement, The Economic Times reported.

title: Kawasaki Launches New Media Start-Up
description: Guy Kawasaki, Apples former mega-evangelist and well-known Silicon Valley entrepreneur, announced on Tuesday the launch of his second media start-up, Alltop.

title: Regulators May Raise Scrutiny of Banks Capital
description: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke and other regulators will propose tougher scrutiny of banks capital in a report on lessons from the mortgage crisis, according to The Los Angeles Times.

title: Target in Talks to Sell $4 Billion in Credit Card Loans
description: The discount retailer Target said on Wednesday that it was in talks with an investment partner to sell an undivided interest in about half of its credit card receivables for about $4 billion.

title: Carlyle Capital on the Verge of Collapse
description: Carlyle Capital, an affiliate of the Carlyle Group, the private equity investor, said on Thursday it was in default on margin calls of more than $400 million and said its lenders would likely take possession of its remaining assets.

title: Scent Notes | Eau de Shalimar  by Guerlain
description: The oriental category of perfumes is basically defined as scents built on two materials, vanilla and labdanum. Vanilla is slightly problematic; the 1960s turned it into a sort of hippie clich. Then theres labdanum, a natural resin from a Mediterranean bush that smells quite strongly like a dock workers armpit. Shalimar, created in 1925 by the perfumer Jacques Guerlain, is historically one of the most important perfumes ever made as it is arguably the progenitor of the entire category of parfums gourmands (culinary perfumes). But Shalimar is also a true oriental, which means vanilla plus labdanum, and that in turn means that Guerlain faces the challenge of selling this great early 20th-century work of art in the 21st-century global marketplace.

title: The Early Word: Off the Trail
description: Could this be? A rare day off the campaign trail? Hillary Rodham Clinton, Barack Obama and John McCain havent all put their campaigns on hold since when, Christmas?

title: Suspect Killed Students at Duke and U.N.C., Police Say
description: Update, 9:38 p.m. Mr. Lovett was also charged in the death of Abhijit Mahato, a Duke University graduate student killed in January, according to CNN and The News & Observer.

title: Core competence
description: Carlyle Group should have stuck to what it knows. Its great at the merchant of death thing; at investment banking, not so much:

title: AOLs Shopping Spree Continues With Bebo
description: Can AOL buy its way out of its troubles?

title: The Morning After: Coverage of Spitzers Resignation
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzers resignation  the culmination of a dizzying fall from grace  has made the front pages of newspapers worldwide. The New York Times, which on Monday broke the story of the governors involvement as a client in a prostitution ring, has a front-page overview by David Kocieniewski and Danny Hakim of Mr. Spitzers decision to resign, leaving his lieutenant governor, David A. Paterson, in charge effective Monday.

title: The Curse of AOL
description: UPDATE: Myer Berlow, who built AOLs interactive marketing group, posted a comment below that offers a different view of history.

title: When a Brain Scientist Suffers a Stroke
description: As a Harvard-trained neuroanatomist, Jill Bolte Taylor has always known more about brains than most people. But when a brain hemorrhage triggered her own stroke, she suddenly had a front-row seat on the deterioration of the brain.

title: Pro-Clinton? SNL Says Youre Joking
description: Bill Carter reports:

title: Has ER Jumped the Shark?
description: Should ER stay or should it go?

title: No Easy Answers
description: Philosophers like to debate the trolley problem, in which they try to decide if its ethical to kill one innocent man to save five others from a runaway streetcar. Thats fun and games for philosophers, but heres a problem from the real world. Following the genocide in Rwanda in 1994 in which 800,000 people were murdered in 100 days, the victimized Tutsis rose up and chased the killers, along with 2 million of their Hutu tribesmen, out of the country. Now the Hutus were camped along the border, and dying by the thousands each day from starvation and disease. You are the United Nations representative charged with assisting these desperate refugees. But the individuals who control the camps are the very people who committed the genocide, and since any relief you provide has to flow through them, your help necessarily increases their authority. Whats more, they are hoping to return to their country and complete the genocidal work they began. Other humanitarian agencies are unwilling to aid the Hutus, even though it means that tens of thousands more may die, so you are their only hope. What do you do?

title: Seeing a Man About a Dog
description: Wednesday morning in Times Square a small crowd gathered in the cool shadow of ABC Studios to watch Michael Strahan, defensive end for the Super Bowl champion New York Giants, drive a car.

title: Headlines you just have to click on
description: Samurai-Sword Makers Reactor Monopoly May Cool Nuclear Revival.

title: Preview | Ts Celebrity Improv Film Series
The Incoming Governor
description: Who is David Paterson? Steven Malanga, a senior editor for City Journal, examines the next governor of New York. The best that can be said about him is that he knows his way around Albany, having spent 20 years there, and that his fellow legislators like and respect him, Malanga writes. He wont enter office facing the resentment that Spitzer engendered. The bad? Malanga continues:

title: What Happens to Spitzers Campaign War Chest?
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer has already raised more than $8 million for a re-election campaign in 2010. Close to $3 million remains in the account. What happens to it? Can Mr. Spitzer spend the money? The state Election Law is typically unspecific. Section 12-130 states: Contributions received by a candidate or a political committee may be expended for any lawful purpose. Such funds shall not be converted by any person to a personal use which is unrelated to a political campaign or the holding of a public office or party position.

title: Hedge Fund Halcyon to Go Public in SPAC Deal
description: Halcyon Asset Management said Thursday that it plans to go public by merging with a blank-check company in a deal that values the firm at $974 million.

title: Bebo: Randy Falcos $850 Million Rescue Plan for AIM
description: AOL has announced it will spend $850 million in cash to buy Bebo, the social network that dominates the United Kingdom and is an also-ran in most of the rest of the world. The deal keys on instant messaging, which is closely related to social networking as a method of communication among young (and not so young) people.

title: Welcome To Up To The Moment
description: As we prepare to sweep away the grays of winter, our new Spring 2008 Design issue brings you a kaleidoscope of color, from the rainbow sensibility of the rock star Lenny Kravitz (and his daughter, Zo) to the trend forecaster Li Edelkoort's shaded view on the new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, "Color Chart: Reinventing Color, 1950 to Today."

title: Icahns Family Ties Bind Him to Sinking Motricity
description: Carl C. Icahn has gained fame over the years at least as much from his blunt talk as from his investment prowess. But the former came to the fore as the billionaire investor sat down for a chat with PEHubs Dan Primack, who wanted to know about Mr. Icahns two investments in Motricity, a wireless content startup.

title: The Next Governor Speaks, Briefly
description: The next governor, David A. Paterson, stopped to answer a question this morning at the Capitol building for a brief moment before heading into his chambers on the third floor. Asked by one of the reporters present what he had to say to the world, he said, Id like to tell them that the government is stable, were in a transition and Ill see you at 2 oclock and Ill tell you more.

title: Obama Chats With Gore
description: DULLES, Va.  With a six-week interval between primaries, the Democratic presidential candidates have a little more time on their hands after a chaotic string of week-to-week primaries and caucuses.

title: The Global Rose as Social Tool
description: NAIVASHA, Kenya  The view persists that a rose is a rose is a rose. But that's so 20th century! In this new era a rose is a global product vested with the power to bring social and environmental change.

title: Driving From Phoenix to the Grand Canyon
description: Correction Appended

title: Second Socit Gnrale Trader Is Freed

Eliot Spitzer  having already lost the governorship, not to mention his reputation and any semblance of family stability  could, in theory, lose his livelihood as well if his law license were suspended or revoked. Legal experts say such an outcome is unlikely, but not inconceivable.

title: SXSW: Drinking Songs From Van Morrison
description: Van Morrison, perpetual outsider, was right at home in Texas, where honky-tonk mingles with blues, R&B and country the way he does. In his club show at La Zona Rosaa big, packed dance floorhe looked as grumpy as he usually does, but he plunged into his music. Like Bob Dylan, Mr. Morrison tours steadily and changes from night to night; sometimes hes inspired, sometimes hes not. But maybe he had something to prove at South By Southwest, playing for an audience that mixed fans and the curious.

title: Why Dont We Invent It Tomorrow?
description: For as much time as youve probably spent wondering when all the astounding technology that science fiction promises will start showing up at your local Best Buy, Michio Kaku has thought about it even more. In his new book Physics of the Impossible, Kaku, a professor of theoretical physics at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, and a cofounder of string field theory, delves deeply into cutting-edge science to tell us what breakthrough innovations we can expect in our own lifetimes  and which our grandchildrens grandchildren will still be dreaming about.

title: Spring Fever
description: The New York Yankees and Tampa Bay Rays have argued all week about whether base runners should collide with catchers at home plate during spring training games. The debate began over the weekend after a Rays player bulldozed a Yankees catcher, fracturing the catchers wrist, and it flared yesterday into a bench-clearing tussle. Should teams play with the same intensity in spring training as they do during the regular season?

description: An e-mail blast from Eric Woolson, Mike Huckabees Iowa campaign manager, this morning offering a fire sale on Huckabee for President T-shirts really just speaks for itself.

Perhaps Im conditioned by years of being a sports fan, but watching a superior athlete purposely keep the score close seemed like a travesty.

title: Axelrod and Penn
description: Democrats tend to make celebrities of their campaign consultants, which is why anyone who has closely followed this campaign could probably pick out Mark Penn or David Axelrod, the chief strategists for Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama, in a bar. To simply refer generically to these strategists as consultants, however, as if they were necessarily experts in the same craft, is to obscure important differences in how they got to where they aredifferences that can often be important to understanding the arc of a particular campaign. This long and remarkable struggle between Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Obama has been a study not just in the brilliance and the blind spots of the candidates themselves, but also those of their most trusted  and highly paid  advisers. Mr. Axelrod is an ad guy. A man who perfected the craft of encapsulating an entire life in 30 seconds, he has a gift for telling personal stories in ways that people can understand. As my colleague Benjamin Wallace Wells wrote in a Times Magazine profile last year, Mr. Axelrods essential insight  the idea that has made him successful where others might have failed  is that the modern campaign really isnt about the policy arcana or the candidates record; its about a more visceral, more personal narrative. This is probably a big reason why Mr. Obama has, from the start, focused almost exclusively on broad themes of hope and change, drawing heavily on his own life story, rather than staking out any particularly new policy ground. In its tone and emphasis, Mr. Obamas campaign reflects all the attributes of a truly great political ad: the stirring words, the beautiful pictures, the simple and elegant storyline of a ruined political system and the man whose moment has arrived.

title: Union Urges Changes in Grading for Schools
description: Unhappy with that C for your school on the report card? Think that the instructor didnt take all the proper measurements under consideration? Consider it unfair and misleading? Do what every student unsatisfied with his or her grades would consider: appeal. Thats the tack the United Federation of Teachers is taking.During a breakfast speech on Thursday to the Association for a Better New York, Randi Weingarten, the union president, presented a detailed proposal on report cards for schools. Instead of assigning one blunt letter grade, as the city report cards did, the six-page report would grade schools on four areas: academic achievement, school safety, teamwork between teachers and administrators and support from the Department of Education.

Fix the economy, reduce health care costs, improve the environment, reform education, deal with rising energy costs and so on. This hearty appetite for an assertive domestic approach arises in no small part from the discontent that large majorities have with the Bush administrations handling of nearly all of these issues.

title: SXSW: R.E.M. Hits the Throttle
description: Accelerate isnt just the title of R.E.M.s new album, which supplied songs for nearly their entire set at Stubbs Bar-B-Q on Wednesday night. (Its available for streaming at npr.org.) Acceleration is also the strategy that recharged the bands music. R.E.M.s last few albums have been thoughtful, textural and  face it  snoozy and enervated. For their new one, they got perturbed over politics, personal insecurities and a vexed relationship with religion and, even better, they hit the throttle. Perhaps they were leery of circling back to their old guitar-band sound: that combination of folk-rock guitar picking and, often, soul-music drumming. But Im glad they did.

title: Diversions and Delights From the Floating World
description: In the theaters, teahouses and brothels of Edo, pleasure was a serious business. For a period during the 17th and 18th centuries, the urban area now known as Tokyo was the worlds largest city, with entire districts catering to the needs of wealthy samurai and a rising merchant class. Both groups acquired a taste for ukiyo-e, paintings and woodcuts that depicted ukiyo, the floating world of leisure and luxury. Ukiyo-e could be idealized images of courtesans, portraits of actors and celebrated beauties, or lavishly illustrated books of poetry.

title: 2 Firefighters Admit They Started Blaze at Firehouse

She is Atina Grossmann, not Grossman.
