description: READING

title: Sales for Nine Inch Nails
description: The new collection of instrumental recordings by Nine Inch Nails, the industrial-rock act, may not have lyrics, but it apparently has monetary value. The band offered 9 of the 36 new tracks free online at ghosts.nin.com and sold various versions of the whole set for as much as $300. Its representatives said first-week sales generated more than $1.6 million. That sum is the result of more than 781,000 transactions, including free and paid downloads, as well as online orders of the CD, according to a news release from the band, led by Trent Reznor. The band said it sold out its run of 2,500 copies of the deluxe $300 package, which includes the music on CD and on vinyl, as well as other material. The figures have not been independently verified, and the group said it did not plan to release the typical sales data to Nielsen SoundScan, the music industry tracking service. The new collection, Ghosts I-IV, is Nine Inch Nails first album since it was released from its contract with the major label Interscope Records.

title: Correction
description: A front-page article on Sunday about the Senate record of Barack Obama referred incorrectly in some copies to his position on a drawdown of troops from Iraq. After joining the Senate in 2005 Mr. Obama spoke in favor of a drawdown, including in a speech on Nov. 22 of that year. He did not propose a drawdown only after he was running for president and polls showed voters favoring it. (What he did do after becoming a candidate was to propose legislation calling for a drawdown.) (Go to Article)

title: AOL Buying No. 3 Social Networking Site
description: Bebo lacks the hundred million friends of MySpace and the charmed social status of Facebook. But it is the third most popular social networking Web site in the United States and, to the besieged Internet company AOL, it is worth $850 million.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A theater review on Wednesday about the musical Take Me Along, at the Irish Repertory Theater, referred imprecisely to its setting. While the production sets the action in 1920, the original Broadway production set it in 1910. (Some revivals place the action in 1906, as in the play from which the musical is adapted, Ah, Wilderness, by Eugene ONeill.)

title: Legally Blind, but Confident in His Best Adaptive Skills
description: One question went unasked on Thursday as Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson walked up and down long flights of marble steps in the State Capitol, fielded questions from a roomful of reporters and tossed off one-liners that Dave or Jay or Conan would have trouble topping.

title: A Free-Spirited Wanderer Who Set Obamas Path
Kidnapped Iraqi Archbishop Is Dead
description: BAGHDAD  The body of a Chaldean Catholic archbishop who was kidnapped in the northern city of Mosul last month as he drove home after afternoon Mass was discovered Thursday buried in a southeastern area of the city.

title: Another Ghost of 9/11 Is Cleared for Demolition
description: Fiterman Hall  a semi-ruin since 9/11 that still stands, like the former Deutsche Bank building, as a ghost on the edge of ground zero  is expected to be razed within a year, now that federal regulators have approved a decontamination plan.

title: Panel Seeks New Limits on Anemia Drugs
MGM Makes a Hire to Expand Film Efforts
description: LOS ANGELES  Moving to rebuild its movie production capacity, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. named Mary Parent, a film industry veteran, as chairwoman for its worldwide motion picture group on Thursday.

title: Husband of Actress Tells Killer to Suffer
description: At first, Andrew Ostroy, the husband of the murdered actress and filmmaker Adrienne Shelly, sounded as if he were reading from a police report.

title: Plucked From Obscurity, They Also Serve Who Ascend by Fate
description: David A. Paterson did not channel an inner Gerald R. Ford. At his first news conference as governor-in-waiting, he said nothing on Thursday along the lines of, My fellow New Yorkers, our short state nightmare is over. He didnt have to. Everyone knew the wringer that Governor-for-three-more-days Eliot Spitzer had put all of us through this trying week.

title: Chrysler Sets a Two-Week Furlough for Most Workers
description: DETROIT  Chrysler plans to halt virtually all operations for two weeks in July as part of its effort to cut costs and return to profitability.

title: Youre Having My Baby: Two Bickering Sisters, United by Pregnancy
description: Among the disillusioning aspects of the new comedy The Return of Jezebel James is the presence of a laugh track, there as if it were a spoonful of peanut butter on a pizza. What business does it have? The question arises because Jezebel is the creation of Amy Sherman-Palladino, a writer who has set her own standards far above convention. On her previous venture, the great, departed Gilmore Girls, the funny lines  about Norman Mailer, Noam Chomsky, Christiane Amanpour, well-known newspaper editors, op-ed columnists, old movies, Susan Faludi  came with such velocity that no laugh track would ever have been able to keep up.

title: Jurors Ask for Evidence in Killing of 7-Year-Old
description: A jury in the trial of Cesar Rodriguez, who is accused of killing 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown, asked the judge on Thursday to view several pieces of evidence, including pictures of the dead girl and Mr. Rodriguezs statements.

title: Boston Ballet to Cut Nearly 20% of Dancers in Company
description: Tumultuous times have returned to the Boston Ballet, which said on Thursday that the number of dancers in its main company will shrink by nearly 20 percent, and that its executive director will leave at the end of the season.

title: The Vision Thing
description: Iowa City

title: Drawing Center Wont Move to Seaport
description: DRAWING CENTER

title: Flu Outbreak Closes Hong Kong Schools
description: HONG KONG  The Hong Kong government on Thursday closed all elementary schools and preschools in the territory a week early for Easter holidays after three children died amid an influenza outbreak, but insisted there was no sign that SARS or bird flu were involved.

title: Reaching Out, Paterson Offers Different Tone
description: With sorrow, seriousness and a dollop of humor, Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson opened his first full day as governor-in-waiting Thursday, pledging his continued commitment to Gov. Eliot Spitzers agenda but breaking markedly with the governors style.

title: A Vicious Attack on Innocent People, on the Screen and in the Theater
description: It is customary to describe film directors who keep a tight rein on their audiences responses, who coldly and meticulously manipulate emotion, as sadists. Not necessarily in a bad way; filmmaking is to a large degree an art of control. Alfred Hitchcock, Stanley Kubrick and Steven Spielberg can all, with some justice, be accused of sadism, a charge that hardly detracts from  indeed, that helps to explain  the way they provide entertainment.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Heights Before Broadway
description: TO be perfectly clear, Lin-Manuel Miranda did not grow up in Washington Heights, the physical and spiritual setting of his musical In the Heights, which opened on Broadway this week. He was raised in Inwood, an area some blocks north with a similar landscape of immigrants, Spanish speakers and urban decay softened by panoramic vistas. Why not stage a musical there?

title: Businesses Face Cut in Immigrant Work Force
description: HYANNIS, Mass.  For years, William Zammer Jr. has relied on 100 seasonal foreign employees to turn down beds, boil lobsters and serve cocktails at the restaurants, golf course and inn he owns on Cape Cod and in nearby Plymouth.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: CANADIAN FRONT, 2008 Denys Arcands satire Days of Darkness, set in the very near future, takes place largely in the mind of Jean-Marc Leblanc (Marc Labrche, above, in a scene from the film), a middle-aged civil servant who works in the provincial citizens rights department listening to the complaints of ordinary people whose problems he is powerless to solve. As his mind wanders, this harried milquetoast entertains grandiose Walter Mitty-worthy fantasies of fame, wealth and sex with beautiful women jockeying for his favor.

title: 8-Kilometer Event Saturday
description: The last time Alan Webb ran a race was Sept. 29, when he won the Fifth Avenue Mile in 3 minutes 52.7 seconds. On Saturday, only yards away from that course, he will run in the United States 8-kilometer championship in Central Park.The 50 men in the race include Jorge Torres, James Carney and Fasil Bizuneh. Among the 30 women in an accompanying invitational race are Shalane Flanagan, Carrie Tollefson and Katie McGregor.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article on Thursday about parallels in the golf careers of Tiger Woods and Arnold Palmer referred imprecisely to an achievement by Gary Player. Although Player is expected to compete in his 51st Masters tournament this spring and break a record he shares with Palmer for the most starts in the event, he did not play the first 50 consecutively  a distinction that belongs to Palmer.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about an agreement between TiVo and YouTube to allow Internet video clips to be viewed on television sets referred imprecisely in some editions to a rival service from Apple. Apple introduced a way to stream videos from YouTube to a television set in March 2007, not January of this year. (In January, it introduced a version with features similar to those planned by TiVo, which will allow the porting of Internet videos to television without the need for a computer.)

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Two Directors Resign From Stratford Shakespeare Festival
description: Just a year and a half after the Stratford Shakespeare Festival, Canadas largest nonprofit performing arts organization, announced that its new management team would be an unusual three-person artistic directorate, two of those artistic directors have stepped down. The resignations were submitted on Wednesday, a little more than a month before the 2008 season  the first under the new management  is to begin on April 23.

title: For a New Brand, Pepsi Starts the Buzz Online
description: A BEVERAGE marketer known for pouring money into splashy ads in the traditional media is taking an unconventional approach with a new product.

title: New Shareholders to Weigh Take-Two Bid
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Electronic Arts, which on Thursday began a direct tender offer to shareholders of Take-Two Interactive, finds itself negotiating with a group of shareholders much different from what it would have faced a month ago, when it first proposed a takeover.

title: A Party of Four at a Foraging Spot
description: CALVERTON, N.Y.  New Navy jets once zoomed over the secluded runways nestled here in the pine barrens, but these days a different type of winged predator flies over the grassy expanse.

title: Preventing Another Genocide
description: The worlds failure to end the killing in Darfur may soon be compounded by renewed fighting in southern Sudan. Another genocide cannot be allowed to happen.

title: The Art Is in the Detail
description: From his terrace, the world is blue and green  mountains and trees  or almost green. Spring is on the way; the geese are back. One, then two, alight on the river, with more still invisible but close behind. Pavilion living! The only way. With the city somewhere down there, and nature everywhere up here, he watches mist rise. River meets sky.

title: At 36,000 Feet, Closer to God
description: IM not the worst flier in the world, but Im also not the best. I get fairly white-knuckled during turbulence, can be highly sensitive to what the authorities call suspicious activity and, in the course of a number of landings, have caught myself thinking that the pilot was going too fast. I know that these feelings, while not quite a pathology, are also not quite rational.

title: Videotape at Trial Shows Legislator Discussing Deal
description: Assemblywoman Diane M. Gordon wanted a house. She said so on the videotape played on Thursday, the opening day of her corruption trial in Brooklyn.

title: A Comedian in the Lineup: Is That Any Way to Play the Game?
description: A swath of Yankees fans kept saying they couldnt wait to see the new, aggressive Yankees under Joe Girardi. I dont think they had Billy Crystal in mind.

title: Southwest Inspects Planes and Resumes Its Normal Service
description: Southwest Airlines found small cracks on 4 of the 38 planes it briefly grounded Wednesday, returning the other 34 planes to service. On Thursday, it resumed a normal schedule re than 3,400 flights a day.

title: A Laid-Back Village With Lots of Snow and Comfort
description: WHEN Greg Dekdebrun was a teenager, his mother used to drive him to the Greyhound station in Buffalo on Friday nights in winter and put him on the bus for the 45-minute trip to Ellicottville, where his father, who owned three ski shops in Buffalo, had opened a small shop in the nascent ski resort.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Chief Turns to Webcast to Pitch G.E.
description: Jeffrey R. Immelt, the chief executive of General Electric, is clearly hoping that Marshall McLuhan was right and that the medium is the message.

title: Debt Collectors Try to Put on a Friendlier Face
description: CHICAGO  Just in time for a recession, the debt collection industry is working to shed its reputation for remorselessly hounding people.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: For Huggins, Winning Is Easy, but Esteem Has Been Elusive
description: Each time I see Bob Huggins, I see all the contradictions of big-time college basketball. I see second and third chances for a coach who has had his share of controversy. I also see an industry that often looks the other way if an extraordinary coach like Huggins can win games, bringing fame and glory to a thirsty university.

title: Correction: On Floridas Gulf Coast, the South Is Still the South
description: A map with an article last Friday about traveling in the Florida Panhandle reversed the positions of two communities on the Gulf Coast. Inlet Beach is east of Rosemary Beach.

title: Is a Night Devoted to Faith Really About the Money?
description: The United States Constitution provides for separation of church and state. It does not provide for separation of church and baseball. Its time, though, for baseballs constitution to dictate separation of church and baseball.

title: Sham Audits May Have Hid Theft by G.O.P. Committee Treasurer, Lawyer Says
description: WASHINGTON  The former treasurer of a Republican Congressional fund-raising committee may have stolen hundreds of thousands of dollars by submitting elaborately forged audit reports for five years using the letterhead of a legitimate auditing firm, a lawyer for the committee said Thursday.

title: White House Offers Plan to Ward Off Credit Crises
description: WASHINGTON  After months of watching a growing credit crisis made worse by steadily eroding home prices, the Bush administration responded on Thursday with the outlines of a plan that officials emphasized is meant more to prevent future crises than to address the current one.

title: In China, a Patriotic Death Reeks of Alcohol
description: BEIJING  No place in China has a tougher policy against official drinking than Xinyang, a decaying city of seven million people in Henan Province where the Communist Party chief has banned civil servants from drinking even one sip of alcohol at lunch.

title: Wiretap Trial Revisits Lawsuit by Comedian
description: LOS ANGELES  The week-old Hollywood wiretapping trial began to live up to its billing on Thursday, at least for 45 minutes in the morning, as the comedian Garry Shandling emotionally  and at times, mordantly  described how it felt to be on the receiving end of the attentions of the private detective Anthony Pellicano.

title: Couple Take Dead Infant to a Church
description: A couple took the decomposed body of a newborn to a church in Queens on Wednesday night and asked a priest there to provide a proper burial for it, the police said Thursday.

title: Wrapped in Mystique, Teasing With Intimacy and Delivering Subtleties
description: Vinicius Canturia, the Brazilian singer-songwriter and guitarist, places great faith in the power of mystique. His music abides by not only the subtleties of bossa nova but also an enterprising haziness shared by experimental rock and the cooler strains of fusion. As a performer he employs intimacy as a strategy, drawing listeners close and then holding them at arms length. His diffidence can seem willful, almost passive-aggressive.

title: Multiple Franchises in a Wii Free-for-All
description: There are video games that try to make you cry. There are games that gross you out. There are games that tell a sweeping story. There are games that make you think seriously about the world around you.

title: In South Africa, Crime Is Childs Play
description: JOHANNESBURG  Violence has become so pervasive in South African schools that children as young as 7 play games such as rape me, rape me, where students simulate sexual attacks, according to a chilling report issued Wednesday by the nations human rights commission.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Tuesday, about Iraqs electricity shortage, incorrectly described the financing for the Musayyib power plant, south of Baghdad. The United States has provided $36 million so far, the Pentagon says; it has not contributed more than $300 million, which is the amount spent by the government of Iraq.

title: Howard M. Metzenbaum, Who Battled Big Business as Ohio Senator, Dies at 90
description: Howard M. Metzenbaum, who for nearly two decades as a Democratic senator from Ohio fought conservatives and big business with such effectiveness and ferocity that he became known as the last angry liberal, died Wednesday at his home in Aventura, Fla. He was 90.

title: A Second Act for Destination Clubs
description: ONE of the challenges for any club is achieving the optimal level of membership: selective enough to feel exclusive, yet large enough to be financially healthy.

title: As Dollar Hits New Lows, Investors Look Elsewhere
description: WASHINGTON  How low can the dollar go?

title: Sleight of Camera, Capturing Fleeting Impressions
description: Pity the photographic negative, consigned to obscurity as digital photographs are manipulated with ease on the computer screen. At the moment, however, the negative is starring in a pair of exhibitions at the New York Public Library that focus on the experimental period after the birth of photography (the 1850s through the 1870s). Film had not yet been invented, but glass-plate and paper negatives allowed artists to micromanage the cameras performance or to bypass it entirely.

title: Fighting the Wrong Foe With the Wrong Weapons
description: If readers thought Michael Scheuer, the former C.I.A. officer who headed the agencys Osama bin Laden unit, was angry about the folly of the Iraq war in his 2004 book, Imperial Hubris (published under the byline Anonymous), then wait until they delve into his latest assessment of the war on terror: Marching Toward Hell: America and Islam After Iraq. This scathing, wildly uneven and often intemperate work eviscerates not just the administrations of George W. Bush and Bill Clinton, but also the entire foreign policy establishment, and it is filled with arguments sure to enrage just about everyone, including Republicans and Democrats, neo-conservatives and liberals, oil companies and international humanitarian organizations.

title: Ukraine: Gas Deal Advances
description: Gazprom and Ukraine have reached agreement on more details of a settlement announced last week to avert a shutoff of Russian gas to European consumers, Gazprom said. The deal appeared to fall short of a demand by Ukraines prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, above, a former gas trader turned critic of the business, to eliminate such middlemen from the trade. The company, the worlds largest natural gas producer, and Ukraine agreed to eliminate middlemen from the domestic gas distribution business in Ukraine. Still, an intermediary, RosUkrEnergo, may continue to export gas to Ukraine. ANDREW KRAMER

title: Global or Local? For Accounting Firms, It All Depends
description: This is the era of the global firm, whether in finance or industry. A company like Toyota or Citigroup may have its headquarters in one city, but it has operations all over the world and gets capital from a similarly broad base. When Citi ran into difficulties, it turned to Abu Dhabi.

title: An Exchange Official Is Charged
description: The vice chairman of the International Securities Exchange, an options and stock exchange in New York, was charged with insider trading on Thursday, accused of leaking confidential information about the $2.8 billion takeover of the market last year.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Japan: Standoff on Bank Post
description: Japans lower house of Parliament approved Prime Minister Yasuo Fukudas candidate to lead the central bank, deepening a political standoff after the upper house rejected the nomination on Wednesday. The lower house, which is controlled by Mr. Fukudas Liberal Democratic Party, approved Toshiro Muto, deputy governor of the bank, to lead the Bank of Japan. The standoff increases the possibility the position will go vacant once Toshihiko Fukuis term expires on Wednesday. The government must propose a new candidate or resubmit the same one after the conflicting votes. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

title: Okemo Mountain Resort
description: Updated: December 2008

title: Bush Acknowledges Economic Troubles
description: President Bush made his most striking acknowledgment yet of the countrys economic troubles on Friday, even as he defended his administrations responses so far and warned against more drastic steps by the government to intervene.

title: Tibetan Marchers Arrested in India
description: NEW DELHI  A group of Tibetan exiles in northern India who began a six-month march this week to protest Chinas control of their homeland were arrested early Thursday. They then began a hunger strike that they say will continue until they are released.

title: Terror Suspect Eludes Posse of 4 Million
description: SINGAPORE  The big mistake, officials here say, was letting the terrorist suspect make a trip to the bathroom.

title: Stocks Tumble on Banks Troubles
description: Stocks took a sharp dive on Friday after an emergency bailout for Bear Stearns, the troubled investment bank, rocked Wall Streets confidence in the fragile credit market.

title: Gold Glitters, Dollar Loses Its Luster
description: Eighty feet below the sidewalks of Lower Manhattan lie half a million bars of gold, the most valuable stockpile of bullion in the world.

title: Prices Held Steady in February
description: Consumer prices held steady in February as the cost of gasoline declined, an unexpected dose of good economic data that opens the door for more aggressive rate cuts by the Federal Reserve.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about the Senate record of Barack Obama referred incorrectly in some copies to his position on a drawdown of troops from Iraq. After joining the Senate in 2005 Mr. Obama spoke in favor of a drawdown, including in a speech on Nov. 22 of that year. He did not propose a drawdown only after he was running for president and polls showed voters favoring it. (What he did do after becoming a candidate was to propose legislation calling for a drawdown.)

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,968 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Thursday:

title: Fox Wins as Viewers Get a Dose of Reality
description: Perhaps someday a television network will produce a reality show about the competition between rival reality shows. On Wednesday, when each broadcast network had a reality series at 8 p.m., Foxs lie-detector show, The Moment of Truth, won the showdown with 10.4 million viewers and a 4.1 rating in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic, according to Nielsen Media Research. NBCs Deal or No Deal placed a close second among total viewers, with 10.2 million, but could not come close among younger viewers, pulling a 2.5 rating. Wife Swap on ABC averaged 6.3 million viewers; Big Brother on CBS delivered 5.4 million viewers; and Americas Next Top Model on CW finished with 3.6 million viewers. At 9 p.m., when CBS and NBC turned to scripted shows, Foxs American Idol easily beat the competition, averaging 26.7 million viewers and a 10.1 rating in the 18-to-49 demographic. A Law & Order: Criminal Intent episode attracted 7.9 million viewers to NBC, and a Criminal Minds repeat averaged 7.4 million viewers for CBS. Supernanny on ABC had fewer total viewers (5.9 million) than NBC or CBS but a higher share of young viewers. At 10 p.m. NBC led with Law & Order, averaging 11.7 million viewers, compared with 6.4 million for a repeat of CBSs CSI: NY and 5.6 million for ABCs Men in Trees.

title: Coin. Smile. Click!
description: ON a recent sunny but frigid morning, I strolled up Broadway through Times Square with Nkki Goranin, a visitor from Vermont making a pilgrimage through the swirling crowds and the sensory overload of all the signage. We stopped on the west side of Broadway between 51st and 52nd Streets. It looked nondescript to me, with the usual fast food, souvenir shop, gym and drugstore.

title: A Product of Private Schools, Advocating for Public Education
description: ZEKE M. VANDERHOEK, the upstart behind the extravagant, much-debated idea that paying teachers at his fledgling charter school $125,000 a year will translate into a top-notch education for students, is tethered by circumstance to a chair in his Chelsea office. It should be noted that Mr. Vanderhoek, 31 and showing the signs of an addiction to almond croissants, had to be coerced into making time to chat.

title: Architect of Florida Mail-In Vote Says Its Chances Are Poor
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  The chairwoman of the Florida Democratic Party promoted her plan Thursday for a new, mail-in presidential primary for the states 4.2 million registered Democrats, but conceded that the embattled proposal had little chance of survival.

title: For Crystal, a Strikeout and a Lasting Memory
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The most famous Yankee of all, at least for a day, traded autographed baseballs late Thursday afternoon with Paul Maholm, the Pittsburgh Pirates left-hander who had struck him out in the first inning of an exhibition game at Legends Field.

title: Investigator Cites Blood on Pistol in Queens Trial
description: A crime scene investigator testified on Thursday that blood was found on the pistol of the detective who fired first at Sean Bell. But defense lawyers were expected to say that the blood did not mean the detective was much closer than originally thought when he shot at the men in Mr. Bells car.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about photographs of John Lennon taken by May Pang, who lived with him for 18 months during the mid-1970s, referred incorrectly to production work Mr. Lennon did for Ringo Starr in that period. He is credited with having supervised the recording of the title track of Mr. Starrs album Goodnight Vienna, a song Mr. Lennon wrote; he did not produce an album for Mr. Starr.

title: Bush Acknowledges Tough Economic Times
description: President Bush acknowledged Friday that the nations economy was going through troubled times, but cautioned against overreacting to current problems, saying such actions could cause longer-term problems.

title: Activists Can Nominate CNet Board, Judge Says
description: A court in Delaware ruled Thursday that a group of activist investors can nominate seven directors to the board of CNet Networks, one of the original online media companies.

title: Top Immigration Official to Resign in April
description: Emilio T. Gonzalez, the immigration official who promised to bring an ethos of corporate efficiency to the immigration bureaucracy but instead found his agency overwhelmed in record backlogs and delays, announced Thursday that he would resign on April 18.

title: Boy, 15, Is Shot and Critically Injured While Visiting Friends
description: A teenager was critically injured on Thursday when a gun went off while he was visiting friends in a Brooklyn apartment, the police said.

title: Vonn and Miller All but Clinch Titles
description: BORMIO, Italy  In different ways and different moods, Lindsey Vonn and Bode Miller all but assured themselves of a remarkable American double at the World Cup Alpine skiing finals.

title: A Host of Voices Raised in Praise
description: A sampling of choral works for the Easter season in New York City. Admission is free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.)

title: Clemsons Rise Driven by Purnells Vision
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  When he was being courted by Clemson to coach its woeful basketball team five years ago, Oliver Purnell kept hearing the same thing from friends.

title: Division III Fencer Says N.C.A.A. Selection System Is Unfair
description: By many accounts, Halli Melnitsky had a great season.

title: Hot Hand Sends UConn to Another Early Exit
description: There may not be a hotter player in the country right now than West Virginias Joe Alexander. He is big, versatile and quick, and he creates a ton of problems for opposing defenses. On Thursday, he took care of Connecticut, scoring a career-high 34 points to lead the Mountaineers to a 78-72 victory in the quarterfinal round of the Big East tournament.

title: Fed Chief Warns Anew on Foreclosures
description: Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, added fresh warnings on Friday about a gathering wave of home foreclosures bearing down on American communities, while pledging new regulations to limit the impact and crack down on predatory mortgage lending.

title: Catching the History of Key West
description: AT the Eaton Street Seafood Market in the historic district of Key West, Fla., a long glass case displayed a whos who of the citys seafood scene: plump piles of pinks (the local shrimp) snuggled next to a yellowtail snapper, a mound of stone crab claws and fresh slabs of grouper. Id come to eat my way through Key Wests delicacies, and here was my map.

title: Ben Heppner to Miss More Tristan Performances
description: Ben Heppner, the leading Wagnerian tenor who withdrew from Mondays Metropolitan Opera performance of Tristan und Isolde, will also miss the next three performances, the Met said on Thursday, including a live broadcast to movie theaters around the world. Mr. Heppner, singing the role of Tristan, withdrew on Monday because of a viral infection, the Met said, and was replaced by John Mac Master. It announced that Gary Lehman will replace him for Fridays performance, but did not say who would assume the role on Tuesday and on March 22. The March 22 performance is part of the Mets much-vaunted program of high-definition transmissions to cinemas. The Met did confirm, though, that Mr. Heppner would not be onstage. That performance is also scheduled for radio broadcast. The Met said Mr. Heppner was expected to return for performances on March 25 and March 28. The Isolde is Deborah Voigt, and James Levine is conducting the run. Mr. Lehman is a budding Wagnerian himself, having stepped in for Plcido Domingo in the title role of Parsifal in 2005 at the Los Angeles Opera. The Met said he had also sung the title role in Tannhuser and Siegmund in Die Walkre.

title: At ESPN, Recruits Arent Welcome, but Coaches Are
description: Forgive my flippancy, but I cant help but get all giggly over the secondary N.C.A.A. violation leveled against the University of Connecticut for arranging a private tour of Bristol for one of its prized womens basketball recruits, Maya Moore, in 2005.

title: Landlord of the Manor
description: ENJOYMENT, income or both? Those are the choices for many second-home owners who are considering whether to offer their getaways to weekend or vacation renters. For those who decide to rent, there are tax implications (rent it out for more than two weeks, and the income is taxable) and concerns about their own use of the property, their personal furnishings and their privacy.

title: New Jersey Assembly Approves Paid Leave to Care for Baby or Ailing Kin
description: TRENTON  Despite strong objections from Republicans, New Jersey moved closer on Thursday to becoming the third state in the country to give employees the right to paid leave to care for a sick relative or a newborn.

title: A Patch for a Robotic System
description: NASA is hoping that a software patch will help jump-start a robotic system for the International Space Station. Spacewalkers from the shuttle Endeavour will assemble and attach the device to the space station in coming days. Mission managers said that they had not been able to power up the robot, named Dextre, but that they believed that tweaking the timing of the start-up sequence could fix the problem. Also, analysts are examining images of the shuttle heat shield for signs of damage by debris from the launching, but LeRoy Cain, chairman of the mission management team, said the shuttle would probably receive a clean bill of health in the next day or two.

title: U.S. Studies Rebels Data for Chvez Link
description: BRASLIA  A senior American official said Thursday that American investigative teams were working in Bogot, Colombias capital, and Washington to pull information from recently seized computers to try to better understand the operations of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC.

title: In This Election, Ahmadinejad Ally Is Now a Critic
description: TEHRAN  During Irans presidential election campaign in 2005, Mohammad Khoshchehreh was one of the biggest boosters in Parliament of the candidacy of Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.

title: 900 Feet Up With Nowhere to Go but Down
description: MOAB, Utah  He had learned this extreme form of tightrope walking from a homeless man who wrote books on quantum physics. But that was years ago, while goofing around on a flexible piece of nylon webbing tied close to the ground between a tree and the bumper of a Chevy van.

title: A Family Joins East to West
description: AS New Yorkers who love to ski, Jim and Zibby Tozer can attest that owning a vacation home in Park City is especially great in winter, when they can schuss downhill on the light, dry powder for which Utah is famous.

title: Duncans Baseball Education: Strictly Old School
description: TAMPA, Fla.  When Art Kusnyer saw the replay of Shelley Duncans rough slide at second base Wednesday, he did not see a reckless thug trying to hurt an infielder. He saw a grown-up version of a fun-loving boy in an Oakland Athletics uniform, a boy who was raised in baseball and paid attention to how it was played.

title: Marching Toward Hell
description: [E]vents started by human folly link themselves in a sequence which no sagacity can foresee and no courage can break through. Joseph Conrad, 1911

title: A Soft Market Offers Some Buyers a Second Chance
description: I COULD have bought this for peanuts in the 90s. Such has been the lament of the many who once passed up buying on Marthas Vineyard and then found themselves watching as real estate prices climbed steadily, eventually reaching record highs.

title: Red Bull Theater Wins Randall Grant
description: The $100,000 Tony Randall Grant has been awarded to the Red Bull Theater for its production of Thomas Middletons Women Beware Women, an early-17th-century play about sexual politics and womens rights, scheduled to open in the fall. The annual grant goes to a nonprofit Equity theater company in New York, New Jersey or Connecticut for the production of a classic play, an adaptation of a classic or a work inspired by the classics. A $10,000 grant will be made to the Classic Theater of Harlem for Molires Tartuffe, opening in the fall.

title: Erica Jesselson, Collector and Benefactor, Dies at 86
description: Erica Jesselson, a philanthropist and collector of Judaica who, with her late husband, founded the Yeshiva University Museum in Manhattan and donated hundreds of artifacts of Jewish history to it and to other institutions, died Wednesday at her home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. She was 86 and also had a home in Jerusalem.

title: Italy: Eyeglass Makers Profit Falls
description: The Luxottica Group, one of the worlds biggest makers of eyeglasses, posted its first profit decline in nine quarters on the costs of combining the sports-eyewear maker Oakley with the companys other divisions. Fourth-quarter profit declined 3.7 percent, to 97 million euros ($151 million) from 100.7 million euros a year earlier, the company said. Luxottica, which is based in Milan, also proposed a 17 percent dividend increase to 49 cents a share. Luxottica, the maker of Ray-Ban sunglasses, paid $2 billion for Oakley in June to cut costs by about 100 million euros a year as profit growth slows and sales weaken in its main United States market. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

title: Palestinians Unite in Anger Against Israeli Attack
description: BETHLEHEM, West Bank  It was a display of Palestinian unity rarely seen since the militant Islamic group Hamas seized power in Gaza last summer and left the rival pro-Fatah Palestinian Authority struggling to hold on to the West Bank.

title: For Bronx Schools Dancers, the Moves Are Irish
description: Taja Garnetts parents are from Belize, but her nickname is Irish girl.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Viceroy Snowmass and the DeckHouses
description: Viceroy Snowmass

title: Connicks Concert in Trouble in China
description: Harry Connick Jr. said on Thursday he was forced to make last-minute changes in his Shanghai concert last weekend because an old song list was submitted by mistake to the Chinese authorities to obtain a performance permit, The Associated Press reported. The authorities insisted that he play the songs on the list, although his band didnt have the music for them. Due to circumstances beyond my control, Mr. Connick, above, said in a statement, I was not able to give my fans in China the show I intended. The concert was the latest to run afoul of the Chinese authorities. At a recent concert in Shanghai the Icelandic singer Bjork shouted Tibet! Tibet! after her song Declare Independence, prompting authorities to threaten to treat foreign performers more strictly.

title: Another Early Big East Exit for Connecticut
description: The Big East tournament continues to give Connecticut fits. For the third consecutive season, the Huskies lost their opening game. This time it was a 78-72 loss to No. 5 seed West Virginia on Thursday.

title: All Told, the Price Tag for Citigroups New Chief Is $216 Million
description: Call him Citigroups quarter-billion-dollar man.

title: An Amendment Aimed to Tease
description: WASHINGTON  Call it the showdown at the budget corral.

title: Mapping Asia Week
description: The annual Asia Week in Manhattan includes auctions at Sothebys (Monday through Wednesday) and Christies (Tuesday through next Friday), and museum and gallery events, as well as visits from out-of-town dealers, and two art fairs. The Fuller Building, 41 East 57th Street, at Madison Avenue, in Manhattan, is full of shows. The Web site for Asian Contemporary Art Week is acaw.net. Here are some highlights.

title: On a Russian Estate, Dormant Passions, Art and Self- Consciousness
description: Theres more than one ham in residence on the country estate where Madame Arkadina, the emotive stage diva from Chekhovs Seagull, flamboyantly spends her down time. Most of the characters in the bizarrely boisterous revival that opened on Thursday night at the Classic Stage Company, directed by Viacheslav Dolgachev and starring Dianne Wiest, appear to be participating in what might be called an act-off, a sort of provincial Russian Idol for thespians.

title: In Lagging Haiti, First Lady Finds Positive Signs
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Most Haitians are unemployed, but the first lady, Laura Bush, spoke to some of the fortunate few who do have jobs here in the poorest country in the hemisphere during her visit on Thursday.

title: Alabama Sends Florida Back to Earth With Rout
description: ATLANTA, March 13  Floridas record was 17-3 after a victory at South Carolina on Jan. 23, but Billy Donovan, the Gators coach, said he was uneasy with his team. He did not see the same passion or commitment that he saw in the squad that won national championships in 2006 and 2007.

title: Are the Grandkids Worth the Money?
description: Arresting global warming wont come cheap. Europe and Japan are already spending billions to meet the modest carbon emission cuts that they agreed to in Kyoto 10 years ago. And according to a recent United Nations report, switching to cleaner energy sources would require investments of up to $20 trillion over the next two decades. Add to that other economic costs, such as the rise in food prices attributable to the worlds embrace of renewable fuels.

title: Delivering the Standards Along With the Scarce
description: Michael Tilson Thomass visits to New York with the San Francisco Symphony are invariably refreshing, partly because the orchestras playing is flexible and energetic but mainly because Mr. Thomass programs usually step beyond the standard canon. Still, major orchestras deserve (and generally demand) to be measured against the competition in the core repertory as well. So in his concerts at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday and Wednesday, Mr. Thomas led his San Franciscans in meticulously balanced programs, with war horses like Beethovens Eroica Symphony and Strausss Four Last Songs offset by worthy rarities like William Schumans Violin Concerto and Samuel Barbers Andromaches Farewell.

title: Not Too Early?
description: The Bush administrations proposal for revamping the nations ailing mortgage market contains some sensible ideas. But they are still too modest and rely far too much on the voluntary cooperation and public spiritedness of the private sector  which has shown little of either since the housing and credit crisis began.

title: Scruggs Pleads Guilty in Bribery Case
description: One of the best-known plaintiffs lawyers in the country, Richard Scruggs, unexpectedly agreed to plead guilty on Friday to a criminal charge of conspiracy in the attempted bribery of a judge.

title: Boarders and Free Skiers Get Own Peak in New Jersey
description: MOUNTAIN CREEK, a New Jersey ski area about 50 miles from Manhattan, took a bold step last summer: It announced that it was relocating all its terrain-park features to a separate, almost stand-alone peak within the resort, but one mile from the main base area. This winter, the area, Mountain Creeks South Mountain, became one of the biggest terrain parks in the Eastern United States, a space dedicated to snowboarding and free skiing.

title: Taxpayer Advocate Says Outsourcing at I.R.S. Is Inept
description: The use of private debt collectors by the Internal Revenue Service is ineffective, the national taxpayer advocate told Congress yesterday, and the program should be canceled.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 13, 2008

title: Hosannas, Hallelujahs and Other Sounds of Easter
description: A sampling of noteworthy musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and concert halls in New York City, from this Sunday (Palm Sunday) through March 23 (Easter Sunday), selected by Vivien Schweitzer. Additional holiday listings are available online at nytimes.com/arts. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations. Unless noted, church choirs are featured in church concerts.)

title: Police Chief Is Shaking Up Chicago Forces Leadership
description: CHICAGO  New commanders have been assigned to almost every district in this citys long-troubled police force in an effort to diversify the ranks, bolster community relations and improve internal affairs, Police Superintendent Jody P. Weis announced Thursday.

title: Brazil: Court Backs Suspected Drug Lords Extradition to U.S.
description: The Supreme Court approved an American request for the extradition of Juan Carlos Ramirez-Abadia, a Colombian accused of smuggling billions of dollars of cocaine into the United States. Brazils president, Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, will decide whether the extradition will go forward. Called the new Pablo Escobar by the Brazilian police when he was arrested in So Paulo last August, Mr. Ramirez-Abadia, left, is said by the State Department, which put up a reward of $5 million for him, to command a multibillion-dollar drug and money-laundering operation that extends from the United States to Europe. He faces indictments brought by United States prosecutors in New York.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in the special Museums section on Tuesday about efforts to learn what museum visitors want described the status of a renovation and gallery reconstruction project at the Detroit Institute of Arts incorrectly. The $158 million project opened last fall; it is not still under construction.

title: Economy Hammered by Toxic Blend of Ailments
description: Almost everything seems to be going wrong for the American economy at once. People are buying less, but most things are costing more. Mortgage rates are rising, the dollar is falling and prices of key commodities like oil are leaping from one record high to the next.

title: Having a Baby Helps Beltrn Leave His Shell
description: JUPITER, Fla.  Carlos Beltrns wife, Jessica, awoke the morning of Oct. 25, 2007, and told him that she could not feel the baby in her womb. His mind raced. No, no, no. Not again.

title: Australia Stirs Controversy Over a Plan to Cull 400 Kangaroos
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The new Australian government is coming under international criticism over a plan to kill 400 kangaroos on a former military base.

title: On the Road to Nowhere in Down-and-Out America
description: Filmed mostly in winter, in browns, grays and soiled whites, Sleepwalking sustains a mood of unrelenting bleakness, wearing its aesthetic of desolation like a badge of integrity. Integrity and quality, unfortunately, are not synonymous. Sleepwalking may linger in downscale territory where few movies  even indies  dare to tread, but it has far too many flaws to make it a likely candidate for awards consideration. And isnt that kind of recognition the only commercial hope for gloomy kitchen-sink dramas?

title: The Spitzer Scandal, and the Fallout
description: To the Editor:

title: Monk Protests in Tibet Draw Chinese Security
description: BEIJING  Chinese security forces were reportedly surrounding three monasteries outside Lhasa, the Tibetan capital, on Thursday after hundreds of monks took to the streets this week in what are believed to be the largest Tibetan protests against Chinese rule in two decades.

title: Los Angeles Art Museum Buys Nearby Land
description: LOS ANGELES  The Los Angeles County Museum of Art, which is undertaking a multipart expansion, has extended its grasp by buying a commercial site across Wilshire Boulevard from its 20-acre campus.

title: Couples, Tied for Lead, Makes It Look Easy
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  For a while on a sunny day in Central Florida, the unrelenting march of time stopped cold, the cosmic pause button was depressed and an athlete who pads with timeless grace through golfs green corridors came gliding back into the sweet spot.

title: JPMorgan and Fed Move to Bail Out Bear Stearns
description: Bear Stearns, facing a grave liquidity crisis, reached out to JPMorgan on Friday for a short-term financial lifeline and now faces the prospect of the end of its 85-year run as an independent investment bank.

title: Marquette and Pitt Keep Upsets Coming
description: The opening day of the Big East Tournament was straight chalk, as all four of the higher-seeded teams won for the first time since 1997. On the second day, someone brought an eraser to Madison Square Garden.

title: Otto Schnellbacher, Football and Basketball Star at Kansas, Dies at 84
description: Otto Schnellbacher, a football and basketball star at the University of Kansas who became an All-Pro defensive back for the New York Giants and also played professional basketball, died Monday at his home in Topeka, Kan. He was 84.

title: New Law Lets Tenants Sue Over Harassment
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed a bill into law on Thursday that for the first time gives tenants the right to sue their landlords in Housing Court for using threats and other forms of harassment to force them out.

title: Obama Lists His Earmarks, Asking Clinton for Hers
description: Senator Barack Obama on Thursday released a list of $740 million in earmarked spending requests that he had made over the last three years, and his campaign challenged Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton to do the same.

title: From Avenue Q to Maupin
description: Its almost going to be a reunion for the Avenue Q team. More than a year ago, Jeff Whitty, who won a Tony in 2004 for the book of Avenue Q, decided his next project would be a musical version of Armistead Maupins 1978 novel of manners, Tales of the City. Jason Moore, who directed Avenue Q, is on board. The songwriters, however, are new blood: Jason Sellards and John Garden, of the glam rock band Scissor Sisters. But otherwise its like reading an old Playbill. Jeffrey Seller, Robyn Goodman and Kevin McCollum, the producers of Avenue Q, are aiming to bring Tales to Broadway for the 2009-10 season.

title: Surgeon Held for Deaths in Australia
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  An American surgeon was in a Portland jail on Thursday awaiting extradition proceedings over charges that he caused the deaths of three patients in Australia.

title: L.I. Mother Enters Plea in 3 Killings: Not Guilty
description: MINEOLA, N.Y.  Her voice barely above a whisper, the 27-year-old woman accused of drowning her three children in a bathtub last month pleaded not guilty to murder charges at her arraignment Thursday in Nassau County Criminal Court.

title: Be Wary About the Water Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Bad Dunk Is Good Stuff for Advancing Trojans
description: LOS ANGELES  The text messages arrived before the game was over. Then they came in bunches. The theme was constant  Arizona State had been robbed, and just what is the deal with Pacific-10 officials? Only the color of the language changed.

title: Rare Works by Eminent Britons
description: RARE WORKS

title: House Rejects Eavesdropping Immunity
description: WASHINGTON  After its first secret session in a quarter-century, the House on Friday rejected retroactive immunity for the phone companies that took part in the National Security Agencys warrantless eavesdropping program after the Sept. 11 attacks, and it voted to place greater restrictions on the governments wiretapping powers.

title: Report Urges Changes in Teaching Math
description: American students math achievement is at a mediocre level compared with that of their peers worldwide, according to a new report by a federal panel, which recommended that schools focus on key skills that prepare students to learn algebra.

title: Emperors Club Sold an Oxymoron: High-Class Prostitution
description: If only one of those elaborate computer programs designed to sort through millions of financial transaction reports could be tweaked to analyze  and answer  a different set of questions swirling around Gov. Eliot Spitzer, most of them involving his psyche.

title: Capturing Movement as It Leaps and Turns
description: Some artists cannot resist the challenge of innovation. Jonah Bokaer is one, and he does not limit his reach to performing and choreography. His latest exploit, in collaboration with John Jasperse, the modern-dance choreographer, is the creation of a center in Brooklyn dedicated to exploring new dance like the work Mr. Bokaer presented on Wednesday at the Abrons Arts Center.

title: Trader Tells Prosecutors Boss Saw Illicit Deal
description: PARIS  Jrme Kerviel, the former trader at the bank Socit Gnrale, has told French investigators that an assistant on his desk conducted at least one large fictitious transaction last spring on their bosss computer  as the boss looked on, according to a court document obtained on Thursday by The International Herald Tribune.

title: Weakness in Economy Isnt Hurting Charities
description: Despite the economic downturn and fears of recession, major charities say their fund-raising has not fallen off.

title: Night at Bowling Lanes Is Chance for Knicks to Boast
description: The Knicks got to do some rare things Thursday night. They smiled and they laughed. And most out of character of all, they got to boast.

title: With Eye on Campaigns, House Passes a Budget
description: WASHINGTON  The House passed a $3 trillion Democratic spending plan Thursday as Congress engaged in a day of budget theater that had as much to do with the political bottom line as federal fiscal policy.

title: Parades, a Donkey, a Seder, Too
description: A sampling of holiday celebrations in New York City, including dance and readings. Admission is free unless noted. (Churches accept donations.)

title: U.S. Is Examining Spitzers Funds
description: ALBANY  Federal prosecutors are investigating whether Gov. Eliot Spitzer used campaign funds in connection with his meetings with prostitutes, including payments for hotels or ground transportation, three people with knowledge of the investigation said.

title: Britain: Reprieve for Gay Iranian Asylum Seeker
description: Home Secretary Jacqui Smith said she would review the case of a 19-year-old gay Iranian asylum seeker who fears he will be put to death if he is forced to return home. The asylum seeker, Mehdi Kazemi, who originally came to Britain in 2005 to study English, fled to the Netherlands last year when his application for asylum was turned down. The Netherlands, too, refused to grant him asylum. Mr. Kazemi says that his boyfriend in Iran publicly named him as his partner before being charged with sodomy and executed. Following representations made on behalf of Mehdi Kazemi, and in the light of new circumstances since the original decision was made, I have decided that Mr. Kazemis case should be reconsidered on his return to the U.K. from the Netherlands, Ms. Smith said.

title: The Rank-Link Imbalance
description: Every society produces its own distinct brand of social misfits, I suppose, but our social structure seems to produce significant numbers of people with rank-link imbalances. That is to say, they have all of the social skills required to improve their social rank, but none of the social skills that lead to genuine bonding. They are good at vertical relationships with mentors and bosses, but bad at horizontal relationships with friends and lovers.

title: Lamping to Oversee Meadowlands Stadium Construction and Operations
description: The Giants and Jets on Thursday named the president of the St. Louis Cardinals to oversee the construction and operations of the $1.6-billion stadium they are building together in the New Jersey Meadowlands.

title: Revamped Lineup Puts U.S. Closer to an Olympic Berth
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Replacing five starters with an Olympic bid at stake does not leave much room between being labeled a genius or a fool.

title: When the Ghost in the Machine Is National Socialism
description: Intriguing, frustrating, exasperating  the French film Heartbeat Detector succeeds best as a provocation. An alternately abstract and blunt intellectual exercise, this artful assemblage of bodies, ideas and camera setups stars Mathieu Amalric as Simon, the staff shrink for the French branch of a German-owned petrochemical company called SC Farb. Something is amiss at Farb, notably its faltering, failing chief executive, Mathias Jst, played as an epic of agony and fragility by the indispensable Michael Lonsdale.

title: Potter Film Finale to Be Doubleheader
description: Fans who cant get enough of Harry Potter will get an extra helping when Warner Brothers Pictures adapts the last of the boy wizards adventures. J. K. Rowlings Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows will be a two-parter, the company announced on Thursday. Jeff Robinov, the president of Warner Brothers Pictures Group, said: In concluding the film franchise, we recognized that Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows is packed with vital plot points that complete the story arcs of all its beloved characters. That said, we feel that the best way to do the book, and its many fans, justice is to expand the screen adaptation of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows and release the film in two parts. Mr. Robinov said David Yates, who directed Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007), and is in production on Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, both starring Daniel Radcliffe, above, will direct Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, adapted by Steve Kloves, who has written previous Potter screenplays. The first of the Deathly Hallows films is to open in the fall-winter holiday season in 2010, and the second in summer 2011.

title: For Spitzer, Lawyers Both Formidable and Familiar Prepare to Do Battle
description: As Gov. Eliot Spitzer begins the delicate dance of fending off criminal charges in the federal prostitution case that led to his resignation on Wednesday morning, he is being helped by an august legal team that blends the comforts of the familiar with an insiders understanding of power politics.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about the trial of a Croatian general who led a brutal operation that drove Serbs out of the Krajina region of Croatia near the end of the Balkans war referred incorrectly to the location of the region. Krajina is in western Croatia, not eastern.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Saving Who-Ville Is a Big Production
description: What distinguishes Horton Hears a Who! from the other recent Dr. Seuss film adaptations How the Grinch Stole Christmas and The Cat in the Hat, in case you need reminding  is that it is not one of the worst movies ever made. Thats faint praise, I know, and Im even willing to go a bit further. There are aspects of Horton, directed by Jimmy Hayward and Steve Martino under the auspices of the 20th Century Fox animation unit responsible for the Ice Age movies, that are fresh and enjoyable, and bits that will gratify even a dogmatic and orthodox Seussian.

title: Blowhard, Patriot, President
description: When John Adams begins acting like a pompous windbag, his wife, Abigail, reproaches him with a single word.

title: Art in Review
description: WINE, WORSHIP AND SACRIFICE

title: An Irish Stew of Wisecracks, Highly Salted
description: Tommy Tiernan starts off Something Mental, his Comedy Central special on Friday night, with a warning. Therell be lots of cursing, he says, and there is. One particular word gets such a workout that it eventually becomes comedically counterproductive (not to mention just plain distracting, since it has to be bleeped for this broadcast).

title: Lilly E-Mail Discussed Off-Label Drug Use
description: ANCHORAGE  John C. Lechleiter, an Eli Lilly official who is about to become the companys top executive, wrote e-mail in 2003 that appears to have encouraged Lilly to promote its schizophrenia medicine Zyprexa for a use not approved by federal drug regulators.

title: Study Finds No Qaeda-Hussein Tie
description: WASHINGTON  There was no direct operational connection between Saddam Husseins government and Al Qaeda before the war in Iraq, says a Pentagon-sponsored study released Wednesday.

title: HUD Has Mail
description: The Housing and Urban Development secretary, Alphonso Jackson, was properly on the Congressional carpet this week for a cynical e-mail exchange by two of his assistants about a dispute Mr. Jackson was having with Philadelphias housing commissioner.

title: Dutch-Traded Fund Moves Toward Collapse
description: LONDON  David M. Rubenstein, co-founder of the Carlyle Group, pledged on Thursday to make amends to investors in a fund that has ties to his firm and is facing collapse.

title: Betting the Bank
description: Four years ago, an academic economist named Ben Bernanke co-authored a technical paper that could have been titled Things the Federal Reserve Might Try if Its Desperate  although that may not have been obvious from its actual title, Monetary Policy Alternatives at the Zero Bound: An Empirical Investigation.

title: Good Friday!
description: Good Friday came a week early in Formula One, as the first practice session wasgood. That is to say, the results show that this season may well be far from decided in the sense that we all thought in advance. As Mark Webber said to a few members of the press yesterday, well only really get any idea at all of what the teams have by watching the afternoon session when they start thinking about race setups.

title: Meet the reigning queen of celebrity real estate journalism
description: In the fast-growing realm of celebrity real estate journalism, Your Mama is the catty gossip columnist with all the inside scoops, offered up with more than a touch of sass.

title: SXSW: Lou Reed, No Fan of MP3s
description: Lou Reed has been writing songs for at least four decades and counting. But in his keynote address at South by Southwest, a casual onstage interview with his producer Hal Willner, he said he still doesnt know how. I dont know how it works or why it works or what it has to do with anything, he said. The thing Ive got going for me is instinct. I can feel it; I try not to think. Thinking wont get me where I want to go.

title: Riddle, Mystery and Conundrum: The Pac-10s Bubble Teams
description: The Pac-10 may have played itself into a quandary. Hoping to get seven teams invited to the N.C.A.A. tournament, and certain it will get at least five, it has only four sure things: U.C.L.A., Stanford, Washington State and U.S.C.

title: The Week 4 Debacle (Eagles vs. Giants)
description: Our guest contributors of the week are Enrico Campitelli Jr. and Matt Pesotskiof the 700 level, the brotherly Philadelphia sports blog.

title: The Ivy League Takes Its Rivalry Online
description: Take a territorial conquest game like Risk, bring it to the Web, and allow thousands of people to play together on teams: That's GoCrossCampus.

title: International Asian Art Fair
description: Additional images from the International Asian Art Fair.

title: House and Senate Pass Budget Plans
description: WASHINGTON  The House passed a $3 trillion Democratic spending plan Thursday, and the Senate followed suit early Friday as Congress engaged in a day of budget theater that had as much to do with the political bottom line as federal fiscal policy.

title: Welcome To Up To The Moment
John Milton at 400
description: Images from the exhibition at the New York Public Library.

title: Irish Down but Optimistic
description: Notre Dame Coach Mike Brey turned to the associate coach Sean Kearney with about two minutes left in Notre Dames Big East tournament quarterfinal loss and asked a simple question: How did we beat these guys once this season?

title: Cliques and Fists
description: A Fight Club for high-schoolers, Never Back Down offers extreme fighting as the modern-day alternative to sex, drugs and rock n roll.

title: Romance and Ransom in Colombia
description: That someone is kidnapped in Colombia every three hours is a startling statistic  and one that offers many cinematic possibilities. But Towards Darkness, which presents one particularly convoluted fictional case, fails to use any of them to advantage, despite how close the writer and director, Antonio Negret, is to the subject: three members of his family have been the victims of kidnappings.

title: Out of Context
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Shareholders Approve Canadian Bid for Auckland Airport Stake
description: After an 18-month political and corporate battle, the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board has won shareholder approval for its 1.4 billion Canadian dollar bid for a stake in New Zealands largest airport.

title: 5 Guilty of Fraud in Health Care Finance
description: A federal jury convicted five former executives of a health care finance company on Thursday in a $1.9 billion scheme to defraud investors.

title: ShareThis Raises $15 Million
description: A software start-up, ShareThis, has raised a $15 million Series B round from a Sand Hill Road venture capital firm, Draper Fisher Jurvetson.

title: Philips Unloads $1 Billion Stake in LG Display
description: Shares in LG Display, the flat-screen joint venture of LG Electronics and Royal Philips Electronics, fell nearly 9 percent Thursday after Philips sold about $1 billion worth of shares in the venture at the bottom of its pricing range.

title: Jenner& Block Names Levy to Top Post
description: In a major change at the top of one Chicagos white-shoe law firms, Jenner & Block has named Susan Levy as its new managing partner, replacing Gregory Gallopoulos, who will join the defense contractor General Dynamics.

title: Evergrande I.P.O. Set to Give China Another Billionaire
description: A new name is set to top Chinas rich list by the end of the month following the planned initial public offering of one of the countrys largest private real estate developers.

title: Sinosteel Makes Hostile Bid for Australias Midwest
description: Sinosteel of China has launched a hostile, all-cash offer for an Australian iron ore prospector Midwest in a deal that values Midwest at 1.2 billion Australian dollars, ($1.1 billion), as it aims to lock up scarce iron ore supplies.

title: V.C. Departs for Widgetland
description: Widget makers arent just drawing big money from investors, now theyre apparently luring the venture capitalists themselves.

title: Benchmark and Benioff Inject $6.5 Million into Zuora
description: Benchmark Capital and Salesforce.coms founder, Marc Benioff, have teamed up to invest $6.5 million in an online subscription software company, Zuora, which opened its Web site Thursday.

title: Specific Media Targets Adviva
description: An online ad network, Specific Media, has acquired a British display ad network, Adviva. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Remembering a Home for Music and Activism
description: Wetlands Preserved is a fond account of the rising, thriving and eventual closing of the TriBeCa club known as the Wetlands Preserve.

title: S.E.C. Suspends Trading of 26 Companies
description: Stepping up its efforts to combat fraud involving microcap stocks, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday temporarily suspended trading of 26 companies, saying they appeared to be involved in corporate hijacking. Corporate hijacking is a term for taking identities of defunct or inactive publicly traded companies.

title: As John McCain Calls It, a Second Childhood
description: More of your late night humor (send via the comment link below):

title: Merrill Settles With DVI Investors
description: Merrill Lynch has agreed to pay about $4.5 million to settle a lawsuit claiming it misled investors in the defunct health-care company DVI, the plaintiffs attorneys said.

title: Hong Kong Crime Stories
description: Set in Hong Kong just before the citys return to Chinese rule, Flash Point plays like the last hurrah of a criminal underclass facing the inevitable shrinking of its bottom line.

title: Duration Capital Said to Cut All Ties With JPMorgan
description: Duration Capital, one of several hedge funds forced to sell hundreds of millions of dollars of municipal bonds when their bets went awry, is severing its links with its main prime broker, JPMorgan Chase, according to Reuters.

title: When a Satellite Makes a Scene
description: David Hoffmans documentary Sputnik Mania, an account of that Soviet satellites effect on the American consciousness, deserves notice for its stunning clips (many of which were found on YouTube, including rarely seen images from sources in the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe). But its main asset is its style. Rather than rely solely on famous talking heads, the movie tells its story primarily through editing and narration and emphasizes its interviews with regular citizens who were kids when Sputnik I went up in 1957.

title: Lampert Raises Stake in AutoNation

title: Ill Take My Blue Plate Not-So-Special
description: As much as I enjoy watching Top Chef and effortlessly rattling off choice entries in the foodie vernacular  ceviche, amuse bouche, molecular gastronomy  Im not what you would call an adventurous eater. I convulse at the mere scent of banana and nothing embodies hell on earth for me quite like the texture of rice pudding. For better or worse, I was raised in a home where chicken was the norm and exotic dishes were discreetly fed to the dog as quickly as they were placed on the table. (Im remembering one instance in particular involving a rice-and-beef-stuffed pumpkin so vile even Sparky wouldnt eat it.) As far as I can tell, I am the typical, boring American eater; I like cheesy, crispy, fatty, salty or sweet food made with ingredients I can pronounce. I crave preservatives and chemically enhanced juices; I crave red-white-and-blue-dyed snack cakes filled with liquefied marshmallow substitute. High fructose corn syrup figuratively  and probably literally  courses through my veins. So you can imagine my growing distress at Americas growing palette.

title: Discovering an Intense, Crunchy Tomato
description: I ate a lot of raw vegetables on this swing through France, Italy, and Spain  some days, in fact, my stomach felt like a juicer. But when I go to markets I have to shop, and when I dont have a stove, I wind up eating uncooked beets, fennel, carrots, celery, green beans  I love the big flat romanos  and now even artichokes.

title: Discovering an Intense, Crunchy Tomato
description: (Photo: Tomatoes, from left: big cherries/small plums; a Genovese; and the Raf, from Spain. (Mark Bittman)) I ate a lot of raw vegetables on this swing through France, Italy, and Spain -- some days, in fact, my stomach felt like a juicer. But when I go to markets I have to shop, and when I don't have a stove, I wind up eating uncooked beets, fennel, carrots, celery, green beans -- I love the big flat romanos -- and now even artichokes.   I didn't see really nice-looking tomatoes, though, until we got to Rome, where I bought two kinds. On the left here are some sort of big cherries/small plums; they were tender, ripe, sweet -- decent, not super-complex flavor. On the right were a kind that looked like a variety I used to grow, but found to be completely different: Nearly as hard as an apple, they had amazing intensity -- almost like tomato paste in crunchy form. I could not stop eating them. (They were, raw, better than any dish served to me at the fancy restaurant I was taken to that same night, one not worth writing about.)   They stumped me. One, I didn't know what they were; two, if they were this hard, why weren't they shipped, preferably directly to my house; three, who used them, and for what?   I was about to post a "Help! Please!" to Bitten, but I was also meeting Mario Batali in Spain, so I brought the remaining tomato over. He called it Genovese (though it was clearly grown in the south), and said it was a salad tomato; that Italians sliced it very, very thin, to mitigate its crunchiness; and that it was served with lettuce.   Makes sense to me, but I wish I had a case to play with. I want to see if they ever soften, and I want to cook with them. Next time.   Meanwhile, in Madrid's Mercado de Paz, a lovely neighborhood market (there are many), I encountered -- as I did last year at this time -- the quite similar Raf tomato (pictured on the right), which I believe is from Valencia (I was told the word was Valenciana in any case). Also highly prized, also fairly expensive (the equivalent of $3 or $4 a pound, which is really not all that bad, considering), also quite crunchy. Given that these experiences happened in the month of March, I was ready to move to southern Europe.   Needless to say I came home. I'll tidy up with a couple of remaining thoughts from the trip, and then back to reality. Also, stay tuned for a slide show of photos from the market.

title: My friend TED
description: The TED spread is the difference between the interest rate banks charge each other on 3-month loans (3-month LIBOR) and the interest rate on 3-month U.S. Treasury bills. Its a measure of financial jitters. If banks believe that their peers are solid, they should be willing to lend each other money on almost the same terms as money lent to Uncle Sam. When they start demanding a big interest rate premium, thats a sign of fear.

title: Party Brief | Disguise the Limit
description: Last nights In Ballo in Maschera benefit at the Frick Collection drew a predictably attractive crowd of men in dinner jackets and ladies in varying states of formality. The partys fancy name (translation: the masked ball), and corresponding dress code, made a veiled reference to a special painting on loan to the museum  a 16th century portrait of a mysterious woman painted by the Italian Renaissance master Parmigianino. While the invitation (above) decreed a dress code of black tie e maschera, the uptown crowds willingness to mask themselves varied. Over the course of the evening we witnessed all types  from The Classicist (in a Venetian-style eye mask con handle) to The Sex Kitten (a ribbon of fancy black lace tied over the eyes), from The Psycho (a terrifying translucent iteration of the Eyes Wide Shut mask) to The Jolly Enthusiast (a woman in a Vegas-style eye mask, a rhapsody in blue feathers). And, regrettably, plenty in the category of The Wimp (senza maschera).

description: There has been a lot of talk lately about the right and the wrong way to play the game. We have heard Shelley Duncans side. But what about the Tampa Bay minor leaguer whose collision with Francisco Cervelli broke Cervellis wrist last Saturday?

Its a science museum whose mission is especially important at a time when cash-strapped local schools are eliminating science programs, and Im a big believer in it. Details are here.

title: Our Warm-Up Is Your Workout
description: I cant stop thinking about CrossFit. Greg Glassman, the founder, has, since 2001, been building a video-driven online fitness empire. Is empire the word? Its more like a ministry. A tyranny. With bellowing and dogmatic seminars and psych-up speeches that make you sit like a sheep and think you finally understand the secret of existence.

description: A top terrorism expert believes Abu Yahya Al-Libi has revealed the secret to bringing down the global Jihadist movement.

Glenn Loury of Brown University, left, and Bruce Bartlett of the National Center for Policy Analysis debate whether black voters could migrate to the G.O.P. in November.

description: ATLANTA  The Alabama band members thought they were being cute when they started chanting, Not your brother.

description: [Warning: the following is a stream of consciousness scrawl written in the heat of qualifying  but I thought Id share the kind of notes I usually write only for myself for things like race reports on Sundays.:]

description: Months of violence have taken their toll on Kenya's tourism industry. Jeffrey Gettleman reports from the Masai Mara game reserve.

description: Melena Ryzik and Jeremy Beiler head south for indie rock, tacos and pool parties (not necessarily in that order).

description: ATLANTA  What was that? The Georgia Dome is shaking. Its loud, like a train is riding along the domes roof.

title: 1,700 Bands, Rocking as the CD Industry Reels
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  I dont want to feel like I dont have a future, sang the Shout Out Louds, one of more than 1,700 bands that have been performing day and night at Austins clubs, halls, meeting rooms, parking lots and street corners since Wednesday.

title: Playwrights Horizons Announces Season
description: Playwrights Horizons has announced the first four of the six scheduled productions of its 2008-9 season. They are Three Changes, a world premiere of a play by Nicky Silver, directed by Wilson Milam; Kindness, a world premiere of a play written by Adam Rapp, who will also direct; Prayer for My Enemy, the New York premiere of a play by Craig Lucas, directed by Bartlett Sher; and Our House, the New York premiere of a play by Theresa Rebeck.

title: Pittsburgh Gets Another Chance at the Final
description: The Pittsburgh basketball teams success in the Big East tournament has always been impressive. Now it is historic.

title: Ravel: A Bit Wicked, a Bit Nostalgic
description: A minor misfortune of Ravels legacy is the relative obscurity of his best piano pieces and the prominence of their candified orchestral versions. Perhaps the best thing about Hlne Wicketts evening at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday was the chance to hear this French composers original thoughts for his Valses Nobles et Sentimentales.

title: Can Democrats Stop Their Squabbling?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Life in Art
description: For her swan song on Thursday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Rosamond Bernier, above, whose subject that evening was French couture, wore a gauzy dress in which she resembled an exotic bird with green-and-black plumage. And that, of course, allowed her to talk about her friendship with the dresss designer, Halston, along with all the other designers and writers and painters that Ms. Bernier, a kind of Cal Ripken Jr. of the art-and-culture lecture circuit, has known in her 91 years. As with Mr. Ripken, who holds the Major League baseball record for most consecutive games played, it is usually best with Ms. Bernier to cite the statistics and step out of the way. She gave her first lecture at the Met in 1971, followed by over 200 more, many about artists who were her friends: Picasso, Matisse, Braque, Lger, Mir, Max Ernst, Giacometti. In a naughty world, she said at the end of Thursdays lecture, which she had decided would be her last there, the Metropolitan Museum has been an oasis of civility and civilization. To have been connected with it, even in a modest way, has been a joy and a privilege.

title: Gere Is No Longer a Wanted Man in India
description: Indias top court suspended an arrest warrant on Friday against Richard Gere for kissing the Bollywood actress Shilpa Shetty at an AIDS awareness event in New Delhi on April 15 last year, The Associated Press reported. Chief Justice K. G. Balakrishnan and Justice R. V.
