Raveendran indefinitely stayed the warrant, which was issued by a court in Jaipur, a northwestern Indian city, for breaking public obscenity laws after Mr. Gere embraced and kissed Ms. Shetty on her cheek. Some religious leaders said the pair had offended the sensibilities of Indias traditionally conservative culture.

title: In Revising Clean Air Rules, E.P.A. Draws Praise and Criticism in the Same Week
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency announced tougher rules governing the soot emissions from train and boat diesel engines on Friday, winning praise from the very environmentalists who have been attacking the Bush administration for its handling of smog standards earlier in the week.

title: Delegate Battles Snarl Democrats in Two States
description: Democrats in Michigan and Florida struggled Friday to resolve the impasse over their disputed January primaries, coming up with a plan to hold a June primary in Michigan while remaining deadlocked in Florida.

title: Return From the Serious Life: Reality TV Has Paris Hilton Again
description: LOS ANGELES  Paris Hilton vows that she will make that promised charity trip to Rwanda. And she definitely plans to build that transitional home for women leaving prison that she spoke so enthusiastically about last summer when she was released from jail.

title: For Florida, Warnings of Complexity of Mail-In Voting
description: SEATTLE  As political opposition appeared to dim the prospects of a mail-in Democratic presidential primary in Florida, election officials in states with experience in mail-in voting suggested that it might be just as well. The Florida Democratic Party would face major logistical challenges if the plan went forward.

title: Resurrection Is Often Misunderstood by Christians and Jews
description: As Christians in most of the world approach the celebration of Jesus Resurrection, it is startling to find three distinguished scholars, all known for scrupulous attention to theological tradition and biblical sources, agreeing that the very idea of resurrection is widely and badly misunderstood.

title: House Votes to Reject Immunity for Phone Companies Involved in Wiretaps
description: WASHINGTON  After its first secret session in a quarter-century, the House on Friday rejected retroactive immunity for the phone companies that took part in the National Security Agencys program of eavesdropping without warrants, and it voted to place tighter restrictions on the governments wiretapping powers.

title: A Jailhouse Conversion Splits Terrorists, and In-Laws
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia

title: Rape Goes Undetected and Officers Are Disciplined
description: Two rookie police officers have been disciplined for lying about making rounds in a housing project in Brooklyn where a 30-year-old woman was raped in a stairwell last week, the police said on Friday.

title: Leaving Musharraf Behind
description: Parliamentary elections in Pakistan last month delivered a verdict that was just clean enough to be credible  a stern rout of President Pervez Musharrafs party. Now, rivals Asif Ali Zardari and Nawaz Sharif, the leading opposition politicians, have further defied expectations by joining forces in a deal that could force Mr. Musharraf from office.

title: Tests Show Campus Gunman Had Stopped His Medicines
description: CHICAGO  Toxicology results released on Friday for the gunman who killed five students and himself at Northern Illinois University in February appear to confirm that he had stopped taking his medications before the shooting and was not using illegal drugs or alcohol.

title: Trojans Make It Close, but Bruins Reach Final
description: LOS ANGELES  When U.C.L.A. and Southern California met in the postseason for the first time Friday night, everything surrounding the neutral court at Staples Center was divided evenly.

title: Goal Set for Reducing Backlog on Citizenship Applications
description: Immigration officials said on Friday that they expected to complete about 930,000 citizenship applications in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, reducing a huge backlog in a time frame that would allow many new citizens to register to vote in the November elections.

title: Stepping Out After a Makeover
description: It loomed just out of reach, a tantalizing prize that Lord & Taylor could not win: Juicy Couture, one of the hottest womens clothing brands and a best seller in rival stores.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the special Museums section on Tuesday with an article about two Chicago building projects reversed the identities of two architects who designed the Spertus Institute of Jewish Studies. Mark Sexton was at the left and Ron Krueck was on the right.

title: Chiara Lubich, Who Founded Catholic Lay Group, Dies at 88
description: ROME  Chiara Lubich, who became one of the most influential women in the Roman Catholic Church as the founder of the Focolare lay movement, which works to improve ties among faiths, died early Friday at her home south of Rome. She was 88.

title: Prosecutor in Spitzer Case Is Seen as Aggressive but Fair
description: The lead prosecutor in the prostitution case that led to Gov. Eliot Spitzers resignation has been described as a classic hard-charging government lawyer, confident and talented yet self-deprecating and fair, who would not allow politics to hinder good judgment.

title: Mexico: 33 Bodies Unearthed in 2 Backyards
description: Investigators said they had found another 19 bodies buried behind two houses used by drug dealers in Ciudad Jurez, bringing the total number of corpses found there to 33. Agents began digging behind the houses on March 1, after they raided one of them, found 3,700 pounds of marijuana and arrested several people. All but three of the bodies appear to be men, and most have been buried at least five years. The cause of their deaths has not been determined, though Ciudad Jurez has for years been plagued by kidnappings and turf wars among drug gangs.

title: NATO Expansion, and a Bush Legacy, Are in Doubt
description: WASHINGTON  President Bushs efforts to cement a trans-Atlantic legacy by adding three nations to NATO appear in disarray as the alliance struggles with internal political divisions, new tensions with Russia and the combat mission in Afghanistan that have exposed disparities of might and will among current members, officials, diplomats and analysts said.

title: Want to Buy Some Pollution?
description: LATER this year, Massachusetts and other Northeastern states will hold the nations first auction of greenhouse gas emissions permits. Congress should take note: this market-based, technology-neutral auction is a model for how to encourage power generators to limit their emissions. And it could provide the foundation for a federal-state partnership to revolutionize energy use.

title: Crane Topples in Manhattan, Killing at Least 4 People
description: A large crane at a construction site on Manhattans East Side collapsed Saturday afternoon, killing at least four people and injuring more than 10, officials at the scene said.

title: A Vision of Mozart
description: A previously unidentified portrait has been declared to be that of Mozart, Agence France-Presse reported. The oil painting was originally owned by the family of Johann Lorenz Hagenauer, a close friend of the Mozarts in Salzburg, Austria, then part of the Holy Roman Empire. Mozart expert Daniel N. Leeson first realized the paintings significance. This is arguably the most important Mozart portrait to be discovered since the composers death in 1791 and only the fourth known authentic portrait of him from his Vienna years, said Prof.  Cliff Eisen of Kings College Londons department of music. Mr. Eisen has authenticated the work, which measures 19 inches by 14 inches and shows the composer in profile, wearing a red jacket that he once described in detail in a letter. Mr. Eisen, after studying Mozarts correspondence, archival documents and estate auction records, said he believed that the work was painted around 1783 by Joseph Hickel, a painter to the Imperial Court of Austria. An American collector bought the portrait in 2005, unaware of its significance.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on March 3 about efforts by some cities and states to change the way their bonds are rated referred imprecisely to the payments state and local governments make for credit ratings. The issuers of the bonds pay a single fee to ratings firms like Standard & Poors, whether or not the securities are insured. They do not pay a second fee for insured ratings. (Bond insurance companies also pay the ratings firms annual fees, which increase as the companies insurance portfolios grow.)

title: AIDS in South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Credit Cards Are Frothy, Not Bubbly
description: A month ago, BusinessWeek ran a cover article essentially predicting that credit cards would be the next shoe to drop in our increasingly precarious economy. The party was paid for with credit cards, read the magazines bold cover line. The hangover will be a whopper.

title: Vanderbilt Competition Comes Down to the Wire
description: At the Spring North American Championships in Detroit, the final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams takes place on Saturday. Play can be seen live on www.bridgebase.com, starting at 1 p.m. Eastern time.

title: Legislator Points Finger at Former Councilwoman
description: In a videotape played on Friday during her corruption trial, Assemblywoman Diane M. Gordon said she was not the only public official in her neighborhood interested in trading favors to a developer for a free house.

title: Police Kill U.S. Soldier in Germany
description: BERLIN  German police officers shot and killed a United States Army soldier in Bavaria after he took a former girlfriend hostage, the local police said Friday.

title: Virginia Tech Stands Out With Victory Over Miami
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Virginia Techs basketball players said Friday that they had no special plans to watch the N.C.A.A. tournament selection show Sunday to find out if they made the cut.

title: Privileged Status at Risk, Malays Protest After Election Losses
description: PENANG, Malaysia  Chanting Long live the Malays! several hundred members of Malaysias largest ethnic group gathered Friday on this largely ethnic Chinese island, defying a police ban on protests and raising tensions after sharp electoral losses by the countrys Malay-dominated governing coalition.

title: Despite Loss, Brey Sees Bright Future
description: Notre Dame Coach Mike Brey turned to his associate coach, Sean Kearney, with about two minutes left in Notre Dames Big East tournament quarterfinal loss to Marquette on Thursday and asked a simple question: How did we beat these guys once this season?

title: A Wall Street Domino Theory
description: The Federal Reserves unusual decision to provide emergency assistance to Bear Stearns underscores a long-building concern that one failure could spread across the financial system.

title: Georgia Tech President to Lead Smithsonian
description: A year after the head of the Smithsonian Institution resigned amid financial scandal, prompting a Congressional uproar and an overhaul of the organizations governance, the museum complex named a new chief on Saturday to set it on course for the future.

title: The Winds of Albany
description: David Paterson was just about to unwrap his lunch, a curried chicken dish delivered to his Statehouse office from a local restaurant, when the governors office called.

title: U.S. Soldier Killed by German Police
description: BERLIN  German police shot and killed a United States Army soldier in Bavaria after he took a former girlfriend hostage, the local police said Friday.

title: In 50-Shot Case, Scrutiny Hits a Moving Target: Sean Bells Car
description: Fourteen minutes past 4 on a chilly November morning, a Nissan Altima in Queens stopped being simply an automobile that Sean Bell had borrowed from his fiance for his bachelor party. Depending on who is describing it, the Altima became at that moment a threat, a weapon or a means of escape.

title: Gingerly, the Athlete Turns Activist
description: In a public service announcement recently shown on cable television and available at several sites online, Kobe Bryant asks for help on a mission that is somewhat more daunting than winning another N.B.A. title.

title: C.I.A. Secretly Held Qaeda Suspect, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  The Central Intelligence Agency secretly detained a suspected member of Al Qaeda for at least six months beginning last summer as part of a program in which C.I.A. officers have been authorized by President Bush to use harsh interrogation techniques, American officials said Friday.

title: Reformers Make Gains in Iran Vote
description: TEHRAN, March 25  With about half of the races for Parliament decided Saturday, more than 30 reformers appear to have won seats although most of their most prominent members had been barred from running by the countrys conservative establishment.

title: President Acknowledges Strains on the Economy
description: President Bush on Friday acknowledged more starkly than ever that the economy has slipped into trouble, dogged by falling home prices and turmoil in financial markets, but he inveighed against government bailouts aimed at limiting the pain.

title: Looks Like a Conflict to Us
description: Former Attorney General John Ashcroft appeared before Congress this week to defend a multimillion-dollar no-bid contract that he got from a top federal prosecutor who also happened to be a former employee. A day earlier  by coincidence, we are sure  the Justice Department issued new guidelines for how these lucrative assignments will be handed out.

title: Stephen Colvin, 64, Inventive Heart Surgeon, Is Dead
description: Dr. Stephen B. Colvin, a heart surgeon who promoted the now widespread use of a pioneering procedure for repairing a leaky heart valve and who also performed heart surgery on children all over the world, died last Saturday in Manhattan. He was 64.

title: Eli Lilly E-Mail Discussed Unapproved Use of Drug
description: ANCHORAGE  John C. Lechleiter, an Eli Lilly official who is about to become the companys top executive, wrote an e-mail message in 2003 that appears to have encouraged Lilly to promote its schizophrenia medicine Zyprexa for a use not approved by federal drug regulators.

title: More Than a Few Encouraging Signs From a Conductor Waiting in the Wings
description: The classical music world is counting on Alan Gilbert to bring fresh vision and youthful excitement to the New York Philharmonic when he takes over as music director in 2009. That he is poised to do so came through palpably on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall when he conducted an urgent, richly colorful and unusually lucid account of Strausss opulent tone poem Ein Heldenleben (A Heros Life).

title: With Contracts Expired, Nurses at Four Hospitals Cite Frustration
description: The largest union of nurses in New York City is voicing dismay that contracts at four large hospitals expired weeks ago without a new agreement being reached.

title: Injury Ends Currys Frustrating Season
description: Eddy Currys bitterly disappointing season will end in an operating room.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the awarding of the Templeton Prize to Michael Heller, a Roman Catholic priest, referred incompletely to a center for the study of science and theology that Professor Heller plans to create with the prize money. It is a joint venture between the Jagiellonian University and the Pontifical Academy of Theology in Krakow. It is not solely based at the Pontifical Academy of Theology.

title: Political Ally of Mexican President Embroiled in Scandal
description: MEXICO CITY  Mexicos interior minister, a rising political star seen as President Felipe Calderns right-hand man, has become embroiled in a scandal over influence-peddling that threatens to sink his career and hobble Mr. Calderns efforts to push important laws through Congress.

title: Candidates for President Put in Calls to Paterson
description: ALBANY  As he prepares to assume New York States highest elected office, Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson is getting plenty of attention from the Democratic candidates for president.

title: Suit Seeks to Bar Party of Premier in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys secular establishment struck a desperate blow against the governing party of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Friday, when a senior prosecutor filed a legal case to close it down.

title: Costs Surge for Stocking the Pantry
description: The government announced Friday that the cost of food had gone up yet again. This came as no revelation to Bruce Newton, a single father of two children.

title: One Adviser Among Many, Under Lights Over Israel
description: WASHINGTON , March 14

title: George Speaks, Badly
description: Watching George W. Bush address the New York financial community Friday brought back many memories. Unfortunately, they were about his speech right after Hurricane Katrina, the one when he said: America will be a stronger place for it.

title: Another Side of Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: Run on Big Wall St. Bank Spurs Rescue Backed by U.S.
description: Just three days ago, the head of Bear Stearns, the beleaguered investment bank, sought to assure Wall Street that his firm was safe.

title: Expedias Path to Expansion Passes Through India
description: Earlier this month, Expedia, the online travel company, entered the Indian market with Expedia.co.in, the 17th Expedia Web site worldwide. Expedia also owns Hotels.com and TripAdvisor, which operate both in the United States and overseas, as well as Hotwire, which operates only in the United States. In addition, it owns a controlling interest in eLong, a Chinese online travel company.

title: Bailout Unnerves Investors, and Shares Take Steep Fall
description: Shares took a dive on Friday after an emergency bailout for Bear Stearns, the investment bank, rocked Wall Streets confidence in the fragile credit market.

title: A Legal Journey From Enron to the N.F.L.
description: WASHINGTON  Michael Levy paid little attention to the N.F.L., the New England Patriots or the teams spying scandal until Matt Walsh became his client. Now Levy finds himself in the middle of an N.F.L. investigation, standing between Walsh and a long list of powerful people who want to talk to him.

title: After Receiving Suspension, Duncan Will Face Rays
description: SARASOTA, Fla.  The Yankees play two games Saturday, one in Lakeland against the Detroit Tigers and one at home against the Tampa Bay Rays. In scheduling Shelley Duncan for the Rays game, the Yankees are essentially daring Tampa Bay to escalate a feud.

title: Can Democrats Stop Their Squabbling?
description: To the Editor:

title: Improvements at Land Border Push Smugglers West, to the Pacific
description: LOS ANGELES  Three Mexican men were charged Friday with smuggling people into the United States after an ill-fated effort to ferry a dozen people to San Diego by boat from an island off Tijuana, Mexico, ended with the vessel adrift for nearly two days.

title: One Small Step for Electronic Waste
description: The sensible way to handle the growing load of electronic waste  televisions, computers, printers and other no longer new technology  is to make manufacturers responsible for their proper disposal.

title: Neverland Is to Remain Jackson's Property
description: Michael Jackson has worked out a confidential agreement with Fortress Investment Group to retain ownership of his 2,500-acre Neverland ranch in Los Olivos, Calif., northwest of Santa Barbara, The Associated Press reported his lawyer as saying. Because Mr. Jackson owed $24.5 million on the property, it had been scheduled for auction on Wednesday. Mr. Jackson has not lived on the ranch since his acquittal on child molestation charges in 2005. A close associate of Mr. Jacksons, who requested anonymity because of the difficult nature of the matter, said it was not clear whether Mr. Jackson would keep Neverland.

title: Civil Rights on the Basketball Court
description: Black Magic opens with the details of a secret basketball game played in Durham, N. C., in a locked gym with no fans to witness it. On a Sunday morning in 1944 the innovative African-American coach John McLendon led his fast-breaking team from the North Carolina College for Negroes in a home game against an intramural squad from Duke Universitys medical school.

title: Founder of Trek Bicycle, Richard Burke, Dies at 73
description: Richard Burke, a founder of the Trek Bicycle Corporation, which capitalized on the luster of Lance Armstrongs victories in the Tour de France to reshape the way top-of-the-line bikes are manufactured, died Monday in Milwaukee. He was 73 and lived in Milwaukee.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 14, 2008

title: Hibbert Comes Around and Propels the Hoyas
description: After Roy Hibbert of Georgetown scored the last of his 25 points in a 72-55 victory over West Virginia on Friday night in a Big East tournament semifinal, he stomped around the corner of the floor at Madison Square Garden.

title: F.D.R.s Safety Net Gets a Big Stretch
description: It was an old-fashioned bank run that forced Bear Stearns to turn to the government for salvation on Friday. The difference is that Bear Stearns is not a commercial bank, and is therefore not eligible for the protections those banks received 75 years ago when Franklin D. Roosevelt halted bank runs with government guarantees.

title: Obama Describes Developer Deal as a Mistake
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama said Friday that he had made repeated lapses of judgment in dealing with an indicted Chicago real estate developer, Antoin Rezko, and acknowledged that Mr. Rezko had raised more money for his political campaigns than he had previously disclosed.

title: Study Quantifies the Frustrations of Parking
description: Its official: There really is nowhere to park in Lower Manhattan.

title: Good Banks Are Punished With the Bad
description: BANK stocks hit fresh multiyear lows this week, and unlike earlier routs the damage was not confined to institutions thought to be most heavily exposed to bad mortgages. Banks that had seemed to come through the crisis with their reputations and capital intact, because of better judgment or maybe better luck, played catch-up in the latest leg of the race to the bottom.

title: Lawsuit Is Settled Over Sale of Clear Channels TV Unit
description: Providence Equity Partners, a private equity group, reached a settlement Friday with one of the banks financing its purchase of the television unit of Clear Channel Communication, people briefed on the matter said Friday.

title: Conquering Castaways
description: On Thursday CBSs Survivor: Micronesia led with 13.1 million viewers at 8 p.m., followed by ABCs Lost, with 11.9 million at 9, Nielsen estimated. Lost placed first in the coveted 18- to-49 demographic, but CBS won the night over all in total viewers and in the 18-to-49 set, thanks to Survivor and repeats of CSI (11.4 million) and Without a Trace (9.9 million). Fox placed second in total viewers , but third, behind ABC, among 18- to-49-year-olds. Low ratings for repeats of My Name Is Earl (4.3 million at 8) put NBC in fourth place, though The Celebrity Apprentice picked up some steam (8.1 million) at 9.

title: Rare American Sweep on World Cup Slopes
description: BORMIO, Italy  There were bear hugs, superlatives and inexpertly sprayed sparkling wine at the finish line Friday when Lindsey Vonn struggled to get the cork out of a bottle of Italian bubbly on the awards stand before gleefully dousing her teammate Ted Ligety.

title: Return of West Side Diner (and Hangout) Is Planned
description: The Market Diner, which fed New Yorkers night and day from 1962 until 2006, will be reopening in about two months, according to a restaurateur with a glistening greasy-spoon rsum of his own.

title: Getting Out of the Mess the Neocons Made
description: To the Editor:

title: Prominent Trial Lawyer Pleads Guilty to Bribery
description: Richard F. Scruggs, the Mississippi lawyer who built a fortune off asbestos litigation and went on to wring billions from cigarette makers, on Friday ducked what might have been the toughest legal battle of his storied career. Mr. Scruggs pleaded guilty Friday to conspiring to bribe a Mississippi state judge.

title: Ailing Author Gives to Alzheimers Research
description: Stricken with Alzheimers disease, the British author Terry Pratchett, 59, has donated $1 million toward research into this debilitating brain ailment, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Pratchett, whose best-selling Discworld books (55 million copies worldwide) are set in a flat universe balanced on the backs of four elephants standing on a giant turtle, said insufficient funds and the perception that Alzheimers was a fairly quiet disease compared with cancer, were stalling efforts to learn more about it.

title: Obama Denounces Statements of His Pastor as Inflammatory
description: In the handful of years Senator Barack Obama has spent in the national spotlight, his stance toward his pastor has gone from glowing praise to growing distance to  as of Friday  strong criticism.

title: Student Aid Availability Questioned
description: WASHINGTON  The federal education secretary told Congressional lawmakers Friday that despite tight credit markets, students would still be able to find a lender to help them borrow money for college.

title: Confronting a Killer Epidemic That Wouldnt Die
description: If youre hungry, heres a piece of your friend, snarls a jailer in the post-apocalyptic action picture Doomsday, sliding a plateful of charbroiled man-flesh to a captive.

title: Powerful Tornado Hits Downtown Atlanta
description: ATLANTA  A powerful tornado scored a direct hit on the commercial center of downtown Atlanta on Friday night, blowing windows out of dozens of high-rise buildings, tossing trees and cars, and severely damaging many of the citys landmarks, including the CNN Center, the Georgia Dome, Philips Arena, Grady Memorial Hospital and Centennial Olympic Park.

title: A Dispute Over Utah Land Intensifies
description: A long-simmering dispute over the best use for millions of acres of federal land has erupted publicly with the request by some Utah legislators that a well-known local environmental organization open its books after two of its directors were sentenced to prison in separate multimillion-dollar bank fraud cases.

title: Fair Goes From Feast to Tasting Menu
description: It is hard to know if the once-distinguished International Asian Art Fair has been dealt a fatal blow or just knocked backward into starter mode, a phase it had previously managed to skip. The fair was born grand 12 years ago, and for a while grew only grander, sailing along as the flagship of Asia Week of sales and auctions in New York, and becoming a gold standard for art fairs in general.

title: Mets Schoeneweis Puts Painful Year Behind Him
description: JUPITER, Fla.  Scott Schoeneweis remembers that when he slipped on a just-watered field in Oakland during the 2005 season, his fellow Toronto pitchers buckled over in laughter. They did not realize that Schoeneweis had just sustained the worst injury of his career.

title: Politics Tests a Town Unity Forged by Gunshots
description: KIRKWOOD, Mo.  After a shared horror, people in tightknit towns often grow still closer. So no one was surprised when signs began sprouting on the wide lawns here: Kirkwood stands together, grieves together, heals together.

title: Up and Running in Space
description: Dextres got juice. The new Canadian robot for the International Space Station, known as Dextre, had been unable to draw power from the station because of an improperly configured data cable in its storage platform. The $209 million device would have been ruined by the cold of space within days. Astronauts fixed the problem Friday night by connecting Dextre to a power source on the stations robot arm. Astronauts also entered the new room for the station, a part of the Kibo science laboratory and the first major component from Japan.

title: Dollar Doesnt Stretch Far in Buying Global Goods
description: THE great American appetite for imports is finally waning, but the country is finding that buying less is not the same thing as paying less.

title: With Flair for Dramatic, Volunteers Grab Victory
description: ATLANTA  There were lobs at the rim, no-look passes, behind-the-back-passes and all kinds of floating, off-balance shots. Under the bright lights of the Southeastern Conference tournament, with a potential No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament at risk, Tennessee held what amounted to an open gym here early Friday afternoon with freestyle basketball.

title: Spare the Pork, but Dish Some Candor
description: Call it coincidence. But with Senator John McCain campaigning as a leading opponent of budgetary pork, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama suddenly endorsed their Republican rivals election-year call for a moratorium on earmarks. The Senate overwhelmingly rejected the proposal on Thursday, but the candidates rare convergence was another demonstration of the power of symbolism over substance in the campaign.

title: Mount Everest Still Beckons, but Nepal Warns, Not So Fast
description: Come early May, the darkness and the hurricane-force winds will fade and in the lambent daylight a calm will fall on the highest place in the world. Mountain climbers await this interlude, the Everest weather window, when nature leaves its great summit open for a two-week spell before the monsoons come.

title: Big Turnout in Iranian Parliamentary Elections
description: TEHRAN  Iranians appeared to have turned out in large numbers on Friday to vote in parliamentary elections nationwide. In Tehran, lines formed at major mosques where polling took place.

title: Tainted Blood Drug to Face Import Tests
description: The Food and Drug Administration said Friday that all heparin products being imported into the United States would be stopped and tested for a possibly dangerous contaminant. The action comes after the agencys inspectors in China found the contaminant in 20 of the 28 lots of the drugs active ingredient inside a plant that supplied it to much of the American market.

title: Cuban Players Fled Their Team for an Uncertain Future
description: At first, Loanni Cartaya Prieto called his grandfather to say hello.

title: Meningitis Suspected in Students Death
description: An 18-year-old student at a state college on Lake Ontario died on Friday from a suspected case of bacterial meningitis. Separately, two students at Cornell University, a 21-year-old woman and a 19-year-old man, have been hospitalized in the span of less than a week with the condition, health officials said.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Friday about West Virginias 78-72 victory over Connecticut in the Big East mens basketball tournament reversed the outcome of a March 1 game between the teams. UConn defeated West Virginia.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the night that Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York spent with a prostitute named Kristen in a Washington hotel, as detailed in an affidavit filed as part of a federal investigation of a prostitution ring, included incorrect information from the affidavit about an Amtrak train referred to in a text message as a possible itinerary for Kristens trip from New York to Washington. Train No. 129 leaves Pennsylvania Station at 4:25 p.m., not 5:39, and arrives in Washington at 7:40 p.m., not 9. (The later timetable applies to Train No. 193.)

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on Thursday, about the depth of the expanded Big East Conference in mens basketball, referred imprecisely in some copies to four league teams that have won national titles. Georgetown, Syracuse, Villanova and Connecticut captured championships while in the conference; they are not the only current members with national titles. (The others  Louisville, Cincinnati and Marquette  were national champions before joining the Big East.)

title: A Movement, a Plan, a Canal
description: Washington

title: Australia Mine Operator Gets Bid From China
description: SYDNEY  The Sinosteel Corporation, the Chinese metals giant, made a hostile bid Friday for an Australian iron ore producer, underscoring Chinas ambition to secure raw materials to support its economy.

title: Two Choreographers, Disparate Visions
description: Usually, artistic directors give split bills to choreographers who they believe are promising but not yet ready to muster a full evenings worth of work on their own. The often disparate pairings can work magically. They can also leave you scratching your head.

title: Moving With Rigor and Then Doing It Again and Again
description: If choreographers had smooth-talking agents to pitch their shows, Brian Brooks would present no problem. Judson Dance Theater meets Elizabeth Streb Lite, an Armani-suited figure might say. Minimalism meets flamboyance; kitsch meets rigor.

title: In Groove on a Familiar Course, Singh Leaves Opponents Queasy
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Above him the gray clouds boiled, ready to drop rain on the Bay Hill Club. Behind him was most of the days work, 11 pars, a chip-in birdie, a bogey, a chip-in eagle and three birdie putts. In front of him, 441 yards of a par-4 hole.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about a Pentagon review of videotaping of interrogations misstated the legal status of Ali al-Marri, who has been imprisoned by the military since 2003 after being designated an enemy combatant. Mr. Marri is challenging the Pentagons assertion that it has the right to hold him indefinitely; the issue of whether the Pentagon can indeed do that has not been settled legally. (A federal appeals court panel ruled 2 to 1 in June that Mr. Marris detention violated the Constitution, a decision that is under review by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.)

title: Chenoweth Bows Out
description: Kristen Chenoweth, above, has withdrawn from the English National Opera production of Leonard Bernsteins Candide, Playbill reported. A statement said she faced unforeseen television filming commitments following the resolution of the Hollywood writers strike. Ms. Chenoweth is a member of the cast of the ABC series Pushing Daisies, scheduled to resume filming in June. Candide opens in previews on June 23 at the London Coliseum. Ms. Chenoweth will be replaced by the American soprano Anna Christy in five performances, beginning with the first preview. Casting for later performances is to be announced.

title: Tracing the Ripples That Flow From Violence
description: In the new Line of Descent, the choreographer Aviva Geismar focuses on violence, though her object is not to capture its direct impact but the repercussions that afflict generations to come. Her own background as the child of a Holocaust survivor, as she writes in a program note, led to a curiosity about how similar backgrounds have affected others.

title: Filling the Corporate Bench
description: IT has been 10 years since consultants at McKinsey & Company published a study, The War for Talent, that warned of an imminent executive shortage. If anything, a different set of McKinsey consultants now say, the problem has become worse.

title: Saving Stray Animals
description: To the Editor:

title: Fate of the IAC Dispute Is Now Up to the Judge
description: WILMINGTON, Del.  The battle of media titans now awaits the words of a Solomon.

title: Nepal Puts Everest Off Limits During Chinas Olympic Torch Relay in May
description: NEW DELHI  There are two routes to the worlds highest peak, and both are scheduled to be off limits to mountaineers this spring, as Beijing strives to inaugurate the Summer Olympics free of pro-Tibetan protests.

title: Times Company Names Treasurer
description: Laurena L. Emhoff, assistant treasurer of The New York Times Company, has been promoted to vice president and treasurer, the company said on Friday.

title: Ailment Sidelines a Singer, but the Opera Still Goes On
description: First Tristan, now Isolde.

title: Chinese Forces Say Theyve Secured Tibets Capital
description: BEIJING  Thousands of Buddhist monks and other Tibetans clashed with the riot police in a second Chinese city on Saturday, while the authorities said they had regained control of the Tibetan capital, Lhasa, a day after a rampaging mob ransacked shops and set fire to cars and storefronts in a deadly riot.

title: Young Frankenstein Marches Off on a New Path for Tickets
description: Look closely at the latest television commercial for The New Mel Brooks Musical Young Frankenstein. After the usual production numbers and excited narration comes an announcement: All tickets $50 to $120. Nothing for $450, $350 or even $225. As if Mr. Brookss previous musical, The Producers, the show that introduced the premium ticket in 2001, never happened.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about a Pentagon review of videotaping of interrogations misstated the legal status of Ali al-Marri, who has been imprisoned by the military since 2003 after being designated an enemy combatant. Mr. Marri is challenging the Pentagons assertion that it has the right to hold him indefinitely; the issue of whether the Pentagon can indeed do that has not been settled legally. (A federal appeals court panel ruled 2 to 1 in June that Mr. Marris detention violated the Constitution, a decision that is under review by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.) (Go to Article)

title: Louis Olah, 79, Racetracks Keeper of Silks, Is Dead
description: Louis Olah, a 4-foot-8-inch, 90-pound jockey who later became a giant in the thoroughbred industry among the jockeys and owners whose colorful silks he cleaned for more than 40 years, died Saturday in Queens. He was 79 and lived in Howard Beach.

title: McCain Plans a Fund-Raiser in London for $1,000 a Plate
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain has been averaging a fund-raiser a day in Americas pockets of affluence  hotel ballrooms in New York, Atlanta, Chicago  but now he will expand his pursuit of campaign donations at a $1,000-a-plate lunch at the 18th-century Spencer House in London.

title: Heathrow Opens New Terminal
description: LONDON  Billed as a pristine departure from gloomy walkways, threadbare carpets, lost bags and institutionalized delays, a fifth terminal at Heathrow Airport was officially inaugurated Friday, opening a contentious new chapter in the battle between aviation and the environment.

title: All the Parks a Stage, and This Proves It
description: Ladies and Gents, a noir-ish thriller from Ireland with a cast of six, will open on Monday for a two-week engagement in the public bathrooms near the Bethesda Fountain in Central Park. Yes, that is right. The play is being put on in the bathrooms, the audience standing in a line along the stalls. Go ahead, make the clever scatological joke. Come up with some headlines for bad reviews.

title: South by Southwest, Shot by Shot
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The South by Southwest festival got under way on Wednesday here in an annual rite of spring for the music business that this year has brought more than 1,700 bands to town. The New York Times sent its chief pop music critic, Jon Pareles, to attend, along with a team of writers and photographers. Real-time dispatches from the festival have been posted at nytimes.com/artsbeat. What follows are highlights of the groups efforts.

title: A Blue Ross 10-Speed Isnt Hard to Find; A Bomber Who Rode It Is
description: The Ross bicycle arrived just after World War II, along with the baby boom, the modern suburb and the cul-de-sac. Millions of the bikes left the companys New York City factories and wound up on streets all over the United States.

title: Mourning After 9/11, Outrage Ever Since
description: This was a perfect idea, Wilton Sekzer believed. His sons name chalked onto a bomb headed to Iraq. When he served with the 101st Airborne in Vietnam, those kinds of requests came in all the time. A husband, a brother, a son  could you please write their name on some artillery pieces? No problem, Mr. Sekzer recalled.

title: Free Music? Only With a Fight
description: LIKE most purveyors of media, music labels are flailing about for a new business model even as their old one is quickly becoming outmoded.

title: A Giants Roaring, Faintly Echoed
description: At the climax of Miltons epic Paradise Lost, Satan is ecstatic in triumph. He has not only freed himself from the bonds tying him to hell, he has also disrupted heavens great human experiment, lured Eve into tasting the forbidden fruit, sabotaged any hope for Adams untainted virtue and mapped a path between hell and earth that he and his minions can freely travel. When he stands before the devilish throng in his dark kingdom, he proclaims his victory, promising a glorious march that will lead his congregation triumphant out of this infernal pit. He is freeing it from the Dungeon of our Tyrant.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,971 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Thursday:

title: Jury Asks Clarification in Death of Girl, 7
description: A jury considering the fate of Cesar Rodriguez, the Brooklyn man charged with killing his 7-year-old stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown, asked a judge on Friday to read back the definition of the second-degree murder charge he faces.

title: Some Blissful Ignorance Can Cure Chronic Buyers Remorse
description: I AM tired of making decisions.

title: In Alabama, a Crackdown on Pregnant Drug Users
description: ANDALUSIA, Ala.  A day after she gave birth in 2006, Tiffany Hitson, 20, sat on her front porch crying, barefoot and handcuffed. A police officer hovered in the distance.

title: Renewable Energy Resources, Harnessed
description: Jeremy Nelsons new Sail is as well made and tasteful as any dance. What made it stand out on Thursday night at Danspace Project was Mr. Nelsons trademark full-blown, surging movement and the vivid individuality of its five hard-dancing performers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Tibetan protests against Chinese rule referred incompletely to comments by Robert Barnett, a Tibet specialist at Columbia University, about the last major protests in Lhasa, the Tibetan capital. Mr. Barnett pointed out that the protests continued into 1989; he did not say that they took place only in 1987 and 1988.

title: Violence in Tibet as Monks Clash With the Police
description: BEIJING  Violence erupted Friday morning in a busy market area of the Tibetan capital, Lhasa, as Buddhist monks and other ethnic Tibetans brawled with Chinese security forces in bloody clashes. Witnesses said angry Tibetan crowds burned shops, cars, military vehicles and at least one tourist bus. State media said at least 10 people died.

title: Mistreatment of Animals
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bit o' Brogue
description: Times reporter Corey Kilgannon asks New York's Bravest and Finest about protecting New Yorkers and preserving their brogues.

title: SXSW Video: Rock, Tacos and Pool Parties
description: Melena Ryzik and Jeremy Beiler head south.

title: The few, the proud, the ignored
description: Dean Baker is mad at Robert Rubin for suggesting that few, if any people saw the financial meltdown coming.

title: With Veras Translating, Cabrera Says Hell Appeal
description: Melky Cabrera spoke this morning in the clubhouse and said he did not punch anybody in Wednesdays melee with the Rays and would appeal his three-game suspension.

title: The Early Word: Losing Baggage
description: Senator Barack Obama made the rounds on several evening news shows Friday night as word came out that his pastor, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., was stepping down from his campaigns spiritual advisory committee.

title: Thats a Lot of Money
description: Aired Friday night on Jimmy Kimmel Live on ABC: President Bush this morning gave a speech at the Economic Club of New York. That sounds like a fun club to be a part of, doesnt it?

title: Tornado Damages CNN Headquarters
description: The Associated Press reports:

title: Big Blue Mania
description: ATLANTA  There was more blue than red inside Alexander Memorial Coliseum and no one was surprised. Kentucky fans, even in a bizarre situation like this, were going to find a way to make their game with Georgia a home game.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Saturday, Mar. 15:

title: Good news on the dollar
description: The original headline for yesterdays column was Desperately seeking traction. I had to can it because it didnt fit the layout (the problem with writing for a dead-tree publication). But looking at the above graphic from the Wall Street Journal it seemed to me that many people still dont quite get the Feds problem.

title: Call the metaphor police!
description: Ive been worried for a while about the fact that, according to financial reporters, the freezing up of the credit markets is causing a financial meltdown. The world is ending in ice and fire, simultaneously. But this is true cause for alarm:

title: CNN Headquarters Hit By Tornado
description: The worldwide headquarters for the cable news network CNN sustained damage from the tornado that rattled downtown Atlanta Friday evening.

title: SXSW: 11 Bands and a Perfect Austin Moment
description: I arrived in Austin Thursday morning, and it took a day to accept the basic laws of physics that prevent me from seeing all six of the bands I have circled on my schedule for 9 P.M.

title: SXSW: Hippies v. Technology
description: Sometimes you can mark a generation gap with gizmos. At any SXSW event, a significant part of the audience is texting, taking digital pictures, or talking on a cell phone. It bothered rock elders like Van Morrison and R.E.M., who complained from the stage, while younger bands took the multitasking for granted.

title: SXSW: Seven Bands, Briefly
description: Bands I saw on Friday night:

title: To Be Fair, I Did Get Her Vote
description: Aired Friday night on NBC: This morning President Bush gave an optimistic speech about the economy even though the dollar fell even more, oil hit record highs and jobs continued to be lost. So when asked what part of the economy is working Bush said, Hookers are doing well.

title: SXSW: Steve Reich, in Interview and Influence
description: None other than Steve Reich, the pioneering Minimalist composer, was at SXSW this year. In an onstage interview with Thurston Moore of Sonic Youth, he described how Coltrane and Motown shaped his own use of repetition, and his music was performed at a showcase. I missed it, but I didnt miss the influence of his pointillistic, interlocking patterns. Two bands I heard were wonderfully pattern-obsessed: Slaraffenland, from Copenhagen, and Collections of Colonies of Bees, from Milwaukee.

title: Tornado Hits Downtown Atlanta
description: At least 27 people were injured in the storm, which severely damaged many of the city's landmarks.

title: Say What?
description: Signs found at funnypicturescenter.com

title: You Have No Future! It Is Over.
description: Aired Friday night on NBC: Happy T.G.I.F. Which, if youre a New Yorker, it means the governor is a freak.

title: March Political Best Seller List
description: Several new titles have moved onto this months list, and are gaining ground.

title: For Medical Students, Skin Is In
description: Young doctors are moving away from treating serious illnesses and toward specialties like dermatology that offer better pay and hours.

title: NHL to Players: No Stomping!
description: Chris Pronger, the towering and ornery all-star defenseman for the Ducks, was suspended Saturday for eight games for stomping on the leg of the Canucks Ryan Kesler after two got tangled up in back of the Anaheim goal on Wednesday.

title: Blogtalk: Pro-Clinton Bloggers Boycott Kos
description: On Friday, it got to be too much for Alegre, a diarist on the flagship liberal blog DailyKos, who frequently writes in support of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: SXSW: Vampire Sinks Teeth Into Austin
description: Is there a Vampire Weekend backlash? A little bit. The success of the New York quartet, who went from preppy Columbia University students to preppy Top 20 rock band in about a year, on the strength of a polished sound that blends Talking Heads and Paul Simon-style multi-culti instrumentation with precious lyricism (they sing about architecture and grammar) has gotten some snarls from grittier, less meteorically rising bands. (Paging Yeasayer  who, incidentally, seem to be on their way.) But it didnt stop Vampire Weekend from being one of the most buzzed-about bands at the festival, not least because people wanted to see if they merited the hype. (Or at least, thats why Elijah Wood wanted to see them.)

title: Obama Calls for Unity
description: PLAINFIELD, Ind.  Senator Barack Obama repudiated the incendiary remarks of his former minister today, imploring Americans to set aside racial divisions and heed the words that Robert F. Kennedy delivered not far from here the night the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated.

title: Welsh Era Ends at Providence
description: Providence College has fired its mens basketball coach, Tim Welsh, ending a 10-year run for one of the most respected coaches in the Big East. Welsh finished his tenure with a 160-143 record, but his ultimate undoing was his 1-9 record in the Big East tournament and the fact that his teams made only two N.C.A.A. tournament appearances, both losses.

title: One Adviser Among Many, Under Lights Over Israel
description: In her Web column today, Helene Cooper writes about Robert Malley, a mid-level adviser to Senator Barack Obamas campaign who has been targeted by a handful of Jewish bloggers as anti-Israel, and a sign that Mr. Obama, too, if elected president, would carry out anti-Israel policies. Go to column

title: Schaap Vs. Knight, Round 2
description: The best line of the postseason basketball tournaments so far goes to Jeremy Schaap, who got a wonderful tweak in about Bob Knights awkward transformation from media tormentor to media member. This comes courtesy the Timess relentless TV and business guru Richard Sandomir, who placed the wonderful nugget at the end of a column about ESPN this week.

title: Georgia Coach Unhappy With Process
description: ATLANTA  When Georgia Coach Dennis Felton found out late Friday night the Georgia Dome could not be used again for the Southeastern Conference tournament because of damage from a severe storm, Felton suggested that Georgias quarterfinal game with Kentucky, which was postponed Friday night, be the only game played Saturday.

title: Minnesotas Mr. Clutch
description: At first glance it might have seemed that Minnesotas Blake Hoffarber channeled Christian Laettner when he made a last-second shot to give the Golden Gophers a 59-58 victory against Indiana in the Big Ten tournament on Friday night.

title: In This Weeks Magazine: Good Vibrations
description: All winter, when I should have been sleeping, I was reading perfume blogs. I would lose myself in a sybaritic rapture, the clock on my screen racing toward morning as I played a bait-and-switch game with my senses, taking in words that describe smells by calling on images, textures, music. The sensory pileup felt good. The blogs tell me that scents ring, sing and lash out in fury; they also cradle, buffer, withhold. I believe them.

title: Manhattan Crane Collapse
description: At least four people were killed when a large crane collapsed at a construction site on Manhattan's East Side.

title: Bloomberg: Intense City Effort at Place of Carnage
description: Updated, 7:40 p.m. | Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and other top New York City officials held a news conference early Saturday evening to discuss the construction accident that occurred at 2:22 p.m., when a giant tower crane collapsed and crushed a town house, killing four people  all of whom were believed to have been construction workers. The mayor called it one of the worst construction accidents in city history and said an intense effort involving search animals and thermal-imaging cameras was underway to determine if anyone was trapped under the rubble. More than 300 firefighters and 150 police officers were at the scene of the accident, at Second Avenue and East 51st Street.

title: 2 Rooms on Ludlow
description: The Lams' apartment on Ludlow Street consists of two rooms at the top of a five-story tenement.

title: SXSW: Blog Love, Returned
description: Maybe it was obvious, but it was worth saying.

title: Raindrops Keep Falling on Their Heads in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA  It was hard not to be struck by how organized Georgia Tech was despite having little notice before becoming the emergency host of the Southeastern Conference tournament.

title: Sundays Breakfast Menu, March 16
description: Two days after some of President Bushs most blunt statements to date about the current economic difficulties, Treasury Secretary Hank Paulson is on Sunday talk duty. He is slated for ABCs This Week, CNNs Late Edition and Fox News Sunday.

title: Duncan Says He Will Appeal His Suspension
description: Shelley Duncan has decided to appeal his three-game suspension for last Wednesdays brawl with the Tampa Bay Rays.

title: Saving Their Vote
description: Though pressured from both sides, many Democratic superdelegates feel they should keep their options open at this point in the race.

title: Your Comments on my Sunday Prostitution Column
description: My Sunday column again grows out of the Eliot Spitzer saga and argues that Kristen is very unrepresentative of the women out on the streets. Many of them arent living a choice but a nightmare and are utterly in the control of their pimps; there should be a far greater outreach effort to crack down on the pimps and customers. Yet the Justice Department has been actively resisting such a crackdown, seeing this as an unwelcome expansion of federal power. More information about the legislation is available at the Coalition Against Trafficking in Women and Equality Now.

title: Greenberg Pleads His Case
description: Virginia Tech could have virtually secured a place in the N.C.A.A. tournament field with a victory against No. 1 North Carolina on Saturday in the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament in Charlotte. After outplaying the Tar Heels but losing by 68-66 on a last-second shot by Tyler Hansbrough, the Hokies are firmly on the bubble.

title: Stars n Cars in Australia
description: I will continue the tradition this year of writing about the visiting stars to the Formula One paddock. I wont always have intelligent things to say about them, but its fun to gaze occasionally. This weekend, for instance, it is well known that the band Kiss is here. The problem is, I wouldnt know what they look like with their make-up off. I did see a few old age pensioners at one of the team shelters that I thought might be the members of that band, but since I never really listened to Kiss anyway, I decided not to ask.

title: Ronaldo Sparks Manchester United
description: Manchester United beat Derby, 1-0, to tie Arsenal for first place in the English Premier League.Cristiano Ronaldo scored in the 76th minute. United and Arsenal each have 67 points. Kolo Toures late header gave Arsenal a 1-1 tie with Middlesbrough.

title: The Sound of One Voice Mending
description: MADRID

title: Kurds Mark 20th Anniversary of Deadly Gas Attack
description: BAGHDAD  Thousands of Kurds gathered Sunday in the town of Halabja, in the northern uplands of Iraq, to mark a grim anniversary: the day 20 years ago when clouds of poison gas swept through the town, killing as many as 5,000 people.

title: Corzine Presses Towns to Combine Services
description: TRENTON

title: Pakistani Discord Undercuts Vow to U.S. to Fight Militants
description: WASHINGTON  American officials say that Pakistans pledge to fight Al Qaeda and Taliban militants in the restive tribal areas is being weakened by disagreements in the Pakistani military and security forces over what their priority should be.

title: Lowball Offers on the Rise
description: WHAT image does the term lowballer conjure up for you? A smirking bottom feeder in a bad suit? A fast-talking investor working the phone?

title: Measuring Wealth by the Foot
description: IN a shipyard in Germany, Blohm & Voss workers are building a mammoth yacht called the Eclipse.

title: Mending a Broken Child? Try a Dog or a Horse
description: BREWSTER

title: Future Shock
description: The legendary Italian architect Andrea Branzi has spent more time trying to break things down than he has trying to build them up. A new show of his work at the Fondation Cartier in Paris (March 28 to June 22) is a case in point. Branzi has created two installations: an elliptical enclosure woven from glass, metal, hemp and plant matter; and a sort of decorative gazebo containing a modular work/sleep unit (above). Difficult to understand as actual structures, perhaps, but elegant metaphors for a society whose needs have become more fluid  and to which architecture has yet to fully catch up.

title: Hockey Fans Fight Leads to Ban on 2 Schools Night Games
description: MORE than 2,000 people packed the Terry Connors Rink in Stamford on a recent Saturday night to watch Darien High School defeat its longtime rival, New Canaan High School, 2-1, for the Fairfield County boys hockey championship. The tension between the two rivals was thick, and the stakes were high. But when a fight broke out afterward that resulted in seven arrests, officials decided that even by hockey standards, this was too much.

title: Hydrogen Fuel Station Opens in White Plains
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: The New Collectibles
description: NICE KITTY: The Rosenau Castle cat is part of Nymphenburgs Big Five porcelain trophy series, $929. At Nymphenburg USA; call (312) 421-3500.

title: Questions of Balance
description: SPUNTINO THREE 60 is a beautiful space. Its on the leading edge of New Brunswicks restaurant alley, steps away from the train station and perfectly situated to offer comfort and sustenance to tired travelers. From the outside, expansive windows offer a view of the warmth within: intimate lighting, a high banquette that divides bar from restaurant and a shiny wall of tiny tiles above the bar that marks the space as up-to-the-moment.

title: A Fertile Imagination
description: In the late spring of 2006, Fritz Haeg spent a frenzied Memorial Day tearing apart a suburban front yard in Lakewood, Calif., a tidy postwar planned community 25 miles south of Los Angeles. Working with a crew of volunteers, three sod cutters and a temperamental rototiller, Haeg ripped out all the neatnik grass, turned the soil and planted crops. It was so stressful, he recalls. We had all our machinery break down. After three days of planting, I was destroyed. Although the lawn didnt even belong to Haeg, the big idea behind the transformation, Edible Estates, was his alone.

title: Sleeping in History
description: Sleeping in History

title: Brownstoners
description: Like most readers, I know too much about New York. I live on a mountaintop in Colorado, and yet I know that on the streets of Manhattan Maclaren baby strollers are becoming pass. How do I know this? Because New York pours into my house through newspapers, magazines and novels. That overexposure puts heavy demands on the author of the Manhattan novel. So many people know so much about New York life that each detail must be spot-on, note-perfect. Which is to say, I wish Shirley Abbott hadnt set her wise, funny, generous first novel, The Future of Love, in New York.

title: Golf Course View, and Those Crab Cakes
description: GUY PEUCH has been known for his crab cakes for more than 25 years, first as the founding executive chef of the Water Club in Manhattan in the 1980s and later at the Inn on the Harbor in Cold Spring Harbor, where he was executive chef and co-owner.

title: Jessica Roybal and Edward McCoul
description: Dr. Jessica Lynn Roybal and Dr. Edward David McCoul were married Saturday at Holy Name of Jesus Church in New Orleans. Msgr. Robert D. Massett, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Beyond the Noise on Free Trade
description: NO issue divides economists and mere Muggles more than the debate over globalization and international trade. Where the high priests of the dismal science see opportunity through the magic of the markets invisible hand, Joe Sixpack sees a threat to his livelihood. This gap in perspective grows especially wide whenever the economy experiences short-run difficulties, as it is now. By all indications, the issue could come to dominate the presidential campaign.

title: Worries Over Being Slimed
description: OUR Marine platoon stayed up late to listen on a hand-cranked shortwave radio as Colin Powell testified before the United Nations about Iraqs weapons of mass destruction. It was February 2003, and we were camped in the northern Kuwaiti desert, awaiting orders to invade Iraq.

title: In a Maine Town, All Eyes Are on a Tall, Cool Woman
description: BETHEL, Me.  She is a white behemoth  festooned in a mica pendant and a cheery red hat  who looks down onto this town from behind lush eyelashes, while flashing a broad smile.

title: Seeing the Light
description: Translucent, Transparent, Reflective or Illuminated From Within, This Seasons Furniture is All Aglow.

title: The Army Grew Into the Job
description: FROM the moment the Bush administration took office, I argued against its apparent preference for high-tech, small-footprint wars, which continued a decade of movement in that direction by senior military leaders and civilian experts. In 2002, I questioned the common triumphalism about American operations in Afghanistan, and particularly the notion of applying the Afghanistan model of low-manpower, high-precision operations in Iraq. I supported the 2003 invasion despite misgivings about how it would be executed, and those misgivings proved accurate.

title: The Lemur
description: Chapter 10: Big Bill

title: Bond Issue Is Approved for Sachem Schools
description: RESIDENTS of the Sachem school district, who decisively voted down double-digit tax increases in 2004 and 2005, approved a $33.1 million bond issue on Tuesday for repairs, renovations and upgrades in the districts 18 schools  but barely.

title: The Anti-Dubai (for Now)
description: DRIVING along a rocky red cliff, with deep canyons yawning below, one could be forgiven for mistaking this rugged place for Utah. But this is the Musandam Peninsula of Oman, an Arabian land of pristine seas, jagged peaks and, for the moment, few tourists. But its proximity to booming Dubai, just two hours south, and a modern road means more development is on its way.

title: Driving Miss Chloe
description: Los Angeles

title: When Girls Will Be Boys
description: It was late on a rainy fall day, and a college freshman named Rey was showing me the new tattoo on his arm. It commemorated his 500-mile hike through Europe the previous summer, which happened also to be, he said, the last time he was happy. We sat together for a while in his room talking, his tattoo of a piece with his spiky brown hair, oversize tribal earrings and very baggy jeans. He showed me a photo of himself and his girlfriend kissing, pointed out his small drum kit, a bass guitar that lay next to his rumpled clothes and towels and empty bottles of green tea, one full of dried flowers, and the ink self-portraits and drawings of nudes that he had tacked to the walls. Thick jasmine incense competed with his cigarette smoke. He changed the music on his laptop with the melancholy, slightly startled air of a college boy on his own for the first time.

title: Worse Than Lyndon Johnsons Team?
description: IN fairness to the Bush administration, I did not expect that we would discover no meaningful activity in rebuilding Iraqs weapons of mass destruction and no Iraqi ties to Al Qaeda. I also never predicted, after the insurgency began, that the extremists in Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia would so alienate Sunnis and tribes in western Iraq that a combination of the surge, win and hold military tactics, American-led nation-building efforts that focused on local and provincial needs, and the cease-fire declared by Moktada al-Sadr could create todays new opportunity for victory.

title: But Why Shouldnt Shops Close on Saturday?
description: To the Editor:

title: Photo Finish
description: Polaroid film

title: Alanna Toll, Jeffrey Schwartz
description: Dr. Alanna Joy Toll, a daughter of Wende and Leslie Toll of Merion Station, Pa., is to be married on Sunday afternoon to Jeffrey Jay Schwartz, a son of Hannah and Charles Schwartz of Plainview, N.Y. Rabbi Yosie Levine is to perform the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, N.Y.

title: Diners in Changing Hands; Greek Ownership on the Wane
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y.

title: Michal Kleinlerer and Jonathan Shenkin
description: Dr. Michal Freda Kleinlerer and Dr. Jonathan David Shenkin were married on Saturday at Blue Hill at Stone Barns, the restaurant on the Rockefeller familys Pocantico Hills estate in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Janise Poticha officiated.

title: The Scholarship Divide: Readers Weigh In
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Castillo Feels No Pain in Spring Debut
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Luis Castillo became the last Mets regular to make his Grapefruit League debut. Then he spoke optimistically about playing enough in the teams final 13 spring games to be ready for the regular season.

title: The Cash Advantage (Even When Rates Are Low)
Aloft, With a Silent Companion
description: BAGHDAD

title: Need a Doctor in the Air? Fly With One
description: WHEN a New York woman died aboard an American Airlines flight returning from Haiti last month, her death raised concerns among passengers about the level of medical treatment available at 30,000 feet.

title: Through Bush-Colored Glasses
description: President Bush admitted on Friday that times are tough. So much for the straight talk.

title: The Dance Card
description: To the Editor:

title: Developer Who Can See From a Rescuers View
description: For James P. Kennelly, the developer of the building where a construction crane fell the length of a city block on Saturday, killing at least four people and injuring 13 others, the building catastrophe had a special resonance.

title: Georgia Tech President to Lead Smithsonian
description: A year after a financial scandal forced the head of the Smithsonian Institution to resign, the organization announced Saturday that it had named a highly regarded university president, G. Wayne Clough of the Georgia Institute of Technology, as its chief.

title: Sino Visions
description: China may be set to overtake the United States in the next decade as the worlds second largest consumer of luxury goods, but the question remains whether Chinas new money will put their yuan behind products made  let alone designed  in their own backyard. China Design Now, at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London through July 13, takes an expansive view of Chinas burgeoning design culture. Still, the fact that the curators saw fit to include projects like Rem Koolhaass CCTV headquarters and Herzog & de Meurons Olympic stadium as well as a pair of Nike Air Force 1s could be taken as a hint. Meanwhile, the KT Wong Charitable Trust has commissioned the Chinese artist Shao Fan to create a garden for the Royal Horticultural Society Chelsea Flower Show in May. Fans design (above, right), which brings a contemporary perspective to the traditional scholars garden, is an elegant example of the Wong Trusts ambition to foster an East/West exchange of a decidedly more cerebral nature.

title: A Hearing on Indian Point That Struggles to Be Heard
description: White Plains

title: A Barometer in Williamsburg
description: WHAT housing turmoil? Despite a rising inventory of unsold condominiums in Brooklyn, one of the largest new condominium projects in recent memory is about to go on sale at the Edge, two glass and concrete towers along the Williamsburg waterfront, about a half mile north of the Williamsburg Bridge.

title: Raze High the Roof Beams, Comrade
description: Now its Chinas turn. The signs of progress that have marred Europe and America for the past century have lately been unleashed in the worlds fastest growing economy, and the eyewitnesses are lining up to testify. Not surprisingly, money is talking loud enough to drown out any dissent, as the fate of an ancient society increasingly rests in the hands of real estate developers. If ever there were an exercise in urban planning, this is it: how to modernize a civilization without obliterating its heritage; how to accommodate density without compromising quality of life; how to learn from the mistakes of the so-called developed countries, now congested and polluted, their major cities homogenized and colonized by the same handful of global brands.

title: Our Sacred Individuality
description: To the Editor:

title: Cheap, Convenient and Teeming
description: WHEN Fiona Gallagher, who is from County Antrim in Northern Ireland, first came to the United States in the 1980s, she followed word of mouth to Woodside, Queens, an unassuming neighborhood along the No. 7 train where scores of Irish immigrants had already landed. She was 20, searching for a place to get settled, and liked its feeling of familiarity.

title: Whirl of Interiors
description: Maelstrom/Before The disorienting details in Francesca Gabbianis paper and acrylic collages  labyrinthine passages, mirrors within mirrors, wallpaper patterns that jump off the canvas  can leave the viewer with a touch of vertigo. Its like being trapped inside, says the Canadian-born Gabbiani, based in Los Angeles. Her inspirations are as eclectic as they are horrific  say, Edgar Allan Poes Fall of the House of Usher or the 70s Belgian vampire film Daughters of Darkness. But in her work, blood and gore are replaced with a cool detachment, as if something bad just happened or is about to happen, she says.

title: Ratify the Law of the Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: Bookshelf
description: APPLES AND ORANGES: Going Bananas With Pairs. Written and illustrated by Sara Pinto. Bloomsbury. $16.95. (Ages 3 to 7)

title: Why Shariah?
description: Last month, Rowan Williams, the archbishop of Canterbury, gave a nuanced, scholarly lecture in London about whether the British legal system should allow non-Christian courts to decide certain matters of family law. Britain has no constitutional separation of church and state. The archbishop noted that the law of the Church of England is the law of the land there; indeed, ecclesiastical courts that once handled marriage and divorce are still integrated into the British legal system, deciding matters of church property and doctrine. His tentative suggestion was that, subject to the agreement of all parties and the strict requirement of protecting equal rights for women, it might be a good idea to consider allowing Islamic and Orthodox Jewish courts to handle marriage and divorce.

title: Lets Not Forget
description: To the Editor:

title: Alexandra Lane, Randy Cohn
description: Alexandra Haines Lane and Randy Marc Cohn were married on Saturday evening at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club in Port Washington, N.Y. Rabbi Paula Winnig officiated.

title: Admission Impossible
description: At the end of our freshman year at Harvard, my roommates and I, having done so well so far in the lottery of life, did badly in the housing lottery. We were sent to live in the Quad, a group of dorms half a mile northwest of the main campus. This was in the mid-90s, before global warming, so on cold winter days, while our classmates rolled out of bed and into lecture with a steaming hot coffee and a warm apple fritter, we trudged through snow and wind to sit there for an hour in our wet socks. On the other hand, cut off from civilization, we had a lot of time to think. We thought about modernity, the Renaissance, etc.; we played a lot of Ping-Pong; and we considered our lives, thus far, and what Harvard meant to them. One of my friends formulated an idea. Weve done the hardest thing, he said, meaning getting into Harvard. He came to be fond of this statement, and in lulls in dining hall conversation hed return to it. Were 19 years old and weve done the hardest thing there is to do, hed say, and then wed sit there, looking stupidly at one another.

title: Jazz Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: Clemson Finds Itself in a Rare Position
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Forward Sam Perry ripped off his jersey in a Brandi Chastain moment of exhilaration, pounded his chest and shouted to a crowd brought to its feet by a victory that Clemson fans have waited 46 years to celebrate.

title: Royal Caribbean Cancels Idol Cruises
description: Five Caribbean cruises with an American Idol theme, scheduled for Nov. 19 to Dec. 21 aboard Royal Caribbean Internationals newest ship, the Independence of the Seas, have been canceled because of unresolved contract issues. These cruises  featuring live performances and amateur competitions  were written about in the Feb. 10 Comings & Goings column.

title: Reining In Runaway Taxes
description: Hauppauge

title: A Proposed Diet for the U.S. Budget
description: IF you are going to buy just one book in this presidential election year, you might want to consider Where Does the Money Go?: Your Guided Tour to the Federal Budget Crisis by Scott Bittle and Jean Johnson (Collins, $16.95 in paperback). This is a book that manages to be entertaining and irreverent while serving as an informative primer on a subject that is crucial to the future of all Americans.

title: When Buying a Home Takes a Lucky Break
description: PATCHOGUE

title: Too Much Homework
description: I serve on my neighborhood homeowners association. Recently we discussed a woman who provides day care for 6 to 10 kids, contrary to our covenants against running a home business. Complicating matters, I, too, work from home, doing desktop publishing, but nobody minds since I dont draw increased traffic to the neighborhood. Is it ethical of us to close this womans business?  J.H., WASHINGTON

title: Trickle-Down Economics in the Dairy Section
description: FOR a tutorial on the complex set of factors driving up the price of a quart of milk, a good person to talk to is Modesto Baez, a Dominican who is the proprietor of the Quisqueya Super Market at Franklin Avenue and Eastern Parkway in Crown Heights, Brooklyn.

title: Five Years
description: LONDON  Five years on, it seems positively surreal.

title: Iraqs Insurgency Runs on Stolen Oil Profits
description: BAIJI, Iraq  The Baiji refinery, with its distillation towers rising against the Hamrin Mountains, may be the most important industrial site in the Sunni Arab-dominated regions of Iraq. On a good day, 500 tanker trucks will leave the refinery filled with fuel with a street value of $10 million.

title: The Wrong War
description: Despite his many lapses and limitations  above all, his tendency to see any other viewpoint as a product of cowardice, stupidity, venality or insufficient loyalty to the United States  Michael Scheuer made significant contributions to the post-9/11 debate with his first two books. In Imperial Hubris: Why the West Is Losing the War on Terror, which he wrote anonymously while still serving as a C.I.A. officer, Scheuer anatomized Al Qaeda and the threat it posed. His earlier book, Through Our Enemies Eyes: Osama bin Laden, Radical Islam, and the Future of America, was more of a harangue. Nonetheless, it offered insights into bin Ladens motivations as well as the context of the Islamic world in which he operated.

title: Dalai Lama Wont Stop Tibet Protests
description: MCLEODGANJ, India  The Dalai Lama said Sunday that he would not instruct his followers inside Tibet to surrender before Chinese authorities, and he described feeling helpless in preventing what he feared could be an imminent blood bath.

title: Argentine Nights
description: THE tango dancers took their places inside a cramped apartment in downtown Buenos Aires, as David Lampson, a 29-year-old television writer from Boston, wiped his brow. Despite the 100-degree weather, the fans had been shut off, spotlights switched on and windows blacked out with trash bags. The cameraman waited until the smoke machine blurred the parquet floor before yelling Action! Then just as the iTunes track reached its dramatic crescendo, the fuse blew. For the fourth time.

title: Fed Chief Shifts Path, Inventing Policy in Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  As chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke has long argued that a central bank should base its policies as much as possible on consistent principles rather than seat-of-the-pants judgment.

title: Interpreting the Text Message
description: Interpreting the Text Message

title: All the Principals Men
description: Life is not like high school. Life is like junior high school. Even high school is like junior high school. That is the real proving ground, the passage from elementary to upper, bliss to hell, where identities are fixed and alliances hammered into place. If youre a kind of Columbus of the near at hand, wanting to map the world, there is nothing better to be than a reporter at a junior high newspaper, just like Adam Canfield, the hero of Michael Winerips new novel. Adam is the star reporter of The Slash, a paper named for the punctuation mark that so aptly describes the school as a place of painful transition: Harris Elementary/Middle School. Of course, Adam, having the body of a middle schooler but the soul of a reporter, likes to think the paper is in fact named for the verb, because the pens of his fellow newshounds were so mighty, they slashed like swords through thick, swampy lies until they reached the truth.

title: Machines for Living
description: Henry Ford has been on my mind lately. The automobile magnate fascinated early-20th-century architects. By adopting his vision of mass production, they believed, whole cities could be ordered with the efficiency of the assembly line. The squalor of the medieval city  with its cramped living quarters and dark, airless alleyways  would be erased forever.

title: Return of Glavin
description: My pilgrimage to my mothers ancestral home in Ireland began with the wrong bus, to the wrong village. Not that the delay mattered much in the scheme of things  no one in my immediate family had set foot in Goleen in more than a hundred years. I learned when I was growing up that my Catholic great-great-grandfather and his brothers left Ireland in a big hurry under dubious circumstances, but none of my relatives knew more than a few details. The bits of lore were vague and portentous, something to do with a widow and her starving children. My mother always said that someday one of us would have to go back and find out what happened.
