description: BEIJING  At the end of a perfect afternoon, when the sky was blue and the sun was not veiled in smog, there was no winner of the first Major League Baseball game played in China. But that did not matter.

title: When Low Offers Start to Pay Off
description: WHAT image does the term lowballer conjure up for you? A smirking bottom feeder in a bad suit? A fast-talking investor working the phone?

title: Real Estate as Art
description: A DESIGNERS work is never done. Domenico Vacca and his wife, Julie, run a family business, a group of fashion and luxury good emporiums that bear his name from New York to Florida to California, and now they are working on the design for their new 39th-floor apartment at the Museum Tower, at 15 West 53rd Street.

title: In the Swamp, on the Hunt for Trees, Old and Invisible
description: SMITHTOWN

title: Events on Long Island
description: COMEDY

title: Lush Life
description: The Quality of Life Task Force: four sweatshirts in a bogus taxi set up on the corner of Clinton Street alongside the Williamsburg Bridge off-ramp to profile the incoming salmon run; their mantra: Dope, guns, overtime; their motto: Everyone's got something to lose.

title: Keep On Truckin
description: Jon Scieszka has a talent for goofy mischief. His first childrens book, The True Story of the 3 Little Pigs!, was a revisionist fairy tale narrated from prison by one Alexander T. Wolf. A manic follow-up, The Stinky Cheese Man and Other Fairly Stupid Tales, also offered new takes on old stories: the ugly duckling grows into an ugly duck, and instead of the sky its the table of contents that falls on Chicken Littles head. These were busy books, verbally and visually (Scieszkas frequent collaborator Lane Smith illustrated both with hyperactive whimsy), and they positioned Scieszka as a sort of Dave Eggers for the Lego set  smart, sarcastic, knowing, silly.

title: A Monster of a Slip
description: SAMANTHA POWER strode across the packed room and took a seat, her long sweep of red hair settling around her like a protective shawl. The audience, filled with human rights students and other assorted admirers, stilled, and took her in. There she was, at New York University, back on American soil and miraculously intact, despite having just weathered the most bruising, spectacularly public  and perhaps first  setback in her seemingly unstoppable career.

title: Editors Note
description: A question-and-answer interview on March 2 in Arts & Leisure with the director and a cast member of the Classic Stage Companys production of The Seagull was conducted by Rosemarie Tichler, a freelance writer who is on the board of directors of Classic Stage. She disclosed this fact in a note to the assigning editor, but it was overlooked in the editing process. Had The Times noticed her affiliation, it would have sought another interviewer for the article.

title: Where Did All the Truckers Go?
description: TEN years ago, when a Bay Ridge businessman named Emmanuel Maropakis bought a former metal fabrication factory on a desolate strip of Third Avenue at Sixth Street in Gowanus, he thought he could make a few dollars renting the place out for storage.

title: A Famed Alps Resort Schusses Into the Future
description: IT wasnt even midafternoon, but the beer and glwein were flowing freely in Zermatt, the picturesque, pedestrian-friendly Swiss ski resort that is the gateway to the Matterhorn. The mulled red wine is a signature beverage at the Igloo Bar, a snow-sculptured outdoor hangout right on the ski slope. Here, the Matterhorns sharks tooth peak  an icon for the Alps themselves  stood sentinel overhead as skiers and snowboarders shed their rainbow layers of Gortex and soaked up the sun. The music was blaring, the fondue was cooking, and for this crowd the resorts top-rate terrain and happening aprs-ski scene were coming together quite nicely. I dont normally imbibe wine as part of my on-mountain plan of attack before the end of the ski day, but when in Switzerland, why not do as the Swiss do?

title: Seeking Recognition for a Wars Lost Laborers
description: KANCHANABURI, Thailand  The flocks of foreign tourists who visit this western Thai city usually head straight to the storied bridge on the River Kwai and the meticulously maintained cemeteries containing the remains of thousands of Allied prisoners of war who died building a railway here during World War II.

title: State Seeks to Regain Recycling Momentum
description: OCEAN TOWNSHIP

title: Its the Lipstick That Draws Attention, and the Name Helps Too
description: WALL TOWNSHIP

title: Sounds Soft and Tough, and a Star in the Trunk
description: Destroyer

title: Black Rabbi Reaches Out to Mainstream of His Faith
description: CHICAGO  Having grown up in the African Methodist Episcopal Church, Capers C. Funnye Jr. was encouraged by his pastor to follow in his footsteps. Instead, he became a rabbi.

title: Jeeves of the Plaza
description: THE PLAZA HOTEL, which reopened on March 1 after a three-year renovation, employs a handsomely attired staff of bellmen (gold-braided uniforms), doormen (silver whistles) and housekeepers (white aprons), along with several concierges (pinstriped suits) and assistant managers (embroidered damask blouses).

title: A Wild Ride Ends in Neutral
description: It was a remarkable week on Wall Street, but you wouldnt know it from the market indexes, which ended more or less where they started.

title: Freezing in Time Choreographys Fleeting Steps
description: TIRELESS pursuit of the unknown has long been a point of pride among contemporary choreographers, and a way of distinguishing themselves from what many see as the musty, out-of-touch traditions of more classically oriented institutions.

title: Correction: The Mind of a One-Woman Multitude
description: Because of an editing error, an article on March 2 about the singer Erykah Badu misstated the name of the song on her new album whose lyrics offer a succinct autobiography. It is Me, not M.

title: Correction: Centenarian Directors Very Long View
description: An article last Sunday about the career of the director Manoel de Oliveira misstated the title of a Luis Buuel film. It is Belle de Jour, not Belle du Jour.

title: Paperback Row
description: When the Book Review introduced a new best-seller list devoted to trade paperback fiction last Sept. 23, the editors explained that the list gives more emphasis to the literary novels and short-story collections reviewed so often in our pages (and sometimes published only in softcover). That suggests the difference between trade and mass-market fiction, but it doesnt really make it clear, and many readers have written to express their confusion. This column, sitting as it does in the print edition next to the full spread of paperback best-seller lists, will attempt to explain the difference.

title: The Flowers
description: Not that many years ago I would go to a house in the neighborhood, not always someone's I knew, one I'd never been inside of, where I'd only have to maybe hop a fence, nothing complicated, and from the backyard I'd crawl through an open window. People always latch the ones in the front but never in the back, and especially not the bathroom one, you know, and it wasn't so small I couldn't get in quick. I could've stole lots of [expletive] in those houses, except that's not what I was going in there for. I wasn't like that. Maybe I don't know exactly what I was doing except I was doing it. I never took nothing, nothing much if I did, because I didn't want to. I was more watching how the people lived, imagining how it would be in their house. I stared at the framed pictures they had of their family. Husbands in suits and wives with necklaces and old grandparents from the other times way before. Unsmiling dudes, glaring at you, in tilted military hats and coats with medals and ribbons. Full-body shots of happy daughters in white veils and lacy crunchy wedding dresses that poured all over into the bottom of the picture. Shocked little babies on blue backgrounds squinting like What's going on here, what's all this light [expletive]? Dopey-dumb I'm-so-proud high schoolers graduating and making a face like they were department store managers. If I felt like it, if I had the mood, I sprawled out on their couches or lay down on their beds. Go, How would I be if I lived here? I'd let that come into me, I'd let my mind go to the show it liked. Maybe you could say I would go off to my own world. To me it wasn't mine, nothing like mine, because it would go to black. I loved that color. It was like when the eyes aren't open but try to see. What would finally come were colors and lines busting through, flying out and off and cutting in, crazy fires and sparks, and it'd come out speeding, and I'd be like a doggie out the window, those lane dividers whiffing by on the freeway straight below an open car window. I'd start to see shapes floating and straightening and wiggling and see it like it was a music that didn't make sound but was making a story. Not a regular story and I don't mean one you would hear some loco nut tell you, one that didn't have nothing to do with people or places you've ever seen. It's that I can't describe it better. Just, I have to watch, I have to listen. It was always good too. Say like when you hear music and it gets inside your brain and goes and goes, sticking there. And so I guess it got in mine like that. I listened and watched until I stopped getting too stupid because, you know, I had to leave and get out of there fast. And once I got up, shook it off and remembered where I really was, even if I opened their refrigerator, when I looked inside, wasn't like I didn't think of eating or drinking, I didn't take even a soda, thirsty as I might have been. I didn't want them to know I'd been there. Though I kind of opened the fridge door because maybe I do think of  well, like orange juice. It's that I like orange juice. So maybe when there was some orange juice I might have taken a gulp or two. But see, even then, nobody'd really know. One time I was in this one house, and I was looking inside a drawer in this girl's bedroom. I knew about her because she was this dude's older sister, and she was in junior college. It was that there were a bunch of bras, and I picked them up and looked at them, touched them because I was holding them. Wasn't like I never seen my mom's and my sister's, it wasn't like I didn't know the difference. And it was the only time there was something like that, swear, and I did stop and yeah I still got jumpy about it and felt like it was [expletive] up, real bad of me and afterward I only snuck into one more house. Like I said, I didn't know what I was doing it for, and it wasn't like I liked doing it.

title: When Omaha Met Cinema
description: WHEN I grew up there, in the 1970s and 80s, Omaha was a great place to live if you were interested in insurance, softball leagues, college football, steak or hamburgers.

title: Deadly Blast at Restaurant in Pakistans Capital
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  An explosion at a restaurant frequented by foreigners here in the Pakistani capital on Saturday night killed at least one person and wounded 11 others, including 5 Americans, the police said.

title: Cutting Dosage of Costly Drug Spurs a Debate
description: When a drug can cost more than $300,000 a year, the right dose becomes a matter of public debate.

title: Living Small
description: THOMAS HOLTON first met the Lam family in 2003 when taking public relations photographs for the University Settlement, an organization that has helped immigrants on the Lower East Side for more than a century. Like thousands of New Yorkers before him, Mr. Holton offered his services to the settlement house as a good-will gesture, but he also had a more personal motive.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE BLUE STAR, by Tony Earley. (Little, Brown, $23.99.) The caring, thoughtful hero of Earleys engrossing first novel, Jim the Boy, is now 17 and confronting not only the eternal turmoil of love, but venality and the frightening calls of duty and war.

title: Lacey Tisch, Lowell Sidney
description: Lacey Ann Tisch, the daughter of Susan Tisch Allen and Andrew H. Tisch, both of Manhattan, was married on Saturday evening to Lowell Jay Sidney, a son of Marcia Sidney and Steven L. Sidney of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Rabbi Philip Hiat, the brides maternal grandfather, performed the ceremony at Central Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: Correction: Evening Hours
description: A picture caption in the Evening Hours column last Sunday misidentified a guest at the 30th anniversary celebration on March 3 for Studio in a School, a program that sends artists into schools. The man standing between Agnes Gund and Samantha Boardman is Bronson Van Wyck  not James Weingrod, another guest.

title: Das Loot
description: IN April 2003, just after American troops secured Baghdad, Iraqis looted the Iraqi national museum. American soldiers nearby made no effort to stop them, much less provide a guard. We either did not have enough soldiers to protect the museum, or we did not care enough to try.

title: Cobblestone Houses That No Wolf Could Blow Down
description: CHILI, N.Y.  Every so often, curious strangers travel down a dead-end road near a park and a bubbling creek, knock on the heavy wood door of the Dillenbecks stately home and start asking questions.

title: Its Not Easy Being Clean
description: The Samurai Shopper is weaving her jumbled thoughts on organic cleaning products into a sage and sanguine worldview. How best to fight tough grime? With cruelty-free self-righteousness? Or headache-inducing supermarket brutes? Mixing rectitude and Begleys Best spot remover  biodegradable in three to seven days plus Ed Begley Jr.s grinning puss  seems sprout-headed. But those monstrous nonbiodegradables are killing me, and not softly either. So Shaklees eco-friendly Scour Off Heavy-Duty Paste is tempting: it promises to disappear oven drippings and not burn off your nose hairs in the process. That works for me.

title: Flowers, via Social Work
description: MY father was a painting contractor who ran the business out of my grandmothers house. His father died when Dad was 19, and my grandmother had to continue the business. For a long time she made believe that my father was running it, but we all knew it was she, in the background.

title: Designing the Inevitable
description: It happens to teenagers the world over. Youve got to pick a university course but dont know which one to go for. Luckily for Naoto Fukasawa, he found the answer in a college guide, which described industrial design as making people happy through industrial products. To a 17-year-old who enjoyed drawing and making weird objects from an early age, it sounded great. There was this feeling of This is it,  he recalls. I was really happy that I could do the things I loved as a job.

title: Breaking a Boards Grip
description: IT may be difficult enough to win election to the board in most co-ops and condominiums, but it is even more difficult, co-op lawyers say, to get rid of an entrenched board that is not doing its job.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 15, 2008

title: Megyn Kelly and Douglas Brunt
description: AS he ducked into the lively Washington tapas bar for his blind date with Megyn Kelly, Douglas Brunt, an Internet security executive, was thinking he had the upper hand.

title: Which Is the Fairest, for a Pint and Shepherds Pie?
description: WHAT qualifies a New York bar as Irish? Irish ownership is good; Irish accents behind the bar are better. Multiple ever-flowing Guinness taps with skilled, patient pourers are good; supplementing them with Smithwicks ale and Magners cider on tap is better. Irish flags and Guinness signs are O.K.; old posters from County This and County That are really cool.

title: Where Was the Plan?
description: FIFTEEN months before the 9/11 attacks, the bipartisan National Commission on Terrorism, on which I served as chairman, reported to the president and the American people that we faced a new and terrible threat: the nexus between states that supported terrorism and killers who wanted to murder Americans by the thousands and were prepared to die doing it.

title: City Ballet: Heres an Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: When a Writer Faces His Own Flaws
description: Its a disillusioning moment when a young adult finally meets a career idol only to find the supposed role model not measuring up to the expected superhuman dimensions.

title: The Ultimate Fan Fantasy: Owning a Piece of the Rock
description: Ive always wanted to own a baseball team. Ten years ago, I even purchased one share of the Cleveland Indians for $16. It was either buy the stock or buy a commemorative cup of soda.

title: The Talk
description: fragile / (fraj& el) / adj. / easily broken or damaged. An attribute of the materials that are enjoying a sudden revival among cutting-edge designers, as in, Arne Quinzes Fluid glass pieces are so fragile, I had to buy them their own seat on the plane home from Design Miami. Could also be used to describe designers egos. In either case, handle with care.

title: Virtues of the Short Sale
description: IS it possible for a homeowner who owes $725,000 on a mortgage to sell a house for only $560,000 and still walk away happy, or at least relieved? The answer is yes, if the transaction is a short sale  defined as selling for less than the mortgage owed, in a deal with the lender to forgive the rest of the debt and head off a foreclosure.

title: No Way to Run Health Research
description: The National Institutes of Health, the main supporter of biomedical research at universities and medical schools, has an annual budget of more than $29 billion. That is far above what any other nation spends on such research, and far higher than the budgets of other agencies that support work in other scientific fields.

title: Look Deeper. Youll See a Bright Side.
description: DESPITE assurances from the Federal Reserve that it stands ready to help struggling investment banks mired in illiquid mortgage-backed securities, the mood on Wall Street continued to deteriorate last week.

title: The Phantom Characters Inhabiting the Stage
description: AND now, presenting this years nominees for the Donald Muller Award for Most Riveting Character Youve Never Seen, the man youve been waiting for  Godot.

title: SXSW: Raunchy Lyrics and a Wild Party
description: Sad, brainy indie rock isnt the best music to get sloshed and dance the night away to. So hip-hop and electronic acts have a particular function here that gets more and more essential as the long days wear on: fueling wild parties.

title: SXSW: Music to Relax To
description: The French Legation Museum, built as a residence for an emissary of King Louis Philippe around 1840, is one of the oldest structures in Austin. On Saturday afternoon, its parklike grounds were also the setting for one of the nicest, most laid-back parties of the festival. The bill was strong, if not raucous: Laura Marling, a young (very young  18) British singer-songwriter; Thurston Moore and the New Wave Bandits; Kimya Dawson, the maternal Moldy Peach-turned-bestselling movie soundtrack artist (for Juno); and She & Him, a new band made up of the singer and guitarist M. Ward and the actress Zooey Deschanel. They met working on a duet for a movie; their debut album, Volume 1, full of sweet, retro tunes, lovelorn country-ish ballads and a few covers, is due out on Tuesday.

title: Tranghese On Expansion
description: As we mentioned earlier this week on The Quad, theres always talk this time of year about N.C.A.A. tournament expansion. Big East Commissioner Mike Tranghese said on Saturday night that it would not happen for two reasons. One was Tiger Woods and the other was cash.

title: Wales Wins Six Nations Tournament
description: CARDIFF  All the honors fell into the waiting Welsh arms on Saturday as it beat France in the final game of the Six Nations rugby tournament.

title: Let the Healing Begin
SXSW: Six Bands, Briefly
description: Bands I saw on Saturday afternoon:

title: Op-Classic, 2007: Eliot Spitzer on Ethical Principles
description: Every week, the Opinion section presents an essay from The Timess archive by a columnist or contributor that we hope sheds light on current news or provides a window on the past.

title: Office Buddies
description: Among the offerings at the South by Southwest Film Conference and Festival in Austin, Texas, last week was this series of very brief animated shorts (mobile video, anyone?)  about two co-workers cruelly imprisoned in adjoining cubicles. Here are two installments, Working Hard?

title: Woe Be Gone
description: In the Sunday Book Review, Garrison Keillor isnt very sunny about Against Happiness: In Praise of Melancholy by Eric G. Wilson:

title: The Week Ahead: Mar. 16-22
description: Theater

title: Down a Firemans Pole Into a Pantsuit
description: Aired Wednesday night on CBS: The drinking water in New York City, have you heard about this? I mean, like we dont have enough problems; 15 different prescription drugs, in our drinking water. You need a doctors prescription to turn on the faucet.

title: Italian Spiderman
description: A parody film trailer spoofs 1960s and 1970s Italian cinema. The Advertiser of Australia says it was made by an southern Australian student, Dario Russo, and friends, and its been pretty popular since being posted on YouTube and Myspace late last year:

title: Rattles Mahler, Vivaldi Vocals and a Tippett Revelation
description: MAHLER:

title: Beach bargains; New record in London; Plan for new Paris towers
description: Headlines from the world of property:

title: Measuring Wealth by the Foot
description: Despite fear of an economic recession and unrelenting job pressures among those who remain yachtless, theres still a lot of money floating around the world. And as the superrich get richer, the size of yachts grows bigger and bigger, too.

title: A Sunday Shocker for Michigan
description: On the same day that N.C.A.A. kicks off its flagship event, one of the ugly realities of college athletics has surfaced.

title: SXSW Video: Backstage With Daniel Lanois
description: Daniel Lanois, who has produced albums for U2, Bob Dylan and many others, has never allowed cameras into the studio while recording. He changed his mind to make Here Is What Is, a documentary about the process of making music. He spoke about it to Jon Pareles at South by Southwest.

title: Okposo Gets the Call
description: Kyle Okposo, the hard-charging power forward of the Islanders future, will play his first NHL game Tuesday, Isles GM Garth Snow announced. The 19-year-olds debut will come at the Nassau Coliseum against the Maple Leafs and its expected he will spend the last nine games of the season with the big team.

title: SXSW: Six Bands, Briefly
description: Bands I saw on Saturday night:

title: SXSW: Love Boat Pop from Indonesia
description: Sometimes it takes a band that is literally from the other side of the world to escape the web of irony that makes watching some shows here an exercise in double-guessing. For example, is Chromeo really in love with Journey, or was it just getting cheap yuks when it ended its set on Saturday afternoon at Stubbs with a medley of Dont Stop Believin, Any Way You Want It and other standards of FM radio from circa 1981?

title: A helpful suggestion
description: Do not send the man who declared, back in April 2007, that the housing correction had reached bottom and that the subprime problem was largely contained to all the Sunday talk shows to declare that our financial institutions, our banks and investments banks are very strong. It just feeds the panic.

title: Capital Decimation Partners
description: Tyler Cowen directs us to Foster and Young explaining how a hedge fund manager can make himself rich simply by exposing his investors to risks they dont understand.

title: Paulson Defends Fed Bailout of Bear Stearns
description: The Bush administration will do what its takes to stabilize chaotic markets and minimize the economic damage, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said Sunday after a tumultuous week capped by the government rescue of the teetering investment bank Bear Stearns.

title: The View From the Catbird Seat
Organics as Big Business
description: Not all organic food has become industrial, but much of it has; check out this chart at Good Magazine showing who-owns-what in the organic world. Gives me the creeps, though that might just show how nave I have been on this subject.

title: Bear Stearns to Sell Itself to JPMorgan for $2 a Share
description: Updated 7:25 p.m. Bear Stearns, facing collapse because of the mortgage crisis, agreed Sunday evening to be bought by JPMorgan Chase for a bargain-basement price of less than $250 million, the two companies announced.

title: Greenspan lectures us again
description: I once said of Alan Greenspan:

title: Obamas Church Responds
description: On the morning news shows today, surrogates of the Obama and Clinton campaigns tried to tamp down the volatile, gut-wrenching elements of racial/gender identity politics that have been playing out in the campaign in the past week, through the Internet and rippling through the electorate.

title: The Cost of Bears Crisis to Its Employees
description: Update: Bear Stearns has agreed to sell itself to JPMorgan Chase for $2 a share. The firms shares closed at $30 on Friday, giving it a market value of $4.1 billion. For DealBooks full coverage of the Bear Stearns crisis, go here.

title: Living in Woodside, Queens
description: With generations of immigrants from around the world living side-by-side, the biggest problem in Woodside, Queens, is coping with the strains of development.

title: Blogging the Boys
description: Our guest bloggers this week will be the Cowboy crew at Blogging the Boys. By way of introduction, we did a Q&A with Dave Halprin, the blogs founder.

title: Selection Sunday
description: Update, 6:58 p.m. Speaking on CBS, Tom OConnor, the head of the selection committee, said there were five contingency plans in place depending on what happened in the various conference title games today. Georgia (17-16) won the Southeastern Conference tournament with its third victory in two days, likely knocking out an at-large team. Illinois, with a sub-.500 record would have also knocked a team out had it won the Big Ten tournament.

title: The End of the Greek Diner?
description: The time when diners were identified with Greek immigrants may soon be history.

title: Memo to the Superdelegates: No Principles, Please
description: In my last column I said in an aside that there are no ethical issues in the controversy about the superdelegates to the Democratic convention. This is the not the view of media pundits who keep asking the question, What is the right thing for the superdelegates to do?  and then, more often than not, answering it by saying (as Time magazine editor Richard Stengel did in the Feb. 25th issue) that the superdelegates should follow the will of the majorities in their districts and their states, because to do otherwise would be undemocratic.

title: Goose Bumps for Billy Hahn
description: One year ago, the West Virginia assistant coach Billy Hahn was watching the N.C.A.A. tournament at an efficiency apartment in New Jersey. Hahn was working for the basketball instructional organization Hoop Group at the time. His wife, Kathi, looked at him and said, Do you ever think well get back doing that again?

title: What Ive Learned as a Blogger for The New York Times
description: Mark Cuban wrote Thursday about why he thinks that newspapers, and The New York Times in particular, are making a mistake by publishing blogs.

title: SXSW Video: Rachael Ray, Indie Rocker?
description: Its kind of weird that shes doing this here, a woman at Rachael Rays music showcase said yesterday afternoon, echoing the collective, Rachael Ray, indie rock  huh? as she stood in the front patio of the Beauty Bar, gobbling the Mexican mac & cheese and barbecue chicken that the TV chef had cooked up for the party.

title: SXSW: Unstoppable Late-Night Beats
description: Just when SXSW fatigue threatened, I turned to music best described as relentless, with pounding, insistent, unstoppable beats running through songs from start to finish. Beyond that, each band was decidedly different.

title: Dreams of Young Designers
description: To get an idea of what's in store for showroom models of the future, take a look at concept cars from young designers.

title: Expectations for the New York Auto Show
description: Like the Knicks, this year's New York Auto Show will focus on rookies and hope for next season.

title: Recapping the JPMorgan Conference Call
description: On an unusual conference call Sunday evening  though little in this saga can be called usual  executives from JPMorgan Chase quickly walked investors and analysts through their $236 million acquisition of Bear Stearns.

title: How We Introduce, and What It Means
description: Recently I had lunch with another author. It was the kind of meal where the ideas were flying and I kept my notebook out to jot down various things requiring that I follow up. We each mentioned people the other should know, and he encouraged me to consider working with his speaking bureau. A couple of weeks later, without any prompting from me, he sent an e-mail to one of the founders of the agency saying wonderful things about me. I was delighted.

title: Behind Closed Doors, Democrats Seek Answers
description: The public phase of the Democratic presidential race will now pause, briefly, for a back-to-the-future experiment in back-room deal-making.

title: Remembering the Feds Last Bank Bailout
description: Among the many astonishing developments that have arisen in the wake of Bear Stearns final meltdown is the level of involvement of the Federal Reserve System.

title: Case of the Vanishing Bear
description: Santa Fe, N.M.

title: Muck in the Middle
description: Of all the first-round games in the N.C.A.A. tournament, the one that I stared at the longest when filling out my picks for Mondays paper was No. 12 Villanova vs. No. 5 Clemson.

title: Setting the Stage for a Showdown in San Antonio
description: The Final Four is set, at least according to the early returns. And, based on completed brackets on ESPNs Mens Tournament Challenge Web site, North Carolina is the projected winner. The top-seeded teams all received the highest percentage of votes in their respective regions to win it all.

title: Dubai fund reaches deal with Spanish real estate giant
description: In the latest twist in the saga of Inmobiliaria Colonial, the troubled Spanish real estate giant has agreed to sell its commercial property operations to an investment fund controlled by the Dubai royal family. It will spin off its residential interests into a separate entity.

title: The Baiji Refinery in Iraq
description: Stolen oil profits help keep Iraq's insurgency running.

title: JPMorgans Expanding Footprint
description: The Defense Department has the Pentagon. Now, JPMorgan Chase can claim the Octagon as its own.

title: A Few Questions About the Bear Stearns Deal
description: How long will it take? Can JPMorgan Chase refuse to complete the deal if things get even worse for Bear Stearns? And can Bears shareholders, facing an almost complete loss, stop it?

title: Phyllis Spira, 64, Cape Town Ballerina, Dies
description: Phyllis Spira, South Africas most eminent ballerina, who won international renown during her three-decade career with the Capab Ballet and who, with her husband, Phillip Boyd, founded Dance for All to spread dance classes into the townships, died on Tuesday in Cape Town. She was 64.

title: Times Co. to Give Board Seats to 2 Hedge Funds
description: The New York Times Company has struck a deal with a pair of hedge funds that want to shake up the company, giving the funds two seats on the board in order to avoid a proxy fight, the two sides announced Monday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on March 7 about arts education in New York City public schools incorrectly described the results of a city survey about instruction in the arts. Only 4 percent of the citys elementary schools meet the states requirement for arts education, not 4 percent of all public schools. And fewer than 30 percent of middle school students  not middle schools  meet the states requirements in arts instruction. (Such instruction is offered by 79 percent of middle schools.) (Go to Article)

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Thursday about Hollywoods plans for several 3-D movies referred incorrectly to one planned for release in 2009, G-Force, from Disney, about a squad of guinea pigs sent to stop an evil billionaire from taking over the world. While it has computer-generated guinea pigs, it is a live-action movie, not animated.

title: Birdie on 18th Gives Woods 5th Palmer Title
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  When it came time to end it Sunday, to catch another giant and write another page in the history of golf, Tiger Woods did what he does best. He immersed himself in the moment, evaluated the situation  one putt for another win  considered the slope of the 18th green at Bay Hill, read the break and judged the speed. Then he started the putt on line.

title: Harmonic Convergence: Orbiting Planets and Fluffy Clouds
description: Giving music names and stories was the unspoken topic of the Philadelphia Orchestra concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday. The Planets, Gustav Holsts beloved potboiler, made seven stops around our solar system. At lower altitudes Nuages, the first of the three Debussy Nocturnes, played before intermission, exhibited, in Debussys words, the slow, solemn motion of the clouds. The suite from Bartoks ballet The Miraculous Mandarin was the evenings other piece.

title: The Case for Another Drug War, Against Pharmaceutical Marketers Dirty Tactics
description: By the time Melody Petersen gets around to interviewing Iowas state nosologist near the end of Our Daily Meds, the facts that she cites dont even sound that grim. The nosologists job is to catalog Iowas deceased according to cause of death. He processes about 27,000 death certificates a year. And by his reckoning there were only five deaths caused by adverse reactions to prescription drugs in 2002. That low figure is jarringly out of whack with Ms. Petersens investigative reporting in an angrily illuminating book on drug-related corporate malfeasance and patient peril.

title: Bar Worker Was Lucky as Building Collapsed
description: It was a mild, sun-soaked Saturday afternoon in Midtown Manhattan, and Juan Perez was doing what he does every day of the week: He was working.

title: Titles, and No Trouble, for P.S.A.L. at the Garden
description: The Public Schools Athletic League AA division boys and girls basketball championships returned to Madison Square Garden without incident Sunday, a year after a series of altercations erupted in the stands.

title: Big Truck May Send Tagg Back to Kentucky Derby
description: The trainer Barclay Tagg is apparently headed back to Churchill Downs in May, five years after winning the Kentucky Derby with Funny Cide. And his horse is sure to draw comparisons with Funny Cide, the underdog gelding who nearly swept the Triple Crown.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on March 4 about the opera tenor Giuseppe di Stefano misstated the dates of his disastrous concert tour with Maria Callas, as well as other aspects of his career. The tour was in 1973-74, not 1972-73. The tours itinerary was North America, Asia and Europe  not the Americas, Asia and Europe. Mr. di Stefano first appeared as Elvino in La Sonnambula before his debut at the Metropolitan Opera in 1948, not after. And he sang the role in several European opera houses, not at the Met.

title: Bitter Protest in Jerusalem Over Attack at Seminary
description: JERUSALEM  Dozens of far-right Israeli nationalists threw stones and scuffled with the police on Sunday evening in and around the Jerusalem neighborhood that is home to the family of the Palestinian gunman who killed eight Jewish seminary students on March 6.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week included todays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills Tuesday.

title: New CDs
description: ARSENIO RODRGUEZ  El Alma de Cuba  (Tumbao)

title: Dow Ends Flat After a Day of Gyrations
description: A day that loomed darkly on Wall Street ended with only a modest decline in the overall market and the Dow Jones industrials in an unlikely place: positive territory.

title: Governor Patersons Tests
description: David Patersons inauguration Monday as New Yorks governor will bring a sigh of relief from many of the state Capitols regulars. This is not necessarily good news for him or for the citizens he will pledge to serve.

title: Dusting Off the Archive for the Web
description: As magazines and newspapers hunt for the new thing they need to be to thrive in the Internet era, some find that part of the answer lies in the old thing they used to be.

title: Horton Earns Box-Office Success
description: Dr. Seuss Horton Hears a Who! made its box-office debut at No. 1 with an estimated weekend draw of $45.1 million, the best opening so far this year, according to The Associated Press. It was the fifth-biggest G-rated opening ever. (The top honor goes to Finding Nemo, with $70.2 million, in 2003.) The computer-generated Horton, above, gave Jim Carrey, who voices the title character, his biggest opening at the North American box office in almost five years. Last weekends box-office winner, 10,000 BC, fell to No. 2 with $16.4 million for the three-day period. That prehistoric action movie, released by Warner Brothers Pictures, has earned $61.2 million over the last 10 days. Never Back Down, an extreme-fighting film aimed at high school students, a Summit Entertainment release, opened at No. 3. with $8.6 million. College Road Trip, a Walt Disney Pictures comedy starring Martin Lawrence, finished in fourth place with $7.9 million and Vantage Point, a thriller from Sony, completed the Top 5 with $5.4 million. Hollywoods revenues rose for the first time after four weekends of declining business. Overall receipts came in at $127 million, up 8.5 percent from the same weekend last year, according to the tracking firm Media by Numbers.

title: Does This Latte Have a Funny Mainstream Taste to You?
description: In 2005, Starbucks looked like it was going to do for undiscovered music what it had done for the nonfat latte. The company decided to stock Careless Love, a CD of sophisticated pop-jazz songs by Madeleine Peyroux, who had attracted only a modest following in this country, plying her craft in small bars. Ms. Peyroux soon found herself at No. 81 on the Billboard chart, and has become a mainstay of jazz.

title: This Weeks Planned Economic Reports
description: RATE CUT EXPECTED The Federal Reserve meets on Tuesday, when it will decide how deeply to cut interest rates. A cut of a half point to three-quarters of a point is expected.

title: Behind Closed Doors, Democrats Seek Answers
description: The public phase of the Democratic presidential race will now pause, briefly, for a back-to-the-future experiment in back-room deal-making.

title: Gay Couples Say Civil Unions Arent Enough
description: Eager to celebrate their partnership, Tracy and Katy Weber Tierney were among the first in line when Connecticut created civil unions three years ago as a way to formalize same-sex relationships without using the word marriage.

title: Georgia Court Refuses New Trial in Death Penalty Case
description: ATLANTA  In a split decision, the Georgia Supreme Court refused Monday to allow a new trial for a man sentenced to death for the 1989 murder of a Savannah police officer, despite recantations from seven of nine witnesses who originally testified against him.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about Boeings decision to protest the award of a large Air Force contract to a rival misstated the former name of the Government Accountability Office, which is charged with investigating Boeings complaint. It was the General Accounting Office, not the Government Accounting Office.

title: Charred Bodies Found in Car
description: Two people were beaten to death and placed in the trunk of a luxury car that was then set on fire in a wildlife preserve in Queens on Saturday night, the authorities said.

title: Alitalia Takes Offer for Buyout
description: PARIS  The board of Alitalia, the money-losing Italian airline, accepted a 747 million-euro takeover offer from Air France-KLM on Sunday, seizing a financial lifeline at the 11th hour after months of political indecision and labor resistance.

title: Paterson Is Calling the Shots on Swearing-In
description: ALBANY  If the swearing-in of David A. Paterson as the 55th governor of New York on Monday looks carefully choreographed, that is no accident.

title: The Untalented Concerto: An a (Flat) for Effort
description: To the Editor:

title: Green Grows the Vodka
description: Just in time for St. Patricks Day, here comes a green vodka.

title: Big East Stands Tallest With 8 Bids
description: By tying a conference record with 8 of its 16 teams earning entries, the Big East had more teams make the N.C.A.A. tournament than any other league.

title: Fears That Bear Stearnss Downfall May Spread
description: The cash squeeze that brought Bear Stearns to its knees is fanning fears that other investment banks might be vulnerable to the crisis of confidence gripping Wall Street.

title: A Poor Choice on Civil Rights
description: President Bush has made yet another ill-considered nomination to the Justice Department, this time selecting Grace Chung Becker to be assistant attorney general for the civil rights division. It is a critically important job, responsible for protecting the rights of racial and religious minorities, the disabled and other groups. The division has been improperly politicized in recent years, and it has worked to undermine the very rights it is supposed to protect.

title: Victims Remembered as Men Who Knew Risks, but Loved the Job
description: The crane operator lugs his lunchbox and thermos into the cab high in the air as his father had before him, and he sits alone. Below him, the riggers work in the open air, and at the end of the day, they all climb down and make their way to their homes in other boroughs and the suburbs.

title: The B Word
description: O.K., here it comes: The unthinkable is about to become the inevitable.

title: Bobby on Parade
description: St. Patricks Day Parade, March 16, 1968

title: Fall of Six-Ton Support Caused Crane to Topple
description: The spectacular collapse of a towering crane on the East Side began when a massive piece of steel designed to secure it to a new high-rise building came loose and pancaked on top of a second support nine stories below, shearing it free and creating a fatal imbalance that sent the 22-story crane toppling across a two-block swath of Turtle Bay, officials said on Sunday.

title: Southwest Festival Wraps Up Its 2,000-Course Feast
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Adam Elliott, the drummer and singer of Times New Viking, summed up the South by Southwest Music festival between the frenetic songs by his band, a three-piece from Columbus, Ohio. Even if Times New Viking were no good, he said, theres a thousand other bands. He added, Those odds are pretty good.

title: Camels Go Easily Through the Eyes of Admirers
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  This time of year, when the weather here is still cool and comfortable and the flowering plants and shrubs are everywhere, how better to spend a day than to be out in the desert with beautiful camels?

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,980 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans:

title: Using the Web at 40,000 Feet
description: The Web is again set to invade the airplane.

title: JP Morgan Pays $2 a Share for Bear Stearns
description: In a shocking deal reached on Sunday to save Bear Stearns, JPMorgan Chase agreed to pay a mere $2 a share to buy all of Bear  less than one-tenth the firms market price on Friday.

title: Youre Not Holden Caulfield? Are Too! Are Too! Are Too!
description: This is not going to be your parents night at the theater. That claim, usually included in the preshow announcement before The Gay Barbers Apartment, isnt exactly true. Yes, Larry Traigers work about prep school seniors who have sex and do drugs in the home of a gay hairstylist is not some stuffy drama. But this presentation from Half Assiduity Arts, a group with a shoestring budget and a wealth of optimism, is the kind of cobbled-together piece that the artists parents might have created when they were young.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A theater entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about Next to Normal, at the Second Stage Theater, misstated the surname of the writer of the book and lyrics. He is Brian Yorkey, not Yorker. (The error also appeared in Weekend on Feb. 15, 22, 29, and March 7.)

title: The Fungus That Conquered Europe
description: London

title: Magda Cordell McHale, 86, Futurist Thinker, Is Dead
description: Magda Cordell McHale, an artist who was one of the founding members of the Independent Group in London in the early 1950s and later became a renowned sociologist and writer in the field of futurism, died on Feb. 21 in Buffalo. She was 86.

title: After Elections Setback, a Chastened Sarkozy Presses On
description: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy plans to press ahead with his program for change but tone down his flashy image in an effort to restore his popularity with low-income voters after his center-right party suffered a setback in local elections that concluded Sunday, officials close to his office said.

title: With Expanding Librarys Promise, Concern About Its Purpose
description: Last week, when the New York Public Library announced a $1 billion expansion, including a transformation of its flagship building on Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street using a $100 million donation by the Wall Street financier Stephen A. Schwarzman, it signaled both a great opportunity and a great temptation.

title: Margin of Victory Is Truer Indicator of Teams Strength
description: The North Carolina Tar Heels had a good day Sunday. They beat Clemson for the Atlantic Coast Conference title, were at the top of the polls and were rewarded with the No. 1 overall seed in the N.C.A.A. mens tournament. They have plenty of momentum, not having lost in more than a month. But will they win the championship? Not in my bracket.

title: UBS Is Said to Consider 8,000 Layoffs
description: ZURICH (Dow Jones)  The Swiss bank UBS is considering cutting as many as 8,000 jobs to save costs, and will not rule out a possible split of its wealth management and investment banking business, a Swiss newspaper reported Sunday.

title: Just the Fashion at Public Apology
description: The look, for him: a dark suit, starched white shirt, red, white and blue striped tie.

title: Fleeing Cranes Fury, With Neighbors Pets in Tow
description: Having had to flee her office on Sept. 11, 2001, Eve Charlack did not flee in panic when a toppling construction crane crashed to the ground just a few yards from her apartment on Saturday afternoon.

title: More Than a Sound Bite, This Clip Has Some Teeth
description: On Jan. 31, Derrick Ashong, a 32-year-old musician, dropped off his pal, Shaunelle Curry, at the Democratic primary debate taking place at the Kodak Theater in Hollywood. After shrugging off her suggestion that he join her in carrying a sign for Barack Obama outside the theater  his band was leaving on tour the next day  he reconsidered and walked back to join her.

title: Accounts, People, Miscellany
description: Accounts

title: Michigan Athletes Steered to Easy Classes, Report Says
description: The independent study courses administered to University of Michigan athletes by a professor there have drawn scrutiny in a published report.

title: Curbs on Protest in Tibet Lashed by Dalai Lama
description: DHARAMSALA, India  The Dalai Lama accused China on Sunday of waging cultural genocide against his followers in Tibet and called for an international inquiry into the suppression of protests there, his strongest defense to date of Tibetan Buddhists who have staged an uprising against Chinese rule.

title: Open-Source Troubles in Wiki World
description: Since he helped create Wikipedia in 2001, Jimmy Wales has been called many things: benevolent dictator, constitutional monarch, digital evangelist and spiritual leader of the tens of thousands of volunteers who have made the online encyclopedia one of the top 10 most visited Web sites.

title: Take It From a Coach: Pick Favorites, Expect Anything
description: The N.C.A.A. selection committee definitely took care of the No. 1 mens seeds, as it should have. The East looks like the strongest region. I wanted to pick Tennessee to go to the Final Four, but I cannot when it is in the same region as North Carolina.

title: Citi Names New Chief of Investment Banking
description: Shaking up its leadership for the third time in six months, Citigroup has named John Havens as the new head of its investment banking and alternative investments group.

title: Another Replacement Sings at the Met
description: With the flu season taking a heavy toll on opera stars, it is boom time for debuts at the Metropolitan Opera. On Saturday evening Ermonela Jaho, an Albanian soprano, stepped in for an indisposed Ruth Ann Swenson, right, as Violetta in La Traviata. She sang opposite the tenor Jonas Kaufmann, as she had done in January when she replaced Anna Netrebko in the same role at the Royal Opera House in London. Hers was the third Met debut in a lead role in two days, after Gary Lehman replaced Ben Heppner, and Janice Baird took over for Deborah Voigt midperformance in the Mets star-crossed revival of Tristan und Isolde on Friday evening. Mr. Lehmans opportunity arose after the first replacement for Mr. Heppner, John Mac Master, struggled with the roles strenuous vocal demands in the opening performance, last Monday. The Met announced on Sunday afternoon that Mr. Lehman would replace Mr. Heppner in Tristan on Tuesday evening. It was not prepared to announce who would sing Tristan on Saturday afternoon, in the matinee to be broadcast live on radio and in movie theaters. Through a representative, Ms. Voigt declined to be interviewed, but sent word on Sunday that she was feeling better and hoping to sing on Tuesday. Ms. Swenson was expected to return to La Traviata for the next performance, on Wednesday evening, a Met spokesman said.

title: Iran Bans Pictures of Foreign Film Stars
description: Nine cinema and lifestyle magazines have been banned in Iran for publishing images of corrupt foreign artists, Agence France-Presse reported on Sunday. The publications were banned by the Culture Ministry for showing photographs of corrupt foreign artists and details about their decadent lives. Thirteen other publications received warnings. The latest issue of one of the banned magazines, Donya-ye Tasvir, included photographs and articles about Nicole Kidman, Reese Witherspoon and several other Hollywood stars. Only a handful of cinemas in Tehran screen foreign movies, Agence France-Presse said, and those films are subject to heavy censorship of any scenes where actresses are scantly dressed.

title: Safe Childbirth, for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqis See a Candidates Agenda in McCains Visit
description: BAGHDAD  Senator John McCain arrived in Iraq on Sunday morning on a trip that was described as a visit by an official Congressional delegation, but that also served to showcase his foreign policy credentials as he campaigns for the White House.

title: The Burden of Hype in the Citys Bright Lights
description: A Knicks fan or perhaps any basketball fan within a 50-mile radius of Madison Square Garden would have to admit how disconcerting it is to learn that New Yorks next best thing can, in the shorthand of a headline, be referred to as Steph from Coney Island.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Feb. 29 about a dispute between a California local of the Service Employees International Union and the unions president, Andy Stern, misstated the number of facilities in Florida owned by the Tenet Healthcare Corporation, which employs some of the unions members. Tenet has 11 facilities in the state, not 23.

title: Science at Risk
description: Nobody was greatly surprised last week when Stephen Johnson, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, proposed new limits on smog-forming pollutants that were weaker than those his scientists had recommended  and more to the liking of industry. In the Bush administration, contests between politics and science are usually resolved in favor of politics.

title: Star for Vince McMahon
description: The best-known promoter of professional wrestling, Vince McMahon, received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame on Friday. Mr. McMahon, who was honored in the television category, is the chairman of World Wrestling Entertainment. WWE produces new television programming 52 weeks a year, according to its Web site, including Monday Night RAW, Friday Night SmackDown and ECW: Extreme Championship Wrestling, which can be seen in more than 130 countries and heard in 22 languages. I already know Im a star, Mr. McMahon said. Im the biggest star of all time.

title: How a Station Tries to Calm Mideasts Rage
description: Amid the latest flare-up in Israeli-Palestinian violence, there are plenty of raised voices on either side. A new ad campaign suggests a different way to address the divide: speak, or even sing, to both sides at once.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on March 7 about Apples efforts to encourage programmers to write software for the iPhone referred incorrectly to the cost of its developer kit. The kit is free; it does not cost $99. (The company is charging $99 for the right to distribute finished programs to iPhone users.)

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture with a report in the World Business Briefing on Thursday was published in error. The photograph was of Wilhelm Zeller, chief executive of Hannover Re  not Toshihiko Fukui, governor of the Bank of Japan. (A reference to Mr. Zeller was edited out of another report in the column.)

title: Georgia Says Wow After Roller Coaster Ride
description: ATLANTA  The overjoyed Georgia mens basketball players gathered on the court and looked up at the video screen in Alexander Memorial Coliseum, the arena of their fierce rival Georgia Tech. The Bulldogs were not being treated as trespassers, but as honored guests waiting for the N.C.A.A. tournament selection show to start.

title: Hard-Drinking Defense Lawyer Is No Miss Manners
description: Imagine if The Devil Wears Prada had featured a grisly crime as one of its subplots. Imagine, in other words, if it had veered away from a rainfall of Herms scarves onto the brittle turf of Law & Order: SVU. What you might be left with is the aggravating new Fox drama Canterburys Law.

title: Shares Slide on Fed Move and Bear Deal
description: TOKYO  European and Asian stocks fell Monday amid fresh concerns about the global banking network and the fallout from the bargain-basement sale of Bear Stearns to JPMorgan Chase.

title: Justices to Hear F.C.C. Indecency Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to hear an appeal from the Federal Communications Commission, which last June suffered a defeat at the appeals-court level on the use of vulgar words on the airwaves.

title: Tainted Drugs Put Focus on the F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON  After a contaminated medicine from China was linked to as many as 17 deaths in the United States, members of Congress clamored for changes while regulators defended their actions.

title: New Home in Space for a Nearly Assembled Robotic Device
description: Building Dextre, the new robotic grappling device for the International Space Station, has meant frustration and elation for astronauts in space and experts on the ground.

title: In Police and Fire Depts., a Bit o Brogue Survives
description: What er ya doin, boyo? the policeman might inquire. Do nt be standin there, the firefighter would command. Get away with yee now.

title: Sale Price Reflects the Depth of Bears Problems
description: In a shocking deal reached on Sunday to save Bear Stearns, JPMorgan Chase agreed to pay a mere $2 a share to buy all of Bear  less than one-tenth the firms market price on Friday.

title: One in Four Girls
description: Teenage girls and their parents need to read the latest government study of sexually transmitted diseases. The infections are so prevalent they are hard to avoid once a girl becomes sexually active. One in four girls ages 14 to 19 is infected with at least one of four common diseases. Among African-American girls in the study, almost half were infected.

title: Music in Review
description: ISABEL LEONARD

title: New-Look Knicks Lineup Achieves Familiar Result
description: Before Sunday nights game, several of the Knicks sat in the locker room comparing how their former high school teams were faring in their respective state playoffs. Afterward, they dissected the N.C.A.A. tournament bracket, which was released while the Knicks were on the court.

title: Even if Youre Ill, You Can Still Stay Connected
description: IF shopping is indeed a form of therapy, why does nobody seem to get better? Because of one innovation, one group of shoppers may start.

title: Move With Rigor. Repeat. Then Repeat. Then Repeat.
description: If choreographers had smooth-talking agents to pitch their shows, Brian Brooks would present no problem. Judson Dance Theater meets Elizabeth Streb Lite, an Armani-suited figure might say. Minimalism meets flamboyance; kitsch meets rigor.

title: More Election Troubles in Florida, but That Doesnt Bother the Governor
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  What does Gov. Charlie Crist, the staunchly sunny (and tan) chief executive of Florida, think about the national attention his states latest ugly election dispute has drawn?

title: HBO Is to Replace a Top Executive
description: After suffering through its longest drought without a new hit series, HBO is making a change at the top of its entertainment division, replacing one of the companys longest-serving executives, Carolyn Strauss.

title: Four Players Came, Four Players Conquered
description: Lightning, in a way, struck for the third time at the Spring North American Championships in Detroit. After two pairs won national titles by leading after both days of play, on Saturday a team-of-four, Boguslaw Gierulski, Krzysztof Jassem, Krzysztof Martens and Jerzy Skrzypczak from Poland, won the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams.

title: Dos and Donts of Gentle Prodding
description: In many hotel bathrooms, there hang hook-shaped plastic cards urging guests to forgo the laundering of their towels. A new study in the Journal of Consumer Research examines how often people follow the requests of such cards, and why.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Subtleties to Showmanship: Pianistic Duality on Display
description: You never quite know what youre going to get at a Lang Lang performance. In recent years he has tempered the rollicking, explosive side of his pianism and brought a measure of weight, thought and maturity to his music making. But he has apparently reserved the right to backslide if the mood takes him, as it did in a New York Philharmonic appearance in June.

title: To Placate Moscow, U.S. Would Keep Missile-Defense System Off for Now
description: MOSCOW - Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Sunday that the United States, in order to calm Moscows concerns over a proposed missile-defense system in Europe, would promise not to turn on elements of it until Iran had demonstrated it had a missile capable of reaching Europe.

title: Bush, Praising Feds Move, Faces Criticism
Federer Halts a Skid and Gains Some Fans
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  If the tennis worlds eyes are fixed on Roger Federer, ready to poke at his recent vulnerability, to test his game after a recent bout with mononucleosis, it appears that Federer has discovered the benefit of appearing to be human.

title: World Banker and His Cash Return Home
description: SINDHEKELA, India  An important man from the World Bank recently arrived in this isolated village, where monkeys prowl rutted roads, rain pours through the school roof and the native son who achieved the most did so by going away.

title: Obamas Brother in China
description: BRUSSELS

title: They Dont Call It a Special Relationship for Nothing
description: Imagine that someone hands you a pamphlet attacking the United States with full-blown rage and loathing. Your first inclination is to toss it. Its the usual screed, spewing standard-issue accusations about American megalomania, imperialism and destructiveness.

title: An Assault Case in New Jersey Stirs Painful Memories
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  The news, disturbingly familiar, made the Rev. Martha Eidmann-Hicks bend her memory back across two decades. In this wealthy and ethnically diverse suburb 15 miles from Manhattan, three high school students were charged in the past two weeks with sexually assaulting a 16-year-old special education student with a broomstick.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on March 5 about the acquittal of a 27-year-old man on charges of trying to murder two police officers outside a Brooklyn nightclub in 2005 gave an erroneous spelling from prosecutors and his defense lawyer for his given name. He is Damion Henry, not Damien. (The error appeared in an article in some editions on Feb. 2, 2006. And an About New York column on Dec. 7, 2005, gave another incorrect spelling, Damian.)

title: Airstrikes Kill 9 in Pakistan Region That Harbors Militants
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Three bombs, apparently dropped by an American aircraft, killed nine people and wounded nine others on Sunday in the tribal area of South Waziristan that provides sanctuary to Al Qaeda and the Taliban, a Pakistani security official said.

title: Bearer of Bad News Decides to Advertise It
description: Consumer Reports is getting feisty in its old age. After more than 70 years, the magazine has decided that a review isnt enough for a bad product  it deserves a provocative ad campaign, too.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Suzanne Alecia joined the Out-of-Home Video Advertising Bureau, New York, as president. She succeeds Kim Norris, who left after nine months as president of the new association to become senior vice president for strategy and business development/digital marketing and commerce at Cablevision Systems. Ms. Alecia had most recently been president for advertising sales at the Hotel Networks, New York.

title: A Strong Early Schedule Is a Key to Getting In
description: The N.C.A.A. unveiled its field for the 2008 mens basketball tournament Sunday, with a few familiar faces missing and teams from outside college basketballs six power conferences still struggling for representation.

title: The New Governor Also Serves as an Inspiration for the Blind
description: WHITE PLAINS  Harold James, a 44-year-old bear of a man with a neatly trimmed beard, works at Lighthouse International, a nonprofit organization that helps people with vision problems. He is also legally blind. And until last week, he was unaware that the second-ranking elected official in the state was also legally blind.

title: Now, Cringing in the Shadows Cast by Cranes
description: New York has always been a city of construction cranes: They are the steel crutches of the skyline, forever pulling it upward. But when one of them collapsed on the East Side on Saturday  killing at least four people, demolishing a building and damaging at least five others  the disaster exposed the often-uneasy relationship cranes have had with the New Yorkers who walk below them.

title: An Accident With One Door Opens Another
description: TAMPA, Fla.  It was not the best way to pave a path to the major leagues. It was painful, and purely accidental. But when Scott Patterson jammed his right middle finger in a door three years ago, it turned his career around.

title: Winning Advice From a 3-Time Loser
description: If nothing else, I am an expert at losing in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament. How many people can say they have lost in the first round the past three years? Its a short list. Trust me, its a miserable list to be on.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Sports of The Times column on Friday, about West Virginias mens basketball success under Coach Bob Huggins, an alumnus of the university and a native of Morgantown, misidentified the Ohio town where he starred in the sport in high school. It was Gnadenhutten, not Morgantown.

title: A Second Chance at West Virginia
description: One year ago, the West Virginia assistant Billy Hahn was watching the N.C.A.A. tournament at an efficiency apartment in New Jersey. Hahn was working for the basketball instructional organization Hoop Group.

title: Pastor Defends His Predecessor at Obamas Chicago Church
description: The new pastor of Senator Barack Obamas longtime church in Chicago took it upon himself to issue a statement Sunday to defend the record of his predecessor, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., whose incendiary sermons have been played on cable television and the Internet in recent days.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article in the special Museums section about a 1975 video that recreates the Kennedy assassination misstated the surname of one of the artists. He is Doug Hall, not Doug Taylor.

title: Martnez Is on Target in His Spring Debut
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  It is no longer so far-fetched to hear someone suggest that Pedro Martnez has such good control he could throw strikes blindfolded. After all, Martnez, the veteran Mets veteran right-hander, pitched several bullpen sessions this spring with his eyes closed.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a new online health research service that the insurer Aetna plans to offer its customers misspelled the surname of an industry analyst who commented on the plan. He is Wes Rishel, not Richel.

title: Rafael Tufio, Artist, Is Dead at 85
description: Rafael Tufio, a painter and printmaker considered one of Puerto Ricos most prominent cultural figures, died on Thursday in San Juan. He was 85 and lived in Old San Juan.

title: Gun Case Causes Bush Administration Rift
description: WASHINGTON  Suppose that after decades of silence on the subject, the Supreme Court was to decide that the Second Amendment protects an individual right to gun ownership, as opposed to a right tied to service in a militia.

title: Fateful Choice on Iraq Army Bypassed Debate
description: BAGHDAD  When President Bush convened a meeting of his National Security Council on May 22, 2003, his special envoy in Iraq made a statement that caught many of the participants by surprise. In a video presentation from Baghdad, L. Paul Bremer III informed the president and his aides that he was about to issue an order formally dissolving Iraqs Army.

title: As Campaign Drags On, Aides Put Lives on Hold
description: There is the abandoned $1,000-a-month temporary apartment in Des Moines, littered with dirty T-shirts and a deflated air mattress. The campaign aide whose 105-degree fever sent her to the hospital. The neglected fiance in New York who handed down an ultimatum: Take a weekend off  or else.

title: Near Rubble, Regulars Miss Regular Bar
description: Here are just a few of the features that can be found in various New York bars these days: Bacon-infused cocktails, girls swimming in tanks, a lively game of boccie, a staff of mostly drag queens, leather-bound books, scientific demonstrations, vintage video games and a $10 manicure-and-martini special.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 16, 2008

title: Meningitis Suspected in Death on L.I.
description: Bacterial meningitis was the probable cause of death for a Long Island man who died on Saturday, health officials said on Sunday.

title: A New Concert Site for New Jersey
description: The historic Wellmont Theater in Montclair, N.J., is to reopen in the fall, a newly formed independent concert-promotion company has announced. The promoter, Montclair Entertainment, comprises principals of the independent promotion company the Bowery Presents  owners of the Bowery Ballroom and Mercury Lounge as well as the recently opened Terminal 5 and Music Hall of Williamsburg  along with Andy Feltz, who brought shows to the Beacon Theater in Manhattan for two decades and recently to the United Palace, also in Manhattan. This will be Bowery Presents first major foray into New Jersey, according to The Star-Ledger of Newark. The theater, which originally opened in 1922 in downtown Montclair, will undergo a roughly $3 million makeover.

title: Voting for the Worst on American Idol Makes Money for an Entrepreneur

title: Carrie Underwood to Join Grand Ole Opry
description: Carrie Underwood, below, will join the Grand Ole Opry in Nashville as its newest member, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Underwood, a former American Idol winner, was invited to join on Saturday by Randy Travis, after she performed his song I Told You So at an Opry show. Her debut album, Some Hearts, released in 2005, has sold more than 6 million copies in the United States and her latest album, Carnival Ride, released in October, includes the No. 1 hit All-American Girl, her sixth consecutive No. 1 on the country charts. Ms. Underwood has also been named the female vocalist of the year by both the Academy of Country Music and the Country Music Association. Ms. Underwood, 25, will be inducted to the Opry on May 10.

title: Clubbing on a funky Parisian junk
description: The sea-faring La Dame de Canton rocked its way to middle age this winter, turning 30 while bobbing along the River Seine. In its early life, this replica of a 17th century Chinese junk sailed on the winds of the world, but nowadays La Dame is a funky Parisian nightclub that lists to the eclectic beat of old French songs, Balkan reggae or Mardi Gras manouche.  You wont find many tourists aboard this ship, which has been keeping the same rhythm as a nightclub for the last 13 years at the foot of the Bibliotheque Nationale, a riverside refuge for other floating clubs. La Dame used to ply the club trade under the name of the Guinguette Pirate, but for its 30th birthday the owners decided to shift back to its original name when the junk logged 38,000 miles and 17 countries

title: How close are we to a liquidity trap?
description: Heres one way to think about the liquidity trap  a situation in which conventional monetary policy loses all traction. When short-term interest rates are close to zero, open-market operations in which the central bank prints money and buys government debt dont do anything, because youre just swapping one more or less zero-interest rate asset for another. Alternatively, you can say that theres no incentive to lend out any increase in the monetary base, because the interest rate you get isnt enough to make it worth bothering.

title: Could Bear Stearns Do Better?
description: Its not surprising that Bear Stearnss stock plummeted Monday after JPMorgan Chase agreed to buy it for just $2 per share. The surprising part is that it didnt plummet even more.

title: Could Bear Stearns Do Better?
description: It's not surprising that Bear Stearns's stock plummeted Monday after JPMorgan Chase agreed to buy it for just $2 per share. The surprising part is that it didn't plummet even more.  After closing at $30 Friday, Bear's stock hovered at about $4 late Monday morning, suggesting that investors expected to get something more than what JPMorgan has offered. But what? The securities firm was nearly forced to shut its doors because of a severe liquidity crunch. As a company that was preparing a bankruptcy filing over the weekend in case the sale effort failed, Bear seems to be in no position to negotiate.   A number of possibilities come to mind.  Investors may think that JPMorgan will increase its price, if only to avoid being seen as a vulture. Theoretically, Bear's shareholders can vote against the deal, though it would take 12 months to reject it fully under Sunday's merger agreement.  Though the deal price is about $270 million, JPMorgan has said that the true cost of acquiring Bear will be much higher -- as much as $6 billion -- when litigation, severance and other costs are taken into account. So in principle, increasing the per-share price would have a relatively small effect on the overall cost of buying Bear.  Wall Street seems to think JPMorgan is getting a huge bargain: Shares of JPMorgan were up 10 percent Monday, even as other financial firms took a nosedive. Its market capitalization grew by $12 billion, paying for Bear Stearns several times over.  Investors may also be putting hope in the idea that another bidder could step up, such as a private equity firm.  That could be difficult, however. Many analysts think JPMorgan's close ties to Bear, including its role as the go-between for Bear's federally backed bailout loan, have already put it at an advantage over other buyers.  And JPMorgan has another leg up over a rival bidder: Bear has already given JPMorgan the "irrevocable" option to buy its New York headquarters even if the takeover deal falls through, according to the merger agreement, which Bear posted on its Web site Monday.   Finally, Bear shareholders may see another potential source of funds: lawsuits.   A report from Reuters on Monday suggested that law firms were being inundated with calls from angry investors looking for answers -- and, presumably, some payouts for their pain.  Go to Article from Reuters via Yahoo News>>

title: Paterson Is Sworn In as New Yorks 55th Governor
description: Updated, 2 p.m. | Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson gathered with leaders of New York States Legislature and judiciary in the Assembly chamber at the State Capitol in Albany at 1 p.m. and then took the oath of office as New York States 55th governor. In a 26-minute inaugural address  the first half of which was devoted to humor-filled acknowledgments of dignitaries and family members  he warned that our economy appears to be headed toward crisis, but also called for a bipartisan spirit of unity and hope. He made indirect reference to his predecessor, Eliot Spitzer, who announced his resignation on Wednesday amid a sex scandal, pledging to move beyond the often confrontational style Mr. Spitzer exhibited in his relations with the Legislature.
