title: For the Moment | A Bing Bang Alphabet
description: Liz O. Baylen

title: For ABC, Oprah Gives Big on Sunday Night
description: On a night of low ratings across network television, ABC earned Sundays most viewers thanks to new installments of Extreme Makeover: Home Edition and Oprahs Big Give.

title: Feedback | Eau de Shalimar Review
description: Keep an eye on the comments! Theres often good information there. Here is a sample of some of the dialog surrounding the Scent Notes | Eau de Shalimar by Guerlain review by Chandler Burr from March 13th. Burrs replies are included below.

title: Progress Is Cited Again in a Baghdad Market
description: BAGHDAD  Abbas Majid, a grizzled newsdealer, shooed the flies away from the dozen or so publications laid out on the sidewalk at the Shorja market.

title: Help . . .
description: Last week I made a kind of frittata with potatoes and asparagus. The interesting thing to me was that, as usual, I was rushed. I wanted the potatoes crisp-ish, but I wanted them soft, and I wanted them done fast. So I nuked them for a few minutes, then quickly peeled and browned them: perfect. Meanwhile, I briefly nuked the asparagus. Took them out, browned the asparagus a bit, lowered the heat, added the eggs, tucked the potatoes on top (better browned side up, for cosmetic purposes), and cooked the eggs while I went about my business.

title: Ballet in London: Compare and Contrast
description: Between 1949 and 1976, the two ballet companies that mattered most to many New Yorkers were the Royal Ballet (or, until 1956, the Sadlers Wells Ballet), which visited New York at least every other year, and New York City Ballet. The Royal Ballet came to seem the divine norm of ballet classicism, while New York City Ballet seemed its radical, if equally celestial, modernist extension.

title: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Iraq
description: At a speech in Washington D.C., Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton outlined her plan for Iraq and criticized her opponents on the issue.

title: Soft Serve | Barnyard Chic, Polo Logo Loco, Walmarts Kinky Recall
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: The Men Behind the Bear Stearns Deal
description: Even in the bright light of Monday morning, it remains one of the most remarkable financial deals in recent years. Bear Stearns, the 85-year-old investment bank that lay bleeding from its mortgage-inflicted wounds, agreed to sell itself to JPMorgan Chase for the still-unbelievable sum of $2 a share.

title: Bothering Your Doctor
description: Does the medical system try to prevent you from bothering your doctor?

title: New Trial Ordered for Former Qwest Chief
description: An appeals court has tossed out all the guilty verdicts against Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications International who was convicted last year of 19 counts of insider trading. The 10th Circuit Court of Appeals reversed the jury verdict in a 2-to-1 decision and has ordered a new trial.

title: The Great (Embarrassing) Bed Debate
description: We have three guest bedrooms sized small, medium and large. When it was time to think about furnishing these rooms, the easiest one was the smallest. We knew we could only fit a twin bed, but we wanted the flexibility to accommodate two people, and to use the room as a den for reading or potentially watching TV.

title: Monday Morning Motorsports: Hamilton, Mayhem Reign at Formula One Opener
description: The weekends results in racing and more

title: Clinton on the Economy and Oil
description: At a press conference in Washington D.C., Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton discussed the mounting worldwide economic troubles.

title: That Falling Crane . . . By the Numbers
description: A crane fell at a construction site on the East Side of Manhattan on Saturday, leaving death and destruction in its wake. The accident gave urban dwellers, who often have a gallows humor about walking underneath large cranes and elaborate scaffolding, one more thing to be worried about.

title: A Well-Covered End to the McCartney-Mills Marriage
description: Divorce settlements rarely call for a news article (or a blog post), let alone analytical essays, immediate YouTube uploads and general wall-to-wall coverage. Then again, this was far from an ordinary divorce.

title: Blank Check
description: Nouriel Rubini, a New York University economist, has been critically following the federal response to the housing market crisis for months now at his blog Global EconoMonitor, and thinks that the governments involvement in bailing out Bear Stearns and in allowing non-bank financial institutions to access the Fed discount window at the same terms as banks amount to the most radical change and expansions of Fed powers and functions since the Great Depression. He continues:

title: Forbidden Swedes?
description: Justin Fox suggests that we learn from the way Sweden dealt with its financial crisis at the beginning of the 90s. Im looking into it.

title: Paulson Discusses 'Liquidity Crisis'
description: CNBC coverage of Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson's comments on the Fed's intervention to push for Bear Stearns's sale to JPMorgan.

title: Falling Geckos
description: For geckos, a quick mid-air flick of the tail is all it takes to land feet-down.

title: On CBS, the Return of the Scripted Series
description: In January, Jon Cryer, an actor on the sitcom Two and a Half Men, was walking the writers guild picket lines in Burbank. In February, with the strike resolved, he was on a soundstage taping a new television episode for the first time in months. Tonight, the episode debuts on CBS.

title: Ballet in London: A Changed Landsacpe
description: In the almost 25 years since New York City Ballets last London visit, what has changed?

title: What to Do With Bears C.E.O.?
description: JPMorgan Chase is obviously acquiring a lot in its $236 million purchase of Bear Stearns. For pennies on the dollar, the banking giant is buying extensive prime brokerage and clearing operations, as well as a $1.2 billion office building.

title: Say What? From the files of the Department of Low Bar-Setting
description: At a meeting of his economic advisers today, after the Bear Stearns fire sale, another Fed rate cut, and the tanking of stock markets around the world, President Bush turned to Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Monday, Mar. 17:

title: Buyers and Sellers
description: Have you had enough of call girls and the men who love them? Of course you havent. AbeBooks.com  in honor of Eliot Spitzer and his fall from grace in a New York minute  has announced the first Hooker Prize, which turns out to be a list of 10 nonfiction books about madams and prostitutes. Among the titles are The Happy Hooker by Xaviera Hollander and Mayflower Madam by Sydney Biddle Barrows, who once reviewed a couple of picture books about beds for the TBR.

title: Paterson Sworn In as New York Governor
description: David A. Paterson was sworn in a week after revelations emerged that his predecessor, Eliot Spitzer, had patronized a prostitute and faced federal investigation.

title: For the Moment | Veronica Webb
description: (Roberto Ligresti)

title: The Michigan and Florida Primaries
description: John Harwood, of CNBC and The New York Times, reports on the Democratic Party's struggle over seating the delegates from Florida and Michigan.

title: Answers About the Rights of Students and Parents, Part 2
description: Following is the second and final set of answers from Andrew Tirrell, a lawyer with the nonprofit organization Advocates for Children of New York, who took questions from readers through March 14 on the rights of parents and students in New York City schools. His first set of answers was published March 12. We are no longer taking questions for this feature.

title: Touch of the Flu Keeps Mario Cuomo Away
description: After being sworn in as New York States 55th governor today, David A. Paterson thanked a litany of dignitaries in the audience, including two former governors, Hugh L. Carey and George E. Pataki. But Mario M. Cuomo, who was governor for three terms, from 1983 to 1994, was absent. Why?

title: Sibling Battles
description: What's your worst sibling memory?

title: Todays a Day When Its Easy Being Green
description: Chilly temperatures and a mazelike grid of barricades did not deter thousands of people from turning out along Fifth Avenue in Manhattan on Monday for New Yorks 247th annual St. Patricks Day Parade, and the spectacle was as much on the sidelines as on the streets, with traditional garb often giving way to the gaudy.Tam o Shanter style hats were outnumbered by floppy striped felt versions seemingly inspired by Dr. Seuss. Dangling green beads looked more like Mardi Gras than County Mayo. There were also feather boas, dyed beers and three-leaf clover green antennas.

title: CNet to Appeal Delaware Ruling
description: CNet Networks said Monday afternoon that it would appeal a Delaware court ruling allowing a hedge fund to nominate seven directors to its board.

title: Space: Also a Frontier for Corny Jokes
description: Space is, as you know, the final frontier. Its about taking technology to the limit, showing courage in the face of risk, and giving expression to the human urge to explore that seems hardwired into our DNA.

title: McCains March Madness
description: In a repeat of last years successful bracketology on his campaign Web site, Senator John McCains campaign is at it again.

title: Hospital Workers Fired for Snooping on Spears
description: Even pop stars have a right to medical privacy.

title: Candidates on the Economy
description: As President Bush welcomed the Federal Reserves intervention in the financial markets, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday questioned whether the Bush administration had reacted swiftly enough to contain the financial crisis gripping Wall Street and the markets.

title: Obama to Give Speech on Race Tomorrow
description: Senator Barack Obama plans to deliver a major speech on race tomorrow in Philadelphia, as his campaign struggled to contain the controversy over his churchs longtime pastor, the Reverend Jeremiah Wright Jr.

title: Drawing the Candidates
description: Although caricatures wont sway an election, they can influence public perception. Through caricatured distortion President Lyndon Johnson, with his elephantine ears and hooked beak, and President Richard Nixon, with his exaggerated five oclock shadow and witches peak, were made equally buffoonish and demonic. The visual satirists time-honored role is to make mountains out of physical molehills, thereby reducing their targets to comical icons, knocking the pomposity right out of them.

title: Blackstone Accused of Breaching ADS Deal
description: Alliance Data Systems said on Monday that the Blackstone Group was in breach of contract on its agreement to buy the credit-card transaction company.

title: M.T.A. Trip Planner Wins Web Award
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has won an award for an online tool. Seriously.

title: A Big Red Perspective on the Tournament
description: Jon Jaques is a sophomore forward on the Cornell mens basketball team and has been kind enough to embrace the task of blogging for The Quad about his experiences in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Jons initial report touches on how the Big Red learned who it would be playing in the first round. Check back with The Quad for updates as No. 14 seed Cornell prepares to take on No. 3 Stanford.

title: Ballet in London: NYCB and The Royal go Toe to Toe
description: New York City Ballet opened its season at the London Coliseum on Wednesday with a program of three Balanchine ballets London dancegoers have often seen danced by the Royal Ballet: Serenade, Agon and Symphony in C. (Darcey Bussell, who retired from the Royal Ballet last June, danced the lead role in all three with great success and danced two of them in her mid-1990s guest seasons at City Ballet.)

title: Sometimes the Bully Wins in the End
description: Our guest bloggers this week are the men behind Blogging the Boys:

title: Florida Democrats Concede Defeat on Mail-In Vote
description: The possibility of a mail-in vote for Floridas Democrats has officially been killed.

title: Lets Talk About Race
description: Barack Obama will give a major speech on the larger issue of race in this campaign, he told reporters in Monaca, Pa., reports the Politicos Ben Smith. (The headline indicates the speech will come tomorrow.)

title: Bloggingheads: Admiral's Axing
description:
Heather Hurlburt of Democracy Arsenal, left, and Eli Lake of The New York Sun discuss the causes of Admiral William Fallon's early retirement.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Ballet in London: A Home Company on Tour
description: Any dance fan knows how interesting it is to watch a visiting company from abroad; it is perhaps even more interesting to see ones home company on tour. Now that I have lived in New York for 11 months, I no longer know whether New York City Ballet or the Royal Ballet is my home troupe. But on Saturday I had my first and perhaps only chance to watch both companies in a single day.

title: The Womens Tournament
description: The field of 64 for the womens N.C.A.A. tournament was just announced, with Connecticut, Tennessee, Maryland and North Carolina grabbing the No. 1 seeds.

title: Revisiting Melanie McDaniel
description: When Melanie McDaniel was diagnosed with a malignant brain tumor in 2001, no one expected that an experimental new therapy would help her live to see her seventh birthday.

title: The uses of incomprehensibility
description: Ive been looking around, trying to see what the great and the good  or at least those who play such on TV  are starting to say about what should be done. And I was particularly eager to read this piece, by a top guy from Pimco. Pimco is a smart outfit, with a deserved reputation for talking frankly about stuff. So what would Mr. El-Erian say?

title: Siblings Behaving Badly
description: When I was in junior high school, a fight with my sister left me so incensed I plotted how to get revenge. I took her favorite white blouse, put it in the sink and poured red Kool-Aid on it.

title: Obamas Irish Times in Scranton
description: SCRANTON, Pa.  Evie Rafalko McNulty helped found the Society of Irish Women here 10 years ago, giving the women of this northeast Pennsylvania region something to do on St. Pattys Day when the all-male Friendly Sons of St. Patrick would meet for its annual dinner.

title: On the Phone
description: The red phone advertisement may become the political equivalent of MasterCards much-imitated Priceless spots.

title: A United Liberal Front
description: A coalition of liberal groups will coordinate $350 million worth of efforts to mobilize voters and advocate for candidates for the general election, its leaders are expected to announce Tuesday.

title: A Rally Turned Violent In Nepal
description: A demonstration at the United Nations in Katmandu turned violent, as police used tear gas and batons in attempts to disperse the crowd.

title: In a Warmer Yellowstone Park, a Shifting Environmental Balance
description: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo.  The grassy sweep of the Lamar Valley in the northeastern corner of this park is famous for its wildlife, especially its vast herds of elk and bison and the wolves that hunt them.

title: Admitting Sexual Abuse, City Councilman Resigns
description: City Councilman Dennis P. Gallagher resigned from office and pleaded guilty on Monday to two misdemeanors, admitting that he sexually abused a woman in his district office in Middle Village, Queens, last summer while he was intoxicated.

title: Terminal Options for the Irreversibly Ill
description: My Feb. 5 column, A Heartfelt Appeal for a Graceful Exit, prompted a deluge of information and requests for information on how people too sick to reap meaningful pleasure from life might be able to control their death.

title: Teenage Suicides Bewilder an Island, and the Experts
description: NANTUCKET, Mass.  If the three deaths were connected, no one on the island could say exactly how. The first, a 15-year-old, killed himself at his home near the high school in February 2007. The second, a 17-year-old A student and an athlete, committed suicide last October.

title: Paper Is Out, Cellphones Are In
description: First came the kiosk, a strange addition to airport terminals when Continental Airlines began offering it as a check-in option in 1995. It was followed by Web check-in, introduced by Alaska Airlines in 1999.

title: China Terrorizes Tibet
description: It was impossible not to notice that the United States removed China from its list of top 10 human rights violators just as the biggest anti-China protests in 20 years erupted in Tibet. Even when handed that undeserved dispensation, the Beijing government cannot control its authoritarian nature.

title: Inflation Up at the Producer Level
description: Businesses paid more for gasoline, automobiles, and most products last month, reinforcing fears that inflation is rising as the Federal Reserve considers how deep to cut interest rates at its meeting Tuesday afternoon.

title: Next Time Jeremiah Sings, Zedekiah Ought to Listen
description: Leon Botstein, the music director of the American Symphony Orchestra, is a tireless champion of the also-rans in music history. On Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall, he presented the remarkable results of his latest salvage operation when he conducted the orchestra, the Concert Chorale of New York and a fine roster of vocal soloists in the American premiere of The Destruction of Jerusalem, a two-part, two-hour oratorio from 1840 by the German composer Ferdinand Hiller.

title: Investigating the Fallen Crane
description: To the long list of urban nightmares, we can now officially add another: falling cranes. An enormous one collapsed Saturday at an East Side construction site, leaving seven dead, many more injured, and all of New York suddenly feeling a bit less safe. The city should quickly get to the bottom of what went wrong, and it needs to reassure residents that the Buildings Department is properly doing its job.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Sunday about the deadly collapse of a construction crane on the East Side of Manhattan included an erroneous spelling from city officials in some copies for the surname of one victim. He was Wayne Bleidner, not Binder.

title: Thomass Past Echoes in Another Knicks Loss
description: INDIANAPOLIS  It seems hard to imagine now, in the waning weeks of what could be the worst season in Knicks history, but Isiah Thomas was once considered a very capable, even promising, head coach.

title: Breaking the Silence
description: WHEN Dal LaMagna, founder of the Tweezerman company, considered how to leave his wealth to his two children, he thought back to his early 30s, just before he achieved success. At the time, said Mr. LaMagna, 61, I thought if I could get 600 bucks a week, I could retire on that, and I would be very happy.

title: Protecting Children From Their Money
description: THE first savings fund that many parents and grandparents set up for young children is a custodial account at a bank, mutual fund company or brokerage house. This simple, low-cost route designates an adult to oversee money for a minor.

title: Bill Clinton Says Critics Distorted Remarks About Obama
description: Former President Bill Clinton struck back on Monday at critics who have suggested that his remarks in South Carolina in January on behalf of his wifes campaign were racially insensitive.

title: Julia Vadala Taft, Official Who Led Relief Efforts, Is Dead at 65
description: Julia Vadala Taft, a former assistant secretary of state who coordinated the federal governments response to earthquakes, floods, famine and locust infestations in foreign countries in the 1980s, died Saturday at her home in Washington. She was 65.

title: Fed Cuts Key Interest Rate by 3/4 of a Point
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve reduced short-term interest rates for the sixth time in six months on Tuesday, capping an extraordinary series of measures it has taken to stabilize financial markets. The cut was smaller than investors had been expecting, though, and exposed some signs of a split among policy makers.

title: Fighting Against Oppression by Strumming and Plucking
description: Such a giddy word, ukulele. If only Sex! Drugs! & Ukuleles! were worthy of it.

title: End of an Age That Was Ruled by Retaliation
description: Dusty Baker was probably right. Were dinosaurs, he said.

title: Major League Baseball Arrives in China, but Traditions Dont Quite Translate
description: BEIJING  My son didnt know what to do with his peanut shells. Hes 12, the Dodgers were playing the Padres in Major League Baseballs first game in China, and Roy didnt want to sully the new baseball stadium with refuse.

title: In Sisters, Love and an Urge to Wring Her Neck
description: The publishing world was shocked to learn that the gang-life memoir Love and Consequences was a fake. But even more startling was how that came to light.

title: Late to Rise
description: Q. Does oversleeping make one feel more tired than sleeping a normal seven to eight hours?

title: Unknown and Eclectic, American Has Arrived
description: WASHINGTON  On Saturday night, a day after helping secure American Universitys first N.C.A.A. tournament bid in the programs 41 years in Division I, Derrick Mercer, the Eagles point guard, woke with a start.

title: Paterson Discusses Past Extramarital Affairs
description: ALBANY  The day after he was sworn in to replace a governor who left office in disgrace because of a prostitution scandal, Gov. David A. Paterson admitted that he had had relationships with women other than his wife, including one who is on the state payroll.

title: Tapping a Flow of Cash From the Credit Crisis
description: THE United States may have already entered a recession set off by the upheaval in the subprime mortgage market and sharp declines in house prices nationwide. For the rich, however, the mortgage crisis and housing slump have created opportunities to leverage their real estate holdings for other investments.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Big City column on Friday, about the clash between fantasy and reality in the prostitution scandal that ensnared Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York, referred incorrectly in some editions to Kristen, the prostitute he is said to have met in a Washington hotel last month. She was not in fact a client of Emperors Club V.I.P. (It was Mr. Spitzer who was a client, according to a federal affidavit.)

title: Having Fun, Fun, Fun as a Freshman at U.C.L.A.
description: LOS ANGELES  For years, Kevin Love did not say that he liked the Beach Boys. Growing up in Lake Oswego, Ore., a damp and leafy Portland suburb, it simply was not cool. The Beach Boys were so ... 40 years ago. They were so ... California.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on March 1 about Ben Chapman, an actor who had the title role in the 1954 film Creature From the Black Lagoon, misstated the name of the California town where a surviving stepdaughter, Elyse Maree Raljevich, lives. It is Coto de Caza, not Coto De Gaza.

title: Bombing Kills 43 in Shiite Holy City in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  A bombing on Monday evening killed 43 people near the Imam Hussein shrine in the Shiite holy city of Karbala, penetrating one of the most secure perimeters in Iraq. Iraqi police officers at the scene and several witnesses said it had been carried out by a female suicide bomber, but the police chief later said the bomb had been hidden.

title: Home Sweet Investment
description: Fairfax, Va.

title: A Novelist Returns
description: Wally Lamb, the novelist twice chosen by Oprah Winfrey for her book club, is scheduled to publish his first novel in 10 years this November. The Hour I First Believed is Mr. Lambs third novel, and like his second, I Know This Much Is True, its a long one: 800 pages. The new novel, which will be published by Harper, an imprint of HarperCollins, begins with a married couple moving to Littleton, Colo., in 1999 to take jobs at Columbine High School, where the wife ends up cowering in the library the day two students go on a shooting rampage. In the aftermath the couple moves to the husbands family farm in Connecticut. She tries to recover, while the husband stumbles on a series of family secrets. Mr. Lambs first novel, Shes Come Undone, was originally published in 1992 by Pocket Books; 4.5 million copies are now in print. I Know This Much Is True, published by Regan Books in 1998, has 2.8 million copies in print. Harper has announced a first print run of 500,000 copies for the new novel.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Saturday about Michael Levy, the lawyer representing a potential witness in the spying scandal involving the New England Patriots, misstated the title for Senator Arlen Specter, the Pennsylvania Republican who has been critical of the N.F.L. in the matter. He is the Senate Judiciary Committees ranking member  not its chairman, a position held by Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont.

title: Iran Reformists Question Conservative Gains
description: TEHRAN  Conservative politicians close to President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad appeared to tighten their grip on power in Iran as the government on Monday announced final results of the first round of parliamentary elections.

title: Celebrating the Push-Up (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Iraq War: 5 Years and Counting
description: To the Editor:

title: Online Games by the Hundreds, With Tie-Ins
description: For some children, watching Dora the Explorer on television is becoming pass. Now, they want to be Dora.

title: East and West Part Ways in Test of Facial Expressions
description: How do you know how someone is feeling? For people in Western societies, it is usually easy: look at the persons face.

title: Yankees and Red Sox Reserve Some Fanfare
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The game was televised in New York and Boston, and a marching band paraded around the field before the first pitch. But as spring training hype goes, the Yankees and the Red Sox have seen much more. Their only meeting in March seemed incidental to the coming trips for both teams.

title: For a Day, at Least, an Era of Good Feeling, Even Unlikely Hugs
description: ALBANY  The doleful expressions of disbelief had faded. And the utterances of shock and sorrow were nowhere to be heard.

title: Bush Sends Putin Missile Defense Offer
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Monday endorsed portions of a private proposal from President Bush that could lead to a new strategic framework between their nations, including progress on troubling issues like missile defense, nuclear arms control and nonproliferation.

title: Troubled Outlook for New York City Economy Turns a Lot Grimmer
description: The outlook for New York Citys economy and its main engine, the financial services industry, had already taken a bleak turn before the sudden failure of Bear Stearns, the fifth-largest firm on Wall Street.

title: Bush Backs Feds Actions, but Critics Quickly Find Fault
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush on Monday welcomed the Federal Reserves sweeping intervention in the nations financial markets as his administration faced accusations that it had supported the bailout of a prestigious investment bank while doing little to address the hardships of Americans facing foreclosures on their homes.

title: New Jersey Court Approves Use of New Drunken Driving Test
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court on Monday approved the use of the states new drunken driving test  a decision that could clear a logjam of more than 10,000 alcohol-related traffic cases.

title: Metropolitan Laurus, Who Healed Rift in Russian Orthodox Church, Is Dead at 80
description: Metropolitan Laurus, who led the overseas branch of the Russian Orthodox Church to a historic rapprochement with the Moscow mother church, from which it split after the Communist revolution in 1917, died Sunday at a monastery in Jordanville, N.Y. He was 80.

title: Youve Made Your Fortune. Now Jump in the Sandbox.
description: WHAT is the fun of having a seven-figure portfolio if you cant act like a millionaire?

title: Rallying the House of Morgan
description: High in a Park Avenue skyscraper, within a maze of soft rugs and wood-paneled walls, James Dimon sits just footsteps from the mahogany roll-top desk of J. Pierpont Morgan, the feared lord of the House of Morgan and the most powerful financier of his time.

title: Saving Wall St. (for Now)
description: The whispers began on Wednesday, and by Sunday it was all over.

title: As Dollar Keeps Falling, Talk of a Move by Japan
description: TOKYO  The dollar, which tumbled to an almost 13-year low against the yen on Monday, may soon find a protector here  the Japanese finance ministry.

title: Patients and Medical Tests (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A headline and an article in the Connecticut section on Sunday about Toquam Magnet, a K-5 school in Stamford, referred incorrectly to its status. A committee of the Stamford School District board is to vote on Wednesday night on whether to close the school, and the full board will take up the matter later; the board has not already closed the school.

title: A Dark and Stormy Night and a Crucible of Emotions
description: If a single image had to stand in for the program presented by the Kazuko Hirabayashi Dance Theater at the Merce Cunningham Studio on Sunday night, it would be a dark, swirling maelstrom. Storms abounded, filling the stage with big emotions and, in the closing Bereft, with churning ranks of dancers.

title: When a Sticky Gecko Starts to Slip, Its Tail Comes to the Rescue
description: Apart from its ability to hawk car insurance, the gecko has gained renown for its skills as a climber. It can ascend vertical walls and even walk across ceilings, courtesy of its sticky feet.

title: Paterson Takes an Oath of Leadership, Then a Turn in the Spotlight
description: For the first 14 minutes, it was almost as if Henny Youngman were governor.

title: Hard Feelings Emerge as Mets Face Lo Duca
description: VIERA, Fla.  Paul Lo Duca and Lastings Milledge, two players no longer with the Mets, sat in the opposing clubhouse Monday and did their best not to say anything controversial about the fact that they now play for the Washington Nationals. Milledge succeeded more than Lo Duca did.

title: Dow Surges 420 Points on Fed Rate Cut and Earnings
description: Casting aside any hesitation about an aggressive interest rate cut, investors sent stocks soaring to their highest gains in five years on Tuesday as shares of financial firms surged in the hopes that the Federal Reserve has finally taken hold of the credit crisis. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 420 points.

title: Passing Eighth Grade Gets a Little Harder
description: The Bloomberg administration won approval for a new eighth-grade promotion policy last night at a meeting repeatedly interrupted by the chanting and heckling of parents who contend that the policy amounts to blaming students for the failings of the citys middle schools.

title: Ford Displays a Wreck to Score Safety Points
description: DETROIT  Even car novices should have no trouble identifying the Ford Taurus at this weeks New York International Auto Show. Its the one with a crumpled hood and half of the front bumper missing.

title: Letting His Lapel Spread the Word About His Cause
description: IM not a famous person, but my lapel pin makes me feel like one.

title: In Our Schools: Two Educators Groups Weigh In
description: To the Editor:

title: Justices Take Up On-Air Vulgarity Again
description: WASHINGTON  The issue of vulgar speech on the nations regulated airwaves, a flash point for decades, reached the Supreme Court again on Monday.

title: Detroit Council Asks Mayor to Resign
description: DETROIT  The City Council on Tuesday asked Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick to resign in light of evidence that he lied under oath and plotted to cover up an extramarital affair with his former chief of staff.

title: The Claim: Cold Water Boils More Quickly Than Hot Water
description: THE FACTS

title: At Lehman, Allaying Fears About Being the Next to Fall
description: Shocked by the rapid demise of Bear Stearns and its fire sale to JPMorgan Chase, investors sold off the stock of Lehman Brothers and several other financial firms Monday.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the coming presidential election in Taiwan misattributed a quotation about a referendum that will ask Taiwanese to choose the name under which the country will apply for membership in the United Nations. It was Hsiao Bi-khim, a former lawmaker and spokeswoman for Frank Hsieh, one of the candidates, who said, We see China as a giant with its hands around our neck, trying to suffocate us, trying to shut off our space on the international stage. It was not Mr. Hsieh himself who made the comment.

title: Bedbugs at Fox News
description: While grappling with MSNBC and CNN for viewers, Fox News has also been battling a smaller, more insidious enemy closer to home: bed bugs in its Midtown Manhattan newsroom. In an interview on Monday, Warren Vandeveer, senior vice president for operations and engineering at Fox News, said the cable channel had realized it had a problem a few weeks ago, when an employee caught a bug and showed it to us. An exterminator determined that the incursion was limited to a very small area in the newsroom. But the source of the bugs was not determined until the exterminator inspected the homes of about 20 employees. Mr. Vandeveer said the exterminator later described one employees home as having the worst infestation he had seen in 25 years in the business. After making large bags available for employees to stash their belongings, and replacing a number of fabric-covered desk chairs, Mr. Vandeveer said that the treatments had ended about a week ago, and that the problem had been contained. Its totally eradicated, he said.

title: Patterns: Bacterium May Reduce Kidney Stone Risk
description: A common intestinal bacterium is associated with a significant reduction in the risk for kidney stones, a new study has found.

title: Melting Pace of Glaciers Is Accelerating, Report Says
description: Most of the worlds mountain glaciers, many of which feed major rivers and water supplies, are shrinking at an accelerating pace as the climate warms, according to a new report.

title: Swearing-In Resonates at a School for the Blind
description: They sat on little wooden chairs at the front of the classroom, lined up in tidy rows close enough to the television to hear the new governor use grown-up words like budget and democracy.

title: Citi Names New Chief of Investment Banking
description: Shaking up its leadership for the third time in six months, Citigroup has named John Havens as the new head of its investment banking and alternative investments group.

title: As Accounts Pile Up, Less Becomes More
description: THE unwieldy task of looking after many financial accounts, the cost of paying for their upkeep and the risk of losing track of money in the process can lead to diminishing returns. In fact, investors who cannot tally their accounts on two hands might want to consolidate, financial advisers say.

title: Progress Slows in Detection of New TB Cases
description: WASHINGTON  Progress in detecting new cases of tuberculosis is slowing, threatening to increase the risks of transmitting drug-resistant strains, the World Health Organization said Monday.

title: Guilty Plea in Body Parts Case
description: A former dentist from New Jersey pleaded guilty on Tuesday to running a corrupt $4.6 million enterprise to harvest human tissue from funeral homes and to sell it for use in transplants and medical research.

title: The Bailout Artists
description: Whats the most underdiscussed issue of this presidential campaign?

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption in some editions on Saturday with a sports article about Georgetowns 72-55 victory over West Virginia in the Big East mens basketball tournament misidentified a Hoyas player who was shown defending Joe Alexander of the Mountaineers. It was DaJuan Summers, not his teammate Chris Wright.

title: Failure of Strap Is Suspected in Crane Collapse
description: A prime suspect in Saturdays East Side crane collapse  a spectacular disaster across two Manhattan blocks that has now claimed seven lives and is expected to cost untold millions  is a $50 piece of nylon webbing that investigators suspect may have broken while hoisting a six-ton piece of steel.

title: An East Asian Library
description: The 68,000-square-foot C. V. Starr East Asian Library at the University of California, Berkeley, opened to the public on Monday. The library, designed by the New York-based architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien, holds more than 900,000 volumes, as well as manuscripts, bronze objects and the most comprehensive collection of historic Japanese maps outside of Japan. The building also incorporates the Center for Chinese Studies Library, the largest academic repository in the United States of materials on the Peoples Republic of China.

title: New York Official Resigns Post Amid Shift in Leadership
description: The changing of the guard at the states troubled economic development agency was already under way when Gov. David A. Paterson took the oath of office on Monday.

title: Corporate Sponsorship for a Wind Farm
description: Companies have long been willing to pay a lot of money to attach their names to prominent places. The future home of the New York Mets in Queens will be called Citi Field, after Citigroup. The Academy Awards ceremony takes place at the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles.

title: Sundance in Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music will open its third annual Sundance Institute series on May 29 with the documentary American Teen. Written and directed by Nanette Burstein (The Kid Stays in the Picture), American Teen, which won the Sundance Documentary Directing prize, tracks the lives of four Indiana high school students over one school year. The Sundance Institute series of breakout films from this years festival will run through June 8. The full schedule will be announced on April 15.

title: Irish Dancers in the Bronx
description: To the Editor:

title: Manufacturing Activity Shows Declines
description: The outlook for the nations manufacturers has gone from bad to worse.

title: Mounds of Sand Stressed Minnesota Bridge, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Interstate 35W bridge over the Mississippi in Minneapolis collapsed last August after construction workers had put 99 tons of sand on the roadway directly over two of the bridges weakest points, according to a National Transportation Safety Board report.

title: ABC Takes Sunday Night
description: ABC had the most viewers on Sunday night, thanks to new installments of Extreme Makeover: Home Edition and Oprahs Big Give, which delivered 12 million and 9.7 million viewers at 8 and 9, respectively, Nielsen estimated. ABCs Here Come the Newlyweds at 10 (7 million) led its time slot among adults 18 to 49, but trailed NBCs Law & Order: Special Victims Unit rerun (7.7 million) over all. CBSs Dexter was third in the hour (6.4 million). CBS and NBC finished in a virtual tie for second place that night. CBSs 60 Minutes drew the networks largest audience, with 11.1 million at 7. Fox placed fourth in total viewers, but second in the 18-to-49 set.

title: Siemens Cuts Earnings Outlook Sharply
description: FRANKFURT  The German engineering giant Siemens, which has been trying to put a huge corruption scandal behind it, gave investors another rude shock Monday, disclosing that delays and canceled orders would cut its quarterly earnings by 900 million euros, or $1.4 billion.

title: For Scientists, a Beer Test Shows Results as a Litmus Test
description: Ever since there have been scientists, there have been those who are wildly successful, publishing one well-received paper after another, and those who are not. And since nearly the same time, there have been scholars arguing over what makes the difference.

title: Suicide Attack on NATO Convoy in Afghanistan Kills 4
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide car bomb struck a NATO convoy in volatile Helmand Province on Monday, killing two Danish soldiers, a Czech soldier, one interpreter and three civilians, provincial officials said.

title: A Guidance Counselors Second (Pained) Adolescence
description: The past few months have offered little reason to maintain a contrarians faith in network comedy. I was just about to bring up Cavemen, but I can hear you doing it first.

title: Jurors Inquire About Charges in Death of Girl
description: Jurors deliberated for a third day on Monday without reaching a verdict in the trial of Cesar Rodriguez, who is accused of fatally beating his 7-year-old stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown.

title: A Cross-Country Flight That Can Cure a Bad Mood
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Russian Scientists Honored for Exploration of Arctic Seabed
description: Move over, polar bears. The standard view of Arctic life is changing after a team led by Russian scientists plunged through pack ice around the North Pole last August and descended more than two miles through pitch darkness to the ocean bottom. They accomplished the historic first in twin submersibles.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,981 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

title: Plunge Averted, Markets Look Ahead Uneasily
description: With the Dow Jones industrial average up slightly more than 21 points by the end of trading Monday on the New York Stock Exchange, it may have looked like a calm day on Wall Street.

title: Writer Is to Leave India
description: Taslima Nasreen, right, the exiled Bangladeshi writer, said she would leave India after living in hiding there for nearly four months, because of failing health, Reuters reported. Violent protests by Muslim groups in November forced Indian authorities to move the writer from her home in Calcutta to an undisclosed safe house in New Delhi, where no visitors were allowed. I have not been able to see a good cardiologist for the last few months, and I have a serious heart problem, Ms. Nasreen, 45, said. She fled Bangladesh in 1994 when a court ruled that she had deliberately and maliciously hurt Muslim religious feelings with her Bengali-language novel Lajja (Shame), in which she argued that the countrys Hindu minority was poorly treated. Ms. Nasreen, who had made her home in Calcutta since 2004, said she would move to France or Germany.

title: Tibetans in India Enraged by Details of Crackdown
description: DHARAMSALA, India  As Tibet erupted in protests against Chinese rule, this small, normally placid town in the foothills of the Himalayas became a nerve center and soapbox for Tibetan exiles and a vital channel through which news from Tibet seeped out into the world.

title: China Tries to Thwart News Reports From Tibet
description: BEIJING   The Chinese government is restricting foreign journalists from entering Tibet and neighboring areas, and blocking some news, video and Internet reports about the protests there from appearing inside China, according to journalists working here.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about the appointment of a new leader of the Smithsonian Institution, G. Wayne Clough, misstated the timing of the retirement of the former director of the Smithsonians National Museum of the American Indian in recounting issues of oversight and accountability with which the institution has been wrestling. While the former director, W. Richard West Jr., remained on the Smithsonians payroll until the end of last year, his retirement in December preceded a Washington Post report about his spending on travel; he did not retire after the report was published.

title: A False Claim of Valor and a Cry of Free Speech
description: When Xavier Alvarez was asked to say a few words about himself at a meeting of a California water board last summer, he decided on these: Im a retired marine of 25 years. I retired in the year 2001. Back in 1987, I was awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor. I got wounded many times by the same guy. Im still around.

title: Memo Pad
description: HIGHER FARES, AGAIN Another sweeping fare increase by major domestic airlines seemed to be holding on Monday even after United Airlines and Continental Airlines partly rolled back some of their increases over the weekend, said Rick Seaney, the chief executive officer of FareCompare.com. The rise in prices, the fourth this year, was initiated late last week by United Airlines, which raised fares $50 on round-trip routes of over 1,500 miles each way. Uniteds competitors among the six so-called legacy carriers followed with similar increases over the weekend. Mr. Seaney said that the scattered rollbacks of the increases on some routes appeared to be responses to normal competitive pressure rather than a signal of a broad retreat from the increases.

title: China: Profit Down at Aluminum Producer
description: The Aluminum Corporation of China, the nations biggest producer of aluminum, posted a 25 percent fall in second-half profit after prices declined and raw material costs increased. Net income dropped to 3.8 billion yuan in the six months ended Dec. 31, from a revised 5.1 billion yuan a year earlier, the company said. Aluminum prices in China dropped 7.7 percent in the second half from a year earlier after producers increased supplies too quickly. The company said higher prices of raw materials, power and transport would put more pressure on costs this year.

title: Queenfish: A Cold War Tale
description: Atop the globe, the icy surface of the Arctic Ocean has remained relatively peaceful. But its depths have boiled with intrigue, no more so than in the cold war.

title: They May Not Use Gasoline, but They Sure Burn Through Water
description: One way to reduce the worlds dependence on oil is to produce more cars that get their power from the electrical grid rather than the gas pump. In the United States, replacing a large percentage of the roughly 235 million cars, light trucks and sport utility vehicles with all-electric vehicles and plug-in hybrids (which have a supplemental gasoline engine) would make a big dent in gasoline consumption, currently about 380 million gallons a day.

title: Harvard Law, Hoping Students Will Consider Public Service, Offers Tuition Break
description: Concerned by the low numbers of law students choosing careers in public service, Harvard Law School plans to waive tuition for third-year students who pledge to spend five years working either for nonprofit organizations or the government.

title: Rescue Tests the Feds Credibility
description: WASHINGTON  Far more than at any time before, the Federal Reserve is putting its vast resources and its reputation on the line to rescue Wall Streets biggest institutions from their far-reaching mistakes.

title: Pumping Iron on Two Sides of Haitis Class Divide
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  The grunts are no different. The clang of the weights sounds pretty much the same as well. And sweat drips off bodies at both the high-end Golds Gym in Port-au-Princes priciest suburb and at the far more humble open-air workout joint farther down the hill, known by regulars as the Temple of Pain.

title: Report Finds Flaws in Terrorist Watch List
description: WASHINGTON  The F.B.I. and other federal law enforcement agencies have sometimes provided outdated and inaccurate information to the governments main watch list for terrorism suspects, according to an internal Justice Department report released Monday.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the impasse over the disputed Democratic primaries in Michigan and Florida rendered incorrectly a word in a quotation from Stacie Paxton, a spokeswoman for the Democratic National Committee, whose chairman is Howard Dean. Ms. Paxton said, Its never productive to negotiate through the press, but make no mistake, Howard Dean will continue to lead the effort to find a workable solution thats fair and consistent with the rules. She did not say, Its never productive to negotiate through the process.

title: Why a Genetic Blood Disorder Seems to Protect Against Malaria
description: Researchers believe they have figured out why a genetic blood disorder found in the tropics protects against death from malaria.

title: Debate Over Little People Intensifies After Recent Island Discovery
description: The dispute over the little people of Flores continues, unabated.

title: The Family Office, Granting Every Wish
description: WHEN Charles D. Haines was founded 22 years ago in Birmingham, Ala., its sole job was to provide financial advice to the moderately wealthy  clients with the equivalent of $1.5 million in assets in todays dollars.

title: No Worries! Bush Has a Check and a Few Jokes
description: To the Editor:

title: Cond Nast Names 2 for European Ventures
description: Both the editor and the publisher who ran Interview magazine for almost two decades will join Cond Nast to help guide one of its fastest-growing businesses, the European editions of Vanity Fair, the company said Monday.

title: One Gene Closer to Understanding Pancreatic Cancer
description: Dr. Terri Brentnall, 51, at the University of Washington, has identified a gene that may be one cause of an inherited form of pancreatic cancer. An edited version of a three-hour conversation follows.

title: Pilots Talks Apparently Fail in a Northwest-Delta Hookup
description: Pilots at Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines appear to have given up efforts to combine their seniority lists, which was considered essential to the two carriers hopes for a merger without crippling rancor.

title: Animated Repatriation: Disney Art Returns
description: A Japanese university plans to return about 250 pieces of original animation art to the Walt Disney Company that were mislaid in storage after traveling to Japan nearly five decades ago.

title: Earths Ineluctable Destiny (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A headline and an article in the Connecticut section on Sunday about Toquam Magnet, a K-5 school in Stamford, referred incorrectly to its status. A committee of the Stamford School District board is to vote on Wednesday night on whether to close the school, and the full board will take up the matter later; the board has not already closed the school. (Go to Article)

title: Umbrella Coverage for Preventing Your Ruin
The Secret of DEET? It Masks Odors That Usually Attract Bugs
description: DEET is the most widely used insect repellent in the world, and for good reason  just a dab or two of a DEET-laden liquid on exposed skin keeps mosquitoes and other bugs away.

title: Aftershocks of a Collapse, With a Bank at the Epicenter
description: The shouts, hoarse and high-pitched, rang out in the cavernous boardroom late Sunday at Bear Stearnss headquarters on Madison Avenue. Alan D. Schwartz, the chief executive of Bear Stearns, was briefing top executives on the deal he had just struck under duress with JPMorgan Chase and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York: their stock in Bear was now worth $2 a share.

title: As Three More Victims Are Pulled From the Rubble, Silence and a Grim Salute
description: By 2:40 p.m. on Monday, the search was over. Three victims who had been missing since Saturdays deadly crane collapse on the East Side had been found, bringing the death toll to seven.

title: Jittery Market Calls for a Steady Hand
description: EVER since the credit crisis began last summer, the markets have been so choppy that even the most seasoned investors are complaining of motion sickness. The rest of us, looking to secure our retirement nest eggs and have enough left for our children and favorite causes, are nervous.

title: Guilty Verdict in Nixzmary Brown Case
description: A jury in Brooklyn acquitted Cesar Rodriguez, the stepfather of 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown, of second-degree murder Tuesday, but convicted him of a lesser charge, first-degree manslaughter, for fatally beating her as punishment for stealing a snack and jamming his computer printer with toys.

title: Disparities: Men Likelier to Be Told to Replace a Knee
description: Women are less likely than men to get a recommendation for knee replacement, a Canadian study reports, even when they have the same symptoms.

title: In Most Species, Faithfulness Is a Fantasy
description: You can accuse the disgraced ex-governor Eliot Spitzer of many things in his decision to flout the law by soliciting the services of a pricey prostitute: hypocrisy, egomania, sophomoric impulsiveness and self-indulgence, delusional ineptitude and boneheadedness. But one trait decidedly not on display in Mr. Spitzers splashy act of whole-life catabolism was originality.

title: Criticizing Pastor, Obama Assesses Race in America
description: PHILADELPHIA  Senator Barack Obama renewed his objection to the controversial statements delivered by the longtime pastor of his Chicago church, but declared in a speech here Tuesday that it was time for America to move beyond some of our old racial wounds.

title: Jumping for the Cause Without Being Asked
description: CONGRATULATIONS. Youve just been named senior vice president, youve gotten a big raise, your net worth now tops $2 million, and youre barely pushing 50.

title: Arthur C. Clarke, Premier Science Fiction Writer, Dies at 90
description: Arthur C. Clarke, a writer whose seamless blend of scientific expertise and poetic imagination helped usher in the space age, died early Wednesday in Colombo, Sri Lanka, where he had lived since 1956. He was 90.

title: Lottery Numbers | March 17, 2008
description: March 17, 2008

title: France: Ex-President Selling One of His Chateaus
description: Former President Valry Giscard dEstaing is selling the 23-room, 15th-century La Varvasse chateau he inherited in Chanonat, in the Auvergne region, according to real estate dealers. The former president, 82, rarely stays at the chateau, which his father bought in 1930. No price was given. In 2005, Mr. Giscard dEstaing bought Chteau dEstaing, in Aveyron, and spends more time there.

title: Odyssey to a Far-Off Galaxy to Save the Human Race
description: Fight Girl Battle World, the latest lark by the proudly lowbrow Vampire Cowboys Theater Company, tells a familiar story about a heroic insurgent who, with the help of a comic, a somewhat fey robot and a Zen-like mentor, saves the human race. It takes place, needless to say, in a galaxy far, far away.

title: Court Rebuffs Georgian on Death Row
description: ATLANTA  A narrowly divided Georgia Supreme Court declined Monday to order a new trial for a man sentenced to death in the 1989 murder of an off-duty Savannah police officer, despite recantations by seven of nine witnesses who originally testified against him.

title: U.S. Adapts Cold-War Idea to Fight Terrorists
description: WASHINGTON  In the days immediately after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, members of President Bushs war cabinet declared that it would be impossible to deter the most fervent extremists from carrying out even more deadly terrorist missions with biological, chemical or nuclear weapons.

title: Multiplying the Dollars Through Matching Gifts
description: JUST as buying a home with a mortgage and investing money every month can grow an acorn into a mighty oak of wealth, charitable donations can also be leveraged. With a little knowledge and persistence a donated dollar can instantly become two, even six.

title: Times Company Agrees to 2 Outsiders on Its Board
description: The New York Times Company has struck a deal with a pair of hedge funds that want to shake up the company, giving the funds two seats on the board in order to avoid a proxy fight, the two sides announced Monday.

title: Anniversary Highlights Iraq Wars Role in Campaign
description: WASHINGTON  This weeks fifth anniversary of the invasion of Iraq provoked an intense exchange over the war Monday among the three presidential candidates, illustrating the deep divisions over how to proceed there even as the violence has ebbed. The day left little doubt that the issue would be a major area of difference between the two parties this fall.

title: A Daring Treatment, a Little Girls Survival
description: In the pages of a medical journal, Melanie Joy McDaniel is a study subject, listed by her patient number and tumor type. In real life shes a little girl whose story is a reminder that medical research can change lives and that the pioneers include patients, some of whom are babies.

title: Ships Pilot Is Charged in Oil Spill in California
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The pilot of a Chinese cargo ship that struck the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge and spilled thousands of gallons of oil into the bay in November was charged Monday with criminal violations of federal environmental laws.

title: China Premier Blames Dalai Lama for Appalling Violence in Tibet
description: BEIJING  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China on Tuesday blamed supporters of the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, for planning and inciting what he described as an appalling violence and destruction in Tibet last week.

title: Global Strategy or Grand Illusion?
description: American troops bogged down in Iraq, a resurgent Taliban in Afghanistan, an overstretched military and National Guard, simmering tensions with Iran and North Korea, and growing hostility toward the United States around the world: these are just some of the consequences of Bush administration foreign policy over the last seven years. To the Slate columnist Fred Kaplan, these woes all stem from two grand misconceptions held by the White House and its top advisers: that the world fundamentally changed after 9/11, when in fact the way the world works  the nature of power, warfare and politics among nations  remained essentially the same; and that in a post-cold-war era, the United States had the power to set the terms of the new world order and could therefore act unilaterally, without entangling alliances and without compromising with competing concepts or interests.

title: High Court Considers Right to Bear Arms
description: WASHINGTON  A majority of the Supreme Court appeared ready on Tuesday to embrace, for the first time in the countrys history, an interpretation of the Second Amendment that protects the right to own a gun for personal use.

title: Barrage of Bullets Into Bells Car Is Outlined
description: In photographs, they are only thin, colorful tubes, as bright and harmless-looking as something from a childs box of toys.

title: Prevention: At Middle Age, Add Alcohol to the Diet?
description: Several recent studies have found that moderate drinking is associated with a lower risk for cardiovascular disease. Now a new study, published in the March issue of The American Journal of Medicine, suggests that teetotalers who begin having a drink or two a day in middle age may also get significant benefit.

title: Who Will Come to the Rescue?
description: The more the Federal Reserve does to avert financial contagion, the clearer it becomes that the Fed alone cannot solve the problems in the financial system. To many Americans, its now obvious that taxpayers will have to step in. Less obvious is that if the United States government doesnt stabilize the markets, foreign governments increasingly will, in exchange for an ever larger stake in the American financial system.

title: M.L.S.s Future Will Include More Foreign Players
description: As Major League Soccer expands to 15 teams next year (Seattle), then to 16 teams in 2010 (Philadelphia), and with more expansion expected, the league plans to search for more foreign players to fill out its rosters.

title: Music in Review
description: SZYMANOWSKI QUARTET

title: Rutgers May Stand Between UConn and Tennessee
description: Having already heated up off the court, the rivalry between Connecticut and Tennessee in womens basketball took a potential step toward renewal on the court Monday night when each team was awarded a No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament pairings.

title: New DVDs: Georges Mlis
description: GEORGES MLIS: FIRST WIZARD OF CINEMA

title: New Trial Is Ordered for Qwest Ex-Chief
description: DENVER  A federal appeals court panel reversed the insider-trading conviction of Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications International, on Monday and ordered that Mr. Nacchio receive a new trial in front of a different judge.

title: Officer Shot in Struggle With Knife-Wielding Man
description: CAMDEN, N.J.  In an unusual confrontation on Monday that the police said they were still trying to sort out, a female officer was repeatedly shot while trying to subdue a naked man with a knife who was then killed by a second officer.

title: Research Center to Study Health-Race Link
description: WASHINGTON  Drugs to treat hypertension and diabetes are substantially less effective in blacks than they are in whites, one of the many mysteries involving the interaction between health and race that the National Institutes of Health hopes to unravel at a new research center.

title: When a Safety Net Can Lead to Risky Behavior
description: Critics of the Federal Reserves role in the sale of Bear Stearns have raised the specter of moral hazard. What is moral hazard?

title: At Stratford Last Man Standing Runs Show
description: STRATFORD, Ontario  It seemed like just another busy Tuesday at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival.

title: Need Money for a Business? Start at the Bank.
description: What is most refreshing about the article on the Small Business Administrations Web site called The Benefits of Making Your Banker Your Friend is that it is written from a real world perspective.

title: New Jersey to Consider Health Plan to Cover All
description: TRENTON  Thrusting New Jersey again into the vanguard of social change, a bipartisan group of legislators unveiled a proposal on Monday that would require all residents to have health care coverage within three years.

title: Breaking Up Is Hard to Do
description: AS a family trust moves into its second and third generations, it is almost inevitable that someone will be unhappy with a trustee.

title: Upstairs, Downstairs and Above the Garage
description: YOUVE made a pile of money and made it even bigger through canny investments. You have a private banker and a crack accountant. Youve given to the right charities, and you belong to the right civic committees.

title: Once a Defender of Indian Point Plant, the State Pushes to Close It
description: There was a time when the owner of a nuclear reactor at Indian Point labored mightily against a cadre of passionate opponents and hostile county officials who wanted the plant to be shut down. But through extraordinary means, the owner won federal approvals that allowed it to keep operating.

title: Patersons Acknowledge Extramarital Affairs
description: Gov. David A. Paterson and his wife, Michelle, have both had extramarital affairs in the past, the couple said in an interview with The Daily News after he was sworn in on Monday.

title: The Lords of Higher Learning
description: It will come as no surprise to any parent who has been on a college tour of late that the gap has never been greater between the elite schools with their Olympian sports facilities, star professors and Michelin-class cuisine and the universities struggling to pay the heating bill.

title: The Lady Doth Protest, but Its Harder
description: Her first protest march? That would have been in the 1950s, a ban the bomb demonstration, Leslie Cagan said. Her parents took her. I was quite little, said Ms. Cagan, now 60.

title: Rich Memories in the Last Days at Dodgertown
description: VERO BEACH, Fla.  On a side field, far from the Holman Stadium set being primped for perhaps its curtain-closing act, two groundskeepers were working and worrying.

title: Whole Class of Debt in Canada Is Bankrupt
description: OTTAWA  A $32 billion segment of Canadas debt market was placed under bankruptcy protection on Monday after a committee established to restructure the troubled debt missed a settlement deadline.

title: Near the Golden Gate, Seeking Broader Access to Parks
description: SAUSALITO, Calif.  While other visitors hiking the majestic bluffs known as the Marin Headlands stare out toward mesmerizing views of the Golden Gate Bridge and the Pacific Ocean, Ann Sieck gazes at the ground, puzzling over a rock jutting up from the path.

title: Anthony Minghella, Director, Dies at 54
description: Anthony Minghella, a British filmmaker who won an Academy Award for his direction of The English Patient, died Tuesday morning in London.

title: Whats in a Name? (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: McCartney-Mills Divorce Settlement
description: A British judge awarded Heather Mills, right, a total of 24.3 million, about $48.9 million, in her divorce settlement with Paul McCartney. In a summary of his decision, the judge in the case, Hugh Bennett, said that Mr. McCartney would pay Ms. Mills a lump sum of 16.5 million (about $33.2 million); this would be in addition to Ms. Millss current assets of 7.8 million (about $15.7 million). Mr. McCartney, 65, must also provide the equivalent of about $70,000 a year for the couples 4-year-old daughter, Beatrice, and pay her school and nanny fees. The judge said that Mr. McCartney had about 400 million in assets, and that Ms. Mills, 40, had originally asked for almost 125 million. They married in 2002 and separated four years later. After the decision Mr. McCartney left the court, declining comment; Ms. Mills spoke at length to waiting reporters. Among other things, she accused Mr. McCartney of wanting their daughter to fly economy, while he flew first class. The judge said he planned to make his entire ruling public; Ms. Mills said she would contest that.

title: French Bank in Scandal Overhauls Top Ranks
description: PARIS  Socit Gnrale, the French bank hobbled by a trading loss of more than $7 billion, announced Monday that it was reorganizing its senior management team.

title: The Court Considers Gun Control
description: Today the Supreme Court will hear arguments in a politically charged challenge to the District of Columbias gun control laws. The case poses a vital question: can cities impose reasonable controls on guns to protect their citizens? The court should rule that they can.

title: Florida Democrats Wont Vote Again, Official Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Florida Democratic Party chairwoman on Monday officially buried the possibility of redoing the states disputed January presidential primary, saying there was no practical or affordable way to conduct a new election.

title: Multitasking Montagues and Capulets in Fair Verona
description: Its hard to give an illuminating performance in a play as familiar as Romeo and Juliet, but Emily Young does it in the production now being staged at the Kirk Theater by Theater Breaking Through Barriers. Her marvelous Juliet is fresh and vibrant throughout, and especially so in that most familiar of scenes, the one with the balcony.

title: Bill Would Bar Linking Class Test Scores to Tenure
description: While the state was consumed by the downfall of Eliot Spitzer last week, the Assembly passed a bill that would pre-emptively bar New York City and other school districts from linking teacher tenure to students test scores.

title: On Defensive, Obama Plans Talk on Race
description: Faced with what his advisers acknowledged was a major test to his candidacy, Senator Barack Obama sought on Monday to contain the damage from incendiary comments made by his pastor and prepared to address the issue of race more directly than at any other moment of his presidential campaign.

title: An Effort to Bridge a Divide
description: Since he was very young, Senator Barack Obama has been something of a mediator of racial concerns, shuttling between black and white worlds and trying to translate the concerns of one to the other.

title: New Governor for New York, Pledging Unity
description: ALBANY  Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson ascended to New Yorks highest office on Monday, pledging civility and unity in government to an enthusiastic and palpably relieved gathering of state lawmakers and officials.

title: Kosovar Serbs Clash With the Police
description: BRUSSELS  Serbs in the northern Kosovo city of Mitrovica fired weapons and threw grenades at international peacekeepers on Monday, wounding dozens of police officers and NATO troops. The clash was the worst violence since Kosovo declared independence from Serbia on Feb. 17.

title: Astronauts Complete Robot
description: Astronauts from the shuttle Endeavour completed the assembly of a giant robot called Dextre on Monday in the third of five scheduled spacewalks outside the International Space Station. Dr. Richard M. Linnehan and Maj. Robert L. Behnken of the Air Force removed thermal covers from the Canadian-built maintenance robots 11-foot arms and attached a 5-foot metal boom to its front for holding equipment and tools. They added a holder for three tools under the 3,400-pound robots right arm and a pan-and-tilt color camera on its body so operators can observe its work. The $209 million robot, which has passed initial operating tests, will be attached to the stations Destiny laboratory module.

Essentially, the mountain storehouses of frozen water that have shaped their history and culture, or that have provided a secure year-round source of water through modern times, are no longer secure.

Bear Stearns had about 14,000 employees, and as many as 8,000 of them worked in the city. Last year, those workers collected more than $3.4 billion in pay and benefits, or an average of about $242,000 per employee. The firm was one of the 25 largest employers in the city and accounted for about one of every 25 jobs in the citys securities industry.

title: A Different View of Boy Named Sue
description: In my Findings column on weird names, I reviewed the shifting views of pyschologists on the effect of unusual or cross-gender names. Four decades ago, there were studies suggesting that children suffered as a result of odd names, but subsequent researchers concluded otherwise. They found that once you adjust for the socioeconomic variables, children with unusual names do as well as others, and that boys with cross-gender names like Leslie turn out just fine  in fact, they have more self-control than average.

title: Ballet in London: Frightful Tutus and Horrid Wrists

When New York City Ballet appeared here in the 1950s, 60s and 70s, British dancegoers spent much time complaining about the companys costumes (especially those designed by Karinska for Balanchine ballets); about the fact that the companys corps de ballet was not in perfect unison; that too many dancers had angled (broken) wrists; that their arms were generally awful; that there was too little evidence of line; that the Royal Ballet at Covent Garden had an infinitely more varied repertory; and, of course, that this New York kind of classical dancing was not nearly as good as the Royals.

And maybe this was better, because it was substantive and peeled away layers to confront sensitive matters that normally go unexamined.

title: Paterson Acknowledges Extramarital Affairs
description: Updated, 2:10 p.m. | One day after taking office, Gov. David A. Paterson held a noontime news conference to discuss news reports that he and his wife, Michelle Paige Paterson, had extramarital affairs during a strain in their 15-year marriage. He acknowledged having affairs with a number of women, including one state employee, several years ago, but said that the relationships were over and that he and his wife had repaired their marriage.With his wife standing by his side, Mr. Paterson, 53, expressed regret for past mistakes but said he was coming forward to clear the air and avoid any innuendo or speculation that might arise. I didnt break the law, he said, toward the end of his news conference, at the State Capitol in Albany. I didnt violate an oath. I didnt use knowingly campaign funds. I didnt use state funds at all. I know that. I dont think institutionally there were any violations here. However, the public wants to know who its elected officials are, and sometimes, even though you are human and you are someone that just has feelings and has faults, there comes a time, perhaps, when you have to tell the public.

title: From 9/11 to Fall of Baghdad, an Ex-Marine Explains What It Means to Him
description: On Sept. 11, 2001, Tim McLaughlin, from Laconia, N.H., was a Marine Corps first lieutenant working in Room 5E678 of the Pentagon. He had broken his leg in training and was temporarily serving in an administrative capacity. He helped fire and rescue teams from within the Pentagon that day. A year and a half later, he commanded the first American tank that rolled into Baghdads Firdos (Paradise) Square shortly after 4 p.m. on April 9, 2003, signaling the end of Saddam Husseins rule. It was his Bravo Company, Third Battalion, Fourth Marines, First Marine Division, using a Hercules tank-recovery vehicle and a heavy chain, that helped Iraqis pull down Mr. Husseins hollow metal statue before the worlds television cameras. It was Lieutenant McLaughlins Stars and Stripes flag given to him by a friend in the aftermath of the Pentagon attack that a marine briefly draped over the statues head that day, an image that symbolized and outraged in equal measure. He left the Marine Corps as a captain on Sept. 1, 2006. Now 30, he is a second-year law student at Boston College.

At the Sunday evening New York City Ballet performance, Janie Taylor (who returned to the stage in February after a prolonged absence) danced the heroine of Serenade, a role she has not yet performed in New York. Though there are a couple of nondance moments when she is in danger of giving a mistaken acting emphasis (as in the late entrance and when she regards the men who will bear her aloft at the end), and though her loosened fair hair is actually too long and intrusive for the final Elegy, her sheer freshness and destiny-driven urgency are more than welcome.

I was sitting in a darkened theater with hundreds of Iraqis, breathing together in collective expectation. Beethoven washed over us like a wave. At the time, Baghdad was plagued by bombings. Later they would seem almost old-fashioned: blind strikes with random victims, different (though no less destructive) from the murderous sectarian hunts of 2006.

title: A Speech to Remember
description: For more than a week, since the media began to report on Rev. Jeremiah Wrights sermons, the anger has been building. First from whites who found these sermons filled with hate, race baiting, and dangerous  radicalism. And then from the black community, who defended Reverend Wright as a modern-day prophet and a speaker of views that resonated with mainstream  black America.

title: Councilmans Resignation Sets Off a Race

And now, with Mr. Gallagher set to leave the Council on April 18, the candidates are openly raising money and seeking support in their Queens district in a not-altogether friendly manner.

title: Unanswered Questions
description: From the beginning, the rationale for Barack Obamas campaign has been his call for Americans to transcend their differences  both ideological and demographic. But Rev. Jeremiah Wrights comments would seem to have forced Senator Obama to choose sides  to either stand with Reverend Wright and others who support his condemnations of the United States, or with those who think they should be rejected out of hand. But Senator Obama didnt choose: he criticized Reverend Wrights statements as wrong and divisive without being willing to distance himself from the pastor who has been so instrumental in the development of his religious faith. Thats certainly Senator Obamas prerogative, but it doesnt answer a number of questions that he will continue to face in the days ahead.

title: Todt Bucked!
description: Jean Todt resigned as chief executive of Ferrari on Tuesday, leaving the reins of the prancing horse to Amadeo Felisa, who had been Ferraris general manager. The move wasnt wholly unexpected, as Todt had said that he would serve as chief executive only while Ferrari chairman Luca Cordero di Montezemolo served as chairman of Italys employers lobby, a term which has recently ended. Mr. Todt says that his retirement will allow him to dedicate more time to myself and the things Im interested in.
