description: Two views from guest contributors on Senator Barack Obamas Race in America speech.

title: Tonights Slate: Desperation on Ice
description: Eight games are on the schedule for tonight and all of them have playoff implications. (Which can mean only that LA does not play Tampa Bay.) Here are the latest standings, and heres a look at tonights action:

title: Time for Rangers Stretch Drive to Start
description: With 10 games to go in the regular season, the Rangers start their stretch drive in earnest with tonights game against Pittsburgh. That is because all 10 games will be against Atlantic Division rivals, two of which remain ahead of the Rangers in the standings.

title: New Protected Buildings Include Webster Hall
description: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission today designated five new city landmarks  four of them in the East Village  and created a new historic district, Fiske Terrace-Midwood Park, in Flatbush, Brooklyn. Descriptions of the five new landmarks and the new historic district follow. The commission held a hearing last October on the four East Village sites, which were identified as worthy of preservation in a 2006 commission study of the East Villages historical heritage.

title: Michigan Up Against the Wall
description: Is the Michigan do-over primary idea dead, too?

title: Going OnceGoing TwiceThe 700 Mhz Spectrum is Sold
description: It ended in a $19 billion whimper. The Federal Communication Commission posted this to its Web site Tuesday afternoon:

title: The Quad Video Series
description: As you ponder all of the different first-round machinations  Will Georgias luck last? Can Clemson sustain its momentum? Is Kansas firing on all cylinders? For how long?  we here at The Quad are asking ourselves similar questions ahead of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament. After all, our picks will be out there for all to see in The Bracket Tournament, and we certainly dont want to be shown up by you, The New York Times-reading public. Weve got a reputation to protect, even if it exists only in our own minds.

title: Sustainable Mobility
description: As oil prices climb, automakers are showcasing fuel-efficient technologies at the L.A. Auto Show.

title: Shades of Green
description: Carmakers seeking to prove their environmental street cred, highlight fuel-efficient models at the Detroit Auto Show.

title: The Smart School Final Four
description: Its a safe bet that InsideHigherEd.com has the only bracket that picks Davidson to beat Belmont in college basketballs title game. As the site itself says, we would not recommend that any of you use this bracket to make your selections in any office pools.

title: Inheritance Reconsidered
description: With the largest intergenerational transfer of wealth in American history now under way, families are reassessing the meaning of inheritance.

title: Ballet in London: Sleeping Beauty at Covent Garden
description: In the Royal Ballets Sleeping Beauty at Covent Garden on Monday night, only three performers (all principal dancers, fortunately) danced as if they were seriously awake at any point, and the ballerina dancing the title character was never one of them. Yet The Sleeping Beauty (especially on its visits to New York) was for decades the Royal Ballets signature ballet. Whats happened?

title: In a Photographers Memory, Images of the Dead
description: Five years have passed since I stood on the border of Iraq and Kuwait, watching the predawn sky for the first salvos in the Iraq war. I am reading political analyses and historical accounts of years that are past. I am thinking of all of the things that had not yet happened as I stood in the desert sand that day.

title: Murtha Endorses Clinton
description: MILLERSVILLE, Pa.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton announced not one but two superdelegate pick-ups on Tuesday, including a big one from Representative John Murtha of Pennsylvania, her first burst of super-delegate good news since her March 4 victories in the Ohio and Texas primaries.

title: Making a Case for Nuclear Power
description: Science reporter Andrew C. Revkin sits down with environmental scientist and author James E. Lovelock to discuss the benefits of nuclear power.

title: Clinton to Fly to Michigan in Push for Revote
description: MILLERSVILLE, Pa. - Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is adding a quick trip to Detroit to her Wednesday campaign schedule in a high-profile push for a primary contest revote there so Michigans delegates are counted in the Democratic nomination fight.

title: In Firefighters Glee at U.S. Deaths, Insurgency Blooms
description: Dexter Filkins was a correspondent for the Baghdad bureau of The New York Times from 2003 to 2006. His book, The Forever War, will be published in September by Alfred A. Knopf.

title: Keeping Up With Blogs
description: People always ask me what blogs Im reading and how I find new ones. I dont have a particular method. I collect blogs randomly, finding them while reading other blogs, through comments on blogs and by generally wandering around online. But now, I can recommend Alltop, a new site that organizes blogs by category. Alltop was created by Nononina, a company owned by Guy Kawasaki, Will Mayall, and Kathryn Henkens. Nononina is also the founder of Truemors, a site posting unusual breaking news stories, and a handy place to waste a lot of time online.

title: Screen star Arlene Dahl selling New York estate for $8.5 million
description: Actress Arlene Dahl is selling Treetops, her 11-acre estate in upstate New York. Built in 1859, the Victorian house includes 14 rooms, nine fireplaces, oak floors and wide verandas, priced at $8.5 million.

title: Pineapple Dreams
description: The other day, I went to the supermarket to buy a pineapple. I didnt select the one that smelled the ripest, but the one with the most impressive leaves: tall, bushy and uncrushed by the journey from Costa Rica. When I got it home, I put it in the kitchen sink, turned on the tap, and watched how the water gathered and formed pools in the spaces between the leaves. And I began to imagine that I was not a human in an apartment in London, but a small frog in a tropical forest, climbing up the leaves of a plant like a pineapple, looking for a pool where I could deposit the tadpole Im carrying on my back.

title: Reconciliation Conference Highlights Iraqs Deep Political and Religious Fissures
description: BAGHDAD  It was billed as a national dialogue that would bring Iraqs disparate and warring factions together to discuss their differences and emerge with a blueprint for peaceful coexistence.

title: Easter Is for Baking, Too
description: PERHAPS its the weather, the twitter of springtime. But the approach of Easter has never inspired cooks to stay in the kitchen and light the oven with the fervor that accompanies the Christmas holiday season.

title: Yemen: Police Officer Killed in Blasts Near U.S. Embassy
description: At least one police officer was killed when three mortar rounds exploded outside a girls school near the American Embassy in the capital, Sana, Yemeni officials said. The explosions, which took place as the girls were leaving school, also injured 13 girls and 3 police officers, the officials said. The Interior Ministry issued a statement saying the blasts were fired by extremist elements but did not provide details. Yemeni officials said it was not clear whether the rounds were aimed at the school or at the embassy, but the State Department spokesman Tom Casey said in Washington, It is fair to say that the embassy was a potential target.

title: Sweets With a Dollop of Southeast Asia
description: A bubble-gum pink, spatter-painted bake shop with crystal chandeliers seems to fit Pichet Ong just right. Mr. Ong, left, is the pastry chef who owns P*ong, the Greenwich Village restaurant where he serves small plates, savory and sweet.

title: Starbucks Announces Sweeping Changes
description: SEATTLE  The chief executive of Starbucks announced sweeping changes for the company on Wednesday as it seeks to reconnect with customers who have left for competitors or pared back their coffee budget in hard economic times.

title: After Scoring Twice, Avery Passes the Credit to Jagr
description: As the Re-sign Avery! chants were echoing through Madison Square Garden in the third period Tuesday night, Rangers forward Sean Avery and his linemate Jaromir Jagr skated toward each other and shared a laugh.

title: Wireless Spectrum Auction Raises $19 Billion
description: WASHINGTON  The government announced on Tuesday that it had closed the most lucrative government auction in history as wireless companies bid more than $19 billion for the rights to radio spectrum licenses.

title: Rules Count
description: Washington

title: Estimates of Iraq War Cost Were Not Close to Ballpark
description: WASHINGTON  At the outset of the Iraq war, the Bush administration predicted that it would cost $50 billion to $60 billion to oust Saddam Hussein, restore order and install a new government.

title: 2. Ubuntu
For Top Medical Students, an Attractive Field
description: BOSTON  March Madness has a different meaning for Thomas Hocker and Meena Singh, a married couple in their final year at the Harvard Medical School, who are waiting to learn Thursday if they have been accepted into their residency programs of choice.

title: China Steps Up Its Accusations Against the Dalai Lama
description: BEIJING  China called on Tuesday for an international investigation of the Dalai Lama, accusing him of masterminding the violent Tibetan protests spreading across China, but the Tibetan religious leader denied those claims and invited observers to scour his office.

title: Miley Cyrus's New Name
description: Miley Cyrus, below, whose given name is Destiny Hope Cyrus, has filed papers in Los Angeles County Superior Court to change her full legal name to Miley Ray Cyrus, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Cyrus, 15, who plays an undercover singing star on the series Hannah Montana, is the daughter of the country singer Billy Ray Cyrus, who filed the papers Friday with his wife, Leticia. Mr. Cyrus said the request was filed to make her commonly used name the same as her legal name.

title: Pelfrey and Hernndez Have Different Styles, but the Same Goal
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Sitting in the Mets clubhouse after striking out against Orlando Hernndez in a simulated game Tuesday, catcher Ramn Castro was asked what pitch got him. It was a fastball, Castro said. Yeah, a dazzling fastball. Then he chuckled softly.

title: Witness Testifies That a Detective in the Sean Bell Shooting Said He Fired Only One Bullet
description: A detective who fired four rounds in the shooting that killed Sean Bell told investigators early on that he was certain he fired just one shot and that he had found the other unused bullets at home in a drawer, according to testimony by an assistant district attorney on Tuesday in the case of the three detectives who fired at Mr. Bells car.

title: Clinton Tries to Keep Plan for Two Revotes Alive
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons hopes of ending the primaries with game-changing victories from new contests in Florida and Michigan grew dim on Tuesday as Florida officially scuttled plans for a new vote and Michigan lawmakers appeared far from a deal.

title: Taking Hostages to Right a Wrong
description: Theres plenty of room in theater for a revisionist Medea in which the worlds angriest betrayed wife is still furious at her husband, Jason, but this time doesnt kill their sons to punish him. (That was always the ultimate act of cutting off your nose to spite your face.) A muddled, sort of revisionist version, though, is what we have in Theodora Skipitaress flat new production at La MaMa. As it ends, Medea ascends in a chariot under the protection of the gods, and says shes taking the boys with her, but its entirely unclear whether the children are dead or alive.

title: Dancing to the Top
description: The sixth-season premiere of ABCs Dancing With the Stars attracted 20.9 million viewers on Monday, Nielsen estimated, leading ABC to first place for the night. The premiere of The Bachelor, which followed Dancing With the Stars, averaged considerably less: 9 million viewers from 9:30 p.m. to 11 p.m. CBS earned a solid second place thanks to the return of its comedy lineup: The Big Bang Theory at 8 (9.1 million), How I Met Your Mother at 8:30 (9.7 million), Two and a Half Men at 9 (14 million) and The New Adventures of Old Christine at 9:30 (11.5 million). NBC was third over all, with My Dad Is Better Than Your Dad at 8 (4.7 million) and Deal or No Deal at 9 (9.9 million).

title: Fed Trims Rates Sharply, Sending the Markets Up
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve reduced short-term interest rates for the sixth time in six months on Tuesday, capping an extraordinary series of measures it has taken to stabilize financial markets. The cut was smaller than investors had been expecting, though, and exposed some signs of a split among policy makers.

title: Voguers Take Back the Night and the Dance Stage
description: After a performance of the work in progress In Search of the Invisible People, a philosophical journey into club dancing, on Monday night, the choreographer Niles Ford made his case for inclusiveness. Everybodys virtuosic, he said, gesturing to his dancers and describing his interest in hybridizing different styles.

title: A Tapestry of New York Is Lost in Leveled Building
description: There are, it seems, no ordinary buildings in New York. There are merely nondescript, workaday buildings that hide their share of the citys social history  its ambitions and achievements, strivings and scandals  until trauma casts them in high profile. Or crushes them.

title: U.S. May Relent on Hamas Role in Talks
description: WASHINGTON After ruling out talks with Hamas, the militant Islamist group, the Bush administration is using Egypt as an intermediary to open a channel between Israel and representatives of the group, in what some diplomats say could be a softening of the American stance.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture on Tuesday with the Books of The Times Review about Daydream Believers by Fred Kaplan, using information provided by a publicist, carried an erroneous credit. The photograph of Mr. Kaplan is by Will OLeary, not Bruno Barbey/Magnum Photos. (Mr. Barbey took the picture on the books cover.)

title: Off the Menu
description: Looking Ahead

title: In Chicago, More Talk About Race After Speech
description: CHICAGO  In the lobby of the Trinity United Church of Christ on the South Side here, a receptionist struggled to keep his head above the tidal wave of calls that poured in just after Senator Barack Obama finished speaking to the nation about race and his complicated relationship with Trinitys former pastor, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr.

title: Sedgemoor Easter Biscuits
description: Adapted from Good Things in England: A Practical Cookery Book for Everyday Use, edited by Florence White, 1932 (Persephone Books, 2003 edition)

title: After an Admission, Unruffled Lawmakers Say Its Time to Get to Work
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson and legislative leaders from both parties gathered on Tuesday afternoon in the same mahogany-paneled room of the State Capitol where, just hours before, Mr. Paterson had stood and admitted to marital infidelity.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Op-Ed page on Friday, about blindness, misidentified the nations first legally blind governor. He was Bob Cowley Riley, who was governor of Arkansas for 11 days in 1975; David Paterson is not the first.

title: A City That Sat on Its Treasures, but Didnt See Them
description: CHANDIGARH, India  Every working day for the past 20 years, Suresh Kanwar, a civil engineer in Chandigarhs Forestry Department, has been sitting on the same battered wooden chair, an object he said had no beauty even if it was, for office use, very comfortable.

title: China Moves to Stem Inflation and Calm Investors
description: SHANGHAI  Stock prices plummeted in China on Tuesday over inflation fears and growing concerns about the ripple effects of an economic slowdown in the United States. Showing its determination to hold down prices, the Chinese central bank then moved to tighten lending.

title: God as the Old Puppeteer and Other Creation Myths
description: Kevin Augustines Lone Wolf Tribe opened at Performance Space 122 on Monday night trailing awards, blurbs of bright critical praise and some fairly impressive sponsors. On the evidence of Bride, the new production the company will present through March, it is difficult to understand why.

title: Citizenship, Thwarted
description: The director of the federal Citizenship and Immigration Services agency, Emilio Gonzalez, is stepping down next month, leaving behind a gummed-up bureaucracy and perhaps a million empty promises. Thats about how many people are stuck waiting to have their citizenship petitions approved by the agency, which was swamped last summer by a flood of applications that it failed to predict or prepare for.

title: A Journal of Sleeplessness, Recording a Fatal Illness
description: It would be nice to say simply that Anthony Staglianos Fade cures the very thing that its about, sleeplessness, and leave it at that. But that wouldnt convey the pretentiousness of this psychological drama: the lingering shots of kitchens and bathrooms and fuzzed-out television screens; the journal-entry voice-overs; the decision to frontload a 74-minute film with 45 minutes of deliberate vagueness.

title: Japan Impasse Leaves Bank Post Open
description: TOKYO  For a second time, the Japanese Parliament blocked selection of a new central bank chief on Wednesday, leaving the crucial post vacant as monetary authorities in Washington and elsewhere fight to contain the deepening financial crisis.

title: A Landmark From the Start, Now Getting Its Official Due
description: The news may be that 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza  the towering silvery monolith that forever changed the Lower Manhattan skyline nearly a half century ago  has not been made a landmark already.

title: Britain: Northern Rock Cutting Staff
description: Northern Rock, the bank that got a 25 billion ($50 billion) bailout from the British government, will cut about a third of its 6,000-person work force and reduce mortgage lending to help repay state loans. The bank, based in Newcastle, plans to become a smaller, more focused, financially viable mortgage and savings company, it said. The job cuts will be complete by 2011.

title: A Great Year Lifts an Unsung Region
description: GREAT vintages send prices surging for wines from high-status regions like Bordeaux and Burgundy.

title: West Virginia Adjusts to New Coaching Style
description: The basketball coaching change at West Virginia last year signified a switch from one philosophical extreme to another.

title: Indianapolis Pinning Lots of Hopes on Airport Project
description: INDIANAPOLIS  A $1.1 billion airport redevelopment project here  the largest civic project in the history of Indianapolis  is part of a larger campaign by this city of more than 780,000 residents to recast itself as a hub for national distribution as well as a center for advanced manufacturing and sports-related tourism.

title: Papers Detail Complaints of Links to Treasury List
description: A sheaf of documents that a federal court forced the Treasury Department to release indicate there have been repeated complaints from American consumers who have been falsely linked to terrorism or drug trafficking during routine credit checks, the organization that sought the documents in a lawsuit said Tuesday.

title: China Tries Rights Advocate; Verdict Expected in Week
description: BEIJING  One of the most prominent human rights advocates in China stood trial on Tuesday morning on subversion charges in a proceeding that lasted three hours and centered on whether his public criticism of the ruling Communist Party represented a threat to the state. A verdict is possible within a week.

title: French Court Upholds Ban on Gene-Altered Corn Seed
description: PARIS  Opponents of gene-altered crops won a victory in France on Wednesday when the top court upheld, at least for the time being, a ban on a corn variety produced by the American seed company Monsanto.

title: For Bands, Songs Remain the Same
description: Step inside an arena where N.C.A.A. tournament games are being played. Close the eyes during timeouts. Listen to the pep bands play their jaunty tunes. And remember what year it is.

title: Mother and Son, Divided by Border, United by Phone
description: Under the Same Moon, an Incredible Journey for the socially conscience-stricken, arrives in theaters trailing a standing ovation from last years Sundance Film Festival and more than a whiff of sanctimony. And even allowing that Sundance audiences are notoriously unreliable arbiters of quality  for every Spanking the Monkey, theres a Spitfire Grill and a Quinceaera  their wholehearted embrace of this manipulative, saccharin product is dispiriting.

title: Court Weighs Right to Guns, and Its Limits
description: WASHINGTON  A majority of the Supreme Court appeared ready on Tuesday to embrace, for the first time in the countrys history, an interpretation of the Second Amendment that protects the right to own a gun for personal use.

title: HBO Cancels Show
description: Days after announcing it would replace its chief series programmer, HBO has canceled a series before broadcasting it. The network said on Tuesday that it would not go ahead with 12 Miles of Bad Road, a satirical Dallas-like series created by Linda Bloodworth Thomason, whose last big hit was Designing Women, which ran from 1986 to 1993. 12 Miles, starring Lily Tomlin as a wealthy Texas matriarch, had shot 6 of a planned 12 episodes before HBO executives decided it was not up to HBO standards. Two recent HBO shows, John From Cincinnati and Lucky Louie, did not perform well. Several other networks have been approached about picking up 12 Miles of Bad Road, most recently Lifetime. A Lifetime executive said on Tuesday that the channel was not interested.

title: Mostly Mozart Festival Plans Lively Summer of Death
description: This summer Mostly Mozart will die. And transform. Again and again.

title: Red Bulls May Play Host to Barcelona in August
description: F.C. Barcelona is nearly certain to return to the United States this summer for at least two games against Major League Soccer clubs.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Evil Haman Loses Again

title: U.S. Files Added Charge Against Former Partner at KPMG Accused in Tax Case
description: Federal prosecutors overseeing a big tax shelter case involving former employees of the KPMG accounting firm brought a separate charge Tuesday against one of the defendants in that case.

title: Arthur C. Clarke, Author Who Saw Science Fiction Become Real, Dies at 90
description: Arthur C. Clarke, a writer whose seamless blend of scientific expertise and poetic imagination helped usher in the space age, died early Wednesday in Colombo, Sri Lanka, where he had lived since 1956. He was 90.

title: Stepfather Is Convicted of Manslaughter in Beating Death of 7-Year-Old Girl
description: A deeply divided jury in Brooklyn convicted the stepfather of 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown of first-degree manslaughter for his role in her fatal 2006 beating, inflicted as punishment for stealing a snack from the refrigerator and jamming his computer printer with toys. But the jury acquitted the stepfather, Cesar Rodriguez, of second-degree murder.

title: Black, White & Gray
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: Morgan Stanley Tops Forecast
description: In another boost to confidence on Wall Street, Morgan Stanley, the investment bank, reported a profit of $1.5 billion for its first quarter Wednesday, surpassing analyst estimates and further easing investor fears of another investment bank failure following the collapse of Bear Stearns.

title: Landis, Stripped of Tour Title, Begins Final Appeal
description: Floyd Landis will attempt to overturn a doping ruling that stripped him of the 2006 Tour de France title during a five-day appeal hearing that begins Wednesday. But unlike the highly public and sometimes dramatic initial examination of his case, this hearing will take place in private at a Manhattan law office.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Saturday about Ladies and Gents, a play that is being performed in the public bathrooms near the Bethesda Fountain in Central Park, misidentified the festival at which it was first performed. It was the Dublin Fringe Festival, not the Dublin Theater Festival.

title: Small Harlem Youth Soccer League Attracts Some Big-Name Friends
description: On an overcast Saturday morning this month, a group of young girls and boys ran around a soccer field. Some tried haphazardly to make the ball go in a particular direction, while others executed crisp passes and showed off deft dribbling skills.

title: Governor Makes Pre-emptive Strike on Scandal: I Didnt Want to Be Compromised
description: Gov. David A. Paterson and his wife, Michelle Paige Paterson, took questions at the State Capitol on Tuesday about their marriage and their extramarital affairs. Excerpts, as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: Dalai Lama Threatens to Resign
description: DHARAMSALA, India  The Dalai Lama on Tuesday invited international observers, including Chinese officials, to scour his offices here and investigate whether he had any role in inciting the latest anti-Chinese violence in Tibet. He also threatened to resign as leader of Tibets government-in-exile in the event of spiraling bloodshed in his homeland.

title: Flight 93 Memorial Effort Gains Over 900 Acres
description: A group made up of relatives of those killed aboard United Flight 93 on Sept. 11, 2001, announced Tuesday that it had agreed to buy a 903-acre tract to be part of a permanent memorial near Shanksville, Pa.

title: Its Bondholders vs. Shareholders in a Race to Buy Bear Stearns Stock
description: Only days after the fire sale of Bear Stearns stunned Wall Street, a battle seems to be brewing in the markets over the fate of the troubled investment bank and the controversial deal that JPMorgan and federal authorities devised to save it.

title: The Fat Pack Wonders if the Partys Over
description: THE bill came due for Jason Perlow in October.

title: Van Halen Reschedules
description: Van Halen has rescheduled a series of dates on its reunion tour, which has been plagued over the last year by delays and postponements related to Eddie Van Halens health. This time the group said only that Mr. Van Halen, right, was undergoing medical tests. The tour resumes on April 19 in Las Vegas and continues through June 2 in Grand Rapids, Mich., with performances at the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., on May 13, and Madison Square Garden on May 23. Tickets for all postponed shows will be honored.

title: Industry Giants Try to Break Computings Dead End
description: Intel and Microsoft said Tuesday that they planned to finance two groups of university researchers to start over and design a new generation of computing systems intended to break the industry out of a technological cul-de-sac that threatens to end decades of performance increases in computers.

title: Heavy Drinking and a Paint Prank Precede a Young Mans Death
description: The authorities were investigating the mysterious death on Tuesday of a young man in Queens whose face and back had been spray-painted blue by a drinking buddy, the police said.

title: In India, Balancing Refugee Care and Relations With China
description: DHARAMSALA, India  The Dalai Lama on Tuesday called on his young and restless followers here to refrain from upsetting their Indian hosts and said he would ask the organizers of a proposed march from here to Lhasa, the Tibetan capital, to reconsider their efforts.

title: U.S. Moves to Free Funds for Home Loans
description: WASHINGTON  With the blessing of the Bush administration, the regulator of the nations two largest mortgage financing companies on Wednesday continued on its path of easing restrictions on the companies in an effort to calm financial markets and stabilize problems in the housing industry.

title: Whitney Museum to Receive $131 Million Gift
description: Leonard A. Lauder, the cosmetics executive and chairman of the Whitney Museum of American Art, said on Tuesday that his art foundation would give the museum $131 million, the biggest donation in the Whitneys 77-year history.

title: Dow Gives Up 293 Points; Gold and Oil Plunge
description: A day after an interest rate cut fueled the best stock session in five years, the Dow Jones industrials slid back nearly 300 points on Wednesday and commodity prices plummeted, signs that a sense of unease has yet to disappear from financial markets.

title: Belgium: Long Deadlock Ends
description: Belgiums leading political parties announced a deal to form a new government, ending an unprecedented nine-month political impasse between the Dutch-speaking north and the poorer, French-speaking south that threatened to break the country apart. The five-party agreement installed Yves Leterme, a Flemish Christian Democrat, as prime minister, replacing a caretaker administration led by Guy Verhofstadt since June. Mr. Leterme, left, is expected to be sworn in on Thursday by King Albert II, but he will need to widen his appeal for his government to last. An opinion poll for the daily La Libre Belgique showed that 54 percent of the north and 92 percent of the south did not trust him as prime minister.

title: McCain Missteps on Iraq; Democrats Pounce
description: JERUSALEM  Senator John McCains trip overseas was supposed to highlight his foreign policy acumen, and his supporters hoped that it would showcase him in a series of statesmanlike meetings with world leaders throughout the Middle East and Europe while the Democratic candidates continued to squabble back home.

title: Footnotes
description: After a critically lauded run last year at Primary Stages, Horton Footes Dividing the Estate is moving to Broadway. Lincoln Center Theater will produce the play, a comic portrait of a Texas family, at a Shubert theater to be announced. Performances are to begin on Oct. 23, with opening night scheduled for Nov. 20. Michael Wilson is directing; Elizabeth Ashley, Arthur French, Hallie Foote, Penny Fuller and Gerald McRaney star. ... Alfred Hitchcocks The 39 Steps is moving to the Cort Theater, following its limited engagement at Roundabout Theater Companys American Airlines Theater. Performances continue through March 29 at the American Airlines and will resume April 29 at the Cort. Opening night is May 8. ... The Irish Repertory Theater will extend its run of the musical Take Me Along from April 13 to May 4. ... Sierra Boggess and Sean Palmer, from The Little Mermaid, will make their Town Hall debuts in The Broadway Musicals of 1954 on April 7, part of the Broadway by the Year series. The show includes songs and dances from The Pajama Game, Peter Pan, The Boy Friend and Fanny, among others. Emily Skinner, Noah Racey, Cheyenne Jackson and Kendrick Jones will also appear. ... Ive Got Your Number: Romance, the Rat Pack and Carolyn Leigh, part of the 92nd Street Ys Lyrics & Lyricists series, will run from March 29 to March 31. It features Debby Boone, Loston Harris, James Naughton and Karen Ziemba.

title: At Robertas in Bushwick, the Pizza as Art
description: LIKE many who migrate to Bushwick, Brooklyn, Chris Parachini moved there to be an artist and a musician. The rents are reasonable and neighbors arent much of a problem unless they play in a noisier band than you do.

title: Merkel Says Holocaust Fills Germans With Shame
description: JERUSALEM  Angela Merkel on Tuesday became the first German chancellor to address the Israeli Parliament, crowning a three-day visit intended to upgrade ties between Israel and Germany.

title: Clinton Records From 90s to Be Released on Wednesday
description: More than 11,000 pages of Hillary Rodham Clintons schedules as first lady, records sought by a conservative watchdog group and journalists, will be released on Wednesday, the National Archives announced Tuesday.

title: Star Banker Returns to Roots With His Own Venture
description: Hes back.

title: Cant Grasp Credit Crisis? Join the Club
description: Raise your hand if you dont quite understand this whole financial crisis.

title: Anthony Minghella, 54, Director, Dies
description: Anthony Minghella, the British filmmaker who won an Academy Award for his direction of The English Patient, died Tuesday morning in London. He was 54.

title: Jurors Say That Several Felt Murder Was Not Proved in Trial of Stepfather
description: The jury in the Nixzmary Brown murder trial voted to convict Nixzmarys stepfather of manslaughter but to acquit him of murder because several jurors felt that prosecutors had failed to offer sufficient evidence, three jurors said in interviews.

title: Knicks Likely to Seek New President
description: INDIANAPOLIS  James L. Dolan remains publicly silent regarding the fate of Isiah Thomas and the future of the Knicks. But his intentions are coming into focus, and they almost certainly include removing Thomas as the teams president.

title: A Premiere Far From Hollywood
description: LOS ANGELES  Leatherheads, which was shot in the Carolinas, is about to get a hometown premiere, even if the hundreds of local people who worked as extras and bit players on this football comedy, set for release by Universal Pictures on April 4, have to do it themselves.

title: Michigan: Suit on Anti-Affirmative-Action Law Is Dismissed
description: A federal judge dismissed a lawsuit that challenged a state law banning racial and gender preferences in government hiring and public university admissions. The ruling upholds the constitutionality of a measure approved by Michigan voters in 2006. It had been challenged by groups including the American Civil Liberties Union and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. The law may have had the most effect on the admissions policies of the University of Michigan. The school previously had considered race as a factor in admission, a policy that was challenged in court in the 1990s.

title: Competition Fuels Broadband Use in Europe
description: BRUSSELS  Fierce competition from new providers has pushed the level of broadband subscriptions in eight European countries above the levels in the United States and Japan, according to figures to be released Wednesday.

title: Heart Condition Led to Runners Death
description: More than four months after Ryan Shay collapsed in Central Park during the United States Olympic marathon trials, the New York City medical examiner determined that his death was caused by an irregular heartbeat that stemmed from an enlarged and scarred heart.

title: Wives With Lifelines Leagues Under the Sea
description: Kristen Kosmass Hello Failure is a hazy daydream of a play that suggests that the only people more isolated and lonely than the men living in a submarine are their wives. You can think it is a very small world out there, says Valeska (Janna Gjesdal), one of several women with husbands at sea, and that it is only water, waiting and wondering.

title: Paterson Says He Would Have Repaid Any Personal Use of His Campaign Funds
description: Gov. David A. Paterson, who has admitted having a number of extramarital affairs, indicated that if he ever used campaign money in the course of those relationships he would have properly reimbursed the campaign account.

title: Oklahoma: Lawmakers Comments Bring Protest
description: Hundreds of gay and lesbian rights advocates protested at the Capitol over comments a state representative made about homosexuals. Representative Sally Kern, Republican of Oklahoma City, drew national attention last week when a January speech she gave before a Republican club in Oklahoma City was posted on the Internet. In the speech, she said homosexuality was the biggest threat our nation has, even more so than terrorism or Islam. Mrs. Kern, the wife of a Baptist minister, has refused to apologize for her remarks. She was not present for the 40-minute protest, and the door to her office was locked.

title: 1. O Ya
description: 9 East Street, Boston; (617) 654-9900. www.oyarestaurantboston.com

title: Tournament Can Bring Out Best and Worst of College Sports
description: How will you watch March Madness?

title: La Sirnes Menu Is at the Will of the Web
description: AT the oddly compelling little bistro La Sirne, you might be able to order profiteroles. Then again you might not. It depends on Didier Pawlickis mood.

title: Pairings: Oysters With Miso Glaze
description: In a recent column, my colleague Eric Asimov discussed drinking red wine with oysters on the half shell. My instinct, like his, would have led me to Chinon. But he preferred a Morgon and a Givry, speculating that perhaps the Chinon he tried was too assertive.

title: This Years Tar Heels Fit the Mold of a Champion
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Sean May, Raymond Felton and others from the 2005 North Carolina basketball team are occasional visitors to the Dean E. Smith Center, where their place in the history of the basketball program is secured by the N.C.A.A. championship banner that hangs in the rafters.

title: Choose, or Lose in November
description: Nashville

title: Big Payday for Wall St. in Visas Public Offering
description: In a boon for big banks and Wall Street, Visa, the credit card giant, went public Tuesday in the largest initial public offering in American history.

title: Text of the Federal Reserves Statement
description: Following is the statement released Tuesday by the Federal Reserve:

title: To the Cheese Course, Prepare to Add Camel
description: WITH cheeses in all shapes, sizes and aromas so easily found, a new curd can have trouble standing out. This is not likely to be a problem for Caravane.

title: Dentist Pleads Guilty to Stealing and Selling Body Parts
description: A dentist from New Jersey pleaded guilty on Tuesday to running a corrupt $4.6 million enterprise through which body parts were plundered from funeral homes and sold for use in transplants and medical research.

title: Tasting Report: From 2005, Chinons With Spicy Fruit Flavors
description: Daniel Chauveau Chinon 2005

title: Broadway Comeback Is Planned for August Wilsons Fences
description: Last July Radio Golf, the final play in August Wilsons epic, 10-play cycle about the black experience in America, closed on Broadway. And now plans are in the works to bring back Fences, his portrait of a bitter and resentful former baseball player and ex-convict in 1957 Pittsburgh, which will be the second revival of a Wilson play on Broadway.

title: Visa Shares Jump Sharply as Trading Starts
description: Shares of Visa Inc., the credit card giant, jumped sharply as they began trading on Wednesday after the largest initial public offering in American history.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about Senator Barack Obamas mother misidentified the profession of his half-sister, Maya Soetoro-Ng. She has a Ph.D. in comparative education and works as a teacher; she is not an anthropologist. (Go to Article)

title: Apple Cake, Gloriously Soused
description: SOAKING a cake in liquor or syrup is an old concept, one that has sometimes been abused.

title: In 53 Minutes, Federer Shows Hes Back in Form
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  It was hard to tell Tuesday afternoon what was causing more people to sweat: a beating sun that had washed away the last gasp of winter, or the sight of Roger Federer looking ready, willing and able to resume his reign over mens tennis.

title: In the Wake of a Crane Collapse, a Home Skewered by a Beam
description: Since Saturdays collapse of a towering construction crane on the East Side of Manhattan, attention has understandably focused on the central and spectacular details, on the lives lost, the 22-story crane that toppled, the building that was demolished. But in New Yorks tightly packed urban grid, even a calamity of such magnitude may be punctuated with sights that people find curious and strange.

title: Deadly Midwest Storms Move East
description: Heavy rains moved into the Northeast on Wednesday after inundating the Midwest, causing flooding, evacuations, washed-out roads and multiple deaths. The storms disrupted air travel in New York and Philadelphia, with arrival delays extending to three hours at Philadelphia and 90 minutes at the major New York airports by midday.

title: Sharing the Easter Basket Goodies
description: Children willing to share their Easter basket goodies with the adults in their life will probably find quite a few who keep coming back, if the basket includes the sabl cookies, below, made by Betty Bakery in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. The cookies  crisp, charming and just sweet enough ($3)  carry scenes from vintage Easter greeting cards showing romping rabbits, chicks and horses.

title: Philip Jones Griffiths, War Photojournalist, Dies at 72
description: Philip Jones Griffiths, a crusading photojournalist whose pictures of civilian casualties and suffering were among the defining images of the war in Vietnam, died Wednesday morning at his home in London. He was 72.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A television review in Weekend on Friday about John Adams, the new HBO mini-series, misidentified the disease one of the Adams children contracts. It is smallpox, not measles.

title: Poll Shows Most Palestinians Favor Violence Over Talks
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  A new poll shows that an overwhelming majority of Palestinians support the attack this month on a Jewish seminary in Jerusalem that killed eight young men, most of them teenagers, an indication of the alarming level of Israeli-Palestinian tension in recent weeks.

title: New Hampshire Cheated, Too
description: POLITICAL leaders in Michigan and elsewhere have long questioned the stranglehold Iowa and New Hampshire have on the presidential nominating process. In most election years, the candidates seem to spend more time in those two states than in all the others put together. The early states usually pick the party nominees, leaving the large majority of states with little influence in this critical national decision.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 18, 2008

title: Corrections
description: An excerpt from Dick Cavetts blog, about William F. Buckley, that was printed in Op-Extra on Sunday misidentified an editor at Time magazine who was a guest on Mr. Buckleys yacht. He was Richard M. Clurman, not Bill.

title: On Other Side of the World, Life Is Still Upside Down
description: Ying Liangs slyly subversive second feature, The Other Half, takes awhile to coalesce, but once it does, it becomes an intriguing exercise in juxtaposition. Its also a fairly assured example of how to start out droll and end up somber.

title: Neurotic Who Makes Scary World Her Banquet
description: For a brief but intense period in 2006, Patricia Pearson logged on daily to Flu Wiki. This is a Web site (fluwikie.com) devoted to the concerns  the very deep concerns  of people convinced that a worldwide outbreak of influenza is imminent, and that it will make the ravages of the Black Death seem like a mildly unpleasant interlude.

title: Construction Is Up, Inspectors Down. Guess What?
description: For nearly a year, people in East Harlem complained that an empty building at 102 East 124th Street was falling apart. They were right. In November, the owner, a developer with big plans, was told by the Buildings Department to fix up an exterior wall. He did nothing. On Jan. 11, city inspectors said the building was unsafe, and ordered immediate repairs.

title: Obama Urges U.S. to Grapple With Race Issue
description: PHILADELPHIA  Senator Barack Obama delivered a sweeping assessment of race in America on Tuesday, bluntly confronting the divisions between black and white as he sought to dispel the furor over inflammatory statements by his former pastor.

title: Villegas Is the Pride of His Nation
description: MIAMI  Camilo Villegas sat coolly at the dais Tuesday at the Doral Resort and Spa, clad in white from hat to shoes, an array of corporate logos placed just so, smiling benignly as he juggled questions in Spanish and English. He looked much like what he is: an athlete with promise, a golfer who could eventually approach the heights on the golf course that he already has scaled off it.

title: Progress in U.S.-Russia Talks
description: MOSCOW  The United States and Russia said Tuesday that they had agreed to negotiate a strategic framework document that would formally put in writing the basic elements of their relationship, but the two nations failed to end the deep division over American plans to base missile defenses in Europe.

title: Rockets Surprising Streak Runs Out of Fuel Against Celtics Star Power
description: HOUSTON  Through 22 games and 49 days of unabated success, the Houston Rockets created a new identity, basked in it and spent each day trying to make it last through one more. They rarely paused to ponder the whys and hows or where the joyride might end.

title: Dollars Fall Is No Cause for Alarm in Euro Zone
description: FRANKFURT  When the euro tiptoed above $1.30 four years ago, finance ministers from Germany, France and Austria wrung their hands about how it would hurt Europes exporters, some muttering that the United States should put its economic house in order.

title: BNP Paribas Ends Talk of Buying French Rival
description: PARIS  Shares of Socit Gnrale, the French bank buffeted by a trading loss of 4.9 billion euros ($7.2 billion), fell 7 percent on Wednesday after a rival bank, BNP Paribas, confirmed that it had no plans to try a takeover.

title: The Air Force Tanker We Should Have Had
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Obamas Profile in Courage
description: There are moments  increasingly rare in risk-abhorrent modern campaigns  when politicians are called upon to bare their fundamental beliefs. In the best of these moments, the speaker does not just salve the current political wound, but also illuminates larger, troubling issues that the nation is wrestling with.

title: Roland Arnall, Mortgage Innovator, Dies at 68
description: Roland E. Arnall, the founder of the Ameriquest Mortgage Company, which once billed itself as a sponsor of the American dream but later found itself at the center of the subprime mortgage crisis, died Monday in Los Angeles. He was 68 and lived in the Holmby Hills section of Los Angeles.

title: An Export in Solid Supply
description: These days, people really are taking coals to Newcastle.

title: Waiting (and Waiting) for the Rebate Check
description: I was immersing 12 empty bottles of Dancing Bull wine in my half-filled bathtub, trying to remove the labels without mutilating them, when I began to wonder whether applying for a rebate of $2 a bottle was worth the hassle.

title: Stalemate in Detroit: City Council Asks Mayor to Resign, but He Refuses to Go
description: DETROIT  The City Council on Tuesday asked Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick to resign in light of evidence that he had lied under oath and plotted to cover up an extramarital affair with his former chief of staff.

title: Straight Ahead, One Foot in Front of the Other
description: BERGENFIELD, N.J.  The track coach wears a vest of rigid plastic. Mounted at the shoulders, a great tangle of hardware rises to fix a metallic band in Saturnian suspension around her skull. Four long screws penetrate her scalp, locking her neck upright, chin parallel to the earth, sea blue eyes on some point in the middle distance.

title: Court Orders Freeing of Some Venezuelan Oil Assets
description: LONDON  Exxon Mobil suffered a setback in its dispute with Venezuela on Tuesday when a British court overturned an earlier ruling that froze as much as $12 billion in petroleum assets controlled by the government of President Hugo Chvez.

title: Swinging Between Optimism and Dread on Wall Street
description: Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers said Tuesday that their profits plunged  and all of Wall Street cheered.

title: Gay and Lesbian Group Gives Awards
description: Barbara Walters, right, and  60 Minutes shared the award for television news magazines at the 19th annual Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation Media Awards in New York on Monday, Reuters reported. Ms. Walters won for My Secret Self: A Story of Transgender Children, on ABCs 20/20, and 60 Minutes, on CBS, won for Dont Ask, Dont Tell, about the United States militarys policy on gay and lesbian service members. The award for outstanding film in limited release went to the Hebrew- and Arabic-language film The Bubble, about a love affair between and Israeli soldier and a Palestinian man. For the Bible Tells Me So was named outstanding documentary. Among the other honorees for coverage of gay and lesbian issues were The New York Times, GQ magazine, CNN.com and the television series Boston Legal.

title: A Meet-Up, Brought to You by Huggies
description: THE company whose tissue brand pops up one at a time, as the old ad slogan proclaimed, is popping up on a leading social networking site.

title: Obama Chooses Reconciliation Over Rancor
description: It was an extraordinary moment  the first black candidate with a good chance at becoming a presidential nominee, in a country in which racial distrust runs deep and often unspoken, embarking at a critical juncture in his campaign upon what may be the most significant public discussion of race in decades.

title: Parisians Singing From Bed to Bed
description: The Paris of Christophe Honors Love Songs (Les Chansons dAmour) belongs unmistakably to the present. Its residents talk on cellphones and drop the name of Nicolas Sarkozy (still an aspirant to the lyse Palace rather than an occupant when the movie was being shot). But they also dwell, just as noticeably, in the Paris of classic French movies  in a vague, bracing atmosphere of good old Nouvelle Vague.

title: Russia: American Executive Sought
description: Russian prosecutors are seeking the extradition from Germany of an American citizen and former executive of a business linked to the now defunct Yukos oil company. Ilya Kantselson, wanted in Russia on fraud charges, has been living in Denmark and denies any wrongdoing. He ran Volgatanker, an operator of oil tankers that serviced Yukos on Russias internal waterways. Over the years, the Russian authorities have arrested four dozen executives linked to Yukos, a company once run by a political opponent of President Vladimir V. Putin, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, who is serving an eight-year sentence in a Siberian prison. Mr. Kantselson was detained in the German state of Schleswig-Holstein late last month. Mr. Putin will step down as president in May.

title: French Trader Is Freed While Fraud Case Advances
description: PARIS  Jrme Kerviel, the former trader accused of causing more than $7 billion in losses at Socit Gnrale, left a Paris prison cell Tuesday after more than five weeks in pretrial custody.

title: In Nice, Their Home Is Their Palace
description: NICE, France

title: New Wave of Upgrades at Grand Central Shops
description: Grand Central Terminal is like a seasoned Hollywood celebrity, aging gracefully with the help of a little nip and tuck now and then, and a major face-lift only when absolutely necessary.

title: Did Obamas Speech Reach the Voters He Needs?
description: Senator Barack Obama gave his speech on race yesterday in Philadelphia. His audience was the whole country, if not the world. But its worth considering what effect the speech might have on his immediate audience in Pennsylvania, which holds the nations next primary on April 22.

title: Facing the Horrors of Distant Battlefields With a TV and Console
description: During the Vietnam War major television networks regularly broadcast real-life images of fighting in jungles, cities and swamps. Just as television was becoming this countrys dominant mass medium, Americans came to perceive through their screens at least a bit of the confusion and pain of the battlefield.

title: I Knew Gene Kelly. The President Is No Gene Kelly.
description: To the Editor:

title: Mainstay at Westchester Train Station Falls on Tracks and Is Killed
description: CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  It was a routine that Theresa Fiorentino followed for as long as anyone could remember: seven, perhaps eight steps from the newsstand to the elevator, a downward ride of about five seconds, and a minute or so smoking a cigarette along one of the concrete platforms at the Croton-Harmon train station in Westchester County.

title: Wall St. Embraces the Feds Relief Efforts
description: Buoyed by an aggressive interest rate cut, investors sent stocks soaring to their biggest gain in five years on Tuesday. Shares of financial firms surged, for a day at least, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 420 points.

title: Scientists Near Source of Altered Heparin
description: Scientists investigating a mystery contaminant in the blood thinner heparin are closing in on what they believe is a counterfeit substance, most likely made in China from animal cartilage, that was chemically altered to act like the real drug.

title: U.N. Envoy Disappointed by Myanmar Visit
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations special envoy to Myanmar told the Security Council on Tuesday that his recent trip there was his most disappointing yet since the countrys military government brutally put down protests led by monks in September.

title: 3 Nations Told to Pay $57 Million to New York
description: The governments of India, Mongolia and the Philippines owe New York City roughly $57 million in property taxes, a federal judge has ruled, closing a long chapter in the Bloomberg administrations efforts to force foreign governments to shoulder some of the costs of their presence at the United Nations.

title: Increase in Producer Prices Feeds Fear of Rising Inflation
description: Businesses paid more for gasoline, automobiles and most products last month, reinforcing fears that inflation is rising.

title: New Governor and Wife Talk of Past Affairs
description: ALBANY  In an extraordinary news conference on his first full day on the job, Gov. David A. Paterson acknowledged on Tuesday that he had had several extramarital relationships, including one with a state employee, but said he had done nothing illegal and had been faithful to his wife in recent years.

title: Asian Stocks Follow Wall Street Higher
description: Markets across Asia followed Wall Street higher on Wednesday as the Federal Reserve reduced interest rates once again. But shares in Europe were down.

title: Can We Get Back to Business, Please?
description: Hours after replacing a New York governor who resigned because of a prostitution scandal, Gov. David Paterson has confessed to extramarital affairs during his decades as a legislator in Albany. The new governor insisted Tuesday that he broke no laws, misused no campaign funds and violated no oaths of office.

title: Doggie-Bag Leftovers, Made This Time From Scratch
description: MY mother is the queen of doggie bags. I spent a mortified childhood cringing in fancy restaurants as she smiled sweetly and asked for every leftover morsel to be wrapped up.

description: Naalehu, Hawaii

title: Clintons White House Schedules Are Released
description: WASHINGTON  The National Archives and the William J. Clinton Presidential Library on Wednesday released more than 11,000 pages of Hillary Rodham Clintons public schedule for her eight years as first lady.

title: Something Fizzy for All Ages
description: Finding a nonalcoholic sparkling drink for both children and adults is not easy. Vignette Wine Country Sodas in Berkeley, Calif., has introduced a ros variety whose sweetness is restrained, but could still thrill a youngster. Its color blushes beautifully in the glass. Add a scoop of raspberry sorbet and you have dessert. The company also has a grape-y pinot noir flavor and a chardonnay that is more winey than sweet. The sodas, in 12-ounce bottles, are $35 a dozen from hellodelicious.com.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about Senator Barack Obamas mother misidentified the profession of his half-sister, Maya Soetoro-Ng. She has a Ph.D. in comparative education and works as a teacher; she is not an anthropologist.

title: Another British Invader Arrives, Guitar in Hand
description: Adele, a 19-year-old singer-songwriter from London, presented two distinct personalities on Monday night at Joes Pub. On one hand she was the self-assured performer whose debut album, 19, recently topped the British pop charts in its opening week. On the other hand she was a jittery teenager playing her first show in the United States, with a head cold.

title: The Way Out of the Financial Ditch
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Eases No Child Law as Applied to Some States
description: The Bush administration, acknowledging that the federal No Child Left Behind law is diagnosing too many public schools as failing, said Tuesday that it would relax the laws provisions for some states, allowing them to distinguish schools with a few problems from those that need major surgery.

title: For Yanks and Hokies, a Game to Remember
description: BLACKSBURG, Va.  The buses wound through the Blue Ridge Mountains, taking the Yankees from the airport in Roanoke to the heart of a campus changed forever last April. Fans cheered from the sidewalks at Virginia Tech, snapping pictures and waving. If the players looked out the windows, they could see decals of memorial ribbons on the backs of many cars.

title: A Bid to Lure Wolves With a Digital Call of the Wild
description: BOZEMAN, Mont.  The long, lonely howl of a wolf shatters the early morning stillness. But is it real? Beginning this June, it might be hard to tell, even for the wolves.

title: From the Attic, a Verdi Craves Attention
description: Verdis Ernani was a big success in 1844 and has fought an up-and-down battle for respectability ever since. Early Verdi operas, both beloved and excoriated for their blunt language and tough-guy exteriors, may be on a new upswing. The Metropolitan Opera has brought back its production after a 23-year absence, and performances began on Monday night.

title: New Yorks New Landmarks
description: Webster Hall, a 19th-century East Village assembly space where F. Scott Fitzgerald once reveled and Emma Goldman urged social change, was one of several buildings designated historic landmarks on Monday by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission. Designed by Charles Rentz and built in 1886, with an annex added in 1992, Webster Hall, a Renaissance Revival structure at 119-125 East 11th Street, is clad in red Philadelphia pressed brick with brownstone trim and red terra-cotta ornamentation. (A mansard roof was destroyed in the 1930s.) The hall, seen above in the 1910s, became famous for masquerade balls after a 1913 fund-raiser for the socialist magazine The Masses and became a hub not only for Village bohemians but also for gay men and lesbians. The artists Charles Demuth, Marcel Duchamp and Man Ray used the hall, as did F. Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald and political and labor leaders like Goldman, Samuel Gompers, Margaret Sanger and Dorothy Day. The Progressive Labor Party was established there in 1887, and the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America in 1914. In the 1950s and 60s, RCA Victor operated a studio there, where Arthur Rubinstein, Duke Ellington, Louis Armstrong, Frank Sinatra, Elvis Presley, Ray Charles, Marian Anderson and many others recorded. Webster Hall later became a rock club. Three other East Village structures also received landmark designation: the 11th Street Public Bath, at 539 East 11th Street, a Beaux-Arts structure designed by Arnold W. Brunner and completed in 1906; the Beth Hamedrash Hagadol Anshe Ungarn, at 242 East Seventh Street, a Beaux Arts synagogue built in 1908 for a congregation of Hungarian Jews; and the Elizabeth Home for Girls, at 307 East 12th Street, a High Victorian Gothic brick and sandstone structure built in 1892 for use by the Childrens Aid Society.

title: Switzerland: Chocolatiers Profit Rises
description: Lindt & Spruengli, the oldest Swiss chocolate maker, said profit rose 20 percent in 2007 on stronger sales of higher-priced dark chocolate confections. Net income climbed to 250.5 million Swiss francs ($255 million) from 209 million francs in 2006, the company said. Thanks to numerous innovations and targeted marketing activities, the group outpaced the growth of the overall chocolate market and gained substantial new market share, the company said. Lindt, based in Kilchberg, said in January that sales increased 14 percent, to 2.95 billion francs, last year.

title: The Worst Spam Ever
description: OK, now Im really, really annoyed.

title: HD DVD Owners, Some Stores Want to Make Amends
description: When a line of consumer electronics is curtailed, its often the retailer that gets the blame for pushing that piece of junk in the first place.

title: Fifty Percent
Arthur C. Clarke
description: Arthur C. Clarke,  best known for his novel "2001: A Space Odyssey," died in his adopted home of Sri Lanka at age 90.

title: World Club Top 10: The Red Wings in Free Fall
description: The European leagues are well into their playoffs, but the NHL still has almost three weeks to go. Thats bad news to the Detroit Red Wings, for whom the regular season cant end soon enough. The Wings have gone just 6-0-2-10 (.370 winning percentage) over the last six weeks, and theyve dropped in the world ranking as well, all the way down to fifth.

title: Recipes of the Day: Sticky Toffee Pudding, and Orange Glaze
description: Todays Minimalist column (and video) is about a very wet cake; to me, sticky toffee pudding is the epitome of same. Not everyone loves this sweet, gooey dessert, but you can count me as someone who does. If youre in my camp, you have to try this easy-to-make version from my friend the English chef John Burton Race (who appears on my public television show, The Best Recipes in the World).

title: Philip Jones Griffiths
description: Images taken by the war photographer who died on March 19.

title: Two Survive. Now, to Choose
description: WHEN I set out to sample more than a dozen of the most promising new restaurants around the country, I knew that Id have some special meals, and I suspected that Id want to pack up a few of the restaurants and bring them back to New York.

description: From the Department of Comic Relief: Stephen Colbert is headed back out on the campaign trail.

description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

title: Fremont to Delay Payments to Creditors
description: Former sub-prime mortgage lender Fremont General said Tuesday that it was trying to restructure some of its debt and would delay making a $6.6 million payment during the negotiations.

title: New Charge Against Ex-KPMG Partner
description: Federal prosecutors overseeing a big tax shelter case involving former employees of the KPMG accounting firm brought a separate charge Tuesday against one of the defendants in that case.

title: CardioNet Cuts I.P.O.
description: CardioNet, a health care technology start-up which Citigroup is taking public on Wednesday, cut the number of shares it allocated in half and lowered the price after several big shareholders backed out of the offering.

title: V.C.s Fund Advanced Power Projects
description: Advanced Power Projects, a new start-up that promises to make new and existing power plants run more reliably and produce less greenhouse gas emissions, has raised an undisclosed amount of funding by Bay Partners, Sequoia Capital and Redpoint Ventures.

title: Colonial Backs Dubais $2.98 Billion Bid
description: Investment Corporation of Dubais 1.95 billion euro ($2.98 billion) plan to break up troubled Spanish property group Inmobiliaria Colonial edged closer to completion Tuesday, after the Spanish real estate companys board backed the arrangement.

title: Canadas Sherritt Bids for Thermal Coal Producer
description: Spurred on by booming commodity prices and unfazed by financial market turmoil, Canadas fast-growing Sherritt International has unveiled a 704 million Canadian dollar ($708 million) stock-and-cash bid for full control of the countrys largest thermal coal producer.

title: Luminus Drops TransAlta Proxy Battle
description: Luminus Management dropped its high-profile push to get TransAlta to load up on debt to fund stock buybacks on Tuesday, saying it is encouraged by the Canadian power generators recent moves to boost its share value.

title: Some Delta Investors Said to Push for Deal Despite Unions
description: Amid reports that pilots at Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines appear to have given up efforts to combine their seniority lists  considered essential to the two carriers hopes for a merger without crippling rancor  industry observers and analysts are wondering: What next?

title: Private-Equity Lawyers a Hot Commodity for Chicago Firms
description: Lawyers who specialize in private-equity deals remain in hot demand despite the cooling off in leveraged buyouts.

title: Alibaba Said to Shop Yahoo Stake to Avoid Micorosfts Grasp
description: Chinas Alibaba Group is seeking investors to buy the 39 percent stake in the Internet company held by Yahoo, according to Reuters, outlining a plan that could stop Microsoft from getting the Alibaba stock.

title: Industry Giants Try to Break Computings Dead End
description: Intel and Microsoft said Tuesday that they planned to finance two groups of university researchers to start over and design a new generation of computing systems intended to break the industry out of a technological cul-de-sac that threatens to end decades of performance increases in computers.

title: BNP Paribas Rules Out Socit Gnrale Bid
description: BNP Paribas, Frances biggest listed bank, said on Wednesday that it has decided not to pursue a possible tie-up with rival Socit Gnrale, which has been hit by a trading scandal.

title: Web 2.0 Funding Set Record in 2007
description: Funding of so-called Web 2.0 companies in the United States reached a record $1.34 billion last year, up 88 percent over 2006, according to a report from Dow Jones VentureSource. But there was some sobering news in the report as well: The rate of deal growth slowed, and a single company, Facebook, accounted for 22 percent of the total.

title: Whither Bears I.P.O.s?
description: One of the question marks hanging over the remains Bear Stearns is what will become of the banks underwriting commitments. The Deal.coms Dealscape blog notes that Bear has a sizable stable of upcoming deals.

title: Hedge Funds in Distressed Debt Rush
description: More than 70 hedge funds  including those run by Blackstone Group and Goldman Sachs  are rushing into the melee to snap up distressed mortgages and securities from banks battered by the subprime meltdown, according to Bloomberg News.

title: A Crash Course on the Credit Crisis
description: The current financial crisis has been going on for seven months now, and many people probably feel as if they should understand it. But, says The Nw York Times David Leonhardt, they dont, not really. And, he says, the confusion is shared by many people who are in the middle of the crisis.

title: Frenzy During McCain Photo-Op
description: JERUSALEM  Pandemonium broke out here Wednesday when Senator John McCain made the traditional pilgrimage to the Western Wall.

description: Buoyed by an aggressive interest rate cut, investors sent stocks soaring to their biggest gain in five years on Tuesday. Shares of financial firms surged, for a day at least, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 420 points.

title: In Bowing to Funds, Did the Times Actually Win?
description: Two activist hedge funds that had been preparing to mount a proxy battle with The New York Times Company were declaring victory Monday, when the newspaper publisher agreed to support two of their rival board nominees at next months annual meeting.

title: S.E.C. Eyes Bear Stearns Comments
description: After the stunning collapse of Bear Stearns, many unhappy investors are directing their anger toward Alan Schwartz, who became the firms chief executive just a few months ago. Much of the criticism is aimed at some reassuring comments that he made last Wednesday on CNBC  see the video below  in which he said that the firms liquidity position was strong and described a $17 billion liquidity cushion that had virtually been unchanged from the end of the year.

title: Visas I.P.O. Is a Welcome Tonic for Wall St.
description: In a boon for big banks and Wall Street, Visa, the credit card giant, went public Tuesday in the largest initial public offering in American history.

title: Yahoo Decides to Release a Rosy Forecast
description: Yahoo has released a rosy outlook for the next two years, hoping to give investors a better understanding of why the company is not willing to sell itself to Microsoft for less than $45 billion.

title: Back to 1988 on CO2, Says NASAs Hansen
description: James E. Hansen, the NASA climate scientist who has long had a habit of pushing past where many colleagues dare go in describing the risks posed by global warming, has done it again.

title: Wireless Spectrum Auction Raises $19 Billion
description: The government announced on Tuesday that it had closed the most lucrative government auction in history as wireless companies bid more than $19 billion for the rights to radio spectrum licenses.

title: Profits Fall at Morgan Stanley, but Top Estimates
description: Morgan Stanley reported $1.55 billion in profit for its first quarter on Wednesday, dragged down by $2.3 billion in write-downs but still well above expectations.

title: Bears Stock Becomes a Battlefield
description: Only days after the fire sale of Bear Stearns stunned Wall Street, a battle seems to be brewing in the markets over the fate of the troubled investment bank and the controversial deal that JPMorgan and federal authorities devised to save it.

title: Quattrone Returns to Roots With New Venture
description: News that Frank P. Quattrone, the former star investment banker whose career was derailed by a four-year fight against obstruction of justice charges, will be launching the Qatalyst Group, a technology-focused merchant banking group based in San Francisco, put an end to one of Silicon Valleys favorite parlor games: guessing what Mr. Quattrone might do next.

title: The Early Word: Clinton Documents to Be Released
description: The National Archives is set to release thousands of pages of records from Hillary Rodham Clintons days in the White House as First Lady, including speeches, logs of visitors and other details.

title: Liquidity trap watch
description: With all the furor over the possibility of a high-speed financial meltdown, its been easy to forget that we still have the problem of a weak real economy, and a Fed that is having a hard time getting traction.

title: In Albany, a Desire to Move On From Scandal
description: Gov. David A. Patersons extraordinary disclosure that he has had extramarital affairs over several years, including with a state employee, made front-page news in The Times and other newspapers today. In Albany, leaders of the Legislature seemed to agree that it was time to move on and get back to the business of governing  a reflection, perhaps, of the good will toward Mr. Paterson in Albany, in sharp contrast to the animosity his predecessor, Eliot Spitzer, had engendered.Some lingering questions remain. Mr. Paterson insisted that no state funds were used in conducting the affairs, and said he would not knowingly use campaign money for any personal purpose. But he suggested that he might have used a campaign credit card for personal expenses when his did not work. It is illegal to spend campaign money for personal use, although by quickly making a reimbursement, a candidate would most likely avoid any penalties. (See related blog post.)

title: Last Night in Bullet Points
description: Media days for the auto show begin Wednesday, but the parties started Tuesday night. Increasingly, the New York auto show is where automakers are throwing their most lavish soirees.   • The hip-hop artist Common played live at the Sirius studios, across the street from Radio City Music Hall, to promote the partnership between Sirius Satellite Radio and Lincoln cars.  • A Ford spokesman said that the partnership was a sign that Lincoln is redefining the brand. He's right. Years ago, they probably would have signed Kenny G.  • Mark Fields gave the intro speech, which he closed by saying, "Common will be kicking it live!" I think he was trying to be ironic.  • Common arrived sans huge posse or entourage. He was wearing matching shirt and scarf, crisp jeans and shoes that were the color of Timberland work boots. Everything looked fresh and new. He looked like a Gap ad.  • Since the performance was broadcast live on Sirius, it started on time and the musicians played inside a small Plexiglas room, like Magneto's jail cell at the end of "X-Men." There were two layers of Plexi and several of us on the outside wondered if he could hear us clapping. There were two tall towers of speakers for us to hear him, but there didn't seem to be any speakers into the Plexi cube, which also made for terrible photography.  (Photo: Common, right, with Tony Touch, a radio personality. (Photograph by Richard Chang for The New York Times))   • At the same time, Sheryl Crow (of Fleetwood Mac?) played at the Mercedes-Benz party, called the House of Bluetec because it was publicizing the company's series of diesel vehicles. Ms. Crow has become a vocal advocate of environmenal causes, to the point of engaging Karl Rove in a well-publicized confrontation last year at the White House correspondents' dinner, and in the course of her performance she repeatedly lauded her hosts and urged them to develop a Bluetec bus for her touring needs. We'll have more on that later...  • In keeping with the blue/blues/Bluetec theme, waiters circulated with trays of blue drinks, including a medicinal-tasting blueberry vodka concoction that Ms. Crow likened to urea, the secret ingredient that cleanses the emissions of Bluetec engines.   • After a spirited set of mostly familiar songs, Ms. Crow closed her set with "Everyday Is a Winding Road." Yes, the same song used as background music in the Subaru commercials.  • Other celebrities circulated in the House of Bluetec crowd, we were told, but the only one we instantly recognized was Christian Siriano, the androgynous enfant terrible who recently emerged victorious in the "Project Runway" fashion designer-reality show. He was not drinking blue cocktails but he looked, well, FIERCE.  (Photo: Sheryl Crow at the House of Bluetec. (Photograph by Jerry Garrett for The New York Times))   • Ford was giving rides around Manhattan in the Flex, which comes out in June. The one I rode to the Saab party at the IAC building along the West Side Highway had a fridge and freezer built into the second row seat armrest. If I had grown up rich, the Flex fridge probably would've sparked memories of my childhood limo. But I grew up upper middle class (at least that's what my parents told me) and I suddenly thought about the big plastic cooler that we took on road trips and my mom stuffed with sandwiches and grapes.  • The Flex was also equipped with Ford's next-generation navigation system, which has an amazing voice recognition system. It could hear me from the back seat. I asked the Ford public relations rep if it could locate restaurants near where we were and he said, "I'm hungry," and a list of restaurants popped up on the screen. That's when I realized that I needed a navigation system for my life.  • Saab closed out the night with a party at the IAC building that was still going when I left around midnight.  (Photo: Saab is showing its 9-X BioHybrid Concept at the New York show. (Photograph by Richard Chang for The New York Times))   • There was a brief fashion show to reveal a line of "eco clothing" created by Swedish designer Josefin Lassbo.  • Everything in the collection was made of 100 percent Bio-cotton, which is a real classification. You can find the collection at Saab Expressions Web site.  • The show lasted about seven minutes.  Related:  Times Topics: New York Auto Show

title: Aspersions and Arguments
description: Leon Wieseltier is a fixture of American cultural life. He has been the literary editor of The New Republic for 25 years, written numerous noteworthy articles, including reviews for The Book Review, palled around with writers like Maureen Dowd, even made a brief appearance in an episode of The Sopranos. (For all his accomplishments, I suspect its this last that is most envied by his friends and acquaintances.) Wieseltier has always enjoyed a good literary brawl, most famously perhaps, with his long takedown years ago of the work and career of Cornel West. One of the pieces he did for The Book Review began This scummy little book. Wieseltier knows how to spew vitriol, and the smoke that rises from the page can be fun for readers to inhale.
