title: The Leaning Landmark of Broadway
description: Talk about endangered landmarks.

title: City Room: The Leaning Landmark of Broadway
description: The expansive cast-iron facades of 287 Broadway seen from the north. The building was designated a landmark in 1989. Enlarge this image. (Photo: David W. Dunlap/The New York Times) See a Slide Show  Talk about endangered landmarks.   The elegant cast-iron building at 287 Broadway, which "graphically illustrates the transformation of lower Broadway in the 19th century from a residential boulevard into the citys commercial center" (as the Landmarks Preservation Commission put it), is leaning about eight inches to the south.   This month, steel shoring is being erected against its south facade to replace the timber bracing that has been in place since late last year. The entire six-story building was vacated Nov. 29 by order of the Department of Buildings, leaving the Pizza Cafe, at the corner of Reade Street, with Christmas holiday decorations still hanging.   "Our engineers feel strongly that 287 Broadway is stable and can be salvaged," said Kate Lindquist, press secretary at the buildings agency. But for the moment, there is no saying when.    That has left the buildings tenants in limbo, uncompensated and uncertain when they can return home or resume business.   "They all know who did it," said David Jaroslawicz, the lawyer for the Yenem Corporation, proprietors of the Pizza Cafe. "Theres no secret here. But nobodys stepped up to the plate to say: 'Wed like to take care of the tenants and the commercial space. And were sorry."'   The "who," Mr. Jaroslawicz said, is the John Buck Company of Chicago, a large development concern that is planning a 20-story condominium apartment building called 57 Reade Street, which will form an L shape around the landmark. It was designed by SLCE Architects.   "I do not intend to comment," Greg Merdinger, a principal in the John Buck Company, said by e-mail. "My goal is to simply finish construction of the building."  As the story goes, however, 287 Broadway was already leaning about four inches when excavation for 57 Reade Street began last spring, as permitted by the city. During excavation, monitors attached to the landmark recorded up to four more inches of movement. The city was notified. A vacate order was issued.   Timber shoring, required by the city, was designed by Richard Herschlag, whom the city identified as the developers engineer. It was built by Hunter Atlantic Inc., which the city said was also responsible for the new steel shoring.   "To safely rescind the vacate order, the remedial work on the foundation of 287 Broadway must be underway," Ms. Lindquist said. "The developers engineer is working to find a way to perform the remedial work on the foundation. We expect the engineer will submit a plan for review within the month. At that time, we can better assess when the vacate order can be safely rescinded."  The saga has attracted coverage in The Tribeca Trib and amNewYork and has drawn comments on the Curbed and Lost City blogs, among others.   Mr. Jaroslawicz said the situation pointed to the need for an insurance or bonding mechanism by which owners who were deprived of their businesses by construction accidents could be quickly compensated, rather than waiting years for the courts to straighten things out  as will almost certainly be the case at 287 Broadway.   "The general contractor is going to blame the underpinning subcontractor, whos going to blame the plant overseer, whos going to blame the guy operating the backhoe, whos going to blame the guy operating the crane," he said. "And all the lawyers are going to have a feeding frenzy for the next couple of years."   There is something curiously appropriate about this, since 287 Broadway has been home to numerous lawyers offices since its completion in 1872. John B. Snook, a leading architect of the day (the original Grand Central was his work), designed the structure for the estate of Stephen Storm, combining Italianate and French Second Empire styles.   "The prestige of the building was indicated both by the mansard roof and an early Otis passenger elevator," the landmarks commission said in its 1989 designation report. It added, "Above the first story, the exterior of 287 Broadway looks much as it did in 1872." This includes a 96-foot-long facade on Reade Street with 52 enormous arched windows, six of them set in monumental dormers.   Antoine Scott, a street vendor on Broadway, has been watching the structural drama from his table full of socks, hats and gloves. "Im just hoping that doesnt fall down when Im working here," he said. "Thats what Im talking about."   Mr. Jaroslawicz did not sound too confident about the fate of the "leaning tower of pizza," as he calls it. "Dont breathe too heavily," he cautioned. "It might collapse."  But city officials sound confident that 287 can and will be saved. "Absolutely," said John Weiss, deputy counsel of the Landmarks Preservation Commission.   "Unless it was determined by the Department of Buildings that there was an immediate danger to public safety and the building had to be taken down right away," Mr. Weiss continued, "a permit would have to be obtained from Landmarks for demolition.   "It would be fair to say that the chance would be infinitesimal that the landmarks commission would authorize demolition of that landmark."

If the underwriters exercise their option to sell extra Visa stock (and given Wednesdays gains, they probably will), the $44-per-share offering could end up raising $19.7 billion, before the deals considerable fees and commissions.

title: Buicks Y-Job, the First Dream Car
description: (Photo: Buick Y-Job on display at Cipriani on Tuesday night. (Photograph by Norman Mayersohn for The New York Times))   The stars of any auto show -- the vehicles we remember years later -- are invariably the wild design exercises that demonstrate what the studios can do when unconstrained by any need to actually sell a product.  Credit for the concept of concept cars is generally given to Harley J. Earl, the legendary General Motors design chief who created the Buick Y-Job in 1938. A sleek black two-seater with prominent "speed lines" running down the fenders, the Y-Job pioneered many styling features that are still seen today, tricks like hidden headlights and a metal hatch cover for the folded convertible top.   (Photo:  (Photograph by Norman Mayersohn for The New York Times))   Though I had seen many vintage photos of the car, I saw it in person for the first time on Tuesday, at a press program Buick held in Manhattan to talk about its design lineage. Looking at the long, low shape parked inside the cavernous Cipriani banquet hall across from Grand Central on 42nd Street, it was easy to see why the Y-Job was so influential. It is a powerful statement, and it previewed many design themes that Buick used for years.  But perhaps the best thing about the car was its original condition. It is beautiful, but not perfect. Small pits in the chrome trim and wrinkles in the seat leather confirm that this car actually saw some service. That earned points from me -- it's a lot more authentic than modern concept cars that are sometimes little more than clay models dressed for their stage debuts.  Related:  Full Coverage: New York Auto Show

title: Commodity prices (wonkish)

Others argue that were witnessing a commodity bubble. These are, of course, not mutually exclusive  we could have a situation in which low rates started the upward movement, and investors, extrapolating, magnified the rise beyond what the low rates themselves can justify.

Fred R. Conrad, a photographer for The New York Times, is creating a series of structural still lifes that will appear every Wednesday for the next three months.

description: The free-falling Islanders just announced that goaltender Rick DiPietro will undergo surgery on his right hip later today and will be out for the rest of the season, leaving Wade Dubielewicz to sweep up again. Following Tuesdays 3-1 loss to Toronto, the Islanders are in 13th place in the Eastern Conference, 11 points behind eighth-place Philadelphia with eight games to play. I dont think Im the only person who doubts Dubie will be magically able to hoist the Islanders into the playoffs, as he did at the end of last season.

title: Driving Mitsubishis Future
description: (Photo: Mitsubishi plans to start selling the i-MiEV electric vehicle in Japan next year.)   On Tuesday, I spent an hour driving the Mitsubishi i-MiEV, an electric vehicle based on its Japan-only i city car. The i is a kei car, a specific classification of cars that is required to be of a certain size and engine displacement.  Yes, Mitsubishi has an electric car.  Yes, it's supposed to go on sale in 2009 in Japan. Moreover, Mitsubishi is expected to announce on Thursday that it will provide a fleet of EVs to an agency on the West Coast this year.  Unlike most driving events held during the New York auto show, my drive in the i-MiEV was without minder, in the best sense. There was no predetermined route and no one to tell me to take things slow and stay on the straight and smooth highway.  I drove the car to Brooklyn. The i-MiEV runs on an electric motor that's placed above the rear axle (the conventional i also has a rear-midship engine). The lithium-ion batteries are under the rear seats, fore of the engine. Range is 80 to 100 miles.  (Photo: The i-MiEV is recharged by plugging into household outlets.)   There are lots of benefits for having the motor back there, Maurice Durand, a Mitsubishi spokesman, told me. One of them is that it has allowed Mitsubishi to narrow the frame in the front, which gives the front wheels serious steering angle and improves turning radius.  Earlier in the day, I spent about 30 minutes in the standard i, which is powered by a 660cc 3-cylinder engine. The i-MiEV accelerates just as well, if not a bit better. On F.D.R. Drive, I took the car up to 110 kilometers an hour (around 68 miles an hour) and passed a cube truck or two. Mr. Durand said the car can hit 85.  Because of their short wheelbase, kei cars have always been known for offering fluffball rides. But Mitsubishi has maximized the length dimensions of the class, and the i-MiEV has a particularly long wheelbase for its size. If the wheels on the i-MiEV were pushed toward the edges any further, they'd be off the car. As a result, the i-MiEV felt stable on both the highway and the tattered streets of downtown Manhattan and Brooklyn; just stay away from cobblestones.  In Brooklyn, a man named Moishe asked, "Why can't we have this car now?"   After I explained that it was still in the testing phase, he asked, "Yeah, but why can't we have it now?"  As I considered my response, he added, "You know, with gas prices getting so expensive."  Moishe wasn't the only enthusiastic observer. A postman offered to trade car keys. "I can really use something like this," he said. A woman commented on the interior size. "It looks small on the outside, but inside it's like a Toyota."  The interior of the i-MiEV, which is in fleets in Japan, looks almost exactly like the standard i, which has enough space for four adults. Even the dashboard looks standard, which is an oddity in the world of hybrid vehicles. There's no colorful electric bar to let you know what the electric motor is doing or that the battery is recharging.  Like many gas-electric hybrids on the road, the i-MiEV has a regenerative braking system, which means the battery recharges under braking. And this does affect brake feel -- slight pulses can be felt underfoot. Charging the battery can also be done by plugging into a 110- or 220-volt outlet. Charge time is 7-14 hours. In Japan, the i-MiEV can be quick-charged in 30 minutes by plugging into a special outlet.  By the time I looped back to the Mitsubishi's temporary headquarters at Chelsea Piers, I had been on the road for a little more than an hour. I had used up approximately half of the charge. Not bad, but Mr. Durand said that Mitsubishi is targeting a range of 160 miles, which will make it more effective for commuters.  Related:  Full Coverage: New York Auto Show

title: Rates Go Up for Con Ed Power Delivery
description: Residents of New York City will see the biggest one-time rise in their bills for electric service next month, after state regulators approved a $425 million increase in rates for Con Edison on Wednesday.

title: Hounded by Iraqi Musclemen, a Journalist Awaited His Own Liberation
description: At the outset, for me, the approach of American troops to Baghdad was an issue of intense personal concern, as much as professional. The Army and Marine units that arrived at the outskirts of Baghdad in the first days of April 2003 were viewed, then, by an overwhelming majority of Iraqis as liberators from the tyranny of Saddam Hussein. But they were my liberators, too.

description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: Opinion: Nudge Me When the Whistle Blows
description: You know what doesnt make me more excited about the N.C.A.A. tournament? The overload of tournament information that Im certain plenty of you adore. You will assert that, thanks to the talk shows and radio programs and selection specials and blog breakdowns and handicapping Web sites, you have never been more pumped for the Big Dance, which you have to admit is kind of a lame nickname for an event that already has a great one.

title: Clinton Praises Petraeus
description: CHARLESTON, W.V.  As critical as she is about the Bush administrations conduct of the Iraq war, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton gave a relatively rare shout-out to the militarys top man in Baghdad, General David Petraeus, calling him an extraordinary leader and a wonderful advocate for our military.

title: Cornell Gets Ready for a Long Trip
description: Monday, the last day of preparation for our trip to the West Coast (known by many as the Best Coast), was hectic. The N.C.A.A. seeding committee bestowed upon our team the gift of the longest trip to a first-round site out of any team (2,306 miles from Ithaca, N.Y., to Anaheim, Calif.). Im not exactly complaining, since my home in West Los Angeles is a 45-minute drive from the Honda Center where we are playing, not factoring in the customary L.A. traffic.

title: Delta Pilots Reject Arbitration in Union Dispute
description: Delta Air Lines pilots union rejected Wednesday the idea of submitting to arbitration with its counterpart at Northwest Airlines to break their impasse over integrating seniority lists as part of a possible combination of the carriers.

description: The knitting and protesting grannies were not to be deterred.

title: E*Trade President to Resign
description: E*Trade Financial, an online brokerage struggling with heavy mortgage losses, on Wednesday said R. Jarrett Lilien plans to resign as president and chief operating officer, less than three weeks after Donald Layton filled the vacant chief executive post.

title: Diary Notes From the Invasion: Sandstorms, Bodies and Burning Tanks
description: (Photo: A sandstorm halted a truck from First Marine Division outside Nasariya in March 2003. (Photo: James Hill for The New York Times. More photographs))  March 25, 2003: Leaving the Euphrates, the road north loses its asphalt and becomes sand. Along the route are more Bedouin either asking for handouts of food or to change dinars for dollars. One soldier exchanged a packet of cigarettes for a 250-dinar bill. When one of his colleagues saw he had a bill with a portrait of Saddam Hussein, he demanded, Why dya want to get a bill with that [expletive] on it?  Suddenly a huge sandstorm has blown up and we can barely see a few feet in front of us. The convoy just stops, swallowed in a yellow haze. The men all put on their goggles, scarves, and sheltered as best they could. In one truck a marine was resolutely eating a pack of Skittles in the teeth of the storm.  The sands drift by as we sit in the car doing nothing. The straps hum and flap, making sounds like an indigenous instrument. The car rocks constantly, such is the strength of the wind. We wait, which I have now realized is a military specialty, though it is hard not to be unhappy, disoriented from losing sight of our surroundings. The weather feels like a much more potent enemy than the Iraqi Army and we feel swallowed by it.  (Photo: A line of Humvees passed a palm grove in Baghdad in April 2003. (Photo: James Hill for The New York Times))  March 26: The sandstorm was still blowing this morning, but a shadow of its former self. We hooked up with another convoy heading north, pushing almost 100 kilometers forward. Our new camp for the night had been the site of an ambush by Iraqi forces on a Marine convoy just ahead of us, and two dead soldiers lay on the side of the road, one face down in the mud, the other staring at the sky as convoy after convoy of military vehicles moved by. I counted at least 15 bodies, and there were many prisoners, nearly all badly dressed and without shoes. An amber fog still hung over them as they huddled in a barbed-wire pen.  One of the seriously wounded had been shot in the head by his officer for refusing to fight. Many other soldiers claimed they had been press-ganged into service and that their families were being kept by forces loyal to Saddam. In all they looked a miserable bunch and hardly a match for these marines.  The American Marine doctor was caring for them and evacuated some out by helicopter. He denied Americans were being moved first. The most serious went first, he said, irrespective of nationality.  (Photo: Marine vehicles drove past a dead Iraqi soldier outside Nasariya in March 2003. (Photo: James Hill for The New York Times))  April 2: We drove through the night, no easy task since everyone has night-vision goggles except us. Awaking early this morning I see two Iraqis being questioned by the side of the road as an enormous convoy of armored vehicles stretched into the distance.  It turned out they were two men who had been caught in the firefight for the Saddam Canal the night before, and a friend of theirs, who had stood up wearing a red bandana to see what was going on, was unsurprisingly killed.  A Marine major went with them to help retrieve the body, which was lying by the bridge. Together they put it into two black plastic bags and then carried it to the Iraqis car. Only the body was too big and by now too stiff to fit in the car. The three of them stood there like cheap Mafia hit men wondering how to dispose of the body. Eventually they managed to squeeze it in and the Iraqis drove away, saying thank you to the major, and meaning it, even though it was the Americans who had killed their friend. The major said sorry and meant it. Such is the perversity of war.  On the front the Americans have pushed a long way today. At dusk, on the Tigris, marines were in rubber boats securing the far bank as engineers were constructing pontoon bridges. A tank captain parked near the river, Ted Card, was moaning that the Iraqis were cowards. My men keep asking me, he told me, When are we going to see some action?. Meanwhile we are now in M.O.P.P. 2 [Measures of Personal Protection], which means we have to wear vast rubber overboots on our feet that make them feel like fish in an oven.  April 7: Immediately after waking up we heard on the radio about a large incursion by the Third Infantry Division into the center of the city. The final phase has begun.  Today they (and we mercifully) went to M.O.P.P. 0, which means we can all take off our chemical suits, which have protected us psychologically but otherwise made us do nothing but sweat.  Changing into trousers, even dirty ones, feels like a great luxury.  Putting them on though I can feel how much weight I have lost in the last few weeks. Anxiety is obviously a terrific hunger suppressant.  The Fifth Battalion of First Marines, with whom we are camped, seems to in no hurry to go anywhere, so we decide to swing back west to find the Seventh Marines.  At this point the embedded/unilateral issue doesnt seem to matter. We arrive at a military column in a GMC Yukon and its Welcome to the war.  The battalion is waiting to cross a bridge over the Diyala River.  On the other bank it is already Baghdad. We stay 500 meters from the bridge while the sounds of battle thunder ahead. It is very hard to understand how much is Iraqi fire. After about three hours there is silence.  Dexter, using his full New York Times muscle, persuades the colonel of the battalion to let us across before any of the other journalists. The Iraqis had tried to blow the bridge but failed. On the right there are the charred remains of T-55 tanks and the bodies of a few badly dressed soldiers. A fire at an oil depot rages on a bit further down the road.  As dusk falls we end up proceeding with an armored column into an abandoned area. Turning into an unknown street, just ahead of us a truck filled with ammunition is ablaze, spitting out bullets, which we can avoid only by attempting to shield behind a large armored vehicle. It is plain idiocy what we are doing, and both Dexter and I know it. But we go ahead nonetheless even though our bravery turns out to be a mistake. Suddenly we find ourselves at the head of the advance and only three tanks between us and the Iraqis. The colonel of the battalion finds us and screams at us, sending us back to the bridge. So we double back, passing the burning truck and through a mine field cleared a few hours before.  Greeting us at the bridge is a horde of flies buzzing lazily from the rotting corpses nearby and a thick oily haze from the nearby depot whose angry flames light up the nearby sky.  April 8: I slept fitfully through the night, waking up constantly from the tarry smoke and in the morning light found a flattened dog only a few meters from my head.

title: Virtual Fence Losing Backers
description: The virtual fence, a system of cameras and radars searching for illegal border crossers, once seemed like a pragmatic improvement to far-flung agents and physical fences. But its backers have grown increasingly wary, and a critical report from the Government Accountability Office released last month appears to be acting as a catalyst in the debate over future funding.

title: Nice Folks: On the Right Track?
description: What an encouraging piece of news to arrive on Wednesday, the day that nice folks everywhere begin questioning whether their altruism is for naught: Harvard study finds that nice guys do finish first.

description: What I wrote as the war began.

description: The big question on the mind of liberals gathered at the Take Back America conference in Washington was: Will we be able to put our differences aside, get our act together and actually win at the polls?

description: Mere words cannot describe this one.

title: Lutz Leaves the Bunny Ears at Home
description: Put away the eggs and the baskets. Send the bunny outfit to the cleaners. General Motors has put off Easter till July.  Last fall, Bob Lutz, the outspoken product czar at General Motors, promised that G.M. would have a significant announcement about the battery technology for its Volt plug-in electric car around the time of the New York auto show. Responding to what he perceived as a putdown of G.M.'s technology by Toyota engineers (a perception not shared by some of the journalists who were present at the Toyota briefing in Japan where the comments were supposedly made), Mr. Lutz issued this challenge:  Lets wait for the Easter Bunny. Somebodys going to have egg on their face. And I dont like having egg on my face. The implicit message was that G.M. would come to the New York show, which opens Easter weekend, with a demonstration of the extended battery range of the Volt. Mr. Lutz has promised to have the Volt on the market (perhaps with a different name, and certainly with a revised, more aerodynamic look) by the end of 2010.  But G.M. ended up at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center with an Easter basket bereft of newfangled batteries, at least for public demonstration. In an interview, Mr. Lutz grumbled that Easter (and the New York show) fell exceptionally early this year. "We could have done the vehicle by Easter, but we didn't have the power electronics ready," he said, explaining that the messages being sent from the controls (like the accelerator) were not yet being processed quickly enough and translated into performance. "The effect would be lousy acceleration," he added.  Now, he said, a July demonstration seems more likely, of cars that will have the essential Volt powertrain in last-generation Malibu bodies. (The design of the production model is not finished.)   The overall Volt development program is on track, Mr. Lutz said, citing both the powertrain engineering and the vehicle's design, which are proceeding on parallel fast tracks in isolated facilities at the G.M. Design Center in Warren, Mich.   While externally, the Volt's lithium-ion batteries have been viewed as the biggest hurdle to production, "up to this point we have no reason to believe that's a stumbling block," Mr. Lutz said. He added that the design had passed computer simulations for crash worthiness, but that real-world testing remained to be done.  The goal remains a range of 40 miles on battery power alone, with a small gasoline engine kicking in after that to recharge the batteries. The batteries need to last 10 years, he said.  And once they do die, how much would it cost to replace them? While declining to be specific, Mr. Lutz said the price tag would be "more than several thousand dollars, but less than $10,000."  Related:  Full Coverage: New York Auto Show   Slide Show: Highlights From Day One

description: CNBC interviews Daniel Mudd, chief executive of Fannie Mae, on its expansion of funds and lending authority for home mortgages.

title: State Police Superintendent Steps Down
description: Remember Preston L. Felton? Mr. Felton, the acting superintendent of the New York State Police, was briefly in the public spotlight last year during the problems over the Spitzer administrations use of State Police records against Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader of the State Senate. Today, Mr. Felton announced his retirement.

title: Home Cooking, Far From Home
description: In the beginning of January 2006, Id been in country six weeks and I was almost completely mad. It was my fifth trip since 2002, and I had very few photographs. It was almost impossible to leave the bureau house in Baghdad, and while I was at the house I was depressed, trying to get out on an embed or a story. Thats when Franco decided to teach me how to make gnocchi.

title: Homeboy Industries
description: A small business makes a big impact in the lives of former gang members.

title: Verizon Details Its Open Wireless Plans
description: Verizon Wirelesss top executives were out in full force at the companys first open development conference for mobile phone makers and programmers held at the Millennium Broadway hotel near Times Square. It was the first step in an initiative Verizon began last fall in an effort to open up its network to entrepreneurs interested in creating devices and mobile applications not sold through the companys retail stores.

title: Making Your Picks at 5,280 Feet
description: It is decided. Im going to choose the winners from the Denver site based on nothing but elevation. Whichever university hails from the highest altitude probably can handle Denvers mile-high elevation the best, right?

title: Campaign Conversations
description: John Harwood of The Times and CNBC talks to John McCain's campaign manager, Rick Davis.

title: Emerging From the Shadows of Tragedy and Scandal
description: Considering all of the calamities the Baylor mens basketball program has gone through in the past five years, it is quite a sight to see the Bears with an at-large bid in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Law & Order Faces a Libel Case
description: Updated, March 21 | In the criminal justice system of televisions Law & Order, the plots are inspired by two separate, yet equally important, groups: the television writers who craft the intricate if sometimes convoluted episodes, and the real-life characters who inspire those writers. This is one of their stories.

title: Market Fears That Merrills Lawsuit Signals More Write-Downs
description: Does Merrill Lynchs lawsuit against a unit of the bond insurer Security Capital Assurance presage another series of write-downs at the securities firm?

title: Poll: Racism More of Problem Than Sexism
description: Americans think racism is a more serious problem than sexism in the United States today. In a CBS News poll taken last weekend, a plurality of Americans, 42 percent said racism was a more serious problem for the country compared to 10 percent who said sexism was the more serious problem. Twenty-three percent said neither racism nor sexism was a problem for the country and another 23 percent volunteered that the problems were equally serious for the nation.

title: The Biggest Threats to the Top Seeds
description: The Quad looks at the strengths and weaknesses of the top seeds in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: From Another Time, Another Country
description: Not long ago, in Beirut, I met an Iraqi, a broken-looking old man with warm brown eyes.

title: Team Chemistry: A Balancing Act
description: After dealing with the Kelvin Sampson saga, can Indiana rally around Coach Dan Dakich and make a run in N.C.A.A. tournament?

title: More Sorrow (and Losses) for Meriwether
description: The fates of finance, it seems, do not look kindly upon John W. Meriwether.

title: Michigan Missives
description: Yet another 11th-hour appeal for a primary rerun to be held in Michigan. On the same day that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton added a Michigan stop to her schedule to push for that state to hold another Democratic contest, some of her biggest donors and most high-profile supporters promised to act as guarantors to deposit up to $12 million to pay for another go-around.

title: Missing the Big Story, but Not the Story
description: When news of the invasion came, I was disappointed in a way that only journalists away from a big story can be.

title: Wisconsin Center Will Have Better Seat This Year
description: OMAHA  Thirteen months ago, the Wisconsin big man Brian Butch found YouTube fame of the worst kind, thanks to grotesquely dislocating his right elbow in a game against Ohio State. The gruesome video generated more than 130,000 hits. Butch said Wednesday that he tried watching it once, after the season, but never made it all the way through.

description:
Juan Cole of Informed Comment, left, and Steve Clemons of The Washington Note discuss what kind of American foreign policy radical Muslims prefer.

title: Unhappy Billionaire Prepares to Act on Bear Deal
description: Bear Stearns shareholders are understandably furious about the investment banks sale to JPMorgan Chase for about $2 a share. Now one of the largest of them is warning that he intends to try and stop it.

title: Did Obamas Speech Reach the Voters He Needs?
description: In her Web column today, Katharine Q. Seelye writes, Senator Barack Obamas campaign often says it needs to introduce Mr. Obama to Pennsylvania, which is another way of saying that voters there dont know him. The campaign clearly made a decision that the benefits of introducing him with a high-profile speech assessing the nuances of race in 21st-century America were worth the potential risks. Go to Column

title: Cows Grazing in the Rumpus Room
description: O.K., the planet is officially out of (or back in?) alignment: American farmers are making money hand over fist while the hedge fund guys are wishing theyd put a little more cash under the mattress. Corn growers in the United States can no longer keep pace with the staggering global demand for the raw material of corn syrup and ethanol and so, seemingly out of nowhere, theres a demand for more farmland.

title: Road Trip: Winthrop to Denver, Through Prairie Dog Town
description: A year ago, when tiny Winthrop of Rock Hill, S.C., earned its near-annual spot in the N.C.A.A. tournament, two reporters from the local paper, The Herald, covered the team from the road. Literally.

description: Antiwar protesters converged in demonstrations across the country to mark the fifth anniversary of the U.S. invasion of Iraq.

description: In the debate about prostitution that has unfolded on this blog and elsewhere, one of the thorniest issues has been those women who are not obviously coerced and participate in the high-priced call girl services. After I wrote about the topic, a reader named Basil Hero sent this story about one such woman:

title: Your Comments on my Obama Column
description: My Thursday column is about Barack Obama, his speech about race, and Jeremiah Wright. Id welcome your comments in particular about the gulf between white and black perceptions. It seems to me that the furor that erupted over Wright is attributable in part to the shock from a lot of whites listening in, almost for the first time, on an intra-black conversation. That shock makes me think that its all the more important to have the discussion about race that Obama started.

title: Emptying the Notebook from Wednesdays Game
description: John Maine is a superstitious sort. He had yet to add his car to the list to be shipped north out of fear that he would not make the team. He did not sign up last year, even though he was, by all accounts, a lock to make the rotation. But he has finally relented. Maybe his 15 wins in 2007 convinced him.

title: Bad news for Trump and Becks; Good news for Versace estate
description: Instead of insights from geeky analysts and numbers-crunching economists, it might be more efficient to use celebrities as a barometer of market trends. Recent reports on the status of some big-name related properties speak volumes about values in their neighborhoods:

description: Robin Lopez, a 7-foot center from Stanford, was discussing Cornell, the Cardinals opponent Thursday in the first round of the N.C.A.A. mens tournament.

title: The Time for Neitzel Is Nigh
description: If Michigan State expects to make a deep run into the tournament, it needs the senior guard Drew Neitzel to be more selfish.

description: New York Times photographer Dith Pran survived the Cambodian killing fields.  He dedicated his life to telling the story of the Khmer Rouge's genocide.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. How can I improve the view from my windows, which look out onto a brick wall?

title: A Day After a Big Rally, a Big Pullback
description: In a sign of continuing unease in the financial markets, commodity prices plummeted and the Dow Jones industrials slid back nearly 300 points on Wednesday, a day after an interest rate cut fueled the best stock session in five years.

title: A Global Sweep on a Tiny Budget
description: WHEN Suchitra Van and Nette Gaastra sent out invitations for their October, 2005, wedding, they wrote on them No gifts. What they meant was: no toasters, no blenders, no coffeepots.

title: Officially Spring
description: For some reason, the look of the woods and pastures now  just at the turning point of spring  make me think of the Civil War. Perhaps its the matted leaves and the flattened grass or the hoof-torn earth where the horses make a habit of standing. Perhaps its simply that the woods look winter-beaten, skeletal, though theyre really no more so than they were in November. The snow withdraws and leaves behind the feeling of something that shouldnt be seen, not yet. I dont know why I imagine a ghostly landscape  the fields overhung with the smoke of campfires and the weary presence of Union and Confederate soldiers  but I do.

title: Bush Defends Iraq War in Speech
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush used the fifth anniversary of the start of the war in Iraq on Wednesday to make the case for persevering in a conflict that could have many more anniversaries. Democrats accused him of lacking a strategy to win and withdraw.

title: So You Want to Be a Blogging Star?
description: MARK CUBAN, the owner of the Dallas Mavericks, has a full plate. Besides his basketball team, the busy billionaire also owns part of a media company, and serves as chairman of the TV channel HDNet. He recently competed for five weeks on Dancing With the Stars on ABC. How on earth does he find time to blog?

title: China Wont Alter Olympic Torch Path
description: BEIJING  Despite violent protests in Tibet, China remains steadfast in its plan to take the Olympic torch to Tibet and to Mount Everest, officials in the Beijing Olympics organizing committee said Wednesday.

title: A Push to Limit the Tracking of Web Surfers Clicks
description: AFTER reading about how Internet companies like Google, Microsoft and Yahoo collect information about people online and use it for targeted advertising, one New York assemblyman said there ought to be a law.

title: Corrections: On the Other End of the Line, Discipline
description: An article on March 6 about the growing popularity of wellness coaches misstated the credentials of one coach, Dr. Julie Desch. She is a certified personal trainer, not a certified athletic trainer. Certified athletic trainers must have, among other requirements, a bachelors or masters degree in athletic training. Although Dr. Desch does have a medical degree, certified personal trainers do not need higher education in the health sciences.

title: Clinton Facing Narrower Path to Nomination
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton needs three breaks to wrest the Democratic presidential nomination from Senator Barack Obama in the view of her advisers.

title: Camcorder Brings Zen to the Shoot
description: Well, this is a little embarrassing. One of the most significant electronics products of the year slipped into the market, became a mega-hit, changed its industry -- and I haven't reviewed it yet.

title: Japan Games Almost Stuck on Tarmac
description: Who said there wouldnt be another baseball strike?

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Sunday about James P. Kennelly, the developer of the Manhattan building where a construction crane toppled, killing seven people, misidentified the school from which he earned his law degree. It is New York Law School, not New York University Law School.

title: Idaho Turns to Chess as Education Strategy
description: Once a week, Deborah McCoy, a third-grade teacher in Donnelly, Idaho, unpacks chessboards and pieces and spends an hour teaching her 20 students how to play the game.

title: Pope Urges Restraint by Both Sides in Tibetan Violence
description: ROME  Pope Benedict XVI appealed Wednesday for an end to the violence in Tibet and neighboring areas in China, saying that the government and Tibetan protesters must choose a road of dialogue and tolerance.

title: Yankees Chamberlain Goes Back to Bullpen
description: BRADENTON, Fla.  The Yankees were so ravaged by injuries last spring that they used 11 starting pitchers before Memorial Day. Taking no chances this time, they prepared Joba Chamberlain as a starter in case injury struck again.

title: Obama Works to Shift Campaign Back to Domestic Issues
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Senator Barack Obama on Wednesday tried to steer his campaign from a focus on race that had threatened to envelop his candidacy and back to the economy, war and a host of other concerns.

title: Federal Investigations Yield Indictments in Mt. Vernon
description: Federal investigations into the Mount Vernon, N.Y., city government culminated in two sets of mail fraud and conspiracy indictments on Wednesday. One case alleged fraud of more than $1.5 million by the former planning commissioner, and the other accused trash haulers of overcharging the city $1.25 million.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Saturday about Chiara Lubich, founder of the Focolare movement, referred imprecisely to the status of another movement, Opus Dei, within the Roman Catholic Church. It is a personal prelature, governed by a bishop; it is not outside the ecclesiastical structure. The obituary also gave the outdated anglicization of the name of her birthplace. It is Trento, not Trent.

title: City Police Force Could Soon Be Smallest Since 90s
description: Facing budget woes and a recruiting crisis, the New York Police Department is poised to shrink to its smallest size in about 15 years, a reality reflected in a plan by the Bloomberg administration to trim funds for 1,000 police officer positions this year.

title: Major Bank Cuts Bonuses of Executives
description: The compensation committee at Bank of America has reduced the bonuses of the banks top executives, according to a proxy statement filed Wednesday.

title: A Company Promises the Deepest Data Mining Yet
description: Amid debate over how much data companies like Google and Yahoo should gather about people who surf the Web, one new company is drawing attention  and controversy  by boasting that it will collect the most complete information of all.

title: Greece: Walkouts Paralyze Country
description: Millions of Greeks in a broad range of professions walked off work, bringing the country to a standstill to protest sweeping pension changes proposed by the government. The walkout capped nearly a month of widespread labor unrest that has resulted in rolling power blackouts, heaps of uncollected garbage and transportation chaos. Tourists bound for Greece faced travel delays as flights were canceled, and public services and schools remained shut, with hospitals treating emergency cases only. The 400-page pension reform bill  meant to address anticipated strains on state finances caused by the fastest-aging population in the European Union  aims to raise the retirement age of working mothers to 55 from 50 and to encourage most employees to work past the current blanket retirement age of 65. The bill is due for a vote in Parliament on Thursday.

title: Iraqi Council Ends Objection to Election Law
description: BAGHDAD  A member of Iraqs Presidency Council, whose objections had blocked a law calling for provincial elections by October, withdrew his objections on Wednesday in a sudden turnaround that raised hopes for long-sought political progress.

title: Credit Suisse Expects to Post a Loss
description: PARIS  Credit Suisse, the Swiss banking giant, said Thursday that it expected to post its first quarterly loss since 2003 because of large write-downs and losses related to intentional misconduct at its trading desk.

title: Disgraced to Embraced: Georgia Makes a Big Comeback
description: WASHINGTON  When Dennis Felton took over as the mens basketball coach at Georgia five years ago, the Bulldogs scandal-ridden program could be summed up with one simple question.

title: Subtleties in the Language Made It Murder, or Not
description: For the Brooklyn prosecutors trying Cesar Rodriguez in the beating death of his 7-year-old stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown, a plea deal was not an option.

title: Stuff of Life (but Not Life Itself) Is Detected on a Distant Planet
description: Astronomers reported on Wednesday that they had made the first detection of an organic molecule in the atmosphere of a planet outside our solar system and had confirmed the presence of water there. The discovery, of methane, clears the way for a bright future of inspecting the galaxy for livable planets, for the chemical stuff of life or even for life itself.

title: A Black Cat, Catching an Elusive Audience
description: At a recent Wednesday night performance of the all-black Broadway production of Tennessee Williamss Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, Ramona Scott, 52, ran into a couple shed worked for as a baby sitter almost 40 years ago. She saw another couple who had been friends of hers during the 1970s. Cat was where everybody seemed to be.

title: Two Who Believe Fashion Is More Than Flash
description: LIKE a telephone number, 6267 can easily be remembered. Its the name of a relatively new Italian label, and maybe its a good thing that the designers Roberto Rimondi and Tommaso Aquilano chose something as impersonal as a number because they are more technicians than creators.

title: G.I.s Death Prompts 2 Inquiries of Iraq Electrocutions
description: WASHINGTON  On Jan. 2, Staff Sgt. Ryan D. Maseth, a 24-year-old Green Beret from Pennsylvania, stepped into a shower at his base in the Radwaniyah Palace Complex in Baghdad and was electrocuted. Now, two months later, his death has resulted in both a Congressional investigation and a Pentagon inspector generals inquiry into similar cases.

title: Just Tell Us Whom You Want to Win
description: Imagine an election that pits Candidates A, B and C against one another. There are 10,000 voters. Candidate A is the clear favorite of 9,999 of them. But Candidate A is nonetheless defeated. How is it possible for Candidate B to beat the other two?

title: At the Window, Lace Thats Old (and New)
description: Coopers Cottage Lace, a company in Amherst, Mass., recently introduced its first collection of updated Arts and Crafts-style curtains. Hunter Rose, below, one of six new designs, was adapted by Dard Hunter III from an original pattern by his grandfather, Dard Hunter, a designer who created books, furniture and pottery for Roycroft, an early 20th century Arts and Crafts community. His grandfather designed the pattern in 1908, for the cover of a magazine called The Fra, which was published by the Roycrofters, Mr. Hunter said, and is stylized in the squared-off, geometric manner that was so popular then. The curtains are sold as single panels, measuring 20 to 47 inches wide and 54 to 72 inches long, and ranging in price from $49 to $179. Information: (866) 579-5223 or www.cottagelace.com.

title: Citigroup to Cut 2,000 More Jobs
description: Citigroup plans to lay off another 2,000 investment bankers and traders before the end of the month, people close to the situation said on Wednesday.

title: Bush Defends Iraq War in Speech
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush used the fifth anniversary of the start of the war in Iraq on Wednesday to make the case for persevering in a conflict that will in all likelihood have many more anniversaries.

title: Con Ed Wins Approval for a Big One-Time Increase in Rates for Electric Service
description: Residents of New York City will see the biggest one-time increase in their bills for electric service next month, after state regulators approved a $425 million increase in rates for Consolidated Edison on Wednesday.

title: South Africa: Utility Seeks Big Price Increase
description: Still reeling from severe power shortages that struck the country in January, Eskom, the state-controlled utility, has asked regulators for a stunning 60 percent increase in the price of electricity, citing higher energy costs and what it called demand-side management. Economists say the private sector has been unwilling to invest heavily in power generation because the price of electricity was too low to generate profits. After public hearings, the regulators will decide how much of a price increase to grant.

title: France: Insurgency Recruitment Trial Begins
description: Six Frenchmen and one Algerian went on trial in Paris, accused of recruiting fighters to join the insurgency in Iraq. The seven, who were arrested at several locations in Paris in 2005, face prison sentences of up to 10 years for criminal association in a terrorist enterprise if found guilty. Prosecutors accuse the principal defendant, Farid Benyettou, 26, who followed the Salafist fundamentalist interpretation of Islam, of leading a cell that recruited fighters from among worshipers at the Addawa Mosque in northern Paris and organized their transfer to Iraq via Syria and Egypt. The trial is set to run about one week, with the verdict to come at a later date.

title: Light and Space Where Fire Alarms Once Rang
description: Rumford, R.I.

title: Setting the Stage, Offstage
description: URSULA the sea witch idolizes Leona Helmsley, Jerry Falwell and Gloria Swanson, which is why their pictures are part of a collage hanging in Sherie Rene Scotts dressing room at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater. Like many stage actors, Ms. Scott, who plays Ursula in the Disney play The Little Mermaid, uses her dressing room to get herself in the mood of her character. Unlike most Broadway actors, however, Ms. Scott has scored a dressing room the size of a Manhattan one-bedroom, and it comes with features: French doors opening onto the street and a pink bathtub (put there for Elizabeth Taylor in 1983, when she was in Private Lives).

title: Governors Gone Wild, the Rest of Us at a Loss
description: At first, the distinctions seemed clear: One governor broke the law, the other cheated on his wife (and she, apparently, had cheated on him). One offered a short apology, the other answered every question that was asked.

title: More Arts in the Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: The Heart of a Prancing Horse
description: Introduced Tuesday: Maserati GranTurismo S 4.7.

title: A Virtual Theater in a Laptop Thats Big and Blue
description: To most, blue conjures up sadness and jazzy riffs on a far-off saxophone. To Acer, the color is a new way to brand its large laptop computers with more media features than an oligarchs home theater system.

title: Heparin Find May Point to Chinese Counterfeiting
description: Federal drug regulators, in announcing Wednesday that the mystery contaminant in heparin was an inexpensive, unapproved ingredient altered to mimic the real thing, moved closer to concluding that Americans might be the latest victims of lethal Chinese drug counterfeiting.

title: Clicking, at Last, on Dont Print
description: WITH this column, I am relearning how to write.

title: New Orleans Grows; Florida Cools
description: New Orleans is slowly beginning to rebound from the severe population losses inflicted by Hurricane Katrina, according to new census data, but growth in a number of previous hot spots slowed in the 12-month period that ended July 1, 2007. Broward County in Florida, which includes Fort Lauderdale, lost population for the first time.

title: For Clarke, Issues of Faith, but Tackled Scientifically
description: Absolutely no religious rites of any kind, relating to any religious faith, should be associated with my funeral were the instructions left by Arthur C. Clarke, who died on Wednesday at the age of 90. This may not have surprised anyone who knew that this science-fiction writer, fabulist, fantasist and deep-sea diver had long seen religion as a symptom of humanitys infancy, something to be outgrown and overcome.

title: British Memoirist Is Denied U.S. Entry
description: Sebastian Horsley, a British author who has written an eyebrow-raising memoir detailing a life of rampant drug use and voluminous encounters with prostitutes, was turned back at Newark Liberty International Airport on Tuesday as he tried to enter the United States for a book party and New York news media tour.

title: Parking Rules for Holy Thursday
description: Because of Holy Thursday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: For Cornell, a Connection Was Made in the Hospital
description: The sun had barely risen above the skyline on a frigid winter morning when Wanda Foote looked around the waiting room at Arnot Ogden Medical Center in Elmira, N.Y., and saw the Cornell mens basketball team.

title: This Took Place Back Then, but It Sounds a Lot Like Now
description: It hardly matters whether Michael Murphy deliberately planted Barack Obama moments in The Conscientious Objector. This play about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.s decision to oppose the war in Vietnam is fraught with contemporary resonance, as a charismatic black man takes a stand against a white president who is stubbornly continuing an unpopular war. Marveling at the news that the recently appointed secretary of defense claims to be shocked at the lack of a war plan, Dr. King says, I mean, has it ever looked like there was a plan?

title: Wagon Lust or Bust
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2009 Audi A4 Avant

title: Prominent Lawyer to Plead Guilty
description: The prominent lawyer Melvyn I. Weiss of the Milberg Weiss law firm, a prolific filer of lawsuits against publicly held corporations, has reached a plea agreement with federal prosecutors in Los Angeles, according to his defense lawyer.

title: Youthful African Envoys of Continuing Traditions
description: The 21 young performers in the lively Spirit of Uganda, a music and dance revue that opened on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, are from a country where, according to the program, 2.4 million children have lost their parents to AIDS, civil war and poverty. Now on a national tour that ends May 1, these Ugandans are performing to raise money for Empower African Children, a Dallas organization that is producing the tour and handled events by the revues predecessor, the Children of Uganda.

title: Footnote
description: Regis Philbin, Martin Short, Charles Grodin and Paul Shaffer will present an evening of comedy and music at Studio 54 on April 14. The proceeds will go to veterans returning from Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Japans Central Bank Is Without Governor, a Blow to a Nations Prestige
description: TOKYO  The top post at Japans central bank now sits empty after a political standoff in Parliament blocked selection of a successor to the departing governor, whose five-year term ended Wednesday.

title: Just a Hotel? For Some, Its an Adventure
description: Correction Appended

title: With Minimal Movement, a Musical Trek Through Time
description: The inventive new-music ensemble Counter)induction called its Tuesday-night program at Merkin Concert Hall Fast Forward: Composers at the Edge. But although the on the edge part was indisputable, the players might as accurately have called their program Rewind.

title: With Beat, Introvert Clears Path to Hope
description: John Darnielle, the songwriter and sometimes sole member of the Mountain Goats, used words like trope and theory when he spoke between songs at Webster Hall on Tuesday night. Mr. Darnielle, who lives in Durham, N.C., is a literary thinker, and the recordings that the Mountain Goats have been releasing since 1991 have revolved around their lyrics: autobiography, travelogues, couple chronicles and character studies.

title: In Mosul, New Test of Iraqi Army
description: MOSUL, Iraq  After the Iraqi Army increased patrols in this northern city earlier this year, Col. Haji al-Zibari found himself chasing two insurgents in a weapons-laden truck.

title: Clooney Movie Heads to Kentucky
description: George Clooney will screen his new movie Leatherheads in Maysville, Ky., on Monday, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Clooneys father, Nick, said that the actor will visit this northern Kentucky town, which is approximately 16 miles east of Augusta, Ky., where the star grew up. Nick Clooney and George Clooneys aunt, Rosemary, were born in Maysville, and the town holds special significance for the family: its where Rosemary Clooneys movie The Stars Are Singing was given its premiere in 1953. The Times reported Wednesday that Greenville, S.C., where the movie was filmed, will have its own premiere, probably without Mr. Clooney and the cast. More than 400 extras from the Greenville area are in the film.

title: A Little Off the Top
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2008 BMW M3 convertible

title: Russia: Raid at Joint Oil Venture
description: Investigators took documents from the headquarters of BPs joint venture here, TNK-BP, which has had rocky relations with the Kremlin. The Russian ministry of interior is investigating a criminal case related to Sidanko, an oil company that merged with TNK-BP when BP bought into the venture in 2003, according to Irina V. Dudukina, a spokeswoman for the ministrys investigative committee. A spokeswoman for TNK-BP declined to comment. The venture is important for BP, based in London, because it accounts for about a quarter of the companys total production worldwide.

title: Judge Rules That Suit Against Law & Order Creator May Continue
description: In the criminal justice system of televisions Law & Order, the plots are derived from two separate yet equally important groups: the television writers who shape the intricate episodes, and the real-life characters who inspire those writers. This is one of their stories.

title: Living at the Limit of Front-Drive
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2009 Nissan Maxima

title: Three Perspectives on the New Governor
description: To the Editor:

title: Countering the Drug Salesmen
description: A potentially useful antidote to drug company influence over the prescribing practices of doctors is under consideration in Congress. The idea is to have government-funded health professionals visit doctors to give unbiased guidance on the safety and effectiveness of drugs to counter the one-sided sales pitches they get from pharmaceutical company representatives. The end result should be better care, quite often at lower cost.

title: Dismal Year Is Forecast for Car Sales
description: DETROIT  The American auto industry is bracing for what may be its worst year in a decade.

title: At Bear Stearns, Meet the New Boss
description: James Dimon tramped through the rain on Wednesday evening and strode into the headquarters of Bear Stearns, the embattled investment bank he hopes to buy for a mere $2 a share.

title: Finalists Announced for Magazine Awards
description: The New Yorker leads the list of 128 finalists with 12 nominations for the 43rd annual National Magazine Awards. Marlene Kahan, executive director of the American Society of Magazine Editors, made the announcement on Wednesday. The 2008 awards, known as the Ellies, had a record-setting 1,964 entries from 333 print and online magazines, the society said. Twenty-five winners will be announced at a gala on May 1 at Jazz at Lincoln Center in Manhattan. Other publications with multiple nominations include New York, Vanity Fair, National Geographic, GQ and The Atlantic; first-time finalists include Babble, Bloomberg Markets, Budget Travel, Chow, Cond Nast Portfolio, Domino, Good, The New York Times Magazine, Paste, Play: The New York Times Sports Magazine, Radar and T: The New York Times Style Magazine.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Tuesday about Ola Brunkert, a former drummer for the Swedish band Abba, using information from the Spanish police, misstated his age. (The headline did so as well.) Mr. Brunkert, who died at his home on the Spanish island Mallorca, was 61, not 62.

title: Figure in Sean Bell Shooting Disputes Detectives Version
description: A central figure in an encounter that took place moments before the shooting of Sean Bell testified on Wednesday that he did not argue with Mr. Bell outside a club and never heard anyone threaten to get a gun, contradicting the version of events given by the three detectives who are on trial in the killing of Mr. Bell.

title: In Tibetan Areas, Parallel Worlds Now Collide
description: GABU VILLAGE, China  For farmers whose lives in this traditionally Tibetan area revolve around its Buddhist temple, an aluminum smelter that belches gray smoke in the distance is less a symbol of material progress than a daily reminder of Chinese disregard.

title: Court Details Opposition to Bias in Jury Selection
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court, ruling that a Louisiana prosecutor had used improper tactics to pick an all-white jury for a black defendants murder trial, on Wednesday overturned the conviction of a man who has been on death row for 12 years.

title: Small Businesses Offer Alternatives to Gang Life
description: IN Los Angeles, a corporation that runs several small businesses is demonstrating that the training and discipline of working in a small company can make a big contribution to changing the lives of former gang members.

title: Mets Still Waiting on Snchez
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Ask Duaner Snchez if he thinks he will be ready for opening day, and he is unequivocal in his response.

title: Apartment Complex Official Accused of Taking $1 Million
description: The controller of one of Harlems best-known apartment complexes has been accused of stealing more than $1 million from the buildings management company and spending the money on furs, jewelry, leased cars and restaurant meals for herself, her family and her friends.

title: What to Ask About Lupus
description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening  and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: Political Fight in Poland Hits Home for Gay Pair
description: Brendan Fay, a well-known gay activist in New York, has found himself, however improbably, a symbol in a political struggle in Poland over equal rights for gay men and lesbians that could affect the nations integration into the European Union and the balance of political power in Warsaw.

title: Sundance Channel Up for Sale
description: The Sundance Channel, a joint venture of NBC Universal, the CBS Corporation and the actor and director Robert Redford, is up for sale, a media analyst said Wednesday. Sundance, a 12-year-old cable channel currently accessible to 26 million homes, is seeking more than $400 million, according to the analyst, Richard Greenfield of Pali Research. A spokeswoman for the channel declined to comment in an e-mail message. If neither NBC nor CBS decide to take full ownership, Mr. Greenfield said, Cablevision, Time Warner and Viacom could be interested. Some cable customers receive Sundance as part of a digital channel package; others must subscribe separately. The Sundance Channel promotes itself as independent-minded and shows films, documentaries and original programming. It operates separately from the Sundance Film Festival but seeks a similar audience. Its programs include Iconoclasts, in which two famous people interview each other, and the environmentally oriented series The Green. Rather than running standard commercials, the channel has allowed marketers to sponsor specific programs.

title: Bears News Is Bad News on the 6:13
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y.

title: Pocket Media Player Aims to Leave Cash in Your Pocket
description: Its not easy being No. 2 when No. 1 is Apples line of iPod music and video players. SanDisk, which holds that slot, is aiming its new Sansa Fuze player squarely at the iPod Nano. The Fuze is competing mainly on price.

title: McCain Visits Israeli Town That Rockets Often Strike
description: SDEROT, Israel  Senator John McCain stood in the shattered kitchen of Aliza and Pinhas Amars house here Wednesday and looked up at what should have been the ceiling. Instead, sunlight streamed through a gaping hole caused by a Qassam rocket fired from nearby Gaza that tore off part of the orange-tiled roof in December.

title: Ivan Dixon, Actor in Hogans Heroes, Dies at 76
description: Ivan Dixon, an actor and director who was best known for playing Sgt. James Kinchloe on the 1960s sitcom Hogans Heroes but whose films included vivid portrayals of black struggles in the American South and insurrectionist inclinations in the North, died on Sunday in Charlotte, N.C. He was 76 and lived in Charlotte.

title: Comfortable Together, but Still Negotiating the Details
description: Chamber music presentations tend to fit one of two broad categories: offerings by dedicated ensembles or ad hoc groupings of diverse players seeking common ground. The Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio has it both ways in its series at the 92nd Street Y, adding the novelty provided by guests to its own well-seasoned chemistry.

title: A New Line of Upholstered Furniture
description: David Weeks may be best known for his spare, Calder-esque chandeliers and lamps, but he is also an accomplished furniture designer. That aspect of his work can be seen on April 3, when his first line of upholstered furniture is introduced at Ralph Pucci International in Manhattan. Sculpt, a collection inspired by the peaks and slopes of topographical maps and Barbara Hepworths stone sculptures, includes an armchair ($6,720), a sectional (not priced), a 10-foot sofa ($15,000) and an 8-foot sofa, above ($12,300). Each piece has a stainless steel frame gently cradling an asymmetrical seat and scooped backrest, shapes that Mr. Weeks said he developed in prototype by hacking away at huge foam blocks without the aid of a ruler, trusting his eye to create visual balance. Sculpt will be available, along with Sarus, Mr. Weekss new line of lighting, at Ralph Pucci International, 44 West 18th Street, (212) 633-0452.

title: Lupus and the Patient-Doctor Team
description: Dr. Jill Buyon, professor of medicine at New York University School of Medicine and founder of the Lupus Clinic at the Hospital for Joint Diseases in Manhattan, has managed more than 1,000 cases of lupus in her career of more than 20 years. There are themes that apply to lupus, but no hard and fast rules, she said of the chronic and unpredictable illness. Lupus has many, many faces, and in general the only single thread that ties the symptoms and signs together is the bodys production of antibodies to itself. Here are five practical measures she says apply to everyone with the disorder.

title: A Break for Freddie and Fannie
description: WASHINGTON  With the blessing of the Bush administration, the regulator of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the nations two largest mortgage finance companies, eased a major restriction on the companies on Wednesday in an effort to unfreeze credit markets and stabilize housing prices.

title: Afghanistans New Deal
description: BAN KI-MOON, secretary general of the United Nations, has appointed a seasoned Norwegian diplomat, Kai Eide, as his special representative to Afghanistan. Mr. Eides success will depend not only on his skills, but also on the friends of Afghanistan at the United Nations providing him with the proper mission, mandate and resources.

title: Snowbasins Upgrade
description: When the 2002 Winter Olympics were awarded to Salt Lake City in 1995, Snowbasin ski resort reaped some of the benefits, as an influx of money went into new buildings and a new lift system. Now, the ski area, located 33 miles northeast of Salt Lake City, has over-the-top facilities to match the over-the-top terrain, The Times reports today. "Unlike other resorts that have lavish on-mountain amenities by so-so skiing, Snowbasin's expert terrain is on par with higher-profile areas like Taos or Crested Butte," the article says. "Real skiers come here, not just people who like to dine or shop against a steep and snowy backdrop."

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about the discovery of the bodies of three more victims of a construction crane accident in Manhattan misstated, in some copies, the given name of the victim from South Florida found in the rubble of a town house at 305 East 50th Street. The victim, who was visiting a friend in New York, was Odin Torres, not Olida.

title: Newly Released
description: Based on this months new titles, the publishing industry clearly has love or, to be honest, its corollary  sex  on its mind. Most of the selections give prominent play to the libidinous side of life, in terms that are sometimes disturbing, sometimes passionate and sometimes, well, commercial. If that last sounds familiar these days, so be it.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about the discovery of the bodies of three more victims of a construction crane accident in Manhattan misstated, in some copies, the given name of the victim from South Florida found in the rubble of a town house at 305 East 50th Street. The victim, who was visiting a friend in New York, was Odin Torres, not Olida. (Go to Article)

title: Britain: Cadbury Sets Terms of Spinoff
description: Cadbury Schweppes, the candy maker, has set the terms of its soda units planned spinoff. Cadbury said that shareholders would receive 64 shares of the Cadbury confectionery unit and 12 shares of the Dr Pepper Snapple Group for every 100 Cadbury Schweppes shares they hold when the split occurs in May. The company has said stock in Dr Pepper Snapple should start trading on May 7, in line with its plan to complete the spinoff by the end of the second quarter.

title: How the Grinch Stole March Madness
description: The N.C.A.A. Tournament is one of the few events that brings together sports fans of every stripe. But since we're feeling ornery and contrarian today -- like Dick Vitale before his first 15 cups of coffee -- we thought we'd weigh in on the downside. So here are five things we are rooting against:

title: In California, Eclecticism Rules
description: CA Boom, the Southern California design trade show, was held March 14 to 16 at the Barker Hangar in Santa Monica, above. The show, now in its fifth year, is known for its eclecticism: In addition to the usual furniture, building materials and kitchen and bath exhibitors, there are lectures, home tours and exhibitions.

title: Eh Tu, Taos?
description: Can we now call it official, that snowboarding's transgressive days are over? Even at Taos Ski Valley in New Mexico, the most famous skiers-only holdout in the country, the slopes were opened to shredders yesterday.

title: Selected Studies: Lupus
description: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Witness Intimidation Is Issue in Newark Murder Trial
description: NEWARK  When she talked to detectives back in September, the 20-year-old woman said her boyfriend, now on trial on murder charges, had threatened to kill her if she talked to the police.

title: 'Transformers' Star Fails to Appear in Court
description: A $1,000 bench warrant was issued for the actor Shia LaBeouf on Tuesday after he failed to appear in court on a charge of unlawful smoking, The Associated Press reported. According to the warrant, which did not contain details of the location of the offense, Mr. LaBeouf, 21, the star of the forthcoming Indiana Jones movie and the blockbuster hit Transformers, was cited last month. He was scheduled to appear in a Los Angeles County court Tuesday on the misdemeanor offense, but neither he nor his lawyer showed up, according to court documents.

title: Rick Ross Scores a Second No. 1
description: The Miami rapper Rick Ross, who made it big two years ago with a hit ring tone (Hustlin), has scored his second No. 1 on the Billboard album chart with Trilla (Slip-N-Slide/Def Jam), left. Nielsen SoundScan reported that it sold 198,000 copies in the United States, significantly more than Snoop Doggs Ego Trippin, (Geffen), which moved 137,000, bowing at No. 3. The pop compilation series Now Thats What I Call Music, usually a blockbuster, had notably slow sales for its 27th volume. It moved 169,000 copies to reach No. 2, the lowest opening-week sales for the series since its first volume 10 years ago. Other Top 10 debuts this week include Fat Joes Elephant in the Room (Terror Squad/Imperial), at No. 6, and Miley Cyruss Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: The Best of Both Worlds Concert (Disney), at No. 10.

title: High Design, Marked Down
description: CITE, a furniture store in SoHo, is holding a floor sample sale to make room for new merchandise. Starting Thursday, everything will be discounted 50 to 70 percent. A Vladimir Kagan swivel chair, upholstered in beige synthetic suede, will be $1,287.50 (reduced from $2,575); a two-door cupboard in zebra wood will be $3,350 (reduced from $6,700). The Relaxer rocking chair, covered in leather, will be $1,247 (reduced from $2,495); a queen-size lacquered wood bed frame by Cecchini, right, will be $2,987 (reduced from $5,975). Sofas and lighting fixtures will be marked down, too. Through March 31 at 131 Greene Street (Houston Street), (212) 431-7272.

title: Mission Still Not Accomplished
description: It has been five years since the United States invaded Iraq and the world watched in horror as what seemed like a swift victory by modern soldiers and 21st-century weapons became a nightmare of spiraling violence, sectarian warfare, insurgency, roadside bombings and ghastly executions. Iraqs economy was destroyed, and Americas reputation was shredded in the torture rooms of Abu Ghraib, Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, and the Central Intelligence Agencys secret prisons.

title: An Inappropriate Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Tristan and the Furious Stage
description: A smooth-running production of Tristan und Isolde  devoid of illness, injury, cancellation or insufficient singing in key roles  would be somehow unauthentic. We dont get them often anyway and certainly havent had one at the Metropolitan Opera the last few weeks.

title: Outrage at Cartoons Still Tests the Danes
description: AARHUS, Denmark  I think this is safe house No. 5, Kurt Westergaard said the other day, and it was clear that he genuinely had lost track.

title: Beyond Americas Original Sin
description: There are things you come to believe and things you carry in your blood. In my case, having spent part of my childhood in apartheid South Africa, I bear my measure of shame.

title: Stuff of Life (but Not Life Itself) Is Detected on a Distant Planet
description: Astronomers reported Wednesday that they had made the first detection of an organic molecule, methane, in the atmosphere of a planet outside our solar system and had confirmed the presence of water there, clearing the way for a bright future of inspecting the galaxy for livable planets, for the chemical stuff of life, or even for life itself.

title: Thousands Protest Budget Cuts Aimed at City Schools
description: Thousands of parents, students, teachers and administrators rallied in front of City Hall in late afternoon rain Wednesday, denouncing budget cuts to the Education Department and demanding that the state and the city fulfill pledges they made last year to drastically increase spending for the public schools.

title: Tongues Are Wagging Over Shoes
description: BECAUSE everyone is talking so openly about sex these days, there should be no shame, in these pages, in discussing a few pairs of shoes.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A brief report in the Off the Menu column in the Dining section on Wednesday about the opening of the restaurant Duane Park misstated its phone number. It is (212) 732-5555.

title: 11,000 Long-Awaited Pages of Clintons Schedules as First Lady Are Released
description: WASHINGTON  The National Archives and the William J. Clinton Presidential Library on Wednesday released more than 11,000 pages of Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons public schedules for her eight years as first lady.

title: Ending Suspense, Top Prospect Pryor Picks Ohio State
description: JEANNETTE, Pa.  Terrelle Pryor had been telling people for a day that he was going to play quarterback at Ohio State.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: A Japanese Master

title: Domestic Security Adviser Named
description: The White House named Kenneth L. Wainstein, a senior Justice Department official, to be President Bushs homeland security adviser. Mr. Wainstein now heads the National Security Division, which coordinates the Justice Departments counterterrorism, intelligence and counterespionage efforts. He was formerly the top federal prosecutor in Washington and general counsel and chief of staff at the F.B.I.

title: Morgan Stanley Gives Wall Street a Brief Lift
description: Morgan Stanley gave Wall Street a shot of confidence on Wednesday morning, reporting profits that surpassed analysts estimates, but the dosage soon wore off.

title: Groups Respond to Obamas Call for National Discussion About Race
description: The speech Senator Barack Obama delivered Tuesday morning has been viewed more than 1.6 million times on YouTube and is being widely e-mailed. While commentators and politicians debated its political success Wednesday, some around the country were responding to Mr. Obamas call for a national conversation about race.

title: Its Your Makeup Artists Autograph That I Want
description: AS celebrities began kicking models off magazine covers in the late 90s, editors found that more and more women wanted to know how to get Drews or Gwyneths dewy cheeks or smoky eyes  and who made the look possible.

title: Tolkien First Edition Is Auctioned
description: A first edition of J.R.R. Tolkiens 1937 novel The Hobbit was sold at an auction at the Bonhams auction house, London, for 60,000 ($122,000), twice its predicted value, on Tuesday, Agence France-Presse reported. Inscribed by the author and dedicated to Elaine Griffiths, a friend of Tolkiens who helped with its publication, The Hobbit has sold more than 100 million copies worldwide since its first print run of 1,500 sold out. The auction also included the last known photo of Tolkien, taken in Oxford in 1973, and the first foreign-language edition of the book, a Swedish translation from 1947. The Hobbit was originally written for Tolkiens children and preceded his fantasy trilogy, The Lord of the Rings.

title: Commodities: Latest Boom, Plentiful Risk
description: The booming commodities market has become increasingly attractive to investors, with hard assets like oil and gold perhaps offering a safe hedge against inflation, as well as the double-digit gains that have fast been disappearing from the markets for stocks, bonds and real estate.

title: Philip Jones Griffiths, Photographer, Dies at 72
description: Philip Jones Griffiths, a crusading photojournalist whose pictures of civilian casualties and suffering were among the defining images of the war in Vietnam, died on Wednesday at his home in London. He was 72.

title: Obama and Race
description: Barack Obama this week gave the best political speech since John Kennedy talked about his Catholicism in Houston in 1960, and it derived power from something most unusual in modern politics: an acknowledgment of complexity, nuance and legitimate grievances on many sides. It was not a sound bite, but a symphony.

title: The Pacers Bad Behavior Could Send Walsh Away
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Conseco Fieldhouse was not conceived as a basketball arena but a shrine, built with bricks and nostalgia. Its design evoked small-town Hoosier values. Its concourses were jammed with memorabilia and tributes to local legends.

title: Monster Gallardo, or Baby Murcilago?
description: Introduced Wednesday: 2009 Lamborghini Gallardo LP560-4

title: Efforts to Restore Shine to Medal Tarnished by Nazis
description: BERLIN  The German Army today has no awards for courage, only for attendance. The painful debate here over reviving the famed Iron Cross to fill that gap underscores how distant Germany remains from normality when it comes to the military.

title: British Papers Blunder in Missing Girl Case
