description: LONDON  The headline, splashed across the front page of The Daily Express on Wednesday, could not have been clearer or more jarring. Kate and Gerry McCann: Sorry, it said.

title: Dancers No Match for 'Idol'
description: ABCs celebrity dancers were no match for Foxs would-be celebrities in Tuesdays ratings. Foxs American Idol easily earned the nights largest audience, averaging 27 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., Nielsen estimated. The Fox show also outpaced ABCs Dancing With the Stars by more than 10 million viewers during the 9 p.m. hour when the two series went head to head. The dance competition drew 16.8 million viewers from 9 to 10:30 p.m., giving ABC a second-place finish for the night behind Fox. The premiere of ABCs Miss Guided at 10:30 attracted 10 million viewers. NBC was third for the night, nearly tying ABC among adults 18 to 49 thanks to the strength of "The Biggest Loser" in that demographic from 8 to 10 (7.9 million). CBS finished fourth over all.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in the Circuits pages of Business Day on March 6 described a feature of the ICD-UX80 voice recorder from Sony incorrectly. The recorder has a U.S.B. connection that allows it to attach to a computer without a cable; it does not have a U.S.B. jack.

title: In East and West, Scrambling for No. 8 Seed
description: East Rutherford, N.J.

title: 13 Die as More Than 12 Inches of Rain Fall on Midwest
description: ST. LOUIS  At least 13 people died and hundreds were evacuated on Wednesday as steady rains delivered more than a foot of water across large areas of the Midwest, flooding rivers and roadways.

title: Rangers Beat Devils for 6th Straight Time
description: NEWARK  All it took for Rangers center Chris Drury to change Wednesday nights game was a split second, a sliver of time and space in front of Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur. He crouched low, making himself smaller than his 5-foot-10 frame, collected a pass, and snapped the puck into the Devils net all in one moment.

title: United Brings Some 747s in for More Testing
description: CHICAGO  United Airlines said Thursday it was retesting an altitude indicating system on seven of its Boeing 747s after discovering that the equipment originally used to test the jets was itself past an inspection deadline.

title: Statements by Weiss and Attorney on Plea
description: ATTORNEY FOR MELVYN I. WEISS

title: From Clinton, New Pressure for a Revote in Michigan
description: DETROIT  With plans for new primaries in Florida and Michigan in limbo, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton challenged Senator Barack Obama on Wednesday to accept at least a new contest in Michigan, arguing that he should match his words with action because a civil rights principle was at stake.

title: The Tough Guy and Political Newcomer Who Counsels New Yorks Governor
description: ALBANY  As Gov. David A. Paterson found himself confronting the first crisis of his day-old administration on Tuesday morning, it was left to Charles J. OByrne, his trusted second in command, to contain the damage.

title: Justices Overturn Death Sentence
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday overturned the conviction and death sentence of a Louisiana man who killed his estranged wifes boyfriend in a jealous rage, finding that the trial judge committed clear error in excluding black jurors.

title: Finding Her Rhythm: Swimmer Adjusts to a Heart Procedure and a New Coach
description: LOS ANGELES  The choice was hers. Rebecca Soni could slide over into the lanes with the U.S.C. distance swimmers for a series of 300-yard repeats with precious seconds to catch her breath. Or she could join the sprinters for a series of 50-yard swims with enough time in between to converse.

title: Not Counting Adds Up to a Lost Title at the Spring Nationals
description: The Lebhar Imp Pairs at the Spring Nationals in Detroit resulted in a narrow win Friday for Doug Doub of West Hartford, Conn., and Adam Wildavsky of New York. They finished 2.41 international match points ahead of Dan Gerstman of Buffalo and Marc Nathan of New York City. For these two pairs, sitting at different tables, the diagramed deal was their last one, the 104th of the event.

title: 2 Witnesses Tell Court of Threats by Detective
description: LOS ANGELES  In some of the most colorful testimony so far in the Hollywood wiretapping trial, the actress Linda Doucett and the former wife of a wealthy Los Angeles investor on Wednesday accused the private eye Anthony Pellicano of threatening them.

title: Tip of the Week: A Shortcut to Macs Dictionary
description: Need to look up a word fast in Mac OS X 10.5? Press the Command key and Space bar together to jump to the Leopards Spotlight window  or just click on the magnifying glass in the top right corner of the menu bar. Type in your word, and the dictionary definition should appear in the Spotlight menu, along with a list of every file or document that also contains the word.

title: Seton Hall Suspends Gonzalez for a Game
description: Seton Hall has suspended Bobby Gonzalez, its mens basketball coach, from next seasons first Big East Conference game because of disparaging remarks Gonzalez made about a referee after his team lost to Rutgers in its final game of the regular season.

title: Playwrights Last Work on the Iraq War, With No End in Sight
description: The ragged structure of The Poor Itch, an unfinished play by John Belluso now on view as part of the Public Theaters Lab series, gives the audience a moving insight into the complexities (and the frustrations) of the playwriting process. The loose ends take on larger meaning too, as this story of a disabled Iraq war veterans emotional struggles goes in any number of directions, suggesting the lighter and darker possibilities any life may contain.

title: Britain Tries to Quash Rumors in Markets
description: LONDON  In an unusual move to calm investors nerves, two of Britains top financial authorities stepped forward on Wednesday to quash a spate of rumors that had sent some financial stocks in London into a tailspin.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article in some editions on Friday about Marquettes 89-79 victory over Notre Dame in the Big East mens basketball tournament misstated Marquettes nickname. It is the Golden Eagles  not the Warriors, a name that was dropped in 1994 because of its association with a logo that was considered insensitive to American Indians.

title: Dutch Influence on Display in SoHo
description: When Dutch Masters at Moss, a show of work by Hella Jongerius, Maarten Baas, and Job Smeets and Nynke Tynagel of Studio Job, opens Wednesday (March 26), the title may raise some eyebrows. Although Ms. Jongerius and Ms. Tynagel were born in the Netherlands, Mr. Smeets is Belgian and Mr. Baas was born in Germany. Both were educated in the Netherlands, which is what Murray Moss, the stores founder, considers relevant: Dutch design, he said, comes from the ideas that they associate themselves with, versus their place of birth. He added: So I call them Dutch masters. Among the pieces on display will be Studio Jobs Perished screen ($55,000), right. Through April 27 at Moss, 152 Greene Street, (212) 204-7100.

title: States Data Obscure How Few Finish High School
description: JACKSON, Miss.  When it comes to high school graduation rates, Mississippi keeps two sets of books.

title: A Mans Love of Pigeons, and His Fight to Feed Them
description: Never once in his 65 years did Cecil Pitts imagine that his life would be upended by pigeons, or that his love of them would land him in court, facing off against the City of New York.

title: Shooting Movies for Your iPhone
Woods May Be at Doral, but His Eye Is on Nicklaus
description: MIAMI  As Tiger Woods enters the first round of the W.G.C.-CA Championship on Thursday, his focus is broadened beyond his current streak of seven consecutive tournament victories. It also includes the tournament that begins in three weeks in Augusta, Ga.

title: Coachs Corner
description: Stronger kicking makes better, faster swimmers, said Gregg Troy, the head swim coach at the University of Florida and Ryan Lochtes personal coach.

title: The Professor as Open Book
description: IT is not necessary for a student studying multivariable calculus, medieval literature or Roman archaeology to know that the professor on the podium shoots pool, has donned a bunny costume or cant get enough of Chaka Khan.

title: The Affluent, Too, Couldnt Resist Adjustable Rates
description: They took out adjustable-rate mortgages at the peak of the housing bubble to buy homes they would otherwise not be able to afford. Or they refinanced existing mortgages to take cash out. And now, two or three years later, the day of reckoning is here.

title: Learn From the Expert
description: Ryan Lochte, perhaps the best American male swimmer not named Michael Phelps, swims 3 to 5 miles most days, sometimes even twice a day -- a distance that few non-Olympic hopefuls could replicate. But other aspects of the 23-year-old Lochte's training (such as his use of fins and buoys) and routines (his dryland exercises) can be adopted by recreational swimmers or athletes. In the first article in a series featuring Beijing Olympic hopefuls offering training and fitness tips for everyday athletes, The Times today explains how to employ Lochte's techniques at your local pool to improve your stroke.

title: Rival Decides Not to Buy Socit Gnrale
description: PARIS  Shares of Socit Gnrale, the French bank buffeted by a trading loss of 4.9 billion euros ($7.2 billion), fell 7 percent on Wednesday after a rival bank, BNP Paribas, confirmed that it had no plans to try a takeover.

title: Obama Challenges the Racial Divide
description: To the Editor:

title: A Compact Way to Give Your Devices Some Power, but Not Too Much
description: Hotel rooms and old tiny apartments never seem to have enough electrical outlets for todays gadget-driven world, but there are alternatives to the big clunky power strip. One is Belkins new Mini Surge Protector With U.S.B. Charger, which makes three outlets out of one and is small enough to fit in a laptop bag.

title: Battlestar Galactica Prequel Announced
description: The Sci Fi Channel has approved a two-hour pilot for the prequel to Battlestar Galactica, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The announcement was made at the cable channels presentation of its new schedule Tuesday in New York. The prequel, Caprica, created by David Eick and Ronald D. Moore, the team behind Battlestar, is set 50 years before the hit show.

title: Temples Transition Hasnt Been a Stretch
description: DENVER  Several of Temples top mens basketball players grew up in Philadelphia, not far from the campus on Broad Street. They knew about Coach John Chaney, then got to know him, then played for him.

title: Many Nights at the Opera Involve Emergency Room
description: When the tenor Gary Lehman slid down the raked stage into the prompters box on Tuesday night during Wagners Tristan und Isolde at the Metropolitan Opera, stopping the show at the start of Act III, he entered a storied history of midperformance mishaps at the opera.

title: Kentucky Tries a New Role: Underdog
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  In a discussion Wednesday about the worst moments of Kentuckys uneven season, Ramel Bradley asked his fellow senior guard Joe Crawford about their first defeat.

title: Uncovering the Mysteries of Immunity, and of Lupus
description: Lupus is in many ways the most fundamental of betrayals. The bodys immune system, schooled to identify and purge outside invaders like bacteria and viruses, mistakenly turns its force instead on healthy organs. The result is inflammation and often lasting damage to the heart, lungs, joints, brain, kidneys, blood and skin.

title: Stocks Bounce Back as Oil and Gold Fall Again
description: For months, wary investors bet their fortunes on the metals and raw materials that make up the commodities market, pushing prices for oil and gold into record territory even as stocks languished.

title: Thomas Says Little About Walsh
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Isiah Thomas, the Knicks coach and president, dodged several questions from reporters Wednesday about his future with the team amid reports that the longtime Indiana Pacers executive Donnie Walsh may join the Knicks as the team president.

title: Governor Is Another Obstacle for the Mayors Congestion Pricing Plan
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs proposal to charge drivers who enter the busiest parts of Manhattan, already on the ropes in Albany, was dealt a further blow on Wednesday when Gov. David A. Paterson declined to support the idea  despite an impassioned pitch from the mayor.

title: Singers Family Revisits Its Reality-Show History
description: In its two short seasons on BET, Keyshia Cole: The Way It Is has stood atop the celebreality genre. The triumphs and travails of Ms. Cole; her sister, Neffe; and their mother, Frankie, have felt less scripted, and consequently more interesting, than anything offered up by Gene Simmons or Scott Baio or Flavor Flav. The shows second season, which ended in December, averaged 1.8 million viewers, a record for a BET series.

title: French Court Says Ban on Gene-Altered Corn Seed Will Remain, Pending Study
description: PARIS  Opponents of gene-altered crops won a victory in France on Wednesday when the top court upheld, at least for the time being, a ban on a corn variety produced by the American seed company Monsanto.

title: Corrections: Personality Plus: A Twin Takes Over
description: A picture caption with the Front Row column on Feb. 28, about Elisa DeCarlo, a fashion blogger, omitted the photographers credit. The photograph, of Ms. DeCarlo, was taken by Michael J. Berkowitz.

title: A Techno-Nerds Dream Come True
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2009 Acura TSX.

title: A Swimmers Different Strokes for Success
description: RYAN LOCHTE may be the best American male swimmer not named Michael. At the 2004 Olympic Summer Games in Athens, he won a silver medal in the 200-meter individual medley, losing only to that Michael (Phelps, of course).

title: Better Angel, Out of the Dressing Room!
description: WHEN Rem Koolhaass Prada flagship opened in SoHo in 2001, it was so razor-fabulous as to inspire awe and terror. Your ears veritably popped from the altitude of hippest chic. Quiet and clean as space, it had its own Formica canyon: a plunging swoop of wood paneling redolent of a skateboard half pipe, on which headless and sometimes dismembered mannequins were arranged like drill squads, donning feats of elegance so ablaze with imagination as to be galaxies away from the scrum of black overcoats elbowing across Broadway and Prince.

title: It Stays Where It Should, and Its Wireless, Too
description: How often has this happened to you? Youre in the last leg of a marathon when your iPod headset falls off. You fumble with it and a competitor rushes by you, beating you by mere seconds.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,982 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Wednesday:

title: States Battles Over Energy Grow Fiercer With U.S. in a Policy Gridlock
description: Utility executives in Kansas were shocked last fall when a state environmental official rejected two coal-fired power plants because of the millions of tons of carbon-dioxide emissions they could produce. In a state where coal generates 73 percent of the electricity, the pro-coal forces were unable to work their will.

title: A Star Turn: Mayo and Beasley Ready to Square Off
description: OMAHA  O. J. Mayo and Bill Walker met in preschool in Huntington, W.Va., just a couple of 4-year-olds who would not snooze when they were supposed to.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about a planned Broadway revival of Fences, by August Wilson, misstated the history of the revival of his plays on Broadway. Ma Raineys Black Bottom, originally on Broadway in 1984, returned there in 2003; the Broadway revival of Fences would not be the first of a Wilson play.

title: Starbucks Plans Return to Its Roots
description: SEATTLE  Howard D. Schultz, the chief executive of Starbucks, announced sweeping changes on Wednesday for the company as it seeks to reconnect with customers who have left for competitors or pared back their coffee budget in hard economic times.

title: Small Group, Big Sound
description: Pat Metheny has cultivated an extraordinarily broad musical terrain over the last 30 years, exerting substantial influence in the process: as a guitarist, as a composer and conceptualist, as a champion crossbreeder. His most steadfast outlet is the Pat Metheny Group, an electro-acoustic ensemble that sheds a generous warmth and illumination; his most explicitly jazz-based outlet is the guitar-bass-drums trio, which projects more of a tight, focused beam.

title: Circus Cyclists Roll Toward the Border of a Record
description: They call it The Eight.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 19, 2008

title: One Star, Two Seats, Six Figures
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2009 Mercedes-Benz SL550 and SL63 AMG

title: Adding Dates to a BlackBerry
description: Q. Can I sync the appointments on a Web-based Google Calendar with my BlackBerry communicator?

title: Titan to Represent Players
description: Tennessee Titans center Kevin Mawae was elected president of the N.F.L. Players Association as the union braces for a potential labor fight. Mawae, 37, replaces Troy Vincent, the unions president since 2004.

title: Sentimental Journey, Sentimental Favorite
description: Ive got my team.

title: So Much to Love
description: Upsets? Overtimes? Emotions? The deluge of games? What is your favorite part of March Madness?

title: On Invasions Anniversary, Protests and Pessimism
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Crowds of protesters rolled through cities across the nation on Wednesday in a series of largely peaceful, and sometimes subdued, marches on the eve of the fifth anniversary of the invasion of Iraq.

title: Juniper Berries? Be Picky
description: Q. The juniper tree beside my new house in Columbia County, N.Y., is loaded with blue berries. When is the best time to harvest them?

title: The Many Faces of Lupus
description: Dr. Betty A. Diamond is a member of the Institute of Medicine and chief of the Center for Autoimmune Diseases at the Feinstein Institute for Medical Research at the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System in New York.

title: Tune in Elsewhere
description: I made a great discovery this week: there is a TV right here in the office that gets the Golf Channel. So while the March Maniacs -- many of whom dont pay any attention to sports the rest of the year -- are tuned into CBS this afternoon, Im going to be watching Tiger Woods at the CA Championship in Florida. A month from now, who will remember which beanpole hit the 3-pointer from the corner for the mid-major from Ohio? But Tiger right now is on a streak -- seven tournament wins in a row -- that people will be talking about for many years. We dont often get to see perfection in sports, but lately hes come close, and if you think its more fun this weekend to watch guys run around in a gym than to see Tiger tackle the Blue Monster at Doral, then thats really Madness.

title: Curtains to Close
description: Curtains will be closing at the Al Hirschfeld Theater on Broadway after the matinee performance on Sunday, June 29. It will have played 511 regular performances and 26 previews. David Hyde Pierce, left, won a Tony for his performance in the musical, a comedy whodunit by John Kander and Fred Ebb, who died in 2004. ...The Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis has already announced a commissioned play by Tony Kushner, The Intelligent Homosexuals Guide to Capitalism and Socialism With a Key to the Scriptures. But theres more Kushner to go around. On Wednesday Joe Dowling, the director of the Guthrie, announced plans for productions of Mr. Kushners musical Caroline, or Change on the Guthries thrust stage, and some of Mr. Kushners short plays in the smaller studio stage, as part of the 2008-9 season.

title: In the Heart of Pennsylvania, a Weary Electorate
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa.  In a city like this, which was suctioned clean of its old life more than a quarter-century ago and has been waiting ever since for a new one, people do not so much ignore national politics as gaze upon it with the long-distance stare of the combat-weary.

title: LETTERS: Obama Challenges the Racial Divide
description: To the Editor:

title: Serving the Lord, With Humor, and Legal Advice
description: Susan Sparks sits at the intersection of a bevy of career trends. First, she needs a rather long string of words to describe what she does, usually beginning with something like Im a lawyer-turned-Baptist preacher who moonlights as a stand-up comic. As a preacher/comic, shes a slash and a hyphenate. As someone who uses her skills as a lawyer in her current career  her church relies on her for the occasional legal perspective on everything from property to contracts  she leads what Penelope Trunk calls a braided career.

title: In Mosul, New Test of Iraqi Army
description: Michael Kamber examines the Iraqi Security Forces.

title: N.C.A.A. Tournament: Day 1
description: Highlights from the first day of the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament.

title: The Big Red Travels in Style
description: I guess the coaches and the administration officials in charge of our travel itinerary figured that since we had the longest trip of any team in the tournament, we might as well travel in style. We definitely did.

title: Small City, Little Hope
description: In Johnstown, Pa., people only gaze at national politics, uncertain about the power of a president to fix anything.

title: The Sharks Are In
description: San Jose clinched a playoff spot with a shootout win against Minnesota on Wednesday.

title: Discussing Bear Stearns Deal
description: The audacious government-orchestrated purchase of Bear Stearns by JPMorgan Chase has dominated headlines and chatter this week. To say there are a plethora of angles to cover  the $2-a-share price, the role of the government, the challenges in closing the deal  is an understatement.

title: British Airways Lifts Stake in Iberia
description: British Airways said it had bought about another 3 percent of the Spanish flag carrier Iberia Airlines, raising its stake to 13.15 percent, and that it would look for opportunities to purchase more of Iberias shares.

title: Raid at BPs Russian Joint Oil Venture
description: Investigators took documents from the headquarters of BPs joint venture i Russia, TNK-BP, which has had rocky relations with the Kremlin.

title: Former Brocade Official Sentenced in Backdating Case
description: The former human resources chief of Brocade Communications Systems, Stephanie Jensen, was sentenced on Wednesday to four months in prison and ordered to pay a $1.25 million fine for her role in a stock options backdating scheme.

title: More Static in Clear Channel Deal
description: It appears that there is some confusion over who is to blame for holding up the buyout of Clear Channel Communications and now, according to a report, the deal may not close at all.

title: A Break for Freddie and Fannie
description: With the blessing of the Bush administration, the regulator of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the nations two largest mortgage finance companies, eased a major restriction on the companies on Wednesday in an effort to unfreeze credit markets and stabilize housing prices.

title: Deal Is Part of Starbucks Plan to Return to Its Roots
description: Howard D. Schultz, the chief executive of Starbucks, announced sweeping changes on Wednesday for the company as it seeks to reconnect with customers who have left for competitors or pared back their coffee budget in hard economic times.

title: Commodities: Latest Boom, Plentiful Risk
description: The booming commodities market has become increasingly attractive to investors, with hard assets like oil and gold perhaps offering a safe hedge against inflation, as well as the double-digit gains that have fast been disappearing from the markets for stocks, bonds and real estate.

title: MGM Backers Said to Question Studios Strategy
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Chairman and Chief Executive Harry Sloans plan to rebuild a full-fledged movie studio is not sitting well with the private equity firms backing the studio, according to The New York Post.

title: Sundance Channel Said to Be on the Block
description: The Sundance Channel, the cable network spawned from Robert Redfords eponymous annual film festival, is up for sale, The New York Post reported.

title: Hedge Fund to Nominate 4 to Dillards Board
description: Barington Capital Group, the hedge fund that has been pressing for changes at Dillards, is making its move to wrest more control of the department store chain.

title: Retrevo Scores $8 Million in New Funding
description: Retrevo, the Silicon Valley company that helps you shop electronic products, and then helps you after the purchase, has raised $8 million more in a second round of financing.

title: Rivals Lure Away Bear Brokers
description: As more than 14,000 Bear Stearns employees watch the value of their stock sink and brace for firings, some of the 550 brokers at the company who handle individual investors accounts are receiving job offers from competitors promising bonuses of $2 million or more, according to Bloomberg News.

title: U.S. Picks Tech Executive for Security Post
description: The Bush administration is planning to tap a Silicon Valley entrepreneur to head a new inter-agency group charged with coordinating the federal governments efforts to protect its computer networks from organized cyber attacks, The Washington Post reported.

title: Morgan Stanley Gives Wall Street a (Brief) Lift
description: Morgan Stanley gave Wall Street a shot of confidence on Wednesday morning, reporting profits that surpassed analysts estimates, but the dosage soon wore off.

title: Chinese Insurer $3.4 Billion Stake in Fortis Unit
description: The Ping An Insurance Company, a leading life insurer in China, has agreed to pay 2.15 billion euros ($3.4 billion) for 50 percent of Fortiss asset management business, the companies said.

title: Ivan Dixon, 76, Black Actor in Hogans Heroes
description: The actor and director was best known for playing the radio techie Sgt. James Kinchloe on the 1960s sitcom Hogans Heroes, but his work included vivid portrayals of American black struggles. Read his obit here. This clip illustrates not only his small role in Hogans Heroes but also much more about identity politics (or the lack thereof) on TV in the 1960s:

title: Visas $45 Billion Day
description: Catapulted by the biggest initial public offering in American history, Visa shares soared 28 percent in their stock market debut on Wednesday as investors bet an accelerating shift to electronic payments will enrich the company.

title: Terra Firma Chief Warns on U.K. Tax Hike
description: Guy Hands, the founder of Terra Firma, is threatening to move part of his private equity group offshore in response to the latest tax rises on capital gains and non-domiciled residents in Britain.

title: Cadbury Sets Terms of Spinoff
description: Cadbury Schweppes, the candy maker, has set the terms of its soda units planned spinoff.

title: Citigroup to Cut 2,000 More Jobs
description: Citigroup plans to lay off another 2,000 investment bankers and traders before the end of the month, according to The New York Times.

title: Britain Tries to Quash Rumors in Markets
description: In an unusual move to calm investors nerves, two of Britains top financial authorities stepped forward on Wednesday to quash a spate of rumors that had sent some financial stocks in London into a tailspin.

title: Pepsi to Buy Majority Stake in Russian Juice Maker
description: PepsiCo and the Pepsi Bottling Group said on Thursday they have agreed to buy 75.53 percent of the juice business of Lebedyansky, Russias leading juice producer, for $1.4 billion.

title: Borders to Consider Selling Itself
description: Borders Group, the struggling bookstore chain, said Thursday it hired JPMorgan and Merrill Lynch to explore strategic alternatives, including a sale of all or part of the company. Shares of Borders initially rose in Friday trading but soon moved sharply lower.

title: Buffett Isnt Just a Billionaire Investor, He Plays One on T.V.
description: Billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett, it seems, has a secret penchant for soap operas.

title: Easter Warning: Crucifixion Is Bad for You
description: The above is the headline on a London Telegraph article about the infection risk to worshippers in the Philippines taking part in Easter crucifixion and self-flagellation ceremonies:

title: Credit Suisse Expects First-Quarter Loss
description: Credit Suisse warned it was unlikely to be profitable in the first quarter, partly because of this months tough markets and partly because of previously flagged pricing errors that it said Thursday stemmed from intentional misconduct by a small number of traders.

title: Ex-Lehman Executive Plans Fund for Mortgage Trading
description: To many people, mortgage-backed bonds and securities are radioactive waste. But it appears that for some traders, theyre a potential gold mine.

title: Credit crisis for make harm glorious republic
description: Global contagion, from Bloomberg:

title: Threatening to Resign II
description: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: The Dalai Lama is threatening to resign from his position as the spiritual leader of Tibet. Yeah. When asked why, the Dalai Lama said, I promised myself Id quit the moment it stopped being fun.

title: Meeting, and Resenting, Bears New Boss
description: James Dimon tramped through the rain on Wednesday evening and strode into the headquarters of Bear Stearns, the embattled investment bank he hopes to buy for a mere $2 a share.

title: Threatening To Resign I
description: Aired Wednesday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: The Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of the Tibetan people, is threatening to resign if the conflict with the Chinese doesnt stop. Not only that, he also says he might refuse to be reincarnated again.

title: The Early Word: Clinton Papers Reveal Little
description: More than 11,000 pages documenting Hillary Rodham Clintons tenure as first lady were released yesterday, and they contain all the emotional punch of a factory-workers timecard, concludes John M. Broder of The New York Times.

title: Love Gov Fever
description: Jon Stewart last night:

title: Go Roma! A Taste of Italian Football
description: They say when in Rome, do as the Romans. Well, what many salt-of-the-earth Romans are doing these days is cheering for their beloved home grown football (soccer) team, AS Roma. Despite a dispiriting loss to Lazio this week, Roma is having a banner year.

title: What I Did During My Husbands Administration
description: Hillary Clinton has released her schedules from her White House years and The Guardian of London feels theyre more notable for whats missing than for whats there:

title: How Few Police Officers Is Too Few?
description: Facing budget woes and a recruiting crisis, the citys Police Department is poised to shrink to its smallest size in about 15 years, a reality reflected in a plan by the Bloomberg administration to trim funds for 1,000 police officer positions this year, Al Baker reports. Facing in hiring fluctuations, military leave and recruitment challenges, a low point of 34,624 officers is projected for the end of June. That is just below the 34,641 officers in June 1993, a time when a program by Mayor David N. Dinkins to pump up the police force was under way. The number peaked in October 2000 with 40,800 officers. The first new officers of Mr. Dinkinss program were entering the police academy by 1993.

title: Looking for a Few Good Cookbooks
description: Over at the Bitten blog, food writer Mark Bittman needs your advice. Hes putting together a list of the best cookbooks ever.

title: Thursdays Tipoff
description: At 12:20 Eastern, Georgia and Xavier start up this years N.C.A.A. tournament with their West Region matchup in Washington D.C. - quickly followed by enough rapid-fire action to keep any college basketball happy for the next 12 hours.

title: After Danish Cartoons, Dutch Film Sparks More Worries
description: The aftermath has flowed predictably enough since Feb. 13, when Danish newspapers reprinted cartoons that sparked fury among Muslims around the world in 2006: There was more fury.

title: Uncovering the Art of Veiling
description: Auto shows are all about the unveiling of new models. But before they are unveiled, cars must be veiled.

title: Uncovering the Art of Veiling
description: Auto shows are all about the unveiling of new models. But before they are unveiled, cars must be veiled.   The design of the veils is revealing. At Saabs party in the IAC Building, the iceberg-like glass structure designed by Frank Gehry, the veils were arctic white and gauzy. The 9-X BioHybrid concept, also white, peeked out from behind its veil like a bride. The glacial white seemed appropriately Scandinavian.   (Photo: Veiled Saabs. (Photograph by Phil Patton for The New York Times))   Across town, Kia rented the Exit Art gallery on 10th Avenue for the premier of its Koup concept. On Tuesday afternoon, the Koup stood naked and red while the designers Peter Schreyer and Tom Kearns contemplated covering it. They agreed on the beauty of what they called the swoosh shape along the Koup's side and Kias new twin-tab grille face.  But designing the cover for the car to attend its coming out party was harder. The crisply outlined car stood in a room of red cloth of a certain bordello flavor, a choice perhaps appropriate to local political news. It was left to Alex Fedorak, the Kia publicity chief, to decide just how to fold the red cloth over the car, which was to be half concealed for the companys party Wednesday night. The car was to be unveiled Thursday morning at Kia's press conference in the Javits convention center.  (Photo: Kia, partially uncovered. (Photograph by Phil Patton for The New York Times))   At the party, held with Vans, the skateboard shoemaker, the Koup posed teasingly clad for journalists. The Koups cloth cover left a front and a rear corner exposed, and hung as thick as drapery in a David painting. From the rear, the red cloth suggested a wrapped coffin.  Draping is design, too. Draping is not easy; it must offer seductive hints, mixed with virtuous concealment.  Related:  Full Coverage: New York Auto Show

title: Now Screening | Brady Corbet in T Takes Episode 4
What the Final Four Means, by Jim Larranaga
description: DENVER  Two years ago, George Mason and its coach, Jim Larranaga, made an out-of-nowhere run to the Final Four. The day after the Patriots beat the heavyweight UConn in the regional final in Washington, George Masons campus in Fairfax, Va., was one giant party: the bookstore had lines out the doors; the admissions office could barely keep pace with phone calls; reporters could not fit inside Larranagas office. The bronze statue of George Mason wore a T-shirt and balloons tied at the wrist.

title: Please Dont Eat the Gravel
description: Smarts party, tied to the release of its commissioned book Sideways, a compilation of words and images offering new takes on environmentalism, was held on an unfinished high floor of Larry Silversteins 7 World Trade Center. The dcor  blue lights and walls of stretched cellophane  was the work of Lot-Ek, the architectural firm known for its use of recycled shipping containers.

title: Please Dont Eat the Gravel
description: (Photo: Edibles and non-edibles on offer. (Photograph by Phil Patton for The New York Times)) Smarts party, tied to the release of its commissioned book Sideways, a compilation of words and images offering new takes on environmentalism, was held on an unfinished high floor of Larry Silverstein's 7 World Trade Center. The dcor  blue lights and walls of stretched cellophane -- was the work of Lot-Ek, the architectural firm known for its use of recycled shipping containers.  Snacks as cute as tiny Smart cars arrived on trays of mirrored glass. In the middle of each tray was a square of crumbly white powder that might have been baking soda, sugar or  I thought with a shock  a controlled substance. Whats that?" I asked, about to nibble on it. Gravel, the server told me: it was a miniature Japanese garden effect.  A single Smart ForTwo stood on a platform and videos flashed across scrim screens. But the views out the windows stole the show: north to a hazy Empire State Building and immediately south, to the ground zero construction site.  Related:  Full Coverage: New York Auto Show

title: YouTube Video Awards
description: On Friday, YouTube announces the winners of its Video Awards.

title: From Then to Now: Optimism Glints Amid Shades of Gray
description: On a recent visit to Iraq, my first trip back in over three years, a few things surprised me. There was the countdown calendar to President Bushs last day in office, sitting openly on a soldiers desk. There was the high-up United States official who told me, by way of introduction, that he did not believe the decision to invade Iraq was reality-based. Before leaving to spend a few days with American troops, I worried about bringing along a book critical of the war. I shouldnt have.

title: The Good Friday Brawl
description: Every year around this time were reminded of the infamous Vendredi Saint brawl at the Montreal Forum between the Canadiens and Nordiques. It happened in 1984, an endless donnybrook, simple lawless frenzy, and it went on so long we need two videos to show it.

title: Shock and Awe: A Novel
description: Way back in 2004, when the war in Iraq was barely a year old, Tom Miller and Gregory McNamee at Kirkus Reviews wondered why novelists hadnt yet tackled it as a subject. At that early date the question seemed more than a little tongue in cheek  they acknowledged that Stephen Crane didnt write The Red Badge of Courage until decades after the Civil War had ended, and their suggested Iraq titles included The Oil Man and the Sea  but now that the wars five-year anniversary is upon us, its starting to feel like they had a point. Wheres the first wave of Iraq War fiction? By Sept. 11, 2006, after all, there were already enough 9/11 novels to constitute a mini-genre.

title: Slice Me Eight More Years of That
description: Aired Wednesday night on CBS: John McCain recently said he supports George Bushs Iraq policy. I said, Well, sure, slice me eight more years of that, will you? Lets go!

title: Recipe of the Day: Tender Spinach With Crisp Shallots
description: Toss spinach quickly in hot olive oil scented with garlic, follow with a squeeze of lemon, and you already have an appealing dish. The next level up is still easy: make a topping of crisp-fried shallots for the greens. By themselves, these crunchy slices are irresistible; combined with tender spinach, they create an alluring contrast in flavor and texture.

title: Scent Notes | Cest La Fte!  by Christian Lacroix
description: Cest La Fte!, which launched in 2007, is a creation of Inter-Parfums, one of the mid-sized perfume licensees. Its splendid Paris offices are located on the exclusive Rond Point of the Champs-Elyses, in the eighth arrondissement. But Inter-Parfums, which owns Lacroixs license and creates scents bearing the designers name, is under the same, not-so-splendid financial constraints faced by the other licensees (like those of Lauder to LVMH). It takes money to make a perfume; like most things in life, the better the raw materials, the more they cost. There are several ways of dealing with this. One of them is known as front-loading.

title: A Bad Omen for Canterburys Law
description: Canterburys Law may not be upheld.

title: The Mother of All Privacy Battles
description: All of the outrage over privacy on the Internet is nothing compared to what may be coming. For years, Web companies have been trying to gather shreds of information about users in order to show them ads for things they are most likely to buy. These schemes have been accelerated over the last year, as the big Web companies like AOL, Microsoft and Yahoo have been trying to combine information they gather on their own sites with data about users gathered from networks that place ads on other sites.

title: The Elusive Truth
description: The latest fake-memoir scandal raised a question: Why not simply convert the purported autobiographical material into fiction?

Yesterday, Senator Barack Obama played a morning round of hoops with soldiers from Fort Bragg in North Carolina. Today, as he arrived here for a campaign event, he completed his NCAA Final Four bracket.

Now, a Democrat, either Hillary or Barack would win if only wine drinkers voted. But heres the interesting part, if we all got really drunk on tequila, Ralph Nader might actually have a shot.

title: Tune in Elsewhere
description: I made a great discovery this week: there is a TV right here in the office that gets the Golf Channel. So while the March Maniacs  many of whom dont pay any attention to sports the rest of the year  are tuned into CBS this afternoon, Im going to be watching Tiger Woods at the CA Championship in Florida, Charles McGrath wrote in this weeks Play newsletter. A month from now, who will remember which beanpole hit the 3-pointer from the corner for the mid-major from Ohio? But Tiger right now is on a streak  seven tournament wins in a row  that people will be talking about for many years. We dont often get to see perfection in sports, but lately hes come close, and if you think its more fun this weekend to watch guys run around in a gym than to see Tiger tackle the Blue Monster at Doral, then thats really Madness.

title: When the Resistance Was Fading
description: I arrived in the Times Baghdad bureau on Sunday, Jan. 25, 2004, with a duffel bag, flak jacket and 12-cup muffin tin that someone had asked me to bring. Back then the bureau was a noisy frat-house like place with correspondents from across the planet living on top of each other and sharing bath soap. I was nervous, lonely, excited and overwhelmed, thrilled by the intensity of all the guns on the street and tanks rolling by and a bit unsettled by it  and the fact that I had now entered the worlds biggest story.

Paterson, although most know little about him and many would like to see Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York City run for the position in 2010. The poll also found that four-fifths of voters supported Eliot Spitzers decision to resign as governor amid a sex scandal.

What once seemed to be an insuperable lead for the Nationalist candidate, Ma Ying-jeou, has narrowed considerably, Mr. Bradsher reported:

title: Cornell Goes Back to High School
description: Ill provide a quick recap of our first evening in Anaheim after a long day of traveling. We practiced at Loara High School, the alma mater of the pop star Gwen Stefani, for a couple of hours. It was a surprisingly crisp and energetic practice, considering we had just been traveling for seven hours. After a team dinner at our hotel, the Hilton Anaheim, we spent the rest of the night relaxing in our hotel rooms getting ready for another day of preparation and practice.

description: The Plaza Hotel reopened this month, after the El-Ad Group of Israel turned the Central Park South landmark into a luxury condominium and hotel, (spending more than the gross domestic product of Monaco, as Anthony Ramirez of The Times put it.)

title: McLaren breakdown on the way to ball
description: Just a quick note on Thursday in Malaysia before we move into overdrive tomorrow. A couple of things got inversed in the move of the F1 circus from Australia to Malaysia within the same week. First, it was Australia that proved to have the Malaysian weather, where Malaysia now has weather we should have encountered in Australia. At practically 38 degrees Celsius everyday in Australia and with no rain and only sun, youd have thought it was the Kuala Lumpur race. Here in Malaysia today, by contrast, it was maybe only 28 degrees Celsius  a veritable refrigerator by comparison  and there was rain yesterday and today. Rain is in the forecast at the track for every day this race weekend.

The fact that Georgia is in the game at all is a tribute to their willpower. Defensively Xavier is causing Georgia all sorts of problems. The Bulldogs are hanging in, but more with gritty one-on-one basketball then anything pretty.

title: City Inspector Is Charged in Crane Case
description: Updated, 5:55 p.m. | A Buildings Department inspector, Edward J. Marquette, has been arrested and charged with lying to New York City authorities about inspecting the crane that collapsed on Saturday afternoon, killing seven people, injuring dozens of others and causing widespread property damage. Officials issued a stern warning that corrupt workers will be punished, but said the failure to inspect the crane on March 4 was almost certainly not a factor in the deadly collapse, which officials think may have been caused by the failure of a nylon strap, which led to a large steel collar coming loose.

title: Former N.R.C.C. Official Plans to Retire
description: The number of Republicans in the House who are retiring this year keeps on mounting, and posing significant hurdles for the G.O.P. to wage battle on so many fronts. That number climbed to 29 today when Representative Thomas R. Reynolds of upstate New York and a former chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee said that he would not seek reelection.

title: Pace Among Kent States Problems
description: Typically in the tournament its the team that is accumstomed to playing at a faster pace that struggles to adjust. Early in the U.N.L.V.-Kent State game, its just the opposite. U.N.L.V. is leaking out on rebounds and creating fast breaks; even after scores the Running Rebels get the ball up the court quickly to seamlessly set up a pick and roll. Thats leading to their scores and a 31-10 lead late in the first half.

title: Keys to a Long Life in 3 Odd Headlines
description: Much of the world is getting older, and tips like from these recently published headlines can only encourage the trend. In short, keep your hair gelled, your gun loaded and always use sterilized nails in crucifixions.

title: Manhattan Population Is Still Growing
description: Here is one way Manhattan is still booming. The latest census figures show that in the year ending July 1, 2007, the boroughs population grew by more people than any other county in the state, and accounted for more than half the states total population increase. Population growth in New York appeared to have slowed, but those numbers are typically challenged by city officials and later revised by the Census Bureau.

The Final Five takes three days instead of the normal two and includes a play-in game between the two lowest seeds on Thursday night. This year, the play-in game is especially interesting because it pits the two remaining Minnesota teams against each other to start the long road to the Broadmoor Trophy.

title: The Return of Sail, and Hemp?
description: It seems theres a push toward the future through the past (pedicabs in Manhattan being just one example). Here are two more examples, involving sails on cargo ships and a proposal to legalize farming of hemp, a plant that was once a big crop in the United States, was banned because the industrial variety (very different than the plants grown to smoke) still has a trace of the compounds that give marijuana its punch.

title: Sean Bell Went Back for His Hat
description: A hat cost Sean Bell his life. The encounters that escalated in the moments before he was killed by police officers began when he went back for what he had left behind at his bachelor party at the Club Kalua, his friend testified Thursday. He left his hat, said the friend, James Kollore, 32, one of several friends celebrating on the morning of Nov. 25, 2006.

title: Democrats in Black and White

Lets think, instead, about the recent history of black and white inside the Democratic Party.

title: Fed funds question (seriously wonkish, and possibly dumb too)
description: The target Fed funds rate is now 2.25%. Everyone expects it to be reduced further; Citi economists predict that it will be down to 1% by mid-year.

title: The Obama-Wright Factor
description: Two separate incidents today highlighted the lingering controversies over the relationship between Senator Barack Obama and his longtime pastor, the Rev. Jeremiah Wright Jr., despite the senators efforts earlier this week in a far-ranging speech on race relations to address the issue.

title: Boilermakers Go Full Steam Ahead
description: WASHINGTON  There are few sure things in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Players graduate, coaches flee and programs re-invent themselves seemingly every couple of years. Other than that, the closest thing to a sure thing in the N.C.A.A. tournament is picking Purdue in the first round.

title: Deadbeat Diplomats Should Pay, Lawmakers Say
description: On the heels of a judges decision this week that said India, Mongolia and the Philippines owe the city almost $58 million in property taxes, there are renewed Congressional efforts to make them pay up.Consulates and missions are generally tax exempt, but Judge Jed S. Rakoff of United States District Court in Manhattan ruled on Monday that foreign nations must pay taxes on those parts of their properties that are used for non-diplomatic purposes like housing low-level staff or operating businesses.

title: Not Flattered to Be Mentioned
description: Another risk taken: Geraldine Ferraro, who seems oddly inclined to open up to The Daily Breeze of Torrance, Calif., said she objects to the comparison Sen. Barack Obama drew between her and Jeremiah Wright, his former pastor. To equate what I said with what this racist bigot has said from the pulpit is unbelievable, she told the paper. He gave a very good speech on race relations, but he did not address the fact that this man is up there spewing hatred.

title: I Want My Candidates to Chat With Veterans
description: MTV staged a series of conversations in Pennsylvania between each of the two remaining Democratic presidential nominees and a group of young veterans of the Iraq war, and plans to televise the dialogues across all the networks cable channels tonight at 6 p.m.

title: When Youre a No. 16 Seed, Its a Short Stay
description: OMAHA  Like all No. 16 seeds, Portland States stay in the N.C.A.A. tournament was brief. The Vikings made only one basket, a Kyle Coston 3-pointer, in the first five and a half minutes against top-seeded Kansas, which was hitting almost every shot it put up. The Jayhawks shot 64.3 percent in the first half and made 12 3-pointers over all to win the first game of the afternoon here, 85-61.

title: City Takes Windermere Owner to Court
description: The saga of the Windermere  a once-grand complex of three 1881 Queen Anne-style buildings that has become a decrepit eyesore of Hells Kitchen despite having received city landmark protection in June 2005  took a new turn today.

title: Volvo Bumps Up Its Safety Systems
description: Few companies have reputation for safety like Volvos. So naturally when the company introduces a new suite of safety technologies people sit up and take notice. I visited with Volvo at the New York auto show and found that rather than making some radical new safety statements, the companys latest systems build on established methods.

title: Volvo Bumps Up Its Safety Systems
description: (Photo: Volvo XC60. (Photograph by Jonathan Fickies/Getty Images))   Few companies have reputation for safety like Volvo's. So naturally when the company introduces a new suite of safety technologies people sit up and take notice. I visited with Volvo at the New York auto show and found that rather than making some radical new safety statements, the company's latest systems build on established methods.  I spent half an hour chatting with Thomas Broberg, Volvos senior technical adviser for safety, about the new package it calls City Safety that will be standard on the Volvo XC60, which comes out this fall. Its actually a collection of technologies that work in concert and are aimed at, in Mr. Brobergs words, assisting distracted drivers.  Headlining the City Safety package is the low-speed automatic braking system, which works at speeds of less than 20 miles an hour. Thats the danger zone for urban fender benders in stop-and-go traffic. So the Volvo system employs a light detection and ranging (or LIDAR) system positioned on the windshield just behind the rearview mirror. A laser is aimed a few feet in front of the vehicle and looks for reflections from, say, bumpers and license plates of other vehicles. When it detects that youre rapidly approaching such a reflection and havent made a move to stop, the car automatically brakes to a stop. And then it flashes at you, so that you dont think somethings wrong with your car.   Recalling how difficult it is for troopers using LIDAR to catch speeders in the rain, I asked about how it would work under such conditions. Mr. Broberg assured me the system would continue to work in the rain because the laser gun is in the cars wiper zone. And while its not designed to detect pedestrians, in some tests it has been successful at doing just that. However, Mr. Broberg emphasized that this is not the systems intended purpose (so aggravated XC60 owners should avoid the temptation to take aim at jaywalking New Yorkers).  All of this is sure to grab consumers' attention. However, rather than representing an entirely new technology City Safety is a maturation of technologies that began with adaptive cruise control and collision warning packages. Those systems also monitor the relative distances between vehicles and brake when necessary. But what really caught my eye was the companys often-overlooked drowsy driver safety system, a k a Driver Alert Control.  I.B.M. and others have research departments that are actively developing interior camera and retina detection systems designed to catch napping drivers. But such systems have yet to appear in cars because they are technically challenging and expensive. So Volvo took a different approach by building on technology already available: the lane departure warning system.   The current lane-departure system alerts drivers with an audible warning should they cross the line without signaling. Its designed to prevent single-vehicle lane-departure crashes as well as head-on collisions. But Volvo gave the system a new twist that could make it even more useful.  Alert drivers are always looking ahead down the road and keep the car in the lane smoothly, explained Mr. Broberg. But drowsy drivers tend to start looking shorter distances ahead and have more trouble keeping the car in the lane. Such drivers tend to make micro corrections in steering to keep the vehicle between the lines, according to Mr. Broberg. So the driver alert system uses the same camera and computer technology used for the lane-departure system but adds another program that looks for those telltale micro corrections.  To test the concept and the technology, Mr. Broberg said Volvo used volunteers who were not allowed to sleep for 24 hours. Then they fed the drivers a big, heavy meal (who says theres no free lunch?), denied them coffee, and then put them behind the wheel on a closed course. Drivers were also not allowed to blast the radio or roll down the windows. (I didnt ask about pinching themselves.) And, of course, the cars were equipped with secondary controls and a copilot should the volunteers actually fall asleep at the wheel.  The test bore out the research departments thesis about micro corrections. So now when the cars computer detects that the driver has been making a series of jerky steering inputs, the vehicle audibly suggests he or she should take a brake break.   Many of us will note that the same drowsy driver zigs and zags are also indicative of cellphone Chatty Cathys and Kens. Indeed, Volvo hopes the alerts will also prompt some drivers to get off the phone. If all cars were outfitted with such systems, I think it might also bring some additional civility to the roadways. After all, its certainly more polite that the typical New Yorkers honking and hand gestures.

title: Returning the Favor
description: Update: With Stanford polishing off Cornell, 77-53, the attention turns to the Cardinals second-round matchup with Marquette. That game will feature a contrast of styles and personnel. Marquette depends on its diminutive guards while Stanford leans on its inside presence. The Lopez twins should be able to score inside, assuming they can stay on the court. Thats not a given. The penetration of the Marquette guards puts Stanfords big men in risk of picking up fouls early. If theyre sitting on the bench it could be a long game for the Cardinal.

title: Touch-Up Icing and Broken Legs
description: Heres the play: Minnesota defenseman Kurtis Foster and Sharks forward Torrey Mitchell, one of the fastest players in the league, fly down the ice on an icing. Mitchell gives Foster a tiny shove and Foster crashes into the boards with a broken leg.

title: Baghdad Bureau Q&A
description: Iraqis discuss what they expect from the next five years.

title: Slowing Down Memphis
description: NORTH LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  With top-seeded Memphis playing less than 150 miles away from its campus this week, the Tigers traveled here Wednesday night on a charter bus.

title: Where the Squares Are
description: Two Nissan Cubes were redecorated inside and out by students at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn. But the cars ended up on display for only the two auto show press days on the lower level of the Jacob Javits Center, far away from the Nissan stand, where the Denki Cube, an electric version of the small car got all the attention.

title: Where the Squares Are
description: Two Nissan Cubes were redecorated inside and out by students at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn. But the cars ended up on display for only the two auto show press days on the lower level of the Jacob Javits Center, far away from the Nissan stand, where the Denki Cube, an electric version of the small car got all the attention.  (Photo: The Nielus, a Nissan Cube customized by Pratt students. (Photograph by Hiroko Masuike for The New York Times))   The Cube is a small city car, similar to the Scion xB. Right now, it is sold only in Japan. But Nissan announced that it will bring the next generation model to the United States next summer, and hopes to attract the young and the savvy.  The Cube is a car in which to go slow, the students said, reflecting real-world driving conditions in Brooklyn. Both student Cubes, named Quaz and Nielus, are adorned with very frenetic surface treatments. "The outside is edgy and vibrating with the buzz and beat of Brooklyn," the Quaz students said in a statement, "while the interior represents an apartment that takes the edge off at the end of the day." The students also designed uniforms to match.   (Photo: The tricked-out Cubes were on display only during the media preview of the New York auto show. (Photograph by Hiroko Masuike for The New York Times))   Nissan executives are still discussing where to show the student Cubes again. They may go on tour and may be shown at the Los Angeles auto show in November. They will be on view during Pratt days in May.  Related:  Full Coverage: New York Auto Show

title: Greed Is Good
description: Going into its game with Kansas State, Southern California was a trendy pick to make a deep run in the tournament. The knock on U.S.C.? Their all-world talent, O.J. Mayo, can get greedy.

title: Fridays Link: In Helping Journalists, a Publicist Helps Himself
description: Several months ago, I wrote about the clever Facebook page, Help a Reporter, put up by the publicist, Peter Shankman, where he shared requests from reporters looking for sources with his large group of Facebook friends. He did it to be of service to journalists, presumably so that they would happily pick up the phone when he called to pitch his clients. His little experiment worked.

title: Arkansas Has Little Love for Texas
description: NORTH LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  Earlier this week, Texas Coach Rick Barnes warned Arkansas fans not to treat his team poorly during its trip here for the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Black Cars Go Green
description: Automotive reporter Lawrence Ulrich searches for a replacement to the ubiquitous triple-black Lincoln Town Car.

title: The Cougars Take Their Time
description: Washington State started the second half with four efficient half-court possessions. In the half court the Cougars only take good shots. They love to milk the clock and that might be the perfect antidote to a team that likes to get up and down like Winthrop.

title: Big Blowouts, Few Surprises
description: Connor Ennis and former Penn basketball player Stephen Danley discuss the less-than surprising early results.

title: Photograph of Bill Clinton and Rev. Wright Surfaces
description: During one of the most difficult periods in the presidency of Bill Clinton, he addressed a group of clerics at an annual prayer breakfast in September 1998 just as the Starr report outlining his dalliance with Monica Lewinsky was about to be published.

title: Peays Power of Positive Thinking
description: NORTH LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  To illustrate that underdogs are capable of winning in the N.C.A.A. tournament, Austin Peay Coach Dave Loos had his team watch the Governors first-round upset of Illinois from 1987.

description: Update: Belmont misses a shot just past half court at the buzzer. Duke wins, 71-70, avoiding the first major upset of the tournament.

title: An Upset Veteran
description: TAMPA, Fla.  With Vanderbilt and Connecticut as the marquee teams, nobodys drawing comparisons between this regional site and, say, the N.B.A.s Western Conference.

title: Stepping Into the Spotlight
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Nobody wanted to interview the Drake senior point guard Adam Emmenecker during the teams preseason media day. A walk-on four years ago, he was finally awarded a scholarship one day before the 2007-8 school year began.

title: Defensive Adjustment Sparks Fighting Irish
description: Its obvious that Notre Dame can light it up. Big Luke Harangody is incredibly tough to guard inside, and the team as a whole shoots over 40 percent from 3-point range. But early on against George Mason the Fighting Irish defense has been equally impressive.

title: They Pulled A Belmont
description: It didnt take long before this N.C.A.A. tournament left us with a possible addition to the sports vernacular. On the postgame podium, Belmont guard Justin Hare succinctly summed up the legacy of No. 15 Belmonts 71-70 loss to No. 2 Duke.

description: It was no secret what Wisconsin wanted to do in the second half against Cal State Fullerton. Then again, it never is.

title: Luxury development plan in the Bahamas wins round in court
description: Developers of a long-delayed 585-acre resort and residential project in the Bahamas are claiming victory, after the Bahamas court of appeals affirmed the legality of the development last month.

title: 2.6 Billion With No Place to Go (to the Toilet)
description: In 1978, fresh out of college, I traveled to the South Pacific to study mans relationship to the sea in isolated island communities. I settled in with a family in a tiny village at the end of a dirt road on Raiatea, in French Polynesia.

title: Partying Like Its 1929
description: If Ben Bernanke manages to save the financial system from collapse, he will  rightly  be praised for his heroic efforts.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A television review in Weekend last Friday about John Adams, the new HBO mini-series, misstated the timing of the illness of one of the Adams children. It followed an inoculation for smallpox; it did not precede the inoculation. The review also referred incorrectly to the man who was tarred and feathered by a mob. He was a customs agent, not a tea merchant.

title: High-Profile Trial Lawyer Agrees to Guilty Plea
description: Melvyn I. Weiss on Thursday became the latest prominent  to some, notorious  trial lawyer to agree to plead guilty to federal criminal charges, acknowledging his role in a scheme to make hidden side payments to plaintiffs in class-action lawsuits filed by his firm, Milberg Weiss.

description: Paris

title: Late Style, Young Performers
description: Late style is a tricky concept. It is also the topic of a three-concert series by the Brentano String Quartet, which played the second engagement at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday night.

title: Russian Ire at U.S. Missile Plan Seems to Ease After Talks
description: MOSCOW  In the wake of high-level talks between the United States and Russia, the Kremlin appears to be expressing somewhat less hostility toward the Bush administrations plan for a missile defense system in Poland and the Czech Republic.

title: Michigan Lawmakers Wont Back a New Primary
description: WASHINGTON  There will be no new primary in Michigan.

title: Richardson Endorses Obama
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico delivered a forceful endorsement of Senator Barack Obama for president on Friday, urging Democrats to unite behind his candidacy to move the nation beyond its racial and partisan divide.

title: State Known as Anti-Tax Hears Calls for Reform
description: DURHAM, N.H.  For decades, it has virtually been a requirement that elected state officials in New Hampshire take The Pledge, a promise not to institute a broad-based income or sales tax.

title: Kansas State Has the Better Supporting Cast
description: OMAHA  Tired but gratified, Kansas State forward Bill Walker was on the bench when the horn sounded to end Kansas States 80-67 first-round upset of Southern California. That placed Walker near the end of the postgame handshake line.

title: For the Wildcats, All That Remains Is Sweat and Tears
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  With three seconds left in Marquettes 74-66 victory over Kentucky on Thursday afternoon in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, Golden Eagles guard Dominic James walked over to the Wildcats bench.

title: In This Corner, the Challenger
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2009 Dodge Challenger SE and Challenger R/T

title: Slump Moves From Wall St. to Main St.
description: In Seattle, sales at a long-established hardware store, Pacific Supply, are suddenly dipping. In Oklahoma City, couples planning their weddings are demonstrating uncustomary thrift, forgoing Dungeness crab and special linens. And in many cities, the registers at department stores like Nordstrom on the higher end and J. C. Penney in the middle are ringing less often.

title: Moodys Weighs Changes to Its Municipal Ratings
description: Responding to criticism that ratings firms underrate municipal debt relative to corporate bonds, one such agency, Moodys Investor Service, said on Thursday that it was considering changes to its ratings system.

title: Midwest Still Threatened by Floods
description: Heavy rains moved out of the sodden Midwest on Thursday after days of downpours that led the National Weather Service to post flood warnings from Texas to Pennsylvania. Although the rain has largely stopped falling, authorities warned that rivers in some areas could crest over flood stage as water continued to run off the saturated land.

title: Obama Shifts Focus to Economic Toll of War
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama tried again on Thursday to shift his campaign away from a focus on race that had threatened to envelop his candidacy, and bring other issues to the fore, notably the Iraq war and the economy.

title: Russia Arrests 2 Tied to BP Joint Venture
description: MOSCOW  Russian security services have detained an employee of BPs Russian joint venture and are accusing that man and his brother of industrial espionage, according to a statement released Thursday.

title: Climate Change? Been There, Done That
description: If you dont think climate change produces winners as well as losers, consider this: In the 12th and 13th centuries England exported wine to France. Vineyards also flourished in improbable regions like southern Norway and eastern Prussia. A centuries-long spell of mild, predictable weather blessed Western Europe with abundant crops, healthy populations and budget surpluses sufficient to finance projects like Chartres Cathedral.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Belgium Forms Coalition Government, Ending Standoff
description: BRUSSELS  Belgium finally got a new government on Thursday, after a nine-month political crisis that prompted speculation that the country might split, but many voters say that the new five-party coalition may be too weak to last.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Frank Ayd, 87, Who Advanced Thorazine Use, Is Dead
description: Dr. Frank J. Ayd Jr., a psychiatrist who by studying his patients responses to early antipsychotic and antidepressant drugs helped give birth to and nurture the field of psychopharmacology, died Monday in Baltimore. He was 87.

title: France: Woman Who Sought Euthanasia Dies
description: A woman who was refused a request for medical help to die, Chantal Sbire, was found dead at her home in Plombires-les-Dijon in eastern France. A court in Dijon had refused her request to receive a lethal dose of barbiturates under a doctors supervision because it violated medical ethics and a law enacted in 2005 that allows passive euthanasia but prohibits assisted suicide. Ms. Sbire, 52, a mother of three, suffered from a rare form of cancer that burrowed through her sinuses and nasal cavities. A government spokesman told Reuters there would be a review to determine whether there is now the will to go further than the law of 2005. Active euthanasia is legal in the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg and Switzerland.

title: Hyundai Books a Genesis
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2010 Hyundai Genesis Coupe

title: Taxes Cut and Promises Unkept
description: Taxpayers may find some solace in one aspect of the sex scandals enveloping the two governors that New York has had in the past week. At a time of economic duress, David A. Paterson seems more prepared to work with a tight budget than Eliot Spitzer was.

title: Break Time
description: Early in the documentary Planet B-Boy, an experienced street dancer asserts that break dancing is as legitimate as any dance that has ever existed. This brisk nonfiction feature directed by Benson Lee makes his case, showing international teams of break dancers  or b-boys  battling to win best-in-the-nation status in their home countries, then going on to compete in the 2005 world finals at the Volkswagenhalle in Braunschweig, Germany.

title: Meeting Cute on the Eve of Destruction
description: Here comes old Armageddon again. During the past several years the apocalypse has been turning up with such regularity on movie screens and the pages of best sellers that its starting to feel like a bad (and melted and mutilated) penny. But that doesnt mean you should count out an engaging little play about the end of the world that opened Thursday night at Ars Nova.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about the legislative record and political career of David A. Paterson on the eve of his installation as governor of New York included an outdated reference to the job duties of his wife, Michelle Paige Paterson. She oversees wellness programs at the Health Insurance Plan of New York; she no longer works on its charitable activities.

title: Sovereign Funds Agree to Shun Geopolitical Investing
description: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration won a commitment Thursday from two prominent foreign government investment funds to disavow geopolitical goals in their investments in the United States and elsewhere, a step the administration hoped would set an example for other funds.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Styles section on Thursday about the Mayflower Hotel in Washington referred imprecisely to Marion S. Barry Jr., the former Washington mayor who was convicted in 1990 on a misdemeanor drug charge after being accused of using cocaine while staying at the Mayflower in 1989. Mr. Barrys possession of drugs at the hotel was described to the authorities by an eyewitness; he was not seen smoking a crack pipe. (That happened in 1990 when a federal sting operation caught him on videotape smoking a crack pipe while staying at what was then the Vista Hotel in Washington.)

title: Duke Escapes, but Is Exposed by Belmont
description: WASHINGTON  No. 15 seed Belmont came tantalizingly close to stunning second-seeded Duke in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament Thursday night in a game that will most likely leave two distinct legacies.

title: Rescue Plans That Alarm Shareholders
description: SANTA FE, N.M.

title: Indictments in International Sales of Forged Art
description: An international art forgery ring has been dismantled by the F.B.I. and the Spanish police, Bloomberg News reported. Seven people have been indicted in two art-fraud schemes that netted a combined $5 million. The ring had tricked hundreds of buyers into purchasing counterfeit prints. United States Attorney Patrick J. Fitzgerald, at a news conference in Chicago, said, Literally thousands of people in different countries and on different continents may come to learn that when they thought they bought an original work signed by Picasso or Dal or Chagall, they in fact bought a fake. Four Americans, along with two Italians and one Spaniard, were charged. Prosecutors said some prints had been sold on eBay and others through two art dealers in Northbrook, Ill.

title: European Banks Try to Inject a Bit of Calm
description: FRANKFURT  Central banks in Europe injected cash into the financial system Thursday in an attempt to bolster nervous banks through the Easter holiday weekend.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Wednesday about Roger Federers resurgence at the Pacific Life Open referred imprecisely to the performances of a potential opponent, David Nalbandian, in their previous head-to-head matches. Although Nalbandian has a .500 record against Federer, he has achieved nearly all of his success on hardcourts like those in this tournament or on carpet, not mostly on clay.

title: Verizon and AT&T Win Big in Auction of Spectrum
description: The two largest cellphone service providers  Verizon Wireless and AT&T  won a greater swath of radio spectrum in the government auction that ended this week, heading off new competition that could have led to lower prices for consumers.

title: Paul Scofield, British Actor, Dies at 86
description: Paul Scofield, the acclaimed British actor who created the indelible role of Sir Thomas More in Robert Bolts play A Man for All Seasons and then repeated it on film in 1966 in an Oscar-winning performance, died Wednesday near his home in southern England. He was 86.

title: Correction: A Laid-Back Village With Lots of Snow and Comfort
description: A picture caption last Friday with the Havens column, about Ellicottville, N.Y., and its two ski areas, misstated the name of the ski resort shown. It is Holiday Valley  not HoliMont, the other resort mentioned in the column.

title: Photo Dealer Takes CBGB Gallery Space
description: The space that used to be the punk bar CBGB, at 315 Bowery, will soon become a John Varvatos boutique. Next door, the former CBs Gallery at 313 Bowery is also getting a high-end makeover: the Morrison Hotel Gallery, which sells fine-art prints of classic rock photographs, will open a location in that space on March 27, with a plan to preserve some of the original, grungy GBGB dcor, including bathroom graffiti and fliers that had been buried in an inner wall. The work of Steve Joester, who chronicled 1970s British punks, will be the first exhibition. In April the gallery will open a show devoted to Bob Gruen, the New York photographer who captured much of the first generation at CBGB. June will bring The Art of Motorcycles. Morrison Hotel, founded in 2001, will maintain its gallery in SoHo as well as locations in Los Angeles and La Jolla, Calif.

title: Store in a Cool, Fertile Place: 1950s California
description: ANDOVER, Mass.  The cool was born in New York. It was in Manhattan that Miles Davis and the nine-piece group he convened in the late 1940s forged a tightly understated alternative to the hot expressionism of bebop and recorded the hugely influential tracks later collected in the album Birth of the Cool. But it was in California in the 1950s that cool jazz and cool art in general took root and flourished.

title: Islands of Calm
description: MICHAEL BENISTY knows what it is to be love struck. When I have a crush on something or someone, I make a fast decision, said Mr. Benisty, a stockbroker in New York.

title: Woods Is Two Back as the Wind Shifts and Doral Loses Its Bluster
description: MIAMI  The wind shifted, the Blue Monster was defenseless and a party broke out during the first round of the W.G.C.-CA Championship at the Doral Resort & Spa on Thursday. A regular fiesta, it was, with Miguel ngel Jimnez, a redheaded, ponytailed Spaniard, playing his first competitive round at Doral and shooting a seven-under-par 65 to tie for the lead with Geoff Ogilvy of Australia.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday with an article about projected automobile sales for 2008 mislabeled the data. United States sales are forecast to be in a range of 14.9 million to 15.7 million vehicles, not $14.9 million to $15.7 million.

title: Patterson Cut by Nationals
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets have a fairly good idea of what Johan Santana can do as a pitcher, and they are gradually learning how talented he is as a hitter. But they were unable to gauge how one affected the other until Thursday night.

title: Some Tibetan Exiles Reject Middle Way
description: DHARAMSALA, India  Long live the Dalai Lama! is the most common cry on the streets here.

description: AROUND TOWN

title: Moment-by-Moment Narrative from Officer in Sean Bell Case
description: An undercover detective, in detailed and at times apologetic grand jury testimony made public for the first time on Thursday, gave a second-by-second account of what led him to fire the first shots at Sean Bells car after, he said, Mr. Bell had ignored his orders to halt and had tried to run him over.
