description: Here is information about the shows mentioned. All are at theaters in Manhattan. Ticket information: ticketmaster.com, (212) 307-4100; telecharge.com, (212) 239-6200:

title: Paramounts Grey Denies Knowing of Any Wiretapping
description: LOS ANGELES  Brad Grey, the chairman of Paramount Pictures, testified on Thursday that he knew nothing of any illicit activity by the Hollywood private eye Anthony Pellicano, who is charged with illegally wiretapping Mr. Greys adversaries in two highly publicized lawsuits.

title: Inspector Is Charged With Filing False Report Before Crane Collapsed
description: A buildings inspector has been arrested and charged with faking a report that he visited a towering construction crane on the East Side of Manhattan on March 4 in response to a complaint. The inspector, the authorities said, never visited the crane, which toppled and killed seven people 11 days later.

title: Working Toward a Future to Rival the Apollos Glittering Past
description: ANY list of New York City landmarks  the Statue of Liberty, the Empire State Building, the Brooklyn Bridge, Central Park  would include, near the top, the Apollo Theater. But unlike those icons, the Apollo has escaped ruin by the skin of its teeth, thanks in large part to Jonelle Procope, the chief executive of the foundation that runs the theater. Tens of millions have been spent restoring parts of the theater in the past five years, but there is still much work to do.

title: Racing the Slopes, Uphill and Down
description: ON a frosty Saturday morning earlier this winter, a posse of skiers lined up at the base of Grand Targhee Resort in Wyoming. The 30 men and 4 women were mainly in their late 20s to early 40s and embodied the unstudied athleticism of someone who might just run up a mountain for fun.

description: POP

title: Wisconsin Pulls Away Late to Top Cal State Fullerton
description: Wisconsin survived, but not before Cal State Fullerton gave it a scare.

title: Retrieving a Hat, Then Trouble
description: A hat cost Sean Bell his life. The encounters that escalated in the moments before he was killed by police officers began when he went back for what he had left behind at his bachelor party at the Club Kalua, one of Mr. Bells friends testified on Thursday.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: See You Next Year
description: IT would be a stretch to say that Marci Gruber was looking forward to that February trip to Florida 17 years ago. Yes, there was golf and tennis and sun. But the weeklong excursion with her husband, Ken, and their two young children was far more obligation than vacation.

title: A Town Trying Not to Live Up to Its Name
description: SLOUGH, England  What is it about this seemingly blameless town that makes people act as if there is a huge Kick Me sign plastered across its back?

title: Nancy Pelosi, Mystery Delegate
description: Nancy Pelosi is no ordinary superdelegate. Even dubbing her a super-duper delegate might not do her justice. Ms. Pelosi is in a class by herself when it comes to the nominating whirl since, as speaker of the House, she will preside over the Democratic National Convention as chairwoman.

title: Guston on Paper at the Morgan
description: GUSTON ON PAPER

title: Traveling With Charley
description: WHEN it comes time to head to the vacation home, the big question may not be whether to pack the golf clubs, but whether to pack the family pet.

title: Obama Campaign Says Clinton Misrepresented Her Support for Nafta
description: Senator Barack Obamas campaign on Thursday accused Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of purposely distorting her position on the North American Free Trade Agreement, pointing to newly released White House schedules that show Mrs. Clinton attended several meetings on the trade pact while first lady.

title: School Chief Tells Council Deep Cuts Are Needed
description: Facing a souring economy and city and state budget gaps, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein testified Thursday that he was considering scaling back everything from consultants to testing contracts but still thought it would be necessary to make direct cuts to schools.

title: Seeking Profits (and Respect) in Ownership
description: REMEMBER the riddle that was all the rage in elementary school, What has four wheels and flies? (Answer: A garbage truck.) Here is a contemporary version, from Madison Avenue: What has 24 wheels and flies?

title: Marking a Milestone With a Light Touch
description: After settling into her station at the piano on Wednesday night at Dizzys Club Coca-Cola, Marian McPartland took a stab at solidarity. Is anybody else here 90? she asked, polling the crowded room.

title: Queens New Album
description: The rock band Queen has announced plans to release its first studio album in 13 years. This will also be the first Queen album without Freddie Mercury, who died in 1991, the BBC reported. Scheduled to be released in September, the album will feature Paul Rodgers, above center, who has replaced Mercury in live shows, and the guitarist Brian May, above right, and the drummer Roger Taylor. The last Queen album, Made in Heaven, released in 1995, contained material recorded with Mercury.

title: Measuring a Coachs Value Merely by Wins
description: Washington

title: 'Idol', as Usual
description: The rocker nurse Amanda Overmyer was eliminated Wednesday from American Idol on Fox, leaving 10 contestants, as the shows audience of 25.5 million viewers easily outpaced its four network competitors combined in the 9 p.m. time slot, according to Nielsens estimates. Fox finished No. 1 in the nights ratings, leading the 8 oclock hour among adults 18 to 49 with The Moment of Truth, which went head to head with CBSs Survivor: Micronesia. But that long-running CBS reality show drew slightly more total viewers: 11.3 million, compared with 10.7 million for The Moment of Truth. CBS finished second on the night but struggled at 9 and 10 with Big Brother (6.7 million) followed by a CSI: NY rerun (6.2 million). NBCs Law & Order won the 10 oclock hour (10.5 million), helping NBC finish third over all, just ahead of ABC.

title: Spartans Use Balance to Advance
description: DENVER  Michigan State arrived at the N.C.A.A. tournament believing that its long-range hopes rested largely in the steady hands of the senior guard Drew Neitzel, who has been urged to become more assertive on offense.

title: Georgias Fortunes Run Out Against Xavier
description: WASHINGTON  In silver marker on his black Nikes, Xavier point guard Drew Lavender scrawled a concise message: NOPE!

title: Disney Plans Show on Young Band
description: The Disney Channel has given the go-ahead to a reality series about the Jonas Brothers, a young pop band with three brothers. The series, to begin this spring, will chronicle the lives of the platinum-selling trio (from left above, Nick, Joe and Kevin) on their current tour, Reuters reported.

title: Socialized Compensation
description: How can one feel sorry for James Cayne? The potential losses of the chairman and former chief executive of Bear Stearns must rank up there with the biggest in modern history. The value of his stake in Bear Stearns collapsed from about $1 billion a year ago to as little as $14 million at the price JPMorgan Chase offered for the teetering bank on Sunday.

title: Never Too Old to Play Loves Fool
description: Verdis Falstaff is a figure of fun, an irascible, bloated ruffian full of devious tricks to woo married ladies. But there is also an underlying streak of melancholy to this aging rogue. In Leon Majors appealing staging, a co-production of New York City Opera and Glimmerglass Opera, which returned to the New York State Theater on Wednesday, the bass-baritone Jan Opalach conveyed both the buffoonish and fleetingly pensive aspects of the title character in a performance notable for its comic flair.

title: China Tensions Could Sway Vote in Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  Chinas suppression of protests in Tibet and missteps by the opposition Nationalist Party have made the Taiwanese presidential election on Saturday an unexpectedly close race. What once seemed to be an insuperable lead for the Nationalist candidate, Ma Ying-jeou, has narrowed considerably, politicians and political analysts said.

title: What Will Be Left of Gehrys Vision for Brooklyn?
description: The growing possibility that much of the multibillion-dollar Atlantic Yards development in Brooklyn will be scrapped because of a lack of financing may be a bitter pill for its developer, Forest City Ratner. But its also a painful setback for urban planning in New York.

title: U.S. Cuts Off Visas in Minsk in a Dispute With Belarus
description: MOSCOW  The United States Embassy in Minsk has temporarily stopped issuing visas to citizens of Belarus in response to pressure by the government there to reduce its personnel. Tensions between the countries have intensified in recent weeks in response to sanctions that the United States has imposed on Belarus, its top state-owned businesses and senior officials.

title: Plan to Use Paper Ballots Is Reversed in Colorado
description: DENVER  A plan to use only paper ballots in Colorado in this Novembers election, which was announced with bipartisan hoopla in January to replace the states troubled electronic voting machine system, died quietly in a state legislature committee room on Thursday.

title: Obama Links Effects of War Costs to Fragility in the Economy
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va.  Senator Barack Obama on Thursday blamed the fragile economy on careless and incompetent execution of the Iraq war, imploring voters in this swing state to consider the trickle-down economic consequences of the war as they choose a successor to President Bush.

title: Stages Shrek Chosen
description: Brian dArcy James will play the title role in Shrek the Musical, DreamWorks Theatricals and Neal Street Productions Ltd. announced. The Broadway show, to begin previews in November, will also star Chester Gregory II as Donkey, John Tartaglia as Pinocchio, Sutton Foster as Princess Fiona, Christopher Sieber as Lord Farquaad, and Kecia Lewis-Evans as the Dragon.

title: When Tradition and Taunts Collide: Gay Hockey Fans Criticize Garden
description: During the final 10 minutes of many Rangers home games, the spotlights focus on Section 407 as Larry Goodman, a longtime season-ticket holder, pumps up the crowd with a goofy dance.

title: G.O.P. Congressman From Buffalo Region Says Hell Retire at the End of the Year
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Thomas M. Reynolds, a five-term Republican legislator from the Buffalo area and perhaps the most influential New Yorker in the House until his party lost control of the chamber, said on Thursday that he would step down at the end of the year.

title: Amanda McBroom Is Alive and Well and Singing About It
description: Although the comparison is a bit of a stretch, Amanda McBroom could be described as a softer, gentler American answer to Jacques Brel, the Belgian-French singer-songwriter she has idolized since she appeared many years ago in a production of Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris.

title: Sex, Blood and Exotica in an Anti-Thriller Thriller
description: Im fairly certain one reason that the French director Olivier Assayas made Boarding Gate is that he wanted to watch the Italian actress Asia Argento strut around in black underwear and punishing heels. And why not? Ms. Argento looks delectable if somewhat demented in Boarding Gate, in which she comes across as a postmodern Pearl White, who starred in silent adventure serials like The Perils of Pauline. Ms. Argento seems to invite trouble, and Mr. Assayas, who has a way of capturing the seemingly ineffable, has a thing for troubled, troubling women.

title: Officer Adds Charges to Lawsuit Against City
description: When an Egyptian-born correction officer working in an elite antiterrorism unit of the New York Police Department sued the city in 2006, he said that although members of the unit had been subjected to hundreds of virulent anti-Arab and anti-Muslim e-mail messages by a city contractor, the police had done too little to stop the slurs.

title: Protector With Big Shtick for 3 High School Nerds
description: At the moment it seems as if no major Hollywood studio will release a comedy without Judd Apatows name somewhere on the label. This is perhaps overdue vindication for a man who once languished making brilliant television shows that too few people wanted to watch, but it also carries risks of backlash and brand dilution.

title: The Seeds Were Close, the Game Wasnt
description: OMAHA  With 4:42 left to play in the first half, Kent State Coach Jim Christian called his second timeout. One more, and it would have matched the number of baskets the discombobulated Golden Flashes had to that point.

title: Something to Focus on Amid Indianas Instability
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  The Indiana mens basketball team has a distraction this week from reports of N.C.A.A. rules violations, the departure of the sullied coach Kelvin Sampson, a one-game suspension of the starter Jamarcus Ellis and the formation of a 10-member search committee to find a new coach.

title: Captain as Maestro, Conducting Amid Crises
description: On a recent winter evening in Mosul, Capt. David Sandoval sat at his desk dealing with the days various crises.

title: United Airlines Grounds 7 Planes
description: United Airlines grounded seven Boeing 747s Thursday when it was told by the Federal Aviation Administration that a maintenance contractor, Korean Air Lines, had checked the planes altimeters using an instrument that was not properly calibrated.

title: Checking In, Glamour-Free
description: THERE was a time, on my frequent trips to the West Coast, when I used to stay at chic West Hollywood hotels, in rooms furnished with designer bottled waters, vinyl beanbag chairs and all manner of pay-per-view television entertainments. Each morning I proudly strode past fitness rooms, spas and barbershops I never visited, and each night I went to bed contentedly knowing that the hotel bar was packed with the sorts of people who would never give me the time of day.

title: Surfs Down on Titan, 50 Miles Below the Surface, Scientists Say
description: Saturns moon Titan is encased in a thick, smoggy haze obscuring its surface, and planetary scientists speculated that the large moon, a little larger than the planet Mercury, might be awash in an ocean of hydrocarbons.

title: Liquid Ocean on a Moon of Saturn?
description: Because Titan, Saturns largest moon, is spinning faster than expected, there is likely a liquid ocean 50 or 60 miles below the surface, a team of scientists reported in Fridays issue of the journal Science. Based on radar images taken on repeated passes by NASAs Cassini spacecraft, the scientists tracked motion on the surface and found the surface to be rotating slightly faster than expected. They believe seasonal winds in Titans atmosphere are pushing on the outer shell, causing it to spin faster. For the outer shell to spin independently, there must be a liquid ocean, probably made of water and ammonia, separating the shell from the inner part of Titan, the scientists reported.

title: Repression in Tibet: The World Must Speak Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Investigators to Put Focus on Cansecos Link to Clemens
description: For years, Jos Canseco has been a frequent guest on WEEI, the sports radio station in Boston. So it was predictable that the station would reach out to him Dec. 13, when George J. Mitchell issued his report on the links between baseball and performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Poker Faces
description: The actors certainly look as if theyre having a good time, and if youre in the right mood, you might too. A disposable, moderately humorous distraction directed by Zak Penn from an idea he cooked up with Matt Bierman, The Grand is a strenuously faked, digital-video documentary about the ins and outs, heavy bets and close calls that take place during a high-stakes Las Vegas poker game. In truth, its an overcrowded party to which the rest of us have been only grudgingly invited, a would-be laugh-in with various funny types  notably Woody Harrelson, Cheryl Hines and Richard Kind  and a whole lot of slapdash filler.

title: Sovereigns of All Theyre Assigned, Captains Have Many Missions to Oversee
description: JISR DIALA, Iraq  During the war in Iraq, young Army and Marine captains have become American viceroys, officers with large sectors to run and near-autonomy to do it. In military parlance, they are the ground-owners. In practice, they are power brokers.

title: Vail Ski Resort
description: Updated: December 2008

title: New Analysis Suggests Earlier Start for Upright Walking
description: As early as six million years ago, apparently close to the beginning of the human lineage, an ancestral species had already developed the transforming ability for upright walking, scientists reported on Thursday.

title: More Fit for the Dollar
description: Introduced Wednesday:  2009 Honda Fit

title: Living With Melanoma
description: To the Editor:

title: Upstate G.O.P. Congressman Retiring
description: WILLIAMSVILLE, N.Y.  United State Representative Thomas M. Reynolds announced Thursday that he will not seek another term in Congress representing the district that stretches between the suburbs of Buffalo and Rochester.

title: New to the Glossary: A Pas de Multimedia
description: LONDON  The choreographer Christopher Wheeldon is always extending himself. So what if you had a problem with his last piece? In his next one hes doing something completely different. And in this refusal to be pinned down we see much of what is admirable and promising about him.

title: State Dept. Finds Breaches of Obamas File
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department has fired two employees and reprimanded a third for improperly opening electronic information from the passport file of Senator Barack Obama, State Department officials said Thursday.

title: Theater Listings
description: SECOND GENERATION  This company, currently in its 11th season, counts among its goals the development of a new generation of Asian-American theater artists. While there are other, older Asian-American companies in New York  the Ma-Yi Theater Company (19 years old) and Pan Asian Repertory Theater (going on 31) come to mind  Second Generation has been carving out its own identity, just as its predecessors did. According to Lloyd Suh, the companys artistic director, Second Generation collaborates with other local companies (he is even a director of the Ma-Yi Writers Lab), but also maintains an individual perspective.

title: Monkey Gods to Textiles: Far East on the East Side
description: This year Asia Week in New York has stretched into Asia Fortnight. The two art fairs that usually coincide on a single weekend have spread out to fall on consecutive weekends.

title: Stalls for Scandal, Mens and Womens, No Waiting
description: Standing in the dark, heat-deprived restrooms at Bethesda Fountain in Central Park waiting for the Irish Arts Centers Ladies & Gents to start, you may fault the timing of this site-specific venture. Its March. Its frigid.

title: Crime-Solving Legends and Those Who Want to Be
description: Lisa Scottoline is known for great-looking legs, not necessarily her own. The gams turn up systematically on the covers of the punchy, wisecracking thrillers that Ms. Scottoline delivers with clockwork efficiency on a more or less annual basis. Two-word titles like Daddys Girl, Dirty Blonde and Devils Corner further play to readers Pavlovian instincts, illustrating the packaging tricks that are obligatory for a mystery franchise. Ms. Scottolines latest is Lady Killer, and it does not break the mold.

title: Working-Class Swagger
description: The synopsis of The Hammer makes it sound like a long-lost Billy Crystal movie: a smart-alecky, self-destructive Los Angeles handyman named Jerry Ferro (Adam Carolla) loses his job and his girlfriend, then reconnects with his past as a Golden Gloves boxer and tries to qualify for the United States Olympic team at 40.

title: Borders Considers Putting Itself Up for Sale
description: Struggling against both online and big-box retailers, the Borders Group, the bookseller, said Thursday that it had hired two investment banks to advise it on a potential sale and had turned to its largest shareholder for additional money.

title: Frank Berger, 94, Miltown Creator, Dies
description: Dr. Frank M. Berger, who helped start the modern era of drug development with his invention of Miltown, the first mass-market psychiatric drug and a forerunner of medical and cultural phenomena like Valium and Prozac, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 94.

title: Collection Agencies Add Scarce Jobs in Hard-Hit Region
description: BUFFALO  In an unremarkable strip mall in the south end of this city, workers were installing 144 new desks last month at Capital Management Services. About 50 feet away, a dozen fresh hires were taking a two-week training course.

title: Escaping a Meek Old Age With an Erotic New Job
description: Irina Palm may be the work of a German-born Belgian director, but it belongs to a sturdy and very British genre: the naughty-granny comedy, in which an older woman is liberated and rejuvenated by an excursion into vice. In this case the iffy activity is sex for hire, which may give the film a jolt of topicality for New York audiences. The workaday London sex shop where parts of Irina Palm take place is decidedly down-market compared with the Emperors Club V.I.P., but it also may be less tawdry. In this kind of movie, sleaze and salaciousness are quickly banished in favor of sentimental good cheer.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: On Visit, Pelosi Offers Support to Dalai Lama
description: DHARAMSALA, India  House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, visiting the Dalai Lamas headquarters here on Friday, described recent protests in Tibet as a challenge to conscience of the world and pressed for an investigation into whether the Dalai Lama masterminded that unrest as the Chinese government has alleged.

title: 3 Moguls in Talks to Buy Newsday
description: Three of New Yorks biggest moguls are in discussions to buy Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, from the Tribune Company, people involved in the sale process said Thursday.

title: Vols Smith Is Fulfilling a Last Wish From His Father
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Tennessee Coach Bruce Pearl had two years to pour some bitterness into the recruiting wound and see just how Tyler Smith liked it. He could have reminded Smith in all sorts of ways that the Volunteers had been to the N.C.A.A. tournament in 2006 and 2007, that this team  Smiths home-state team  was doing just fine without him.

title: Footnotes
description: The actor Shia LaBeouf has pleaded not guilty to an unlawful-smoking charge, according to The Associated Press. After a Los Angeles County Court judge issued a $1,000 bench warrant for Mr. LaBeoufs arrest, the lawyer Michael Norris entered the plea on his behalf on Wednesday. A hearing is set for April 24. If convicted, Mr. LaBeouf, 21, faces six months in jail and a $1,000 fine. ... The John S. and James L. Knight Foundation is donating $25 million to the Newseum, dedicated to the history of news, The Washington Post reported. The donation will be the biggest single gift from a media organization to the Washington museum, to open April 11.

title: At Harvard, Students Muslim Traditions Are a Topic of Debate
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Two issues of Muslim practice  whether the call to prayer should ring out across Harvard Yard and whether the university should grant women separate gym hours  have unleashed small waves of controversy over how Harvard practices tolerance.

title: Storming the Campuses
description: This winter, the armies of Yale invaded Massachusetts and conquered Harvard. Cornells troops turned Dartmouths militia into a vassal force. Columbia allied itself with Yale and occupied Long Island, before getting routed by the Princeton-Cornell alliance.

title: Vatican Security Worries Over bin Laden Tape
description: ROME  The Vatican on Thursday rejected an audiotaped accusation from Osama bin Laden that Pope Benedict XVI was leading a new Crusade against Muslims, but Italian security officials were concerned about the threats included in Mr. bin Ladens new message.

title: Syracuse Wins in N.I.T
description: Jonny Flynn had 23 points to lead four Syracuse starters in double figures as the Orange advanced to the quarterfinals of the National Invitation Tournament with a victory over visiting Maryland on Thursday night.Arinze Onuaku added 14 points and 14 rebounds for Syracuse (21-13), which will play the winner of Saturdays second-round game between Massachusetts and Akron. Paul Harris added 19 points and Donte Greene tossed in 16.Top-seeded Syracuse used a 15-5 spurt late in the second half to pull away from Maryland (19-15), which got 23 points and 11 rebounds from James Gist before he fouled out in the final minute, and a career-high 21 from Bambale Osby. (AP)

title: China Tensions Could Sway Vote in Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  Violent unrest in Tibet has created shock waves in another volatile region on Chinas periphery, shaking up the presidential election in Taiwan and sapping support for the candidate Beijing had hoped would win handily.

title: As We Enter Year 6 of the War in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Passport Files of 3 Candidates Were Improperly Viewed
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department said on Friday that it was investigating several incidents in which the passport files of all three presidential contenders were improperly accessed by employees.

title: Colorado Court Rules No Smoking Means Exactly That, Even on Stage
description: DENVER  Would Mrs. Robinson be as much of a smoldering volcano in The Graduate if she could not wave her cigarette so suggestively? Would George and Marthas living room broadsides in Whos Afraid of Virginia Woolf? be equally vicious without their boozy veil of smoke?

title: Parking Rules for Good Friday and Purim
description: Because of Good Friday and Purim, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Basel Symphony Names Director
description: The American conductor Dennis Russell Davies has been named music director of the Basel Symphony Orchestra in Switzerland, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Davies will be filling a position that has been empty since 2006. The appointment begins in the 2009-10 season and will last five years. Mr. Davies, 63, has been chief conductor at the Brooklyn Philharmonic and the New York-based American Composers Orchestra, which he helped found. He will retain his position as chief conductor and music director of the Bruckner Orchestra Linz and the Linz Opera in Austria.

title: Clinton Treats Obama Pastor With Extreme Caution
description: ANDERSON, Ind.  Ever since Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton started running for president, her team has argued that she is more electable than Senator Barack Obama: more experience, as first lady and senator; more spine, after years fighting Republicans; and more popular with key voter blocs, like women, Hispanics and the elderly.

title: UConn and Calhoun Wary of an Upstarts Pedigree
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Coach Bill Griers rsum suggests the University of San Diego Toreros might soon take their place among famous N.C.A.A. tournament upstarts and interlopers.

title: Yankees Top Seats Grow Pricier
description: If youre a Yankees fan with lots of spare cash, parts of the new Yankee Stadium will be for you. Consider two offerings sent to season-ticket holders in an e-mail message Thursday.

title: Saving a Natural Treasure
description: For thousands of years, the Palisades have soared above the west banks of the Hudson River as one of the natural wonders of the East. Its hard to believe that New Jersey officials are allowing builders to chip away wide sections of these rocky cliffs to gain more room for condominium developments that would last, at most, a tiny fraction of that time.

title: Kurt Masur, With Bach and a Choral Force
description: Even when he was younger, Kurt Masur seemed the embodiment of the Old World conductor, a German musician of discipline and rectitude, steeped in the great repertory, technically assured and immune to flashiness. Among the core composers he laid claim to was Bach, who spent the last 27 years of his life in Leipzig, a city closely associated with Mr. Masur, who had a career-defining tenure as music director of the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,984 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Wednesday:

title: Oil and Gold Prices Continue to Slide
description: Oil, gold and other major commodities fell sharply on Thursday, capping their steepest weekly drop in a half-century, as investors fled what many had believed to be the last safe haven in turbulent markets.

title: Tranquillity Between Killington and Okemo
description: ON a weekday in the dead of winter, silence descends over the wide fields of Plymouth, Vt., where sheep and horses graze in the shadows of the Green Mountains. Roads are nearly empty, and business slows to a crawl at the Plymouth Country Store.

title: Notre Dame Ends Shot for Repeat by Mason
description: DENVER  The Pepsi Center crowd was split evenly between Notre Dame fans and those rooting for a memorable surprise. A young woman in the second row held a sign reading, George Mason is this years George Mason.

title: Broadway for Big Kids, Beyond Spoonfuls of Sugar
description: TAKING your kids to a Broadway musical might seem like a no-brainer. What could be more of a treat than the excitement of lights going down, the curtain going up and actors performing live onstage? But beyond the Lion Kings, Mary Poppinses and Little Mermaids, the terrain gets more complicated.

title: Credit Suisse Predicts First Loss Since 2003
description: Credit Suisse said on Thursday that it was likely to post its first quarterly loss since 2003 because of large write-downs and intentional misconduct at its trading desk.

title: Thoroughly Modern Do-Gooders
description: Fashions in goodness change, just like fashions in anything else, and these days some of the very noblest people have assumed the manners of the business world  even though they dont aim for profit. They call themselves social entrepreneurs, and you can find them in the neediest places on earth.

title: Rape in Brooklyn Project, 2 Weeks After Similar Case
description: A 19-year-old woman was raped in a housing project in Brooklyn on Thursday, two weeks after a 30-year-old woman was raped in a stairwell in the same complex, the police said.

title: U.S. Defends Tough Tactics on Spitzer
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department used some of its most intrusive tactics against Eliot Spitzer, examining his financial records, eavesdropping on his phone calls and tailing him during its criminal investigation of the Emperors Club prostitution ring.

title: Tests in Space on Repairing Shuttle Tiles
description: Two NASA astronauts left the International Space Station on Thursday evening to test techniques for repairing delicate shuttle tiles with a kind of orbital spackle.

title: Name this Truck, Please
description: Introduced on Wednesday: Pontiac Sport Truck

title: Doing Something Sketchy? Its Harder to Cover Up Now
description: Among the many humiliations that have befallen Eliot Spitzer lately, there are those that fall under the category of technological. His lack of regard for the traceability of so many financial transactions (some of his led investigators to the prostitution ring) speaks to a certain technological ineptitude  like hearing a friend talk about the husband who promised he would TiVo In Treatment and got her a half-hour of Noggin instead.

title: Washingtons Grand Experiment to Rehouse the Poor
description: WASHINGTON  When District of Columbia officials tore down the decrepit housing project in southeast Washington where Samantha Jackson lived with her teenage son, they promised that they would build a more attractive, mixed-income community and that former tenants like herself could come back.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about this summers Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center, using information from a publicist, referred incorrectly to the debuts of the three young conductors Lionel Bringuier, Edward Gardner and Susanna Malkki. Their appearances at the festival will be their New York debuts, not their American debuts.

title: Allegations Against a Government
description: Who did it? asked the filmmaker Andrei Nekrasov when his friend the exiled Russian agent Alexander Litvinenko died of polonium poisoning in a London hospital in November 2006. That question resonates throughout Poisoned by Polonium: The Litvinenko File, Mr. Nekrasovs extraordinary testament to a man whose incendiary allegations against his government might have had fatal consequences.

title: Public Health Risk Seen as Parents Reject Vaccines
description: SAN DIEGO  In a highly unusual outbreak of measles here last month, 12 children fell ill; nine of them had not been inoculated against the virus because their parents objected, and the other three were too young to receive vaccines.

title: Annan Says U.N. Is Overstretched by Global Conflicts
description: UNITED NATIONS  Kofi Annan, the former secretary general, said Thursday that the United Nations was overstretched in conflict areas and should resist taking on new responsibilities as long as major powers proved unwilling to supply needed support.

title: Fire Marshals Widow Is Indicted in His Killing
description: The widow of a New York City fire marshal has been indicted in his Dec. 2 shooting death in their Staten Island home, culminating an investigation that had been the talk of the community, a law enforcement official said on Thursday.

title: Turkeys Democracy on Trial
description: The lawsuit filed by one of Turkeys top prosecutors last week, asking the countrys Constitutional Court to shut down its largest political party, gravely threatens political and economic stability and Ankaras international reputation.

title: CIT Taps Credit Lines and Talks of Asset Sales
description: Even as financial shares led a stock market rally Thursday, the crisis in the credit markets threatened to engulf one of the nations largest commercial finance companies.

title: American Vintage From Japan
description: Introduced on Wednesday: Scion Hako.

title: No Admission for Evolutionary Biologist at Creationist Film
description: Two evolutionary biologists  P. Z. Myers of the University of Minnesota, Morris, and Richard Dawkins of Oxford  tried to go to the movies at the Mall of America in Minneapolis Thursday evening. Dr. Dawkins got in. Dr. Myers did not.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions last Friday about the opening of the corruption trial of Diane M. Gordon, a New York State assemblywoman from Brooklyn, misspelled, in some copies, the given name of the prosecutor who delivered the opening argument. He is Michel Spanakos, not Michael.

title: Slow Economy Likely to Stall Atlantic Yards
description: The slowing economy, weighed down by a widening credit crisis, is likely to delay the signature office tower and three residential buildings at the heart of the $4 billion Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, the developer said.

title: Segal Awards Named
description: Alisa Weilerstein, a cellist, and Thomas Kail, a stage director, are the winners of the 2008 Martin E. Segal Awards, Lincoln Center announced. The awards, given to rising young artists, include $7,500 to be used for study. Mr. Kail made his Broadway debut with the musical In the Heights. Ms. Weilerstein has performed this season with the Pittsburgh, San Francisco and Toronto Symphonies and the St. Petersburg Chamber Philharmonic in Russia.

title: Art in Review
description: STERLING RUBY

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Chamberlain Resumes Role as an Intimidator
description: DUNEDIN, Fla.  Joba Chamberlain rumbled into the game in the eighth inning, as he did so often during his magical ride last season. When the Yankees needed a bridge to closer Mariano Rivera during the last two months of 2007, Chamberlain was there to provide it.

title: U.S. Travel Plans: Heartland to China
description: Nashville

title: Tis a Gift to Be Complex
description: TIS A GIFT

title: 92nd Street Y Sets Schedule
description: Russian music from the turn of the 20th century, a series of Beethoven string quartets and piano sonatas, and new works by contemporary composers will be part of the 92nd Street Ys 2008-9 concert season, which opens on Oct. 6 with a discussion with the composer John Adams. Among the performers will be the oboist and composer Heinz Holliger, who will celebrate a musical friendship with Elliott Carter in two concerts; the Tokyo String Quartet, which will begin a three-season look at Beethoven with help from Garrick Ohlsson and other pianists; the violinists Pinchas Zukerman and Nikolaj Znaider; the pianists Peter Serkin and Hlne Grimaud; and the cellist Steven Isserlis. An eight-concert series called Russian Evolutions will feature the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio and the poet and pianist Lera Auerbach. Also planned are performances by the Israeli singers Chava Alberstein and David Broza. Information and tickets: 92y.org or (212) 415-5500.

title: Two Tough Eves of Genesis
description: (Photo: Hyundai introduced its 306-horsepower Genesis Coupe with an action spectacular that included driving stunts by two of Hollywood's best. (Photograph by Hiroko Masuike for The New York Times))   Honeyed hair, trim builds, hip-hugging racing suits: the two female stars of Hyundais Genesis press conference were models, hired for their looks, right? You wish, guys. As top Hollywood stuntwomen, Melissa Stubbs and Kathy Jarvis not only know their way around roundhouse kicks and perilous falls, they could likely whip every journalist in attendance around a racetrack -- in a car or motorcycle.  Hyundai hired the women to twirl a pair of its new Genesis coupes during its Wednesday press conference. But the spins and slides they executed around the makeshift indoor course were childs play compared to their usual work: flipping burning cars, jumping motorcycles, swan-diving through glass ceilings, you name it.   (Photo: Kathy Jarvis, left, and Melissa Stubbs. (Photograph by Hiroko Masuike for The New York Times))   Ms. Jarvis and Ms. Stubbs have racked up stunt credits in everything from "The Italian Job" to the upcoming Indiana Jones and the Crystal Skull. Ms. Stubbs has been a stuntwoman for 20 years and has doubled for the likes of Angelina Jolie, Lucy Liu, Ashley Judd, and Jessica Alba. She also teaches motorcycle skills to celebrities, including actor Antonio Banderas; you can check out her work at her Web site.   After wrapping the Hyundai action scene, Ms. Stubbs told me that she started doing stunt work at age 17. A mentor had encouraged her to become a stunt driver to extend her budding career.   Your body starts to break down, and you can only do it for so long, said Ms. Stubbs, whose own breakdowns include three broken legs. If you can drive, you can keep working for many more years.  Ms. Jarvis, meanwhile, is an accomplished off-road racer, an instructor at Team ONeil Rally School in New Hampshire, and the founder of Femme Fatale Motorsports, which is dedicated to bringing more women into auto racing. She is also keeping her fingers crossed, hoping for a once-in-a-lifetime chance to drive faster than any human being before.   Adventurer Steve Fossett had been planning to break an 11-year-old ultimate land-speed record -- he called it "Target 800 m.p.h." -- when the aircraft he was piloting disappeared over Nevada last September. Mr. Fossett was recently declared dead, but Target 800 m.p.h. is proceeding as planned. And Kathy Jarvis is on a short list of drivers to fill in for him, seeking to break the current mark of 766 m.p.h. over a one-mile run.  Ms. Jarvis said the team prefers a woman driver, in part because of the extremely tight cockpit in the 4.5-ton, 47-foot-long racer.  Shes preparing to take high-speed, low-altitude runs with a jet pilot to acclimate to the G-force stresses she would have to endure to break 800 miles per hour in a planned summer run at the Bonneville Salt Flats. The low altitude is required to experience the dramatic blurring of scenery and effects on vision while hugging the ground at supersonic speeds.  At that speed, your peripheral vision is shut down because your heart cant get blood to your head, she said.   Team backers plan to run at Bonneville during the worst heat of the summer; higher temperatures push the sonic barrier to higher speeds, which will get racers closer to their record-setting speed when they hit the resistance caused by breaching the speed of sound.  Related:  Full Coverage: New York Auto Show  2010 Hyundai Genesis Coupe

title: Lexus: 19 Reasons to Crank It Up
description: Taking a break from pounding the carpets at the New York auto show, I spent a few minutes drifting off in the soft seats of the Lexus LS 600h L, the companys six-figure luxury hybrid. Closing my eyes, I was reminded of an often neglected part of the driving experience: the sound system.  Lexus began offering a premium Mark Levinson sound system in its vehicles back in the 2001 model year. The current top-of-the-line system is the Mark Levinson Reference Surround, a true surround sound system boasting 19 speakers and 450 watts of power.  Mere power and multiple speakers arent enough to make a high fidelity sound system, however. A lot more engineering goes into generating sonic clarity, including thousands of hours devoted to tuning the system to the peculiarities of a cars cabin, with all of its reflective glass, unusual angles and sound eating seats.   Mark Levinson clearly took its time in this case. The sound is crisp without becoming harsh and precise without losing its warmth. I found that the Reference system even made music I find immensely distasteful sound (that Yanni-style fluff that companies often demo for the press), well, wondrous. The dynamic range was surprisingly open and accurate.  By the way, when I say true surround, I mean the Mark Levinson system delivers 5.1 discrete channels of music, rather than just simulating the surround effect with digital signal processing. But why would you want this, considering the paucity of surround sound music CDs? Because when you want to make a rest stop you can push a button to engage the cars automatic parking brake and then be allowed to watch DVDs on the dashboard screen -- in full surround sound theater mode. Now thats a real respite.

title: Western Kentucky Wins at the Buzzer
description: Update: Western Kentucky wins, 101-99, in a crazy finish. The final series was started by a huge mental error by Western Kentuckys Boris Siakam. Perhaps thinking his team was losing he fouled Leonard Houston out at half court with less than a minute left. But Siakam made up for it on the other end by grabbing an offensive rebound and getting fouled on the putback. He made both foul shots to give the Hilltoppers a 1-point lead. On the other end Adam Emmeneker missed a shot. In the ensuing scuffle for the ball Western Kentuckys Tyrone Brazelton fouled Jonathon Cox. Cox made both free throws to give Drake a 1-point lead with 5.7 seconds remaining. The Hilltoppers then drove it down the court and Ty Rodgers hit a 30-footer to win it in the first buzzer-beating finish of this tournament.

title: The Flying Game
