At the New York show, the basement is the place to go when youre sick of looking at cars that dont fly. Because the Lamborghinis and whatnot upstairs are all very nice, but compared with a Milner Motors AirCar theyre all somewhat lacking in ambition.

title: The Flying Game
description: (Photo: The Milner Motors AirCar prototype still needs clearance for take-off. (Photograph by Hiroko Masuike for The New York Times))   At the Detroit auto show, the basement is where youll find all the crazy one-off vehicles, the misshapen ogres unfit for the harsh glare of the lights above, and the Chinese automakers. At the New York show, the basement is the place to go when youre sick of looking at cars that dont fly. Because the Lamborghinis and whatnot upstairs are all very nice, but compared with a Milner Motors AirCar theyre all somewhat lacking in ambition.  I dont know much about flying cars, having never driven or flown one myself, but it seems to me that the main challenge is that planes have wings, and wings are a nuisance in the Home Depot parking lot. The Milner solution is to fit the AirCar with power folding wings that reduce overall width to seven feet in ground mode.   But it turns out that the wing issue isnt the only technological hurdle. After speaking with Chris Milner, a partner in Milner Motors, I came to realize why the promise of so many Popular Mechanics covers has yet to become reality, why the skies arent filled with Chevys. It turns out that its not a question of making a car that flies, its a question of making a plane that drives. And planes dont make very good cars for reasons besides just the wings.   For instance, weight distribution on an airplane is somewhat different than it is on a car. As in, 90 percent of the weight is on the rear wheels, so that the nose can be angled skyward on takeoff. Naturally, a 10-90 front-rear weight distribution would be less than ideal when it comes to, say, steering around corners (though I suspect Porsche could figure out how to make it work surprisingly well). So in addition to the folding wings, the AirCar has an adjustable wheelbase, with the rear wheels swinging into an aft position for road driving. Thats one thing.  Another problem is power. Planes dont have driven wheels, and apparently itd be poor form to throttle up the AirCars twin rotary-powered ducted pusher fans in the ol neighborhood cul de sac. So for ground work, the AirCar carries a 40 horsepower electric motor hooked to a continuously variable transmission. Top speed: 85 miles an hour. In the air, the 300 total horsepower from the rotaries make for a more impressive 200-mile-an-hour cruising speed.  Of course, those airborne specifications are just a prediction at the moment. Right now, the AirCar is a non-flying prototype and Milner is looking for a manufacturer to assess production. In the meantime, the company does have another project in progress, the ElectriCar, which looks much like an AirCar sans wings because thats exactly what it is. As Milner explained, the qualities that make for a good airplane  light weight and slick aerodynamics  also benefit efficiency on the ground, and the ElectriCar needs only six horsepower to cruise at 60 miles per hour. Which is fortunate, since it has the same 40-horsepower motor as the AirCar. The plan is for the ElectriCar to have 100 miles of range on battery power alone, and then recharge itself with an onboard generator, sort of like a Chevy Volt minus the crashworthiness.  But honestly, its hard to get worked up about an electric car when its parked next to a flying car. Or a driving plane.

title: The Backstory | Hanging with an Art Handler
description: The art handler Justin Anderson. (Gareth McConnell)

title: Butlers Shooting Strategy
description: Tennessee has good reason to complain. First, it gets seeded as the lowest No. 2 on the board (in the same bracket as North Carolina, the overall No. 1). Next, it gets paired up with Butler in the second round. Yes, that Butler, the No. 10 team in the USA Today poll.

title: Italys Mozzarella Makers Fight Dioxin Scare
description: Heres one for the Soiling Your Own Nest file. In the economically depressed area of southern Italy near Naples, where it can be hard to make a good living on the up and up, the corner-cutting ways of the local mafiosi seem to have dealt a serious, unintended black eye to one of the regions few legitimate economic success stories: buffalo mozzarella.

title: Soft Serve | Snakes in the Grain, Socialites Compete, Pillow Fight!
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: A Shrinking Lead for KMT
description: Keith Bradsher is right about the nasty, personalistic nature of Taiwan politics. In this case, the two candidates arent that far apart on the issues, so character becomes a tempting target. But two other factors are at play.

title: Reports That Jericho Has Been Cancelled (Again)
description: Update: 5:14 p.m.: CBS has confirmed that the series finale will be shown next week. Without question, there are passionate viewers watching this program; we simply wish there were more, Nina Tassler, the president of CBS Entertainment, said in a statement.

title: M.T.A. Is Getting Close to Hudson Railyards Deal
description: The winner of the billion-dollar battle for the right to develop 26 acres of vacant land overlooking the Hudson River may emerge as soon as Sunday, according to real estate executives who have been briefed on the negotiations. A field of five bidders narrowed to two finalists on Thursday, with Tishman Speyer Properties vying with a joint venture of the Durst Organization and Vornado Realty Trust to build a cluster of residential and commercial skyscrapers on a platform over a pair of railyards that sit on both sides of 11th Avenue between 30th and 33rd Streets.

title: Poll: Obama Receives High Marks for Race Speech
description: A new national poll released Friday showed voters who heard or read about Barack Obamas speech on his relationship with the Rev. Jeremiah Wright and race relations, broadly approved of it.

title: Drake Loses Its Appetite
description: TAMPA, Fla.  About a dozen pizza boxes were stacked on a table in the Drake locker room, a perfect meal for a college victory party. Nobody felt like eating, though, in the wake of a stunning 101-99 overtime loss to Western Kentucky.

title: Stations of the Cross on 42nd Street
description: Alicja Ryczek carried a cross with other members and supporters of Pax Christi Metro New York as they marked Good Friday in a walking prayer procession on 42nd Street. The group also held speeches addressing social and global issues such as the war in Iraq, the economy and health care. They stopped at what they called 15 contemporary stations of the cross, a Christian tradition that symbolizes the final journey of Jesus Christ toward his crucifixion, death and resurrection, which most Christians celebrate on Easter Sunday this weekend.

title: Revkin on Climate on Web and TV
description: I probably havent done enough to alert Dot Earthers when Im giving public presentations on relevant issues, so Ive posted a couple of programming notes below. (ALERT: One show is tonight, 3/21, 7 p.m.)

title: Jozy Altidore: A Day to Kick Back
description: Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore contributes items for The New York Times Goal blog each week. Altidore is in Nashville with the United States mens Olympic team, which qualified Thursday for this summers Games in Beijing by defeating Canada, 3-0.

title: Texas Flashback
description: Austin Peay isnt giving Texas as much trouble as my Penn Quakers did as a 15 seed two years ago.

title: Pitts Round Mound
description: DENVER  Did Steve Lavin really use the term bootylicious on E.S.P.N. Thursday night? He was referring to the Pittsburgh freshman center DeJuan Blair, who swings a lot of weight on the back end of his 6-foot-7 frame, and usually a broad smile on the front.

title: Paterson Backs Mayors Congestion Pricing Plan
description: Updated, 9:45 p.m. | Gov. David A. Paterson threw his support today behind the idea of charging drivers to enter the busiest parts of Manhattan, introducing a bill in the State Legislature to establish the controversial program and rescuing it from the brink of death.The turnaround came after an impassioned pitch to the governor from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg behind closed doors at City Hall on Wednesday, when Mr. Paterson privately expressed support for the proposal, city officials said, but warned he needed first to tell Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, who has shown little inclination to approve it.

title: Cost of Ownership Across 50 States
description: Robert Peele writes in the Sunday Automobiles section about the cost of owning a car in New York versus other states. For those who want to see the list of ownership costs in all 50 states, its below the fold.

title: The Week in Pictures for March 21
description: Here is a slide show of photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the swearing-in of Gov. David A. Paterson in Albany, the crane collapse on the East Side and the Orchid Show, with thousands of varieties on display.

title: Update: Jericho Is Really Really Really Really Really Really Cancelled by CBS
description: Its dead. For the second time. And this time, it looks permanent.

title: Guitar Hero Becomes Lawsuit Fodder
description: Like Peter Townshend capping an electrifying Who concert by dashing his Stratocaster to bits, the people at the Gibson Guitar Company have suddenly, after three years of cashing royalty checks from the wildly popular Guitar Hero video game series, touched off a storm of patent-rights litigation over the game and others like it.

title: Two Realities of Tibet
description: Two sets of images have already come to dominate outsiders understanding of this months events in Tibet, where a pro-independence movement has seen some 40 protests of greater intensity and extent than in some four decades.

title: In This Weeks Magazine: Gods Workout
description: The superfit walk among us. They saunter or strut, depending on whether theyre showcasing their magnificent agility or their oxlike strength. They ignore the chatter in the health media over treadmill technique and pedometer steps. They scoff even at seemingly rigorous practices like Mysore Ashtanga yoga and marathon training. They are Americas self-styled fitness elite, adherents of a punishing online exercise regime called CrossFit, which orders its followers to cultivate a distinctly martial  not to say paranoid  ideal of physical preparedness.

title: The First Stage: Denial
description: When the Politico (then in its infancy, and known as the Capitol Leader) poached big-name journalists like Jim Vandehei from the Washington Post and Mike Allen from Time, the idea was that wed get insiders explanations of how the news media worked, that these renegades would, as a sidebar on the site puts it, pull back the curtain on coverage decisions and the media mindset. And so we have todays Vandehei-Allen epic Story Behind the Story: The Clinton Myth.

title: Krzyzewskis Ill Communication
description: WASHINGTON  Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski said he had a temperature of 104 degrees during the second-seeded Blue Devils narrow victory against No. 15 Belmont on Thursday.

title: Just Like He Drew it Up
description: What do you draw up, down 1 point with 5.2 seconds left in overtime? If thats the real test of a coach, San Diego Coach Bill Grier just proved his worth.

title: Huggins: I Was Incredible
description: WASHINGTON  When West Virginia Coach Bob Huggins returned to the locker room after his off-day news conference, he offered this blunt critique of his performance. I was incredible.

title: Rival College Web Game Amasses Troops in the West
description: If success has many fathers, the same can be said for GoCrossCampus, the popular college Web game that I wrote about in Fridays New York Times.

title: Bookshelf Etiquette
description: As someone whose identity, professional and otherwise, is bound up with books, I admit to having a somewhat conflicted relationship with the physical reality of the things themselves. Sure, they do furnish a room, but the realities of New York apartments and a bunch of moves in the past few years have slowly worn down my inborn neurotic-acquisitive pack-rat mentality and replaced it with a permanent (Im hoping) mood of wild and reckless deaccessioning.

title: Tournament Is a Hit Online
description: The number of viewers for NCAA March Madness on Demand, the free Internet companion to CBSs broadcast of the mens basketball tournament, more than doubled during Thursdays first round to 1.75 million unique users.

title: Verizon Licks Its Cheap Megahertz Pops
description: Heres the telecom geek quiz of the day: Whats a megahertz pop?

title: Wang Will Start Opening Day for the Yankees
description: It was not surprising news. In fact, it was expected news. But Manager Joe Girardi made it official Friday when he named Chien-Ming Wang the starter for the Yankees season opener against the Toronto Blue Jays on March 31.I think hes earned it, Girardi said. Hes won 19 games the last couple of years. Hes thrown the ball very well the last couple of years. Im comfortable starting him Opening Day.Wang was supposed to start the 2007 opener, but he strained his hamstring. Carl Pavano, yes, the always injured Carl Pavano, wound up starting the opener. My hunch is Yankees fans will be happier seeing Wang on the mound for the last opener at the current Yankee Stadium than they were about seeing Pavano there a year ago.

title: The Surprising Arrest in New Yorks Deadly Crane Accident
description: When a crane accident in Manhattan last Saturday killed seven people, the district attorney began investigating whether anyone involved in the construction was guilty of criminal negligence.

title: It's Just a Matter of Time
description: Connor Ennis and Stephen Danley discuss the first round's first big upsets and standout individual performance.

title: The Value of a Political Endorsement
description: John Harwood, of The New York Times and CNBC, analyzes Gov. Bill Richardson's support of Senator Barack Obama.

title: Construction Progress
description: Readers have been requesting photos of the interior of the house; so have friends and family. And, even though Im busy coordinating furniture deliveries and negotiating with suppliers that I dont have time to think, the other day I started to yearn for a photo or two, as well.

title: A Cover Jinx?
description: This should have been a pretty good week for Connecticut forward Jeff Adrien. He entered the N.C.A.A. tournament leading the Huskies with 14.8 points and 9.1 rebounds a game, and he recently became a magazine cover boy courtesy of Sports Illustrated.

title: Another Day, Another Bill Clinton Quote
description: Former President has made yet another comment ripe for interpretation as a swipe at Senator Barack Obama. NBC reports on his musing about a general election fight between Senators John McCain and Hillary Rodham Clinton:

title: The Movieum (Get It?): A London Movie Museum
description: You can find a museum devoted to just about anything in London. But since the closure of the Museum of the Moving Image in 1999, there has been no museum for the movie industry.

title: Bloggingheads: Obama's Grandmother
description:
John McWhorter of the Manhattan Institute, left, and Glenn Loury of Brown University consider the meaning of Barack Obama's speech.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Tracing Sienas Defense
description: Sienas half-court pressure is disruptive. It pushes the offense out of scoring range and makes it difficult to merely get in a position to run a play. Thats partially because the Saints have exceptionally quick athletes on the perimeter. Its also because their players are very active with their hands.

title: Booing the Band
description: NORTH LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  When the Texas band arrived early Friday during the second half of Miamis 78-64 victory against St. Marys, it was greeted by a chorus of boos.

title: The Man in Full
description: Recently Tom Wolfe visited the Book Review to sit for a podcast interview. We hoped for perhaps 30 minutes of his time. Instead he settled in and spoke to us for more than an hour  ranging over the whole of his remarkable half-century career: his years as a graduate student at Yale (in American Studies; his thesis was on literary Communism), his early newspaper days (he was posted to Havana during the first phase of Castros rule), his invention of the New Journalism in the 1960s (he described the four devices that defined the genre) and his decision to switch to fiction, beginning with The Bonfire of the Vanities, the subject of this blog for the next two weeks.

title: Art World Matchmakers
description: Yvonne Force Villareal and Doreen Remen unite artists with private sponsors to create large-scale public art in New York City.

title: Advice: Dont Run with the Heels
description: This is what happens when you try to run with North Carolina. Mt. St. Marys hung tough early, but North Carolina is the best transition basketball team this side of the Phoenix Suns.

title: Vows: Diane and Philip
description: After losing their first spouses tragically, a couple finds happiness with each other.

title: This Was Worth the Trip
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  It took Cynthia Godbold 16 hours to drive here from Brooklyn to watch her son, David, play for Oklahoma. She was not sure if he was going to start, since he had spent time in Coach Jeff Capels doghouse, but she was going to make the trip anyway. Anything for David, anything for Oklahoma.

title: Evolving the Role of Captain
description: Capt. Chas Cannon, 3rd Infantry Division, is responsible for an area of farming communities, east of Baghdad.

title: Loveable Losers
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  According to the American Kennel Club, retrievers are the first and fourth most popular breeds in the United States. Yet they never seem to win popularity contests at the Westminster Kennel Club. No retriever has ever won Best in Show.

title: Evolving the Role of Captain
description: Capt. Chas Cannon, 3rd Infantry Division, is responsible for an area of farming communities, east of Baghdad.

title: Great Answer, Coach
description: OMAHA  There may not be cheering in the press box, but there was certainly some in the television and video work room at the Qwest Center.

title: Driving the BMW 128i
description: Automotive reporter Ezra Dyer takes the BMW 128i out for a spin.

title: A Longhorn Licks His Chops
description: NORTH LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  After his teams 74-54 victory Friday over No. 15 seed Austin Peay, the Texas reserve center Dexter Pittman was asked if had been licking his chops to play the Governors because of their undersized starting lineup.

title: A More Agile Party
description: Returning to Taiwan for this election, I am impressed by how much the KMT has improved its campaign fighting skills since the last time in 2004. It has learned how important rapid response is in a campaign, and is a much less sleepy party.

title: Two Brothers Dancing
description: Last year, Steve and Pat Rossiter traveled from their Staten Island home to Buffalo to watch their son Steve Jr., a freshman forward for Davidson College, play in his first N.C.A.A. tournament. The trip was quick: the Wildcats lost in the first round to Maryland.

title: What Tough Words Now May Mean Later
description: Alan Romberg, Doug Paal and Richard Bush all have mentioned that the unrest in Tibet has had an impact on the Taiwan elections, seemingly narrowing the gap between Ma Ying Jeou and Frank Hsieh. As Richard Bush notes, the DPP has skillfully exploited the events in Tibet and Western China, painting a picture of the threat to Taiwan of closer relations with the mainland. One DPP TV ad says, When China is cracking down on Tibet  the Ma camp is drawing ever closer to China.

title: Is It the Economy?
description: Richard Bush has captured well the sense of grievance against the incumbent DPP administration vs. the Hsieh campaigns more agile nature and its ability to play on certain issues that can feed voters doubts about turning the presidency over to the KMT.

title: Facing Your Former Boss
description: NORTH LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  With No. 2 Texas and No. 7 Miami set to play Sunday, Hurricanes Coach Frank Haith is preparing himself to face his former boss, Longhorns Coach Rick Barnes.

title: Double Ouch: Two Injuries Sting Rangers
description: The Rangers tried to make a good show Friday night of facing their immediate future without two of their regular centers, Scott Gomez and Blair Betts.

title: Miami Outlasts Notre Dame in CCHA Semis
description: Notre Dames junior goalie Jordan Pearce stood up to the nations top-ranked offense Friday in Detroit. And the high-flying Miami (Ohio) RedHawks struggled to knock him down. But it wasnt as if the Fighting Irish, playing without their leading scorer, Erik Condra (Ottawa Senators), had any answer for Miami goalie Jeff Zatkoff (Los Angeles Kings).

title: Michigan Survives Test to Reach Final
description: The Northern Michigan Wildcats werent going to let No. 1 Michigan walk all over them. Coming in as heavy underdogs against the nations second-best offense, Northern Michigan took advantage of its chances and put up quite a fight in the second CCHA semifinal game Friday night at Joe Louis Arena in Detroit.

title: Attracting Audiences With Intricacy
description: When the brilliant French pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard signed a solo recording contract with Deutsche Grammophon last year, the first project he proposed was a complete account of Bachs Art of Fugue. This rigorous work, which preoccupied its composer in his final years, explores every dimension of the contrapuntal technique in a set of 14 fugues (the last left incomplete) and four canons. Bach adapted the subjects for each piece from the same elemental theme. The Art of Fugue would hardly seem popular mainstream repertory.

title: Return to Starters Role Suits Godbold and Oklahoma
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  First, Oklahoma guard David Godbold harassed St. Josephs leading scorer, Pat Calathes. Then, Godbold started sinking shots, handing out assists and settling his team down as a senior often does in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An art review last Saturday about the International Asian Art Fair referred imprecisely to 583 Park Avenue, where the fair was held this year. Although the buildings owner, Third Church of Christ, Scientist, rents it regularly to organizers of events, Christian Science services are still held there; it is not a former church.

title: Fleeting Pleasures of Life in Vibrant Woodcut Prints
description: The cult of celebrity and the commercialization of art are not unique to the West. In 19th-century Japan kabuki actors and high-priced geishas were idolized by commoners, and the sale of colorful woodcut prints portraying them became a big, competitive business.

title: Rocky at First, Tennessee Finishes on Top
description: Birmingham, Ala.

title: Western Kentucky, a Long Shot, Beats Drake at Buzzer
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Ty Rogers sprinted down the court, his Western Kentucky teammates in frantic tow, and circled back to the exact spot where he had just inducted himself into the pantheon of N.C.A.A. tournament buzzer-beaters.

title: Under the Big Top, Adopting a Persona With XXL Shoes
description: I WADDLED out of clown alley and into the spotlight leading with my big red glue-on prosthetic nose. The arena floor of the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., was teeming with Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus performers and early arriving spectators who had come to mingle with them during the 40-minute preshow before the two-hour main event.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 21, 2008

title: An Officer on Patrol Is Fatally Shot in Connecticut
description: NORWALK, Conn.  A veteran police officer was shot and killed in a church parking lot in a gritty section of South Norwalk early Friday morning as he got out of his squad car to investigate suspicious activity.

title: A Midmajor Bucks the Trend in the Womens Game
description: After a quarter century under the N.C.A.A.s control, womens college basketball, like mens, is dominated by programs from the power football conferences, where the gyms are big and the wallets are fat.

title: M.T.A. Leaning Toward Tishman Speyers Railyard Bid
description: Tishman Speyer Properties, the company that controls Rockefeller Center, the Chrysler Building, Stuyvesant Town and many other properties, emerged Friday as the probable winner in the billion-dollar battle to develop 26 acres of vacant land overlooking the Hudson River, said two real estate executives who have been briefed on the negotiations.

title: Ogilvy Keeps Lead, but Woods Edges Closer
description: MIAMI  The Australian Geoff Ogilvy shot his second consecutive bogey-less round on Friday, a 67 to go with his opening 65. It was good enough to distance himself from the field at the W.G.C.-CA Championship, but not from Tiger Woods.

title: Taiwan Wants to Focus on Building Its Own High-Tech Brands
description: HSINCHU, Taiwan  Mike Liang earns the equivalent of $37,500 a year, owns a four-bedroom apartment and can afford to send his two daughters to English tutorial schools.

title: Groundhog Day
description: Hollywood loves sequels. So, apparently, does Washington.

title: The Royalty Scam
description: Dorset, England

title: In a City Park, a Crime Against Nature
description: Jennifer Hoppa pivoted over a rock. Be careful, she said. The stumps are hard to see. She pointed down.

title: Jets and Giants Fans May Pay for the Right to Pay for Tickets
description: National Football League franchises across the country have helped pay for modern stadiums since the mid-1990s by asking season-ticket holders to ante up for the right to preserve their seat locations in the teams new homes.

title: Hes Telling You This for the Last Time
description: In what he is calling his farewell show, Jackie Mason has finally settled on the perfect  or poifect, as he would say  title. The posters for his previous seven solo productions, all of which were on Broadway, hang above him onstage, revealing some duds (Jackie Mason: Brand New? Please.) and some good tries (Prune Danish).

title: Lofty Pledge to Cut Emissions Comes With Caveat in Norway
description: OSLO  Last year, as United Nations scientists were warning of the perils of man-made climate change, this small country of fjords and factories reacted with an extraordinary pledge: by 2050 Norway would be carbon neutral, generating no net greenhouse gases into the air.

title: Harangody a Prankster, but His Game Is No Joke
description: DENVER  An accomplice let Notre Dame center Luke Harangody inside a teammates hotel room the other night. Then Harangody stuffed his 6-foot-8 frame into a cabinet and waited, in the dark, for Tom Kopko to arrive.

title: A Kansas Rivalry Comes to Omaha
description: OMAHA  The wind blew briskly at the corner of brick-lined Howard and 11th Streets in Old Market district here Friday. Yet Linda Davis left her red coat unbuttoned, revealing a deep blue University of Kansas sweatshirt. That, and the Jayhawks logo on her shopping bag, left no dispute about her rooting interest at this Midwest Region site.

title: Democrats and the Delegate Debacle
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Man Is Charged in Two Rapes at Housing Project
description: A 29-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested on Friday and charged in connection with two rapes that occurred this month in the Van Dyke Houses, a public housing project in Brownsville, the police said.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An exhibition review last Saturday about John Milton at 400: A Life Beyond Life, at the New York Public Library, misstated a line from Paradise Lost about the purpose of the work. It is And justify the ways of God to men, not to justify the ways of God to man. The review also misidentified the event in English history that Milton welcomed because of its promised transformation of English life and of which Oliver Cromwell was a leader. It was the rebellion, sometimes called the revolution, that overthrew Charles I and established a commonwealth; it was not the Reformation.

title: A Haunting Intruder From the Darkroom
description: No, the deluge of Asian fright films remade in Hollywood hasnt dried up yet. Not by the evidence of Shutter, produced by people behind the American versions of The Grudge and The Ring and itself a remake of the 2004 Thai film Shutter. Fans of J-horror (for Japan, where the genre was born; its conventions have since spread to South Korea and Thailand) will find Shutter familiar; others may just doze.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The State of the Art column in Business Day on Thursday, about a new class of inexpensive, easy-to-use camcorders, referred incorrectly to a model made by Thomson. It is the RCA Small Wonder EZ201, not EX201.

title: First a Tense Talk With Clinton, Then Richardson Backs Obama
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  I talked to Senator Clinton last night, Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico said on Friday, describing the tense telephone call in which he informed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton that, despite two months of personal entreaties by her and her husband, he would be endorsing Senator Barack Obama for president.

title: Eight New Works, Newly Unwrapped
description: Meet the Composer invited eight performers to choose a composer and commission a work; then it presented the eight scores back to back on Wednesday evening at Symphony Space. The results, the awkwardly named New Music for Soloist Champions, were perhaps inevitably mixed, but you could not have asked for a more stylistically varied program.

title: Between Organist and Keyboard, a Crane
description: To a discriminating group of jazz aficionados, shes known for her exuberant rendition of Cherokee, and her meditative All of Me.

title: Guessing the Trump Suit, With a Lot at Stake
description: The Jacoby Open Swiss Teams occupied the final weekend of the Spring North American Championships in Detroit. Ending last Sunday, the event was won by Chris Compton of Dallas; Perry Johnson of Bloomfield Hills, Mich.; Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla.; and Eric Rodwell of Clearwater Beach, Fla.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on March 10 about the reluctance of federal juries in New York State to impose the death penalty referred incorrectly to Mississippis record. The federal death penalty has not been imposed in any cases in Mississippi in the 20 years since the penalty was revived.

title: Leading Obama Adviser Attacks Ex-President for Remarks
description: MEDFORD, Ore.  As Senator Barack Obama folded his arms and looked on, one of his leading military advisers forcefully defended Mr. Obamas patriotism here Saturday and accused former President Bill Clinton of trying to employ divisive attacks to promote his wifes presidential candidacy.

title: YouTube Awards
description: Winners of the second annual YouTube Video Awards were announced on Friday, The Associated Press reported. The awards recognize the top user-created videos of 2007 on the popular Web site. Users voted on six nominees in each of 12 categories: music, sports, comedy, instructional, short film, inspirational, commentary, creative, politics, series, eyewitness and adorable. This years winners include Tay Zonday, 25, above, for his music video Chocolate Rain, which had been viewed 15,768,410 times as of Friday. A work by Neil Cicierega, featuring Harry Potter hand puppets, won the comedy category, while Guillaume Reymonds Human Tetris took top honors in the creative category. All nominated videos can be viewed at youtube.com/ytawards07.

title: Families of Iraq Captives Cling to a Grisly Find
description: For the families of five American contractors kidnapped in Iraq more than a year ago, the months of waiting with no news of their fate have made for a battle of hope against dread.

title: Pakistani Partys Leader Chooses Prime Minister
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The leader of the main party in the new Pakistani government, Asif Ali Zardari, named a low-key party stalwart to become prime minister on Saturday in an announcement that seemed mostly prelude to a drive by Mr. Zardari to take the job himself in the next few months.

title: Offering Money Where the Big Banks Wont
description: LONDON  Turkiye Garanti Bankasi is on no ones list of global financial heavyweights. But the Turkish bank is going where the mightiest banks on Wall Street fear to tread.

title: From Warrior to Bird, With Gentle Precision
description: There was something distressing about the way Yass Hakoshima swept in and out of the Ailey Citigroup Theater on Thursday night  if only because it was a one-night appearance.

title: DNA Tests Lead to Arrest in a 25-Year-Old Killing
description: PELHAM, N.Y.  It was a warm summer day in 1983 when Nancy Lovallo, who was 19 and pregnant with her first child, found her mother-in-law strangled in her apartment here.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report by Agence France-Presse in the Arts, Briefly column last Saturday about the authentication of a previously unidentified portrait of Mozart omitted the name of the Mozart expert who first realized the paintings significance. He is Daniel N. Leeson.

title: New Focus of Inquiry Into Bribes: Doctors
description: A long-running federal investigation into the orthopedic device industrys suspected kickback payments to hip and knee surgeons now has the doctors in the spotlight.

title: For Depleted Rangers, a Point Well Taken
description: PHILADELPHIA  When Rangers center Scott Gomez slammed into the boards in the first period against the Flyers on Friday night, the Rangers day went from bad to worse. Already absorbing the news that they would be without center Blair Betts for up to three weeks, the Rangers watched Gomez leave the ice doubled over and helped by trainers.

title: Fire Marshals Widow Is Indicted in His Killing
description: The widow of a New York City fire marshal has been charged with second-degree murder in his shooting death Dec. 2 in their Staten Island home, culminating an investigation that had been the talk of the community.

title: Hopes for Wireless Cities Fade as Internet Providers Pull Out
description: PHILADELPHIA  It was hailed as Internet for the masses when Philadelphia officials announced plans in 2005 to erect the largest municipal Wi-Fi grid in the country, stretching wireless access over 135 square miles with the hope of bringing free or low-cost service to all residents, especially the poor.

title: Deal Provides an Edge
description: NBC eked out a rare victory in Thursdays ratings, attracting the most viewers for the night by the slimmest of margins, thanks largely to the strength of Deal or No Deal. According to Nielsen estimates, Deal drew 10.2 million viewers at 8 p.m., finishing second to ABCs Lost (11.3 million) for the nights largest audience. But that was enough to win the night, because ABC attracted only 6.3 million viewers to its new 8 p.m. comedy, Miss Guided. Up against Lost at 9 p.m., NBCs Celebrity Apprentice earned a modest 8.6 million viewers. At 10, the networks Lipstick Jungle (7.2 million) delivered its best ratings since its debut in February, but still trailed ABCs Eli Stone (7.5 million). Despite the edge in total viewers, NBC finished third among adults 18 to 49 behind ABC and CBS, which led the night in that demographic with its coverage of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament. Fox ranked fourth for the night.

title: Aaron Asher, Editor of Literary Heavyweights, Dies at 78
description: Aaron Asher, a prominent book editor who for decades worked with many of the worlds leading writers, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 78.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Second Opinion column in Science Times on Tuesday, about a young girl who received a successful experimental treatment for a brain tumor when she was a baby, misidentified the institution where the late Dr. Judah Folkman, whose work led to the girls treatment, spent his research career. It was Childrens Hospital Boston, not the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute.

title: Accepting the Unacceptable
description: IS it possible to lead a balanced life, devoting enough time to both family and career?

title: Pen Sets Festival Events
description: The schedule for the fourth annual PEN World Voices Festival of International Literature was announced Thursday by Francine Prose, the PEN American Centers president, and Caro Llewellyn, the festival director. Highlights of this years festival, from April 29 through May 4, are to include the Arthur Miller Freedom to Write Lecture, to be delivered by Umberto Eco; a conversation about efforts to end genocide in Darfur between the actress Mia Farrow and the French philosopher Bernard-Henri Levy; and a cabaret night. This years festival will include appearances by more than 100 authors and, for the first time, events in Albany, Rochester and Boston as well as New York. Among the authors scheduled to take part are Ian McEwan, Joyce Carol Oates, Mario Vargas Llosa and Salman Rushdie. The full schedule is available at pen.org.

title: 'Jericho' Is Gone Again
description: CBS has canceled the postapocalyptic drama Jericho for the second time in two years. Tuesdays season finale will also be the series finale, the network said Friday. The series, which starred Skeet Ulrich and followed the events in a small Kansas town after nuclear attacks devastated cities across the United States, was first canceled in May 2007. A campaign by fans combined with data showing that the show was being recorded and watched outside its broadcast time persuaded CBS to order a short second season. But the show has performed poorly since the new episodes began appearing last month. The most recent episode attracted fewer than six million viewers and a 1.9 rating in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic. Without question, there are passionate viewers watching this program; we simply wish there were more, Nina Tassler, the president of CBS Entertainment, said in a statement. Carol Barbee, an executive producer of Jericho, said she was pursuing other venues for the series, giving credence to reports that a cable network could pick it up.

title: Let Finances Be a Chore, Not a Phobia
description: THE No. 1 financial complaint I hear from women, delivered in tones that range from exhausted to ashamed to defiant, is this: I hate dealing with money, so my __ (fill in the blank) takes care of everything.

title: President Bling-Bling
description: President Nicolas Sarkozys center-right party got a rebuke from French voters in recent local elections, with leftist parties narrowly beating Mr. Sarkozys party and its allies. The opposition Socialists tried to spin this as a rejection of economic reforms, the platform on which Mr. Sarkozy was elected 10 months ago, but they knew as well as everyone else in France that was not the issue.

title: A Supercar That Drives on Corn
description: Introduced on Thursday: Saleen S5S Raptor

title: Alcoa, Accused of Bribery, Is Under U.S. Investigation
description: Alcoa Inc., the worlds third-largest aluminum producer, is under criminal investigation by the Justice Department over accusations that the company bribed officials in Bahrain in an effort to obtain business.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about Idahos plan to teach chess to all second and third graders misstated the source of funding, based on information from state officials, for the program, which is estimated to cost $200,000 to $250,000 a year and as much as $600,000 the first year. The states education department will provide up to $60,000, then seek private financing for the rest. The department will not pay for the entire project.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A Pop listing in Weekend on Friday about the Beatles parody band, the Rutles, referred incorrectly to the performers at the shows on Wednesday and Thursday at the Blender Theater at Gramercy in Manhattan. The performance, called Rutlemania, will be by the group the Fab Four; it will not be a reunion of the Rutles themselves.

title: A Trend Toward Putting Consultants on Payrolls
description: THE news about jobs has darkened recently. The Labor Department estimated that the country lost 63,000 jobs in February. It was the second consecutive monthly decline, and the third straight drop for private-sector jobs.

title: Under Fire in Sderot
description: To the Editor:

title: Weakness Inside Limits Duke to Outside Chance
description: WASHINGTON  The Duke Blue Devils are a No. 2 seed in this years N.C.A.A. tournament, but their prospects of advancing to their first Final Four since 2004 appear dim.

title: Taking Play Seriously at the Public Library With Young Video Gamers
description: And you thought libraries were supposed to be quiet. Not on Friday.

title: BP Faces Environment Inquiry in Russia
description: MOSCOW  BPs problems in Russia continued Friday.

title: McClintons Second-Half Outburst Powers Miami
description: NORTH LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  Until his senior year, Miamis Jack McClinton rarely started a high school game.

title: A Dutch Antagonist of Islam Waits for His Premiere
description: THE HAGUE

title: Pakistan to Talk With Militants, New Leaders Say
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Faced with a sharp escalation of suicide bombings in urban areas, the leaders of Pakistans new coalition government say they will negotiate with the militants believed to be orchestrating the attacks, and will use military force only as a last resort.

title: Dido and Aeneas, Pursued by Paparazzi
description: For a modern-dance choreographer, Dido and Aeneas is not just a story from Virgils Aeneid or a 17th-century opera by Purcell but, most frighteningly, a celebrated work by Mark Morris. None of this seems to have daunted Jody Oberfelder, who has created a fresh, imaginative and utterly charming version of this piece in collaboration with the Orchestra of St. Lukes and the La Guardia High School senior chorus.

title: He May Be a God, but Hes No Politician
description: London

title: Kansas Governor Vetoes Bill to Revive 2 Coal-Fired Plants
description: Gov. Kathleen Sebelius of Kansas vetoed a measure on Friday that would have forced the state to approve two coal-fired power plants producing large amounts of carbon dioxide.

title: Military Kin Struggle With Loss and a Windfall
description: For some relatives of service members killed in Iraq and Afghanistan, the money feels, at first, like an affront, as if the government were putting a price tag on a loved ones life. Others are thrown off balance by the sudden infusion of $500,000, spending with abandon to assuage grief or finding themselves besieged by hard-up friends and relatives. And the newfound wealth often strains relations among in-laws.

title: Unreliable Voting in New Jersey
description: Voters nationwide have seen that electronic voting cannot be trusted, and New Jerseyans are the latest to learn this unfortunate lesson. It is now clear that the states machines produced suspicious results in the Feb. 5 presidential primary. Rather than working to put doubts to rest, the machines manufacturer is resisting a proper inquiry. New Jersey needs to quickly get to the bottom of the problem to ensure voters that in November their ballots will be counted accurately.

title: Vols Exhale and Advance
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Garrison Carr, an American University guard, had just made another 3-pointer and the 15th-seeded Eagles trailed by a point with six minutes remaining against second-seeded Tennessee on Friday in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Big Storms Continue to Strike Midwest
description: Floodwaters continued to rise Friday in parts of the Midwest as rivers and streams from Texas to Pennsylvania surged past their banks, causing the evacuation of hundreds of houses.

title: Death Claims a Judge
description: The death on Tuesday of the director Anthony Minghella has left the organizers of the 11th Shanghai International Film Festival without a jury chairman. The festival, scheduled for June 14-22, said on Friday it was seeking a new chairman, The Associated Press reported. Crystal Yu, the festivals spokeswoman, also said it planned a retrospective of Mr. Minghellas works.

title: Conflicting Takes, Here and Abroad, on Clintons Role in Northern Ireland Accord
description: Brokering the 1998 Good Friday peace agreement in Northern Ireland was one of President Bill Clintons proudest foreign policy achievements. But Mr. Clinton has withdrawn from a 10th anniversary commemoration to be held in Belfast next month, adding a new element of intrigue to the controversy over exactly what role his wife, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, played in that peace process.

title: On Visit, Pelosi Offers Support to Dalai Lama
description: DHARAMSALA, India  As far as visits by American politicians go, it would be hard to stage a warmer reception.

title: Donner Party Democrats
description: When they set out, it all looked so bright  away to the West, to the Denver convention, nothing but blue skies ahead. They had a continent to cross, a nation to convince, and they vowed to do it in a way that had never been done before.

title: Debt-Gorged British Start to Worry That the Party Is Ending
description: LONDON  At one point, Alexis Hall had more than 50 pairs of designer shoes and handbags. It never occurred to the 39-year-old media relations executive from Glasgow that her 31,500 in debt ($63,000) would be a problem.

title: Rutgers Women Open Play With an Eye Toward UConn
description: DES MOINES  The three Rutgers players assumed their positions Friday, collecting their wits  and breath  in anticipation of a full-court press. But when the person running the news conference opened the floor to questions, silence flooded the room.

title: Yankees Name Wang as Opening Day Starter
description: TAMPA, Fla.  When Chien-Ming Wang of the Yankees threw his first pitch Friday in a warm and peaceful setting, it was in front of fewer than 100 fans at a minor league game. When Wang throws his first pitch of the regular season, the scene will be dramatically different. He will be performing before about 55,000 fans at the final opening day at the current Yankee Stadium.

title: A Tiny Electric Visitor
description: Introduced on Thursday: Subaru R1e

title: Greece and NATO
description: To the Editor:

title: Offering Teachers Incentives; and a Chance to Live Their Faith
description: JERSEY CITY

title: Paterson Supports Congestion Pricing
description: Gov. David A. Paterson added his support on Friday to the idea of charging drivers to enter the busiest sections of Manhattan, rescuing the controversial program from the brink of death by submitting a bill to the State Legislature to establish it.

title: 2 Senators Want HUD Official Out
description: WASHINGTON  Two Senate Democrats on Friday called for the resignation of the secretary of housing and urban development, Alphonso R. Jackson, saying they were deeply troubled by the growing number of allegations of impropriety against him.

title: Suzukis Prelude to a Kitsch
description: Introduced on Thursday:  Suzuki Concept Kizashi 3.

title: Mitsubishis Electric Pu Pu Platter
description: Introduced on Thursday: Mitsubishi i MiEV Sport

title: Thinking Green While Sifting Through the Sand
description: NECKER ISLAND, British Virgin Islands  Richard Branson was lounging under the starry midnight sky on this palm-dappled speck of an island recently when he popped a sobering question.

title: A Catered Affair
description: Back in 1881, when U.S. Senator Thomas Platt of New York was visiting Albany, word went around the State Capitol that he had rented a hotel room for a tryst. According to The Albany Argus, Platts political enemies quickly got hold of the adjoining room, brought in a stepladder, some whiskey, some crackers and cheese and cigars and spent the next several hours taking turns peering over the transom.

title: San Diego Shows Its Not Afraid of Heights
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The plan was simple: Be aggressive, show no fear. With the game on the line and the ball in his hands, DeJon Jackson represented San Diegos casual arrogance in ousting Connecticut in a first-round West Region game Friday.

title: Cornell Star Divides Her Time, and Conquers
description: When Cornell recruited Jeomi Maduka, it was primarily for her ability to jump horizontally, not vertically. Track, not basketball, seemed to be her best sport.

title: Democratic Donations Keep Pouring In, but for Clinton, Theres a Catch
description: Democratic fund-raising continued at a breathtaking pace in February, according to filings with the Federal Election Commission, with candidates breaking records as soon as they were set. But behind the unprecedented numbers are several trends: Big money has come from the smallest donors and the impressive amounts raised by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton mask some shakier campaign finances.

title: Wife of Fire Marshal Pleads Not Guilty in His Death
description: For five decades, the oak tree survived weather and the passage of time in the front yard of the Mercereau home on Staten Island. After Douglas Mercereau was shot dead in his bed on Dec. 2, his brother James found comfort speaking about that tree, noting at his funeral that it was like Doug.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Saturday about the bicycle that investigators believe was ridden by the man who set off an explosion at the military recruiting station in Times Square, a blue Ross 10-speed, misstated the history of the Ross, a brand name that was purchased by Rand International after the original owner, Ross Bicycles Inc., went bankrupt. Rand continues to sell bicycles under the Ross name; the brand has not faded from the bicycle market.

title: Currys Hot Hand Carries Davidson Past Gonzaga
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Stephen Curry pounded his chest twice and pointed to the ceiling at the RBC Center as the crowd roared and the N.C.A.A. tournament first-round game between Davidson and Gonzaga on Friday afternoon suddenly and irreversibly turned.

title: Irked by a Ticket? Now Drivers Can Rate the Officer Who Issued It
description: LOS ANGELES  Inspired by the many Web sites that allow users to rate their teachers, their doctors, even their neighbors, a couple from Culver City have created one that allows people to rate police officers and sheriffs deputies across the country.

title: Clinton Sees Rise in Online Donations
description: In the middle of her victory speech after the Ohio and Texas primaries this month, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton paused to reel off the Web address for her campaign.

title: Paterson Reimburses Campaign for Expenses
description: Gov. David A. Paterson reimbursed his campaign committee this week for two stays at a Manhattan hotel that he has acknowledged using to carry on an extramarital affair, his aides said Friday.

title: France Adds Nuclear Sub and Vows to Cut Warheads
description: PARIS  Dedicating one of Frances fourth generation of nuclear-armed submarines, President Nicolas Sarkozy on Friday defended his countrys arsenal as vital to deter a range of new threats, including the prospect of a nuclear-armed Iran with intercontinental missiles.

title: Passport Files of 3 Candidates Were Pried Into
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department, in an embarrassing revelation, said Friday that it was investigating several episodes in which an employee and several contract workers peered into the passport files of all three presidential contenders.

title: In Europe, Women Finding More Seats at the Table
description: As the homeland of strong female figures, from former Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland to the character Nora in A Dolls House, Norway seemed the natural place for a law requiring companies to fill 40 percent of corporate board seats with women by 2008.

title: Pentagon Urges Delay in U.S. Troop Reductions in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  Senior military commanders have presented the Bush administration with proposals to put off any plans for further reductions of troops in Iraq at least until the end of summer. At the same time, the proposals would limit new deployments to 12 months, instead of 15 months now, military and administration officials said Friday.

title: No Longer a Phenom but Unquestionably a Force
description: Fifteen years ago the saxophonist Joshua Redman released Wish, his second album on the Warner Brothers label, solidifying his stature as one of the brightest young stars in mainstream jazz. A number of things have changed since  Warner no longer has a jazz department, and its harder to say just what mainstream jazz entails  but not the basic facts of his prominence or his talent. As he closes in on 40, Mr. Redman resembles something like a frank, assiduous fulfillment of the promise held out by his younger self.

title: Accounting for the Full Ante in Washington
description: Among the titillating details in the criminal downfall of former Representative Randy Cunningham were the friendly Washington poker games he attended  not just with other members of Congress, but with some sporting gamblers from the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Corner of Finance Where Women Are Climbing
description: Any growth in the ranks of women at the highest reaches of corporate America tends to be measured in small increments, particularly in the so-called C-suite jobs like chief executive and chief operating officer.

title: Engineers Arrest Spurs Review of 29 Building Inspections
description: The citys Buildings Department has begun a comprehensive review of other construction jobs that were approved by an engineer who has been charged with lying about his inspection of a Bronx building that collapsed in 2006, killing two firefighters.

title: China Shows Photos of Tibetan Protesters
description: SHANGHAI  The Chinese government, pursuing its crackdown on Tibetan protesters, has released photos of the 21 most-wanted suspects it blames for violent riots in Lhasa, Tibets capital, last week.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article on Sunday about the lack of adequate mosque facilities for Spains Muslim population misstated, in some copies, the day that the photograph of men in front of a garage converted for use as a mosque was taken. It was a Friday in December, not on Friday, March 14. (Go to Article)

title: Beach Boys End Their Legal Dispute
description: A long legal dispute over the rights to the Beach Boys name has been settled. After a two-day conference in Superior Court in Los Angeles, two original members of the group, Al Jardine and Mike Love, reached an agreement over use of the name on Wednesday, The Associated Press reported. The Beach Boys were founded in 1961 by Carl, Dennis and Brian Wilson, above; Mr. Love, their cousin; and a friend, Mr. Jardine. Dennis Wilson died in 1983, and Carl Wilson died in 1998. Mr. Love had sued Mr. Jardine, claiming Mr. Jardine improperly used versions of the name while fronting his own band. A federal judge ruled in 2000 that Mr. Jardine was engaging in trademark infringement for touring under names including Beach Boys Family & Friends, and that Mr. Love, a co-founder and one of the original lead singers, was sole licensee of the name. A federal appeals court upheld that ruling in 2003. Mr. Love and Carl Wilsons estate sued Mr. Jardine again in 2004 for $2.2 million in legal fees spent in the original litigation against him. It was that case, set for trial in April, that was settled this week. Details of the settlement were not disclosed, but lawyers suggested it could pave the way for a reunion of the bands three surviving founders.

title: A Preachers Views and the Divide They Reveal
description: To the Editor:

title: A British Dynasty for All Seasons
description: Among the many things for which he will be remembered, Paul Scofield, who died on Wednesday at 86, helped to usher in a whole era of classy, lushly produced costume films set in the Tudor period. He made the 16th century seem glamorous.

title: The Thin Skin of Apple Fans
description: IN his new book, True Enough: Learning to Live in a Post-Fact Society, Farhad Manjoo, a writer for Salon, argues that new communications technologies are loosening the cultures grip on what people once called objective reality.

title: Bush Silent, but Others Speak Out on Tibet Crackdown
description: WASHINGTON  Chinas violent crackdown on protesters in Tibet is having powerful political reverberations in Washington, where the White House is weighing how far to go in condemning the Chinese government, even as it defends President Bushs decision to attend the Summer Olympics in Beijing.

title: Clemson Falls Prey to the Turmoil in Tampa
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Villanova swept aside the last of the higher seeds at St. Pete Times Forum on Friday night, rallying from a 16-point first-half deficit to oust Clemson, 75-69.

title: Cyprus Leaders Agree to Restart Talks on Reunification
description: ISTANBUL  Leaders of Greek and Turkish Cyprus agreed Friday to restart talks on uniting the island, the first serious effort in two years to erase the 1974 division.

title: Officials Close Steel Bridge in Minnesota After Bent Plates Are Found
description: CHICAGO  A 51-year-old steel truss bridge over the Mississippi River in St. Cloud, Minn., was abruptly shut down on Thursday after inspectors found that its gusset places were bending  a problem similar to the one believed to have critically weakened the Interstate 35W bridge that collapsed in Minneapolis in August.

title: Thomas Turns to Future, Which He May Not See
description: Isiah Thomas, the Knicks coach and president, insists he is still part of the teams future and still dedicated to winning in the present, although he would have a tough time proving either point to a skeptical audience.

title: Meet Porsches 5,000-Pound Sports Car
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2008 Cayenne GTS.

title: Ovation Greets Paterson in Harlem
description: After days of intense scrutiny over his admitted extramarital affairs, Gov. David A. Paterson met a welcome reprieve on Saturday morning when he returned to his home neighborhood of Harlem for the first time since becoming governor.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article on Sunday about the lack of adequate mosque facilities for Spains Muslim population misstated, in some copies, the day that the photograph of men in front of a garage converted for use as a mosque was taken. It was a Friday in December, not on Friday, March 14.

title: China Orders New Oversight of Heparin, With Tainted Batches Tied to U.S. Deaths
description: SHANGHAI  Chinas top drug safety agency has ordered its local bureaus to increase supervision over the production of heparin, a blood-thinning drug that has been linked to at least 19 deaths and hundreds of allergic reactions in the United States, Chinas state-run news agency reported Friday.

title: William L. Hayward, Film and Television Producer, Dies at 66
description: William L. Hayward, a lawyer and producer whose best-known films include Haywire, a television movie based on a memoir by his sister Brooke about their charmed, tragic Hollywood family, was found dead on March 9 at his home in Castaic, Calif. He was 66.

title: Obamas Speech on Race Played Well, a Poll Finds
description: A national poll released Friday showed that voters who had heard or read about Senator Barack Obamas speech this week on race relations and on his relationship with the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr. broadly approved of it.

title: Taiwan Elects a Leader Who Seeks Closer China Ties
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  Taiwan on Saturday elected its first president who had campaigned for closer economic relations with Beijing, paving the way for a considerable lessening of tensions in one of Asias oldest flash points.

title: Mary Meader, 91, Pioneering Aerial Photographer, Dies
description: Mary Meader, who as a spunky new bride in the 1930s took off on a 35,000-mile journey to advance geographic knowledge by making unprecedented aerial photographs of South America and Africa, died Sunday in Kalamazoo, Mich. She was 91.

title: Serving a Buffet of Morality and Humor
description: The Court Street 12-plex in Brooklyn is a perfectly ordinary movie theater, a vertically arranged variation on what is found in suburban shopping malls throughout the land. It is a place to watch Hollywood blockbusters in stadium seating with a concession-stand combo special in your lap. The crowds, though, are anything but generic, thanks to the cinemas location. Its an easy trip from both brownstones and housing projects, a short walk from the blue-collar Fulton Street Mall and the gentrified retail strips of Court and Smith Streets south of Atlantic Avenue. Its one of those increasingly rare New York spots where the citys various demographic strands cross and commingle.

title: Another Lawyer Pleads Guilty in Bribery Case
description: David Zachary Scruggs, the son of the well-known and recently disgraced trial lawyer Richard F. Scruggs, reached a plea agreement on Friday with federal prosecutors who had charged him with a role in a conspiracy to bribe a state court judge.

title: A Newsman Stays Put
description: Bob Schieffer, right, the host of the CBS News Sunday morning program Face the Nation since 1982, has agreed to postpone his planned retirement. Yes, Im going to remain with the show after the inauguration, Mr. Schieffer, 71, said Friday. He had said in January that he would step down early next year following the swearing-in of a new president. I really had every intention of retiring then, Mr. Schieffer said in a telephone interview. But he said that the president of CBS News, Sean McManus, had come to him a few weeks ago and asked him to put off his retirement. Mr. Schieffer, a 39-year veteran of CBS News, said there was no specific date set for his eventual departure: Were going to have a transition period, maybe try some people out.

title: Resist the Impulse to Panic Over Finances
description: A major investment bank has collapsed, and the Fed is cutting interest rates to stave off a recession that we may already be in. More and more people seem to be having trouble making their mortgage payments, and credit card delinquencies are up.

title: A Place for Upsets
description: TAMPA, Fla.  At least one fan had an inkling that a third upset was about to occur here Friday night. As Siena put the finishing touches on its 83-62 blowout of Vanderbilt, a Saints fan leaning over a upper deck railing at St. Pete Times Forum was crazily waving a sign that read: 1,200 miles  22 hours  2 speeding tickets  2nd round bound!

title: Respond to Todays Column: Catered Affair
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Saturday, Mar. 22 column.

title: Out With a Whimper
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  The whimper you just heard was Indianas basketball season coming to an end Friday night with an 86-72 loss to Arkansas in the first round of the East Regional at the RBC Center.

description: Selected writings of Pfc. Ryan J. Hill, 20, who was riding in a Humvee on Jan. 20, 2007, when an IED buried in the middle of the road detonated under his seat, killing him instantly. Warning: Contains language that could be offensive to readers.

description: Selected writings of Spc. Jerry Ryen King, who was killed on April 21, 2007, when suicide bombers exploded two dump trucks outside his combat outpost, a former school in Sadah.

Staff Sgt. Juan Campos
description: Selected writings of Staff Sgt. Juan Campos, 27, who was riding in a Humvee on May 14, 2007, when it hit an IED. Severely burned over 80 percent of his body, he died June 1. Warning: Contains language that could be offensive to readers.

title: The promise of qualifying in Malaysia
description: This is just what the new season needed: The two Ferraris have returned to strength, but it is Felipe Massa and not Kimi Raikkonen, who scored the pole position. The two McLaren Mercedes were third and fourth, but it was Heikki Kovalainen and not Lewis Hamilton, who was the faster of the two drivers.

title: Minnesota Shocks Colorado College
description: The Minnesota Golden Gophers struggled to gain respectability most of the season. That was then.

title: Boston College Beats UNH in 3rd Overtime
description: Boston College outlasted New Hampshire, 5-4, in three overtimes Friday to advance to the Hockey East championship. The Eagles will play Vermont, 3-1 victors over Boston University.

title: Siena Exerts Dominance Over Favored Vanderbilt
description: The clock had just ticked below two minutes when guard Ronald Moore stepped toward the sideline and motioned for more applause from the Siena section.

description: Alex Ovechkin got two goals against Atlanta on Friday and No. 2 of the evening was his milestone 60th of the season. See it here, or here:

title: The Early Word: Spring Break
description: The candidates are taking it easy on this holiday weekend, but analysis of campaign finance data shows they had a busy month in February.

description: 7:11 a.m. EDT

title: Norways Green Plans  and Carbon Reality
description: My friend and colleague Libby Rosenthal has a sobering story in The Times today on the contrast between Norways grand plan to become carbon neutral by 2030 and the reality on the ground in a country with an economy built around oil and gas production.

title: F1 Pole Poll Vote
description: After todays controversy in Malaysia, the first of the short F1 season, take a moment to vote in the poll I created over at formula1.about.com.

title: Schieffer Postpones His Planned Retirement
description: Bob Schieffer, the host of the CBS News Sunday morning program Face the Nation since 1982, has agreed to postpone his planned retirement, Bill Carter reports. He had said in January that he would step down early next year following the swearing-in of a new president.

title: The Economic Effect
description: To pick up on one the last points raised in Keith Bradshers report, the most immediate effect of Mas victory will be economic, felt on the Taiwanese stock market and in the value of the Taiwan dollar. Jim Rogers, co-founder with George Soros of the Quantum Hedge Fund, told Bloomberg TV this week that he was buying Taiwan-tied funds in the expectation that eventually the Taiwanese and Chinese currencies and economies would merge. The Taiwanese dollar is up 5.5 percent against the dollar over the year.

title: The Iron Is Unkind
description: NORTH LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  The basket in front of the Oregon bench here at Alltel Arena on Friday was unkind to 3-point shooters during No. 8 seed Mississippi States 76-69 victory against the ninth-seeded Ducks.

title: Broad Concerns About Internet Voting
description: The verdict is in on Internet voting, and if Caucus readers are any guide, its a non-starter, at least for now.  We asked our readers a few days ago whether Internet voting might be a plausible way to stage re-votes in Michigan and Florida.

title: Specialist Daniel E. Gomez
description: Selected writings of Specialist Daniel E. Gomez, 21, an Army combat medic who died in Adhamiya on July 18, 2007, when the Bradley fighting vehicle he was in struck a roadside bomb. Warning: Contains language that could be offensive to readers.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Saturday, Mar. 22:

title: Yellowstones Bison Face Slaughter
description: A record number of the migrating animals have been killed by hunters or rounded up and sent to slaughterhouses by park employees.

title: Broad Concerns About Internet Voting
description: In her Web column today, Katharine Q. Seelye rounds up the responses from 440 Caucus readers like you and finds that most voters are wary of Internet voting. However, there have been some successful online elections. Go to the column.

title: An Opening for Cross-Strait Stability
description: Adam Segal and Shelley Rigger are correct that events in Tibet, and Ma Ying-jeous statements about them, create a cloud over the future. But Mas talk of an Olympic boycott was well hedged, and his margin of victory suggests that the public wasnt buying the DPPs claim that Chinas behavior in Tibet was significant for Taiwan. In substance, the two issues are very different, in part because of the economic value that Taiwan represents for Beijing (see Adams most recent post). And if Chinese leaders wanted to improve their general image in the wake of their Tibetan crack-down, what better was to do it than to make some positive gestures towards Taiwan?

With a work ethic seemingly straight from the Joe Gibbs School of Sleeping in the Office, Michael blogs or writes for, among others, FanHouse, ProFootballTalk.com, Football Outsiders and The New York Sun. He was named one of Sports Illustrateds mainstream bloggers of the year. By way of introduction, heres a Q&A with Michael, with discussion that includes the draft, Mark Cuban and blogging tips (dont discount the benefits of large quantities of caffeine and an understanding spouse):

title: The Next Challenges
description: All parties involved in the triangular Taiwan-PRC-U.S. triangle will face a challenge to seize the opportunity presented by the Taiwan election. On the one hand, President-elect Ma will need to follow through on his commitment to work for more constructive cross-Strait relations, albeit in a framework of consolidating Taiwans economic, political and military position. On the other hand, to be successful in these efforts, he will have to follow through on his pledge to reach across party lines to engage the opposition DPP and others in the society in creating a broad consensus to move ahead in this way.

title: Cornell Comes to the End of the Road

The Cardinal play a physical, post-oriented brand of basketball and make the opposition adjust to their unique style, which just happens to include agile and strong 7-foot twins, Brook and Robin Lopez. To be honest, Im pulling for them to make the Final Four, and they are definitely capable of making it to San Antonio.

title: After a Bitter Fight, a Hope for Unity

The toxic animosity that has prevailed for the past eight years has many causes, but the effect has been to weaken Taiwan and undermine the democratic system. The island will be better able to face the challenge of China if it is unified than if it is divided.

title: For the U.S., Positive News
description: From the United States perspective, the election results are good news. There was, over the last years of Chen Shui bians administration, a real fear in Washington that the United State could unwittingly be drawn into a conflict with China in the Taiwan Strait. The application to join the U.N. under the name of Taiwan and the referendum were both seen as unnecessary and provocative. Thomas J. Christensen, U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, gave a speech in September 2007 that essentially rebuked Taiwan, saying the U.S. hoped for a strong and moderate Taiwan.

Smalligan had started every game for the Mountaineers this season and Huggins was proud of his selflessness.

title: Mixed Messenger

After a time, she looked at my girl  who resembles my Japanese-American husband  commented on her height and asked, Do you know if her birth parents were tall?

title: Who Asked You?

title: The Ethics Teacher
description: Heres a thought experiment: Imagine an impoverished graduate student, minutes away from receiving his Ph.D., who walks away from the degree because it requires some compromises. Then imagine this man, without prospects of an academic career, being offered a lucrative job to teach ethics to a young woman on a tropical island. Should he accept the offer? This isnt an especially knotty philosophical problem, nor a particularly convincing situation, but its the premise from which James Morrows inventive, entertaining, but curiously hollow 10th novel, The Philosophers Apprentice, starts out. Mason Ambrose is the author of an idiosyncratic, Darwinist dissertation called Ethics From the Earth; his pupil, Londa, is a teenager whose mother is a fabulously wealthy and brilliant molecular geneticist.

title: Intimate Palaces to Suit Every Taste
description: NO matter where you are in Rome there is probably a house museum around the corner if not right in front of you. The popes were not alone in thinking that the rooms, hallways and loggias of their stately residences ought to be overscaled and highly decorated, with frescoed ceilings, gilt-framed paintings and gleaming marble Greek gods and goddesses propped in every corner. Popes had nephews who also used their digs for personal art collections; so did several centuries worth of cardinals, wealthy nobles, queens in exile, art-loving French imperialists and Romantic-leaning English poets, as well as painters, sculptors and other artists from around the globe. Collectively, they left behind a wealth of treasure palaces and curious cubby holes displaying something for every taste.

title: The Tension Builds (Its Almost Monday)
description: THE feeling is familiar: you are savoring the last of a leisurely Sunday lunch or a long walk in the park when you abruptly realize that your weekend will be over in a matter of hours. In an instant, you are deep in what John Updike called the chronic sadness of late Sunday afternoon. As you envision the to-do pile on your desk, the meetings on your calendar, and that trip to Topeka on Tuesday, your mood shifts again, your muscles tense and your head begins to ache.

title: Gods Workout
description: The superfit walk among us. They saunter or strut, depending on whether theyre showcasing their magnificent agility or their oxlike strength. They ignore the chatter in the health media over treadmill technique and pedometer steps. They scoff even at seemingly rigorous practices like Mysore Ashtanga yoga and marathon training. They are Americas self-styled fitness elite, adherents of a punishing online exercise regime called CrossFit, which orders its followers to cultivate a distinctly martial  not to say paranoid  ideal of physical preparedness.

title: For the Feds Next Act ...

Shame was also part of the deal, because a bank that went to the Fed for help was stigmatized as weak.

title: After Frida
description: Inverted Utopias  the blockbuster exhibition that, in the summer of 2004, filled much of the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston with Latin American art  startled viewers as much with its omissions as with its contents. Where were the Social Realist tableaus of Diego Rivera, the flamboyant self-dramatizations of Frida Kahlo, the Surrealist visions of Wifredo Lam? Instead of those landmarks, Mari Carmen Ramrez, the museums curator of Latin American art, beamed a spotlight on the less-familiar alleyways of the South American avant-garde, especially the artists working in Brazil, Argentina and Venezuela during the quarter-centuries on either side of the end of the Second World War. Visitors to the museum gazed on striated panels that seemed to move when a spectator moved, made by the kinetic artists Jess Rafael Soto and Carlos Cruz-Dez in Venezuela; the sinuously calligraphic drawings and vehemently left-wing sculptures of the Argentine Lon Ferrari; the mysterious steel-wire hangings, like sun-warped or moth-eaten Bauhaus grids, by Gertrude Goldschmidt, a wartime German refugee to Venezuela who was known professionally as Gego; and the many-faceted work of the Rio de Janeiro artists Hlio Oiticica and Lygia Clark, close colleagues whose protominimalist and precociously interactive work in the 60s (like his capes to be danced in and her hinged sculptures to be reconfigured at will) exert a powerful influence today. And those are the famous ones: about a third of the artists in Inverted Utopias were rarely, if ever, exhibited in the United States before. We wanted to introduce these new values into North America, since they had been overlooked, Ramrez, who is 52, said recently. My objection to Frida Kahlo is the phenomenon of Frida Kahlo and the way it obscures Latin American art. She was a woman with an exceptional capacity to present her own suffering through an amazing and rather unique style. But she didnt have many followers. You cant use her as an emblem for an entire continent. Its absurd. Then she flashed a mischievous, gap-toothed grin. And of course, she wasnt such a great painter either.
