title: 36 Hours in New Delhi
description: A SEAT of power for more than a thousand years, the city-state of Delhi is a survivor of conquest and change. The Lodi and Mughal dynasties ruled this area, as did the British, until it was again transformed by the refugees of partition. Today, new money has conquered the region, which includes New Delhi, the capital of a rapidly changing India. Spiraling rents have put a Swarovski shop where a small independent bookshop once stood, and in the same market, a shop called Its All About Bling sells spangly earrings. Thankfully, much of the remarkable history has survived, allowing the visitor to travel easily through the accordion pleats of time.

title: For Abandoned Pets, the Kindness of Strangers
description: BRANDEE LaCAVA dreads late spring because that is the time when once-adored bunnies that were presented as Easter pets have grown up and become too much bother for their owners.

title: A Place to Savor Flavors of Thailand
description: NORTHERN reaches of the county have, in recent years, enjoyed a slow but steady flow of restaurants dedicated to satisfying diners increasing interest in cuisines beyond our shores.

title: Artist Paints From Memory, and at 101, Its Long
description: Adele Lerner is a painter who had her first art show not long ago in Flushing, Queens.

title: On This Show, Vinny From Lincoln High Is Host
description: At precisely 1 p.m. on Friday, an unlikely radio program blares to life on the lower end of the FM dial. The program is all sports, all the time: interviews with players and coaches, discussions about big games and steroids  the kind of fare that is a staple of sports radio everywhere.

title: Anonymous Korean War Dead Still Await Trip Home
description: PAJU, South Korea  The hillside cemetery here is unlike any other in South Korea. The graves, arranged in neat rows, have no headstones. Instead they have identical three-foot-tall, white wooden stakes, most of them reading Anonymous and revealing little else about who lies beneath.

title: Clintons Schedules Offer Chance to Test Assertions
description: When the World Trade Center was attacked for the first time on Feb. 26, 1993, President Bill Clinton flew to New York to be briefed on the attack and the response by city, state and federal authorities. According to newly released White House calendars of Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons time as first lady, Mrs. Clinton stayed behind in Washington to attend a photo shoot with Parade magazine and a performance of Jesus Christ Superstar.

title: Keen Shooting Eye and Competitive Edge Run in the Curry Family
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Dell Curry spent 16 seasons smooth-shooting his way through the N.B.A. as a guard for Utah, Cleveland, Charlotte, Milwaukee and Toronto. He was a model of consistency from behind the 3-point arc, which inevitably made him unbeatable in all of those family games of H-O-R-S-E.

title: To the Ramparts (Gently)
description: ONE March morning two years ago, a Pace University freshman named Brian Kelly and a dozen or so friends piled into a few cars and drove to the universitys Westchester County campus in Pleasantville, to attend a speech by former President Bill Clinton.

title: Suffolk Moves to Ban Youth-Tempting Drug
description: BEFORE voting Tuesday to ban the sale and possession of the hallucinogenic drug Salvia divinorum, Lynne C. Nowick, a Suffolk County legislator, showed her colleagues two videos posted on YouTube.

title: In a Lustrous Space, Steak Plus Dishes Rarely Seen
description: THERE is a cookie-cutter sameness to many steakhouses, but Macs, in Huntington, breaks the mold. All its beef is from Niman Ranch, grass fed and dry aged at least 28 days. The pork is from the Berkshire breed. The restaurant also serves a few dishes rarely seen on Long Island, like braised beef cheeks and Hawaiian white tuna.

title: Phenom Director Goes to War
description: TORONTO

title: Correction: Cold War, Hot Pianist. Now Add 50 Years.
description: A picture caption with an article on March 9 about the pianist Van Cliburn reversed the identities of two men shown standing with him as he gave a toast at the Kimbell museum in Fort Worth. Mayor Mike Moncrief of Fort Worth was at the left and Aleksandr S. Sokolov, Russias culture minister, was at the right.

title: A Skeptical New Look at Special Tax Districts
description: BEING dead was no obstacle to receiving health benefits from Hempstead Sanitary District No. 1 in Lawrence, one of 24 special sanitation districts in the Town of Hempstead.

title: Town Houses at Risk
description: WILLIE KATHRYN SUGGS has been selling brownstones in Harlem since the bad old days, when crime was rampant and downtown brokers did not venture there. Now Ms. Suggs, a key figure in the Harlem town house renaissance over the last two decades, is in danger of losing two town houses she owns in West Harlem.

title: Osaka, Japan: Kogaryu
description: In Osaka, there is no escaping the octopus.

title: Worried Missouri Residents Watch as Floods Rise
description: PACIFIC, Mo.  After days spent sandbagging, rounding up livestock and spiriting their valuables to higher ground, residents along the Meramec River basin watched Saturday as the volatile river neared record levels. The river engulfed hundreds of homes, threatened to overwhelm a major Interstate and left residents to worry what they would come home to when the water finally receded.

title: Pakistani Partys Leader Chooses a Prime Minister
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The leader of the main party in the new Pakistani government, Asif Ali Zardari, picked a low-key party stalwart to become prime minister on Saturday in an announcement that seemed mostly prelude to a drive by Mr. Zardari to take the job himself in the next few months.

title: Voting Yes, Thinking No
description: Chillicothe, Ohio

title: Clash of the Zealots
description: For historians of the United States, the middle years of the 19th century present an exceptional challenge. How does one capture the meaning of a half-century in which Americans elected first Andrew Jackson and, later, Abraham Lincoln president; fought the Mexican War and the Civil War; flocked to millennarian creeds; joined or clashed with movements for the rights of black people and women and workers of all races; endured the shift from a decentralized agrarian society to a united, industrial powerhouse; and lived in a country that more than doubled in territory and quadrupled in population?

title: Events in New Jersey
description: COMEDY

title: Fake Books, Genuine Limelight
description: THE Mayflower Hotel in Washington has a curving facade, lots of gold leaf and a lounge with a piano. President Harry Truman called the hotel, which stands just five minutes by foot from the front door of the White House, Washingtons second-best address.

title: The New Big Brother: Mom and Dad?
description: To the Editor:

title: Elegance Is Abundant; Groceries Are Less So
description: THE restoration of town houses may be one of the most popular hobbies in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, a neighborhood that prides itself on its brownstone blocks.

title: Letters
description: A Matter of Priorities

title: Getting to Europe Is About to Get Easier
description: AIR travel to Europe is about to undergo a significant change, one that is likely to spell more choices and cheaper fares for travelers.

title: Birth Control for Others
description: The first large-scale scientific test of family planning took place in Khanna, India, beginning in the early 1950s. Backed by the Rockefeller Foundation and the Harvard School of Public Health, researchers asked 8,000 villagers how often they had sex, whether they wanted to conceive and the details of the womens menstrual cycles. The researchers met the villagers monthly and provided contraceptives, while closely monitoring another group that was given no contraceptives. After five years, the women given contraceptives had a higher birth rate than those who hadnt received any assistance.

title: Boisterous Welcome Home in Harlem for New Governor
description: After days of intense scrutiny over his admitted extramarital affairs, Gov. David A. Paterson met a welcome reprieve on Saturday morning when he returned to his home neighborhood of Harlem for the first time since becoming governor.

title: Nancy Labiner and Robin Gray
description: Nancy Labiner and Robin Gray were married on Saturday evening at Loft Eleven, an event space in New York. Bettina Yiannakourou, an interfaith minister, officiated.

title: Singapore to Double Cruise Ship Capacity
description: This month, Singapore announced that it would open a new cruise terminal by 2010, doubling the citys cruise ship capacity. The International Cruise Terminal at Marina South will have two new berths that will be able to handle the largest ships in service, as well as those under construction.

title: Off Broadway Musicals: Tackling Difficult Themes
description: To the Editor:

title: Ill Have Some Rum, Hold the Umbrella
description: WHEN a former bootlegger calling himself Donn Beach unveiled a potent triple-rum drink named the Navy Grog at his Hollywood restaurant Don the Beachcomber, he reportedly limited customers to two. At Elettaria, a restaurant and lounge that opened late last month in Greenwich Village with the Navy Grog on its menu, theres no such limit. At least not yet.

title: Well, Bambis Cousins Are All Here. What Now?
description: SHARON

title: A Collaboration Moves Forward Into the Past
description: WHEN the British director James Macdonald  who drew praise for his productions of Caryl Churchills recent plays A Number and Drunk Enough to Say I Love You?  was asked by Manhattan Theater Club to direct a Broadway revival this season of Ms. Churchills early success, Top Girls, he gave that 1982 work a quick reread.

title: Morning or Afternoon, Theres a Kettle Brewing
description: HOW versatile is tea? It can evoke anything from stuffy formality to cozy comfort.

title: Correction: For France, an All-Purpose Heartthrob
description: A picture caption with an article last Sunday about the actor Louis Garrel misspelled the given name of an actress who appeared in Ma Mre with him. She is Isabelle Huppert, not Isabel.

title: Driving a Bargain in New York
description: EVERYONE knows New York is the most expensive place to own a car, right?

title: Adapted Screenplay
description: To the Editor:

title: Tough-Guy Player Emulates Tough-Guy Coach
description: Washington

title: 300,000 Gallons of Jaws
description: THE New York Aquarium is a notoriously unwelcoming structure: a walled seaside compound with no sea view and a parking lot for an entrance.

title: Paperback Row
description: HOW DOCTORS THINK, by Jerome Groopman. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) These elegant essays by Groopman  a professor of medicine at Harvard and staff writer for The New Yorker  explore the way doctors and patients interact with one another and reveal what goes on in a doctors mind as he or she treats a patient. Diagnosis is still an art as much as a science, Groopman argues, and many factors can lead to misdiagnosis. The clinical episodes he describes are both absorbing and affecting.

title: Xanadu in Meadowlands
description: To the Editor:

title: Permalinks
description: Ten years from now, well all be inured to blogs. A whole generation will have grown up never knowing a time when there werent several million Barney Blogspots and Tina TypePads noodling away on their keyboards, and we current adults will no longer concern ourselves with how frisky, naughty, inflammatory, overly confessional or scarily paradigm-threatening these blog things are.

title: Iraq, $5,000 Per Second?
description: The Iraq war is now going better than expected, for a change. Most critics of the war, myself included, blew it: we didnt anticipate the improvements in security that are partly the result of last years surge.

title: Living With Music
description: To the Editor:

title: For Takeout, a Tasty Oasis at a Mall
description: The Italian- and American-inspired salads and sandwiches at the self-service cafe P.F. to Go provide sustenance to shoppers at the Grove at Shrewsbury, an outdoor mall.

title: At the Hotel New Yorker
description: The inventor Nikola Tesla is a historical novelists dream. He was the brain behind alternating current, radio, wireless communication and remote control. He was a friend of Mark Twain and a foe of Thomas Edison. Like Alfred Nobel, he had the hubris to believe he could invent a weapon that would ensure eternal peace. He tore up a contract with Westinghouse worth millions. After he died, destitute and forgotten, an F.B.I. agent wrote that the government was vitally interested in his papers. Tesla believed he had communications with Mars. He was extremely fond of pigeons. His every action gleams with a kind of guarantee: strange, but true.

title: Obama Adviser Steps Up His Criticism of Bill Clinton
description: MEDFORD, Ore.  As Senator Barack Obama folded his arms and looked on, a retired Air Force general who is one of his leading military advisers forcefully defended Mr. Obamas patriotism Saturday and accused former President Bill Clinton of trying to use divisive attacks to promote his wifes candidacy.

title: Events in Westchester
description: Comedy

title: The Wisdom of the Ages, for Now Anyway
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: On the Market
description: Because of an editing error, a listing on the On the Market page last Sunday about a duplex condominium for sale on Dean Street in Brooklyn misstated the cost of parking in the building. It is $295 a month; it is not free.

title: After 53 Years of Beauty Sleep, the B.A.T. Is Back
description: THERE was disappointing news ahead of the Geneva motor show this month: for the first time in decades, Bertone, one of Italys great coachbuilders, would not have its own display inside the exhibit halls.

title: Correction: A Frigidaire in the Court of King Arthur
description: An article on March 2 about Mark Morriss production of Henry Purcells semi-opera King Arthur, at the New York City Opera, omitted the name of a dance in paraphrasing Mr. Morriss comments about work that he set to Brahmss Liebeslieder Waltzes. In addition to New Love Song Waltzes, he was referring to Love Song Waltzes.

title: Insiders, at Least, See Reason to Smile
description: CORPORATE insiders generally dont believe that stocks are about to enter a major bear market. On the contrary, they are more bullish than they have been at any time since late 2005, when the bull market was very much alive and well.

title: Glimmers of Progress at a Failing School
description: THIRD grade has always been a hard year for Rahmana Muhammads children, and therefore for her. All of a sudden, it seems to this mother of four, their textbooks have fewer pictures, their homework lasts for hours, and their test scores plummet.

title: Three Books That Will Take You Back on the Road
description: KEN KESEY was one of an eclectic group of writers challenging society in the late-1950s and 60s  the turn on, tune in, drop out generation, as it was later called by Timothy Leary. And some of their books called many of their readers to the open road. Here are three notable examples.

title: Three Sisters, One Battle to Break a Chain of Cancer
description: Valley Stream

title: Two Helpings of Pie From Broadways Fridge
description: SOUTH PACIFIC and Gypsy, which both return to Broadway this spring, originally opened 10 years apart, standing neatly as theatrical bookends of the 1950s. The Rodgers and Hammerstein romance set in the Pacific during World War II had its New York premiere in April 1949, on the cusp of that fabled decade of American prosperity and self-confidence. The brassy musical inspired by Gypsy Rose Lees memoir first took a bow in May 1959, as the decade drew to a close and only a few shadows of the more fractious era ahead could be discerned on the horizon.

title: A Bright Spot for Housing Investors?
description: FALLING prices, tighter credit and rising foreclosures have taken their toll on the housing market, but there is one residential sector that could actually benefit from these economic woes: multifamily rentals.

title: Thinking Outside the Cube
description: TO help spread the word about the Cube, the shoebox-on-wheels it will bring to American showrooms next year, Nissan offered two of the microvans to the Pratt Institute for cosmetic makeovers. Students of Martin Skalski, a professor of industrial design at the Brooklyn-based art and design school, customized the vehicles inside and out to emphasize the primary styling theme: the assignment was to express cubeness.

title: Jacob DeShazer, Bombardier on Doolittle Raid, Dies at 95
description: Jacob DeShazer, a bombardier in the storied Doolittle raid over Japan in World War II who endured 40 months of brutality as a prisoner of the Japanese, then became a missionary in Japan spreading a message of Christian love and forgiveness, died on March 15 at his home in Salem, Ore. He was 95.

title: Mom, Its Me, Your Son, Finally
description: A YEAR after my marriage failed, and on the day before my estranged mother would have turned 77, I was flying into San Francisco for work. I had been back to the city many times since my childhood, but never in such a state of grief and confusion.

title: Was This Street Made for Walking?
description: ON a weekend stroll down Prince Street in SoHo, past the vendors with foldout tables heaped with jewelry and movie scripts, the crowds flocking in and out of the Apple store, and the milling clusters of overtired out-of-towners, it might seem hard to imagine that the neighborhood could suffer from more foot-traffic congestion than it already does.

title: Divided and Conquered
description: When Napoleon Bonaparte led his army into Egypt in 1798, he had more than military conquest on his mind. Along with 30,000 soldiers, his entourage included what amounted to a mobile university, complete with economists and poets, architects and astronomers, a balloonist, and a baritone from the Paris Opera. They carried with them a library of a thousand books, featuring Montesquieu and Rousseau, Montaigne and Voltaire, and other classics of the Western canon.

title: 4 Americans Killed in Iraq; U.S. Attack Kills 6
description: BAGHDAD  Four American soldiers were killed near the capital in the past two days, the military said Saturday, and north of Baghdad an American attack helicopter killed six people who the Iraqi police said were pro-American Sunni militia fighters.

title: How Confidential Are Board Discussions?
description: Q In a phone conversation with me, a board member of our co-op made reference to another board members stand on a particular issue but refused to give me the board members name. He said he was not at liberty to disclose that information. Is this right?

title: A Failing Grade
description: I teach at a state university. Sometimes at the end of a semester a student asks me to raise a grade. Typically it is a student with children, who receives financial aid, health insurance and housing and risks losing these benefits if she receives the F she earned rather than the D I could bestow  harsh consequences. Should I raise the grade? l; V.H., MONTANA

title: No Grapes for Merlot, but Potatoes for Vodka
description: Baiting Hollow

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article about a filmmaker on the cover of the Arts & Leisure section this weekend misspelled her surname in some instances. She is Kimberly Peirce, not Pierce. (Go to Article)

title: Opening Day
description: The Yankees and Mets openers March 31 are rites of spring that require celebratory fizz.

title: Practicing Patients
description: Todd Small was stuck in quicksand again. It happened, as always, on the floor of the Seattle machine shop where he worked. His shift complete, Small was making the 150-yard walk from his workstation to his car, when he realized that his left leg was sinking deep in the stuff. Though this had happened before  it happened nearly every day now  he stopped and glanced down at his feet. His Nikes looked normal, still firmly planted on the shops concrete floor. But he was stuck, just the same. His brain was sending an electrical pulse saying walk, but as the signal streaked from his cerebellum and down his spinal cord, it snagged on scar tissue where the myelin layer insulating his nerve fibers had broken down. The message wasnt getting to his hip flexors or his hamstrings or his left foot. That connection had been severed by his multiple sclerosis. And once again, Small was left with the feeling that, as he described it, Im up to my waist in quicksand.

title: Great Expectations, and Versatility to Match
description: THE painting of the composer Thomas Ads that hangs in the National Portrait Gallery in London, commissioned in 2002, carries a worried expression. Perhaps it reflects the pressure of his having long been trumpeted as the next messiah of British composition.

title: Basketball Reigns in the Northwest
description: SEATTLE  Three tattoos on Nate Robinsons heavily inked body give directions to the Northwest basketball boom. Just follow the ink, from the 206 area code on his wrist, to the Space Needle, a local landmark, on his biceps, to the Mariners logo covering half his stomach.

title: Repairing Credit Histories
description: The Mortgage column on March 2, about credit-repair services, referred incorrectly to the average credit score of 692. That is the average score of consumers evaluated by Experian  not the average for other credit bureaus or the Fair Isaac Corporation.

title: Girl (Scout) on a Mission
description: UNIONDALE

title: Plans Afoot on the East End
description: Just as dormant vines prepare for bud break, some Long Island producers are hatching plans for the new vintage year. Among them are Macari and the members of the Long Island Merlot Alliance.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: THE LABRADOR PACT, by Matt Haig. (Viking, $23.95.) In Henry IV, Part 1, Falstaff much prefers survival (and a good breakfast) to honor and duty: What is that word honor? ... Who hath it? He that died o Wednesday. Doth he feel it? No. The demands of virtue are also a problem for Prince, the canine narrator of Haigs curiously affecting take on Henry, which tells the story of a loyal Labradors efforts to hold his human family together. If only he follows the pact of his breed, Prince tells himself, he can save these people from themselves  from all their lies and tensions and betrayals and injustices. His friend Falstaff, a chubby mixed-breed he meets in the park, begs to differ. Duty schmooty, he bays (or however fictional dogs utter their dialogue) when faced with Princes insistence on duty over all. Dark, comic and quite brilliantly adult, Haigs thinking animals never stray into the sickly sweet zone. As the duplicities mount (among both species), Princes Labrador dogma proves inadequate to the task: Whereas dogs can learn to suppress their instincts, he realizes, for humans there is no hope.

title: A Hybridist Jamming With the World
description: LIONEL LOUEKE, a guitarist from the West African country of Benin, was a spellbinding presence at Joes Pub a couple of months ago as he started into the title track of Karibu, his exceptional major-label debut. His long fingers flickered across the strings, eliciting not just a syncopated groove but also a shifting undergrowth of chords. He was just as busy vocally, clicking his tongue in percussive counterpoint, singing phrases in a floating cadence. It all felt rooted in African folk traditions but also cosmopolitan, progressive, harmonically fluid.

title: A Show in Search of a Silver Lining
description: AUTOMAKERS sputtered into Manhattan this week, hoping that mortgage-challenged Americans will soon cut loose and buy cars and still have garages to park them in.

title: Reading File
description: THE PEACE SYMBOL, EXPLAINED

title: The Invention of Everything Else
description: Lightning first, then the thunder. And in between the two I'm reminded of a secret. I was a boy and there was a storm. The storm said something muffled. Try and catch me, perhaps, and then it bent down close to my ear in the very same way my brother Dane used to do. Whispering. A hot, damp breath, a tunnel between his mouth and my ear. The storm began to speak. You want to know what the storm said? Listen.

title: Spoiler Alert
description: To the Editor:

title: Portuguese Delivered in Name and Taste
description: WHEN I lived near the Ironbound section of Newark, I made a habit of eating at its Portuguese and Spanish restaurants, but got out of the habit of ordering paella. Why bother with what too often was bland, dried-out rice with overcooked, undercleaned seafood?

title: The Royal Life (Some Facts Altered)
Lots of New Jazz: Some Eclectic, Some Restrained, Some Unrestricted
description: John Ellis

title: Back From Addiction, and Sharing the Lessons
description: I GRADUATED from the Dickinson School of Law of Pennsylvania State University in 1999. Then I got a clerkship, which should have been the first step in a great law career.

title: Nice Tower! Whos Your Architect?
description: THE HL23 tower, planned for a site on 23rd Street in Chelsea, is the kind of commission Neil Denari has being waiting for his entire working life. Mr. Denari, a Los Angeles architect who once ran the Southern California Institute of Architecture, has labored on the professions periphery for decades. But because of a recent demand for name-brand residential architecture in New York, he is finally getting a chance to test his ideas in the real world.

title: Marist Refuses to Give Up After Falling Far Behind
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  A year ago, Marist became the pride of the midmajors in the N.C.A.A. tournament, reaching the regional semifinals as a 13th seed and hinting that some measure of parity might have arrived in womens college basketball.

title: Correction: Photograph
description: A picture caption on Feb. 3 with a review of Artists in Exile, by Joseph Horowitz, repeated the photo agencys misidentification of the first woman in a line of dancers working with George Balanchine. She is Mary Ellen Moylan  not Balanchines second wife, Vera Zorina, who is not shown. (The other dancers, from front to back, are Kathryn Lee, Julia Horvath, Jane Ward, Georgia Hiden, Marie-Jeanne, and Anne Barlow.)

title: Haunting Obamas Dreams
description: WASHINGTON

title: Affairs of the Art World
description: When Margot Henderson and Melanie Arnold were scouting for a place to hold a dinner for the artist Anselm Kiefer after his opening at Galerie Thaddaeus Ropac in Paris last fall, they found the perfect spot: a metal factory. For the two women, who run Arnold & Henderson catering in East London, it wasnt just the factorys location, which is near the gallery in the citys Marais district; it was the rawness of the industrial space  a complement to their no-frills cuisine as well as the artists rugged aesthetic. The 240 guests, including the French prime minister, sat down at long banquet tables while the cooks worked out of a makeshift kitchen. Dishes were served family-style from large bowls and platters; the entre, veal shin on the bone, arrived with a knife sticking out of it. The chichi Parisians had to carve it themselves. They went mad for it, Arnold recalls. And so did the artist. Since then, Arnold & Henderson has gone on to produce other dinners for Kiefer in London, the most recent in a Soho parking garage.

title: Letters: Teaching to the Testosterone
description: Ideas about education that are separate but equal in approach, that are gender-exclusive and usually racial in scope are at variance with our civil rights policies that have promoted integration and disfavored group prejudgments and suspect classifications based on race and/or sex (Elizabeth Weil, March 2). If one needs any further evidence of the pitfalls of such segregative thinking and sorrowful patterns in public education, your article provided it, with experts actually touting the need to lower the temperature in boys classrooms and to speak softly to girls; to paint boys classrooms blue and girls yellow.

title: Events on Long Island
description: COMEDY

title: The Ten-Cent Plague
description: Sawgrass Village, a tidy development about twenty-five miles east of Jacksonville, Florida, is named for the wild marsh greenery that its turf lawns displaced. It has 1,327 houses, each of them pale gray on the outside. On the inside, the one at 133 Lake Julia Drive is a dream shrine-a temple not to the past, like many other homes of retirees, but to a life imagined and denied. All the walls in its eight rooms, as well as the halls, are covered with framed paintings by Janice Valleau Winkleman, who moved there from Pittsburgh with her husband, Ed, in 1982, when he ended his four-decade career in sales (first, chemicals, then steel products). She had been painting almost every day for nearly thirty years. Having shown artistic talent at an early age, she had taken some formal training in fine art and illustration, and, at age nineteen, she began working professionally, drawing for Quality Comics in Manhattan. Then, one evening eleven years later, she came home from work and never went back.

title: The Fuzzier Crystal Ball
description: Whether Arthur C. Clarke is measured by such enduring science-fiction novels as 2001: A Space Odyssey, in which he conceived of a space-travel program before man walked on the moon, or purely scientific papers like Extraterrestrial Relays, in which he described geosynchronous communications satellites two decades before one ever orbited the earth, the author, who died Wednesday at age 90, will long enjoy a legacy as a titan of speculative thought, seemingly capable of willing innovations into existence simply by imagining them.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Three pictures with the Playlist column on Page 18 of the Arts & Leisure section this weekend carry erroneous credits. The photograph of Miguel Zenn was taken by Rafa Rivas/Agence France-Press  Getty Images; the picture of 2 Foot Yard is by Merri Cyr; and the one of John Ellis is by the photo agency Peak.

title: Some Banks (Yes, Banks) May Be Back in Favor
description: THERE is blood in the water, but some long-term investors, defying danger, have begun wading into financial stocks.

title: Taiwan Elects a Supporter of Closer Mainland Ties
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  Taiwan on Saturday elected its first president who had campaigned for closer relations with Beijing, paving the way for a considerable lessening of tensions in one of Asias oldest flash points.

title: On States Fields, a World Cup in Miniature
description: NEWARK

title: New York City Ballet: Its Not the Repertory
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports Lift Up Downtrodden Town
description: JEANNETTE, Pa.  Once known as glass city, when 70 percent of the worlds glass was made here, this town is probably better known now as the home to Terrelle Pryor, the No. 1 college football prospect, who signed a letter of intent on Wednesday to attend Ohio State.

title: War Dodgers
description: Next month, the Canadian House of Commons is slated to debate a resolution that would allow conscientious objectors who have refused or left military service related to a war not sanctioned by the United Nations to apply for residency in Canada. The phrasing is vague but the intent is not. The war in question is the Iraq war, and the resolution represents the culmination of a four-year debate about what to do with the small but steady stream of American soldiers who have fled across our northern border to avoid fighting in Iraq.

title: Rain Falls, Putts Dont and Woods Is Trailing
description: MIAMI  For Geoff Ogilvy and Adam Scott, the rain came at a bad time Saturday. For Tiger Woods, it might have come just in time.

title: Horse Advocates for Millions Just by Being Mentioned
description: Autism Awareness has been hurt and is off the Kentucky Derby trail, but Johnny Taboada insists his horse is meant to do something really special. He figures that minor knee surgery cannot stop his mission: to bring attention to autism, the disorder that affects his 8-year-old son, Renzo, and millions of others, through the colts exploits.

title: Rachel Schneider, David Greenspun
description: Rachel Mira Schneider and Dr. David Todd Greenspun were married on Saturday evening at Bridgewaters, an event space in New York. Rabbi Reuven Siegel officiated.

title: As Turmoil Subsides, Tourism in Nepal Surges
description: AS morning crowds of sari-clad women and mustached men packed the busy streets of Katmandu on the first day of December, The Himalayan Times, an English-language daily newspaper, trumpeted a staggering discovery.

title: Two Brothers, Two Upsets and One Family Memory
description: Steve and Pat Rossiter said a tearful goodbye to their son Ryan on Saturday morning after watching his Siena Saints upset Vanderbilt, 83-62, in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament in Tampa, Fla.

title: In the Feds Cross Hairs: Exotic Game
description: IN the week or so since the Federal Reserve Bank of New York pushed Bear Stearns into the arms of JPMorgan Chase, there has been much buzz about why the deal went down precisely as it did.

title: Memphis Trip Is Revisiting Inspiration for Randolph
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Sometime Friday night, Willie Randolph will step inside the old Lorraine Motel in Memphis and peer into Room 306. He will close his eyes, transporting himself to a different time.

title: Dropping the Torch
description: San Francisco

title: Aging Suburbs Start to Address Citylike Challenges
description: Maplewood

title: Flavors Far From Kishke, but Close to Home
description: MY Aunt Betty holds out those thick freckled arms and exclaims Stevie! as if she hadnt just seen me the night before at my house in Roslyn Heights. Cmere, she says, pulling me nose first into that massive bosom. Oh my God, youre so skinny! Doesnt your mother feed you? Inside the suffocating cleavage, I hear the muffled, icy voice of my mother right behind: He eats just fine, Betty. Well, she cackles, we gotta fatten him up if were ever going to eat him! And with that I am dragged by my bony 9-year-old wrist into a steamy kitchen stuffed with red-cheeked aunts in aprons: Miriam, Susie, Sylvia, Judy and some women, distant cousins I suppose, whom Ive never seen.

title: A Farewell to Print
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on March 9 with an article in T: Mens Fashion magazine, about trench coats and suits, misidentified the designer of a trench coat and gave an incorrect price. It is by Tom Ford, not Yves Saint Laurent, and it costs $5,530, not $2,595.

title: The Republican Resurrection
description: THE day before Barack Obama gave The Speech, Hillary Clinton gave a big speech of her own, billed by her campaign as a major policy address on the war in Iraq. What, you didnt hear about it?

title: Its Car Time in New York
description: An article last Sunday previewing the New York auto show described the engine in the 2009 Acura TSX incorrectly. The redesigned model will continue to have a 4-cylinder engine, but it is not turbocharged.

title: Body of Work
description: To the Editor:

title: What Politicians Say When They Talk About Race
description: Americans and their political leaders have been tongue-tied on the subject of race. We were reminded of that last week when Senator Barack Obama, the front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination, took the almost unimaginable step of going before a national audience at a precarious juncture in a close campaign and speaking explicitly about what race means to blacks and whites. He spoke of black anger and white resentment and the significance of race in American history; his purpose was political but he spoke with seriousness and gravity and at length. Whether the speech helped or hurt him remains to be seen. But the moment was unlike virtually any in the more than 40 years since the triumphs of the civil rights struggle tore up party alignments of the past and tamped down explicit discussion of race by presidents and major-party candidates addressing the American people.

title: New Products, Roof to Floor
description: LIKE clockwork, in the spring many homeowners start to think about improvement projects. What better place to start than at the local home show, for an overview of whats on the market? These were products to be found last weekend at the Westchester County Home Show, held at the State University College at Purchase, N.Y.

title: The Emperors Club
description: In this age of memoir and thinly veiled autobiographical fiction, writers who take high dives into deeply imagined waters have become increasingly rare  and valuable. What a pleasure, then, to discover that Jennifer Cody Epstein, whose luminous first novel, The Painter From Shanghai, is based on the actual life of Pan Yuliang, a former child prostitute turned celebrated painter, also happens to be one such writer.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 22, 2008

title: What if a Flu Like 1918s Broke Out Now?
description: WHEN an outbreak of the Spanish flu spread worldwide in 1918, a doctor in Newark advised his patients that they could cure their illness with red onions and coffee. In Atlantic City, the authorities closed amusement parks and theaters indefinitely. And in upstate New York, public health officials distributed a poster warning people against careless spitting, coughing, sneezing.

title: In Easy Victory, Rutgers Gives Itself a Workout
description: DES MOINES  With 2 minutes 20 seconds left in the Rutgers womens basketball teams 85-42 victory against Robert Morris on Saturday, Essence Carson staggered to the bench with a bloody lip.

title: Watch Those Curves
description: ACROSS America, little girls dream of growing up to be Danica Patrick, 25, the Indy-car driver who in 2005 became only the fourth woman ever to qualify for the Indianapolis 500.

title: The Supreme Court and Indecency
description: The Supreme Court is throwing itself back into the debate over indecency on television, and that may not be a good thing. It agreed last week to review the Federal Communications Commissions policy of punishing broadcasters for airing fleeting expletives  a few isolated bad words. A federal appeals court wisely struck down the F.C.C.s harsh rules, which have done serious damage to free speech. We hope the Supreme Court does not authorize the F.C.C. to return to its censorial policies.

title: With the Fed to the Rescue, Stocks Surge
description: It was a week of extraordinary intervention in the financial markets by the Federal Reserve, and of wild swings in prices. The stock market ended up with substantial gains, while commodities had their biggest sell-off in decades.

title: Connecticut Schools Confronting Proficiency Demands
description: IT looms in the distance, a goal meant to challenge the nations schools to reach ever higher.

title: The Democrats Endless Winter
description: Belgrade Lakes, Me.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article about a filmmaker on the cover of the Arts & Leisure section this weekend misspelled her surname in some instances. She is Kimberly Peirce, not Pierce.

title: Diane Cole and Philip Barnett
description: WHEN an armed band of American Muslim militants invaded several buildings in Washington on March 9, 1977, Diane Cole, then 24, became one of more than 100 hostages. The gunmen threatened to decapitate captives before she and the others were released 39 hours later.

title: Two Discoveries
description: I was 7 when my grandmother died, almost 10 years ago. It was the day after her funeral, when my father and I were going through some of her things, that I found a box full of her kid gloves tucked into an old chest of drawers.

title: You Say Recession, I Say Reservations!
description: THE collapse of a major financial institution is usually an occasion for hand-wringing and tut-tutting over potential job losses, lower consumer spending and missed mortgage payments.

title: The Lemur
description: Chapter 11: Terri With an I

title: How Did Your Computer Crash? Check the Instant Replay
description: ANYONE who uses a computer knows what its like to have the system crash. Crashes are the digital worlds addition to that short list of inevitables, death and taxes. But what if you could record the crash and play it back, like TiVo for software?

title: Regret Name? Never Entered His Mind
description: YONKERS

title: Editors Choice
description: LUSH LIFE, by Richard Price. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) Chandler  and Bellow, too  peeps out from Prices novel, in which an aspiring writer cum restaurant manager, mugged in the gentrifying Lower East Side of Manhattan, himself becomes a suspect.

title: Traveling, and Always Shooting
description: A journey of a thousand miles, the saying goes, begins with a single step.

title: She Left Her Heart in Manhattan
description: GRACE LUMINATO never expected to live in a condominium in a modern high-rise in Brooklyn, a borough she had ignored during most of her life in Manhattan.

title: The China Card
description: While the United States remains focused on the Middle East, China quietly and relentlessly creeps forward as a national security challenge. Its economic rise is being followed by its military rise. In 2006, a Chinese Song-class attack submarine, equipped with Russian-made wake-homing torpedoes, stalked the U.S.S. Kitty Hawk carrier strike group in the Pacific. The sub surfaced within firing range before being detected only five miles from the carrier itself.

title: Persevering for a Saint of Their Own
description: Convent Station

title: Sara Bieber, Daniel Shulman
description: Sara Beth Bieber, the daughter of Carole and Richard Bieber of Rye, N.Y., was married on Saturday evening to Daniel Marc Shulman, a son of Jane and James Shulman of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Eric B. Stark officiated at Tribeca Rooftop, an event space in New York.

title: Why Old Technologies Are Still Kicking
description: IN 1991, Stewart Alsop, the editor of InfoWorld and a thoughtful observer of industry trends, predicted that the last mainframe computer would be unplugged by 1996. Last month, I.B.M. introduced the latest version of its mainframe, the aged yet remarkably resilient warhorse of computing.

title: Bid for Travel and Donate to Charity
description: If you buy one week in a Squaw Valley Lodge condo near Lake Tahoe in California, youll be contributing to scholarships at the Westmark School in Encino, Calif. If you buy a 12-night cruise of the Greek islands and Egypt, a percentage of the money will go to the Nanuet Hebrew Center in New City, N.Y. And if you buy seven nights on the Mexican Riviera, youll be contributing to animal welfare through United Animal Friends. These are just a few of the trips currently being auctioned off on Biddingforgood.com, a new Web site where users may bid on trips (and other items) that have been put on the block by various nonprofit organizations to raise money (91 percent of proceeds up to $100,000 goes to the sponsoring charities; 100 percent after that). Users may search by category (travel, toys, tickets), and may sort auctions by cause or state.

title: For 14-Year-Old Chinese Girl, Grandmaster Title Is in Sight
description: It is becoming increasingly clear that Hou Yifan of China, who turned 14 a few weeks ago, will soon join only a handful of women who have earned the title of grandmaster.

title: U.C.L.A. Pulls an Escape
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  U.C.L.A. trailed Texas A&M by 10 points in the second half and was on the brink of a devastating upset that would have eliminated one of the four No. 1 seeds in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Jennifer Henle, Douglas Davis
description: Dr. Jennifer Henle and Douglas Goodfriend Davis were married on Saturday evening at Temple Bnai Tikvah in North Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi Avi Maza performed the ceremony.

title: Hoboken Comes to Union City
description: The In the Region article in New Jersey copies on March 9 about residential development in Union City misstated the distance between the Lincoln Tunnel and the Thread Building, a former embroidery factory that is now a condominium. It is about a half mile, not 380 feet.

title: In El Norte, a New Life Amid the Tires
description: THREE years ago, when I lived along Fourth Avenue in South Brooklyn, the street had begun its transition. I lived in a brand-new apartment building that looked as if it belonged in a Houston suburb. A cafe called Mule (horse and deer were big that year) had opened across the street. There was talk of condos and boutique hotels.

title: Recycling Violators, Take Note
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: Making Sense of a Scared New World
description: IN light of recent events, I present to you Steins Laws of Modern Financial Markets:

title: New Jersey Schools Confronting Proficiency Demands
description: IT looms in the distance, a goal meant to challenge the nations schools to reach ever higher.

title: Letter: Helping the Poor
description: To the Editor: Regarding "Slum Visits: Tourism or Voyeurism?" (March 9): As a parent of Indian descent who volunteers time and money to charitable organizations working in poor areas around the world, I read this piece with much interest. Having visited a slum in India just this past January, the title stopped me in my tracks. I wondered whether our well-meaning trip to see how our dollars would be used qualified as voyeurism.

title: When a Drug Costs $300,000
description: The extraordinarily high prices of some drugs used to treat ultrarare diseases raise troubling questions for the American health care system. When prices mount into the hundreds of thousands of dollars a year, they impose a burden on patients and sometimes on employers and insurance programs that must pay most of the bill.

title: The Cup Runs Aground in Court, Not on the Water
description: VALENCIA, Spain  Clarity? Not quite. For all those who may still actually care about the Americas Cup after the shortsighted shenanigans of the past nine months, fans still do not know when and where sailings main event will take place.

title: Typhoid Warning on L.I.
description: Nassau County officials issued a health advisory on Saturday to anyone who had recently eaten at an Italian chain restaurant in Hicksville, after a worker there was found to have typhoid fever.

title: Athletic Official Defends Memphiss Reputation
description: NORTH LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  A University of Memphis official, as well as some Tigers players, disputed that the mens basketball team had a negative and nonacademic image.

title: Human Smoke
description: Alfred Nobel, the manufacturer of explosives, was talking to his friend the Baroness Bertha von Suttner, author of Lay Down Your Arms. Von Suttner, a founder of the European antiwar movement, had just attended the fourth World's Peace Conference in Bern. It was August 1892.

title: In a World of Tennis, Tennis Is Her World
description: Judy Mayer is back on her game.

title: Rwanda, Speaking in Its Own Voice
description: IT is safe to say that when most American filmmakers think about the global reach of their movies, they are not considering the concept in quite the same way as Lee Isaac Chung, whose first feature, Munyurangabo, happens also to be the first narrative feature made in Rwandas native language of Kinyarwanda.

title: One Site. Two Games. Four Underdogs.
description: TAMPA, Fla.  As the San Diego Toreros stood in the tunnel and soaked in the N.C.A.A. tournament scene here, they became riveted by the final minutes of Western Kentuckys dramatic overtime victory against Drake.

title: Evolved and Going Nowhere
description: IS the new Jeep Liberty a little homewrecker?

title: Obamas Talk Fuels Easter Sermons
description: This Easter Sunday, the holiest day of the Christian calendar, many pastors will start their sermons about the Resurrection of Jesus and weave in a pointed message about racism and bigotry, and the need to rise above them.

title: Nice Hybrid, if You Can Get It
description: TESTED 2008 Nissan Altima Hybrid. (New this year: standard mud flaps!)

title: Penny Dreadfuls
description: My first hallucinatory experience had nothing to do with drugs, unless you consider comic books to be a form of drug. On a spring morning in 1953, I strolled into Mrs. Shelburnes sixth-grade classroom at the Mark Twain School and spotted a classmate covertly flipping through a Superman comic. Only it wasnt quite Superman. Not the Man of Steel I idolized, but a grinning thug-imposter in red cape and blue tights, gut-punching a helpless geezer on crutches as his false teeth flew out and a mob of citizens cheered, and a babe far leggier and bustier than Lois Lane leered her approval. The monsters name bulged in thick red letters atop the panel: Superduperman. My good-guy stomach rolled. Everything stretched and went slantwise; a parallel universe yawed open, like jaws, and threatened to suck me inside. Then Mrs. Shelburne waddled into class; the kid stowed the comic; the jaws evaporated. Too soon, I realized dizzily. Wait! I wanted in!

title: Arts Get Their Cue
description: UNDAUNTED by the prevailing real estate malaise, New Brunswick is acting on ambitious plans to rebuild its theater district and add office space, stores and hundreds of residential units downtown.

title: On Day of Resurrection, a Church Unveils Its New Organ
description: Jack M. Bethards stood on a catwalk in a room the size of a walk-in closet, a little room that his crew had built in the front of a little church on the Upper West Side.

title: Cougars Set Slow Pace and Cruise Past Irish
description: DENVER  The second-biggest roar from the Washington State contingent at the Pepsi Center came with 1 minute 6 seconds left in the Cougars game against Notre Dame. A timeout was called, and Washington States five starters headed to the bench, serenaded by a chorus of appreciation.

title: Inside the List
description: OY VOX: Nicholson Baker has placed just one book on the Times best-seller list. Vox, his phone-sex novel, appeared here for 12 weeks in 1992, the year Bill Clinton was elected president. Vox rose as high as No. 3 on the hardcover fiction list. (Reviewing it here, Randall Short wrote that even those who do not buy Playboy for the fine articles on sports cars will probably feel they got their moneys worth, since Vox can certainly be read  superficially  as a catalog of the perkier trends in current pornography.)

title: Surprising Sophistication
description: Much of the art in the College of New Jerseys latest exhibition, Parable of the Garden: New Media Art from Iran and Central Asia, shows a level of sophistication that may come as a surprise to many viewers.

title: Sandwiches and Drinks That Satisfy
description: Its easy to spot the Black Cat Caf along Main Street in Irvington. A reproduction of Steinlens famous poster of a green-eyed black cat against a red moon (made for the old Chat Noir in Paris) takes over part of the narrow storefront window. A black cat also has a personal connection for the owner, Emily Feliciano. The name immortalizes Sabbath, her late, black 24-year-old cat.

title: Letter: Golf in Vietnam
description: To the Editor: The Travel sections article "This Ho Chi Minh Trail Ends at the 18th Hole" (March 9) left me baffled by the value of going to a culturally rich country like Vietnam and spending ones nights in a Western enclave like one of the Sofitel hotels mentioned and ones days on an entirely artificial, manufactured landscape.

title: Jeeves of the Plaza
description: An article last Sunday about the butlers at the Plaza Hotel misidentified the type of coat they wear. It is a frock coat, not a morning coat.

title: Baryshnikovs Artistry, Behind the Camera
description: MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV, one of the greatest dancers in history, has turned dance photographer. His images reveal an entirely unorthodox style; as the title of his new exhibition at 401 Projects, Merce My Way, suggests, his subject is the equally unorthodox work of another dance artist, Merce Cunningham.

title: Millionaires Have Range of Opinions on Tax Plan
description: The fourth floor of Bergdorf Goodman, where Oscar de la Renta suits and Valentino gowns wait to be given proper Upper East Side homes, has a clientele that possesses few reservations about spending money.

title: Michigan State Muscles Its Way Past Pittsburgh
description: DENVER  Fans watching Pittsburgh against Michigan State on Saturday night might have half-expected a rugby scrum, but the teams got just what they expected  a tight, tenacious, body-banging game that reflected their personalities.

title: Descended From Salinger
description: Last March I read a sharp story in The New Yorker, Playdate, by Kate Walbert, in which two anxious Manhattan mothers get soused and spill secrets during a get-together of their young daughters. When one of the little girls scolded her imaginary sister, I felt a jolt of dj vu. Lonely child, see-through friend: the image cued another, classic New Yorker story, J. D. Salingers Uncle Wiggily in Connecticut, published 60 years ago this month. While both Uncle Wiggily and Playdate explore idealized memories  of a dead lover, of a lost time when family life seemed easy  the stories essential ingredients are young children who, though not quite at home in the world, can at least face life more bravely than their parents. As the highball-soaked afternoon of Uncle Wiggily darkens, a reluctant mother seeks solace from an old college friend, pleading, I was a nice girl ... wasnt I? Playdate takes the conceit of maternal insecurity even further, depicting a tipsy mom who hangs on her 6-year-olds thin shoulders to regain her footing, then asks: But it was a gold star day, baby. Wasnt it?

title: Keira Driansky and David Simon
description: Keira Ellen Driansky, a daughter of Robin Matlin Driansky and Richard Driansky of Penn Valley, Pa., was married on Saturday evening to David Aaron Simon, a son of Jacalyn Simon of Boca Raton, Fla., and Phillip Simon of Eden Prairie, Minn. Rabbi Richard F. Steinbrink officiated at the Radnor Valley Country Club in Villanova, Pa.

title: Rebecca and Chris Hufferdine
description: REBECCA WALLISON HUFFERDINE attacks married life as if she were in a scrum.

title: Crux of War Depicted in Human Terms
description: Intimacies of Distant War, now at the Samuel Dorsky Museum of Art in New Paltz, examines some of the ways American artists are trying to come to terms with the Iraq war. This is a contentious subject, but the intention of the curator, Brian Wallace, is not to make any sort of political statement but to prompt discussion.

title: Toting Easels Where Others Took Pail and Shovel
description: The Wadsworth Antheneum Museum of Art has spent the past year treading water after the resignation last April of its director, Willard Holmes, and the abandonment of expansion plans into the Hartford Times building in October. Those were dark days. But things are back on track with Susan Lubowsky Talbott set to take over as the new director in May and the opening of an exhibition so smart in its conception and lovely to look at that it reminds you of, well, earlier Atheneum shows.

title: A Guide to the French. Handle With Care.
description: PARIS  Every man has two countries, his own and France, says a character in a play by the 19th- century poet and playwright Henri de Bornier. In five and a half years living in Paris as an American correspondent, I have tried to make the country my own, knowing that I never will completely fit in, but always will be fascinated. So as I finish my stint as Paris bureau chief and move on to a new beat here, it seems a good moment to offer eight lessons learned.

title: Winosburg, Ohio
description: The only display of civic pride evident in Donald Ray Pollocks first book is a blue tattoo  the words Knockemstiff, Ohio  etched like a road sign on the bony white backside of a crackhead named Sandy. And even thats suspect, since the tattoo seems less a proud-spirited nod to her hometown than a dog-tag-like reminder of where she needs to return, or be returned. Located 60-some miles south of Columbus, Knockemstiff, which derives its name from a long-ago fight between two women, is a ramshackle cluster of shotgun houses and rust-streaked trailers where the air is suffused with rotten-egg-scented smog from the local paper mill. Once there was a store, selling gasoline and Doans liver pills and cigarettes and chain-saw oil, and also a tavern, Haps, where the bartender dealt speed on the side. A baseball diamond, built by a Vista worker in the 60s, then swiftly reclaimed by green briars, and also a church  but that too, as Sandys boyfriend notes, had fallen on hard times. Its a mean little place, in Pollocks rendering, where the dominant occupation seems to be petty crime, where wife-beating louts drink Old Grand-Dad out of car ashtrays and where restless teenage boys spend their weekend nights throwing darts at the fat kid and compensating him with bong hits.

title: Hot Off the Presses: The Newsstand Stays
description: FOR 17 years, a forest green newsstand has stood near the corner of Third Avenue and East 77th Street. For most of those years, a friendly Pakistani who identifies himself only as Malik has earned his livelihood selling newspapers, sodas and snacks from inside the stands four small walls.

title: Letters: The Money Issue
description: You devoted your March 9 issue to a discussion of how the wealthiest Americans can best have an impact on philanthropy. But none of the articles asked a fundamental question: Is the nations reliance on voluntary, uncoordinated charity  provided by people who may benefit from massive tax cuts  the best way to solve pressing social problems?

title: Just a Few Favorite Indulgences
description: ISNT there any other color but green?

title: So Much Sex, but Whats Fit to Print?
description: ITS been quite a time for New Yorks tabloids:

title: Good Faith
description: In Sophocles tragedy, Antigone is caught between her religion and her state. After her brother is killed assaulting the city, her uncle Creon forbids her to bury him. But according to the tenets of her faith, if Antigone does not bury her brother, she will have disobeyed the gods and forfeit her own afterlife. Eventually, she kills herself.

title: No Matter the Opponent, Stubborn Butler Plays at Its Own Speed
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  The basketball monks at Butler, who preach humility and servitude, scored 81 points against South Alabama on Friday in a first-round rout in the N.C.A.A. tournament. The Bulldogs, however, remain humble.

title: The Patroness
description: On a gray afternoon in Milan, while models, electricians and seamstresses scrambled with last-minute preparations for that evenings Prada show, several dozen elderly women attended Mass across town at Santa Maria Annunziata in Chiesa Rossa. A working-class parish church, behind a glum brick facade, Chiesa Rossa was designed in 1932 by Giovanni Muzio, a noted Novecento architect, and its an airy barn inside, whitewashed and classically detailed. A decade ago, fluorescent tubes in different colors were discreetly installed, blue along the apse, red across the transept and yellow making a kind of halo out of the high altar.

title: Luxury Resort to Open on Kangaroo Island
description: Until now, lodging possibilities on Kangaroo Island, often considered the Australian Galpagos, with its 21 national parks and five wilderness protection areas, home to wildlife like koalas, wallabies, and kangaroos  only consisted of boutique hotels and bed-and-breakfasts. But on March 29, the first large-scale luxury lodge is set to open there. Southern Ocean Lodge (www.southernoceanlodge.com.au) will offer 21 suites with sunken lounges and outdoor terraces, a spa with treatments based on Aboriginal medicine and spirituality, and a restaurant with a view of Hanson Bay.

title: Mulligan Primary
description: Or a firehouse caucus?

title: Up Front
description: Colm Toibin was a journalist and editor before he became a novelist. He began writing fiction, he said in an e-mail message, as a way of surviving the excitement, the false buzz, of journalism. His first novel, The South, dealt in part with the Spanish Civil War; the 1938 bombing of Barcelona, Toibin said, continued to haunt the city even in the 1970s, when he was living there.

title: Of Bikes and Railings
description: Of Bikes and Railings

title: No Hope to Spare
description: Shorewood, Wis.

title: Gomez Is Day to Day
description: The Rangers said Saturday that center Scott Gomez was not seriously injured Friday night after slamming into the boards in a game against the Philadelphia Flyers. The team said Gomezs unspecified upper-body injury turned out to include no broken ribs and should not keep him out for an extended period. He is listed as day to day and could even play in Tuesdays rematch with the Flyers at Madison Square Garden. Gomez leads the Rangers in points with 67 and assists with 51.

title: Amy Goldman, Ethan Brown
description: Amy Elana Goldman, a daughter of Janice T. Goldman and Kenneth A. Goldman of Smithtown, N.Y., was married on Saturday evening to Ethan Daniel Brown, a son of Sylvia R. Brown and Dr. Michael R. Brown of Tucson. Rabbi Eric B. Wisnia officiated at the Historical Thatched Cottage in Centerport, N.Y.

title: Toronto: The Hazelton Hotel
description: THE BASICS

title: Mending a Heart, Finding a Calling
description: IN 1963, when Jaime Debbah was 28 years old, he left his fiance, his family and the close-knit Jewish community around Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn  his entire world  to go to East Africa. He took with him a bruised heart and an anxious mind, but a few weeks later, he returned, carrying a bagful of colorful beads and the makings of a new life.

title: Sing Out, Laura. Its Your Turn.
description: ITS hard to cover a tattoo when theres a striptease involved.

title: Megaminister
description: As a prominent evangelical pastor based in San Antonio, you were recently catapulted into national controversy when you endorsed Senator   John McCain for president. Is it true that McCain actively sought your endorsement? Its true that McCains campaign sought my endorsement.

title: Gladiator
description: Shortly after he was released from Californias Avenal State Prison in early 2005, Shad Smith got a call from the organizers of an underground fight club called Felony Fights. Was he available? they asked. I was just out of prison and out of money, Smith told me recently. He was incarcerated for failing to comply with the probation terms of an earlier D.U.I. conviction, a relatively minor offense in his long criminal rsum. They said theyd give me 800 bucks to show up and double that if I won.

title: Its Hard to Thaw a Frozen Market
description: REAL estate bubbles have burst before, without bringing such trouble to the financial system. What is distinctive today is the drying up of market liquidity  the inability to buy and sell financial assets  caused by a lack of good information about asset values. The American economy is suffering from an old conundrum: that liquidity is there when you dont need it, but missing when you do. The results have been a form of financial gridlock.

title: Voice for Abused Women Upsets Dubai Patriarchy
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  For years, Sharla Musabih has fought a lonely battle to protect battered wives and victims of human trafficking here. She founded the Emirates first womens shelter here and she became a familiar figure at police stations, relentlessly hounding officers to be tougher on abusive husbands.

title: A Season of Song, Dance and Autism
description: LOS ANGELES

title: B-Boys and B-Girls
description: Where do music genres go when they age? To the groves of academe. And so hip-hop, hugging 30, sits confidently alongside jazz and rock n roll in the academy, subject of college courses and scholarly scrutiny. Its been a navel-gazing genre from the get-go, chronicled and dissected since its childhood in the 1980s. But in recent years, as the hip-hop-history industry has thrived like never before, highbrow words spent on the culture have seemed as copious as the platinum on P. Diddys wrist.

title: Reining In Runaway Taxes
description: A picture caption with the In the Region article in Long Island copies last Sunday about soaring property taxes misstated the location and price of the house at the top of the page. It is on Glen Cove Road in Roslyn, not in Glen Cove, and was listed at $1.15 million, not $1.5 million. The caption also misstated the reason that homeowners complained at a recent meeting in Hauppauge. They were complaining about variations in taxes, not assessments.

title: Off The Dribble
description: Back to Philadelphia

title: Split Is Forming Over Regulation of Wall Street
description: WASHINGTON  As Congress and the Bush administration struggle to contain the housing and credit crises  and prevent more Wall Street firms from collapsing as Bear Stearns did  a split is forming over how to strengthen oversight of financial institutions after decades of deregulation.

title: Hoist a Stein to Home-Style Fare
description: WE knew that we wanted to visit the New Britain Museum of American Art before warmer weather offered too many outdoor distractions. So a few weeks ago, a friend and I spent part of an afternoon there, followed by an early dinner at the East Side Restaurant, about five minutes away in a neighborhood where the Dwight Street trolley used to run, just on the other side of Route 9.

title: Giving Old Planes New Life
description: MARANA, Ariz.  NOTE to domestic airlines now talking about taking some gas-guzzling older airplanes out of service because times are tough: John F. Keating might just have a deal for you and your plane. Parking is provided.

title: Why Radical Islam Just Wont Die
description: THE big surprise, viewed from my own narrow perspective five years later, has taken place in the mysterious zones of extremist ideology. In the months and weeks before the invasion of Iraq, I wrote quite a lot about ideology in the Middle East, and especially about the revolutionary political doctrine known as radical Islamism.

title: Their Vilest Hour
description: In 1960, after his essay on the Democratic National Convention had appeared  written in his customary flamboyant style  Norman Mailer received a letter from Jacqueline Kennedy, who wondered if the impressionistic way in which he had treated the convention could be applied to the writing of history.

title: Correction: A Night Out With | Sam Branson, Polar Opposites
description: The Night Out column last Sunday, about Sam Branson, misstated the place of residence of Sigrid Ekran, one of his partners in a 1,400-mile sled-dog expedition scheduled to begin later this month. She lives north of Fairbanks, Alaska, near the Yukon River; she does not live in the Yukon Territory of Canada.

title: Generation Dependent
description: To the Editor:

title: Death Among the Gentry
description: BUCKINGHAM PALACE GARDENS (Ballantine, $26) is Anne Perrys 25th novel featuring her 19th-century police inspector, Thomas Pitt. But unlike so many detective series gliding on cruise control, this mature work provides a fine introduction to Perrys alluring world of Victorian crime and intrigue. Ever the master of her milieu, she delivers sumptuous descriptions of life among the gentry when England still basked in its imperial glory. And in an intricate plot about a murder at the palace while the Prince and Princess of Wales are in residence, she also marshals the seriess major themes: the way crime reverberates throughout the social classes; the precarious status of women of every rank; and the need for honorable heroes to preserve and protect the Empire, sometimes from itself.

title: Westchester Schools Confronting Proficiency Demands
description: IT looms in the distance, a goal meant to challenge the nations schools to reach ever higher.

title: Immigration Referrals by Police Draw Scrutiny
description: WOODBURY, N.J.  A green-card holder from Guatemala said he was asked about his immigration status last month when he went to pick up his nephew from the West Deptford, N.J., police station.

title: In Athletics and Admissions, the Months of Madness
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: City Mule, Country Mule
description: Kansas City, Mo.

title: Maris Kotcher and Adam Ackerman
description: Maris Kasper Kotcher, the daughter of Betsy and Raymond Kotcher of Long Beach, N.Y., was married on Saturday evening to Adam Scott Ackerman, the son of Sheryl and Steven Ackerman of Bellmore, N.Y. Cantor Bette Cohen officiated at Cipriani Wall Street in Manhattan.

title: Fear of Not, Er, Flying
description: Scorn was the reaction of many people, while many others reveled in a sense of righteous superiority.

title: A Snitch Like Me
description: ONE hot night last summer, just past midnight, I discovered that in the apartment building across the street from my duplex in Fort Greene there was a little crack house.

title: Correction: Five Years
description: An article last Sunday about the five-year course of the war in Iraq misidentified the type of warplanes that dropped bombs on the Dora Farms complex in Baghdad, where Saddam Hussein was believed to be at the start of the American campaign. The two planes were F-117A stealth fighters, not B-1 bombers.

title: Paying for the Elevator
Thats One Way to Shock the Bourgeoisie
description: EIGHT years and two months. Thats how long Scott Schaefer waited for the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles to acquire Arii Matamoe (The Royal End), an 1892 painting by Paul Gauguin that Mr. Schaefer, the museums senior curator of paintings, called the most famous painting by Gauguin that has been seen by no one.

title: In Babel of Tongues, Suriname Seeks Itself
description: PARAMARIBO, Suriname  Walk into a government office here and you will be greeted in Dutch, the official language. But in a reflection of the astonishing diversity of this South American nation, Surinamese speak more than 10 other languages, including variants of Chinese, Hindi, Javanese and half a dozen original Creoles.

title: Reducing the Tax Bite on Apartment Sales
description: The Your Home column on March 2, about income-tax breaks for co-op and condominium owners, referred incompletely to the circumstances under which payments used for buildingwide capital improvements can be added to the tax basis of an apartment. In co-ops, such payments may be added to the tax basis only when they have actually been made by the shareholder to the co-op. In condos, an owner may increase the units tax basis by its proportionate share of the cost of an improvement when the money is spent by the condo, even if the owner has not yet made any payments to the condo.

title: Regular Bloke Takes a Dip in Star Territory
description: I THINK the reason actors become idiots is because youre treated so well, the British actor Simon Pegg said recently over multiple cups of coffee at a chic downtown hotel. Youre driven everywhere, and youre put up in really nice places. The actors that turn into idiots are the ones that start believing its because they deserve it, not because theyre just not trusted, which is the truth. The truth is actors are flaky, unreliable and mostly unstable people, and they need to be mollycoddled at all times.

title: Gap in Life Expectancy Widens for the Nation
description: WASHINGTON  New government research has found large and growing disparities in life expectancy for richer and poorer Americans, paralleling the growth of income inequality in the last two decades.

title: Princeton Goalie Silences Harvard
description: Sophomore goaltender Zane Kalemba made 35 saves as Princeton turned back Harvard, 4-1, in Albany on Saturday to win the ECAC tournament and an automatic bid to the NCAA Frozen Four.

title: Dont pop that champagne quite yetColonial-Dubai deal is off
description: The Inmobiliaria Colonial soap opera continues. A week after a Dubai-based investment fund announced plans to buy the Spanish property giants commercial business and take on something like 9 billion in debt, the deal is off.

description: Every week, the Opinion section presents an essay from The Times's archive by a columnist or contributor that we hope sheds light on current news or provides a window on the past.

title: An Excerpt From a Sranan Folk Song
description: The following translation of a traditional song from Suriname was prepared by Ivan Cairo for The New York Times. Audio of the excerpt and a transcription of the lyrics in the original Sranan  a Creole developed by African slaves in the 17th century  is below.

title: To Anyone Who Kills That Guy
description: Aired Friday night on NBC: A big insurance company just announced they will give $10 million to anyone who can invent a car that gets 100 miles per gallon. Yeah. And meanwhile, Exxon says theyll give $11 million to anyone who kills that guy.

description: Q: What kind of fools do infomercials take us for? A: First-class.

description: When two more Democratic debates were announced this month, both Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama quickly accepted the invitation to meet in Pennsylvania on April 16.

description: Aired Friday night on NBC: Winter officially ended this week. So thats good news. Yeah, yeah. Today, Al Gore blamed the end of winter on global warming.

description: Last week, Daniel Altman wrote that alarm bells should be ringing in Argentina, where violence and mayhem at soccer matches is disturbingly commonplace. Things have not improved.

description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  You can start the counting, and then the accounting. By the end of games on Sunday, the debate will have ramped up even more about which conference is stronger: the Pac-10 or the Big East.

title: The $15 Million Minor League Showdown
description: The Yankees had an interesting minor league game at Legends Field on Sunday morning. Mike Mussina, who will earn $11 million this year, started for Class AA Trenton team, while Kei Igawa, who will earn $4 million, started for Class AAA Scranton-Wilkes Barre. It was probably the most high-priced pitching showdown in minor league history.There were only a few fans in attendance when the game started at 10 a.m. Mussina playfully said that Manager Joe Girardi did not tell him the first pitch was at 10 until after Mussina agreed to face the minor leaguers.But the early hour did not prevent Mussina and Igawa from dominating the younger hitters. Mussina gave up one run and three hits in seven innings while Igawa struckout eight in four scoreless innings.It wasnt bad, Mussina said. Ten oclock in the morning. Full house.When the spring started, Mussina was one of six starters competing for a spot in the five-man rotation. Mussina, who has 251 victories, said that he did not deserve a spot if he did not earn it. But Mussina has earned it with a solid spring and will probably be the No. 3 starter.Ive been pleased because Ive been able to throw breaking balls for strikes and pitch the way I would in May or June, Mussina said.

title: Siena Struggles Against Villanova
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Siena was lucky to be trailing by only 10 points at halftime against Villanova.

title: Not Everyone Loves an Underdog
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Perhaps in the spirit of the regional games here, U.C.L.A. flirted with being the victim of another upset Saturday night. Kansas was sloppy in the first half against U.N.L.V., before bearing down and winning big.

title: Pettittes Back Is Still Bothering Him
description: Andy Pettitte, who has back spasms, wanted to play catch on Sunday, but his back was still bothering him so he did not pick up a baseball. Pettitte said the earliest that he will probably be able to start a game is Friday, a day later than the Yankees were hoping he could start. This was another unfortunate development for Pettitte, whose scheduled start in the second game of the regular season could be in peril. I want to make sure Im healthy, Pettitte said. I dont want to go into the season with a bad back.

title: Pearl Remembers His Roots
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  An hour before a game that could keep his program rolling toward a more prominent place in college basketballs upper echelon, Tennessee Coach Bruce Pearl walked to the Butler bench and put his arm around the Bulldogs star guard, Mike Green. The two shared a few laughs and Pearl walked off.

description: Update: Davidson moves on and, once again, Stephen Curry is the star. Curry finished with 30 points and the 10th-seeded Wildcats beat No. 2 Georgetown, 74-70, despite losing by 11 at halftime. Butler couldnt quite pull off the upset of Tennessee, falling by 76-71 in overtime. Meanwhile, San Diego made a game of it against Western Kentucky in an unlikely second-round matchup before losing, 72-63.

description: After weeks of speculation, the NCAA Tournament field is set and the path to the National Championship is clear.

description: Christ and St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Manhattan raced to get its new pipe organ installed and ready for Easter.

title: Denouncing and Renouncing
description: Some years ago when a high ranking official of the Nation of Islam was being interviewed on TV, he was challenged to denounce another prominent member of the Nation who had called Jews bagel-eating vermin who had escaped from the caves of Europe to pollute the world. He replied, Im not in the denouncing business. He did not elaborate further, but I understood him to be saying, It is not my job either to defend or repudiate every statement made by someone I know. Neither my integrity nor my lifes work depends on my clearing myself of suspicions provoked by the words of others.

title: A Present for McCain as the Other Side Fights
description: Feuding Democrats have handed Senator John McCain the gift of time. How well he uses it may determine his chance to beat them in November.

title: All You Need to Know About Davidson
description: The breakout star of the N.C.A.A. tournament is Stephen Curry, who has scored 70 points in two games for Davidson. The Wildcats, seeded 10th, came back from 16 points down in the second half to beat No. 2 Georgetown, 74-70, on Sunday. It was their 24th consecutive victory.
