description: Headlines from the world of property:

title: No More Worries for North Carolinas Lawson
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  The one question that has dogged North Carolina for weeks is the health of its point guard, Ty Lawson, who missed six games in February with a sprained ankle. Lawson has been back since March 1, but has been cautious with the ankle at times.

title: A Rangers Rookies Stature Grows With Each Shootout Goal
description: When Nigel Dawes faked to his forehand and slid the game-winning goal between the pads of the Devils Martin Brodeur in a shootout last week, the incredulity on Brodeurs face could be seen through his mask. In a Rangers lineup full of big names and dangerous scorers, Brodeur suffered the indignity of having a 5-foot-9 rookie beat him for the victory. Later, Brodeur brushed it off as a lucky shot.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A caption on Friday with a photograph of a spotted eagle ray that killed a woman when it leaped from the water and jumped in her boat gave an incorrect classification from The Associated Press for the animal. The spotted eagle ray is not a type of stingray.

title: Sexual Health of Teenagers
description: To the Editor:

title: Cachao, Mambos Inventor, Dies at 89
description: Israel Cachao Lpez, the Cuban bassist and composer who was a pioneer of the mambo, died on Saturday in Coral Gables, Fla. He was 89 and lived in Coral Gables.

title: Haydn, Politics and Poetry on Calvary
description: Haydn kept returning to his Seven Last Words of Christ. Deadlines and workload often led him to borrow whole movements from old pieces and adapt them to new ones, but this was something different. Here was a man uncharacteristically obsessed by one of his own creations, which is why it comes down to us in so many forms.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A chart on Tuesday comparing Eliot Spitzer, the former governor of New York, with his successor, David A. Paterson, on various issues misidentified the court that in 2004 threw out New Yorks death penalty, which Mr. Spitzer favored under some circumstances and Mr. Paterson opposed. It was the State Court of Appeals, not the State Supreme Court.

title: Dissension Arises at Fox News Over Treatment of Obama
description: Critics of the Fox News Channel regularly complain that the network beats up on Democrats and takes comments out of context. Usually, though, those critics are not Fox anchors.

description: GNARLS BARKLEY

title: Clinton Backer Points to Electoral College Votes as New Measure
description: Senator Evan Bayh of Indiana, who backs Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton for president, proposed another gauge Sunday by which superdelegates might judge whether to support Mrs. Clinton or Senator Barack Obama.

title: Pettitte Wont Push a Sore Back
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Andy Pettitte of the Yankees wanted to pick up a baseball and simply play catch Sunday, but the back spasms that have limited him the last four days continued to be a hindrance. Pettitte still felt discomfort in his lower back as he practiced his pitching motion, so he rested again.

title: G.O.P. Consultant Says He Reported Spitzer Trysts in 2007
description: A Republican political consultant said on Sunday that his lawyers wrote a letter to the F.B.I. in November stating that Gov. Eliot Spitzer had patronized high-priced prostitutes during trips to Florida.

title: A Quick Jump in Diamonds Proves a Little Too High
description: The Machlin Womens Swiss Teams was contested over the final weekend of the Spring North American Championships in Detroit, which ended March 16. The winners were Lisa Berkowitz of Boca Raton, Fla.; Cheri Bjerkan of Elmhurst, Ill.; Joann Glasson of Pennington, N.J.; and Sue Weinstein of Las Vegas.

title: Wall St. Journal to Make Over Popular Section
description: The Wall Street Journals transition to more breaking news and shorter articles will continue in the coming weeks with a makeover of its Marketplace section, editors and reporters there said.

title: Selections for Two Vocalists in French, German, Italian
description: The George London Foundation for Singers lets its winners ease into the recital world by presenting each one in a program with a more established artist. These concerts recall a programming style common in the early decades of the 20th century, when several singers (and often instrumentalists) regularly shared a bill. And having a well-known artist as a draw guarantees an eager audience for the newcomer. That probably is an unnecessary precaution, given the foundations reputation and track record, but its a charming idea.

title: Businesses Say New Yorks Clout Is Emigrating, With Visa Policies to Blame
description: New York officials have long taken pride in the citys status as a global gateway. But lately, senior executives of some of the countrys biggest corporations, like Alcoa, have been complaining that American immigration policies are thwarting New Yorks ability to compete with other world capitals.

title: Cheney Meets Israelis and Palestinians to Promote Peace
description: JERUSALEM  Vice President Dick Cheney met Sunday with Israeli and Palestinian leaders here and in the West Bank city of Ramallah in what American officials described as an effort to promote the peace process.

title: Tristan No. 3 Holds a Steady Course, Despite an Offstage Crash and Thump
description: The latest chapter in the continuing drama of the Metropolitan Operas star-crossed Tristan und Isolde arrived on Saturday afternoon as Robert Dean Smith, an American tenor who has spent much of his recent career in Europe, became the third singer to take the role of Tristan in this run of six performances. Ben Heppner, originally scheduled for the entire run, is now listed on the Mets Web site for only the final performances, on Tuesday and Friday. At this point even those seem dubious.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Acme Brand Content Co., New York, was opened by David F. Caruso, president, who had been chief operating officer at Alliance, New York, part of the Grey Global division of the WPP Group. Acme Brand opens with clients like the Mark brand sold by Avon Products and the Tag Fragrance division of Procter & Gamble.

title: Performers Minding Their Ns and Ons
description: Geraldine Cardiels On/Off was frustrating. The program of two premieres, seen on Friday night at Joyce SoHo, was clearly the work of an active, engaged mind. But Ms. Cardiel never burrowed far beneath the surface of her ideas.

title: London Troupe and New York Visitors: Ripples in and Out of Sync
description: LONDON  Which matters more in dance: energy or synchronicity? In its two-week season at the London Coliseum, which ended on Sunday, New York City Ballet closed its all-Balanchine program with Symphony in C. In a famous episode in its finale, while four ballerinas center stage do complex pirouettes, dozens of dancers lined at the sides and back do the most basic step in the Balanchine lexicon: tendu (a pointing of a foot that involves the transfer of weight from both feet to one and charges the working leg with energy from hip to toe). I first saw this ballet in New York in 1979, danced by City Ballet, and I can still remember the shock of that moment.

title: Pushed Around, Tennessee Holds Its Ground
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  It was overtime, and Tennessee refused to leave Butlers 3-point shooters as they floated up to the wings or settled down into the corners. So Bulldogs guards Mike Green and A. J. Graves kept charging to the basket with determined dribbles, head up, eyes open.

title: Ford and Tata Said Near a Deal on Luxury Brands
description: NEW DELHI  After months of talks, the Ford Motor Company and Tata Motors may finally have a deal.

title: The Free-Throw Misses Outnumber the Makes, but Memphis Holds On
description: NORTH LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  With less than a minute left Sunday, the players on Memphiss bench confidently locked arms and swayed while grinning.

title: Horton Hears Ka-Ching
description: Dr. Seuss Horton Hears a Who held on to first place at North American box offices over the weekend, while three new releases broke into the Top Five. Horton, a 20th Century Fox release, grossed an estimated $25.1 million in its second week, beating Tyler Perrys Meet the Browns (Lionsgate). In its debut that film, a comedy and morality tale starring Angela Bassett, took in $20 million, according to the box-office tracking company Media by Numbers. Another newcomer, the horror tale Shutter (Fox), finished third, with $10.7 million, followed by Drillbit Taylor (Paramount), a comedy starring Owen Wilson, which rang up $10.2 million in its first weekend. Fifth place went to another holdover, 10,000 B.C. (Warner Brothers), which grossed $8.6 million in its third week.

title: Study Finds Record Education Earmarks
description: Congress set aside a record $2.3 billion in pet projects for colleges and universities last year for research on subjects like berries and reducing odors from swine and poultry, according to an analysis by The Chronicle of Higher Education to be published on Monday.

title: Finding Names for Hart Islands Forgotten
description: The babies names are single-spaced, fill hundreds of pages, and seem to share little in common apart from the startling brevity of their owners lives. Baby girl Walburton, died Feb. 12, 1990. Age: 9 days. Baby girl Mieses, died March 19, 1990, 2 hours old. Baby boy Suazo, died March 20, 1990, five minutes after being born.

title: DiMaggio to Mantle to Williams to ... Gardner?
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Brett Gardner envisions himself as the center fielder of the future for the Yankees. About a millisecond after Gardner was asked if he could see himself starting in center for a team that has a crowded, mostly well-paid outfield, he said, Absolutely.

title: Parks in Peril
description: The countrys treasured open spaces are no more immune to air pollution from coal-fired power plants than are its big cities. Sulfur dioxide causes acid rain and kills trees. Mercury emissions poison streams. Nitrogen oxides and sulfates create smog and haze.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: The 80s Video That Pops Up, Online and Off
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Before the womens basketball game at Eastern Washington University on March 8, as the Eagles of E.W.U. faced off against the Montana State Bobcats, attendees were greeted by a 1980s flashback.

title: Longhorns Fend Off Hurricanes Late Rally
description: NORTH LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  After second-seeded Texas beat Miami, 75-72, on Sunday, Hurricanes Coach Frank Haith stopped Longhorns Coach Rick Barnes in a hallway at Alltel Arena.

title: Regal, Like AMC, to Add Imax Screens
description: The Regal Entertainment Group, which owns the nations largest movie theater chain, will work with the Imax Corporation to open 31 new, large-format outlets. The two companies said they would share the cost of installation and the revenue, but declined to reveal more detailed financial information.

title: Early, Early Beatles
description: Lawyers for the Beatles are suing to thwart distribution of previously unreleased recordings that were made in December 1962, four months after Ringo Starr joined the Beatles, at the Star Club in Hamburg, West Germany, in 1962, The Associated Press reported. Under the title Jammin With the Beatles and Friends, Star Club, Hamburg, 1962, the eight tracks are said to include Paul McCartney singing Hank Williamss Lovesick Blues and Mr. McCartney and John Lennon singing Ask Me Why. Apple Corps, the London company formed by the Beatles, maintains that the songs were taped without their consent, and that Fuego Entertainment of Miami Lakes, Fla., and two sister companies have no right to distribute them. Apples lawsuit contends that the recordings are of poor quality and that circulating them dilutes and tarnishes the extraordinarily valuable image associated with the Beatles. Paul LiCalsi, a lawyer for Apple Corps, said, This appears to us to be a garden-variety bootleg recording. Hugo Cancio, the president of Fuego, said: Dont claim that these were just bootlegged. Its not like today, that you just go in with a phone or BlackBerry and you record. He added: The world deserves to hear these tracks. The fact is that we have it, they dont, and that is whats bothering them.

title: On the Lam? Dont Stumble In on This Bunch
description: A big man in a black fedora and trench coat over a plum-colored shirt and a matching tie, swung open the double wooden doors on a Thursday evening this month into a hidden back room with dark paneled walls surrounding red leather booths. Inside, a group of about 20 mostly middle-aged men sat around a table running the length of the room.

title: Newspapers New Owners Turn Grim
description: Critics of newspapers say that part of the problem is that the industry has lost its ability to surprise. Tell that to the guys who have just bought in.

title: A Murdoch Sets Her Own Course in TV
description: One morning last May, Elisabeth Murdoch was leaving a Starbucks in London when her cellphone rang. Her good friend Ben Silverman was calling from Los Angeles to say he could no longer discuss selling her his independent television production company, Reveille.

title: The Private Sectors Tramping in Iraq
description: As the nonpareil war profiteer in Iraq, Blackwater Worldwide keeps outdoing its own mercenary record. Ranking Blackwater executives have used inside influence as administration fund-raisers to multiply their no-bid war contracts a thousandfold to more than $1 billion. Armed Blackwater guards redefined Ugly American for the Iraqi people last September in fatally shooting 17 civilians with impunity in a burst of spray and pray panic on the streets of Baghdad.

title: 4 Die Before Commercial Fishing Vessel Sinks in the Aleutians
description: SEATTLE  Four people died Sunday off the coast of Alaska when a commercial fishing boat carrying 47 people began sinking west of the remote port town of Dutch Harbor, officials with the Coast Guard said.

title: Rutgerss Stringer Still Has Fans in Iowa
description: DES MOINES  It is always primary season in Iowa for Bill Fennelly. Every month for the past 13 years, Fennelly, the Iowa State womens basketball coach, has hit the campaign trail, crisscrossing the state to expand his constituency one civic breakfast at a time.

title: Arthur C. Clarke Buried
description: A minutes silence was ordered across Sri Lanka on Saturday as the visionary British science-fiction writer Arthur C. Clarke was buried in a plot in the General Cemetery in the capital, Colombo, Agence France-Presse reported. Tamara Ekanayake, daughter of his business partner, Hector Ekanayake, said, He wanted us to write on his tombstone: Here lies Arthur Clarke. He never grew up but didnt stop growing.  Clarke was 90 when he died on Wednesday. Family, friends, schoolchildren and space buffs walked behind his coffin as the police and security personnel led the way to the cemetery. Clarke had asked for a funeral without political pomp or religious rites, but politicians, a dozen Buddhist monks and a Catholic priest joined the mourners and watched as his body was buried. The government asked people to observe a minute of silence at midafternoon, when the burial took place, and a newspaper headline mourned the final voyage of a titan.

title: Clinton Calls for Action on Housing
description: PHILADELPHIA  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton returned to one of her major campaign themes Monday  the economic impact of the home mortgage crisis  and called on Congress to provide $30 billion to help states and communities minimize the number of foreclosures.

title: A Boy the Bullies Love to Beat Up, Repeatedly
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on March 10 about the business of surrogate motherhood in India misstated the geographic location of Gujarat, the Indian state where commercial surrogacy got its start in the country. It is in western India, not eastern India.

title: Taming the Beast
description: Were now in the midst of an epic financial crisis, which ought to be at the center of the election debate. But it isnt.

title: Elliott Carter Side by Side by Schumann and Haydn
description: We are hearing a lot of Elliott Carters music in the prelude to his 100th birthday in December. Most of it has been isolated in concerts devoted entirely to his works: safe islets in which confirmed admirers can bask without disturbing nonbelievers or, for that matter, being disturbed by them.

title: Outburst in McCartneys Divorce, as Evoked by the Press
description: Last week, while millions of Americans were watching Beatles Week on American Idol, the British public was preoccupied with the travails of one particular Beatle, Paul McCartney, whose ex-wife won nearly $50 million against him  and promptly dumped a pitcher of water on his lawyers head.

title: A Saab That Seems Too Familiar
description: Introduced on Wednesday: Saab 9-X BioHybrid

title: The Weeks Major Economic Reports
description: COMPANY REPORTS It is a light week for earnings, with reports coming from Tiffany and Walgreen (Monday); SAIC (Tuesday); Oracle (Wednesday); the Apollo Group, ConAgra Foods, Lennar and Red Hat (Thursday); and KB Home (Friday).

description: To the Editor:

description: March 23, 2008

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,985 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Sunday:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in the special Museums section on March 12 about corporate cocktail parties and other special events at museums, using information from the Whitney Museum of American Art, erroneously included an event at the Whitney. The museum is not hosting Vanity Fairs 75th anniversary party in September.

title: London Rings Folds
description: The $25 million London production of The Lord of the Rings, above, will close at the Theater Royal Drury Lane on July 19 after 492 performances, Broadway.com reported from London. The Guardian of London reported that the show would enter the record books as one of the West Ends costliest failures, and it noted that the show had also flopped in Toronto, where its budget was a reported $23 million. Nevertheless, Broadway.com said, the producers are discussing a German-language version, to open in Germany next year, as well as tours of New Zealand, Australia and Asia.

title: Mutis Flu Leads to Philharmonic Debut
description: Flu has forced Riccardo Muti out of concerts with the New York Philharmonic this week. He will be replaced by Michael Christie, right, who will make his debut as conductor of the orchestra, leading works by Elgar and Copland on Thursday at 7:30 p.m., Friday at 11 a.m. and Saturday at 8 p.m. At all three concerts Pinchas Zukerman will be featured as the soloist in Elgars Violin Concerto. Mr. Christie will also conduct at 2 p.m. Saturday, when the program will include Schuberts Octet, performed by musicians from the orchestra, followed by Coplands Third Symphony. Mr. Christie has been the music director of the Brooklyn Philharmonic and the Phoenix Symphony since 2005 and is also the music director of the Colorado Summer Music festival and principal guest conductor of the Queensland Orchestra in Australia, where he was chief conductor until 2004. He came to international attention in 1995 when he won a special prize for outstanding potential at the First International Sibelius Conductors Competition, in Helsinki.

title: Shuttle Undocks From Station
description: The space shuttle Endeavour and the International Space Station parted ways on Monday evening after an emotional farewell ceremony for the combined crew of 10 astronauts.

title: Animal Instinct: Staking Claims With Aggression and Comic Touches
description: Daniel Clifton begins his Marked Territory on a decidedly melancholy note. As he repeatedly falls onto and rises from the floor, a small choir softly sings John Dowlands Flow My Tears, whose line Down vain lights, shine you no more! sums up at least the look of what is to follow. In this moody dance-theater production, performed Friday at the Abrons Arts Center, the lights are kept deliberately low.

title: Speak Out on Tibet
description: China has cracked down on Tibet and neighboring provinces. It sent more troops into restive regions and made scores of arrests in Lhasa. It acknowledged firing on demonstrators in Sichuan. Yet, the response of the international community  and of the International Olympic Committee  has been tepid. Beijing must be called to account, especially since it will host the 2008 Games.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Tuesday about the rivalry between the elite figure skaters Evan Lysacek and Johnny Weir misspelled the surname of a woman on the University of Michigan club team who admires Weir. She is Laura Sigler, not Signer.

title: Louisvilles Defense Shuts Down Oklahoma
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Louisville Coach Rick Pitino would not be as ruthless as his team. There were seven minutes remaining and the Cardinals were leading Oklahoma by 29 points when Pitino screamed from in front of the Louisville bench: No press! No press!

title: Spitzer Pushed Staffs Effort to Smear Bruno
description: Former Gov. Eliot Spitzer was deeply involved in his administrations efforts last year to discredit the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, holding detailed discussions with senior aides, ordering damaging information about Mr. Bruno released, and calling an aide at home repeatedly to check on the progress, according to several people with direct knowledge of the investigation.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about the conviction of Cesar Rodriguez for killing his 7-year-old stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown, misstated the number of bedrooms in the familys apartment on Greene Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, where Nixzmary was found beaten to death. It has three bedrooms, not two.

title: 13 Iraqis Killed by Shells Fired at the Green Zone
description: BAGHDAD  As many as 20 mortar shells were fired Sunday at the heavily fortified Green Zone, one of the fiercest and most sustained attacks on the area in the last year.

title: Journalist in Pellicano Case Will Get Her Day in Court
description: LOS ANGELES  The long series of events leading to the trial of the Hollywood private investigator Anthony Pellicano on charges of racketeering and wiretapping began on June 20, 2002, when a journalist, Anita M. Busch, found a note saying Stop taped to her car, a fish and a rose in a tin tray on the hood, a bulletlike hole piercing the windshield.

title: Ogilvy Leads as Play Is Halted; Woods's Streak in Danger
description: MIAMI  With nine holes to play, Geoff Ogilvy clung to a two-stroke lead over Jim Furyk and Vijay Singh in the rain-delayed W.G.C.-CA Championship on Sunday. Ogilvy was at 17 under and 260 yards down the middle of the 10th at the Blue Monster course when play was halted by darkness in the weather-plagued event  which was hit with a rain delay of nearly three hours.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary last Monday about Magda Cordell McHale, an artist and futurist, misidentified the university where her husband worked with the futurist thinker Buckminster Fuller. It was the Southern Illinois University campus in Carbondale, Ill., not the University of Illinois.

title: Waging the Iraq War From Safely Inside the Beltway
description: Barely a shot is fired in the two-and-a-half-hour opening installment of Bushs War, a two-part Frontline report beginning Monday on PBS. But there are hostilities aplenty, of the Washington turf war variety.

title: Roman Relics Retrieved
description: About 1,000 ancient artifacts found in the country home of a wealthy engineer outside Rome have been traced by archaeologists to one of Emperor Trajans first-century villas, CBC News reported. The archaeologists said the pieces, used as decorations in the engineers weekend residence, came from the walls of what is believed to have been Trajans hunting retreat in Arcinazzo Romano. The suspect in the case has not been identified because the matter remains under investigation, and he is not in police custody. The police did not provide a date for their raid on the home but indicated that it took place more than a year ago.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week included Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Trials Mystery Man Puts Argument in Doubt
description: The S.U.V. guy was late.

title: Discipline First for Taiwans New Leader
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  Growing up in Taiwan as the only boy among five children, Ma Ying-jeou bore the weight of his fathers expectations.

title: Presidential Vote Fuels Taiwans Market
description: TAIPEI  Stock prices soared in Taiwan on Monday as investors welcomed the presidential election victory over the weekend of Ma Ying-jeou, a Nationalist who has called for closer relations with mainland China that could spur the islands lagging economy.

title: A Change of Heart Has Marist Pumped
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  Julianne Viani grew up in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and wanted to go away to college. So when a local school, Marist, offered a scholarship, she declined and headed off to the University of Rhode Island in the summer of 2004.

title: Where the Cranes Come Home to Roost
description: If Miriam Grullon ever needed a German-made, all-terrain construction crane capable of lifting 625 tons, she would not have to venture far. She could, in fact, make her selection by stepping into her backyard and looking up.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture with a report in the World Briefing column on Thursday about early elections in Kuwait was published in error. The photograph was of the countrys prime minister, Sheik Nasser al-Mohamed al-Ahmad al-Sabah  not of the Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Sabah al-Ahmed al-Sabah, who dissolved parliament and called for the elections. (Go to Article)

title: A Present for McCain as the Other Side Fights
description: Feuding Democrats have handed Senator John McCain the gift of time. How well he uses it may determine his chance to beat them in November.

title: Confident Hilltoppers Keep Rising
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Western Kentucky Hilltoppers do not want to be known as bracket busters. They believe it is not their fault that few outside the Sun Belt Conference recognize their talent, particularly that of their star guard, Courtney Lee.

title: New Motion Isnt Ready for Mets Rotation
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Manager Willie Randolph began his news conference after the Mets 14-4 loss to the St. Louis Cardinals on Sunday by announcing the first four members of his rotation. His enthusiasm for identifying the fifth waned once the two candidates, Orlando Hernndez and Mike Pelfrey, failed to distinguish themselves in their auditions. Hernndez, in his spring debut, struggled with his revised mechanics, suggesting he would not be ready anytime soon.

title: Career Climbing, With Claws Bared
description: The pseudo-improvised reality series The Hills, as it plays out beyond MTV, on tabloid covers and in nearly every other byway of the modern media, is above all a vicious decimator of hope. It mocks our hearts; it plays with our allegiances, and we welcome the abuse.

title: David Challinor, Conservationist, Dies at 87
description: David Challinor, a conservationist who combined his career as a top scientific administrator at the Smithsonian Institution with an equally intense pursuit of excellence as a champion oarsman, rowing competitively into his 80s, died on March 5 at his home in Washington. He was 87.

title: As Tibet Erupted, China Security Forces Wavered
description: BEIJING  In the chaotic hours after Lhasa erupted March 14, Tibetans rampaged through the citys old quarter, waving steel scabbards and burning or looting Chinese shops. Clothes, souvenirs and other tourist trinkets were dumped outside and set afire as thick gray smoke darkened the midday sky. Tibetan fury, uncorked, boiled over.

title: Eggs Wanted, Dyed and Otherwise
description: In 2007, as in most years, Americans bought more eggs during the week before Easter than at any other time, according to figures collected from supermarkets and drug stores by the Nielsen Company.

title: A New Tool From Google Alarms Sites
description: Retailers and publishers have fought hard to work their way up in the ranking of Googles search results and refine the search features of their own Web sites to help users once they arrive. Now, Google is taking a greater role in helping users search within particular sites. And some of the same retailers and publishers are not happy about it.

title: A Second Life in Champagne
description: AY, France

title: Stop Those Checks
description: Great Falls, Va.

title: Neil Aspinall, Beatles Aide, Dies at 66
description: Neil Aspinall, who left an accounting job to become the Beatles road manager when the group was still a local dance band and who went on to manage the bands production and management company, Apple, died Sunday night in Manhattan. He was 66 and lived in Twickenham, England.

title: JPMorgan in Negotiations to Raise Bear Stearns Bid
description: JPMorgan Chase was in talks on Sunday night for a deal that would quintuple its offer for Bear Stearns, the beleaguered investment bank, in an effort to pacify angry Bear shareholders, according to people involved in the negotiations.

title: Lets Not, and Say We Did
description: I shuddered only once while watching Barack Obamas speech last Tuesday.

title: New Brooklyn Vistas, and a Fight Over Plans for Them
description: For the first time in decades, visitors to the north side of Brooklyns Pier 1 can see something breathtaking.

title: Wall St. Cheers Bear Deal and Housing Data
description: Shares soared Monday after weekend negotiations salvaged the bailout of the investment bank Bear Stearns and the Realtors reported that housing sales snapped a six-month streak of declines.

title: For Davidson, Good Times Never Seemed So Good
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Davidson College has always toiled amid the giants of college basketball, but just beyond the spotlight that follows North Carolina, Duke and the other power programs in the heart of the Atlantic Coast Conference.

title: Two McCain Moments, Rarely Mentioned
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain never fails to call himself a conservative Republican as he campaigns as his partys presumptive presidential nominee. He often adds that he was a foot soldier in the Reagan revolution and that he believes in the bedrock conservative principles of small government, low taxes and the rights of the unborn.

title: Peacekeeping in Darfur Hits More Obstacles
description: ABU SUROUJ, Sudan  As Darfur smolders in the aftermath of a new government offensive, a long-sought peacekeeping force, expected to be the worlds largest, is in danger of failing even as it begins its mission because of bureaucratic delays, stonewalling by Sudans government and reluctance from troop-contributing countries to send peacekeeping forces into an active conflict.

title: Pope Calls for Peace and Celebrates Conversions
description: VATICAN CITY  Pope Benedict XVI led prayers for peace on the holiest day of the Christian year at a rainy outdoor Mass here on Easter Sunday, exulting conversions to the faith hours after the Vatican highlighted the baptism of Italys most prominent Muslim.

title: A Give and Take Between Experienced and Emerging
description: Since 1993 Itzhak Perlman and his wife, Toby, have coached a parade of superb young chamber players in what began as a summer music school and now runs through the year. The public face of the Perlman Music Program is a series of concerts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Younger Players Rejuvenate Villanova
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The commands by the sophomore guard Scottie Reynolds carried an especially authoritative tone Sunday, snapping his Villanova teammates to attention at every important juncture of their 84-72 victory against Siena.

title: Unused Hospital Supplies Get Second Chance Overseas
description: Already confounded by their own bodies insurrections, patients entering hospitals find themselves in a system thick with new codes and contradictions. Theres the feeling of widespread economy, in the canned peas and abrasive sheets, clashing with signs of protocol-inspired excess  the pileup of unused supplies, still wrapped in plastic, that get thrown away with the trash after every operation.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture with a report in the World Briefing column on Thursday about early elections in Kuwait was published in error. The photograph was of the countrys prime minister, Sheik Nasser al-Mohamed al-Ahmad al-Sabah  not of the Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Sabah al-Ahmed al-Sabah, who dissolved parliament and called for the elections.

title: Before They Prescribe
description: To the Editor:

title: At Grim Milestone, White House Says Focus Is on Success in Iraq
description: The White House acknowledged another grim milestone in the war in Iraq on Monday  the rise in the overall American death toll to at least 4,000  but said that President Bush, although grieved by the new numbers, would continue to push forward and focus on succeeding.

title: One Bruising Scenario for Clinton
description: WASHINGTON  To listen to some of the discussion about the Democratic presidential contest these days, one would think that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton should have spent Easter weekend in Chappaqua, writing her withdrawal speech and preparing for her return to the Senate.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Friday about the prospect of more expensive seating in the new Yankee Stadium referred incorrectly in some copies, to the highest-priced box seats when the stadium opens in 2009. They will not cost significantly more than the current price of $250.

title: With Economy Tied to Wall St., New York Braces for Job Cuts
description: New York is accustomed to job losses on Wall Street. They come with just about every economic slump, and their impact is felt throughout the city.

title: Aretha Franklins Evening
description: An announcer hailed Aretha Franklin as the Empress of Music at Radio City Music Hall on Saturday night before reverting to her usual title, the Queen of Soul. Then the large assemblage of musicians wrapped up the opening medley and started into (Your Love Keeps Lifting Me) Higher and Higher. And out came Ms. Franklin, moving at a processional pace, in an abundance of glitter and black chiffon. It was a manifest vision of music royalty, whatever sobriquet you choose.

title: Tribute to a Reptilian Icon
description: Introduced on Wednesday: Iconic GTR Roadster.

title: Where Wall Streets Caviar Set Still Thrives
description: Fifteen thousand jobs lost in the financial sector since the fall. Recession. Panic on Wall Street. Crisis in the housing market. Bear Stearns sold at $2 a share.

description: To the Editor:

title: JPMorgan Raises Bid for Bear Stearns to $10 a Share
description: JPMorgan Chase raised its offer for Bear Stearns, the beleaguered investment bank, to $10 a share Monday morning in an effort to pacify angry Bear shareholders.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture in The Arts on Thursday with an article about opera mishaps carried an erroneous credit. The photograph, of Ludwig Schnorr von Carolfseld and his wife, Malvina, who both starred in the premiere of Tristan und Isolde  he died soon after  was from the State Administration of Castles for Bavaria, not Germany.

description: Accounts

title: Bodies of 2 Contractors Found in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  Two American contractors kidnapped in Iraq more than a year ago have been found dead, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said Monday, only days after the severed finger of one of the men was sent to American military authorities.

title: Intellectuals in China Condemn Crackdown
description: SHANGHAI  A group of prominent Chinese intellectuals has circulated a petition urging the government to stop what it calls a one sided propaganda campaign about Tibet and initiate direct dialogue with the Dalai Lama.

title: Serbs State Their Case in the Finals at Indian Wells
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif.  The intersection of sports and politics may be an increasing rarity in the United States, but put Serbian athletes on a stage  even one as remote as this sun-baked desert oasis  and politics are sure to follow.

title: The Solstice Gets a Hard Hat
description: Introduced on Wednesday: The 2009 Pontiac Solstice Coupe.

title: Depths of Obsession in Scottish Highlands
description: Disbelief needs to be suspended early and often in Simon Farquhars Rainbow Kiss, a frantic yet tedious play about male sexual obsession in Aberdeen, Scotland, being presented by the Play Company at 59E59 Theaters.

title: The War Endures, but Wheres the Media?
description: Five years later, the United States remains at war in Iraq, but there are days when it would be hard to tell from a quick look at television news, newspapers and the Internet.

title: Zito Alters Motion in Attempt to Regain His Form
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  A month after winning his American League Cy Young award in 2002, Barry Zito relaxed on a couch in his parents home in California and discussed what the hardware meant.

title: Before a Game, Clear Memories of Darker Days
description: Birmingham, Ala.

title: If You Have to Ask, Its $1,150 Per Horsepower
description: Introduced on Wednesday: 2008 Limited Edition Boxster RS 60 Spyder.

title: Dueling Marley Films
description: Competing films about the reggae star Bob Marley, above, are sparring over his music and the timing of their release dates, Reuters reported. The adversaries are the makers of a Weinstein Company drama and a Martin Scorsese documentary. Marleys family, including his son Ziggy Marley, executive producer of the Scorsese film, has refused to license any of his music for the Weinstein film, even though Marleys widow, Rita Marley, is its executive producer. The Scorsese documentary is being produced by Tuff Gong Pictures, owned by the Marley family, and Steven Bings Shangri-La, which has licensed Marley songs. The family members say they believe the Weinstein dramas release date, expected to be late 2009, would conflict with the planned opening of their documentary, February 2010. (Marley was born on Feb. 6, 1945; he died in 1981.) Chris Blackwell, president of Blue Mountain Music, publisher of Marleys music, said he expected an agreement soon under which Weinstein would take a stake in the documentary and agree to postpone its drama.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on March 13 about New Jersey legislators criticism of Gov. Jon S. Corzines $33 billion budget referred incorrectly to Mr. Corzines planned cutback of $168 million in municipal aid. That amount would apply to all municipalities statewide  not just the 323 smallest, which stand to lose $57 million. (The error appeared on March 7 in an article about how the proposed cuts would affect small towns.) The March 13 article also referred imprecisely to a vow by several senators to restore the $168 million. The money would go to all municipalities, not just the smallest towns, although the senators expressed particular concern about those towns.

title: Spitzers Interest in Travel Expense Ethics Could Come Back to Haunt Him
description: ALBANY  Last fall, Eliot Spitzers administration asked a state ethics commission to determine whether officials, including the governor, who fly on state aircraft should be required to reimburse the state if part of a trip was not for official business.

title: Living for Art Gives You Arias to Resort to in Your Time of Need
description: Different governments disagree on what constitutes torture and when such interrogation techniques are justified. But the psychological abuse in Act II of Tosca would surely run afoul of the Geneva Convention. In Mark Lamoss stark staging for the New York City Opera, which updates the story to Fascist Rome, the sadistic police chief Baron Scarpia and his henchmen are dressed in intimidating uniforms and boots, making the threat of cruelty all the more ominous.

title: For a Prize Bull, Next Big Test Is in Genetics Lab
description: GUADALX DE LA SIERRA, Spain  He is a mean, magnificent beast. And during his 16-year life, Alcalde has sired scores of bulls that have proved awesome opponents for some of Spains most celebrated bullfighters. Now, however, the splendid stud is in his twilight years and his owner, Victoriano del Ro, has turned to science to safeguard his precious genes.

title: To Reject or Embrace a Dark Heart as Savior
description: In her newsletter for devotees, which is actually called Pi-Cult, Jodi Picoult describes doing research for her new novel, Change of Heart. Some of it took her to a prison in Arizona, where she found herself right next to the lethal-injection gurney while discussing the death penalty with the warden. She also visited a gas chamber. She spoke with a condemned man.

title: For Wounded Veterans and Their Families, a Journey Without Maps
description: How much more can this country keep demanding of Justin Bunce, Daniel Verbeke and Michael McMichael?

title: Replacing Wire With Laser, Sun Tries to Speed Up Data
description: Sun Microsystems is trying to do for computing what all the kings horses and men failed to do for Humpty Dumpty. For decades, the semiconductor industry has broken silicon wafers into smaller chips to improve manufacturing yields.

title: Do-It-Yourself Logos for Proud Scion Owners
description: TOYOTA likes to think of its quirky, boxy Scion as a 21st-century chariot of the soul  not just an affordable car, but also a unique expression of the young, hip person who Toyota hopes is driving it.

title: Changing the Way Math Is Taught
description: To the Editor:

title: The King Is Hiring; Long Live the King
description: Decades ago, commercials asked, Arent you hungry for Burger King now? Today, a campaign from Burger King is seeking consumers with an appetite for work.

title: Talk to the Newsroom: Director of Copy Desks Merrill Perlman
description: Merrill Perlman, who manages copy desks across the newsroom, is answering reader questions this week. She also answered questions from readers in March 2007. Please submit your questions to asktheeditors@nytimes.com. To move directly to the most recent answer, click here.

title: Sgt. Ryan M. Wood
description: Sgt. Ryan M. Wood, 22, was in a Bradley fighting vehicle on June 21, 2007 when it hit an I.E.D. Warning: Contains language that could be offensive to readers.

title: 'The Finder'
description: Three girls in a car at night, on their way to the beach in Brooklyn. Two are Mexican, about nineteen or twenty, young and pretty  like a lot of Mexican girls you see in New York City. Straight black hair, soft faces, a sweet-eyed optimism not yet destroyed by labor. Dressed in identical blue service uniforms with corpserve patches on the breast, they are nestled in a Toyota two-door subcompact as it flies along the Belt Parkway. The rattling, uninsured car is fifteen years old, carries expired Georgia plates, and has a market value of $125. In New York City you can always buy a car like this and you can always sell one. Who cares about the paperwork? That's for people who have big money to lose. These Mexican girls have no money. They work cleaning offices in Manhattan. Their day begins at seven p.m., so the hour now might be five in the morning, just before dawn. They go out afterward almost every night, a way of saying this work is not yet destroying us. A few minutes sitting in the car at the beach, then they'll swing back to the house on Avenue U, where they live with nine other people. Why drive? The subway, it don't go where we live. And the bus, it takes like forever. So the girls drive. Often they will smoke a little pot some boys gave them and giggle. Open the car's cracked sunroof, let the smoke drift upward. They are enjoying their freedom, their few hard-won dollars, their provisional American identities. They smoke, maybe drink some too, listen to the radio. Giggling and sweet, but tough  tougher than American girls. In the country illegally. Each carrying some kind of fake green card that she bought for $150. They've made the journey and are not yet beaten down, not yet burdened with children and husbands. They have cookouts and volleyball in one of the Mexican sections of Marine Park. And they have guys, when they feel like it, know what to do to make their men feel bien. Sex yet another kind of labor. Their mothers back home don't know  don't know a lot. Be careful! they beg, Nueva York is dangerous for girls like you. But that's wrong. Mexico is where girls get found in the desert, legs wide open, hair dragged with dirt, dead eyes already eaten out by bugs. New York City is big and safe and filled with rich, fat norteamericanos. Maybe the girls won't even marry Mexican men. Why should they? They talk about the office guys. The tall ones who look so good in a suit. You want to do him, girl, I know you do. No, no, es muy gordo, too fat. They laugh. They see a lot of powerful people leaving their offices at the end of the day. Men and women in business clothes. Nice haircuts, good watches. White ladies who think they's better than us. A corporate world so close they could reach out and touch it with their cherry-colored fingernails. Yet given the stratifications of American society, it is a world they are unlikely ever to know from within. They are like Nigerians in London, Turks in Paris, Koreans in Tokyo, Filipinos in Riyadh  outsiders in their new homelands. Their only advantages are their youth and willingness to suffer, but they will lose these advantages, as eventually they will lose everything, including their lives. Come to think of it, they will lose everything a lot sooner rather than later.

title: Revenge of the Living Dummy
description: You may wonder why my best friend, Molly Molloy, and I were in the old graveyard late at night.

title: This Land: A History of Bullying
description: Billy Wolfe has been the target of bullies in Fayetteville, Ark., since the age of 12.

title: The Aussies Explain Subprime
description: There are lots of deconstructions of the crisis, but maybe this one from the Australian comedy duo John Clarke and Bryan Dawe is as good as any:

title: Business Update
description: From The Onion:JPMorgan Chase Acquires Bear StearnsIn Tedious-To-Read News Article

title: Youve Been Rick-Rolled
description: Ever had an irritating pop song stick in your head so long you wanted to veer into oncoming traffic? If its Never Gonna Give You Up by Rick Astley, better get a designated driver. Its gotten a lot harder to get away from that tune since the phenomenon of rickrolling. As todays Times notes, the popular prank is a descendant of an older Internet joke called duckrolling. A Web site or blog post offers a link to something popular that leads unsuspecting viewers to a bizarre image of a duck on wheels. Or, in the case of rickrolling, the 20-year-old video for the Astley tune, or images like the above. Read more

title: Affairs of State
description: Tell us whats going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned photos were posting each week. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: JPMorgan in Talks to Raise Bear Stearns Bid
description: JPMorgan Chase was in talks on Sunday night for a deal that would quintuple its offer for Bear Stearns, the beleaguered investment bank, in an effort to pacify angry Bear shareholders, the New York Times reported citing people involved in the negotiations.

title: China Life Pours $300 Million into Visa I.P.O.
description: China Life Insurance, the countrys biggest life insurer, said on Monday that it had invested $300 million in Visas initial public offering in its maiden overseas investment.

title: Carrington Capital Seeks Cash to Replace Loans, Report Says
description: Carrington Capital Management, a $1 billion hedge fund specializing in mortgages, is trying to persuade its investors to lend it up to $200 million to replace bank loans, in the latest sign of concern about banks pulling credit lines to hedge funds, The Financial Times reported.

title: Qatar Petroleum Raises $2.45 Billion in I.P.O.
description: Investors offered 8.9 billion riyals ($2.45 billion) for state-owned Qatar Petroleum, five times more than it was looking to raise in the initial public offering of a new holding company grouping three of its services firms.

title: Analyst Expects Big Loss Reserves at BofA
description: Bank of America, the largest U.S. retail bank, may set aside a record $6.5 billion in the first quarter to cover possible future loan losses, including in its mortgage and home equity portfolios, according to a banking analyst.

title: Banks Said to Be Eyeing Mumbai Real Estate Venture
description: Lehman Brothers and Deutsche Bank  may invest as much as $500 million in a Mumbai real estate venture of Unitech, Indias second biggest developer, the Economic Times reported.

title: Buyout Shops Bow Out of Bid for Pub Operator, Report Says
description: Apax and Cinven, the private equity groups, have abandoned plans to participate in a takeover bid for Britains Mitchells & Butlers, The Telegraph reported, underlining the difficulties facing financial buyers as they consider offers for the troubled pub operator.

title: Apax Said to Cool on Reed Unit
description: Apax, the British buyout shop, has cooled its interest in the 1.25 billion pounds auction for Reed Business Information, the publisher, The Independent reported.

title: Carlyle and K.K.R. Said to Eye U.K.s Infineum
description: The Carlyle Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts are among several private equity firms keen on British biofuel additives producer Infineum, The Telegraph reported on Sunday.

title: Rival Alitalia Suitor Asks for 3 Weeks
description: The chairman of the Italian airline Air One, Carlo Toto, said in comments published on Saturday that his company was ready to make a new offer for Alitalia, but needed three weeks to study its books.

title: 3Com Shareholders Approve Failed Bain Deal
description: Shareholders of 3Com approved a merger agreement with Bain Capital Friday  one day after the private equity firm called off the deal following opposition from U.S. lawmakers.

title: Visas Shine Unlikely to Rub Off on Other I.P.O. Hopefuls
description: The blockbuster initial public offering of Visa  the largest ever in the United States  will do little to revive the slowing I.P.O. market, which has been dampened by investors spooked by the credit crisis.

title: Israels Modu Said to Raise $100 Million
description: Modu, an Israeli start-up founded in 2007, is going to be adding $100 million to the $20 million in venture capital theyve already raised, according to The Globes, an Israel paper. The company will create tiny modular phones that can be slipped into different device devices, like an MP3 player or digital camera.

title: CIT Seeks to Raise Cash from Foreign Bank, Report Says
description: CIT Group is in talks with an overseas bank to raise funds for its lending business, according to The Wall Street Journal.

title: Small World Labs Snags $1 Million
description: Small World Labs, an Austin, Tex. consultancy and software firm that helps businesses to install and use applications like social networks and blogs, has raised $1 million its its first round of funding.

title: EADS Looks at New Anti-Takeover Options, Report Says
description: EADSs core investors are to consider a fresh protection mechanism to stop foreign takeovers as an alternative to giving France and Germany golden shares, the chairman of the European aerospace and defense group, told The Financial Times.

title: Funds Said to Desert Bear Stearns
description: JPMorgan was last week rushing to reassure hedge fund clients of Bear Stearns prime brokerage of its commitment to the business to prevent an exodus of assets before the integration, according to Financial News.

title: Sovereign Funds Still Spend Amid Crisis
description: The credit crunch has led to an acceleration of investment in U.S. and European banks by sovereign wealth funds, with the amount invested in the first two months of this year nearly matching half the 2007 total.

title: Marathon Acquisition Announces a Deal
description: Marathon Acquisition, a special-purpose acquisition company led by former buyout executive Michael Gross, said Monday it would merge with Global Ship Lease, which owns and operates container ships.

title: UBS to Consider Investor Request for More Capital, Report Says
description: UBS shareholders will consider a proposal for a fresh capital hike of 10 billion Swiss francs ($9.88 billion) next month, according to a Swiss newspaper report on Sunday.

title: Purple States: A Look Back
description: The citizen reporters who brought their concerns directly to the presidential candidates review their experiences on the campaign trail.

title: In the Feds Cross-Hairs: Exotic Game
description: In the week or so since the Federal Reserve Bank of New York pushed Bear Stearns into the arms of JPMorgan Chase, there has been much buzz about why the deal went down precisely as it did.

title: Offering Money Where the Big Banks Wont
description: Turkiye Garanti Bankasi is on no ones list of global financial heavyweights. But the Turkish bank is going where the mightiest banks on Wall Street fear to tread, The New York Times reported.

title: A Corner of Finance Where Women Are Climbing
description: Any growth in the ranks of women at the highest reaches of corporate America tends to be measured in small increments, particularly in the so-called C-suite jobs like chief executive and chief operating officer.

title: Bears Fate Tied to a Crisis of Confidence, Cox Says
description: Was Bear Stearns really weak? Or did it suffer a death by a thousand rumors? If Christopher Cox, the Securities and Exchange Commissions chairman, is to be believed, its the latter.

title: Split Is Forming Over Regulation of Wall Street
description: As Congress and the Bush administration struggle to contain the housing and credit crises  and prevent more Wall Street firms from collapsing as Bear Stearns did  a split is forming over how to strengthen oversight of financial institutions after decades of deregulation.

title: Prayer, Faith and Doctors
description: Religion isnt often talked about in medicine, but should it be? I asked New York psychiatrist Dr. Robert Klitzman, author of When Doctors Become Patients, to tell us about his experiences with patients, prayer and faith.

title: What Created This Monster?
description: Bill Gross of Pimco is no stranger to market crises. But this new meltdown is different from the others, the famed bond manager tells The New York Times as part of a long examination of how we arrived at this point.

title: Thinking Green, on a Private Island
description: Richard Branson was lounging under the starry midnight sky on Necker Island, his palm-dappled speck of an island, recently when he asked high-powered visitors, among them Larry Page of Google, Jimmy Wales of Wikipedia and Tony Blair, the former prime minister of Britain, whther they thought global warming threatened the planet.

title: Anatomy of a Short-Selling Rumor
description: The near-collapse of HBOS sent shivers through the financial world, as many wondered whether the same sort of rumor-mongering that dogged the British lender could have been at play in the demise of Bear Stearns.

title: Monday Tipoff

title: Man vs. Computer: Crime-Fighting Edition
description: The sum of two news reports provide a rather unscientific counter to a Lede post in July on the unbeatable checkers program. In matters of video surveillance, it seems, Man is quite capable of besting technology. Or at least he was on Friday:

title: The Early Word: The Economy
description: Right now, hundreds of children have invaded the White House lawn intent on rolling painted eggs all over the grass, but theres serious political business happening away from Washington.

title: The Price of Dithering
description: The results are in from the Shapes Experiment, featuring a game in which Lab readers repeatedly chose between two shapes and scored points proportional to the area of the shape. Most of the players hurt their scores by spending too much agonizing over decisions that didnt make much difference  and therein lies a lesson for making decisions in the real world, according to Dan Ariely, the researcher who ran the experiment.

title: Chase in Talks to Raise Bid for Bear
description: CNBC interviews Andrew Ross Sorkin of The New York Times about his report that JPMorgan Chase is likely to raise its bid for Bear Stearns.

title: No End in Sight to Spitzers Woes
description: Two weeks after Eliot Spitzers role as a client of a prostitution ring emerged, and a week after Mr. Spitzer left the governors office in disgrace, his woes continue. In a front-page article today, Raymond Hernandez and Danny Hakim report that Mr. Spitzer was deeply involved in his administrations efforts last year to discredit the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, holding detailed discussions with senior aides, ordering damaging information about Mr. Bruno released, and calling an aide at home repeatedly to check on the progress, according to several people with direct knowledge of the investigation.

title: Bears Big Guarantee
description: Did JPMorgan Chase get snagged in a legal loophole?

title: Now Screening | Saffron Burrows in T Takes Episode 6
Dare to Share?
description: No, really, co-presidents: Are you tired of the endless Obama-Clinton, Clinton-Obama campaign for the presidency? Or would you like to see it continue for the next 16 years? Akhil Reed Amar, a constitutional law professor at Yale, sees a loophole in the Constitution that would permit Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton to share the presidency for four terms.

title: CNBC Video: Chases Talks to Raise Bear Bid
description: Monday brought a rare bit of good news for Bear Stearns beleaguered shareholders: The New York Times reported that JPMorgan Chase was in talks over the weekend to raise its bid for Bear to $10 per share from $2 per share.

title: Officials in Lenins Birthplace Ordered to Learn English
description: Before the fall of the Soviet Union, people would often make pilgrimages to Ulyanovsk, the city about 600 miles east of Moscow that birthed Lenin. These days, the Lenin museum struggles while the city tries to lure foreign investment with an unusual plan.

title: JPMorgan Raises Bear Bid to $10 Per Share
description: Its official: JPMorgan Chase and Bear Stearns have announced new terms for their merger deal, confirming Mondays report in The New York Times. The new agreement raises JPMorgans offer for Bear to $10 per share in JPMorgans stock, up from $2 per share, quintupling the payout for shareholders of Bear, the securities firm that nearly collapsed earlier this month amid concerns about its liquidity.

title: Recipe of the Day: Hard-Shell Clams with Parsley Pesto

title: Opinion: Things Are Good When Even Dick Vitale Is Right
description: I was sitting around Sunday night feeling relieved, exhilarated even, that the most underwhelming first day of the tournament in recent memory had not been an indicator of what was to come.

title: Poll: Public Backs Traffic Fees if the Money Goes to Mass Transit
description: Updated, 1:09 p.m. | Half of New York State voters oppose Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs plan to charge motorists for driving in Manhattan  but a majority in the city, in the suburbs and upstate would support the congestion pricing plan if the fees were used to improve mass transit in and around New York City, according to poll results released by Quinnipiac University.Skepticism about how the money would be used appears to be the biggest hurdle for proponents of the traffic fees; half of voters said they did not believe that new revenues from congestion pricing would actually be devoted to mass transit.

description: While interviewing Brett Gardners father, Jerry, for an article in Mondays newspaper on the Yankees Class AAA center fielder, he told me that Willie Randolphs parents are his neighbors in Holly Hill, S.C. Like Willie, Brett was born in Holly Hill. Brett still lives there.

title: Final Score, 5-4 . . . in Six Overtime Periods

The IIHF Web site has the story of the match, played before 16,869 at the Cologne Arena and second in length only to the 1936 Red Wings-Maroons 1-0 game ended by Mud Bruneteaus legendary goal  by just eight minutes. Heres the winning goal, from Colognes Philip Gogulla

It can be used in place of home broadband service from the phone or cable company. And it may also provide an alternative to cellphone networks for on-the-go Internet access. Intel has been a main backer.

title: Illegal Signs and a Reporters Broken Camera
description: The takeover of public space for commercial promotion may be offensive, but it is usually legal. Occasionally, however, it is not. On Friday, March 14, it bordered on the criminal.

description: CBS, which started showing The Price Is Right on Friday nights last month, has ordered four more after-dark episodes of the venerable daytime game show.

title: Bonfire in 2008
description: If you think The Bonfire of the Vanities is a period novel, then carry a copy of it around Manhattan, as I did in the last week. To a Madison Avenue hair salon. To the deli. To the Fairway at 132nd Street. Read it in a doctors waiting room or on the subway. People stare. They offer opinions. One man just shook his head as the No. 1 trains doors opened at Columbus Circle, and said, Ah, Bonfire, as he pushed to get off.

title: Patriots Examine Drafts Most Intriguing Player
description: The Patriots might seem like the last team that would think about selecting a quarterback in next months draft. Tom Brady is the reigning Most Valuable Player, hes never suffered a serious injury and the Patriots have him locked up with a long-term contract.

title: John McCain's Gift of Time
description: Feuding Democrats have handed Senator John McCain the gift of time, reports John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times.

title: At Least the Beds Are Done
description: When I was about seven months pregnant with my first child, I developed an obsession with baby underwear. Even though the babys room wasnt finished, and I hadnt yet acquired essentials like a car seat or a stroller, I was consumed with the idea that I had to have a sufficient inventory of onesies. Only after I dragged my friend to the store and made her help me load the cart with enough onesies for three babies did my anxiety ease.

title: When Is It Worth Going Out of Your Way?
description: Several times a year, someone asks me if its worth the trip to Spain to visit El Bulli. This results in a conversation, because its a long haul and therefore a tough call. Whether any meal is worth a 3,000 plane ride, a hundred mile drive, a night in hotel, and a return trip is a personal decision.

title: Counting Wall Streets Casualties
description: Citigroup: 6,200. Lehman Brothers: 4,990.

title: Defense Suggests Special Treatment for Bell Witness
description: A friend of Sean Bells who was shot  five months after Mr. Bell was fatally shot  was never questioned by detectives or prosecutors as he recovered from his injuries, he testified on Monday. That led defense lawyers to suggest that he was given special treatment in exchange for testifying against the three detectives charged in Mr. Bells death.Mr. Bells friend, Johnell Hankerson, now 30, testified that in April 2007 he was eating pizza on Rockaway Boulevard in Queens when someone shot him. A friend took him to the hospital, he said. Two lawyers representing Mr. Bells fiance, Nicole Paultre Bell, his sister-in-law, visited him in the hospital, he said.

title: ABC Leads the Way on Easter Sunday
description: ABC edged past CBS in attracting what few viewers tuned in to network television on Easter Sunday. According to Nielsens estimates, Extreme Makeover: Home Edition at 8 p.m. and Oprahs Big Give at 9 p.m. led the way for ABC, drawing 11.1 million and 9.9 million viewers, respectively, and delivering the nights top ratings among adults 18 to 49.

title: M.T.A. Postpones Subway and Bus Service Upgrades
description: Subway and bus riders are about to feel the impact of the slowing real estate market and Wall Street turbulence. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has postponed a $30 million package of service improvements that it had promised to riders as a way to sweeten the pill of a fare increase, which went into effect at the beginning of this month.The postponed service upgrades included plans to add more frequent service on the G line in Brooklyn and Queens, extending B and W service on weeknights to 11 p.m. from the current 9:30 p.m., and shaving one or two minutes from waiting times for evening service on the 1, 4 and 6 lines. The M.T.A. had also said it would create a new bus line, the M13, from the Lower East Side to East Midtown, and would extend the B71 and B77 buses from Brooklyn via the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel into Manhattan, where they would go to South Ferry.

description: T Magazines Senior Editor Sandra Ballentine opens up her little black book of tips on where to go, what to buy and whom to know.

Knickman, the president and chief executive of the New York State Health Foundation, who is taking questions from readers through March 29 on a range of issues from universal health care and Medicaid to the prevalence in New York of problems like obesity, diabetes, smoking and substance abuse. Readers are invited to submit additional questions using the comment form below.

title: Theyre Really, Really Out to Get Us
description: Thirty-five years ago, I never thought I would miss Richard Nixon. But lets face it, the guy was  is  endlessly entertaining. In a new book, In Nixons Web: A Year in the Crosshairs of Watergate, L. Patrick Gray recalls an audience he and his wife were granted at the White House in May 1972. At the time Gray had just been named acting director of the F.B.I., after the death of J. Edgar Hoover. Nixon, of course, could never stop talking about the press and broached the subject almost immediately, offering Gray a master class in media relations:

title: Officials Seek Benefits for Slain Auxiliary Officers
description: More than a year after two auxiliary police officers were chased down and shot to death by a gunman in Greenwich Village, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly and Senator Charles E. Schumer are leveling harsh criticism at the Department of Justice for denying federal death benefits to the families of the two slain officers.At a news conference in Manhattan today, Mr. Schumer said the families of the officers, Nicolas T. Pekearo and Yevgeniy Marshalik, were each entitled to about $300,000 in federal benefits intended to compensate police and other public safety officers who die in the line of duty. He said officials of the Justice Department turned down applications from the two families in September, saying that neither of the two auxiliary officers qualified as public safety officers because they did not have the power to make arrests.

title: Still a Great Read  But of Urban History
description: I couldnt get enough of Bonfire of the Vanities when it came out in 1987, and not only because it was a great read, but because Wolfe was chronicling my world  the opportunistic, roiling New York City of the mid-1980s. I was covering Ed Kochs City Hall for The Times, Id covered the citys politics and politicians all of my journalistic life, and I delighted in how Wolfe got it right.

title: Finding a Toilet as Performance Art
description: Longtime readers know that toilets have been a subject of weird fascination for City Room. But just when we thought we had run out of public toilet stories, along comes Tommy Mintz, 31, an artist who works in digital photography and collage.On Sunday, as part of an art performance at the Jewish Museum, Mr. Mintz unveiled the NYC Public Toilet Map, a laser-printed, wallet-sized fold-out map that he is selling for $2 (along with 50-cent mailing charge) over the Internet. The map details locations of more than 250 public toilets in Manhattan, from the obvious (Starbucks) to the lesser-known (the Eyebeam Atelier, a nonprofit arts and technology center in Chelsea).

title: A.L. Predictions for 2008

I was shocked and dismayed that he picked my boyhood heroes, the Mike Schmidt-era Phillies, for fourth place. I think he wound up being right, but I didnt know that in March. All I knew was that this Ivan Maisel fellow mustve had it in for the Phillies.

title: Hammer to Lead NBC Cable Entertainment
