title: Al Copeland, a Restaurateur Known for Spice and Speed, Dies at 64
description: Al Copeland, a poor boy from New Orleans who marshaled gumption, perspicacity and a fiery fried chicken recipe to emerge as a flamboyant multimillionaire with fast speedboats and successive business empires, died Sunday in Germany near Munich. He was 64.

title: Mayor of Detroit Faces 8 Counts in Perjury Case
description: DETROIT  For the last two months, as scandal swirled on and on, residents here knew that their mayor, Kwame M. Kilpatrick, was under criminal investigation. Still, when a county prosecutor announced charges against him on Monday, Detroit was left reeling at the scope and seriousness of them.

title: Missing the Old Days in Albany
description: Dont you find yourself missing the old Albany? Were talking about a distant past that is now no more than a gauzy outline in memory.

title: Foes of Museums Move Ask Judge to Reconsider
description: Opponents of a plan to move the Barnes Foundation and its world-renowned art collection from a Philadelphia suburb to a downtown site asked a Pennsylvania judge on Monday to reconsider his 2004 decision allowing the relocation. Lawyers for the Friends of the Barnes Foundation, a community group, and for the government of Montgomery County, where the Barnes has been since its founding in the late 1920s, appeared before the judge,  Stanley R. Ott of the Montgomery County Orphans Court in Norristown, to request that he reopen the case. Judge Otts ruling in 2004 permitted the foundation, which has struggled financially, to bypass the charter and bylaws of its founder, Albert C. Barnes, who stipulated that no picture in his collection could be lent, sold or moved from the walls of the galleries that he built in Merion. The judge said he considered the move the only viable alternative to save the Barnes from bankruptcy. But the opponents contend that the collections financial troubles have been overstated and that new ways to raise the money to prevent a move have emerged. The county has offered, for example, to buy the foundations buildings and land for $50 million or more to keep the collection in place. But lawyers for the foundation and for the Pennsylvania attorney generals office argued before Judge Ott that the countys plan had come too late and that it could expose the foundation to extraordinary financial risk.

title: Hugo Claus, One of Belgiums Most Renowned Authors, Dies at 78
description: Hugo Claus, one of Belgiums most renowned authors despite his often caustic portrayals of his nation, particularly of its ambiguous role in World War II, died on Wednesday. He was 78.

title: Marist Thinks Upset; L.S.U. Has Other Ideas
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  Carrying a 22-game winning streak and a reputation as a giant killer, Marist came to Louisiana State on Monday night hoping to again make the improbable routine, to turn the unlikely into the predictable.

title: Shuttle Departs From Space Station
description: The space shuttle Endeavour and the International Space Station parted ways toward the end of a busy 16-day mission devoted to station construction. The Endeavours astronauts conducted five spacewalks, and leave behind a new Japanese science lab and a robotic assistant named Dextre for outside work. The tone of the execute package of instructions sent from the ground was jocular and congratulatory. All good rides come to an end, and you are out of quarters, mission managers wrote. The shuttle is scheduled to land in Florida as early as Wednesday evening, weather permitting.

title: Jittery Markets Make the Most of Good News
description: Wall Street appears to be developing a case of whiplash.

title: Peru: Oil Field Protests End
description: Pluspetrol, the Argentine energy company, has reopened an oil field in Perus northeastern Amazon region as violent clashes between police and members of the local indigenous community subsided. The company said Block 1-AB in the Loreto department was operating normally. Pluspetrol had suspended operations at Block 1-AB, which accounts for most of Perus oil output, on Thursday after protesters demanding higher salaries for local Pluspetrol workers stormed the installations. The clashes with police grew violent, and one officer was killed and five were wounded.

title: Deadly Players on a Financial Killing Field
description: Colin Harrisons New York is an-eye-for-an-eye, dog-eat-dog Darwinian world with similar map coordinates to Tom Wolfes Manhattan and the Los Angeles of Raymond Chandler and James Ellroy. Its a place where glossy corporate offices and glitzy penthouses float upon a nasty, bilge-filled river of power and ambition, where malice and murder and mayhem lurk beneath supposedly civilized exchanges about cool restaurants and expensive shrubbery and hot new investments. Its a place where newly arrived immigrants from China and Mexico cross paths with highflying masters of the universe and mob-connected hooligans, a place where the newly globalized marketplace creates megadeals as well as mistrust, miscommunication and deadly misalliances. In short, a Weegee world on steroids and crystal meth.

title: After Campus Shootings, U.S. to Ease Privacy Rules
description: The Federal Education Department proposed on Monday new regulations to clarify when universities may release confidential student information and, after the Virginia Tech shootings last year, reassure college officials that they will not face penalties for reporting fears about mentally ill students.

title: Convicted Imam Seeks Evidence of Wiretapping
description: Lawyers for an Albany imam convicted of supporting terrorism in an F.B.I. sting operation asked a federal appeals court on Monday to release parts of a judges secret order in the case  one they say might show that their client was spied on improperly by the National Security Agency.

title: Make Sudan an Offer It Cant Refuse
description: Charlottesville, Va.

title: Corrections
description: Business Day

title: Indonesia: Warnings on Failure to Contain Avian Flu and on Increased Risk of Deadly Mutation
description: The avian flu situation in Indonesia is grave, and the risk of mutation into a human pandemic form will worsen if more is not done, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization warned last week.

title: Goosebumps Rises From the Literary Grave
description: When R. L. Stines characters confront a creepy villain, they may gasp, they may shiver, they may even cringe. Mostly, though, they shriek.

title: Paterson Says He Tried Cocaine and Marijuana in 1970s
description: A week after admitting that he had been unfaithful to his wife on multiple occasions, Gov. David A. Paterson made another confession about his past, telling a television interviewer on Monday that he had tried both cocaine and marijuana in his early 20s.

title: For G.O.P. Moderates, Hope in a Newcomer
description: TRENTON  Forget about slaying dragons.

title: Airing of Spitzer Inquiry Is Sought
description: Gov. David A. Paterson has been asked by the Albany County district attorney, P. David Soares, to grant waivers that would allow a full airing of the district attorneys findings in its latest investigation of former Gov. Eliot Spitzers administration.

title: Out of East Germany via Bulgaria
description: MUNICH  Two dangling strands of barbed wire have haunted Olaf Hetze for over a quarter century, since his failed attempt to escape from the Communist bloc, not by going over the Berlin Wall but around it by a little-known route through Bulgaria.

title: Canada: Paper Maker to Sell Bond
description: AbitibiBowater, North Americas largest newsprint maker, agreed to sell $350 million of convertible bonds to Fairfax Financial Holdings Ltd. to help avoid defaulting on debt due in the second quarter. The sale is part of a previously announced $1.4 billion refinancing plan. AbitibiBowater, based in Montreal, has struggled to win creditor support to extend the maturity of its debt amid turmoil in credit markets and falling North American consumption of newsprint.

title: McCain Warns Against Hasty Mortgage Bailout
description: Drawing a sharp distinction with the Democratic presidential candidates, Senator John McCain warned Tuesday against hasty government action to solve the mortgage crisis, saying it is not the duty of government to bail out and reward those who act irresponsibly, whether they are big banks or small borrowers.

title: Salt Deposits on Mars Appear to Be Like Those Seen in Earths Deserts
description: With its dry and barren terrain, the surface of Mars has a lot in common with some earthly deserts. Now a new study points to another feature they share: salt deposits.

title: France: A New Shape for the Eiffel Tower
description: The Eiffel Tower has always had its critics. As it greeted the world in the 19th century, phrases like useless and monstrous, arrogant ironmongery, black factory chimney and disgraceful skeleton poured forth, though none stopped it from becoming one of the most recognizable and beloved structures in the world. In 2006, 6.7 million people visited, a record.

title: Stars on Bill at Lincoln Centers July Festival
description: Drama will be center stage at the Lincoln Center Festival this summer, with productions of Euripides and Samuel Beckett, Laurie Andersons latest performance piece and a rare production of Bernd Alois Zimmermanns gargantuan opera, Die Soldaten.

title: More Delay and Frustration, and All at a Higher Fare
description: OF the eight trips I have booked or taken in the last two months, two were scuttled, either by a missed connection or by an interminable delay that made the journey pointless.

title: New DVDs: The Phantom Empire
description: THE PHANTOM EMPIRE

title: Bats Perish, and No One Knows Why
description: Al Hicks was standing outside an old mine in the Adirondacks, the largest bat hibernaculum, or winter resting place, in New York State.

title: Hard Times Hit a Postage-Stamp Land
description: ANDORRA LA VELLA, Andorra  Every year on the Feast of St. Charles Borromeo, the families that dominate banking in this mountainous capital meet to assess the years business. But not even the saints could brighten the latest gathering. The bankers have to watch their waistlines, said Antoni Armengol Aleix, the general manager of the Association of Andorran Banks.

title: Emerald Swell: Riding the Frigid Waves of a Raging Sea
description: BUNDORAN, Ireland  It was a typical late-winter day on the Irish coast, no worse than usual. Bands of black clouds sailed ominously across the sky. Rain bucketed down in freezing torrents. Icy winds pummeled and churned the ocean.

title: Justice as a Game Played Rough, if Tunefully
description: The depiction of New Yorks criminal-justice labyrinth in the Law & Order shows, for all their flirtations with shaded morality, ultimately proves more reassuring than not, invariably sympathetic to the agenda of prosecutors and the police. Now Denis Woychuk, an author and former lawyer for mental patients, has written the book and lyrics for Attorney for the Damned (titled after his memoir), a rock musical articulating his satirical, nightmarish views of the system. (Its at the Kraine Theater, which Mr. Woychuk owns.) For all its raucous caricature and contrivance, the production feels more convincing than anything on television because its perspective offers a more stinging ambiguity. With humor and songs, no less.

title: At 11th Hour, Rivals Vie for Deal on West Side Railyards
description: Less than 36 hours before the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was to select the winning bidder to develop the West Side railyards, the developers Douglas Durst and Steven Roth were still hotly pursuing the 26-acre project on Monday, offering a joint bid that was nearly as high as the front-runners, but with a starkly different vision for the property.

title: Early Egyptians Revered Lowly Donkeys
description: When archaeologists excavated brick tombs outside a ceremonial site for an early king of Egypt, they expected to find the remains of high officials who had been sacrificed to accompany the king in his posthumous travels.

title: Sad Iraq Milestone: 4,000 U.S. Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: Efforts of Dancing Bees Are Often Wasted on Distracted Audience
description: Much has been made about the waggle dance, a fox trot of sorts that foraging honeybees do to tell their hive mates when they have found a good food source. The dance  a zigzagging figure eight maneuver performed in the hive  provides cues as to the direction and distance of the trove of flowers so the other bees can locate it.

title: Small Firms Find Credit Is Tightening
description: Lenders credit woes are starting to take a toll on small businesses.

title: Money for Health Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Calls for $30 Billion for Home Mortgage Crisis
description: PHILADELPHIA  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton returned to one of her major campaign themes Monday  the economic impact of the home mortgage crisis  and called on Congress to provide $30 billion to help states and communities lessen the number of foreclosures.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,986 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

title: Midnight Practice Prepares a Player for Prime Time
description: Coming out of high school in suburban Maryland, Joe Alexander could not entice a Division II program to offer him a scholarship. Now, as he finishes his junior season at West Virginia, he is suddenly confronted with the decision of whether to enter the N.B.A. draft.

title: Writing About Women Who Are Soccer Moms Without Soccer
description: Barely glancing at the menu, the novelist Meg Wolitzer ordered some scrambled egg whites, seven-grain toast and a Coke at the Three Guys diner on the Upper East Side one recent morning. As she scanned the room for mothers fresh from dropping off their children at one of several private schools in the neighborhood, she pointed out a pair of 30-something women in jeans and sweaters talking earnestly, heads together. I think theyre planning a school event, Ms. Wolitzer said.

title: Election Outcome in Taiwan Buoys Stock Market
description: TAIPEI  Stock prices soared in Taiwan on Monday as investors welcomed Saturdays presidential election victory of Ma Ying-jeou, a Nationalist Party leader who has called for closer relations with mainland China  a development that could spur the islands lagging economy.

title: Former Philippine Leader Diagnosed With Cancer
description: MANILA  Corazon C. Aquino, the former Philippine president who played a major role in the ouster of two of the countrys presidents, has colon cancer, her family announced Monday.

title: For Mets Tristan, a Star Is Back
description: It looks as if the Metropolitan Operas Tristan und Isolde will have a happy ending. The Canadian tenor Ben Heppner, right, who missed the first four of six scheduled performances because of illness, will appear as Tristan in the final performances, on Tuesday and Friday, the company confirmed on Monday. Mr. Heppner, the reigning Wagnerian tenor, was initially said to be suffering from a virus, but The Vancouver Sun reported that he had said that his illness had been misdiagnosed in New York. Mr. Heppner told The Sun that after consulting his doctor in Toronto, he had decided to go home, and at North York General Hospital, the doctors discovered that I had a blood-borne infection that had abscessed in the pelvic region. I was immediately put on heavy-duty antibiotics to attack the infection, and the abscess was drained through a surgical procedure. I felt so much better immediately and began the road to recovery.

title: Suggestive Forms That Come Out of the Plywoodwork
description: Bigger names have come and gone, but few careers in painting have been more consistently interesting over the last 25 years than Carroll Dunhams. Mr. Dunham, who is 58 and lives in New York, is known for his cartoonish paintings of blockheaded men with penis-shaped, bullet-firing noses, who star in hectic stories of sexual conflict and global warfare. Driven equally by rage, anxiety and hilarity, his paintings deliver an uncommonly potent combination of formal punch, narrative intrigue and metaphorical resonance.

title: Pakistans New Prime Minister Frees Detained Judges
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  To thunderous applause from fellow lawmakers and a packed visitors gallery, the newly chosen prime minister of Pakistan on Monday immediately released the judges detained by President Pervez Musharraf when he imposed emergency rule last year.

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, an obituary on Friday about Dr. Frank J. Ayd Jr., a psychiatrist who did early testing of antipsychotic and antidepressant drugs, omitted the given name of one of his surviving daughters. She is Virginia Simpson of Umbria, Italy. It also misidentified the state of residence of another daughter. Margaret Reid lives in Towson, Md., not in Virginia.

title: From Just Two Letters, a Hipper Harbor
description: DANA POINT, Calif.  What would brokenhearted Lindsay have to say about the goings-on at this outpost of fish and chips? Would Ryan stare balefully at the recycling truck, thinking about what could have been?

title: A Runner Dreams of Gold Under a New Flag
description: TUCSON  Bernard Lagat leaned forward at his dining room table, staring at his laptop computer. He felt beneath his right arm.

title: John E. List, 82, Killer of 5 Family Members, Dies
description: John E. List, who escaped his drab existence as a failed New Jersey accountant by killing his family in 1971, disappearing and building a new life far away until a true-crime show on television led to his capture almost 18 years later, died on Friday. He was 82.

title: Trying Again After Recurrent Miscarriages
description: Valerie and John Quinones, a Brooklyn couple in their mid-30s, were more than ready for a baby. Ms. Quinones had no trouble conceiving, but miscarried her first pregnancy at 6 weeks. Soon she was pregnant again, but this time no heartbeat was detected at 9 weeks.

title: The Claim: Grapefruit Can Increase the Risk of Breast Cancer
description: THE FACTS

title: White House Offers Grim Outlook for Medicare
description: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration issued a grim report on the financial outlook for Medicare and Social Security on Tuesday, but said that, by two important measures, the condition of the programs had not deteriorated since last spring.

title: Pro-Tibet Demonstrators Disrupt Olympic Ceremony
description: OLYMPIA, Greece  A small group of protesters angered by Chinas crackdown in Tibet upstaged the Olympic flame-lighting ceremony in Olympia, Greece, on Monday, calling for a boycott of the Summer Games in Beijing.

title: For President, Knicks Could Look Nearby
description: If Donnie Walsh, soon to be gone from the Indiana Pacers, is coming home to New York, can we foresee a day when a game between the Knicks and the Nets will be more compelling than Monday nights matchup of a longtime playoff team in transition (Nets) and a terrible one submerged in the draft lottery tank?

title: Israel: Central Bank Cuts Rate
description: The Bank of Israel cut the April interest rate by 50 basis points, to 3.25 percent, citing the probability of a world economic slowdown, which would decrease inflationary pressures. Taking this cut into consideration, the central bank expects inflation over the next 12 months to be 2.7 percent, within the governments target range for annual inflation of 1 to 3 percent. The rate cut is the banks second consecutive 50-basis-point monthly reduction. In late February, it cut the rate to 3.75 percent for March.

title: Theory on Dinosaurs and Volcanic Activity 65 Million Years Ago
description: An asteroid or comet impact gets most of the credit for the event that wiped out the dinosaurs 65 million years ago. But massive volcanic activity around the same time might have played a role, too, by pumping enormous amounts of gases containing sulfur and chlorine into the atmosphere.

title: Social Entrepreneurs: Heres What They Can Do
description: To the Editor:

title: M.T.A. Delays Improvements, Citing Drop in Real Estate Sales Taxes
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Monday postponed $30 million in service improvements that it had promised in connection with recent fare and toll increases, saying its finances had worsened sharply.

title: Memo Pad
description: PREMIUM AIR TRAVEL SAGS Premium traffic, which had been increasing robustly around the world in recent years, is now slowing sharply, said the International Air Transport Association, noting that the number of passengers traveling globally in first- and business-class seats barely grew in January compared with January 2007. Premium traffic on the lucrative trans-Atlantic routes grew 5.6 percent in 2007, and was 2.6 percent higher in January compared with January 2007. But that represented slowing compared with December, when trans-Atlantic premium traffic rose 5.7 percent over December 2006. Premium traffic to and from the Middle East continued to grow unabated, with a 20.6 percent increase last year, the international airline trade group said. Continental Airlines has announced a sharp reduction in 60-day advance-purchase business-class fares to Europe for the summer. Heres a sample round-trip fare: Newark-London Heathrow, $1,798 plus taxes and fees.

title: Opening Day in First Trial Connected With Balco Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The trial of the former cyclist Tammy Thomas began here Monday in what could be a preview of the governments case against Barry Bonds. The trial is the first in connection with the five-and-a-half-year investigation of the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative.

title: USA and SciFi Chief to Lead NBC Cable Entertainment
description: NBC Universal signed one of its top cable network executives, Bonnie Hammer, to a new contract Monday while also expanding her duties to include control over the development of all entertainment programming for cable channels.

title: Google Plan Would Open TV Band for Wireless Use
description: Google proposed a plan on Monday that may let wireless Internet devices use vacant television airwaves without interfering with current equipment.

title: Heavy Turnout in First Bhutan Election
description: NEW DELHI  Orders from the palace sent the people of Bhutan rushing to the polls for their first national elections on Monday, as the once reclusive Land of the Thunder Dragon further opened its doors and joined the worlds democracies.

title: Serbia Formally Proposes Ethnic Partition of Kosovo
description: BRUSSELS  Serbia on Monday formally proposed dividing newly independent Kosovo along ethnic lines, a move that was immediately rebuffed by Kosovos ethnic Albanian leadership in Pristina.

title: Finding New Inspiration on Business Trips
description: Creative inspiration often strikes at the most unexpected times  in the shower, while out for a walk or lying on the sofa  and with depressingly less frequency at the office when workers are actually paid to generate it. But business travel can be fertile ground for discovering creative ideas for work or even a new business, many travelers say.

title: Clinton Says She Misspoke About Dodging Sniper Fire
description: BLUE BELL, Pa.  As part of her argument that she has the best experience and instincts to deal with a sudden crisis as president, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton recently offered a vivid description of having to run across a tarmac to avoid sniper fire after landing in Bosnia as first lady in 1996.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 24, 2008

title: Seeking Fast Deal, JPMorgan Quintuples Bear Stearns Bid
description: Confronting a crowd of furious Bear Stearns executives last week, James Dimons temper suddenly flared. Pounding the table, his voice rising in anger, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase defended the $2-a-share price he had struck for Bear Stearns as well as the governments support of the deal.

title: Detroit Mayor Is Charged in Scandal
description: DETROIT  Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick was charged on Monday with misconduct in office, obstruction of justice, conspiracy to commit obstruction of justice and perjury, felonies that could end his political career and send him to prison for a lengthy term if he is convicted.

title: When the Disease Eludes a Diagnosis
description: Lucy, one of my longtime patients, has a neurological ailment she believes I have been unable to adequately diagnose.

title: In Pennsylvania Towns, a Sense of Disenfranchisement as Primary Vote Nears
description: DOVER, Pa.  In the seamless way of small towns, people in this neatly combed community of farms and businesses 20 miles south of Harrisburg observe a self-imposed taboo against discussing a subject that consumed everybody, pretty much, just a few years ago.

title: Mets Commit to 5-Man Rotation, No Matter What
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  The Mets will not need a fifth starter until April 12. The two candidates for that role, Orlando Hernndez and Mike Pelfrey, imploded during their outings Sunday. So, common sense says the Mets should give Hernndez time to hone his mechanics in Florida and let Pelfrey begin the year in the minor leagues, and hope that one of them will be ready when they need him.

title: Spotlight on Skin
When the Bully Sits in the Next Cubicle
description: An eye roll, a glare, a dismissive snort  these are the tactics of the workplace bully. They dont sound like much, but thats why they are so insidious. How do you complain to human resources that your boss is picking on you? Who cares that a co-worker wont return your phone calls?

title: Obamas Test: Can a Liberal Be a Unifier?
description: WASHINGTON  At the core of Senator Barack Obamas presidential campaign is a promise that he can transcend the starkly red-and-blue politics of the last 15 years, end the partisan and ideological wars and build a new governing majority.

title: TB Patients Chafe Under Lockdown in South Africa
description: PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa  The Jose Pearson TB Hospital here is like a prison for the sick. It is encircled by three fences topped with coils of razor wire to keep patients infected with lethal strains of tuberculosis from escaping.

title: Looking Forward to Remind Viewers What They Missed
description: ITS time to dream again, according to an emotional advertisement on ABC. Its time to feel again. Its time to come together again.

title: Link to Global Warming in Frogs Disappearance Is Challenged
description: In the scientific equivalent of the board game Clue, teams of biologists have been sifting spotty evidence and pointing to various culprits in the widespread vanishing of harlequin frogs.

title: Corrections
description: The Samsun Journal article on March 11, about an effort by a group of Turkish intellectuals to expand their countrys awareness of its cultural diversity, referred incorrectly to a group known as the Molokan. While Molokans have their roots in Russia, they are not Russian Old Believers, the group that rejected the Church reforms initiated by Patriarch Nikon in the 17th century.

title: New York to Boston for $1? Yes, for Some Who Call Early
description: For travelers who want to get from New York to Boston for less than it would cost for a cup of coffee at Starbucks, two emerging bus lines may have the answer.

title: U.S. and Canada Accuse Drug Maker of Fraud
description: OTTAWA  The Securities and Exchange Commission and a Canadian regulator accused the drug maker Biovail and four executives of accounting fraud on Monday, citing deceptions that included attributing a quarterly earnings shortfall to a fatal truck accident near Chicago.

title: Perceptions: Feminists More Open-Minded on Weight
description: If beauty is in the eye of the beholder, then try to be beheld by a feminist.

title: Far Below the Surface of the Worlds Oceans, a Tough Place for Foam Cups
description: Last August, as a team at the North Pole prepared to plunge more than two miles to the bottom of the Arctic Ocean, some of the dozens of specialists who staged the dive engaged in a time-honored ritual: drawing on foam cups, decorating more than 100 of them.

title: Guidelines for Epidemics: Who Gets a Ventilator?
description: It may sound unthinkable  the idea of denying life support to some people in a public health disaster like an epidemic. But a new report says doctors, health care workers and the public need to start thinking about it.

title: New Investor in Distressed Mortgages Gets Backers
description: BlackRock, the publicly traded asset manager, and a hedge fund firm, Highfields Capital Management, are backing a new company seeking to raise $2 billion to buy delinquent residential mortgages.

title: The Census at High Risk
description: The 2010 census is in trouble again. At a recent Senate hearing, Census Bureau officials and outside experts warned that the bureaus new hand-held computer system  nearly four years and $300 million in the making  is not up to the task of reliably counting millions of Americans. Congressional investigators recently put the census on their high-risk list, because of management and budget problems on top of the computer troubles.

title: Colorado: U.s. Proposes Workplace Fine
description: The Department of Labor proposed fining two companies more than $1 million for what it called violations of federal workplace safety and health standards in a fire that killed five workers in October. The fire occurred at Xcel Energys Cabin Creek hydroelectric plant near Georgetown on Oct. 2 after vapors from a flammable solvent ignited inside a tunnel. The five workers, who were trapped in the tunnel, died from asphyxiation. The California company that employed the workers, RPI Coating Inc., was cited for using unsafe electrical equipment, failing to install carbon monoxide alarms and other violations. Xcel was cited for failing to employ proper safety and rescue precautions and incurred proposed fines of $189,900.

title: Last Chapter in Yellowstone
description: For a mere $8 million, Congress can bring one of the great conservation disputes of the late-20th century to a happy ending while providing Yellowstone National Park with protection against future mining claims.

title: Imbibing Scientists (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Nears Sale of Jaguar and Land Rover
description: NEW DELHI  After months of talks, the Ford Motor Company and Tata Motors may finally have a deal.

title: Doctors Remove 6 Organs, Then Cut Out a Tumor
description: MIAMI  Lodged behind several organs and attached to arteries, the lemon-sized tumor in Brooke Zepps abdomen appeared to be inoperable. It was malignant and out of reach.

title: With a Powerful Speech, Obama Offers a Challenge
description: Barack Obama was on the phone, speaking about the one issue he had not wanted to focus on in his campaign: race.

title: In an Era of School Shootings, a New Drill
description: MONMOUTH JUNCTION, N.J.  Tim Matheney stalked the silent hallways of South Brunswick High School one recent Wednesday at 1:07 p.m., peering into dark, seemingly empty classrooms and jotting down room numbers whenever he heard giggles behind locked doors. Students were supposed to remain silent and out of sight.

title: Ogilvy Holds Off Fearsome Foursome
description: MIAMI  When four days stretched into five, when four major championship winners tried to take the lead that Geoff Ogilvy had slept with for four nights, he simply refused to yield. With an unbending display of Aussie resolve, and a little bit of luck, Ogilvy won the rain-delayed W.G.C.-CA Championship at the Doral Resort & Spa on Monday with nine consecutive pars, snapping Tiger Woodss tournament winning streak at seven.

title: Of Mates and Fidelity (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Long Defeat
description: Hillary Clinton may not realize it yet, but shes just endured one of the worst weeks of her campaign.

title: In Queens Trial, Detectives Fear and 31 Bullets
description: The detective pointed his gun at a passenger in the car in front of him and pulled the trigger again and again and again, and in what seemed like only a second or two there were no more bullets, he told the grand jurors.

title: ABC Enjoys Its Easter
description: ABC edged past CBS in attracting viewers on Easter Sunday as Extreme Makeover: Home Edition and Oprahs Big Give drew the nights top ratings among adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsens estimates, the two shows drew 11.1 million viewers and 9.9 million total viewers at 8 and 9, respectively. CBS nearly eclipsed ABC, however, thanks to an overrun of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament coverage in the 7 oclock hour. CBSs 60 Minutes followed, netting more than 10 million viewers. CBSs ratings faltered later as Big Brother, Cold Case and Dexter averaged fewer than seven million viewers. NBC ranked third over all, winning the 10 oclock hour in total viewers with a Law & Order: Special Victims Unit rerun (eight million), even as ABCs Here Come the Newlyweds (6.9 million) led the time slot in the 18-to-49 set. Fox finished fourth for the night.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about an advance at Sun Microsystems that may increase the speed of a new generation of computers described incorrectly a petaflop, a measure of a computers processing speed. It can be expressed as a thousand trillion instructions per second, not a million trillion.

title: Home Prices and Consumer Sentiment Slide
description: Home prices across the country continued to fall in January at record rates while one measure of consumer confidence reached a five-year low.

title: Reach Out and Write to Someone
description: Why are we so lonely? Why cant we communicate or connect? These questions haunt contemporary playwrights, and Garret Jon Groenveld gives them an unusual spin in his interesting but uneven Missives, having its New York premiere at 59E59 Theaters.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about the book editor and publisher Aaron Asher misspelled the surname of an author with whom he worked. He is Ronald Steel, not Steele.

title: Disparities: Wealth Factor Seen in Mammogram Rates
description: Researchers who looked at the mammogram rates of more than 4,000 women 65 and older have found that wealthier women were more likely to get them than poorer ones were  even if the poorer women were better candidates for the procedure.

title: Monks Do a Deal
description: The record label that is home to Amy Winehouse and Eminem is now home as well to a group of Gregorian chanting monks. The monks from the Abbey of the Holy Cross, who number Pope Benedict XVI among their fans, have been signed by Universal Records, Reuters reported. Though they are based at the worlds second-oldest Cistercian monastery, established in 1133 and 10 miles west of Vienna, the monks were discovered in a very modern way, by responding via YouTube to advertisements seeking medieval chanters. They beat more than 100 other entries from around the world. The monks spokesman, Father Karl Wallner, said they answered the ad for fun. But now it has become a very serious and positive thing for us, because Gregorian chant is an expression of our spirituality; its how we pray, he said. Were not Robbie Williams or Michael Jackson; were just a group of monks who sing every day because its our prayer and its our life. The first album is scheduled for release by summer.

title: Benefits Denied for Officers Kin, Stirring Criticism
description: When they were chased down and killed a year ago by a distraught gunman in Greenwich Village, Nicholas T. Pekearo and Yevgeniy Marshalik became heroic symbols of New York Citys auxiliary police, an unheralded force of volunteer officers who are trained, uniformed and authorized to patrol the citys streets, but not to carry guns.

title: Pressed Over Tibet, China Berates Foreign Media
description: SHANGHAI  Chinese officials have sharply criticized foreign reporters here over their coverage of the riots in Tibet, accusing them of biased reporting and preventing them from traveling to Tibet or neighboring provinces to report on the unrest.

title: China Still Has Some Tarnish on Its Image
description: Chinas violent suppression of protests in Tibet does not present the optimal image of an Olympic host, any more than barring live TV shots from Tiananmen Square during the Summer Games in Beijing this August burnishes the governments reputation.

title: A Speedways Last Lap on Memory Lane
description: WALL TOWNSHIP, N.J.  The replica checkered flag, its white squares dotted with signatures and farewell messages from fans, was propped against the racetracks giant marquee, not far from a lone bouquet of flowers still wrapped in cellophane.

title: When Owners Offers Better Reflect Starters Worth
description: Theres nothing glamorous about the 32nd time for anything. People dont throw big parties for their 32nd anniversary. If a baseball player achieves something for the 32nd time, whether its a home run or a save, no one makes anything of it. They go for big round numbers  50, for example.

title: Its Appeal Slipping, the Senior Center Steps Livelier
description: CHICAGO  At a cheerful cafe and neighborhood gathering spot, eight women squeezed around a table, with bottomless cups of 35-cent coffee and plenty to do between the salads and paninis.

title: Consensus on Counting the Innocent: We Cant
description: A couple of years ago, Justice Antonin Scalia, concurring in a Supreme Court death penalty decision, took stock of the American criminal justice system and pronounced himself satisfied. The rate at which innocent people are convicted of felonies is, he said, less than three-hundredths of 1 percent  .027 percent, to be exact.

title: India: Software Maker to Expand
description: VMware, whose software lets computers run multiple operating systems simultaneously, will spend $100 million to build a research center in Bangalore and double its engineering work force in India. The investment will help give the Indian operations more than 1,000 engineering workers in the next two years, VMware, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said. VMware entered India in 2004 and employs about 500 developers there.

title: 5 Dead in Attack on Mine-Clearing Team in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In one of the bloodiest attacks in months on a nongovernmental organization, gunmen killed five members of a mine-clearing team and wounded seven more in northern Afghanistan on Sunday, officials said Monday.

title: Tejano Singer Injured
description: The Grammy Award-winning Tejano singer Emilio Navaira was in critical condition on Monday after he and seven other passengers aboard his bands bus were injured in a crash on a highway in Houston, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Navaira, 45, underwent surgery at Memorial Hermann Hospital to remove a blood clot in his head, said Joe Casias, his agent. The next 24 hours are very critical, Mr. Casias added. The bus, carrying Mr. Navaira and his band, Rio, after a performance in a Houston nightclub on Saturday night, was the only vehicle involved in the crash, above, about 5 a.m. on Sunday. Mr. Navaira won the 2003 Grammy for best Tejano album for Acurdate.

title: Lost Watteau Turns Up
description: Missing for 160 years, a painting by the French master Jean-Antoine Watteau has been found in a private home in England and will be sold at a Christies auction in London on July 8, when it is expected to fetch $3 million to $5 million, Reuters reported. The painting, La Surprise (about 1718), depicts a seated actor playing a guitar and glancing to his right at a couple amorously embracing. It was last noted in a probate valuation in 1848, when it was bequeathed to the family of the current owners, who had no idea what they had. A spokesman for Christies said, It was found during a routine valuation in the corner of a small sitting room in an English country house. The only other known version of the painting is a copy in the Royal Collection at Buckingham Palace. The current record price for a Watteau is $4.75 million.

title: Footnotes
description: On April 22 Jenifer Lewis, now on screen in Tyler Perrys Meet the Browns, will replace Darlene Love in the role of Motormouth Maybelle in the musical Hairspray at the Neil Simon Theater on Broadway. Ms. Lewis last performed onstage in New York in 2006 with Meryl Streep in the Shakespeare in the Park production of Mother Courage and Her Children. ... Brian Sullivan, a longtime anchor for Bloomberg Television, has resigned from the network, a company spokeswoman confirmed on Monday. Mr. Sullivan is expected to join Fox Business Network.

title: From Forgotten Luggage, Stories of Mental Illness
description: A trunk in a dusty attic holds a sleeveless peach-colored silk dress belted in creamy lace, a cane topped with a carved ducks head, kid gloves, a riding habit, a few red leather date books and an eight-page typed essay analyzing Napoleon Bonapartes love life.

title: Police Reveal Few Details of Arrest in 2006 Killing
description: GREENWICH, Conn.  As his wealthy, pampered life as an ambitious real estate developer was caving in around him, Andrew M. Kissel grew close to the one person who had stayed with him until to the end: his chauffeur, Carlos Trujillo.

title: A Boys Life, Guided by the Voice of Cosmic Wonder
description: On the night last week after Arthur C. Clarke, the science fiction writer and space visionary, died at the ripe age of 90, it was cloudy and threatening rain in New York. I was frustrated because I wanted to go outside to see if the stars were still there.

title: With Victory, Rutgers Hopes Its Stock Rises
description: DES MOINES  Nothing was getting in the way of Rutgers guard Matee Ajavon making one more trip to the Round of 16. She was very adamant about that, drawing three charges in the first half of the Scarlet Knights second-round game against Iowa State at Wells Fargo Arena.

title: India: Yahoo Strikes Research Pact
description: Yahoo has struck an agreement with Computational Research Laboratories, a unit of Tata Sons Ltd., to pursue research on cloud computing technologies, in which programs are run from remote data centers instead of a local computer. Yahoo said the project with the laboratory in Pune would use the worlds fourth-fastest supercomputer and Apache Hadoop, a framework for creating software that can handle large amounts of data using several computers.

title: Justices Rule Against Bush on Death Penalty Case
description: WASHINGTON  In a death-penalty case that has become an international issue, the Supreme Court declared on Tuesday that President Bush had no power to tell the State of Texas to reopen the case of a Mexican who has been condemned for murder and rape.

title: Exercise: Tying Neighborhoods to Fitness Efforts
description: Researchers have found that poorer people are less likely to exercise. But a new study finds that the neighborhood they live in may play just as big a role as their income.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Monday about The Hills, on MTV, gave an incorrect identification in some editions for the character who has Whitney as a close friend and colleague. She is Lauren, not Heidi.

description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department gave approval on Monday to the merger of two rival radio networks, XM and Sirius, a marriage that would create a de facto monopoly in satellite services now used by more than 17 million subscribers.

title: Skipping Cereal and Eggs, and Packing on Pounds
description: Researchers have found evidence that Mom was right: breakfast may really be the most important meal of all. A new study reports that the more often adolescents eat breakfast, the less likely they are to be overweight.

title: Two Contractors Abducted in Iraq Are Found Dead
description: WASHINGTON  The bodies of two American contractors kidnapped in Iraq more than a year ago have been found, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said Monday, days after the severed finger of one of them was sent to American military authorities.

title: Pain at the Pump and Beyond
description: The surge in the price of energy couldnt come at a worse time. The average price nationally of regular gasoline has shot up to a record $3.28 a gallon. Combine that with the collapse of the housing market and the seizing financial sector, and it is putting a boot to the gut of an economy that is either already in a recession or close to one.

title: More on Ex-Governor Spitzer
description: With each revelation about the way New Yorks former governor, Eliot Spitzer, operated while in office, our disappointment with the man and his methods grows. The latest disillusionment comes from one of several investigations into efforts by Mr. Spitzer and his aides to publicize politically damaging information about Joseph Bruno, the State Senate majority leader and the states top elected Republican.

title: Neil Aspinall, Beatles Aide, Dies at 66
description: Neil Aspinall, who left an accounting job to become the Beatles road manager when the group was still a local dance band and who went on to manage its production and management company, Apple, died Sunday night in Manhattan. He was 66 and lived in Twickenham, England.

title: Pettitte Says First Start of Season Is in Doubt
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Andy Pettitte played catch Monday, which is more than his lower back had allowed him to do a day earlier. But he admitted his back was still tight, and his first start of the regular season remains in question.

title: Belarus: U.S. Cuts Embassy Staff
description: The State Department announced that with great regret it would cut the staff of the American Embassy in Belarus by almost half amid a widening rift between the countries. The unfortunate actions by the Belarus authorities demonstrate that Belarus has taken a path of confrontation and isolation rather than a path of engagement and democratic reform, the State Department said in a statement. Belarus successfully pressed the United States ambassador, Karen B. Stewart, to return to Washington this month and recalled its ambassador.

title: 2 City Employees Admit Taking Bribes From Bridge Contractor
description: A former New York City transportation official and an engineer pleaded guilty to bribery charges on Monday, admitting they took part in a scheme to help a company that was seeking millions of dollars in a contract dispute over a bridge renovation.

title: Donkey Ends Career With Maryinsky Ballet
description: After 19 years with the Maryinsky Ballet Company of St. Petersburg, Russia, Monika the donkey, above, has retired, Reuters reported. At a farewell party given by the Maryinsky, Monika, 21, waltzed with one of the companys ballerinas and was given a carrot cake, a pinafore and a kerchief. Monikas principal role was in Don Quixote, carrying Quixotes overweight servant, Sancho Panza. She loves to perform, and she loves applause, said Tatyana Solomatina, a spokeswoman for the St. Petersburg zoo, which is home to Monika between performances. She knew the exact time to appear in the ballet, even without someone accompanying her. Monika will be succeeded by Alina.

title: Tampering Costs 49ers a Pick
description: The San Francisco 49ers lost twice with linebacker Lance Briggs, failing to sign him in free agency and forfeiting their fifth-round draft pick in next months draft after N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell determined Monday that the Niners had tampered with Briggs, a violation of league rules. The 49ers and the Bears will also exchange their picks in the third round, giving the Bears San Franciscos seventh pick, while the Niners will get the Bears pick at No. 12. Briggs was with the Bears last season when reports surfaced that the 49ers had had contact with Briggss agent, Drew Rosenhaus. The Bears had made Briggs their franchise player in 2007, and Briggs, who was angered by the move, stated he would not return to the Bears after he played out his one-year contract. But Briggs re-signed with the Bears this month. In the meantime, the Bears filed a tampering charge with the league.

title: Paterson Asks Retired Colonel to Return as State Police Leader
description: Gov. David A. Paterson on Monday nominated a retired State Police colonel to succeed Preston L. Felton, the embattled acting police superintendent who announced his resignation last week.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about Dr. Frank M. Berger, the inventor of Miltown, the first mass-market psychiatric drug, misstated the date and place of his death and described incorrectly the facility where he discovered that a chemical agent he was working with had a tranquilizing effect on laboratory animals. He died last Tuesday, not March 16, and his death took place at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center, not at his home. The facility was a publicly financed research laboratory in Britain, not a drug company laboratory.

title: Bush Given Iraq War Plan With a Steady Troop Level
description: WASHINGTON  Troop levels in Iraq would remain nearly the same through 2008 as they have been through most of the five years of war there, under plans presented to President Bush on Monday by the senior American commander and the top American diplomat in Iraq, senior administration and military officials said.

title: Senior Centers Now a Cafe Society
description: Two facilities in the Chicago area are reinterpreting the senior center model to appeal to baby boomers and today's elderly.

title: On the Road Again
description: A protracted nominating campaign and unreliable Senate schedules have made it difficult for the presidential candidates to make it back to Washington to vote. So difficult, in fact, that Senator John McCain of Arizona has missed more than half of the roll-call votes since January 2007, more than any other senator except Senator Tim Johnson of South Dakota, who spent most of 2007 recuperating from a brain hemorrhage. When Mr. McCain ran for president in 1999-2000, he missed just 30 percent of the Senate votes.

title: The Canadiens Are In
description: Montreal locked down a playoff spot Monday by beating their arch-nemesis, Ottawa, 7-5 at the Bell Center. Theyve got the Senators once more in their last five games (two each with Buffalo and Toronto) but likely have seen the last of them in their rear-view as they tuck away the Northeast Division crown, if not first over all in the East.

title: The Ten-Year Nap
description: All around the country, the women were waking up. Their alarm clocks bleated one by one, making soothing sounds or grating sounds or the stirrings of a favorite song. There were hums and beeps and a random burst of radio. There were wind chimes and roaring surf, and the electronic approximation of birdsong and other gentle animal noises. All of it accompanied the passage of time, sliding forward in liquid crystal. Almost everything in these women's homes required a plug. Voltage stuttered through the curls of wire, and if you put your ear to one of the complicated clocks in any of the bedrooms, you could hear the burble of industry deep inside its cavity. Something was quietly happening.

title: Tata to Raise $850 Million in Debt for Chemical Deal
description: Tata Chemicals Ltd. will raise $850 million through debt to fund its acquisition of U.S. soda-ash maker General Chemical Industrial Products, its managing director said on Tuesday.

title: Air China and Shanghai Airlines Deny Equity Tie-Up
description: Executives at Air China and Shanghai Airlines, denying speculation that has boosted their shares, said on Tuesday that the companies had no intention of forming an equity tie-up.

title: China Wealth Fund Said to Invest More Than $100 Million in Visa
description: Chinas sovereign wealth fund has taken a stake in Visa, according to a media report on Tuesday, dipping its toe back into the market as Beijing agonizes over whether to be more aggressive in its overseas investments.

title: A $30 Million Round for Trius
description: Blue-chip venture firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has led a new $30 million second round of funding for antibacterial pharmaceutical developer Trius Therapeutics, providing ample capital for continued clinical trials on the start-ups primary drug candidate.

title: First Calgary Board Members Resign Amid Activist Campaign
description: Three of First Calgary Petroleumss board members resigned Sunday amid the Canadian energy company efforts to beat back a dissident shareholder motion to remove its chief executive officer over the development of a natural gas field in Algeria.

title: Brown and Sarkozy to Call for Full Disclosure of Write-Downs

title: Sasol to Sell $3.2 Billion Stake to Black Investors
description: Sasol, the worlds biggest producer of motor fuel from coal, will sell shares valued at 25.9 billion rand ($3.2 billion) to black investors in South Africas largest redistribution of wealth since the end of apartheid.

description: When billionaire Carl C. Icahn lost a battle last year to win seats on Motorolas board, he vowed that if the company failed to deliver better results, hed be back. Now he is  and he has brought his lawyers with him.

title: Thornburg Lifts Ceiling on Ownership Stakes
description: Thornburg Mortgage, which is scrambling to raise nearly $1 billion this week to avoid bankruptcy, said it has changed its by-laws to allow a single investor to buy up to $300 million of stock.

title: Fine Print | The Endless City
description: Did you know that the number of buildings over eight stories in Shanghai went from 121 in 1980 to 10,045 in 2005? That 56 percent of all London residents in 2001 were foreign born? And that 65 percent of New Yorkers belong to an ethnic minority? You will after flipping through The Endless City (Phaidon), a chronicle of the unprecedented shift towards urban living that the world has been experiencing since the early 20th century. In 1910, 10 percent of the worlds population lived in cities; we are currently at 50 percent and the projection for 2050 is 75 percent.

title: Seven Deadly Words of Book Reviewing
description: Like all professions book reviewing has a lingo. Out of laziness, haste or a misguided effort to sound literary, reviewers use some words with startling predictability. Each of these seven entries is a perfectly good word (well, maybe not eschew), but they crop up in book reviews with wearying regularity. To little avail, admonitions abound. The best critics, Follett writes, are those who use the plainest words and who make their taste rational by describing actions rather than by reporting or imputing feelings. Now, the list:

title: Is Bonfire a Great Novel?
description: Just like Joyce, I couldnt get enough of The Bonfire of the Vanities when it came out, both because it was a great read and because Wolfe was chronicling my world  except it was a different world from hers. I was working on Wall Street and Sherman McCoys education and upbringing exactly corresponded with mine. Having read and re-read Wolfe constantly since I was twelve, I could not help but be engrossed when he dissected Shermans and my tiny node of America. More broadly, though, as a native New Yorker living in Manhattan at the time, I was fascinated by his portrayal of the city as a whole, and simply as a novel-reader, I loved the book. Reading it twenty years later, I again found it completely absorbing; it still crackled with wit, insight and drama. Maybe most amazingly, I didnt find it at all dated, even though, as Joyce says, the New York of today differs so much from the New York of 1987. Bonfire transcends its era, a remarkable achievement for a book so dependent on period details.

title: My Big Red Crush
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ky.  We avoid bias here at The Quad. And The New York Timess ethical standards, not to mention our own sense of pride, dont allow us to cheer for teams in games were covering. But Im about to expose a loophole in all of that: Theres nothing in our employee handbook preventing us from supporting a mascot.

title: Let Them Read Books
description: I like books. And I like charities. But this has to be one of the unlikelier nonprofit efforts in the New York metropolitan area. From their Web site:

title: Court Rejects State Protections for Air Travelers
description: A federal appellate court has rejected New York States right to penalize airlines for not providing adequate services to passengers trapped on planes at airports for more than three hours.

title: You Decode: The Highlights of The Hills
description: What makes The Hills the most popular show among 18- to 34-year-olds? MTVs unrealistic-reality series returned for season three-and-a-half on Monday, and if last years ratings were any indication, millions of young viewers were watching.

title: N.F.L. Rules Spying 11 Times Worse Than Tampering
description: Commissioner Roger Goodell ruled yesterday that taping another teams signals is 11 times as bad as tampering with another teams players.

title: McCains Housing Speech
description: As he ramped up his campaign stops after a week overseas, Senator John McCain planned to speak today at a roundtable of small business owners in Orange County about the housing/mortgage crisis.

title: Clintons Mortgage Solution: Bring in Greenspan?
description: With the Democratic presidential primary still dominating the headlines, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday turned her attention again to financial issues, floating several ideas for easing the still-raging mortgage crisis.

title: Even in War, Not All Is War
description: It is a warm morning in February 2004, before the uprisings, before the mosque bombings, before Abu Ghraib and beheading videos and sectarian cleansing. A man named Kadum Abdullah, his bent figure draped in a green robe, is poling me and my colleague Razzaq on a wooden skiff through the marshlands of southern Iraq.

title: Hands Off Our Palms, Union Says
description: The folks who study fingerprints at crime scenes do not want their palms scanned to verify their time clocks. Forensic workers at the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner and their union, Local 375 of the Civil Service Technical Guild, are holding a protest today at 5 p.m. at 125 Worth Street against the citys palm-scanning surveillance system.

title: Ohio Echo in Clintons First Pennsylvania Ad
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is up with her first spot in Pennsylvania, which holds its primary on April 22. Notably, it is identical to an ad she used in Ohio, suggesting her camp is planning to try to repeat that winning strategy in the economically struggling state next door.

title: For Political Dropouts, Its Giveback Time
description: With all the money going into politics, it might be refreshing to find that some candidates - only losing ones, of course - are now sending money back to their donors.

title: Clinton: Wright Would Not Have Been My Pastor
description: GREENSBURG, Pa.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton broke her week-long silence Tuesday morning about Senator Barack Obamas relationship with the Rev. Jeremiah Wright, saying that she would have changed churches if her pastor had made the racially divisive and anti-American remarks that Mr. Wright had made.

title: Malthus was right!
description: The Wall Street Journal has an article titled New Limits to Growth Revive Malthusian Fears, which begins:

title: Emilys List to Promote Clinton in Philly
description: Emilys List, the political action committee that works to get female candidates elected, plans to bombard women voters in the Philadelphia area with direct mailings and phone calls on behalf of Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Who Owns the Tips?
description: Thanks to an E.U. ruling, gratuities paid with a credit card legally belong to the restaurants owner in the U.K., who can even use them as a contribution towards paying waiters the minimum wage. This piece in The Guardian  spurred by the Starbucks tip-jar fiasco (more on that in The Times)  raises some interesting tipping issues that are barely ever considered in the U.S.

title: Did Bill Gates Really Say That?
description: Fred Shapiro, the editor of The Yale Book of Quotations, published in 2006, prides himself in the high success rate he has had chasing down the origins of a popular quotation.

title: Ballet Oops
description: Its seldom fun to be wrong, and 99.9 percent of the corrections we scrupulously print here at the Book Review make us wince. But a recent error wound up producing something rather wonderful.

title: Yahoo Joins Social Network Group, as Google Gives Up Control
description: As anticipated, Yahoo is joining the Google-led OpenSocial alliance, which is developing a common set of standards for programmers to create applications that can run on social networks and other sites.

title: Soft Serve | Worst-Dressed Wintour, Tinsley Goes to Work, Yankees New Luxury
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: Friend of Sean Bell Describes Shooting Threat
description: A friend of Sean Bells testified on Tuesday that not only did Mr. Bell argue with a stranger outside the Club Kalua the night Mr. Bell was killed, but also that the stranger told Mr. Bell, Ill shoot you.The testimony followed hours of witnesses over the last 17 days of trial who have turned the exchange in front of Club Kalua into something out of Rashomon, with everyone seeming to see and hear something different. Accounts have ranged from a heated exchange between Mr. Bell and his friends and the stranger, Fabio Coicou, to a pleasant conversation about their neighborhood, Far Rockaway.

title: Freedoms Watch Hires Romney Aide
description: The conservative group, Freedoms Watch, which has endured some prominent staff departures in recent months, announced today the hiring of Carl Forti, who was most recently political director for Mitt Romneys presidential bid, to run the groups issue advocacy campaign in the fall.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Tuesday, Mar. 25:

title: Nancy Reagan Endorses McCain
description: The foot soldier in the Reagan revolution was set to receive the endorsement of Nancy Reagan while campaigning in California on Tuesday.

title: Campaign Conversations
description: John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC talks to Gov. Phil Bredesen of Tennessee.

title: Explaining That Yankees Prediction
description: I spent the morning watching Andy Pettitte play catch at chilly Legends Field. He wont start the second game of the season (Mike Mussina will), but he said hes confident he can pitch a bullpen session on Wednesday and maybe start the third game of the year.

title: Street Trees Are No Longer an Optional Accessory
description: I think that I shall never see a zoning text amendment lovely as a tree. But the new Section 26-41 of the Zoning Resolution, which was approved on Monday by the City Planning Commission, no doubt comes close for fans of a green city. It requires the planting of street trees for new developments, as well as major enlargements and certain conversions of existing buildings. One tree is required for every 25 feet of street frontage.

title: NBC Schedules a Chat About Prime Time
description: NBC, which made a big point last month about moving to a year-round schedule of program introductions and changing the way it introduces its shows to advertisers, has announced a prime time press presentation to be held on April 2, six weeks before the traditional week of network upfronts.

title: Hey, Kids! Dont Eat the New Lunch Trays
description: Opponents of the use of polystyrene trays in New York City public schools have a new idea: sugar cane.

title: Assigning Blame, From Loose Fuses to Loose Nukes
description: Updated

title: Eliot Spitzer Erotic Fiction
description: Those four words pretty much say it. 236.com, a comedy news site, has folded some of its favorite claims  Spitzer liked to watch; he wore calf-length black socks  into a romance-novel excerpt that might hold its own alongside some of the books on our mass-market best-seller list. (Spitzer could tell something wasnt right. Hed been told this couple were pros)

title: What Stinks? The Mourners Wore Hazmat Suits
description: The coffin held the South Bronx. The mourners wore asthma inhalers and face masks. And the litany of complaints regarding the New York Organic Fertilizer Company was all too familiar: the smell was unholy, the demands righteous.Neighbors of the New York Organic Fertilizer Company, on Oak Point Avenue in the Hunts Point section, held a candlelight vigil in front of the plant this afternoon. Sludge from the city sewer system is burned there and made into fertilizer pellets.

title: Ill-Advised Getaway Cars
description: Amid news of a new movie called The Perfect Getaway, three recent attempts that were far from it, all involving a poor choice in escape vehicles.

title: Car of the Decade? How About the Porsche Cayenne?
description: Tesla Motors, the nascent dot-car manufacturer that promised the world an electric sports car, announced last week that series production of the Tesla Roadster had begun at the Lotus plant in Hethel, England. The Roadster is powered by a 185 kilowatt (248 horsepower) three-phase, four-pole brushless electric motor and promises to be the only mass-production electric car offered for sale in America when it comes later this year.

title: Earth in Flux: An Antarctic Ice Shelf Crumbles
description: Scientists who study the warming seas and complicated climate and ice trends around Antarctica got a big jolt in recent days as yet another great fringing, floating ice shelf jutting from the Antarctic Peninsula began to disintegrate.

title: How Dirty Is Your Subway Line?
description: If it is true that cleanliness is next to godliness, then riders of the L train may have a closer relationship with the divine than therest of us. At least, thats a conclusion that could be drawn from the latest survey by an advocacy group that tried to measure subway cleanliness. The survey released today by Straphangers Campaign, which is financed by New York Public Interest Research Group, found that the L train had the cleanest cars in a recent series of visits to the various lines. The dirtiest cars run on the E and the Q lines, the group concluded.

title: Wrights Fla. Event Canceled
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Church officials here canceled a scheduled appearance by the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr. this afternoon, citing the media attention his sermon had attracted.

title: Man of 101-Plus Voices
description: Brock Baker says, Lets face it, Im just a broke dude in his early 20s making videos in his basement in hopes of moving out to California  to be even poorerer. Here are his first 101 impressions (quite the YouTube hit) followed by the more recent sequel. If you can recognize all the pop culture references in both videos, you might want to reexamine your life:

title: City Announces Changes to Crane Inspections
description: In the wake of crane accidents in Manhattan and Miami, officials are scrambling to shore up crane operations and improve public safety.

title: ABC and CBS Top Monday Nights Ratings
description: A guest appearance from Britney Spears helped CBSs How I Met Your Mother attract its largest audience of the season on Monday as 10.6 million viewers tuned in to the 8:30 p.m. sitcom, according to Nielsens estimates.

title: Chicago Tribunes Owner Blesses Counter-Prank
description: BRIEFS Last week, The Chicago Sun-Times suffered as its joke on Sam Zell, the billionaire owner of The Chicago Cubs, The Chicago Tribune and other properties, backfired. This week, Mr. Zell expressed approval for a video that mocked him a bit: It was a deft grab of the ball away from that other paper. What was their name again? [LA Observed, via Gawker]

title: John Pavlus
description: Lets talk about Web newscasts.

title: Q and A: Seamus Mullen
description: With the opening of the Spanish restaurant Boqueria in 2006, Seamus Mullen caught the attention of many of the citys most discerning food lovers, some of whom also took note of the huge improvements he subsequently made at Suba on the Lower East Side. He oversaw the overhaul of Subas kitchen and menu last year.

title: Rodent Tool Use
description: Degus, small rodents from South Africa, were trained over a period of weeks to use a rake as a tool to reach food.

title: Penny Wise, Nickel Foolish
description: An article by David Owen in The New Yorker has prompted a smattering of bloggers (from The New Republics Isaac Chotiner to The Atlantics Andrew Sullivan and Matthew Yglesias) to call for the abolition of the penny as well as to link to a 2004 William Safire column in the Times making just that argument.

title: LAffaire Roy: Now the Police Are Involved
description: OTTAWAPatrick Roy, the former NHL goalie, and his son Jonathan, a goalie on the Quebec Remparts team his father owns and coaches in the provincial junior league, were both suspended for several games on Tuesday. But that may be the least of their worries.

title: Should Wine Be a Family Affair?
description: My column in tomorrows newspaper is about whether or not it is legal, safe and desirable to give my two teenage sons small portions of wine at the dinner table. Heres the background:

title: Rangers Face Flyers Down Another Man
description: To the loss of centers Scott Gomez (bruised ribs) and Blair Betts (foot surgery), the Rangers have added defenseman Michal Rozsival, who will sit for Tuesday nights game against the Flyers with an upper leg strain.

title: How to Treat Stranded Passengers
description: BRIEFS A federal court today rejected New York States attempt to require airlines to provide water, fresh air, power and working restrooms during lengthy delays, precisely the situation encountered today on a flight of the London Eye, the British capitals Ferris wheel attraction. Whether or not it was legally required to do so, the Eye rushed a raft of comforts for stranded passengers: water, blankets, glucose tablets and commodes.

title: Housing Crisis? The H.U.D. Secretary is a Little Distracted Right Now
description: Alphonso Jackson, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, shocked an audience of business leaders two years ago when he told of denying a government contract solely because the head of the bidding company spoke ill of President Bush.

title: State Identifies Failing School Districts
description: A total of 34 school districts outside of New York City have failed to meet annual benchmarks for standardized test scores and high school graduation rates under the federal No Child Left Behind law, or six more than the previous year, according to a list released Tuesday by the State Education Department.

title: Look and feel 15 years younger!
description: The latest report of the Social Security Trustees is out. I think the key message is what has happened to the estimate of actuarial balance  the difference between projected outlays and projected revenues over the next 75 years. This is the thing thats supposed to get steadily worse as time goes by, as the 75-year window contains ever fewer years in which the baby boomers are in the work force, paying payroll taxes, and ever more years when the boomers are out of the work force and collecting benefits.

title: Ron Pauls Graphics Revolution
description: Steven Heller is the co-chairman of the MFA Design program at the School of Visual Arts. (Full biography.)

title: Q&A: U.S. Womens Coach Pia Sundhage
description: Pia Sundhage is the sixth coach in the history of the United States womens national team, but the first from outside the country. Sundhage, 48, was hired by U.S. Soccer last November to replace Greg Ryan, who was fired after the American team finished third in the Womens World Cup in China. She is charged with qualifying the United States for this summers Olympics in Beijing and defending the gold medal won by the American women four years ago in Greece. Sundhage was interviewed by phone last week from Stockholm, where she was preparing to travel to Los Angeles where the United States team is now training for next weeks qualifying games in Ciudad Juarez, Mexico.

title: Volvo Puts On a Party With a Purpose
description: As Richard Chang mentioned in an earlier post, auto show week always brings an abundance of parties thrown by various automakers, each trying to outdo the others in glitz, gimmicks and celebrity appearances. The Volvo For Life Awards, held last Wednesday at Cipriani 42nd Street, were a little different.

title: Slinging It Back and Forth
description: Sometimes, if you just keep repeating the negative, connecting the dots with the name-calling, it doesnt really matter anymore who flung which insult at whom. (And no one remembers who started it.)

title: Hockey Night in Blogdom: Eastern Bubble Edition
description: The last few games of the season are upon us, and the death-struggle for the final playoff berths hurtles to its unspeakable climax! What better time to ask our crew of highly partisan independent bloggers the two biggest questions: Who must prevail, and who must fail? Heres what those who follow the teams in the Eastern battle say.

title: Hockey Night in Blogdom: Western Bubble Edition
description: The last few games of the season are upon us, and the death-struggle for the final playoff berths hurtles to its unspeakable climax! Now is the time to ask our crew of highly partisan independent bloggers the two biggest questions: Who must prevail, and who must fail. Heres what those who follow the teams in the Western battle say.

title: Bringing Outlook and Gmail Closer Together
description: UPDATED

title: Anxiety Near Tibet
description: Chinese police have been monitoring the Tibetan community in Chengdu, in Sichuan Province, which adjoins Tibet.

title: Reflections About Work, Hour by Hour
description: A new book, Water Cooler Diaries by Joni B. Cole and B.K. Rakhra adds another resource to the list Ive been keeping of ways to know what it is like to do various jobs. This one grew out of an experiment on March 27, 2007, when 500 women kept a diary of their day at work. Thirty-five of the diarists made it into the book. In honor of the experiments one-year anniversary, here is a glimpse of what a handful of the diarists were doing at roughly 9 a.m. on the day they kept their log:

title: Evolving the Wow! Factor
description: (Being the third part of an occasional series about mutations.)

title: Thailand may be next for global investment surge, CBRE says
description: Economists these days are raving about the continued growth of cross border transactions, the movement of investment money from country to country. Even with the much-discussed property slowdown, the amount of money flowing around the world is at unprecedented levels, they say, bolstering markets and creating quick run ups.

title: Missing Ingredient, Gone for Good
description: YOU have one. Everybody does. The dish that stands out above all others: the most delicious food ever cooked by a beloved person who is no longer here to cook it.

title: A Political Comeback: Supply-Side Economics
description: When Ronald Reagan ran for president in 1980, he promised to cut taxes in what seemed, at the time, a magical way. Tax revenue would go up, not down, he said, as the economy boomed in response to lower rates.

title: Aid to College Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 25, 2008

title: John McCain Wants You
description: Washington

title: Ford Sells Land Rover and Jaguar to Tata
description: NEW DELHI  Tata Motors, part of Indias fast-growing Tata Group, is buying Jaguar and Land Rover from the Ford Motor Company for $2.3 billion.

title: Space Shuttle Completes 16-Day Mission, and Lands
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla.  The space shuttle Endeavour returned safely to earth on Wednesday evening, completing a record-breaking 16-day mission to the International Space Station.

title: Consumer Attitudes and Home Prices Sour
description: Americans are bracing for rising unemployment and shrinking salaries, a gloomy outlook that could translate into a serious cutback in consumer spending, the primary engine of the economy.

title: Spaghetti Stir-Fry and Hambagoo: Japan Looks West
description: TOKYO

title: An Investment Banker Finds Fame Off the Books
description: HONG KONG  Until about four years ago, Chetan Bhagat was an investment banker distinguished from the suited phalanx in this citys crowded financial district only by his secret hobby.

title: The Juveniles Are Gone, Yet the Jails Remain
description: The public pays about $500 a night for each of the 25 beds in the Auburn Residential Center  a place for teenagers who have gotten into lower-grade trouble with the law, a junior-varsity jail. For the last two weeks, the beds in Auburn have been empty. And state officials expect them to remain empty, permanently.

title: Gunfire Was Threatened, a Friend of Bells Testifies
description: A friend of Sean Bells testified on Tuesday not only that Mr. Bell argued with a stranger outside Club Kalua on the morning Mr. Bell was killed, but also that the stranger told Mr. Bell, Ill shoot you.

title: Thomas Dangles While Knicks Court Walsh
description: Isiah Thomas has a disastrous win-loss ledger to rival Larry Browns, with all of the attendant controversy and confusion. So it seems only natural that Thomas, like Brown before him, now finds himself trapped in a minefield of uncertainty, awkwardness and speculation. Impromptu roadside interviews could be in his near future.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Arts, Briefly column on Thursday about plans by George Clooney to hold a screening of his new movie, Leatherheads, in Maysville, Ky., misstated the location of Maysville in relation to Augusta, Ky., where Mr. Clooney grew up. It is about 16 miles east of Augusta, not west.

title: F.A.A. Wants Stoplights Added to Runways
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Aviation Administration will add a runway version of traffic signals at 20 busy airports in the next three and a half years, the agency said Monday. The signals are part of a program to keep taxiing airplanes or vehicles from intruding on runways where other planes are taking off and landing.

title: U.S. Shares Mixed at Open as Global Markets Rise
description: PARIS  European and Asian stocks posted strong gains Tuesday after JP Morgans revised offer for Bear Stearns bolstered financial shares, but the U.S. market faltered at the opening on another dose of sobering housing data.

title: The Showhouse That Sustainability Built
description: ERIC DOUB knows the difference between talking about building a green home and living in one: more than 2,600 energy-conscious visitors have traipsed through his model home in the last two and a half years.

title: Corrections
description: Business Day

title: Remains of Human Ancestors Found
