description: Excavations in a cave in the mountains of northern Spain have uncovered the oldest known remains of human ancestors in Western Europe, scientists reported Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Anita M. Busch, a former reporter who received a threat that began the series of events leading to the trial of a Hollywood private investigator, Anthony Pellicano, misidentified those who doubted her account and called her the Tawana Brawley of the newsroom. They were people at The Los Angeles Times when she was a contract writer there, according to a 2002 article in The Washington Post, which did not identify them. It was not The Washington Post that referred to her that way.

title: Retired Couple Cheers Rutgers Women
description: DES MOINES  At daybreak Tuesday, a few hours after the Rutgers womens basketball team knocked off Iowa State, 69-58, in the second round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, a three-car caravan planned to pull out of here and nose onto Interstate 80, headed for Chicago.

title: McCain Rejects Broad U.S. Aid on Mortgages
description: SANTA ANA, Calif.  Drawing a sharp distinction between himself and the two Democratic presidential candidates, Senator John McCain of Arizona warned Tuesday against vigorous government action to solve the deepening mortgage crisis and the market turmoil it has caused, saying that it is not the duty of government to bail out and reward those who act irresponsibly, whether they are big banks or small borrowers.

title: A Survey of the Cleanest, and Dirtiest, Subway Trains in New York City
description: Wet, sticky spots on the train floor, chicken bones, nut shells, spilled coffee, hot dogs and lots and lots of rolling bottles often greet subway passengers who travel on the E and the Q trains  rated the dirtiest lines in the New York City subway system in the latest survey by a rider advocacy group.

title: New Places: Nizza and Sookk
description: Nizza

title: A Chevy With an Engine From China
description: OSHAWA, Ontario  General Motors car engines were once the stuff of American legend. The Beach Boys sang, nothing can touch my 409, about a powerful Chevy V-8. Oldsmobile owners in 1981 were so angered that their cars had been fitted with Chevrolet engines instead of Oldsmobile Rockets, the subject of another hit song, that they successfully sued G.M. over the swap.

title: Clinton Criticizes Obama Over His Pastor
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton ended her silence on Senator Barack Obamas pastor on Tuesday, sharply criticizing Mr. Obama for not leaving the Chicago church where the pastor made inflammatory remarks about the United States, spread conspiracy theories about the government and made sensational comments about Mrs. Clinton.

title: Fighting  in Iraq Continues Amid Crackdown
description: BAGHDAD  Heavy fighting continued for a second day Wednesday in two of Iraqs largest cities, as Iraqi ground forces and helicopters mounted a huge operation to break the grip of the Shiite militias controlling Basra, and Iraqi forces clashed with militias in Baghdad. The fighting threatened to destabilize a long-term truce that had helped reduce the level of violence in the five-year-old Iraq war.

title: Motorola Moves to Split Itself Into Two
description: After a two-month review of its businesses, Motorola, the telecommunications equipment maker, said on Wednesday that it would split into two separate entities, spinning off its unprofitable mobile phone unit to investors.

title: Voigt's Isolde Is Latest Casualty in Metropolitan Opera's Tristan
description: Truth remained stranger than even Wagnerian fiction for the Metropolitan Operas six-performance revival of Tristan und Isolde in its fifth outing, on Tuesday. With the tenor Ben Heppner recovered from illness and set to assume the role of Tristan for the first time in the run, the Met announced that the soprano Deborah Voigt, right, the Isolde, was ill and would be replaced by Janice Baird. In the first performance, on March 10, Mr. Heppner was replaced by John Mac Master, who was himself later reported to have been suffering from allergies and was coolly received by audience and critics alike. In the second, Gary Lehman took over to a better reception, but the curtain came down in midperformance when Ms. Voigt took ill and had to be replaced by Ms. Baird. In the third, Ms. Voigt returned, but the curtain again came down prematurely, when a stage mechanism malfunctioned and Mr. Lehman slid down the raked stage on a pallet into the prompters box. He returned after 10 minutes and finished the performance. In the fourth, Mr. Lehman, still with a lump on his head, was replaced by Robert Dean Smith. At press time the Met was still holding out hope that Mr. Heppner and Ms. Voigt would finally take the stage together for the last performance, on Friday.

title: Day of Embarrassment for Hollywood in Court
description: LOS ANGELES  A rollicking day of salacious testimony in the wiretapping trial of the Hollywood private eye Anthony Pellicano began with prosecutors revealing that Bert Fields, a top entertainment lawyer who often hired Mr. Pellicano, would invoke his Fifth Amendment right not to testify if called by the prosecution.

title: Regulators Stamp Copper as a Germ Killer
description: The market for antimicrobial doorknobs, hospital fixtures and other products that kill germs on contact may be about to take on a coppery sheen.

title: 201 Feet to Left, 440 Feet to Right: Dodgers Play the Coliseum
description: LOS ANGELES  The foul pole stands only 201 feet down the left-field line. A 60-foot-high net snickers beside it, ready to entice hitters and tickle the necks of two laughably cramped left fielders.

title: Millions of Jobs of a Different Collar
description: EVERYONE knows what blue-collar and white-collar jobs are, but now a job of another hue  green  has entered the lexicon.

title: Early Wake-Up Call for Red Sox Fans
description: BOSTON  It had the trappings of a classic home game: the Fenway Park lights ablaze, the sidewalks jammed, the parking  make that pahking  impossible.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: A picture caption with the Our Towns column on Sunday, about the intersection of March Madness for college basketball with the anxiety felt by high school seniors in April, when they find out which colleges have accepted them, misidentified the fan at center watching a game at the Black Bear Saloon in White Plains. He is Justin Marinucci, not Jason Zulauf.

title: Swift Steps Help Avert Foreclosures in Baltimore
description: BALTIMORE  When Wilbert and Patricia Savage missed two mortgage payments on their tidy row house here last fall, Mr. Savage, 75, despaired that they could ever catch up.

title: How to Survive in New York on 99 Cents
description: I LOVE shopping at my local Gourmet Garage as much as the next guy. But sometimes I plop a can of chicken broth down on the checkout counter and think, $2.19? For someone to boil chicken bones? I want that job.

title: Jumbo Lenders Shares Rise 36% on Private Placement
description: Shares of Thornburg Mortgage, a provider of jumbo mortgages that is trying to stave off a bankruptcy filing, rose 36 percent on Tuesday after the company disclosed plans to raise $1.35 billion.

title: Company Plans Vehicle for Trips to Cusp of Space
description: A small aerospace company in California announced plans for a rocket-powered vehicle that could carry adventure travelers to the cusp of space for a brief experience of black sky and weightlessness. Xcor Aerospace of Mojave, Calif., said its Lynx craft would be slightly smaller than a business jet and would be propelled by a blend of kerosene and liquid oxygen. The companys co-founder, Jeff Greason, said the first version would be flying by 2010 and would reach an altitude of 38 miles; the next version of the craft, he said, would reach 68 miles, an altitude broadly accepted as suborbital space. The company, like Sir Richard Bransons Virgin Galactic, expects a market to emerge for space tourism.

title: Cigarette Company Paid for Lung Cancer Study
description: In October 2006, Dr. Claudia Henschke of Weill Cornell Medical College jolted the cancer world with a study saying that 80 percent of lung cancer deaths could be prevented through widespread use of CT scans.

title: A Request to Release Findings on Spitzer
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson has been asked by the Albany County district attorney, P. David Soares, to allow the district attorney to make public the findings in his latest investigation of former Gov. Eliot Spitzers administration.

title: Citi Pays $1.66 Billion to Settle Enron Claim
description: Seeking to put its legal problems behind as it confronts larger financial ones, the banking giant Citigroup said on Wednesday that it had settled claims accusing it of helping the energy trader Enron deceive investors.

title: Majoring in Renewable Energy
description: AS business and industry are taking more interest in renewable energy, academia is not far behind. Anticipating increased demand for new technical and design skills, colleges and universities across the nation are offering degree programs in the field.

title: Report Assails Auditor for Work at Failed Home Lender
description: In a sweeping accusation against one of the countrys largest accounting firms, an investigator released a report on Wednesday that said improper and imprudent practices by a once high-flying mortgage company were condoned and enabled by its auditors.

title: Two Views of Life, Enduring, Unyielding
description: If nothing else, the struggle between East and West has a distinguished pedigree. In Worlds at War the British historian Anthony Pagden traces the seemingly endless series of misunderstandings and armed conflicts between an ever-shifting West and equally amorphous East to the time of myth, when Paris abducted Helen, provoking the Trojan War.

title: The Great Barrier Reef and Beyond
description: EVERY morning, starting around 7, small groups of sleepy tourists toting towels and oddly shaped nylon satchels appear on the beachfront main street in the small town of Palm Cove on Australias northeast coast. This is the mundane beginning of a day trip to the Great Barrier Reef.

title: What a Rodent Can Do With a Rake in Its Paw
description: Degus are highly social, intelligent rodents native to the highlands of Chile. They adorn the openings of their burrows with piles of sticks and stones, have bubbly personalities and like to play games.

title: Rodriguez Is a Target in Cansecos New Book
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Jos Canseco had intimated that his coming book would have some damning information about Alex Rodriguez of the Yankees, maybe even that Rodriguez had used steroids. But when details from the book were unearthed Tuesday, Cansecos strongest allegation was that he introduced Rodriguez to a known steroids supplier whom Canseco failed to identify.

title: Clorox Courts Sierra Club, and a Product Is Endorsed
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.

title: 10 Prints Are Better Than 2, Homeland Security Says
description: Under the stern gaze of passport officials and the even sterner gaze of television cameras, the two British citizens, fresh off a morning flight from London on Tuesday, passed through customs at Kennedy International Airport separately and came to separate conclusions.

title: Defects Go Unfixed for Years in Dozens of Dams, New York Comptroller Finds
description: New York States oversight of thousands of dams has been so deficient in recent years that serious problems in dozens of dams holding back billions of gallons of water have gone years without being fixed, according to a report released on Tuesday by the New York State comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli.

title: Banks Balk at Paying for Clear Channel Deal
description: The $19.5 billion sale of the radio broadcaster Clear Channel Communications to two private equity firms is in jeopardy.

title: Wonderful World of Lopez Twins
description: Brook Lopez, a 19-year-old college sophomore, is writing two novels and a play. He has acting experience, and he can play the saxophone. His twin brother, Robin, an aspiring artist, visited the Sistine Chapel last summer to study Michelangelos Last Judgment.

title: Philippines Worried About Rice Shortages
description: MANILA  President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo ordered a crackdown on rice hoarders on Tuesday, as her administration tried to blunt the impact of rice shortages that could fuel public unrest.

title: Hal Riney, Adman for Reagan and G.M., Dies at 75
description: Hal Riney, the iconoclastic copywriter who helped build San Francisco into a creative center for advertising with low-key, upbeat campaigns for Saturn cars, Bartles & Jaymes wine coolers and the re-election of President Ronald Reagan, died on Monday at his home in San Francisco. He was 75.

title: Mas Is Not Just Older, Its Better
description: TOO many restaurants start off like gangbusters, only to sag into a sour, cynical middle age while theyre still young. Once theyve made their first impression, they focus mainly on making money. In lumbering lock step, the Champagne flutes and the servers lose their sparkle.

title: Japan: Trade Surplus Rose in February
description: Japans trade surplus rose 0.9 percent in February from a year earlier, to 970 billion yen ($9.69 billion), in the first increase in four months, the Finance Ministry said. The trade surplus with the United States fell 13.3 percent, to 696.9 billion yen ($6.96 billion). The surplus with Asian nations including China jumped 104.8 percent, to 922.2 billion yen ($9.22 billion).

title: U.S. Team Needs International Mind-Set
description: What becomes apparent during the N.C.A.A. tournament is that there is an abundance of outstanding basketball talent in the United States, from California to North Carolina, Michigan to Texas.

title: Moment of Truth on Congestion Pricing
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority confessed this week that it is suspending a plan for $30 million in service improvements that were promised just a few weeks ago when subway and bus fares were raised. The loss of these upgrades  including extended evening service on some lines and more trains to reduce crowding  is disappointing. It is another reminder of why the State Legislature and the New York City Council need to approve congestion pricing. The system then could finally have a reliable source of income.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: A jazz entry in the Listings page on Friday, about the Randy Johnston quartet at the Kitano Hotel, misspelled the given name of the bass player and included an extraneous punctuation for the initial that follows it. He is Harvie S, not Harvey S.

title: Court Hears Arguments on Americans Held in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  After spending the last several years considering the rights of noncitizens held by the United States military, the Supreme Court on Tuesday turned its attention to the legal status of American citizens held by the military in Iraq for transfer to the Iraqis on criminal charges.

title: 5 Cooks, $40, 5 Dishes, 3 Desserts
description: SAY what you will about Eric Ripert, the man knows how to cook frozen fish.

title: California Delays Plan to Track Prescription Drugs
description: SAN DIEGO  In a reprieve for the pharmaceutical industry, California regulators agreed on Tuesday to delay by two years a requirement that all prescription drugs be electronically tracked as a means of thwarting counterfeiting.

title: Tasting the Future of Starbucks Coffee From a New Machine
description: HOWARD D. SCHULTZ, the chief executive of Starbucks, dropped a bombshell last week at the annual shareholders meeting when he announced that as part of an effort to concentrate on making better coffee, the corporation had bought the Coffee Equipment Company of Seattle, maker of the Clover coffee brewer.

title: For the Phinney Family, a Dream and a Challenge
description: BOULDER, Colo.  Like any proud father, Davis Phinney marvels at the man his son has become.

title: City Tightens Its Regulation and Inspection of Cranes
description: New York City ordered broad changes on Tuesday to the way it inspects and regulates tower cranes, in the wake of a crane collapse that killed seven people on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: Court Strikes Down State Law Protecting Fliers
description: A federal appellate court on Tuesday rejected New York States attempt to penalize airlines for not providing adequate services to passengers trapped on planes at airports for more than three hours.

title: Many Muslims Turn to Home Schooling
description: LODI, Calif.  Like dozens of other Pakistani-American girls here, Hajra Bibi stopped attending the local public school when she reached puberty, and began studying at home.

title: Louisiana Extols Culture in Recovery
description: Mitchell J. Landrieu (above, right), the lieutenant governor of Louisiana, has emphasized the importance of culture to his states recovery from Hurricane Katrina and Hurricane Rita. At a news conference on Monday at Jazz at Lincoln Center in New York, he said: Culture in fact means business. It is an end in and of itself. Mr. Landrieu said that the second World Cultural Economic Forum, a three-day conference on arts-related issues, would take place in Louisiana in October. The first forum was held in August 2007. In addition, the Louisiana Cultural Economy Foundation, established after the hurricanes, announced a $750,000 economic opportunity fund to help people in creative fields. Its first recovery fund of $1 million was distributed in 300 grants. Of the 144,000 culture-related jobs in the state, about 80 percent have returned since the hurricanes,  Scott Hutcheson, the foundations executive director, said in an interview. At the news conference the actress Patricia Clarkson, a New Orleans native (above, with the pianist Jonathan Baptiste), said, I think my state made me the actress I am today, adding that she was about to travel to Cairo to make a film and Im going to bring beignets.

title: Fred Thompson Seeks Make-Believe Roles
description: Fred Thompson, eliminated from the long-running reality show that is the campaign for United States presidency, is returning to the make-believe of acting, Reuters reported. Mr. Thompson, 65, a former United States senator from Tennessee and recently the fictional New York district attorney Arthur Branch on the television crime drama Law & Order, has signed an agreement to be represented as an actor by the William Morris Agency. Mr. Thompson has appeared in numerous television shows and films, including Die Hard 2 and In the Line of Fire. His quest for the Republican presidential nomination attracted little support and he abandoned the race in January.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article on Saturday about the increased number of women holding top managerial jobs in foundations misstated the position of Susan E. Manske, of the MacArthur Foundation. Ms. Manske is vice president and chief investment officer; she does not head the foundation. (Jonathan F. Fanton is its president and Robert E. Denham is chairman of the board.)

title: At Shuttered Gateway to Tibet, Unrest Simmers Against Chinese Rule
description: CHENGDU, China  In the back room of a Tibetan teahouse, three robed monks spoke in whispers.

title: Be It Ever So Illogical: Homeowners Who Wont Cut the Price
description: In 2005, Randolph Harrison and his wife, Pamela, decided to move north from Silicon Valley, over the Golden Gate Bridge into wooded Marin County to be closer to her new job. They found a six-bedroom house that seemed ideal except for the price, $1.875 million. The current owner, they knew, had bought the house a year earlier for $1.475 million.

title: To Look at Those Photos of the Young and the Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Seeks to Soften Impact of Misstatement
description: GREENSBURG, Pa.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton tried Tuesday to put a softening spin on her misstatement that she ran from sniper fire at an airport in Bosnia as first lady, saying the comment was a mistake that proves Im human.

title: NRG Energy Sets Up an Entity to Build Nuclear Plants
description: A second company planning to build nuclear plants has established a partnership with a reactor vendor to play a major role in building reactors around the United States.

title: Thailand Tries to Allay Tourists Fears After Killings
description: BANGKOK  The Thai police say they will start handing out whistles to foreign women who visit this country after the latest in a long series of periodic sexual assaults and killings.

title: Obamas Tax Returns Show Donation Spike
description: Senator Barack Obama and his wife, Michelle, sharply increased their charitable donations as Mr. Obama began to run for president and the familys income increased from book sales, according to tax returns that the couple released on Tuesday.

title: New Owner Hears His 1741 Violin Played
description: A $3.9 million Guarneri violin, made in 1741, was played in public for the first time in more than 70 years when Pinchas Zukerman, above, performed in Moscow on Saturday at a private concert before 160 guests of the instruments new owner,  Maxim Viktorov, a lawyer who bought it at a Sothebys auction last month, The Guardian of London reported. Mr. Viktorov, 35, a violin collector who likes to play to the piano accompaniment of his wife, Anastasia, said: I tried out the instrument a little in London before I bought it. But since then, I havent been able to touch it. The instrument cannot bear any agitation. I want the maestro, who lives by his art, to be the first to play it so the violin is receiving the respect it deserves. Then I might find the strength to play it myself because its a great source of energy.

title: Cyclist Linked to Steroids
description: A former chemist for the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative testified in a San Francisco courtroom that he had provided the former cyclist Tammy Thomas with designer steroids, directly contradicting her grand jury testimony.

title: Ex-Official Cleared to Continue Work on Big City Projects
description: The citys Conflicts of Interest Board cleared the way Tuesday for Daniel L. Doctoroff, who left City Hall for a private position two months ago, to remain involved in a range of city projects that were begun while he was deputy mayor for economic development.

title: Foreign Courts Wary of U.S. Punitive Damages
description: In the late summer of 1985, Kurt Parrott, a 15-year-old who loved baseball and Pac-Man, was thrown from his motorcycle in Opelika, Ala. The buckle of his helmet failed, and he died when his bare head hit the pavement. Mr. Parrotts mother sued the Italian company that made the helmet, and an Alabama court awarded her $1 million.

title: The Candidates as Cousins Much Removed
description: Next time youre considering whether to run for president, dont forget to weigh the value of the fast and free genealogical research that comes with candidacy, guaranteed to uncover your ancestral connection to a modern-day celebrity  or at least a minor historical figure.

title: Spearss Bit Part: Not a Comeback
description: Bad, sad or trying hard to behave, Britney Spears can still attract an audience. The question on Monday night was which audience. And its enlightening to see exactly where this falling pop star fits on televisions implacable scale of celebrity redemption.

title: Ivory for the Taking, From Beasts Well Beyond Caring
description: NOVY URENGOI, Russia  As Viktor Seliverstov works in his makeshift studio in this Siberian town, he is enveloped in a cloud of ivory dust. His electric carving tool whirs over the milky surface of the teeth and tusks, as he whittles them into key fobs, knife handles and scrimshaw figurines.

title: What You Get for ... $800,000
description: Englewood, Fla.

title: Partly Off the Grid, With a Mini-Utility in the Cellar
description: Astor Wines and Spirits went beyond the conventional notions of a wine shop two years ago when it relocated to the landmark Theodore De Vinne Press Building and added a cooking school and wine tasting area on the second floor.

title: Yahoo Is Joining an Alliance on Social Networks
description: Yahoo said Tuesday that it would join an alliance organized by Google, its principal rival, that will try to make it easier for programmers to write software that can run on the pages of many social networks and other Web sites.

title: At 15, Hes Bullied, Again and Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article on Friday about the near-autonomy that Army and Marine captains have in the Iraq war described the rank of captain incorrectly and misidentified the type of bonus that captains may receive if they continue beyond their initial commitment. Captains are officers who are commissioned, not enlisted, and therefore they receive retention bonuses, not re-enlistment bonuses.

title: Hillary or Nobody?
description: WASHINGTON

title: Justices Block New Hearing for Mexican
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that the Texas courts were not required to give a new hearing to a Mexican on the states death row, despite a directive from President Bush and the finding of the World Court that the defendants trial for murder violated United States treaty obligations.

title: Social Sites New Friends Are Athletes
description: Late last year, Pamela Firestone, the mother of Tony Parker, the San Antonio Spurs point guard, went rooting through her home in Paris and dug up a VHS tape of a 9-year-old Tony on a Parisian basketball court with his two brothers.

title: A Family Utility, Up on the Roof
description: WITH the price of oil at historical highs and concerns about energy security and global warming intensifying, many people are looking for ways to make a personal contribution to cutting oil imports and shrinking carbon emissions.

title: A Widow Roaming the Chechen Front, With Curiosity and History in Tow
description: Alexander Sokurovs Alexandra  a film of startling originality and beauty  feels like a communiqu from another time, another place, anywhere but here. Mr. Sokurov, a Russian director best known in America for Russian Ark (2002), makes films so far removed from the usual commercial blather that it sometimes seems as if hes working in a different medium. His work is serious, intense, at times opaque and so feverishly personal that it also feels as if youre being invited into his head, not just another reality.

title: Art Meets Feast, and Feast Steals the Show
description: IT was a sunny Easter Sunday on the Upper East Side, but the pig of honor did not look much like a traditional Easter ham.

title: Correction
description: The recipe with the Minimalist column last Wednesday, for bourbon apple cake, misstated the amount of butter that should be used in Step 2. It is one and a half sticks, not cups. (The reference to 12 tablespoons was correct.)

title: Outlook Remains Bleak for 2 Programs
description: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration issued a grim report on Tuesday on the financial outlook for Medicare and Social Security, but said the condition of the programs had not significantly deteriorated since last spring.

title: The Supporting Actor Wore Radials
description: THE stars are coming out in movies scheduled for release later this year: Angelina Jolie in Wanted, Harrison Ford in Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull, Christian Bale as Batman in The Dark Knight, the Dodge Caravan in Soccer Mom. ...

title: Two Bad Plays, and Another Tough Defeat
description: For three periods and into overtime Tuesday night against the Flyers at Madison Square Garden, Rangers forward Sean Avery tried gamely to fill the hole left by the injury to center Scott Gomez. Having played center in the past, Avery moved into that role again, doggedly pursuing his new job of winning face-offs and directing traffic for his line.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the Justice Departments approval of a merger of XM Satellite Radio and Sirius Radio referred incorrectly to a competing radio technology. It is called HD Radio, not high-definition radio. The HD is simply part of a brand name.

title: Croissants Made by Robots
description: The logo of Rheon Cafe proclaims Croissants since 1989. But it has been only about three months since the shop opened at 189 Spring Street (Thompson Street) in SoHo, offering its specialty: croissants. The earlier date was when Rheon, a Tokyo company, introduced its bakery items wholesale in the United States.

title: Saving the Planet? Not With My Money
description: GREEN is green has become a mantra of environmentalists and, increasingly, corporate chiefs. Between money saved by energy efficiency and money made from selling environmentally sound products, they say, going green is great for shareholders as well as the planet.

title: A Do-It-Yourself SAT Class, With No Whining, or Parents, Allowed
description: MIAMI SPRINGS, Fla.

title: Smashing Pumpkins Sue Virgin Records
description: The Smashing Pumpkins filed a breach of contract lawsuit against Virgin Records, accusing the company of using the bands name and music in promotional deals that injured its credibility with fans, The Associated Press reported. In Los Angeles County Superior Court on Monday, the members contended that Virgins use of the band in a promotion with Amazon.com and PepsiCo threatens their artistic integrity. The Pumpkins lawsuit argues that Virgin, which released the bands music for 17 years, had no contractual right to use it in campaigns to sell other products. The band asked to be compensated with Virgins profits from the promotion, and also requested an injunction to bar use of its name and music. Virgin did not immediately respond to a call for comment.

title: DNA Means New Suspect in Murder, Lawyer Says
description: Forensic evidence from the murder of Linda Stein, the broker to the stars, showed that male DNA was mixed with her blood in a bathroom sink in her apartment, according to a medical examiners report disclosed by a defense lawyer on Tuesday.

title: Advice on Taking an Entrepreneurial Leap
description: Terry Corbell, a management consultant, has some advice for all the readers who responded to an invitation I made last month to send him questions about running a business. Make a list of your weaknesses, he told those who asked how to get started. Because so many e-mail messages poured in, Mr. Corbell, the author of a column called The Biz Coach that appears on the Web sites of an all-news radio and television station in Seattle, chose to address in this column the ones that reflected three major entrepreneurial dilemmas: how to take the leap into the small business world, how to market your product and, for retail ventures, how to find the best location.

title: Lilly Settles Alaska Suit Over Zyprexa
description: Eli Lilly has agreed to pay $15 million to the state of Alaska to settle a lawsuit claiming that the companys schizophrenia drug Zyprexa caused patients to develop diabetes, Lilly and the state said Wednesday morning.

title: Russia: Dispute Over BP Workers
description: BPs regulatory troubles in Russia deepened this week as authorities idled 148 expatriate engineers and geologists in a dispute over the legality of their work permits. Last week, BPs joint venture in Russia, TNK-BP, was confronted with charges an employee engaged in industrial espionage and the announcement of an environmental inspection at its largest oil field. TNK-BP is in a dispute with Gazprom, the Russian state gas company, over the terms of sale of a large gas field in Siberia.

title: The Maverick and the Media
description: Amagansett, N.Y.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,989 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Afghans Lack $10 Billion in Aid, Report Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Western countries have failed to deliver $10 billion of nonmilitary assistance pledged to Afghanistan over the last six years and the United States, by far the biggest donor, is responsible for half of the shortfall, a new report published here on Tuesday said.

title: Building Dorm Rooms Cheaper, Quicker and Quieter
description: NEW HAVEN  Modular construction may have an image associated with prisons and barracks, but it is also increasingly being used in a more refined setting, to create quick and convenient dormitories and classrooms for colleges and universities.

title: Footnotes
description: George Michael, below, is planning his first tour of North America in 17 years, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Michael, 44, who sang with the 1980s pop group Wham! before starting a successful solo career, will begin his 22-date 25 Live tour in San Diego on June 17 and finish in Sunrise, Fla., on Aug. 3, after stops that include New York, Atlanta, Las Vegas, Los Angeles, Seattle and Chicago. ... Illness has forced the pianist Murray Perahia to withdraw from a concert with the Academy of St. Martin in the Fields at Avery Fisher Hall on April 8. An announcement said he would be replaced by Marc-Andr Hamelin in the program of Mozart and Haydn works conducted by Neville Marriner. ... Woody Allen and his New Orleans Jazz Band will make their first appearance at the Montreal International Jazz festival on June 30.

title: For Sox Fans, a Welcome Wake-Up Call
description: BOSTON  It had the trappings of a classic home game: the Fenway Park lights ablaze, the sidewalks jammed, the parking  make that pahking  impossible.

title: Killings in 2 Brooklyn Neighborhoods
description: Two men were killed in Brooklyn in separate encounters, the police said on Tuesday.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a letter on Tuesday from Dorian de Wind of Austin, Tex., about Iraq misidentified the military branch in which he served. He is a retired Air Force major, not Army.

title: Iraqi Crackdown on Shiite Forces Sets Off Fighting
description: BAGHDAD  Heavy fighting broke out Tuesday in two of Iraqs largest cities, as Iraqi ground forces and helicopters mounted a huge operation to break the grip of the Shiite militias controlling Basra, and Iraqi forces clashed with militias in Baghdad. The fighting threatened to destabilize a long-term truce that had helped reduce the level of violence in the five-year-old Iraq war.

title: Crane Collapses in Miami, Killing 2
description: MIAMI  Two construction workers died and at least five were injured Tuesday when a 20-foot section of crane fell 30 stories onto a Miami home made famous by the film Theres Something About Mary.

title: Its Time to Level the Playing Field
description: This 30-second television advertisement for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, began running in Pennsylvania on Tuesday. It is titled Level.

title: Missile Parts Sent to Taiwan in Error
description: WASHINGTON  Instead of sending helicopter batteries, the United States shipped four electrical fuses for Minuteman nuclear missile warheads to Taiwan, a mistake that was discovered only last week  a year and a half after the erroneous shipment, Pentagon officials disclosed on Tuesday.

title: Devils Demonstrate That You Cant Win Without Scoring
description: NEWARK  Devils Coach Brent Sutter climbed atop his bench, grabbed a stick and slapped it against the boards, attempting to summon a referee for an explanation. A goal had been taken from the Devils.

title: A Mortar and Pestle for Pounding, and Savoring
description: What sets this heavy-duty mortar and pestle apart is not its spice-colored trim, but the breadth of the pestle, with a flattened head, the better to pound mustard seeds and peppercorns without them flying around the kitchen. It was designed by Suvir Saran, a chef and an owner of Devi, and made in England for a line of products called the American Masala Collection. They are dishwasher-safe but frankly, I wouldnt go that route; a little spice residue buildup never hurts. The mortar and pestle sets are $50 at (866) 362-4422 or www.thekitchenstoreonline.com. It is also sold at A Cooks Companion in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Tokyo Temple Bought $14.3 Million Buddha
description: A Buddhist temple in suburban Tokyo revealed itself on Tuesday as the buyer that paid $14.3 million for an 800-year-old cypress wood sculpture of Buddha at a Christies auction in New York last week, Agence France-Presse reported. The Shinnyo-en temple said it bought the sculpture of the Dainichi Nyorai, or supreme Buddha, above, with donations from the faithful because it did not want the icon to fall into foreign hands. The sale set a record for a piece of Japanese art and exceeded the sculptures presale estimates of $1.5 million to $2.5 million.

title: Heparin Is Recalled in 3 Countries
description: Health officials in Denmark, France and Italy began recalling stores of the blood-thinning drug heparin and any ingredients used in it that had originated in China, as a precautionary measure. In the United States, certain batches of the drug have been linked to 19 deaths and hundreds of allergic reactions. The lots were manufactured by Baxter International and used ingredients from China; investigators discovered that the faulty batches contained a contaminant. Baxter has recalled virtually all its heparin products. In Germany, heparin made by Rotexmedica from Chinese raw materials is believed to be the cause of more than 80 cases of allergic reactions. There have been no reactions reported in Denmark, France or Italy, according to the European Medicines Agency.

title: Off the Menu
description: OPENING NEXT WEEK

title: U.S. Sent Missile Parts to Taiwan in Error
description: WASHINGTON  Four high-tech electrical fuses for Minuteman nuclear warheads were sent to Taiwan in place of helicopter batteries, a mistake discovered only last week  a year and a half after the erroneous shipment, Pentagon officials disclosed Tuesday.

title: Michigan: Not Guilty Pleas at Mayors Arraignment
description: Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick of Detroit must notify court officials when he travels outside the state, a magistrate said as Mr. Kilpatrick was arraigned on eight felony charges, including perjury and official misconduct. Steve Lockhart, the chief magistrate for Michigans 36th District Court, entered not guilty pleas on behalf of Mr. Kilpatrick and Christine Beatty, Mr. Kilpatricks former chief of staff, who is charged with seven felonies. Prosecutors say Mr. Kilpatrick, who is married, settled a lawsuit for $8.4 million in taxpayers money to prevent the public from learning that he had lied under oath about an affair he had with Ms. Beatty. Mr. Kilpatrick, below, who was released on a $75,000 personal bond, has said he will be exonerated.

title: Britney Spears Lifts CBS
description: A guest appearance from Britney Spears helped CBSs How I Met Your Mother attract its largest audience of the season on Monday, as 10.6 million viewers tuned in to the sitcom at 8:30 p.m., Nielsen reported. The series, in its third season, also earned its highest ratings on record among adults 18 to 49, lifting CBS into first place on the night in that demographic. Although ABC drew more total viewers, thanks to Dancing With the Stars from 8 to 10 (20.3 million), CBSs Two and a Half Men at 9 (14.3 million) eked out a victory as the top-rated show with the 18-to-49 set. CBS also led during the 10 p.m. hour with CSI: Miami (15.8 million), which easily outpaced both NBCs Medium (8.8 million) and ABCs Bachelor (8 million). ABC ranked second for the night in the 18-to-49 age bracket, followed by NBC and Fox in a tie for third. NBC garnered solid ratings at 9 for Deal or No Deal (10 million) but lagged behind at 8 with My Dad Is Better Than Your Dad (4.3 million). Fox broadcast a House repeat at 8 (7.6 million) and New Amsterdam at 9 (6.3 million).

title: Volunteering Abroad to Climb at I.B.M.
description: In July, a team of 8 to 10 I.B.M. employees will travel to Ghana to help tiny businesses make their operations more professional. Another team will help entrepreneurs seek microloans in Turkey, while yet another will create training programs on information technology in Vietnam.

title: A Secret Staple Begging to Be Used
description: THEY might sit there, unnoticed and undisturbed, in your fridge or cabinet, for weeks or months or even longer. But theyre waiting  or at least they should be  until your stir-fries need a jolt of distinctive, impossible-to-mistake flavor that nothing else can give you.

title: Europe Starts Inquiry of Visas Fees
description: BRUSSELS  European regulators on Wednesday opened an investigation of Visa Europe to determine whether the fees it charges on cross-border transactions within the European Union break laws against price fixing.

title: Stars Dust May Hold Clue to New Planet
description: Is this a planet in the making?

title: Affordable Wines From Near and Far
description: The team behind In Vino, an East Village wine bar, has expanded its franchise with Alphabet City Wine, a k a ABC Wine, 100 Avenue C (Seventh Street). David Hitchner, below, the managing partner of the shop, with Angus McDougal and Keith Beavers, have stocked the shelves with reasonably priced selections from far and wide, including Austria and South Africa.

title: Richard Widmark, Actor, Dies at 93
description: Richard Widmark, who created a villain in his first movie role who was so repellent and frightening that the actor became a star overnight, died Monday at his home in Roxbury, Conn. He was 93.

title: Two Senate Panels to Investigate Bear Stearns Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Leaders of two Senate committees said Wednesday that they would investigate the taxpayer-backed takeover of the foundering Bear Stearns investment firm  an arrangement that Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. defended even as he called for more transparency on the part of Wall Street.

title: Big Ideas in Deceptively Small Packages
description: For nearly four decades New Directors/New Films has been the straightforward, serviceable name of a generous program presented every spring by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art. Im not suggesting that they change or rebrand it, but after watching the first half of this years lineup, movies of modest means and evident ambition, I prefer to think of the festival as Serious Directors/Small Films.

title: Findings Point to Suicide in Norwalk Officers Death
description: NORWALK, Conn.  Four days after a Norwalk police officer on patrol was found fatally shot in a church parking lot, officials said Tuesday that he had probably committed suicide, and that an AK-47 rifle was found at the scene along with his service pistol.

title: Safeguarding Private Medical Data
description: Almost 2,500 patients taking part in a federal medical trial recently had their private health data compromised when a researchers laptop computer was stolen. The National Institutes of Health, which was responsible for safeguarding the data, made things worse by delaying in notifying the patients. This disturbing incident underscores the need for a strong federal law to protect medical privacy and for greater responsibility by those who handle sensitive medical information.

title: Season Opens as Surely as Day Follows Night
description: TOKYO  If Britney Spears played baseball, you would have some idea of what the past few days were like for Daisuke Matsuzaka on his first appearance back in Japan in a Boston Red Sox uniform.

title: The Buzz on the Bus: Pinched, Press Steps Off
description: As Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama debated in Cleveland on a snowy evening in late February, 650 journalists descended on the city to follow every jab and parry, albeit on enormous televisions in two makeshift filing centers.

title: Half-Brothers Mired in Full-Blown Hate
description: Jeff Nicholss Shotgun Stories, a drama about warring clans of brothers in small-town southern Arkansas, defines the classic western phrase doing what a mans got to do as both a moral imperative and a biological compulsion. The movie is filled with unremarkable men who would rather die than appear weak.

title: Republicans Back Some Claims by Clemens
description: Republicans on the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform issued a 109-page report Tuesday that appeared to support some of Roger Clemenss testimony at a hearing last month.

title: Italys Trash Crisis Taints Reputation of a Prized Cheese
description: ROME  Italians often minimize what afflicts them with this philosophy: Without the bad, no one would appreciate the good.

title: Amid Warnings, Europes Economy Is Holding Up
description: PARIS  The European economy is fairing better than many analysts had expected, data released on Wednesday suggested, but officials warned that a slowdown in growth was probably inevitable, given the tight credit market and the slowdown in the United States.

title: Irish Famine Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Mukasey Goes to Court to Argue a Terrorism Case
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey overcame his self-confessed stage fright and told the Supreme Court on Tuesday that it should reinstate an explosives conviction against an Algerian terrorist who had planned to bomb Los Angeles International Airport in 1999.

title: Colorado Upholds Ban on Stage Smoking
description: A Colorado appeals court has ruled that stage performances are not exempt from the states two-year-old ban on indoor smoking, including the smoking of herbal cigarettes, which is permitted onstage in New York and many other places, The Denver Post reported. In a unanimous ruling, the three-judge panel said: The smoking ban was not intended to prevent actors from expressing emotion, setting a mood, illustrating a character trait, emphasizing a plot twist or making a political statement. But it added, Smoking, by itself, is not sufficiently expressive to qualify for First Amendment protection. Chip Walton, founder of the Curious Theater Company, one of three plaintiffs in the case, said an appeal to the Colorado Supreme Court was likely.

title: Cross-Strait Opening
description: Taiwans voters have given themselves and China a chance for a healthy, new start. Last week, they elected a president who promised to strengthen relations with the mainland  while ensuring the autonomy of Taiwans vibrant democracy. That should be a relief for both sides of the straits.

title: Mussina, Not Pettitte, Will Start in 2nd Game
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Yankees announced Tuesday that Mike Mussina would start the second game of the season, April 2 against Toronto, instead of Andy Pettitte.

title: Pay for the Power, Not the Panels
description: INNOVATION is driving a boom in solar power, but some of the most compelling advances are taking place in financial engineering rather than photovoltaic technology.

title: U.S. Women Go on Attack for Top Ranking
description: The United States womens national team is back on top of the world, No. 1 in the latest FIFA rankings, after winning the Algarve Cup earlier this month in Portugal.

title: New Pakistani Leaders Tell Americans Theres a New Sheriff in Town
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The top State Department officials responsible for the alliance with Pakistan met leaders of the new government on Tuesday, and received what amounted to a public dressing-down from one of them, as well as the first direct indication that the United States relationship with Pakistan would have to change.

title: Woman Accused of Running Prostitution Ring on East Side
description: A woman was arrested Tuesday afternoon and accused of running a large prostitution ring on the East Side, the police said.

title: Rethinking Is Urged on a Vaccine for AIDS
description: WASHINGTON  Researchers must go back to the drawing board before they can develop an effective vaccine against H.I.V., AIDS experts said at a scientific meeting on Tuesday.

title: Behind in the Ratings, CBS News Hopes for Help From a Debate
description: It is an axiom of political debates that lagging competitors always want them more than front-runners. CBS News, which lags well behind its competitors in most areas of television news, wants a debate between Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton in the worst way.

title: The Campaign Monitor Goes Missing
description: Moneywise, this is an eerily liberating time to be running for president or Congress. Donations are being harvested and spent at a record rate, while the Federal Election Commission  the campaigns designated referee  has been reduced to a nonentity.

title: Working for Dollars and Feeling the Decline
description: HONG KONG  Anthony del Rosario, who crews an oil tanker plying the route between the Middle East and South Korea, is sending home less money to his family in the Philippines. Takeshi Okada, a shoe maker in Japan, is concerned about the possibility of declining export sales.

title: A Turn to Alternative Chemicals
description: JOEL TICKNER is trying to build a greener future one molecule at a time. Dr. Tickner directs the chemicals science and policy program at the Lowell Center for Sustainable Production at the University of Massachusetts, Lowell. The center researches and promotes environmentally sound chemicals policy and production.

title: Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Bonds of Friendship, Frayed by Envy
description: Forget three. Two is crowd enough in The Four of Us, a comic drama by Itamar Moses about a pair of aspiring writers and their egos, one tender and one Teflon. A clever if modest study of the strains that success can put on a sturdy friendship, the play is less flashy but far more appealing than Mr. Moses notable previous drama about the anxieties and rewards of the artistic life, Bach at Leipzig.

title: Dow Falls After 2 Downbeat Reports
description: Stocks dropped on Wednesday after a pair of pessimistic reports on home sales and business spending reminded investors about the precarious state of the economy.

title: U.S. Judge Upholds Water Release in Flood Area
description: ST. LOUIS  Despite the floods that ravaged parts of Missouri last week, a federal judge on Tuesday denied the state attorney generals request to block the release of hundreds of thousands of gallons of water from a dam into the Missouri River.

title: Paterson Family Is Moving Into the Executive Mansion
description: Gov. David A. Paterson will reside in the Executive Mansion when in Albany, a spokeswoman said on Tuesday.

title: Oil and Gold Prices Rise
description: Gold prices rallied for a second session Wednesday after the dollar sank and crude oil prices spiked  inflationary signs that pointed investors to the relative safety of precious metals.

title: Hope and Fear for Zimbabwe Vote
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe  When 100 young men stormed onto his property last week, Knox Solomon Danda, an opposition candidate for Parliament in rural Zvimba, hid under a table with his wife and children, he said, pulling the tablecloth low to the floor to better conceal their cowering shapes. His 5-year-old daughter began to whimper. He held her close to muffle the sound.

title: Two Workers Are Killed in Miami Crane Accident
description: MIAMI  Two construction workers died and five were injured Tuesday when a seven-ton section of crane fell 30 stories onto a Miami home made famous by the film Theres Something About Mary.

title: Efficient Connecticut Runs Winning Streak to 13
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  In a span of 2 minutes 30 seconds early in the first half Tuesday night, Maya Moore, Connecticuts heralded freshman, took four 3-point shots and made them all. With that impetus and with its speed, superior rebounding and 60 percent shooting from the floor (39 of 65), Connecticut routed Texas, 89-55, in the second round of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Old Ally of Gotti Is Said to Turn Informer in Case Against the Gambinos
description: In his long friendship with John J. Gotti, the Gambino family boss, Lewis Kasman played a narrow though important set of roles.

title: U.S. Has Moral Responsibility in Iraq, McCain Says
description: Senator John McCain made his case for continuing the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, saying on Wednesday that those countries are at the core of a region extending from the Middle East to Southeast Asia.

title: Worlds at War
description: Preface

title: Can Sips at Home Prevent Binges?
description: PARENTS always want to share their passions with their children. Whether youre a fan of baseball or the blues, sailing or tinkering with old cars, few things are as rewarding as seeing a spark of receptivity in the eyes of the next generation.

title: Moderates Hold Key in Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  One of the most significant results of Pakistans elections in February was the defeat of the religious parties that ran this critical border province for the last five years. In their place, voters elected moderates from a small regional party that may now wield big influence over Pakistans changing strategy toward its militants.

title: For Carbon Emissions, a Goal of Less Than Zero
description: IF the world is going to sharply reduce the amount of carbon dioxide pumped into the atmosphere by midcentury, then many businesses will have to go carbon neutral, bringing their net emissions of the greenhouse gas to zero.

title: A Thicker, Sweeter, Spicier Ketchup, Just Right for Slathering
description: Good old-fashioned Heinz ketchup is the devil I know  and love  despite the high-fructose corn syrup in the recipe. Most fancy-pants ketchups do not quite measure up in terms of tangy-sweetness.

title: Room on the Bus
description: Many daily newspapers have chosen not to dispatch reporters to cover the leading Democratic candidates on a regular basis.

title: Heinrich Zille
description: Images from exhibitions in Berlin about the work of the artist Heinrich Zille.

title: $800,000 Homes
description: Properties on the market in Florida, California and Texas.

title: What This Country Really Needs is a Cosigner
description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

title: Wing On, Hong Kongs Great Department Store
description: The first summer that I ever spent in Hong Kong, I lived in a pricey serviced apartment that charged $100 extra a month for linen service. I figured I could buy my own linen for less than the cost of the rental, so I set out one day in search of inexpensive bedsheets, towels and comforters. But where to go?

title: The Boys of Spring
description: Baseball has begun  in Tokyo, as the game expands worldwide  but the teams other than the Red Sox and As are still in Florida and Arizona, and for a few more days theyre all contenders. Thats part of whats so great about spring training: anything is possible; every team starts from the same point, zero wins and zero losses. Players from all over the world descend upon sunny climes, just as hopeful as their fans.

title: Earnings Rise at Two Chinese Banks
description: The Bank of China and the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China posted higher fourth-quarter profits Tuesday, buoyed by the countrys surging economy but dragged down by holdings in American subprime-related securities.

title: South Korea Puts Daewoo Shipbuilding Stake on the Block
description: South Korea said on Wednesday it has started the sale of Daewoo Shipbuilding and Marine Engineering, the worlds No. 3 shipbuilder, by putting up a 50.4 percent stake worth $3.6 billion at current market prices.

title: Asias Value Partners Posts 66% Surge in 2007 Profits
description: Value Partners Group, Asias second-largest hedge fund manager, said 2007 profit surged 66 percent on growing assets.

title: Investors Sue Morgan and Merrill Over Auction Rate Securities
description: Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley were sued on Tuesday by clients accusing them of deceptively marketing auction rate securities.

title: AES and Riverstone Team Up for $1 Billion Solar Venture
description: AES, a worldwide power-plant developer, announced Tuesday that it will partner with private-equity firm Riverstone Holdings to invest up to $1 billion in solar energy projects around the world.

title: Bio-Imaging Technologies in $24 Million Deal
description: Bio-Imaging Technologies said it bought Phoenix Data Systems, a privately held provider of clinical data services, for $24 million in cash and stock.

title: Caterpiller Moves to Take Control of Japan Venture
description: Caterpillar, the worlds largest maker of earthmoving machinery, will take control of a 44-year-old Japanese venture with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries to help expand in Asia.

title: Malayan Bank to Pay $1.5 Billion for Stake in Indonesian Rival
description: Malaysias biggest lender, Malayan Banking, is set to buy a controlling stake in Bank Internasional Indonesia, or BII, for $1.5 billion, gaining a foothold in Southeast Asias biggest economy.

title: Pequot to Launch New Opportunistic Fund, Report Says
description: Pequot Capital Management is in launch mode as the $6.5 billion hedge fund firm prepares to debut its second hedge fund of the year. The Connecticut multi-strategy shop is launching the Pequot New Vision Fund on April 1 with $18.1 million in assets, according to FINalternatives.

title: Social Sites New Friends Are Athletes
description: In most families artifacts such as childhood videos are merely heirlooms, their value measured in memories. For the Hollywood talent agency Creative Artists Agency and the hedge fund Pequot Capital, however, these are assets to be exploited.

title: Jumbo Lenders Shares Rise 36% on Private Placement
description: Shares of Thornburg Mortgage, a provider of jumbo mortgages that is trying to stave off a bankruptcy filing, rose 36 percent on Tuesday after the company disclosed plans to raise $1.35 billion.

title: JPMorgan to Acquire ClimateCare
description: JPMorgan Chase agreed the acquisition of carbon offset provider ClimateCare for an undisclosed sum, the two businesses said in a joint statement.

title: Londons Liffe to Launch Clearinghouse
description: Liffe, the London-based futures and options exchange, has turned up the heat on rivals including Rainbow, the planned European derivatives exchange backed by investment banks and brokers, by confirming it plans to launch a clearinghouse, a move that will hit its existing supplier LCH.Clearnet.

title: McCain Warns Against Hasty Mortgage Bailout
description: Drawing a sharp distinction between himself and the two Democratic presidential candidates, Senator John McCain of Arizona warned Tuesday against vigorous government action to solve the deepening mortgage crisis and the market turmoil it has caused, saying that it is not the duty of government to bail out and reward those who act irresponsibly, whether they are big banks or small borrowers.

title: Banks Balk at Paying for Clear Channel Deal
description: The $19.5 billion sale of the radio broadcaster Clear Channel Communications to two private equity firms is in jeopardy.

title: In a Day of Downgrades, Merrill Takes a Hit
description: The embattled financial sector took another hit on Tuesday as JPMorgan Chase and UBS cut their earnings forecasts for Merrill Lynch and said they expect the Wall Street firm to disclose more write-downs.

title: The Fortress Playbook: Go Shopping
description: Fortress Investment Group, the alternative asset manager that Tuesday reported a $29 million loss for the fourth quarter, aims to raise $15 to $20 billion in new capital this year to help the hedge fund and private-equity firm pounce on opportunities created by the global credit crunch, Chief Executive Wes Edens said on Tuesday.

title: Vale Abdandons Xstrata Talks
description: Brazils Vale, the worlds largest iron ore miner, said that talks to buy Swiss rival Xstrata had failed and that Vale would look at other potential takeover targets.

title: L.S.E.s Depressed Share Price Renews Takeover Rumors
description: The London Stock Exchanges share price has hit nearly a four-year low, sparking fresh takeover rumors for the exchange that has been coveted by everyone from the Deutsche Borse to the Nasdaq Stock Market, Financial News reported.

title: Willis Stein Said to Target $1 Billion Fund
description: In a move that has apparently left peHUBs Dan Primack confused, Chicago-based private equity firm Willis Stein & Partners is pre-marketing its fourth fund, just weeks after its largest-ever investment, Ziff Davis, filed for bankruptcy protection.

title: Bear Stearns Memorabilia Sells Like Hot Cakes
description: A used T-shirt bearing the Bear Stearns logo has sold for $151.76 online, worth about 14 or 15 shares in the once venerable Wall Street investment bank, Reuters reported.

title: Honk if You Like Ostentatious Do-Gooderism
Soot in the Greenhouse, and Kitchen
description: [UPDATE, 4/16: Libby Rosenthal has gone into the field to explore soot in the kitchen and greenhouse.]

title: Whitney Sharply Cuts Citi Earnings Estimates
description: One of Citigroups most persistent critics hasnt changed her negative view on the stumbling financial giant.

title: Deutsche Bank May Miss 2008 Profit Goal
description: Deutsche Banks shares fell Wednesday in Europe after the German banking group warned that a business slowdown and possible write-downs could make it hard to achieve its profit goal for the year. The shaky outlook suggested that Deutsche Bank, which managed to avoid taking any write-downs related to subprime mortgages in the fourth quarter, is not out of the woods yet.

title: Motorola to Split Itself in Two
description: Motorola said Wednesday that it would split itself into two publicly traded companies as it struggles to boost its stock price and faces pressure from activist investor Carl C. Icahn.

title: A Doctors View of Medical Mistakes
description: Two decades ago, an anesthesia catastrophe at a Wisconsin hospital killed a pregnant woman named Joy.

title: Tata to Buy Jaguar, Land Rover for $2.3 Billion
description: Indias Tata Motors says it will acquire British automakers Jaguar and Land Rover from the Ford Motor Company for $2.3 billion, sealing a long-expected deal for the luxury car lines.

title: Dining on a Dime
description: Eric Ripert, a four-star seafood chef, takes on a 99-cent frozen salmon fillet.

title: The Early Word: Obama Back on the Road
description: Back from vacation in the Virgin Islands, Senator Barack Obama hits the road right away  today in North Carolina  and just as quickly he has several issues confronting him. In a brief chat with reporters before leaving the islands, he said the economy would be uppermost on his mind. And his new schedule boasts a major speech on the economy set for Thursday in New York.

title: How Doctoroff Will Keep Working on City Projects
description: The citys Conflicts of Interest Board cleared the way for Daniel L. Doctoroff, who left City Hall for a private position two months ago, to remain involved in a range of city projects that were begun while he was deputy mayor for economic development, as Patrick McGeehan and Ray Rivera report.

title: Geometries | Highbridge Park Water Tower
description: Peering up the winding iron staircase in the water tower at Highbridge Park in Washington Heights. The tower was built in 1872 as part of the Croton Aqueduct system, which started bringing a dependable supply of fresh water into New York City in 1842 and remained in use as a pumping station until 1949.

title: Schwarzenegger to Eastwood: Hasta La Vista, Baby
description: An action movie hero turned governor fires a Hollywood icon turned parks commissioner over a project that pits his constituents hopelessly irreconcilable passions for cars and beaches against one another. And as an added bonus, the news arrives with a perfect sound bite. Thats California politics, sweetheart:

title: Gravel to Run for Libertarian Nod
description: Fed up with being excluded from the debates and otherwise marginalized, former Senator Mike Gravel of Alaska announced today that he will seek the Libertarian Party nomination for president.

title: Now Screening | Mark Webber in T Takes Episode 8
Poll: Ellen Named Top TV Host
description: Reuters reports:

title: Intermission
description: See, this is what happens when you dont have a primary for a few weeks: the traveling press is getting bored. [W]ere in the phase of the campaign I dont find especially interesting, The New Republics Noam Scheiber writes at The Stump, his magazines campaign blog. He continues:

title: Wednesdays Links: One Day More of Waiting
description: While Michael Beasley toils over whether to become filthy rich now or next year, feel lucky that you dont have such difficult decisions hanging over your head.

title: Red, White, Blue  and Black?
description: The United States mens national team will be outfitted with new black away jerseys (and shorts and socks) for its friendly match in Poland on Wednesday. And you have to wonder: Whats going on here?

title: Fords Money-Losing Rides
description: Lots of us have bought a car that turned out to be a lemon and then been forced to sell it at a loss. For Ford Motor Company, though, the loss had nine zeroes after it.

title: Anti-American Idol
description: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Im a little upset. You know, Hillary Clinton was supposed to be our first guest tonight, but she got pinned down by sniper fire and was not able to come in.

title: More Countries Than Any Other Year
description: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: The White House has announced that during President Bushs last year in office, hes going to visit more countries than in any other year of his Presidency. Bush says hes going to accomplish all of this in one weekend by going to Epcot Center.

title: National Darwinism
description: Sometimes extreme books can be more clarifying than careful ones. A few years ago Michael Scheuer had a surprise best-seller with a fierce, angry polemic about United States foreign policy, Imperial Hubris, which he published anonymously because he was a high-level C.I.A. agent at the time. Now, as a professor at Georgetown, he writes under his own name, and he seems just as angry, maybe more so.

title: Citi Strikes $1.66 Billion Settlement With Enron Creditors
description: Citigroup has agreed to pay Enron creditors $1.66 billion as the final part of a settlement of a lawsuit over banks responsibility in the energy trading firms downfall, a group representing creditors said on Wednesday.

title: Martinez and Schneider, Old Friends
description: Pedro Martinez was showing off a photograph this morning of him and a boy, maybe 13 at the time, that was taken 15 or 16 years ago. Pedro was skinnier then, about 155 pounds, and he wore a blue satin Dodgers jacket and a Dodgers cap. The boy wore a gold Florida State hat and a Northampton baseball T-shirt.

title: The Forecast Today in Haiti
description: .. And pretty much the forecast every day in Haiti:

title: U.K. Regulator Admits Fault in Northern Rock Collapse
description: Britains financial services regulator admitted Wednesday that it had done a poor job of supervising Northern Rock, the mortgage lender which became Britains most prominent victim of the subprime mortgage crisis.

title: Iraqi Forces Battle Shiite Militias
description: The fighting threatened to destabilize a long-term truce that had helped reduce violence in the five-year-old Iraq war.

title: Answers About Health in New York, Part 2
description: Following is a second set of answers from James R. Knickman, the president and chief executive of the New York State Health Foundation, who is taking questions from readers through March 29 on a range of issues from universal health care and Medicaid to the prevalence in New York of problems like obesity, diabetes, smoking and substance abuse. Readers are invited to submit additional questions using the comment form below.

title: A New Master for Jaguar
description: On Wednesday, the Ford Motor Company agreed to sell its Jaguar and Land Rover brands to Tata Motors in India. Tata will pay Ford $2.3 billion  or $200 million less than what Ford paid for Jaguar alone in 1989  while Ford will contribute $600 million for the Jaguar-Land Rover pension fund.

title: I Cant Find the Brownie Mix!
description: Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Heres news from Hollywood. You know Pamela Anderson? Well, she recently had her marriage annulled. The marriage lasted two months. I mean, she goes through husbands like New York goes through governors.

title: Poll: Democrats Might Vote McCain if Their Candidate Isnt the Nominee
description: The increasingly ferocious standoff between Senators Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama could take a toll in November, says a new survey from Gallup:

title: At This Stage in the Games
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: For Rich or Poor TV Buyers, Its Price First
description: It wasnt that long ago10 years at mostthat consumers would blanch at spending $800 for a large-screen traditional picture tube TV. But today, with CRT TVs nearing extinction (even Costco doesnt stock them any longer), many customers seem perfectly happy with plunking down even $2,000 for a wide-screen HDTV.

title: Honduras Fights U.S. Ban on Its Cantaloupes
description: Adding his own twist to the Latin American strongman railing against American policies, President Manuel Zelaya of Honduras began talking to journalists on Tuesday. Here I have the box of melons, he said, according to CNN. Permit me to make a demonstration.

title: Recipe of the Day: Stir-Fried Chicken Wings With Black Bean Sauce
description: Todays Minimalist column (and dont forget the video) is about fermented black beans, which, needless to say, I messed around with quite a bit in the course of putting together that piece. I love them with clams; to make them, just follow the shrimp recipe, cooking the clams  hard shells only, please  until they pop, at which point theyll release a bunch of liquid. Theyre also great with cut-up pork, cubes of tofu, especially pre-cooked, scallops, and so on.

title: The High Low | Tim Hamilton for Uniqlo Shirt, $39.50
description: In The High Low column, Ts fashion team roll up their Balenciaga sleeves to rummage for the cheap and the chic.

title: The Jam | Burberry Prorsum
description: The Jam column presents fashions latest soundtracks.

title: The Caveman Tapes
description: Al Qaedas latest tape has just dropped, so whats the verdict of the hipster music site Pitchfork? From 236.com:

title: John McCains Foreign Policy Speech
description: The following is the text as prepared for delivery of Senator John McCains speech on foreign policy to the Los Angeles World Affairs Council, as provided by his presidential campaign.

title: Paulson on Wall Street Regulation
description: CNBC coverage of Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson's speech in which he discusses the possibility of new federal oversight for Wall Street investment houses.

title: The Coming Food Crisis
description: Every indicator you can think of is pointing to a real crisis in food in the coming years, as you can see from this lovely series of charts from the BBC (hat tip to Suzanne Lenzer). Food prices are up; ethanol production is up, which will put further pressure on grain prices; population growth continues apace, as has been well publicized.

title: Scientists Detect Nice NYT Readers
description: Dear Readers, you may post nasty comments at times, but deep down youre wonderfully benevolent, joyful souls  well, at least many of you who responded to last weeks invitation to fill out a survey.

title: Let the Litigation Begin
description: Detroit struck first.

title: N.F.L. Teams Show They Like Glenn Dorsey by Questioning His Health
description: Louisiana State defensive tackle Glenn Dorsey is working out in front of more than 100 N.F.L. coaches and scouts today at the schools pro day. But nothing he does in the 40-yard dash, vertical jump or bench press will eliminate the nagging questions about whether he can stay healthy through a professional season.

title: American Cancels 200 Flights
description: CNBC reports on American Airlines's cancellation of more than 200 flights in order to check plane wiring.

title: The I.R.S. Meets YouTube
description: YouTube opens its tent to all kinds of folks  from offbeat, off key and off kilter to the Old Gray Lady herself. So why not the I.R.S.? A USA Today article today on the tax agencys online video efforts quotes one of them  the YouTube generation  drawing the line:

title: Where the Air Marshals Are, or Arent
description: Is there a shortage of air marshals, or is that a myth? It depends on whom you believe.

title: M.T.A. Votes to Sell West Side Land Rights to Tishman Speyer
description: The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority gave tentative approval shortly before noon today to sell a 99-year lease to develop 26 acres of vacant land overlooking the Hudson River to Tishman Speyer Properties for just over $1 billion.

title: Coming Not-So-Soon: New Dramas on USA
description: In anticipation of its upfront presentation on Wednesday, USA has revealed four of the projects on its development slate. But viewers will not see any of the shows for years, if ever.

title: McCains Foreign Policy Speech
description: In a speech setting out his worldview, Senator John McCain reiterated his opposition to withdrawing troops from Iraq at this time, and drew a stark line between his presidential candidacy and the Democrats ideas.

title: Is That a Light Saber on Your Bus Shelter, Or
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: The Whistle-Blower Was Sinbad
description: Aired Tuesday night on The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson on CBS: Hillary Clinton has been caught telling a lie about a trip she took to Bosnia, and the whistle-blower was Sinbad, the comedian. Nothing says great journalism like the co-star of Jingle All The Way.

title: A Day of Internationals Big and Small
description: Its a full day of internationals Wednesday  friendlies and not-so-friendlies. In the latter category, North Korea and South Korea were forced to play their World Cup qualifying match at a neutral venue after FIFA ruled Pyongyang too inhospitable for sport. The Democratic Peoples Republic of Korea refused to play the Republic of Koreas national anthem or allow the South Korean flag to be flown on their turf. So, the teams played in Shanghai where they drew 0-0.

title: Beyond Roe v. Wade
description: Would Hillary Clinton gain politically by distancing herself from pro-choice activists? Clinton does have one group of political activists to whom she is especially indebted, writes Michael Sean Winters at In All Things, the editorial blog of America, the national Jesuit weekly. Pro-choice groups like NARAL, NOW and Emilys List have been the base of her fundraising and organizational support. They have sent e-mails and placed phone calls to voters in key primary states questioning Obamas commitment to Roe v. Wade.

title: Between Us and the Subway Lampposts
description: The IRT and the BMT still live. So does the IND.

title: All is Vanity
description: Unlike James and Joyce (nice phrase, that), I have little experience of New York itself. I left Harlem when I was six, and have rarely spent two days in the city since. I cannot join the debate on whether The Bonfire of the Vanities was  or is  in some sense the quintessential New York novel. So I will, with apologies, slip off on a tangent.

title: Weekly Ratings: Dancing Joins Singing Atop Nielsen List
description: The Associated Press reports:

title: NBCs Cable Farm Team
description: NBC may borrow a fourth show from the stable of its cable network USA.

title: Growth Hormones Uncertain Future
description: Is recombinant bovine somatotropin (rBST, more commonly called bovine growth hormone, or BGH) on its way out? Once considered inevitable, it has met with so much consumer resistance that its use is in decline. And as this story demonstrates, that resistance is as middle-of-the-road as Hot Pockets. Im not sure this is a victory for sustainable agriculture or anything else  and I think the beginning of this story is hyperbole of the first order  but its a sign of the power American consumers have. Whats next? Grass-fed beef at McDonalds?

title: Amtrak Service Is Restored Between New York and Philadelphia
description: Updated, 2:45 p.m. | Amtrak suspended train service between New York City and Philadelphia for about 90 minutes as a precautionary measure after what it called a power fluctuation that began at 12:17 p.m. The railroad reported that power was restored by 1:50 p.m.

title: Report on 1994 Rapper Shooting in Doubt
description: The newly installed editor of The Los Angeles Times, Russ Stanton, opened an investigation today into a report linking Sean Combs to the shooting of Tupac Shakur at a Manhattan recording studio in 1994.

title: Jean Todts talk with the press
description: Was it just a coincidence? Jean Todt ceased as team leader and sporting director and all the rest, and he did not show up at the first race of the season, and Ferrari lost both cars to engine problems. Todt then showed up at the second race of the season, in Malaysia, and the team won the race.

title: Purple States: Huckabee Reviewed
description: Citizen reporters consider the effectiveness of Mike Huckabee's candidacy.

title: Words Will Tell
description: In about a week I will load up my car with amplifiers and guitars and drive to Nashville to begin recording my next record. I dont drive much anymore and Im glad for that except that I used to write a lot while on the road. Solitude, boredom, and the desperate need to entertain oneself are ideal stimuli for songwriting.

title: Just Browsing
description: Just Browsing sews together the latest fashion news from our global sources of mags, trades, blogs and tipsters.

title: Fords M&A Legacy
description: For Ford Motor Company, the $2.3 billion sale of British automakers Jaguar and Land Rover to Tata Motors is a big step in its turnaround plan.

title: Jericho Goes Out With a Ratings Whimper
description: CBSs sci-fi show Jericho limped across the finish line Tuesday, earning just under 6 million viewers in its series-finale, according to Nielsens estimates. Jericho  which was canceled last spring, revived over the summer after an outcry from devoted fans, and then canceled once again  finished third in its 10 p.m. time slot behind ABCs Primetime (10.4 million) and a repeat of NBCs Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (8.5 million).

title: Mister Dog and Other True Stories on the Blotter
description: Last September, the historian and filmmaker Suzanne Wasserman, who directs the Gotham Center for New York City History at the City University of New York Graduate Center, started a new feature, Gotham History Blotter, as part of the centers Web site.

title: Soft Serve | Superduper Yachts, Whos-Your-Daddy Test, Dinosaur on Ebay
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: When Auditors Cave
