description: In the Enron debacle, one of the most disturbing disclosures was that Arthur Andersens technical accounting experts were overruled by the engagement partners in Houston, allowing accounting decisions to be approved even though Andersens experts knew they were wrong.

title: Clinton Donors Ask Pelosi to Back Off
description: Twenty-one top contributors to Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential campaign sent a letter today to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, essentially asking her to back off and keep out of the superdelegate fight.

title: The Home Stretch?
description: Wed like to apologize to all the subcontractors and suppliers in the Anna Maria Island area who have been yelled at this week by our builder, John Agnelli, for not measuring correctly or delivering less than the full order.

title: The Ketchup Wars Continue
description: In the Dining section today, a challenge to a condiment that dominates America was presented in Katchkie Ketchup. Most fancy-pants ketchups do not quite measure up in terms of tangy-sweetness, Florence Fabricant wrote. But this one has what it takes. For a fascinating description of exactly what it takes to transform tomatoes, vinegar and sugar into the iconic Heinz, read this excerpt from The Ketchup Conundrum, an essay that Malcolm Gladwell published in The New Yorker in 2004:

title: Immigrants March for Schools and Housing
description: About 1,500 immigrant New Yorkers and their supporters marched to City Hall from Battery Park today to draw attention to school financing, on-the-job accidents in the construction industry, access to housing and other issues that they described as critical for the citys foreign-born population.

title: Circling Back: Centovini
description: I keep going back to Centovini. I keep thinking that any month now, Im going to have a flat-out, front-to-start great meal there, and the reason I keep that thought alive is that theres always a dish or two I adore, among  sadly  many other dishes that are pro-forma toss-offs, neither conceived nor prepared with particular distinction.

title: Obama Talks About His Faith
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  Back on the campaign trail this afternoon after a brief vacation, Senator Barack Obama made a spirited defense of his church, Trinity United Church of Christ, and said everyone is welcome to come and hear the sermons there  one day after Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said that she would have left her church if her pastor had made the controversial remarks that Mr. Obamas former pastor had made.

title: Worldwide PC Sales Could Still Grow by Double-Digits
description: A new report released Tuesday from Gartner, the market research firm, predicts year-over-year PC sales to grow 10.9 percent worldwide. Thats down from a December forecast of 11.6 percent, and the reduction is due to the worsening world economy. While a further downturn could slow growth to single digits, the industry is showing strength across all segments from laptops to desktop replacements, the company said.

title: Bill Clinton, Cowboy Campaigner
description: Former President Bill Clinton, who has been no stranger to fallout from controversial comments made on the campaign trail, said surrogates should saddle up instead of stepping down after they say something off-message.

title: The Middle Seat
description: On my flight out to Phoenix for the Round of 16 of the N.C.A.A. tournament, I struck up a conversation for the final hour with the man to the left of me in the middle seat. It turned out to be Junior Spivey, the former baseball All-Star who had just been released from Red Sox camp.

title: Hows the Economy? Ask Ohio
description: Ohio is often considered the great American bellwether state. It likes to call itself the Mother of Presidents because of the large number of its natives who have moved into the White House.

title: Words, Glorious Words
description: Crapulence  that word appeared this month in our review of Scott Spencers book Willing, and when I came across it during an edit, its first four letters sent me straight to the dictionary. The Timess bearers of standards wrinkle their noses at words excremental, and I was pretty certain Id have to make a note to the author (Sorry, bud, no crapu-etc. in The Times). But to my delight, the word turned out not to be unsavory at all, and was instead an unusual way of referring to excessive drinking (or, in the context of the review  in which it appeared as sexual crapulence  excessive anything). Excellent! I wrote a very different note: This is my new favorite word.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Wednesday, Mar. 26:

title: Video Q&A: Answers From Iraqis, Part 2
description: Video

title: Fat City? 10 Million Pounds Gained in 2 Years
description: About 173,500 adult New Yorkers became obese and more than 73,000 received new diagnoses of diabetes from 2002 to 2004, according to a new study by the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. Put another way, the citywide weight gain totaled more than 10 million pounds in just two years, the city noted in a news release summarizing the study, which is being published in the April issue of Preventing Chronic Disease, a medical journal published by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Report on 1994 Rapper Shooting in Doubt
description: Updated, 5:11 p.m. Scroll to bottom for doubts voiced last week, how the reporter responded to them, and threats today of a lawsuit against the L.A. Times

title: Clear Channel, Buyers Sue Banks to Force Buyouts Completion
description: The two proposed buyers of Clear Channel Communications filed two lawsuits on Wednesday against six banks that agreed to finance the companys $19.5 billion buyout.

title: Family Files Claim Over Carol Gotbaums Death
description: Updated, 5:58 p.m. | The family of Carol A. Gotbaum, the Manhattan woman whose death in police custody in the Phoenix airport last September drew national attention, has filed a notice of claim against the city of Phoenix, a requirement before filing a civil lawsuit.

title: The Mini Minimalist
description: Found on YouTube by my daughter Kate, who forwarded it to me. MB

title: The Gomez Rib Watch
description: Rangers center Scott Gomez took the ice by himself after his teammates practiced Wednesday and seemed less than pleased to find an audience of reporters watching him skate laps as Rangers assistant coach Perry Pearn timed him.

title: Anxiety Near Tibet's Border
description: Chinese police have been monitoring the Tibetan community in Chengdu, in Sichuan Province, which adjoins Tibet.

title: Man Is Arrested in Fire Off Henry Hudson Parkway
description: The police have arrested a homeless man for setting a heavy fire Wednesday afternoon that destroyed trees and bushes, backed up traffic on the Henry Hudson Parkway and required the efforts of more than 60 firefighters to bring under control. No one was injured.

title: Obama Warms to Wrapping Up Contest
description: ABOARD THE OBAMA CAMPAIGN PLANE  Senator Barack Obama this evening called Tennessee Gov. Phil Bredesens proposal of resolving the Democratic nomination contest in June a good one  although Mr. Obama seemed to be endorsing a June wrap-up more than the governors specific plan to let superdelegates caucus to choose either Mr. Obama or Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Bloggingheads: Democratic Meltdown
description:
Robert Wright of Bloggingheads.tv, left, and former Secretary of Labor Robert Reich discuss the possibility of superdelegates giving the election to Hillary Clinton.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Montreal Is in the M.L.S. Mix
description: The inclusion of George Gillett, the owner of the Montreal Canadiens and part-owner of Liverpool of the English Premier League, has catapulted Montreal to the top of a long list of possible expansion cities bidding for teams in Major League Soccer.

title: Goodbye, Legends Field  Hello, Steinbrenner Field
description: Today is the last day anyone can use the term Legends Field and still be accurate. The Yankees Tampa home will officially become Steinbrenner Field in a ceremony before Thursdays game against the Pirates. The Yankees will break camp afterward for a two-game set with the Marlins in Miami.

title: Coughlin Had It Worse
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Back in December, Louisville faced an uncertain future. The Cardinals, who lost three times in four games, had three players injured, another gone for academic reasons, and one on suspension for a game.

title: Clinton Women Take the Stage in D.C.
description: WASHINGTON  With the help of the Dunbar High School marching band, Hillary Rodham Clinton made a grand entrance onto the grand stage at the Daughters of the American Revolution Constitution Hall, where women like Ella Fitzgerald and Bette Davis have trodden before.

title: Bonfire, Relit
description: Over in the Book Reviews Reading Room, were talking about Tom Wolfes Bonfire of the Vanities. One of the big questions: How does the book hold up today, as rooted as it is in close observations of late 1980s New York? Is it a period piece best read as a work of urban history? Or did Wolfe capture the timeless spirit of the city (or, for that matter, the fundamental nature of man)?

title: Lets Talk About Health Insurance. And Talk, and Talk.
description: As the regulars at Shifting Careers know, weve been doing a lot of talking about health insurance for the self-employed since my initial post, Health Insurance for the Self-Employed, and a follow-up post, The Minefield of Health Insurance, a few weeks later. While it is shameful that adequate and affordable health insurance is so difficult to find that it affects peoples career choices, I did find one bright light in researching this subject. People are willing to share information in a way that genuinely helps others, that is until the government or private industry steps up with some better solutions.

title: Your Comments on my Hillary Clinton Column
description: My Thursday column is about the duel for the Democratic nomination. I argue that Senator Clinton has only a minimal chance of winning the nomination  but a fair chance of creating such discord in the Democratic Party that John McCain can claim the White House. You see that in the exit polls, in which Obama and Clinton supporters said back in January that they would be perfectly happy if the other person ended up as the nominee  while now they are much less happy with the other person and in some cases they say they would vote for McCain.

title: Heaves It Like a Pea? Must Be Love
description: If U.C.L.A. is down late and needs a full-court, desperation shot  non-Tyus Edny style  then theres no question who theyll be going to late in the game. The U.C.L.A. assistant coach Scott Garson tipped off the Quad on watching the freshman big-man Kevin Love shoot half-court, three-quarter court and full court shots. And, oh my, what a tip.

title: Point Man for Tennessee
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Coach Bruce Pearls bold decision to switch point guards in the N.C.A.A. tournament has paid off so far for No. 2 seed Tennessee, which faces No. 3 Louisville in the East Regional semifinals at Charlotte Bobcats Arena on Thursday.

title: The Fog of War
description: Update, Thursday a.m.: A Texas state court judge has granted Clear Channels request for a temporary restraining order. Here are some initial thoughts on that.

title: Modern architects design U.K. project around old cathedral
description: Tribeca

title: Los Angeles Times to Examine Its Report on Attack on Rapper
description: The Los Angeles Times announced on Wednesday that it was conducting an internal investigation into whether an article it published last week about the 1994 assault on the rapper Tupac Shakur was based on fabricated information.

title: An Alternative to PDF
description: Q. What is this thing called XPS Document Writer in the printer settings on my Vista computer?

title: Rearranging the Bedroom Is Easier With a Rotating Bed
description: Jack OBrien, the director of the Broadway hits Dirty Rotten Scoundrels and Hairspray, had a not uncommon concern when he built a home in New Milford, Conn.  where to position his bed in the master bedroom. It was, you might say, the driving problem of his bedroom design.

title: Richard Widmark, Films Hoodlum and Flawed Hero, Dies at 93
description: Richard Widmark, whose movie debut as a giggling killer made him an overnight star, giving rise to an enduring Hollywood career playing a gallery of chilling hoodlums and flawed heroes, died Monday at his home in Roxbury, Conn. He was 93.

title: With a 500-Gigabyte Drive, Every Song You Know Fits in Your Pocket With Room to Spare
description: Since the advent of portable hard drives, we have dreamed of holding over 100 full-length movies or 128,000 MP3s in the palm of one hand. With the 500-gigabyte MiniStation TurboUSB from Buffalo Technology, that dream has come to pass.

title: Synching Just Became a Cinch
description: If youve ever lost important computer files, then you already know about the five stages of grieving: Denial, Anger, Bargaining, Depression and Moving to the Amish Country.

title: Home & Garden Calendar
description: Bottle by Bottle

title: Wireless Headset for Internet Phone Calls
description: The Logitech ClearChat wireless headset, which the company says is the first of its kind with Internet calling in mind, is also meant to be faux-pas-proof.

title: Corrections
description: Business Day

title: Balco Founder Rebuts Testimony on Bonds
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The founder of the Bay Area Laboratory Co-operative told associates that he provided Barry Bonds with performance-enhancing drugs, the former girlfriend of a chemist who sold steroids to the laboratory testified Wednesday.

title: Running High
description: "Every athlete has heard of it, most seem to believe in it and many say they have experienced it," Gina Kolata writes in The Times today about the so-called runner's high. "But for year scientists have reserved judgment because no rigorous test confirmed its existence." Now, she writes, medical technology has caught up with exercise lore, and German researchers have reported that running does elicit a flood of endorphins in the brain. "The endorphins are associated with mood changes," she writes, "and the more endorphins a runner's body pumps out, the greater the effect."

title: A Lesson in Politics as Unusual
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y.

title: A Threat to Public Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Time to Sober Up, Bride-to-Be, and Smell the Coffee
description: The three young women staggering through a fateful night on the town in Adam Bocks flimsy but sweet comedy The Drunken City are the kind that some of us would pay a kings ransom not to be seated near in a Manhattan restaurant.

title: The Uncle Al Election
description: When I was a kid in Cincinnati, there was a local childrens TV show that always featured a race. Little boys and girls ran around in circles for what seemed like a very long time, until the host threw up his hands and yelled: Everybody wins!

title: France: No Eiffel Redesign Planned, Says Architect Who Made Proposal
description: David Serero, principal of Serero Architects, said in a telephone interview that his firms proposal was merely a spontaneous design it had submitted to the Eiffel Tower management group in view of the towers approaching 120th anniversary and, he said, was neither a response to a design competition nor solicited by the towers management.

title: Experimenting With Makeup: What Puts the Ick in Lipstick?
description: BOSTON

title: Supplier Under Scrutiny on Arms for Afghans
description: This article was reported by C. J. Chivers, Eric Schmitt and Nicholas Wood and written by Mr. Chivers.

title: Porter and the Jaguars: A Lesson in Free Agency
description: Jerry Porter was packing up his Bay Area home recently, eager to become a full-time Floridian, desperate to make the cathartic flight from Oakland to a fresh start with the Jacksonville Jaguars. For Porter, the Jaguars represent an opportunity to restart a career and reshape a reputation with a team that is free of the Raiders almost comical chaos.

title: Cougars Defense Makes Williams Defensive
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Washington State arrived in the N.C.A.A. tournament Round of 16 playing the kind of defensive-minded basketball that North Carolina Coach Roy Williams openly mocked years ago.

title: Red-Hot Nets Sizzle, at Least for a Night
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  On a night when no one seemed to put a priority on defense, the Nets had four players score 20 or more points, shot 54.4 percent from the field and defeated the Indiana Pacers, 124-117, on Wednesday at the Izod Center.

title: As the Dollar Slides, Two Continents Feel the Side Effects in Divergent Ways
description: HONG KONG  Anthony del Rosario, who works on an oil tanker that travels between the Middle East and South Korea, is sending home less money to his family in the Philippines. Takeshi Okada, a shoe manufacturer in Japan, is concerned about the possibility of declining export sales.

title: Slowly but Surely, the Mets Take Shape
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  There are 41 players left in the Mets major league camp, meaning that General Manager Omar Minaya must bid adieu to 16 by Sunday to finalize their opening day roster. Most of the decisions will not be fulfilled until Friday, when the team leaves Florida, but the lucky 25 who will be introduced Monday at Dolphin Stadium are slowly but surely taking shape.

title: The Carrot Some Vegans Deplore
description: TWO things that you can find a lot of in Portland, Ore., are vegans and strip clubs. Johnny Diablo decided to open a business to combine both. At his Casa Diablo Gentlemens Club, soy protein replaces beef in the tacos and chimichangas; the dancers wear pleather, not leather. Many are vegans or vegetarians themselves.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: A headline on Saturday with an article about the increasing number of women who serve as chief investment officers for university endowments and foundations used a glass ceiling metaphor in a way that conveyed the opposite point made by the article. The headline should have said something to the effect that The Glass Ceiling Is Lifting, not The Glass Ceiling Is Edging Lower.

title: Danity Kane on Top of Charts, Again
description: The MTV-bred girl group Danity Kane, above, scored its second No. 1 on the Billboard album chart this week. Its new release, Welcome to the Dollhouse (Bad Boy/Atlantic), moved 236,000 copies in the United States, Nielsen SoundScan reported. The only other debut in the Top 10 had surprisingly low sales: Flo Rida, the Miami rapper whose song Low is the biggest-selling digital track ever, sold only 86,000 copies of his album Mail on Sunday (Atlantic) to reach No. 4. The pop compilation Now Thats What I Call Music! Vol. 27 is No. 2 with 170,000; Rick Rosss Trilla (Slip-N-Slide/Def Jam), last weeks No. 1, fell two spots with 90,000 sales; and Jack Johnsons Sleep Through the Static (Brushfire/Universal) is No. 5 with 67,000. Also this week, Miley Cyrus became the first female artist since LeAnn Rimes 11 years ago to have two albums in the Billboard Top 10, with Hannah Montana 2 /Meet Miley Cyrus (at No. 6) and Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: The Best of Both Worlds Concert (No. 10), both released by Disney.

title: Equity Loans as Next Round in Credit Crisis
description: Little by little, millions of Americans surrendered equity in their homes in recent years. Lulled by good times, they borrowed  sometimes heavily  against the roofs over their heads.

title: Tatis Is Likely to Earn Mets Final Bench Spot
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  There are 41 players left in the Mets major league camp, meaning that General Manager Omar Minaya must bid adieu to 16 by Sunday to complete the opening day roster. Most of the decisions will not be fulfilled until Friday, when the team leaves Florida, but the lucky 25 who will be introduced Monday at Dolphin Stadium are slowly but surely taking shape.

title: Rodriguez Wont Comment on Contents of Book
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.  Home runs exploded from the cage during batting practice Wednesday at Bright House Field. Alex Rodriguez was at work. One ball soared over a tiki bar above left field. Others sizzled on a line to a grass berm above left center.

title: Women Against Women, From Anywhere in the World
description: From April 7 to 13, the World Bridge Federation and Bridge Base Online will run a festival only for women. At www.bridgebase.com there will be four 10-board tournaments each day, two for individuals and two for pairs. You can play in as many competitions as you like and get into the spirit of global B.B.O. by competing in the pair events with a partner from another country. Each tournaments entry fee is $1 per person, and the times are 5 a.m., 10 a.m., 3:40 p.m. and 7 p.m. Eastern. As an added incentive World Bridge Federation master points will be awarded.

title: Plans to Mix Oil Drilling and Art Clash in Utah
description: ROZEL POINT, Utah  Will McMillin and Liz Wing walked more than three miles of rutted, muddy road on a recent afternoon carrying a bicycle wheel, a wooden stool and a golf club.

title: Tip of the Week: Hiding Your Mouse Pointer
description: If you find that mouse pointer on screen distracting while youre typing on your Windows machine, you might be able to hide it. Go to the Start menu to Control Panel and open the Mouse icon. In the Mouse properties box, click the Pointer Options tab and put a check in the box next to Hide pointer while typing and click O.K. This option may not be available with all systems or mouse drivers.

title: A Search for a Baker Who Can Take Direction
description: The crisis began in October. Bernard Moreau, the manager of the Century Association, received two weeks notice from the bakery in Hells Kitchen that for 60 years had supplied the Centurys dining rooms with its beloved macaroons.

title: The iPod Is Here; the Music Comes Out Over There
description: Operating an iPod from across the room usually requires three devices: the iPod, a stereo dock and a remote. But Monster, the company best known for its fancy cables, has cut out the middle man. Its iSoniCast Wireless Audio Bridge lets you beam music from the iPod itself to a distant stereo.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An obituary on June 7, 2006, about the rock keyboardist Billy Preston misstated his date of birth. His Web site recently announced that he was born on Sept. 2, 1946  not Sept. 9, as was widely reported.

title: Puerto Rican Governor Faces 19 Counts
description: MIAMI  Anbal S. Acevedo Vil, the governor of Puerto Rico, has been charged with 19 criminal counts related to the financing of three political campaigns from 1999 to 2004, including conspiracy to violate federal campaign laws, wire fraud and illegally using campaign funds for his personal use, according to a federal indictment unsealed on Thursday.

title: South Korea Adds Terms for Its Aid to the North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The new, conservative South Korean government took a tougher line on North Korea on Wednesday, warning that it would speak out against human rights abuses in the Communist North and that it would not expand economic ties unless the North abandoned its nuclear weapons programs.

title: Reigning Wagnerian Tenor Returns to 'Tristan'
description: The main rationale for the Metropolitan Operas decision to revive its 1999 production of Wagners Tristan und Isolde  the selling point, to put it bluntly  was to bring the tenor Ben Heppner and the soprano Deborah Voigt together to sing the title roles. Though these acclaimed Wagnerians have performed excerpts from the opera in concert, they have never appeared together in a staged production.

title: McCain Said 100; Opponents Latch On
description: Within hours of uttering the phrase maybe a hundred years at a town-hall-style meeting in New Hampshire in January, Senator John McCain came under attack by Democrats and antiwar groups for promoting a seemingly endless troop presence in Iraq.

title: Funny Thing Happens to Knicks on the Way to the Lottery
description: Isiah Thomas sat for the television cameras, strolled Madison Square Gardens lower corridors and patrolled the Knicks bench  a walking, breathing place-holder with a cloud over his head and an expiration date to be determined.

title: For Ailey Troupe, at 50, a Street and an 18-Month Tribute
description: There has long been an Alvin Ailey Street in Rogers, the small town in southeast Texas where Ailey was born in 1931. And now, worlds away in bustling Manhattan, West 55th Street from 9th to 10th Avenues will be named Alvin Ailey Place.

title: Jeans for the Lean Years
description: DURING Americas most recent Gilded Age, which I guess ended last week, I wrote fashion copy for a mens magazine. While coming up with witty headlines (Beanies, Baby!) and justifying the existence of an $1,800 melon-pink cashmere sweater emblazoned with a skull (adds a touch of rebellion under a blazer!), I witnessed firsthand the emergence of the premium jean.

title: Currents | Limited Editions From a Paris Dealer
description: Twenty First/Twenty First, a new gallery in Chelsea, specializes in limited-edition modern furniture. It is the first New York showroom for Renaud Vuaillat, the owner, although he sold furniture for 15 years in Paris, he said, first at the Clignancourt flea market and then in a gallery in St. Germain. But unlike Paris, he said, New York is all about desire! What I find here, and what is seriously missing in France, is that people react positively in front of something they discover.

title: Obama Urges Regulation in Wake of Housing Slump
description: Senator Barack Obama called Thursday for tighter regulation of mortgage lenders, banks and other financial institutions, even as he spoke of pumping $30 billion into the economy to shield homeowners and local governments from the worst effects of the collapse of the housing bubble.

title: California Utility to Install Solar Panels
description: An electric company plans to install a huge patchwork of solar cells, 10 times bigger than any previous such installation, on more than 100 large rooftops around Southern California.

title: Tastings and Viewings by Design
description: The Design Industries Foundation Fighting AIDS will present Dining by Design, its annual exhibition of tables set by designers, starting on Sunday. The installation opens to the public on Sunday with a Table Hop and Taste from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; the $45 admission includes cocktails and food tastings from various restaurants. On Monday, a cocktail party with the designers will be held from 7 to 10 p.m.; admission is $150. The final event is a sit-down dinner and dance on Tuesday, from 6:30 to 11 p.m.; tickets are $800. Dining By Design will be held at Skylight, 275 Hudson Street (Spring Street); for information and tickets: diffa.org.

title: Europe and U.S. Press China Over Tibet
Half a Dream Team, Going Wholeheartedly
description: The main rationale for the Metropolitan Operas decision to revive its 1999 production of Wagners Tristan und Isolde  the selling point, to put it bluntly  was to bring the tenor Ben Heppner and the soprano Deborah Voigt together to sing the title roles. Though these acclaimed Wagnerians have performed excerpts from the opera in concert, they have never appeared together in a staged production of this, or any, opera.

title: Pressured, Motorola Splits in Two
description: After a two-month strategic review of its businesses, Motorola said on Wednesday that it would split itself into two separate publicly traded companies, spinning off its unprofitable mobile phone unit to investors.

title: Shimmy, Spasm, Stamp With Mozarts Requiem
description: When words and music are addressed to God, its a rare choreographer who can accompany them with movement that looks anything other than piffling. Dance  by showing the ideal qualities of the human form and/or by making use of time and space  can reveal the sublime, but it usually looks thin when it tries to address the religious.

title: Circuits | Whod Win a Match Between Donkey Kong and Princess Peach? Not Me
description: I was repeatedly beaten up by a 16-year-old girl.

title: A Tree That Survived a Sculptors Chisel Is Chopped Down
description: A tree grew in Long Island City.

title: Finding Health Insurance if You Are Self-Employed
description: If there is one thing that separates the self-employed from those employed by others, it is their preoccupation with health insurance.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 26, 2008

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. Is dark molding appropriate in a modern interior?

title: Parachute May Have Link to 1971 Hijacking Case
description: SEATTLE  The worn parachute that children found while playing on their familys property in rural southwestern Washington this month may be the one that D. B. Cooper used on that mysterious night in 1971 when he carried out what the authorities call the only unsolved hijacking in United States history.

title: Finding Political News Online, the Young Pass It On
description: Senator Barack Obamas videotaped response to President Bushs final State of the Union address  almost five minutes of Mr. Obamas talking directly to the camera  elicited little attention from newspaper and television reporters in January.

title: Nesting With a Vengeance (and a Deadline)
description: ANGELA KINSEY, who plays Angela Martin on the television comedy The Office, is seven months pregnant and trying to prioritize all the improvements she is making on her 1950s single-story home in Los Angeles. She came up with a to-do list during the writers strike, when she was basically unemployed. But the real reason for the list, she said, is that being pregnant makes you crazy to get things done around the house.

title: Thefts Are Reported From Apartments Evacuated After Crane Collapse
description: The recent crane collapse that claimed seven lives, demolished a town house and destabilized a neighborhood on the East Side of Manhattan also created an opportunity for looters, officials said on Wednesday.

title: On Frigid Celtic Waves, Surfers Where Youd Least Expect Them
description: BUNDORAN, Ireland  It was a typical late-winter day on the Irish coast, no worse than usual. Bands of black clouds sailed ominously across the sky. Rain bucketed down in freezing torrents. Icy winds pummeled and churned the ocean.

title: Iraqi Armys Assault on Militias in Basra Stalls
description: BAGHDAD  An assault by thousands of Iraqi soldiers and police officers to regain control of the southern port city of Basra stalled Wednesday as Shiite militiamen in the Mahdi Army fought daylong hit-and-run battles and refused to withdraw from the neighborhoods that form their base of power there.

title: Ringside at the Democratic Slugfest
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bad Reaction to a Diet
description: VOGUE made the proposal, but was it indecent?

title: Michael Lesch, Who Helped Identify a Rare Disorder, Is Dead at 68
description: Dr. Michael Lesch, a medical educator whose name is attached to a hereditary disorder characterized by self-mutilation that he helped identify as a medical student, died on March 19 while on a fishing trip in Patagonia. He was 68.

title: In Potential Studio Split, Who Keeps the Movies?
description: LOS ANGELES  Among the dozens of movie projects in the works at Paramount Pictures DreamWorks division is a comedy about a couple who have to live Valentines Day over and over again until they finally get it right.

title: Afghanistan: Bomb in Market Kills 8
description: On a day when the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, said his country intended to strengthen its military presence in the NATO force in Afghanistan, a car bomb exploded at a crowded farmers market in southern Afghanistan, killing eight civilians and wounding 17, Afghan officials said. There was no military or police target, said Muhammad Hussain Andiwal, the police chief of Helmand Province.

title: In Speech, Bush Praises Iraqs Government
description: WRIGHT-PATTERSON AIR FORCE BASE, Ohio  President Bush praised Iraqs government on Thursday for ordering the military assault in southern Iraq that has set off violence and protests across that country. Mr. Bush said the fighting demonstrated the willingness of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to impose order and defeat what he called militia groups and fighters.

title: M.L.S. Looks to Latin America to Help Lift Its Game
description: David Beckham arrived in Los Angeles last July under a shower of Mylar confetti to inject a level of celebrity and credibility into a second-class soccer league. But Beckham played in only five Major League Soccer games because of injury, recalling a number of other fading European stars who came into M.L.S. promising much and delivering little.

title: P. S. Penland, Coast Expert, Dies at 54
description: Patrick Shea Penland, a coastal geologist who studied how Louisianas coastal marshes and barrier islands form, evolve and vanish, and became in the process a forceful advocate for their preservation, was found dead on Tuesday at his home in New Orleans. He was 54.

title: Sarkozy Urges China to Hold Talks with Dalai Lama
description: LONDON  One day after hinting at a possible boycott of the opening ceremony of the Beijing Olympics, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France on Wednesday urged China to conduct a true dialogue with the Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of Tibet.

title: Equal Alliance, Unequal Roles
description: Stockbridge, Mass.

title: All Nippon Is First to Order Jet Made in Japan
description: PARIS  All Nippon Airways of Japan said Thursday that it had placed an order for regional jets made by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, becoming the first customer for what could be the first new Japanese aircraft in a generation.

title: NASAs Science Chief Resigns
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla.  S. Alan Stern, an experienced planetary scientist who came to NASA less than a year ago to lead the agencys science division, resigned unexpectedly on Wednesday.

title: Inquiry Assails Accounting Firm in Lenders Fall
description: A sweeping five-month investigation into the collapse of one of the nations largest subprime lenders points a finger at a possible new culprit in the mortgage mess: the accountants.

title: Iran Asks for Apology on Sanctions
description: Iran said the United States, Britain, France and Germany should apologize to the countrys leaders and scientists for damaging their reputations through United Nations Security Council sanctions resolutions against the countrys nuclear program and said it might seek compensation and pursue unspecified legal actions.

title: The Great Cornball Anthem
description: One moment, not exactly shining: It's 1986, and in a bar in East Lansing, Mich., a woman approaches a struggling folk musician named David Barrett. "A waitress," Barrett recalled last year, "too beautiful for words. What do I say to this woman?" He panics, glances at the TV, sees Larry Bird "using someone like soap." So he starts talking about Larry Bird, "how amazing he is, blah blah blah." The woman is unimpressed. Barrett slinks out of the bar, thinking that he might write a song about basketball, and a phrase pops into his head, out of nowhere, and the next morning he sits down for lunch and scribbles on a napkin the great cornball anthem that, two decades later, still makes grown men cry.

title: Canseco Declines to Support Latest Steroid Allegations
description: In a Nightline interview to be broadcast Friday night, Jos Canseco declines to provide more information to support allegations in his new book indirectly linking Alex Rodriguez to steroids.

title: Weaning Teenagers Off Gossip, for One Hour at a Time
description: It would seem an odd, perhaps even absurd, announcement to make over a high schools public address system.

title: Court Looks at Legal Role for Mentally Ill
description: WASHINGTON  A landmark Supreme Court decision 33 years ago gave criminal defendants the right to represent themselves at trial.

title: Dykstra, Like His Father, Is Reckless in Good Way
description: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif.  The royal blue and orange leadoff hitter with DYKSTRA over his No. 4 rapped a grounder through the left-side hole, recklessly rounded first and then broke for second, safe by an inch and jumping up covered in dirt.

title: U.S. Says Hussein Spy Agency and Iraqi-American Arranged 02 Trip by Lawmakers
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department said Wednesday that Saddam Husseins principal foreign intelligence agency and an Iraqi-American man had organized and paid for a 2002 visit to Iraq by three House Democrats whose trip was harshly criticized by colleagues at the time.

title: Hacker Artists Cleared in Czech TV Stunt
description: A Czech judge dismissed charges on Tuesday against seven artists accused of scaremongering by Czech Television after they hacked into a live broadcast in June and superimposed images of a nuclear explosion on a picture of mountains being used as the backdrop for a weather forecast, above, Agence France-Presse reported. At the end of a six-hour hearing in the Trutnov regional court, the judge, Stanislava Suchankova, said: The images of the explosion could not have created public unrest. People were rather amused at how easy it was to disrupt the signal. Cheers and applause welcomed the decision, but the state prosecutor, Zdena Hourova, said the state would consider an appeal. The artists of the Ztohoven collective had faced a maximum sentence of three years in jail. The stunt, which was posted on the Internet, attracted international notice and won them a national prize for young artists.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: Because of an editing error, the chess column on Sunday, about Hou Yifan, a 14-year-old rising star in the chess world, referred incorrectly in some editions to her ranking at the Corus tournament in January, in which she finished in the middle of the field. She was the second-lowest-ranked player in just the B section of the tournament  not in the tournament over all.

title: Corzine Urges Tougher Rules for Drivers Under 20
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J.  He should know.

title: Preseason Games in Europe for Nets
description: The Nets will be one of four teams to open their preseason schedule in Europe next fall, as part of the N.B.A,s effort to market itself overseas. They will be joined by the Miami Heat, the New Orleans Hornets and the Washington Wizards.

title: Clinton Donors Warn on Superdelegate Fight
description: WASHINGTON  Leading contributors to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton intensified their effort to keep the Democratic presidential contest alive on Wednesday and urged Speaker Nancy Pelosi to stay out of the superdelegate fight, admonishing her for suggesting that the candidate ahead in pledged delegates  now Senator Barack Obama  should become the nominee.

title: A Sisterly Rivalry Leads Directly to Pies
description: MAYBE it is just sibling rivalry, but I have an uncontrollable urge to grow blueberries this year.

title: Mourners Absent From Jericho Finale
description: CBSs sci-fi show Jericho limped across the finish line on Tuesday, attracting just under six million viewers for its series finale, Nielsen reported. Jericho, first canceled last spring but revived over the summer after an outcry from devoted fans, only to be canceled once again, finished third in its 10 p.m. slot, behind ABCs Primetime (10.4 million) and a repeat of NBCs Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (8.5 million). CBS ranked fourth for the night, despite drawing higher ratings with an NCIS rerun at 8 (9.4 million), followed at 9 by Big Brother, which also attracted 6 million viewers but fared better than Jericho among adults 18 to 49. Fox easily led over all, thanks to a 90-minute edition of American Idol from 8 to 9:30 (24.4 million). ABC was second with Dancing With the Stars at 9 (17.2 million). NBC finished third.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a popular Internet video prank known as rickrolling referred incorrectly to its use during a March 8 womens basketball game at Eastern Washington University, based on information provided by Pawl Fisher, a student; Davin Perry, who shoots game videos for the university; and Dave Cook, its sports information director. The stunt, which involves a person lip-synching the 1980s hit song Never Gonna Give You Up while dressed as the British singer Rick Astley, was performed before the start of four separate basketball games, and the pranksters distilled the performances into a YouTube video. The March 8 game, between Eastern Washington and Montana State, was not interrupted by a performance.

title: Exercise Test: Truth or Myth?
description: SOME exercise folklore, such as the runners high, is eventually proved. But far more common are the persistent myths, including the following two.

title: Dispatches on the State of the Piano
description: In the 18th century the piano danced. In the 19th it sang. The 20th century liked to use the piano as an assault weapon. Keys to the Future, a three-concert affair at the Greenwich Houses tiny Renee Weiler Concert Hall, concluding on Thursday, is letting us know what piano music is like lately. Eight pianists are playing pieces by 23 composers. Four performed music by six of them on Tuesday night.

title: A Tanker Contract for Airbus, Amid a Setback
description: PARIS  The British Defense Ministry helped to bolster the military ambitions of European Aeronautic Defense & Space on Thursday, formalizing a $26 billion contract with an EADS-led consortium to supply the Royal Air Force with combat refueling tankers.

title: Footnotes
description: Bob Dylan, below, will join Amy Winehouse,  the Police and other performers at the Rock in Rio festival in Madrid in July, Agence France-Presse reported. ... On Departure, the first play in nearly two decades by the former Czech president Vaclav Havel, will have its premiere on May 22 at the Archa Theater in Prague, Agence France-Presse reported. ... Justin Timberlake will serve as the host of the annual ESPY Awards at the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles on July 20, The Associated Press reported. Ill do my best to deliver a great show, as I do not want to be roughed up backstage by these athletes who are bigger, faster and stronger than me, he said.

title: Despite Thunderclouds in the United States, Business Confidence Is Up in Europe
description: FRANKFURT  Europe is shrugging off the thunderclouds in the United States, with new surveys on Wednesday showing rising business confidence in Germany, France and Belgium, while the president of the European Central Bank damped hopes for a cut in interest rates anytime soon.

title: Citigroup Resolves Claims That It Helped Enron Deceive Investors
description: Seeking to put its legal problems behind as it confronts larger financial ones, the banking giant Citigroup said on Wednesday that it had settled claims accusing it of helping the energy trader Enron deceive investors.

title: Florida Legislature Apologizes for States History of Slavery
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  The Florida Legislature formally apologized Wednesday for the states shameful history of slavery, joining five other states that have expressed public regret for what Senator Barack Obama, the Democratic presidential candidate, recently called Americas original sin.

title: A Hibiscus, Far From Home
description: A Hibiscus, Far From Home

title: Needed: Efficient Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Medical Specialties and Our Health Care System
description: To the Editor:

title: New Day, Line by Budget Line
description: Moving beyond the steamy executive headlines, the New York Statehouse had better show taxpayers something more promising than business as usual as it tackles the deficit-threatened state budget. One quick test, buried in the fine print, would strike a blow for both juvenile justice and budget savings by shutting six of the states 31 residential detention centers for juveniles.

title: Yes, Running Can Make You High
description: THE runners high: Every athlete has heard of it, most seem to believe in it and many say they have experienced it. But for years scientists have reserved judgment because no rigorous test confirmed its existence.

title: Finally, Feeling the Vibrations of PlayStation 3 Games
description: When Sonys PlayStation 3 came out last year, purists demanded  and did not receive  game controllers with vibrational feedback like those for the PS2 and the Xbox 360. This great wrong has been righted, however, with the Nyko 83009 Zero Wireless gamepad.

title: The Atlantic Hires Away Publisher of Wired
description: Jay Lauf, the successful publisher of Wired magazine, will leave Cond Nast Publications to become vice president and publisher of The Atlantic, the magazine announced on Wednesday.

title: The Builder Who Pushes Tokyo Into the Clouds
description: TOKYO  Minoru Mori, Japans most prolific developer, will finish one of the worlds tallest buildings in May. Many of his colleagues might consider the 101-story Shanghai World Financial Center the crowning achievement of a long career. But Mr. Mori has lots of plans for a 73-year-old.

title: Key Metropolitan Areas Growing, but More Slowly
description: Fewer people flocked to the nations fastest-growing metropolitan regions last year compared with the year before, the Census Bureau is reporting on Thursday.

title: Senators Seek Details About Bear Stearns Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Senior senators signaled their unease on Wednesday with the Federal Reserves shotgun marriage of JPMorgan Chase and Bear Stearns, demanding detailed information by next week about how the $30 billion deal was reached.

title: Regulating Oil Markets
description: To the Editor:

title: For Railyards, the Hard Part Is Still Ahead
description: With the announcement on Wednesday that officials had struck a tentative deal with Tishman Speyer Properties to develop a dozen residential and commercial towers over the windswept railyards on the Far West Side of Manhattan, Gov. David A. Paterson said that deal would send an enormous signal of confidence in New York Citys future.

title: Four Stars Bright Idea Still Shines 90 Years On
description: According to Hollywood lore the earth all but trembled that day in the spring of 1919, when four of the most popular figures in American movies  the director D. W. Griffith and the actors Charles Chaplin, Douglas Fairbanks and Mary Pickford  gathered to create their own distribution company.

title: Saving Zimbabwe
description: It has been painful to watch the terrible decline of Zimbabwe, a country so rich in human and natural resources. Perhaps that is why the elections scheduled for Saturday still raise hopes that President Robert Mugabes destructive rule can be brought to an end, despite the certainty that the vote will be neither free nor fair.

title: Law Enacted to Protect Tenants Using Vouchers
description: The City Council overrode on Wednesday the mayors veto of a bill to prohibit landlords from discriminating against tenants who intend to pay their rent with federal rent-subsidy vouchers or any other form of government assistance.

title: Youll Know How Much You Spent
description: TOMAS MAIER cultivates tenacity. If a tree in his garden doesnt thrive, he simply uproots it and replants. If a supermarket tomato is not tangy enough for his taste, he is apt to grow his own. People like myself cannot get happy, Mr. Maier mused last week as he sat in the courtyard below one of his namesake stores in Palm Beach, Fla. Im always looking for something that is not there.

title: A Lacrosse Face-Off
description: LACROSSE is one of the fastest-growing sports in the country, with the number of active players on organized teams growing to 480,627 in 2007 from 253,931 in 2001, according to the most recent survey by US Lacrosse, the sports national governing body. The largest percentage increase occurred at the high school level.

title: Kazakhstan: Court Sentences Presidents Former Son-in-Law
description: A closed military court sentenced in absentia Rakhat Aliyev, who was married to President Nursultan Nazarbayevs oldest daughter, Dariga, and lives in self-exile in Europe, to 20 years in prison on a variety of charges, including planning to overthrow the government.

title: Harvard Hires Wellesleys Investment Manager
description: Jane Mendillo has been appointed president and chief investment officer at the Harvard Management Company, which oversees the universitys $34.9 billion endowment, Harvard said Thursday.

title: Ford Reaches Deal to Sell Land Rover and Jaguar
description: NEW DELHI  Tata Motors, part of Indias fast-growing Tata Group, is buying Jaguar and Land Rover from the Ford Motor Company for $2.3 billion  about half what Ford paid for the brands when it bought them.

title: What the Heir Did With the Heirloom
description: LIKE many men, Ken Shepps is not much for jewelry. But like many men, he has fond memories of his grandfather. He remembers how, after his grandfather died, his gold watch chain and fob went to his mother (who took to wearing it as a necklace), and the pocket watch to his uncle.

title: Japanese Poetry Persists in Korea, Despite Disapproval
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Rhee Han-soo has spent a lifetime pursuing a passion that he refuses to discuss even with his closest friends.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Tuesday with a report in the World Business Briefing column about plans for Turkeys first nuclear power plant was published in error. The man shown is Turkeys president, Abdullah Gul  not its prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

title: Correction
description: An article on the Op-Ed page on Wednesday about John McCains relationship with the press imprecisely described an encounter he had had with Tim Russert, the host of Meet the Press. Mr. McCain did not give Mr. Russert an index card with a gotcha quote by Mitt Romney on Iraq; he displayed the card and read the quote himself on the show.

title: Recalling Forward Thinking at Western Kentucky
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ky.  With 20 N.C.A.A. tournament appearances, a Final Four berth and a spot among the top 10 in victories by a Division I program, Western Kentucky has an unusually strong rsum for a team regarded as a tournament darling.

title: American and Delta Ground More Than 200 Planes
description: American Airlines and Delta Air Lines said Wednesday that more than 200 of their planes might not comply with Federal Aviation Administration rules for securing wire bundles, and that they were taking the planes out of service for inspections.

title: Mayor Proposes That Police Run Trade Center Security
description: The Bloomberg administration is proposing that the Police Department, not the Port Authority, assume the main responsibility for securing the streets that will run through the new World Trade Center site and to control access to the complex once it is complete, city and state officials said.

title: Salmon Virus Indicts Chiles Fishing Methods
description: PUERTO MONTT, Chile  Looking out over the low green mountains jutting through miles of placid waterways here in southern Chile, it is hard to imagine that anything could be amiss. But beneath the rows of neatly laid netting around the fish farms just off the shore, the salmon are dying.

title: Kids  Broadway
description: To the Editor:

title: You Promised That Youd Forget Me Not, but You Forgot to Remember
description: In the midst of his improbably upbeat debut novel, Stefan Merrill Block tells the story of Lord Alban Mapplethorpe and his descendants. The Mapplethorpes came from Iddylwahl, England, a place that Mr. Merrill says is now long since wiped from map and memory alike. Lord Mapplethorpe was an exceptional man, not only for his many trysts but also for his inability to be secretive about these affairs. Precisely what is it that we must act as if never happened? he would ask his lady friends.

title: Oracles Profit Rises, but Shares Fall
description: The Oracle Corporation, the business software company, reported a 30 percent rise in quarterly profit on Wednesday, but a lower-than-expected increase in new software licenses caused shares to fall in after-hours trading.

title: Lively Eye on Old Berlin: Wonderful Life, Ja?
description: BERLIN  Onstage and in various exhibitions Berlin this year has been celebrating the 150th anniversary of the birth of Heinrich Zille.

title: New Orders for Goods Fall Sharply
description: Manufacturing orders dropped sharply in February, and sales of new homes fell to a 13-year low as falling prices seemed to do little to lure buyers.

title: Gotbaum Family Moving to Sue Over a Death Ruled an Accident
description: The family of Carol A. Gotbaum, the Manhattan woman whose death in police custody in the Phoenix airport last September drew national attention, has filed a notice of claim against the city of Phoenix, a requirement before filing a civil lawsuit.

title: Somalia: More Gains for Islamist Forces
description: Islamist fighters overpowered government troops and briefly seized a strategic town, the latest in a string of recent victories. According to residents, Islamist fighters stormed into the town, Jowhar, about 50 miles north of Mogadishu, the capital, and killed seven government soldiers. The Islamists freed several prisoners in the towns jail and seized weapons before withdrawing. Government officials said the fighters were connected to an Islamist movement that controlled much of Somalia in 2006 until it was driven out by Ethiopian troops backing Somalias transitional government.

title: State Moves Toward Deal on a Budget
description: ALBANY  With five days until the deadline for enacting a state budget, Gov. David A. Patersons support of congestion pricing has revived hopes for it in the capital, while Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silvers proposal to increase taxes on people making $1 million or more remains on the table.

title: Clank Away From the Charity Stripe
description: Nothing makes my father angrier than when one of our beloved Illinois Fighting Illini players misses a free throw. It just drives him nuts. Clunkers were a particularly prevalent problem for the Illini in this disappointing season, and point guard Chester Frazier was my father's most frequent target. "The guy is getting a free ride to college, to play basketball, and he can't make a free throw! And he's not even tall!"

title: Two-Part Plan on Recycling of Electronic Gear Passes
description: The City Council voted on Wednesday to establish one of the nations toughest recycling programs for electronic gear, employing an approach that lawmakers said would allow them to move forward with most of the plan while continuing to work through the most controversial elements.

title: Early Dazzle, Then Tough Path for a Governor
description: BOSTON  Gov. Deval Patrick has lately addressed doting crowds around the country as a surrogate for Senator Barack Obama of Illinois, his friend and fellow gifted orator. Last month, Mr. Obama even acknowledged borrowing language from Mr. Patricks stump speeches, casting a flattering light on a novice politician barely known outside Massachusetts.

title: A Place to Hang Her Hats
description: MIMI WEDDELL, model, actress and blithe spirit, is finally about to have her grand moment, as the subject of the documentary Hats Off, which opens Friday. As she is 93 and has been modeling on and off for decades, this is not an overnight success, but it is a tribute to her resilience.

title: Appeal Allows Lawsuits by Ground Zero Workers
description: A federal appeals courts ruling appears to have cleared the way for thousands of lawsuits filed against New York City and its contractors by ground zero workers to move closer to trial or settlement.

title: Profit and Public Good Clash in Grand Plans
description: The bitter battles over reconstruction plans for ground zero. The unraveling of the Atlantic Yards development in Brooklyn. And now this.

title: JetBlue Founder Starting Airline in Brazil
description: David Neeleman, who as founder of JetBlue Airways helped to redefine start-up carriers in the United States by using new jets and offering above-bargain-basement service, said Thursday that he would start a domestic airline in Brazil.

title: Tired of Juggling Remotes? Take Control With a Universal
description: WHEN Barry Gordon watches a DVD on his 10-foot diagonal-measurement home theater screen, hes not simply watching TV; hes watching a major production.

title: Court Orders Release of Ex-Governor From Prison
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.  The former governor of Alabama, Don Siegelman, was ordered Thursday to be released from prison on bond by a federal appeals court, pending his broader appeal in a bribery conviction last June.

title: How Not to Prevent Foreclosures
description: With foreclosures surging, the last thing the nation needs is another government-hosted meeting where mortgage lenders pledge once again to do their utmost to help distressed borrowers stay in their homes  and then go back to the business of foreclosure.

title: I Think This Song Is About Me
description: WITH everyone hunched over laptops the other day, typing away inside their respective cones of silence, the place looked more like a Starbucks than my kitchen.

title: Cocoa Mint Lip Balm
description: This formula for homemade lip balm is adapted from a recipe used by students in a Cosmetic Chemistry course, with adult supervision, at the Museum of Science in Boston.

title: You Might Move Out, but You Cant Move On
description: MARK SCHOENFELD and Scott Field have bought seven houses together since they met in 1994. We find something, put our stamp on it, then were ready to move on, said Mr. Schoenfeld, a senior vice president of the Corcoran Group, the New York real estate concern. He and Mr. Field, a broker at Elyse Harney Real Estate in New Preston, Conn., say they are addicted to the adventure and constant motion of the house hunt. But in 1996 they found a place for sale in Danbury, Conn., that stopped them cold.

title: United Artists Tribute: Series Highlights
description: THE PARTY AND A SHOT IN THE DARK Two great physical comedies (1968 and 1964) directed by Blake Edwards and starring the maddeningly gifted Peter Sellers. (Tuesday)

title: Developer Sues to Win $12.3 Billion in 9/11 Attack
description: Larry A. Silverstein, who has won nearly $4.6 billion in insurance payments to cover his losses and help him rebuild at the World Trade Center site, is seeking $12.3 billion in damages from airlines and airport security companies for the 9/11 attack.

title: Trumpeting a Move to Put the Sun in SunChips
description: MADISON AVENUE has always been a place for sun worshipers, whether it was naming brands like Sun, Sunlight, Sunbird, Sunbeam and Sol; coining slogans like A day with orange juice is like a day without sunshine; or sending the Coppertone girl and her dog out on the beach to urge, Dont be a paleface.

title: Imagined Snipers, Real Challenges
description: Heres some news for Hillary Clinton: the Bosnian war was over in 1996.

title: Obama, Clinton  and Echoes of Nader?
description: Yes, Hillary Rodham Clinton may still have a chance of winning the Democratic nomination. But its probably smaller than the chance that a continued slugfest will hand the White House to John McCain.

title: All Is Well: The Voice Is Coming Back
description: Baldwin, N.Y.

title: A Foolish Immigration Purge
description: Leave it to the Bush administration to throw thousands of law-abiding American workers and companies off a cliff in perilous economic times.

title: Fossils Link Pre-Humans in West Europe to Earlier Date
description: Excavations in a cave in the mountains of northern Spain have uncovered the oldest known remains of human ancestors in Western Europe, scientists reported Wednesday.

title: Phinney Pedals His Way to the Olympics
description: When Taylor Phinney, a 17-year-old high school senior from Boulder, Colo., was in second grade, he took his parents Olympic cycling medals to school for show and tell. Now, after finishing eighth in the track cycling world championships Wednesday, he may have a chance at winning an Olympic medal of his own.

title: Videotaping Could Influence Meeting
description: N.F.L. owners will discuss everything from head (a proposal to prohibit a players hair from covering the name and number on his jersey) to toe (a measure to allow instant replay review of field goals) at next weeks annual meeting in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Researchers Play Tune Recorded Before Edison
description: For more than a century, since he captured the spoken words Mary had a little lamb on a sheet of tinfoil, Thomas Edison has been considered the father of recorded sound. But researchers say they have unearthed a recording of the human voice, made by a little-known Frenchman, that predates Edisons invention of the phonograph by nearly two decades.

title: India Orders New Inquiry Into 2002 Clashes
description: NEW DELHI  The Indian Supreme Court has ordered fresh investigations into several high-profile cases of Hindu-Muslim violence in 2002 in Gujarat State, effectively concluding that justice cannot be done in the Hindu-dominated state.

title: Tales of Two Programs
description: Western Kentucky and Washington State are both underdogs in their games today, but the similarities between the two programs basically end there. Washington State, behind a tough defense, is making its first appearance in the Sweet 16. Western Kentucky, as The Times reports today, is steeped in college basketball history, "but memories of Western Kentucky's run of dominance in the 1960s seem to have faded with the set shot and canvas sneakers. In part, the run came about because of Western Kentucky's willingness to integrate its team at a time when such a policy was still taboo in the South. Those involved with Western Kentucky still take great pride in the university's breaking of racial barriers."

title: Take a Room. Fix It Up. Showpiece!
description: The democratization of taste continues with Myles of Style, a decorating show that began this month on HGTV. The host is Kim Myles, a bubbly self-taught designer who believes in empowerment. Unlock your imagination! is her catchphrase. Watch enough design shows, and you may decide that some imaginations should stay locked up, as should some homeowners.

title: 660 Held in Tibetan Uprising, China Says
description: SHANGHAI  China said Wednesday that 660 people implicated in Tibetan protests and riots in western China over the past two weeks had surrendered to the authorities.

title: Currents | Familiar Furniture, Moving Out of the Spotlight
description: Props for Today, a company that rents furniture for television and movie sets, is cleaning house. At its spring-cleaning sale, which starts Friday, many familiar (as well as obscure) pieces will be available to the public. The sale includes pieces of furniture seen on Saturday Night Live, All My Children, 30 Rock and Sex and the City (Jasper Morrisons Air Chair, above, will be $25). Furniture from movies like Michael Clayton will also be on sale (a glass-top end table used in that film will be $35). Through March 30 at Props for Today, 330 West 34th Street (Eighth Avenue), 14th Floor.

title: Agency Partners Appear at Hollywood Wiretap Trial
description: LOS ANGELES  Two top partners at the Creative Artists Agency made cameo appearances in the Hollywood wiretapping trial on Wednesday as prosecutors drew a link between Michael S. Ovitz, a founder of the agency, and illegal database checks by Anthony Pellicano, the private investigator on trial on charges of racketeering.

title: Keeping Time in iTunes
description: Q. Is there a way to get the beats per minute information for a song automatically filled in for iTunes tracks?

title: The Enlightened Age of Home Furnishings
description: Gustav Stickley: The Enlightened Home, an exhibit of early 20th-century furniture and decorative objects made at the Gustav Stickley Company, opens Tuesday at the Fenimore Art Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y.

title: Space Shuttle Completes 16-Day Mission, and Lands
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla.  The space shuttle Endeavour returned safely to Earth on Wednesday evening, completing a record-breaking 16-day mission to the International Space Station.

title: YouTube Feature Tells Video Creators When and Where a Clip Is Being Watched
description: In a move to provide better data to its users, YouTube formally announced late Wednesday that it had added a free feature that will show video creators when and where viewers are watching their videos. With this, the company hopes to turn YouTube from an online video site into a place where marketers can test their messages, Tracy Chan, YouTube product manager, said.

title: Rent Gets a New Lease on Life
description: Quick lesson in how to do business on Broadway: Say you have a popular show nearing the end of its run. First announce a closing date, perhaps the beginning of June. Then stand back and watch. If ticket buyers go nuts: Oh, did I say June? No, no, that was a suggestion.

title: A One-Stop Site Offers All the Photo Functions, From Posting Online to Red-Eye Removal
description: Flickr and Facebook allow you to share photos online, and desktop programs like Picasa, iPhoto and Photoshop Elements let you make the pictures look good before you upload. But starting today with its new Photoshop Express site, Adobe is putting the two together.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption with the Advertising column on Tuesday misidentified, in some editions, the television network that is promoting the return of its scripted comedy shows with a campaign featuring the theme song from Welcome Back, Kotter. It is NBC, not CBS.

title: Glory Days Is Bound for Broadway
description: Coming in as a last-minute addition to the already eclectic lineup of musicals on Broadway this season, Glory Days, a show about four high school friends that had its premiere this year at the Signature Theater in Arlington, Va., is moving to the Circle in the Square Theater. Previews begin on April 22, with an opening scheduled for May 6. The musical, directed by Signatures artistic director, Eric Schaeffer, was written by Nick Blaemire and James Gardiner, who are each, gulp, 23. (Mr. Blaemire is currently in the ensemble of another Broadway show, Cry-Baby). The four-person cast of the Signature production is making the transfer intact.

title: Oracle Sales Fall Short, but Profit Is Up 30%
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Oracle, the business software company, reported a 30 percent rise in quarterly profit on Wednesday, but a lower-than-expected increase in sales raised investor concern that a troubled economy could take its toll on technology spending.

title: McCain, in Foreign Policy Talk, Turns His Back on Unilateralism
description: LOS ANGELESIn a wide-ranging speech on foreign policy, Senator John McCain sought Wednesday to distance himself from the unilateralism that has been a hallmark of the Bush administration, saying Americans must, in the words of the Declaration of Independence, show decent respect to the opinions of mankind.

title: Alaska Suit Against Lilly Is Settled
description: The prospect of a pending Supreme Court case that could sweep away many lawsuits against drug companies loomed over Alaskas decision to settle the states suit against Eli Lilly over the schizophrenia drug Zyprexa, lawyers for Lilly and the state said Wednesday.

title: Indecision Cloaks Route of Olympic Torch
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Olympic torch is coming to San Francisco. Exactly where is another question.

title: 6 Banks Are Sued in Clear Channel Deal
description: The buyers of Clear Channel Communications received a curious e-mail message last July from Credit Suisse, one of the banks financing the radio broadcasters sale. But it was misdirected and not meant for their eyes.

title: McCain and Mortgages
description: To the Editor:

title: $2 Million Bail Set for Woman in Brothel Case
description: A prosecutor accused a Manhattan woman on Wednesday of controlling a ring of several dozen high-priced prostitutes and said that she tried to dismantle the operation when she sensed the authorities closing in.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: A listing of credits on Wednesday with a theater review of The Four of Us, presented by the Manhattan Theater Club at City Center, misspelled the given name of the companys artistic director. She is Lynne Meadow, not Lynn.

title: Putin Invites Bush to Confer in Move to Avoid Public Clash
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush announced Wednesday that he had accepted an invitation by President Vladimir V. Putin to visit Russia next week, signaling an effort to avoid a public clash over NATO and missile defenses when Mr. Bush travels to Europe next week.

title: Exotica of Brazil in Motion
description: For those who would like a virtual trip to Brazil, Grupo Corpo offers a safe adventure. Its the exotic as tourist package: the undulating torsos and rhythmic stamping footwork that connote an African heritage, and the stretched, balletic limbs and light, airborne jumps of the European colonizers. And all set to pulsating music, performed by virtuoso dancers who seamlessly integrate these disparate influences into their ever-malleable, apparently tireless bodies.

title: Renewing Appeals for Slain Officers Benefits
description: The federal governments decision to deny death benefits to the families of two auxiliary police officers killed a year ago by a gunman in Greenwich Village provoked a fresh round of appeals on Wednesday. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly testified at a United States Department of Justice hearing in Manhattan and Senator Charles E. Schumer called Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey and asked him to intervene.

title: A Bit Premature?
description: The Boston Red Sox and Oakland As kicked off the baseball season in Japan on Tuesday, nearly a week before other Major League teams played their first games. Has that game taken something away from the splendor of Opening Day?

title: Oscar Claim Rejected
description: No Oscar for Bob Yari. That was the decision by the Second District Court of Appeal in California, which decided that Mr. Yari, below, was not entitled to a statuette even though he was one of the six credited producers of the 2005 film Crash, winner of the Academy Award for best film, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Yari sued after the Producers Guild of America and the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences named only two people as producers for purposes of Oscar credit. He contended that the snub damaged his reputation, but the appeals court ruled that private organizations can make their own decisions about their awards. Mr. Yari called the decision unfortunate. Bruce Davis, executive director of the academy, said it was nice to be assured that the courts dont want to be in the business of deciding who wins an Academy Award.

title: Tate Britain to Send 100 Turners to Moscow
description: A Russian billionaire is bankrolling an exhibition that will send about 100 paintings by J. M. W. Turner to the Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow from Tate Britain in London in November, Reuters reported. The show will be the first Turner exhibition in Russia since 1975. The generations have changed since Turner was last in Moscow, and its important that the young see him, said Zinaida Bonami, deputy director of the Pushkin. The man behind the deal is the Russian metals magnate Alisher Usmanov, ranked 142nd last year on the Forbes list of the worlds wealthiest people.

title: A Towel Exchange
description: Few folks in the U.S. Airways Arena on Wednesday could come up with first-hand recollections of the former Western Kentucky coach E.A. Diddle. But the CBS announcer Bill Raftery spun a few yarns about the Diddle, who is still among the top 20 in career victories (759) for mens coaches.

title: Players to Watch in M.L.S.

Of the 24 new players in the league, 19 are from South or Central America, where coaches and general managers can find players with more flair and better skills than most homegrown players offer.

This week, Kaku talks about three long dreamt-of technologies that he categorizes as class I, class II and class III impossibilities  in other words, things youll simply never see during your time on earth. title: Recipe of the Day: Streamlined Cassoulet
description: Authentic cassoulet from southern France contains beans, braised mutton, sausage, confit of goose or duck and maybe a slab of bacon, all stewed together so the flavors meld. The idea of preparing it in 40 minutes or less is heresy, but I was determined to find a reasonable compromise when, a few years ago, I realized I would be unable to schedule the usual three-day production to serve to friends.

title: Sudden Drama at the Window, With Workmen Dangling
description: It sounded like an explosion just outside the bedroom windows, eight floors up, and suddenly the air-conditioner was wrenched out of its sockets. I pulled up the blackout shades  rarely opened, but curtains raised now on an extraordinary urban drama  and saw the aluminum scaffold that workmen had been using for weeks to point the facade. The scaffold had collapsed on one side, and was tilted crazily at a 45-degree angle, the left (lower) end just outside our windows, resting on the shattered air-conditioner, and the right end somewhere out of sight, up on the ninth or tenth floor. At either end of the platform, workmen dangled perilously, both of them cradled in yellow safety harnesses, but helpless and hanging on ropes anchored to the parapet on the 17th floor.

title: Are You Taking Advantage of Web 2.0?

The train that derailed was the 9:35 a.m. from Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, scheduled to arrive at Hempstead at 10:28 a.m. A second train, the 9:34 a.m. from Penn Station to Huntington, was hit by the derailed train. About 20 minor injuries were reported. WNBC has video.

This was a particularly prevalent offense for the Illini in this disappointing season, and point guard Chester Frazier was my fathers most frequent target. The guy is getting a free ride to college, to play basketball, and he cant make a free throw! And hes not even tall!

title: Krazy Glue Moments
description: Why do some political missteps haunt their candidates forever, while others are easily put to rest? John Kerry saying he voted for the war funding before he voted against it, or Howard Dean screeching on a stage in Iowa, instantly becomes the stuff of political history, but when George W. Bush admits that he was once arrested for driving under the influence, it immediately fades into obscurity. Some politicians, as they used to say of Ronald Reagan, seem coated in Teflon, while others seem covered in Krazy Glue, unable to shake the stickiness of what seem like minor embarrassments.Heres a political postulate for you: whether or not a bad moment sticks to the candidate depends on how closely related it is to the core rationale of that candidate or his opponent. In other words, if your gaffe goes directly to the main argument you are trying to make about yourself with the electorate, or if it substantiates the most relevant thing that your rival would have us believe about you, then it has the potential to become a serious problem. If, on the other hand, you do something completely idiotic that is tangential to what voters most hope or fear about you, then you tend to get a pass. So Mr. Kerrys choice of wording hurt because it played into the main theme that the Republicans had chosen to discredit himthe notion that he wanted to have everything both ways. By contrast, Mr. Bushs brush with the law had nothing to do with the story he was telling about himself as a competent manager, nor did it underscore the central argument that Democrats were advancing about him (because, really, there wasnt one).

So the news that Polian has signed a contract extension that will keep him in Indianapolis through 2011 is very good news for Colts fans.

title: New York State Lost Jobs in February
description: The number of jobs in New York State dipped in February, signaling that the state may be following the nation into a recession. According to the state Department of Labor, employment in New York, adjusted for seasonal fluctuations, declined by 0.1 percent last month to 7.27 million jobs. That was the first decline from one month to the next since last summer and it came as economists watched for signs that turmoil in the financial markets may have halted a four-and-a-half-year expansion fueled by a boom in New York City.

title: Court Finds City Was Negligent in S.I. Ferry Crash
description: Updated, 3:40 p.m. | A federal appeals court on Thursday found that New York City was negligent for the deadly crash of a Staten Island ferry in 2003 and cannot have its liability limited. The ruling is a major victory for dozens of plaintiffs who have sued the city, including relatives of some of the 11 people killed in the crash of the ferry, the Andrew J. Barberi.

title: Scent Notes | Fuel for Life Pour Femme by Diesel
description: Diesel puts great stock in weirdness  a calculated, carefully-designed meticulously-crafted weirdness. Its new fragrance, Fuel for Life Pour Femme, smells like canned fruit compote. The smell is canned because its vaguely metallic. Fruit because its fruity in the way that Juicyfruit gum is fruity. I use the word compote because there is absolutely no recognizable fruit species here; not even the hybridized tangelo comes close. But remember, the actual smell is incidental in a perfume like this; its purpose is not to be beautiful, but to be a scent marker, identifying its wearer as part of a tribe, a sort of olfactory cattle brand.

I think Mayor Bloombergs proposal for congestion pricing is a thoughtful and innovative approach to the problem, Mr. Obama told Bob Hennelly of WNYC, in an interview that is scheduled to be broadcast during National Public Radios All Things Considered at 4 p.m. Mr. Obama said that revenue from congestion pricing should not replace federal financing for mass transit, WNYC said in a statement describing the interview.Following is an excerpt from the WNYC transcript of the interview by Mr. Hennelly.

title: A Lockdown, Then Relief, at a Brooklyn School

The student then picked up the gun and ran from the classroom, the police said.Within minutes, police had surrounded the school and kept students inside the building, but several students had already left before the police arrived. After searching the school for more than two hours, the police were unable to find the student with the gun.

But on Thursday, the Clinton campaign used its daily conference call to remind reporters that it has been a two-way battle, and that the Obama campaign has not been tactically pure.

title: A Star in the Making
description: Connor Ennis and Bryan Curtis from Play magazine discuss Stephen Curry's scoring, Wisconsin's defense and the round of 16.

title: Girls Soft Serve | A Hand Dryer Faster Than Your Porsche, W in Fisherman Pants, Nail Polish Gone Wild
