description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: Ground Zero Memorial Assumes a Concrete Form
description: A $103.9 million concrete contract, the largest single construction contract for the National September 11 Memorial and Museum at the World Trade Center, was awarded Thursday to a company in Long Island City, Queens, that has not yet performed work at ground zero.The Queens company, Navillus Contracting, together with Bovis Lend Lease, which is heavily involved at the trade center site, won the contract from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. It covers 36,000 cubic yards of concrete to build slabs, decks, walls and the enclosures of the waterfalls and pools that will mark the site of the twin towers, and 9,000 cubic yards of concrete for adjacent underground areas.

title: Obama Details Economic Proposals
description: CNBC interviews presidential candidate Barack Obama about his economic proposals

title: Obama Details Economic Proposals
description: CNBC interviews presidential candidate Barack Obama about his economic proposals

title: Cloverbucks
description: Ever since Starbucks announced last week that it had bought Coffee Equipment Company, which makes the Clover  a new fangled machine that brews one cup of drip coffee at a time  the online coffee forums and blogs have been afire with chatter about the sale and its implications for those in the coffee world who dont wear green aprons.

title: Pelosi Letter Writers Are Mega-Million $ Donors
description: This shouldnt surprise anyone who reviewed the names on that oh-so-close-to-a-threat letter sent by the mega-donors who were asking House Speaker Nancy Pelosi to change her tune a bit on the role of superdelegates weighing in on the Democratic nomination.

title: Who Your 2008 Mets May Be
description: For all of you wishing to know the 25 men who will constitute the opening day roster, sit tight. The Mets will pare down the 41 players remaining in camp to a more manageable number tonight, but the major decisions will not be announced until Saturday in Memphis, according to Willie Randolph.

title: Obama-Bloomberg Speculation Takes Off After Joint Appearance
description: It was only hours after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg finally made it clear he was not running for president that his chief political guru, Kevin Sheekey, publicly floated the notion that he would be the perfect running mate for Senator Barack Obama.

title: Blogtalk: The Bloomberg Buzz
description: The buzz at The Cooper Union this morning was less about what Barack Obama would say about Wall Street and more about whether Mr. Obamas warm-up act, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York, would endorse his former breakfast buddy.

title: In U.S., a Stronger Order to Learn English
description: Just the other day, a Russian governor ordered his underlings to learn another language, English. The officials will have to take an exam to show their proficiency, Peter Piatetsky wrote, And keep taking it, until they pass.

title: Bradley and Carr Reminisce
description: Davidsons Stephen Curry has caught the imagination of college basketball fans around the country with his performance through the first two rounds of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Co-Heads of Citis Prime Brokerage Leave in Shake-Up
description: From Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague:

title: One Class
His Name Is Zucker
description: While the networks have been using all sorts of feel-good euphemisms to tease the return of their scripted series after the writers strike, the chief executive of NBC Universal is about to give viewers some straight talk.

title: Davidsons Free Ride
description: DETROIT  It is a good time to be a Davidson student.

title: What Happened to the Stars?
description: If youre wondering what happened to the Dallas Stars, check here as co-GM Les Jackson answers questions from readers of The Dallas Morning News. Among other things, he says the light schedule for March has thrown off their game after a hectic (and highly successful) February. He also says a slump can help focus attention on what the team needs to build on for the playoffs. So a 3-7-0 run is  a good thing?

title: Bentleys Green Car Manifesto
description: Which is the greenest car company at the 2008 New York auto show?

title: Another Taiwan Special?
description: When West Virginias Joe Alexander dunked on Connecticuts Stanley Robinson in the Big East tournament two weeks ago, ESPNs Bill Raftery called it a Taiwan Special.

title: A Few Free Throws Among Friends
description: HOUSTON  Prior to his Thursday news conference, Texas Coach Rick Barnes was talking to several members of the news media when Memphis Coach John Calipari happened to walk by.

title: No Recession at Red Hat
description: Red Hat, the Linux software company, gave a nice welcome present Thursday to its new chief executive, James Whitehurst.

title: Off the Tourist Track in Ljubljana
description: My husband and I have booked a guided adventure trip in Croatia from the end of May to the beginning of June and are considering a few days in Ljubljana. Can you suggest any must-sees for two travelers who dont do sights and museums? And Im wondering about the weather this time of year.

title: Backyard Brawl
description: HOUSTON  Growing up in New Orleans, the Texas sophomore point guard D.J. Augustin honed his skills in his backyard in one-on-one matchups with the former Oklahoma guard Hollis Price that are now part of local lore.

title: Hillary Clinton and Health Care
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton discussed with The Times's Kevin Sack what her approach to health insurance would be if she were elected president.

title: Raymond From Nowhere
description: PHOENIX  Sometimes the best kind of March stars are the unexpected kind.

title: My New Neighbor
description: PHOENIX  After filing a game story from Xaviers overtime thriller against West Virignia I came back to press row to find the Musketeers Coach Sean Miller in the seat next to me.

title: Black and White Magic
description: Catemaco, Mexico, is a booming destination for people seeking the service of witches.

title: Sing! in London
description: Anyone with an unfulfilled desire to sing might be interested in an upcoming festival at Londons Southbank Centre. Chorus, devoted to choral singing and the human voice, runs from May 11th  18th and offers opportunities for both participation and listening.

title: Tracking an Assassin
description: Any film that dares attempt a nonjudgmental portrait of Mark David Chapman, John Lennons assassin, would most likely be accused of tastelessness, but in the case of Chapter 27  a drama based on Jack Joness book Let Me Take You Down  the charges are justified.

title: China Law Could Impede Microsoft Deal for Yahoo
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Microsofts hostile-takeover attempt against Yahoo may encounter an unexpected hurdle in August after a Chinese antimonopoly law takes effect that will extend the nations economic influence far beyond its borders.

title: Contemporary Chinese on Sale in Hong Kong
description: CONTEMPORARY CHINESE

title: Guatemala as Muse and Base for a Writer
description: TO reach her favorite place in the world, Joyce Maynard flies for five hours from San Francisco, near her main home in Mill Valley, Calif. Then she is jostled for two and a half hours in a hired minivan over dusty two-lane roads beset by construction delays and clogged by buses spewing fumes. Finally, she boards a launch for a 45-minute ride to the tiny dock near her casa.

title: Game Put on a Pedestal for Teams at Ford Field
description: DETROIT  Scottie Reynolds of Villanova looked around the unusual configuration for a basketball game at Ford Field and asked a reasonable question about the court, which is raised 27 inches above the football field, almost like a boxing ring.

title: Britain: Hiccups at New Air Terminal
description: After weeks of advance hoopla trumpeting the opening of Londons Heathrow Airport new, high-tech Terminal 5, the facility opened in something less than glory. Initially, British Airways, which has sole use of the $8.7 billion terminal, boasted to customers that everything has been streamlined and designed to make your journey through the terminal calm and relaxed. But after a series of baggage delays in the morning, the airline canceled 34 flights and suspended baggage check-in. By late afternoon, the airline acknowledged that the opening day had been marred by problems with car parking provision, delays in staff security screening and baggage performance issues.

title: Glavine Says He Retains Emotional Bond With the Mets
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  Tom Glavine had just finished answering questions about his new team, the Atlanta Braves, when he started asking some about his old one, the Mets: How serious is Moises Alous injury? Is David Wright inundated with interview requests? Whats going on with Scott Schoeneweis?

title: Putting Faces on 5 Victims of Tibetan Riots
description: SHANGHAI  In life, the five young women who burned to death in a Chinese clothing store during rioting in Tibet on March 14 were not the types who would make headlines.

title: The Rangers Go 7 for 7 Against the Devils
description: For all the dramatic twists and turns in the Rangers game Thursday night against the Devils  and there were many, starting with Scott Gomezs gutsy return to the lineup  the outcome hung on a replay of one of the weirdest goals of the Rangers season.

title: On and Off the Utah Slopes, Over the Top
description: IT started with the cheesecake. We were at the cafeteria in Earls Lodge, a sumptuous timber building at the bottom of the Snowbasin ski resort in Utah, meaning to grab a latte and some muffins before heading up the mountain. But as we approached the counter, my husbands eyes grew wide.

title: An Abuse of Power in the Immigration Service
description: To the Editor:

title: He Could Be Cranky, but He Was Her Neighbor
description: When the fire marshal wanted a layout of the third-floor apartment that caught fire early Monday in the Bronx, Michelle Wilson could describe every corner of it for him in cinematic detail.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article last Friday about the difference between the Dalai Lamas stance on Tibet and the more aggressive position of some of the younger exiles misstated his followers beliefs about his reincarnation. They regard the Dalai Lama as the reincarnation of Avalokitesvara, the Buddha of Compassion  not the Buddha himself. The article also referred incorrectly to Samdhong Rinpoche, prime minister of the Tibetan government in exile. Rinpoche is an honorary title given to a monk; the prime minister is not known as Mr. Rinpoche.

title: Leadership of Kirov in Question
description: Uncertainty swirled around the leadership of the Kirov Ballet of the Maryinsky Theater of St. Petersburg, Russia, on Thursday, five days before it was due to arrive for a three-week residency at City Center in New York. The Kirovs director, Makhar Vaziev, has given conflicting signals about whether he was leaving the company, saying as recently as Wednesday night that he was retiring, said Sergei Danilian, the companys promoter in New York. One day hes in; one day hes out, Mr. Danilian said. The Maryinskys overall director, the conductor Valery Gergiev, said in an interview that he fully expected to Mr. Vaziev to come to New York. He acknowledged Mr. Vaziev was not totally happy, and he said Mr. Vaziev told him he would discuss retiring this summer, once the busy Kirov season is over. Mr. Vaziev, who has led the company since 1995, could not be reached for comment.

title: TBS Picks Announcers
description: TBS announced yesterday that Ron Darling and Buck Martinez would be the analysts for its first season of Sunday afternoon broadcasts that are to begin on April 6 with Boston playing Toronto. Each will work separately with Chip Caray, the play-by-play announcer, and Darlings appearances will not conflict with his schedule as a Mets game and studio analyst for SportsNet New York.

title: Monks Protest During Press Tour of China
description: SHANGHAI  Weeping and yelling, Tibet is not free, a group of red-robed monks on Thursday disrupted a carefully scripted tour for foreign journalists in Lhasa, Tibets capital, as Chinese officials tried to portray the recent Tibetan riots as the work of thugs and separatists.

title: Two New Prizes for Playwrights
description: The board of the Harold and Mimi Steinberg Charitable Trust announced on Thursday the creation of two theater awards for American playwrights. The first, to be given later this year and every other year afterward, will go to a midcareer American playwright who has received recognition for his work. That award comes with a cash prize of $200,000, making it among the largest ever given in the American theater. The second award, to be given in 2009 and every other year after that, will go to two playwrights in the early stages of their careers. That award comes with $50,000 for each honoree. Among those on the advisory committee nominating playwrights and selecting the winners are Andr Bishop, the artistic director of Lincoln Center Theater; Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater; and Martha Lavey, the artistic director of the Steppenwolf Theater Company of Chicago.

title: Taxi! Directly to the Jail. Or to a Nearby Hospital. Dont Forget the Award.
description: It was 5 oclock on an early autumn morning last year, and Adil Aboussalham, 31, a cab driver from Astoria, Queens, was nearing the end of his shift. Suddenly, on First Avenue near 11th Street in Manhattan, a frenzied man hailed his yellow cab, jumped in and yelled, Go, go, go!

title: Our Story Begins
description: Bullet in the Brain

title: Turning to a Turnaround Pro
description: DETROIT  If General Motors were to design a president and chief operating officer from scratch, the new model would probably look a lot like Frederick A. Henderson.

title: Giants and Redskins Will Open the N.F.L. Season
description: The Giants are expected to begin the defense of their Super Bowl championship at Giants Stadium against the Washington Redskins on Thursday, Sept. 4.

title: Study Ties Genetic Variations to Schizophrenia
description: A new study has found that rare and previously undetectable genetic variations may significantly increase the risk that a person will develop schizophrenia.

title: Harvards $34.9 Billion Endowment Makes Its Choice for New Chief
description: The Harvard Management Company, which oversees the universitys $34.9 billion endowment, appointed Jane Mendillo, the chief investment officer at Wellesley College, as its president and chief executive on Thursday.

title: Art Aragon Dies at 80; Was One of the Rings Golden Boys
description: Art Aragon, the lightweight and welterweight boxing contender of the 1950s known as Golden Boy for his flamboyant ring presence and love for the Hollywood life, died Tuesday in Northridge, Calif. He was 80.

title: Five Amateurs Picked to Take on U.S. Open Course
description: When reality seeps in, when the fairway narrows to the width of a French Quarter alley as the United States Golf Association official on the first tee intones, Play away, please, how will an amateur golfer respond?

title: Allman Brothers Band Revises Tour Schedule
description: The Allman Brothers Band announced on Thursday the postponement of its annual 15-show engagement at the Beacon Theater in Manhattan, scheduled for May 5 to 24. New dates are to be announced, and tickets will be honored at the rescheduled concerts. The band canceled its performances as host of the annual Wanee Festival in Live Oak, Fla., although the festival will continue as scheduled on April 11 and 12. For six months Gregg Allman, a founding member of the band, has been treated for hepatitis C, and the announcement said the treatment has so far been successful.

title: Seoul Says North Hurts Only Itself in Expulsions
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea said Thursday that it was deeply regrettable that North Korea had ordered South Korean officials to leave its territory, but that the South was undaunted.

title: Corrections: Monet Meets the Colt .45 in Hartford
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about Hartford and its attractions misstated the type of aircraft included in the collection at the New England Air Museum. It is the F-14 Tomcat, not the F-4 Tomcat.

title: Leaf-Dappled Light of Frances Yesteryears
description: WASHINGTON  On first encounter In the Forest of Fontainebleau: Painters and Photographers From Corot to Monet at the National Gallery of Art seems to be aimed at a narrow audience. The demographic might include, say, ecotourists, early-photography buffs and scholars of French landscape painting just before the shimmering light of Impressionism switched on.

title: Stern Sees Light at End of Knicks Tunnel
description: Donnie Walsh will probably be running the Knicks soon. And N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern is optimistic about the Knicks. But Stern insists the two things are not necessarily related.

title: 5 Enter Open Challenge
description: Five finalists for the Golf Digest United States Open Challenge were named Thursday, selected from 56,374 entries. The winning finalist will play Torrey Pines Golf Course in San Diego, the site of the 2008 United States Open, on the Friday before the first round of the championship. An hourlong show documenting the round will be broadcast June 15, as a lead-in to NBCs live coverage of the final round. The winner will be determined by online ballots cast March 28 to April 30 by voters 18 or older at gdopencontest.com.

title: New Japanese Jet Gets Its First Buyer
description: PARIS  All Nippon Airways of Japan said Thursday that it had placed an order for regional jets made by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, becoming the first customer for what could be the first new Japanese aircraft in a generation.

title: Tips for Surviving in Antarctica
With Assist From Greed, Money Makes the Man
description: Greed is good and comes without a hint of conscience in 21, a feature-length bore about some smarty-pants who take Vegas for a ride. Loosely based on the nonfiction book Bringing Down the House by Ben Mezrich, and adapted for the screen by Peter Steinfeld and Allan Loeb, this bankrupt enterprise asks you to care about a whiny M.I.T. moppet, Ben Campbell (Jim Sturgess, serviceable), who because he cant afford Harvard Medical School (boo hoo), starts counting cards to rake in some serious cash.

title: Finding of Fraud Led to Suspension of Company Supplying Arms to Afghanistan
description: When the United States Army decided this week to suspend the main supplier of munitions to Afghan security forces from future federal work, it did so after a field investigation documented what it called an act of fraud.

title: Fox's 'Idol' and 'Truth' Pile Up Numbers
description: No other network came close to catching Fox in the ratings on Wednesday, as 25.4 million viewers tuned in for the results edition of American Idol, Nielsen reported. The 9 p.m. episode, which included the elimination of 22-year-old Chikezie, left, came after Foxs game show The Moment of Truth led the 8 oclock time slot with 10 million viewers. The two programs were Wednesdays highest-rated, with NBCs "Law & Order" repeat at 10 trailing in third with 8.1 million viewers. NBC tied CBS for a distant second place on the night. CBS broadcast reruns of Criminal Minds at 9 (6.9 million viewers) and CSI: NY at 10 (7.5 million) following Big Brother at 8 (6 million). ABC, despite a fourth-place finish in total viewers, edged past CBS and NBC for second place among adults ages 18 to 49.

title: Palestinians Fear Two-Tier Road System
description: BEIT SIRA, West Bank  Ali Abu Safia, mayor of this Palestinian village, steers his car up one potholed road, then another, finding each exit blocked by huge concrete chunks placed there by the Israeli Army. On a sleek highway 100 yards away, Israeli cars whiz by.

title: Newspaper Says Article on Rapper Was False
description: A reporting coup has turned into an embarrassment for The Los Angeles Times, which acknowledged on Thursday that it had relied on apparently forged documents for its investigation into an assault on the rapper Tupac Shakur in 1994.

title: Celebrating Masculine Immaturity
description: Only in America are adult men who refuse to grow up considered cute rather than developmentally disabled, and only in American movies is masculine immaturity celebrated with such regularity. This trend continues with Backseat, a road movie whose flailing, 30-something protagonists, while not exactly 40-year-old virgins, can have avoided that fate only by the tender mercies of women with abysmally low expectations.

title: U.S. Issues Indictment of Governor in Puerto Rico
description: Gov. Anbal Acevedo Vil of Puerto Rico, charged in a federal indictment unsealed on Thursday with campaign finance violations, denied any wrongdoing and vowed to remain in office and fight the charges.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Thursday about the mortgage crisis misstated Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons position on bankruptcy reform. She has endorsed proposals that would allow troubled home buyers to have their mortgages modified in court.

title: Obama to Begin Push in Pennsylvania in Hope of Offsetting Clinton Advantages
description: PHILADELPHIA  When he steps aboard a campaign bus in Pittsburgh on Friday, Senator Barack Obama begins a six-day journey across Pennsylvania and its complex political landscape, one that is largely favorable to his rival, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Rapper Pleads Guilty to Gun Charges
description: The Grammy Award-winning rapper T. I., below, pleaded guilty in federal court on Thursday to three charges of illegally possessing weapons, reversing his plea of not guilty, Reuters reported, citing Atlanta news media. He could face up to 10 years in prison for each charge, the United States Attorneys Office said at the time of his arrest. He will be sentenced later. Agents of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives arrested T. I., whose real name is Clifford Harris, in October after a sting operation as he took delivery of three machine guns and two silencers that had been bought on his behalf. T. I., 27, was convicted of a drug offense in 1998 and is barred from owning or buying firearms. The Atlanta Journal-Constitution said he would probably do extensive community service and only one year in prison under his deal.

title: Sense and Insensitivity in Pakistan
description: Since winning parliamentary elections last month, the leaders of Pakistans new coalition government have shown good judgment: putting aside destructive personal rivalries and moving quickly to revive their countrys moribund democracy.

title: Massachusetts Subpoenas 3 Banks
description: Massachusetts has subpoenaed three big investment banks to determine whether investors were properly informed of the risks of auction-rate securities, a state official said Friday.

title: Back From Iraq, on a Road Going Nowhere
description: Stop-Loss, Kimberly Peirces long-awaited follow-up to Boys Dont Cry, arrives in theaters in the wake of some dispiriting milestones. We have just marked the fifth anniversary of the United States-led invasion of Iraq and the 4,000th American military death since the war began. The level of violence appears to be creeping up again, and troop levels are likely to stay where they are, at least until the next presidents inauguration.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: International

title: Funny, You Dont Look Like a Subject for Warhol
description: What was Andy Warhol thinking? In 1980, when his critical reputation was at a low ebb, he produced Ten Portraits of Jews of the 20th Century. The series of 40-inch-square silk-screened canvases appeared at the Jewish Museum that year, and critics hated it. A reviewer for The Philadelphia Inquirer called it Jewploitation. The Village Voice critic said it was hypocritical, cynical and exploitative. Hilton Kramer of The New York Times wrote, The way it exploits its Jewish subjects without showing the slightest grasp of their significance is offensive  or would be, anyway, if the artist had not already treated so many non-Jewish subjects in the same tawdry manner.

title: A New Name on a Special Day for Steinbrenner
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Every Yankees player was perched on the dugout steps before Thursdays game in a show of respect for the principal owner, George Steinbrenner, on the day the team broke camp.

title: Nonstop Talk Raises Volume on SNY Shows
description: If Ralph Kramden were watching SportsNet New York this week, he would utter one word: Blabbermouths. Theyre blabbermouths, Norton. Blabbermouths!

title: Agency Yields to Concerns of Flood-Weary Missourians
description: ST. LOUIS  Heeding concerns of flood-weary Missourians, the Army Corps of Engineers announced Thursday that it would counteract the release of millions of gallons of water into the Missouri River.

title: Travelers in Search of Mexicos Magic Find Town of Witches and Warlocks
description: CATEMACO, Mexico  To kill a man, Alejandro Gallegos Garca explains, all you need is a black cloth doll, some thread, a human bone and a toad. Oh, and you must ask the devil permission, in person, at a cave in the hills where he is said to appear.

title: Hip-Hop Star Remy Ma Convicted in 07 Shooting
description: It was a case of betrayal by a member of her entourage, Remy Smiths lawyer told the jury. They swam in her pool, borrowed her free designer clothes, used her fame as a hip-hop artist to promote their own music.

title: Judge Limits Trial Tactics Against Drug Executive
description: Three years after he was indicted on charges that he misled investors by manipulating inventory at Bristol-Myers Squibb, the companys former chief financial officer, Frederick S. Schiff, was to go on trial this week.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Reclaiming Space on the Waters Edge
description: ABOUT 160 miles separate the town of Warren, Pa., from the big city of Pittsburgh, but the two places have something powerful in common: the Allegheny River, a scenic waterway that meanders for 325 miles after rising near Coudersport in northern Pennsylvania.

title: Hillary Clinton Is No Ralph Nader, and Other Musings
description: To the Editor:

title: For Americans, a Bit of the Swagger Is Gone
description: Americas self-confidence is on the wane.

title: A City Left Behind, but Still Inspired
description: HOUSTON  D. J. Augustin had seen the video and the photographs of the destruction that Hurricane Katrina had caused to his home in New Orleans.

title: My Brother, My Rival: Those Ties That Bind and Chafe
description: In Italian movies social conflict  class struggle, ideological warfare, political contention, you name it  is often expressed through sibling rivalry. If the nation can be imagined as an unruly, dysfunctional family, then the most fitting symbol of its internal crises must surely be bickering brothers, Romulus scrapping with Remus.

title: House Panel to Examine Afghan Arms Contract
description: WASHINGTON  The House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform will investigate the award of a federal contract for nearly $300 million to provide ammunition for Afghanistan army and police units, the panels chairman said Thursday.

title: Who Does This Playwright Think He Is? Hemingway?
description: Beneath the image of the ice-in-the-veins alpha male that Ernest Hemingway cultivated in his novels, there always lurked a romantic. In The Fifth Column, Hemingways play about love and espionage in the Spanish Civil War, now being presented by the Mint Theater Company, the tough guy with a heart of gold is center stage.

title: After Years of Neglect, Rebirth for a Blues Singers House
description: COLUMBUS, Ga.  She danced the black bottom, doled out world-weary advice and claimed to be ready with a butcher knife if she caught her lover straying. She was a whiskey-slugging contralto with raunchy songs, a sound business sense and bisexual tastes.

title: Study Hints of Gene Link to Risk of Schizophrenia
description: A new study has found that rare and previously undetectable genetic variations may significantly increase the risk that a person will develop schizophrenia.

title: The United Plates of New Jersey
description: SIMON and Garfunkel were right. When the cars go to look for America, they often wind up on the New Jersey Turnpike. Just count them: More than 250 million motorists traveled along the turnpike in 2006. Though many of them were daily commuters, plenty of drivers were traveling farther, since the turnpike is also a well-worn vacation route, part of Interstate 95, the highway from Maine to Florida.

title: Obama Casts Wide Blame for Financial Crisis and Proposes Homeowner Aid
description: Senator Barack Obama called Thursday for tighter regulation of mortgage lenders, banks and financial houses, even as he spoke of pumping $30 billion into the economy to shield homeowners and local governments from the worst effects of the collapse of the housing bubble.

title: Brains, Tulle and Wonder Bread Give Their All for Art
description: As a general rule, if something is weird it will be interesting. But rules are made to be broken, and for long stretches of the Performance Mix Festivals opening program at the Joyce SoHo on Wednesday, the artists seemed intent on exploring that rarefied air where the wacky and the engaging never meet.

title: Smooth and Safe at Pier 94
description: These days contemporary-art fairs tend to travel in franchised packs. A large successful fair spawns parasite copycat fairs, and before you know it, youve got an art-fair fair.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An obituary on Monday about Israel Lpez, the Cuban bassist and composer known as Cachao, who was a pioneer of the mambo, misidentified the documentary about him that is to be released next month. It is Cachao: Uno Ms, not Cachao, Ahora S. (Ahora S was a documentary released in 2004 with the CD of that name.)

title: American Anchor Quits Al Jazeera English Channel
description: David Marash, the most prominent American anchor on Al Jazeera English, has quit the 24-hour international news channel, citing an increased level of editorial control exercised by the channels headquarters in Doha, Qatar.

title: Sponsors of Olympic Torch Caught in Tibet Protests
description: The disruption of a Chinese officials address during the Olympic torch lighting ceremonies in Greece last week was just the beginning of a string of protests planned to coincide with the torchs trip around the globe.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: As Builders Grand Visions Dissolve, So Does Our Faith
description: The governor and the mayor used the phrase a vote of confidence in New Yorks future, or similar words, at least half a dozen times the other day. They were gushing over the billion-dollar deal in which the Metropolitan Transportation Authority gave Tishman Speyer Properties the development rights to the Hudson railyards on the Far West Side.

title: A British Fund Says It Will Close
description: LONDON (Bloomberg News)  Pentagon Capital Management, a 1 billion ($2 billion) hedge fund run by the investor Lewis Chester, said Thursday that it would close its funds and return investors money because of a mutual fund trading investigation by the United States Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article on March 12 about financial problems in Jefferson County, Ala., stemming from a series of exotic bond deals, misidentified the business of the Birmingham firm of Porter White, which is advising the county on its finances. It is an investment banking firm, not a law firm. The article also misidentified the elective office of Larry P. Langford, a local official who signed off on the bond deals. He was elected a county commissioner in 2002 and was appointed president by his fellow commissioners; he was not elected county president. The article also misstated the degree to which sewer bills have increased in the last decade, partly as a result of the ill-fated deals. With an increase of more than 300 percent, they have quadrupled  not tripled.

title: Still Restrained, Still Eclectic After All These Years
description: Paul Simons solo career has carried him from New York to Johannesburg, London to Bahia, Brazil. Here are reviews of the 11 studio albums he has made as a solo performer.

title: Finally, a Vision for the West Side
description: For years, politicians, planners and business leaders have failed to come up with a workable plan for developing Hudson Yards on Manhattans Far West Side  the largest swath of underused land on the island.

title: Comcast Adjusts Way It Manages Internet Traffic
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Comcast, the countrys largest residential Internet provider, said on Thursday that it would take a more equitable approach toward managing the ever-expanding flow of Web traffic on its network.

title: Clinton Details Premium Cap in Health Plan
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said in an interview on Wednesday that if elected president she would push for a universal health care plan that would limit what Americans pay for health insurance to no more than 10 percent of their income, a significant reduction for some families.

title: Its Hide the Matzo for Real: Tam Tams Are Scarce
description: Why is this Passover different from all other Passovers  or at least the last 68 of them?

title: Theater Listings
description: T J & DAVE AND TWO MEN TALKING A latecomer could sit through an entire performance by this duo without realizing that there is no script. Without hearing their regular opening line, This is all made up, you might not gather that these Chicagoans are masters of long-form improvisation, creating an original, full-length play on the fly at every performance.

title: Send China a Message About Tibet
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tale of the Iron Cross
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 More Bodies IDd as Kidnapped Contractors
description: WASHINGTON  Two bodies found in Iraq have been identified as those of American contractors kidnapped more than a year ago, the F.B.I. said Thursday. The results of tests to identify a third body are not yet available, the bureau said.

title: A Tropical Getaway in Puerto Rico Thats Also a Bargain
description: TO get an idea why Culebra is an ideal Caribbean getaway for the bargain-savvy, look no further than the ferry that makes the hour-long trip there from mainland Puerto Rico. It costs $2.25.

title: An Obama-Bloomberg Ticket? No Cheers From the Mayor
description: It was only hours after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg finally made it clear that he was not running for president that his chief political guru, Kevin Sheekey, suggested that he would be the perfect running mate for Senator Barack Obama.

title: Abby Mann, Nuremberg Screenwriter, Dies at 83
description: Abby Mann, the screenwriter who brought incisive characterization and a searing sense of justice to Judgment at Nuremberg and other social dramas, died on Tuesday in Beverly Hills. He was 83.

title: Ex-Governor of Alabama Is Ordered Released
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.  Donald Siegelman, former governor of Alabama, was ordered released from prison on Thursday by a federal appeals court, pending his appeal of a bribery conviction that Democrats say resulted from a politically driven prosecution.

title: A Few Tense Moments as U.C.L.A. Prevails
description: PHOENIX  The differences between No. 1 U.C.L.A. and No. 12 Western Kentucky were far greater than their seedings. Each program entered the West Region semifinals of the N.C.A.A. tournament with starkly different styles.

title: Harlem to Antarctica for Science, and Pupils
description: The pitch: Eight weeks in Antarctica. Groundbreaking research into the climate before the Ice Age. Glaciers. Volcanoes. Adorable penguins.

title: Jon Hassler, 74, Novelist Known for Minnesota Tales, Dies
description: Jon Hassler, the author of a series of novels that affectionately mocked the foibles of small-town teachers, gossips, troublemakers and assorted other eccentrics, most from the fictional town of Staggerford, Minn., died March 20 in St. Louis Park, Minn. He was 74 and had homes in Minneapolis and Melbourne Beach, Fla.

title: A Bright Future for Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: Medicares Financial Woes
description: Warnings that Medicare spending is growing at an unsustainable rate come with mind-numbing regularity, so it was no surprise that the latest report from the Medicare trustees found that the system is still headed for a financial abyss. Medicares problems get scant attention on the campaign trail but will demand strong corrective action by the next president.

title: Footnotes
description: Conor McPhersons well-received Seafarer will close on Sunday at the Booth Theater on Broadway, but fans of this Dublin-born playwright wont have long to wait for his next work. Port Authority, an interwoven story of three generations of Irishmen in Dublin, will have its New York premiere at the Atlantic Theater Companys Linda Gross Theater, with previews starting April 30 and the official opening on May 21. ... Oliver Stone has cast James Cromwell and Ellen Burstyn, top row above, as George Herbert Walker Bush  and Barbara Bush in W, his film about the formative years of their oldest son, President George W. Bush, Variety reported. Josh Brolin and Elizabeth Banks, above, are to play the president and Laura Bush. Filming is to begin at the end of April in Shreveport, La. W may be ready for release in November. ... Fox has canceled the sitcom The Return of Jezebel James, created by Amy Sherman-Palladino (Gilmore Girls) and starring Parker Posey and Lauren Ambrose as sisters, Reuters reported. The show had its premiere this month.

title: Backers (One Fewer Than Thought) Act to Aid Detroit Mayor
description: DETROIT  Supporters of Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick, who was charged Monday with obstruction of justice, perjury and other felonies, have begun soliciting donations to help him pay for a defense team that promises to be expensive.

title: Tapes Destruction Hovers Over Detainee Cases
description: WASHINGTON  When officers from the Central Intelligence Agency destroyed hundreds of hours of videotapes documenting harsh interrogations in 2005, they may have believed they were freeing the government and themselves from potentially serious legal trouble.

title: More NATO Security Aid Needed, Afghan Official Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistans defense minister, Abdul Rahim Wardak, called on NATO countries on Thursday to use their summit meeting next month in Romania to reaffirm their commitment to his nations security, and especially to help Afghanistan build up its own security forces faster and more effectively.

title: Into the Classical Arena, in the Spirit of a Jam Band
description: SAVANNAH, Ga.  In the DVD accompanying Orchestralli, a CD featuring the rock drummer Stewart Copelands works for film, orchestra and ballet, he jokingly says he gravitated toward film because its a more civilized life than rock and because every drummer has this urge to prove he is an actual musician.

title: Fiery Momentum on the Keys
description: Jury and audience members sometimes differ on who merits first prize in music competitions. The 26-year-old German pianist Benjamin Moser won the audience favorite prize at last years International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow, but placed fifth in the official lineup. That year he also won the Young Concert Artists International Auditions, and the organization presented him in his New York recital debut on Tuesday at Zankel Hall, part of the Young Concert Artists Series.

title: Good-Natured Raunchiness
description: With its breezy shots of male genitalia and characters nicknamed Long John and Tripod, A Four Letter Word is a surprisingly endearing romantic comedy that explores gay relationships with low-budget verve.

title: Coaches Judged by Wins, Losses and Money Raised
description: Charlotte, N.C.

title: Wisconsin Becomes a National Power by Staying Close to Home
description: When Wisconsin faces Davidson on Friday night in the N.C.A.A. tournaments Midwest Region semifinal, the game will be billed as a bout between a mighty program from the powerful Big Ten and a charming little upstart.

title: An Aristocratic Look and a Powerhouse Personality
description: Ten years in the making, Hats Off is a documentary tribute to the 93-year-old actress Mimi Weddell, one of those people for whom the word individual seems especially apt.

title: Honduras: Cantaloupe Ban Criticized
description: Officials are denouncing a Food and Drug Administration decision asking American grocers to stop selling cantaloupe imported from a Honduran company because of links to a salmonella outbreak that has left at least 50 people sick in 16 states. The decision led the company, Agropecuaria Montelbano, to lay off 1,800 workers. To show that Honduran fruit is safe, President Manuel Zelaya bit into a cantaloupe on television this week. Charles Ford, the American ambassador to Honduras, denied reports that the decision was tied to the closeness between Mr. Zelaya and President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela. As for Mr. Zelayas televised melon-eating, the ambassador told The Associated Press, I wish him luck.

title: Corrections: Islands of Calm
description: An article last Friday about the second-home market in the Venetian Islands near Miami Beach misstated the percentage homeowners pay in property taxes. It is about 2 percent of the purchase price of a property, not 2 percent of the assessed value or around 20 percent of the purchase price.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Xavier Has Torn Its Midmajor Tag to Shreds
description: PHOENIX  All season long, Xavier Coach Sean Miller and the university bristled at the notion of their basketball program being described as a midmajor.

title: A School Board Clash in Pennsylvania, With Echoes
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa.  If you closed your eyes, the voices in the hottest local political debate sounded like they issued straight from the giant diaphragm of a certain presidential race.

title: Four Cars Are Struck by Gunfire in Virginia
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  At least four cars were struck by gunfire on Interstate 64 here early Thursday morning, forcing the closing of the highway for several hours. Two people suffered minor injuries.

title: Trade-Off Looms on Mitchell Proposals
description: With all 30 major league teams about to begin the regular season, the players association and the commissioners office continued efforts Thursday to reach an agreement on the Mitchell reports recommendations on performance-enhancing drugs.

title: French First Lady More Than Tames British Press
description: LONDON  Was she the new Kennedy Onassis or a reborn Diana? With her flat Dior pumps and calf-length gray overcoat, was she a high school student on vacation, or, as one columnist asked, Jackie O dressed as a nun?

title: Birth of Los Angeles Art, Assisted by Hip Midwives
description: The Cool School, a breezy, lively documentary about a thin slice of the Los Angeles fine art scene in the 1950s, is easy on the eyes, and the ears too. The focal point of this historical gloss is the Ferus Gallery, which opened in 1957 and soon became a cultural hub with shows dedicated to local talent like Ed Ruscha, Robert Irwin, Ed Moses, Wallace Berman and Ed Kienholz and a then-unknown out-of-towner with a fondness for Campbells Soup named Andy Warhol.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: 304,000 Inmates Eligible for Deportation, Official Says
description: At least 304,000 immigrant criminals eligible for deportation are behind bars nationwide, a top federal immigration official said Thursday.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 27, 2008

title: Memorial for Mailer
description: A memorial for the author Norman Mailer will be held at 4 p.m. April 9 at Carnegie Hall, Random House and the Mailer family have announced. Mr. Mailer died on Nov. 10.

title: Obama Finds Street Support
description: Of the 8.9 million passenger vehicles registered in New York State, only one has license plates spelling out Tibi Vasilescus choice for president: OBAMA 08.

title: Angsana Saman Bay and Legacy Condominiums
description: Angsana Saman Bay

title: Pieces of History for New Churches
description: LaGRANGEVILLE, N.Y.  The Roman Catholic churches stand 66 miles apart, one in the center of Harlem, the other on 82 acres between a farm and a hunting club in this rural hamlet in Dutchess County.

title: In 50-Shot Case, Sean Bells Eyesight Becomes an Issue
description: Sean Bells vision was greatly impaired in his right eye without lenses, but his left eye was strong enough for him to drive legally in the State of New York, an optometrist testified on Thursday.

title: Canada: Agency Puts Conditions on Phone Buyout
description: Canadian communications regulators approved the 51.7 billion Canadian dollar ($50.9 billion) buyout of BCE, the countrys biggest phone provider, and set conditions that require the carrier to remain Canadian controlled. One of the six criteria requires Ontario Teachers Pension Plan to appoint six directors, instead of the five proposed. The pension plan and its United States partners agreed to modify the original deal to appease the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission, which had expressed concerns that BCE might end up being controlled by United States investors. That proposal did not go far enough, the agency said in its decision. Deborah Allan, a spokeswoman for the pension plan, said the pension fund was reviewing the conditions and had no further comment.

title: Finding a Swap
description: Here is a sampling of home-exchange Web sites:

title: Curtain Up! Its Pattis Turn at Gypsy
description: Watch out, New York. Patti LuPone has found her focus. And when Ms. LuPone is truly focused, shes a laser, she incinerates. Especially when shes playing someone as dangerously obsessed as Momma Rose in the wallop-packing revival of the musical Gypsy, which opened on Thursday night at the St. James Theater.

title: A New Diplomatic Order in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  If it was not yet clear to Washington that a new political order prevailed here, the three-day visit this week by Americas chief diplomat dealing with Pakistan should put any doubt to rest.

title: Assessing Property Taxes
description: To the Editor: Those of us whose only home is in Vermont might be a bit miffed by second-home owners complaining of high taxes (Havens: Plymouth, Vt.; March 21). I think second-home owners in Vermont need to be aware that they too must contribute their tax share to Vermont for its schools, infrastructure, health care, human services, etc.

title: Precision and Spectacle by Two Hyphenates in Progress
description: In recent years the relationship between choreographer and dancer has become more fluid, producing new ways of moving as well as adaptable performers with diverse rsums and healthy imaginations. Two such examples, Walter Dundervill and Heather Olson, have struck out on their own in a shared program at Dance Theater Workshop, first presented on Wednesday night.

title: Corzine Wants to Change Formula for Local Aid
description: LAMBERTVILLE, N.J.  After listening to weeks of complaining by small-town officials over proposed budget cuts, Gov. Jon S. Corzine said on Thursday that he wanted to do away with the states 13-year-old multibillion-dollar formula for municipal subsidies and come up with a new system by the end of the year.

title: Fed Hearings on Countrywide Deal
description: WASHINGTON (Dow Jones)  The Federal Reserve announced Thursday that it would hold public meetings next month on the offer by Bank of America to acquire Countrywide Financial.

title: Tar Heels Play Cougars Game and Still Romp
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Washington State hoped for a slow, plodding, defensive game against North Carolina in its N.C.A.A. tournament East Region semifinal. The Cougars got what they wanted.

title: Home Exchanges, a Bit at a Time
description: ABOUT once a month, Mark Bollozos makes the four-hour drive up to Lake Tahoe from his home in San Francisco for a few days of skiing or mountain biking. A couple of weeks before he leaves, Mr. Bollozos nails down which getaway hell call home that weekend.

title: One Mezzo, Wide Terrain
description: The mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato has covered a lot of territory in her operatic appearances, in the process swiftly securing a position as one of the most engaging, consistently satisfying singers around. In a recital she presented in Lincoln Centers Art of the Song series at the Rose Theater on Wednesday night, she ranged farther still.

title: Helping the Help Desk, the Intel Way
description: PURPORTEDLY perfect places go by many names, among them Shangri-La, Oz, paradise, Wonderland, Xanadu and Utopia. A major technology marketer is about to conjure up an ideal world called ITopia.

title: Newark Lists Another Killing, but Is Still Way Off 07 Pace
description: For a stretch of 43 days this year, there were no murders in Newark, a period of calm that startled residents and police officials alike and stirred talk of the good old days.

title: Job Total Dips in State, but the City Gains a Bit
description: The number of jobs in New York State dipped in February, a sign that the state, like the nation, may be heading into a recession. But the jobs numbers in New York City, moving counter to that trend, increased slightly last month.

title: J.C. Penney Warns of a Spending Downturn
description: By all accounts, J.C. Penney, the department store chain, has done everything right to weather an economic downturn.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: The Really? column on Tuesday, about the debate over the risk of breast cancer from eating grapefruit, misstated the relationship between the enzyme CYP 3A4 and grapefruit. Grapefruit contains several compounds that inhibit the 3A4 enzyme, thus increasing the level of substances that are normally metabolized by 3A4, including estrogen. Grapefruit does not contain the enzyme itself.

title: Using Lifes Mundane Clay to Mold a Fantasy of Life
description: Tobias Wolffs characters are compulsive storytellers and liars; they are constantly spinning their own lives into melodramas, inventing or embellishing personas, daydreaming themselves into fantasy worlds, or turning their pasts into confessional anecdotes. Some embroider the truth to try to make themselves seem more interesting. Some lie out of self-delusion. Some invent phony identities so that they can cheat strangers out of money. Some fantasize as an escape from the banality of their lives. In Mr. Wolffs hands their storytelling becomes a metaphor both for peoples need to make narrative order out of the chaos of daily existence and for the fiction-making process he practices himself.

title: Before 73 Coup, Chile Tried to Find the Right Software for Socialism
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  When military forces loyal to Gen. Augusto Pinochet staged a coup here in September 1973, they made a surprising discovery. Salvador Allendes Socialist government had quietly embarked on a novel experiment to manage Chiles economy using a clunky mainframe computer and a network of telex machines.

title: Northwest Seeks to Push Ahead on Delta Merger
description: Informal merger talks have resumed between Northwest Airlines and Delta Air Lines  two weeks after their pilots unions appeared to give up on merging their all-important seniority lists, a person with knowledge of the discussions said Friday. Northwest, the person said, had essentially inquired whether Delta would be interested in pursuing a combination even without prior approval from the pilots.

title: Nasty, but Not So Brutish and Short
description: In its depiction of the early reigning years of Henry VIII, The Tudors, which returns on Sunday for its second somnolent season on Showtime, plays a game of historical hopscotch. Timelines are abbreviated, papacies are rearranged, and while the shows creators have adequately defended these practices as a means of narrative efficiency, they have yet to be held accountable for producing a version of Tudor England that appears to have been spritzed with Febreze.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article on March 18 about suicides by teenagers in Nantucket, Mass., referred incorrectly to a population area of 130,000 in Wales where 17 young people are thought to have killed themselves in the course of last year and early this year. It is the county borough of Bridgend  not the town of Bridgend, population 39,000, located in the borough.

title: Broken Ice in Antarctica
description: Winter is coming to Antarctica, and that may be the only thing that keeps another of its major ice shelves from collapsing. On Tuesday, scientists from the British Antarctic Survey announced that there had been an enormous fracture on the edge of the Wilkins ice shelf, which started breaking last month.

title: A Little Warmth, at a Cost
description: DINING beside the patio fireplace in Maine in April. Swimming in the backyard pool in Arizona late into a cold March night. Nightcaps around the outdoor fire pit in South Carolina in November.

title: Out on the Waves
description: A confused young artist is torn between his family and his future in Shelter, a sensitive romantic drama from the writer and director Jonah Markowitz.

title: Odd Crop Prices Defy Economics
description: Economists note there should not be two prices for one thing at the same place and time. Could a drugstore sell two identical tubes of toothpaste, and charge 50 cents more for one of them? Of course not.

title: An Outsider at the Center of a Musical Universe
description: It may be hard to think of Paul Simon as an outsider. He rode high on the pop charts for three decades, has collected a dozen Grammy Awards and was a shoo-in for various halls of fame. He can sell out arenas whenever he decides to reunite with his 1960s partner, Art Garfunkel. He wrote and starred in a movie and mounted a Broadway musical. He has gone globe-hopping and drawn musicians who are national heroes to sit in as sidemen.

title: Hundreds of Flights Canceled for Inspections
description: Hundreds of flights were canceled Thursday as mechanics for American Airlines and Delta Airlines inspected wiring in aircraft to ensure the planes met federal safety rules.

title: Drawing on the Repertory to Celebrate Teachers Past
description: Just about every major dance figure has passed through the Juilliard School. The founding faculty included Martha Graham, Antony Tudor and Jos Limn, who all began teaching in 1951 and continued into the 1970s. The school honored the three with Dance Masterworks of the 20th Century, an eloquently danced program of three pieces that opened Wednesday at the schools Peter Jay Sharp Theater.

title: Voigt and Heppner in Last, and Webcast, Tristan
description: Dont bet the farm on this, but the soprano Deborah Voigt is expected to be back on Friday night, the Metropolitan Opera said on Thursday, and its Web site, metopera.org, will stream Ms. Voigt and the tenor Ben Heppner singing together (at last) in the final performance this season of Wagners Tristan und Isolde. Illness has kept one or the other star out of the first five performances of Tristan. Mr. Heppners first replacement, John Mac Master, was himself later reported to have been suffering from allergies, and the second, Gary Lehman, slid down the stage and into the prompters box in one performance, injuring his head. Mr. Lehman was replaced by Robert Dean Smith for the fourth performance, and Mr. Heppner was well enough to appear in the fifth, which Ms. Voigt, who was ill, missed.

title: An Artist From Russia Disappears in Berlin
description: BERLIN  A prominent artist who had run-ins with both church and state in her native Russia after taking part in a controversial exhibition has disappeared without a trace from her new home in Berlin.

title: When the Islamic World Was Inspired by the West
description: Sometimes in the history of art everything seems to be happening everywhere, all at once. The 16th century was like that. It was a grand global burst of lights. The Ming dynasty in China; the Renaissance in Europe; Islamic empires in India, Iran and Turkey were all burning at high incandescence. Visitors traveled from one to another, buying, selling, making plans, taking notes, amazed.

title: California Trims Goal for Number of Emission-Free Vehicles
description: SAN FRANCISCO  California regulators cut by 70 percent the number of emission-free vehicles that automobile manufacturers must sell in California in the three years beginning in 2012. At the same time, the regulators effectively required, for the first time, that tens of thousands of plug-in hybrid vehicles be sold in those years.

title: A Run Does the Trick for a Case of Cold Feet
description: The beleaguered man-boy Dennis Doyle (Simon Pegg) is always running, running, running, an activity befitting the hero of the British comedy titled Run, Fat Boy, Run. In the films prologue he runs away from his pregnant fiance, Libby (Thandie Newton, charming in a largely reactive role), minutes before their scheduled wedding. When we catch up with him years later, hes a chubby security guard sprinting after a shoplifter. Soon after, Dennis decides to enter the same marathon as Libbys rich American boyfriend, Whit, to show Libby and his now elementary-school-age son, Jake, that he can make plans and see them through. You cant even finish a sentence, Libby says.

title: Bush Gives Apology for Suez Shooting
description: CAIRO  President Bush apologized to the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, on Thursday for the killing of an Egyptian vendor when a cargo ship chartered by the United States opened fire on his small boat near the Suez Canal on Monday in an episode that has enraged Egyptians.

title: Turning Stereotypes Into Artistic Strengths
description: More, please has been the critical response to WACK! Art and the Feminist Revolution, the survey of pioneering feminist art currently installed at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center. The Bronx Museum of the Arts anticipated the demand with Making It Together: Womens Collaborative Art and Community, which focuses on the groups and collectives that linked feminist art to a larger social context.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: February Spending Flat, Inflation Threat Recedes
description: Consumer spending stayed stagnant in February, growing at the slowest pace in more than a year, as the housing slump and a weak job market continued to put pressure on the pocketbooks of Americans. The number helped drive the markets lower Friday.

title: Extra Tax Slips Out of Budget
description: ALBANY  Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the State Assembly, backed away Thursday from his plan to seek an income tax increase for New Yorkers who earn more than $1 million a year, as lawmakers took a step toward completing a state budget.

title: Tested Over Time
description: Barack Obama says: John McCain is determined to carry out four more years of George Bushs failed policies. Obama is a politician, so its normal that hed choose to repeat the lines that some of his followers want to hear. But before people buy that argument, Id ask them to read three speeches.

title: Belarus: Journalists Homes Raided
description: Security forces raided the apartments of journalists from independent and foreign news media, days after the police broke up an opposition rally in the capital, Minsk. Officers questioned at least 16 journalists, possibly in connection with a 2006 cartoon video that was deemed offensive to President Aleksandr Lukashenko, said the Belarus Association of Journalists. Belarus, which Western diplomats call Europes last dictatorship, has received heavy criticism for its human rights record.

title: Founder of JetBlue Is Planning a Start-Up Airline for Brazil
description: David Neeleman, who as founder of JetBlue Airways helped to redefine start-up carriers in the United States by using new jets and offering above-bargain-basement service, said Thursday that he would start a domestic airline in Brazil.

title: 2 Fatally Shot in Newark
description: Two people were killed and a third was injured by gunfire outside a bar in Newark on Thursday night, the police said.

title: Dutch Film Against Islam Is Released on Internet
description: NIJMEGEN, The Netherlands  The anti-Islam Dutch politician Geert Wilders on Thursday released on the Internet his highly charged and much-anticipated anti-Koran film, which matches graphic images of terrorist attacks and death threats against Jews by Muslim extremists with verses of the Muslim holy book.

title: Down $900 Million or More, the Chairman of Bear Sells
description: Only a year ago James E. Caynes stake in Bear Stearns was worth more than $1 billion. But on Thursday, Mr. Cayne, the chairman of Bear, disclosed that he had sold all of his shares in the troubled investment bank this week for just $61 million.

title: Davidson Actively Recruits Foreigners
description: DAVIDSON, N.C.  Davidson Coach Bob McKillop has been building his mens basketball program for years in the hope that the Wildcats would one day make a run in the N.C.A.A. tournament. He apparently did not expect it to come this year.

title: Assault by Iraq on Shiite Forces Stalls in Basra
description: BAGHDAD  American-trained Iraqi security forces failed for a third straight day to oust Shiite militias from the southern city of Basra on Thursday, even as President Bush hailed the operation as a sign of the growing strength of Iraqs federal government.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,993 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Wednesday:

title: Loans and Leadership
description: When George W. Bush first ran for the White House, political reporters assured us that he came across as a reasonable, moderate guy.

title: Western Snow Without the Celebrity Scene
description: SILVER STAR MOUNTAIN, in British Columbia, serves up a big helping of Western-style skiing, but its small-town feel helps make it the antithesis of Whistler Blackcomb, its glamorous, sprawling cousin to the west.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Cherchez le Sugar Daddy (et Sugar Mom)
description: Forget Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous, Cribs and reality shows exalting American gluttony, and savor the more refined amenities on the coasts of southern France in the cynical Gallic comedy Priceless. In luxury hotels from Biarritz to Nice, Irne (Audrey Tautou) and Jean (Gad Elmaleh) trade sexual favors for gifts with well-kept sybarites on the far side of 60.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about Hartford and its attractions misstated the type of aircraft included in the collection at the New England Air Museum. It is the F-14 Tomcat, not the F-4 Tomcat.

title: Art in Review
description: ADRIAN PIPER

title: Bringing a School Shooting to the Screen
description: THE innovative opera director Chen Shi-Zheng is looking not-so-fresh after the red-eye flight from Los Angeles, where he screened his intentionally disturbing film, Dark Matter, a fictionalized version of a 1991 shooting by a distraught Chinese graduate student who killed five University of Iowa colleagues and himself at a physics department meeting. The stunned audience at Caltech clapped and cried. Perfect.

title: Station Plan Put in Doubt as Garden Opts to Stay
description: The dream of transforming Pennsylvania Station and creating a new financial district around it suffered a potentially fatal blow on Thursday when the owners of Madison Square Garden announced that they would renovate the 40-year-old arena instead of moving to a new location a block away.

title: Parties Differ on Whom Economic Aid Should Help
description: WASHINGTON  When an election campaign coincides with both a crisis on Wall Street and soaring home foreclosures across the country, the traditional ideological battles over more government or less government become blurred.

title: A Meissen Collection With Its Own History
description: Collections have personalities, said Maureen Cassidy-Geiger, a Meissen porcelain scholar and the longtime private curator for the New York banker Henry Arnhold, who owns more than 500 pieces of 18th-century porcelain made in Meissen. (The town, in eastern Germany, is near Dresden, where Mr. Arnhold was born.) The collection, widely considered the best of early Meissen in private hands in the United States, reflects the personal tastes and preferences of two generations of Arnholds, Ms. Cassidy-Geiger said.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: The headline on the baseball roundup in some copies on Thursday misspelled the surname of the Oakland Athletics pitcher who won Wednesdays game against the Boston Red Sox in Tokyo. He is Rich Harden, not Hardin.

title: Multiple Personalities, All of Them Disordered
description: Its hard to find an appellation that really suits Tracey Ullman. Impressionist, used by Rich Little and Monet, isnt right. Impersonator sounds too much like a drag show. Comedian is constraining, since Ms. Ullman also acts, dances and sings. And even the term satirist, which certainly applies to her more biting celebrity send-ups, is undercut by her works loony warmth.

title: Cut by a Diamond-Crusted Glass Ceiling
description: Flawless is a mildly diverting period heist movie in which an odd couple conspire to loot an evil London diamond company, for which they both work. In the story, set in 1960, before the term glass ceiling was coined, Demi Moore plays Laura Quinn, a grimly ambitious company executive of 40 whose career has stalled. Early in the movie she learns that the pompous, corrupt gargoyles who stole her ideas intend to fire her.

title: Louisville Keeps Going; Tennessee Is Still Stuck
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Bruce Pearl has turned Tennessee into an elite program in three seasons, but Rick Pitino and Louisville kept the Volunteers from taking the next step.

title: The State of the United States, in a Chamber-Rock Stew
description: From the beginning of her career Laurie Anderson has cast an analytical eye over American culture and politics and turned her observations into cutting musical works that straddle the line between art song and stand-up comedy. Her most durable essay on the subject is the 1983 multimedia work United States I-IV, a work that came to mind often during her performance of her newest piece, Homeland, at Zankel Hall on Wednesday evening.

title: Cyclists Trial Has Testimony From Novitzky
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Jeff Novitzky, an I.R.S. special agent and lead investigator on the Balco case for the past five and a half years, testified publicly Thursday for the first time in the investigation.

title: Inside Crumbling Walls, Sounds of Bells and Copland
description: I may not be the best person to write about Traces, at the Angel Orensanz Center on Wednesday night. A listener indifferent to, uninformed about or just plain hostile to the classical-music world and its conventions might be better  someone coaxed into this multimedia event and then presented with its sales pitch.

title: Home sales in Spain plummet, industry experts talk of crisis
description: Evidence continues to mount that Spains property market is heading for a crash, not a slowdown.

title: New Parodies, Anyone?
description: Comedy Central has successfully satirized evening newscasts on The Daily Show with Jon Stewart and news talk shows on The Colbert Report with Stephen Colbert. Last month it introduced a court show satire by Lewis Black called Root of All Evil. Up next: spoofs of reality shows and news magazines.

title: National League Picks for 2008
description: O.K., full disclosure. I havent stopped questioning my A.L. picks since the moment I posted them. Im not second-guessing my pick of the Yankees to miss the playoffs; I still cant believe I couldnt squeeze the Tigers in there. I guess Ive just seen teams (the late 1990s Mariners) with awesome lineups become undone by a bad bullpen. And that Angels pick looks shakier with each passing injury out there, but oh well. In the words of Brian McNamee, it is what it is.

title: Un-nemesizing the Devils
description: The Rangers seventh straight victory over the Devils this season came with so many subplots, it was hard to keep them all straight Thursday night:

title: Bespoke Bombay
description: India is known around the world for many things: the Taj Mahal, curry, call centers, arranged marriage, Rajasthan and the caste system, to name a few. But it ought to be known for bespoke.

title: A Career Night for Keefe
description: PHOENIX  Give credit to the members of the U.C.L.A. band, who showed that their basketball I.Q.s matched their lofty S.A.T. scores. As the seconds drained down in No. 1 U.C.L.A.s 88-78 victory over No. 12 Western Kentucky, the Bruins band chanted one name: James Keefe.

title: A Storybook in the Snow
description: A look at Silver Star Mountain, in British Columbia.

title: Round of 16
description: Thursday night's action in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Bob Casey Endorses Barack Obama
description: The following is a transcript of Senator Bob Casey of Pennsylvania endorsing Senator Barack Obamas presidential campaign, as provided by CQ Transcriptions via The Associated Press.

title: Sacred Objects
description: When Catholic churches close, their  precious artifacts find new homes.

title: Highway 443
description: A major access road to Jerusalem has taken on special significance in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: the test
description: TK copy

title: Satellite Fairs
description: Additional images from the exhibitions,

title: Pentagon Capital to Close Its Doors
description: Pentagon Capital Management, a 1 billion pound ($2 billion) hedge fund run by the investor Lewis Chester, said Thursday that it would close its funds and return investors money because of a mutual fund trading investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Xerox to Pay $670 Million to Settle Securities Case
description: The Xerox Corporation said Thursday it would pay $670 million to settle a securities lawsuit from 2000, without admitting wrongdoing.

title: New A.I.G. Jab at Ex-Chief Focuses on Fiduciary Duties
description: American International Group has filed a complaint in New York State Supreme Court against its former chief executive, Maurice R. Greenberg, and six other former directors and officers, accusing them of breaching their fiduciary duty.

title: Credit Suisse Ponies Up $300 Million for Clean Energy Deals
description: Credit Suisse Group will allocate at least $300 million to Hudson Capital Managements Hudson Clean Energy Partners fund, the companies announced Thursday.

title: Bids Due for U.K. Pubs Operator
description: Mitchells & Butlers will discover on Friday which private equity groups, if any, are willing to take up its offer of partial stakes in the British pubs group, having concluded that market conditions have all but killed off the prospect of an outright cash offer.

title: Chinas CNOOC in Talks for Independent Refineries
description: China National Offshore Oil Corporation, the parent of CNOOC, said it is in talks to acquire several independent refineries in eastern Chinas Shandong province.

title: Illinois Tool Nails Down Deal for Quipp
description: Illinois Tool Works said Thursday it would buy Quipp, a publicly traded maker of newspaper production equipment, in a deal valuing Quipp at less than $10 million.

title: Finish Line Books $81.5 Million in Merger-Related Costs
description: Athletic shoe retailer retailer Finish Line, fresh from fleeing a merger with rival Genesco, said the escape cost it $81.5 million and led to a fourth-quarter loss of nearly $40 million.

title: Bite-Size Pieces of Kosher Cardboard
description: More of your late night jokes(send via the comment link below):

title: Air France Offers Concessions to Alitalia Unions
description: Air France-KLM agreed to take on about 900 more employees of Alitalias ground services unit than planned under a new proposal to secure its takeover of the struggling Italian carrier, according to Reuters.

title: Monosol Rx Withdraws I.P.O.
description: MonoSol Rx, a drug delivery company, has canceled its planned initial public offering of 4 million shares, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing on Thursday.

title: 3i Posts a Drop in Proceeds
description: 3i Group, the publicly-listed London private equity firm, on Thursday reported a 72 percent increase in its investments for the first 11 months of its financial year, but said there was a decline in its realization proceeds for the same period.

title: Boussard & Gavaudan Plans London Listing
description: The first hedge fund to float in Amsterdam plans to add a London listing in a boost for the London Stock Exchanges efforts to attract so-called alternative fund listings.

title: Could It Be More Annoying?
description: Gripes from the complaint blog whitewhine.com:

title: Man Group Outshines Rivals With Rosy Projections
description: Man Group, the worlds largest publicly traded hedge fund manager, said Thursday that annual earnings would surpass analysts estimates as its flagship fund gained even as competitors faltered.

title: Its Take Your Daughter to War Day
description: From The Onion:

title: Boston Fed President Says Banks Woes May Mount
description: The woes of United States banks could mount, Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren said Friday, adding that the Federal Reserve, with its access to their confidential information, can use those data to make sound policy.

title: Harvards $34.9 Billion Endowment Makes Its Choice for New Chief
description: The Harvard Management Company, which oversees the universitys $34.9 billion endowment, appointed Jane Mendillo, the chief investment officer at Wellesley College, as its president and chief executive on Thursday.

title: SolarWinds Breaks a Tech Offering Drought
description: SolarWinds, a provider of network management software, filed to go public last week, becoming the first enterprise technology company to do so in three months. The 451 Group looks at its prospects and concludes it could shine on Wall Street.

title: Fannie and Freddie Plan to Raise Up to $20 Billion
description: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-chartered mortgage companies, may raise as much as $20 billion in capital as part of an agreement that allows them to buy more debt securities, their regulator told Bloomberg News .

title: JPMorgan Buys Nordea Bank Assets
description: JPMorgan Chase, the worlds second-biggest custodian of assets, agreed to buy 200 billion euros, or $315.6 billion, of investments from Nordea Bank, the Nordic regions biggest bank by value.

title: Clients Sue Citigroup Over Auction Rate Securities
description: Citigroup was sued on Thursday by two clients accusing the financial institution of failing to properly disclose the risks of investing in auction rate securities.

title: JetBlue Founder Plans Start-Up in Brazil
description: David Neeleman, who as founder of JetBlue Airways helped to redefine start-up carriers in the United States by using new jets and offering above-bargain-basement service, said Thursday that he would start a domestic airline in Brazil.

title: Hedge Fund Shutdowns Slow, Report Says
description: Despite all the headlines in recent months about high-profile hedge-fund collapses and near-collapses, data from the industry publication Absolute Return suggests that 2008 is actually on pace for the smallest number of fund shutdowns in several years.

title: Airbus Grounds Deal Talks
description: European aircraft manufacturer Airbus on Thursday ended talks to sell three German production sites to financial investors, blaming instability in the financial markets and a record euro.

title: Obama Casts Wide Blame for Financial Crisis
description: Senator Barack Obama called Thursday for tighter regulation of mortgage lenders, banks and financial houses, even as he spoke of pumping $30 billion into the economy to shield homeowners and local governments from the worst effects of the collapse of the housing bubble.

title: China Law Could Impede Microsoft Deal for Yahoo
description: Microsofts hostile takeover attempt against Yahoo may encounter an unexpected hurdle in August after a Chinese antimonopoly law takes effect that will extend the nations economic influence far beyond its borders.

title: Fridays Link: Even Secret Service Agents Want Work/Life Balance
description: Clearly, work/life balance has captured the worlds attention when part of the recruiting strategy of Israels domestic intelligence agency is allowing four of its agents to blog anonymously about their workaday lifestyles. Check out this item, Israeli secret agents blog on work-life balance, from the Daily Telegraph.

title: What Do Clear Channels Buyers Want?
description: As rumors swirled in recent weeks that the banks backing the $25 billion buyout of Clear Channel Communications would scotch the deal unless the private equity buyers agreed to rewrite the credit terms, many observers  including The Deal Professor  suspected the sponsors, too, would be secretly delighted to see the deal die.

title: Analyst Upgrades Lehman as Rumors Swirl
description: Will Lehman Brothers bounce back?

title: Wall St. Firms Increase Borrowing From Fed
description: Big Wall Street investment companies have jumped all over the Federal Reserves unusual offer to obtain emergency loans, as borrowing more than doubled in the programs second week, The Associated Press reported.

title: Bears Cayne Follows His Own Advice to the End
description: To the end, James E. Cayne, the chairman one-time chief of Bear Stearns, heeded the advice he often gave his colleagues at the investment bank: hold on to your stock. Whether the stock was flying high, as it was early last year, at $171, or plummeting, as it did in recent months, Mr. Cayne kept the vast bulk of his 5.6 million shares.

title: Lessons in Home Cooking
description: The most healthful meal is the one you cook at home. But for those of us skilled at the art of takeout, the idea of cooking in our kitchens is daunting. Who has time after a busy day to shop, chop, prepare and cook?

title: Citi Said to Make More Changes in Management
description: Citigroup plans to hire an outsider to take over its flagging U.S. consumer business, The Wall Street Journal said on Friday.

title: The Early Word: Casey to Endorse Obama
