description: Senator Bob Casey Jr. of Pennsylvania, one of the states last undecided superdelegates, plans to endorse Barack Obama during a rally at the Soldiers and Sailors Military Museum and Memorial in Pittsburgh this morning.

title: Warning, Tornado Ahead!
description: For all of you who were wondering why the folks working in the XM and Sirius displays at the New York auto show last week seemed to be snuggling up: the two satellite radio companies  once fierce competitors  were pleased with the announcement that the Justice Department had approved their proposed merger.

title: Paris Hiltons newest video, a la Turka
description: Society news has always graced the colorful front pages of Istanbuls biggest newspapers, often leading visitors to scratch their heads wondering why this unknown-outside-of-Turkey heiress or that obscure bikini-clad model merited top play, especially in a seemingly conservative country. Well, its all part of the fascinating melange, and of course, it sells newspapers, just like everywhere else.

title: Justice?
description: One of the scariest stories in recent American politics is that of the imprisonment of former Alabama governor Don Siegelman. The case against him seems extremely weak, and theres a lot of circumstantial evidence that he was the target of a GOP-directed vendetta. Basically, it looks as if he was jailed for the crime of being a Democrat. And if it could happen to him, it could happen to others.

title: Albany Leaders Agree on $124 Billion Spending Ceiling
description: Gov. David A. Paterson and the leaders of the State Legislature announced an agreement on Thursday night for a rough spending ceiling of $124 billion for the fiscal year that begins April 1, Jeremy W. Peters reports. Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the State Assembly, backed away  for now  from his plan to seek an income tax increase for New Yorkers who earn more than $1 million a year, as lawmakers took a step toward completing a state budget.

title: Let Your Gestures Do the Talking, or ;-)
description: There are times when the gestures available to the average New Yorker are just not sufficient. Wouldnt it be great if there were a discreet sign you could make when you see a celebrity on the street and want to express admiration for his or her work, without interrupting any conversations or causing any discomfort? Wouldnt a universally understood gesture be handy to express, while driving  yikes, sorry, didnt mean to cut you off, my mistake  to pre-empt more common gestures that fly during such encounters? How about a polite one for please put your knees together, mister, as youre taking up three subway seats?While certain gestures have become notorious lately, like that push-the-thumbtack into-my-teleprompter to-prove-a-point move that says I want to be presidential, or the facial expression through which a governor says, in effect, I am swallowing my lips because I am so busted sorry, there is a need for an expansion of the number of widely understood gestures.

title: Little Fish in an Increasingly Competitive Pond
description: When Carlos Ruiz first came to Major League Soccer, he had his doubts about the league.

title: Bracket Racket
description: Losing your NCAA tournament pool? Blame the scoring system! Josh Patashnik, a reporter-researcher at The New Republic, thinks the most common methods used to calculate the winners of March Madness office pools are deeply flawed. Did you have North Carolina in the Sweet 16? Yes? Well, you and 96 percent of the country can go ahead and pat yourselves on the back, Patashnik writes at The Plank, his magazines staff blog. How about Western Kentuckydid you have them, too? Really? And you live outside of the greater Bowling Green area? Now thats something to write home about.

title: Friday Tipoff
description: Is your basketball knowledge at an elite level when it comes to tonights sweet matchups? Read up:

title: A Forgotten Artist Gets a Second Life in Rome
description: A wonderful exhibit at the Palazzo Venezia showcases the remarkable talent of Sebastiano del Piombo, the 16th century painter, whose initial fame was eventually obscured by that of contemporaries like Michelangelo, Raphael, Titian and Giorgione.

title: McCains General Election Ad
description: And were off. John McCain has released the first ad of the general election, a one-minute clip that highlights his military service and poses a series of patriotic questions to American voters.

title: Now Screening | Josh Lucas in T Takes Episode 10
Obama on Reverend Wright
description: In an interview on ABCs The View that will be broadcast at 11 a.m. today, Senator Barack Obama talks again about his relationship with his longtime pastor, the Rev. Jeremiah Wright Jr., saying that he would have stopped going to Trinity United Church of Christ if the circumstances were different.

title: Ts New Spring Travel Issue
Russia Challenges West  on Runway
description: Paris, Milan, New York. Moscow?

title: Vt. Senator Calls for Clinton to Drop Out
description: Updated Senator Patrick Leahy, who has endorsed fellow Senator Barack Obama, called for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton to drop out of the presidential race in a radio interview.

title: Podcast: Follow the Money, if You Can
description: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

title: Runaway health care costs  were #1!
description: The latest Trustees reports from Social Security and Medicare show, once again, that there is no such thing as Socialsecuritymedicareandmedicaid. Social Security, the subject of thousands of demands that we get serious and cut benefits, is doing relatively well. The real problem lies in health care costs.

title: Recipe of the Day: Sausages With Grapes
description: When I saw salsiccia alluva  sausages and grapes  on the menu in a trattoria in Tuscany a few years ago, I ordered it out of curiosity. My imagination could not prepare me for the utter simplicity of the dish: beautifully browned sausages nestled on a bed of cooked grapes that were in varying stages of doneness.

title: Feel So Lucky Now, Punk?
description: Aired Thursday night on NBC: Barack Obama back from his vacation in the Virgin Islands. He played a lot of shuffle board down there. See, hes pretty smart. He was doing that in case John McCain challenges him to a duel.

title: Color and the Car
description: Automobile paint looms large in the Museum of Modern Arts current exhibition, Color Chart: Reinventing Color, 1950 to Today, which I recently wrote about for Voice, the online publication of AIGA, the professional association for design.

title: The Casey Endorsement
description: In a surprise move, Senator Bob Casey of Pennsylvania has endorsed Senator Barack Obama in advance of the April 22 Democratic primary. Mr. Casey had said he would remain neutral in the race in part because he wanted to help broker a reconciliation between Mr. Obama and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton afterward.

title: While Race Roiled the City
description: Bonfire of the Vanities an indictment of Reaganism! Wow, that is a new one on me. Stephen writes that the Reagan theory of Bonfire was the prevailing theory in academic circles. Who knew?

title: Stray Questions for: Fareed Zakaria
description: Fareed Zakaria is the editor of Newsweek International. His new book, The Post-American World, will be published next month.

title: Product Displacement
description: From the obituary today for Abby Mann, 80, Oscar-winning screenwriter for the Holocaust trial drama Judgment at Nuremburg:

title: Ts New Spring Travel Issue
description: Ever the rolling, restless stone, T is on the move again. In the Spring 2008 Travel issue, we step into Asia, where Taipei stands at a crossroads, and continue on to the Alpine region of Tyrol, which straddles Italian and Austrian borders. Berlin, a city once divided, is in the midst of a new era of artistic expression, while stateside an Anchorage restaurant safeguards the spirit of Old Alaska and the boho paradise of Boulder, Colorado, takes the lead in the green movement. For those who don't feel like moving much, T serves up all-you-can-eat artisanal cheese in the Dairy State.

title: Immigration Debates Intensity Claims an Irreverent Voice
description: Updated, April 1, 4:59 p.m. Yes, it was an early April Fools Day prank.

title: Obama Makes Personal Pitch to Indiana
description: Amid a grim setting, Barack Obama tries to send an inspiring message to Indiana voters: Hell bring back jobs.

title: In Indiana, Clinton Keeps On Running
description: MISHAWAKA, Ind.  Before presenting her economic plan at a rally here today, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton opened with a piece of political commentary: There are some people who are saying, you know, we really ought to end this primary, we just ought to shut it down.

title: Bear Attack? Not to Worry
description: When I went on a dogsled and ski expedition in the Arctic, we carried a rifle and a flare gun for protection against polar bears, and we still worried about being attacked by the bear wed heard was the most fearsome on the planet. But we were mistaken both in our strategy and our concerns, according to Thomas S. Smith, a biologist who has analyzed close encounters between humans and bears in Alaska.

title: Goliaths, Untested
description: North Carolina and Kansas, two of the tournament's top seeds, have not yet been legitimately tested and may not be until the meet in the Final Four.

description: Stanford's low-post presence goes up against Texas' guard play.

title: PaidContent vs. TechCrunch: Two Visions of Bloggings Future
description: Michael Arrington and Rafat Ali are both forceful, sharp-tongued, quick-tempered and plugged in, and both have built successful technology blogging ventures. So its no surprise that there is more than a little sparring between them.

title: Have Video Cameras, Will Pedal
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Strewn Storage: Chopsticks Become Pick-Up Sticks
description: Robert Clark and Lai Ling Jew have heard more than their share of chopstick jokes in the last month, in what Ms. Jew figures must be every permutation imaginable. Not that the couples situation is particular humorous: they lost their work space in a shuttered Williamsburg loft building at 475 Kent Avenue, then took on thousands of dollars in damages when the floor above Mr. Clarks storage locker collapsed.

title: Extending China's Reach
description: The network of roads is a major milestone for China and its neighbors.

title: The Sycophant and the Saboteur
description: Tale of an office toadys revenge:

title: Harvesting Wind at the Fresh Kills Landfill
description: Call it tilting at Fresh Kills. Or call it a possible dream. James P. Molinaro, the Staten Island borough president, sent a letter to Gov. David A. Paterson on Thursday asking him to consider turning Fresh Kills, the former landfill, into a wind farm.

title: Over on Well . . .
description: I had a wonderful talk (an interview, I guess) with Tara Parker-Pope, who writes the super blog Well, all about learning to cook. Take a look.

title: NBC Pokes CBS In the Eye, Which Is Legal In Mixed Martial Arts, Apparently
description: Theres no better lead than this one, so: NBC beat CBS to the punch, TV Week reports.

title: CBS Names An Heir To Roger King
description: The company responsible for distributing The Oprah Winfrey Show, Wheel of Fortune, Judge Judy, Inside Edition and other popular syndicated programs has a new president.

title: Clear Channel Warns Buyout May Collapse
description: Radio broadcaster Clear Channel Communications said on Friday its pending $20 billion buyout may collapse, as the banks had failed to provide funding for the deal under previously agreed terms.

title: Comments of the Week: Leaving Jericho
description: The series finale of Jericho, shown Tuesday on CBS, left fans with some hope that the show could go on  albeit on another network. At the end of the episode the lead characters defused a nuclear bomb threat but instigated a new American civil war between the eastern and western states.

title: The Week in Comments: Isnt It Amazing How Picky Weve All Become?
description: Monday, March 24

title: Rate Your Brooklyn Bus Routes
description: For many Brooklynites, the public bus system is a lifeline for getting around. The B61 in Red Hook, the B37 in Bay Ridge, the B48 in Sheepshead Bay and the B83 in Starrett City are all vital pathways for commuters, particularly in neighborhoods that have few or no concentration of subway stations. Unlike the notoriously slow crosstown buses of Manhattan, Brooklyn buses are a different creature. (Take the culture of express-bus commuters, for example.)

title: Low-Income Residents Get High-Speed Access
description: Last summer, when Earthlink pulled the plug on plans to build a citywide Wi-Fi network in San Francisco, it looked like only those with the money to pay for high-speed Internet access (or with a decent laptop and a good map of free hotspots) would be able to get it.

title: Feelings of Inadequacy
description: Earlier this week, Take-Two Interactive filed its Schedule 14D-9 with the Securities and Exchange Commission, a required response to the hostile takeover bid from rival video-game maker Electronic Arts.

title: The House Guest Who Came to Visit and Stayed to Cook
description: David Latt is a blogger, tv producer and writer (he worked on both Hill Street Blues and Twin Peaks, pretty good credentials if you ask me), and a friend of mine. He lives in L.A. and is a really good home cook. Today, we welcome him as an occasional Bitten guest poster, and allow him to show off a bit: three dishes from one chicken MB

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Friday, Mar. 28:

title: Why Jerry Jones Wont Draft Darren McFadden
description: The N.F.L. draft rumor that simply wont go away is that Cowboys owner Jerry Jones wants to trade his teams two picks late in the first round for a pick near the top of the first round, so he can select Arkansas running back Darren McFadden.

title: Cantaloupe Recall Widens
description: BRIEFS The controversial cantaloupe recall tied to salmonella widened in the United States with Chiquitas voluntary participation.

title: Jimmy Cayne Sells Bear Stake
description: CNBC reports on James E. Cayne, chairman of Bear Stearns, selling his entire stake in the company for $61 million.

title: NCAA Drops the Puck
description: As the NCAA tournament gets under way tonight, the matchup to watch is Colorado College against Michigan State. The Tigers are the second seed in the West Regional and will be on their home ice against last years national champions.

title: F1 in Schools video from Malaysia
description: When I was in Malaysia for the race I attended the F1 in Schools world championship races and did a story on it in the IHTs new special F1 page. I also did a short video about the event, and have now put it up on the site and linked it to the story I wrote about the F1 in Schools event. And as you can see, Ive also placed it below:

description: To all the Huck Finns, Nancy Drews, Hannah Montanas out there

description: When I was in Malaysia for the race I attended the F1 in Schools world championship races and did a story on it in the IHTs new special F1 page. I also did a short video about the event, and have now put it up on the site and linked it to the story I wrote about the F1 in Schools event. And Ive also linked it below:

title: Not a Vacation
description: So you are going on vacation, my postal carrier, Leslie, said with a smile when I asked her to hold my mail in Massachusetts.

title: Ratings: A Revived Apprentice Finale Wins Out
description: Piers Morgan, best known for his role as a judge on NBCs Americas Got Talent, became the seventh winner of NBCs Apprentice series on Thursday as the shows two-hour finale earned the nights highest ratings. According to Nielsens estimates, 12.1 million viewers tuned in from 9 to 11 p.m. for the Apprentice conclusion, the largest audience for any episode of the series since the finale of The Apprentice 4 in December 2005.

title: Soft Serve | Anti-Terrorist Beds, $3 Million Tax Rebates, The Worlds Chicest Helicopter
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: The Insider | Kevin Francis Gray
description: (Kevin Francis Gray)The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here the British artist Kevin Francis Gray  shares a few of his stylish essentials with The Moment. VOLTA NY, which coincides with its sister fair, The Armory Show, will be showing Grays work through March 30. Catch him now before hes back home in Hackney.

title: Clintons Fund-Raising Appeal: We Arent Going to Step Aside
description: If Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons newest fund-raising e-mail isnt a response to some calls for her to quit the Democratic presidential primary, were not sure what would be.

title: A Small Lifeline for Clover Users
description: Yesterday, when I spoke to a representative of the Coffee Equipment Company, which makes the Clover brewing machine, she confirmed that CloverNet, the technology that connects Clover users,  would no longer be available to anyone other than Starbucks, C.E.C.s new owner.

title: Groups Seek End to Personal Use of Campaign Money
description: In the wake of Gov. David A. Patersons recent revelations that he used campaign funds to pay for hotel stays with his paramours, furniture and clothing, a group of government watchdog groups came together this afternoon to urge leaders in Albany to ban the personal use of such money.

title: Fallout From the Mozzarella Scare
description: The Italian buffalo mozzarella industry seems to finally be getting somewhere in its efforts to combat a dioxin-contamination scare that has been clobbering cheese sales.

title: Auriemma, UConns Chess Master
description: One of the givens in womens college basketball is that Connecticut will be at the top or close to it. But what has happened this season is ridiculous.

title: Just Browsing
description: Just Browsing sews together the latest fashion news from our global sources of mags, trades, blogs and tipsters.

title: In This Weeks Magazine: Lost and Found
description: Not too long ago, the only people who collected things were retirees, housewives and underemployed eccentrics. My grandfather was into coins; my grandmother stockpiled seashells. An aunt propped up 100 Beanie Babies in a glass display case. A friends father hoarded lead Civil War soldiers even though he was English. My dads colleague collected railroad ties and would show kids that a whole train line  and a bygone era in American history  could be reconstructed from what looked like a single big, crude nail.

title: The Writing on the Wall at Rent
description: Heres the perfect mix for poignant remembrances:

title: The Rangers Russian Intrigue
description: A planned trip to New York by Anatoly Bardin, the general manager of the Russian Elite League team Avangard Omsk, next week has all kinds of implications for the Rangers.

title: George W. Bush Speaks About Iraq
description: The President sees a "defining moment" in Iraq and "a test" for the Iraqi government. (NBC Video)

title: A Healthy Battle Between Obama and Clinton
description: After my hand-wringing about the damage to the Democratic Party from the feuding between Obama and Clinton supporters, heres a healthy rivalry for a change. Stephen Colbert challenged partisans in each camp to duke it out at Donorschoose.org, a terrific web-based program that allows people to support specific school projects. My wife and I have supported projects on DonorsChoose and were pleased to see this competition. At last count, those giving in honor of Obama are ahead of those giving in honor Clinton by 1,220 to 115so you Hillary fans had better make your move.

title: Watering Down Smoking Bans
description: As indoor smoking bans spread through the United States and Europe, so do creative ways to water them down.

title: Student Stabbed at Crown Heights School
description: An 18-year-old student was stabbed and critically injured just before lunch today at Paul Robeson High School, at 150 Albany Avenue in Crown Heights, Brooklyn.The student was stabbed in the right shoulder by another male student, said Marge Feinberg, a spokeswoman for the Education Department.

title: Answers About Health in New York, Part 3
description: Following is a third and final set of answers from James R. Knickman, the president and chief executive of the New York State Health Foundation, who took questions from readers during the past week on a range of issues from universal health care and Medicaid to the prevalence in New York of problems like obesity, diabetes, smoking and substance abuse.

title: Casey Endorses Obama
description: Senator Bob Casey of Pennsylvania endorsed Senator Barack Obama. (NBC Video)

title: Literary Dealbreakers
description: Over the years Ive thought a lot about the connection between reading habits and dating habits. In a back-page essay this Sunday, I explore what I call literary dealbreakers. In the deputy editorati semi-circles in which I often travel  where everyone subscribes to the New York Review of Books and at parties in brownstone Brooklyn young writers are forever asking each other What are you working on? and advising each other to totally pitch that to Harpers  book talk is as central to the scene as drinking, sex and even talk about real estate. (Well, maybe not as central as real estate.)

title: Chelseas Choice
description: This question, posed to Chelsea Clinton, left us pining for a follow-up.

title: Its Pittsburgh, With an H
description: We all have our issues when it comes to speed-writing and spell-check, but on the day that your candidate begins a six-day bus tour across the Keystone State to allow voters to get to know him, well, maybe you should be careful with your spelling of Pennyslvanias bigger cities.

title: Obamas Big Oil Ad Draws Fire
description: Updated In his second new TV spot of the day  this one now playing in Pennsylvania  Barack Obama takes a strong stand against Big Oil, saying he wont let them block change anymore.

title: About the Social Security trust fund
description: I see from comments on an earlier post, plus some of the incoming links, that the whole there is no trust fund, so the system will be in crisis in 2017 thing is still out there. So Im just going to reprint what I wrote about this three years ago:

title: George Gillett Speaks
description: The co-owner of Liverpool of the English Premier League, the owner of the Montreal Canadiens of the N.H.L. and the potential owner of a new M.L.S. team in Montreal, was interviewed on the FAN590, a sports-talk radio station in Toronto. Heres the link.

title: Somalia on the Brink
description: Fighting this year has displaced many Somalis. Aid organizations say that more than half of Mogadishus estimated one million people are on the run.

description: A trailer for The Lost Ring, an alternate reality game  that McDonald's commissioned for the Olympics.

title: A Zoo Jumps for Joy Over the Life of Riley
description: At least they didnt call it Akituusaq.

title: Clinton Says Shes in It for the Long Haul
description: HAMMOND, Ind.  To answer questions that have been swirling around her candidacy all day, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton arrived here in northwest Indiana  just a few miles from her Democratic rivals home on Chicagos South Side  to unequivocally say she has no intention of leaving the presidential race.

title: No Charges, but Spitzer Played Role in Bruno Matter, Report Says
description: Updated, 7:25 p.m. | Gov. Eliot Spitzer was deeply involved in his administrations effort last year to discredit the states top Republican politician, Joseph L. Bruno, and may have been not truthful when he was interviewed by investigators about the matter, according to a highly critical report released this afternoon by the Albany district attorney, P. David Soares.

title: The Armory Show
description: An air of orderly professionalism pervades the Armory Show on Pier 94.

title: Fox Cancels Jezebel James
description: The Return of Jezebel James will not be back.

title: Kids' Choice Awards
description: A video clip from the 2007 show featuring Justin Timberlake.

title: Out Of Treatment
description: In Treatment, the innovative HBO series where Gabriel Byrne stars as a therapist who sees his patients each day  and ends the week by sitting down for his own therapy sessions  will conclude tonight after an intensive nine-week run.

title: Kids' Choice Awards
description: A video excerpt from last year's Kid's Choice Awards show on Nickelodeon.

title: A Tale of Two Camcorders
description: Regarding my review of the $150, ultra-simple Flip camcorder last week:

title: Heeeeeeeres Sean
description: PHOENIX  Xavier Coach Sean Miller complimented U.C.L.A. Coach Ben Howlands wry sense of humor on Friday.

title: If Market Prices Are Too Low, Ignore Them
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is out today with a letter to companies that own a lot of financial instruments whose current market value must be reported to shareholders. For more than a few companies, disclosing market values is neither easy nor convenient.

title: Holding China Accountable on Tibet
description: Some of the worlds leaders are finally beginning to respond in a serious way to Chinas crack down on Tibet, which by Friday included hundreds of arrests in the remote Himalayan region as well as at least 19 deaths.

title: Lil Wayne Is an Augustin Fan
description: HOUSTON  The Texas sophomore D.J. Augustins favorite musician is the rapper Lil Wayne.

title: Web and the Single Girl
description: The upcoming release of "Sex and the City," the movie, is creating plenty of talk about the perils of New York City's social scene.

title: Bloggingheads: Cash for Grades
description:
Glenn Loury, left, of Brown University and Heather MacDonald of the Manhattan Institute discuss whether students should be paid for good behavior.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: The Week in Pictures for March 28
description: Here is a slide show of photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the third annual New York City Pillow Fight, protests on the fifth anniversary of the war in Iraq and the cleanest line in the subway system, the L train.

title: Williams Sees No Advantage for Tar Heels
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  No coach has taken more umbrage than North Carolinas Roy Williams each time he has been asked about the Tar Heels supposed home-court advantage in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Clarkson Guts Out Win Over St. Cloud
description: The first game of this years NCAA tournament matched St. Cloud States finesse and Clarksons grit. While finesse held on for a while, in the end, Clarksons playoff grit outworked the Huskies to a 2-1 win and a spot in Saturday nights regional final. The Golden Knights will face the winner of tonights game between Michigan and Niagara.

title: Being Multiracial in America
description: Students at Rutgers University discuss the joys and challenges of being Americans of mixed race.

title: Dot Earth: Local Cooking
description: Times environment reporter Andrew C. Revkin cooks up a local salad with Chef Peter Hoffman.

title: Dot Earth: Local Cooking
description: Times environment reporter Andrew C. Revkin cooks up a local salad with Chef Peter Hoffman.

title: U.C.L.A. and the X Factor
description: Will U.C.L.A.'s luck hold against a surging Xavier?

title: They're All Dangerous Now
description: Will Louisville's momentum carry them past a dominant but untested North Carolina?

title: What Is a Midmajor Anyway?
description: Smaller schools are challenging larger programs in this year's N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: The Masque of the Red Death
description: Like Joyce, I found Stephens comments about how Bonfire was received in the academic world  as an attack on Reaganism  to be very interesting, because for many years before the book came out Wolfe had been making his conservative beliefs well-known. Many people, myself included as a college student in the seventies, were shocked that Wolfe, the liberating stylist and journalist, turned out to be very antipathetic to liberals and leftish intellectualism in all its forms, political, literary, artistic and architectural. Yes, in about 1970 he had written Radical Chic and Mau-Mauing the Flak Catchers, but they were brilliant pieces that didnt necessarily demonstrate a systematic conservatism. By the late 1980s, though, Wolfe had written and lectured often about his conservative views, he had been a guest of Reagans and Christopher Hitchens had called him the moth-eaten court jester for the White House. Wolfe would probably be amused that the academy was so insulated and so steeped in its own conventional wisdom that its members simply assumed that he agreed with them.

title: Troubles for Sampson Stuns Former Player
description: HOUSTON  As a fearless, gritty player at Oklahoma, Hollis Price embodied the hard-nosed approach of the former Sooners coach Kelvin Sampson.

title: Literary Mating, Continued
description: Reading Rachel Donadios reference to Norman Rushs Mating in her post on literary dealbreakers  hot on the heels of Jennifer Balderamas most mellisonant post about obscure words  reminded me of John Updikes review in the New Yorker of that remarkable 1991 novel about a brilliant young American anthropologist in Botswana who falls in love with an older and even more brilliant man. After praising Mating as aggressively brilliant, Updike took Rush to task for his aggressive modernist designs on conventional reading habits, epitomized by his ostentatiously arcane vocabulary. (Yes, lots of brilliance and lots of aggression here.)

title: Wooden Watches From Afar
description: PHOENIX  U.C.L.A. Coach Ben Howland spent part of his news conference after Thursday nights 88-78 victory over Western Kentucky joking about how the Bruins loved to make games close so that they would be exciting for their fans.

title: Welcome to T5
description: London Heathrow's Airport opened its new $9 billion terminal, T5, but it didn't take off with rave reviews.

title: Candidate, Improve Your Appearance!
description: Hillary Clinton is just beginning a live speech as I type. And I just failed in my purpose.

title: Joe Girardi, Jedi Master
description: I never thought of Joe Girardi as Yoda. For one thing, hes not 900 years old. Hes not green. And while Girardi may carry a baseball bat at times, Ive never seen him with a cane.

title: X Marks The Spot
description: PHOENIX  Xavier Coach Sean Miller gave a state of the union about his program Friday and it provided an interesting perspective on just how much the Musketeers have quietly accomplished.

title: Translating Homer: To Each His Own Muse
description: Robert Fagless translations departed markedly from those of his predecessors, as shown below in the opening lines of The Odyssey.

title: Pettitte Placed on D.L. as Yankees Pare Roster
description: MIAMI  Joe Girardi returned Friday to his first home as a manager, the place where he learned just how fitting the job was for him, even if the Florida Marlins did not invite him back for a second season after 2006.

title: Payments Are Ordered in Searches of Inmates
description: More than 20,000 nonviolent inmates who were wrongfully strip-searched at the Nassau County jail in the late 1990s are now eligible to receive compensation, under a federal judges ruling issued Thursday evening.

title: A Multitude of Vaccine Benefits, Yet Controversy Persists
description: Public health experts generally agree that after clean water and flush toilets, the most important health advances in history have been vaccinations.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: The cover article in The Times Magazine this weekend, about the recent struggles of the Republican Party, misspells the surname of the Democratic congressman who helped devise the strategy for the Democratic gains in the 2006 Congressional elections. He is Rahm Emanuel, not Emmanuel.

title: Incoming at the Governors Office
description: Gov. David Paterson of New York is being bombarded from all sides. The $124 billion state budget is due Monday at midnight. Mayor Michael Bloombergs proposal for congestion pricing needs to be approved within days. The plan to transform Manhattans grimy Pennsylvania Station into Moynihan Station, a grand complex, is now in limbo, courtesy of the owners of Madison Square Garden. Mr. Paterson can win these battles, but none are going to be easy.

title: Not Everyone Is Cheering Lower Rates
description: THE large reduction in interest rates this year is a boon to debt-heavy homeowners and businesses, and it may yet save the economy from recession. But it does no favors for people who receive more interest income than they pay out, like those in, or close to, retirement.

title: Richard Widmark DVD Essentials
description: KISS OF DEATH (1947) Mr. Widmark became a sensation in his debut film under Henry Hathaways direction, as a style-setting psychotic killer. (Fox, $14.98, not rated)

title: Call Girl Linked to Spitzer Knew Reputed Mob Affiliate
description: Federal investigators have developed information that the prostitute whom Eliot Spitzer is said to have met in Washington last month has some relationship with a man who the authorities contend is an associate of organized crime, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

title: What to Ask About Vaccinations
description: Most pediatricians follow the recommended schedule for childhood vaccinations, making parents jobs easier. But with all the new vaccines that have been rolled out in recent years, its a good idea to have a vaccine conversation with your doctor, especially when it comes to older children and adults. Here are some questions you may not think to ask, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: More Flimflam on Warming
description: On April 2, 2007, the Supreme Court ruled that the Clean Air Act clearly empowered the Environmental Protection Agency to address greenhouse gas emissions from cars and trucks. The ruling instructed the agency to determine whether global warming pollution endangers public health and welfare  an endangerment finding  and, if so, to devise emissions standards for motor vehicles.

title: Speaking Strictly Financially, Stick With the Hamster
description: MY 9-year-old son, Gabriel, wants a dog. He is desperate for a dog. All his friends are getting such cute little puppies.

title: Turning the Spotlight on McCain
description: To the Editor:

title: Gang Fights in Prison Injure 22 and Kill One
description: HOUSTON  A federal prison in Texas erupted in violence early Friday when two gang-related fights broke out almost simultaneously in facing housing units. One inmate was killed, and 22 were injured, officials said.

title: From Peruvian Obscurity to a Major Derby Prep
description: No one is quite sure what to make of Tomcito. He has done great things on the racetrack but has done them far from the limelight and against suspect competition. Is he for real, a legitimate Kentucky Derby contender, or is he a horse who will turn out to be outclassed when he faces the cream of the American 3-year-old crop?

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: A picture caption and a headline in some copies on Friday about a fire on the Lower East Side, using information from a city official, referred incorrectly to the casualties. Although some people were injured, no one in fact died.

title: Gipp Lawsuit Is Dismissed, but an Appeal Is Planned
description: The decision by a Michigan judge to dismiss a lawsuit over the exhumation of the remains of George Gipp did nothing to quiet the main parties on either side of the case.

title: A Conductor Steps in, With Big Shoes to Fill
description: One mans discomfort is another mans opportunity. Thats show business. Riccardo Muti has canceled his conducting dates with the New York Philharmonic because of an illness, and the young Michael Christie has stepped in. On Thursday at Avery Fisher Hall, Mr. Christie took on Elgars Violin Concerto, the Copland Third Symphony and a big-time symphony orchestra sitting in front of him. Pinchas Zukerman, an old pro, was the violinist.

title: Sudan States Its Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuba Allows More Cellphones
description: MEXICO CITY  Cuba announced Friday that it would allow ordinary citizens to purchase cellphones, which up until now have been set aside for Communist Party elite or those with connections.

title: To Protest Fuel Costs, Truckers Plan Idle Day
description: Dan Little says $4-a-gallon diesel fuel and other soaring costs forced him to temporarily halt his cattle-hauling business in Missouri several days ago, and he may have persuaded truckers across the country to pull their rigs off the road next week.

title: Tibetan Students Climb Wall to Ask Help of U.N. Officials in Nepal
description: NEW DELHI  Roughly 20 Tibetan high school students scaled a brick wall surrounding the United Nations compound in Katmandu, Nepal, on Friday morning, carrying a small homemade sign that read Free Tibet and asking the United Nations to help their cause, according to a United Nations spokesman.

title: Ruling Gives Heirs a Share of Superman Copyright
description: LOS ANGELES  Time Warner is no longer the sole proprietor of Superman.

title: Corporate Sponsors Nervous as Tibet Protest Groups Shadow Olympic Torchs Run
description: The disruption of a Chinese officials address during the Olympic torch lighting ceremonies in Greece last week was just the beginning of a string of protests planned to coincide with the torchs trip around the globe.

title: California: Brothers Injured by Tiger File Claim
description: Two brothers who were attacked by an escaped tiger at the San Francisco Zoo have filed claims against the city alleging negligence and defamation. The brothers, Kulbir and Amritpal Dhaliwal, are seeking monetary compensation for serious physical and emotional injuries. The claims are a prerequisite for filing a civil lawsuit. The two were injured on Dec. 25 after a Siberian tiger attacked them and killed their friend Carlos Sousa Jr. The animal was shot dead by the police.

title: Britain: More Chaos at Heathrow
description: For the second successive day, British Airways canceled dozens of flights at Heathrow Airports glittery new Terminal 5 as its staff struggled with state-of-the-art technology supposed to hasten check-in and baggage-handling procedures. The hitches since the terminal opened on Thursday were definitely not British Airways finest hour, the airlines chief executive, Willie Walsh, told reporters. Some passengers slept overnight inside the steel-and-glass terminal, reviving precisely those images of delay and decline in British aviation that British Airways said Terminal 5 would banish.

title: Freed Ex-Governor of Alabama Talks of Abuse of Power
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.  Former Gov. Don Siegelman of Alabama, released from prison Friday on bond in a bribery and corruption case, said he was as convinced as ever that politics had played a leading role in his prosecution.

title: Discussion of Discipline Slows Talks on Doping
description: Commissioner Bud Seligs reluctance to forgo punishment for players named in the Mitchell report has slowed negotiations between Major League Baseball and the players union over the adoption of numerous recommendations in the report.

title: As a Musical Winds Down, the Writings on the Wall
description: At the lime-green wall, soon to be whitewashed, all the elements are there for poignant remembrances: a curtain scheduled to come down, forever; a creative genius who dies young, before his dreams come to life; a show about an exotic dancer who dies young and musically and slowly; and a doorway where the fans, more devoted than most, wait longer than usual, before and after each show.

title: Jail Guard Gets 2 Years in Prison
description: A former prison guard who pleaded guilty last year to helping to cover up the assault of an inmate at the federal jail in Brooklyn was sentenced on Friday to two years in prison.

title: Harvey Picker, 92, Pioneer in Patient-Centered Care, Is Dead
description: Harvey Picker, the former president and chairman of a major X-ray equipment maker whose wifes illness inspired him to start a foundation that is considered a leader in promoting patient-friendly medical care, died on March 22 at his home in Camden, Me. He was 92.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: A jazz entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the Michael Weiss Trio, at the Village Vanguard, misstated the day Dennis Mackrel is to fill in for Lewis Nash on drums. It is Wednesday, not Tuesday.

title: Today in Business
description: S.E.C. NOMINEES President Bush will nominate two Democrats to join the all-Republican Securities and Exchange Commission, an administration official said Friday.

title: The Dashwood Quest for Civil Unions
description: The screenwriter Andrew Daviess latest adaptation of Jane Austen  Masterpiece Theaters production of Sense and Sensibility, beginning on Sunday night on PBS  proves again that we should all suffer the misfortunes of real estate endured by the downgraded heroines of Austens tributes to love and property.

title: Firings at the Voice
description: The Village Voice has dismissed its dance critic, Deborah Jowitt, leaving the weekly with no full-time staff dance writers. Ms. Jowitt, right, began at the newspaper in November 1967 and was one of its senior arts writers. She said in a telephone interview that she learned on Tuesday that her position was being eliminated for economic reasons, along with that of the film critic Nathan Lee. Julie Lichtenstein, a spokeswoman for the paper, said in an e-mail message: Financial constraints force us to convert two full-time positions to freelance jobs. Both Deborah Jowitt and Nathan Lee have been asked to continue writing for The Voice. Ms. Jowitt said, I was told that the dance page would continue to exist, adding that her dismissal came as a complete shock to me.

title: Cuba: Cellphones for Anyone
description: The government announced that it would permit the general public to buy cellphones, which until now were set aside mainly for the Communist Party elite. The move was seen as a sign of liberalization by the new president, Ral Castro. But most Cubans, who earn only about $20 monthly in state salaries, will find it hard to afford the phones without help from relatives off the island.

title: 2 Arrested in Virginia Highway Shootings
description: Two teenagers were arrested on Friday in connection with a series of highway shootings near Charlottesville, Va., that left two people with minor injuries and shut down the road for several hours early Thursday, the state police said.

title: Nationals Look for Fresh Start at New Stadium
description: WASHINGTON  Look around. The cherry blossoms are in bloom, the pope is planning a visit and the presidential contest is taking its toll in fingernails. But the capital city is all fired up over  wait for it  baseball.

title: A Mothers Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: Provoked by a Force of Nature
description: A performance can occasionally provoke near-simultaneous sensations of impatience, irritation, fascination and curiosity. Such was the case on Wednesday night during Wendy Ossermans new Out of Place, presented at the Hudson Guild Theater.

title: Spitzer May Have Lied, Prosecutor Says
description: ALBANY  Evidence collected by the Albany district attorneys office indicates that Gov. Eliot Spitzer lied to the public last year about his role in an effort to discredit a political rival and may have misled the district attorneys office itself in an interview last year, according to a report released late Friday.

title: Obama Communicates, Even Without Words
description: Senator Barack Obama didnt go on The View on Friday solely to talk about race and the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr. He also wanted to address the gender issue. And if the fluttery response of the shows five co-hosts is any harbinger, Mr. Obama will not have any trouble assuaging female voters if Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton drops out of the Democratic race for the White House.

title: Trying to Feel Iraqs Contrasting Realities
description: The American invasion of Iraq has seldom been addressed directly in modern dance in New York, so the notion that Victoria Marks would take on this overwhelming issue was very good news. But Not About Iraq, seen on Thursday night at the Danspace Project at St. Marks Church, is a disappointment.

title: Bush Says Iraq Has Reached Defining Moment
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush strongly defended Iraqs prime minister on Friday at what he called a defining moment for the Baghdad government, saying the United States supported its offensive against a Shiite militia and would provide any military assistance that was sought.

title: In ESPNs Studio, Knight Remains in Command
description: Its fascinating how much ESPN is making of having Bob Knight in its employ during the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament. He has been Bobby-in-the morning on Mike and Mike on ESPN radio, which is simulcast on ESPN2, then repurposed on other shows during the day. On tournament nights, hes on SportsCenter, which is replayed hither and yon, and his repartee with Digger Phelps, Dick Vitale and Rece Davis is recycled.

title: McCain Forecloses Early
description: I dont see how anybody could deny that John McCain is a straight-talker. The country is terrified of economic collapse and hes been sounding like Mr. Potter, the banker in Its a Wonderful Life. You cant get more forthright than that.

title: Footnotes
description: Katie Holmes is in negotiations to star in a Broadway-bound revival of Arthur Millers All My Sons, the British newspaper The Daily Mail reported. John Lithgow is already attached to the production, scheduled to open this fall. Eric Falkenstein, the shows producer, would not comment on the report; messages left for Ms. Holmess agent and publicist were not returned.

title: Plastic Card Tricks
description: Americans are struggling with a very rocky economy while they are also holding almost $1 trillion in credit card debt. In most cases, those cards provide a little flexibility with the monthly bills. But an increasing number of people are defaulting because of the tricks and traps  soaring interest rates and hidden fees  in the credit card business.

title: A System Overdue for Reform
description: A week ago Thursday, just days after the big Bear Stearns crisis, Representative Barney Frank gave a speech to the Greater Boston Chamber of Commerce. Most people know Mr. Frank, a Democrat from Massachusetts, as one of the most liberal members of Congress.

title: Barry Diller Wins as Court Allows His 5-Way Division of IAC
description: In the battle of the billionaire media moguls, the protg won.

title: Old Dominion Tries to Recapture Success
description: NORFOLK, Va.  Fifteen minutes from where Jazzmin Walters was raised stands Old Dominion University, a sprawling 188-acre campus in a coastal city that once was a hub of womens college basketball.

title: Switching Gears, From a Magazine to a Quiz
description: The final edition of Bridge Today magazine, edited by Pamela and Matthew Granovetter, will be published shortly. It started 20 years ago in a printed edition but five years ago went onto the Internet, copies being delivered to e-mail in-boxes.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article on Page 52 of The Times Magazine this weekend about this summers Olympics in Beijing and the effects of political activists on them and their sponsors omits a sentence in a statement from Microsoft, a sponsor of the games, about the need for international organizations to intervene in Sudan, which buys weapons from China. The passage containing the statement should read: The company further commend[ed] Dream for Darfur and other organizations for their leadership in casting a spotlight on this atrocity and the need for immediate international resolution. Governments and international organizations  the United Nations chief among them, as well as humanitarian relief organizations  will need to continue to work together locally and globally to address the problems in the Sudan. Microsoft will continue to support these organizations in their mission through technology assistance and other resources.

title: Japanese Court Rejects Defamation Lawsuit Against Nobel Laureate
description: TOKYO  A Japanese court rejected a defamation lawsuit on Friday against Kenzaburo Oe, the 1994 Nobel laureate in literature, agreeing with his depiction of involvement by the Japanese military in the mass suicides of civilians in Okinawa toward the end of World War II.

title: Memphis Stays Focused, Routing Michigan State
description: HOUSTON  As Memphis Coach John Calipari and his players walked off the court at halftime, the teams rabid fans gave the Tigers a standing ovation.

title: My Great Escape
description: To the Editor:

title: Freed Alabama Ex-Governor Sees Politics in His Case
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.  Former Governor Don Siegelman of Alabama, released from prison today on bond in a bribery case, said he was as convinced as ever that politics played a leading role in his prosecution.

title: The Sky Really Is Falling
description: WHILE working on the renovation of an apartment on West 27th Street about 10 years ago, I witnessed a friend accidentally drop a hammer out of an eighth-floor window onto a busy sidewalk. It was one of those hot New York summer days, and the air-conditioning had yet to be hooked up. The hammer just slipped from his grip on an upward swing, bounced once on the window ledge and disappeared from our view.

title: Surprise Backing From Senator Reflected Frustration and Desire for Healing
description: Senator Bob Casey of Pennsylvania left for his Easter vacation in Florida determined to remain neutral in the increasingly bitter battle for the Democratic presidential nomination. But rain there kept him inside, and he began ruminating about the election and what was at stake.

title: Selected Studies: Immunizations
description: Government agencies, universities, doctors and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Playing the Odds as a Way of Life
description: Prokofiev was in his mid-20s and eager to shock when he began composing his second opera, The Gambler, in 1915. Looking to precedents by Mussorgsky, among others, Prokofiev decided to write a dialogue-driven opera, almost an anti-opera. There would be no set pieces, hardly any melodies, and no conventional ensembles with multiple characters singing at the same time. The Gambler, with a libretto by Prokofiev, adapted from the 1866 novella by Dostoyevsky, would be dramatically stark, an opera of musicalized dialogue driven by a teeming orchestra.

title: Thieves Leave Cars, but Take Catalytic Converters
description: CHICAGO  Jose Fernandez said he decided some time ago that on his salary as a restaurant worker, he was better off without his 1996 Toyota 4Runner. He hoped to make a nice bit of cash from its sale.

title: Somalias Government Teeters on Collapse
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  The trouble started when government soldiers went to the market and, at gunpoint, began to help themselves to sacks of grain last week.

title: Trying to Get the Swiss to Talk
description: GENEVA  Like Paul Revere, Konrad Hummler sounded the alarm last week as he made his way by train and by plane to his banks branches across Switzerland. This countrys storied role as secret banker to the worlds wealthy is under threat like never before, Mr. Hummler warned.

title: Typing Becomes a Travel Skill
description: LAST year was the first time that more travel was purchased online than off, Cond Nast Traveler reports. But the convenience of doing business over the Web comes with potential problems. To avoid them, the magazine suggests these steps:

title: Dalai Lama Warns China on Its News Reports
description: SHANGHAI  The Dalai Lama, Tibets spiritual leader in exile, criticized Chinas state-controlled media on Friday, saying its coverage of the unrest in Tibet earlier this month was biased and could eventually sow the seeds of racial tension there.

title: The Stars Return
description: George Clooney and Rene Zellweger, below, the stars of Leatherheads, the new 1920s-era comedy-romance-football movie, returned Thursday to Greenville, S.C., where some of the films scenes were shot, The Associated Press reported. The actors greeted fans and accepted keys to the city, more than 400 of whose residents worked as extras on the movie. The city, which reportedly enjoyed its brush with celebrity, decided to hold its own gala premiere on April 4 at the local Camelot Cinemas, the same night that the two stars attend the opening in Hollywood.

title: William Hyland, Who Guided Foreign Policy, Dies at 79
description: William G. Hyland, who helped shape United States foreign policy, particularly toward the Soviet Union, as a top-level bureaucrat and then became editor of the influential journal Foreign Affairs, died on March 25 in Fairfax, Va. He was 79.

title: Up, Up and a Ways Off the Track
description: To call Superhero Movie a satire, or even a parody, of the genre specified in its title would be misleading, since those terms imply at least an attempt at wit. But no real mockery is intended by this harmless, mindless grab bag of slightly used gags, which lampoons some of the conventions of recent comic-book epics and adds the expected staples of juvenile humor: urine, vomit and intestinal gas.

title: U.S. Airstrikes Aid Iraqi Army in Basra
description: BAGHDAD  The American military conducted airstrikes Thursday and Friday to back up stalled Iraqi forces in Basra and battle Shiite militias in Baghdad as continued violence and political infighting worsened the prospects for any timely reconciliation among Iraqs warring factions.

title: Stars and Slime at Kids Awards Show
description: LOS ANGELES  On Saturday night more than six million children and their parents are expected to tune in to the 21st annual Kids Choice Awards on Nickelodeon, where the host, Jack Black, will introduce Harrison Ford, Steve Carell, Cameron Diaz and Janet Jackson, among other adult presenters, as well as performances by Miley Cyrus and Nat and Alex Wolff of the Naked Brothers Band, each too young to drive.

title: Northwest Looks to Delta to Revive Merger Talks
description: Northwest Airlines has asked Delta Air Lines if it would like to restart merger talks, despite the inability of the carriers pilots to agree on how to merge their all-important seniority lists.

title: Resurgent Apprentice
description: NBCs Apprentice finale earned Thursdays highest ratings. Nielsen estimated that 12.1 million viewers tuned in from 9 to 11 p.m., the largest audience since the finale of The Apprentice 4 in December 2005. Ratings for the series had fallen since its inaugural 2004 season, which averaged almost 21 million viewers an episode, reaching its lowest level a year ago, with an average of just over seven million viewers. For the night over all, NBC ranked first, just ahead of CBS, which broadcast N.C.A.A. basketball. Fox was third and ABC fourth.

title: Disorder on the Border
description: TUCSON

title: Feet, Arms and Foam Tubing, All Moving to Led Zeppelin
description: Dance New Amsterdam was smart to name Laura Peterson as one of its 2007-8 artists in residence: as a set designer, she is a problem solver. This theater has flaws, notably the six columns planted firmly on the stage, along with the sad fact that the seats arent staggered  sometimes its best to just give up and sit in the front row.

title: Footnote
description: Katie Holmes is in negotiations to star in a Broadway-bound revival of Arthur Millers All My Sons, the British newspaper The Daily Mail reported. John Lithgow is already attached to the production, scheduled to open this fall. Eric Falkenstein, the shows producer, would not comment on the report; messages left for Ms. Holmess agent and publicist were not returned.

title: South Korea Plays Down Missile Test by the North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea drove up tensions on the Korean Peninsula on Friday, test-firing short-range missiles off its western coast, threatening to slow down its promised disabling of nuclear weapons facilities and accusing South Korea of sending warships across a disputed border, which it said could lead to naval clashes.

title: Warning: Ultraviolet Rays Are Around the Corner
description: It is early spring, though the weather in parts of the country still feels more like winter. But Brent Saunders, president of the consumer health care division of Schering-Plough, the maker of Coppertone, is thinking about summer.

title: Stalemate in Kenya Over Top Posts
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Power-sharing in Kenya, apparently, is easier said than done.

title: Eight Undeveloped Acres and Secret Videotapes Figure in Officials Trial
description: There is a gate at Cobblestone Estates  once promoted as the citys next gated community  just over the East New York border in Lindenwood, Queens. It is made of green-painted particleboard and tattered black tarp lashed to a chain-link fence.

title: Illinois: Reviewing Universitys Response to Shooting
description: Northern Illinois University, where a gunman killed five students and then himself, will assemble a task force to conduct an internal review into how it responded to the shooting, both immediately and in the weeks that followed. The task force, convened by the board of trustees, will also examine broader questions of mental illness on campus, investigating how universities can balance concerns about privacy with public safety. Cherilyn Murer, chairwoman of the board, said she hoped the review would contribute to a national discussion on campus shootings. Steven P. Kazmierczak, a graduate of the university, apparently went off medications before bursting into a lecture hall on Feb. 14 and shooting into the audience of students there.

title: Closing Case, Prosecutors Focus on Former Mayors Ties to Publicist

title: Art and the Nazis, Times Two
description: The Leopold Museum Private Foundation of Vienna has been accused of knowingly purchasing works that could have been stolen by the Nazis, The San Francisco Chronicle reported. A law professor commissioned by Austrian Jews found that at least 11 of the foundations works, including some by Egon Schiele (whose Liegende Frau is above), Anton Romako and Albin Egger-Lienz, belonged to people persecuted by the Nazis and that the collector Rudolf Leopold certainly knew that they might have been looted. He knew, or he must have known, that these paintings belonged to people who were persecuted by the Nazis, said Georg Graf, the professor. Because of that knowledge, he must have been aware of the possibility that these were stolen goods. Mr. Leopold, in an interview with Die Presse, disputed the allegation. In my eyes, the pictures were acquired lawfully, he said. The Austrian culture minister, Claudia Schmied, said at a news conference this week that she expected the foundation to approve an independent examination of its collection. ... The National Gallery in London said its painting Cupid Complaining to Venus, by the German artist Lucas Cranach the Elder, was once part of Hitlers private collection and may have been looted during World War II, The Washington Post reported. A researcher, Birgit Schwartz, spotted the painting  showing Cupid complaining to Venus that he has been stung by bees after stealing honey  in a photograph of Hitlers private gallery contained in an album at the Library of Congress in Washington and brought it to the attention of the National Gallery. The museum has been unable to account for the paintings ownership or whereabouts from 1909, when it was sold at auction in Berlin, to 1945, when an American war correspondent took it from a warehouse of art guarded by American troops in southern Germany, a National Gallery spokesman said. The gallery bought the painting in 1963 from E & A Silbermann, a New York art dealer; that company, no longer in business, said the work had been purchased from family descendants of the 1909 buyer. But in December 2004, the National Gallery spokesman said, the museum received an e-mail message from Jay Hartwell of Hawaii, who said that his mother, Patricia Lochridge Hartwell, had owned the painting from 1945 until she sold it to E & A Silbermann in 1963. Ms. Hartwell, who died in 1998 at 82, had been a reporter during the war, and she took the painting from the warehouse and returned with it to New York, where it hung, her son recalled, in their home.

title: Davidson Is Dazzling in Toppling Another Giant
description: DETROIT  While scoring 33 points to lead Davidson to a 73-56 upset of Wisconsin on Friday night, Stephen Curry made six 3-point field goals, including one while falling backward to the floor. But that was not the shot that got LeBron James on his feet.

title: Treasurys Plan Would Give Fed Wide New Power
description: WASHINGTON  The Treasury Department will propose on Monday that Congress give the Federal Reserve broad new authority to oversee financial market stability, in effect allowing it to send SWAT teams into any corner of the industry or any institution that might pose a risk to the overall system.

title: Reaching the Final Turn in 3 Years of Bumpy Road

The plan was to present the premieres of a dozen newly commissioned concertos in three annual installments, and mishaps werent long in coming. At the first concert, a piano concerto by Ichizo Okashiro, The Starry Night, proved too difficult to prepare in the available time and was postponed. It turned up in the finale, on Thursday evening. But a cello concerto by Marc-Andr Dalbavie was put off until next season, when it will be part of a Composer Portrait.

Onstage hes nonchalantly skillful, while she works herself into sweaty, disheveled, riveting turmoil. But they have collaborated on each others songs, and now they are sharing the Heart of the City tour, which came to Nassau Coliseum here on Thursday night and reaches Madison Square Garden May 2, 6 and 7.

Not coincidentally, both are high-polish concert artists, as they confirmed with a satisfying double bill on Thursday night at the Rose Theater.

title: Repatriated Art in Rome
description: Nine classical artifacts that until recently belonged to the New York philanthropist Shelby White will go on view Saturday at the Palazzo Poli in Rome as part of an exhibition of illicitly excavated antiquities returned to Italy by American museums, dealers and collectors. Among the pieces Ms. White handed over this year after long negotiations are two from the fifth century B.C., a bronze statuette of a nude youth and a calyx-krater attributed to the so-called Eucharides Painter. A 2,500-year-old krater attributed to the Greek master Euphronios will go back to Italy in two years under the agreement Ms. White reached with the Italian Culture Ministry. In a statement issued on Friday by both sides, Ms. White said that her collection had been purchased at public auction from dealers whom she and her husband, Leon Levy, who died in 2003, had believed to be reputable. She said she had nonetheless concluded, based on Italian government evidence, that their export from Italy was questionable. The Italian government has never accused Ms. White or Mr. Levy of any wrongdoing, and the joint statement said that Ms. White had shown great sensitivity and taken the initiative voluntarily to offer to return 10 items. The exhibition at the Palazzo Poli is an expanded version of Nostoi: Recovered Masterpieces, a show of some 70 pieces recovered mostly from four American museums, which opened in December at the Quirinale, or presidential palace, in Rome.

title: LETTERS: The Readers Speak
description: Re Playing Favorites? Dont Be So Sure (March 9):Ive noticed some other, more subtle forms of bias  both in The New York Times and in other news sources  that I dont quite understand.For example, when Senator Barack Obama wins a state he is expected to, like Wyoming, the victory seems to be played down. But when Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton wins a state she was expected to, like Ohio, it is heralded as a major alteration of the nominations dynamic.I can see this story line being developed for Pennsylvania, which is being framed as the crucial contest, but one that Mrs. Clinton begins with great strength.If the rules as set up by the Democratic National Committee are to choose a candidate by the total delegate count, and Mr. Obama has essentially a total that cannot be surpassed through regular state primaries and caucuses, I wonder why news coverage continues to treat the race as essentially even, and worse, that Senator Clinton somehow is gaining the upper hand.There are not always two equal sides to a story. In the case of the Democratic contest, it seems that the media are willing to engage in this subtle bias to continue the competitive narrative.Marc SchlossbergEugene, Ore., March 10, 2008

It has interviews with a number of prominent city players, including Hikaru Nakamura, Maurice Ashley (the only African-American grandmaster) and Joshua Waitzkin, on whose life the book and movie Searching for Bobby Fischer is based. There are also interviews with children and chess teachers, and a timeline of events with some archival photographs. A good deal of the historical material is about Bobby Fischer, the American champion who grew up in Brooklyn and who died two months ago. The students, Radha Vij and Jennie Cohen, are not chess players but became immersed in the culture as they worked on the project.

Kliel Rose performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in Miami Beach.

title: Davidson Seeks Final Four and Savors Moment
description: DETROIT  The players, coaches, cheerleaders and band members of Davidson are staying at a suburban hotel called the Dearborn Inn, built by Henry Ford, who also built behind it replicas of the historic homes of Patrick Henry, Walt Whitman and Edgar Allan Poe.

title: Why Blog? Reason No. 92: Book Deal
description: THIS is how it happens.

title: Happy Birthday to Mr. Hockey as Howe Turns 80
description: Before he was the walking embodiment of hockey, Gordie Howe, who turns 80 on Monday, looked up to the renowned defenseman Eddie Shore, the original Mr. Hockey.

title: Beverly Hills, Calif.: Thompson Beverly Hills
description: THE BASICS

title: Heidi Hertel, Greg Hodes
description: Heidi Melissa Hertel and Greg Alan Hodes were married on Saturday at the Beverly Hills Hotel in Beverly Hills, Calif. Rabbi Allen I. Freehling officiated, with the Rt. Rev. Alexei Smith, a Roman Catholic priest, participating.

title: Cheap, Convenient and Teeming
description: A map with the Living In article on March 16 about Woodside, Queens, referred incorrectly to a subway line in the neighborhood. The G, R and V line does not carry E and F trains. (Within Woodside, E and F trains run on a separate line, not shown on the map, but that line eventually merges with the line carrying the G, R and V trains.)

title: Steep Gas Prices on the South Fork Draw More Than a Shock
description: GASOLINE prices on the South Fork are consistently 20 to 50 cents more per gallon than in other areas of Long Island. But the recent run-up in gasoline prices to record levels has been a rude awakening for some South Fork residents.

title: Retribution: The Battle for Japan, 1944-45
description: Dilemmas and Decisions 1. War in the East

title: Tough Test for a Young Player: Seven Grandmasters in a Row
description: It is not uncommon in a big open tournament to face two or three grandmasters. But seven in a row is a rare and possibly unsettling experience.

title: If a Roommate Moves Without Giving Notice
description: Q  I rent an apartment in Manhattan and was subletting a room to the friend of a co-worker. One day, he moved out, with no notice, while I was at work.

title: Insurer Puts Pets in the Policy
description: MORE than anything, Kathleen McKamey remembers the day she was in a crash because it was one of the few times she did not have her Lhasa Apso, Cuddles Marie, with her.

title: Tackling Directing and George Clooney
description: JUST as fans of the NBC sitcom The Office were celebrating the transformation of the fictional colleagues Jim Halpert and Pam Beesly from unrequited lovers to an honest-to-goodness couple, the writers strike cruelly stalled their romance and halted production on the show for several months. But for John Krasinski, the actor who plays Jim, the affable everydude of The Office, the news wasnt all bad. He used the hiatus to resume postproduction work on his directorial debut, an adaptation of David Foster Wallaces Brief Interviews With Hideous Men, a collection of short stories and monologues that he has been trying to make into a film for more than five years.

title: What the Bear Meant for the Street
description: BACK in the days of ticker tape, when Wall Street firms like Morgan Stanley hired young men with pedigrees from colleges like Princeton and clubs like Piping Rock, Bear Stearns was the kind of place where hardscrabble Brooklynites could get a job.

title: A Tristan und Isolde Well Worth the Wait
description: All day on Friday the word from the Metropolitan Opera was good. The tenor Ben Heppner and the soprano Deborah Voigt were feeling fine and ready to go. Finally, after respective bouts of illness had prevented these acclaimed Wagnerians from appearing together in any of the five previous presentations of Wagners Tristan und Isolde, they would sing the sixth and final performance in this ill-fated run.

title: Plan to Help Homeowners Gains Steam
description: WASHINGTON  Federal housing agencies are moving closer to a possible plan to help homeowners caught between rising interest rates on their mortgages and falling home prices that preclude selling or refinancing to pay off those debts, officials said Saturday.

title: The Murky Politics of Mind-Body
description: From Plato and Aristotle to Descartes, the great thinkers have for millennia argued over what is known in philosophy as the mind-body problem, the relationship between spirit and flesh. Dualism tends to win the day: The mind and the body, while linked, are separate. They exist independently, perhaps mingling but not merging.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE SAVAGE DETECTIVES, by Roberto Bolao. Translated by Natasha Wimmer. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $15.) This craftily autobiographical novel (as our reviewer, James Wood, put it) was originally published in Spain in 1998, five years before Bolao died of liver failure at 50. Written in long, musical sentences that pile image upon image, the novel concerns two poets, one a lightly disguised version of the author, who search for a precursor from the 1920s who has disappeared. This is not just a postmodern game, Wood said. The Savage Detectives ... is both narrowly about poetry and broadly about the difficulty of sustaining the hopes of youth. It was one of the Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2007.

title: A Loopy Foray Into the World of Classic Myth
description: In the original version of the Greek legend, Jason and the Argonauts sailed the globe on their ship Argo in pursuit of the celebrated Golden Fleece. In Argonautika, Mary Zimmermans latest foray into the world of classic myth, now on stage at the McCarter Theater, these loopy, star-crossed swashbucklers introduce themselves in the guise of hip-hop rappers riffing to the beat of Caribbean percussion.

title: A Governor Who Knows His Way Around the Island
description: LONG ISLAND politicians are greeting David A. Patersons ascent as the new governor as if he were a hometown guy.

title: Kimberly Peirce: No Iraq Blockbuster
description: To the Editor:

title: Nanny of Camelot
description: When it comes to reporting on celebrities and politicians, a few tattered standards of privacy remain. But where the tabloids end and fiction begins, the authors of alternate histories root through a mix of real and imagined dirty laundry, exposing a character called, say, the Princess of Wales to indignities including scrubbing public bathrooms (in Mark Helprins Freddy and Fredericka) and managing a McDonalds (in Peter Lefcourts Di and I).

title: Time to Go on a Liquid Diet
description: AS the market keeps torturing us, many people say the problem is fallout from the losses in subprime mortgages. Others say it is fear of a recession because of the credit crisis, rising oil prices and the collapsing dollar and its flip side, inflation.

title: A Different Kind of Student Exam
description: JIM HENNESSY, a Darien High School junior, does not go to school dances anymore. The 16-year-old is boycotting them because to get in, he has to take a test that he thinks is unfair: Before he and classmates are allowed to enter a dance, they are asked to breathe into a device to determine whether they have consumed alcohol.

title: Applying Gandhis Ideas to Climate Change
description: GARRISON, N.Y.

title: A Veteran Mad Man Remains in the Fold
description: THIS was going to be a simple artist-at-work article about Al Jaffee, a man who could lay claim to being the worlds oldest adolescent and who just now is enjoying a fresh burst of public and professional recognition. The idea was to look in on him as he created the latest installment of a feature he has been drawing for Mad magazine since, incredibly, 1964.

title: An Unlikely Obsession: School Auctions
description: PATTY FURNER circled the chandelier-lit catering hall, trolling for bargains as she passed by row after row of gorgeously wrapped gift baskets at an auction this month to benefit the Hillside Elementary School in Livingston, N.J.

title: Just Grate
description: Sneer all you want, but I like cheese on seafood pasta. For years I even managed to escape the wrath of the Italian people for this supposed transgression. And then I went to Milan.

title: One Owner, Two Markedly Different Designs
description: TWO Brooklyn telephone buildings separated by only a block are nevertheless eons apart in their architecture: primly Beaux-Arts from 1898 at Willoughby and Lawrence Streets and a sizzling Art Deco skyscraper from 1930 at Willoughby and Bridge.

title: The Dukes of Broadway
description: IS it any wonder that when Tom Wopat and John Schneider, better known as good ol boys Luke and Bo Duke of the 1980s-era television show The Dukes of Hazzard, get together, they talk about... show tunes?

title: Out of Africa, the Wisdom of a Warrior
description: IT was late November at the American Museum of Natural History, and the actress Liv Tyler was standing next to a Masai warrior. This was a living, breathing man  he had arrived from Africa just a few days earlier  but he stood as motionless as the stuffed antelope that Ms. Tyler was pointing out to him. Giraffe-bone disks glinted in the mans ears, and a pheasant feather rose high above his headdress.

title: Cracking Down on the Cyberbully
description: DOBBS FERRY

title: Eos Airlines Lightens Its Menu
description: Eos Airlines (www.eosclass.com), an all-business-class carrier that flies between New York and London (and which will introduce service between London and Dubai in July), recently announced that it was upgrading its menu to emphasize lighter eating.

title: A Civil War Iraq Cant Win
description: Washington

title: Eyes Wide Open
description: To read a Tobias Wolff story is to sink into the soft seat of your grandfathers strong, modest old Buick and let yourself be carried through an America of small towns, small joys, small struggles and small despairs  a landscape so familiar as to be invisible, the landscape of homeland. As each tale proceeds, unhurried, unjudging, the car slows, the turn signal makes its reassuring clicks, and the car glides without resistance into the drive, delivering you, consoled yet strangely disquieted, to the place you came from  a place you thought youd left behind.

title: Whos a Good Boy?
description: In June 2006, an article appeared in the Modern Love column of this newspapers Sunday Styles section, under the headline What Shamu Taught Me About a Happy Marriage. The writer, Amy Sutherland, had spent time at a college for animal trainers while researching her book Kicked, Bitten, and Scratched. Watching students train baboons, emus, cheetahs and others, she picked up a few techniques that proved effective on a somewhat gentler beast: her husband, Scott. Apparently, readers everywhere were impressed by Sutherlands success at getting Scott to pick up his laundry, and the article began ricocheting across the Web  eventually becoming the single most viewed and most e-mailed Times article of 2006. You can guess the rest: Hollywood came calling (Naomi Watts is slated to star in the film version of Kicked, Bitten, and Scratched) and Sutherland landed a book deal.

title: Origin Story
description: Jackie Ormes, nee Zelda Mavin Jackson, was a journalist, artist, socialite and progressive political activist, a well-known figure in Chicagos black community in the 50s and 60s. She was also, as the subtitle of Nancy Goldsteins biography indicates, the first African-American woman to write and draw widely distributed comic strips: four different series, published between 1937 and 1956 in black newspapers including The Pittsburgh Courier and The Chicago Defender. Ormes was well ahead of her time; the first black woman to create a syndicated daily strip for mainstream papers was Barbara Brandon-Croft, whose Where Im Coming From didnt appear until 1989.

title: Taking Center Stage
description: Decades ago, Lincoln Center made the area just north of Columbus Circle a center for culture, but it took the Time Warner Center to transform the neighborhood into a hub of fine restaurants, among them these new or improved places.

title: 9/11 Lawyer Made Name in Lawsuit on Diet Pills
description: In the years since the 9/11 attack, more than 9,000 ground zero workers have sued New York City, saying it failed to protect them from the toxic dust at the site that they say made them sick.

title: Twenty-Five Square Miles Surrounded by Reality
description: My brother-in-law Peter lives in Boulder, Colorado. Whenever I use the bathroom in his house, I heave a bucket of used bath water down the toilet to flush it. This provides a welcome opportunity to enhance my deltoids, and it can save approximately 7,300 gallons of fresh water per year. Peter usually bikes, but occasionally hell drive his hybrid Honda from where its parked next to his xeriscaped yard to the Buddhist meditation classes he teaches downtown. He is, in short, the quintessential Boulderite.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 29, 2008

title: Natural Wonders
