description: Vancouvers sense of style has evolved past yoga pants, but the fashion establishment hasnt completely renounced its crunchiness. These top labels take cues from Mother Nature: silhouettes drape and flow, embellishments are subtle, and form follows function.

title: Uncivil Action
description: Thrillers thrive on villains and heroes, and usually these characters are not overly complicated; writers dont want to confuse or slow the plot. In John Grishams page turners the villains are corporate titans and their lawyers, and the plucky, idealistic heroes (played in the movie versions by Tom Cruise in The Firm and Julia Roberts in The Pelican Brief) are renegade lawyers or law students, shocked into action by the corruption they have stumbled across.

title: From Harvey River
description: The baby was plump and pretty as a ripe ox-heart tomato. Her mother, Margaret Wilson Harvey, gently squeezed the soft cheeks to open the tiny mouth and rubbed her little finger, which had been dipped in sugar, back and forth, over and under the small tongue to anoint the child with the gift of sweet speech. "Her name is Doris," she said to her husband, David.

title: Trumping the Unbearable Darkness of History
description: THAT history has not been just a string of kindnesses and gifts of beauty for the ancient, golden city of Prague is far from apparent at first glance.

title: Correction: Eddie Izzards Master Plan
description: An article on March 16 about Eddie Izzard described the setup to his Cake? Or Death? routine incorrectly. He imagined what would have happened if the Church of England rather than the Roman Catholic Church had run the Inquisition  not if the Church of England rather than the Romans had tried to conquer the world.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Page 52 of The Times Magazine this weekend about this summers Olympics in Beijing and the effects of political activists on them and their sponsors omits a sentence from a statement from Microsoft, a sponsor of the games, about the need for international organizations to intervene in Sudan, which buys weapons from China. The passage containing the statement should read: The company further commend[ed] Dream for Darfur and other organizations for their leadership in casting a spotlight on this atrocity and the need for immediate international resolution. Governments and international organizations  the United Nations chief among them, as well as humanitarian relief organizations  will need to continue to work together locally and globally to address the problems in the Sudan. Microsoft will continue to support these organizations in their mission through technology assistance and other resources.

title: Dark Musicals: South Pacific Optimism
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding Her Voice
description: WHEN I first met Nicole Von Valkenburg, she was sitting in front of a mirror, intent on her morning grooming ritual, which involved tweezing, applying makeup, parting her dark blond hair, and fitting her long streaked blond wig over her head. When she was finished, she emerged as another person, a diva who had stepped from a 70s movie, ready for a night out.

title: Neuberger Museum Gets Spot in Manhattan
description: SINCE its opening in 1974, the Neuberger Museum of Art has been cloistered away from the art world, atop a hill on the campus of Purchase College of the State University of New York. Soon, it will also have a presence in Midtown Manhattan.

title: Lindsey Berger and Thomas Brems
description: Lindsey Wade Berger, a daughter of Julie Collins Berger and Lawrence Howard Berger of Devon, Pa., was married on Saturday evening to Thomas Josef Brems, the son of Nancy Brems and Richard Kenneth Brems of St. Charles, Ill. Judge Christopher J. ODonnell of the municipal court in Brunswick, Ga., officiated on Sea Island.

title: You Cant Just Blow Up History
description: The wreckers will arrive at Shea Stadium soon after the Mets final home game in late September or sometime in October. In February or March, Yankee Stadiums dismantling will begin. The old ballparks will be taken apart piece by piece over two to three months with hydraulic jackhammers, blowtorches and grapplers.

title: Does Recession Mean Doom for Restaurants?
description: When the economy is falling down all around you, it is only natural to want to protect yourself with some austerity measures. Thoughts of walking that 30 miles to work, using a washboard instead of a washing machine, and sewing clothes out of old curtains may come to mind.

title: Take Them Out, and Let Them Shake That Stuff
description: FIFTEEN men auditioned. Fifteen made the cut. Few could tell an eight-count from a pivot turn, but no matter: Ladies and gentlemen, make some noise for the Manatees, Major League Baseballs first all-male, plus-size dance troupe.

title: Food From All Over the Italian Map
description: IN the deluge of Italian restaurants that have washed over Connecticut during the past 20 years, there have been very few really, really poor ones, but there have been relatively few remarkable ones either. Most of the newcomers have shown competent skill in preparing standard Italian fare, with occasional flair in certain dishes and ingredients.

title: Not Just for Golfers Anymore
description: Baiting Hollow

title: In Mexico, Luxe Newcomer Adds to the Riviera Nayarits Cachet
description: The up-and-coming Riviera Nayarit region, along Mexicos Pacific coast north of Puerto Vallarta, has a new luxury resort. The Hotel des Artistes (www.hoteldesartistesdelmar.com) in the Punta de Mita Beach Club and Spa, in the town of Punta de Mita, features two- and three-bedroom oceanfront suites with original Mexican art (available for purchase) and kitchens outfitted with Viking appliances.

title: For Rowings Stars, a Hall of Their Own
description: Mystic

title: Not Quite Passing the Hat, but Already Feeling the Pain
description: ROBERT BENFATTO, the usually serene district manager of Community Board 4 in Manhattan, was standing in his lemon-yellow office suite last week pointing an accusing finger at Nelly Gonzalez, a staff member.

title: Mama Goodie
description: In July 1954, 7-year-old Lorna Goodison left her home in Kingston, Jamaica, to spend the summer with her aunt in the village of Harvey River, a 14-hour drive away. Her maternal great-grandfather William Harvey, an Englishman, had given his name to both the swiftly flowing river beneath the Dolphin Head Mountains and the town that grew up along its banks. Young Lorna ran wild that summer  roaming the countryside, knocking fruit from the trees, eating picnic lunches with her cousins among the tombstones of her ancestors. This seemingly idyllic spot would, she writes, shape my imagination for the rest of my life.

title: Pondicherrys French Connection
description: AS colonies go, Pondicherry was not exactly a success story. Almost immediately after the French set up this lovely nugget on the Bay of Bengal in 1674, it was captured by the Dutch, retaken by its founders, then sacked and destroyed by the British. And though the French kept rebuilding it, Pondicherry never became more than a stopover on the way to Indochina. Even after Pondy, as it is nicknamed, rejoined India  late, in 1956  it languished, out of step with the rest of the nation. In other words, for most of its history, Pondicherry was a backwater, in decline.

title: More Than a Pet Project
description: IT was the cats that caused Tania Dudina and George Kokoris to think about buying a place.

title: Ilana Saal, Daniel Forchheimer
description: Ilana Lindsay Saal, the daughter of Debbie and Marty Saal of Nesconset, N.Y., is to be married on Sunday to Daniel Eric Forchheimer, a son of Shelley and Mark Forchheimer of Plainview, N.Y. Rabbi Ian S. Jacknis will perform the ceremony at the South Huntington Jewish Center in Melville, N.Y.

title: If You Cant Sell, Good Luck
description: WHERES my bailout?

title: Traveling Circus
description: Now that bureaux de change are doing brisk business in rubles and yuan, its clear theres a new world order in travel. People from everywhere are going everywhere, says Ian Bremmer, the president of the consulting firm Eurasia Group. And with new wealth come fresh stereotypes  remember the Ugly American? Bremmer ascribes clichs to pure economics. Its whos spending the most money and annoying the locals. Here, a pop-anthropological look at the travel universe now. ANNA LOUIE SUSSMAN

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the New York auto show misidentified a new Volvo utility wagon. As noted in a subsequent reference, it is the XC60  not the XC90, a larger vehicle that has been available since 2003.

title: A Century of Futility on Chicagos North Side
description: In 2006, the Cubs failed to follow the Red Sox and the White Sox as teams that won the World Series after having gone nearly 100 years without doing so. Instead, the Cubs finished with the worst record in the National League.

title: Nearing 50, Franco Still Going Strong in Mexican League
description: Most people who lie about their age try to make themselves appear younger than they really are. It was suggested to Julio Franco, though, that he might have wanted to make himself appear older. He laughed, understanding the reason for the suggestion.

title: Before the Olympics, a Parade of Companies
description: THE Olympic torch set off last week from Athens for Beijing. By the time it arrives in August for the start of the Olympic Games, Beijing will have largely completed a transformation from a staid seat of government to a modern metropolis.

title: What if a Flu Like 1918s Broke Out Now?
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about preparations for a flu pandemic included outdated rankings on emergency-preparedness given to states last year by Trust for Americas Health, a Washington-based nonprofit health watchdog group. Thirty-seven states scored 8 or higher on a scale of 1 to 10, and the lowest score given to any state was 6. More than half the states did not receive a score of 5 or lower last year. (Those rankings were from a 2005 report.)

title: In Deep-Dish Pizza Land, a Thinner Blue Line
description: CHICAGO  Perhaps its not fair, given all the temptation on the beat from deep-dish pizza and Chicago-style hot dogs (thats with pickles and tomatoes) and with vast parts of the city smelling of chocolate thanks to a downtown candy factory.

title: The Sounds of Senegal, Atlanta and Two Alto Saxophones
description: Orchestra Baobab

title: The Joy of (Still) Cooking
description: YOU still cook dinner every night? a friend asked incredulously one day recently. We were talking on the phone, and she could hear me rummaging around in the kitchen.

title: The Shame of Yonkers: Dog Fights
description: To the Editor:

title: Jamie Stulin Philip Schreiber
description: Jamie Lee Stulin and Philip Michael Schreiber, both lawyers, were married on Saturday evening at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington. Rabbi Harold S. White officiated.

title: Megan Mann, Andrew Clark
description: Megan Elizabeth Mann and Andrew Duncan Clark were married on Saturday evening at Emmanuel Church in Newport, R.I. The Rev. Everett Greene, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Why Dumps Are Gaining in Allure
description: JUST off Mount Pleasant Avenue in Dover, opposite the Rockaway Townsquare Mall, there is a place now being transformed into a point of refuge for business travelers  after more than 30 years spent as a point of refuse.

title: Letters: Whats the Real Racial Divide?
description: If Senator Clinton prevails in her claim that because she has won all the big states she should be the choice du jour of the superdelegates, the Democrats will lose in November (Matt Bai, March 16). The question those delegates must answer is which of the two candidates is more likely to secure the votes of the others supporters when one drops out of the race. Neither can beat John McCain without the full support of all Democrats and most Independents. Obamas support is stronger among blacks and young people, two constituencies with fragile links to the voting system and with a high likelihood of staying home if they feel betrayed by the primary process. If Clinton, despite losing the popular and delegate vote, wins the nomination through manipulation of the party bosses, watch the flight of African-Americans and first-time voters.

title: Southern Living
description: 1. After 15 years in banking, the Buenos Aires-based Marcelo Lucini decided to leap from the corporate realm into a more creative one. Inspired by Argentinas abundant natural resources and craft-making traditions, he started Airedelsur, a line of stylish home furnishings made from local materials. Although Airedelsur is sold at stores like Bergdorf Goodman, youll save a lot of pesos by going directly to the source, in the citys swank Recoleta district (Arenales 1618; 011-54-11-5811-3640; airedelsur.com).

title: For a Purchase Premiere, A Musical Outcry
description: Purchase

title: A Perfect Place for Man and Beast
description: DR. TOM DeVINCENTIS has lived on the Upper East Side since 1971, but he has never taken the subway or bus to work. Ive always lived close to my office and walked or taken my bike, said Dr. DeVincentis, a veterinarian with a practice on East 75th Street. Ive almost always taken my dogs to work, too. I put them in the basket of my bike.

title: Fine Details, at the Start and at the Finish
description: EVERY aspect of the appetizer  plump grilled shrimp layered over wilted greens and basmati rice pilaf  was a pleasure. It looked lovely. It was expertly prepared. And the surprise kicker? The shrimp were skewered with slices of sugar cane, which, combined with a red-pepper wasabi sauce, lent a hot sweetness to the dish.

title: Hip Hotels, Fine Food and a Basilica
description: TOP reader suggestions about Mexico City, compiled from user comments on the Travel sections Web site. You can read more comments, as well as add your own, at nytimes.com/travel.

title: Pyramid Scheme
description: Before Borat made benefit glorious nation of Kazakhstan, the former Soviet republic had begun attracting plenty of international attention on its own. Bordering Russia and China, Kazakhstan sits on vast reserves of oil and natural gas and in the next decade could be among the worlds

title: Triumphant or Not, in Cook They Trust
description: NEXT weekend, scores of people are expected to convene at the Yale Club in Midtown to honor an explorer from Brooklyn whose critics have tried to crush his claims, as if to bury them under the Arctic wastes he explored.

title: Hilary Alexander | Style Pundit
description: Machu Picchu, Bhutan, the Sultanate of Oman, Kazakhstan, Mongolia: theres no place too far or too exotic for the fashion critic Hilary Alexander. I travel all over the place, she says. The key to traveling is to never be surprised by anything. Alexander, the fashion director of The Daily Telegraph and twice the recipient of a British Fashion Award for journalist of the year, likes to keep things as simple as a fashionista can while trotting the globe. She never goes anywhere without an electric toothbrush charger, a pair of flats,

title: The Taste Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: At Peak Times, a Hungrier Meter?
description: PARKING spaces on the Upper West Side are precious resources, to be hoarded like coal in wartime. The familiar street-cleaning shuffle requires paramilitary levels of vigilance and guile. So it is no surprise that the city is eyeing the neighborhood as a place to test a new program that would raise and lower the price of parking to match demand.

title: Cinema Society
description: Ever since Hollywood came to town  thanks to generous tax incentives and a diverse landscape  Vancouver has been a favorite filming location for big-budget productions and struggling indies alike. Heres where to catch some of the towns best moviemaking and watch visiting stars spending their per diems.

title: Beating Good Teams Isnt Quite Good Enough
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  Kimberly Becks face went blank at the mention of Dereck Whittenburg. And Sarah-Jo Lawrence? She had never heard of Lorenzo Charles.

title: Elegance Is Abundant; Groceries Are Less So
description: A photograph with the Living In article last Sunday about Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, was published in error. It shows properties on Lafayette Avenue in Fort Greene, not in Clinton Hill. Also, the article misidentified the street of the local branch of the Brooklyn Public Library. It is on Washington Avenue, not Clinton Avenue.

title: Eyes on the Sky at the First Crane Jump Since a Collapse
description: Throughout New York Citys building boom, so-called crane jumps, an intricate procedure in which a crane is jacked up to raise its height, have been a frequent and little-noticed routine at construction sites.

title: From Reggie to Chub: One Last Roll Call
description: More than three hours after Reggie Jacksons three homers in Game 6 won the 1977 World Series for the Yankees, he was still in his pinstriped uniform at his locker when he suddenly had a quiet question for the half-dozen reporters who had been questioning him.

title: Correction: The Royal Life (Some Facts Altered)
description: An article last Sunday about dramatic license taken in the television show The Tudors misidentified the king whom Princess Margaret is depicted marrying against her will during Season 1. It was the King of Portugal, not Spain.

title: R.E.M. Tries Picking Up the Pace
description: ATHENS, Ga.

title: A Film Festival Thats Unabashedly Local
description: WHEN Gabrielle Berberich screened Greetings From the Shore, a film inspired by her last adolescent summer in Lavallette, to California audiences, one thing drove her crazy.

title: Phuket: Lemongrass House
description: Lacquered lemon yellow and lime green, three shipping containers set along the road between Surin and Bang Tao Beaches in Phuket hardly look like a source of products for pamperers. Inside, however, body lotions, skin-calming powders and massage oils are concocted on the spot, using more than 90 natural scents and essential oils

title: The Power of a Russian Birthright
description: The older I become, the closer I feel to Russia, the Siberian baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky said recently over tea at a Manhattan hotel. And he seemed surprised to hear himself say it.

title: Matzo? Chopsticks? Are Locusts Next?
description: A LITTLE more than two months ago, when Robert Clark found many of his possessions pushed out into the cold Brooklyn night along with those of 200 of his neighbors because the building they all lived or worked in was declared a fire hazard as a result of a broken sprinkler system and an ad hoc matzo factory in the basement, they might have assumed the worst was over.

title: Identity Theft
description: Tapeworms, fleas, writers: all are essentially parasites, insinuating themselves into the intimate spaces of a host organism and then sucking out any material deemed valuable. So what if they cause distressing gastrointestinal effects, maddening itching or irreparable family feuds? The universe of the parasite is amoral, knowing no good other than its own.

title: Events on Long Island
description: COMEDY

title: Headed for the Rocks, Grasping for a Life Buoy
description: BEFORE we were married my husband and I had a counseling session with our officiant, an Episcopal priest as humorless as driftwood. He asked us questions like, Are you on the same page about how to spend money? (Sure, I answered. Whoever has a working credit card at the moment pays.)

title: How We Got From Grief to Pancakes
description: I WAS nervous about meeting my future husbands parents, even though I am old enough to be a grandmother. When I told a friend I was marrying again, he said, What? And lose your widow status?

title: Correction: Marching Toward Hell
description: A review on March 16 about Marching Toward Hell, by Michael Scheuer, referred incorrectly to Scheuers tenure with the C.I.A. unit charged with pursuing Osama bin Laden. He was the units head from 1996 to 1999 and acted as special adviser to its chief from September 2001 to November 2004, the year he retired from the agency; he did not end his career as head of the unit.

title: Blues Traveler
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters: Supreme Court Inc.
description: Jeffrey Rosens fine article (March 16) shows the meaninglessness of terms like liberal and conservative when used to describe Supreme Court justices. Justices David Souter, Ruth Bader Ginsberg and Stephen Breyer, the so-called liberals, think corporately and conservatively rather than in any populist or liberal strain. In no way can they be compared to the liberals of the Warren and even Burger courts, Justices Brennan, Black and Douglas, and to the liberals of the World War II and F.D.R. courts. In another day these justices would be seen as centrists, if not conservative.

title: Correction: Q&A
description: The Q&A column on March 16 about a suggested itinerary in Arizona misstated the name of a mountain near Phoenix. It is Piestewa Peak  not Squaw Peak, its former name.

title: The Stone Gods
description: Planet Blue

title: Nailing Down the Loose Ends and Asking the Hard Questions
description: BROKERS say it is critical that all aspects of the broker-seller relationship be nailed down from the outset.

title: In a Heart, Mind and Notebook, the Bronx Will Always Be Up
description: When you grow up a baseball fan in one particular ballpark and then on more than the rare occasion go to work there, there is a tendency to form an attachment to the place. Milestones become lifes markers.

title: Heather England, Christopher Reznik
description: Heather Anne England, a daughter of Godfrey G. England of Dix Hills, N.Y., and the late Barbara A. England, was married on Saturday evening to Christopher Matthew Reznik, a son of Susan H. Reznik and John W. Reznik of Baton Rouge, La. The Rev. Thomas W. Hoffman, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the St. Louis Cathedral in New Orleans.

title: A Journey to Baseballs Alternate Universe
description: Ithaca, N.Y.

title: With No Issues, Williams Is Content
description: Charlotte, N.C.

title: Taking the Forest to the Hamptons
description: SOUTHAMPTON

title: Foreclosure Machine Thrives on Woes
description: NOBODY wins when a home enters foreclosure  neither the borrower, who is evicted, nor the lender, who takes a loss when the home is resold. Thats the conventional wisdom, anyway.

title: Correction: Giving Old Planes New Life
description: The Travel Bug column last Sunday about the Evergreen Maintenance Center, which stores airliners and returns them to service from an Arizona site, misstated the model number of three Boeing planes there that were operated by MaxJet, an airline that went bankrupt in December. They are 767s, not 757s.

title: Arts Get Their Cue
description: A caption last Sunday with the In the Region article about developments in downtown New Brunswick, N.J., misidentified the project shown in the architectural rendering. It is the Gateway, not the New Brunswick Cultural Center. The rendering also carried an erroneous credit. It is by Ehrenkrantz Eckstut & Kuhn Architects, not the New Brunswick Development Corporation.

title: The Drug Scare That Exposed a World of Hurt
description: When cold medicine containing a poison made in China killed nearly 120 Panamanians in 2006 and early 2007, Americans could take some comfort in the belief that a similar epidemic could never happen here, not with one of the best drug regulatory systems in the world.

title: Interdisciplinary Study
description: THEY may seem like strange academic bedfellows, but the names of Tom Cruise, Herman Melville and Toussaint LOuverture, the 18th-century Haitian independence fighter, are likely to pop up  along with performances by the tenor saxophonist Joe Lovano, the pianist Vijay Iyer and the trombonist Ray Anderson  at the three-day jazz conference and festival that starts Thursday at Stony Brook University. All events are open to the public, some at no charge.

title: A Disability, and a Dispute
description: THE first thing that Barbara Gutmacher Girard asked about before signing a contract two years ago to buy a condominium at the Plaza Hotel was access for the handicapped, she recalled last week.

title: Imaginary Hors dOeuvres, but Real Job Skills
description: JAMARIS VALLADARES of Brooklyn has never had a formal job interview. Ive only had part-time, minimum-wage jobs, selling and as a cashier, she said.

title: At a Polish Dance Hall, Music That Never Fades
description: Elizabeth

title: For Busy Mothers, a Chance to Connect
description: Jericho

title: Raising the Bar
description: No matter what you get up to after dark, Vancouvers got you covered.

title: A Historic Lounge Awaits Its Final Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Middle Eastern Munch
description: The kosher Moroccan and Middle Eastern dishes at Chez Sima in Fair Lawn reflect the heritage of the owner, Sima Elmatad. The cafe, which opened in 2004, has room for 12, between three tables and a counter.

title: The Republic Formerly Known As ...
description: One thing about the Balkans, they have the most esoteric crises. NATO is holding its summit meeting next week, and wants to bring in three Balkan states  Albania, Croatia and Macedonia. But Greece, a NATO member since 1952, is threatening to veto Macedonias membership over its name.

title: Adding a Youthful Vibe to Historical Discourse
description: Khalil Wilsons braids bounced as he bobbed his head, snapped his fingers and sang a cappella, his high-pitched voice carrying across the ballroom. The cheers he drew from the audience were nothing new for a boy who has been singing since age 3 and once auditioned for a role in The Lion King.

title: As Jinx Turns 100, the Friendly Confines Are Getting Feisty
description: Sam Zell does pretty much whatever he pleases. He curses at employees in his $6 billion empire. At 66, he motorcycles 115 miles per hour and extreme skis. So if he wants to buy a major league baseball team  particularly the pickled-in-tradition Chicago Cubs  not only do their fans not have to like it, but he doesnt, either.

title: Serving Platters of Minced Politician
description: IT had been a very bad week for politicians, which made it a busy one for Lizz Winstead.

title: 36 Hours in Berkeley, Calif.
description: ANYONE who thinks that Berkeley is just a hotbed of political radicalism is in for a surprise. College Avenue, the towns main drag, is packed with more hipsters with BlackBerrys than hippies with beards. The citys revamped shops can compete label-to-label with SoHos sophisticated boutiques, and its restaurants match its bigger neighbor across San Francisco Bay. But the spirit of 1969 hasnt completely gone away. Walk down Telegraph Avenue and along one block youll find activists for Free Tibet, patchouli-scented advocates of homeopathic medicine, and crusty purple-haired free-love followers, still eager to convert you to their cause.

title: Pravda
description: LOVE AND CHAOS Gabriel Glover

title: Clare Lambe, Robert Malchman
description: Clare Louise Lambe and Robert Ernest Malchman were married on Monday at the Brooklyn Municipal Building. Maliker Morris, a supervisor in the New York City Clerks office, officiated.

title: Zimbabweans Vote, Desperate for Change
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe  Lines were long at the polling stations here well before morning had unscrolled its first light. And when the doors did not open exactly at 7 a.m., voters in the impoverished township of Warren Park rushed the schoolyard gate, most of them desperate to cast a ballot to oust the man who has been president for most of their lives, Robert Mugabe.

title: German Expressionism
description: What New York was in the 80s, Berlin is now, says Nadja Vancauwenberghe, the French editor in chief of Berlins English-language magazine, the Exberliner. Thats the clich. She shakes her head and smiles. The reality, Maurice Frank, the Exberliners publisher, chimes in, is that rents here are a third of what they are in Paris or London.

title: Justice as Drama, Then and Now
description: WHEN my father was nearing the end of his life, he developed a new affinity for the TV, and one of his favorite shows then was The Peoples Court. This was in the early 80s, and when Id visit him on weekends, he would often regale me with Judge Joseph Wapners latest decisions. Over dinner we would discuss his judgments on assorted divorces, family feuds, tenant-landlord disputes and petty thefts. My father was in his late 70s then, and his appreciation of the judge was philosophical, rueful, faintly amused.

title: Art and History Clash in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO  From the floor-to-ceiling windows in his office atop the Gap headquarters, Don Fisher, the companys billionaire founder and chairman emeritus, has dazzling IMAX-style vistas of San Francisco Bay. But the killer view has stiff competition from the flotilla of Calders, Diebenkorns, Rauschenbergs, Twomblys and a succession of Mick Jaggers by Andy Warhol that form a veritable art park in his midst.

title: On The Q.t.: Amy Sacco
description: The New York nightclub owner Amy Sacco is expanding her brand: in addition to opening a London outpost of Bungalow 8, she recently became the creative director of both the Hard Rock Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas and the all-business-class airline Eos. Between flights, Sacco took the T Travel Questionnaire.

title: The Informer
description: It is surely true that, as Nietzsche observed, without a constant falsification of life ... man could not live. Our perception of the world rests on a dense trellis of falsehoods that make it possible for us to get out of bed in the morning and face the day. This is part of the huge challenge facing truth commissions, bodies entrusted (as was, for example, the South African Truth and Reconciliation Commission) with helping broken societies to achieve nothing less than individual healing, communal atonement and, of course, our old friend closure. In his new novel, the Irish writer David Park invents a truth commission dealing with the aftermath of Northern Irelands Troubles. Its an ambitious premise thats almost intolerably weighty; but with guile and wonderful imaginative sympathy, Park stays afloat on the most treacherous of thematic currents: the inhumanity of violence, the vulnerability of the individual before history, truths inextricability from power, the elusive nature of redemption.

title: U.S. Energy Policy, as the Energy Secretary Sees It
description: To the Editor:

title: Talk of Past and Future as Mets Visit Memphis
description: MEMPHIS  Willie Randolph usually passes off the catching duties of a ceremonial first pitch to his coaching staff, but this was an honor he wanted for himself, because Martin Luther King III was throwing it. Randolph, the Mets manager, scooped the pitch and met King in front of the mound. King extended his hand. Randolph shook it. They hugged.

title: Bed Check
description: The city has a hotel to suit every taste. Ts favorites, in five categories.

title: 3 Contenders and an Icon Whos Not Named Bonds
description: This was an interesting division last year; this year, it could be more interesting. Last year, the Diamondbacks, the Rockies and the Padres nearly wound up in a three-way tie for first. This year, all three teams will contend again, but this year will also feature Joe Torre as the manager of the Dodgers after his 12-year tenure with the Yankees resulted in four World Series titles.

title: Up Front
description: Steven Brill, the founder of The American Lawyer magazine and Court TV, knows a smart legal thriller when he reads one. And he has long been an admirer of John Grisham, whose new novel, The Appeal, he reviews on this weeks cover. I think his writing about the dynamics of the legal system, Brill told us by e-mail, has the texture and authority of someone whos been exposed to it.

title: Gearing Up to Dominate the World, and Prove Parents Wrong
description: EASTCHESTER

title: Grim Outlook for an AIDS Vaccine
description: Back in 1984, federal health officials, flush with excitement over discovery of the virus that causes AIDS, famously predicted that they would have a vaccine ready for market within three years. Now, after almost a quarter-century of toil and struggle, the effort has crashed in failure. No one yet knows whether a vaccine to prevent the disease will ever be possible.

title: Frankly, My Dear ...
description: David Brets angle on Clark Gable is this: Gable was gay for pay and rough trade, and he enjoyed having sex for bucks. In addition, he would sometimes scrub his penis until it bled and used a device to prolong erections. If these tidbits from the books first few pages arent too much information for you, youre in luck. This breathtakingly trashy biography does not skimp on sordid anecdotes.

title: Indie Jones
description: Style Map | Shanghai As international brands continue to conquer Shanghais malls and main drags, a corner of the

title: Minal Damani and Monish Kundra
description: Minal Jitendra Damani and Monish Kundra were married Saturday at the Vanderbilt Mansion of the Fisher Island Hotel and Resort in Miami Beach. Jitendra P. Damani, the brides father, who is a notary public in Florida, officiated. The couples parents and two sisters led a ceremony combining elements of the Hindu and Jain religions.

title: Top-Seeded North Carolina Rallies From 18 Behind
description: NEW ORLEANS  North Carolina fell behind by 18 points in the first half against Louisville on Saturday in the New Orleans Region and appeared to be the first No. 1 seed headed for a premature exit from the womens N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Wed to Strangers, Vietnamese Wives Build Korean Lives
description: KWANGMYONG, South Korea  The two couples baby girls were born last month only two days apart, the younger one on the morning of the Lunar New Year. Each girl, everyone later agreed, had her Korean fathers forehead and her Vietnamese mothers nose.

title: Students of Virginity
description: There was a time when not having sex consumed a very small part of Janie Fredells life, but that, of course, was back in Colorado Springs. It seemed to Fredell that almost no one had sex in Colorado Springs. Her hometown was extremely conservative, and as a good Catholic girl, she was annoyed by all the fundamentalist Christians who would get in her face and demand, as she put it to me recently, You have to think all of these things that we think. They seemed not to know that she thought many of those things already. At her public high school, everyone, literally everyone, wore chastity rings, Fredell recalled, but she thought the practice ridiculous. Why was it necessary, she wondered, to signify youre not doing something that nobody is doing?

title: Spin Factor
description: Calling Diego Della Valle a frequent flyer is certainly an understatement. Most mornings the chairman and C.E.O. of Tods Group shuttles by helicopter or private jet from his main home in Casette dEte, Italy, to the company headquarters in Milan. Beyond this regular commute, there are frequent jaunts to London and Paris, business trips to Asia and occasional getaways to New York and places like Parrot Cay in Turks and Caicos. So its no surprise that Della Valle is obsessed with globes. I have been a collector for about 50 years, he says. All my friends give them to me as presents. He found this one at Florian Papp, a small antiques shop on Manhattans Upper East Side; its become a favorite and now has pride of place in his office. I think I like them so much because I miss traveling for my soul rather than business, he says. Id love to stay for a long time in a small place where the food is fantastic and there are no phones. Della Valle hopes to hit the road soon, renting a motor home with his son and driving across America, making stops at places like Yellowstone National Park; Jackson Hole, Wyo.; and Palm Springs, Calif. After that, he might head off the beaten path. Maybe Ill just spin the globe, put my finger on it and go wherever it lands. Thats the dream. ARMAND LIMNANDER

title: When Grand Central Was Younger
description: THOMAS WOLFE wrote that the late Pennsylvania Station was vast enough to hold the sound of time. More than half a century ago, across town at Grand Central Terminal, a 23-year-old industrial design student named Boris Klapwald did something else with time: He stopped it.

title: Walking the Talk
description: Most linguists approach language as just another kind of natural fact, like cells or rocks. Most of the intellectual action takes place in chairs, and it ends less often in triumphant discovery than in quiet revelation.

title: Critical Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Kitchen Sink
description: Source of everything but . . .

title: The Bold and the Bad and the Bumpy Nights
description: BETTE DAVIS, born 100 years ago this week, made her first appearance on film in 1931 and her last in 1989, and like every star of her generation she was always ready for her close-up. The difference with Davis  part of what makes her, I think, the greatest actress of the American cinema  was, she didnt need it. You could tell what she was thinking and feeling from across the room, even a very large one like the ballroom she swoops into, wearing a red dress, in William Wylers Jezebel (1938), scandalizing the haut monde of 1852 New Orleans; unmarried young women like her character, Julie Marsden, are expected to wear white. But Julie wants to make an impression, and she does; and as she takes a turn on the dance floor with her stiff-backed escort, you can see, although most of the sequence is long shots, her growing awareness that she has made a terrible mistake, that she has gone, for once, too far.

title: Students With Needs Discover Their Talents
description: MAMARONECK

title: Edison ...Wasnt He the Guy Who Invented Everything?
description: San Francisco  Invention may be mothered by necessity. But determining the father can require a paternity test.

title: When the Long View Isnt So Scenic
description: THE subprime mortgage crisis and its ever-expanding aftermath have kept investors mesmerized about the present  and for good reason. But what do we see when we step away from todays turmoil and try to look into the future?

title: Testing for Drugs Is Always in Season
description: Just in time for opening day in North America, baseball is about to firm up its latest drug-testing policy  the one that strengthens year-round testing of your favorite superstars, and not a moment too soon.

title: Toward New Rules for Wall Street
description: In the weeks since the Federal Reserve put up some $30 billion to grease the sale of Bear Stearns to JPMorgan Chase, a national debate has begun over how best to regulate 21st-century financial markets.

title: Another Red Balloon Alights in Paris
description: Rotterdam, the Netherlands

title: The Spirits of Yankee Legends Permeate a Locker Room
description: As the Yankees of 2008 walk out the blue door from their clubhouse toward the green field of Yankee Stadium, the last image they will see on the hallway wall is a black-and-white photograph of Mickey Mantle, Billy Martin and Whitey Ford.

title: 8 Days to Eat
description: For many restaurantgoers on the East End, the annual Hamptons Restaurant Week is the first sign of spring. The eight-day promotion, which this year runs from March 30 through April 6, marks the end of cabin fever, according to Walter Struble, the general manager of Della Femina in East Hampton. It gets people out of the house to come and try the restaurants, he said.

title: Diplomats Visit Tibet Amid Anxiety Over Unrest
description: SHANGHAI  A group of foreign diplomats, including an official from the United States, completed a two-day visit to Tibet on Saturday. There were conflicting reports of renewed pro-independence protests there and a possible weapons cache and mass arrests at a Tibetan monastery in southwestern China.

title: Mother Russia
description: Edward Docxs second novel, Pravda, opens with 32-year-old Gabriel Glover, a London-based magazine editor, receiving a late-night phone call from his ailing mother. After many years in exile, she has returned to her native Russia  and now shes insisting that he fly out immediately to visit her in St. Petersburg. There are so many things I have to tell you, she cries. But Gabriel is too late. He arrives at her apartment only to find her lifeless form crumpled on the floor.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The cover article in The Times Magazine this weekend, about the recent struggles of the Republican Party, misspells the surname of the Democratic congressman who helped devise the strategy for the Democratic gains in the 2006 Congressional elections. He is Rahm Emanuel, not Emmanuel.

title: Petal Pusher
description: CH CAROLINA HERRERA SUITCASE, $790.

title: In Search of Better Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: The War on Error
description: There are really two debates going on about the Iraq war, but only one of them is being heard at the present time. Was the decision to invade a mistake from the beginning? For the most part, Democrats say yes and Republicans say no. The other debate centers on the invasions aftermath. Is the current debacle the result not of the decision to overthrow Saddam Hussein but of the inept policies that followed? Since this question suggests that success in Iraq was always a possibility, it is generally being ignored both by Democrats, who dont want to muddy their antiwar position, and by Republicans, unwilling to face up to the Bush administrations serial failings.

title: Sainthood Sought for Revered New Haven Priest
description: NEW HAVEN

title: A Snitch Like Me
description: A picture last Sunday with an essay about a crack house in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, was published in error. The three houses in the picture are on the same street as the crack house, but none of the three figured in the essay.

title: Preparing for Pandemics
description: To the Editor:

title: Events in Westchester
description: Comedy

title: Deep Inside the Big Ballyard in the Bronx
description: The Yankees second baseman is named for the Brooklyn Dodgers second baseman, the man who stole home at Yankee Stadium in the first game of the 1955 World Series. Where Jackie Robinson once slid, Robinson Can now hits.

title: Changing the Rules of the Games
description: On a morning in mid-February, the four staff members of Dream for Darfur sat in silence in what they call their war room, contemplating posters of Beibei the Fish and her four fellow Olympic mascots taped to the walls. In this cramped office in a shared space on the 16th floor of a downtown Manhattan Art Deco building, Beibei smiled welcomingly, as did Jingjing the giant panda, Huanhuan the red Olympic flame, Nini the green swallow and Yingying the horned orange Tibetan antelope: anime-style drawings that regardless of name appear strikingly the same, Medusa hair fused on teddy-bear faces with little-girl expressions. Once the Summer Games begin in Beijing on Aug. 8, Chinese Olympic officials plan to sell millions of the mirthful mascots; the Chinese government has planted them everywhere in the country, hanging like religious icons from the rearview mirrors of Beijing taxis, greeting guests as stuffed toys atop hotel check-in desks and buzzing above city skylines on huge billboards like hovering fairies.

title: Show Stopper
description: Biggest misconception about burlesque: That its about dancing around in hot pants with feather boas. Burlesque was about the striptease. The stars of burlesque took their clothes off, end of story, period.

title: Coming Soon, to Any Flat Surface Near You
description: TIRED of hearing other peoples cellphone conversations? It may become worse. Soon you may have to watch their favorite television shows and YouTube videos, too, as they project them onto nearby walls or commuter-train seatbacks.

title: China Contends It Has Evidence of Tibet Riot Plot
description: SHANGHAI  After two weeks in which China contended that Tibets government in exile had instigated the riots earlier this month to tarnish the coming Summer Olympics in Beijing, the Chinese government on Sunday issued for the first time what it said was evidence of the plot.

title: For a Temporary Best-Friend Fix, Rent a Dog (Kibble Included) for a Day
description: Sarah Stevenson scampered through a heavy rain one recent Friday evening, arriving at a Manhattan rental agency just before it closed.

title: Letters
description: Lift Those Voices

title: Mayor Seeks Job Switch, but Response Is Lukewarm
description: MEMPHIS  In the last 10 days, Mayor Willie W. Herenton has upended this citys political order by announcing first that he would retire in July, a mere six months into his record fifth term, then explaining that he was doing so in order to return to his previous job as superintendent of city schools.

title: The Case for Fitting In
description: When Eliot Spitzer resigned his governorship for committing the very crimes hed publicly denounced only a few months before, he seemed mystifyingly inconsistent. Yet one character trait does shine through the separate, supposedly incompatible compartments of his life. A self-described steamroller, he had that self-confident drive to do what hed decided needed doing, never mind others expectations, never mind who or what gets hurt. In politics, and in his sexual life, he embodied nonconformity. Voters ate it up when he ran for governor, because Americans have a prejudice in favor of lone wolves. Moral superiority, we like to think, belongs to the person who stands alone.

title: Market Leader
description: As an uncommonly outspoken business leader who was appointed secretary of the Treasury in 2001, then forced out in short order after challenging President Bushs tax cuts, are you surprised by the recent flurry of depressing financial news? Not really. Weve been creating this pass of events for several years.

title: Correction: Robert Creeley: Selected Poem, 1945-2005
description: A review on Feb. 24 about Robert Creeley: Selected Poems, 1945-2005 misquoted a word in the poem The Rain. The lines in question should read, am I to be locked in this / final uneasiness, not and I to be locked.

title: Gatekeepers to the Art World
description: ON a balmy Saturday afternoon in far west Chelsea, the aprs-brunch art stroll gathers force, as the gallery tourists emerge from winter hibernation. Snippets of gossip in a confetti of languages! Purse pooches! Lets see who youre wearing, lets see whos on the walls. Springtime warmth dances friskily along West 24th.

title: Paul Arthur, 60, Film Historian and Critic, Dies
description: Paul Arthur, a film historian, scholar and critic well known for writing about American avant-garde cinema and documentaries, died on Tuesday at his home in White Plains. He was 60.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Canseco May Become

title: Despite Infighting, Meeting of Arab Leaders Gets Under Way in Damascus
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  As Bashar al-Assad, Syrias president, opened the annual Arab summit meeting here on Saturday morning, Saudi Arabias foreign minister convened a competing news conference in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, with new criticism of Syrian policy, underscoring the bitter political feud that nearly upended this years Arab gathering.

title: Lauren Amyot, Brendan Voege
description: Lauren Marie Amyot and Brendan Gerard Voege were married on Saturday at St. Mary of the Assumption Church in Katonah, N.Y. The Rev. Edmund P. Connors, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Big East Reaps Benefits of Being Tough on Itself
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  They were supposed to be getting ready for practice Saturday afternoon, but the Connecticut womens basketball players could not tear themselves away from the television. Like Girl Scouts at a campfire, they sat huddled around the set in their designated locker room at Greensboro Coliseum, aglow from the show being put on by Louisville, one of their Big East Conference rivals.

title: In the Many Enclaves, One Neighborhood
description: THE United Nations vividly altered Turtle Bays shoreline in the 1940s, replacing slaughterhouses and rotting piers with its six-block limestone-and-glass campus. Like the republics, kingdoms and nations represented within its walls, Turtle Bay is a loose group of enclaves. Micro-neighborhoods scattered along Midtown Manhattans eastern fringe, they have boundaries drawn by developers, brokers and block associations.

title: In Mideast, Rice Urges Cooperation on Security
description: JERUSALEM  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice began a trip to the Middle East on Saturday by calling on Israeli and Palestinian negotiators to find ways to improve security in the West Bank for Israelis and to ease roadblocks there that hamper movement for ordinary Palestinians.

title: Cars So Hip That It Hurts
description: TOYOTAS creation of the Scion brand seemed like a great idea. While Lexus caters to the rich and Toyota sates the masses appetite for mainstream transportation, Scion is supposed to tap into a contingent of young buyers with short money and a penchant for the funky. Then (goes the theory) when those Scion buyers eventually get better jobs and have their face tattoos removed, they move up the ladder to Toyota. Or to Lexus.

title: Karachis Winter Days
description: Ive been living in Houston for some time, but I often return to Pakistan to visit my parents. In December, when I arrived in Karachi with my 3-year-old daughter, Minal, the city was spinning with more than the usual winter weddings, parties and reunions. President Musharraf had issued emergency rule to hold back a possible Supreme Court ruling against him, and Benazir Bhutto had returned to Pakistan at her own risk. There had been suicide bombings, the lawyers were battling for restoration of an independent judiciary and parliamentary elections were a few weeks away. My husband, Ren, wanted me to postpone our trip, but my father wasnt well, and it was important to go. I assured Ren Id do my best to stay away from the political action.

title: One New American, Imitating Many
description: Los Angeles

title: Creative License
description: The Vancouver School  the 1980s movement led by the conceptual photographers Jeff Wall and Ian Wallace  put the city squarely on the art-world map. Now the scene has graduated beyond photography to include painting, sculpture and video.

title: Lisa Diamond and Ravi Sharaf
description: Dr. Lisa Cari Diamond and Dr. Ravi Narain Sharaf were married on Saturday evening at the Westin Arlington Gateway, a hotel in Arlington, Va. Rabbi Kenneth B. Block officiated, with Dr. Shashikant M. Sane, a Hindu priest, taking part.

title: A Republicans Argument for Two-Party Rule
description: MOUNT VERNON

title: Outward Bound
description: Hiking the Grouse Grind is a rite of passage for any Vancouverite and a favorite cardio jolt for fitness fanatics (and there are more than a few of those here). The intense 1.8-mile stair-climb straight up Grouse Mountain has its rewards, particularly the phenomenal panoramic views of the city, Vancouver Island and northern Washington State  not to mention a cozy mountaintop pub serving local brews and perfectly credible nachos. Or you can take the easy way up: the tram. 6400 Nancy Greene Way; (604) 984-0661; grousemountain.com.

title: Circle Line, on Foot
description: Circle Line, on Foot

title: Not All Odometers Are Created Equal
description: AS researchers who test the accuracy of odometers know, your mileage may vary, and when it comes to a cars warranty, that could cost an owner money. An odometer that piles up mileage faster than it should will push a car out of warranty quicker than an odometer that is calibrated correctly.

title: Leah Paulos, Andrew Davis
description: Leah Paulos and Andrew Davis were married on Saturday evening in the Fels Planetarium at the Franklin Institute Science Museum in Philadelphia. Rabbi Yitzhak Nates officiated.

title: Marisa Pizarro, Joshua White
description: Marisa C. Pizarro, the daughter of Patricia Pizarro and Dr. Oscar Pizarro of Ridgewood, N.J., was married on Wednesday to Joshua White, a son of Kathy White and Tony White of Greenwich, Conn. Blanca Martinez officiated at the New York City Municipal Building.

title: Accomplished (and Generous)
description: THE chef at the four-month-old Vineyards Restaurant, Patrick Yves Pierre-Jerome, says he has spent most of his career getting yelled at in French. Born in Haiti, he came to New Jersey at age 10 and has cooked both in France and in some of this regions most demanding kitchens  including his own place, Yves, in Montclair. (It closed in 1995 and, Im told, is still fondly missed.)

title: Fancy Digs, Still Tricky Enough for Art
description: MOSCOW

title: Not a Mercury or Saturn, but It Goes Way Off Road
description: HOUSTON

title: Its Not You, Its Your Books
description: Some years ago, I was awakened early one morning by a phone call from a friend. She had just broken up with a boyfriend she still loved and was desperate to justify her decision. Can you believe it! she shouted into the phone. He hadnt even heard of Pushkin!

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: BLACK GLASSES LIKE CLARK KENT: A GIs Secret From Postwar Japan, by Terese Svoboda. (Graywolf, paper, $14.) When Svobodas uncle Don, who had served as an M.P. at a prison in postwar Japan, died, he left behind a mystery. In taped reminiscences, he had talked about wide-scale executions of American prisoners. The prison was getting overcrowded, he had said, and a captain said he was going to have to start executing the prisoners, the ones in the death cells. Or Don may have accidentally killed a prisoner; he never mentioned the death on tape, but his brother believes it happened. After the Abu Ghraib scandal in 2004, he suffered from depression and symptoms of post-traumatic stress. How post is post? Svoboda asks the Harvard psychohistorian Robert Jay Lifton. Its certainly not fixed in time, he says. Sixty years? Its been documented. Throughout the book, Svoboda, a poet and fiction writer, seems self-absorbed, describing a weight-lifting class (I curl a bicep) and domestic scenes. Yet Black Glasses Like Clark Kent is suspenseful, and contains a message about war that makes it worthwhile. She interviews people here and in Japan, but never determines whether her uncle knew firsthand about war crimes or imagined them. It almost doesnt matter: his depression was debilitating; he tried antidepressants and electroshock. The thing that sustained him was talking into the tape recorder, describing his nightmare. When he was done, he killed himself, another casualty of war.

title: Dont Paint Nest Eggs in Company Colors
description: BY helping Bear Stearns avert a potential bankruptcy, the federal government essentially declared the venerable investment bank too important to fail. Over the years, many of the firms employees clearly felt the same way: collectively, they accumulated one-third of the companys stock.

title: A Shrine to 15-Minute Fame
description: THE Upper East Side town house where Andy Warhol created some of his earliest and most influential Pop Art is about to go on the market, giving Warhol scholars and fans a rare opportunity to explore the space where he painted his early Campbells soup cans, dollar bills and comic strips.

title: Editors Note
description: An article on March 16 profiling three sex workers in the wake of Gov. Eliot Spitzers resignation after revelations that he patronized prostitutes misconstrued how two of the women, identified by the pseudonyms Faith ODonnell and Sally Anderson, said they earned a living. The resulting misrepresentation of the two womens work included a headline that referred to them as high-priced call girls and a paragraph that said they practiced the 21st-century version of the oldest profession.

title: Preparing to Create the Sims of the Future
description: IF you own a Ph.D. in Donkey Kong or have solid references from the Super Mario Brothers, you might be in line for a job at Bloomfield College, which is seeking applicants for a tenure-track position for someone to teach game design.

title: In a Swollen Park, Not a Swing to Spare
description: THE little blond boy in the camouflage jacket looked longingly at the swings. He was fifth in line, behind a girl in a pink headband and another in Converse sneakers, all of them fidgeting. It looked as if it was going to be a long afternoon.

title: Shiite Militias Cling to Swaths of Basra and Stage Raids
description: BAGHDAD  Shiite militiamen in Basra openly controlled wide swaths of the city on Saturday and staged increasingly bold raids on Iraqi government forces sent five days ago to wrest control from the gunmen, witnesses said, as Iraqi political leaders grew increasingly critical of the stalled assault.

title: A Middling Week, but a Good One for 2008
description: It was a so-so week for the stock market. The broad market declined modestly, but the Nasdaq composite index, which is heavily laden with technology stocks, managed a slight gain.

title: Last Days of Taipei
description: there is nothing particularly Taiwanese about the Astoria Caf. Thats what made it special when Archibald Chien opened the place over a half century ago, on the west side of Taipei, the old downtown. The bakery sold fresh bread and homemade cakes downstairs. Upstairs, Chien served dark, bitter coffee, Italian style. Well, not really Italian. French, he told me. Swiss, he said, picking up a plate of perfect little cakes. Then he laughed. The coffee, the pastries and the cakes  actually, all Russian. But we could not call anything Russian. Just about everything gets political in Taipei. Even dessert.

title: Correction: London: The Rockwell
description: The Check In/Check Out column on March 16, about the Rockwell hotel in London, misspelled its street address in one reference and referred incorrectly to the hotel at another point. It is at 181-183 Cromwell Road, not Crowell Road, and the hotel is not known as the Cromwell.

title: Classical Music Cruises
description: The sequined performer belting out show tunes seems to be the clich of live cruise music. But several boutique cruise lines are offering classical-music-themed trips this year.

title: A Google Friend Is Now Facebooks
description: In a sign that Googles status as the coolest place to work may be waning, the company has lost another high-ranking employee to the social networking site Facebook.

title: Velvety and Piquant
description: Chteau la Rame, in Ste.-Croix-du-Mont, an obscure sweet-wine subregion of Bordeaux, made a marvelous dry sauvignon blanc in 2007.

title: For Star Singers, a Worthy Partner
description: IN late November the British accompanist Roger Vignoles visited the Juilliard School for his first New York master class. It was not the sort of public star turn often marketed under that name, but an internal, properly educational affair. Five students sang, accompanied by five student pianists preparing for careers as collaborative artists. Mr. Vignoles scrutinized singers and pianists alike with the same eagle intensity.

title: Well Always Have the Paris
description: Against the deadpan sameness of downtown Anchorage, a marquee featuring an Eiffel Tower and the words Club Paris in cursive neon juts out from a nondescript storefront. Anchorage is an oil boomtown that was built on the remnants of a gold and fur boomtown that was largely wiped out by an earthquake in 1964. Club Paris is that rare elderly building that survived. (Large portions of a J. C. Penney landed around it, but failed to destroy it.)

title: Retooled Tigers Will Challenge Indians
description: It took the Tigers 12 successive losing seasons, one of them with a 43-119 record, to wake up to reality. If they were ever going to compete again, they would have to spend some money. Ever since General Manager Dave Dombrowski was given the authority to do that, he has done a championship-caliber job.

title: Lost and Found
description: Not too long ago, the only people who collected things were retirees, housewives and underemployed eccentrics. My grandfather was into coins; my grandmother stockpiled seashells. An aunt propped up 100 Beanie Babies in a glass display case. A friends father hoarded lead Civil War soldiers even though he was English. My dads colleague collected railroad ties and would show kids that a whole train line  and a bygone era in American history  could be reconstructed from what looked like a single big, crude nail.

title: Other Voices: Bias in the Eye of the Beholder
description: Re Playing Favorites? Dont Be So Sure (March 9):

title: Katherine Anderson, Stewart Wight
description: Katherine C. Anderson and Stewart Andrew Sutherland Wight were married on Saturday evening at Trinity United Methodist Church in McLean, Va. The Rev. James C. Sprouse performed the ceremony.

title: Market Tables
description: The 100-Mile Diet, by the Vancouverites J. B. MacKinnon and Alisa Smith, spawned a craze for farm-to-table eating here. Sample the best of the local bounty from these award-winning kitchens.

title: Mariners Are Getting Better All the Time
description: If there is a dark-horse candidate for an A.L. division champion, it is the Mariners. They have made great progress in the past few seasons: from 63 victories to 69 to 78 to 88, and only a one-game deficit in the division race as late as last Aug. 25.

title: Fuller Picture Emerges of Patersons Aid to Hospital That Employed His Wife
description: When Gov. David A. Paterson was the State Senate minority leader, he got in touch with Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a fellow Democrat, with what seemed like a routine request: Would he meet with a representative of a small Harlem hospital that was in need of financial assistance?

title: Hugo Claus, 78, Belgian Novelist and Poet, Is Dead
description: Hugo Claus, one of Belgiums most renowned authors despite his often caustic portrayals of his nation, particularly its ambiguous role in World War II, died on March 19. He was 78.

title: Files Suggest Venezuela Bid to Aid Colombia Rebels
description: BOGOT, Colombia  Files provided by Colombian officials from computers they say were captured in a cross-border raid in Ecuador this month appear to tie Venezuelas government to efforts to secure arms for Colombias largest insurgency.

title: Arielle Kagan, Jason Rubenstein
description: Arielle Dena Kagan, the daughter of Deborah L. Kagan and Martin H. Kagan of Houston, is to be married there on Sunday afternoon to Jason Bassi Rubenstein, the son of Laurie J. Bassi and Herbert R. Rubenstein of Golden, Colo. Dr. Bernard Steinberg, the president and director of Harvard Hillel, is to officiate, with Cantor Steven Berke participating, at the Hilton Houston Post Oak hotel.

title: Profile in Style
description: his planet, himself

title: Push Comes to Chvre
description: When I tell people that Im from Racine, Wis., I tend to get two responses: either Cheese heads! or Mars Cheese Castle! The store just off Interstate 94 (technically in Kenosha) has always been popular with tourists craving cheese curds and waxy, cow-shaped cheddars. But a lot has happened to the cheese heads since I last visited 10 years ago. Wisconsin has joined the United States of Arugula, and its cheese producers, until recently outclassed by the offerings emerging from Vermont and California, have learned the magic word artisanal. Now more than 60 of the states 114 plants (there were 2,800 in 1925) are manufacturing at least one handmade or small-batch cheese. The state took home a third of the gold medals at the 2006 World Championship Cheese Contest. Theres even a blog, Cheese Underground, to follow award sweeps and other local news.

title: Stephanie Carter and Samuel Glickman
description: Stephanie Janice Carter, the daughter of Concordia S. Carter and John C. Carter of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there on Friday to Samuel Reuben Glickman, the son of Anne S. Glickman and Franklin J. Glickman of Brookline, Mass. The Rev. Frances Wise Grenley, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at Scarsdale Congregational Church.

title: Alleys for Cool Cats
description: WHILE Paris has its boulevards and Miami its beaches, San Franciscos lure is its labyrinth of back alleys, those mysterious midblock detours that seem to offer, in equal doses, the promise of discovery and the slightly scary possibility of getting lost  really lost.

title: Thinking Outside the Companys Box
description: ONE of the oldest barriers to innovation is Not Invented Here, a persistent bias of even the most creative people toward their own creations and against those of people who work for other companies. And the problem of N.I.H. isnt limited to business; it can also infect the military and government research agencies.

title: She, Robot
description: The apocalypse is coming. Youll need something to read. The Stone Gods, Jeanette Wintersons new novel, makes an excellent choice for desert-planet reading  scary, beautiful, witty and wistful by turns, dipping into the known past as it explores potential futures. Among the possibilities: Humans alter their genes to preserve youth and get plastic macro-surgery to exaggerate whats left. They create robot traffic cops and take Robo sapiens lovers or visit a perverts-only sex club. Amid ecological disaster and impending war, theres also good news: a new, livable planet just discovered. But dont get your hopes up  the newfound land is still home to dinosaurs.

title: A Local Jazz Group Hits Its Stride
description: Chappaqua

title: Right at Home With the Yankees
description: The other night I slid hard into the living room sofa, bowling over my husband.

title: Farmers Fear Agriculture Dept.s Abolition
description: ALLENTOWN

title: Death in the Pacific
description: In the war against Japan, American naval commanders faced what might be called the prison ship problem. Submarines had little way of knowing which Japanese transport ships were carrying prisoners of war. In any case, the U.S. Navy adopted a ruthless view, Max Hastings writes. Destruction of the enemy must take priority over any attempt to safeguard P.O.W. lives. As a result, some 10,000 Allied prisoners were doomed (including more than twice as many Americans as have perished in Iraq). And if the Americans didnt kill the P.O.W.s, then the Japanese did. Aboard the tramp steamer Shinyo Maru, the Japanese guard commander told the prisoners that if the ship was attacked, he would slaughter them all. As promised, when it was torpedoed in September 1944, the Japanese guards machine-gunned the prisoners trying to abandon ship. About 20 men escaped into the sea and were rescued by another Japanese ship. When their identities were learned, they were executed.

title: Designer Towers: Mixing It Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: Lisa Sette and Peter Shikany
description: BY 2002, Lisa Sette and Peter Shikany were in an advanced state of dating, but they were not looking to buy a house together, let alone an unfinished one with a fabric roof that had been the cause of head- and heartaches for its original owners.

title: Under Andalusian Skies
description: Last fall, just days after the inauguration of the tram system in Seville, Spain, one of the cars derailed on Avenida de la Constitucin, the citys busiest street. No one was injured  the local horse-drawn carriages seem to move at a faster clip  and the mayor rode it the next day to reassure his citizens that the tram was safe. Still, not too many people were riding it recently.

title: Homeowners Pleas Put G.O.P. Lawmakers in Bind on Defaults
description: HIALEAH, Fla.  In Los Portales, a pink and terra cotta condominium complex in this city of hard-striving Hispanic immigrants and often harder luck, many of Juan Carpios neighbors are losing their homes.

title: Mountain High
description: Every traveler has a landscape that, for him, contains the wonder and mystery behind all travel. It could be the beach, or a cathedral square, or the rain forest, or a volcanic island  for me, it is the mountain pass. The mountain pass, roughly defined, is that point on the map where the winding road up is transformed into the winding road down. It marks the border where valleys meet, and often is where provinces divide, where one nation becomes another, with a corresponding change in language and road signs. To get to the mountain pass, you begin on a fertile plain, often crossed by a river, and drive through terraced fields and sleepy villages until the road gets steeper, the switchbacks get scarier and signs of human settlement fall away behind you.

title: Letters
description: That Creature in the Markets

title: My Way or the Highway
description: President Bush likes to talk about not being swayed by public opinion, especially the views of Democrats. At a news conference last December, he said the most important criterion for picking a president is whether or not somebodys got a sound set of principles from which they will not deviate as they make decisions.

title: Did Your Shopping List Kill a Songbird?
description: Woodbridge, Ontario

title: Russian Vodka With a Feminine Kick
description: MOSCOW

title: Channeling Carrie
description: MAYBE, just maybe, if Carrie Bradshaw, the dynamo at the center of the phenomenally successful television series Sex and the City, were still in her 20s and just starting her ascent into New York life in 2008, maybe, just maybe, she would be like Julia Allison, who this evening is sitting leggily astride a leather ottoman in Houstons, a bar in the Flatiron District.

title: Tea, Herbs and Massages, Too
description: Passiflora Tea Room and Herbal Apothecary is about a healthy lifestyle, said Karen Tyson, who was inspired to open Passiflora five years ago as a result of a self-described midlife crisis. Her goal, she said, was to educate people about vital health, and create a sense of community.

title: Making It Safer to Back Up
description: AFTER years of lobbying by child safety advocates, legislation to make it safer to back up the family minivan was signed into law last month.

title: In This Shiite Battle, a Marked Shift From the Past
description: The most intense fighting in Iraq in months had the ring of the familiar. Another battle against followers of a rebel Shiite cleric. Fighting in the south that spread to other cities.

title: Recalling the Madness
description: Viagra is just another pill in the medicine cabinet these days, one of three on the market to treat the once all-but-unmentionable problem of erectile dysfunction. But 10 years ago last week, when government regulators approved it for sale, Viagra became the first pill available to treat the problem. The reaction was, well... Heres what reporters for The New York Times found in the drugs first months.

title: Ode to an Onion Ring, and Other Fast Food in the Slower Lane
description: I have told my fiance that I love her many times in our relationship, but I never meant it as sincerely or intensely as I did on the morning I expressed this to her in the parking lot of a Carls Jr. hamburger restaurant on a vacation in Santa Monica. The feelings might have been spurred by the sense of independence we felt as we drove across Southern California in a rented convertible, but they were more likely induced by the thrilling union of meat, bun and fried egg I had just eaten known as a Breakfast Burger.

title: Troopers Havent Forgotten One Who Died Young
description: KENILWORTH

title: Shuffling Deck, UConn Still Holds Winner
description: One of the givens in womens college basketball is that Connecticut will be at the top or close to it. But what has happened to the Huskies this season is anything but typical.

title: A Fabric of Life Loses a Thread That Binds
description: AFTER nearly a quarter-century of removing stains, pressing suits and altering dresses in a storefront on Court Street in Cobble Hill, the dry cleaners known around the neighborhood as Mr. and Mrs. Oh closed the doors of their shop, Trusting Cleaners, for the last time on March 15. The couple, both in their 60s, were priced out of their storefront rental, as the story so often goes, forcing them into an early retirement.

title: The Sophisticated Traveler: Know When To Fold em
description: You may not be able to live without your oversize Fendi clutch, but is it packable? These zip-and-go travel bags fold up to become chic wallet-size cases that fit snugly in your suitcase. Devi Kroells shoulder candy comes in dyed alligator and contrasting nylon ($2,690; devikroell.com). Hermss compact shopper is done in its iconic scarf prints ($960; hermes.com). And Lanvin has even done a convertible suede lambskin duffel for men ($652; lanvin.com). ALEX HAWGOOD

title: What Moral Turpitude Looks Like
description: THIRTEEN days ago, United States Customs authorities refused to admit the infamously debauched writer Sebastian Horsley into the country for a book tour. After a lengthy interrogation at Newark airport, he was put on a plane back to England.

title: Material Gains
description: Wabi-sabi  beauty in imperfection  is the citys reigning ethos, and these designers get it just right.

title: Rock Steadies
description: Three leaders of the strikingly original (and influential) Vancouver indie-rock scene  and where to hear them.

title: For Those Obscure Objects You Might Really Need
description: NEED a sterling silver strawberry fork? You think you dont, but flea markets can change the way people feel about obscure objects. Twirl those slender prongs by their dainty handle and, suddenly, other strawberry-eating tools (opposable thumbs, for example) become barbaric by comparison.

title: A Case of the Blues
description: The Oklahoma Congressman Tom Cole is 58 years old, but he has never been famous before, and after this year, he will most likely never be famous again. Even this kind of fame, brief and slight, is uncomfortable on him. Cole is a party man, a lifelong Republican consultant, campaign worker and politician whose career, like that of a typical European Social Democrat, has recognized only a fluid and fungible line between political operative and elected official. It sometimes seems an accident hes in Congress at all. He is tall and slightly formal, and slightly awkward; people who meet him casually describe him as cordial or gentlemanly. The Republican Party, in its current uncertainty, might have chosen an ideologue to fill Coles post or, as is its habit, a money man. Its choice of Cole, an operative, was the establishment insisting that its own learned habits were enough to save itself. Right now, with where we are, Ken Mehlman, a former chairman of the Republican National Committee, told me, Tom Cole is the perfect leader.

title: Between West and East
description: First-time visitors to Lebanon are often startled at how different the country seems from the rest of the Arab world. Spectacular snow-capped mountains rise sheer from the shores of the Mediterranean. Freewheeling Beirut, where almost everything short of murder and rape is allowed, feels more like Hong Kong or Amsterdam than dreary Damascus or Cairo. Elegant women, Muslim as well as Christian, dress as stylishly as their counterparts in Milan and Manhattan. Plastic surgeons are as ubiquitous as decadent and erotically charged nightclubs. Democracy isnt pushed on the Lebanese by diplomats or foreign soldiers  its taught in schools, and has been for more than a half-century.

title: The Talk
description: magnet / (mag& nit) / n. / a place that has attracted a following among a particular group, e.g., Berlins become a total magnet for artsy expats  its to today what Paris was to the 20s. For travelers, connotes how an influx of fresh blood can create newly interesting destinations, as in, Eco-geeks have made Boulder a magnet city of the green movement. They even have an official bicycle ambassador!

title: Rembrandts Mistress
description: Contemplating the whole hideous inverted childhood of aging in his poem The Old Fools, Philip Larkin wondered, Why arent they screaming? In Gerard Woodwards funny and sharply observed novel A Curious Earth, the old fools get their chance. Like two decrepit Lears on a drunken spree, Aldous Jones, a former art teacher, and his old school chum, Cliff Ashbrittle, get ready to let out a shriek as they stumble across a darkened Hampstead Heath. Im going to take my teeth out, Aldous says, before I have a go.

title: Classic Wilde, the Bons Mots Flying
description: The one American in A Woman of No Importance has an interesting take on the sexual double standard. Hester Worsley, played by Erica Sullivan in the Yale Repertory Theaters witty and sprightly revival, doesnt argue that women should not be punished for sexual indiscretion. She just wants men to be punished too.

title: Mets on a Mission After an Epic Collapse
description: The Mets won the Johan Santana championship last winter. Now they will go for the National League East championship this summer.

title: Greek Revival
description: At 18, I went to Athens, and I couldnt see the stars, recalls Andreas Dourakis, who, like many young Cretans, left his small village to study and work. Later I learned about light pollution, but at the time I thought, Did they go away?

title: Things He Knew He Had
description: This exuberant story collection by N. S. Konings resembles her first novel, The Blue Taxi, in its irreverent, hilarious and frequently moving take on postcolonial life  and the human condition in general. Of the novel, which unfolds in Vunjamguu, a fictitious East African city loosely based on Dar es Salaam, Konings has said: I think the book is very much about the wild stories we cook up to try to make sense of this weird situation. Being alive, I mean.

title: Sexual Advances
description: In her previous books, Stiff and a follow-up, Spook, Mary Roach set out to make creepy topics (cadavers, the afterlife) fun. In Bonk, she turns to sex, covering such territory as dried animal excreta used as vaginal drying agents; a rats tail lost in a penis; and a man named William Harvey, patent-holder for a rolling toaster-size metal box outfitted with a motorized resiliently pliable artificial penis. In short, she takes an entertaining topic and showcases its creepier side.

title: Dream Works
description: Las Pozas seems like a myth, a kind of rain-forest mirage. The Surrealist sculpture garden was built more than four decades ago by the eccentric English artist Edward James 2,000 feet into the mountains of the Mexican jungle. It encompasses more than 80 acres of natural waterfalls and pools interlaced with towering Surrealist sculptures in concrete, including Bamboo Palace, a three-story structure with walls that look like shoots of bamboo; Stairway to the Sky, a Piranesi-like staircase that soars up several stories and ends in thin air; and Homage to Max Ernst, an outdoor aviary that is a forest of concrete columns.
