Las Pozas is near the village of Xilitla, a four-hour drive southwest of the nearest sizable airport, in Tampico, and seven hours north of Mexico City. Despite its remoteness (or, perhaps, because of it), the garden has long had a certain cult devotion. But since its sale last year, 23 years after Jamess death, to a consortium that includes two of Mexicos most prominent billionaires, Las Pozas has suddenly attracted fresh attention from preservationists and art-world luminaries intent on saving one of the worlds most curious creations.

title: Sisters in Idiosyncrasy
description: EVE LEVINE, a 34-year-old real estate broker, recalls fondly the five years when she was, as she calls it, low-cost bicoastal. Her primary residence was in Brooklyn  first Williamsburg, then Bushwick and now Greenpoint  but she also had an apartment in the Fruitvale section of Oakland, Calif., that she visited for long stretches.

title: An English Home, American Style
description: HUNTINGDON, England

title: Editors Choice
description: HUMAN SMOKE: The Beginnings of World War II, the End of Civilization, by Nicholson Baker. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) Turning an unorthodox hand to history, Baker passionately assaults the notion that the deliberate targeting of civilians can ever be justified.

title: Belfast Bounces Back
description: Nothing symbolizes the recent transformation of Belfast, the capital of Northern Ireland, better than the Merchant Hotel (35-39 Waring Street; 011-44-28-9023-4888; themerchanthotel.com; doubles from about $430). Besides one-upping the old Europa  once Europes most bombed hotel  the Merchant sells the worlds most expensive cocktail, a mai tai made with hand-cut Fijian ice and rare Wray & Nephew rum, for 750.

title: Tubs and Showers Made New Again
description: IS your bathtub dull, chipped, rusty or just plain dreary? There are alternatives to hauling out that 800-pound elephant and replacing it. It can be refinished or covered with an insert, and the same things can be done with showers.

title: Looking Out My Window Into the Past and the Future
description: As we anticipate the final months, weeks and days of Yankee Stadium, the memories  mountains of memories  can be overwhelming.

title: Top Guards Meet Again, But With More on Line
description: HOUSTON Derrick Rose vividly remembers the only time he played against D. J. Augustin.

title: Jonathan Williams, Publisher, Dies at 79
description: Jonathan Williams, the founder of the Jargon Society, the small publishing house in the western mountains of North Carolina that for more than 50 years has introduced the works of unknown, little-known and soon-to-be-better-known writers, photographers and artists, died on March 16 in Highlands, N.C. He was 79 and lived and worked in Scaly Mountain, N.C.

title: Ballparks Come, Ballparks Go, the Memories Are Forever
description: My father played hooky to attend the first game in Yankee Stadium. I always think of him when I see pictures of the raw new ballpark in the Bronx. The first time he took me to the Stadium was in 1947 to see a dying man in a camel hair coat, rasping on the loudspeaker, which made me a Babe Ruth fan for life. Ever since, the Stadium has seemed funereal to me. But then again, we were Brooklyn fans.

title: Prize Patrol
description: For a few years now, Type A travelers have been racing off to polo matches in Mongolia and Norwegian salmon-fishing expeditions with waiting lists that can last a lifetime. But lately the idea of the trophy trip has reached a peak, as the travel industry keeps offering rarer and more meaningful ways to connect to the world.

title: Bleakonomics
description: Since the bank runs of the 1930s, federal protection of retail depositor institutions has been a hallmark of American capitalism. The Federal Reserve, in a sweeping extension, has now extended the privilege to gilt-edged investment firms.

title: Gastown a Go-Go
description: In Vancouvers most dynamic neighborhood, boutiques and restaurants sprout so rapidly it can be hard to keep pace. Whats hot right now?

title: The Games Not Over, Clinton Backers Agree
description: MUNCIE, Ind.  In the height of basketball season, here in the heart of basketball country, it was perhaps inevitable that the state of the Democratic presidential race would be boiled down in championship terminology.

title: The Lemur
description: Chapter 12: The Protestant Pound

title: Hillarys St. Patricks Day Massacre
description: MOST politicians lie. Most people over 50, as I know all too well, misremember things. So here is the one compelling mystery still unresolved about Hillary Clintons Bosnia fairy tale: Why did she keep repeating this whopper for nearly three months, well after it had been publicly debunked by journalists and eyewitnesses?

title: Letters: When Girls Will Be Boys
description: Alissa Quart (March 16) gets it right! The genderqueer revolution is not about fitting easy definitions. Were transmen/women as well as gender nonconformists, who run the gamut from post-op transsexuals to those who pass as the biological sex we were born into. (Trans being the operative word, we transcend gender in a way that the gay and lesbian community does not transcend sexuality.) That society reduces us to a group born into the wrong body is offensive, for it implies that there is a right body to be born into.

title: Cape Towns Foodie Suburb
description: TWO years ago, Arnold Hoon, a chef from Johannesburg, was driving along South Africas West Coast in search of lunch. On a whim, he and his wife, Annelise Bosch, followed an old wooden sign to Paternoster, a traditional fishing village about 90 minutes north of Cape Town.

title: Elite Women Prove That A&M No Longer Stands for All Male
description: When Trigg Crawford arrived at Texas A&M to play basketball in 1977, the womens team finally got its own locker room. It was a converted mens dressing room and came with curious decorating choices. The walls were bubble-gum pink, as was the shower curtain. And the bathroom?

title: Obama Mixes Bracket Talk With the Usual Politics
description: Team up two basketball players on the campaign trail and look where they end up: at a sports bar talking N.C.A.A. pool tactics  for a moment or two, anyway.

title: Alley Fighters
description: BAGHDAD  Sometime during my four years of traveling to Iraq, I developed a recurring dream in which a Middle Eastern country invades the United States and occupies, among other places, my old neighborhood on the South Side of Chicago. The dream flashed briefly through my mind on Thursday as I walked the dirty, broken streets of Sadr City, a teeming Baghdad slum that forms the power base of Moktada al-Sadr, the radical Shiite cleric.

title: Maya Nath, Benjamin Curtis
description: Maya Dwaraka Nath, the daughter of Dr. Shashikala and Dr. Gopala Dwarakanath of Andover, Mass., was married on Saturday to Sgt. Benjamin A. Curtis, a son of Mary Curtis and John G. Curtis of Ann Arbor, Mich. Pandit Srinivasa Sastri performed the Hindu ceremony at Chinmaya Maruti, a Hindu religious center in Andover.

title: Motel 6s Light Is on in a New Kind of Room
description: The streamlined minimalist look of modern hotel rooms has trickled down to the budget chain Motel 6 (www.motel6.com). The company recently announced a new prototype that will open early next year in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.

title: When Parents Say No to Vaccines
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions last Sunday about a protest in Manhattan against the Iraq war misspelled the surname of one protester in some copies. She is Eileen Stareshefsky, not Scareshefsky.

title: Letters: Airborne Medical Care
description: To the Editor: I read with interest "Need a Doctor in the Air? Fly With One" (Practical Traveler, March 16), on medical emergencies on airplanes. It had particular pertinence for me. I was returning from Portland, Ore., to New York on JetBlue when I was overcome by severe stomach pains and bloating; I was in agony. My wife talked to a flight attendant who asked if there was a doctor on board.

title: An Oilman Entices, and Investors Cry Foul
description: LIKE so many of the over-the-top birthday parties that typically appear on My Super Sweet 16 on MTV, Ariels celebration took the fairy-tale-princess theme to new heights.

title: The Appeal
description: The jury was ready.

title: Doctor, Bully
description: The gynecologist Ive seen for seven years has begun requiring patients to waive their right to a day in court and to accept binding arbitration to settle any potential disputes, or she will not treat them. I sought care elsewhere but discovered that nearly all ob-gyn practices in the area make the same demand. Is this policy ethical? KATHLEEN WAGNER, PALM HARBOR, FLA.

title: From Page to Stage, Experienced Guides Showing the Way
description: PLAYWRIGHTS who bemoan those long periods of readings and revisions that rarely lead to a production must have been intrigued last fall when the Roundabout Theater Company announced Roundabout Underground, an initiative to help usher plays by lesser-known writers to the stage. Just a few weeks ago Lincoln Center Theater declared that this fall it would present the inaugural production of its new play enterprise, LCT3. And the Public Theater, already a venerable theatrical incubator, recently started an Emerging Writers Group, which, while not providing early career playwrights with productions, will offer other resources.

title: Estelamari Rodriguez and Louis Valente
description: Dr. Estelamari Rodriguez was married on Saturday to Louis Valente. Judge Eddie Ros Bentez of the Superior Court of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico officiated at the Condado Plaza Hotel in San Juan.

title: Iraqi Offensive Revives Debate for Campaigns
description: The heavy fighting that broke out last week as Iraqi security forces tried to oust Shiite militias from Basra is reverberating on the presidential campaign trail and posing new challenges and opportunities to the candidates, particularly Senator John McCain.

title: Multitasking, Then and Now
description: I GREW up Italian Catholic, in a small town in Passaic County, N.J. My parents were very active in the church, and I went to Catholic school.

title: That 6% Is Getting Harder to Earn
description: IN any real estate market, the question is asked, in voices both low and loud: What exactly do those brokers do for their 6 percent commission?

title: Style Decoder
description: QR Code scarf

title: Knowing What Its Like for Davidsons Coach
description: The day after George Mason reached the Final Four in 2006 with a stunning victory against Connecticut in the regional final, Patriots Coach Jim Larranaga shared a quiet moment with his wife, Liz. The frenzied run the 11th-seeded Patriots had made seemed surreal to Larranaga, and he sought another frame of reference. So he pretended he was someone else.

title: Taking in the River View From Both Banks
description: MAYBE it was the sun dancing on the water or the Statue of Liberty looking so majestic or the ferries making their way to and fro. I was dazzled by the views that two buildings  one in Jersey City, the other in Battery Park City  will have in common.

title: Just Like the Old Days: U.C.L.A. Rolls Onward
description: PHOENIX  Since John Wooden retired in 1975, U.C.L.A. has spent the better part of three decades trying in vain to replace him.

title: City Subpoenas Creator of Text Messaging Code
description: When delegates to the Republican National Convention assembled in New York in August 2004, the streets and sidewalks near Union Square and Madison Square Garden filled with demonstrators. Police officers in helmets formed barriers by stretching orange netting across intersections. Hordes of bicyclists participated in rolling protests through nighttime streets, and helicopters hovered overhead.

title: At Least 10 Killed as Somali Troops Shell a Market Used as an Insurgent Base
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  At least 10 people were killed in Mogadishu, Somalias chaotic capital, on Saturday afternoon after government troops shelled a market area known to be an insurgent hide-out.

title: Sleeping Giants
description: Looking across Shanghai, its hard to believe that the 22-story Park Hotel, built in the 1930s, dominated the skyline for half a century.

title: Yankees Prospect Says He Wont Be Down Long
description: MIAMI  The Yankees promoted Scott Patterson to Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre last September, and when the season was over he went home to Pittsburgh. He was moving furniture with his father when his cellphone rang. It was Pat Roessler, the Yankees player development director, and Patterson nudged his father. Surely, he thought, this would be The Call.

title: The Adroit Speaker Doesnt Wing It
description: Q. You have been asked to give a speech, and even though youre an expert on the topic, you feel terrified. Why?

title: Letters: Why Shariah?
description: Noah Feldman (March 16) argues forcefully that at the root of the Islamic legal system, or Shariah, lies an ideal of the rule of law  an ideal that can eventually foster and sustain democratic civil societies across the Muslim world. The disagreeable fact that Feldman most urgently needed to confront squarely, and didnt, is that, as he says, Shariah is not just a set of legal rules. Shariah has a metaphysical purpose: to mete out the justice embodied in Gods naked command. Feldman owes us an explanation of how a system of law in which Gods law sets the ground rules can function as something like a modern constitution  how a religious authority that claims a monopoly on the truth can preside over a civil order in which the truth is an open question, not bound to the naked command of any authority, no matter what its metaphysical pedigree. Modern constitutions, one would think, are secular for a reason.

title: Haymaker
description: Larry Woiwode established his reputation as a writer with his novels What Im Going to Do, I Think (1969) and Beyond the Bedroom Wall (1975). He wrote about human connectedness as expressed in family life across generations  relations between fathers and sons, husbands and wives. He was fascinated by the power of place to shape personal identity. His fluid structures and style suggested times permeability, capturing how memories from various periods in peoples lives flowed freely through their present actions, how consciousness built itself.

title: Upscale Variation on an Older Sibling
description: ELMER RUBIO is a living example of the American dream. He came to this country from El Salvador in 1989 and got a job as a dishwasher at the Mill River Inn in Oyster Bay, then worked his way up to sous-chef at places like Tupelo Honey in Sea Cliff and Meritage in Bellport. In 2003 he opened his own restaurant in East Patchogue, Chachama Grill, named for his hometown in El Salvador.

title: Having Your Cake
description: A simple get-together can become something special when the grand finale is a remarkable cake. At Riviera Bakehouse in Ardsley, Kaye Hansen and Peter Simon, the owners, are experts in theme cakes and often help customers decide on the best designs for their events.

title: Spice Girls (and Boys)
description: AT 11:59 on a Monday morning a few weeks ago, PS Coffee Tea and Spices, a little shop on Fifth Avenue near Fifth Street in Park Slope, was its usual quiet self. A woman had come in to buy a box of tea bags, and two others entered 10 minutes later, looked around for a while, smiled at Brenda Chan Casimir, the owner, and left without buying anything.

title: Guess Whos Coming to Power
description: After the collapse of Communism, the new world order quickly disintegrated into the new world disorder, as pent-up nationalism erupted, most dramatically in the Balkans. The nationalistic volcano subsided, replaced by fears about the clash of civilizations, which meant the West against the rest, and primarily Islam. After 9/11, the ism of concern became terrorism, and our book shelves groan under the weight of policy prescriptions from public officials, academics, journalists and even former spies.

title: Cold War Chill in McCain Remarks on Russia
description: WASHINGTONSenator John McCain made clear this week that for him, Europe ends at the border with Russia.

title: A Shot of Goji, Please
description: CHICAGO is known for being as hard-edged and industrial as the Sears Tower itself, but it is also Oprahs city, Obamas city, a city of change.

title: Clinton Shouldnt Feel Forced to Quit Race, Obama Says
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa.  Senator Barack Obama had a few words of advice Saturday for his rival, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton: Do not drop out on my account.

title: 6 Are Hurt in a Fire in Newark
description: NEWARK  Two people were in comas and a young girl was severely burned early Saturday after a fire gutted an apartment house here, city officials said.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: COMEDY

title: Shea in 64: The Planes Above, the Mets Below
description: At Shea Stadium, five dollars sometimes covers the cost of a seat way at the top of the upper deck but not the Sherpa to lug the oxygen tanks. The view is comparable to that from the ubiquitous low-flying planes, whose passengers, if so inclined, could reach out the window and take a bite from your Italian sausage. Buying another one would involve navigating a concourse roughly the width of a coffee table and sidestepping the bathroom line that started forming five innings earlier.

title: Surrender Already, Dorothy
description: WASHINGTON

title: Corrections: For the Record | EDITOR'S NOTE
description: Editors' Note

title: With a Few More Brains ...
description: Ten days ago, I noted the reckless assertion of Barack Obamas former pastor that the United States government had deliberately engineered AIDS to kill blacks, but I tried to put it in context by citing a poll showing that 30 percent of African-Americans believe such a plot is at least plausible.

title: Climb Every Mountain
description: Julie Andrewss memoir is full of crisp locutions like poor unfortunate and banished to the scullery and trivet, a characteristically precise term that the dictionary defines as an iron tripod placed over a fire for a cooking pot or kettle to stand on. It opens with a soppy poem she wrote about England, but what follows is a decisively unsoppy account of a typically dismal English childhood, complete with cramped lodgings and brutish relatives, which Andrews tells briskly and without self-pity.

title: Schooling the Artists Republic of China
description: BEIJING

title: Why Fight Invasive Vines? Just Turn Them Into Art
description: THE cry of a mortally wounded wood chipper is a piteous sound, somewhere between a car crash and a bull elks warning bugle. The dead machine was duly towed off by the men we had hired to help us clear the back of a field. Recriminations flew in the cab of their truck: Bittersweet vine you cannot chip! Its the devil! Strangles trees and machines.

title: In Boston, Residents Seek Face-to-Face Advice to Avoid Foreclosure
description: BOSTON  Carol Anderson has gone the entire winter without heat or hot water in her home here, because the payments on her adjustable rate mortgage have ballooned to $5,000 a month and she cannot afford paying a gas bill.

title: Pacific Heights
description: Between snowcapped mountains and the ocean shore, Vancouver has always been Canadas beauty queen. But the city isnt relying on its looks alone. With trailblazing chefs, designers and artists  not to mention a thriving film scene  its become the hottest spot north of the border.

title: In Treasury Plan, a Reluctant Eye Over Wall Street
description: The Bush administration is proposing the broadest overhaul of Wall Street regulation since the Great Depression. But the plan, to be unveiled on Monday, has its genesis in a yearlong effort to limit Washingtons role in the market.

title: Inside the List
description: THE BACK LIST: Twenty years ago this week, Robert Ludlum was still alive to write his own best sellers  others do it for him now  and first novels by Tom Wolfe and Scott Turow were riding high. On the nonfiction side, Donald Trump had his first best seller, while a university press book atypically cracked the list (Battle Cry of Freedom) and a final, posthumously published biography by the great Richard Ellmann held on at No. 9. Here are the complete New York Times best-seller lists from March 27, 1988:

title: California Kitchens
description: Despite a sensational farmers market, Santa Monica, Calif., has long been something of a culinary void. But lately things have been looking up. Rustic Canyon Wine Bar and Seasonal Kitchen (1119 Wilshire Boulevard; 310-393-7050; entrees $16 to $34) began the turnaround with Samir Mohajers seasonal dishes like lamb shanks with polenta and roasted baby artichokes. Michael Reardons Catch (above; 1910 Ocean Way; 310-581-7714; entrees $26 to $42) serves inventive seafood plates in the Casa del Mar hotel, and in the Huntely hotel, the Penthouse (1111 Second Street; 310-393-8080; entrees $22 to $48) features farmers market fare prepared by Seth Greenburg.

title: Deer and Lyme Disease in Connecticut
description: To the Editor:

title: Conjunction Junction
description: 1. The design and branding company Ideo makes a surprise foray into travel, harnessing its global network of cool-hunters to reinvent the guidebook. The highly selective Eyes Open volumes (Chronicle Books), which for now cover New York and London, contain just enough for a quick urban getaway.

title: Making Music, and Their Own Rules
description: MELVILLE

title: The Importance of Being Kennedy
description: Accidentally, Through the Keyhole

title: Letter: Buenos Aires Culture
description: To the Editor: I read with great dismay "Argentine Nights" (March 16), which posits that Buenos Aires has been transformed into an artistic and cultural mecca by expatriates from the United States and Europe. It may be helpful to recall that Buenos Aires and many other destinations featured in The Times have their own centuries-old cultural heritage, including numerous scholars, artists and authors.

title: Datebook
description: PALM BEACH, FLA.

title: Waging the Battle of the Overhead Bin
description: ON her US Airways flight from New Orleans to Washington this month, Corinne Marasco, a science writer from Kingstowne, Va., was forced to check her small wheelie bag at the gate because there was no room left in the overhead bins. It didnt matter that the gate agents kept reminding passengers that they were limited to one item of carry-on luggage, plus one personal item; the overhead bins were stuffed with shopping bags, knapsacks and pieces of luggage that clearly didnt pass the size test.

title: An American League Superiority Complex
description: Brian Cashman, the general manager of the Yankees, did not want to sound boastful or disrespectful, but he also did not want to lie. So when he was asked to compare the strength of the American League and the National League, he gave an emphatic response.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Sunday about Sharla Musabih and her efforts to protect battered wives and victims of human trafficking in Dubai paraphrased incorrectly from her comment about the need to take strong action to protect women. She said she was fighting any attitudes that made domestic abuse possible; she did not say that she was fighting patriarchal Arab traditions.

title: The Topic Is Race; the Art Is Fearless
description: IN the 1970s the African-American artist Adrian Piper donned an Afro wig and a fake mustache and prowled the streets of various cities in the scowling, muttering guise of the Mythic Being, a performance-art version of a prevailing stereotype, the black male as a mugger, hustler, gangsta.

title: Dave Stevens, 52, Artist Who Created the Rocketeer, Dies
description: Dave Stevens, the comic book artist and commercial illustrator who created the hero the Rocketeer and was famous for his 50s-pinup-style renderings of women, died in Turlock, Calif., on March 10. He was 52.

title: In Memoriam
description: The art of losing isnt hard to master, Elizabeth Bishop tells us  and yet artistry can often seem the least appropriate response to the misery of loss. When pain is primitive and specific, as it is after the death of a loved one, then we dont want an exquisite performance filled with grand abstractions. What we want is to go beyond art, beyond society and beyond speech itself, as Lear does when he enters carrying the body of his daughter and crying, Howl howl howl howl! We want heavens vault to crack. We want the veil parted and the bone laid bare. This is what Tennyson meant when he wrote in Canto 54 of In Memoriam, his tribute to his friend Arthur Hallam, that his grief left him no language but a cry.

title: Journal Issues Warning on Two Cholesterol Drugs
description: CHICAGO  Two widely prescribed cholesterol-lowering drugs, Vytorin and Zetia, may not work and should be used only as a last resort, The New England Journal of Medicine said in an editorial published on Sunday.

title: A Race Will Play Out Without an Added Ace
description: The ghost of Johan Santana could haunt the Red Sox and the Yankees this season.

title: From Daydreaming to Filmmaking, Through the Lens of Dyslexia
description: Litchfield

title: Amy Levy, Michael Caplan
description: Amy Victoria Levy and Michael Benjamin Caplan were married Saturday evening at the Yale Club in New York. Cary S. Lane, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

description: This article is adapted from the book Bushs Law: The Remaking of American Justice, by Eric Lichtblau, which is being released Tuesday by Pantheon Books.

title: Are You a Good Driver? Heres How to Find Out
description: COULD a video game make you a better driver? More important, could computer software prevent teenagers from making fatal mistakes or even weed out older drivers whose debilities make them crash-prone?

title: Cracking Down on Home Invasion
description: THE killings of three members of a Cheshire, Conn., family during a home invasion in July has spurred a flurry of legislative proposals in the region to crack down on a crime that officials say has become more prevalent in recent years.

title: Hansbrough Lifts Tar Heels Into Final Four
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  North Carolina was in the midst of a stunning collapse in its N.C.A.A. tournament Round of 8 game with Louisville on Saturday night. The shooters had gone cold, the double-digit lead had disappeared and the favored Tar Heels were on the brink of gut-wrenching disappointment for the second year in a row.

title: Staying Put, in a Mobile Home
description: BREWSTER

title: The Longhorn From Nowhere
description: HOUSTON  When the Texas starting lineup is introduced before games, the Longhorns junior forward Connor Atchley is announced as hailing from Clear Lake, Tex., even though no such city actually exists.

title: Barack Bowl
description: ALTOONA, Pa.  Barack Obama spent Saturday evening in a close encounter with the fierce urgency of a gutter ball.

title: Polar Cities a Haven in Warming World?
description: Danny Bloom, a freelance writer, translator and editor living in Taiwan, is on a one-man campaign to get people to seriously consider a worst-case prediction of the British chemist and inventor James Lovelock: life in polar cities arrayed around the shores of an ice-free Arctic Ocean in a greenhouse-warmed world.

title: What Do You Bid?
description: School auctions are no longer low-key affairs for parents and teachers.

description: Photos of some of Dmitri Hvorostovsky's performances at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: An Animal Lover's Haven
description: Dr. Tom DeVincentis, a veterinarian with a practice on East 75th Street, has lived on the Upper East Side since 1971, but he has never taken the subway or bus to work.

title: The Hunt: More Than a Pet Project
description: Two adopted cats provide the impetus for George Kokoris and Tania Dudina to move.

title: Op-Classic, 1992: The Art of Writing Another Baseball Column
description: Every week, the Opinion section presents an essay from The Times's archive by a columnist or contributor that we hope sheds light on current news or provides a window on the past.

title: Last Word
description: New York Times photographer Dith Pran survived the Cambodian killing fields.  He dedicated his life to telling the story of the Khmer Rouge's genocide.

title: Its Called Living on Social Security
description: Aired Friday night on NBC: I know we have a lot of college students here. Now, heres kind of a philosophical question. Now, if a sniper fires a gun in the woods and nobody is around, does Hillary Clinton still hear it?

description: From The Onion:

Zimbabwe Opposition Claims Victory
description: HARARE, ZimbabaweZimbabawe's main opposition party claimed a landslide victory Sunday, insisting that unofficial results show that the Movement for Democratic Change has unseated Robert Mugabe, the man who has led this nation for 28 years.

title: 2008 N.L. Predictions
description: It is raining here in Memphis, where Im stranded at the airport for a few hours at lovely Gate B6 waiting for the plane to arrive from Jackson, Miss., where it had to land after it was diverted from Omaha and, well, you get the idea. But the forecast in Washington, where the 2008 National League season will open tonight, calls for clear skies. Baseball is back, and with it comes optimism that your team, regardless of injuries or expectations, can have a great season.
