description: Headlines from the world of property:

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Sunday, Mar. 30:

title: Big East Allegiances
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  The Rutgers womens basketball players say they root for their fellow Big East players in the tournament but some of their fans arent so magnanimous.

title: Even a Brain Tumor Cant Stop This Goalie
description: The second-longest game in hockey history was played last weekend, as host Klner Haie beat Adler Mannheim, 5-4, in the sixth overtime of their German DEL quarterfinal, a contest that lasted a total of 168 minutes 16 seconds. But there was something even more incredible about that game.

title: UConn vs. Tennessee
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  Connecticut Coach Geno Auriemma and Tennessee Coach Pat Summitt dont talk to each other anymore, their mutual grudge apparently arising from their tug-of-war recruitment of Maya Moore, the all-world freshman.

title: Living in Turtle Bay
description: As diverse as the United Nations and spread over 70 blocks, Turtle Bay offers some charming urban oases.

title: Global Warming Creates Odd Couples
description: Al Gore and his organization, the Alliance for Climate Protection, are hoping that a campaign pairing unlikely couples will generate more support for their cause.

title: Women's Round of 16
description: Sunday's action in the women's N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Rendell Likes Idea of Clinton-Obama Ticket
description: Gov. Edward G. Rendell of Pennsylvania, a supporter of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, said that he would love to see Mr. Obama and Mrs. Clinton on a ticket together, as Mario Cuomo, the former governor of New York, proposed earlier this week (without saying who would be in which slot).

title: Men's Round of 8
description: Sunday's action in the men's N.C.A.A. Regional Finals.

title: Rock CHALK Riverwalk
description: Well, the teams are set for one of the most buzz-worthy and high-profile Final Fours in N.C.A.A. history. Kansas hung on to beat Davidson after a buzzer-beater heave to win the game missed left for Wildcats.

title: Memphis Has a Fan in the N.F.L.
description: HOUSTON  New Orleans Saints cornerback Mike McKenzie was among those celebrating in the Memphis locker room after the top-seeded Tigers advanced to the Final Four with an 85-67 victory Sunday against Texas.

title: Enough Distractions. Lets Talk About Me.
description: MERIDIAN, Miss.  Senator John McCain is hoping to move the campaign narrative from the current events section of the popular imagination to the biography section with his tour this week of places important to his life story.

title: Boston College and North Dakota Complete Frozen Four
description: Boston College had to reach down deep to send Miami (Ohio), the No. 2 seed in the NCAA tournament, on its way in the Northeast regional final Sunday. Likewise North Dakota, who needed overtime to end Wisconsins ice dreams. The Eagles and the Fighting Sioux will square off in the semifinals of the Frozen Four.

title: Derrick Rose Is Tiger Woods?
description: HOUSTON The Memphis freshman point guard Derrick Rose is often compared to Jason Kidd of the Dallas Mavericks.

title: Dith Pran, RIP
description: Dith Pran has been a legendary figure in The New York Times family for decades, and so we are in mourning today after his death from pancreatic cancer. Hes best known of course for The Killing Fields, the movie of his odyssey in Cambodia under Pol Pot. The movie is the true story of how, as the interpreter/fixer for The New York Times in Cambodia, he relentlessly gathered news and saved the life of our correspondent, Sydney Schanberg. When the Khmer Rouge arrived Schanberg tried to get Dith Pran out but couldnt.

title: Calling China
description: I think Im going to write my next column about China, in the wake of the Tibetan protests, and Id love to hear from some Chinese readers. For those of you in China, has the Times website been restored so that you can access this site? I gather that it was cut off after the Tibetan upheavals, but maybe the links have been restored. In any case, my sense is that many Chinese  whether in China or outside the country  are deeply indignant at U.S. media coverage of Tibet in particular and China-U.S. relations in general. I get waves of angry emails whenever I write about China and Darfur. So heres your chance: What do we get wrong, and why?

title: Two Tigers Cut Down the Nets
description: HOUSTON  Unlike more traditional net-cutting ceremonies after regional final victories in which the entire team takes part, only the Memphis seniors Andre Allen and Joey Dorsey snipped the nets after beating second-seeded Texas, 85-67, Sunday.

title: Final Four: A Look Ahead
description: No. 1 Memphis vs. No. 1 U.C.L.A.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about an internal investigation at The Los Angeles Times into whether sources provided fabricated documents for an article on an 1994 assault on the rapper Tupac Shakur misspelled the name of the reporter who wrote the article. He is Chuck Philips, not Phillips.

title: Rosy Words for Clinton by 90s Nemesis
description: To Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton, Richard Mellon Scaife qualifies as a charter member of the vast right-wing conspiracy, having bankrolled an elaborate multimillion-dollar campaign throughout the 1990s to unearth damaging information about the couple.

title: Firsthand Look at Basra Shows Value of White Flag
description: BASRA, Iraq  I walked, ran and crawled into central Basra on Thursday, constantly dropping to the ground because of gun battles between Mahdi Army militiamen and the Iraqi Army and the police.

title: Once Part of Yanks Lineup, Girardi Names It
description: Playing catch with the team and throwing batting practice during the Yankees final preseason workout Sunday, Manager Joe Girardi might have wished he could be in the opening day lineup.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 30, 2008

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A theater review on Friday about The Fifth Column, at the Mint Theater, misstated the directors surname. He is Jonathan Bank, not Banks.

title: Saying No to Broadwater
description: Here is our position on Broadwater, the quarter-mile-long floating energy barge in Long Island Sound that could supply New York and Connecticut with a billion cubic feet of natural gas a day  provided it wins regulatory approval, is built as planned and doesnt get blown up by terrorists or sunk by market forces:

title: How the Poll of Baseball Fans Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted March 15 through March 18 with 1,067 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 492 adults identified themselves as fans of major league baseball, saying that they were very or somewhat interested in following the sport.

title: Programs for All Ages
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Waterfront: Brooklyn Bridge Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Reaching the Final Turn in 3 Years of Bumpy Road
description: Even by the adventurous standards of the Miller Theater, the Pocket Concertos series that it started in 2006 came with built-in land mines. The plan was to present the premieres of a dozen newly commissioned concertos in three annual installments, and mishaps werent long in coming. At the first concert, a piano concerto by Ichizo Okashiro, The Starry Night, proved too difficult to prepare in the available time and was postponed. It turned up in the finale, on Thursday evening. But a cello concerto by Marc-Andr Dalbavie was put off until next season, when it will be part of a Composer Portrait.

title: Inoculated Against Facts
description: Philadelphia

title: Feet, Arms and Foam Tubing, All Moving to Led Zeppelin
description: Dance New Amsterdam was smart to name Laura Peterson as one of its 2007-8 artists in residence: as a set designer, she is a problem solver. This theater has flaws, notably the six columns planted firmly on the stage, along with the sad fact that the seats arent staggered; sometimes its best to just give up and sit in the front row.

title: In Amsterdam, Overtime on the Way to a Title
description: The White House Junior Championship took place in Amsterdam from March 10 to 15. Twenty-four teams from 18 countries competed in a 10-board round robin to qualify four teams for the 24-board semifinals.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An art review on Friday about In the Forest of Fontainebleau: Painters and Photographers From Corot to Monet, at the National Gallery of Art, misidentified the man depicted in Frdric Bazilles painting The Improvised Field Hospital, which is in the exhibition. He is Claude Monet, not Alfred Sisley.

title: The Weeks Major Economic Reports
description: ECONOMIC SIGNALS The main economic event of the week will be the unemployment report for March, to be released on Friday. Employment is expected to fall by 40,000 jobs.

title: The Baton Passes to Asia
description: HONG KONG

title: Experience Is Afterthought After Dominating Victory
description: The Kentucky Derby is a demanding test of speed, stamina and toughness, and it has a way of chewing up inexperienced horses. The races exacting nature will be put to the test again this year, and this time the Kentucky Derby may just meet its match.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: The CBC Orchestra Plays Taps for Itself
description: The CBC Radio Orchestra, described as the last radio orchestra in North America, is to be disbanded at the end of November, The Globe and Mail of Toronto reported. Really, its a straight-up case of economics, Jeff Keay, a spokesman for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, said. We couldnt afford to maintain the orchestra. He said the orchestras annual budget, which he placed at less than $1 million, would be used to commission music from other orchestras across Canada. Andrew Brown, a violist with the Vancouver-based CBC orchestra, formed in 1938, said, It is a travesty that this decision has been made. Including core and occasional players, the orchestra has about 45 members.

title: Farmers Cut Back on Corn and Add Soybeans
description: Strong worldwide food demand, and the accompanying higher prices, are beginning to influence American farmers.

title: The Year of Magical Budgeting
description: Financial counselors often tell their clients to prepare monthly budgets rather than yearly ones, on the theory that it is easier to predict expenses over a short period. But a paper recently published in The Journal of Consumer Research turns that advice on its head.

title: Sadr Offers Deal for Truce as Fighting Persists in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  The Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr on Sunday took a step toward ending six days of intense combat between his militia allies and Iraqi and American forces in Basra and Baghdad, saying in a statement that his followers would lay down their arms providing the Iraqi government met a series of demands.

title: David Gale, Who Created Marriage Algorithm, Is Dead at 86
description: David Gale, a wide-ranging mathematician who helped develop an algorithm for pairing individuals into couples that has also been used to match hospitals with fledgling doctors for medical residencies, died on March 7 in Berkeley, Calif. He was 86.

title: Inflation Accelerates in Europe in March
description: Euro-zone inflation accelerated in March to the fastest pace since 1992, official data showed Monday, giving the European Central Bank reason to look with concern on the announcement of a big wage deal in Germany.

title: A Stadium, and With It a Season, Opens With Fanfare in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  It was only a pitch, a man throwing a baseball Sunday night.

title: BBC Costumes Sold
description: The BBC costume department, home to more than a million coats, dresses, frilly shirts, cuffs and collars, has been sold to Angels the Costumiers, Britains biggest supplier of costumes to the film and television industry, the BBC reported. The sale ends uncertainty about the future of the costumes after the BBC announced last year that it would sell the department as part of a wide-ranging cutback. Angels, a family-run business with a warehouse that contains six and a half miles of costumes, has provided tunics to Star Wars, loincloths to Gladiator and ruffs to Elizabeth: The Golden Age.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: International

title: Supreme Court Rules for Delaware in River Dispute
description: WASHINGTON  For many decades, the states of Delaware and New Jersey have fought over the river that separates them. On Monday, Delaware won the latest battle, as the Supreme Court said it could block New Jerseys plan to build a huge gas-processing plant on the Jersey side of the Delaware River.

title: A Tintin Is Born
description: Thomas Sangster, a 17-year-old British actor, below, has been chosen by Steven Spielberg to play Tintin in the first of three planned films about the adventures of the young Belgian reporter and hero in comic strips and books created by Georges Remi (1907-83) under the pen name Herg, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Sangsters credits include Love Actually and Nanny McPhee. ... This week, in Argentina, Francis Ford Coppola is to begin filming Tetro, about the struggles of two brothers from an Italian family in Argentina in the present day, The Associated Press reported. Im trying to have a new start with my career, making more personal, smaller films, said Mr. Coppola, 68, whose credits include the Godfather trilogy and Apocalypse Now. I never made films as a grand maestro, he said. I always made films more as an imaginative child. ... Kirschblten (Cherry Blossoms), a film by Doris Drrie about a cranky old Bavarian civil servant and his metamorphosis in Japan after his wifes death, topped the list of nominees for Lolas, the German Film Prizes, which were announced in Berlin on Friday by the German culture minister, Bernd Neumann, and the actress Senta Berger. Kirschblten earned six nominations, including best film and best director. Winners of prizes totaling $5 million are to be announced on April 25, Reuters reported.

title: From Views to Fastballs, Wagner Wont Hold Back
description: MIAMI  In late November, about a week after Tom Glavine signed with Atlanta, Billy Wagner told MLB.com that he viewed the Mets as a third-place team. Within a few days, Wagner received a call from General Manager Omar Minaya, who asked if he was misquoted. Wagner said no.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on Wednesday about the Rangers 2-1 loss in overtime to the Philadelphia Flyers misstated the sequence of action leading to the winning goal, by Mike Richards. Sean Avery of the Rangers turned over the puck to Flyers defenseman Jason Smith, who passed it to Richards. Avery did not send the puck directly to Richards.

title: Clear-Cut Case of the Blues, in a Bebop Mode
description: Time and again at Town Hall on Friday night Ornette Coleman tacked toward the blues. The dimensions of his pristine alto saxophone tone  a small, bright thing with a flavor both tart and sweet  kept warping slightly, in the manner of an R&B singer. He phrased in short, soulful bursts as well as fluid outpourings, frequently skimming a pentatonic scale. And his band invoked the blues clearly at times, with a smattering of riffs and backbeats, and one vamp evocative of the Peter Gunn theme.

title: Japanese Traditions on the Move
description: Cross-cultural meldings of Eastern and Western dance styles and aesthetics must have been unusual and perhaps somewhat exotic when the Saeko Ichinohe Dance Company was founded in 1970. But in an age when no ethnic dance form is too obscure to be featured on YouTube and when choreographers borrow rampantly and triumphantly from a vast mix of movement styles, Ms. Ichinohes work looks strangely purist and somewhat old-fashioned.

title: Pelfrey, With 8.14 E.R.A., Gets the Nod for the Mets
description: MIAMI  The right-hander Mike Pelfrey, who had an unsightly 8.14 earned run average in spring training, will open the season as the Mets fifth starter, Manager Willie Randolph said Sunday.

title: In Showcase of Top Teams, Everyone Has a Favorite
description: PHOENIX  The 25-foot heave from Davidson point guard Jason Richards was wide left, finishing the Wildcats charmed season in the N.C.A.A. tournaments Round of 8.

title: Defending Detective, Lawyer Feels the Heat
description: It was in the opening days of the trial of three detectives in Queens, and Anthony L. Ricco, a lawyer for the undercover detective who fired the first shots of a barrage that killed Sean Bell, was on his way to lunch when the question came.

title: Memphis Routs Texas, No Doubt About It
description: HOUSTON  All season, Memphis has complained of being disrespected nationally.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Empire Zone column in some editions on March 10 about a bid to legalize so-called mixed martial arts fighting in New York State referred incorrectly to the rules of the Ultimate Fighting Championship, a league devoted to the sport. Choke holds are in fact allowed, not banned.

title: Obstacles Seen as Treasury Proposes New Financial Rules
description: WASHINGTON  As Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. on Monday formally laid out an ambitious plan to overhaul the regulatory apparatus that oversees the countrys financial system, senior lawmakers and lobbyists from industries opposed to the plan predicted that most of it would be dead on arrival.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Young, but With Enough Experience to Look Back
description: It had to have been gratifying to the directors of Carnegie Hall that the Making Music program featuring the British composer Thomas Ads sold out Zankel Hall on Saturday night. Though just 37, Mr. Ads is a major musician in Britain, admired as a composer, pianist and conductor. Among his champions in America is Esa-Pekka Salonen, music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, who has made Disney Hall practically a home away from home for Mr. Ads.

title: Tibet Protest at Olympic Ceremony
description: ATHENS  Greek officials handed over the Olympic flame to organizers of the Beijing Summer Games on Sunday, but demonstrators angered by Chinas clampdown in Tibet sought to disrupt the ceremony, evading heavy security to unfurl protest banners.

title: Klugman Sues Over Quincy
description: Jack Klugman, below, who often uncovered foul play when he starred for years on television as a medical examiner on Quincy, M.E., has decided that there is something fishy about NBC Universals handling of the money from the show. So he sued NBC Universal on Friday in Los Angeles County Superior Court, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Klugman said his 1976 contract with NBC entitled him and his company, Sweater Productions, to 25 percent of the net profits of Quincy, which ran from 1976 to 1983 and was rerun afterward. I recently heard that they made $250 million, and its still on TV in Germany, said Mr. Klugman, 85. I dont want their money. I want my money. I worked my tail off. I got up at 4 in the morning and stayed at the studio. I did rewrite. I edited. He said that his copy of the contract was lost when his agent died and that NBC refused to provide a copy. According to the lawsuit, NBC provided Mr. Klugman with an accounting statement showing that the series lost $66 million through 2006. Mr. Klugman said he believed that NBC was lying and that the series made money. NBC did not reply immediately to a request for comment.

title: Israelis Agree to Reduce West Bank Roadblocks
description: JERUSALEM  Israel agreed Sunday to remove about 50 roadblocks in the West Bank and promised Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, who is visiting here, that it would upgrade checkpoints to reduce the waiting time for Palestinians who have been hampered in their efforts to go about their daily lives.

title: Barth Healey, 68, Times Editor and Stamp Columnist, Dies
description: Barth Healey, an editor at The New York Times for three decades who also wrote the newspapers stamp column from 1988 to 1993, died Saturday at a hospice in Melville, N.Y. He was 68.

title: For the Finale, a Tune That May or May Not Be the Bosss Favorite
description: What is Robert A. Igers favorite title from the Disney songbook? Entertainment industry titans attending a fund-raiser in Los Angeles this month found out. Or at least thought they did.

title: Nothings Wasted, Especially Garbage
description: There is nothing more disgusting than garbage that doesnt know its place. Thats one reason its garbage in the first place. It is something we are done with, that no longer belongs near us. It must be removed, taken away. Otherwise it contaminates, disgusts. The anthropologist Mary Douglas suggested that the very definition of dirt was matter out of place: a hair on ones head is one thing, a hair in a glass of water is another. A half-eaten plate of food is a savored delicacy in one context, a mound of waste in another.

title: Hope in Albany for Passing Budget on Time
description: ALBANY  Legislative leaders and the Paterson administration said Sunday night that it was possible they could complete the state budget close to Mondays midnight deadline, a task that seemed all but unattainable just hours earlier.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on March 22 about State Department workers improperly looking at the passport files of the three presidential candidates misstated the middle initial for the department spokesman. He is Sean I. McCormack, not Sean D. McCormack.

title: McCain Faces Test in Wooing Elite Donors
description: With attention focused on the Democrats infighting for the presidential nomination, Senator John McCain is pressing ahead to the general election but has yet to sign up one critical constituency: the big-money people who powered the Bush fund-raising machine.

title: Fledgling Violinist Flies Solo in Carnegies Vast Space
description: Augustin Hadelich is at least the second young violinist of German origin to have played Bartoks Sonata for Solo Violin in New York this season. Viviane Hagner, at the 92nd Street Y last month, had the advantage of playing it in a space small enough to show it to its best advantage.

title: Detainee Charged in Embassy Attack
description: WASHINGTON  Military prosecutors filed war crimes charges on Monday against a Guantnamo detainee who was formerly held in the Central Intelligence Agencys secret prisons and has been indicted previously by federal prosecutors in New York.

title: Europe Takes a Closer Look at Employee Stock Ownership
description: FRANKFURT  For Wolfgang Eder, now chief executive of Voestalpine, a metal working company in Austria, meetings with employees a few years ago invariably turned into lengthy attempts at calming nerves.

title: Dith Pran, Photojournalist and Survivor of the Killing Fields, Dies at 65
description: Dith Pran, a photojournalist for The New York Times whose gruesome ordeal in the killing fields of Cambodia was re-created in a 1984 movie that gave him an eminence he tenaciously used to press for his peoples rights, died on Sunday at a hospital in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 65 and lived in Woodbridge, N.J.

title: Penguins Capitalize Against Penalty-Prone Rangers
description: PITTSBURGH  The Rangers have found themselves perched so precariously in the Eastern Conference playoff race that they entered Sunday afternoons game against the Pittsburgh Penguins eyeing the top of the standings and left it  after a 3-1 loss at Mellon Arena  warily eyeing the bottom.

title: Stocks Fall in Europe and Asia
description: PARIS  Stocks fell in Europe and most of Asia on Monday amid expectations of more losses in the banking sector, as investors prepared to close out a dismal quarter. Futures prices showed Wall Street was set to open lower.

title: Hollywood Producer Set to Make Shows for Xbox
description: LOS ANGELES  Microsoft, seeking to expand offerings on its Xbox 360 console, has reached an agreement with a company headed by Peter Safran, the veteran Hollywood producer and talent manager, to produce original shows for distribution on the system.

title: Citizen Huff
description: Ari Emanuel called me last night with an idea for a blog, Arianna Huffington said last week as she sipped an iced coffee in the New York offices of The Huffington Post.

title: Top U.S. Housing Official Resigns
description: WASHINGTON  Housing secretary Alphonso R. Jackson resigned on Monday, saying that he needed to devote more time to his family. The announcement came as federal authorities were investigating whether he had given lucrative housing contracts in the Virgin Islands and New Orleans to friends.

title: Brake Problems Led to United Jet Skids
description: WASHINGTON  Two United Airlines A320 jetliners skidded off runways in recent months because of crossed wires in their antilock brakes, the airline said.

title: Tracking a Marine Lost at Home
description: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla.  A week after Eric W. Hall disappeared into the woods of Southwest Florida, his mother stood in a parking lot overlooking the Gulf of Mexico. She had asked for volunteers. Would they come?

title: Flirting by Text Message, Indians Test Social Limits
description: MUMBAI  In this romantically corseted society, Ashish Chettri is as close as you get to a Don Juan.

title: Chinese Nationalism Fuels Tibet Crackdown
description: BEIJING  Like so many Chinese, Meng Huizhong was horrified by the violent Tibetan protests in Lhasa. She cringed at videos of Tibetan rioters attacking a Chinese motorcyclist. Her anger deepened as Tibet dominated her online conversation groups, until it settled on what might seem like an unlikely target: the Communist Party.

title: For Top Two in Big East, the Reward Is a Rematch
description: GREENSBORO, N.C.  It was not considered an impudent question here, where basketball is recognized as a secular religion and people worship the midrange jumper.

title: Snoopers on Subway, Beware Digital Books
description: The man riding the A train uptown on a recent Friday afternoon was a little hard to place. He was middle-aged and looked faintly distinguished, with neatly cropped silver hair and a close shave. His clothing, however, was incongruous, young for the rest of him: a parka layered over a snazzy, black zip-up sweater. The book in his hand provided a possible clarification: Death of a Salesman. There you go  an actor, perhaps, not famous, but the kind of working player who populates the city, showing up as Guildenstern or Sentry No. 4.

title: Woman, 27, Is Fatally Shot in Brooklyn
description: A woman in a Brooklyn playground was shot to death on Sunday night, the police said.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture on Tuesday with an article about guidelines that New York State health officials use to determine who should receive breathing machines called ventilators during an epidemic was published in error. It showed a mask for anesthesia, not a ventilator.

title: Wiring Is Blamed in Airliner Skids
description: WASHINGTON  Two United Airlines A320 jetliners skidded off runways in recent months because of crossed wires in their antilock brakes, the airline said.

title: Bernsteins Singing Presidents: A Recount
description: Few American composers work is performed as frequently as Leonard Bernsteins, and that will be particularly apparent this year with concert programming honoring his 90th birthday.

title: Where Is Your Rebate Check Going?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ontarios Example on Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Justices Let Stand Ruling on Illegal F.B.I. Search
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday let stand a lower court ruling that the F.B.I. went too far in searching the office of Representative William J. Jefferson, a Louisiana Democrat accused of using his position to promote business deals in Africa.

title: 2 Irish Billionaires Clash Over Publishers Course
description: LONDON  Irish history is rich in epic feuds of kings and family clans. A modern version is now being played out, as two Irish billionaires spar over the future of the publisher of Londons Independent, The Irish Independent and more than 100 newspapers.

title: We Want It, and Waiting Is No Option
description: The Virgin Megastore in Times Square was bustling last Thursday during the lunch hour, but with two remarkably different universes of consumers. One group of shoppers  none of whom appeared to be under 40  were browsing manually through CDs, no doubt some of them drawn by Virgins profit-killing $10 price.

title: Islands Past and Future, in a Layer Cake
description: SMITH ISLAND, Md.  With the blessing of state lawmakers in Annapolis, a sweet blend of flour, butter, eggs and chocolate may provide an economic boost to this small, struggling island in the middle of the Chesapeake Bay.

title: The Drugs Are Expensive, but They Transform Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Baseball Expands Its Web Presence to China
description: Baseball fans in China will be able to see highlights, scores, photographs, statistics and some games on a new Web site in their language developed by BroadWebAsia under a licensing agreement with the Internet division of Major League Baseball.

title: Online Chat, as Inspired by Real Chat
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Compared with other forms of human interaction, online social networking is really not all that social.

title: The Judge, the Director and the Vagaries of Justice
description: The sharply argued documentary Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired isnt about the innocence or guilt of its title subject, who after pleading guilty in 1977 to having unlawful sexual intercourse with a minor flew from Los Angeles to London, never again to return to America. Neither is it about Mr. Polanskis likability, his tragic past, morals, short stature, brilliant and bad films, the sleaze factor or your personal feelings on whether theres anything wrong with a 43-year-old mans having sex with a 13-year-old girl. All these elements come teasingly into view here, but really this is a movie about a very different kind of perversion.

title: Zimbabwe Opposition Says It Has Beaten Mugabe
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe  Zimbabwes main opposition party said Sunday that it had won a landslide victory, insisting that unofficial election results showed that the Movement for Democratic Change had unseated President Robert G. Mugabe, the man who has led this nation for 28 years.

title: East Side vs. West Side: Whos No. 1? Who Cares?
description: Believing that Manhattan was an island divided, Steve Bernstein organized a series of competitions that would pit East Siders against West Siders.

title: Vatican Sees Popes Visit as Chance to Soften Image
description: WASHINGTON  When Pope Benedict XVI makes his first papal trip to the United States in April, he will be guided by a seasoned Vatican ambassador who sees the visit as an opportunity to introduce a little-known pope to a complex set of audiences: American Catholics, Americans in general and global opinion leaders.

title: Tons of Snow Test a Place Where Cold Is No Stranger
description: OTTAWA  People here are divided between those longing for a few more inches of snow to set a record and others who think the 14 feet that has already landed, and mostly lingered, is more than enough.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about Minoru Mori, Japans most prolific developer, attributed an erroneous distinction to one of his buildings. The Taipei 101 in Taiwan is currently the worlds tallest building, not Mr. Moris 101-story Shanghai World Financial Center. (His building does have the tallest roof height at 492 meters, but a spire on the building in Taipei makes it taller, at 508 meters.)

title: North Korea Threatens to Reduce South Korea to Ashes at Slightest Provocation
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea continued Sunday to lash out at the new conservative government in Seoul, threatening to reduce the South to ashes if the South Korean government made the slightest move to attack.

title: Miller Says He Plans to Stay at Xavier
description: PHOENIX  Xavier Coach Sean Millers team exited the N.C.A.A. tournament with a blowout loss to U.C.L.A. on Saturday. But no coach in the tournament, aside from Davidsons Bob McKillop, may have raised his market value more than Miller.

title: For Yankees, Its Still Win, but Not Win Now or Else
description: The evidence is unmistakable. As opening day dawns in the Bronx on Monday afternoon, the most decorated franchise in sports is in transition.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about a Los Angeles Times article on a 1994 assault on the rapper Tupac Shakur, which turned out to have been based on forged documents, misstated the location of the article in that paper. It appeared on the cover of the entertainment section, not on the front page. (The newspapers explanation and apology appeared on the front page.)

title: The Political Specter at Justice
description: Attorney General Michael Mukasey was supposed to end the cynical politicization of the Justice Department. But the sudden disbanding of the United States attorneys public corruption office in Los Angeles looks like business as usual.

title: As Jobs Vanish and Prices Rise, Food Stamp Use Nears Record
description: Driven by a painful mix of layoffs and rising food and fuel prices, the number of Americans receiving food stamps is projected to reach 28 million in the coming year, the highest level since the aid program began in the 1960s.

title: Sorrow in Seductive Adornment
description: Sorrow wrapped in guitar filigree, elegant romance with a tragic undercurrent  thats the tradition of Portuguese fado that Ana Moura joins. At Symphony Space on Friday night she started her World Music Institute concert facing not the audience but a band member: Angelo Freire on guitarra (Portuguese guitar), the round, high-strung instrument thats inseparable from fado. She sang to the guitarra, begging it to break the silence and save her. She was dressed in black, with a shawl over her shoulders.

title: Israel Agrees to Ease Access for Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM  Israel agreed Sunday to remove about 50 roadblocks in the West Bank and promised Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, who is visiting here, that it would upgrade its checkpoints to reduce the waiting time for Palestinians who have been hampered in their efforts to go about their daily lives.

title: Accounts, People, Miscellany
description: Accounts

title: Glamour Is Chastened After Caddish Remarks by Dating Blogger Incite a Revolt
description: Last July, when Mike Cherico, a Los Angeles high school teacher, began writing a blog about dating for Glamour magazine, he came with a kind of Good Housekeeping seal of approval: he was a buddy of the previous blogger, Alyssa Shelasky, and readers had adored her, said Ellen Seidman, a deputy editor at Glamour.

title: The Right Balance for Juveniles
description: To the Editor:

title: Top-Seeded Memphis Cruises to Final Four
description: HOUSTONAll season Memphis has complained of being disrespected nationally.

title: Making Appointments for Doctor or Dinner
description: THE e-commerce bandwagon bypassed millions of carpenters, massage therapists, lawyers and other service providers, mostly because it is impossible to drop an appointment into a shopping cart without unleashing a scheduling nightmare.

title: Six Degrees (at Least) of Contenders for President
description: Last week, the New England Historic Genealogical Society issued a press release that it knew would get some bounce: the group said it had traced the ancestry of the presidential candidates and found that all of them had blood ties  albeit distant ones  to unlikely famous people.

title: Newspaper Ad Revenue Down 7.9%
description: Newspaper advertising revenue fell 7.9 percent in 2007, the second-worst year in more than half a century, the Newspaper Association of America said on Friday. Those figures include continued growth in online advertising.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,996 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Sunday:

title: In Isolated Hills of Asia, New Roads to Speed Trade
description: LUANG NAMTHA, Laos  The newly refurbished Route 3 that cuts through this remote town is an ordinary strip of pavement, the type of two-lane road you might find winding through the backwoods of Vermont or sunflower fields in the French provinces.

title: Spitzer Is Gone, but Trooper Inquiry Is Still Going
description: ALBANY  Its not over.

title: G.M. Closes Car Plant; Parts Maker Tries to Push U.A.W.
description: DETROIT  American Axle and Manufacturing, the auto parts maker, is trying to force an end to the industrys longest strike in a decade by calling back laid-off employees, advertising for replacement workers and threatening to move production out of the United States.

title: Double Whammy: Virus Spread by Terrorists and a Plague of Drug-Addled Escapists
description: De Profundis (out of the depths) was Oscar Wildes biblical title for his despairing memoir of disgrace and imprisonment. In its contemporary reach for an equivalent despair Last Last Chance could as well be titled out of the shallows.

title: Cleric Suspends Battle in Basra by Shiite Militia
description: BAGHDAD  The Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr on Sunday called for his followers to stop fighting in Basra and in turn demanded concessions from Iraqs government, after six days in which his Mahdi Army militia has held off an American-supported Iraqi assault on the southern port city.

title: Spat Between Actors Unions Snarls Negotiations With Studios
description: LOS ANGELES  A sudden split between two actors unions over the weekend added an unhappy twist to Hollywoods troubled contract cycle: It appeared to weaken the labor organizations without making life easier for the studios they bargain with.

title: Race and the Social Contract
description: In 1893, Friedrich Engels wrote from London to Friedrich Adolph Sorge, another German Communist then living in New York, lamenting how Americas diversity hindered efforts to establish a workers party in the United States. Was it possible to unify Poles, Germans, Irish, the many small groups, each of which understands only itself? All the bourgeoisie had to do was wait, and the dissimilar elements of the working class fall apart again.

title: Doubt Cast on 2 Drugs Used to Lower Cholesterol
description: CHICAGO  Two widely prescribed cholesterol-lowering drugs, Vytorin and Zetia, may not work and should be used only as a last resort, a panel of four cardiologists told an audience of more than 5,000 people at a major cardiology conference on Sunday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A film column on Thursday about a tribute to United Artists at Film Forum referred imprecisely to the ownership of the company. While Sony is a co-owner of MGM, United Artists is owned jointly by MGM, Tom Cruise and Paula Wagner. Sony has no direct ownership interest in United Artists.

title: Enough Distractions. Lets Talk About Me.
description: MERIDIAN, Miss.  Senator John McCain is hoping to move the campaign narrative from the current events section of the popular imagination to the biography section with his tour this week of places important to his life story.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Santiago Journal article on Friday, about an experiment by the government in Chile with an early computer system that helped the government survive a devastating strike by truckers and other groups in 1972, misstated the duration of the strike. It lasted from Oct. 9 to Nov. 5. It did not end within a week.

title: Faster, Maybe. Cheaper, No. But Driving Has Its Fans.
description: It was the birth of her son a year and a half ago that put Eden Matteson, 30, behind the wheel in Manhattan.

title: Survivors of 2006 Police Shooting Are Set to Testify
description: After five weeks of examining nearly every aspect of the police shooting that took the life of Sean Bell, prosecutors in the trial of three detectives will summon the two men who survived the hail of 50 bullets fired at Mr. Bells Nissan Altima.

title: French Company Is Said to Buy Maker of Absolut Vodka
description: Pernod Ricard, the French liquor company, agreed on Sunday night to acquire the parent of Absolut vodka, people involved in the deal said.

title: 21 Rakes in the Chips
description: 21, the Columbia Pictures release about a team of math geniuses assembled by a professor (Kevin Spacey, right) to beat the Las Vegas blackjack tables, hauled in an estimated $23.7 million in its debut weekend at North American theaters. It ousted Dr. Seuss Horton Hears a Who from the No. 1 ranking after a two-week reign. Horton (20th Century Fox), in second place, grossed $17.4 million to swell its three-week total to $117.2 million, according to the box-office tracking company Media by Numbers. Third place went to the satirical Superhero Movie (MGM), which drew $9.5 million in its opening weekend. Tyler Perrys Meet the Browns (Lionsgate), last weekends second-ranking film, dropped to fourth place with $7.7 million its second week, followed by another comedy, Drillbit Taylor (Paramount), with $5.8 million in its second week.

title: Voice, Eyes and Camera of Katrina Survivors
description: The main reason to check out the second and slack final week of this years edition of New Directors/New Films, presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, is the superb documentary Trouble the Water, about Hurricane Katrina and its equally calamitous aftermath. One of the best American documentaries in recent memory, the film was directed and produced by Tia Lessin and Carl Deal, a couple of New Yorkers who, like much of the rest of the world, were watching television in horror in 2005 as the natural disaster was quickly followed by a human one.

title: The Weirdest Title
description: The votes are in, and a British trade magazine has announced the winner of the Diagram Prize for the oddest book title of 2007: If You Want Closure in Your Relationship, Start With Your Legs. The apparently pseudonymous author, Big Boom, calls his work a self-help book, written by a man for the benefit of women. Joel Rickett, deputy editor of The Bookseller magazine, said: The winner, If You Want Closure, makes redundant an entire genre of self-help tomes. So effective is the title that you dont even need to read the book itself. In the balloting by the public, Big Booms book triumphed over I Was Tortured by the Pygmy Love Queen and, in third place, Cheese Problems Solved. The Diagram Prize has been offered since 1978, when the winner was Proceedings of the Second International Workshop on Nude Mice.

title: Atop a Hallowed Mountain, Small Steps Toward Healing
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.

title: Minister Sees Salvation of Harlem in Boycott
description: For the past several months, elegantly dressed men and women have been handing out thousands of postcards to passers-by on the streets of Harlem. It is part of a campaign to boycott neighborhood shops to protest gentrification. While the boycott itself has had little impact, the man behind it, an ex-convict turned minister named James D. Manning, has been increasingly difficult for some to ignore.

title: China Says It Has Evidence Dalai Lama Incited Riots
description: SHANGHAI  After two weeks in which China contended that Tibets government in exile had instigated the riots earlier this month to tarnish the coming Summer Olympics in Beijing, the Chinese government on Sunday issued for the first time what it said was evidence of the plot.

title: The Dilbert Strategy
description: Anyone who has worked in a large organization  or, for that matter, reads the comic strip Dilbert  is familiar with the org chart strategy. To hide their lack of any actual ideas about what to do, managers sometimes make a big show of rearranging the boxes and lines that say who reports to whom.

title: Children Elect Hollywood Favorites
description: It was a night when children were given the floor to bestow accolades on Hollywood. At the 21st annual Kids Choice Awards on Saturday, Miley Cyrus, below, the star of the Disney Channel series Hannah Montana, was chosen favorite television actress and female singer, while Drake and Josh, a Nickelodeon series, was honored as favorite television show with one of its stars, Drake Bell, as favorite television actor. The awards were the result of more than 80 million votes that Nickelodeon said were cast through its Web site, nick.com. Also honored at the ceremony, which was held in Los Angeles and shown on Nickelodeon, were Alvin and the Chipmunks (favorite movie); Johnny Depp (movie actor, for Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End); Jessica Alba (movie actress, Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer); American Idol (reality show); Chris Brown (male singer); and the Jonas Brothers (music group).

title: A Nervous Wall St. Seems Unsure Whats Next
description: Most everyone on Wall Street, and on Main Street, wants to know when will the financial crisis end. So far, despite the governments efforts, the markets are whispering an answer that no one wants to hear.

title: Is the Ad a Success? The Brain Waves Tell All
description: NEVER mind brainstorms. These days, Madison Avenue is all about brain waves.

title: Bravos Chief Reaches Out to the Prosperous Urban Woman
description: Lauren Zalaznick, the woman behind the surging success of cable televisions Bravo network is, in many ways, a model of the channels viewers:

title: New CDs
description: GEORGE STRAIT Troubadour (MCA Nashville)

title: Kansas (Barely) Joins Three Other No. 1s in Final Four
description: DETROIT  Like four aces in a deck of playing cards, the four top seeds in the N.C.A.A. tournament are going to the Final Four. The hand was completed Sunday when Kansas defeated Davidson, 59-57, in a tense and rugged Midwest Region final at Ford Field.

title: Fans Concerned About Steroid Use and Believe Its Widespread, Poll Shows
description: Despite a contentious off-season, in which he found himself linked to the use of performance-enhancing drugs, Roger Clemens is drawing more support from baseball fans than Barry Bonds, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about the growing number of Muslims in the United States who have chosen to home-school their children referred incorrectly to Pakistans location. It is in South Asia, not Southeast Asia.

title: Who Are We? New Dialogue on Mixed Race
description: Jenifer Bratter once wore a T-shirt in college that read 100 percent black woman. Her African-American friends would not have it.

title: Zeffirellis Bohme for the 347th Time
description: Metropolitan Opera audiences have loved Franco Zeffirellis production of La Bohme for its overstuffed, hyper-realistic sets ever since the company first staged it in 1981, and critics have disparaged it for nearly as long, although the familiarity that comes with 27 years of repetition has eventually blunted the complaints.

title: In Transcripts, Tough Talk by Terror Suspects, and Informant
description: While on a trip to the Poconos early last year with his friends, a young immigrant named Agron Abdullahu talked about building bombs using nitroglycerin or pipes, and buying a rifle with a powerful scope, the authorities have said. He spoke disparagingly about the American soldiers he had encountered as a teenager when he spent five weeks in a Macedonian refugee camp.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about the candidacy of Andrew Unanue, a political novice who moderate Republicans in New Jersey say has the best chance to defeat Frank Lautenberg, a Democrat and the states senior United States senator, gave the wrong year in some editions for a bid by Murray Sabrin, a conservative Republican candidate for the Senate seat, for governor as a Libertarian. It was 1997, not 2000.

title: First Crane Jump Since Collapse Is Smooth Operation
description: After the last massive section of crane slid into place late Sunday afternoon at a construction site in Brooklyn, Thomas Auringer, the owner of the company that pulled off the feat without a hitch, sat on the bed of a pickup across the street, swinging his legs.

title: Biography Isnt Enough
description: The McCain campaigns first general election ad, released Friday, includes moving footage of him as a prisoner of war. What was Democratic Chairman Howard Deans reaction? While we honor McCains military service, the fact is Americans want a real leader who offers real solutions, not a blatant opportunist who doesnt understand the economy and is promising to keep our troops in Iraq for 100 years.

title: Being Red Bull-ish on Soccer in New York
description: The American appetite for sports seems almost insatiable, failures like the XFL notwithstanding. Case in point, metropolitan New York, the market perhaps most crowded with teams, fans and sports media outlets.

title: Belatedly Making Nice
description: George Bush and Vladimir Putin, after months of acrimony and years of inaction, are suddenly ready to talk seriously about serious matters. We hope it is not too late, since both are nearly at the end of their presidencies. There are certainly a lot of things they need to address.

title: Wal-Mart Savings Ads Assailed
description: One commercial features a family embarking on a long overdue vacation. Another depicts a father and son preparing to buy a used car. In both, Wal-Mart shopping bags are visible in their cars.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Friday with an article about a West Bank road at the center of a dispute over whether Palestinians can be required to use separate roads referred incorrectly to a truck shown. Concrete barriers  not the truck  were blocking the entrance to the road.

title: Report Says HUD Secretary Will Resign
description: WASHINGTON  Housing Secretary Alphonso R. Jackson is expected to resign Monday, The Wall Street Journal reported Sunday night.

title: In West, a Slip Can Send a Top Team Tumbling
description: What should the mighty Dallas Mavericks be feeling right now? Exhilaration, or anxiety? Whither the inner compass of the resurgent Houston Rockets? On pride, or panic? Whats the emotion du jour in Oakland? Hope, or despair?

title: French Architect Wins Pritzker Prize
description: Jean Nouvel, the bold French architect known for such wildly diverse projects as the muscular Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis and the exotically louvered Arab World Institute in Paris, has received architectures top honor, the Pritzker Prize.

title: A Womans Perspective: Robust Music, Racy Lyrics
description: Fundador, a Spanish brandy reputedly favored by Ernest Hemingway, conspicuously entered American popular song literature in 1964 with the Cy Coleman-Carolyn Leigh hit When in Rome (I Do as the Romans Do). Ms. Leighs racy lyrics in this paean to self-indulgent tourism insist, Dont deplore my fondness for Fundador/You know how a Fundador can lead to a few/And baby/ When in Rome I do as the Romans do. It was performed on Saturday evening at the 92nd Street Y by Karen Ziemba as an amused tribute to Anita Ekbergs trance-dance in the Trevi Fountain in La Dolce Vita.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Brinker Capital, Berwyn, Pa., an investment management firm, named Stein Rogan & Partners, New York, as its interactive agency, handling duties that had been handled internally. Billings were not disclosed.

title: French Company Wins Auction for Vodka Maker
description: Pernod Ricard, the French liquor company, announced Monday that it had agreed to acquire the parent of Absolut vodka for 5.63 billion euros ($8.87 billion).

title: Showing Power, but Weakening a Neighborhood
description: Baseball season is an 85-year-old fact of neighborhood life. Happens every spring. Still, opening day is no less jarring, a fresh reminder to a longtime resident of how the Yankees rule.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Tuesday about a last-minute bidding contest over development rights for the West Side railyards in Manhattan gave an outdated name for an investment bank that was to have been the anchor tenant for office towers planned by one bidder, Tishman Speyer Properties. The bank, which has since dropped out of the project, is now Morgan Stanley, not Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. (The error appeared in an article in some editions on Oct. 6 about Morgan Stanleys initial plans to join the project.)

title: Augustin: Should He Stay or Should He Go?
description: HOUSTON  After being thoroughly outplayed by the Memphis freshman point guard Derrick Rose in an 85-67 loss Sunday, the Texas sophomore point guard D.J. Augustin talked as if he would be back with the Longhorns next season.

title: The Road to Remote Upland Asia
description: In isolated hills of Asia, new roads promise Chinese trade.

title: Extending China's Reach
description: The network of roads is a major milestone for China and its neighbors.

title: The Bin Ladens
description: "WE ALL WORSHIP THE SAME GOD" October 1984 to February 1985

title: Start-Ups That Make Appointments for Doctor or Dinner
description: The e-commerce bandwagon bypassed millions of carpenters, massage therapists, lawyers and other service providers, mostly because it is impossible to drop an appointment into a shopping cart without unleashing a scheduling nightmare.

title: Online Chat, as Inspired by Real Chat
description: Compared with other forms of human interaction, online social networking is really not all that social.

title: VaxGEn and Raven Scrap Merger Plans
description: VaxGen, after failing to make an effective HIV vaccine and losing its $877.5 million federal contract to make an anthrax vaccine, said Friday its last-ditch effort to save itself through a merger has foundered and its days may be numbered.

title: Will I.P.O. Slump Starve New Start-Ups?
description: A slumping stock market has stalled the Silicon Valley public offering assembly line that produced almost two dozen of them last year, and that slowdown will probably slow the creation of new start-ups over the next year or two, The San Jose Mercury News reported, citing discussion with venture capitalists and entrepreneurs.

title: Much Ado About Allianz
description: Germanys banking landscape could be on the verge of a huge upheaval, according to several German reports.

title: Pay for U.S. Traders Hit Harder Than for London Rivals
description: The global credit crisis dented the salary and bonus packages of U.S. traders more severely than those of their London peers this year, according to a survey released on Sunday.

title: Abu Dhabi Fund in Talks for Stake in U.S. Real Estate Firm
description: Abu Dhabi government investment firm Mubadala Development said on Sunday it was in discussions to buy a stake in The John Buck Company, a U.S. real estate firm.

title: German Watchdog Said to Eye $600 Billion in Banking Losses
description: The financial market crisis could cause losses of up to $600 billion at banks and other financial institutions worldwide, a German magazine reported on Saturday, citing an internal report by German financial watchdog BaFin.

title: Putting a Buy on Blodget
description: Few tech-bubble analysts have received as much attention  and derision  as Henry Blodget, the one-time Merrill Lynch star analyst who, after being barred from the securities industry, refashioned himself as an industry commentator.

title: Lehman to Sue Japans Marubeni for Fraud, Report Says
description: Lehman Brothers will file a lawsuit on Monday against Japanese trading house Marubeni, saying it was defrauded of more than $355 million, Reuters reported.

title: Bank of America May Scrap Prime Brokerage Sale, Report Says
description: JPMorgan Chases deal to buy Bear Stearns may have thrown a wrench into Bank of Americas plans to sell its prime brokerage business.

title: Pernod Ricard Wins Auction for Maker of Absolut Vodka
description: Pernod Ricard, the French liquor company, announced Monday that it had agreed to acquire the parent of Absolut vodka for 5.63 billion euros ($8.87 billion).

title: Indias Religare Makes Offer for U.K.s Hitchens Harrison
description: Indias Religare Enterprises has made an offer to acquire British stockbroking firm Hichens Harrison & Company for $99 million.

title: Zuckerman and Murdoch Still Said to Be Eyeing Newsday
description: Rupert Murdoch isnt the only newspaper mogul who is aggressively pursuing a purchase of Newsday, according to the publication. Newsday reported that New York Daily News owner Mort Zuckerman is still in the game.

title: Treasury Set to Announce Regulatory Overhaul
description: The Bush administration is proposing the broadest overhaul of Wall Street regulation since the Great Depression, in effect allowing it to send SWAT teams into any corner of the industry or any institution that might pose a risk to the overall system. The plan is to be unveiled on Monday morning, although key elements were provided to the media in advance. In a news analysis over the weekend, The New York Times said the overhaul has its genesis in a yearlong effort to limit Washingtons role in the market.

title: 3i in Deal to Take Civica Private
description: 3i Group, the London-based buyout firm, agreed Friday to acquire software company Civica for about 220 million pounds ($440 million) including debt.

title: EU Regulators Extend Antitrust Probe of Nokias Navteq Deal
description: European Union regulators said Friday they are extending an antitrust probe into Nokias proposed $8.1 billion acquisition of U.S.-based digital mapmaker Navteq.

title: Chicago Stock Exchange Hires Bank to Evaluate Options
description: The Chicago Stock Exchange said Thursday that it hired an investment bank to help it evaluate a possible merger or new partnerships, after some shareholders said the company needed new leadership and direction.

title: A Nervous Wall St. Seems Unsure Whats Next
description: Most everyone on Wall Street, and on Main Street, wants to know when will the financial crisis end. So far, despite the governments efforts, the markets are whispering an answer that no one wants to hear.

title: Gilat Satellite Agrees to Buyout Deal
description: Gilat Satellite Networks said Monday it agreed to be taken private by a consortium including Gores Group and Mivtach Shamir Holdings Ltd. in a $475 million transaction.

title: Gaming Out the Clear Channel Lawsuits
description: After a few days, the Clear Channel litigation increasingly appears to be more game theory than litigation.

title: Man Group Buys Half of Ore Hill
description: Man Group, the worlds largest publicly traded hedge fund manager, said Monday it has agreed to buy a 50 percent stake in Ore Hill, a United States-based credit specialist fund manager.

title: 3 Firms Are Asked for Data on Auction-Rate Shares
description: The top securities regulator in Massachusetts has subpoenaed Merrill Lynch, UBS Securities and Banc of America Investment Services for information relating to their sales of auction-rate preferred shares.

title: Tom Perkins Puts His Yacht on the Block
description: Tom Perkins, the prominent Silicon Valley venture capitalist, is apparently looking to cash in one of his investments  but in this case, the investment is not a Web start-up but a high-tech superyacht. Mr. Perkins has put The Maltese Falcon up for sale, just two years after he first set sail on it.

title: Citi to Form Credit Card Unit
description: Citigroup said Monday it would consolidate its global credit-card business into a single unit and revamp its consumer-banking business along geographical lines. The announcement prompted some observers to speculate about a potential sale or public offering.

title: What the Bear Meant for the Street
description: Back in the days of ticker tape, when Wall Street firms like Morgan Stanley hired young men with pedigrees from colleges like Princeton and clubs like Piping Rock, Bear Stearns was the kind of place where hardscrabble Brooklynites could get a job.

title: Before She Teamed Up With Sonny
description: Some of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

title: Barry Diller Wins as Court Allows IAC Breakup
description: In the battle of the billionaire media moguls, the protg won.

title: Northwest Looks to Delta to Revive Merger Talks
description: Northwest Airlines has asked Delta Air Lines if it would like to restart merger talks, despite the inability of the carriers pilots to agree on how to merge their all-important seniority lists, The New York Times reported.

title: Taco Liberty Bell? Nacho Fast
description: The Museum of Hoaxes trumpets a list of the Top 100 April Fools Day Hoaxes of All Time, but lists only 10, among them (excerpts):

title: Trying to Get the Swiss to Talk
description: Like Paul Revere, Konrad Hummler sounded the alarm last week as he made his way by train and by plane to his banks branches across Switzerland. This countrys storied role as secret banker to the worlds wealthy is under threat like never before, Mr. Hummler warned.

title: A System Overdue for Reform
description: A week ago Thursday, just days after the big Bear Stearns crisis, Representative Barney Frank gave a speech to the Greater Boston Chamber of Commerce. Most people know Mr. Frank, a Democrat from Massachusetts, as one of the most liberal members of Congress.

title: Hour by Hour Accounts of Work  Share Yours
description: After my post last week about Water Cooler Diaries, a new book consisting of diary postings of 35 women throughout their work days, readers started doing the same in the comments of this blog.

title: Home Is Where the Vote Is
description: Congress reopens for business today after an extended two-week break and lawmakers will already be thinking about home  the homes of their constituents, that is.

title: UBS Shares Fall Amid Talk of More Capital-Raising
description: UBS, the European bank with the highest losses from the U.S. subprime crisis, fell in Swiss trading after reports that it may need to raise capital to offset writedowns on mortgage-related assets, Bloomberg News reported.

title: The Early Word: More Endorsements for Obama
description: The field of Democratic senators who are undecided (or just keeping quiet) about which colleague they prefer for president will shrink by one today when Sen. Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota comes out in support of Sen. Barack Obama of Illinois.

title: Mullah Time
description: Moktada al-Sadr, Iraqs young firebrand, has called for his followers to stop fighting in Basra and in turn demanded concessions from Iraqs government, after six days in which his Mahdi Army militia has held off an American-supported Iraqi assault on the southern port city.

title: And then there were two
description: Press release from the Clinton campaign  not on the web site yet, but presumably will be there soon. It says:

title: Now Screening | Michael Pitt in T Takes Episode 11
Pax Iranica
description: Juan Cole on the latest developments in Iraq:

title: New Yorkers Who Love to Drive
description: In a city known for crowded subway platforms and standing-room-only buses, many residents, even those with robust public transit options, remain fiercely loyal to their cars, Diane Cardwell writes. Despite the threat of traffic jams, honking horns and the urban version of road rage, these New Yorkers choose to drive, whether to shave time off their commutes, run their errands with less hassle or have a few moments to themselves inside mobile oases. Many of these drivers would be affected by the mayors congestion pricing proposal, whose future is still in doubt as the plan heads toward votes in the State Legislature and City Council.

title: Fat Bias Worse for Women
description: It only takes a modest weight gain for a woman to experience weight discrimination, but men can gain far more weight before experiencing similar bias, a new study shows.

title: Monday Tipoff
description: Why does Davidson have Stephen Curry bring the ball up the court on that last possession, forcing him to dribble around off screens searching for his seam with the ball in his hands?

title: An Early Start to Opening Day for Girardi
description: Yankees Manager Joe Girardi maneuvered his silver sports utility vehicle into the parking lot at Yankee Stadium around 7:45 a.m. on Monday, more than five hours before the first pitch of Opening Day. But Girardis car was not the first one there. Bench coach Rob Thomson had already parked his S.U.V. in the lot and was working in the clubhouse, which was no shock to Girardi.

title: Long-Missing Soldiers Remains Identified in Iraq
description: The long wait of Keith and Carolyn Maupin ended on Sunday when an Army general delivered the sad news to them just east of Cincinnati. Sgt. Keith Matthew Maupin, who was abducted in an ambush outside of Baghdad in 2004, had been added to the American death toll in Iraq, which now exceeds 4,000.

title: The North Atlantic conspiracy
description: Is Iceland the victim of a financial conspiracy?

title: The Jam | Anna Sui
description: The Jam column presents fashions latest soundtracks.

title: Hong Kong: Do You Have a Card?
description: My personal chop: Mak Laan Yan

title: Formula One Boss on Video With Five Prostitutes
description: The Times of London reports that Max Mosley, president of Formula Ones governing body, was caught on video in, get this, a Nazi-style orgy with five prostitutes.

title: Conspiracy-Theory Circle of Life: Diana and Bobby
description: In the span of a few days, two famous deaths were given fresh looks in the news, one of which encouraged the conspiracy theorists while the other dismissed them completely.

title: Sheppards Voice Will Be Here
description: It wont be Bob Sheppard at the microphone today when the lineups are introduced here at windy, drizzly Yankee Stadium for the final opening day. Sheppard is recovering from an illness and hopes to be back by midseason.

title: Recipe of the Day: Nearly Instant Miso Soup
description: Think of miso  the Japanese paste of fermented beans (usually soy), grains (usually rice) and salt  as soy sauce squared, more intense but not saltier. It can be used in dressings for salads, meats, tofu and vegetables, and it can turn a cup of hot water into soup in about 30 seconds.

title:
Talk to the Newsroom: David Carr,
Culture Reporter and Business Columnist
description: David Carr, culture reporter and business columnist, is answering questions from readers March 31 to April 4. Questions may be sent to askthetimes@nytimes.com. To move directly to the most recent answer, click here.

title: Walking the Talk Therapy
description: Updated, April 1 | It seems like a marriage made in New York heaven: combining the necessary insights and breakthroughs of the psychotherapeutic 50-minute hour with  a walk in the park.Karen L. Arthur, 55, a licensed clinical social worker, former marathoner and current Pilates and yoga teacher, has started offering Walking and Talking Psychotherapy. As described in her advertisement in New York Spirit, she urges her clients to Live life from a grounded perspective. Take your therapy outdoors.

Spat Between Actors Unions Snarls Negotiations With StudiosMichael Cieply reports: A sudden split between two actors unions over the weekend added an unhappy twist to Hollywoods troubled contract cycle: It appeared to weaken the labor organizations without making life easier for the studios they bargain with.

title: The Kids Choice: Hannah Montana and Drake and Josh
description: It was a night when children were given the floor to bestow accolades on Hollywood, Jacques Steinberg reports. At the 21st annual Kids Choice Awards on Saturday, Miley Cyrus, the star of the Disney Channel series Hannah Montana, was chosen favorite television actress and female singer, while Drake and Josh, a Nickelodeon series, was honored as favorite television show with one of its stars, Drake Bell, as favorite television actor.

title: Kathie Lee Signs On To Today
description: Kathie Lee Gifford, the longtime co-host of Live with Regis and Kathie Lee, is returning to morning television as the host of the fourth hour of NBCs Today program, the network confirmed Monday morning.

title: Why Edwards hasnt endorsed yet
description: Via Jeralyn at Talk Left, John Heilemann on why John Edwards hasnt endorsed anyone yet:

title: Injured Friend of Sean Bell Testifies
description: Trent Benefield, a passenger wounded in the police shooting that killed Sean Bell, testified on Monday morning in the trial of three detectives charged in the case that he was shot first in Mr. Bells back seat and again as he ran away.The testimony from Mr. Benefield, 24, appeared to contradict the grand jury testimony of the detectives, none of whom have said they shot at him as he ran away. Mr. Benefield said he was first shot in both calves in the back seat.

title: McCain Surprised by Iraq Developments
description: MERIDIAN, Miss.  As he launched a tour here designed to highlight his familys long tradition of military service, Senator John McCain said Monday that he was surprised by the latest turn of events in Americas current war in Iraq.

title: Hilarity in 08, Cavett Says
description: From Dick Cavetts New York Times blog Talk Show:

title: Soft Serve | Bespoke Whoppers, Hot-Dog Connoisseurship, Feminine Vodka
description: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for soft news  coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, maam.

title: Local Democrats Cheer HUD Secretarys Exit
description: Updated, 12:47 p.m. | Among New York politicians, there was little sympathy over the resignation of Alphonso R. Jackson as the secretary of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development. [Read the full article on his resignation here.]

title: Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards
description: Jacques Steinberg roamed the orange carpet in Los Angeles as children elected their Hollywood favorites.

title: Report finds U.K. sellers ignoring unpleasant realities of market
description: U.K. home sellers may be engaging in a bit of irrational exuberance, according to Rightmove, the property portal. Asking prices actually rose in March despite the tough market conditions, the companys latest data shows.

title: Paulson Proposes Regulation Overhaul
description: CNBC coverage of Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson's remarks on proposals to reorganize the regulation of Wall Street and the markets.

description: Theres a friendly face outside the Yankees clubhouse right now: Harlan Chamberlain, the father of Yankees reliever Joba Chamberlain.

description: An interesting take by a scientist on cooking, looking at it from the perspective of Ferran Adri, Herve This and the other so-called molecular gastronomists. (Hat tip to Ed.)

title: Necessity is the Mother of What?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paulson Urging Regulation Overhaul
description: CNBC coverage of Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson's remarks on proposals to reorganize the regulation of Wall Street and the markets.

title: Madison Avenue Sells S.U.V.s. Can It Sell Climate Action?
description: Daniel Schrag, a climate scientist at Harvard, once told me that two factors determine whether there will be meaningful action to limit global warming: public will and the relative cost of nonpolluting energy options and fossil fuels. You can work to raise public will to accept higher energy costs or improve technologies to lower the cost of clean energy (or both).

title: The Second-Worst Phrase on Opening Day: Rain Delay
description: The Yankees are eager to play the final Opening Day at Yankee Stadium but, two and a half hours before it is scheduled to start, the weather is not cooperating. Rain is falling, it is raw and chilly and the tarpaulin is covering the field. The Yankees have and announced that the start of the season opener against the Toronto Blue Jays has been delayed. The game was scheduled to start at 1:05 P.M. The Yankees did not say when theyhoped to start the game.

title: An Olympians Cubicle Workout
description: British Olympic swimmer Sharron Davies doesnt look like someone who spends much time at a desk, but she has nonetheless devised a desk-based workout for those of us who do.

title: New Questions for a New Season
description: Its about 4 hours before first pitch here at Dolphin Stadium. The grounds crew is chalking the batters box. TV crews are setting up in front of the Marlins dugout. And the seats, the seats have never looked so, so, so orange.

title: Santana Starts Can Paralyze Venezuela
description: I first met Alfredo Villasmil, a sportswriter from Venezuela, while covering the World Baseball Classic two years ago. I called Alfredo Mr. Venezuela because he was so passionate about baseball and his country, and he called me his friend from The New York Times.

title: City Council Measure on Congestion Pricing
description: Updated, 8 p.m. | The City Council had scheduled a 3:30 p.m. vote on Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs plan to charge drivers to enter Manhattan south of 60th Street, but action was delayed into the evening. A committee approved the measure shortly before 6 p.m., as did the full Council later in the evening [Read the Latest Updates.]The reasons for the earlier delay were not clear. Council members milled around City Hall, some of them in the lobby outside the ornate second-floor chamber. By 5:30 p.m., the Committee on State and Federal Legislation began a meeting on congestion pricing, run by the committee chairwoman, Councilwoman Maria Baez, Democrat of the Bronx.

title: Historys My Hobby  Get Your Own
description: It seems everywhere you turn lately you run into ads for HBOs epic miniseries, John Adams. The iconic Join or Die banner featuring a fragmented snake seems to be everywhere, from buses to newspapers to the sides of buildings. People are talking about the show too. Amazing, say some. Boring, say others. Did you know Ben Franklin would play chess with women while in the bath? Isnt that wonderful? says someone else. Yikes. Wasnt this supposed to be the country where historical was right at home in front of amnesia? Now historys sweeping the land. I hate it.

title: Flash Flood
description: My colleague Jeff DelVisciowho among other admirable qualities loves to see animated objects roll, topple and tiponce sent me to this great Dutch site that I still visit from time to time. It still brings on a childlike glee, and, like the work of John Pavlus, it suggests what can be done when all the visual clichs that crowd our computer screens are upset.

title: Channel Sisters
description: No pulling-finger jokes, please. Thats too easy. But tell us whats going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). Its the latest of the uncaptioned photos were posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last weeks funniest captions are at right.

title: What I Ate Last Night Department: Classic Trattoria Fare
description: Back in Italy and yes, I work for a living. Im here on assignment, and dragged my friend Fred along with me. Very aggressive first day including a touristy visit to Pisas Piazza dei Miracoli, which really is quite gorgeous. Heres a picture of Fred next to some tower that seems about to fall down.

title: The Great Syracuse Shrimp Ramp
description: Its hard to find an admirer these days of old-school civic poetry  poetry written, that is, to order, to officially commemorate a person or event.

title: Clips: March Madness, Soapnet, Star Wars on Spike
description: March Madness basketball coverage is winning ratings for CBS, but several columnists have asked: How many commercials is too many? TV By The Numbers recaps the complaints.

title: Food Allergies Hit the Music Charts
description: Food allergy advocacy groups often struggle to be noticed. Except for families who have a child with a life-threatening allergy to peanuts or another food, most people dont worry much about the issue.

title: Opinion: Tearing My Hair Out From the Free-Throw Line
description: Im fairly certain the statute of limitations has passed on this but forgive me, Im still a little sore. Id like to take issue with my esteemed colleague Mr. Will Leitch, who wrote last Thursday that, contrary to conventional wisdom, good free-throw shooting is not critical to winning in the N.C.A.A. tournament. His timing could not have been worse (for me).

title: Super Tuesday in the NHL
description: There are two games on the card for tonight: Atlanta at Tampa Bay (yawn!) and Pittsburgh at the Rangers.

title: Rain Postpones Opening Day
description: Update: Opening Day will have to wait. The game has been called and rescheduled for tomorrow.

title: Lighting Up at the Bus Stop
description: Think of the clock faces on the Trinity Church steeple at the head of Wall Street. Or the sidewalk clock in front of the Sherry-Netherland. Or the digital clock on the Midtown office tower formerly known as MONY. Sponsored time is an enduring tradition, and one that is clearly making its way into the 21st century.

title: Fighting College Plagiarism With Plagiarism?
description: Colleges have been writing honor codes for hundreds of years. Plagiarism stretches even further back. So it may have been simply a matter of time until the two forces collided in irony of the highest order, courtesy of The San Antonio Express-News:

Bravos Chief Reaches Out to the Prosperous Urban Woman Bill Carter reports: The channel has the highest concentration of viewers in households making more than $125,000. Derek Baine, a media analyst with SNL Kagan, said that Bravo had become a power in advertising sales in cable television. Read more

title: The Piper, Unpaid
description: This isnt going to good for P.R.: Among the debts reported this month by Hillary Rodham Clintons struggling presidential campaign, the $292,000 in unpaid health insurance premiums for her campaign staff stands out, reports Kenneth P. Vogel at the Politico.

description: More campaign-related opinion for Monday, Mar. 31:
