title: Chiseled, High-Def Power
description: Jos Cansecos new book, Vindicated: Big Names, Big Liars, and the Battle to Save Baseball, has just been published, and its an I-told-you-so sequel to the No. 1 best seller Juiced. Theres not a lot of news in it  he loves poker and martial-arts movies; he hates A-Rod and is not into poetry  but once again, with the talk of players injecting steroids into all dem bums, the question must be asked: Is a syringe just a syringe?

title: Dreaming of a 3-D Web
description: Vivaty, the company I wrote about in Mondays paper, represents the fulfillment of a 14-year-old dream to bring 3-D images to the Web.

title: Two N.F.L. Owners Choose Vanity Over Money
description: At the annual N.F.L. owners meeting this week, the hottest topic of conversation will be the collective-bargaining agreement with the players union, which a growing number of owners consider a sweet deal for labor at the expense of management.

title: CBS Savors That Basketball Bump
description: With a boost from its afternoon coverage of the N.C.A.A. college basketball tournament, CBS eked out a slight ratings victory on Sunday, edging past ABC as the nights most watched network.

title: For the Moment | Ben Elliot
description: This weeks guest blogger is Ben Elliot, a co-founder of Quintessentially, the global concierge service that counts Madonna, Gwyneth Paltrow, Scarlett Johanson, Sean Combs and Harvey Weinstein amongst its members. Elliot is also the nephew of Camilla Parker Bowles and divides his time between New York and London.

title: Yanks and Jays to Play Tuesday
description: Three years ago, the Yankees played host to the Boston Red Sox for the ESPN Sunday night opener. But most of the time, opening day at Yankee Stadium is an afternoon affair.

title: Comcasts Blurry High Definition Picture
description: Not only has Comcast been slowing down Internet users exchanging files with the BitTorrent protocol, it has been quietly reducing the quality of some high definition television networks it carries as well.

title: Markowitz Has Plans to Eat (and Run, Maybe)
description: City Room is used to getting advisories about politicians whereabouts (at least the ones they want us to know about), but public officials dinner plans are another thing entirely. Today, the office of Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, announced that he will be having dinner at 7 oclock tonight at Anise Asian Bistro, at 8608 Fourth Avenue in Bay Ridge.

title: Were Almost Done
description: When we arrived at Sarasota airport on Saturday morning, there was a message on my voice mail.

title: Jozy Altidore: Its All About Being in M.L.S. Cup
description: Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore contributes items for The New York Times Goal blog each week. Altidore and the Red Bulls will open their M.L.S. season against the Columbus Crew on Saturday.

title: Summitt Making Nice With Auriemma
description: During Sunday nights telecast of the regional semifinal between Tennessee and Notre Dame, the announcing team of Nancy Lieberman and Pam Ward revealed that in a sit-down interview with Lady Vols Coach Pat Summitt the previous day, the topic of the national coach of the year balloting came up and Summitt said she voted for Connecticut Geno Auriemma.

title: Television and the Pursuit of Happiness
description: BRIEFS From a survey of about 1,000 people across the world, a headline that would have made Eddie, New Yorks craziest electronics salesman, swoon: TV Ownership May Be Good for Well-Being. [Gallup]

title: There Will Be Baseball Today
description: Have no fear, one New York team will play today. Its gorgeous here in south Florida  a few scattered clouds, slight breeze  although well get the atmospheric conditions (this is the only stadium in baseball where the press box announcer uses that term. Love it.) once the game begins.

title: Did Your Shopping List Kill a Songbird?
description: An interesting op-ed piece from yesterdays paper, on migratory birds, pesticides and bird-friendly foods, that you might have missed . . .

title:
All Too Familiar Name
In an Unfamiliar Location
description: I do like coincidences. On Saturday afternoon as I was reading Dave Kehrs appraisal of the late Richard Widmark, my wife was watching a movie, Conspiracy Theory, on television. Just as I was reading about Widmarks breakout performance as Tommy Udo in Kiss of Death, where he famously ties an old lady to her wheelchair and throws her down a flight of stairs, there on the small screen was Mel Gibson, bound to a wheelchair  dont ask  and actually throwing himself down a flight of stairs. A fitting tribute to an underrated actor  Widmark, not Gibson.

title: Gores Commitment Still to Environment
description: Despite much uncertainty in the Democratic nomination contest, one things for sure: Al Gores top loyalty still lies with the environment, not with Hillary Rodham Clinton or Barack Obama.

title: Hansbrough and Beasley Headline A.P. All-America Team
description: The North Carolina junior Tyler Hansbrough and the Kansas State freshman Michael Beasley were both unanimously selected to the Associated Presss All-America team Monday.

title: Market Plunges, Fed Acts
description: Say this for the Fed. It pays attention to what Wall Street wants.

title: Bjork's 'Wanderlust'
description: The new video from Bjork, "Wanderlust."

title: City Allows Work to Resume on Trump Condo-Hotel
description: The citys Buildings Department announced today that it has partly rescinded the stop-work order at the Trump SoHo luxury hotel and condominium tower at 246 Spring Street. The general contractor, Bovis Lend Lease, will be permitted to continue construction in phases.

title: The Upfronts: Discovering A New Look for Discovery
description: Marketing and agency executives who attended the upfront presentation by Discovery Channel in Chicago on Monday afternoon got a sneak peak at a new brand-image campaign for the network.

title: Is New York the Most Pet-Friendly Place?
description: Forget our odd tendency to keep big dogs in small apartments. Or the Metropolitan Transportation Authoritys ban on dogs on the subway unless they are enclosed in a container and carried in a manner which would not annoy other passengers (service animals and police dogs are excepted). Or the fact that taxi drivers arent required to allow dogs to ride along with their owners. Or the perennial brouhaha over off-leash rules governing when dogs can roam free in the parks. Or the out-of-the-way nooks and crannies where the city places its dog runs.

title: War on the Penny Continues Unabated
description: A week after a piece in The New Yorker calling for the end of the penny in America stirred bloggers (here, here and here) and presidential candidates alike, the debate seemed, for a moment, to move to other currency.

title: Lautenberg Wants One More Term
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, announced on Monday that he is running for re-election. If he wins, Mr. Lautenberg, 84, would serve his fifth term in the Senate  and his second consecutive term since coming out of retirement to replace Senator Robert Torricelli, who dropped his 2002 re-election bid because of corruption allegations. Mr. Lautenberg, who served in the Senate from 1983 until he retired in early 2001, was named to replace Mr. Torricelli on the ballot.

title: Rangers Fourth Line Needs a Jolt
description: The news that center Blair Betts would be lost to the Rangers for a few weeks did not exactly set off alarm bells among Rangers fans, but it is an underrated loss. Now, combine that with forward Colton Orr being out indefinitely with what the team now said is a broken toe, the fourth line has lost much of its personality as the Rangers checking line.

title: Small screen me
description: Lehrer, on the Paulson non-plan, about 25 minutes from now. Princeton now has a TV studio  actually just a classroom with a camera  in its basement.

title: First Impressions: Madaleine Mae
description: Its a nice spot, the corner of Columbus Avenue and 82nd Street that Madaleine Mae inhabits. There are windows on the avenue, facing west, and windows on the cross street, facing south. Inside, the restaurant has a clean, uncluttered look. The bar is long and feels like its part of the room, not some separate, greater event, or some separate, lesser one.

title: See You Tuesday Night, Yankee Fans
description: This afternoon may have been a washout for Yankee fans  the 1:05 p.m. Opening Day game was delayed because of rain and finally called off for the day at 2:30  but not for the Arthur Avenue Italian Deli branch in the stadium. Rain delays are always great for selling food, said David Greco, who owns an Italian deli in the stadium. We had so many people buying our eggplant parmigiana, they were practically attacking us. Theyre coming back tomorrow night, so we got a bonus day, said Mr. Greco, who also owns the Arthur Avenue Cafe and Mikes Deli in the Bronx.

title: Its Not Reality, But Its Unscripted: ABCs Summer Schedule
description: Reality show contestants on ABC will face ever-more extreme ways to embarrass themselves this summer: Obstacle courses! Insults from C-list celebrities! Rejection by a once-rejected dating show participant!

title: Bank Robber Left Behind Photo ID, Police Say
description: If only all bank robbers were so considerate, the police would have an easier time of it.

title: Rangers Prospect Sanguinetti Heads to Hartford
description: The Rangers announced that their top draft pick from 2006, defenseman Bobby Sanguinetti, has been assigned to the Hartford Wolf Pack, the franchises top farm team.

title: Council Votes 30-20 for Traffic Fees
description: Updated, 10:48 p.m. | Shortly before 7:30 p.m., the New York City Council approved a measure urging state lawmakers to vote in favor of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs congestion pricing proposal. The vote was 30 to 20, with one member absent. (See the full roll call below.)Minutes later, Mayor Bloomberg held a news conference with the Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, to celebrate the passing of his plan, which has left city and state lawmakers sharply divided. (The article prepared for Tuesdays editions, by Diane Cardwell, is now online.)

title: Bloggingheads: On "Islamofascism"
description:
Blogger Heather Hurlburt and writer Paul Berman debate the validity of the term "Islamofascism."
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

title: Animal Prints | Vogue Uproar
description: The most volatile clash of sports and fashion since Flo Jos one-legged unitard? It may be the April 2008 cover of Vogue, featuring Gisele Bundchen and the NBA superstar LeBron James (the magazines first African-American male cover subject). For several days, the photo, taken by Annie Leibovitz, has fueled blogosphere debate and dinner-party chatter on the topic of racist imagery. James is shown baring his teeth, dribbling a ball, with his arm around a smiling Gisele  a pose that bloggers have likened to representations of King Kong. (A commenter on Feministe wrote, I see a scary animalistic black man, a primal scream, and a beautiful white woman.) Did Leibovitz intend the questionable reference? As a Rare, Rare Find points out, the basketball players nickname is King James. For what its worth, Style.coms behind-the-scenes video of the shoot shows the pair dancing, jumping and skipping together. Furthermore, James, Vogue and the NAACP have all weighed in on the matter. Now its your turn.

title: Profane and Divine
description: Well, lets see. A blog about the creative process. This is a good time to begin this as I have just gotten off the road from promoting Beauty & Crime, which was my first album in six years. I had a lot of ideas during that time and not everything made it onto that record, so now I am beginning to splash around and see whats up for this next one.

title: Is Dell Cutting Costs or Sending Smoke Signals?
description: Dell on Monday announced that it plans to close a desktop computer manufacturing plant in Austin, Texas. The company said the closure is part of a massive reorganization effort to revive Dell while also cutting $3 billion in costs.
